title: AIDS Patients Deserve a Home
description: General apprehension about AIDS, the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, is understandable and probably useful in arousing support for research on the fatal disease. But the fear has turned destructive in Queens, where New Yorkers are mobilizing to block a plan to house homeless AIDS patients in a nursing home. That fearful reaction is untempered by reason or scientific fact. It should not be allowed to scuttle a safe and badly needed program.

HERS
description: ONE often hears about the Talmud of disciplined logic and rigorous problem-solving, the one that produces legal scholars, bridge masters and tax specialists, but one seldom hears about the other Talmud, the one that transformed the childhoods of Marc Chagall, I. B. Singer and generations of dreamers like myself, the Talmud of magic.

title: People Express To Fly to Brussels
description: People Express Airlines Inc. said yesterday that it planned to begin flights between Newark and Brussels in early September with an introductory fare of $99.

title: Baseball;   July: A Month of Extremes
description: July, the month of extremes in the sport of extremes, was extremely hot for Pedro Guerrero, who hit .475, and extremely cold for Kevin McReynolds, who hit .151. It was scorching for the Los Angeles Dodgers, who gained 10 games in the standing, and frigid for the San Diego Padres, who lost 15 of their 25 games and fell nine games in the standing.

title: CRIMES AND OTHER VIOLATIONS IN CITY'S SCHOOLS DROP 2.5%
description: Reported crime and other security violations in the city's schools declined 2.5 percent during the academic year that ended last June, the Board of Education said yesterday.

description: Camp Topridge, the lavish Adirondack Mountain retreat of the late Marjorie Merriweather Post, was sold by the state at public auction today for $911,000 to a businessman from New Jersey.

title: Les Ledbetter Is Dead; Former Times Reporter
description: Les Ledbetter, a former reporter and editor for The New York Times, was found dead Monday in his apartment in San Francisco. He was 44 years old.

title: Is Video Next?
description: It is a telltale sign of the electronic age that many constituents who used to pen rambling, semi-coherent letters to their representatives in Congress are now voicing their sentiments on tape. According to Christopher J. Matthews, top press aide to House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., the tapes fare no better even if they are more costly than plain paper. For they, too, he says, generally end up in a wastebasket.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch yesterday from Spring Hill, Tenn., about the impact of that community's selection as an auto-manufacturing site, incorrectly cited the increased asking price of one property quoted by a real estate agent. It rose to $600,000 from $250,000.

title: GROWTH IN SPENDING ON HEALTH CARE SLOWS TO 9.1%
description: Total spending on health care in the United States grew by 9.1 percent last year, the slowest rate of increase in two decades, the Government reported today.

title: GENERALS EXPECTED TO MERGE
description: The long-simmering merger between the Generals and the Houston Gamblers reached the boiling point yesterday when Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, said that the clubs' owners would be at a news conference today to ''announce details of their teams' future in the U.S.F.L.''

title: One Flies Over the Cuckoo's Nest
description: Wherever you look - in Federal agencies and on Congressional staffs, in law offices and public relations concerns, in universities, trade associations and research organizations - there are countless men and women who came here intending to work for a year or two but have stayed for a lifetime.

title: Cruise Ship Contract
description: France's Chantiers de l'Atlantique shipyard at St. Nazaire has won a $150 million contract to build what is said to be the world's largest cruise liner, a 2,550-bed vessel ordered by Norway's Royal Caribbean Cruise Line, its owners, Alsthom, have announced.

title: MUSIC: MOSTLY MOZART
description: IF audience size can be taken as an indication of public response to original-instrument performance of 18th-century music, the gathering of paying customers for the Mostly Mozart concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Tuesday night suggested that lots of music-lovers are, at the very least, curious about it. The rows of empty seats that have seen at Mostly Mozart events in which the performers were better known and the interpretive approach wholly conventional were not in evidence at this concert conducted by Christopher Hogwood.

description: For more than a week opaque columns of smoke rose into the sky at Hellgate Canyon, near Missoula. As darkness gathered, dozens of wind-driven blazes, like distant candles, flickered in the thickly forested mountains on the outskirts of town.

title: FOR CITY WINDOWS IN THE SUMMERTIME
description: ONE of the big problems during New York summers is that if you open the windows, the dirt comes in. One way to solve the problem is by using window ventilators that have a built-in filter system.

title: LIGHT, AIR AND A SPARE STYLE FOR A RESTORED 1825 FARMHOUSE
description: PEOPLE who are passionately fond of their homes tend to recall the first sight of them with the clarity of parents recalling the first sight of a newborn. Witness the description by Duane Michals, a photographer, of the day 14 years ago that he found the house in which he spends every possible weekend. ''I'd looked for two years upstate, and whenever a real estate agent said, 'Oh, you're going to love it; it's just been remodeled,' my heart sank. Remodeling always meant fluorescent lights, fake pine paneling - it was the kiss of death. But on a bright, crisp Sunday morning in January when the snow was 20 inches deep, I saw this, and suddenly there was a sense of finding the right place.''

title: Almost an Endorsement
description: Governor Cuomo came about as close as one politician can come to endorsing another politician yesterday - without calling it an endorsement.

description: House and Senate negotiators reached agreement tonight on a bill that would impose economic sanctions on South Africa.

description: Maureen Reagan said today that her father, President Reagan, had promised to avoid strenuous activity during his forthcoming vacation at his California ranch.

description: IT'S not exactly the kind of store one expects to find on Main Street in Bridgehampton, L.I., but that may be the reason for Mix's success.

title: TV NEWS MAGAZINES AIM AT DIVERSE VIEWERS
description: They are both magazine-format programs, and they are both produced by network news divisions. But the sharply distinctive styles of CBS's ''West 57th Street'' and NBC's ''American Almanac,'' which will have their premieres in the next two weeks, suggest a television journalism traveling in divergent directions.

METS WIN, 5-2, FOR SWEEP
description: He bounded up the dugout steps in what has become baseball's curtain call, turning to face the crowd, then pumping his arms overhead, thus sharing a moment of personal satisfaction and vindication with the fans. Gary Carter may understand as well as anyone that a trade cannot be evaluated on the basis of one game, a month or season, but that every time at bat is a status report and a chance for his former teammates to say, ''I told you so.''

title: Technology;   'New Frontier' In Plastics
description: AN ice skating rink in Port Washington, L.I., has no ice. There is, instead, a quarter acre of white plastic, which provides slightly more friction. ''It's great for training and it's cheaper - no refrigeration,'' said Bryan Trottier, the hockey star of the New York Islanders and owner of the plastic skating rink.

title: MAUREEN REAGAN ASSESSES NAIROBI
description: MAUREEN REAGAN, the head of the United States delegation to the United Nations Decade for Women conference, told a news conference yesterday at the State Department in Washington that she had been prepared to lead her country's representatives in a walkout had the 2,100 delegates from 159 countries approved a resolution equating Zionism with racism in the meeting's final document.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. Boxing semifinals and men's gymnastics team and all-around competition will be the highlights.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's a lot of joy on the flight deck.'' - Col. Roy D. Bridges Jr., pilot of the shuttle Challenger, after a balky telescope finally locked on the sun. [A20:1.]

title: United Energy Trades Heavily
description: United Energy Resources' stock traded heavily yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as rumors spread that a buyout bid was imminent for the natural gas and oil pipeline operator.

title: CONTRACEPTION NOTICES REJECTED BY NETWORKS
description: A MEDIA campaign designed to curb unintended pregnancy among teen-agers encountered a setback yesterday when two major television networks - CBS and ABC - rejected the two-minute public service announcements because, they said, the subject of birth control was ''too controversial.'' NBC was still considering whether to air the announcements but Cable News Network said it would carry them.

title: A Noose on the News
description: The White House, apparently sensitive to Democratic complaints of discrimination, has stopped making copies of its daily news summary available to Republicans in Congress.

description: The Eastman Kodak Company, hurt by the impact of the strong dollar, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1985 plunged 28.3 percent as sales slipped 4.3 percent.

title: COLECO SMITTEN BY 'RAMBO'
description: Coleco Industries, the company whose cuddly Cabbage Patch Kids became a national craze, said yesterday that it would market a line of dolls and accessories based on Rambo, the muscle-bound movie hero portrayed by Sylvester Stallone.

title: AID FOR WOMEN STARTING BUSINESS
description: HOW many of you were told as little girls that when you grew up, you would be the head of a big, successful company?'' the instructor asked. The 40 women in the room laughed at once, recalling the home-and-hearth mission that was instilled in girls of past generations.

title: 90 Jets Grounded by Navy
description: The Navy, warned of a problem with suspect jet engine blades, has grounded 90 of its 300 A-7E attack jets for inspection and possible replacement of their engines, a Navy spokesman said today. The spokesman said at least two crashes this year had been linked to the possible defect. The engines are made by the Allison Gas Turbine Division of the General Motors Corporation.

title: LEADING INDICATORS CLIMB 1%
description: The Government's main economic forecasting gauge jumped 1 percent in June, aided by a surge in new businesses, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: A DECORATOR'S DAY OF BARGAIN HUNTING
description: SOME decorators specialize in antiques. Others specialiize in the ultramodern. Tony Moses has a different sort of specialty: He tries to save his clients money. This he accomplishes by combing thrift shops, secondhand furniture stores and discount fabric marts. His forays take him to the Bronx, to Harlem, to the Upper West Side and to the Lower East Side. Oh, he'll go to a wholesale showroom if it's absolutely necessary, but he finds it much more challenging and far more interesting to look for bargains.

description: While plays by Eugene O'Neill and Arthur Miller are performed in England with some regularity and authenticity, Tennessee Williams has encountered a curious ambivalence on the part of the critics and the public. This is an idea whose time has come. A nightly news broadcast ought to be in prime time, and better it should be ''MacNeil/ Lehrer.''

title: Striking Out

title: Britain Bestows Citizenship on Yehudi Menuhin

Now, by virtue of grants from countries that wish to claim him, Mr. Menuhin is officially a citizen not only of his native United States and Switzerland, but, as of May 1, Britain.

Morgenthau said the defendant was a suspect in 20 other cases involving sexual attacks or robberies since he was paroled from prison.

description: Statements by President Truman and other officials that the nuclear bombing of Japan in World War II saved 500,000 to 1 million American lives are ''vast exaggerations'' and contradict military predictions given to the officials at the time, two researchers said today.

title: HOUSE PASSES FIRST FOREIGN AID BILL SINCE '81
description: The House, ending a four-year impasse, approved a two-year, $25.4 billion foreign aid authorization bill today and sent it to the White House. The vote was 262 to 161. Not since 1981 have both houses of Congress been able to agree on foreign aid spending authority. Negotiations broke down in discord over policy disputes, forcing the Reagan Administration to use stopgap financing measures.

title: Houston Mayor Runs Again
description: Mayor Kathy Whitmire announced Monday that she planned to seek a third term. Her main opponent is expected to be Louie Welch, 66 years old, who served five terms as Mayor from 1964 to 1973. He announced his candidacy in May.

They returned to regular gear for the afternoon session.

title: THE REAL MCDOWELL GOES TO THE MOUND
description: The problem all along, Roger McDowell smiled and insisted, had nothing to do with twisted ankles or changes in his pitching motion or poor control. After all the time Mel Stottlemyre, the Met pitching coach, had spent studying videotape of the struggling relief pitcher, McDowell produced the solution all by himself. The problem, he announced, had been a serious breach of security at Shea Stadium.

title: 1 of 8 in Federal Trial Found Not Guilty of a Robbery Plot
description: One defendant was acquitted of the only charge against him when the jury reached a partial verdict last night in the conspiracy trial of eight people accused of plotting armed robberies and escapes of two men imprisoned in connection with the 1981 Brink's armored car robbery in Rockland County.

title: Bomb Blast at Belfast Hotel
description: A car packed with some 300 pounds of explosives blew up outside the entrance to a hotel today, heavily damaging the building but causing no injuries, the police said. The outlawed Irish Republican Army took responsibility for the blast, which set fire to the Greenan Lodge Hotel in West Belfast.

The order did not set a new starting date for the trial, which was to have begun next Monday. . . . The Cowboys have decided to fine Tony Dorsett $1,000 a day for not reporting to camp. . . . Silver Lining
description: The strike that the players' union has threatened to call next Tuesday would undoubtedly be bad for baseball fans, bad for baseball players and bad for most of baseball's owners, but the way one baseball executive sees it, a strike might not be so bad for the Pittsburgh Pirates. According to Doug McCormick, the Pirates' treasurer, a walkout could help solve the club's financial problems. ''By not having to play our games, not having to play our players and not operating the stadium, we would still have a negative cash flow,'' he said, ''but it would be somewhat better.''

title: SCREEN: 'FRIGHT NIGHT,' VAMPIRE TALE
description: ''FRIGHT NIGHT'' has a lot more personality than the usual horror film, which is a distinctly mixed blessing. It tells of a nice teen-ager, played by William Ragsdale, who becomes alarmed at the possibility that a dapper vampire may have moved next door. To investigate the secret life of this soigne neighbor (played by Chris Sarandon, who's made a specialty out of playing smug, slightly dissipated heavies), he enlists the help of an over-the-hill screen star.

title: Retirement Home
description: John Henry, the richest thoroughbred race horse in history, will retire to the Kentucky Horse Park here, only a few miles from where he was foaled. John Henry, who collected $6,597,947 and seven Eclipse awards and twice was voted Horse of the Year, was forced to retire at age 10 when he injured a tendon during a workout at Hollywood Park July 19.

title: Dr. Gross: Not 'Not Guilty'
description: Once again, the professional abilities of New York City's Medical Examiner, Dr. Elliot Gross, have been called into question, this time by the State Health Department. It has leveled 11 charges of gross incompetence or negligence against him. Questions raised by a series of articles in The New York Times six months ago continue to haunt Dr. Gross, and one of the answers evident then is even clearer now.

title: THREE VISITING ROCKERS ON THE FRONTIERS OF POP
description: TO many people, a pop song equals four catchy minutes of truisms about love. Since the 1960's, however, many songwriters have decided to circumvent the cliches. Dark lyrics with light tunes, character studies from bizarre points of view, irony, alienation, paradox and the whole Pandora's box of literary distancing devices have moved into pop - and that's not to mention the musical twists. Formula songwriting isn't dead, but it's no longer the only game in town.

title: FED REBUFFS CITICORP ON INSURANCE
description: The Federal Reserve Board today denied Citicorp permission to buy a bank in South Dakota that is involved in the insurance underwriting business.

title: AT NASSAU COUNTY MUSEUM, WORKS OF 'AMERICANS ABROAD'
description: FOR American artists of any ambition in the 18th and 19th centuries, there was no place like Europe. They went off to London, Paris, Rome and Florence -and later, Dusseldorf and Munich, to study the works of dead masters and take instruction from living ones. For them, the Continent not only provided firsthand contact with glorious works of the past, but a finesse that couldn't be acquired at home for creating those of the present. Not until our own century, when great art and good instruction were more readily available here, did Americans begin to feel a lessening of the need to go abroad as a vital part of their training.

title: Bridge: Hudson Valley Survives Play In Grand National Teams
description: A new format in the Grand National Teams brought 24 strong entries into action here Wednesday. Eight of them survived into tonight.

description: Philadelphia agreed today to allow women guards to serve in men's prisons and pay $950,000 in back pay to women who were discriminated against, the Justice Department said.

description: Conch captured the Hambletonian Oaks, the trot for fillies, tonight at the Meadowlands Race Track.

title: Substitution II
description: It has been some years now since protocol at formal Washington dinners called for the women to withdraw from the dining room after dessert, leaving the men to their port, cigars and weighty debate. But, in a city often given to rituals, some of those who entertain still seem to be groping for an entirely satisfactory substitute.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: STELLA FLAME gave a birthday party for Herman Melville, the New York-born writer who would have been 166 years old yesterday. ''I love Melville,'' said Miss Flame, a fashion designer. Not only that, but ''denizens of the deep,'' Miss Flame assured her guests, ''will be a big fashion motif next summer, with octopi especially important.''

description: Cecil John Rhodes, the British colonialist, is said to have dreamed of a day when the empire he sought to expand in the late 19th century would span a continent, linked by railroad from the Cape to Cairo.

title: SQUATTERS AND CITY BATTLE FOR ABANDONED BUILDINGS
description: A crowd of people carrying hammers and crowbars pried the metal seal off an abandoned city-owned building this week in the East New York section of Brooklyn and said it now belonged to them.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FIELD OF BLOOD. By Gerald Seymour. 352 pages. W. W. Norton. $14.95. THE strongest of the international suspense stories are diminished when they are cubbyholed in bookstores or in book reviews simply as mysteries or thrillers. Even the modern master of the genre, Graham Greene, once had a problem with classification. He labeled seven of his own books - including ''The Third Man'' and ''Our Man in Havana'' - ''entertainments,'' as if to tell the reader that these titles did not carry the full weight of his seriousness. Of course, they did; a fine writer cannot help doing his best, even when his subjects are designed to entertain. In recent years, Mr. Greene himself recognized this. Now he lists his ''entertainments,'' along with such books as ''The Power and the Glory'' and ''The Comedians,'' simply as novels.

title: I.B.M.-Japan Patent Details
description: The International Business Machines Corporation will receive a number of advanced technology patents in its agreement with the Japanese Government, the company said today.

title: Talk of a Trade
description: A trade between the Boston Celtics and the Los Angeles Clippers involving Cedric Maxwell and Bill Walton is under discussion, according to Carl Scheer, the general manager of the Clippers. Yesterday, he denied a report in The Boston Globe that the deal was close to completion.

title: A QUADRIPLEGIC PAINTER
description: When Joon Ho Kim fell and broke his neck in 1976, he did not lose his fascination with painting, even though he had lost the use of both arms and legs. Mr. Kim, a quadriplegic, taught himself how to paint by holding a brush in his mouth, and in time he became recognized as one of South Korea's leading artists.

title: Substitution I
description: From the National Institutes of Health comes word that scientists are considering giving up the use of mice and rats in their experiments. ''We're thinking about substituting lawyers,'' one doctor was heard to say the other day, tongue in cheek about a creature that is plentiful in the capital. ''No one gets emotionally attached to them,'' he explained.

title: Helsinki in the Victims' View
description: Judged by results, the Helsinki Final Act scarcely merits a 10th anniversary observance in the city where it was signed during the false dawn of detente. The generous hope was that freedoms in the Soviet bloc could be enlarged in exchange for more explicit Western acceptance of the bloc's ''security,'' notably the boundaries securing the partition of Germany. Before the ink was dry, the human rights planks of the accord were scorned by the Kremlin, which made it a crime for Soviet citizens even to monitor compliance.

title: JAZZ: DICK HYMAN ON PIANO
description: AFTER four programs focused on various musical styles, the ''Jazz in July'' series at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday turned the spotlight on an individual - the pianist Dick Hyman, who is the artistic director of the series and who was a ubiquitous supporting performer in all of the earlier programs.

ARNO JOHNSON, 84, A FORMER EXECUTIVE IN ADVERTISING, DIES
description: Arno Hallock Johnson, a former vice president and senior economist for J. Walter Thompson, the advertising concern, died Tuesday at his home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: FORD PLANS TO ACQUIRE THRIFT UNIT

title: HOUSE CALLS: A GROWING TREND IN FITNESS
description: Some teach exercises rooted in dance, some rely on aerobics. Others prefer working with weights or passive body toning. Still others teach yoga and isometrics and preach weight loss. That exercise teachers favor varying paths to fitness is not new, but increasingly in the East, particularly in Manhattan, they are teaching and training not in gymnasiums, health clubs or spas but privately, in peoples' homes.

description: Now and for the next several months - timed for the dramatic pursuit, the anticipated passing and the expected publicity bonanza thereafter of Pete Rose and the career base-hit record - there is and will continue to be a merchandising extravaganza.

title: BROADWAY
description: IT may seem like the Long Snore at the moment, but the New York theater is stirring and stretching and coming even now out of its summer sleep. Sure to shake things up is ''A Map of the World'' by David Hare, the angry, youngish British playwright, which will lead off the Public Theater's 1985-86 season. Casting of the major roles has just been completed.

title: Phoenix Steel Sale

She said the offer by David B. Hermelin and William M. Davidson was in the best interest of the company's creditors. The alternative would have been liquidating the company's assets, its Claymont, Del., and Phoenixville, Pa., plants.

title: Third-Year Festivities For Intrepid Museum
description: Balloons, bands and skywriting planes will herald the third anniversary of the Intrepid Sea-Air-Space Museum tomorrow afternoon at the ship, docked at the Hudson River and West 46th Street. The aircraft carrier, a veteran of World War II air and sea battles, contains planes, exhibits, films and other items documenting its 31 years of service.

title: M-1 Growth Of $3.7 Billion
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board announced a larger-than-expected rise in the nation's basic money supply. But by late in the day, rates were up only by small amounts for issues due in less than seven years, while longer-dated issues were little changed.

description: A jury completed its third day of deliberations yesterday without a decision on most of the charges against the seven remaining defendants in a conspiracy trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: CYCLING ON THE RISE
description: Coit Tower shimmers like a magic wand above the waterfront of San Francisco, drawing the eyes upward and pulling at the feet with an almost mystical urgency. Tomorrow morning in the city by the bay, some of the finest bicycle racers in the world, including France's Bernard Hinault, America's Greg LeMond and Canada's Steve Bauer, will be given the opportunity to race toward the gleaming white tower.

title: THE SCREEN: 'ANIMALS ARE BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE'
description: CORNY as it is, animal anthropomorphism is pretty hard to resist. And in ''Animals Are Beautiful People,'' Jamie Uys has accompanied a series of cute voice-over observations about various desert creatures with footage that is sufficiently fascinating to dispense with any sense of silliness. Mr. Uys, the South African director of ''The Gods Must Be Crazy,'' made this documentary several years earlier and gives it a naive charm very like that of his big hit. He is not beyond occasionally manipulating the footage to achieve this, but the result is still an engaging naturalism.

description: Joseph Ushkow, a former board chairman of Endo Laboratories, the pharmaceutical concern, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Great Neck, L.I. He was 83 years old.

title: Nine Comedians Appear On Dangerfield Special
description: Although the world of standup comedy is bursting with interesting conceptual performers and character comedians, the front lines of American humor are barely visible on ''Rodney Dangerfield's Ninth Annual Young Comedians Special,'' which will have its premiere on Home Box Office, the pay-cable channel, tomorrow at 9:30 P.M. Out of nine comedians, each of whom is given about five minutes, only one - the superb comic actor-impressionist Bob Nelson -shows an imaginative zeal that transcends the mundane.

title: ALPINE GROUP INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
U.S. Judge in Texas Finds Bias in Public Housing
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Housing and Urban Development Department's public housing policies discriminate against minority groups in 36 East Texas counties.

title: CONDOMINIUMS THRIVING IN AREA OF LINCOLN CENTER
description: References to the ''audience'' for his condominiums and the ''previews'' beginning this weekend keep cropping up when Lewis Futterman talks. It is not his former career as a record producer that inspires these dramatic references but rather his latest building, the Bel Canto, at 1991 Broadway, about two blocks north of Lincoln Center.

title: ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PERU ADOPTS EMERGENCY ECONOMIC MEASURES
description: Peru's new Government announced emergency economic measures today, including a currency devaluation, that are intended to increase Government revenue and curtail inflation, which has been running at close to 12 percent a month.

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MARCOS SAID TO PLAN TO QUIT AND HOLD A SPECIAL ELECTION
description: Pentagon and State Department officials said tonight that they had been told by the Philippine Embassy here that President Ferdinand E. Marcos planned to resign in September in order to call a special election this fall as a test of his popular support.

title: SETON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-earlier results were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split paid in September 1984.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE term mesquite is such a restaurant cliche these days that it has become almost a permanent prefix to the word ''grilled'' - joining the roster of such other menu puffery as garden-fresh, homemade, oven-baked, hand-picked and vine-ripened. I don't know how much of this overpriced Texas firewood needs to be tossed over the coals to legitimately call something mesquite-grilled, but based on my dining experiences, it cannot be much.

title: FILM: 'WEIRD SCIENCE,' YOUTH FANTASY
description: WITH ''Sixteen Candles,''

title: COLUMBINE EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including extraordinary items of $20,000 for the quarter and $40,000 for the six months. There were no share earnings for the latest periods because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: INTEGRATED GENETICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALLIED NURSING CARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DATAKEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RICHARDSON LEADS GOLF QUALIFIERS
description: Tom Richardson of Greenwich, Conn., who played the No. 1 position on the University of Richmond golf team before his graduation last June, won the medal today in the qualifying rounds of the 83d championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: Dr. Ruth Bakwin Dies; Professor of Pediatrics
description: Dr. Ruth Bakwin, a retired professor of pediatrics at New York University, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Kodiak, Alaska, where she was vacationing. She was 87 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: CHOLERA REPORTED SPREADING IN ETHIOPIA CAPITAL AND SUDAN
description: A disease that medical authorities believe is cholera appears to be spreading rapidly here in the Ethiopian capital.

title: METS MAKE RUSH
description: It was the type of talk usually saved for September when time grows short and the significance of every game is magnified. The Mets, who otherwise might be satisfied with their second-place showing at this point, will begin what could be the last series of the 1985 baseball season against the Cubs in Chicago today, hoping to accomplish in a weekend what they ordinarily would be assured of having two more months to do.

title: EWING'S DEMAND WOULD SET RECORD
description: The question of how much Patrick Ewing is worth is not new. There has been speculation concerning the millions he would earn as a professional ever since the shot-blocking, seven-foot center led Georgetown to the national final as a freshman four years ago. But now that negotiations between the Knicks and Ewing's representatives are under way, the figures reportedly being discussed are staggering.

title: NEW YORK PUTS CURB ON MEDICAL STUDENTS FROM THE CARIBBEAN
description: The New York State Department of Education said yesterday that several medical schools in the Caribbean and Mexico could no longer send medical students to complete their clinical training in New York teaching hospitals.

title: TWO NEW STORES THAT MAKE SHOPPING A SAFARI
description: A jeep rusts in a mound of dirt, weeds and palm trees sprouting around it. A tattered map of Southeast Asia lies forlornly on the floor, next to a recent copy of Il Mattino. Luggage spills from the rear. The scene is not a jungle in Vietnam, it's Greenwich Village, where Banana Republic opened last week at Avenue of the Americas and Bleecker Street.

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANT SCUTTLED
description: The nation's first commercial synthetic fuels plant, which has supplied natural gas derived from coal to millions of consumers in the Middle West for a year, was scuttled yesterday as uneconomic. Energy analysts said the move means the virtual abandonment for this century of the 1970's goal of independence from imported oil.

title: CENTER BANC SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $34,377 for the quarter and $247,894 for the year. Year-ago per share figure is subsequent to the bank's conversion to a stock association in September 1983.

title: MARCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 30
description: Results are for 16 weeks for the latest fourth quarter and 17 weeks for the year-ago fourth quarter.

title: GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOODE UNPERTURBED BY U.S. INQUIRY
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode of Philadelphia today defended his actions in the confrontation with the radical group Move and said he had no fear of a Federal investigation into the incident.

title: Rumasa Sale Complete
description: Spain's Socialist Government has completed the sale to private industry of Rumasa, the business empire expropriated by the state in 1983 after losing nearly $3 billion, the Finance Ministry said today.

title: STAGE: LEVY'S 'SPRINGTIME FOR HENRY'
description: THE Roundabout Theater Company refers to ''Springtime for Henry'' as a ''rarely seen'' play, a statement that might have caused the author Benn W. Levy to shudder. The rarity may be true in modern times. But, in its day, stretching from 1931 well past the midcentury, ''Springtime for Henry'' was the bread and butter for both Mr. Levy and the actor Edward Everett Horton. Touring the farce eternally, Mr. Horton treated it as his own personal ''Count of Monte Cristo.'' The title found its final resting place in parody mythology when Mel Brooks dreamed up ''Springtime for Hitler.''

title: GENERALS-GAMBLERS MERGER IS OFFICIAL
description: Harry Usher, the commissioner of the United States Football League, announced yesterday that the Generals and the Houston Gamblers had agreed to a merger that would preserve the Generals' identity while apparently being dominated by Gambler officials, coaches and players.

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JAPAN 40 YEARS AFTER WAR: RICH, POWERFUL, UNEASY
description: Forty years after abject wartime defeat, Japan is grappling with its peacetime role as a world power.

title: GENERAL RE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $1,864,000 for the quarter and $2,146,000 for the 6 months and losses from discontinued operations of $29,492,000 for the quarter and $28,528,000 for the 6 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $286,000 for the quarter and $771,000 for the 6 months, income from discontinued operations of $1,754,000 for the quarter and $3,973,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $80,460,000 for the 6 months from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: BACK IN THE CITY, A DISPLAY OF THE FIGURE IN MODERN ART
description: AT a time when a growing number of modernist-based artists have decided that they are not obliged to repudiate or fragment the human figure, almost any broad survey of figurative painting and sculpture would be welcome. ''The Figure in 20th-Century American Art: Selections From the Metropolitan Museum of Art,'' at the National Academy of Design, 89th Street and Fifth Avenue, through Sept. 1, is not only broad but also thoughtful and filled with good work. Organized by the Metropolitan and the American Federation of Arts and selected by Lowery Stokes Sims, in association with William S. Lieberman, chairman of the Met's Department of 20th-Century Art, it is the largest traveling show generated by the department in its 15-year history.

title: Craxi Backed on Lira
description: Prime Minister Bettino Craxi's Government won a confidence vote tonight, easing political tension caused when the Treasury Minister and central bank governor offered their resignations because of the recent collapse of the lira. Both men have now decided to stay in the Government.

title: SEIBELS BRUCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a capital loss of $131,639. c-After capital gains of $91,009 for the quarter and $55,374 for the 6 months. d-After a capital gain of $76,440.

title: DIAGNOSTIC-RETRIEVAL SYSEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Oxoco Cash Flow
description: Oxoco Inc. said that if some exchange offers it recently extended are not successful, it probably would not have sufficient cash flow to meet its obligations and would be compelled to liquidate or reorganize under Federal bankruptcy laws. The oil drilling and production company also said that it had received a preliminary proposal from its lending banks to repay about $34 million of senior secured bank debt. Oxoco extended its exchange offers to holders of $86 million principal amount of its outstanding subordinated debt securities until Aug. 21.

title: SMITH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income The latest second quarter and 6 months nets include $27.8 million provision for possible damages and related expense in connection with ongoing patent litigation with Hughes Tool Co. The latest quarter includes a $6 million foreign tax provision for income from international operations. Results also were penalized by several other factors, including the devaluation of the Mexican peso and increased discounting due to competitive market conditions.

title: Soviet Battle Photos
description: ''Soviet Photography of World War II: 1941-45,'' an exhibition of 175 black-and-white photographs, some never before seen outside of the Soviet Union, will be on view through Sept. 8 at the International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street.

title: FROM MARILYN TO MADONNA, THE UNGLAMOROUS BUSINESS OF POSING IN THE NUDE
description: In late 1977, an 18-year-old University of Michigan dance student named Madonna Louise Ciccone posed nude at $10 an hour for a corporate graphics artist whose private work in photography generally ran to insects and flowers.

title: FROM DIPLOMACY TO HORSE RACING
description: The decision to turn down a diplomatic assignment from the Swedish Government in the Belgian Congo in the 1950's and emigrate to the United States instead proved to be the key for Hans Enggren, the breeder and co-owner of Prakas, the favorite in the Hambletonian Saturday.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 2, 1985
description: International

title: Topics;   On the Street Meter Beaters
description: Happy birthday: the parking meter is 50 years old. The first one appeared not in some world-famous center of congestion, but at the corner of First Street and Robinson Avenue in Oklahoma City.

title: Money Fund Assets Dip
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $1.35 billion, to $209.43 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 67 institutional funds dropped $1.35 billion, to $53.72 billion, while the 187 general purpose funds rose $204.6 million, to $60.89 billion, and the 89 broker-dealer funds fell $206.4 million, to $94.82 billion.

title: Love Amid Squalor
description: A story was told earlier this week about a young woman and man who first met on the Brooklyn Bridge, where they had gone separately to celebrate New Year's Eve 1984. They plan to be married this month.

title: CONTINENTAL HEALTH AFFILITES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in Febuary 1985.

title: UNITED CABLE TELEVISION CORP reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,925,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $4,226,000. The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in July 1985.

title: CHELSEA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Mortgage Art
description: In one of those increasingly popular ventures by commerce into art, the Mortgage Bankers Association is sponsoring a contest for paintings, sculpture, photographs, prints and ceramics on the theme ''Shelter.''

title: Followers of Guru Win Election Panel Ruling
description: The Federal Election Commission has decided unanimously that the Rajneesh Foundation and its leaders did not violate Federal election laws when they bused several thousand homeless people into their central Oregon commune last year.

title: Evening News Dismisses Executive
description: The Evening News Association, a Detroit-based broadcasting and publishing concern, dismissed an executive yesterday who the company said gave confidential internal documents to a group attempting to take it over.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the violinist and conductor Yehudi Menuhin gave his age incorrectly. He is 69 years old.

title: MARGIOTTA SAYS HE CHECKED APPLICANTS FOR COUNTY JOBS
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, who for 16 years was the Nassau County Republican chairman, testified today that he had routinely approved applications for county jobs, raises and promotions.

title: TREASURY STUDY CITES TAX DISPARITY
description: More than 50,000 taxpayers with total incomes above $250,000, including more than 5,000 millionaires, paid a smaller proportion of their total income in Federal taxes in 1983 than typical middle-income families, according to a Treasury Department study released today.

title: STOCKER & YALE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARGOSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $34,000 for the quarter and a loss of $116,000 for the year on securities.

title: A CRITIC'S GUIDE TO ART BEYOND THE CITY LIMITS
description: It's the time of the year when art can become an excuse for a weekend trip and, as usual, there are plenty of excuses to be found within a radius of 120 miles, for art does not end at the New York City limits.

title: With Restraint
description: What with the significance to New York of Tom Seaver's bid for his 300th victory at Yankee Stadium this Sunday, WPIX-TV is bringing in a ''Seaver expert'' to offer commentary during the game's telecast.

title: 'IRRITATED SKIN' IS REMOVED FROM SIDE OF REAGAN'S NOSE
description: A piece of skin was removed from President Reagan's nose Tuesday, the White House said today. Later, officials said that it had been determined that ''no further treatment was necessary.''

title: ENDO-LASE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fleet Will Acquire First Connecticut
description: Fleet Financial Group Inc. said that it had reached a definitive agreement to acquire First Connecticut Bancorp in a stock transaction valued at $193 million. The terms of the agreement call for each share of First Connecticut to be exchanged for $62 of Fleet Financial common stock, or a minimum of 1.55 Fleet shares and a maximum of 1.77 shares.

title: 6 ACCUSED BY F.B.I. IN IRAN ARMS PLOT
description: Six people, including an Iranian and an Army lieutenant colonel who had top-secret clearances, have been arrested in what the Government said was a plot to smuggle more than $75 million in advanced missiles and weapons to Iran.

title: GENERAL DYNAMICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $6.7 million for the quarter and $15.8 million for the 6 months and an estimated loss on the disposition of discontinued operations of $5 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $8.1 million for the quarter and $11.2 million for the 6 months.

title: Advertising;   Philip Morris's Latest: Adjustable Filter Brand
description: Philip Morris Inc. has put an adjustable filter on the tip of a new brand of cigarettes called Concord.

title: HEPATITIS B VIRUS IS LINKED TO AIDS
description: Scientists say they have found genetic material from hepatitis B viruses inside the blood cells of patients infected with the virus suspected of causing acqured immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS. The finding strengthens a suspicion that other viruses may play a role in causing AIDS in some cases.

title: Economic Scene;   Signs of Pickup In Second Half
description: DESPITE anxieties about the dollar, and both the budget and trade deficits, the American economy is showing signs of perking up. It now looks as though the second half of this year will be markedly better than the nearly stagnant first half.

title: 11 MORE NATIONS RECALL PRETORIA ENVOYS
description: In a signal of displeasure over the situation on South Africa, 11 more Western European nations recalled their ambassadors from Pretoria today for what were termed consultations.

title: GOODY PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains from the sale of land of $142,000 for the quarter and $151,000 for the six months. Results include operations of Duray Inc., acquired in October 1984 and Opti-Ray Inc., acquired in May 1985.

title: 'EUROPEAN' SOPRANO RETURNS TO RAVES
description: When Linda Roark-Strummer -the New York City Opera's imposing new Odabella in Verdi's ''Attila'' -flew in from Europe not long ago, customs officers asked her if she were a visitor to this country or an American coming home. The question gave her pause, and she finally admitted to a little of both.

title: PRO-IRAN LEBANESE DENIES HIS FAMILY HOLDS 7 AMERICANS
description: A leader of pro-Iranian Moslem militants said today that he considered it a ''badge of honor'' that his family had been accused of holding seven kidnapped Americans. But he denied the accusation, which was made in Washington this week by sources in Lebanon and relatives of the hostages.

title: U.S. COURT SAYS TEXAS ERRED BUT DOESN'T DELAY ELECTION
description: A Federal appeals court ruled today that Texas erred when it failed to obtain Justice Department approval for a critical election in the state's First Congressional District, but it said it would not delay or invalidate the election, set for Saturday.

title: Whirlpool Gains In Kitchenaid Deal
description: The Whirlpool Corporation said Federal District Judge Alvin I. Krenzler had lifted a preliminary injunction restraining it from acquiring the Kitchenaid division of Dart & Kraft Inc. White Consolidated Industries, which has claimed the deal violates antitrust laws, said it would appeal the ruling.

title: HEALTH-CHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $7,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $2,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $246,000 for the quarter and $876,000 for the 6 months, a gain on the disposal of discontinued operations of $4,940,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a tax credit of $96,000 for the quarter and 6 months. d-Net income

title: Knicks Tickets Going Fast
description: One of these days, after he and the Knicks have arrived at whatever stratospheric figure is mutually acceptable, Patrick Ewing will be playing basketball again. But if you have hopes of watching him from a very-close-up perspective, forget it.

title: U.S. FINDS POISON IN 12 BRANDS OF WINE IMPORTED FROM AUSTRIA
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said today that 12 brands of wines imported from Austria to the United States had been found to be contaminated with diethylene glycol, and that it was advising consumers to drink no Austrian wines until the tests are completed.

title: EXPOSAIC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IN HELSINKI, RUSSIANS COURT PRESS
description: The Russians appear to have turned the tables on the Americans in public relations during three days of meetings here, demonstrating a new style of affability that seems to reflect the approach of their leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: SCANDAL OVER POISONED WINE EMBITTERS VILLAGE IN AUSTRIA
description: The billowing white banner over the highway told anyone entering Rust, population 1,700, that this was ''the prettiest winegrowing town in Austria - with unadulterated wine.''

title: AUCTIONS
description: AUCTION practices and the consignor's special role became one of the most discussed subjects in the art field last month after there was a disclosure in court papers that David Bathurst, chairman of Christie's London and New York, had falsely reported the sale of three Impressionist paintings in New York in 1981, when in fact only one had been purchased. Mr. Bathurst, who was president of Christie's in New York when the auction took place, resigned as chairman of the auction house two weeks ago.

title: Old Court Owners Sued
description: The conservator of the Old Court Savings and Loan Association has filed a civil suit against the Maryland thrift institution's owners and directors charging that they misappropriated funds and failed to meet their responsibility to depositors. The suit charged that their actions ''may have constituted the largest financial fraud in the history of the state of Maryland'' and asked for punitive damages of $200 million.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a nonrecurring gain of $1,135,000, or 13 cents a share, related to the previously undistributed earnings of the company's domestic international sales corporation. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given. AMERICAN HARVEST RESTAURANT, Vista International Hotel, World Trade Center (938-9100) -

title: FARMERS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
UNIVERSAL LEAF TOBACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The fiscal 1985 earnings include 28 cents a share reported in the first quarter from tax credits associated with the discontinuance of the company's domestic international sales corp.

title: Dole Picks Key Political Aide
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, has named Donald J. Devine as a key official of his political action committee, taking what is considered another step in the early maneuverings for the 1988 Presidential race. Mr. Devine is the former personnel chief for the Federal Government, Mr. Dole, a Republican from Kansas, said Wednesday that he had picked Mr. Devine as consulting director of the his political action committee, Campaign America, because of Mr. Devine's organizational abilities.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $107,000 for the quarter and $225,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $113,000 for the quarter and $194,000 for the 6 months.

title: Market Place;   Bright Spots In All Sectors
description: ALTHOUGH some pivotal business sectors, such as energy and housing, are currently experiencing problems, analysts continue to be bullish on selected stocks in certain beleaguered industries.

title: BUS-RADIO PLAN TERMED DISASTER IN GOLDIN AUDIT
description: The Transit Authority has spent nearly $12 million on two-way radios for its buses, but drivers still have ''virtually no ability to call for help in an emergency,'' according to a report released yesterday by the City Comptroller.

title: Is This Museum Needed?
description: Not all women in the art field think a separate museum of art by women is such a welcome idea.

title: Topics;   On the Street Police Story
description: Anita McKeown of Santa Monica, Calif., is determined to be a policewoman even if it kills her. In the last year the 24-year-old rookie has been bitten by a rattlesnake, shot at, stabbed in the chest (a bulletproof vest saved her life), clubbed on the head and hit by a car.

title: Ex-Official Installed As Uganda's Premier
description: Paulo Muwanga, who was Vice President and Defense Minister under the ousted President, Milton Obote, was sworn in today as Prime Minister of the military Government that seized power in a coup five days ago.

title: MASSTOR SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSE DEMOCRATIC LEADERS ASSAIL REAGAN ON ECONOMY
description: Democratic leaders in the House sharply attacked the Reagan Administration's economic record today and charged that rising budget deficits ''will haunt us for generations.''

description: b-After tax credits of $1,897,000 for the quarter and $4,312,000 for the 9 months. c-After the reversal of a tax credit of $800,000.

title: Promises
description: Throughout baseball's labor negotiations, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth has insisted that he is neutral, siding with neither the players nor the owners. And, at a news conference yesterday where he discussed the talks and offered some possible solutions to the stalemate, he carried that stance one step further.

title: Diner's Journal
description: LOOKING for an amusing place to have a good cheap lunch or to sate the post-movie munchies? Try Exterminator Chili, a wacky diner-like eatery at 305 Church Street (at Walker) in the lower Broadway section of Manhattan. The name of this seven-month-old establishment is quite apt. Chili comes in three gradations on the gastronomic Richter scale: residential (mild), commercial (medium) and industrial (Is there a gardening hose in the house?). For $4.50 at lunch, you get a hefty bowl of chili served with slaw or potato salad and, if desired, a topping of sour cream, onions and cheddar cheese. A mild vegetarian chili also is available for the same price. (At dinner, portions are larger and chili is in the $6.50 range.) The types of chili sampled - I drew the line at commercial grade - were fresh and tasty. Unfortunately, the restaurant has no beer license, so you will have to make do with fruit juice or mineral water.

description: Debt Issues

title: A Certain Focus On Women's Art
description: Just up the street from the White House is a long disused headquarters of a male bastion that is soon to become the home of the world's largest collection of art by women.

Unassailable
description: Mike Ilitch, owner of the Detroit Red Wings, explains why his club has been loading up during the offseason in an aggressive pursuit of free agents: ''I hate to lose. I happen to be a fan with an owner's pocketbook.''

title: The Stakes in the Ford-Memoir Case
description: Our Constitution includes two fundamental concepts that usually work in concert but occasionally come into conflict. One is freedom of the press to report the news, guaranteed by the First Amendment. The other is Article I's authorization to Congress to secure ''for limited times to authors and inventors the exclusive right to their respective writings and discoveries.'' This was later expressed in the Copyright Act.

title: QUINTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOM'S COMMAND IS UPSET
description: The showdown between Mom's Command and Majestic Folly lived up to its billing today, with Mom's Command edging her highly regarded rival by a neck, but the two star fillies ended up finishing second and third behind the longshot Lady's Secret in the $121,000 Test Stakes today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: RUSSIANS PRESSING U.S. ON TEST BAN
description: The Soviet Union pressed the United States today to join in a moratorium on nuclear testing that was announced Monday by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

title: Driessen to Giants
description: Seeking pitching help for the final two months of the season (barring a players' strike), the Montreal Expos yesterday traded Dan Driessen, their starting first baseman, to the San Francisco Giants for the right-hander Bill Laskey, the reserve infielder Scot Thompson and a player to be named. The Expos, in third place in the National League East, are acquiring a ''hot'' pitcher in the 27-year-old Laskey, who has won his last four decisions.

title: TAYLOR: EXTRAORDINARY SKILL, ORDINARY FRUSTRATION
description: Some people think he is the best player in professional football. Some think he is the best linebacker ever. But in many ways, Lawrence Taylor is an ordinary man with ordinary weaknesses and frustrations.

title: SOTHEBY'S SETTLEMENT ON JUDAICA CHALLENGED
description: Officials of Hebrew Union College in Cincinnati yesterday asked a New York State judge in Manhattan to set aside a tentative settlement and order a trial to determine who owns a collection of Hebrew books and manuscripts sold by Sotheby's in New York last summer.

title: Slaying Confession May Be Admitted
description: Judge Seymour L. Hendel of Superior Court today denied a defense motion by Michael B. Ross to suppress a confession he gave in connection with the slaying of a 17-year-old Griswold girl.
