title: Blast Hurls a Manhole Cover; Street Vendor Seriously Hurt
description: An underground explosion blew off a manhole cover at Eighth Avenue and 42d Street at about 5 P.M. yesterday, seriously injuring a hot-dog vendor.

title: Andrews Improving
description: According to Dr. John Garrett, the team physician for the Atlanta Falcons, William Andrews, the all-pro running back, may be able to report to the team in mid-October. Andrews missed last season after his left knee was injured during training camp in August. He suffered nerve damage that left him with partial paralysis in his foot.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day yesterday with an article about the index of leading indicators misstated the percentage change in the index for June. It rose 0.96 percent.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, announced that Curtis B. Timmons has been named president of Angeles Real Estate Management Co., the company's property management subsidiary.

title: Knocking Out the Prop Under Marcos
description: The beginnings of a real transition to democracy in the Philippines may lie in the House's vote on the Administration's request for aid to President Ferdinand E. Marcos.

title: Stadium Is Factor In Sale of Giants
description: Peter Stocker, a real estate developer, says he reached a tentative agreement to buy a controlling interest in the San Francisco Giants, providing a downtown stadium can be built for the team.

title: Gasworks Issue By Philadelphia
description: The City of Philadelphia is offering $108.04 million of gasworks revenue bonds that are tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.277 percent for bonds due in 2012, through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. Boxing semifinals and women's gymnastics will be featured. (Television - ESPN, 8 P.M. to 11 P.M.) Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 8:35 P.M. Opener of a four-game weekend series and, in the event of a long strike, possibly the final home stand for the Yankees this season. (Television - Channel 4, 8:15 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 8:20 P.M.) Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. Opener of a four-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 4 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 4 P.M.) Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. The $300,000 Oliver Wendell Holmes Pace for 3-year-old colts and geldings will be contested in two heats worth $75,000 each - the second and third races - and a $150,000 final among the top five finishers in each preliminary. Primus, at 9-5, and Handsome Sum, at 2-1, are early favorites in the first heat. Pershing Square at 9-5, Anxious Robby at 2-1 and Marauder at 5-2 are favored in the second heat. (Television - MSG Network, midnight.) Roosevelt, 8 P.M. The $100,000 New York Sire Stakes is the feature. Monticello Raceway, 7:30 P.M. Tennis United States vs. West Germany, at Hamburg, Davis Cup quarterfinal competition. Boris Becker, the Wimbledon champion, is the new star of the West German team, which has never beaten the United States in six Davis Cup meetings. The United States team consists of Eliot Teltscher, who will face Becker, Aaron Krickstein, and the doubles pair of Ken Flach and Robert Seguso.

title: Chevron Net Down 9%
description: The Chevron Corporation reported today that earnings for the second quarter of 1985 declined 9 percent from a year earlier.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I appeal to the authorities, please do not try to find reasons for confrontation to make worse a situation which is already bad.'' - Bishop Desmond M. Tutu. [A1:2.]

title: HOUSE BACKS ECONOMIC SANCTIONS AGAINST SOUTH AFRICA, 380 TO 48
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican leader, appealed to South Africa's white authorities today to cancel newly announced restrictions on funeral rallies by blacks.

title: Dr. Reagan Can Use President Reagan's Help
description: To the Editor:

title: UNEASINESS ON SOUTH AFRICA GROWS
description: Many of the 300 American companies operating in South Africa are increasingly uncomfortable with their presence there, and some are looking for ways to retreat or reduce their involvement, according to interviews yesterday with executives at dozens of these companies.

title: ITT and General Dynamics Net Up
description: The ITT Corporation, buoyed by the results of its divestiture program, reported yesterday that earnings in the second quarter of 1985 rose 50.7 percent on a 6.3 percent increase in revenues.

title: EXPERIMENTS GO 'EXTREMELY WELL' DESPITE SOME PROBLEMS ON SHUTTLE
description: Extending their record of scientific successes, the Challenger astronauts today released a tiny satellite from the space shuttle's payload bay, took aim and shot it with a looping beam from an electron gun. Then, after a series of fancy flying maneuvers 190 miles above the earth, they plucked the satellite from space with the shuttle's 50-foot mechanican arm.

title: Jules Moch, French Socialist; Was Interior Minister in 40's
description: Jules Moch, a Socialist politician who served as Interior Minister in the 1940's, died today. He was 92 years old.

title: The New Soviet Style
description: Something is changing in Soviet-American relations. There hasn't been any breakthrough, beyond agreement to start serious preparations for the Reagan-Gorbachev summit conference in November.

title: OPPENHEIMER & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
200 Join Nicaraguan in Fast
description: About 200 members of the Central Committee of the World Council of Churches fasted today in solidarity with Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman of Nicaragua, a council spokesman said. Father d'Escoto has been fasting for a month to protest United States policy toward Nicaragua.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 2, 1985
description: The Economy

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, said it had completed the sale of its 27 percent interest in Alumina Partners of Jamaica, an refinery in southwest Jamaica, to Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corp. and Reynolds Metals Co. Terms were not disclosed.

title: STREET THEATER IS OFFERING SATIRE
description: The Theater for the New City is taking to the streets with ''The Man of Wax,'' its latest mix of music, dance, burlesque and political satire.

title: KULICKE & SOFFA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,571,000 for the quarter and $346,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income.

title: UEBERROTH OFFERS IDEAS ON DISPUTE
description: Combining his ideas with suggestions from fans and nonpaid consultants, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth yesterday unveiled a series of ideas he said he hoped would lead to a settlement of the protracted labor dispute between the baseball owners and the players and avert a strike set for Tuesday.

title: Sam Wooding, Pianist; Led a Black Big Band
description: Sam Wooding, who was one of the first musicians to introduce big-band black American jazz in Europe and South America, died yesterday at St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $132,000. c-Including tax credits of $1,852,000 for the quarter and $5,264,000 for the 6 months.

title: Tax Imported Oil
description: A tariff on imported crude and petroleum products has long been the best means of reducing our dependence on foreign oil. But never before have the circumstances for imposing one been so ideal.

title: Advertising;   Supermarkets May Be The Ultimate Ad Arena
description: With the help of their public relations people and some magical messaging of data, Bruce F. Failing Sr. and Jr. have decided that July 15 was the historic date when a single buy of in-store supermarket advertising surpassed any single television show in its ability to reach the nation's largest advertising audience.

title: INSTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses after net losses of $1,233,000 for the quarter and $1,659,000 for the 6 months and extraordinary credits of $22,000 for the quarter and $98,000 for the 6 months. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $109,000.

title: MILITANT SIKHS TO FIGHT ACCORD
description: Militant Sikh leaders pledged today to step up their protests against a recent accord to settle three years of agitation in the northern state of Punjab.

title: Chorus and Drums
description: The drummer and santeria priest Milton Cardona will lead a chorus and drumming group in ceremonial music and dancing tonight at 8 o'clock in the Summergarden series of the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street (708-9880). Admission is free.

title: Big Sister on the BBC Telly
description: We confess we have not seen ''At the Edge of the Union,'' a 45-minute documentary about Northern Ireland produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation. But neither have Prime Minister Thatcher or her Home Secretary, Leon Brittan. Relying on press accounts, they made an astonishing request that the program be suppressed - and the BBC's Board of Governors has complied with alarming alacrity. It's a bad show all around.

title: AT A HIMALAYAN REFUGE, BUDDHA VIES WITH VIDEO
description: Up the rocky mountainside they came in buses, trucks, motorcycles, jeeps and on foot, to witness a celebration of drums, cymbals and ''devil dances'' that has occurred once a year for centuries.

title: Dow Rises by 8.17 On Budget News
description: An apparent agreement in Congress yesterday on cuts in the Federal budget deficit helped Wall Street score its third straight advance, but the stock market's gains may have been kept in check by new concerns about President Reagan's health.

title: Panel Approves License For Coast Nuclear Plant
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved a full-power operating license for the second reactor at the Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California.

title: MONUMENTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net realized losses on investments of $692,000 for the quarter and $691,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss. d-Including net realized gains on investments of $127,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 6 months.

title: Time of Reappraisals For Ties to Pretoria
description: The making and remaking of U.S. policy on South Africa. Washington Talk, page A8.

title: McDonnell Douglas Offers Parts Refund
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation announced today what it called the ''most comprehensive'' refund policy in the aerospace industry on sales of spare parts and support equipment to the United States Government and foreign military customers.

title: 'PERIL,' A FRENCH MYSTERY AND ROMANCE
description: CHRISTOPHE MALAVOY, who plays David, the somewhat passive protagonist of ''Peril,'' wanders through much of the movie with an air of perplexity. As the events and characters pile in on him, the audience can only sympathize.

title: Dutch Dance Debut
description: Dansproduktie, a repertory dance company from Amsterdam, will make its New York City debut this weekend at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street.

title: QUANTRONIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $140,000.

title: SPIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'TONGUES' SHOWS OFF VIDEO DEVICES
description: ''ALIVE FROM OFF CENTER,'' public television's summertime fling into video technology and art, continues on Sunday night with ''Tongues'' - words by Sam Shepard, performance by Joseph Chaikin, direction by Shirley Clarke. It is, roughly, a work about life and death, and the world that lies between them. Mr. Chaikin speaks in strange voices; Miss Clarke computerizes his image. On the whole, however, it is Mr. Shepard's words that lend the film its distinction. ''Tongues'' can be seen on Channel 13 at 10:30 P.M.

title: CONCERT: 'LUISA FERNANDZ,' ZARZUELA
description: ANYONE wanting an alternative to next week's outsized zarzuela extravaganza at Madison Square Garden can visit the tiny Gramercy Arts Theater on East 27th Street. Here, for most of August, Repertorio Espanol is offering a remarkably attractive production of Federico Moreno Torroba's ''Luisa Fernanda.''

title: License Pictures Optional
description: Governor Kean signed a bill today making optional the requirement that drivers older than 21 have licenses with their photographs. The law, which makes all licenses valid for four years, eliminates the two-year period for conventional licenses. Drivers over 21 who obtain a New Jersey license for the first time must still have photo licenses.

title: Touche Ross Fills 3 Leadership Posts
description: Touche Ross & Company, the Big Eight accounting firm, announced that its partners had elected three executives to assume overall leadership of the firm.

title: German Cost of Living
description: The cost of living decreased two-tenths of 1 percent in West Germany in July from June, to a level 2.3 percent above that of July 1984, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Cantor David Kusevitsky yesterday and its headline incorrectly described his tenure. He was the cantor at Temple Emanu-El in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn at his death.

title: SUPERTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: MACMILLAN BLOEDEL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: STV ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ORION RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $61,000 for the latest first quarter and $141,000 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: DR. REAGAN CAN USE PRESIDENT REAGAN'S HELP
description: To the Editor:

title: BRACKEN EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOUSEHOLD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FILM: BIG BIRD ON THE BIG SCREEN WITH THE 'SESAME STREET' GANG
description: AFTER 16 years as an ornament of children's television, ''Sesame Street'' has made it into the movies. To be sure, Jim Henson's Muppets are already veterans of the big screen, but ''Sesame Street Presents: Follow That Bird,'' which opens today at the R.K.O. Century Warner Twin and other theaters, introduces their human friends and neighbors and the celebrated street itself. Although at moments they seem slightly displaced on the big screen, they make good company.

title: Science Fiction
description: It's not easy to find an expert witness to weigh in against the Reagan Administration's Strategic Defense Initiative, the space-based defense against missiles, widely known as ''Star Wars,'' because it thus far exists only in the imagination of scientists and intercontinental defense experts.

title: PRECISION CASTPARTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,176,000.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday JUMPING AT CONEY ISLAND They bill themselves the Golden Knights, and when the members of the United States Army Precision Parachute Jump Team perform free air shows this weekend at Coney Island, their stunts will include passing batons back and forth in midair, special effects involving smoke trailing from brackets attached to their boots, free-fall demonstrations and a four-person drop, in which the jumpers maneuver their bodies in position to create a tight formation. The Knights will jump from 13,500 feet onto a banner in the form of a cross 10 feet long by 1 foot wide in a target area at ''show center.'' The shows will be held today, tomorrow and Sunday from 1:30 to 2 P.M. as a highlight of the fourth Coney Island Midsummer Festival. The stunts should be visible from any place along the Boardwalk. ''Show center'' will be at the foot of West 10th Street, near the Astroland amusement park and the Cyclone roller coaster. Information: (718) CO6-3434.

title: MINNESOTA PANEL RESUMES HEARING ON HANDLING OF SEX ABUSE CASE
description: After a seven-week delay, an executive commission resumed hearings today on how a prosecutor handled a child sex abuse case in Jordan, Minn., that ended in dismissal of nearly all charges.

title: OVERLAND EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: PAGEANT RESTORES 'THERE SHE IS'
description: Miss America Pageant officials have bowed to public pressure and re-instated the traditional crowning song ''There She Is'' after a three-year absence. However, the former master of ceremonies, Bert Parks, said today that he had declined an offer to return to sing the tune to Miss America 1986.

title: DICKENS CHARACTERS ARE SET TO MUSIC
description: ''For years I was an apple trying to be an orange,'' Rupert Holmes reflected last week. As an ''orange,'' the 38-year-old singer, composer and arranger toiled in the record business through the 1970's making seven pop albums and producing a number of acts, including Barbra Streisand.

title: RAMADA INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $681,000 for the quarter and $923,000 for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $233,000 for the quarter and $380,000 for the 6 months. The net income for the latest quarter and 6 months includes a pre-tax gain of $5.4 million and $8.3 million, respectively, from the sale of property. The net income for both year- earlier periods includes pre-tax gains of $1.1 million for the quarter and $3.9 million for the 6 months from the sale of property.

title: A Reunion
description: More and more political candidates from various parts of the country are holding fund-raising affairs in Washington these days, and that includes former members of Congress with revived ambitions.

title: ALLIED PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $3,172,000 for the quarter and $5,163,000 for the six months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,022,000 for the quarter and $1,618,000 for the six months and tax credits of $1,215,000 for the quarter and $1,857,000 for the six months.

title: COMMERCIAL FEDERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $991,000. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $619,000. Year-ago per share figures were unavailable because the company went public in September 1984.

title: AMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a provision of $350,000,000 for the quarter and the six months for losses on properties and investments. c-Net income including a pretax gain of $20,700,000 for the quarter and the six months from the sale to Britloil of a 50 percent interest in most of the company's domestic oil and gas reserves and a tax credit of $5,600,000.

title: AMAX Posts Big Loss
description: AMAX Inc. said yesterday that it lost $394.9 million in the second quarter, in contrast to earnings of $9.8 million, or 6 cents a share, a year ago. Sales were down 19.7 percent, to $523 million, from $651 million in the 1984 period. The loss partly reflects a $350 million write-down of properties and investments, including $175 million in termination costs for copper facilities in Arizona and Carteret, N.J.

title: ADVANCED TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Andre Obrecht Dies in France; Longtime Chief Executioner
description: Andre Obrecht, France's chief executioner for a quarter of a century, died Wednesday in a hospital here after a career in which he beheaded hundreds of criminals.

title: Mobile, BellSouth Plan to Sue MCI
description: The Mobile Communications Corporation of America and the BellSouth Corporation said they would proceed with legal action against the MCI Communications Corporation for MCI's repudiation of an agreement signed July 24.

title: Venezuela Cuts Price of Oil
description: Faced with growing pressure from competitors, Venezuela dropped the price of its heavy crude oils by an average of $1.95 a barrel today, in a move that had been expected.

title: Study Backs Shift Of Lilco Gas Unit
description: The sale of the Long Island Lighting Company's natural-gas operations to the Brooklyn Union Gas Company would reduce Lilco electric rates by 2.5 percent, according to a report released today that favored the sale.

title: SPENDING RISES ON BUILDING
description: New construction spending rose a moderate seven-tenths of 1 percent in June, the Commerce Department said today. While private building activity declined, there was a big increase in Government projects.

title: Advertising;   More Than Yuppies in Baby Boom
description: SO you know all you want to know about yuppies, but what about so-called workers, elite workers and would be's who make up the rest of the 21-to-39 age group bulge known as the baby boomers.

title: Victim at Lifeguards' Party
description: A guest at a party for lifeguards celebrating their first drowning-free swimming season in memory drowned Tuesday, the director of the New Orleans Recreation Department said today. Madlyn Richard, the department director, said the body of Jerome Moody was found on the bottom at the deep end of a department pool as the party ended. She said Mr. Moody, who was 31 years old, was not a lifeguard, but four lifeguards were on duty at the party.

title: An Offer Refused
description: The sun worshiper made a rare midweek visit to Jacob Riis Park in Queens and was enjoying a plum, a book and some music via earphones, when it happened:

title: Cluett Rejects Takeover Offer
description: Cluett, Peabody & Company rejected a $336 million takeover bid, but the two California investors who made the bid said they would ''vigorously pursue'' their efforts to acquire the New York apparel company and would consider making an all-cash tender offer to shareholders. The investors, Paul Bilzerian and William Brodovsky, hold a 9.9 percent stake in Cluett and last week offered to buy the company, whose brands include Arrow shirts, for $40 a share, half in cash and half in debt securities.

title: CETEC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including 9 cents a share writeoff of inventory valued at approximately $341,000 due to Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings instituted by Semi Processes Inc.

title: E. F. Hutton Testimony
description: Current and former middle-level employees of E. F. Hutton & Company defended their money management and check overdrafting practices today before a House of Representatives panel.

title: Wait a Wowate
description: On the questionable theory that what Washington needs is one more acronym, R. James Woolsey, former Under Secretary of the Navy, has produced a new unit for measuring time: the Wowate. The initials stand for ''World War II equivalent,'' and one Wowate is equal to the time between Pearl Harbor and the Japanese surrender, or three years and eight months.

title: PRIMO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Western Union Strike Grows
description: About 600 workers represented by the Communications Workers of America struck the Western Union Corporation Wednesday, joining about 6,500 United Telegraph Workers who struck the company on Sunday.

title: U.S. in Steel Accord
description: The United States reached an agreement with the European Economic Community today on steel exports to this country.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THOUGH it seems only natural for a director to have a rooting interest in a picture, Martha Coolidge takes the position that there's more at stake than personal success when ''Real Genius'' opens next Wednesday.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $5,573,000, or $1.44 a share, for the quarter and the six months from an accounting change. c-Including a gain of $771,000, or 21 cents a share for the quarter and the six months, from retirement of bonds.

title: PROSECUTOR IN ALASKA INQUIRY TELLS OF WARNING TO GOVERNOR
description: Alaska's chief prosecutor said today at impeachment proceedings against Gov. Bill Sheffield that he warned the Governor at a detailed briefing in April about a possible scandal in his administration.

title: Ameritech Seeks Waiver
description: The American Information Technologies Corporation said today that it had asked the Justice Department for permission to make telecommunications and computer equipment overseas.

title: Media Concerns Attract Paine Webber Officer
description: Since last January, when he was named president of PaineWebber Capital Inc., Jack L. Rivkin has been getting the firm, a unit of Paine Webber Inc., into the communications business.

title: VARIED PROGRAM OF BARYSHNIKOV TROUPE ON TOUR
description: New York-area dance fans have a chance to see Mikhail Baryshnikov perform in not one but three ballets on Sunday, when Baryshnikov & Dancers appear at the Garden State Arts Center in Holmdel, N. J. The event will be repeated Monday night at Symphony Hall in Springfield, Mass., where the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival will present the dancers in a gala benefit. But there's more to the performances than a rare chance to savor Mr. Baryshnikov's art. Audiences will also be able to see some of the American Ballet Theater's most promising young dancers, as well as leading company members, in roles they do not ordinarily get to perform during New York seasons.

title: COMPROMISE AVOIDS MAJOR CUTS IN BENEFITS
description: The budget agreement reached today by House and Senate negotiators generally avoids making deep cuts in Federal benefit programs for the elderly, poor people and residents of the nation's cities.

title: CONGRESS PASSES BUDGET FOR 1986, ENDING DEADLOCK
description: Ending months of sometimes bitter disagreement, the House and the Senate tonight approved a 1986 budget plan that would shrink projected deficits by $55.5 billion in 1986 and by $276.2 billion over three years.

title: Nicaragua Calls Alert After Report on Carrier
description: The Defense Ministry said today that its armed forces had been placed on maximum alert after a United States aircraft carrier was detected off the Atlantic coast.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Operating loss. c-Net loss.

title: CFS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. Year-ago per share figure was unavailable because the company did not convert to a stock company until May 15, 1985.

title: Davis Cup Team Prepares for Becker
description: The tall kid in the blue sweat pants with the striped short-sleeved sweater over his T-shirt didn't seem to mind the 60-degree, overcast weather. Standing on the back court at the Rothenbaum tennis club, pumping one searing ball after another over the net, he was creating heat of his own.

title: ITT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago revenues have been restated.

title: CALIFORNIA DREAMING?
description: In a city intrigued with such things as who's on first at the White House, even a mere list of the top aides who will accompany President Reagan on his three-week vacation in California has a certain fascination.

title: GENERAL REFRACTORIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $450,000 for the quarter and $950,000 for the six months. c-Including tax credits of $55,000 for the quarter and $400,000 for the six months.

title: DIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Musicians' Blues
description: Deep in the heart of Wall Street, the music of Ellen Seeling and the Big Apple Jazzwomen echoed among the skyscrapers. While the lunchtime crowd listened, the all-woman band struck some new notes.

title: U.S. WARNS OF MALARIA PERIL AT MEXICAN COASTAL RESORTS
description: Federal health officials warned American vacationers today of the possibility of getting malaria at Mexican tourist resorts on the Pacific Coast.

title: A DOUBLE LIFE
description: BEFORE MY LIFE BEGAN. By Jay Neugeboren. Simon & Schuster. 391 pages. $18.95. Novels of growing up Jewish are such a well-mined genre that it takes considerable imaginative daring to tackle the subject again - and considerable originality to try to do it new. Unfortunately, Jay Neugeboren's latest foray into this territory only makes us feel that we have been there before - and that the tour, by now, has a stale familiarity.

title: Consumers Power
description: The Consumers Power Company said the Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a formal inquiry into whether the company had properly disclosed cost overruns and delays on its Midland nuclear plant. Construction was halted on the plant last year. The company had said previously that the S.E.C. was making an informal investigation.

title: Phillips Petroleum Retirement Offer
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, which already has granted early retirement to 1,930 employees aged 58 or older, is extending a second retirement incentive program to about 1,200 employees between the ages of 55 and 57, officials said today. C. J. Silas, chairman and chief executive of the company that fought off a pair of recent takeover attempts, said payroll reductions through Aug. 1 are expected to save the company $72 million this year.

title: Indians Buy Katy Unit
description: A group of Wisconsin-based Indians has bought the Simpson Electric Company from Katy Industries for $22.9 million. Katy's chairman, Wallace Carroll, said the new owners, the Lac du Flambeau band of the Lake Superior Chippewa Indian tribe, told him the sale was the largest purchase of a manufacturing company by an Indian tribe in the United States. Simpson, which makes electrical meters, has a plant on the tribe's Wisconsin reservation that employs 400 people.

title: Genstar Seeking Canada Trustco
description: The Genstar Corporation said that it plans a $4-a-share offer to acquire 12 million common shares of the Canada Trustco Mortgage Company, which would increase its stake in the company to 50.1 percent, from 9.8 percent.

title: PRESIDENTIAL LIFE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AMERICAN PIONEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax benefit of $825,000 for the quarter and the six months and a provision of $2,400,000 for the six months for losses in the settlement of five Alabama lawsuits.c-Including a tax benefit of $410,000 for the quarter and the six months. There were no share earnings for the latest six months because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRETORIA AGREES TO MEET WEST EUROPEANS
description: South Africa agreed today to a visit by three West European Foreign Ministers, but it warned them not to interfere in the country's affairs.

title: GARAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JURY IS DELIBERATING IN TRIAL OF 4 ACCUSED OF BOMBING SCHEME
description: A Federal jury began deliberations today in the trial of four suspected members of a Puerto Rican group charged with plotting to bomb two military installations on the Fourth of July two years ago.

title: SYNALLOY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $17,062 from discontinued operations for the quarter and the 6 months.

title: ARCHIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $219,000 for the quarter and $429,000 for the nine months.

title: RAUSCHENBERG CARRYING HIS ART TO MANY LANDS
description: Robert Rauschenberg calls it the ''Rocky Road Tour,'' and he admits that it may indeed get a bit rocky before he reaches the end of his projected five-year, 22-country odyssey.

title: TAKING THE TRUST OUT OF CONTRACTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Du Pont-Taiwan
description: The Du Pont Company will invest about $160 million to set up a titanium dioxide plant in Taiwan, the largest foreign investment there for 10 years, Paul Costello, vice president of Du Pont Far East Inc., said. He said the plant should be completed in two and half years and will produce 60,000 tons a year, part of which will be exported to Southeast Asia.

title: PLAYBOY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $244,000 for the quarter and income of $1,213,000 for the year from discontinued operations, a tax charge of $87,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $2,456,000 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,016,000 for the quarter and $12,433,000 for the year and tax credits of $1,790,000 for the quarter and $8,605,000 for the year.

title: 3 EUROPEAN COUNTRIES PLAN JET FIGHTER PROJECT
description: Britain, West Germany and Italy announced today that they would push ahead with a $15 billion program to develop an advanced new jet fighter for the 21st century.

title: F.C.C. BACKS RULING ON CABLE
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would not try to save a rule, recently struck down by a Federal court, that required cable television operators to carry local commercial television signals.

title: COMDIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $4,500,000 resulting from the sale of Comdial Ltd. c-Including a provision of $6,000,000 for costs associated with the consolidation of the Upland, Calif. manufacturing activities into the Charlottesville, Va. facility.

title: JURY IS CHOSEN FOR TRIAL OF F.B.I. AGENT ON COAST
description: Seven women and five men have been seated on the jury to hear the espionage trial of Richard W. Miller, the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation to be charged with spying.

title: BY PHONE, LEGAL FIRST AID FOR A FIXED FEE
description: For less than $100 a year, some companies are selling what they say can be a seven-minute over-the-telephone solution to most day-to-day legal problems. Such plans are one type of prepaid legal service, and they occupy the middle ground between keeping a lawyer on retainer and writing to ''Dear Abby.''

title: TEACHING MANAGERS TO HANDLE CRISES
description: New managers quickly learn we live in an imperfect world. A world with cartels, sudden economic shifts, fierce competitors like the Japanese, and - even worse - crises.

title: TENANTS VS. OWNERS: A NEW WEST SIDE STORY
description: On a mild, sunny summer's day, along a serene and picturesque little side street of brownstones and trees, a woman sticks her head out a front door and yells: ''If you can't afford to live in New York, you oughta get out!''

title: A BEL CANTO PANEL PLANNED AT MERKIN HALL
description: A ''Bel Canto Singers' Panel'' will be the final installment in the Bel Canto Festival Lectures series sponsored by the New York City Opera.

title: BOLD G.M. PACT DRAWS PRAISE, AND SOME CAVEATS
description: Experts are praising the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers for the bold approach they have taken on the company's Saturn project, one that could mean a dramatic break with methods that have dominated American industry for three-quarters of a century.

title: OLYMPIA, CHEVRON IN NEW PACT
description: Olympia & York Ltd., the Canadian real estate company, yesterday bought control of Gulf Canada Ltd., just two weeks after breaking off a purchase agreement and forfeiting a $25 million deposit.

title: EFFORT TO IMPEACH ALASKAN EXPECTED TO FAIL
description: An apparent consensus to exonerate Gov. Bill Sheffield has emerged in the Alaska Senate after 11 days of impeachment hearings.

title: Southland-McColl
description: The Southland Corporation, the Dallas-based retailer and gasoline company, said it would sell its Southland-McColl Ltd. subsidiary to Martin the Newsagent P.L.C., a unit of Guinness P.L.C. Southland-McColl has 371 confectionary, tobacco and news stores in Scotland and Northern England, which will continue to operate under the R.S. McColl trade name. Southland, parent of the 7-Eleven chain, did not disclose the price, but Guinness said it paid about $33 million.

title: QUEENS PARK RISES IN RUINS OF WASTELAND
description: In the 1970's, the 54-acre site in St. Albans, Queens, was a sprawling, perilous eyesore that deeply troubled the surrounding community.

title: MEDSTAT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
JOHN HANCOCK INVESTORS TR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Brewery Venture
description: The Adolph Coors Company said that it and two other family-controlled breweries, Molson Breweries of Canada and Kaltenberg Castle Brewery of West Germany, have formed the Masters Brewing Company. It said that the new company is not a merger of the three but will operate independently. It said that Masters would compete against the three companies in various markets.

title: Eastern L.I. Bays Still Contain Algae
description: An algal bloom that began turning parts of some bays brown on eastern Long Island more than a month ago is diminishing but still dense in many areas, marine scientists said today.

title: BOOTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
TREND-SETTING QUONSET HUT IS DEMOLISHED ON L.I.
description: Too young to be preserved as a historic landmark and too old to be enjoyed by its owner, a house symbolizing postwar Modernism in the Hamptons was demolished yesterday.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FARMERS' MARKET LURES OFFICE WORKERS AT LUNCHTIME
description: Investment bankers jostled for the last pint of raspberries, lawyers debated the growing season for broccoli and secretaries stripped the husk from corn to check the size of the kernels.

title: GROSS SAYS HE IS VICTIM OF 'WITCH HUNT' BY STATE
description: Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, accused state health authorities yesterday of leading a ''lynch mob'' and a ''witch hunt'' by charging him with negligence, incompetence and professional misconduct in the handling of a series of cases.

title: 4 Important Feet
description: When Donald J. Trump thinks about building, he usually thinks big and bold.

title: L.I. TOWN WORKERS TELL ABOUT GIVING TO G.O.P.
description: Several employees of the Town of Hempstead testified in Federal court today that they had made political contributions to the Republican Party because they believed it was necessary to get promotions and salary increases.

title: AMERICAN LOCKER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $40,538 for the quarter and a gain of $32,058 for the six months from discontinued operations and a gain of $59,583 for the quarter and the six months from the disposal of assets. c-Including a gain of $33,933 for the quarter and a loss of $53,936 for the six months from discontinued operations and a gain of $436,946 for the quarter and the six months from the disposal of assets.

title: WHITE HOUSE WON'T COMMENT ON NOSE OPERATION
description: White House officials turned away questions today about the minor surgery in which a piece of skin was removed from President Reagan's nose.

title: PRESSURE PIPING COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $238,000 for the year and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $33,000 for the quarter and $2,645,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $221,000 for the quarter and $419,000 for the year.

title: SOVEREIGN DON WINS
description: Sovereign Don, who is not even the most highly regarded 2-year-old in the Wayne Lukas Stable, continued to make a name for himself today by winning the $72,000 Saratoga Special by a neck at Saratoga Race Track. Sovereign Don, who scored an upset in the Tremont last month, overtook Hagley's Reward in the stretch, with the entry of Bullet Blade and Mr. Classic finishing another four lengths back.

title: CORRECTION
description: A sampler of writings by Heinrich Boll, printed July 17 with his obituary, misattributed the translation of ''Billiards at Half-Past Nine.'' The book was translated anonymously, though an early paperback version erroneously credited Leila Vennewitz.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $877,000 for the quarter and $774,000 for the 6 months. c-After a capital loss of $27,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $586,000 for the 6 months.

title: ROD CAREW IN TWILIGHT
description: Just two months short of his 40th birthday and two hits short of 3,000 for his career, Rod Carew might be expected to take the mellow approach of an elder statesman. Not so.

title: Rolls-Royce Milestone
description: Rolls-Royce, builder of the world's most luxurious automobiles, rolled out its 100,000th motor car today - a royal blue Silver Spur sedan. The car is to go on permanent display at the factory alongside a 1904 two-cylinder open tourer that was built in the year that the racing driver Charles Rolls and the electrical engineer Henry Royce formed their partnership.

title: ON THE 7TH DAY HE'LL REST
description: Many members of Congress cultivate a humble, just-folks manner back home to assure constituents that their heads have not been swelled by the company of all those inflated egos in Washington.

title: ALUMAX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GUATEMALA ECONOMY DEEP IN GLOOM
description: There are lines for gasoline, beggars are common, and the national currency is sliding so fast that importers increase prices almost daily.

title: A TIDY RIBBON
description: Aware that large gatherings in Washington often become unruly to the point of many arrests, the 100,000 or so people arriving this weekend to loop 11 miles of ''peace ribbon'' around the Pentagon, the Ellipse and the Capitol have been well briefed on the do's and don'ts of assembly.

title: HEAD OF E.P.A. WARNS OF DELAY ON TOXIC WASTE
description: The head of the Environmental Protection Agency says he is being forced to slow or halt the cleanup of toxic waste sites because Congress has not yet renewed the program.

title: REMOVAL OF SKIN FROM REAGAN'S NOSE PROMPTS QUESTIONS ABOUT TREATMENT
description: Less than three weeks after President Reagan had major surgery to remove a cancerous polyp from his colon, he had another operation, this one minor, and again questions have come up.

title: BRITISH NEW-COLONIALS UPSET HONG KONG
description: The British authorities here, who will have to turn Hong Kong over to China in 1997, are alienating the public in their efforts to show that they are not a lame-duck administration. Dire consequences could result.

title:
PATENTS;

Studying of Metal Ions In Cell Walls Is Aided
description: A patent received this week by the Research Foundation of the State University of New York, in Albany, is regarded as valuable in scientific research.

title: UNITED TELECONTROL ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Murchison Wins Round
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge refused today to appoint a special trustee to handle the finances of Clinton W. Murchison Jr., former owner of the Dallas Cowboys, rejecting creditors' assertions that the millionaire was too sick to oversee his businesses. Judge John C. Ford, who is presiding over the bankruptcy case involving $400 million in debts, found Mr. Murchison, 61 years old, to be mentally competent and capable of reorganizing his businesses under Chapter 11 protection.

title: HAMBURGER HAMLETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains from the sale of property of $83,647 for the latest first quarter and $446,409 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: 2 Killed, 4 Injured In Brooklyn Blaze
description: A fast-moving fire that officials labeled suspicious burned a three-story Brooklyn brownstone yesterday, killing two women, one of them the building's owner, and injuring four other people, one seriously, authorities said.

title: AMERICAN GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $8,077,000 for the quarter and $21,404,000 for the six months. c-Including capital gains of $10,665,000 for the quarter and $19,678,000 for the six months. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: JAPAN CHIP 'DUMPING' IS FOUND
description: In a major trade victory for United States semiconductor makers, the International Trade Commission issued a preliminary finding yesterday that Japanese memory chip manufacturers were ''dumping'' chips in the American market.

title: 2 Held in Attempt To Claim Building
description: Two Brooklyn men were arrested yesterday for breaking into an abandoned, city-owned building in the East New York section of Brooklyn and trying to occupy it, according to the police.

title: WISH COMES TRUE
description: John Candelaria, the 31-year-old pitcher who wanted a trade, got his wish yesterday as he and two other highly paid, disgruntled Pittsburgh Pirates were sent to the California Angels for three younger players, including Mike Brown, a 25-year-old outfielder, and Pat Clements, a 23-year-old left-handed pitcher. The third Angel in the deal will not be identified until he clears waivers.

title: BUCKEYE FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MOUNTAIN MEDICAL EQUIPENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
I.M.F. WARNS EGYPT ABOUT MOUNTING DEBTS
description: The International Monetary Fund has warned Egypt that its balance of payments position is facing ''serious deterioration'' and that there is an ''urgent need'' to enact an austerity program.

title: MONITOR LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Semiconductor Production Halt
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation said that it would stop production for at least five days during this quarter in both the United States and Europe because of a prolonged slump in semiconductor sales.

title: 3 WORKERS KILLED BY FIRE IN INDIANA GASOLINE SPILL
description: A gasoline leak from a ruptured pipeline erupted today into a 200-foot fireball that killed three people working to clean up the spill.

title: Difference of Opinion
description: As Mayor Koch left a housing dedication ceremony on East 103d Street the other day, a shout rang out from somewhere in the middle of a crowd of about 100 spectators.

title: ATLANTA GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $4,509,000 on an exchange of debt for equity.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results include a realized gain of 3 cents a share from an insurance claim resulting from flood losses at the New Jersey distribution center.

title: Soviet Plans to Compete
description: The Soviet Union, which led a Communist- bloc boycott of the Los Angeles Olympics, will have a team at the 1988 Summer Games in Seoul, South Korea, one of its key officals said today.

title: KEY PHARMACEUTICALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ARAB UNIVERSITY IN WEST BANK CLOSED BY ISRAEL FOR 2 MONTHS
description: An Arab university in the West Bank town of Nablus was ordered closed for two months today by the Israeli military authorities.

title: U.P.I. PLAN TO VOID UNION PACT HAULTED
description: United Press International today withdrew an application to Federal Bankruptcy Court to abrogate its contract with its major union and agreed to begin mediation sessions with the union Aug. 14.

title: PAWLING SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago per share figures are not available because the bank converted from mutual form in August 1984.

title: AMERICAN LAND CRUISERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TRANS-LOUISIANA GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RICO RECOGNIZES RACKETEERS WHO WEAR THREE-PIECE SUITS
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I doubt Congress will do all the things we've been asked to do, and the deficit will really be much larger in three years than anticipated in the debate on the budget resolution.'' - Bob Dole, Senate majority leader. [1:5.]

title: 2 UNDER ARREST IN IRAN ARMS PLOT ARE SUSPECTS IN PREVIOUS DEALINGS
description: Federal investigators, having foiled what they said was a plot to smuggle missiles from the United States to Iran, said today that they were seeking to determine whether some of the people arrested in the last two days previously shipped arms to Iran.

title: UGI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bond Prices Show Declines
description: Bond prices fell yesterday after prospects for lower interest rates were dimmed by the Government's report of larger-than-expected employment growth in July.

title: ACCENTS FROM THE COUTURE
description: In keeping with the classic look of the Paris couture collections, the breathtaking array of accessories that blinded the eyes and overshadowed the clothes in other seasons has been replaced by less aggressive accents. In last month's fall and winter shows, the accessories carried out the luxurious but subdued look of the clothes.

title: NUTRI-FOODS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: GUARANTY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $2,000 for the quarter and $1,109,000 for the six months. c-Net losses after a capital loss of $1,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $81,000 for the six months.

title: DIRECT MARKETING THRIVING IN U.S.
description: Although Montgomery Ward & Company is planning to close out its catalogue operation, the business of direct marketing is booming in America.

title: BASEBALL TALKS SET TO RESUME
description: Negotiators for baseball's club owners and players will apparently not settle their differences on the basis of Commissioner Peter Ueberroth's suggested solutions, but they will begin talking again today in an effort to keep the players from walking out after Monday's games.

title: GRANT WILLIAMS
description: Grant Williams, the actor who starred in the science fiction film ''The Incredible Shrinking Man,'' died at the Veterans Administration Hospital here last Sunday after being treated for blood poisoning.

title: JETS' JONES TO HAVE SURGERY ON FINGER
description: Coach Joe Walton of the Jets seemed almost embarrassed today to announce another of what he termed ''one of those tough breaks'' - a disabling injury to a starter.

title: FLOWER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
German Jobless Rate
description: West Germany's unemployment rate rose to 9 percent in July, from 8.7 percent in June, the Federal Labor Office said today. The office said 2.2 million people were out of work in July, compared with 2.16 million in June.

title: IMPROVING CREDIT RATING
description: THE National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has compiled tread-wear ratings for 134 brands of radial tires. Each rating point is equivalent to approximately 200 miles of driving.

title: SOUTH KOREN DISSIDENT FREED FROM DETENTION
description: Kim Dae Jung, the opposition leader, was freed early today from house arrest that had been imposed on the eve of a national convention of his New Korea Democratic Party.

title: MANVILLE OFFERS ASBESTOS VICTIMS $2.5 BILLION FUND
description: The Manville Corporation, after grappling for 15 years with thousands of asbestos-related claims, yesterday offered to pay victims $2.5 billion in the largest health-related settlement proposal ever made by an American company.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BROTHERS DIE IN FIRE
description: Two brothers were killed, another was critically burned and seven police officers and firefighters were injured in a fire that officials said broke out at 12:35 A.M. today in the kitchen of a row house in Upper Darby Township, a suburb of Philadelphia.

title: IN HOTELS VIEW, IT'S BETTER TO GIVE
description: As recent travelers have discovered, the number of small gift items found in a traditional hotel room has been increasing. With occupancy rates either flat or declining in many cities, hotels are eager to distinguish themselves from competitors. And one way to do so is through amenities - from body lotions and bath gels to sewing kits and chocolate mints.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMAX Inc., Greenwich, Conn., said it would cut its staff by 109 in reorganizing and consolidating various departments into its Golden, Colo., offices.

title: HOME OWNERS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $284,000 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. stock dividend. Year-ago share earnings are not available because Home Owners Federal went public June 1, 1984.

title: ELGIN NATIONAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M. to 4 P.M., live, and 8 P.M. to 11 P.M., live.) Mobil Big Apple Games final, at John F. Kennedy High School, 230th Street and Terrace View Avenue, the Bronx, 9 A.M. Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 1:35 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:20 P.M.) Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. (Television - SportsChannel, 4 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 4 P.M.) Reds vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Cincinnati. The red-hot Dodgers meet the red-hot Reds and Pete Rose. (Radio - WCBS 880, 3 P.M.) Football Giants vs. Houston Oilers, at Canton, Ohio, Hall of Fame exhibition game. Joe Namath, Roger Staubach, O. J. Simpson, Commissioner Pete Rozelle and Frank Gatski will be inducted into the pro football Hall of Fame at halftime. Namath makes his debut as a commentator on the ABC telecast. (Television - Channel 7, 2:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 2:30 P.M.) Golf Western Open, at Oak Brook, Ill., third round. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) L.P.G.A. Jamie Farr Toldedo Classic, third round. Metropolitan Amateur Golf Championships, Ridgewood Country Club, Paramus, N.J., 18-hole semifinal round, 1 P.M. Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 12:30 P.M. The $1 million Hambletonian, second leg of the triple crown series for 3-year-old trotters, is the feature of this special afternoon program. (Television - ESPN, 3:30 P.M., live. MSG Network, midnight, tape.) Roosevelt, 8 P.M. The $100,000 Challenge Cup Trot is the feature.

title: GRADCO SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income after a loss from discontinued operations of $220,000.

title: POWER FAILURE IN LOUISIANA
description: A barge snagged Houma's main power line early Thursday morning, cutting electricity to about a quarter of the 32,600 residents. For seven and a half hours, until most power was restored, boat traffic on the Intracoastal Waterway was tied up because lift bridges over the canal could not be raised. All 9,000 homes and businesses served by the city power system were affected.

title: EARTHQUAKE JOLTS PAKISTAN
description: An earthquake rocked towns across northern Pakistan today, three days after a quake demolished dozens of houses and killed several people in the same area. Government officials said there had been no reports of any injuries or damage from the latest quake, which lasted less than a minute.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 3, 1985
description: International

title: CRIMINALS, VICTIMS - AND VICTIMS
description: In 1975 Joseph Kallinger, a Philadelphia shoemaker, was convicted of killing a nurse named Maria Fasching, a 10-year-old boy and his own 14-year-old son. Another teen-age son accompanied him on several of his vicious sprees. Now the man is in a hospital for the criminally insane.

title: RAYCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,061,000. c-Including tax credits of $1,231,000 for the quarter and $7,485,000 for the year.

title: OPPOSITION IS EAGER TO TAKE ON MARCOS
description: Opposition leaders, responding to an announcement that President Ferdinand E. Marcos is seriously considering calling a presidential election this year, expressed eagerness and optimism today at the prospect of an electoral battle.

title: CONCERT: TINA TURNER PERFORMS AT THE GARDEN
description: Tina Turner capped one of the most extraordinary career resurgences in popular music history on Thursday night with a performance at Madison Square Garden in which she fully lived up to the label ''queen of rock and roll'' that people have been applying to her in the last year.

title: MASSCOMP reports earnings for Year to June 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $750,000. c-Net loss.

title:
PATENTS;

Device and Method Get Drugs to Heart Rapidly
description: Dr. Robert T. Gordon, chief of the department of cardiac surgery at the Lutheran General Hospital, Park Ridge, Ill., has invented a device and method for the rapid delivery of drugs and therapeutics to the heart.

title: CONCERT: MOZART AND MORE
description: The air-conditioning and the music had much in common at Thursday night's Mostly Mozart concert in Avery Fisher Hall. Over the audience and these performances, at least, blew a pleasant, slightly glacial breeze - one calculated to maintain listeners in comfort and disturb them only minimally.

title: GIVE MERIT RAISES TO SCHOOLS
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST GERMANS LEAD DAVIS CUP BY 2-0
description: West Germany added a minor deity to its new tennis pantheon today after Hansjorg Schwaier joined Boris Becker in sweeping the United States in the singles round of the Davis Cup quarterfinals.

title: SIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INTERNATIONAL SEAWAY TRADNG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $136,000 for the quarter and $305,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: CONQUEST EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AST RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $250,000 for the quarter and $888,000 for the 6 months.

title: SALVAGING SOMETHING FROM K.A.L. 7
description: The tragedy of the Korean airliner shot down in September 1983 has had one positive result: a tentative agreement among the United States, the Soviet Union and Japan on a warning system that could prevent a recurrence. In the absence of more significant accords, even a token of cooperation is welcome, particularly in view of the sensitivities raised on each side by the plane's loss.

title: MCCLAIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ACTIVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BULOVA WATCH CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax benefits of $176,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $564,000, or 13 cents a share, for the six months. c-Including tax benefits of $755,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,270,000, or 28 cents a share, for the six months.

title: Presenting The Presenters
description: Behind every good man, there is a kind of best man, at least when it comes to inductions at the Pro Football Hall of Fame. So when Joe Namath, O. J. Simpson, Roger Staubach, Frank Gatski and Pete Rozelle take center stage with enshrinement today in Canton, Ohio, each will have someone of his own choice to present the award, as has long been the custom.

title: Keeping Two Dreams in Play
description: They sat back on the twin beds, a few miles from the Knicks' camp for rookies and free agents, waiting for the next practice in their latest opportunity. As they rested before the first and second practice sessions yesterday, David Russell and Russell Cross had more in common than a hotel room number. They shared a need for a job, and a fall from basketball grace.

title: Louisiana Utilities Seek Cost Ruling
description: Middle South Utilities Inc. said that two operating subsidiaries asked Federal courts to order that Grand Gulf nuclear costs be charged to Louisiana customers. The company said that the subsidiaries are also seeking damages of $1 billion from New Orleans and its city council and $1.5 billion from Louisiana Public Service commissioners for their failure to abide by a Federal order distributing the costs to consumers using power from the plant.

title: Housing of Youths By Church Barred
description: The Church of Bible Understanding, a religious group that operates a carpet-cleaning business to support itself, was ordered yesterday to stop housing runaways and other unaccompanied children in its buildings in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Import Duty On Ethanol
description: William von Raab, the Commissioner of Customs, said today that, in response to complaints from domestic producers, he was reversing an earlier ruling and imposing a duty of 60 cents a gallon on imports of blended ethanol, effective today.

title: WARD CATALOGUE, 113, BECOMES HISTORY
description: Montgomery Ward & Company, which pioneered the use of the mail-order catalogue more than a century ago, said yesterday that it would discontinue the catalogue operations because of persistent losses.

title: U.S. BANKS CUT LOANS TO SOUTH AFRICANS SHARPLY
description: After years of substantially increasing their lending in South Africa, American banks have begun to cut back sharply on such loans, according to figures released this week by the Federal Reserve Board.

title: BALKY TELESCOPE DEVICE REPAIRED FOR BEST DAY ON THE SPACE MISSION
description: The astronauts in the space shuttle Challenger finally repaired one of their most important experiments today, paving the way for their best day in space.

title: Bids Sought For Teleglobe
description: The Canadian Government invited bids today for Teleglobe Canada, a Government-owned international telecommunications carrier.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Jim Bunning, the former major league pitcher who lost a bid to become Governor of Kentucky two years ago, announced that he would seek the Republican nomination for Congress in the state's Fourth District. . . . Antonio McKay, who was on the gold-medal 1,600-meter United States relay team at the 1984 Olympics, has dropped out of Georgia Tech to concentrate on his track career.

title: HAVERTY FURNITURE COS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $3,503,000 for the quarter and $3,545,000 for the 6 months. c-Including a gain on the sale of real estate of $195,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: SUITS AGINST MOSCOW BARRED IN JET DOWNING
description: A Federal judge today dismissed lawsuits against the Soviet Union over the downing of a Korean Air Lines jetliner in 1983. He ruled that United States courts had no jurisdiction to consider the lawsuits, which asked for millions of dollars in damages.

title: Refund on Your Refuse
description: As it made its way through traffic from the repair shop on Randalls Island to its home base on Staten Island, a Parks Department garbage truck cut as impressive a figure as a garbage truck can.

title: JUST LIKE JOLSON
description: I thought of Pablo, who had been a good man once but was no good anymore by the time Robert Jordan came to blow the bridge. I also thought of Pilar, who was played beautifully by Katina Paxinou in the movie in which Gary Cooper was miscast as Robert Jordan. ''Pablo was a good man once, but now he has the fear,'' Pilar was constantly telling Robert Jordan, or words to that effect.

title: DEFICIT FORECAST TOO OPTIMISTIC LEADERS REPORT
description: Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders said today that the 1986 Federal budget approved by Congress on Thursday would not shrink deficits by the official projection of $276.2 billion over three years.

title: GALVESTON HOUSTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AS SECTARIAN ATTACKS GO ON, INDIA STATE IS PUZZLED
description: The shops in one of the busiest parts of this historic city remain shuttered most of the day. Frightened residents and merchants cower indoors, wondering when the next round of violence will erupt.

title: DON'T ASK
description: Dave Bliss, the Southern Methodist coach, said he had withdrawn his name from consideration as the coach of the Nets. ''I talked with the ownership of the Nets this morning and asked that my name be withdrawn,'' Bliss said yesterday. ''The Nets were very considerate in their interest, but I felt at this time, that it was in our best interest to remain at S.M.U. We have the nucleus of a fine basketball team returning and I am looking forward to the challenge of the upcoming season.''

title: Doctor Sentenced In Medicaid Theft
description: A Yonkers psychiatrist was ordered today to perform six months of community service and to treat 50 Medicaid patients for free as punishment for stealing $100,000 from the state's Medicaid program.

title: TIGERS' TANANA HURLS 1-HITTER
description: Frank Tanana pitched a one-hitter and faced just 28 batters, and Chet Lemon keyed a three-run fifth inning with his fifth homer to lead the Detroit Tigers to a 4-1 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers tonight.

title: OH, REALLY, NO THANKS
description: One of the oldest maneuvers in politics is making a potentially generous offer, secure in the knowledge that the opposition will never accept it. To be really effective, the proposal should involve some familiar personalities or controversial issues, so that the news media will have difficulty resisting its attention-getting value.

description: Lillian Upshur, a one-time political ally and confidante of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, died Tuesday at Mt. Sinai Medical Center, where she was hospitalized last week after collapsing at her home in Harlem.

title: HOME BOX OFFICE AND SHOWTIME LOSE SUBSCRIBERS
description: For the first time, the nation's two biggest subscription television services, Home Box Office and Showtime, have suffered a decline in the number of their subscribers over a six-month period.

title: BOTH JEWISH AND ARABIC
description: As a boy, I labored over a strange book. The cover was green and the frontispiece was a photograph of King Farouk of Egypt in a fez. On succeeding pages were drawings of children and goats and palm trees and hundreds of squiggles. As hard as I tried, I could not make sense of them. After a while, even though I'd urged my dad to get me the book, we agreed to put it aside. But I carried it into adulthood. It is a kindergarten-age primer of the Arabic language. It has taken on the properties of a family heirloom, an amulet. When we moved from one house to another, I made sure we took the book. ''It reminds me how humble I am,'' I told my wife.

title: U.S. Wins, 2-1, In Youth Soccer
description: The United States got second-half goals from Larry Phail and Curtis Pride to score a 2-1 comeback victory over Bolivia today in second-round action of the under-16 World Soccer Tournament.

A spokesman, Officer Robert Fitzpatrick, said the victim, believed to be in his 20's, was found at 2:40 P.M.

title: CORNERBACK TRADED
description: Anthony Washington, a Redskin cornerback who has not missed a game in his five-year National Football League career, was traded to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for Kelly Thomas, a third-year tackle. . . . Wilbert Montgomery, the running back who had complained about austerity measures imposed by the Philadelphia Eagles' new owner, Norman Braman, withdrew his request for a trade.. . . Dan Marino, the quarterback who is seeking a renegotiation of his contract, told the Miami Dolphins' owner, Joe Robbie, that he would end his walkout and return to training camp immediately if Robbie would agree to submit the dispute to binding arbitration. Robbie, asserting that salary arbitration has ''done serious damage to major league baseball,'' said he would have no part in introducing the practice to professional football, but made a counterproposal. He said he would meet with Marino as soon as he returned to camp. . . . Tony Dorsett, the Dallas Cowboys running back who is being fined $1,000 a day for staying away from training camp, got a bit of financial relief. The Internal Revenue Service agreed to suspend interest and penalty payments, which reportedly represent about half of a disputed tax debt of $415,000, as Dorsett appeals an I.R.S. ruling that disallowed tax shelters he used. . . . The linebacker Clayton Weishuhn, sidelined for all but one game last season because of a knee operation, will miss this season after having reconstructive surgery on the same knee, the New England Patriots announced. . . . The running back Tim Spencer, the second player taken in the 1983 United States Football League draft, was signed yesterday by the San Diego Chargers to a series of one-year contracts.

title: METS FALTER AGAIN AT WRIGLEY FIELD
description: High or low, streaking or slumping, winning or losing, the Mets always seem to meet their Waterloo in 71-year-old Wrigley Field. And they did it again today when they arrived with a three-game winning streak and promptly lost to the Chicago Cubs, 2-1.

title: THE LUXURY OF LOBSTER MAKES A SUMMER FEAST
description: The 1622 version of bread and water was lobster and water. According to ''Eating in America'' (William Morrow 1976), the fascinating history of food by Waverley Root and Richard de Rochemont, ''When a group of new colonists arrived in Plymouth, Governor William Bradford was deeply humiliated because his colony was so short of food that the only 'dish they could presente to their friends was lobster . . . without bread or anything els but a cupp of fair water.' ''

ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12. 1. Using vacuum cleaners, scientists are gathering honeybees in Oswego, N.Y., to determine whether any Africanized bees, called ''killer bees,'' were aboard a ship from Brazil that docked there last year. 2. Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican leader in South Africa, protested sweeping restrictions imposed by South Africa's white authorities on funeral rallies for black victims of civil unrest. 3. The number of candidates in the Democratic primary for Mayor was reduced to two when the Board of Elections ordered the removal of Herman D. Farrell Jr. from the ballot on the ground that he had submitted only 9,683 valid petition signatures, instead of the required 10,000. 4. Health care. 5. Coleco Industries, manufacturer of the Cabbage Patch Kids dolls, said it would market a line of dolls and accessories based on the movie character Rambo. 6. The videotape, showing Andrei D. Sakharov, the exiled Soviet dissident, apparently in good health and reunited with his wife, Yelena G. Bonner, coincided with the ceremony marking the anniversary of the signing of the Helsinki accords. The United States said it would use the gathering to accuse the Soviet Union of failure to abide by the human rights clauses of the accords. 7. Lou Brock, the St. Louis Cardinal base stealer; Enos (Country) Slaughter, the Cardinal outfielder; Joseph Floyd (Arky) Vaughn, a .318 hitter with Pittsburgh and Brooklyn, and Hoyt Wilhelm, who pitched in 1,700 games, more than any other pitcher. 8. Boston. 9.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. 1. This man is using a vacuum cleaner on a hunting expedition. What is he looking for? 2. ''I do not want to break the laws of this land. But if they pass laws which are quite unjust, quite intolerable, then I will break that law,'' a spiritual leader said. Who is he and to what was he referring? 3. In New York City, 9,683 names instead of 10,000 resulted in 2 names instead of 3. Explain. 4. Last year, for the first time since 1965, spending on a key component of the national economy rose by less than 10 percent. What is the component? 5. Gun-slinging ex-Green Berets will soon join cuddly Cabbage Patch Kids. Explain. 6. A videotape of a man was broadcast on French televison as foreign ministers from 30 nations arrived at a European capital to mark a 10th anniversary. What was the videotape and why was the timing of its appearance with the anniversary noteworthy? 7. Four players were enshrined in the Baseball Hall of Fame in Cooperstown, N.Y. Who were they? 8. A city whose school system has been the focus of racial confrontation for a decade has selected a black school commissioner. What city is it? 9. To score 100 percent, each woman who took a test in Manhattan had to lift and toss 147 bags weighing a total of almost 3,000 pounds in 27 minutes.

But it is hard to detect that here.

title: Peru Misses U.S. Payment
description: Peru has failed to repay some $200,000 to the United States for military equipment it bought on credit and is now automatically cut off from new aid consideration, State Department officials said today.

title: Music
description: It is always instructive to hear the work of one great musician through the ears of another. When Maurice Ravel orchestrated Modest Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' a new, and distinctive, masterpiece was the result.

title: CONCERTS AT SARATOGA WILL BE DIFFERENT NOW
description: Beginning Wednesday, the Philadelphia Orchestra will be celebrating its 20th summer season at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center, and with Dennis Russell Davies in place as SPAC's first principal conductor and classical music program director, there's a decidedly new look to the programs in store for audiences this year. Not one to rely on the tried and true, Mr. Davies seems likely to inject just the spirit of imagination and enterprise that SPAC has been needing.

title: I.B.M.'S PHILIP D. ESTRIDGE, 47
description: Philip D. Estridge, a vice president of the International Business Machines Corporation who pioneered the company's highly successful personal computer operation, was killed Friday evening in the crash of the Delta Airlines jumbo jet flight at the Dallas-Fort Worth Airport.

title: Massachusetts Court Backs A Ban on Chemical Weapons
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has upheld the legality of a ban on the testing, storage, transportation and disposal of chemical weapons in Cambridge.

title: Too Much 'Process' Can Set Back Peace
description: Negotiations are always good in themselves, right? If the Middle East ''peace process'' is moved along, who can complain?

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: MODERN LANDSCAPE To the casual observer, a connection between the canvases that go on display today at the parrish Art Museum and any gographic vista might be difficult to make. But landscapes these works are -specifically, examples of ''Painting as Landscape: Views of American Modernism, 1920-1984.'' The exhibition is a joint venture of the Baxter Art Gallery of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena and the Southampton museum; Klaus Dertess of the Parrish is the curator. It seeks to chart the relevance of landscape to modernist painting, from the 1920's and the works of such early modernists as Arthur dove, John Martin and Mark Tobey, through such abstract artist as Willem de Kooning, James Brooks and Clyfford Still and right up to such contemporary artists ad Julian Schnabel, Terry Winters and Cora cohen, Accompained by gallery tours, lectures and films, the show is to run through Sept. 22 and may be seen from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Mondays through Saturdays, except Wednesdays, and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays. For a schedule of events, call 283-2118.

title: AN UNDERRUFF DEFEATS A SLAM
description: Those who like to challenge the analytical abilities of their friends can put them to the test with the diagramed deal. Ask them whether they would prefer to play or defend a six-heart contract. And remember that you are free to bet on analysis although not, in the view of the American Contract Bridge League, on tournament results.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

SOUNDS OF SUMMER
description: THE sound was carried by electronic amplifiers, but it was easy to think of it as echoing off the reservoir wall. Twenty-six voices raised in song, bouncing off 186 feet of stone, hitting the great dam and going out into the hot summer night - it might not have happened exactly that way, but it made for pleasant speculation.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTH
description: THE TRIANGLE FIRE, by Leon Stein. (Quicksilver/ Carroll & Graf, $7.95.) Because the fire on March 25, 1911, in New York City's Triangle Shirtwaist Factory killed 146 persons who were mostly young immigrant women, it reached into homes in Russia, Austria, Palestine, Jamaica, Hungary, Rumania and England. The fire reached into most American homes, ultimately, through New Deal reform legislation. Leon Stein, of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union - whose organizing efforts were spurred by the fire - interviewed survivors while writing his 1962 book. Tom Brooks wrote in The Book Review that Mr. Stein ''recreate[d] the tragic events of the fire in all their dramatic intensity.'' MRS. MINIVER, by Jan Struther. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $3.95.) ''Mrs. Miniver'' is about the impact of World War II on traditional, prosperous English family life. Nathalie Sedgwick Colby wrote here in 1940 that ''tears do not fall in this book,'' but ''when at the end of the last chapter . . . we feel a thrill of added intimacy to find for the first time that her name is Caroline, we know that we are pervaded by the endearing charm of Mrs. Miniver.'' A screen adaptation won six 1942 Academy Awards. THE CASE FOR ANIMAL RIGHTS, by Tom Regan. (University of California, $9.95.) The chapter headings in this 1983 book include ''Animal Awareness,'' ''Animal Welfare,'' ''Ethical Thinking and Theory'' and ''Justice and Equality.'' These indicate the nature of Tom Regan's arguments. Robert Nozick remarked in these pages that Mr. Regan ''has written a lucid, closely reasoned and dispassionate book presenting the case for animal rights.

title: FIRST PUBLIC HOUSING ROJECTS SINCE 1972 RISING IN YONKERS
description: GROUND is being cleared on two sites in Yonkers for 100 subsidized apartments for the elderly, the first public housing to be built in the city since 1972. But there are critics who complain that one site is on a flood plain and that the building there will have to be built on piers.

title: JOAN H. BALL TO MARRY STEVEN J. JOFFE OCT. 27
description: The engagement of Joan Helen Ball and Steven James Joffe has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ball of New York. The wedding is planned for Oct. 27.

title: COMPUTERS EASE THE LOAD - AT TIMES
description: AFTER a personal computer was deposited on her desk six months ago, Barbara Dand, a secretary at Gulf and Western, has been scheduling the corporate jet and billing for its use. Without the new equipment, ''I don't think I would have had time to take on those tasks,'' she said.

title: NEW CASSETES: GLORIOUS 'FALSTAFF,' VIBRANT HEPBURN
description: The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman Starring Cicely Tyson, with Richard A. Dysart, Katherine Helmond and Michael Murphy; directed by John Korty, 1973 Prism 106 minutes. $59.95 Back in 1973, ''The Autobiography of Miss Jane Pittman,'' based on a novel by Ernest J. Gaines, swept up a parcel of Emmy Awards as it demonstrated how the newfangled form called a ''TV movie'' could tackle significant material with imagination and intelligence.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANNING EFFECTIVE COMBINATIONS
description: THE effective use of plants in esthetically pleasing combinations spells the difference between having a garden or just a collection of plants. Too many gardeners preside over the latter -one of this and one of that, planted wherever a bit of space allows and according to what happens to strike one's fancy.

title: UGANDA REGAINING UNEASY NORMALCY
