description: A semblance of calm rested uneasily on this East African country today, a week after a military coup brought a wave of looting and a plague of uncertainty.

title: Use Income as Base For Setting Rents
description: I read with personal interest the article in today's Westchester section of the paper regarding the idea of rent controls being based on income [''Rent Board Weighs Means Test,'' July 21] . I for one would favor this approach, providing it was based on net, not gross, income.

title: Watching Baseball in a Park Near Ground Zero
description: THE CHANGE of pitchers at Hiroshima Stadium is something to see. Relievers are brought out of the bullpen in a golf cart with an antenna on the back. Directed by remote control, it deposits the relief pitcher at the mound and then, weaving along the right-field foul line, returns empty-handed to its berth in the bullpen. Meanwhile, the Hiroshima fans slurp their soup and noodles, drink their Kirin beer and go a little crazy over their Carp - winners of the 1984 Japan World Series. All this in an old ball park that is adjacent to ground zero.

title: ALOIS CARIGIET, SWISS PAINTER KNOWN FOR CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Alois Carigiet, the Swiss painter and graphic artist best known for illustrating children's books, died Thursday in his native Trun after a long illness, his family said today. He was 82 years old.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE TRANSFORMING PRINCIPLE: Discovering That Genes Are Made of DNA. By Maclyn McCarty. (Norton, $14.95.) Maclyn McCarty, a professor emeritus at the Rockefeller University and the surviving member of the research team that identified DNA as the genetic material in 1944, here recounts the story of the discovery with clarity and dedication.

title: Dietary Constraints May Not Be Necessary
description: In the July 7 issue, Janice Hecht bemoaned her dietary restrictions, which she ascribed to ulcerative colitis, a form of inflammatory bowel disease [''Mourning the Loss of Ice Cream, Nachos and Quiche''] . As a gastroenterologist, I am somewhat dubious about such constraints, as there is no clear evidence that food either causes or intensifies such diseases.

title: NEW YORK INSPECTORS CITE 23 FOOD OUTLETS FOR CODE VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 23 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: DORI K. BERNSTEIN TO WED DANIEL NATHAN ON SEPT. 8
description: Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Bernstein of New Britain, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dori Kay Bernstein to Daniel Allen Nathan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Ira Nathan of New York and Carmel, N.Y. A Sept. 8 wedding is planned.

title: IT'S STILL A MAN'S WORLD
description: ALONE IN A CROWD Women in the Trades Tell Their Stories. By Jean Reith Schroedel. 268 pp. Philadelphia: Temple University Press. $24.95. WOMEN WORKERS IN FIFTEEN COUNTRIES Essays in Honor of Alice Hanson Cook. Edited by Jennie Farley. 195 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: ILR Press, New York State School of Industrial and Labor Relations, Cornell University. Cloth, $24. Paper, $9.95. THESE two books appear at first as collections of fragments. One contains excerpts from 25 interviews; the other, a series of short essays with added comments. Yet their coherent voice offers a surprisingly consistent account of the condition of wage-earning women in our modern world.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DOUBLE TAKE. By Gregory Dowling. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) Poised on the edge of parody, this delightful first novel manages to ridicule the cliches of espionage fiction even as it takes the genre through some imaginative new turns.

title: PATTI R. ROSE ENGAGED TO WED MARK MANDEL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jules Rose of Kings Point, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter Patti Renee Rose to Mark Steven Mandel, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Mandel of Bayside, Queens. The wedding is planned for May.

title: MURDER OF INDIA M.P. HEATS UP DEBATE OVER SIKHS
description: The murder of a popular young Member of Parliament and his wife has jolted the Government of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi and stirred concern that other politicians might be on a ''hit list'' compiled by Sikh extremists.

title: CHAPTERS OF THE IMMIGRANT EXPERIENCE
description: Promise, followed by disillusionment and struggle: The experience of a multitude of immigrants moves along that hard pattern. And a trio of films coming to cable this week explores the universality of that experience, involving such disparate cultures as the Japanese, Norwegian, Jewish and Brazilian.

title: CHANGES CONTINUE FOR THE GENERALS
description: The dismantling of the Generals continued yesterday as the team announced the release of all but 15 players from the squad that finished last season as the third-ranked team in the United States Football League.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - High View Farm, Pittsbord, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (914) 434-8719.

title: SATURN DIVISION FINDS A HOME IN THE HEARTLAND
description: In the seven months after General Motors Corporation announced its plan to create a subsidiary to build cars in a new way, 25 state governors came courting to the northern suburbs of Detroit. Each hoped to return home with a promise from G.M. to build the new Saturn Corporation's $3.5 billion manufacturing complex in their state.

title: JANE H. MICHEL IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. James Clark Michel of Westfield, N. J., have anounced the engagement of their daughter Jane Humphreys Michel to Bernard Louis McCracken 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. McCracken of Wildwood Crest, N. J.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: COWARD AT WILLIAMSTOWN Noel Coward's ''Tonight at 8:30,'' a 1935 collection of one-act plays he wrote with two stars in mind, himself and Gertrude Lawrence, is being staged with an unusual coda by Ellis Rabb at the Williamstown Theater Festival in Massachusetts Tuesday through Aug. 17.

title: ELEANOR JOHNSON WEDS AN AUTHOR
description: Eleanor Lee Johnson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Alan Johnson of New York and Gay Head, Mass., was married yesterday to Samuel Peabody Osborne, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick R. L. Osborne of Auburn, N.Y., and Pointe au Pic, Quebec, The Rev. M. Dennis Lee performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Foster Memorial Chapel at Casowasco Conference Center in Scipio, N.Y.

title: THE ROLES JEWELRY CAN PLAY ARE MANY
description: ''JEWELRY can be anything,'' says Sarah Bodine, the editor of Metalsmith magazine. ''It can be an outward sign of personality or a place to make a statement.''

title: MISS MOFFAT, ADVERTISING SUPERVISOR, IS ENGAGED TO JAMES BLAND LAWRENCE
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Moffat of Naples, Fla., and Cooperstown, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Douglas Moffat, to James Bland Lawrence, a son of Mrs. J. Bland Lawrence of Dallas and Harding J. Lawrence of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 7.

title: ONE LITTLE RABBIT, ONE BIG WORLD
description: ''YOU must do something!'' A frenzied dealer came running to me in the middle of the antiques fair I had organized as a fund-raising event for a local organization.

title: BOOM IN L.I. DEFENMSE WORK HELPS LURE YOUNG ENGINEERS
description: ERIC BYLER'S degrees from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Stanford University could have landed him a job almost anywhere in the country. But like hundreds of students emerging from engineering schools last year, he settled on Long Island.

title: RESIDENTIAL LOOK
description: A design with a distinctly residential look is planned for an office building proposed for a midblock site on East 55th Street between Park and Lexington Avenues.

title: SINN FEIN IS SEATED BUT HARDLY LISTENED TO
description: A storm erupted here last week over a decision by the British Broadcasting Corporation, under Government pressure, not to air a television documentary featuring a man alleged to be the chief of staff of the Irish Republican Army. The uproar highlights a contradiction that perplexes all sides in Northern Ireland.

title: IONA FAIERMAN TO BE WED TO MEDICAL STUDENT NOV. 2
description: Dr. and Mrs. Daniel Faierman of Fort Lee, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Iona Faierman, to Albert Sharf, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Moe Sharf of Fort Lee.

title: ASSOCIATE DEAN AT STATE U.
description: Dr. Tamarath K. Yolles, a professor of community and preventive medicine and associate dean of the State University of New York School of Medicine at Stony Brook, L.I., died Monday at University Hospital in Stony Brook. She was 66 years old and lived in Stony Brook.

title: When Someone Comes to Fix It
description: Would Richard F. Shepard please send along the names of his mechanic, television repairman, plumber, doctor and dentist? [''Something Is Wrong If Things Go Right,'' About Long Island, July 14] . Our experience with the practitioners of these professions and others has been just the opposite of his, and we'd much prefer it the other way.

title: Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: DR. GLENNA WEISBERG WEDS HANS ANDERSEN
description: Dr. Glenna Raynes Weisberg, an obstetrician and gynecologist, and Hans Ulfson Andersen, a lawyer, were married yesterday at the Bristol Chapel of Westminster Choir College in Princeton, N.J. Rabbi Morton M. Rosenthal performed the ceremony.

title: FACING UP TO GERMANY'S PAST
description: To Germany's Past It is troubling to note the readiness of young Germans to ask rhetorically why they have to bear the responsibility or guilt for acts they did not commit (''Facing Up to Germany's Past,'' by James M. Markham, June 23). No one, including President Richard von Weizsacker, has asked this new generation to shoulder such a burden.

title: TO BUSES, WITH LOVE
description: There was a time when small boys, asked what they wanted to be when they grew up, put bus driver on their lists along with G-man and Pee Wee Reese.

title: TWO SIDES PRESS KEAN ON JOB-RETENTION BILL
description: EACH day last week, union members kept vigil at the State House to pressure Governor Kean to sign a bill that would require companies to give employees six months' notice before they terminated or transferred their businesses.

title: Northern Ireland Foils Apparent Terrorist Plot
description: The authorities foiled an apparent terrorist plan to attack a police station today when several mortar launching tubes were found in a van during a police check at a parking lot in the border town of Newry, a police spokesman in Belfast said.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''Peru has one overwhelming creditor: It is our own people.''

title: MANY IN CONGRESS CALL ITS RECORD FRUSTRATING
description: Lawmakers started their summer holiday this weekend expressing frustration and disappointment with a legislative record that contained only a modest list of accomplishments in the first six months of the 99th Congress.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: IT may be a small world, but it's a big Island.

title: Blast at Italian Post Office
description: A powerful bomb damaged a post office in the southern outskirts of Florence early today, but no one was wounded, the police said. No group immediately took responsibility, the police said, and there was no indication of a motive.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JOURNEY TO THE FORBIDDEN CHINA. By Steven W. Mosher. (Free Press, $17.95.) Steven W. Mosher went to China six years ago as a Stanford University graduate student in anthropology.

title: STATE'S HISTORIAN ENDS 33-YEAR POST
description: IN 1952, a young professor at the University of Connecticut was asked to become the state historian, a job that would include writing a scholarly history of the state.

title: Fiery Collision Kills Girl
description: A gasoline tanker truck rammed an automobile stalled on the shoulder of Interstate 44 Friday, causing an explosion and fire that killed Rojeana M. Fisher, 13 years old, of Eaton, Ind., the authorities said. The highway was closed for several hours.

title: DEMOCRAT WINS CONGRESSIONAL RACE IN TEXAS
description: Jim Chapman, the Democratic candidate, won a narrow victory today in a runoff election in the First Congressional District, thwarting Edd Hargett's bid to become the district's first Republican congressman in 114 years.

title: HOW IMAGINATION RETRACED A MURDER
description: When Ruth Ellis was hanged in 1955 for murdering her lover, David Blakely, I was still at school and more interested in other things, myself principally, so her execution made little impression on me at that time. I didn't think about her again until about 30 years later when a film producer, Roger Randall-Cutler, asked me to write a script based on her life.

title: MISS KRONICK TO WED EDWARD M. SHUMSKY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Kronick of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Dana Kronick, to Edward Manno Shumsky, the son of Violet Manno Shumsky of Ventnor City, N.J., and the late William Shumsky. The wedding is planned for Aug. 29.

title: METS WIN IN 10TH ON JOHNSON HOMER
description: There were 36,775 witnesses in Wrigley Field today, and they may still not believe what they saw.

title: Cheyenne Cleans Up After Deadly Storm
description: Soggy mattresses and soaked carpets were piled on front lawns today and street crews cleared piles of hailstones as the cleanup began after by one of the deadliest storms in the city's history.

title: Lee Leads Yokohama
description: Leron Lee, a former major leaguer, slugged his 16th homer to lead the Yokohama Taiyo Whales to a 6-4 victory over the Hiroshima Toyo Carp today in the Japanese League. Dick Davis, formerly of the Toronto Blue Jays, hit a two-run homer to help the Kintetsu Buffaloes beat the Nankai Hawks, 8-7.

title: U.S. FAIR-HOUSING EFFORTS DEBATED
description: THE Justice Department brought more housing-discrimination cases in 1984 than in any year since 1978, a Justice Department official said at a seminar on fair housing and fair lending held late last month at a two-day seminar at the Summit Hotel in New York.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN THE SECRETARIAL WORLD
description: IN the 1935 hit movie, ''She Married Her Boss,'' Claudette Colbert fulfilled America's image of the secretary by exchanging her steno pad for a diamond solitaire.

title: PRESSURE BUILDS BUT SOUTH AFRICA ISN'T BUDGING
description: Like the settlers of the American West, the white Afrikaners who trekked north from South Africa's cape to settle the interior in the 19th century drew wagons around their camps against hostile forces. The wagons were circled again last week, as the white minority Government defied increasingly critical international reaction and continued its crackdown on black protest.

title: GANDHI REACHES OUT TO THE SIKHS - AND UNITY
description: ''Some kind of a dream of unity has occupied the mind of India since the dawn of civiization,'' wrote Jawaharlal Nehru, the country's first Prime Minister. In recent years, nothing has jeopardized that dream more than the confrontation with members of the Sikh religious sect, agitating for greater autonomy in the strategically vital farming state of the Punjab. The Sikh crisis led to the assassination last year of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, Nehru's daughter, and threatened to transform Punjab into a permanently wounded region comparable to Northern Ireland.

title: Broadcast TV
description: First telecast in April 1984, the production of Kurt Weill's ''Down in the Valley'' that Channel 13 will rebroadcast on Friday evening at 9 will be of interest to lovers of opera and musical theater and to Weill specialists and those with a particular interest in the evolution of the American folk opera. Conceived in 1945 as a radio opera and then expanded slightly for its 1948 world premiere at the University of Indiana, the work is an American equivalent of the sort of determinedly populist operas Weill wrote with Bertolt Brecht in Germany in the late 20's.

title: REAGAN'S HIDDEN 'INDUSTRIAL POLICY'
description: THE 1984 Presidential campaign buried the idea of ''industrial policy.'' Or did it?

title: JOANNE MARIE MIKULICH TO BE MARRIED SEPT. 28
description: A Sept. 28 wedding is planned by Joanne Marie Mikulich and Robert Alexander de Guardiola, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Mikulich of Sherman, Conn., have announced.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WOMEN OF LYME Homage is being paid to eight women of Lyme in an exhibition of paintings, letters, furniture, clothing, china and photographs at the Historical Society, 96 Lyme Street, Old Lyme, through Sept. 15.

title: YANK HOMERS END LOSING STREAK
description: There was nothing appealing about the way the Yankees beat the Chicago White Sox yesterday, except that they ended a dismal losing streak that had reached four games. They flexed their collective muscle in the first inning, scoring four times, and coasted to an 8-4 decision at the Stadium.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. AIDE SAW PRESSER JURY
description: The Justice Department lawyer who decided not to prosecute Jackie Presser, president of the teamsters' union, went to Cleveland this week to explain the decision to the Federal grand jury that investigated the union leader, according to a department official.

title: RUTGERS SESSIONS OFFER ALCOHOLICS HELP
description: HE LOOMED up out of the vastness of the campus cafeteria and leaned on the table where Joan A. Evers was getting up from lunch.

title: On Getting Reality Mixed Up With Films
description: Hilda Bary (Personally Speaking, July 7) seems to be suffering from the same problem that Mia Farrow had in ''The Purple Rose of Cairo.'' She's getting reality mixed up with the movies.

title: FINISHING TOUCHES FOR THE GARDEN
description: A garden is never really ''finished.'' There is always something else to be added such as a decorative accent. It can create a mood, enhance the landscape or dramatize a focal point. But there is one rule: accents must harmonize with the architecture and its setting.

title: THE SEASON OF THE CRAB
description: Summertime, and the eating is varied in the nation's capital and the other cities and towns around the Chesapeake Bay.

title: THE STRUGGLE TO KEEP SKYLINES IN LINE
description: SAN FRANCISCO -

title: WIND BURSTS SEEN AS WORST HAZARD
description: The conditions surrounding the jet crash at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport are typical of those associated with the violent wind shifts that are now considered aviation's worst hazard, an expert said yesterday.

title: Data Bank; August 4, 1985
BETSY SAVED FROM DISCONTENT
description: FRIENDS ALONG THE WAY By Julia Markus. 264 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95.

title: MOTHER IS THE GOALIE
description: PLAY BY PLAY By Isaac Goldemberg. Translated by Hardie St. Martin. 172 pp. New York: Persea Books. $13.95.

title: FLIGHT RECORDERS OFFER FEW CLUES TO JETLINER CRASH
description: Preliminary examination of the flight recorders aboard the Delta Air Lines jumbo jet that crashed here Friday registered no alarm among the crew that anything was wrong and no warning from ground controllers of hazardous wind shifts, according to Federal investigators.

title: SWEETBREADS
description: A 40-year-old reference work in my home states that ''sweetbreads are rarely found on the home table, and seem tacitly accepted as a delicacy peculiar to the rich.'' Recently, however, they seem to have gained a broader constituency.

title: COMING SOON: TREASURY III
description: Early next month, the House Ways and Means Committee and Administration officials will closet themselves to draft a tax revision bill to present to the House. Whether the Senate will act this year is an open question. More to the point, so is how much the measure will look like the one President Reagan proposed.

title: CORDELIA REARDON TO MARRY SEPT. 7
description: A Sept. 7 wedding is planned by Cordelia Marie Reardon and William Laverack Jr., her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roy L. Reardon of New York, Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Landgrove, Vt., have announced. Mr. Laverack is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Laverack of Andover, Mass., and Sorrento, Me.

title: CAMERA'S EYE ON JAPAN, BERMUDA CRUISE
description: 15-Day Tour To Tokyo And Beyond The time is autumn. The place is Japan. And the emphasis is twofold: photography and culture.

title: GROUP DISPUTES CITY INCINERATOR PLAN
description: Saying that the Koch administration's $1.5 billion plan to build five incinerators would delay a garbage crisis for only seven years, an environmental group yesterday urged the city to greatly expand its plans for recycling.

title: KOCH LOSES A LINE
description: Mr. Koch developed a petition problem of his own last week.

title: CUOMO SIGNS BILL LETTING CHILDREN TESTIFY BY TV
description: Children who are victims of sexual abuse will now be able to testify in court by means of two-way, closed-circuit television under one of several bills signed into law this week by Governor Cuomo.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HUGH HEFNER'S FIRST FUNERAL AND OTHER TRUE TALES OF LOVE AND DEATH IN CHICAGO. By Pat Colander. (Contemporary Books, Paper, $8.95.)

title: THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: At age 18, in 1971, after having been comatose for two months and hospitalized for another month, I went to the Burke Rehabilitation Center to learn to walk, talk more coherently and improve my impaired coordination (''The Long Road Back,'' by Kerry Gruson, June 30).

title: LOTS OF TALK, BUT WHO'S LISTENING?
description: The question about ''Soapbox, With Tom Cottle,'' respectfully asked, is whom is it for? Who should be watching? A topic is chosen - parents and teen-agers, say, or teen-age sexuality, which is the topic for today's program - and teen-agers discuss it. Mr. Cottle, a psychologist, moderates the discussion. He is a benign presence, perched on a wooden crate (the teen-agers perch on crates, too) and he allows the teen-agers to talk, while mostly he listens. Occasionally, he asks a question, and, once in a while, he makes a judgment. Beneath the discussions, meanwhile, is the assumption that when problems are talked about, light is shed in dark corners. Problems become easier to bear. This is also the assumption beneath psychoanalysis and, to an extent, confessions in church. On the analyst's couch or in the confessional booth, however, it's clear who benefits by talking. In television studios, it's not.

title: THE 1960's DEFENDED
description: To the Editor:

title: ANNA MCDONNEL TO MARRY SEPT. 7
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. Murray McDonnell of Peapack, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter Anna Maria McDonnell to Samuel Huntting Harper, a son of Mr. and Mr. Paul C. Harper Jr. of New York and Old Lyme, Conn. The wedding is planned for Sept. 7.

title: AIRPORT ACCESS
description: To the Editor: It is often easier to go across the country from airport to airport than to get from the airport to the final destination and vice versa.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Barry N. Malzberg's playful new novel, THE REMAKING OF SIGMUND FREUD (Ballantine/Del Rey, Paper, $2.95), digs beneath the surface of history to reveal the answers to such questions as: Why was Dr. Freud, the famous Viennese alienist, murdered in his office by Col. Robert McCormick, publisher of The Chicago Tribune? And what did Samuel Clemens say to Emily Dickinson in a St. Louis hotel room the night they first made love? As should be apparent, nothing is sacred to Mr. Malzberg, who successfully brings off one of the most difficult variants of alternate-universe science fiction - the futuristic story based on a past that both resembles and widely differs from our own.

title: RON RICHARDSON OF 'BIG RIVER' TAKES SUCCESS IN STRIDE, FAITH
description: ONE has heard all sorts of stage stories about ''overnight'' successes and stars suddenly being ''born'' -after years of relatively unacknowledged accomplishments.

title: YANKEES ARE NOT AMUSED BY A 'FUNNY' PLAY
description: There was something funny about it: two base runners, one almost on top of the other, scampering innocently toward home plate and being tagged out in succession. But there was no laughter in the Yankee clubhouse when the game finally ended after midnight Friday.

title: AIDS AND THE BLOOD SUPPLY
description: Although scientists have yet to find a treatment for AIDS, much less a cure, they have apparently eliminated one of the ways in which the deadly disease is spread. According to studies reported last week at the National Institutes of Health, a new test has succeeded in screening AIDS-tainted blood, leaving only the remotest chance that transfusions will continue to spread the disease.

title: COACHES' QUESTIONS
description: Most high school seniors who want to get into the country's most selective colleges need total scores on the Scholastic Aptitude Test well above the national average of 897. At Yale, for example, most incoming freshmen have scored between 1,150 and 1,390. Although the test results are just one part of a selection process that also weighs high school marks, class standing and extracurricular activities, many students believe that they must do well even to begin to be considered.

title:
DINING OUT;

'GINGERBREAD SPA BY THE SEA'
description: CAPE MAY, the ''gingerbread spa by the sea,'' has become a center for interesting dining, with a number of engaging restaurants clustered downtown a block or two from the beach. Current favorites are Restaurant Maureen, tiny Louisa's and 410 Bank Street.

title: THE RIGHT CHAOS, THE RIGHT AGUENESS
description: GROUND WORK Before the War. By Robert Duncan. 175 pp. New York: New Directions. Cloth, $19.50. Paper, $10.95. CAMUS said that Kafka's art consisted in forcing the reader to reread. The same holds true for Robert Duncan, if for opposite reasons. His work is difficult right on the surface. His sheer reach and range of associations and patterning are so complex that the reader is forced to scan the page as one scans a horizon and register some sense of a visual whole before proceeding to the parts. Since ''The Opening of the Field'' (1960), he has been engaged in a search for what Alfred North Whitehead calls ''the right chaos, the right vagueness.'' But for all his erudition and allusiveness, he is not a poet for scholars only. If his oeuvre can fairly be viewed as a grand collage, the leaps, gaps and juxtapositions stimulate the reader to uncover, in his words, ''resonances of meaning exceeding what we / understand, words freed from their origins.''

title: And a Toast to Zenger's Jury
description: This day demands a tribute, professional as well as patriotic, to John Peter Zenger, the publisher of New York's first independent newspaper, and Andrew Hamilton, his wily Philadelphia lawyer. For today is the 250th anniversary of the libel trial at which they turned common law on its head and established the freedom of our press.

title: PRISONER WINS IN RIGHTS CASE
description: A Federal jury has held that a prison superintendent violated the First Amendment rights of an inmate by transferring him to another facility after the publication of an article he wrote that was critical of prison guards.

title: WILLIAM SCHUMAN AT 75
description: ''I don't really think that today's musical community is much different from what it was 50 years ago,'' the composer William Schuman said a few days ago. ''The universities turn composers out by the score - bad pun, I guess - but only a few of them have much to say. Only a few of them have voices of their own.''

title: AID FOR TRAVELERS IN TROUBLE
description: DONNA OULLETTE looks for trouble on Interstate 95 between Westport and Greenwich. She generally finds it at least a dozen times a day.

title: Restore the Grain-Reserve Programs
description: To the Editor:

title: Animal Cruelty
description: To the Editor:

title: CRUISING, 50's-STYLE, IN BETHEL
description: BY the time Earth Angel rolled into the parking lot with Eddie Staib, his hair slicked into a ducktail, behind the wheel, Cruise Night was in full swing at the Sycamore drive-in restaurant in Bethel.

title: FOR JETS' O'BRIAN, FOOTBALL IS FUN AGAIN
description: The smile has returned to Ken O'Brien, along with the easy banter with his teammates and the sense that football may be fun after all.

title: The U.S. Was Right
description: Forty years ago this week in Hiroshima: the dreadful flash, the wrist watches fused forever at 8:16 A.M. The question still persists: Should we have dropped the atomic bomb?

title: INFORMERS ARE ASSAILED IN REFUGEE-HARBORING CASE
description: Members of the church-based movement to provide sanctuary to refugees have asked for a Federal inquiry into the activities of informers used by the Government to infiltrate churches and make secret tape recordings of the movement's meetings.

title: Gabon Plotter Is Doomed
description: A court martial in Gabon has sentenced an air force captain to death for plotting to overthrow President Omar Bongo, court sources said today. The sources said that they did not know when the captain, Alexandre Mandja Ngoukouta, was to be executed, but that the verdict was announced on Thursday.

title: City Council on Coast Takes Therapy Weekend
description: Wracked by conflict, including a rivalry between the Mayor and a Councilman who wants her post, the West Hollywood City Council was spending the weekend in group therapy at a seaside resort.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: LOUISE FONTAINE would like everyone at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck to speak up.

title: NEW CASSETES: GLORIOUS 'FALSTAFF,' VIBRANT HEPBURN
description: Verdi's 'Falstaff' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Donald Gramm, Benjamin Luxon, Kay Griffel, Elizabeth Gale; stage-directed and designed by Jean-Pierre Ponnelle, conducted by John Pritchard, 1976 Video Arts International 123 minutes. $69.95 This is a genuine winner, although on a normal television set the monaural sound is thin.

title: SUSAN BALDWIN TO WED IN FALL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Tyler Baldwin of Fairfield, Conn., have announced the engagment of their daughter Susan Walker Baldwin to Theodore William Kietzman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Kietzman of New Canaan, Conn. An October wedding is planned.

title: FEDERAL AGENCY TO HOLD 3d PIANO COMPETITION
description: The United States Information Agency's Artistic Ambassador program will hold its third annual piano competition for ''undiscovered musical talent'' this fall.

title: FARRELL IS OFF THE BALLOT, AT LEAST FOR NOW
description: Carol Bellamy knocked assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. off the ballot last week in the September Democratic primary for mayor, then found her other principal opponent, Mayor Koch, in Mr. Farrell's corner.

title: Suit Is Filed
description: A lawsuit has been filed in connection with the crash of an out-of-control race car that slammed into a concession stand last week, killing a woman and injuring 20 people. The suit was filed against the driver, Jim Dunn; the Firebird Raceway of Emmett, Ida.; the American Drag Racing Association, and several track officials.

title: ITALIAN RADICCHIO: TOSS IT OR GRILL IT
description: One of Italy's favorite vegetables is radicchio, a crisp salad green belonging to the chicory family, with a slightly bitter taste that can also be refreshingly nutty.

title: HELSINKI HELPS LAY THE GROUND WORK FOR A SUMMIT
description: THE United States and the Soviet Union put on affable faces in Helsinki last week, as Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze took initial steps toward a successful summit meeting in November. They were small steps to be sure but what counted most was the positive mood surrounding their meeting. Even the jockeying for advantage, such as the proposals by Washington and Moscow on nuclear testing that each knew the other would reject, was kept within bounds.

title: JOHN S. RICE, A FORMER ENVOY
description: John Stanley Rice, United States Ambassador to the Netherlands during the Kennedy Administration and a prominent politician and businessman in his native Pennsylvania, died in a hospital here Friday. He was 86 years old.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: CRACKER JACKSON By Betsy Byars. 144 pp. New York: Viking Kestrel. $11.95. (Ages 10 to 14)

title: 40 YEARS AFTER A-BOMBS, MEDICAL BURDEN IS UNCLEAR
description: In looks and in feel, there is not much that is obviously special about the Hiroshima Atomic Bomb Hospital.

title: LILIAN UPSHUR, A POLITICAL ALLY OF REP. ADAM CLAYTON POWELL
description: Lillian Upshur, a one-time political ally and confidante of Representative Adam Clayton Powell, died Tuesday at Mt. Sinai Medical Center, where she was hospitalized last week after collapsing at her home in Harlem.

title: A GOING-AWAY PRESENT
description: At 26, Jan Wojcik signed dismissal papers and left the Jesuits (''A Going-Away Present,'' About Men, June 23). At 26, I signed papers and perpetually vowed myself to the Jesuits.

title: LETTING THE PORTFOLIO SELL THE PHOTOGRAPHER
description: THE well-designed picture portfolio can open many doors. In view of its importance in helping to further a photographer's career, it is instructive to listen to the advice of an expert in the field. What are the characteristics of a good portfolio? Should it present only the photographer's point of view, or should it be aimed at the person who will evaluate it?

title: A REMEBRANCE OF SUMMERS PAST
description: MY 19-year-old son, in an uncharacteristically nostalgic mood, was reminiscing recently about the summers of his brief past.

title: VANCOUVER
description: It's dress rehearsal time for Vancouver as the city gets ready for its big year of celebrations. Next year, this west coast Canadian city will mark its 100th birthday and present Expo 86, a world's fair on transportation and communications. But visitors this summer are getting a taste of things to come because every local group, from theater company to music club, is practising its act for next year.

title: NEW CASSETES: GLORIOUS 'FALSTAFF,' VIBRANT HEPBURN
description: Chuck Berry Featuring Chuck Berry, with Tina Turner Passport Music Video 60 minutes. $29.95 Thirty years ago, Chuck Berry wrote songs that are cornerstones of rock-and-roll - and he still performs them with their rebellious joy intact.

title: WINERIES RISE WHERE MOONSHINE WAS KING
description: As a chorus of katydids began to serenade the fall of night from the mountain laurel beyond the cabin porch, Tobe, a ''white likker'' man, held a glass of his host's homemade wild fox grape wine. All things considered, he said, ''I'd rather have my old moonshine.''

title: Agreement Reached
description: Richard Dent, the Chicago Bears' all-pro defensive end, ended his holdout and returned to training camp under an agreement that will allow him to participate in drills as contract talks continue. Dent, a third-year pro and the National Football Conference leader in sacks, is seeking to renegotiate his contract, which now runs through 1986.

title: SPAIN'S STYLE OF OPERETTA GOES ON DISPLAY
description: Zarzuela is a Spanish word referring to a sort of bouillabaisse and a palace near Madrid. But to musical theater lovers, it is recognized as the Spanish variety of operetta. Until recently, most of us had to content ourselves with the tantalizing morsels recorded by nearly every notable singer of Spanish extraction, including Victoria de los Angeles, Teresa Berganza, Montserrat Caballe, Alfred Kraus and Placido Domingo. Most have sung zarzuela in Spain and have often included zarzuela excerpts in their concerts here.

title:
HIROSHIMA REMEMBERED;

The Day You First Heard the News
description: Where were you when you first heard about the atomic bomb? My guess is that most Americans over the age of 50 can answer that question instantly.

title: SUSAN A. LEIVY BRIDE OF THEODORE T. FLIGOR
description: Susan Alison Leivy, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. David Mayer Leivy of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., was married yesterday to Theodore Thomas Fligor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fligor of Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. Carleton Lee of St. John's Episcopal Church in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Rabbi Irwin Lowenheim performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Thousands Turn Out For Nigerian Cleanup
description: Nigerians worked to move mountains of garbage today as part of the country's national sanitation day.

title: JOCELYN JONES TO MARRY F. P. GREALY, A LAWYER
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Fenwick Jones of Baltimore, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jocelyn Fenwick Jones, to Francis P. Grealy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Grealy of Crestwood, N.Y., and Vero Beach, Fla. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: A BIG 'IF' FOR THE PLAYERS
description: IF it happens, Lance Parrish of the Detroit Tigers will ''go home and cry.'' David Palmer of the Montreal Expos will go home and go fishing. Dennis Eckersley of the Chicago Cubs will ''go home and stay in shape.'' The umpires will go home and collect for 45 days, regardless.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HAVEN AND HOME: A History of the Jews in America. By Abraham J. Karp. (Schocken, $24.95.) Jewish settlement in the United States began with 23 refugees from Brazil arriving in New York more than 300 years ago.

title: JURORS SCARCE IN SOUTHAMPTON
description: A GROWING number of residents and visitors in Southampton Town have resulted in more crime, arrests and trials, but the court system is short of jurors to conduct the trials.

title: Marcos Hints at Calling Early Elections
description: President Ferdinand Marcos said today he would decide by early next month whether to hold an early presidential election.

title: KATHI JEAN PATON ENGAGED TO BRO UTTAL
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Brewster Paton of New Vernon, N.J., and Orleans, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kathi Jean Paton to Bro Uttal, a son of Mrs. Edmund Leon Anderson of New York and Quogue, L.I., and the late Fred Uttal. The wedding is planned for Sept. 28.

title: Topics;   Stages of Growth What a Doll
description: With an eye to the Christmas trade, the makers of those Cabbage Patch Kids have come up with a cuddly idea: a Rambo doll.

title: O'NEILL AND G.O.P? SPAR OVER SURPLUS
description: AS Connecticut's budget surplus continued to mount, Republican leaders of the State Senate renewed their push last week to convene another special session of the General Assembly, to share the wealth with the taxpayers and the municipalities.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DARK GODS. By T. E. D. Klein. (Viking, $16.95.) This table d'hote of four nightmarish novellas by the author of ''The Ceremonies'' features the supernatural, the preternatural and the unnatural - quite a banquet for horror mavens.

title: ON THE MOVE
description: Susan E. Phillips has resigned as director of the Institute of Museum Services, which distributes Federal grants to museums, to join the Office of Presidential Personnel, which recruits people to fill top Government jobs.

title: Dance
description: The American component of Dance Theater Workshop's Out-of-Towners festival opens on Thursday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater with performances by Pam Quinn and Michael O'Connor. The series, in its eighth year, offers New Yorkers a chance to see what's going on in dance west of the Hudson.

title: Wake Forest Coach
description: Bob Staak, who guided Xavier of Ohio to two 20-victory seasons in the last three seasons, was named the Wake Forest basketball coach yesterday, replacing Carl Tacy, who had resigned three weeks ago. Staak said he had ''mixed emotions'' about leaving the Cincinnati school for the Wake Forest job.

title: CORRECTION
description: The illustration for the About Men column of July 21ied an erroneous credit line. The artist was Steve Carver.

title: TRAIN WRECK IN FRANCE KILLS 21
description: Two passenger trains collided head-on in rural France today, killing 21 people and injuring at least 145, the police said.

title: MUSIC AS HISTORY, MOVIES AS MOVIES
description: OPERA & IDEAS From Mozart to Strauss. By Paul Robinson. 279 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: TRIAL FOR GOETZ IS STILL MONTHS AWAY
description: Bernhard H. Goetz's case is on the court calendar in Manhattan tomorrow, but his trial is still months away as his lawyers seek to have the State Court of Appeals, New York's highest court, dismiss the charges.

title: THE POET WHO WORKED FOR THE K.G.B.
description: FIRST LOYALTY By Richard Lourie. 405 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $17.95.

title: Top Soviet Uzbekistan Aide Dismissed for Incompetence
description: A high-ranking official of the Uzbek Communist Party has been dismissed for incompetence and abusing his position for personal gain, the Tass press agency said today.

title: STEALING STREETS
description: New York City's Bureau of Highway Operations said thieves were making off with some of the streets.

title: ARE CRIMINALS MADE OR BORN?
description: A REVOLUTION IN OUR UN-derstanding of crime is quietly overthrowing some established doctrines. Until recently, criminologists looked for the causes of crime almost entirely in the offenders' social circumstances.

title: WHEN THE JUSTICE SYSTEM IS PUT UNDER CONTRACT
description: Six couples were before the bench of Atlanta's Magistrate's Court one recent morning. The husbands were charged with wife-beating. The magistrate, JoAnn Bayneum, was told that they had never been in court before. ''Referred to the Neighborhood Justice Center,'' she said. Also referred were several assault and battery cases involving neighbors, and a case involving the theft of a television set.

title: YOUNG SOCCER TEAM IN EUROPEAN VICTORY
description: IT was an abrupt change for the members of the D.Y.A.

title: PATRONS' CHANGE ADDS UP TO A $500 FRESH AIR GIFT
description: When Wilbur McCullars was growing up, his parents could not afford to send him to summer camp. So when he learned about the Fresh Air Fund, which is sending 13,000 low-income youngsters to the country this year, he was eager to help.

title: THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: Kerry Gruson mentioned that in her early hospitalization the occupational therapists offered her time-wasting projects consisting of puppets and washcloths.

title: Stynchula, Former Colt, Killed in Car Accident
description: Andy Stynchula, a former player with four teams in the American and National Football Leagues from 1960 through 1968, died Thursday night in an automobile accident on the main road here, the police said.

title: TRADITIONAL CRAFTS IN THE SWISS STYLE
description: In the popular imagination, there are several Switzerlands - the skier's, the banker's, the watchmaker's. It is the country of chocolate and of cheese as well as of prompt trains. The Switzerland we learn about first, though, and the one that predates all the others, is the rural Switzerland of folk art and fine craftsmanship. The remote Alpine countryside of Heidi and Peter, alphorns and cowbells, chalets and embroidered blouses, is as representative as the Matterhorn peak. And almost as durable. ''Made in Switzerland,'' be it on a wristwatch or an apron, are three of the most encouraging words in the lexicon of international shopping.

title: LAURIE F. BAKER IS FIANCE OF C. S. STINE, AN EXECUTIVE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Paul Baker of Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie F. Baker, to Charles Seward Stine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Newhard Stine of Manlius, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: POLISHING ENDGAME TACTICS
description: It used to be common to think of the endgame as a sort of cleanup operation, as a way of exploiting material gains achieved in the middle game. Yet this denies the creative endgame the prominence it deserves.

title: CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday on the races for town supervisor in the county, the political affiliation of Vincent Valenti, a candidate in Mount Pleasant, was misidentified. Mr. Valenti is a Republican who has been endorsed by the town's Democratic and Conservative parties.

title: MY HOUSE IS YOUR HOUSE - WHILE YOURS IS MINE
description: When Barbara and Brian Rosner were offered a home in Freiburg im Breisgau, West Germany, in exchange for use of their Manhattan apartment, they were apprehensive. ''We planned to be away four weeks,'' Mr. Rosner, a lawyer, said, ''and we had our year-old son, David, with us. We were attracted by the idea of having a home as our base for day trips instead of a hotel room, but we were scared about who these people were who would be staying in our home in New York.''

title: MT. LAUREL HOUSING ISSUE FINALLY RESOLVED
description: THIS rapidly developing Burlington County township of some 20,000 people has reached the end of a 15-year battle over affordable housing, a battle that resulted in two State Supreme Court decisions and upset zoning practices all over the state.

title: HOPE JOSEPH TO MARRY MICHAEL L. FITZGERALD
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Joseph of Muttontown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Hope Joseph, to Michael L. Fitzgerald, a son of Helen Fitzgerald of Plandome, L.I., and the late James G. Fitzgerald.

title: Rudolph Taylor, Aide At Parks Agency, Dies
description: Rudolph B. Taylor, assistant commissioner for legal affairs in the City Department of Parks and Recreation, drowned Thursday in Haiti, where he was on vacation. He was 36 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PORTRAIT OF A SMALL BLACK CHURCH
description: Only one of us who was reared in the black church could have written such a perceptive piece as David Bradley's ''Portrait of a Small Black Church'' (June 30). But all people whose lives have centered around the church can appreciate the article.

title: HOW ANHEUSER BREWS ITS WINNERS
description: A CROWD of more than 5,000 people gathered last Saturday at Boys and Girls High School in the bleak Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn to watch black cowboys display their bronco-riding skills in the Black World Championship Rodeo.

title: BOX OFFICES ARE BOOMING AT CAPE COD'S THEATERS
description: The three summer theaters on Cape Cod - with their mix of old and new plays, familiar musicals, established stars and young actors - are enjoying one of their busiest seasons in a decade, their owners say.

title: Q AND A
description: Primary Residency Question: I own a stabilized apartment in Manhattan. How can I verify that the tenant is filing a resident tax return and is a primary resident? . . . H. G., Manhattan Answer: There is no simple answer because primary residency, which tax returns are often used to prove or disprove, is determined by courts based on the facts in each individual case. But here are some points you should know.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE REARRANGEMENT. By Nancy Pelletier. (Macmillan, $18.95.) The problem with most autobiographical novels is not autobiography. It's that writers who fail to see patterns in life insist upon writing them.

title: ARTISTRY FROM THE ORIENT FEATURED
description: Two recent issues from Japan and Nationalist China show the artistry of the Orient.

title: MURPH THE SURF
description: Jack Murphy, also known as Murph the Surf, faced a bleak future in 1969 after being sentenced in Florida to two life terms for the murder of two secretaries. A year earlier he had been convicted of burglary, and before that he had been imprisoned for the 1964 theft of the Star of India sapphire from the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.

title: THERE IS REAL DRAMA IN 'WINTERREISE'
description: Two lawyers look over a deed, a will or a contract.

title: LYNN MANGANARO WEDS
description: Lynn Manganaro, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Manganaro of Upper Saddle River, N.J., and Thomas Gallagher, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Gallagher of Bergenfield, N.J., both 1981 graduates of Lehigh University, were married yesterday. The Rev. Carol J. Smith, a Methodist minister and uncle of the bride, officiated at the Stony Hill Inn in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Electric Future
description: To the Editor:

title: NANCY EVANS TO WED STEVEN SPERBER OCT. 20
description: Bernice Schwartz of New York and Bernard Schwartz of Mount Vernon, N.Y., and West Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Evans to Steven Crabill Sperber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Sperber of Los Angeles and Surfside, Calif. An Oct. 20 wedding is planned.

title: NIMES TO ROUSSILLON A WEEDEND JOURNEY
description: Suppose you have a weekend to spend in the south of France. Just Saturday and Sunday. No more. Where is the best place to go?

title: THE LEGAL AID SOCIETY ON THE DEFENSIVE
description: When Chester Mirsky and Michael McConville of New York University Law School began circulating their draft report on legal services to the poor in New York City last month, their timing was no accident. They assumed that the local bar would at least have most of the summer to digest the unpalatable findings in private.

title: THEIR DAY OF FULFILLMENT
description: WHEN they gathered Friday, the enshrinees had been warned. ''For you,'' Marion Motley, who grew up here before playing fullback for the Cleveland Browns, told them, ''this will be a day of fulfillment - you will fill up.'' And so they did, some more than others, as they were inducted yesterday into the Pro Football Hall of Fame - Joe Namath, O. J. Simpson, Roger Staubach, Pete Rozelle and a reminder of an earlier era, Frank Gatski, once a Browns' center.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: THE FORTY-NINER. Written and illustrated by Oscar de Mejo. Harper & Row. $11.50. (Ages 5 to 9) A surreal account of Homer McMillan Solo (born with a beard and mustache) and his experiences in the California Gold Rush (including a visit with an extraterrestrial) in the inimitable style of the well-known primitive artist.

title: HIROSHIMA AT 40: GRAPPLING WITH THE UNTHINKABLE
description: Scarcely had the atomic bomb been dropped on Hiroshima than Americans began to ponder its effects: Would the event sear the national psyche and significantly change our lives, or would it be absorbed along with all the other terrors of the century? The issue remains as unsettled, and unsettling, today as the issue of whether the bomb should have been dropped 40 years ago.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday on ice cream in Florence gave an incorrect address for the Gelateria Frilli. The correct address is 53-57 Via San Niccolo.

title: Dance Training For the Young
description: I wish to commend you and David Wilson, author of the recent feature on the plight of Connecticut's ballet companies, including Ballet Today of Stamford [''Ballet Troupes Discuss Merger,'' July 7] .

title: BRADFORD ADAMS, MARY PAT FEARSON EXCHANGE VOWS
description: Mary Pat Fearon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Fearon Jr. of Oneida, N.Y., was married yesterday to Bradford Alan Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Adams of Virginia Beach, Va. The Rev. Dr. Henry Fearon 3d, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony at the First United Methodist Church of Oneida, assisted by the Rev. Bruce Barden.

title: SPAIN LAW ALLOWING SOME ABORTIONS TAKES EFFECT
description: Abortion became legal in Spain today over the bitter objections of many doctors and a statement by the Spanish Roman Catholic Church that anyone ''who cooperates physically or morally'' in the operation will be ''automatically excommunicated.''

title: Hypocrisy?
description: To the Editor:

title: BASEBALL PLAYER, 15, OPTS FOR RETIREMENT
description: FIFTEEN is a young age at which to retire from anything. But in the case of Lisa Letendre of Colchester, it is actually relatively late.

title: BLACK AND JEWISH PUPILS JOIN FOR A HERITAGE TRIP
description: Six black and six Jewish teen-agers were sitting around a table for a final briefing before they left Tuesday night on a monthlong journey to Senegal and Israel to explore each other's heritage. Steven Segal, 16 years old, offered a quick synopsis of ''Explorers,'' a movie he had just seen. Then he got to the point: ''It's like we're explorers, too, going to discover what we didn't know about each other.''

title: Topics;   Stages of Growth Long Life
description: The seven obituaries published in The Times on Friday concerned vastly different men and women -among them a mathematician, France's former executioner, an advertising executive, a pioneer of big-band black American jazz. But all seven articles reported something fundamental in common.

title: HIROSHIMA AT 40: WHEN WORDS FAIL
description: LAST year I attended the anniversary commemoration of the bomb in Hiroshima, and from the moment our group of American visitors stepped off the bus we were awash in a flood of words.

title: MIGRAINE
description: To the Editor:

title: FERRY ADOPTS 7-DAY SERVICE
description: THE Rocky Hill-Glastonbury Ferry, one of the nation's oldest continuously operating ferries, will be plying its way across the Connecticut River more often this summer.

title: MISS GENNARO, A DANCER, TO WED SCOTT A. EVANS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Gennaro of New York and Oxford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Liza Gennaro, to Scott Alan Evans, a son of William R. Evans Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y., and Mrs. Eliot Yehle Marshall of Philadelphia.

title: SAILING
description: To the Editor: Regarding the question from a reader in Princeton concerning any United States resorts that include sailing in their rates (Q & A, Travel, May 19): There is one such place I know of from personal experience - my daughter and I have been going there for one week every summer for the past 10 years.

title: Middle Class
description: To the Editor:

title: WHO OWNS ATLANTIC CITY?
description: Where land is concerned, the odds favor the house in Atlantic City, proponents of urban redevelopment contended last week. One casino, Resorts International, either owns or has under option 14 percent of the city's assessed property (including almost half of the large vacant lots that could be used to build new housing and schools), a state official told legislators at a hearing of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

title: WHAT NEXT FOR THE BABY BOOMERS?
description: WHEN in the course of the lives of the Baby Boomers of the United States, it becomes necessary for us to buy outrageously expensive sports cars, contemplate affairs with monks, or switch careers that took 20 years to build, we dissolve any connection with our predecessor generation and do establish a need for mid-life crises.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

TEACHER OF 'ABSTRACT SEEING'
description: In 1923 Walter Gropius appointed Laszlo Moholy-Nagy (1895-1946) to the faculty of the Bauhaus in Munich, Germany. More a synthesizer than an innovator, Moholy-Nagy rejected the art of the past and transformed himself from a provincial Expressionist artist into one of the pioneering photographers and film makers of the 1920's.

title: REALIST HERO: THE RUSSIANS MOURN A POET
description: They gathered at the cemetery again last week in the rain, thousands of Russians carrying bouquets, sheaves of poems and tape recorders from which a gruff, urgent voice sang of the ironies and hardships of their lives.

title: BLACK MOURNERS DEFY SOUTH AFRICA ON FUNERAL RULES
description: About 1,500 black mourners today challenged regulations imposed under South Africa's emergency decree that limit the size and nature of funerals for victims of civil unrest.

title: PLAYERS' GREAT FEAR: SUMMER INACTIVITY
description: THE baseball strike of '81 - how I remember that frustrating time! It was like taking a thumb out of a baby's mouth or a shot glass from a bartender's hand - it was so unreal.

title: NICARAGUAN OFFICIAL ENDS FAST
description: Foreign Minister Miguel d'Escoto Brockman said today that he had broken a 26-day fast he began to protest United States policies in Nicaragua.

title: OLIVE OIL
description: To the Editor: Your readers might like an explanation of the inexplicable - the seeming absurdity of the term ''extra virgin'' olive oil referred to by R. W. Apple Jr. in his delightful review of Italian restaurants, ''Italian Cooking Renaissance'' (Travel, June 23).

title: MANVILLE OFFER TO ASBESTOS VICTIMS
description: Nearly three years ago, the Manville Corporation, once the world's largest asbestos producer, filed for bankruptcy. The purpose was to protect itself from billions of dollars in claims from thousands of workerswith asbestos-related health problems while settlements were worked out.

title: MIDRANGE CONDOS
description: In the three decades since the opening of the Garden State Parkway, communities in Monmouth and Ocean Counties in central New Jersey have drawn middle-income families seeking moderate-priced housing within commuting distance to New York City and Philadelphia. And since 1980, when zoning laws in Jackson Township in Ocean County were relaxed to allow six homes per acre instead of one, developers have wasted no time in building moderately priced condominium communities.

title: SEVERING AN IRANIAN LINK
description: Federal law enforcement officials said the arrest last week of six people, including an Army lieutentant colonel, for plotting to smuggle more than $75 million in sophisticated missiles and weapons to Iran illustrated the Middle Eastern country's increased aggressiveness in seeking American arms for its war with Iraq. The case, the latest in a series involving illegal arms ships to Iran, also seemed to illustrate what other recent spy cases have: the profit motive can be more powerful than patriotism.

title: ROSEMARY HARRIS, STEWARD THOMSEN WED IN ANDOVER
description: Rosemary Borden Harris, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peyton Randolph Harris of Andover, Mass., and Stewart Griffing Thomsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Edward Thomsen of Baltimore, were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Andover by the Rev. James A. Diamond.

title: ROCKVILLE CENTRE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEIGHBORS, BUT NOT NEIGHBORLY
description: Sunny Trefman's article rings a familiar note on my experience in the Jericho area with indifference and unfriendliness.

title: LAURIE CREEDON TO WED SEPT. 14
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard S. Creedon of Stamford, Conn., and Chatham, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laurie Kathleen Creedon to Todd Joseph Martin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Martin of De Pere, Wis. The wedding is planned for Sept. 14.

title: SHARKS RETURN TO L.I. AFTER 'CURIOUS YEAR'
description: LONG ISLAND'S south coastal waters are teeming with a wide variety of shark species, unlike last year, when the shark population largely migrated past this area because of unusual oceanographic conditions.

title: FLORENCE
description: To the Editor: Anne Marshall Zwack's mention of the Pensione Annalena in the article ''In Florence, Rooms With a View'' (Travel, June 30) took me back to 1945.

title: LAWYER'S DEPOSITION IN RIGHTS CASE IS SEALED
description: The Reagan Administration has obtained a court order preventing public disclosure of testimony by a Justice Department lawyer who contradicted the Government's position on the legality of steps taken by the City of Birmingham, Ala., to promote blacks under an affirmative action plan.

title: PERU'S BOLD MOVE TO CONTROL ITS DEBT
description: Peru wants to limit its foreign debt payments to 10 percent of export earnings and bypass the I.M.F. in debt negotiations. In a series of bold and swift moves that began the day he was inaugurated, President Alan Garcia Perez devalued the currency and increased - and then froze -wages and prices. Other Latin American debtors took up the call. In a Lima declaration and in meetings in Havana, the nations pledged stronger resistance to pressure from the West. But analysts say Mr. Garcia's Government could find the new program politically impalatable, and Peru could find it more difficult to negotiate directly with Western bankers than with the I.M.F.

title: BELLINI'S 'NORMA GETS A DASH OF THE AVANT-GARDE
description: Andrei Serban, who cheerfully tells interviewers that he is known as ''the director who destroys the classics,'' was in high spirits last week during rehearsals for a classic at the New York City Opera, Bellini's ''Norma.'' ''I hope it won't disappoint you,'' he said at the outset, ''but Norma isn't Geraldine Ferraro and Pollione isn't Ronald Reagan. I don't think that's the only way to save opera.'' This newest in the operatic projects that have taken an increasing role in the avant-garde director's career will open Friday at the State Theater with Olivia Stapp in the title role and Richard Bonynge conducting.

title: WELLFLEET SEEKING AN OYSTER REVIVAL
description: The Old Colony Railroad once hauled savory oysters and clams from this Cape Cod town toward markets in New York, Boston and elsewhere at the rate of 300,000 barrels a day.

title: ALLISON REISMAN TO MARRY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Reisman of New York and Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison Fern Reisman, to Peter John Menkes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Menkes of Toronto. A March wedding is planned by the couple, both graduates of the Boston University School of Management.

title: TENNESSEE'S GOVERNOR WINNING POLITICAL FRIENDS, AND INDUSTRY
description: At the Gridiron dinner in Washington last March, and again at a United Way banquet in Memphis in April, Gov. Lamar Alexander made his quiet pitch to the General Motors chairman, Roger B. Smith: Put your new Saturn automotive plant in Tennessee and take on the Japanese head to head.

title:
HIROSHIMA REMEMBERED;

The U.S. Was Wrong
description: Though it has not yet received broad public attention, there exists overwhelming historical evidence that President Harry S. Truman knew he could almost certainly end World War II without using the atomic bomb: The United States had cracked the Japanese code, and a stream of documents released over the last 40 years show that Mr. Truman had two other options.

title: A DRAMATIC TRIBUTE TO EUDORA WELTY
description: In praise of Eudora Welty, Katherine Anne Porter once wrote, ''There is no blurring at the edges, but evidences of an active and disciplined imagination working firmly in a strong line of continuity, the waking faculty of daylight reason recollecting and recording the crazy logic of the dream.'' The title character in Miss Welty's short story, ''Why I Live at the P.O.,'' can seem ever so reasonable. How could Sister, as she is called, share a home with her spoiled younger sibling, Stella-Rondo, who stole her beau, Mr. Whitaker, ''the only man who dropped down in China Grove?'' Sister's jealousy and her anger at other members of her family lead her, headlong, to setting up residence in her place of business, the ''next to smallest'' post office in the State of Mississippi.'' Listening to her monologue, we realize that there is an obsessive personality at work. Sister is a single voice of honesty in a world of self-deceivers, whose guardian angel might as well be Cousin Annie Flo, who ''went to her grave denying the facts of life.''

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics National Sports Festival, at Baton Rouge, La., final day. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M. to 3 P.M. live, and 8 P.M. to 11 P.M. live.) Baseball Yankees vs. Chicago White Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. Tom Seaver of the White Sox goes for his 300th victory, and it will be Phil Rizzuto Day at the Stadium. Rizzuto's uniform number (10) will be retired. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2 P.M.). Mets vs. Cubs, at Chicago. Dwight Gooden of the Mets goes for his 17th victory. (Television - Channel 9, 2:20 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 2:20 P.M.) Golf Met Amateur Championships, at Ridgewood Country Club, Paramus, N.J., 36 holes, final round of match play, 8:30 A.M. and 12:30 P.M. Western Open, at Oak Brook, Ill., final round. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M.) Ladies PGA Jamie Farr Toledo Classic, final round. Tennis United States vs. West Germany, Davis Cup quarterfinals, reverse singles, at Hamburg, West Germany. (Television - ESPN 7 A.M., live, and 10:30 A.M. and 5:30 P.M., tapes.) Men's 40 National Hardcourt Championships, at Port Washington Tennis Academy, 100 Harbor Road, Port Washington, L.I., 10 A.M., second day of tournament that runs through Aug. 9. Thoroughbred Racing Saratoga, 1:30 P.M. Dwyer Stakes winner Stephan's Odyssey is the early favorite for the $100,000-added Jim Dandy for 3-year-olds at a mile and an eighth. (Television - SportsChannel 6:30 and 11 P.M.) Other Events BASKETBALL: Stroh's Rucker Pro Summer League, doubleheader, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, West 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Blvd, 2 and 4 P.M. BICYCLING: Coors International Classic, at San Francisco, second day.

title: UGANDA'S NEW LEADERS TRY TO TAKE CHARGE
description: The Ugandan officers who deposed President Milton Obote last weekend have announced a military Government they say will be temporary. Uganda radio spoke of elections within 12 months, but the officers mentioned no dates. They appealed to anti-Obote guerrillas who control much of southern Uganda and to Obote loyalists in the north to put aside the murderous tribal warfare that has plagued the East African country (population, 14 million) for decades.

title: ELITISM?
description: To the Editor:

title: Genghis Khan, Back in Favor, Conquers Hearts of Tourists
description: China has given foreigners permission to visit the newly restored tomb of Genghis Khan, the Mongol conqueror whose empire once stretched from China to Europe, the China News Service said today.

title: Misuse Of Drugs By Aged On Rise
description: SUFFERING from diabetes, the 70-year-old woman took her medication every morning as prescribed and, by and large, monitored her diet. But every afternoon her willpower would weaken.

title: A Soviet Icebreaker Guides Ship Out of Antarctic Icefield
description: The icebreaker Vladivostok conducted a Soviet research ship out of a thick Antarctic icefield today, freeing it after four months of captivity, a Tass correspondent aboard the Vladivostok reported.

title: CHINA'S 'OPEN DOOR' TO WEST BEGINS TO CLOSE
description: China's ''open door'' policy has run into a tangle of economic and political trouble, so much so that Deng Xiaoping and other top leaders are having to pull back sharply on some of their most cherished projects.

title: Meet Mr. Shevardnadze, Soviet Economic Reformer
description: To the Editor:

title: SYMBOLS OF GUILT AND GENEROSITY
description: THE HIROSHIMA MAIDENS A Story of Courage, Compassion, and Survival. By Rodney Barker. Illustrated. 240 pp. New York: Viking. 6.95. IN the instant before nuclear dawn, some Japanese girls looked up to notice a plane flying over Hiroshima and, thus innocently posed, received the concussion of radiation heat that melted the skin from their upturned faces. By chance rescue and family heroics, they came to number themselves among the tiny minority of their schoolmates who survived the bomb, but they retained disfigurements so grotesque that they eventually huddled together in a sorority of pity. ''One could not smile because the contractions tugged her lips over her teeth into a permanent snarl,'' writes Rodney Barker in ''The Hiroshima Maidens.'' ''Another had her right eyelid seared away; unprotected, the eye watered steadily as though possessed with a grief of its very own.''

title: 'VILLAGE' DORM
description: To the Editor:

title: DUSAN BERNIC, CHEF WHO OWNED TERRACE RESTAURANT, IS DEAD AT 43
description: Dusan Bernic, a Yugoslav-born chef who owned the Terrace Restaurant atop Columbia University's Butler Hall, died of cancer Thursday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 43 years old and lived in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: BRADLEY AIRPORT UPGRADES SECURITY
description: BRADLEY International Airport in Windsor Locks, the state's only international airport, has taken a number of security measures since the hijacking of a T.W.A. jet in Greece last June, airport officials say.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ENTER THE YANKEE Plays written by early Americans will be presented in dramatic readings at Van Cortlandt Manor, the late-18th-century historic site in Croton-on-Hudson, at 5:30 P.M. today and again on Aug. 18. The adaptations were prepared and directed by Jane E. House, a graduate of Stanford University and a doctoral candidate in theater at the City University of New York.

title: A VOICE OF CONSERVATISM WITH THE POPE'S EAR
description: Except perhaps for Pope John Paul II, no one in the Vatican arouses as much passionate argument as Joseph Cardinal Ratzinger, a West German theologian who is the head of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith. Cardinal Ratzinger is charged with enforcing Roman Catholic orthodoxy, which means correcting what he sees as erroneous interpretations of church doctrine and occasionally punishing those who stray from the true faith.

title: PRAKAS WINS HAMBLETONIAN
description: Prakas captured the Hambletonian, the second leg of the triple crown for 3-year-old trotters, and the pacer Nihilator narrowly missed becoming the fastest horse in the history of harness racing today at the Meadowlands.

title: Memories Of DiMaggio
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COMPUTER CRAZINESS
description: COMPUTER illiterates arise! Join the new movement, Compu-Stop, or Citizens Opposing More Proliferation of Undesirable Systems to Outdate People.

title: LAGGING SALARIES CAUSE SHORTAGES
description: TEN years ago, when the term was new, office automation conjured in many minds a futuristic vision of desks populated by electronic occupants with silicon souls - while the secretaries who once occupied those desks stood on the unemployment lines.

title: Babcock Wins 3 Events In Festival Gymnastics
description: Brian Babcock, the national champion, won three individual gold medals in men's gymnastics tonight and equaled the National Sports Festival record with a total of seven medals.

title: NEW FUND FOR THE ARTS GETS A TRYOUT IN BOSTON
description: A multimillion-dollar fund designed to help major arts groups become financially stable is having its first test in Boston. Should the plan succeed there, leaders of the fund say, they plan to extend it to other cities, possibly including New York.

title:
INVESTING;

CHASING OPTION AND DIVIDEND INCOME
description: THE use of stock options - once exclusively considered ''racy'' speculative investments -to hedge portfolios and increase total return is now accepted Wall Street practice. But Edward A. Greene, the founder of E. G. Capital Management Inc., is one investment manager who has turned such option strategies into a veritable science.

title: MARCEL AT THE TRANSOM: SOMETHING IS WRONG WITH PROUST'S NARRATOR
description: THE critic Percy Lubbock, in ''The Craft of Fiction,'' makes the point, sufficiently obvious today but much less so in 1921, that a lack of artistic organization in even a great novel, which may be concealed by brilliance of style or of characterization on a first reading, will become more apparent on subsequent visitations and may at least seriously diminish the reader's pleasure. Lubbock was particularly concerned with how the novelist handled his ''point of view,'' that is, the way his story was apprehended by the reader, and he considered James and Flaubert the masters of this technique and Tolstoy a lax practitioner. The last time I reread ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' in the splendid C. Scott Moncrieff and Terence Kilmartin translation, I found myself wishing that Lubbock had included Proust in his study because, for the first time, I was conscious of a flaw in that great work that seemed attributable to a confusion in the point of view from which the story is told.

title: HELPING PARENTS PLAN THEIR FINANCES
description: One of the greatest concerns of adults is the possible physical and mental deterioration of their elderly parents and the ensuing financial problems. Many of these adults are parents themselves - members of the ''sandwich'' generation, caught between the financial obligations of sending their children to college while worrying about the costs of caring for parents.

title: BUSINESS SCHOOLS, JAPANESE STYLE
description: HERE, in the shade of bamboo and pines, at a company school far from their offices, Hitachi Ltd. executives gather to study management. In the mornings, they hear lectures about Japanese architecture, American history and the relationship between the Japanese and nature. In the afternoon, they break for exercise, standing in slippered feet and stretching to the sky. And in the evenings, over sake and beer, they discuss the day's lessons in a class called ''We Are One.'' Management training? Very much so, says Yasuhiko Shigenaga, director of the Hitachi Institute of Management Development. Knowledge of Japanese design and architecture, he explains, may help a manager tailor products to consumer tastes. Classes like ''We Are One'' reinforce Japan's emphasis on teamwork and relationships as the cornerstones of management. And the sayings of Hitachi's founder that grace the walls at the Abiko school provide a corporate identity.

title: PRESERVING A BEAUTIFUL FINISH ON A HARDWOOD FLOOR
description: A BEAUTIFULLY finished hardwood floor should not need refinishing for many years if properly maintained, but it will soon show signs of wear if neglected or abused. This holds true regardless of the type of finish used on the floor -and regardless of what some advertisers claim for their finishes.

title: GREENWICH MARKET
description: To the Editor: Having spent many happy and rewarding hours browsing and buying at Greenwich Antiques Market, I would like to add the name of this delightful market in the London area to those already mentioned in Donald Goddard's excellent article ''Beyond Portobello Road'' (Travel, June 23).

title: CONCERT: MOZART PIECES FOR CLARINET AND PIANO
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra presented its Avery Fisher Hall audience with two of the composer's great gifts to the concerto literature Friday night - the Piano Concerto in D minor and the Concerto for Clarinet in A. Both soloists were young Americans but cut from different stylistic cloth. Ken Noda's piano playing, for example, was a study in subdued elegance - very expressive in its own way but always within strict boundaries of order and symmetry. Richard Stoltzman, on the other hand, played his clarinet like a sly but irrepressible raconteur. There was playfulness in his bendings of tempo in the outer movements and an eloquent songfulness in the Adagio. Mr. Noda played Beethoven's cadenzas, Mr. Stoltzman those by Mozart himself, and it was in these moments that both men gave most of their own distinctive personalities.

title: TALKS RECESS AFTER 2 HOURS
description: Baseball's labor teams met yesterday after a two-day hiatus, but they ignored the package of proposals presented by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth. They also failed to make even a bit of progress, bringing them a day closer to Tuesday's strike deadline with no settlement in sight.

title: O'Brien Plays Well
description: It was only a scrimmage today, but it was against the Washington Redskins, and O'Brien displayed greater poise and improved techniques. The Jets won by 30-25.

title: FOR CHIEF PLAINTIFF, A 15-YEAR BATTLE
description: ETHEL LAWRENCE wishes that she had written down the stories her grandmother used to tell the family, stories about slave ancestors who escaped to freedom by way of the Underground Railroad before the Civil War.

title: SEAVER SEEKS 300, ON NEW YORK MOUND
description: It is a coincidence of scheduling that Tom Seaver is back in New York, but it is fitting, too. Twice he pitched for the Mets, and twice he was sent away: once in an upsetting trade to the Cincinnati Reds in 1977 and again when he was left unprotected in the compensation pool in 1984.

title: SORE? WHO'S SORE?
description: It may not have been detectable on the weather radar, but the air between New Jersey and South Dakota has been blue lately with testy messages between Senator Bill Bradley and the State Attorney General, Mark V. Meierhenry. The controversy, on its face, has more to do with ethnic politics than the fact that the Senator is a Democrat and the state official a Republican.

title: Signs for Soccer
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Judge Backs Amish Ban On Buggy Warning Signs
description: Amish farmers have a constitutional right not to put bright orange warning signs on their plain black buggies because their conservative religion prohibits such displays, a judge ruled Friday.

title: Crime Wave
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH WRITERS: THE UNDERGROUND IS ON TOP
description: THE most sought-after book in Warsaw these days is an extraordinary, illicitly produced volume called ''They.'' Its only rivals among the unofficially published books that have proliferated in Poland over the last few years have been ''A History of Solidarity'' and ''Konspira,'' a compilation of the self-critical recollections of fugi-tive leaders of Solidarity's clandestine wing. ''They'' has been so popular that the free-market price of the 256-page, small-print paperback is now roughly one-tenth of a doctor's monthly salary; copies, secured through secret-police-dodging book runners, are lent or even rented out, carefully wrapped in brown paper to avoid soiling.

title: BANK JOINS LIST OF ARTIST SHOWPLACES
description: THERE are now so many corporations investing in art that it takes a directory the size of the Bergen County telephone book to list them.

title: SUIT IN CHASE THROWN OUT
description: A state appeals court has ruled that a police officer involved in a high-speed chase who then suffered a heart attack could not sue the fleeing suspect for damages. The ruling, handed down this week by the State Superior Court, resulted from a suit filed by Paul Zanine, a police officer, against Robert Gallagher and six other occupants of a car he chased in December 1977.

title: 7 DEVELOPERS OFFER PLANS FOR SOUTH FERRY SITE
description: New York City has received proposals from seven groups for the redevelopment of a site on the southern tip of Manhattan that would include construction of a new skyscraper, restoration of a landmark building and modernization of the Staten Island ferry terminal.

title: SPACE SHUTTLE MISSION EXTENDED BY ONE DAY
description: Space agency officials said today that the shuttle Challenger's $72 million payload of telescopes and other instruments was working so well that the weeklong mission would be extended by one day, until Tuesday.

title: MOVEGOERS HELP INSTITUTE REACH A 50Th
description: ''The American people are generous and will forgive almost any weakness, with the exception of stupidity.'' - Will Rogers WHITE PLAINS THE audience at the RKO Movie Theater in Mamaroneck had just spent $5 for Clint Eastwood's ''Pale Rider'' and there was an usher moving from aisle to aisle, jar in hand as if among a congregation of the faithful asking for contributions to benefit the Will Rogers Institute.

title: HOME FOR NESTLE
