description: The Nestle company, which sold its half-finished new headquarters building to International Business Machnes in 1982 when its parent company in Switzerland ordered a belt-tightening, has now revealed its new headquarters site -- directly across Manhattanville Road in purchase from the building it sold to I. B. M. The new headquarters will be a four-story glass and granite building next to the Center at Purchase office park, on a high point overlooking Route I-684 and I-287.

title: PANEL IN ALASKA ADVISES ENDING BID TO IMPEACH
description: A state legislative panel recommended today that Gov. Bill Sheffield not be impeached for his role in the awarding of a $9.1 million state lease.

title: BEYOND THE BRINK OF DESTRUCTION
description: HIROSHIMA With a New Postscript. By John Hersey. 196 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.95.

title: The Amazing Shrinking Pork Barrel
description: To judge by stories of $600 toilet seats and mountains of surplus butter, one might assume that Washington can never curb its inclination to waste money. In fact, Congress has just taken a monumental step toward fiscal responsibility. What makes it all the more amazing is that the prospective savings come from the political pork barrel -public works projects that turn little-known legislators into local heroes.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 4, 1985 Fiction

title: BANKING BY BOAT ON FIRE ISLAND: G-STRINGS, PINA COLADAS, DRAMAMINE AND COLD CASH
description: A bank boat begs for a joke: liquid assets, floating loans, something fishy in the accounts. A customer comes aboard, giggling as she steps from the dock onto the fantail.

title: THE STRAIN OF CARING FOR THE LITTLEST AIDS VICTIMS
description: Dr. Arye Rubinstein is about to open a day care center at Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the Bronx for children who suffer from AIDS, acquired immune deficiency syndrome. And he hopes that in time he can offer extra care for those secondary victims of the disease, the people who treat the children.

title: COATS FOR ALL WEATHER
description: RAINcoats do more than repel rain. A somewhat obvious observation, perhaps, but one worth repeating as autumn approaches. Without a lining, raincoats serve as lightweight topcoats; with it, as all-purpose winter overcoats. And whatever the season -since few men have been known to worry about wrinkles on raincoats - they are always the appropriate coats to pack for travel, be it business or pleasure.

title: PLANNED YONKERS SCHOOL DEBATED
description: THREE months ago, Dr. Joan M. Raymond, the Yonkers School Superintendent, proposed the opening of an alternative high school in September for students with disciplinary and academic problems.

title: HELENE HOLBROOK TO WED ROBERT KNOX
description: Helene Morison Holbrook and Robert Eden Knox plan to be married Sept. 14, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. David D. Holbrook of Katonah, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Knox's parents are Dr. and Mrs. H. Donald Knox of Springfield, Va.

title: THE PEACH RISES TO MANY OCCASIONS
description: PEACHES, the rich but fragile summer treasures, can be tricky to select, to store and to use. It is better to buy them a little on the firm side and allow them to ripen - for another day or so - at room temperature. Then store them in the refrigerator where they will keep a few days longer.

title: JERSEY BEACHGOERS FIGHT RESTRICTIONS
description: The sun was hot, the clouds few, so Jane Bickert found a nice beach and stopped to enjoy it. Then came the parking problem. Mrs. Bickert, who lives in Point Pleasant, left her car in one of this borough's one-hour parking spots. After 45 minutes, she found another spot nearby. But when she returned half an hour later, she encountered a police officer and a $25 ticket.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: VICTORIAN AFLOAT LIKE many young girls, Monica Randall liked to play dress up when she was little.

title: A MOMENT OF TRUE FEELING
description: Slow Homecoming By Peter Handke. Translated by Ralph Manheim. 278 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $16.95 THE Austrian novelist and playwright Peter Handke is unmistakable one of the best writers we have in that self-discovering tendency incontemporary writing we have chosen to call postmodernism. He came out of the conflicts of postwar German writing and famously resisted the urgent pressres toward realism and ''history.'' He believes in writing as an artistic and philosophical inquiry, a search into forms. His plays and novels have steadily and splendidly put to the test many of our essential presumptions abut the nature of language and reality in literary art.

title: MISS BRENNAN, BANKER, WEDS CHARLES SHUTT 2D
description: The wedding of Alison Marie Brennan, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edward Noel Brennan of Greenwich, Conn., to Charles Edward Topper Shutt 2d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Shutt of Stamford, Conn., took place yesterday at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich. The Rev. John Olofson, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: A COLLEGE STREAKER BARES THE WHOLE NAKED TRUTH
description: IT WAS 11 years ago, in the spring of 1974, when I was a freshman at Barnard College, that I committed an act unprecedented in the annals of both my alma mater and her counterpart (Columbia, across the street).

title: Making Music, With Time To Swim
description: WHILE house guests in summer are as common in the Hamptons as congested roads and benefit parties, the folks now visiting the Bridgehampton home of Marya Martin, the flutist, and her husband, Ken Davidson, aren't exactly ordinary; nor will they 'pay' for their stays with the customary bread-and-butter trinkets.

title: ATLANTIC SALMON ARE COMING BACK
description: THIS YEAR'S spawning runs of Atlantic salmon in the United States and Canada have given the salmon's champions cause for rejoicing.

title: TWO PERFORMERS WHO DARE
description: It happens that the two finest screen actors' performances of the moment, and very probably of the year, both involve artifice so conspicuous that it amounts to a kind of audacity. Neither Jack Nicholson in ''Prizzi's Honor'' nor William Hurt in ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' makes any pretense of taking his character entirely literally, and neither should the viewer. Yet Mr. Nicholson's Charley Partanna, a businesslike mob hit man, and Mr. Hurt's Luis Molina, a flamboyant homosexual in a South American prison, emerge as fully-drawn, credible figures who perfectly embody the morality of the films centered around them.

title: PATRICIA J. DUNN TO BE THE BRIDE OF K. M. LEVEY
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Dunn of Rye, N.Y., and South Lee, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Jane Dunn of Wilton, Conn., to Kenneth Mark Levey, the son of Barbara Levey of Grand Cayman, a British island in the Caribbean, and Howard Levey of Lakewood, Colo. An Oct. 12 wedding is planned.

title: WAITING ON TABLES, LIVING ON DREAMS
description: At 7:55 on a Wednesday night, Jane Perkins stood in front of the mirror, teasing her hair into a vintage-1967 flip. In a few minutes she would start the next-to-last rehearsal of Larry Ketron's ''Asian Shade.'' The show, she said, shaped up as the best piece of theater she had ever done. Some of the others she had told even her husband to skip.

title: THE LIFE THT IS IN THINGS
description: OURS is the greatest discarding century in history. Objects and ideas become obsolete before we can get accustomed to them. Like victims of a flood, we watch our lives flow away from us on a tide of change. Kurt Schwitters, a German born in 1887, believed that we define ourselves in what we discard as much as in what we create, and he evolved a critical and esthetic history of his age by recycling its junk into art. His collages were composed of debris, his poems of cliches; his famous Merzbau in Hanover, a huge Constructivist combination of house and sculpture, consisted of autobiographical shards and scraps.

title: CREATIVITY AND CLICHES FROM TWO ACTS ATOP THE CHARTS
description: Tears for Fears? Bryan Adams? Neither of these best-selling pop acts is yet a household word. But in the last three weeks, the newest albums by the British quartet Tears for Fears and the Canadian singer-songwriter Bryan Adams have occupied the top two positions on Billboard's pop album chart, outselling Bruce Springsteen, Prince, Sting and Madonna. Though they have almost nothing in common stylistically or thematically, each takes a different broad genre of mainstream pop and extends it in a conservative direction.

title: GOODEN IS MAKING A STRONG PITCH FOR THE CY YOUNG AWARD
description: Late last season, when Joaquin Andujar was one victory away from becoming the National League's lone 20-game winner, he assessed his chances of winning the Cy Young Award. ''They're not going to give me Cy Young,'' the inimitable St. Louis pitcher remarked. ''I lead the league in wins, complete games and shutouts, but I know they won't give it to me. I got to go to the moon and win 120 games; then they'll give me Cy Young on the moon.''

title: ADDING A DASH OF VISUAL SPARKLE
description: EVERY reviewer has certain built-in prejudices that color the way in which a subject is handled. Those personal biases should really be stated as caveats, although they do become obvious enough to readers after awhile. In my own case, for instance, if I were reviewing music, I would have to admit to a strong partiality toward pre-1900 compositions. When it comes to literature, I'll take Dickens, Hardy - or even, yes, a good Rex Stout mystery - over Hemingway any day.

title: THE TELEPHONE LOBBY: NO LONGER A ONE-COMPANY SHOP
description: THE nation's telephone lobby used to operate much like a dictatorship.

title: THE BIG THREE AT WAR AND DINNER
description: SUMMIT AT TEHERAN By Keith Eubank. Illustrated. 528 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95. THE trouble with anniversaries, as President Reagan now has reason to know, is that they tend to call forth ghosts. Whatever his intentions in going to the military cemetery in Bitburg, West Germany, that gesture only confirmed how much more difficult it is to bury the memory of the past than its victims. Ironically, though, the visit to Bitburg appears to have crowded out another specter that was hovering around the edges of our consciousness only a few months ago - the ghost of Yalta. The 40th anniversary of that conference moved the President himself to proclaim, this past February, that Yalta symbolized ''the dividing line between freedom and repression,'' a boundary that ''can never be made legitimate'' and that ''I do not hesitate to say . . . we wish to undo.'' President Carter's national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, seized upon the occasion to condemn Yalta in the pages of Foreign Affairs as ''a synonym for betrayal,'' and to call for a new effort to undo - peacefully, to be sure - the division of Europe. Both men thereby revived the tradition, once much in vogue among American politicians, of Yalta bashing.

title:
ANTIQUES;

BENEFIT SHOW IN GLASTONBURY
description: IT seems only fitting and proper, when a historical society needs the money to maintain a house museum, that it should turn to those who share similar interests. Next Saturday, the historical society in Glastonbury will sponsor the 12th annual Outdoor Antiques Festival on the 18th-century village green at Main and Hubbard Streets. Under the direction of Betty Forbes, exhibitors from 10 states will set up 150 booths of antique furniture and accessories, all for sale. The show will run from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M., rain or shine.

title: DANCE: DAWN WATSON
description: ''SIX BY SIX,'' an evening of dance presented by Dawn Watson on Friday at the Merce Cunningham Studio, had the look of a program put together by a group of friends. The dances varied in theme and quality, but they complemented each other well.

title: CHILEAN POLICE CHIEF REPLACED IN WAKE OF KILLINGS
description: In a sudden move, President Augusto Pinochet has replaced the head of the paramilitary police force in an effort to contain a scandal over police involvement in the killings of three Communists.

title: ONE MAN'S ART: BAGS FOR MESSENGERS
description: A STREET hatch opens onto a steep well of crooked stairs. Below, large spools of colored canvas lean against old tables and sewing machines, while flourescent lights vie for ceiling space with huge pipes. Scissors and awls lie about and pictures of schooners line the walls.

title: MISS WEISER, LAWYER WED
description: Laura Jean Weiser, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Frank Weiser of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., was married yesterday to William Lie Zeckendorf, a son of William Zeckendorf of New York and Chappaqua, N.Y., and Guri Lie Zeckendorf of New York. Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week:

title: APLOMB AND ART DECO AT CLARIDGE'S
description: Strolling down narrow Brook Street in London's Mayfair, one might easily overlook the small white letters on the black awning that announce the entrance to Claridge's. Stepping through the hotel's small entry foyer, one is transported to an earlier, more luxurious era by the splendor of its newly refurbished Art Deco interior. Ahead is the front hall, with its large columns designed by Jonathan Brunshill and the grand staircase off to the right, every brass rod of which is polished daily.

title: IN PERU, A NEW PERSONALITY ATTRACTS A CULT
description: After learning to live with economic collapse, social decay and political violence, Peruvians are adjusting to the novelty of a 36-year-old President with the mandate, popularity and determination to prove that the country can be governed.

title: ON THE EAST PLAZA
description: Despite a bipartisan effort in the House to turn the plaza east of the Capitol into a scenic car-free park, it may be years before Congress works it out. The biggest stumbling blocks are financing the project and finding parking spaces elsewhere for the 300 cars now parked there.

title: NEW YORKERS TURNING TO PRIVATE WELLS IN DROUGHT
description: Scores of New York City residents are having private wells dug this summer for fear that their lawns, shrubbery and flower gardens will die because drought restrictions prohibit them from being watered.

title: JANE HOLCOMB DUPONT
description: Jane Holcomb duPont of Rockland, Del., the mother of former Gov. Pierre S. duPont 4th, died Thursday of leukemia at the age of 71.

title: NEW JERSEY JOUNRAL
description: WHEN tickets for a series of Bruce Springsteen concerts at Giants Stadium in East Rutherford went on sale last month, not too many people were surprised when the supply was sold out in a record 15 hours.

title: SCOTT HERMAN TO WED KIMBERLY JANE MARKEL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas O. Markel of Loveland, Colo., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberly Jane Markel, to Scott Edward Herman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Herman of Washington.

title: SIMMS'S HAND IS INJURED AS GIANTS DEFEAT OILERS
description: The Giants got a victory and a scare today. They beat the Houston Oilers, 21-20, in the Hall of Fame game, but they lost their starting quarterback, Phil Simms, for 7 to 10 days.

title: REPAIRS TO DIVERT 2 IND RUNS
description: Riders of the B and D subway lines of the IND between Manhattan and Brooklyn will face diversions and delays until November because of major repairs to tracks on the Manhattan Bridge, according to the Transit Authority.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANNING EFFECTIVE COMBINATIONS
description: THE effective use of plants in esthetically pleasing combinations spells the difference between having a garden or just a collection of plants. Too many gardeners preside over the latter -one of this and one of that, planted wherever a bit of space allows and according to what happens to strike one's fancy.

title: TRACK BARRON CAPTURES WHITNEY AT SARATOGA
description: Track Barron and Chief's Crown, two stars who had been somewhat on the skids recently, scored impressive victories at Saratoga Race Track today, though both triumphs demanded footnotes. Track Barron was the beneficiary of an unexpectedly slow pace that carried him to a narrow victory in the $222,800 Whitney Handicap, and Chief's Crown was disqualified and placed fourth after finishing first in the $55,300 Tell Stakes on the grass.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: SECRET CONTENDERS: The Myth of Cold War Counterintelligence. By Melvin Beck. (Sheridan Square Publications, P.O. Box 677, New York, N.Y. 10013, Cloth, $14.95.

title: Cultural Center Urged For Every Community
description: Congratulations on John Pekich's article (July 7) concerning production for new playwrights.

title: NOT HIS DAY
description: William C. Brennan, a State Supreme Court justice, had his day in court last week. He appeared in Federal District Court in Brooklyn to plead not guilty to charges that he took $47,000 in bribes to fix four criminal cases.

title: Move by Arlington
description: Arlington Park, ravaged by a fire that destroyed the Chicago track last Wednesday, will resume its 55-day thoroughbred racing meeting tomorrow at the Hawthorne Race Course. The Illinois Racing Board unanimously approved the move, despite objections from the harness racing operators at nearby Sportsman's Park.

title: INDIAN GROUP BLOCKS WORK ON HIGHWAY
description: A small group of Seneca Indians who call themselves traditionalists are blocking the construction of a highway through Indian territory.

title: A TURKISH BOHCA, A FLEMISH FLAMSKVAV AND OTHER RARITIES
description: Summertime, and Florian Papp, a purveyor of English antique furniture at 962 Madison Avenue (at 76th Street), decided to devote itself to less weighty matters. Its exhibition of ''Soft Antiques,'' which occupies the second-floor gallery of the shop and will run through Aug. 30, is its first foray into the field of textiles.

title: COMUNITY SERVICE SOCIETY TO RETHINK GOALS
description: The Community Service Society, considered the city's leading private family welfare organization, is shifting its focus to concentrate, in its words, on ''the problems which create a permanent poverty class in New York City.''

title: MODERN ART MUSEUMS: THE SURPRISE IS GONE
description: In my line of work, I get to go to a great many museums of modern art. I prowl through them, one and all, with an undiminished curiosity. But sometimes, after a week or two on the road, I catch myself forgetting which one I happen to be in.

title: THE STAGE: 'RED BWAI' AND 'COYOTE'
description: THE third American Folk Theater Playwrights Festival has brought a gifted group of British youths and a company of American Indian actors to the Judith Anderson Theater, in short plays written by members of the troupes. They are very different plays, but they add up to a short evening of satisfying entertainment.

title: NEW MUSEUM SET FOR OLD MACHINES
description: ONE of the largest museums on the agricultural and industrial machinery of the late 18th and early 19th centuries is to be built in Kent by the Connecticut Antique Machinery Association.

title: A ROUND OF GOLF WITH ARNIE
description: YOUR mind can do funny things during a round of golf. Actually, funny might not be the right word. Strange, maybe. Or even bizarre.

title: RECORDINGS PROVIDE A HARVEST OF SONG
description: Admirable musicianship coupled with some particularly inviting repertory makes the current harvest of song literature recordings a bountiful one for connoisseurs of the vocal art. For example, there are two reasons why astute discophiles should waste no time in purchasing ''Olympia's Lament'' (Hyperion A66106): First, it affords the listener a rare opportunity to hear the venerated Claudio Monteverdi beaten on his own turf by another composer, Sigismondo D'India. Second, its cover is embellished enchantingly with a copy of Daniel Maclise's voluptuous ''Origin of the Harp'' (the Irish harp, to be sure), a poetic slice of cheesecake that is among the jewels of Victorian painting.

title: CABERNET SAUVIGNON'S IDENTITY CRISIS
description: CABERNET HAS fallen on hard times. Once America's unchallenged leader in red-wine prestige and desirability, cabernet sauvignon is going through a kind of identity crisis. What sort of wine should it be, anyway? Big and rich and mouth-filling, with lots of body, color and alcohol? Or should it be lighter, leaner, more ''sculpted,'' which is a word Robert Mondavi likes to use for this newer style of wine. Ten years ago, cabernet was judged by its muscles. A great cabernet was characterized by inky dark color, bouquet that could fill a room and flavors that hit you right between the eyes. Alcohol content hovered around 15 percent and more, even if the label didn't always say so. It was closer to sippin' whisky than table wine. It turned teeth purple and imposed long siestas on anyone who drank it at midday. There were critics, a carping few, but no one to pay them heed. All was well in the wine country.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE RETREAT OF RADIANCE: A Novel of Revenge. By Ian Moffitt. (Stein & Day, $15.95.) Ian Moffitt's novel takes a grim look at what happens when innocence confronts violence it doesn't understand.

title: TIPS ON HOW TO GET TO THE MEAT OF IT
description: Following are instructions from the National Fisheries Institute on how to pick the meat from a cooked blue crab: 1) Twist off claws and legs. 2) Turn crab on its back and pull apron (i.e., the segmented abdominal part of the body underneath the carapace) up and off. 3) With a knife, cut under the bottom shell, just under the mouth of the crab. Press thumbs into this cut space and lift off top shell. 4) Remove spongy white gills (''dead man's fingers''), which are inedible.

title: TO HONOR, BUT NOT TO PAY
description: MASSACHUSETTS officials say they have scotched a plan for a $1 million retirement ceremony in honor of the state's National Guard commander.

title: FACING UP TO GERMANY'S PAST
description: James Markham's article reports President Richard von Weizsacker as saying that his father welcomed the Munich Agreement of 1938 because, in addition to seeming to gain time for peace, ''it returned the Sudetenland to the Reich.''

title: NEIGHBORS, BUT NOT NEIGHBORLY
description: What a shame that after 18 years of living in Huntington, Sunny Trefman finds herself so estranged from her neighbors and those among whom she lives - and she a professor of English at Nassau Community College!

title: A CLOSER LOOK AT ECOLOGY AND HISTORY
description: ''IN this high-tech, fast-paced world, there is a need for children to wonder, to investigate, to touch nature - to learn that they are an integral part of the natural world.''

title: BURMA PARLEY IS WATCHED FOR CLUES TO FUTURE
description: The ruling Burmese Socialist Program Party opens its fifth major party convention this weekend, and diplomats and Burmese say they are watching the agenda for clues to who might be in line to succeed Gen. Ne Win, who has ruled the country since 1962.

title: 8 INMATES SUE FOR BETTER AIDS CARE
description: EIGHT inmates at the Sing Sing Correctional Facility who are suffering from AIDS last week filed a class-action suit against the Westchester County Medical Center to force it to treat any inmate with AIDS who needs hospital care.

title: California Newspaper Halts
description: The Southeast News Signal, a six-day-a-week morning newspaper, ceased publication Friday. The Hearst Community Newspapers Group gave no specific reason for closing The News Signal, which had a circulation of 11,000 in southeast Los Angeles County.

title: DEATH OF A RUNNER BRINGS ON DOUBTS
description: WHEN Jim Fixx died while running on a New England road last summer, a good many joggers went scurrying off to their doctors for stress tests. I scurried off with them. After all, Jim Fixx was the guru of running. If it proved fatal to him, then what about me? He covered more miles in a day than I netted the entire week. He looked fit and trim, while I still aspired to achieve such an appearance. The only common bond we had was our age group. We were both in our 50's, but this time I had the lead!

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 4, 1985
description: International

title:
RECORDINGS;

MOZART AND HAYDN: A MUTUAL ADMIRATION
description: There has been, perhaps, too much preoccupation, in word and drama, with the true and imagined outrages against Mozart by a musical lightweight like Antonio Salieri. It is infinitely more rewarding from the human point of view to look into the relationship that linked Mozart and Haydn. There we find mutual affection and admiration, a seemingly selfless and noncompetitive bond between two superlative musical minds.

title: CANADA'S CITY OF FLOWERS
description: The city gardener and native New Yorker (with the attendant conceits such a birthright implies) is embarrassed to admit to more than a tweak of envy for the citizens of Vancouver, British Columbia. I suppose I could survive without their ring of postcard-perfect snowcapped mountains. Ditto for a shimmering portside setting where endless masts are backlit by a late-day sinking sun. Yet as if such natural endowments were not enough, there is also a cache of jewel-like parks and public gardens - all of which are ever so inviting, ever so cleverly planted and ever so astonishingly cared for. Herewith a potpourri for visitors. Queen Elizabeth Park, a former rock quarry of 130 sloping acres, is at the metropolitan area's geographical center. The requisite putting greens and tennis courts are there, of course, but so are sunken gardens with velvety lawns etched with serpentine beds of flowers. Seen first from the high spot - 500 feet above sea level - the cheerful patterns are a fitting foreground for mountainous views beyond. The gently bubbling streams and tumbling waterfalls are also popular frames for local wedding photographers; on sunny weekends distraction is provided by bridesmaids by the score in gowns of rainbow hues, competing more or less successfully with the park's other color displays.

title: A JUNIOR LEAGUE GIFT ON MUSCOOT'S 10TH
description: OVER the last decade it has experienced some of the same problems that forced other farms to fail: a lack of livestock and equipment, insufficient hired help and inadequate governmental subsidies. But Muscoot Farm in Somers has endured and, last week, it celebrated its 10th birthday.

title: CAMDEN PRISON CALLED ASSET
description: ONE WOULD hardly term it a ''glamorous'' supplement to this city's continuing Enterprise Zone Development Plan, a project that began 17 months ago as a blueprint for recovery from chronic unemployment and deeply embedded urban blight.

title: PRESERVING A BEAUTIFUL FINISH ON A HARDWOOD FLOOR
description: A BEAUTIFULLY finished hardwood floor should not need refinishing for many years if properly maintained, but it will soon show signs of wear if neglected or abused. This holds true regardless of the type of finish used on the floor -and regardless of what some advertisers claim for their finishes.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: FAMILY PASSIONS. By Betsy Aswad. (Dial/ Doubleday, $16.95.) Most of the people in this entertaining novel are gorgeous, wear beautiful clothes and have no worries about money - all of which makes them endearingly innocent despite their sophistication.

title: Traveling Soprano Takes Capital Stage
description: AFTER six months on the road, touring towns that were ''so small that they didn't even have a McDonald's, Barbara Kilduff, a soprano, says she still flinches at the sight of a Greyhound bus.

title: EXISTENTIALISM, SEMIOTICS AND ICED TEA
description: CONVERSATIONS WITH WALKER PERCY Edited by Lewis A. Lawson and Victor A. Kramer. 325 pp. Jackson: University Press of Mississippi. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.

title: ZAHRINGER TO PLAY MINER IN GOLF FINAL
description: PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 3 -

title: MARK HOLMES IS STOPPED IN 2D
description: In the same arena where his famous brother started boxing professionally in 1973, Mark Holmes suffered his family's first pro loss today.

title: Chess Master, 22, Aims At Top
description: LIKE an expert chess player, Jonathan Schroer of Stony Brook assessed his position.

title: DON'T TOUCH THAT DIAL
description: Only 10 years ago, Congress opened up its conference committee sessions, those critical meetings at which final legislative compromises are shaped by a handful of senior lawmakers who had previously enjoyed the luxury of private negotiation. Today such proceedings are so accessible to the public that a participant can't even grimace without arousing public protest.

title: FACTORY-BUILT HOMES WIDEN THEIR REACH
description: CHUCK HATCHER and the Rev. Louis Gigante would seem to have little in common. Mr. Hatcher is a brawny and ebullient builder of luxury condominiums in northern Westchester County; Father Gigante, a Roman Catholic priest, develops subsidized housing in the South Bronx.

title: Free Public Schools The Rule in Colonies
description: To the Editor:

title: Recent Sales
description: Hanover, N.J. $191,000 16 Slope Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; *2* enclosed porch with skylights, family room, *2* 2-car garage; taxes $2,308. Englishtown $73,500 9B Pine Cluster Circle *2* 2-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 12-year-old town-house condominium; *2* mirrored doors, enclosed patio, electric heat, *2* $87 monthly charges; taxes $1,260. Morganville $164,900 6 Macleish Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old ranch; two-tiered *2* deck with trellis, pool, quarry-tile foyer; taxes $2,933. South Orange $235,000 52 Duffield Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old colonial; hearthstone *2* fireplace, recessed lighting, built-in cabinets; taxes $6,999. Summit $221,500 163 Ashland Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; *2* family room with fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $3,714. Upper Saddle River $505,000 17 Hopper Farm Road *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 8-year-old contemporary; central air- *2* conditioning, great room, 0.95 acre; taxes $5,533. OTHER AREAS Rye, N.Y. $240,000 12 Harding Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old frame *2* split-level; family room, patio; taxes $3,690. Darien, Conn. $525,000 32 Tulip Tree Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old *2* colonial; pool, pond, 1 acre, taxes $4,134. Islip, L.I. $117,000 Brookville Avenue *2* 4-bedroom, 2-bath, new high ranch; dining *2* room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,500.

title: JAPAN PROMISES TO BUY AMERICAN
description: Growing concern over the United States foreign trade deficit and moves in Congress to retaliate against Japan led Tokyo last week to announce measures that a trade official said would make Japan's market ''the most open in the world.''

title: ABC-TV MANAGER KIDNAPPED IN BEIRUT
description: Gunmen kidnapped the operations manager of ABC News in Beirut today as he was on his way to the airport to go to the United States for a medical checkup.

title: BOMBING IN THE BEKAA
description: Israeli warplanes attacked the Syrian-controlled Bekaa region of eastern Lebanon twice last week. Witnesses said they destroyed the headquarters of the Syrian Social Nationalist Party 10 miles from the Syrian border, killing two militiamen and wounding four other people.

title: THREE WITNESSES AND THE BOMB
description: WITNESS: THE WORLD SINCE HIROSHIMA By Roger Rosenblatt. 110 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $6.95. FOR various reasons, including a gnawing sense of mortality engendered by rampant terrorism and other violent events and by repeated failures of statecraft and diplomacy, the 40th anniversary of the dropping of the atomic bomb on Hiroshima has prompted a fresh spate of reminiscence, rumination and moral reflection about what the bomb really meant and what, if anything, can be done about it. Doomsday prognoses notwithstanding, these personal accounts seem to me a healthy historical manifestation; they make me hope I'm still around to catch the next decadal installment.

title: '1940's RADIO HOUR'
description: THE current production of Walton Jones's ''The 1940's Radio Hour'' at the Studio Theater turns the show into a frame for a musical portrait at the expense of its characters and historical setting.

title: Q and A
description: Question:Is there a free list of the travel and tourism bureaus of each state in the United States, with full names and addresses? - W. V., Brooklyn Answer:The United States Travel and Tourism Administration, the Federal agency that encourages travelers from other countries to visit the United States, can supply a list of all the state travel bureaus, with addresses and telephone numbers. The office also has a list of all city convention and visitors' bureaus. They can be obtained by writing to the United States Travel and Tourism Administration, Room 1865, Department of Commerce, Washington, D.C. 20230 (202-377-0137). Some guidebooks include a complete list of state travel offices. One is ''Birnbaum's United States 1985'' (Houghton Mifflin, $11.95). However, it should be remembered that addresses and telephone numbers of these offices are subject to change and a published list may not remain completely accurate for very long. Question:I will be vacationing in Switzerland in September and would like to view the private art collection of Baron Thyssen in Lugano. How can this be arranged? - J. A., New York Answer:Advance arrangements are not necessary to visit the art gallery at Villa Favorita, the Thyssen mansion at Castagnola on the outskirts of Lugano. The gallery is normally open from Easter until the second Sunday in October, on Friday and Saturday from 10 A.M. to noon and 2 to 5 P.M. and on Sunday from 2 to 5, with an admission of about $2.50.

title: PENDING COURT CAES DECREASE
description: THE state's court system disposed of cases more quickly in 1984-85 than in the previous year. But because of an increase in the number of cases filed, the number of cases pending in some areas was still up for the year.

title: LATIN ARTS FIND A NEW YORK SHOWCASE
description: There are those who may find it curious that one of the most prestigious surveys of contemporary Latin American performing arts should take place in the Yankee cosmopolis of New York. This annual affair, which begins its fifth year on Thursday, is the 11-day polyglot ''Festival Latino in New York.'' It will be bigger, perhaps even better, than ever, with 60 presentations from 16 countries: plays, music and dance and films.

title: MISS LLOYD WEDS PETER C. MONSON
description: The wedding of Rebecca Adams Lloyd, a second-year law student at George Washington University, and Peter Conrad Monson, a trial lawyer for the Land and Natural Resources Division of the Department of Justice in Washington, took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard T. Speck performed the ceremony at the Park United Methodist Church in Hamilton, N.Y., assisted by the Rev. Vernon H. Ross.

title: STEAMTOWN IN THE POCONOS
description: Steamtown USA - among the nation's largest, oldest and most famous railroad museums - is alive and well and is settling comfortably in new quarters in Scranton, Pa. Steamtown is in the process of moving lock, stock and steam locomotives from its longtime home in Bellows Falls, Vt., to more spacious and accessible digs in the foothills of the Poconos. It is an appropriate new home, since in the last century Scranton took its initial strength from iron, coal and steam.

title: KATHERINE BROWN WEDS D. B. TEGEN
description: Katherine Adair Brown, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Dale Marius Brown of Schenectady, N.Y., was married yesterday to Douglas Bocher Tegen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Frederick Tegen of Hingham, Mass. The Rev. Donald Stake performed the ceremony at the Union Presbyterian Church in Schenectady.

title: $1.47 MILLION PARCEL
description: A 144,000-square-foot city-owned parcel of land on Staten Island that went on the auction block at an upset price of $119,000 - and was sold to a home builder for $1.47 million - is to be the site of new residential development.

title: CANADA MAY TRY MAN SOUGHT IN U.S. DEATHS
description: Law-enforcement officials in Canada say they plan to prosecute Charles Ng on several charges, including attempted murder, before considering any application to extradite him to the United States, where he is a suspect in a number of killings at a remote cabin in California.

title: BURDENS OF ILLEGITIMACY
description: To the Editor:

title: IN LEFT FIELD: THE COMMISSIONER
description: CALIFORNIA seems so far away. Peter Ueberroth could summon people into a conference room, close the doors, bat his baby blues at them, invoke civic pride and patriotism, and cajole busy talented people into working for free.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

THE FAITHFUL DESPERADO
description: I JUST COMPLETED SEVEN YEARS of marriage without having to scratch the famous Itch. It's not something I dwell on, but when I speculate - usually idly -on having an affair, I'm surprised to have been faithful since my wedding.

title: U.S. DOUBLES TEAM WINS IN DAVIS CUP
description: Having yielded a 5-4 advantage to West Germany in the decisive fifth set of their Davis Cup quarterfinals doubles match, Ken Flach and Robert Seguso battled back today and defeated Boris Becker and Andreas Maurer, 6-2, 6-8, 6-1, 4-6, 7-5, rekindling America's Davis Cup hopes.

title: Bus Crashes in England
description: A double-decker bus overturned in northeast England today, killing a woman and injuring 50 other passengers, at least 8 seriously, the police said. A rescue worker said the driver might have swerved to avoid a sheep. The bus was traveling from Newcastle-upon-Tyne to London.

title: State Faulted on Cost Of Relocating Offices
description: New York State has incurred more than $3.5 million in ''avoidable'' costs in moving state offices from the World Trade Center to other parts of the city, the State Comptroller's office has concluded in an audit.

title: TEDDY KOLLEK'S JERUSALEM
description: THE WALLS OF MAYOR Teddy Kollek's office are lined with pictures of Jerusalem in its many different historical poses. Ever the tour guide, Teddy loves to take visitors on a spin around his office, dispensing stories long and short about the history of each of his photographs and lithographs. But there are three in particular that hold his fancy. They hang to the right of his desk, and, in a way, they say everything one needs to know about Teddy. If these pictures had titles, they might be called ''Jerusalem as It Was,'' ''Jerusalem as It Is'' and ''Jerusalem as It Could Be but Isn't.'' Jerusalem as It Was is a picture taken in June 1967, just as the walls between the Arab and Jewish sectors tumbled down in a cloud of dust and concrete. Jerusalem as It Is features a colorful panorama of the united city of today. Jerusalem as It Could Be is a picture of Berlin, taken near the wall that slices the German city in half.

title: Amateur Leading Western Open by 1
description: Scott Verplank shot a 3-under-par 69 today - his third consecutive sub-par round - to keep the lead in the Western Open and move closer to becoming the first amateur to win a professional tounament since 1954.

title: JEANNE O'NEILL MARRIES
description: Jeanne Marie O'Neill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. O'Neill of Rye, N.Y., and Michael Andrew Loferski, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph J. Loferski of Providence, R.I., were married yesterday by Msgr. Thomas V. McMahon at the Church of the Resurrection in Rye. The bride is a legal assistant with Rumford Property and Liability Insurance in Providence, and her husband is a product design engineer with Hasbro Industries in Pawtucket, R.I.

title: CITIZEN OF THE WORLD
description: For many years, Yehudi Menuhin has been a citizen of two countries - the United States, where he was born 79 years ago, and Switzerland, where he has directed the Yehudi Menuhin Festival in Gstaad for 29 years. It was reported last week that he has added a third country to the list, Britain.

title: ARE THINGS LOOSER IN THE EASTERN BLOC? YES AND NO
description: As officials of the United States, the Soviet Union and 33 other countries gathered last week to mark the 10th anniversary of the Helsinki accords on East-West cooperation, Eastern Europeans were assessing the extent to which the declaration had altered their lives. The effects of the accords, which tied together ideas about security, access to capital and technology and human rights and humanitarian objectives, have varied widely, of course. For Solidarity union activists returned to Polish prisons, or for members of the harassed Turkish minority in Bulgaria, implementation of the human rights provisions has clearly been flawed. For most of Eastern Europe, the anticipated flow of Western credits and technology has not materialized.

title: Some Ways to Recycle New York Hospitals
description: To the Editor:

title: A CULINARY PASSAGE TO INDIA
description: A GUEST at an adjoining table at Satkar in Cedarhurst was recently overheard remarking that this was the first Indian restaurant to open on the South Shore, an accurate observation. It might be added that it is a fine first.

title: NEW MILFORD SETS VIETNAM PARADE
description: HUNDREDS of Vietnam veterans are expected to march through the streets of New Milford next Sunday in what organizers of the event are calling Connecticut's first ''welcome home'' parade for those who served in the Vietnam War.

title: RETALIATION IN EL SALVADOR?
description: When four United States marines, two American businessmen and seven other people were gunned down in San Salvador while sitting at an outdoor cafe, President Reagan swore vengeance. Last week, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said the Salvadoran Army had delivered - killing or capturing ''a number of people'' believed to be responsible.

title: CHILD CARE FINDS A CHAMPION IN THE CORPORATION
description: LAST year was a nightmare for Carol Berning. Each day after dropping off her two pre-school children at the baby sitter's, the 34-year-old consumer research manager for Procter & Gamble went to work with a knot in her stomach.

title: GRIM DOINGS IN VICTORIAN BRITAIN
description: In the early 19th century, British surgeons relied on body snatchers and murderers to supplement the meager supply of corpses available for dissection. The law allowed anatomists the bodies of 10 executed people a year, but no surgeon seeking to refine his craft, or to further medical research, could make do with the hangman's quota.

title: FOR CONCERTGOERS, A TRIP OUT OF STATE IS WELL WORTH IT
description: NOW that the warm weather makes a short drive a plausible prelude to concertgoing, why not take a look at some of the musical enticements in nearby parts of New York State?

title: ASBESTOS PERIL: DOES AYONE CARE?
description: The town I live in, a 'bedroom community'' of New York city, is supposed to be experiencing a revival.

title: UNFINISHED BUSINESS
description: 'Sadly, the 20th anniversary of Medicare and Medicaid is only a bittersweet occasion. The sweet side is the recognition that Medicare and Medicaid have provided essential health care to millions of poor, disabled and elderly. The bitter side is the unfinished agenda: nearly 30 million elderly Americans who remain uninsured against expensive long-term care, and 20 to 30 million Americans who remain completely uninsured.' rrRepresentative Edward R. Roybal rrDemocrat of California, chairman of the Select Committee on Aging.

title: WHERE CAN ONE TURN TO SLOW A BLITZKRIEG?
description: ''Let's Guide Development to Save the Palisades,'' by James L. Wunsch (June 30), was directly on target. Regrettably, no mention was made as to where distraught citizens can turn to stop, or even slow down, the waterfront blitzkrieg being mounted in Hudson County.

title: FOR HUNGRY FANS, AN ALTERNATIVE MENU OF GAMES
description: AS major league baseball faces its second players strike in four years, it comes to mind that the people who publish those travel guides for vacationers should consider adding a minor league listing -when applicable - under ''What to See and Do.''

title: U.N. SAYS FOOD IS REACHING NORTH ETHIOPIA
description: Distribution of emergency food aid and other relief supplies has significantly improved in the northern Ethiopian provinces of Eritrea and Tigre, according to United Nations officials.

title: HOW TO LEARN ABOUT PLANTING DESIGN FROM NEIGHBORS
description: Gardening by the book does not always put the bloom on a yard. Note the plants shown on any printed page. Their hamburger-sized flowers send an intimate message: Plant me, plant me.

title: TAKING OUT TRASH, TAKING IN MONEY
description: LOWER Merion Township, Pa., a Main Line suburb just west of Philadelphia, is, like many towns in the Northeast, serious about recycling its trash.

title: 'INARTFUL' DODGER
description: POLITICAL LIFE, AS we shall see, follows art.

title: NEW CASSETES: GLORIOUS 'FALSTAFF,' VIBRANT HEPBURN
description: Morning Glory Starring Katharine Hepburn, Adolphe Menjou, Douglas Fairbanks Jr., Mary Duncan, C. Aubrey Smith; directed by Lowell Sherman, 1933 RKO Video 74 minutes. $34.95 ''Morning Glory'' is dated, to put it mildly.

title: Forecasting
description: To the Editor:

title: AN $80-MILLION PARK PLANNED ATOP TREATMENT PLANT
description: DRIVERS on the Henry Hudson Parkway may realize that the huge construction site they pass between 138th and 145th Streets is a nearly completed sewage treatment plant. But not many know it will have an $80 million park on the roof.

title: Satellites Leave Trail in Sky
description: Two Navy navigational satellites were rocketed into orbit Friday night and the vapor trail left in the sky was visible as far away as Nevada. The blastoff painted the darkening sky with ''a long stream of grey streaks'' that could be seen by residents from one end of Los Angeles to the other, said Judy Cane, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Police Department. Residents of Palm Springs, Calif., and Las Vegas, Nev., also reported seeing the trail from the rocket.

title: MULTIDEALERSHIPS AN ASSET FOR ANTIQUERS
description: The advantage of a multi-dealer busines in antiques, especially one with a strongly indefinable perspective, is obvious -- and sometimes more.

title: AUDIO TAPES GIVE DOG-CARE TIPS
description: WHEN Bardi McLennan of Weston treats someone like a dog, she uses love, compassion, knowledge and understanding. And she is making it her business to instruct other dog owners in the same manner.

title: DISMISSED NUCLEAR WORKER AWARDED $70,000
description: The Labor Department has awarded a $70,000 damage judgment to an employee who was dismissed after complaining of safety violations at a plant making fuel for nuclear reactors. The Labor Department said the dismissal at the General Electric Company's Wilmington, N.C., plant was ''retaliatory.'' The award is believed to be a record. The case concerns Vera M. English, 59 years old, who informed the Nuclear Regulatory Commission of what she said were safety violations that had been ignored by the company.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Historian as Tragic Poet For Herbert J. Muller, history is the grandest of all dramas. While it has its comic aspects, the general trend has been toward tragedy and this is how he proposes to approach the great civilizations in ''The Uses of the Past'' (Schocken).

title: JERSEY WEDDING FOR MISS ENGLISH
description: Holly English, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Taylour English of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to Frederick Smagorinsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Smagorinsky of Princeton, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Jan Vickery Knost at the Unitarian Church of Summit, N.J.

title: BAYLOR: A STRONG LEADER
description: THE LOOK isn't there, says Don Baylor. When he comes into the clubhouse these days, he can't help thinking back to four years ago, and wonders why his teammates don't look as concerned, as bedraggled.

title: New Caledonia Militants End Blockade of Mine
description: Militants demanding independence for France's South Pacific territory of New Caledonia ended a five-day blockade of the Thio nickel mine today after the Government agreed to reduce the police presence in the area.

title: PROSPECTS
description: The Market's Takeoff The stock market is poised for a major advance late this year and into next year, says Leon G. Cooperman, partner and co-chairman of the investment advisory committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company. And its two most popular indexes - the S.&P. 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average - are poised for a change in pattern, he adds. ''In the first half, the Standard & Poor's 500 index outperformed the Dow Jones industrial average,'' he said. ''The reverse will happen in the second half of 1985.''

title: TO HIGHEST BIDDER GOES THE PARK
description: THE CITY of Providence, R.I., has decided to sell a rundown park to Raymond J. Patriarca, the reputed leader of organized crime in New England.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANNING EFFECTIVE COMBINATIONS
description: THE effective use of plants in esthetically pleasing combinations spells the difference between having a garden or just a collection of plants. Too many gardeners preside over the latter -one of this and one of that, planted wherever a bit of space allows and according to what happens to strike one's fancy.

title: CAN EAST HAMPTON SLAM THE DOOR ON DEVELOPERS?
description: This summer, as in years past, the ponds, marshes, woods and beaches for which East Hampton is famous have beckoned vacationers. But the town's 14,000 full-time residents, who grew concerned in recent years that too much land was being sacrificed for condominiums and beach houses, are now breathing easier.

title: NEW CASSETES: GLORIOUS 'FALSTAFF,' VIBRANT HEPBURN
description: Rikki-Tikki-Tavi Directed by Oscar Dufau; narrated by Orson Welles Chuck Jones Productions 20 minutes.

title: PENANG ISLAND
description: To the Editor: Barbara Crossette's story ''On Penang Island, a Legend Lives'' (Travel, June 30) brings back memories of a 1952 stay at the even then old E & O Hotel. I was fortunate to have one of the few rooms, at that time, with a telephone.

title: LEADING LADY STARS IN THIS 'MUSIC MAN'
description: IN the opening number of ''The Music Man'' - the rapid-fire ''Rock Island,'' spoken in sing-song style by traveling salesmen on a railway coach - everything sounds as though it is popping at the Darien Dinner Theater. The beat is there and one wants to sing along.

title:
ART;

A BIT OF THE OLD WEST IN GREENWICH
description: IN Connecticut, an exhibition called ''Women of the American West'' might seem very exotic. It is especially so the way that Dorothy Kosinski, the curator of art at Greenwich's Bruce Museum, has mixed it up.

title: THE LONG ROAD BACK
description: ''The Long Road Back'' is the title of a book I published in 1957 (Beacon Press), of which the subtitle was ''The Story of My Encounter With Polio.'' Rehabilitation stories tend to have a family resemblance - hard work; hard-won, sometimes infinitesimal gains, ambivalent feelings toward therapists and other patients.

title: ANOTHER INDUSTRIAL REVOLUTION IS ABOUT READY TO TAKE OFF
description: On sale these days is a product of exotic provenance: nearly a billion tiny polystyrene beads, each 1/2,500ths of an inch in diameter and perfectly round, each made in space. They were produced on board a space shuttle and are being sold to industrial and scientific laboratories. The beads are of a known uniform size and so can be used as a precise means of calibrating instruments such as microscopes that study such tiny matter as red blood cells. A vial of 30 million beads goes for $384.

title: LONDON'S SAVOY
description: To the Editor: The story about London's Savoy Hotel (Travel, June 23) failed to mention a distinguished turn-of-the-century guest: Claude Monet. The vantage point for his famous views of the Charing Cross, Waterloo and Westminster bridges was Room 504 at the Savoy.

title: JUDITH ANN HEROLD, EDITOR, WEDS BARRY DAVID BENDAR
description: Judith Ann Herold and Barry David Bendar were married yesterday in the Essex and Sussex Hotel gardens in Spring Lake, N.J., by Mayor Harry Erbe of Spring Lake.

title: EASING BURDEN OF MONTHLY PAYMENTS
description: Creative financing has been around for some time now, primarily a creature of real estate prices that went through the roof. And, with today's automobile sticker looking like the price of yesterday's house, it isn't surprising that the money men have applied their tricks to car loans.

title: ELMHURST
description: A YOUNG Korean man asks a Colombian woman standing outside her home how to get to Lamont Avenue. Across the street, two young Koreans are taking their baby for a late afternoon walk; nearby, a group of Hispanic teen-agers listen to a radio.

title:
GARDENING;

PLANNING EFFECTIVE COMBINATIONS
description: THE effective use of plants in esthetically pleasing combinations spells the difference between having a garden or just a collection of plants. Too many gardeners preside over the latter -one of this and one of that, planted wherever a bit of space allows and according to what happens to strike one's fancy.

title: REAL-LIFE 'JAWS'
description: Great white sharks attacked three people off northern California and one off Oregon in two weeks in September 1984, raising fears that the waters in the region might be permanently unsafe for swimming and diving. One person was killed in the attacks, and the others were badly gashed.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Waterfront Zoning: 2 Cases to Compare
description: What should a municipality that likes the present balance of land uses along its waterfront do to assure that it will never be disturbed? The answer to this question can vary widely. Thus, seeking to provide continued access to a waterfront facility for fishing boats that were being pushed out by current land value and development dynamics in Newport, the State of Rhode Island purchased a privately owned wharf [''Development of Newport Waterfront Forces Fishermen to Fight for Space,'' The New York Times, July 7] . In the village of Mamaroneck, the governing body, encouraged by the Department of State of the State of New York, found an easier solution: it froze existing land uses in perpetuity by a mere wave of its magic zoning wand. As a result, the owners of all water-dependent uses in its coastal zone, such as beach clubs and boatyards, are now prohibited from devoting any portion of their properties to other than its present use [''Coastal Plan in Mamaroneck Seeks to Preserve Traditional Uses,'' Westchester section, June 30] .

title: PHILADELPHIA FIRE BLAMED ON POLICE
description: By everyone's reckoning, it was one of the worst fires in Philadelphia's history. But what caused the fast-moving blaze that gutted 61 houses in a mostly black neighborhood last May? Was it the bomb dropped by the police on the house occupied by the radical group Move? Or was it touched off, as some city officials speculated at the time, by the cult members themselves?

title: TRIBAL INVESTMENT BANK HELPS INDIANS AND MAINE
description: Daniel Zilka's office looks much like that of any successful investment banker. The Egyptian-born Mr. Zilka, with three generations of international bankers in his family, sits at a polished, 18th-century mahogany desk with a copy of a Picasso tapestry hanging on the exposed brick wall.

title: Cable TV
description: It would be difficult to find two more contrasting films this week than a pair of cable premieres - the science-fiction farce titled ''The Adventures of Buckaroo Banzai'' (1984) and a realistic drama about American Midwestern farmers called ''Northern Lights'' (1978).

title: PAINTING A GOOD FACE N THE BUDGET
description: ''SOONER rather than later,'' said Senate Budget Committee chairman Pete V. Domenici last week, ''we have to add the two big issues, unless the United States is prepared to live with deficits of $130 billion to $140 billion forever.'' But as Congress finally passed a budget resolution for 1986, to go off an hour later on its August break, the legislators seemed to have chosen later rather than sooner. Rather than face up to the political consequences of raising taxes and holding down Federal benefit programs - Senator Domenici's ''two big issues'' - wide bipartisan majorities settled for a measure that claimed it would produce a deficit of $171 billion. The red ink was barely dry when Congressional leaders said the projection was over-optimistic.

title: TURKEY SEEKING CHANGES IN U.S. AID
description: Turkey is dissatisfied with the level of American military aid and is preparing a request to revise a military and economic cooperation agreement with the United States, according to senior officials and military officers directly involved.

title: BAYBUH, BAYBUH...
description: Edwin Newman's article ''Baybuh, Baybuh. . . .'' (On Language, June 23), berates what is merely an ordinary Southern United States dialecticism. He might sneer equally at the Neapolitan dialect of some of the greatest Italian opera singers or, for that matter, at the frequently bad pronunciation of non-Italian singers.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TRUMP. By Jerome Tuccille. (Donald I. Fine, $17.95.) This is a gee-whizzer of a biography that invites us to regard the New York real-estate developer Donald J. Trump with awe but tells us almost nothing about what makes him chase after ever-bigger deals.

title: OF BYTES AND BULLETIN BOARDS
description: TO THE NAKED EAR, THE shrill sustained squeal that I get when I dial 516-698-4008, a Long Island number, sounds like steam escaping out of a tea kettle. It betrays no melody nor hint of meaning, and could easily be interpreted as an inoperative number. But from the computer, to which I've hooked up the telephone, the sound of the squeal provokes a congenial response. It has connected with another computer!

title: A SPECIAL SUMMER FOR IRISH CHLDREN
description: MICHELLE MELLON, a 12-year-old Protestant girl from Belfast, Northern Ireland, and James Reid, a 12-year-old Catholic boy from the same city, are spending the summer together, riding bicycles, going on trips and lounging on the deck each night after dinner, talking about the things that interest 12-year-olds - sports, clothes, music.

title: ENJOYING THE BOUNTY OF PROVENCE
description: The wind comes up quickly. At first, seemingly out of nowhere. Then, distinctly from the north. You're driving calmly along one of the winding roads of this northern tip of Provence, purple carpets of lavender to the left, giant sunflowers to the right, regimented rows of green, green grapevines in the distance, and the mistral, with a ferocious force of nature, threatens to toss your car into the next, narrow lane.

title: LONDON'S ROYAL BALLET IS GOING THROUGH TROUBLED TIMES
description: Now that the dance season is drawing to a close, it seems right to draw attention to a few newsworthy items that might have been lost in the shuffle. One is that Anthony Dowell has recently been named to succeed Norman Morrice as director of Britain's Royal Ballet and the other is that France's National Center of Contemporary Dance is organizing tributes in Paris and Angers to Esther Williams!

title: CATESBY HALSEY TO WED OCT. 19
description: Mrs. S. MacRae Halsey of New York and Charles Day Halsey Jr. of New York City and Carmel, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Mary Catesby Halsey to Joyce Kilmer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. N. Joyce Kilmer of Palm Beach, Fla., and Southampton, L.I. The wedding is planned for Oct. 19. The future bride, who is known as Catesby, is the executive secretary to the treasurer of the Hertz Corporation in New York.

title: LENDERS FORESEE SLOWER PACE IN BUILDING UPGRADING
description: THE state housing agency's plan to impose a 6 percent annual limit on rent increases for major capital improvements will force owners of well-maintained buildings to restrict renovations or spread them out over two or three years, mortgage lenders say.

title: LOW-INTEREST LOANS SPUR RHODE ISLAND INQUIRIES
description: As interest rates reached record highs in 1981 and 1982, a score of Rhode Islanders with political connections got 8.5 percent loans from the state, well below the prevailing rates.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

GUARDIAN OF OUR BLOCK, CREATOR OF TEMPESTS
description: HER nose was as sharp as her tongue. It led the way for her onslaught, piercing an atmosphere thick with accusations, denials and resentment as she marched back and forth in the middle of the street. Head thrust forward, she stridently upbraided the small band of young boys interrupted in their ballgame.

title: LOW POWER LINES HAZARD TO SAILORS
description: The scene is re-enacted thousands of times a day at yacht clubs and boat- launching ramps across the United States. A car pulls into the parking lot carrying a rigged sailboat ready to be launched from a trailer. The boaters then proceed to slip the boat into the water, a method that is relatively foolproof - unless there happens to be an overhead power line in the area.

title:
ART;

Forcefulness That Demands Attention
description: SUMMER offerings in East End galleries occasionally introduce current work by the region's well-known artists. Such is the case in the present exhibition at the Vered Gallery in East Hampton, where Balcomb Greene's new series of powerfully realized heads has a featured spot.

title: PAYING WITH SWEAT FOR NEW HOUSING
description: LESS than a mile away from the corporate headquarters buildings in downtown Stamford is the city's West Side, with its reputation for drug problems, vacant buildings and crime.

title: PHILLIES TRIUMPH OVER CARDS IN 10
description: Derrel Thomas delivered a two-out two-run double while pinch-hitting in the 10th inning tonight, sparking the Philadelphia Phillies to a 6-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals in a game delayed twice by rain.

title: ARMS AGAINST THE EXPERTS
description: FILTERS AGAINST FOLLY How to Survive Despite Economists, Ecologists and the Merely Eloquent. By Garrett Hardin. 240 pp. New York: Viking. $15.95.

title: A FATHER'S FOREWARNING VOICE
description: ''Forewarned is forearmed,'' -- my father's family motto -- was not emblazoned ona coat of arms, but etched indelibly on the brain. Forewarned is forearmed, and my father wanted his three children to be forewarned of every disaster they might possibly encounter.

title: Another Record for Yeager
description: Charles E. (Chuck) Yeager, the former test pilot, set yet another aviation speed record as he flew here from Boston this week on a tour promoting his new autobiography. Mr. Yeager made the 412.5-mile trip in 1 hour 13 minutes 48 seconds Thursday, besting the time of 1 hour 21 minutes posted last year for twin-engine turboprop planes between Boston and Washington. The 335.35-mile-an-hour trip in a Piper Cheyenne was the pilot's 20th speed record.

title: FED, NOT TREASURY, SHOULD TAKE THE LEAD
description: FINANCIAL failure can be a powerful educational tool. Bank failures in the early 1930's taught us something about bank investment policies that had been missed by contemporary economics. In the same way, the failures this spring of E.S.M. Government Securities Inc. and Bevill, Bresler & Schulman Inc., both unregulated Government securities dealers, have shown us the regulatory gaps in the marketplace.

title: EDUCATION FOR THE AUTOMATED OFFICE
description: SHORTHAND, typing and transcription - for decades, the secretarial curriculum remained unchanged.

title: VIVIEN FRIEDMAN TO MARRY ROBERT M. NEWMAN OCT. 20
description: An Oct. 20 wedding is planned by Adele Vivien Friedman and Robert M. Newman, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lou Friedman of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced. Mr. Newman is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Newman of Brooklyn and West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: VISIT TO JAPAN
description: To the Editor: In April and May my husband and I celebrated our 30th wedding anniversary by visiting Japan, where we had met in 1953 when I was an entertainment director for the United States Army and he a manager of a military-facility banking office.

title: THE FORTUNES OF THE LOWER EAST SIDE ARE RISING
description: Two years ago, 15-year-old Carmen Iris Rivera was killed when a stray bullet from a drug dealer's gun struck her in the head as she walked with her mother and sister along East Eighth Street. Three days later on East 10th Street another stray bullet from another drug dealer's gun struck 13-year-old Jeanette Rivera, no relation, in the hand.

title: PORTRAIT OF A SMALL BLACK CHURCH
description: I, too, was a minister's son in Bedford, Pa. My father, Rankin Sutton Caldwell, was pastor for 50 years at the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

title: JEAN-ALICE UEHLINGER WED TO REV. W. CHRISTIAN KOCH
description: Jean-Alice Uehlinger was married yesterday to the Rev. W. Christian Koch, an Episcopal priest. Bishop Frank T. Griswold 3d of Chicago performed the ceremony at the House of the Ascension in Acton, Me., a retreat center of which Mr. Koch is director.

title: FOR GOOD LISTENING, IT HELPS TO GO BY THE NUMBERS
description: It is generally agreed that nothing much happens in August. This convenient hot weather rule may not apply to everything, but in the audio business the lull is quite reliable. August is the time when new models are being shipped to the shops to tempt the customers in fall when they are presumably settling in for another season of listening. And while the dealers are unpacking the new equipment, there is a quiet spell allowing us to turn to fundamental precepts that are often slighted in the headlong rush of new developments. Yet it is only in terms of these basic principles that we can sensibly evaluate claims made on behalf of new methods or designs.

title: ODYSSEUS' ISLE
description: My home is on the peaked sea-mark of Ithaca Under Mount Neion's wind-blown robe of leaves, in sight of other islands . . .

title: REPUBLICAN FAMILY FEUD DEEPENS AS 1986 LOOMS
description: Representative William H. Gray 3d, chairman of the House Budget Committee, was asked last week about the feud between the Republicans in the Senate and the Republicans in the White House over budget policy. ''In North Philadelphia,'' the Democrat answered with a laugh, ''we learn you don't get involved in somebody's else's fight. You might get shot.''

title: DOCUMENTARIANS WITH A DIFFERENCE
description: Every documentary is born in its own way. A new film about the Shaker religious sect was conceived three years ago on Route 20 in Pittsfield, Mass. Ken Burns and his wife Amy, the young independent documentarians responsible for bringing the project to life, were driving along the quiet, pastoral highway when they spotted an old round barn, gleaming white in the early morning sunlight. They were captivated. ''I slammed on the brakes, and we went in,'' Mr. Burns recalls. The barn turned out to be part of Shaker Village Restoration. After touring the building and roaming the grounds, the 31-year-old film maker remembers, ''I was animated by the question: Who are these people?'' The Burnses' answer - ''The Shakers: Hands to Work, Hearts to God'' - will be broadcast this Wednesday evening at 8 on Channel 13.

title: JET CRASH AS SURVIVORS AND WITNESSES SAW IT
description: John K. Moore remembers the initial plunge and his own absolute certainty that Flight 191 was going to crash.

title: WHY LEAVE ALL THE LIGHTS OUT?
description: LONG ISLAND is now second only to New York City as the highest energy-cost area in the nation, yet businesses in Nassau and Suffolk Counties lag behind many other parts of the country in the use of existing technology that can slash those costs by 20 to 50 percent a year.

title: DIRECT CONNECTION TO NOWHERE
description: IT is even more difficult than might be expected, several studies suggest, to ''reach out and touch someone'' in Boston City Hall and the Massachusetts state government.

title: Tax-Exempt Bonds And .I. Growth
description: I would like to correct a statement attributed to me in ''U.S. Tax Plan Seen Stifling Long Island Growth'' [July 14] .

title: LAURIE J. STABBERT AN UPSTATE BRIDE
description: Laurie Jane Stabbert, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Stabbert Jr., of Callicoon, N.Y., and Hilton Head, S.C., was married yesterday to Richard D. Sanford, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell R. Sanford of Margaretville, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Village Justice Michael A. Jacobs at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Glen Joseph, friends of the couple, in Stamford, N.Y.

title: SOME ARMOR FOR THE AMAL
description: Until last week, Nabih Berri's Amal militia, the main militlary force in Moslem West Beirut, nevertheless was the only major player in the Lebanese power struggle that did not have its own tanks. But now Syria has altered the balance of armor by turning over 50 old Soviet-built T-54's to Mr. Berri's Shiite followers.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

MUSEUM ISSUES MEDAL FOR THE STATUE OF LIBERTY
description: The centennial of the Statue of Liberty continues to inspire numismatic tributes.

title: ATTACKER SHOT
description: Two transit police officers were slashed during a struggle with a suspected farebeater on a Brooklyn subway platform yesterday afternoon before one of the officers shot the man twice in the abdomen, the police said.

title: BOLIVIAN CONGRESS PICKING PRESIDENT
description: The Bolivian Congress met today to elect a president, and the candidates competed for the legislators' votes in a barrage of newspaper advertisements, street rallies and behind-the-scenes arm twisting.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All this may well not be directly related to the bomb, but I'll probably never know.

title: THE 1930's RETURN TO A STATION
description: MAUD H. BONNELL of Yonkers once commuted on the old New York Central Railroad, which was also her employer in Manhattan, and she remembers what the Yonkers railroad station at Larkin Plaza was like in the 1930's.

title: BRADLEY CONWAY WEDS NICHOL DU PONT
description: Nichol du Pont, a daughter of Peter Rhett du Pont of New York and Mrs. Thomas Martin Green 3d of Hobe Sound, Fla., was married yesterday to Bradley Livingston Conway, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Granville Elliot Conway of Morristown, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Alfred M. Niese Jr. performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of St. John on the Mountain in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: Comings and Goings
description: X-rays taken on the little finger of Tommy John's left pitching hand were negative. The 40-year-old John, who joined the Oakland A's on July 12 in a comeback attempt, suffered the injury in the third inning of collision Friday night with Phil Bradley, the Seattle Mariner third baseman. John, who was forced to leave the game, was taken to the hospital for the X-rays. . . . The Utah Jazz has resumed contract negotiations with Karl Malone, its top draft choice.

title: LISA A. HUBER MARRIES GIDEON GIL, A REPORTER
description: Lisa A. Huber, a doctoral candidate in educational linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, and Gideon Gil, a reporter for The Courier-Journal of Louisville, Ky., were married yesterday at All Saints Roman Catholic Church in Dunwoody, Ga. The Rev. Martin Iott performed the ceremony.

title: Lebanese to Boycott Planned Arab Parley
description: Prime Minister Rashid Karami said today that Lebanon would boycott the Arab League conference in Morocco next week because of the lack of a unified Arab position.

title: 'Flying Tigers': Criticism Critiqued
description: I was disheartened to read the poorly written and carping review by Helen A. Harrison of an exhibition, ''Flying Tigers,'' now on view at the Parrish Art Museum in Southampton [''Home-Front Art From the War Years,'' June 23] .

title: CORRECTION
description: ''The Biographer as Detective,'' an essay by Ronald Steel in the July 21 Book Review, was not properly credited. It was adapted from a lecture in a series on the art and craft of American biography, held at the New York Public Library and sponsored by the Book-of-the-Month Club.

title: AUTHOR AND PLAYWRIGHT
description: Coleman Dowell, an author and playwright, died yesterday in a 15-story plunge from his apartment at 1080 Fifth Avenue, at 88th Street. The police said a note left by Mr. Dowell, who was 60 years old, indicated he had been despondent.

title: PAMELA B. MILLSPAUGH TO WED ANDREW SABEL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Plant Millspaugh of Huntington Bay, L.I., of which he is Mayor, have announced the engagement of their daughter Pamela Bishop Millspaugh to Andrew Charles Sabel, a son of Patricia Sabel and the late Bernard C. Sabel of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for Sept. 20.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

A CARAMOOR SALE
description: The Caramoor Center for Music and the Arts in Katonah is planning to sell two homes on four-acre plots to raise cash for its endowment. The president of Caramoor, Michael Sweeley, said the two houses were on the outskirts of Caramoor's 100-acre property and the sale would not affect the main portion of the institution's land. Caramoor now rents the two houses. 'We're not in the real-estate business here, and keeping rental property is ot our function and we need the money for our endowments,'' Mr. Sweeley said. Asked if Caramoor was facing financial hardships, Mr. Sweeley said no, adding that ''we need a good injection into our endowment just to keep the place going.'' Caramoor runs on a $1 milion budget each year. Half of the money comes from earned income, including concert-ticket sales and the like. The remaining $50,000 comes from public and private contributions.

title: KEEPING OWNERS INFORMED
description: FEW activities are as vital to the smooth running of a condominium or a cooperative as the regular publication of a newsletter.

title: THE CASUALTIES AND SURVIVORS OF DELTA CRASH
description: Following is a list, compiled from various sources, of the known victims and survivors of the crash of Delta Air Lines Flight 191. The list was provided by The Associated Press.

title: NORTHERN ITALIAN IN DARIEN
description: IN Darien, the low-slung, white stucco building near exit 13 of Interstate 95 has recently undergone yet another metamorphosis.

title: LAURIE M. DAVIS TO WED SEPT. 9
description: Michael E. Davis of Beverly Hills, Calif., and New York, has announced the engagement of his stepdaughter, Laurie M. Davis, to Harrison M. Gray, a son of Mrs. Bernard Leyden of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., and David Gurvitz of New York. A Sept. 8 wedding is planned.

title: POLITICS AFTER DALEY
description: CHICAGO DIVIDED The Making of a Black Mayor. By Paul Kleppner. Illustrated. 313 pp. De Kalb: Northern Illinois University Press. Cloth, $26. Paper, $9.50. IN 1975, when Richard J. Daley was re-elected to an unprecedented sixth term as Mayor of Chicago, there were many voters who could not remember a time when someone else had held that office. Presidents came and went; Daley endured, his power rooted in the vaunted political machine that he relied upon and controlled. His death in 1976 opened a decade of political instability and conflict. Jane Byrne's defeat of Mayor Michael Bilandic in the 1979 Democratic primary shocked the machine politicians who had anointed Mr. Bilandic Daley's successor. United States Representative Harold Washington's victory over Mayor Byrne and Daley's son Richard M. Daley, the State's Attorney, four years later in the Democratic primary and the Congressman's subsequent defeat of Bernard Epton, a Republican, in the general election were even more aston-ishing. What had once seemed impossible was, in 1983, a reality: Chicago had elected a black mayor.

title: TICKET WOES IN PHILADELPHIA
description: An audit of the Philadelphia Traffic Court has disclosed that one-fourth of all traffic tickets issued here last year were dismissed. The city controller, Joseph Vignola, in announcing the audit's findings Tuesday, warned that traffic court employees would face criminal charges if the authorities discovered that tickets were fixed. The district attorney has alleged that court employees agreed to dismiss tickets and expunge violators' records in exchange for cash.

title: SELF-HELP GROUP IMPROVES NEWARK AREA
description: DAMAGED by riots and disheartened by years of neglect, the Central Ward in the heart of Newark is the city's most enfeebled section. Yet it has managed to help itself despite its problems.

title: SHEDDING NEW LIGHT ON AN ENIGMATIC CAREER
description: In the 1960's Bill Brandt, Britain's preeminent 20th-century photographer, began to reprint his best-known images from the first 30 years of his career. The black-and-white prints he produced from then until his death in 1983 are larger, and more stark in contrast, than those made earlier, and they have a distinctly unpleasant, chalk-and-soot demeanor. Unfortunately, anyone who has seen Brandt's pioneering work of the 1930's in exhibition in the last 25 years has seen it only through the mediation of these prints, and probably has taken them to be faithful representations of Brandt's photography. But what they represent is a self-conscious fabrication, not historical actuality.

title: LIMITED CONGRATULATIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Neighbors, But Not Neighborly
description: There is a lot of truth in Sunny Trefman's article, ''An Island of Neighbors, but No One Is Neighborly'' [Opinion Page, July 7] .

title: ELECTRIC FUTURE
description: To the Editor Mr. Navarro asserts that the electric utility industry ''needs help to avert an electricity shortage in the early 1990's.'' He urges establishment of a Presidential commission to focus publicity on the ''problem.''

title: WASHINGTON, SAN FRANCISCO REACH FINALS IN BRIDGE PLAY
description: Two powerful teams from Washington, D.C., and San Francisco (Bay Area) moved into the finals of the Grand National Team Championship at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals here today.

title: MISS FIATARUOLO TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Fiataruolo of Trumbull, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Ann Fiataruolo, to Emil Rainero, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominick Rainero of New York. The wedding is planned for Sept. 8. Miss Fiataruolo is a senior at the University of Rochester, from which Mr. Rainero graduated and received a master's degree and where he is a doctoral candidate in computer science.

title:
DINING OUT;

COLONIAL SOLIDITY IN POUND RIDGE
description: RESPECTFUL restoration of this lovely old Colonial house has preserved its age and solidity. The rooms are a treasure of dark beams and rafters, stucco walls, floors of burnished pine upstairs and of slate in the cellar below, where, beyond a glass wall, a lovely garden flourishes. Famous for its early American charm, Emily Shaw's Inn in Pound Ridge has long been a popular spot for celebrating special occasions, entertaining out-of-town guests and holding small business meetings. Thus it is a pity that in the six years we have visited the restaurant, management after management and chef after chef haven't been able to meet the high standard set by this handsome building. Food aside, they have somehow failed to see what many diners must: badly chipped plates, bent utensils, wines listed without vintage, soiled menus, poorly paced service - elements that can be corrected without damaging the preserved status, the history of the place.
