Nor would maintaining old traditions require that the ways of the kitchen be cast in bronze. Renovation in that quarter is long overdue.

title: MICHELE SELTZER WEDS DAVID SETH BRESLIN
description: Michele Seltzer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abe Seltzer of Purchase, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Seth Breslin, the son of Sandra Breslin and the late Irwin Breslin of East Windsor, N.J. Rabbi Arnold Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison, N.Y., assisted by Cantor Bernard Dienstag.

title: Animal Instinct and Human Intelligence
description: To the Editor:

title: Greenpeace Ship Sails for Bomb Test Site
description: The Greenpeace vessel Alliance, with a crew of seven, headed for an atomic test site at Mururoa Atoll in French Polynesia today to join a flotilla protesting French nuclear testing.

title: THE PARASOL IS OPTIONAL; THE GLOVES AREN'T
description: THEIR manner is stately in a most reassuring and attractive way. They are dignified and pristine - a hair is rarely out of place - and slightly aloof, yet not at all forbidding.

title: CHURCH AND STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: IT CAN EVEN BE USED FOR THE CAR
description: THIS may be the year we put the car in the garage at night.

title: 39 HURT IN MEXICO PROTEST ON VOTING RESULTS
description: Police officers using tear gas and riot sticks dispersed a large crowd that gathered Friday night in Monterrey, the capital of Nuevo Leon, to protest what they said was the fraudulent election of a governing party candidate for Governor.

title: A NEW QUARANTINE
description: Virtually none of the estimated 18,000 American students from medical schools in Mexico and the Caribbean will any longer be able to complete their clinical training in New York teaching hospitals. If they want to be doctors, the State Department of Education said last week, they will have to go to hospitals in other states.

title: TOP DOLLAR WITH VIEW
description: An investor has paid $785,000 for the first house in what is perhaps the most expensive development of single-family houses now in construction in New York City, on land overlooking the Hudson River in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: CAREW GETS HIT NO. 2,999
description: Doug DeCinces socked a two-run homer off Bert Blyleven with one out in the bottom of the ninth inning tonight to give the California Angels a 5-4 victory over the Minnnestoa Twins.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

HISTORIC PLAYLAND
description: Susan C. Swanson of Pelham hs a birthday coming up in two weeks,and she says that when it arrives she would like to go to Playland and try out the new rides. ''I think it's good idea,'' she said, then added; ''Of course, I'll have to bring my 82-year-old mother along to watch me while I do.''

title: NANCY WESTCOTT BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Nancy Westcott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Thomas Westcott of Attleboro and East Orleans, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Roger Neville Pocock, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard Neville Pocock of Bahrain, in the Persian Gulf. The Rev. Livingston H. Lomas performed the ceremony at the Federated Church of Orleans, United Church of Christ, in East Orleans.

title: TRYING TO RUN A BIGGER HASBRO
description: ''G. I. JOE - A Real American Hero'' turned out to be ''G. I. Joe - A Real Hasbro Hero.'' Sales of the 3 1/2-inch plastic figure, with his 47 friends and myriad accessories, hoisted Hasbro Inc. securely over the $100 million sales barrier in 1982, a revenue level it has far surpassed since then.

title: HOYT AMMIDON 3D EXCHANGES VOWS WITH PAMELA J. LIPSCOMB IN PRINCETON
description: Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Pamela Jill Lipscomb, a daughter of Jack Carleton Lipscomb of Manassas, Va., and Barbara M. Lipscomb of Centreville, Va., to Hoyt Ammidon 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ammidon Jr. of Princeton. The Rev. Daphne Hawkes performed the ceremony.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE MAN IN THE CARDBOARD MASK. By Alvin Greenberg. (Coffee House Press, Paper, $8.95.) The theme of this story collection is stated succinctly by its least likely character, a nonagenarian whose musings about the elusive movements of history lead to a conundrum: ''Is it the essence of our condition, always, not to know what our condition is?'' Puzzling over their predicaments is the main activity of Alvin Greenberg's rootless heroes, mostly middle-aged men adrift in featureless cities or nameless towns, haunted by memories of wrecked marriages.

title: ELLEN GALLAGHER IS MARRIED TO JON W. ZINKE, A LAWYER
description: The wedding of Ellen Gallagher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Gallagher of Freehold, N.J., to Jon William Zinke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard D. Zinke of Garden City, L.I., took place yesterday. The Rev. John Muthig performed the ceremony at St. Robert Bellermine Roman Catholic Church in Freehold, assisted by the Rev. Ronald M. Meyer.

title: HUDSON PUSHING REMOVAL OF WASTES
description: MILLIONS of dollars in cleanup costs and delays in some major development projects in the Hudson County Meadowlands and along the waterfront here are expected from widespread chromium contamination, state and environmental officials say.

title: WALKING PAPERS
description: If Howard Fields didn't have a 1981 Nissan Maxima, he might still have a job. Mr. Field's problem arose from a contract between the Ford Motor Co. and the United Auto Workers. In his Lima, Ohio plant, cars made abroad were cosigned to a special lot, about a half mile away.

title: DR. GROSS FACES CHARGES
description: For the second time this year, Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, has taken a leave of absence to defend himself against accusations of professional misconduct. Dr. Gross's action followed the filing last week of 11 charges of incompetence or negligence against him by the State Health Department.

title: SOUNDS ELSEWHERE IN THE STATE
description: NOW that the warm weather makes a one or two hour's drive a not implausible prelude to concertgoing, let us take a look at some of the musical enticements beyond the county's borders in New York State.

title: TOURISM RECOVERS AFTER HOTEL STRIKE
description: Two retired sisters from Minnesota were there, and two young men from Montreal, and a father from Texas showing his daughter New York just as his parents had shown it to him years ago.

title: NASSAU G.O.P. PRACTICE DETAILED IN TRIAL
description: THE Nassau County Republican Committee, having barely recovered from the 1981 conviction of its former chairman, Joseph M. Margiotta, in a municipal insurance kickback scheme, is back in the headlines again in another kickback case.

title: THE LONG RED
description: MY IDEA OF SLOW reading used to be ''The Brothers Karamazov.'' At age 15, I took this Dostoyevsky masterpiece to the park one summer to attract girls.

title: JERSEY SYMPHONY'S WUNDERKIND
description: When Hugh Wolff, a 31-year-old wunderkind, was named music director of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra recently, it was the end of a particularly long search for the right man with the baton.

title: CHAMBER SERIES DRAWING TO A CLOSE
description: THE Princeton Outdoor Chamber Concert series will conclude tomorrow night with a performance by the Concord String Quartet.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: JAZZ IN NEW BRUNSWICK Stars under the stars could be the theme of New Brunswick Tomorrow's summer concert series. Last week, it was Lionel Hampton, the jazz vibraphonist, and this week it will be Billy Taylor, the jazz pianist, and his trio.

title: 'To Break, Blow, Burn, and Make Me New'
description: To the Editor:

title: SPACE SHUTTLE IN EXPERIMENT TO AID TELESCOPES ON EARTH
description: The crew of the space shuttle Challenger fired the craft's jets today to punch temporary holes in the earth's thin upper atmosphere, or ionosphere, allowing radio telescopes on the ground to peer deeper into space.

title: Cruise Line Campaign
description: The Cruise Lines International Association, a trade group made up of more than 24 cruise line operators, has gone to Doyle Dane Bernbach/ New York for an advertising and promotion campaign to promote cruise taking by consumers. McFarland & Drier of Miami continue to do the trade promotion, which is largely aimed at travel agents.

title: Randi Beth Greenberg Weds Assif Rozovsky
description: Randi Beth Greenberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Greenberg of Allentown, Pa., was married yesterday to Assif Rozovsky, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eliezer Rozovsky of Cherry Hill, N.J. Rabbi Michael Meyerstein assisted by Rabbi William Greenburg performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Allentown.

title: BROKER WINS MET FOR THIRD TIME
description: After some slipshod play in the morning, George Zahringer 3d recovered in the afternoon to play 17 holes in four under par to defeat Clement Miner Jr., 2 and 1, in the 36-hole final of the 83d amateur championship of the Metropolitan Golf Association.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DIPLOMATIC ENTRY New York is the international city - home of the United Nations, consular center for commerce - and yet New Yorkers rarely visit the usually elegant premises occupied by foreign representatives, many of them ensconced in mansions on the Upper East Side. That is a pity, because in many of these offices one can often get a flavor of the country, either through decor, personnel or publication.

title: Mired in the Superfund Swamp
description: After five years, Superfund is still a daunting swamp of disappointment and discord. The Federal program to clean up abandoned toxic-waste dumps is due to expire, but Congress and the Administration cannot agree on how to renew it. James Florio, one of Superfund's authors, says a new House bill ''isn't worth passing.'' Senator Dole has refused to bring a Senate committee's bill to floor vote. E.P.A. Administrator Lee Thomas fears the program's disruption if Congress cannot agree.

title: BECKER ENDS U.S. BID FOR DAVIS CUP
description: Boris Becker beat Aaron Krickstein in straight sets today as West Germany eliminated the United States from Davis Cup tennis competition, 3-2, in a quarterfinal series. This was West Germany's first team victory over the United States in Davis Cup play.

title: BOWERY SALE DEAL SAID TO BE COMPLETE
description: Negotiations have been completed between a group of investors led by Richard Ravitch, the former head of the Metropolitan Transit Authority, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, under which Mr. Ravitch's group will acquire the ailing Bowery Savings Bank, banking sources said yesterday.

title: Catching Up
description: * Ronnie Harmon, the running back who formerly played at Bayside High School in Queens, has been lifting weights, jumping rope and running this summer, and, all in all, he seems to be recovering well from the double fracture to his left leg that he suffered in Iowa's game against Wisconsin late last season. Still, he has not yet received medical clearance to report to the Hawkeyes' opening practice Aug. 20.

title: JAMES C. MARTIN
description: James C. Martin, founder of the J.C. Martin Studio for Graphic Arts, which produced the Chiquita Banana designs, died Friday of cancer at Ellis Hospital in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Schenectady.

title: JAMES F. NOLAN
description: James F. Nolan, a character actor in films and on television, died of cancer on July 29 in the Motion Picture and Television Hospital in Woodland Hills, Calif., according to a nursing supervisor.

title: WOMEN'S AND BAR GROUPS FAULT DIVORCE LAW
description: Five years after sweeping changes in New York State's laws governing property and alimony settlements in divorce cases, major bar associations and women's groups generally agree that the goals of the laws are not being met and that revisions are needed.

title: FORMER DRAFT PICKS ARE SIGNED BY JETS
description: The once-hidebound Jets continued to pick up players today by retrieving two of their former third-round draft picks who have played in the United States Football League.

title: NEW PROSPERITY FOR THRIFT INDUSTRY
description: Reaping the benefits of lower interest rates, the nation's thrift institutions are earning more money now than at almost any time in their history, according to Government and industry reports.

title: Letter: On Animal Tests;;   Better to Study Humans Directly
description: To the Editor:

title: Shira Lander, Teacher, Wed to David Portnoy
description: Shira Li Lander, the daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Yechiael Lander of Northampton, Mass., was married yesterday to David Portnoy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Portnoy of Baltimore. The bride's father performed the ceremony at the Helen Hills Hills Chapel at Smith College, where her father is chaplain and director of the Hillel Society.

title: A Bushy-Tail Story
description: Cliff dwellers exist in a constant state of either murderous animosity or uneasy truce with what passes for wildlife here. So it is cheering to offer Michael Florescu's upbeat tale of a tail.

title: Market Place;   Airline Stocks And Oil Prices
description: AIRLINE stocks are basking in investor enthusiasm these days, following Saudi Arabia's assertion that it plans to use every bit of its oil production quota from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, thereby doubling its current output.

title: EX-NAVY OFFICER TO GO ON TRIAL ON SPY CHARGES
description: Arthur J. Walker, a retired Navy lieutenant commander, is to go on trial in Federal District Court here Monday on charges that he participated in what American officials have termed the most damaging spy ring in decades.

title: KNEE INJURY PUTS KNICKS' WILKINS OUT FOR SEASON
description: The Knicks received a grim reminder today of their injury-plagued 1984-85 season. Eddie Lee Wilkins, who suffered an injury to his left knee Saturday at the camp for rookies and free agents at Princeton University's Jadwin Gym, is out for the season.

title: FOR THE AUTHOR OF 'SPIDER WOMAN,' HOLLYWOOD PROVIDED HOPE
description: Early in the film ''Kiss of the Spider Woman'' the camera scans the cell shared by two prisoners. One of them, Molina, has pasted pictures of movie stars on the wall, among them one of Rita Hayworth. Later in the film, Molina is released, and on the wall of his apartment hangs a poster of the same photograph.

title: A WOMAN'S FIGHT AGAINST BREAST CANCER
description: Nancy G. Brinker calls herself ''the Carrie Nation of breast cancer.'' The 38-year-old Dallas social figure heads a foundation devoted to breast cancer research, which she founded in 1982 in memory of her sister, Susan, who died of the disease.

title: Edward V. Kolman, 67, Dies; Played for the Chicago Bears
description: Edward V. Kolman, a former offensive tackle for the Chicago Bears and line coach with the New York Giants, died last Wednesday. He was 67 years old.

title: IN BASEBALL, AN AFTERNOON OF MILESTONES
description: Here's the way it was in major league baseball yesterday:

title: SHADOW ON THE STONE
description: We have known the facts and feelings since John Hersey's ''Hiroshima.'' But the place itself has an impact beyond any visitor's expectation.

title: After 250 Years, Zenger's Editorial Victory Lives On
description: Yesterday marked the 250th anniversary of the trial of John Peter Zenger. So irresistible is the story-book quality of the trial that it is tempting to overlook its continuing meaning.

title: PAUL B. SALMON
description: Dr. Paul B. Salmon, head of the American Association of School Administrators for 14 years, was among those killed Friday in the Delta airliner crash near Dallas.

title: Futures/Options;   Default Case Is Examined
description: HARDLY anyone in the futures and options industry was surprised last week to read the Government's version of the unusual events that led to the default and liquidation last March of Volume Investors, members of New York's Commodity Exchange.

title: BLACK UNION PLANS WALKOUT AT MINES IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: South Africa's principal black mine workers' union called today for a strike over pay to begin this month at gold, diamond and coal mines. In a separate warning, the union threatened to boycott white businesses unless the Government rescinded its emergency decree within 72 hours.

title: Thanks for Nothing
description: It's a little unnerving for members of Congress when the Pentagon is unable to distinguish between friend and foe. Last month Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger sent a letter of ''personal thanks for your support during the recent debate and events leading up to the successful House votes on the chemical warfare deterrence program'' to Representative Bob Edgar, Democrat of Pennsylvania. The only problem was that the recipient of the Defense Secretary's ''gratitude and warm regards'' had been one of the most active and vocal opponents of the nerve-gas legislation.

title: 11 STRAIGHT FOR GOODEN
description: With a remarkable sense of timing and a slightly sprained ankle, Dwight Gooden pitched the Mets to a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs today, won his 11th straight game and broke the club record set 16 years ago by Tom Seaver.

title: On Sending Messages to Other Governments
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 5, 1985
description: International

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: GOOD ENOUGH TO DREAM. By Roger Kahn. 351 pages. Doubleday. $16.95. THE mood that Roger Kahn creates at the start of his delightful ''Good Enough to Dream'' is a dissonant one -a mixture of sweet nostalgia and impending doom. In a narrative that hopscotches from past to present scenes and back again, he first recalls the dream, ''full of innocence and sunlight,'' of playing the game.

title: Cram's 2,000 Time Sets Another Mark
description: Steve Cram of Britain set his third world record in 20 days when he lowered the mark in the men's 2,000-meter run with a time of 4 minutes 51.39 seconds today at a Mobil Grand Prix track and field meet.

title: TWO PROPOSALS ON SCHOOL PAY FALTER IN JERSEY
description: A proposal by Governor Kean to reward exceptional teachers is jeopardizing enactment of an $18,500 minimum salary for teachers in New Jersey, the keystone of his package of educational reforms.

title: Bridge: Team From San Francisco Adds to Collection of Titles
description: One of the world's strongest bridge foursomes added to its collection of titles in the early hours this morning.

title: Ballooning U.S. Refundings
description: To present-day participants in the credit market, this week's Treasury financing is just another ''record sized'' borrowing package - the inevitable result of a $200 billion Federal budget deficit. But to a Rip Van Winkle-type character returning to the market after a few years' absence, the amounts would seem staggering.

title: Crash Kills All Five in Car
description: A car careened off a rural road Saturday night, rolled over and plunged into a drainage ditch, killing all five young men in the car, the police said today. The wreck was found by a farmer about 30 miles south of Sacramento, said Officer Larry Cox of the Highway Patrol. The victims were in their early 20's, the Sacramento County coroner said.

title: GIANTS' SIMMS GETS GOOD INJURY REPORT
description: The news today on Phil Simms's injured hand was good. Coach Bill Parcells said at the Giants' training camp here that the injury to the starting quarterback should heal in a week.

title: DANCE: 'THE UNINVITED'
description: A distinctive repertory and well-trained, exuberant dancers made for a program of exceptional vitality on Saturday afternoon when the Clive Thompson DanceCompany performed at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival in Becket, Mass.

title: Amid Enmity, a Thank You
description: Mixed signals are part of the normal traffic among politicians. Sometimes they come almost too fast to sort out.

title: An Underground Reverie
description: Escape was on the traveler's mind - escape from the roar of the trains that made his teeth grind and his temples pound, escape from the steamy subway tunnels that made his shirt stick to his back and his forehead drip and his palms itch.

title: 300! SEAVER ARRIVES SMOOTHLY AT MILESTONE
description: When it was over, Seaver, clearly drained after throwing 145 pitches, rushed to a box near the White Sox dugout and embraced his wife and family. He was presented with an engraved bowl by Phil Niekro of the Yankees, then he faced the news media in a half-hour press conference and returned to the visiting clubhouse, where he was drenched in a traditional champagne shower.

title: A FAMILY AFFAIR
description: THE day began with a bat in Tom Seaver's bedroom. Not a Louisville Slugger, but an airborne mammal who had found his way through a window into the Seaver family's house in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Turner Talked To MGM/UA
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company has confirmed that it had discussed a partial sellout to Ted Turner, the Atlanta broadcast entrepreneur.

title: WILLIAM J. BONTEMPO
description: William J. Bontempo, secretary and librarian for William France Gibbs, the naval architect, died Saturday at University Hospital in Augusta, Ga.

title: STABLES OF DIVERSE COMPANIES
description: Machine tools, trucking, construction, lodging, retail stores. An enterprise with all of those businesses under the same roof could be an old-fashioned conglomerate.

title: Queen, or King, for a Day
description: It's the only way to go.

title: Send It Third Class
description: Who says nobody watches the Democratic responses to President Reagan's speeches? Who says the public doesn't write Congressional leaders anymore? Certainly not Representative Dan Rostenkowski, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.

title: REBORN STEEPLECHASE PARK PLANNED AT CONEY I.
description: Plans are under way for the rebirth of Steeplechase Park at Coney Island, with its razzmatazz of roller coasters, Ferris wheels, carnival music, chute-the-chute and heart-stopping, free-falling parachute jump.

title: A BIG DAY FOR SCOOTER
description: HOLY cow, Bill White, did you see that?

title: MUSIC: NEW WORKS AT TANGLEWOOD
description: Tanglewood's annual Festival of Contemporary Music, which got under way in earnest Saturday afternoon at the Theater-Concert Hall, is in transition.

title: ALBORETO CAPTURES WEST GERMAN PRIX
description: Michele Alboreto of Italy sent his Ferrari to the lead on the 44th of the 67 laps today and held on to win the German Grand Prix.

title: Arthur Mahoney, 81, Dancer And Former Texas Cowhand
description: Arthur Mahoney, a cowhand who left a Texas ranch for a career in ballet, died Friday in Jackson, Miss., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and had lived in Jackson since 1978.

title: BEATRICE CHAIRMAN IS OUSTED
description: The board of directors of Beatrice Companies removed James L. Dutt, chairman and chief executive officer of the food and consumer products company, in an unexpected action Saturday.

title: HEART RECIPIENT IS CHEERED BY THOUSANDS IN VISIT HOME
description: Welcomed by thousands of cheering people, William J. Schroeder returned to his hometown today for the first time since he became the world's second recipient of an artificial heart eight months ago.

title: The Senate and Synthetic Fuels
description: With the House of Representatives voting to virtually wipe out the Synthetic Fuels Corporation by taking away its funds, the corporation's opponents have now begun to size up their prospects in the Senate. It will be much harder there, however, because several staunch S.F.C. defenders hold key posts.

title: Dr. Richard L. Fischer Is Wed to Miss Storms
description: Catherine Eugenie Storms and Dr. Richard Lewis Fischer were married yesterday at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club by Judge Judith S. Kaye of the New York Court of Appeals.

title: A Fledgling Protest Movement Gathers Steam
description: Seldom has the capital's political Establishment had to scramble so quickly as in catching up with the Free South Africa Movement, a mere idea in the head of an angry human rights lobbyist eight months ago. Since then the fledgling protest, responding to racial abuse in South Africa, has been a main spur in Congress's decision to challenge President Reagan's policy toward Pretoria.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: PHILLIES SHUT OUT CARDS
description: The Phillies' Kevin Gross pitched a four-hitter today as Philadelphia defeated St. Louis, 6-0, cutting the Cardinals' lead over the Mets to one-half game in the National League East.

title: SALARY ARBITRATION IS MAJOR OBSTACLE
description: If baseball runs into a strike tomorrow, the cause - after nearly nine months of fruitless negotiations -could be salary arbitration, the 12-year-old procedure that was the first to give players contract bargaining leverage.

title: Quake Hits California; No Damage Reported
description: A strong earthquake shook a large area of California early today, jostling people out of their beds but causing no serious damage or injuries.

title: FESTIVAL'S IMPACT ASSESSED
description: When Mayor Pat Screen learned that Baton Rouge had been selected to host the sixth National Sports Festival, he had a vision of the city reaping significant economic and sociological benefits.

title: Republicans Plan Event At Von Bulow Mansion
description: The Newport mansion where Claus and Martha von Bulow spent their summers before Mrs. von Bulow fell into a coma will be the site of a $500-a-person fund-raising event this month for the Rhode Island Republican Party, organizers announced Saturday.

title: COUP LEADER IN UGANDA CALLS FOR UNITY
description: The leader of the military coup that overthrew the Government of President Milton Obote eight days ago appealed today for unity among the various political factions in this East African country so that elections can be held in a year.

title: Nancy A. Popper Marries a Physician
description: Nancy Ann Popper, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin S. Popper of Syosset, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Daniel B. Magilavy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Magilavy of Akron, Ohio. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the ceremony at the Treehouse at the Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I.

title: 'Japan-Bashing' Will Not Solve the Trade Problem
description: There are several possible things to do when you don't know what else to do about a problem: You can rant and rave, kick a door, look for a Communist or - the latest fad - jump on Japan. The last, now commonly called ''Japan-bashing,'' involves using blunt instruments as a substitute for clear thought.

title: PURCHASERS SEE FLAT ECONOMY
description: The nation's industrial economy continued to sag for the sixth consecutive month in July, with production at its lowest level in 32 months, the National Association of Purchasing Management said in its latest report released today.

title: Tighter Fannie Mae Rules
description: Today the Federal National Mortgage Association is expected to announce tightened credit requirements on mortgages it buys from mortgage bankers and thrift institutions.

title: Lawyers Were Heroes In Brown Decision
description: To the Editor:

title: PGA TOUR CHIEF CALLS FOR FIFTH MAJOR TOURNAMENT
description: Lee Trevino will begin defense of his PGA Championship at Cherry Hills Country Club Thursday in the fourth and last of the year's four major tournaments - or is it the fifth and last major tournament?

title: Japan Plans Space Shuttle
description: Japan plans to begin a research program aimed at developing its own space shuttle by the 21st century, the Yomiuri Shimbun reported today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AEL Industries, Montgomeryville, Pa., which designs and manufactures radar and other electronic equipment, promoted Mark Ronald and George King to senior vice presidents.

title: 'COVENANT,' MOVIE ON NBC
description: IN its way, ''The Covenant'' explains history: A single, powerful family, rather like the Ewings or Corleones, only smarter and more polished, has been making us miserable for 3,500 years. This is an interesting idea, and if ''The Convenant,'' the NBC movie at 9 o'clock tonight, wasn't so languid and dopey, it might even be fun to believe.

title: Reagan Keeps Gearing Up to Overthrow the Sandinistas
description: Backed by the actions of a craven Congress, President Reagan is deliberately bringing his Nicaraguan policy to the point of no return.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 5, 1985: *2*MONDAY Cincinnati Bell Lockheed Corp General Motors Corp Rexnord Inc Jefferson-Pilot Corp *2*TUESDAY AMF Inc Hershey Foods Corp Adams-Mills Corp Illinois Power CBI Industries Inc Iowa Elec Lt & Pwr Central Ill Pub Serv Kansas City Pwr & Lt Electrospace Syst MGA Inc Emerson Elec Mickelberry Corp General Housewares Monarch Mach Tool Goodyear Tire Pioneer Corp (TX) Hall (Frank B) & Co Revco DS Inc *2*WEDNESDAY Carter Hawley Murphy Oil Corp Eagle-Picher Indus Peoples Energy Ingersoll-Rand TNP Enterprises Inc Jostens Inc Thomas & Betts Corp Leggett & Platt UtiliCorp United Inc Munford Inc *2*THURSDAY Carpenter Technology Maytag Co Conrac Corp Owens-Illinois Inc Dover Corporation Robins (AH) Co First City Bncrptn TX Sabine Corp Hammermill Paper Timken Co MAPCO Inc *2*FRIDAY Global Marine Inc Hecla Mining

title: REDSKINS REALIGN AMID CONCERN ABOUT RIGGINS
description: For most of the last eight years, John Riggins has been a joy for the Washington Redskins. He has run for 6,795 yards and 71 touchdowns, set numerous records, including several in a Super Bowl victory, and endeared himself to his teammates for his dedication, endurance and sense of humor.

title: Confusion Over Two World War II Massacres
description: To the Editor:

title: Lasting Impressions
description: You've got your autographed action posters on the wall, an official team jacket in the closet and maybe even an authorized beefsteak calendar featuring your favorite players in provocative poses. But how can you call yourself a real football fan if you don't have a collection of framed plaques bearing impressions of actual handprints and footprints of your team's stars?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some guys out there are cutting throats by running a bad truck.

title: IN JAPAN, TIME IS SAVED BUT EQUITY IS CRITICIZED
description: Tens of millions of Americans would no longer have to face the April 15 tax-filing ordeal under President Reagan's plan for revising the tax system. Although citizens would still have to pay taxes, the Government would do the paper work for them.

title: JOEL W. SCHENKER, A PRODUCER ON BROADWAY AND DEVELOPER
description: Joel W. Schenker, a Broadway producer, real-estate developer, builder and philanthropist, died at Lenox Hill Hospital Saturday, after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HIROSHIMA BOMB'S RADIATION REMAINS A SCIENTIFIC MYSTERY
description: Forty years after the city of Hiroshima was leveled by the first atomic bomb used in war, the exact strength and radiation output of that bomb remain a deep scientific mystery.

title: METS ROOT SEAVER HOME
description: Tom Seaver, who won 198 games in 11 seasons with the Mets, may have been gone but he was not forgotten. He was watched and cheered by his former teammates today as they clustered round a television set in their locker room in Wrigley Field to watch him win the 300th game of his career.

title: Toll Is Now 34 In French Rail Crash
description: The death toll in France's worst train accident in 13 years rose today to 34.

title: JERSEY TRIES AGAIN ON CAR INSURANCE ADVICE
description: The state is trying again to encourage New Jersey motorists to take advantage of a 1984 law intended to help them save money on auto insurance.

title: NEW YORK REGION IS CRACKING DOWN ON UNSAFE TRUCKS
description: More than one in four trucks stopped for spot inspections in the New York region in recent months have been ordered off the road because of defective equipment and illegal drivers.

title: Why Banks Are Not Like E. F. Hutton
description: To the Editor:

title: Time Runs Out
description: Close followers of the National League may remember Tony Brizzolara. He is the tall right-hander who signed with the Braves out of the University of Texas in 1977 and got a reasonably lengthy look-see with the parent club two years later, when his 5.30 earned run average made him lucky to compile even a mediocre record of 6-9. It was not until 1983 that Brizzolara made it back to Atlanta, this time for only 14 games. And, after an even briefer stint last year, he is now out of options, which means that the Braves cannot recall him again without exposing him to waivers. Not that they think there's much room for him on the big-league staff anyway.

title: SYMBOLIC RIBBON PROTESTS NUCLEAR ARMS
description: Thousands of peace marchers today linked sections of fabric to connect the nation's symbols of democracy and war with a figurative ribbon of opposition to nuclear arms.

title: IN POLAND'S WILD ECONOMY, DOLAR TALKS LOUDLY
description: Irena is a 19-year-old university student who has a job for the summer washing the windshields of cars that pull in to a gas station 25 miles from here. She is earning six times as much a month in tips as her father makes as a professor at Warsaw University, and almost as much as Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader.

title: AMERICAN FLIES FLAG AT MOSCOW FESTIVAL
description: By the time the weeklong Moscow youth festival was over this weekend, John Bal, a 39-year-old youth worker from New York City, had given away 500 American flags, 200 pins showing the Empire State Building, 40 five-inch bronze replicas of the Statue of Liberty and nearly 1,000 postcards with scenes of New York.

title: Rebecca Vogel, a Banker, Is Married to Stephen Barr
description: Rebecca Vogel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Vogel of Pennington, N.J., and Stephen Barr, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Barr of New York, were married yesterday at the Edith Memorial Chapel in Lawrenceville, N.J. Rabbi Susan Schnur performed the ceremony.

title: GUNMEN SLAY 2 AND WOUND 9, SETTING OFF PANIC IN JERSEY PARK
description: Several gunmen opened fire in a crowded New Jersey recreational park yesterday, killing two people and wounding nine others in a fusillade that witnesses said went on for minutes and set off panic in a throng of about 1,000 people.

title: ISRAEL TO REVIVE DETENTION POLICY
description: Israel announced today that as part of a crackdown on Arab terrorism it was reinstating its policies of administrative detention without trial and deportation of people who are considered security risks.

title: Airplane Sale in China
description: The Chinese air force is to sell more than 200 transport planes to civilian firms at knockdown prices to help expand civil aviation, the New China News Agency reported today. The deal, which includes provision of crews, follows sharp official criticism of the service and safety standards of the state airline, CAAC. A number of regional airlines and even a few small private carriers are being set up to break CAAC's domestic monopoly.

title: HOW JAPAN GOT READY FOR SUICIDE
description: In the summer of 1945, as American forces prepared to invade Japan, a Japanese high school girl named Yukiko Kasai was given a carpenter's awl and told to be prepared to use it as a weapon.

title: MORTIMER ZUCKERMAN: A DEVELOPER WHO THRIVES ON HIGH-STAKES DEALING
description: The trim man in the perfect suit was frenetically dealing with lawyers, with city planners, with bankers, with the architect. Then, there was a party for a publisher, cocktails with an old Washington friend, two dinner parties and a late plane so he could be on time for breakfast with a senator.

title: Nationwide's Head Cites Reasons for Ford Link
description: A number of analysts interpreted last week's announcement that the Ford Motor Company would acquire the First Nationwide Corporation, owner of the nation's ninth-largest savings and loan company, as an attempt by the auto maker to move into businesses providing a less cyclical return.

title: Susan Goldberg Is Married To John Gevertz, a Lawyer
description: Susan Alison Goldberg, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Joel Goldberg of Scarsdale, N.J., and John Neil Gevertz, a son of Joan A. Gevertz of Scarsdale and Allan H. Gevertz of New York, were married yesterday at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y., by Rabbi Jack Stern Jr.

title: Dr. Bernard Kaminetsky Wed to Melanie Renchner
description: Melanie Eve Renchner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Renchner of the Bronx and Lenox, Mass., was married yesterday to Dr. Bernard Kaminetsky, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Kaminetsky of Jerusalem and Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Yaacov Pollak performed the ceremony at the Sephardic Temple of Cedarhurst (L.I.).

title: Renegades Claim Bandits' Reaves
description: The quarterback John Reaves, who led the Tampa Bay Bandits to the United States Football League playoffs in 1984 and 1985, has been claimed on waivers by the Orlando Renegades.

title: 3000! CAREW GETS HIS BIG HIT
description: Rod Carew became the 16th player in major-league history to reach 3,000 career hits when he singled in the third inning today off Frank Viola of the Minnesota Twins.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: How many major league teams has Dave Kingman been with and did he ever hit .300 for any of them?

title: THEODORE C. LEVENSON
description: Theodore C. Levenson, the chairman of Leviathan Management Inc., a consulting firm based in Ridgefield, Conn., died after a brief illness Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco, N.Y. He was 59 years old and lived in Waccabuc, N.Y.

title: Reagan Plans to Meet Reporters on Economy
description: President Reagan plans to meet with reporters on Monday to make a statement on the economy and to answer questions, a White House spokesman said tonight.

title: Peking Says a Clash Left 200 Vietnamese Dead
description: A Peking newspaper said today that Chinese artillery killed more than 200 Vietnamese soldiers in a recent border clash in Yunnan Province.

title: Article 168986 -- No Title
description: Treasury financings dominate the credit markets this week. The Government has scheduled three sales of notes and bonds totaling $21.75 billion.

title: Continental Bank Study
description: A House panel has criticized the way Federal regulators responded to the near collapse of Continental Illnois National Bank in a study prepared under the guidance of Representative Fernand J. St Germain, Democrat of Rhode Island and chairman of the House Banking, Finance and Urban Affairs Committee.

title: GOOD LIFE ON A PITTANCE IN THE BRONX
description: George Glock pays $46 a month for a million-dollar waterfront view that few New Yorkers even know exists.

title: DEPLOYMENT OF DETECTORS
description: Advanced technology, which has been successfully tested at the Denver airport, can prevent crashes caused by severe low-level wind shifts, the phenomenon that is the focus of the inquiry into Friday's airline crash in Dallas, many governmental and other experts say.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 5, 1985
description: Companies

title: A 'RITE OF PASSAGE' FOR AMERICAN SOCCER
description: If the United States is to rank one day alongside the great powers of soccer, what unfolded here in the past week will be remembered as one of the rites of passage.

title: Scientists Test Theory Of 'Nuclear Winter'
description: Forestry officials set fire to a tract of diseased woods Saturday watched by seven scientists who were testing the ''nuclear winter'' theory.

title: STEPHAN'S ODYSSEY TRIUMPHS
description: Stephan's Odyssey, whose style has developed into that of a heart-stopping Silky Sullivan, may also be developing into a better 3-year-old than he had appeared earlier this year. The son of Danzig scored his second straight last-to-first victory when he won the $121,800 Jim Dandy today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: Elizabeth Vreeland Tompkins, Poet and Arts Commentator
description: Elizabeth Vreeland Tompkins, a poet and arts commentator for National Public Radio, died of cancer Saturday night at her home in Washington. She was 57 years old.

title: Russians Swap Vodka For Tank, Paper Says
description: Four Soviet soldiers who got lost on maneuvers in Czechoslovakia traded their tank to a tavern owner for two cases of vodka and were found sleeping it off in a forest two days later, a West German newspaper reported.

title: Lincoln Center's Festival Extended
description: Lincoln Center Out of Doors, the annual summer festival of free performances, has been extended from three to four weeks, it was announced by Lincoln Center's chairman, Martin E. Segal. The festival's 15th season will begin tomorrow at 11 A.M. with a parade and ''mini-events,'' followed by a noon ceremony and excerpts from ''Sweet Saturday Night,'' a street and social dance review on the roots of black dancing.

title: On Sending Messages to Other Governments
description: To the Editor:

title: Shirley D. Brandman Becomes a Bride
description: Shirley D. Brandman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Brandman of Briarwood, N.Y., was married yesterday to Howard M. Shapiro, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Paul Shapiro of Mahway, N.J. Rabbi Harold Berman performed the ceremony at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I.

title: HUTTON REVAMPING ITS LOOSE STRUCTURE
description: In the wake of pleading guilty to defrauding banks through a check overdrafting scheme, E. F. Hutton & Company is undertaking a sweeping overhaul of its organizational structure and management practices.

title: G.I.'s in the Mideast Start Big War Games
description: United States forces today began their largest Mideast military exercise ever.

title: CONSERVATION AND TOURIST INTERESTS AT ODDS IN DISPUTE AT YELLOWSTONE
description: It is high summer in America's first national park, the cars and campers are bumper to bumper, the campgrounds fill up for the night by noon and the trade in plastic tomahawks and polyester bear-paw slippers is brisk at the souvenir stands.

title: MUSIC: HANDEL 'ALLEGRO' AT CARAMOOR
description: HANDEL'S ''Allegro, il Penseroso ed il Moderato'' is so vivid in its format and of such unusual quality that its absence from the general repertory is bewildering indeed. A performance of it at the Caramoor Festival in Katonah Saturday night -a splendid one featuring John Nelson, the Orchestra of St. Luke's and five soloists - was a forceful argument for the piece's resuscitation. It was also one of the more satisfying of this year's Handel tricentennial celebrations.

title: CASTRO SAYS VESCO IS LIVING IN CUBA
description: President Fidel Castro acknowledged today for the first time that the fugitive American financier Robert L. Vesco had been living in Havana and receiving medical treatment. But in an angry response at a news conference this afternoon he denied the financier was being held under house arrest in Havana.

title: STUDY SAYS STATES SEIZE INITIATIVE ON WORLD TRADE
description: As the states seek to improve their economies with exports abroad and foreign investments at home, they are striding rapidly into the arena of international trade, according to a report released today at the annual convention of the National Governors' Association.

title: DEMOCRATS CHEER RESULTS IN TEXAS
description: Despite the unusual interest of party leaders outside the district, Democrat Jim Chapman insisted throughout the hard-fought battle for Texas's First District Congressional seat that the contest here in northeast Texas was more regional than national.

title: ALASKAN LOOKING FOR 2D VICTORY
description: Supporters of Gov. Bill Sheffield say they will defend him Monday on the floor of the State Senate against what he regards as the partisan remnants of a failed impeachment effort.

title: KAHANE APPEAL TO OUST ARABS GAINS IN ISRAEL Israel revived policies of detention and deportation against Arabs considered security risks. Page A6.
description: When Rabbi Meir Kahane was elected to the Israeli Parliament a year ago, most political commentators here dismissed him as an ''American import'' and a ''racist lunatic'' who would never find a serious following in Israeli society. His election, they said, was ''a fluke.''

title: NO DOG DAYS FOR THE ARTS AT KENNEDY CENTER
description: ''It's like an artist colony, so many things are going on at the same time - it makes it a great place to work,'' said Jeff Perry, looking about at the number of fellow actors who had slipped in to watch the matinee peformance of the Wisdom Bridge Theatre production of ''Kabuki Medea.''

title: FOREIGN FUNDING OF RESEARCH
description: When Harvard and its teaching hospital, Massachusetts General, turned to a West German company to finance research in molecular biology four years ago, they provoked an uproar. For the company, Hoechst A.G., was given the right to capitalize on any findings, in return for its $70 million contribution.

title: AMATEUR IS WINNER IN WESTERN OPEN
description: Scott Verplank became the first amateur golfer in 29 years to win a professional tournament when he rolled in a 6-foot, par-saving putt on the second hole of sudden death today and defeated Jim Thorpe for the Western Open title.

title: Publisher Is Named For High Technology
description: Thomas H. King, for almost four years president of American Business Press until he resigned in June to get back into the fray, has been named publisher/vice president of High Technology magazine.

title: EX-PRESIDENT OF BOLIVA, 77, SEEMS HEADED FOR NEW TERM
description: A 77-year-old conservative populist seemed assured today of the presidency of Bolivia as small political parties lined up behind his candidacy.

title: City Weighing Impact of Strike
description: A strike in major league baseball would cost the city's economy more than $1 million for every canceled game at either of New York's two stadiums, according to a report issued yesterday by Harrison J. Goldin, the city comptroller, who termed his estimates conservative.

title: ANIMATED DUO
description: ''ROCK & RULE'' is an animated comic book with heavy-metal overtones, more interesting for its sound track than for what transpires on the screen. The score includes songs from Lou Reed, Debbie Harry, Iggy Pop and other performers, and could be much more tolerably listened to at home. The animation, which involves an evil, aging superstar named Mok and his efforts to subvert a pretty young singer named Angel, has an unfortunate way of endowing the male characters with doggy-looking muzzles. In any case, the mood is dopey and loud.

title: Accounts
description: * Starkives Company to Diener/ Hauser/Bates.

title: ROCK MUSIC WILL HAVE ITS OWN HALL OF FAME
description: The music industry has established a Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, and top executives from major labels have agreed to serve on its board of directors.

title: TEACHING CHILDREN MORALITY
description: ''MANY parents, I think, are troubled about whether, and how, their children will acquire a moral education,'' said Dr. Michael Schulman, a clinical psychologist who has counseled many parents about their children's moral development.

title: 47 INJURED AS ARMY BOMBS EXPLODE IN OKLAHOMA
description: A truck hauling bombs from an Army munitions plant was in collision with a car early today, setting off explosions that injured at least 47 people, forced up to 6,000 from their homes and left a crater 35 feet across and 27 feet deep in Interstate 40, officials said.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: LONG ROOTS OF SOUTH AFRICAN VIOLENCE
description: Sometimes, as now in South Africa, a nation's ghosts and phantoms can return to haunt the present.

title: Washington Watch;   Talent Hunt For the Fed
description: THE White House has begun its search to fill an upcoming vacancy on the Federal Reserve Board, but most experts believe there is likely to be a considerable period during which the nation's central bank operates at less than full strength.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Dearborn, Mich., Saturday about Jackie Presser, the head of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, misidentified the Reagan Administration aide who congratulated him. He is Edward J. Rollins, assistant to the President for political affairs, not Edwin J. Rollins.

title: Translating Records
description: When Steve Cram of Britain broke records in both the mile and the 1,500 meters last month, he furthered one tradition in the smashing of world track-and-field marks, but he defied another.

title: Dr. James L. Novick Wed To Leslie Meredith, Editor
description: Leslie Ann Meredith, an editor in the general books department of the McGraw-Hill Book Company, and Dr. James Landa Novick, a physician in Westport, Conn., were married yesterday at the Fort Hamilton Officers' Club in Brooklyn. Rabbi William Kloner officiated.

title: Mickelberry Net Falls
description: The Mickelberry Corporation, holding company of ad agencies, announced Friday that its second-quarter earnings were down 59.3 percent, to $187,000, or 3 cents a share, from $460,000, or 8 cents a share, in the similar quarter last year. Revenues were up 13.3 percent, to $35 million, from $30.9 million.

title: DIVIDEND DECISION FOR BANK AMERICA
description: The acting Comptroller of the Currency, H. Joe Selby, and other bank regulators are expected to attend a crucial meeting of the BankAmerica Corporation's directors on Monday at which the board will consider cutting the ailing bank's dividend for the first time in more than 50 years.

title: Lynne Millheiser Wed To Steven Swanbeck
description: Lynne Millheiser, a daughter of Alice Sacks and the late Irwin Millheiser of New Hyde Park, L.I., was married yesterday to Steven Swanbeck, a son of Adina Swanbeck and the late J. Leonard Swanbeck of East Hanover, N.J. Judge Lester Sacks of the New York City Criminal Court performed the ceremony at the Gill/ St. Bernard's School in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: A Milestone Remembered In Fight for a Free Press
description: The murmur of tourists and the shuffle of their shoes across the timeworn stone floor are the usual sounds in the rotunda of the Federal Hall building on Wall and Nassau Streets.

title: 2 Named to Lead Goldman Division
description: Robert E. Rubin and Stephen Friedman, widely considered to be the next tandem to run Goldman, Sachs & Company when John L. Weinberg retires, have been named to head the firm's fixed-income unit.

title: IN BRITAIN, GOAL IS CLEAR BUT RULE ARE COMPLEX
description: Tens of millions of Americans would no longer have to face the April 15 tax-filing ordeal under President Reagan's plan for revising the tax system. Although citizens would still have to pay taxes, the Government would do the paper work for them.

title: MOYNIHAN SAYS NEW YORK STATE IS SHORTCHANGED
description: New York State residents paid $2.1 billion more in Federal taxes in the last fiscal year than they received in Federal outlays, according to a study released today by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: When TV Censors Sex
description: It no longer requires access to a blue-movie TV channel to find a seminaked couple and enough double-entendres to drown a whale. Turn on the set any time, any channel, and there they are - consenting adults (and teen-agers) consenting like crazy. As an ABC-TV vice president announced last year, ''We are reaching the point of physical motion under the covers of a bed.''

title: BOOKS RECALL HORROR OF ATOMIC BOMB
description: An unusually large number of books about Hiroshima are being published this summer for the 40th anniversary of the day the atomic bomb was dropped on Japan, Aug. 6, 1945. Some are paperback reprints of hard-cover books, others are being published for the first time, and several are by Japanese authors for whom the bombing was the pivotal event in their lives.

title: Barbara Underwood Marries a Playwright
description: Barbara Dale Underwood, counsel to District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn, chief of appeals for her office and an adjunct professor of law at the Brooklyn Law School, was married yesterday to Martin Halpern, playwright, poet and professor of theater arts at Brandeis University. Rabbi Gary Bretton-Granatoor performed the ceremony at the Music Barge at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn.

title: For the 107th Congress . . .
description: Every once in a while, there is a glimmer of hope that today's Congress may be raising a new breed of public servant.

title: READY FOR THE JUDGEMENT
description: The power failure on Capitol Hill Tuesday, which plunged the Senate into near darkness and stilled its portable microphones, prompted Senator Robert C. Byrd to tell a story of how an earlier body of lawmakers reacted to sudden darkness.

title: The Hammer and the Fickle
description: What purer market is there than an auction? Informed buyers compete openly and the highest bidder wins. So much for that illusion, at least as it applies to auctions for art, heirlooms and other elegances. It now turns out that some auction houses do their business rather like houses of another kind, with large mirrors and loose morals.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Gifts at Memphis St. Cited
description: Some Memphis State football recruits may have received cars, cash and tuition fees from booster club members, according to a newspaper report published today.

title: D.D.B. Adds Coast Agency
description: The Doyle Dane Bernbach Group, whose worldwide operation includes a health care agency in New York, has just added a second such agency in Los Angeles.

title: Philadelphia to Review Fire Victims' Autopsies
description: The city's health commissioner has said he will conduct a thorough review of autopsy records to determine why the medical examiner's office overlooked an unfired bullet in the body of a victim of the fire that destroyed the headquarters of the radical group Move.

title: A&E, THE ARTS CHANNEL THAT MANAGES TO THRIVE
description: Cable was supposed to be a boon for lovers of the fine arts, but most of the cable channels that were meant to provide cultural programming for discriminating viewers quickly failed. CBS Cable and the Entertainment Channel closed within a year of starting up, and a cable channel contemplated by the Public Broadcasting System never even got started. Only one cable arts channel has managed to thrive: the Arts & Entertainment Network, a joint venture of the Hearst Corporation, ABC Video Enterprises and RCA Cable.

title: REAGAN MESSAGE CRITICAL OF REGULATORY PROCESS IS DUE TODAY
description: President Reagan, in the first overall message by a President on regulation, criticizes laws he contends are preventing the Government from responding ''to the real needs of society.''

title: Double Bogey
description: According to the Professional Golfers' Association, the Reagan Administration's proposal for reorganizing the income tax laws threatens to drive the established system of weekly tournaments, with their big prizes, charitable contributions and television coverage, off the fairways and into the rough.

title: Advertising;   Explaining Toys to Children
description: THERE are still places in the world where unsophisticated children who do not know better have a heck of a good time with toys that they have made themselves. They need no instructions on how to use such playthings.

title: Briefcases
description: * To remedy overlapping regulation, Raymond J. O'Connor, chairman of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, suggests giving states sole authority over small hydropower projects, and consolidating authority over big projects at the Federal level.

title: Iraq Says It Struck Enemy Oilfield Twice
description: Iraq said today that its navy mounted the second attack in two days on an Iranian oilfield in the Persian Gulf.

title: Thief Grabs an Empty Billfold And Leaves $70 of His Own
description: A hitchhiker snatched a motorist's wallet today, but he found the billfold empty and lost $70 of his own in the process, the police said.

title: 'COMMAND 5,' ABC FILM
description: WITH terrorism having established itself in recent years as a fact of life, one might assume that those who are creating dramas might have learned more about the subject that they could bring to bear on whatever it is they are making. However, ''Command 5,'' on the ''ABC Monday Night Movie'' at 9 o'clock, sticks to its guns, the guns of formula production that date back to the earliest years of Saturday matinees at the local Bijou.

title: INVASION OF JAPAN? AMERICANS RECALL DREAD OF THE MILITARY AND CIVILIAN TOLL
description: By the summer of 1945 the United States had strategically won the war with Japan. But America faced a certain and severe clawing if it finished its enemy at close quarters.

title: DANCE: CHOREOGRAPHY WORKSHOP BY GRAHAM'S PERFORMERS
description: SINCE the 1940's, selected members of the Martha Graham Dance Company have occasionally presented their own choreography under Miss Graham's sponsorship.

title: RANGERS TOP JAYS, END SLIDE
description: Wayne Tolleson's bases-loaded infield single in the seventh inning scored Toby Harrah with the tie-breaking run as Texas snapped a five-game losing streak with an 8-4 victory over the Blue Jays today.

title: U.S. Shift on Fuel Plant Perplexes Tenneco Aide
description: Clifford W. Rackley has done business with the Federal Government in the past. He says he expects he will do some more in the future. But as a result of his most recent experience, Mr. Rackley admits that his perspective on how Washington operates has changed.

title: Nolen in 'Casanova'
description: Timothy Nolen will sing the title role in Dominick Argento's opera ''Casanova,'' when it receives its New York City Opera premiere on Nov. 1. Mr. Nolen made his New York City Opera debut last year in Stephen Sondheim's ''Sweeney Todd.'' Mr. Nolen replaces George Hearn who withdrew from the role due to his busy performance schedule, said an opera spokesman. Mr. Hearn is scheduled to make his debut with the City Opera in Wright and Forrest's ''Kismet'' on Oct. 3.

title: Outdoors: Pursuing Bluefin Tuna
description: WHEN the sandy cliffs of Noman's Land Island were no more than a barely-visible dark hump on the horizon to the northeast about 17 miles behind us, our Loran told us that we had reached the area where boats had been loading up with bluefin tuna several days before.

title: DELTA PILOT TOLD TO ABORT LANDING, APPARENTLY AFTER IT HAD CRASHED
description: Federal investigators disclosed tonight that an air traffic controller ordered the Delta Air Lines jumbo jet that crashed here Friday night to abort its landing, but this order apparently came only after the plane had struck the ground once and was again airborne.

title: Computer Fingerprint System Could Have Prevented Rapes
description: To the Editor:

title: CUOMO FORMS STUDY PANEL ON GASOLINE-SALES ABUSES
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he was forming a task force to investigate the problem of gasoline dealers who sell substandard and mislabeled gasoline in New York State.

title: GUIDED IBM PERSONAL COMPUTER
description: Philip D. Estridge, who pioneered the extraordinarily successful entry of the International Business Machines Corporation into the personal computer field, was among those killed Friday in the crash of the Delta Air Lines jet at the Dallas-Fort Worth airport. He was 47 years old and lived in New Canaan, Conn.

title: ISSUES IN THE DISPUTE
description: Salary Arbitration - The procedure permits a player with at least two years of major league service to have his salary decided by an arbitrator. The arbitrator chooses either a figure submitted by a player or one submitted by his team.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: HAMPTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago share earnings have been restated for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed to shareholders of record in July 1985.

title: ENTERRA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: WAR SHADOW LIFTS IN U.S.-JAPAN TIES
description: Forty years after World War II, strong majorities of both Americans and Japanese regard their countries as friends, with old hostilities apparently receding into the background, according to a New York Times/CBS News/Tokyo Broadcasting System Poll.

title: LEUCADIA'S 3D INTERGROUP BID
description: In its third foray against National Intergroup, the Leucadia National Corporation yesterday offered to buy the company for $35 a share, or a total of $750 million.

title: Addendum
description: Peter Vane Advertising and Steve Dorso Advertising Art relocated to 401 Park Avenue South.

title: Coping With Islamic Fundamentalism
description: In the aftermath of the Beirut hostage crisis, many in Washington are searching frantically for an American policy toward Islamic fundamentalism. This is a foolish search for a policy we do not need.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid June 12.

title: HARVARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BIBB CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Deaths Halt Drug Studies
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday it had halted some tests of Bepridil, a heart drug not yet marketed in the United States, because of deaths among patients in the studies. Robert Kniffin, a spokesman for the New Brunswick, N.J., company, declined to say how many deaths had occurred or how many patients were involved.

title: A Sound Budget Process
description: The budget resolution approved last week by the House and Senate represented a victory for a much maligned and prematurely buried creature known as the Congressional budget process.

title: Advanced Micro
description: The United States Philips Corporation, a subsidiary of the United States Philips Trust, said it had filed a patent infringement suit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif. U.S. Philips said the suit, filed in a Federal District Court in California, charges infringement of three patents covering technology for local oxidation of silicon, a process in the manufacture of semiconductors.

title: Who'll Manage the Port?
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey faces the difficult task of replacing Peter Goldmark, its accomplished executive director since 1977. His departure is just two weeks away but no successor has yet been chosen. More is at stake than enlightened management of its airports, river crossings, docks, container ports and terminals.

title: WHAT MAKES SUN SHINE? NEUTRINOS MAY PROVIDE A CLUE
description: MANY years ago, scientists deduced that the primary energy source of the Sun and other stars is the fusion of hydrogen nucleii. Experiments intended to verify this fundamental presumption, however, have indicated that something is seriously amiss. In theory, such a fusion reaction would bombard Earth with a stream of ghostly subatomic particles called neutrinos, yet this rich flow of neutrinos has not been observed.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SATELLITE SYNDICATED SYSEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The year-earlier figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Satellite Program Network on March 1, 1985.

title: Shanley Purchase
description: The Shanley Oil Company has agreed to acquire proven reserves totaling 2 million barrels of oil and 24.14 billion cubic feet of gas, valued at about $60 million, from Petrosouthern Inc.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 6, 1985
description: Companies

title: New York Lawyer Aims To End Manville Fight
description: Leon Silverman is no stranger to legal disputes. In more than 35 years as a lawyer, he has represented scores of corporate clients, and three years ago he headed a special Federal investigation of former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan.

title: SOVIET EMIGRE LOVER DUE TO TESTIFY
description: Opening statements are scheduled for Tuesday in the trial of a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent who is charged with conspiring with a Russian couple to pass American counterespionage secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: COSMETIC LINE'S TV DEBUT
description: A SMALL East Rutherford, N.J., health care products company with $7 million in annual sales, Roberts Proprietaries Inc., wanted a television commercial. ''We were ready,'' said Keith Roberts, the president of the company, which markets depilatories, denture cushions and Covermark, a 50-year-old line of special cosmetics designed to cover serious flaws. Covermark, he felt, could be an important product if the company promoted it properly.

title: Change Set At National Distillers
description: The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation yesterday named John Hoyt Stookey, president, to succeed Drummond C. Bell as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Bell retires in April.

title: No Headline
description: A Boston-based utility holding company is seeking to place a big bet on the troubled Seabrook nuclear project.

title: Gulf Broadcast Liquidation Price
description: The Gulf Broadcast Company said it declared an initial liquidating distribution on its common stock of $12 a share payable Aug. 26. The company said its early distribution was made possible by the July 31 closing on its sale for $760 million of substantially all of its television and radio broadcast properties to the Taft Broadcasting Company in Cincinnati.

title: Stock Quotes Via Macintosh

title: BEATRICE SHAKE-UP SEEN AS HELPFUL
description: The forced resignation of James L. Dutt as chairman of the Beatrice Companies is a step in the right direction for the food and consumer products giant, industry analysts said today. They remain unconvinced, however, that Beatrice has put its troubles behind it.

title: June Payments Surplus
description: West Germany's balance of payments swung to a surplus of 1.364 billion marks, or nearly $490 million, in June from a deficit of 1.066 billion marks a year earlier, the Deutsche Bundesbank said today. But for the first half of 1985, Germany's balance of payments showed a deficit of 6.688 billion marks, or about $2.4 billion, after a surplus of 6.109 billion marks in the first half of 1984, the central bank said. The balance of payments measures all of a country's international trade in goods and services and in capital transfers.

title: FANNIE MAE TIGHTENS RULES FOR HOME BUYERS
description: Potential home buyers unable to make a 10 percent down payment will have a harder time qualifying for a conventional mortgage under guidelines announced today by the nation's main supplier of money for home loans.

title: Cabinet Backs Shoe-Import Quotas
description: The Cabinet has agreed to recommend that President Reagan impose quotas on imports of shoes to alleviate harm to the domestic industry, but may exclude athletic shoes and low-priced footwear, an Administration official said today.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs Sets 1,300 Layoffs
description: Cleveland-Cliffs Iron Co. announced it will temporarily lay off 1,300 employees, more than half its Michigan work force, when it closes the Empire Mine for six weeks beginning Sept. 1.

description: Reporting the results of an audit, New York City's Comptroller, Harrison Goldin, describes a Transit Authority program to put two-way radios on city buses as ''a disaster by every definition.'' The managers of the transit system, used to taking their lumps, plead no contest: ''We basically concur with the report,'' says a spokesman.

description: A judge yesterday sentenced the defendant convicted of killing a drama student on a Manhattan roof to life in prison, saying the crime was of ''Shakespearean proportions in its foul and tragic dimensions.''

title: Orders for Boeing
description: The Boeing Commercial Airplane Company, a unit of the Boeing Company, said British Airways has ordered three more 757 aircraft and Japan Air Lines has ordered an additional 747-300 aircraft. British Airways' new twinjets will be delivered in March 1986, bringing its total number of 757's to 23, Boeing said. Japan Air's newest 747 is scheduled for delivery in April, bringing its total 747's to 54.

title: RUDOLPH, TOWNSELL ARE BACK WITH JETS
description: They left the Jets for Los Angeles and the United States Football League, but today Jojo Townsell and Ben Rudolph returned, sounding like two shipwreck victims rescued at last.

title: 2 ISRAELI SOLDIERS AND 3 GUERRILLAS KILLED IN SOUTH LEBANON SHOOTOUT
description: Two Israeli soldiers and three Lebanese guerrillas were killed today in a shootout in south Lebanon, an Israeli Army spokesman announced.

description: CMT International, a unit of the Connecticut Mutual Life Insurance Company, is issuing $343.7 million of Eurobonds backed by commercial mortgages, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers International.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Adams Drug Co., Pawtucket, R.I., which operates retail drugstores, said that Charles Salmanson, chairman, and several members of the Salmanson family, including the president and chief executive, Donald, and the secretary, Jerrold, would retire.

title: COUNSELING STIRS SOME CHARGES
description: CAREER counseling has fallen on difficult times. In fact two of the country's biggest and best-known job advisers are the subject of state legal actions and several small firms have gone out of business.

title: HEALTH BENEFITS OF LIFELONG LEANNESS ARE CHALLENGED BY NEW WEIGHT TABLE
description: A NEW controversy over the safety of moderate weight gains in middle age has been set off by a Federal researcher's challenge of the prevailing medical view that lifelong efforts to stay lean are best for health.

description: Sixteen prominent opponents of the South African Government went on trial for treason today.

title: TRIAL DATA DEPICT WALKER'S ENLISTMENT AS SPY
description: Arthur J. Walker has told Federal investigators that when he was despondent over the failure of a family business in 1980, his brother recruited him as a spy, according to statements unsealed here today.

title: MGM/UA IN TALKS WITH TURNER
description: The MGM/UA Entertainment Company said yesterday that it was engaged in negotiations for the sale of the company to the Turner Broadcasting System for $29 a share in cash, or a total of $1.5 billion.

title: Merrill Lynch Offering Convertible Zero Notes

description: General Motors is known, of course, for being the world's biggest maker of automobiles. But it has other ambitions, too, one of which is to be a leading financial institution.

description: Proposals to reform the way the Government makes and executes defense policy bloom along the Potomac with the same regularity as the cherry blossoms. They then fade in the summer heat - and with good reason.

description: The Soviet Union has agreed to open two of its nuclear power reactors to international inspection later this month, Western diplomats said today.

title: Gold Can't Save Apartheid
description: More swiftly than anyone foresaw, South Africa's choices are being narrowed. The country's white rulers seem incapable even of a gesture of conciliation to nonviolent blacks like Bishop Tutu, and this has the effect of encouraging civil if not revolutionary disobedience. Though isolated as never before and the target of multiplying sanctions, South Africa's leaders no doubt have the power to put down this summer's defiance. But they seem to be condemning their country to a downward cycle of repression and recession.

title: Late-July Car Sales Off 10.5%
description: Sales of domestically produced new cars declined 10.5 percent in the last 10 days of July, the manufacturers reported today. For the entire month, sales were down 11 percent from July 1984.

title: SOME CHEMOTHERAPY FAILS AGAINST CANCER
description: Adjuvant chemotherapy, the use of toxic drugs to wipe out microscopic cancer cells presumed to remain hidden in the body after visible tumors have been removed, was hailed as ''one of the major achievements of the past 10 years'' by scientists at the National Cancer Institute in late 1983.

title: Rena Marie Smolski Weds John Spangler
description: Rena Marie Smolski, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester E. Smolski of Bristol, R.I., and John David Spangler, the son of David T. Spangler of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Mrs. Spangler, were married yesterday at the Oceancliff resort in Newport, R.I. Judge Paul Del Nero of the Newport District Court officiated.

title: Golden West Deal

The company said its purchase of Bell's liabilities is being offset by payment of an undisclosed sum by the F.S.L.I.C. Golden West, parent of the World Savings and Loan Association, said the units will become its first in Texas. The thrift institution already operates in Kansas and Colorado, in additon to California.

description: WHILE Wall Street has been treated to a smorgasbord of major corporate mergers this year, no industry has brought more to the feast than the natural gas pipeline business, where profit-shrunken companies are stumbling over one another to find suitable partners.

Mr. Hilton, 31 years old, was previously with Forbes magazine, where he served as co-director of special projects. He succeeds Dan Horowitz, who left the magazine in May.

title: Shy Governor, Retiring Teachers
description: Governor Cuomo of New York is not commonly shy; then why was he so quiet about signing a bill to allow early retirement for teachers? Perhaps because this bill represents a costly cave-in to the state teachers' union, and one that may set a precedent for other civil servants.

description: A former employee of the Central Intelligence Agency and a Ghanaian national were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on spying charges.

THE PRESSURE ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: The pressures for businesses to curtail links with South Africa because of that country's apartheid policy are expanding around the world, from Canada to Australia.

title: CUOMO TO SIGN CHILD-SUPPORT BILL
description: A bill making it easier for divorced women to collect child-support payments from their former husbands will be signed into law Wednesday by Governor Cuomo, an aide to the Governor said today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: IRISH The concertina has been in the throes of revival in Western Ireland, according to the latest advices that have reached these shores by way of the Irish Traditional Musicians Association, which presents Wednesday programs in the homey backroom of the Eagle Tavern, 355 West 14th Street (924-0275). It is a squeeze box smaller than an accordion, and with buttons instead of a keyboard, and it will be making music at the Eagle tonight in the hands of a virtuoso.

title: SOVIET OFFICIAL PROVIDES DETAILS ON DARING RESCUE OF FAILED SPACE STATION
description: A top Soviet space official today provided the first detailed account of a daring mission last June by two Soviet astronauts who rescued a derelict space station that was drifting aimlessly in orbit around the earth.

title: Tax Proposal Speeds Hospital Refundings
description: Hospital revenue bonds have been in ample supply recently, as many hospitals have sought to complete their financings before any new restrictions are imposed by a revision of Federal tax laws. In particular, hospitals are eager to refund old, high-interest bonds with new issues bearing lower interest rates - a kind of financing that would be eliminated under the President's tax-revision program.

description: I REVEL in corn on the cob and tomatoes fresh from the vine. I take great pleasure in cutting assorted herbs - tarragon, fresh basil, chervil and a dozen others - from my now-flourishing garden.

description: The Corning Glass Works has announced the signing of an equity joint venture contract with China to establish the Shanghai Corning Engineering Corporation. The new company will provide equipment and services in the production of specialty glass, Corning officials said.

title: FOR PLAYWRIGHT, INSPIRATION LIES IN JAMAICA
description: Perhaps because he was brought up close to the land in a small village, Trevor Rhone, one of Jamaica's foremost playwrights and screenwriters, prefers staying in the place he knows best.

Little Change in Interest Rates
description: Interest rates were little changed yesterday as the Treasury embarked on the first leg of a three-part $21.75 billion financing.

title: MOVIES PINCH-HIT FOR BASEBALL
description: Yankee fans, if they stayed tuned to WPIX-TV, Channel 11, last night were treated to ''The Magnificent Seven Ride,'' a 1972 film with Stefanie Powers and Mariette Hartley. And if the baseball strike is not settled by tomorrow night, WOR-TV, Channel 9, will show its loyal Mets fans ''The City Across the River,'' a 1949 film starring Tony Curtis.

description: The Halliburton Company yesterday reported a net loss of $474.8 million in the second quarter as a result of nonrecurring charges against income that totaled $523 million.

title: Board Game Account Goes to Kolker & Gill
description: Kolker & Gill Advertising will handle the advertising for the new ''All My Children'' board game, based on ABC's soap opera.

title: It's Appropriations That Count
description: The Congressional budget resolution is a fraud.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THE stomach is subject to a laundry list of complaints. It can growl, groan, churn, turn, bloat, burn, cramp, ache and even double us over with stabbing pain.

title: AS POLITICIANS DICKER, CONNECTICUT'S BUDGET SURPLUS BURGEONS
description: Connecticut's economic good times are producing something of a political embarrassment of riches. The tax money is flowing in faster than state leaders can agree on ways to spend it, or to send it back to the taxpayers.

title: French Stationmaster Charged in Train Deaths
description: The stationmaster on duty when two trains collided in rural south-central France, killing 35 people, has been charged with negligent manslaughter, a judge said today.

title: COTTON BAGGING IT ON WEEKENDS
