description: b-Including gains on the sale of assets of $57,000 for the quarter and $266,022,000 for the 9 months and a loss of $15,569,000 for the 9 months on the disposition of real estate. c-Including a gain of $698,000 on the sale of assets. Year-ago results are not comparable because the company sold 19 shopping centers on Nov. 30, 1984 which represented most of the trust's assets.

title: ICAHN RAISES T.W.A. STAKE TO 40.6%
description: Carl C. Icahn and his group of investors have increased their stake in Trans World Airlines to 40.6 percent, or 13.9 million shares, the financier disclosed yesterday in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Supreme Anniversary
description: For most of its history, the Supreme Court occupied space in other government buildings, relatively humble quarters that gave little indication of the importance of its function. But 50 years ago this fall the Court moved into its own classic pillared home, opposite the Senate across Capitol Park, in a building designed on a scale that reflected the influence of the institution rather than the number of judges and aides who occupied it.

title: SUCCESSOR IS SWORN IN
description: Linden Forbes Sampson Burnham, who ruled the South American country of Guyana since 1964, died today in a Guyanese hospital after a throat operation. He was 62 years old.

title: Moscow's Policy Toward Israel
description: Relations between the Soviet Union and Israel have become a favorite topic of the Western press, which is trying to distort the essence of Soviet policy - to present the Kremlin's approach to Israel in a tendentious light and accuse the Soviet Union of anti-Semitism.

title: Record Rarities
description: Steve Cram's rare streak of record-breaking, which he hopes to extend Friday night in the 1,000 meters at Gateshead, England, has set some buffs to recalling other records and other unusual occurrences in the world of track and field. For instance, Philip Semas, a graduate of the University of Oregon who is now the managing editor of the Chronicle of Higher Education, a weekly publication for university administrators, notes that the first sub-four-minute mile ever run on American soil was the 3:58.6 achieved at Los Angeles in 1956 by Jim Bailey, an Australian who was attending Oregon. So when Dyrol Burleson of Oregon ran a 3:58.6 at Eugene four years later in a dual meet against Stanford, he set a record for American citizens but merely tied the Ducks' school mark.

title: Grey's Net Off 2.4%
description: Grey Advertising announced second-quarter net income of $4.1 million, down 2.4 percent from $4.2 million in the same period last year. Earnings per share fell to $6.09 from $6.54. The agency reported gross billings of $386.7 million, up 4.4 percent from $370.3 million in 1984.

title: Clemson Report
description: Clemson athletic officials made improper use of funds belonging to a student organization, according to a two-year-old audit released by the university this week. In releasing the audit in response to a request filed under the Freedom of Information Act by The Greenville (S.C.) News, Walter Cox, Clemson's interim president, said that most of the abuses cited by the school's auditor, Michael P. Hughey, had been corrected and that jurisdiction over the club's treasury was being transferred from the athletic department to its faculty adviser to prevent further abuses. Among the improper expenditures cited by the audit, which covered the period from July 1981 through December 1982, were a $10,000 loan to help a newly hired athletic department assistant move to Greenville.

title: LIBERTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,150,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,272,000, or 13 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Including capital gains of $165,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $483,000, or 5 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: LASER PRECISION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HAILED AS SUCCESS
description: The space shuttle Challenger, which lost one of three main engines on its ascent to orbit eight days ago, returned safely to earth today after a mission that an official called ''superbly successful.''

title: OHIO COLLEGE DISMISSES SELLER OF HEBREW BOOKS
description: The professor involved in the contested auction of 56 Hebrew books and manuscripts at Sotheby's last year has been dismissed by a rabbinical seminary in Cincinnati where he taught since 1940, it was disclosed yesterday.

title: Why a Death Penalty For Spies Is a Bad Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Advertising;   Utility Plan To Deflect Criticism
description: THE Boston Edison Company, apparently tired of being criticized for high energy costs, has created an archenemy to take the blame. He is Oilybeest, a giant hairy creature drawn by Edwin Koren, the artist, to represent high oil prices. ''He's supposed to be cranky, difficult and obnoxious,'' said Dave Greeley, creative director and vice president of Quinn & Johnson/BBDO Inc. in Boston.

title: Solvency Test For Lloyd's
description: A record number of ''names'' - the wealthy individuals who underwrite Lloyd's of London - have failed a solvency test, the insurance market said today. Lloyd's chief executive, Ian Hay Davison, said that 517 ''names'' had not shown ready realizable assets of $134,000.

title: HANDLE WITH BRAWN
description: The news these days is mostly about anniversaries of interesting events that happened long ago. Last week, for instance, it was the 10th anniversary of the Helsinki agreement. This week it's the 40th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Japan. Next week it will be about the 40th anniversary of Japan's surrender.

title: Weeden Son to Form Namesake Brokerage
description: Donald E. Weeden, a Wall Street maverick who in the 1970's was a leader in third-market securities trading, will leave Moseley, Hallgarten, Estabrook & Weeden, the brokerage that took over his family's firm in 1979, to start a new independent firm.

title: Strike Fallout On River Ave.
description: Like just about everybody else with some kind of stake in the success of major league baseball, merchants along River Avenue, the aging Bronx thoroughfare that passes behind Yankee Stadium's bleachers, are in little mood to cheer. As game time approached Monday evening, the souvenir hawkers along this little commercial strip were still in full bellow -''Get your Yankee caps, posters, pennants, pins!'' - but it seemed a certainty that it was the cry of a swan song. Until the players and the baseball owners got their own business settled, River Avenue between 158th and 161st Streets would become something of a ghost town, many of the merchants simply too dependent on Yankee crowds to avoid closing, at least temporarily, in the face of the strike.

title: Lebanese Opposition Group Calls for Closer Ties to Syria
description: About 100 Moslem, Druse and moderate Christian leaders announced today that they were forming a National Unity Front, calling for political and social change and closer ties with Syria to end Lebanon's civil war.

title: 17 IN ARAB LEAGUE MEET IN MOROCCO
description: Seventeen representatives of the 21 active Arab League members were assembling here tonight for an emergency meeting, which was described by a senior Moroccan official as a last-chance effort to save the 40-year-old organization.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Empire State Games, opening-day ceremonies for eighth edition of the games, at Amherst Campus of the University of Buffalo, 6 P.M. Governor Cuomo and Al Oerter, the Olympian, are among those scheduled to help open the largest sports festival in the world, except for the Olympics. More than 6,000 athletes representing six districts of the state will compete in 24 sports through Sunday. Basketball Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, 5 P.M., and Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, at Jadwin Gymnasium, Princeton. Third night of five-night summer league for free agents and rookies. Harlem Week Golden Hoops tournament, at Levien Gymnasium, 7 P.M. and 9 P.M., semifinals of tournament among six teams of outstanding city high school players. The final will be Friday night. Boxing Marlon Starling vs. Reggie Miller, 10 rounds welterweights at Atlantis Hotel and Casino, Atlantic City. First preliminary 8 P.M. This is a nontitle fight for Starling, the U.S.B.A. champion from Hartford who has only lost three times in 36 professional fights, twice to the W.B.A. champion, Donald Curry, and once to Pedro Vilella. Starling has scored 20 knockouts and only one of his two losses to Curry was a title challenge. Miller, from Lake Charles, La., is 17-3 with 11 knockouts. Other Events BICYCLING: Coors International Classic road race, through Aug. 18. Today: Lake Tahoe to Reno and Reno criterium. BOWLING: PBA Molson Golden Challenge at Windsor, Ontario. (Television - ESPN 9 P.M.) HARNESS RACING: The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. (Television - MSG Network, midnight).

title: BRENTWOOD INSTRUMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NERWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1985
description: International South African police raided the home of Winnie Mandela, an anti-apartheid leader, after firing rubber bullets and using whips to break up a demonstration outside. Lawyers for Mrs. Mandela, who is the wife of the jailed nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, said an infant grandchild had disappeared after the raid. [Page A1, Column 1.] 17 Arab countries are represented at a meeting today in Casablana of the 21 active members of the Arab League. The meeting is being boycotted by Syria, Lebanon, Southern Yemen and Algeria. [A1:3.] Forbes Burnham died in a Guyanese hospital after a throat operation at the age of 62. He had ruled Guyana since 1964. [A9:1-3.] National The shuttle Challenger landed safely at Edwards Air Force Base, Calif. The spacecraft lost a main engine after liftoff, but an official said the eight-day mission had otherwise been ''superbly successful.'' [A1:6.] A baseball strike began as 650 players stayed away from major league parks and forced the cancellation of 13 games. Negotiators held their longest bargaining meetings of the nine months of talks, but no significant progress was reported in efforts to reach a new collective-bargaining accord. The last baseball strike, in 1981, lasted 50 days. [A1:4.] Widespread student loan defaults totaling $4.1 billion have prompted the Education Department to ask the Internal Revenue Service to withhold income tax refunds for a million people who defaulted on the loans unless they begin paying their debts.

title: OWNER SUGGESTS LOOKING TO MINORS
description: Baseball officials said yesterday that no plan or formula had been outlined yet for staging the pennant races if the major leagues should be shut down by a lengthy strike. But John McMullen, the owner of the Houston Astros, suggested that the fans be polled to see if they would want the season resumed with minor league players if the strike lasted until Sept. 1.

title: Burroughs Unit
description: The Memorex Corporation, a unit of the Burroughs Corporation, said that it and the Control Data Corporation had agreed to dissolve Disk Media Inc., a jointly owned concern with about 200 employees. They also agreed that Magnetic Peripherals Inc., principally owned by Control Data, would buy Memorex's share in Peripheral Components Inc., a second venture.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Net income

title: Mary Kay Shares Drop
description: The price of Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc.'s stock fell sharply yesterday in heavy volume as fears spread that a leveraged buyout plan is running into dificulty arranging financing. The shares fell $1.875, to $11.625, on consolidated volume of nearly 1.1 million shares.

title: PANTASOTE INC reports earnings for 16 wks to July 12
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $10,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $53,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $149,000 for the quarter and $317,000 for the 6 months.

title: But New York City Still Needs That 63d Street Tunnel
description: To the Editor:

title: BEYOND COFFEE AND CROISSANT AT THE NEW PARIS CAFES
description: OVER the centuries, cafes are where Parisians have plotted wars and revolutions, written poetry and novels or just sat around sipping cafe au lait or Pastis, herb tea or Suze and watched the world go by. In the meantime, the food at these establishments has become as venerable, and as much a French symbol, as the beret. Standard fare at Paris cafes is the crusty buttered baguette with ham and Gruyere, the melted cheese sandwich known as the croque-monsieur, rillettes - a terrine of preserved pork - pates, crudites, omelettes, quiches and coffees that range from the frothy cafe creme to the more intense espresso.

title: A USEFUL NUCLEAR STEP BY MOSCOW
description: The surprising announcement by Mikhail S. Gorbachev of a unilateral moratorium on nuclear testing has just as suddenly and surprisingly become a nonevent. In an alarming display of unanimity, the major American print and electronic news organizations have uncritically promoted the White House view that the Soviet initiative is nothing more than a propaganda ploy.

title: Bureaucracy;   Trying to Tame the Monster Called Analysis
description: If there is any job likely to be more frustrating than shepherding a bill into law -hearings, subcommittee and committee approval, floor action by House and Senate, conference committee reconciliation and Presidential signature - it can only be that of getting rid of silly or outdated proposals that have made it to the statute books.

title: WIDE LOSS OF COMPUTER DATA SEEN IN NEW SPY CASE CHARGE
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, one of four men accused of spying on the Navy, provided the Soviet Union with extensive information about a computer system used to transmit confidential military messages, officials charged today.

title: WASHINGTON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After investment gains of $252,000 for the quarter and $3,840,000 for the 6 months. c-After an investment loss of $3,036,000. d-After an investment gain of $2,154,000.

title: CROWN CRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

description: b-After extraordinary tax benefits of $1,715,000 for the quarter and $4,400,000 for the 6 months. c-Includes nets from discontinued operations of $19,008,000 for the quarter and $15,751,000 for the 6 months.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Patrick Ewing, the Knicks' top draft choice, who was born in Kingston, Jamaica, returned to his hometown for the first time since he moved to the United States in 1975 and found himself something of a national hero. Ewing, who celebrated his 23d birthday on Monday, was the guest of Prime Minister Edward Sega at ceremonies marking the 23d anniversary of the island nation's independence from Britain. . . . Gerard Phelan, the New England Patriots' rookie wide receiver who hurt his knee in practice Monday, was told that he will be out at least two months and perhaps longer if surgery is required. . . . John (Hot Rod) Williams, the former Tulane basketball player scheduled to go on trial Monday on charges of sports bribery, lost a bid to have one of the four charges against him dropped. . . . Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, the 7-foot-2-inch Los Angeles Laker who already has a couple of movie credits under his belt, says his height should give him a special advantage as a Hollywood leading man after he retires from basketball.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: INNER TUBE. By Hob Broun. 210 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95. ''IT isn't that she lacks a sense of humor,'' says the narrator of ''Inner Tube,'' describing a friend, ''only that in her perverse tropism she turns inevitably toward what is blackest.'' The same might easily be said of every other character in this novel, as well as the author himself. Though enlivened by patches of nasty black comedy and splashes of nervous irony, ''Inner Tube'' - which opens with a suicide and then moves on to more depressing subjects - is one of the most relentlessly bleak works I've come across in a long time. Reading it is a lot like staying up all night, listening to a stranger you don't particularly like tell and retell the story of his life in stoned, didactic monologues. It's not something you're likely to forget right away. On the other hand, it doesn't make for a particularly pleasant - or illuminating - evening, either.

title: THERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
43 Arrested in Scheme To Sell Mislabeled Drugs
description: Forty-three people, including 12 doctors and 13 pharmacists, were charged today in what the authorities said was a scheme to obtain prescription drugs at discount prices and resell them, sometimes under false labels, Federal officials announced.

title: MHP MACHINES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $12,000 for the quarter and a net loss of $20,000 for the 9 months from foreign currency translations. c-After net losses from foreign currency translations of $25,000 for the quarter and $19,000 for the 9 months.

title: IN CALIFORNIA, VINTNERS REDISCOVER THE VALUE OF WINE CAVES
description: DIGGING into history, and then into local hillsides, the vintners of California have unearthed a valuable lesson in wine storage. They have discovered that their 19th-century forebears - without air-conditioning and at relatively little expense - knew how to keep wines under perfect conditions. Those early wine makers simply dug caves - cool, dark, humid tunnels.

title: WESTERN UNION PACT IS ANNOUNCED
description: Negotiators for the Western Union Corporation and a union representing 6,500 workers reached an agreement late Tuesday calling for concessions, ending a 10-day-old nationwide strike, a union official said.

title: TURK DENIES BEING PRESENT WHEN AGCA SHOT POPE
description: A Turkish leftist who Mehmet Ali Agca has said was with him in St. Peter's Square the day in 1981 when he shot Pope John Paul II testified today that he last saw Mr. Agca in 1979 and never left Turkey before today.

title: Menagerie
description: What a day at the A.S.P.C.A.

title: FARRELL FILES SUIT TO REGAIN A PLACE ON BALLOT FOR MAYOR
description: Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday in an effort to get his name restored to the Democratic primary ballot for mayor.

title: Damrosch Dancing
description: The sun was hot but the sounds were cool as they rippled off Lincoln Center Plaza yesterday, heralding the annual Out-of-Doors Festival. The nightly, and sometimes daily, performances are free.

title: INFINITE GRAPHICS reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Strike Threat in N.H.L.
description: The National Hockey League Players'

title: GAMES CALLED OFF
description: The second baseball strike in five seasons began yesterday when 650 players stayed away from major league parks and forced 13 scheduled games to be called off.

title: Malrite's Founder Has Growth Plans
description: Milton Maltz bought his first radio station, a 500-watt daytime outlet in the small town of Plymouth, Wis., for a down payment of $9,000 in 1956. Since then, he has parlayed that investment into Malrite Communications Group, which owns nine radio and four television stations and had sales of $77 million last year.

title: 12 Reports on the Hit List
description: Following are the reports that the Office of Management and Budgets finds most egregiously unnecessary, with the office's reasons in parentheses:

title: PACIFIC GAMBLE ROBINSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OLYMPIC-STYLE COMPETITION FOR MASTERS
description: On the theory that sports are not entirely for kids, a sort of Olympics for oldsters are scheduled to open here Wednesday, the world's first Masters Games.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Summer Radicchio Zuccherina, from an upstate New York farmer, is a new green currently featured at Fairway Fruits and Vegetables, 2127 Broadway (74th Street), for $2.29 a pound, while supplies last. Described as summer radicchio, zuccherina is the green leaf of the radicchio plant before it is headed up and covered to give it its maroon and white color.

title: ALCO STANDARD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,467,000 for the quarter and $3,965,000 for the 9 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $476,000 for the quarter and $484,000 for the 9 months.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL UTAH (NBA) - Agreed to terms with Karl Malone, rookie forward.

title: Control Data Revises Results
description: The Control Data Corporation sharply revised downward yesterday its reported earnings for 1984's fourth quarter and for this year's second quarter, citing a variety of accounting changes and oversights.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 7, 1985
description: Markets

title: The Gun That Shoots Crooked
description: The Army hails the latest test of its Sergeant York antiaircraft gun as a triumph, even though it may not have brought down a single target. How can that be? Why would senior officers foist a defective weapon on their troops? We are back in the tragicomedy of the Sergeant York, a weapon that can neither kill nor be killed.

title: Darkness and Light
description: A report in this space last Friday said that guests at a dinner at the Israeli Embassy had interpreted an off-and-on flashing of the lights as a signal that the party was over. But according to one of the guests at the dinner, Wolf Blitzer, Washington correspondent for The Jerusalem Post, the flashing was a chance occurrence, not a deliberate go-home signal, however it might have been interpreted by the diners.

title: IMAGES AND ARRESTS MARK HIROSHIMA'S DARK DAY
description: More than 200 people were arrested around the country yesterday in protests marking the day 40 years ago when a United States atomic bomb was dropped on Hiroshima. But in many cases the police overlooked thousands of symbolic images of the dead painted on city streets.

title: LANDMARKS PANEL LISTING BROADWAY THEATERS
description: After three years of hearings and debate, the City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday began a sweeping move to give landmark status to Broadway theaters.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Including $1.6 million from insurance proceeds of a fire claim. c-Including $264,000 from life insurance proceeds.

title: Non-Communist Poles Unopposed on Ballot
description: A dozen people who are not members of the Communist Party were named today along with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski and his top aides in a list of 50 at-large candidates who will be running unopposed in parliamentary elections Oct. 13.

title: AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MORLAN INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On the Waterfront
description: A fierce multimillion-dollar competition over development of a choice 10-acre site on Washington's waterfront is coming to a climax. Within the next few days the District of Columbia Redevelopment Land Agency is expected to designate one of three high-powered real estate groups to build the equivalent of a small city within the capital less than a mile south of the White House.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from La Paz on July 15 about early returns in Bolivia's presidential election was edited to incorporate an erroneous report from earlier Times articles describing the political background of one candidate, Victor Paz Estenssoro. Mr. Paz Estenssoro had been President not twice but three times between 1952 and 1964. After his election in August 1964, he was overthrown after less than three months in office. His latest victory is reported today on page A3.

title: RESULT OF F.B.I. SEARCH: HOLE AT SERVICE STATION
description: For the last week, the two Ferrara brothers have watched unhappily as construction equipment dug an increasingly bigger and deeper hole at their Brooklyn service station in a spot where four gasoline pumps once stood.

title: Boy, 9, Killed Over Bike; 3 Playmates Charged
description: Three young playmates have been arrested and accused of stabbing and beating to death a a 9-year-old boy who refused to share his bicycle.

title: Timken to Restructure
description: The Timken Company announced plans today to restructure its operations and strengthen its position ''in the fiercely competitive markets it serves.'' The Canton, Ohio, company which makes alloy steel and is the world's largest producer of tapered-roller bearings, announced that 500 salaried positions would be cut over the next few months through early retirement, layoffs and attrition.

title: BANKAMERICA PRAISED FOR CUTTING DIVIDEND
description: The BankAmerica Corporation's decision Monday to cut its dividend by almost half led to a flurry of selling of the company's widely held shares today.

title: HIROSHIMA'S SURVIVORS LOOK BACK AT BOMBING
description: AS part of a day-late three-hour commemoration of the 40th anniversary of the bombing of Hiroshima, Channel 13 is carrying - starting at 8 o'clock tonight - a 45-minute Japanese-made film, ''Hiroshima: The People's Legacy.'' The legacy consists of drawings and paintings done by survivors, accompanied by their memories: ''I'm the little girl sitting in the center watching my mother and my badly burned brother. My brother died.''

title: It's an Artistic Life at Duke Ellington High
description: It was already oppressively hot and humid and not yet noon, and the school gymnasium lacked air-conditioning. But dozens of dancers tirelessly pirouetted, dipped and bounced to the beat of the congas as a choreographer counted: ''three, four, five, seven and one; three, four, five, seven and one.''

title: Journalists at the BBC Start a 24-Hour Strike
description: The board of the British Broadcasting Corporation affirmed its ban on a television documentary about extremists in Northern Ireland on Tuesday and, right after midnight, many of its journalists began a 24-hour walkout, expected to silence most broadcast news operations in Britain.

title: $85 Million Issue Set By California
description: An $85 million issue of California general obligation bonds was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Chase Manhattan Bank with yields ranging from 4.75 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 6.50 percent in 1990, 7.70 percent in 1995, 8.50 percent in 2002 and 8.70 percent in 2005.

title:
Economic Scene;

Blacks' Share Of U.S. Income
description: ONE important measure of the health of an economy is the degree of inequality in its distribution of income. While there is no consensus among analysts or politicians as to what constitutes an ideal distribution, most agree that too great an economic disparity between haves and have-nots threatens the political stability of a society, on which everyone's prosperity depends. This issue has been particularly important in the developing countries, where rapid G.N.P. growth has often been accompanied by an increase in the gap between rich and poor.

title: McEnroe Beats McEnroe
description: John McEnroe soundly beat his future doubles partner today, but he couldn't savor the victory.

title: CALIFORNIANS BALK AT REAGAN TAX PLAN
description: President Reagan's plan on tax revision is encountering some resistance in his home state.

title: GUARD TESTIFIES BOSS DEMANDED WORK FOR G.O.P.
description: A Hempstead town security officer testified in Federal District Court today that he had been forced to purchase a $150 ticket to the annual Nassau County Republican Party dinner, then work at the dinner as a guard without pay.

title: GUNFIRE IN PARKING LOT ENDS FLORIDA FEUD FINALLY
description: It took them years and years, but Hayward Bryant and James MacDonald Booth settled their differences, finally. On July 24 the two men, small ranchers who had been childhood playmates, shot each other dead in the parking lot of a grocery.

title: SCREEN: 'REAL GENIUS'
description: SCIENTIFIC prodigies are the subject of ''Real Genius,'' and the film is best when it takes them seriously, though it does so only intermittently. The story is set at a college with a highly advanced science program, which is being used - unbeknownst to the whiz kids - to develop advanced weapons for the military. It centers on a twentyish boy wonder (Val Kilmer) who has developed a tirelessly facetious sense of humor - he likes to wear animal slippers and panda earmuffs, for example - and a 15-year-old newcomer (Gabe Jarret) who has yet to get the hang of college life.

title: APPEALS COURT BACKS CURBS ON JAPAN WHALING OFF U.S.
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ordered the Government today to restrict Japanese fishing rights in American waters because of Japan's continued killing of scarce sperm whales in defiance of an international pact.

title: 4 Flee East Germany
description: Four defectors from East Germany drove to the Czechoslovak border last night and then walked through heavy rain unnoticed into Austria, the police said today.

title: Little Is Enough
description: Lyle Blackwood, the steady defensive back for the Miami Dolphins, explains why he decided to end his two-week holdout despite not getting the money he wanted from the front office, ''A little bit of something is better than a whole lot of nothing.''

title: NATIONAL FUEL GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONTRACTOR PROFITS HELD REASONABLE BY PENTAGON
description: The Pentagon, in its first major study of the profits of military contractors in nearly a decade, today concluded that the profitability ''has not been unreasonable'' and few changes were needed in how the military pays its manufacturers.
