title: A FILM ON THE SHAKERS OFFERED BY CHANNEL 13
description: THE film ''The Shakers:

title: INTERFACE FLOORING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 30
Absent Eagles Warned
description: Five Philadelphia Eagles who have stayed away from training camp in an effort to force a renegotiation of their contracts have been told they will be suspended for the season if they don't abandon their holdouts. According to Harry Gamble, the club's general manager, the new owner, Norman Braman, who is on a campaign to hold down salaries, has no intention of giving in to the players' demands. ''We're absolutely not going to renegotiate contracts, especially those with several years to go on them,'' Gamble said. One of the five holdouts, Dennis Harrison, a defensive end, is entering the option year of his contract and wants a raise. The others, Wilbert Montgomery, a running back; Mike Quick, a wide receiver; Jerry Robinson, a linebacker, and Dean Miraldi, an offensive tackle, say that the Eagles' former owner, Leonard Tose, had promised to renegotiate their contracts. Under league rules, a team can put as many as five players on a reserve-left-camp list that prohibits the players from being reactivated until the following season. Gamble said that no deadline had been set, but that time was running out for the holdouts. ''There will come a time soon when we will have to make a decision,'' he said. . . . Ray Childress, the Houston Oiler defensive end who is staying away from training camp in an effort to force a renegotiation of his contract, said he was prepared to sit out the entire season if the Oilers didn't meet his demand for a four-year, $2 million contract or trade him to a team that would.

title: FARM BANK SYSTEM AT ISSUE
description: The recent problems involving the Federal Intermediate Credit Bank of Omaha and other members of the Federal Farm Credit System are shedding light on a little-known network of cooperative lending institutions that is the largest source of loans for the nation's farmers.

title: BATTLE FOR JET JOBS IS FIERCE
description: Wesley Walker described it as a ''little collision we had out there today,'' adding, ''but I know how to protect myself.''

title: U.S. HALTS EFFORTS TO DEPORT OUSTED ANTI-SANDINISTA
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has halted deportation proceedings against a Nicaraguan exile dismissed from the the largest anti-Sandinista rebel force for criticizing the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: AIDES IN ANKARA SAY BULGARIA HAS SLAIN 1,00 ETHNIC TURKS
description: Senior Turkish officials assert that Bulgaria has killed at least a thousand ethnic Turks and imprisoned several thousand others in its campaign to force them to adopt Bulgarian names.

title: CANDIDATES FOR BOROUGH CHIEF SPLIT OVER STATE OF THE BRONX
description: Borough President Stanley Simon of the Bronx and his Democratic primary challenger, Assemblyman Jose E. Serrano, painted totally different pictures of the Bronx in a debate yesterday.

title: Carter-Wallace Action on Drug
description: Carter-Wallace Inc. said that it had suspended clinical testing of bepridil, a heart drug that has been linked to deaths among some patients using the drug in studies. The Carter-Wallace statement came one day after Johnson & Johnson said that its McNeil Pharmaceutical unit had suspended testing of bepridil on patients suffering from arrhythmia, or irregular heartbeat.

title: A SPICY NEW ALBUM BY CARLY SIMON
description: ''SPOILED GIRL'' (Epic/Portrait), Carly Simon's first album in two years, is a spicy, lighthearted romp of a record in which the 40-year-old singer-songwriter imaginatively comes to terms with the frivolous spirit of mid-80's pop. Nine producers, including the electronic wizard Arthur Baker, worked on the album, whose songs range in style from the kind of catchy folk-pop that has long been Miss Simon's stock in trade to ultracontemporary dance-oriented tunes with electronically tricked-up textures.

title: NATIONAL CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $26,000 for the quarter and $117,000 for the 6 months and a pretax gain of $400,000 for the quarter from the settlement of litigation. c-Net losses.

title: People
description: * Burton Vaupen, executive vice president, chief financial and chief administrative officer, has been elected to the board of Kenyon & Eckhardt, a Lorimar Company.

title: DOW SLIDES BY 21.73, TO 1,325.16
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday on renewed concern over the course of interest rates.

title: Jacuzzi Whirlpool Bath Returns to Thompson
description: Jacuzzi Whirlpool Bath, a Walnut Creek, Calif.-based maker of whirlpool baths and spas and a subsidiary of Kidde Inc., has returned its account to the San Francisco office of J. Walter Thompson/West.

title: NORTH BACK HOME FOR PGA TITLE BID
description: Seven years ago, Andy North struggled up the 18th hole at Cherry Hills Country Club in the final round of the United States Open. He drove into the right rough. He hit into the left rough. Then he dumped his third stroke into a bunker before finally getting up and down for a bogey 5.

title: American Can's Stake in Jefferies
description: The American Can Company said that it had agreed to increase its stake in the Jefferies Group Inc. to as much as 20 percent.

title: WINE TALK
description: Each wine scandal, including the current one in Austria, prompts a flurry of assurances from industry leaders and government officials of whatever country is involved that it will not happen again. The formal announcement usually promises that the next session of the country's legislature will pass airtight laws that will render this kind of chicanery - which officials insist involves only a handful of miscreants - a thing of the past.

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Merck Buyback
description: Merck & Company said it would buy up to $200 million of its common stock for its treasury, continuing a stock repurchase program. In the most recent phase of the program, completed in January, the company acquired 2.3 million shares. Merck now has about 72 million shares outstanding.

title: Mosco Carner, Musicologist; Wrote Biography on Puccini
description: Mosco Carner, a biographer of Puccini and a conductor, critic and musicologist, died of a heart attack Saturday while on vacation. He was 81 years old and lived in London.

title: DEAL APPEARS SET FOR DEAK'S BANK
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge approved a reorganization plan yesterday for Deak & Company, the precious metals and foreign exchange concern based in New York. The approval sets the stage for the sale Friday of the Foreign Commerce Bank, a Deak unit based in Zurich.

title: PATH Service Returns After Repairs to Bridge
description: Service on the Port Authority Trans-Hudson line between Pennsylvania Station in Newark and Journal Square in Jersey City was resumed yesterday in time for the afternoon rush hour.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aeroquip Corp., Toledo, Ohio, a subsidiary of Libbey-Owens-Ford which makes hoses, fittings, couplings and cylinders, has named G. William Moody president, succeeding Harry A. Bancroft.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 7, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 3 P.M.

title: FIRST NATIONAL SUPERMARETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,019,000, or 39 cents a share. c-Net income.

title: DANCE: BARYSHNIKOV OFFERS DIVERSE PROGRAM
description: The ballet road companies that go out in the summer are too often made up of a star or two, a few capable but untried youngsters and a repertory of scraps spiced by a few familiar pyrotechnical displays. But Baryshnikov and Company, presented by the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival on Monday at the Springfield Symphony Hall, offered a performance that could serve as a model for the ballet tour. The troupe's repertory ranged over a wide variety of styles and moods, and the 15 dancers appearing with Mr. Baryshnikov, all members of the American Ballet Theater, seemed to have been selected not just for their technical gifts but for the quality of their presences.

title: HANNA, M A CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $133,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months as a provision for plant closing and writedown of certain affiliates. c-Net income including a gain of $6,213,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the exchange of stock for long-term debt.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp., Morris Township, N.J., said the proration factor for its tender offer for 22 million shares of Signal Cos. was about 30.9 percent.

title: FAFCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: How to Find Blacks for Faculties
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Tap Dance Kid' Closing
description: ''The Tap Dance Kid,'' a musical with book by Charles Blackwell, music by Henry Kreiger and lyrics by Robert Lorick, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Minskoff Theater. Directed by Vivian Matalon, the play will have run for 669 performances and 38 previews.

title: Steinberg Gains at Brokerage
description: With a sweeping reorganization of its top management, Frank B. Hall & Company, the nation's third-largest publicly traded insurance brokerage, effectively placed control of the company yesterday in the hands of Saul P. Steinberg, its largest stockholder.

title: FOREST LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $124,700, or 2 cents a share.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income of $136,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $232,000, or 3 cents a share, for the 6 months from amortization of deferred gains. c-Including income of $307,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and $600,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 6 months, from amortization of deferred gains.

title: MCA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WORD OF REAGAN SKIN TEST DELAYED
description: White House officials knew Friday that a preliminary pathology report said skin cancer had been found in a ''pimple'' removed from President Reagan's nose, Administration officials said today.

title: Cohn Gets a Delay In Discipline Case
description: Roy M. Cohn says that the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court has halted until at least October a disciplinary committee's proceedings that could lead to disbarment.

title: LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ESQUIRE RADIO & ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WALL ST. PAMPERING LAW STUDENTS
description: Lauri Kien and 16 other summer associates at Lord, Day & Lord left work early the other night to go to a Mets game. The law firm paid for their box seats, provided a bus from Wall Street to Shea Stadium and back, and even arranged a pregame audience with Fred Wilpon, a co-owner of the team.

title: U.S. Labels Ex-Agent As Willing Soviet Spy
description: A prosecutor today described the first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever charged with spying as a ''disgruntled and vulnerable American'' willingly led to espionage by a seductive Soviet emigre.

title: PAST IS SWINGING AT CLUB FOR 'COLORED MUSICIANS'
description: On Buffalo's Broadway, where the city crumbles into a patchwork of empty lots and boarded-up buildings, an orange neon sign glows ''MUSICIANS'' from the second-story window of a solitary, two-story brick building.

title: Pale and Pudgy, but Not Paunchy
description: Attractive is arduous. But suddenly it seems a lot easier. Pale is definitely in, and pudgy may be coming up fast.

title: MILTOPE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: G.O.P. FUND LETTER TOUCHES OFF BITTER CLASH AT GOVERNORS' PARLEY
description: A bitter political dispute disrupted a meeting of the nation's governors today, with Democrats forcing Republicans to withdraw a fund-raising letter one Governor described as ''a pack of lies.''

title: SAGA OF STAND-UP WAITER, 78, OR IS IT 76?
description: ''TELL him about the time I changed the roast beef? I'll tell him,'' says Eli Samaras, launching into one of his gastronomic monologues.

title: NORTH CAROLINA NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBI Industries In Writedown
description: CBI Industries said today that it would take a special pretax charge of $153 million against second-quarter earnings, resulting in a net charge of $88.1 million for the quarter.

title: The Right of Scouts to Believe in God
description: To the Editor:

title: Toyota's Sales In U.S. Up 35%
description: The Toyota Motor Company said today that it sold 70,158 cars in the United States during July, up 35 percent from 51,962 sold in July 1984.

title: Jokes and Laughter
description: Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican majority leader, is known on Capitol Hill as a man with an impromptu wisecrack for every situation. But last week, as Congress slogged toward adjournment for the summer, legislative congestion multiplied and the White House turned its back on Senator Dole's budget efforts, associates noted that the leader's joke output had tapered off measurably.

title: Stephen Spector, 49, Dead; Art Consultant and Collector
description: Stephen Spector, art consultant and collector, died Sunday night at his home on the Upper East Side after a long illness. He was 49 years old.

title: GREY ADVERTISING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenues represent gross billings.

title: 31 U.S. Activists Start Boat Trip in Nicaragua
description: A group of 31 Americans set out by boat Monday on Lake Nicaragua for a former rebel base on the Costa Rican border that was recently captured by Nicaraguan soldiers.

title: IONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Child With AIDS Barred From Class on Coast
description: A 3-year-old boy suffering from acquired immune deficiencey syndrome, or AIDS, has been barred from a class for handicapped children and will receive private instruction at his home if he is accepted into the county special education program, officials said today.

title: MYLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. The company went public in October 1984.

title: TRANSIT AIDE SUSPENDED IN INQUIRY ON EXPENSES
description: The Transit Authority official in charge of the agency's widely praised car-cleaning program has been accused of falsifying his expense-account claims and has been suspended without pay, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Michaels Again to Head 'Saturday Night Live'
description: Lorne Michaels, the creator of ''Saturday Night Live,'' will return to the irreverent comedy program as executive producer this season after a five-year absence, Mr. Michaels and NBC officials said yesterday.

title: BOLIVIAN IN AN ENCORE: VICTOR PAZ ESTENSSORO
description: When his opponent announced victory the day after Bolivia's presidential elections, Victor Paz Estenssoro waited patiently for the official tally to be completed. In the end, he lost the general election by 2 percent, but won in Congress, becoming the first civilian to take the presidency without a majority of the popular vote.

title: MGM Sale Talks Continuing
description: Turner Broadcasting System's bid to take over the MGM/UA Entertainment Company hit some snags yesterday, but approval was still expected, possibly as early as today.

title: RELIANCE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After net realized gains on investments of $18,491,000 for the quarter and $26,903,000 for the 6 months. c-After net realized gains on investments of $54,798,000 for the quarter and $64,589,000 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange.

title: HOUSE OF ANTI-APARTHEID FIGURE RAIDED BY POLICE DRING A PROTEST
description: South African police officers today raided the home of Winnie Mandela, a leading foe of apartheid, after firing rubber bullets and using whips to break up a demonstration outside her home.

title: MICROCOMPUTER MEMORIES reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
METS RELUCTANTLY HEAD HOME
description: Dwight Gooden threw the garment bag over his shoulder, walked out the lobby door onto Dorchester Street and said, ''I'm going home.''

title: INTERNATIONAL BANKNOTE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $2,676,000 for the quarter and $7,096,000 for the 6 months from the termination of a pension plan. c-Net losses from discontinued operations of $299,000 for the quarter and $528,000 for the 6 months.

title: Stewart Arrested In '81 for Drugs
description: The prosecution in the Michael Stewart case disclosed yesterday that Mr. Stewart, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man who died nearly two years ago while in the custody of the transit police, was arrested in 1981 for smoking marijuana.

title: Rome Blames the Mafia For Murder of 2 Officers
description: Gunmen opened fire with automatic weapons in Palermo, Sicily, today and killed a top police official who had been investigating the Mafia.

title: Israeli Officers Cleared In Deaths of 2 in 1984
description: None of the security officers involved in the storming of an Israeli bus hijacked by Palestinian terrorists last year will be charged with the deaths of two of the four hijackers, Israel radio said today.

title: WHY THE PLAYERS WALKED
description: The players did not believe the owners. That was the bottom line as baseball players scattered to their homes yesterday to wait and see whether there will be any more season.

title: Freak Waves Hit France
description: Two freak waves more than six feet high hit France's Mediterranean coast before dawn today, drowning one person and terrifying hundreds of campers suddenly trapped on flooded beaches. The waves swept across six miles of dunes near the mouth of the River Rhone. Weather experts said the waves were caused by violent northwest winds and a sudden drop in temperature over most of the country.

title: EDITORS' NOTE
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the real-estate developer and magazine publisher, described his career, which reached a high point last month when his company was chosen to develop the Coliseum site at Columbus Circle. Through opinionated phrases and unattributed characterizations, the article established a tone that cast its subject in an unfavorable light.

title: LIGHTING THE BARBECUE
description: ANYONE who has tried to light a charcoal barbecue grill on a windy day with matches knows how frustrating it can be. My home grill is a few feet from the beach, where stiff ocean winds often make it impossible to get the charcoal ignited without getting a group of people to form a protective huddle around it.

title: Usual Crowds
description: The idea that baseball fans might stay away in droves on the eve of the strike, either to show their anger with the threat of the walkout or simply because they were thoroughly disgusted, did not pan out. Of the 10 major league stadiums where games were played Monday afternoon and night, eight drew crowds that were roughly equal to the season average at those parks or that were substantially larger than the average.

title: GLOBAL NATURAL RESOURCES PROPERTIES LC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STRIKE ENDANGERS MORE THAN PENNANT RACES
description: Jeanette Corrado, a 45-year-old mother of six who lives in Flushing, is in charge of concession stand 110, outside the third-base line, on the field level at Shea Stadium. She makes $58 each day the Mets play a home game.

title: Market Place;   Realty Trusts In a Comeback
description: REAL estate investment trusts, whose image suffered badly (along with the fortunes of their shareholders) in the mid-1970's, are suddenly looking respectable again.

title: CATHOLIC RELIEF SERVICES INVOLVED IN DISPUTE OVER SPENDING OF ETHIOPIA AID
description: The spending of money collected for Ethiopian famine victims has become the center of a dispute involving Catholic Relief Services, the largest private charity operating in Ethiopia.

title: 2 Midwest Banks In Merger Pact
description: Boatmen's Bancshares Inc. of St. Louis said that it had agreed to merge with the General Bancshares Corporation, also of St. Louis, in a transaction valued at about $218 million.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET PLAN WORLD GAMES
description: A new international sports competition involving American and Soviet athletes was announced yesterday by broadcasting officials in the United States and Moscow.

title: 'Back to the Future' Leads Box Office Sales
description: ''Back to the Future'' went back to the top spot at the box office over the weekend, grossing $8.7 million to boot ''National Lampoon's European Vacation'' down to No. 2.

title: SARATOGA SOCIAL SET IS OFF AND RUNNING
description: Guests at the annual Museum Ball here, in their Givenchys, Scaasis and Blasses, their ruffled shirts and their cummerbunds, cheerfully wedged their way through a succession of people knots. There were people clustering around the Saratoga hostesses Mollie Wilmot, Sue Whitmore and Edna Morris, and the new arrivals skirted around them and around hors d'oeuvres trays and frosted glasses to get to Ian Balding. Everyone, it seemed, had to hear him tell about the Queen's stable.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the bankruptcy filing of Sakowitz carried an incorrect name, obtained from a bankruptcy court document, for one of the store's unsecured creditors. The creditor is the Kennsington Company Ltd.

title: One for 'Pops'
description: Joel Youngblood, a Houston native whose ninth-inning homer for the Giants on Monday night failed to overcome a big Astro lead, found immense satisfaction in it anyway, a result of a request that his dying grandfather made more than a decade ago.

title: SCOUTING GROUND FOR FOREIGN COACHES
description: As the Nets waited for the Washington Bullets to finish their practice session today, Ken Orange, who is playing for the Nets, was talking with Sandro Gamba, the coach of Granarolo Bologna in the Italian League. Orange, a 6-foot-11-inch, 240-pound center who played for the Long Island Knights of the United States Basketball League, was also the topic of discussion between Ed Krinsky, who scouts for Maccabi of Tel Aviv, Israel, and Artie Hecht, who represents Holon, Israel.

title: KNAPE & VOGT MANUFACTURINGG reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Corporate Debt Insurer Set to Spend $1 Million
description: Financial Security Assurance Inc., a week-old company formed to insure corporate debt, said it planned to spend more than $1 million for advertising and promotion in the next four months. The company, which says it is the first insurance company to specialize in guaranteeing corporate bond issues, will begin its print campaign on Thursday.

title: A New Zippo Lighter
description: After 53 years of making the same basic cigarette lighter, the Zippo Manufacturing Company said today that it would introduce in September a butane model designed for the ''upwardly mobile'' and called Contempo. Zippo will still make the traditional windproof lighter.

title: ECHO BAY MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: QUESTIONS AND ANSWERS ON THE STRIKE
description: Here are some of the basic questions being raised about the major league players' walkout, and the answers. Q. How did the strike begin? A. The labor contract between the players and the owners expired last Dec. 31. After negotiations for a new contract produced little movement, the players on July 15 set a strike deadline for yesterday. Unable to reach an agreement before yesterday's games, the players struck.

title: MARQUEST MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Good Sense From Peru on Paying Foreign Debt
description: To the Editor:

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: SOMEONE called out my name on Madison Avenue the other day. I turned around. ''The last time I saw you,'' the man said, ''you were selling hot dogs in Ebbets Field.''

title: Digital Profit Drops 23%
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation, the world's second-largest computer maker, said yesterday that net income for its fourth quarter fell 23 percent, to $100.4 million, or $1.66 a share, from $130.6 million, or $2.28 a share, a year ago.

title: Gunman Is Killed By Officer on IRT
description: An off-duty police officer shot and fatally wounded one of five men who tried to rob an off-duty corrections officer in a Brooklyn subway station last night, the police reported.

title: TWO OR MORE BOSSES: BETTER THAN ONE?
description: A DECADE ago, when Sylvia Cash worked as the personal secretary to the lawyer Joseph Yablonski, she was, as she puts it, ''part of the family.'' After the birth of his daughter, when Mr. Yablonski, then general counsel to the United Mine Workers, had to be in court, it was Miss Cash who went to the hospital to fetch the newborn and her mother.

title: IN SOUTH LEBANON, MAN RIDING A MULE SETS OFF EXPLOSION
description: A man riding a mule detonated saddle baskets full of explosives in south Lebanon today.

title: MCGRATH RENTCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAMPLING THE WARES BY THE GLASS AND BOTTLE
description: It is quiet in the old streets around the Ecole Polytechnique these lazy summer days. The brilliant young students are at St. Tropez and the local people are camping in the Haute Savoie or ''bronzing,'' as they call it here, at Arcachon or Carcassonne.

title: Required Reading;   Money, Money, Money
description: Excerpts from an exchange between Senator Donald W. Riegle Jr., Democrat of Michigan, and Paul Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, at a Senate Banking Committee hearing, July 18:

title: NOT A GOOD TIME FOR BASEBALL'S BEST
description: Pete Rose is just 24 hits short of breaking Ty Cobb's career record. Phil Niekro, the Yankees' 46-year-old pitcher, needs six victories for 300. Don Sutton needs 10. The Toronto Blue Jays are slowly nearing the first division title in their history.

title: Bridge: A Grand Nationals Winner Ahead in Life Master Pairs
description: The world's biggest-ever bridge tournament, the Summer Nationals of the American Contract Bridge League, continued here this afternoon at the Las Vegas Hilton Hotel. Attendance in the first four days was almost 10 percent higher than when the previous record was set here in 1979.

title: GUEST SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
18-MONTH TERM FOR WINANS
description: R. Foster Winans, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, was sentenced yesterday to 18 months in prison, a $5,000 fine and five years' probation for his part in a scheme to trade securities based on advance information about stock market columns he and others wrote.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'll play baseball somewhere, even if I have to go out and play with my horses.'' - Pete Rose. [A15:1]

title: COLUMBIA GAS SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FILM: AUSTRALIAN WORKING WOMEN
description: BY pairing two short Australian movies about young working-class women on a bill that opens today at Film Forum I, the enterprising proprietors of the theater on Watts Street are sponsoring a sort of contest between a documentary and a drama: Which better conveys the reality of the women's condition?

title: MARRIAGE, 'DRY' CITY, WORKSHOP
description: The perfect solution is where you find it, so when Rex Smith and Deirdre Brown decided to marry after five years of living together, they followed the path of several thousand other couples and went to High Point, N.C., to the Dallas Furniture Store.

title: U.S. Budget Aide Resigns
description: Donald W. Moran, executive associate director of the Office of Management and Budget, has resigned effective Sept. 1 to become vice president of ICF Inc., a Washington consulting concern specializing in environment aland health issues, the budget office announced Monday.

title: SUNNY THREESOME RIPE FOR COOKING
description: TOMATOES, peppers and eggplant - flavorful summer vegetables in full season in the Northeast - are traditional staples of Mediterranean cooking. Alone or in combination, raw (in the case of tomatoes and peppers) or cooked, combined with onions and garlic, fragrant olive oil and aromatic herbs, dressed with cheese or stuffed with meat, rice or fish, they are the backbone of literally dozens of savory main-course dishes, not to mention garnishes, salads and sauces.

title: CME-SAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NAVY ENGINEER TERMS WALKER DATA 'SIGNIFICANT'
description: A Navy engineer testified today that the classified documents Arthur J. Walker is charged with passing to the Soviet Union contained ''significant tactical information.''

title: Mirrors in Space
description: To the Editor:

title: Letter: On Job Programs;   The Folly in Federal Funding Cuts
description: to the Editor:

title: Seoul to 'Re-educate' Student Dissidents
description: The South Korean Government said today that it would introduce a new law to ''re-educate'' students engaged in anti-Government activities.

title: CRAM AIM: A PUSH TOWARD HIS LIMIT
description: The wind that roars off the nearby River Tyne could be a mighty opponent Friday, when Steve Cram, the golden boy of British runners, tries for his fourth consecutive world record.

title: Turned Off
description: Buck Rogers football got a temporary setback when designers of a helmet-to-helmet radio system that would keep quarterbacks in touch with receivers said the equipment needed reworking and would not be ready for its planned debut in an exhibition game between the Indianapolis Colts and the Seattle Seahawks on Saturday. The system, which had been targeted for a six-game tryout, is designed to make sure that receivers hear check-off signals at the line of scrimmage when crowd noises drown out the sound of the quarterback's voice.

title: Tick-Borne Fever Strikes 3 Girls in Pennsylvania
description: Three girls have contracted the tick-borne Rocky Mountain spotted fever after visiting a camp in Pennsylvania and all remained hospitalized today, one in critical condition, state health officials said.

title: Legal Brothel in Nevada Is Sold for $18 Million
description: Saying 30 years in the business was enough, the man who pioneered Nevada's move into legalized prostitution has announced the sale of the nation's largest legal brothel for $18 million.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COSMO COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FAR WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the year-ago periods include revenue of $16,400,000 and net income of $8,400,000, or $4.16 a share, from the sale of Gulf Corp stock.

title: AMERICAN TRIAL PUTS CHINESE JUSTICE TO THE TEST
description: When Richard S. Ondrik flew from Peking to this city on April 18, he was as prepared as an American can be for the trade opportunities unfolding in China.

title: EASCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: About Real Estate;   Slab Aid Program Keeps Manufacturers in the City
description: Building anew on old city streets requires patience, testing and a certain amount of luck. Factories and warehouses that are razed only from street level upward leave behind foundations, underground vaults and subterranean passageways that are filled with debris, covered over and forgotten until a new project goes up on the site.

title: Administrative Judges' Head
description: Judge Charles D. McFaul was sworn in yesterday by Mayor Koch as the city's chief administrative law judge. Judge McFaul will direct the Office of Administrative Trials and Hearings, which deals mostly with Civil Service trials, contract defaults, license revocations and discriminatory employment by city contractors. Judge McFaul, 40 years old, worked four years at the Corporation Counsel's office and two years with the State Division of Criminal Justice Services before being appointed by Mr. Koch in 1979 as an administrative law judge.

title: CONCERT: A WORK BY JOHN ADAMS
description: As in the Brecht-Weill parable, when ''God came to Mahagonny,'' Minimalism came to Tanglewood tonight, incarnated as John Adams's ''Harmonielehre'' (1985). The score received a standing, cheering ovation from a big audience in the Theater-Concert Hall.

title: Mortgage Funds For Cook County
description: Cook County, Ill., is offering $84.3 million of single-family mortgage revenue bonds with a maximum yield for interest-bearing bonds of 9.30 percent for those due in 2009, through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company. The financing also includes shorter maturities with yields ranging from 6 percent in 1987 to 7.25 percent in 1990, 8.40 percent in 1995 and 9.25 percent in 2005.

title: AIRPORT'S WATER TANKS MAY HAVE DOOMED PLANE
description: Even though crippled and out of control, a Delta Air Lines jet probably could have survived a crash here Friday had it not struck two water tanks on the airport grounds, the Federal Government's chief accident investigator said today.

title: EMERSON ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Woman's Day Account Moves to Leber Katz
description: After three years with Calvillo, Shevack & Partners, Woman's Day magazine has moved its advertising account to Leber Katz Partners, which will handle both trade media and consumer circulation promotion.

title: SATELLITE ORBIT RULES IRK 3D WORLD
description: A conflict between industrial and developing countries over the use of space is shaping up as the dominant issue at a conference of 150 countries that opens Thursday in Geneva.

title: AS SEALSKIN TRADE WILTS, ESKIMO HAMLET WITHERS
description: In the lingering twilight of an Arctic summer night, a solitary hunter worked on his boat.

title: Jartran Sale Likely
description: Jartran Inc., the nation's third-largest truck rental company, may be put up for sale because it has continued to lose money after emerging from Federal bankruptcy proceedings, according to its parent company, Frank B. Hall & Company.

title: FAIRNESS DOCTRINE ASSAILED BY F.C.C.
description: The Federal Communications Commission said today that the Fairness Doctrine no longer serves the public interest. It said, however, that it would continue to enforce the rule, which requires broadcasters to cover important community issues and present balanced reporting and differing views where there is controversy.

title: World Chess Title Play Scheduled for Sept. 3
description: The opening game of the replay of the world chess championship match between the titlist, Anatoly Karpov, and his challenger, Gary Kasparov, will be Sept. 3, the Soviet news agency Tass said today.

title: ARAB LEAGUE OPENS TALKS AMID DEEP SPLITS
description: An emergency Arab League meeting opened here today with King Hassan II of Morocco seeking to heal a rift that led five hard-line Arab Governments to boycott the conference.

title: CROWN AUTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $413,000 for the quarter and the six months from life insurance benefits.

title: POLICE SEEK ATTACKER OF 8 WOMEN IN PELHAM AREA OF BRONX AT NIGHT
description: Eight women have been attacked, four of them sexually, by the same man since July 3 in the Pelham Bay section of the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: JERSEY ALLERGIST EXPECTS A SHORT AND MILD HAY FEVER SEASON
description: The hay fever season is approaching, but it will be shorter and milder than last year's because of the drought, according to an authority on the allergy.

title: NICARAGUA REBELS GETTING ADVICE FROM WHITE HOUSE ON OPERATIONS
description: The following dispatch is based on reporting by Joel Brinkley and Shirley Christian and was written by Mr. Brinkley.

title: ARMY ENGINEERS FAULTED ON WETLANDS
description: A decision by the Army Corps of Engineers to permit the construction of a shopping mall over a small swamp in Massachusetts has stirred new criticism of the corps's stewardship of wetlands.

title: Holtz Intercepts Raise
description: Since Lou Holtz took over as football coach at Minnesota last year, season-ticket sales increased by 18,000 and income from the football program jumped by $2 million. With all that extra money, the university figured it could share some of it with the man responsible for the windfall.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Eddie Gregg will fight Tony Tubbs, the champion, for the World Boxing Association heavyweight title Sept. 7 in Montreal. . . . Michael Graham, who left Georgetown last year after helping lead the Hoyas to the 1984 national championship as a freshman, will return to school this fall. According to sources close to the Georgetown basketball program, Graham and Ralph Dalton, a five-year student, will play for Coach John Thompson this season.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell
description: The Netherlands has asked Venezuela to grant lower prices on heavy crude supplies to Royal Dutch/Shell Group's Curacao refinery while plans are worked out for new ownership, said Jan De Koening, the Dutch Antillean Affairs minister. He said the proposed price concession would last three months until Oct. 31.

title: LUNDY ELECTRONICS AND SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Boatmen's Chief Backs Banking Consolidation
description: Donald N. Brandin began his career as a trainee at the Bankers Trust Company nearly 40 years ago. But he has built his reputation in the Middle West as chairman and chief executive of Boatmen's Bancshares Inc. in St. Louis.

title: WITNESS SAYS OFFICERS BEAT STEWART AS OTHERS STOOD BY
description: A college student testified yesterday that he saw a group of transit police officers beat Michael Stewart with a stick or a club while another group of transit officers stood by.

title: DECISION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax loss of $227,556 and a tax credit of $81,000. c-Including a nonrecurring pretax gain of $77,954, a tax credit of $234,000 and income from discontinued operations of $2,000.

title: The Politics of Latin Debt
description: Latin America's debt problem is back in the headlines. In Cuba, Fidel Castro is calling for a suspension of all debt payments by Latin states. In Peru, incoming President Alan Garcia Perez has unilaterally set a limit on the debt service his nation will pay foreign creditors. Politics is rapidly shortening the fuse of the debt bomb.

title: DRUG TEST FOR STUDENTS IS SET
description: A policy requiring mandatory urine testing for drugs for high school students was passed today by the school board here, and the American Civil Liberties Union promised to challenge it in court, a school board attorney said.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Boston on Tuesday about a libel suit by John R. Lakian against The Boston Globe, and another yesterday, inaccurately described the jury's findings.

title: FLORIDA ROCK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POSTCARD PROTEST OF REMARKS ON RELIGION PROMPTS DISPUTE
description: After a California man sent a postcard to the Education Department's Denver office protesting the distribution of a speech asserting that the United States was a Christian nation, he received an angry response from an official in another agency in Washington.

title: MILESTONES FOR WESTWAY PLAN
description: Following is a short history of the Westway project: 1971 - Two members of the State Urban Development Corporation propose the Wateredge development, Westway's predecessor. It envisions the creation of 700 acres of new land along the West Side of Manhattan. 1973 - An asphalt-laden dump truck, dispatched to repair the roadway of the old West Side Highway built in the 1930's, crashes through an elevated section of the road. Much of it is closed, never to be reopened. 1974 - The Westway project is proposed to create a new West Side Highway and redevelop the West Side corridor. Opponents sue to block it. Hugh L. Carey, after winning the election for Governor, reverses his opposition to the project. 1977 - The State Transportation Department applies to the Army Corps of Engineers for a Hudson River landfill permit. 1978 - Edward I. Koch, after winning election as Mayor, reverses himself and backs the Westway project. 1981 - The Corps of Engineers issues a dredging and landfill permit. President Reagan presents the city with a symbolic $85 million check to buy rights of way, declaring that ''the Westway project begins today.'' 1982 - Judge Thomas P. Griesa of Federal District Court blocks the permit, saying the corps did not adequately consider the landfill's effects on striped-bass hatcheries in the Hudson River. 1983 - A report commissioned by Governor Cuomo favors abandoning the Westway project and trading in the money for mass-transit funds. The Governor rejects the recommendation. 1984 - The Corps of Engineers holds public hearings on the project and its environmental impact, especially the effects on striped bass. 1985 - The corps issues a new permit, and the matter returns to Judge Griesa.

title: FOR PARIS'S PONT NEUF, A HUGH NYLON WRAPPING
description: One afternoon in 1961, an unknown Bulgarian art student named Javacheff blocked the tiny Rue Visconti, in the Latin Quarter here, with a wall of colored barrels. To anyone who asked, he explained that it was a protest against the Berlin Wall, then only recently erected. The wall - his wall - was torn down after a few hours and forgotten; not so its creator.

title: C.D. Yields Rise Again
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds continued to show increases during the week ended yesterday, while rates on bank money market accounts showed little, if any, movement.

title: Drug Raid Copter Fired On
description: Gunmen blasted dozens of holes early today in a helicopter used in raids Monday and Tuesday on marijuana growers.

title: TRANSIT AIDE ACCUSED OF 'UNREASONABLE' EXPENSES
description: A Transit Authority executive accused this week of falsifying his moving expenses submitted claims for ''unreasonable or nonexistent'' car mileage, hotel bills, meals and storage costs, according to a report released yesterday.

title: LIFTING LAYERS OF GRIME
description: DEPENDING upon the amount of use it gets, neglected furniture gradually becomes lifeless in appearance. But it can also get that way through well-meaning but excessive attention of the wrong kind.

title: 'I'M COMPLETELY CREDIBLE'
description: Following is an excerpt from an exchange Tuesday between Larry Speakes and two members of the White House press corps, Sam Donaldson of ABC News and Helen Thomas of United Press International, as recorded by Federal Transcript Inc.:

title: MOBILE COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LIBEL'S LINK TO DAMAGE
description: A jury's unusual verdict in the libel action brought by a former gubernatorial candidate against The Boston Globe has prompted a vigorous controversy regarding who won the trial and whether libel occurred.

title: AUDIT IS CRITCAL OF N.Y.R.A.
description: An auditors report released today by the State Comptroller's Office says that the New York Racing Association incurred unnecessary expenses through excessive employee fringe benefits between 1981 and 1983.

title: Citizens Banking
description: The Citizens Banking Corporation said it would acquire the Second National Corporation for $68.3 million.

title: YANKS TO PLAY 2 GAMES TONIGHT;   PLAYERS HAD SCATTERED
description: When the word came early yesterday afternoon, Dwight Gooden was arriving home in Tampa, Fla., to throw in the backyard. Jesse Orosco was already in Florida checking out his new house. Dave Johnson, the manager, was at the gate at La Guardia Airport ready to board his flight home to Orlando.

title: STEELMAKERS LISTEN TO DETROIT
description: Three years ago, the Ford Motor Company was rejecting and returning nearly 9 percent of the steel it purchased from suppliers because of surface defects or faulty chemistry. Now, the rate has been reduced to less than 2 percent.

title: RELIEF AGENCY DEFENDS MOVES
description: Catholic Relief Services, the largest private charity distributing United States Government food in Ethiopia, yesterday defended its handling of funds collected for famine victims.

title: Equipment Near White House Found to Be Leaking PCB's
description: Two transformers leaking PCB's have been found in the White House complex, a spokesman said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Market Place column in Business Day on Tuesday incorrectly described a merger between Internorth and Houston Natural Gas. Internorth, not Houston Natural Gas, was the acquiring company.

title: '20/20' EXAMINES A MERCY KILLING
description: ABC'S ''20/20'' enthralls us tonight; the question is, is it proper that it does so? ''20/ 20'' reports on a ''mercy killing'' in Florida, and allows us to play I, the Jury. But should we be playing? Where is television taking us now? The program will be seen on Channel 7 at 10 P.M.

title: GIANTS' WILLIAMS LEARNS TO CONCENTRATE
description: After the Giants' season ended last December, Pat Hodgson, the receivers' coach, had a party at his home for the wide receivers. Afterward, Hodgson and Byron Williams, one of those receivers, had a long talk in front of the house.

title: Nihilator to Race At Monticello
description: Nihilator, the 3-year-old pacer who holds the world race record, will make his debut on a half-mile track Aug. 25 at Monticello Raceway, John Manzi, a Monticello spokesman said today.

title: 10% OF JERSEY'S EDUCATION GRADUATES FAIL U.S. TEST
description: Ten percent of the new graduates of New Jersey teacher-training schools will be barred from teaching in the fall because they failed a standardized test for prospective teachers.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A SMOOTH finish will often make the difference between an obviously homemade project and one that looks as if it was turned out by a professional.

title: Who Are the Realists?
description: ''When I found my mother, her whole body was burned. I couldn't tell where her eyes were, her nose, her ears. But even though she was dying, she was happy to know I was there. And I was lucky to see her before she died.'' - Mrs. Masako Hironaka, 71 years old, resident of the Atomic Bomb Survivors' Nursing Home. Since the Hiroshima and Nagasaki bombs in 1945, the United States has manufactured 60,000 nuclear warheads of 71 different types, for use in 116 weapons systems. The cost so far has been $750 billion. So far. The United States is now spending more to make nuclear warheads than it did on the Manhattan Project, the emergency atomic effort of World War II. That cost a little over $16 billion in terms of current dollars. The MX missile will cost over $30 billion before it is done, the Trident submarine and its missiles as much as $100 billion.

title: Governments Must Behave Better Than Terrorists
description: To the Editor:

title: PIC 'N' SAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ACCORD ON INTERIM AID TO BHOPAL SEEN NEAR
description: An offer of $5 million of interim relief for victims of the Bhopal disaster is likely to be accepted within days by the Indian Red Cross, a court-appointed attorney told a Federal judge yesterday. The relief offered by the Union Carbide Corporation was rejected by India in late April.

title: ASTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Lloyd Advances Easily in Toronto
description: Chris Evert Lloyd led a parade of seeded players into the round of 16 at the $260,000 Player's Challenge women's tennis tournament today.

title: JOHN PAUL, ON EVE OF TRIP TO AFRICA, SPEAKS OUT AGAINST APARTHEID
description: Pope John Paul II leaves Thursday for a 12-day journey through Africa, where the Roman Catholic Church faces competition from Islam, debates over reconciling African culture with Christianity and disagreements over birth control.

title: FIGHT OVER RULE IS SEEN IN COURTS, NOT CONGRESS
description: Broadcasters reacted enthusiastically yesterday to the Federal Communications Commission's declaration against the Fairness Doctrine, but supporters of the regulation predicted a long, hard battle.

title: Paid Ads On Public Television
description: VIEWERS of WNET/Channel 13, the educational broadcasting corporation serving 2.2 million households in New York City and parts of New Jersey, Connecticut and New York State, will soon see more commercial advertising on the public station. Yesterday, the nonprofit corporation announced that it is shopping for sponsors for 30-second spots that will allow corporations to identify themselves and their products.

title: THUNANDER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUPREMA INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Housing Offering Takes Innovative Approach
description: The New York City Housing Development Corporation has arranged an innovative $40 million bond issue to finance about 700 units of low- and middle-income housing.

title: SUIT ACCUSES PRIEST OF DISCLOSING THEFT CONFESSION
description: A Marin County woman has filed a $5 million civil suit against her Episcopal priest, charging that he violated the secrecy of her confession that she had embezzled church funds.

title: CENTURY TELEPHONE ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WESTWAY IS AT THE CROSS ROADS AGAIN
description: Nearly 15 years after it was first proposed, Westway is foundering in the face of court constraints and Congressional opposition.

title: Uganda's New Rulers Reportedly Detain 1,000
description: The new military rulers of Uganda have detained more than 1,000 members of the ousted President's secret police and bodyguard in a maximum-security jail, prison administration sources said today.

title: Zimmerman Still on Hold
description: Gary Zimmerman of the Los Angeles Express, 6 feet 6 inches and 275 pounds of Grade A offensive tackle, would be a sure standout for the Giants, who gained rights to him in the National Football League's supplemental draft of players from the United States Football League. And, despite Zimmerman's protests that he wants to play on the Coast, it seems just as sure that he will sign with the Giants if the price is right.

title: MUSIC: PLACIDO DOMINGO AT GARDEN
description: ZARZUELA met Madison Square Garden in a struggle to the death Wednesday night. An old Spanish stage form - darkened and enriched by three centuries of tradition - had on its side some wonderful music and dancing - along with the tenorial splendors of Placido Domingo. The Garden countered with its huge space, redolent plastic seats, sprawling sound system and the ghostly patina of all the goalies, rock singers, point guards, opera stars and light heavyweights who have performed there.

title: 'Only Lipstick'
description: There were some double-pump layups and behind-the-back dribbles to be seen Tuesday night at Corlears Junior High School on the Lower East Side, as well as an injury timeout.

title: A Dark Day for U.S. Workers Is Dawning at Toyota-G.M. Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: GALAXY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $784,406, or 6 cents a share, from an exchange of debt issues made during the first quarter.

title: Locating the Real Trade Issues
description: Most members of Congress want to help ailing manufacturers by shutting out foreign competitors. In refreshing contrast, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey aims to treat the disease, not just its symptoms. He may not have all the answers, but it's good to find someone in Washington looking to save open trade, on which the world's prosperity depends.

title: Your Friendly Police
description: One group came as a herd of sheep, for Sheep Meadow. Another group, grass sprouting from their heads, came as the Great Lawn.

title: Pride of the Mud Hens
description: The good news, that the baseball strike has ended quickly, arrived just in time to head off the bad news, if not also the Bad News Bears. Had the strike lasted, one owner suggested, it would have been ''interesting'' to bring up minor-league players to finish out the season.

title: ICAHN CLOSES IN ON CONTROL OF T.W.A.
description: For the second time in as many days, Carl C. Icahn disclosed yesterday that he and his group of investors have increased their stake in Trans World Airlines, increasing the likelihood that he will be able to gain control of the airline.

title: BARYSHNIKOV SIDELINED
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov, who injured his right knee during a recent road tour, will not perform with the American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House in September. Mr. Baryshnikov's performances with the company at the Wolf Trap Farm for the Performing Arts in Vienna, Va., during the last week in August have also been canceled.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE WAYS OF DARKNESS. By Joseph Hayes. 307 pages. Morrow. $16.95. GIVE Joseph Hayes this much: He wastes no time shifting into high gear in his latest thriller, ''The Ways of Darkness.'' Within the first eight pages, Todd Horgan, a college student camping out in the Vermont woods, is assaulted by two hunters, one of whom throws Todd off a cliff while the other chases Todd's naked girlfriend, Lynnette Durand, into the woods.

title: CAMP SAGAMORE: A BRIGHTER FUTURE
description: A THREE-YEAR-OLD controversy over the fate of 11 decaying buildings in the Adirondack Forest Preserve ended in June when the New York State Legislature approved the Sagamore Land Exchange, guaranteeing the preservation and restoration of Camp Sagamore near the small upstate town of Raquette Lake.

title: PETROLEUM EQUIPMENT TOOLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEARNEY NATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $97,000 for the quarter and $356,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Mary P. Halloran, 62, A Professor at Hunter
description: Dr. Mary P. Dolciani Halloran, a mathematician who taught at Hunter College and wrote a series of textbooks that sold millions of copies, died Monday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 62 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: WESTWAY PROJECT IS BLOCKED AGAIN BY FEDERAL JUDGE
description: A Federal judge yesterday barred construction of the Westway project, continuing his three-year-old injunction and once again casting doubt on whether the project can ever be built.

title: Put New York's Water Supply in Private Hands
description: To the Editor:

title: New UA Will Start As 'Shell Company'
description: Kirk Kerkorian is likely to continue his role in Hollywood motion picture production through United Artists after the rest of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company is sold to Turner Broadcasting Systems Inc. But how big a factor United Artists will be is not known.

title: NORTHWESTERN PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITIZENS FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Janerette Conflict
description: The district attorney's office in Philadelphia said that it had decided not to prosecute the police officer who shot and killed the former National Football League lineman Charles Janerette Jr. because there was not enough evidence that the officer had acted improperly in the incident last October. The 45-year-old Janerette, who played for four N.F.L. teams including the Giants and the Jets in the 1960's, after having played at Penn State, was shot in the back of the head last Oct. 28 by the officer, Kurt VonColln, under circumstances that have been in dispute.

title: SEASIDE GARDENING: TRIAL AND ERROR BREED SUCCESS
description: UNTEMPERED wind, relentless sun and sandy soil are not assets when it comes to the garden. Yet, on Long Island's easternmost edge these conditions are the norm. Dotting the wild meadows, tucked amid potato fields or dug in behind the dunes, there are seaside gardeners who manage to succeed. A few toil on weekends, while others are in residence all year long. Nature's challenge has been met by most with flexibility - and a series of trials and errors.

title: HERS
description: SEVERAL years ago, when, as a newly ordained rabbi, I had performed only a dozen or so weddings, I officiated at the ceremony of a couple in their late 30's that was boycotted by the bridegroom's mother.

title: TROUBLED 'OFF PRICE' CHAINS
description: Specialized discounters, who only a few years ago appeared to pose a major threat to department stores, are running into increasing problems. Three leading players closed their doors last year and a fourth now may be on the way out.

title: RAI RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Includes a disc tax credit of $252,000.

title: A TRAIL OF EVENTS FROM BOATS TO BERRIES
description: A 10-mile hike culminating in a raid on a blueberry patch, and a boat trip on the Hudson between Manhattan and Bear Mountain with a five-mile walk tossed in are among this weekend's activities sponsored by member clubs of the New York-New Jersey Trail Conference.

title: HERBERT IS SIGNED BY SAINTS
description: Bobby Hebert, the quarterback who led the Michigan Panthers to the first United States Football League championship and who was on the runner-up team for the last two years, signed last night with the New Orleans Saints.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fireman's Fund Leader
description: The American Express Company, as expected, named John J. Byrne today as chairman and chief executive of the Fireman's Fund Corporation, the holding company for its insurance operations. Mr. Byrne used to be chairman of the Geico Corporation.

title: Hail the New Directory
description: The typical Washington office is replete with directories of all kinds, most of them huge volumes listing positions and telephone numbers of key Government and Congressional officials. But it is perhaps safe to say that the handiest of all such publications is a pocket-size directory that Hill & Knowlton, the international public relations concern, began publishing more than 40 years ago.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AFG Industries, Irvine, Calif., which makes glass for the construction industry, has elected to its board Donald M. Koll, chairman and chief executive officer of the Koll Co.

title: Now Pitching . . .
description: On Tuesday evening, clients of United Press International's sports wire received this word on probable pitchers for Wednesday: ''Players (Fehr 0-1) at Owners (MacPhail 0-1).''

title: POLISHED IMAGE FOR UEBERROTH
description: ''Does this mean,'' someone in the Yankee office yesterday afternoon wanted to know, ''that the commissioner will be taking bows?''

title: BUSINESS MEN'S ASSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including investment gains of $4,277,000 for the quarter and $5,375,000 for the six months. c-Including investment gains of $133,000 for the quarter and $891,000 for the six months.

title: Shoemaker Sits Out
description: Bill Shoemaker, thoroughbred racing's career leading rider, will be sidelined from three to six weeks because of a fractured vertebra in his lower back.

title: Merrill to Seek Seat in Tokyo
description: Merrill Lynch will try again to gain a seat on the Tokyo Stock Exchange when the exchange decides new membership rules this fall, the chairman of Merrill Lynch Japan said today.

title: CONCORD COMPUTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: STARRETT HOUSING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary tax credits of $687,000 for the quarter and $1,114,000 for the 6 months.

title: BRIEFS
description: Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, said it had signed an agreement with Banco Hispano Americano to acquire a significant minority interest in La Estrella, a multi-line insurance company with assets of more than $84 million.

title: BOSTON CHILD STUDY FINDS DEATH RATE HIGHER AMONG THE POOR AND THE BLACK
description: Children in this city who are poor or black have a substantially higher chance of death than those who are white or from wealthier families, according to a new study.

title: VERMONT FEDERAL BANK reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: AVIATION GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Computation for share earnings includes the effect of interest on convertible subordinated debentures , which are considered to be common stock equivalents.

title: BRITISH COUNTRY HOUSES PACKING UP TREASURES FOR U.S. SHOW
description: Some of the greatest works of art and fine craftsmanship in Britain, among them porcelains and paintings, silver and furniture, jewelry, tapestries, sculpture and arms and armor are now being removed, in unmarked security vans, from British country houses at the rate of about 10 a day.

title: Attorney General In Shift on Hutton
description: The Connecticut Attorney General said yesterday that he had reversed his earlier decision to reopen an investigation into whether E. F. Hutton & Company should be allowed to remain a broker in the state. The state has already held hearings, investigating Hutton in the wake of its guilty plea to Federal charges that it defrauded banks in a check overdraft scheme.

title: SAFEGUARD HEALTH ENTERRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BALDWIN TAKES JOB
description: Joe Klecko, the Jets' defensive lineman, strained a muscle on the left side of his ribcage in a workout this morning and is expected to be out of action for at least two weeks.

title: COMPUCORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONSOLIDATED PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 3
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $90,000 for the quarter related to the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $50,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income. d-Including tax credits of $130,500 for the quarter and $337,500 for the 9 months.

title: STORMS OF WIND, RAIN AND SNOW OVER EUROPE KILL AT LEAST 16
description: Storms packing high winds, heavy rain, funnel clouds and snow swept Europe from the French Mediterranean coast to Denmark yeterday and Tuesday, killing at least 16 people, authorities reported today.

title: L.F. ROTHSCHILD REJECTS A TAKEOVER BID BY FELT
description: The investment banking firm L. F. Rothschild, Unterberg, Towbin announced yesterday that it had rejected a takeover bid made last week by General Felt Industries, the company used as an investment vehicle by Marshall S. Cogan and Stephen C. Swid.

title: Cleaning Up
description: It may be the least glamorous job in all of sports, but someone has to do it.

title: Ramon Cruz Is Dead; Ex-Chief of Honduras
description: Ramon Ernesto Cruz, President of Honduras for almost two years until he was ousted in a coup, died Tuesday, apparently from a heart attack, officials said.

title: MICRO D INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Ship With Japanese Cars Is Burning Off Alaska
description: A Panamanian ship bound for Los Angeles with a load of 2,503 Japanese automobiles was burning off the Alaskan coast today but radio reports indicated crewmen were making headway against the fire, Coast Guard officials said.

title: A RARE YARN IN ALASKA
description: Each year, Eskimo women living in a dozen remote villages in western Alaska receive small packages containing cones of a rare yarn, called qiviut, spun from the winter underwool of Alaska muskoxen. Before the yarn reaches them, however, the wool is combed from the shaggy coats of muskoxen at a ranch 1,000 miles away, shipped another 4,000 miles to a mill in Woonsocket, R.I., to be cleaned, carded and spun, then returned to a small shop in Anchorage for distribution to the knitters.

title: RENAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $39,000.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The attitude that regards entanglement with religion as something akin to entanglement with an infectious disease must be confronted broadly and directly.'' - Secretary of Education William J. Bennett, criticizing a Supreme Court ruling limiting public aid to parochial schools. [A18:4.]

title: View on Cluett: Overpriced
description: PUBLICLY held apparel manufacturers are becoming a rare breed, with many companies either having gone private or been acquired. So, when an old-line concern such as Cluett, Peabody & Company, maker of Arrow shirts, is thought to be up for grabs, investors pay attention.

title: Ranger Via Alaska
description: With 109 points in 34 games, he was the nation's leading scorer in collegiate hockey last season, but Steve Moria did most of his scoring against mostly weak opposition while playing for Alaska-Fairbanks, a school making its first appearance in Division I. Accordingly, not many National Hockey League scouts got a chance to see him. One who did, however, was Chuck Grillo of the Rangers, who liked what he saw when he watched Moria score three goals and an assist in a winning effort against Minnesota-Duluth. Yesterday, the Rangers announced that Moria, a 24-year-old free-agent center, had been signed to a contract and was expected to make the team when the Rangers gather for training camp in September. No contract terms were disclosed.

title: HARLEM WEEK OPENS ON A EUPHORIC NOTE
description: The 11th annual Harlem Week celebration began yesterday with a theme of ''You Haven't Done This Town Until You've Done It Uptown'' and a goal of promoting Harlem as the capital of black America to tourists and residents alike.

title: INTER-CITY GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a special gain of $5.5 million for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including a special gain of $270,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: THE LOST CONTRACT AT LIGGETT
description: The Liggett & Myers Tobacco Company, which pioneered generic, no-name cigarettes in an industry built on advertising and brand names, is finding it tough to defend that niche. Generics, it is discovering, can be a marketing no-man's-land.

title: CHAIN-SAW SAFETY SAID TO IMPROVE
description: Eight years after it began looking into the dangers of chain saws, the Consumer Product Safety Commission concluded today that significant safety advances had made government regulation of the machines unnecessary.

title: U.S. SEIZES AIR JAMAICA JET IN DRUG CASE
description: The Customs Service seized an Air Jamaica jetliner at Kennedy International Airport yesterday, saying the line had failed to provide adequate security against narcotics smuggling.

title: Officials Cleared In Fatal Crash
description: Criminal charges will not be filed against Firebird Raceway officials and the driver Jim Dunn after a crash that killed one woman and injured 20 others, officials announced today.

title: NO JOY FOR YANKS' ARMSTRONG
description: The move was set in motion at 5:30 on Monday afternoon at Cooper Stadium in Columbus, Ohio. Stump Merrill, the manager of the Columbus Clippers, had a message from New York to deliver to Mike Armstrong, a pitcher who had been demoted from the Yankees to Columbus on July 17. ''Everybody in the clubhouse saw Stump talk to me,'' Armstrong said, ''and everybody knew what was going on.'' They were all wise to the scam. As the labor discussions crept along on Monday, the chance of a strike on Tuesday moved from possibility to near-certainty. Which would seem to explain the sudden need for an 11th pitcher on the Yankee staff, whose status in the last two months had deteriorated from ineffective reliever to doghouse inhabitant to minor leaguer.

title: Topics;   Past Perfect Bring Backs
description: Last month the Coca-Cola Company, blushing hotly, decided to bring back the old Coke. This month the sponsors of the Miss America pageant made a similar decision: the strains of ''There She Is . . .'' will once again accompany Miss Tearful down the runway.

title: On Escaping the Marcos Embrace
description: It's rare for the staid American Bar Association to excoriate friendly foreign countries for human rights abuses. It has now done so in the scandalous instance of the Philippines, where lawyers who defend victims in political cases are mysteriously killed. At least three have been murdered and five arrested, one on the peculiar charge of ''human rights lawyering.'' And as the rule of law totters, a Communist guerrilla movement grows, its chief asset being the rickety and corrupt regime of President Ferdinand Marcos.

title: Texas University $75 Million Issue
description: The University of Texas System is offering $75 million of university revenue bonds with yields ranging from 5 percent for bonds due in 1986 to 7.20 percent in 1990 and 9 percent in 2000, through underwriters led by Prudential-Bache Securities Inc.

title: AVALON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $150,000 for the quarter and $550,000 for the six months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $82,000 for the quarter and $308,000 for the six months.

title: Commonwealth Buys G.E. Unit
description: The Commonwealth Savings Association said it had acquired the General Electric Mortgage Corporation from the General Electric Credit Corporation, a unit of the General Electric Company.

description: There are nearly 300 long-distance telephone companies in the United States today, and 23 kinds of Nine Lives cat food. Revlon makes 157 shades of lipstick (41 of them pink) and Tower Video offers 5,000 video cassettes for sale or rent. The Love drugstore chain carries 41 varieties of hair mousse.

title: Topics;   Past Perfect Name That Lawyer
description: The hallmark of an Establishment law firm is the list of partners on its letterhead. It's an understated way of saying ''Look how big we are.

description: NO sooner had wind shear been identified as the probable cause of the Delta Air Lines L-1011 crash that killed 133 people last week than a bevy of Government and industry experts asserted that the accident was probably avoidable.

THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Empire State Games, at Buffalo. The first full day of competition in the eighth annual festival, which has moved from Syracuse. More than 6,000 athletes representing six regions of the state will compete through Sunday. Baseball Yankees vs. Cleveland Indians, at Yankee Stadium, twilight-night doubleheader, 5:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 5:30 P.M.) Mets vs. Expos, at Montreal (Television - Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Basketball Nets vs. Philadelphia 76ers, 5 P.M., and Knicks vs. Washington Bullets, 7 P.M., Jadwin Gymnasium, Princeton. Summer league doubleheader for rookies and free agents. Boxing Troy Darrell vs. Terry Crawley, 10 rounds, junior middleweights, at Felt Forum. First preliminary, 7:30 P.M. Darrell, an unbeaten fighter from New Rochelle, has 16 knockouts in 18 professional victories. Crawley, from Hyannis, Mass., is 10-7-2 with 3 knockouts. (Television - MSG Network, 7:30 P.M.) Golf 67th PGA Championship, at Cherry Hills Country Club, Denver, opening round. Lee Trevino, who first won the PGA Championship in 1974 at Tanglewood in North Carolina, won for a second time last year at Shoal Creek in Birmingham, Ala. But he is languishing in 94th place on the earnings list this season. (Television - ESPN, 3:30 P.M. live). Ladies PGA Henredon Classic at High Point, N.C., opening round. Patty Sheehan, who shot a tournament-record 16-under-par 272 to win this tournament in 1983, successfully defended her title last year, beating JoAnne Carner and Dot Germain by a stroke.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: Ark Curtain Stolen at West Point
description: A hand-dyed, woven silk ark curtain commissioned by the United States Military Academy at West Point for its Jewish chapel was stolen Sunday evening from the Long Point Gallery in Provincetown, Mass.

title: Another Mark for Biondi
description: Matt Biondi, who shattered the world record in the 100-meter freestyle Tuesday, came back today to set an American record in the 200-meter freestyle in the United States Long Course National Championships.

title: Why Is Congress Foiling Reagan?
description: With Congress in recess, it is timely to ask why President Reagan is unable to translate his near-record high personal popularity with the public into more Congressional support for his major programs. Why is he unable to duplicate the early successes of his first term, following an election victory even more sweeping than his defeat of Jimmy Carter in 1980? In the answers lie some fundamental truths about the Presidency.

title: BELLAMY PRESENTS BILL TO BAR WAREHOUSING OF APARTMENTS
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy and some Council members yesterday proposed legislation intended to prevent landlords from keeping apartments vacant.

title: Upjohn Plant
description: The Upjohn Company said it was investing $23 million in a plant to make a drug that may cure baldness. The drug, minoxidil, is in the final stages of testing on human volunteers, and Upjohn hopes to ask the Food and Drug Administration this year for permission to market the product as a prescription medicine, said Peter Maas, a company spokesman. The drug has been prescribed for years to control high blood pressure under the trade name Loniten, but F.D.A. approval of its use to cure baldness may be several years away.

description: Companies

EX-AGENT DEFENDED AS TRYING TO TRAP SPIES
description: The first agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation ever accused of espionage was repeating the maneuver of another agent in an attempt to trap Soviet spies, his lawyer told a jury today. But while the other agent's effort failed, the lawyer said, in this case ''the fish was on the hook.''

title: HIGHWAYMEN STALK DRIVERS ALONG MIAMI EXPRESSWAYS
description: A new breed of urban highwayman is stalking Miami motorists.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: HARBOR SIGHTS There are few grander spectacles in New York than the harbor itself, that spacious entryway from the sea that oversaw the growth of the great metropolis. The most recent entry in the small flotilla of craft that ply the harbor for sightseers is a sidewheel paddleboat, the Andrew Fletcher, that sails from the piers of the South Street Seaport Museum at Fulton Street and the East River.

description: The 67th PGA Championship at Cherry Hills Country Club might open with a long-range artillery barrage of tee shots Thursday at the 346-yard, par-4 first hole as the big hitters attempt to reach the green and duplicate Arnold Palmer's famous shot a quarter of a century ago.

title: Regulators Reorganize Thrift Unit in California
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said last night that it had chartered a new mutual savings and loan association to take over the Butterfield Savings and Loan Association of Santa Ana, Calif., which it declared insolvent.

description: Three men were arrested on the street in a quiet Queens neighborhood yesterday as law enforcement authorities acted on mounting complaints of open drug dealing in the middle-class area.

description: The top three seeded players - John McEnroe, Ivan Lendl and Jimmy Connors - moved easily today into the third round of the $315,000 Volvo International tennis tournament with straight-set victories over unseeded players.

title: U.S. SAYS SMUGGLERS BRING RECORD COCAINE FLOW
description: Despite improved vigilance by Federal and local agencies, more cocaine than ever is entering the United States, law-enforcement officials say. And they expect that improved smuggling strategies and unrelenting demand will keep the record-breaking flow coming.

title: Guilty Plea Made By John Paul Jr.
description: John Paul Jr., the race car driver, pleaded guilty today to charges of Federal racketeering and possession of a false passport as part of a plea agreement reached last month with the Government. In exchange, the Government said it will drop four other drug-related charges against him at sentencing.
