description: The patients include the 97-year-old Goddess of Liberty atop the Texas Capitol, two 20-foot-high Indians from Chicago and Hans Christian Andersen from Central Park in New York.

title: Agca Tells of Meetings In Plot to Kill Pope
description: Mehmet Ali Agca described in detail to a court here today meetings of Turkish terrorists in Vienna and Milan to plan the assassination of Pope John Paul II.

title: Power Agency's Top Yield 9.68%
description: The Sam Rayburn Municipal Power Agency of Texas is issuing $193.3 million of electric revenue refunding bonds that were tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 9.68 percent for 9 5/8 percent bonds due in 2004, though underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: ON THE STOCK MARKET, THE WEATHER AND OTHER THINGS CYCLICAL
description: Things seem to run in cycles. The days revolve dawn to dusk around the wheel of seasons. History has its ends and its beginnings, too. ''Turning and turning in the widening gyre,'' wrote Yeats. Scientists track the loop of life and death. And poets, like Wallace Stevens, spend their time spinning: ''Yet that things go round and again go round has a rather classical sound.''

title: ABC News Employee Released in Lebanon
description: An ABC spokesman said in New York yesterday that Shakib Humaidan, a Lebanese employee of ABC News in Beirut who was kidnapped last week, had been released by his captors.

title: Heckler Leaves Hospital
description: Margaret M. Heckler, Secretary of Health and Human Services, was released from the Columbia Hospital for Women Tuesday and is recuperating at home after a hysterectomy last week, the department said today.

title: Busy, Busy, Busy
description: For those who like to keep score on Congress, let the record show that both the Senate and the House have been in recess more often than in session since first convening this year. Of the 209 days from the start of this Congress Jan. 3 to the beginning of a monthlong recess last Friday, the Senate was in session 101 days, while the House met on just 91 days, according to a ''Resume of Congressional Activity'' in the Congressional Record.

title: Hail the Conservatives
description: President Reagan may still face major problems getting what he wants in the way of conservative legislation from Congress this year. But the Fund for a Conservative Majority says a recent survey proves the ''Reagan Revolution is alive and well.''

title: Utility Backed On Plant Costs
description: Middle South Utilities Inc. said today that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has denied requests from states served by Middle South's operating units to stay an earlier order allocating nuclear power plant costs.

title: Ruling Hinders Bid for Newspaper
description: Michigan law must regulate two television producers' $453 million takeover bid for the Evening News Association because stock in the company is not publicly traded, a Federal judge ruled today. ''The protection of resident shareholders of a Michigan corporation is a legitimate state interest,'' Federal District Judge Robert DeMascio said, noting that half of the company's 333 shareholders live in Michigan.

title: VICTORIAN STYLES IN HOME DOORBELLS
description: BEFORE the advent of electricity, an alternative to the door knocker was the mechanical twist-type doorbell. Often seen on Victorian homes, two types of these doorbells were common. One kind was mounted on both sides of the door with the lever on the outside and the bell on the inside; the other was installed on the outside of the door only.

title: WOMEN AND STRESS ON JOB AND AT HOME
description: WHAT makes a woman's work stressful? When researchers first began to study stress in men they looked at occupational factors, theorizing that high-powered, demanding jobs were a cause of strain and might even be linked to illnesses such as heart disease. In some recent studies of women, however, it has emerged that the job, especially when it is a high-powered job, may be the least stressful element in a woman's life.

description: Justice Department officials said today that an investigation had been opened recently into allegations that Hitachi Ltd. engaged in predatory pricing of semiconductor products in the United States.

Key Banks
description: Key Banks Inc., an Albany-based bank holding company, said it had agreed in principle to acquire the First Interstate Corporation, a one-bank holding company based in Anchorage, Alaska, for $19.80 a share, or about $46.3 million. First Interstate has assets of about $400 million and has been a franchise of the First Interstate Bancorp in Los Angeles since 1983. In July, Key Banks made its first move into Alaska, acquiring the Alaska Pacific Bancorporation, which had $695 million in assets.

title: CITY DECORATING THAT CAPTURES THE SPIRIT OF SUMMER
description: IN New York, at least, there seem to be two types of summer people: those who are content to spend time in their city homes and those who rush out of town at the drop of an invitation. While there is little hardship in sunbathing on a penthouse terrace or relaxing in a brownstone garden, achieving the look of a summery retreat in a boxy high-rise apartment, a brownstone or a loft takes a bit more ingenuity. It means interpreting the coolness of summer with white paint and bare floors or mirroring the season's richness with decorative trompe l'oeil flourishes.

title: CONCERT: CLEVELAND ENSEMBLE

The program consisted of Schubert's Quartet in E flat (D. 87), Mozart's ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik'' and Brahms's Quintet for Clarinet and Strings in B minor. James VanDemark, double-bassist, joined the quartet in the Mozart, and Richard Stoltzman was the clarinetist in the Brahms.

title: Remembering Rogues and Heroes
description: Marc Pachter reads the obituaries with more than usual care. It is not that Mr. Pachter is ghoulish. But as chief historian of the National Portrait Gallery, the only national repository of famous, and infamous, Americans, he has a professional interest in such matters. One of the gallery's few rules is that someone must have been dead at least 10 years to enter what Mr. Pachter calls ''our circle of remembrance,'' and the gallery has to keep track of these things.

description: b-Net losses after a charge of $6,182,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the disposition of vessels and a charge of $48,347,000 for the 6 months for an accounting change.

title: 4 DIE AS SOUTH AFRICA UNREST SPREADS
description: The strife in South Africa spread today to townships near Durban, on the southeast coast, where at least four people, all apparently blacks, were reported killed as hundreds of Zulu youths fought pistol-firing policemen on streets littered with burned-out trucks and cars.

title: LEGISLATIVE CHANGES JEOPARDIZE MICRONESIAN PACT
description: Disagreements within the Reagan Administration and amendments by Congressional committees threaten to undo a pact signed with Micronesia, according to officials and legislators.

title: ANTINUCLEAR PACT SIGNED IN PACIFIC
description: Eight Pacific nations including Australia and New Zealand have signed a treaty declaring the South Pacific a nuclear-free zone. They said they would ask the United States, France and Britain to abide by its terms.

title: BRITISH NEWSCASTS STOPPED BY STRIKE
description: Radio and television news broadcasts were blacked out for 24 hours Wednesday throughout Britain and Northern Ireland by journalists protesting a BBC decision to cancel a broadcast hat featured a politician purported to be the chief of staff of the Irish Republican Army.

title: BRASCAN LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 FASHIONABLE RETAILERS INDICTED IN AIDING SALES-TAX EVASION
description: Two fashionable Manhattan stores were charged yesterday with scheming to help customers evade city and state sales taxes on expensive purchases.

title: 'JERSEY JAZZ GUITARS'
description: LES PAUL, Bucky Pizzarelli and his 25-year-old son, John, and Tal Farlow - the featured artists in ''Jersey Jazz Guitars'' - are jazz traditionalists whose styles differ enough to make a concert of the four of them an interesting study in contrasting musical personalities. The show, which airs tonight at 8 o'clock, was taped at Rutgers University's Nicholas Music Center, in New Brunswick. It is the second in Channel 13's three-part ''New Jersey Summerfare Series.''

title: Salvaged Liquid
description: An odd little vehicle - it looked something like a miniature tank truck - sat parked among potted evergreens at Rockefeller Center.

title: GENEX CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sculpture in Dallas
description: Contemporary sculpture by Jonathan Borofksy, Beverly Pepper, Anthony di Caro, Mark di Suvero, Tony Smith and Jenny Holzer and others will be on exhibit at the NorthPark Center in Dallas, Tex., through Dec. 31. The exhibition, which marks the 20th anniversary of the shopping mall, opened on Aug. 1 and contains 34 large-scale works by 24 leading contemporary artists. The architecture of the NorthPark mall, built in 1965, set a precedent that was widely copied in shopping malls around the country.

title: CNA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $50,753,000 for the quarter and $90,115,000 for the six months. c-After realized investment losses of $23,767,000 for the quarter and $20,788,000 for the six months. d-Net loss.

title: TURNING A FACADE INTO A FALSE FRONT
description: ONE of the most intriguing voices in the ongoing debate in New York over ''facadism'' - the practice by which the facades of old and small buildings are preserved as false fronts for new and large skyscrapers that are squeezed behind them - was that of a letter-writer to The New York Times not long ago who wondered why this critic found facadism so disturbing in New York when it ''has been achieved historically and with great panache in the greatest of all cities, Rome.''

title: WEATHERFORD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $4 million.

title: NIXON HAS SKIN CANCER REMOVED
description: Richard M. Nixon underwent minor surgery last week to remove a cancerous tumor from the skin behind his left ear, his doctor said last night.

title: VAN SCHAACK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LIST OF 29 REPORTEDLY HELD
description: Following is a list of the 29 people that the interfaith group Witness for Peace said had been abducted by anti-Sandinista rebels. The group said two other people left the party's boat Tuesday in the town of El Castillo.

title: MANITOWOC CO() reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
DOUGLAS & LOMASON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dow Closes Virtually Unchanged
description: Stock prices fell very slightly yesterday as the market stabilized after its sharp drop on Tuesday.

title: Officer Arrested in Slaying
description: A New York City transit police officer was arrested today and charged with murdering Rex Hoon, 18 years old, outside the officer's home here in Putnam County, the police said. The officer, Frank Losavio, 44, was arraigned on a second-degree murder charge early today. The police said the victim had been visiting the officer's daughter.

title: Argentina Spurs Oil Search
description: Argentina has introduced a new model for oil contracts in an effort to attract private investment, uncover new oil, bolster shrinking petroleum reserves and encourage expansion in exports.

title: TECHAMERICA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Landmark, of Sorts
description: The award was not really official.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized gains on investments of life insurance operations of $1,512,000 for the quarter and $1,632,000 for the 6 months. c-After a realized loss of $1,000 for the quarter and a realized gain of $586,000 for the 6 months.

title: RETIRED NAVY MAN PLEADS NOT GUILTY
description: Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy radioman, pleaded not guilty today to a new, 12-count indictment charging him with selling secret military information to the Soviet Union.

title: ROCKWOOD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $16,000 for the latest first quarter and $301,000 for the year-ago first quarter. The company is listed on the Philadelphia and Pacific stock exchanges.

title: HOT BLUE JAYS SWEEP ORIOLES
description: Treating their strike-induced layoff as little more than a second All-Star Game break, the Toronto Blue Jays let their American League opponents know tonight that the short-lived work stoppage left no ill effects.

title: ROSALIND ELIAS IS SINGING NEW KIND OF REPERTORY
description: What happens when you put a Metropolitan Opera-sized voice in a small Lower East Side theater? What happened for Rosalind Elias, the Metropolitan mezzo-soprano who is now heading the cast of ''Pearls'' at the Jewish Repertory Theater, was something very nice.

title: Athletic Director Out
description: Mary Alice Hill, who was the only female athletic director of all sports at a Division I-A school belonging to the National Collegiate Athletic Association, was dismissed yesterday by San Diego State after two weeks of uncertainty about her status. Last July 25, the university president, Dr. Thomas B. Day, ordered her to take a two-week vacation when she dismissed three members of the athletic department and a private contractor in charge of promotions.

title: 29 U.S. ACTIVISTS REPORTEDLY FREED IN NICARAGUA
description: A group of 29 American peace activists reported captured by United States-backed rebel forces Wednesday were released today, according to a spokesman for the group that sponsored their trip.

title: Steelworkers Bar Talks
description: Members of the United Steelworkers of America on Wednesday rejected ideas put forth by mediators for resuming talks with the strikebound Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, and a company director said today that the steelmaker would be forced to liquidate if the walkout was not settled soon. Paul Rusen, the union's chief negotiator, said he had no idea when the two sides might resume bargaining over what level of pay cuts would be necessary to help the nation's seventh-largest steelmaker emerge from reorganization in Federal Bankruptcy Court. About 8,200 union members struck the company 19 days ago.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 9, 1985
description: Companies

title: IRVINE SENSORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: LOEWS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $10,628,000 for the quarter and $13,482,000 for the 6 months and net income of CNA Financial Corp. of $78.9 million for the quarter and $151 million for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,677,000 for the quarter and $4,448,000 for the 6 months, a loss of $3.3 million of CNA Financial Corp. for the quarter and net income of $25.4 million of CNA Financial Corp. for the 6 months. Per share figures reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid March 1.

title: SCREEN: 'PEE-WEE'S BIG ADVENTURE,' A COMEDY
description: THERE are two funny things in ''Pee-Wee's Big Adventure,'' which opens today at the National and other theaters. One is a waitress who explains why her boyfriend doesn't want to go to Paris. ''He flunked French in high school and now thinks everybody over there is out to make him look dumb.'' The other is a pretty, unstoppably gushy young woman named Tina (Jan Hooks) who acts as a tour guide at the Alamo in San Antonio.

title: COMARCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
OVERSEAS SHIPHOLDING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $2,550,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,304,000, or 9 cents a share, for the 6 months related to disposal of vessels .

title: AMERICAN SHIP BUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $475,000 for the quarter and $219,000 for the six months.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If necessary, we can even take stronger steps than we have taken so far.'' - President P. W. Botha of South Africa. [A1:6.]

title: Wanted to Buy
description: The city of Pittsburgh and a group of private investors made an offer to buy the Pittsburgh Pirates yesterday in a meeting attended by the club president Dan Galbreath, Mayor Richard Caliguiri and the chairman of Westinghouse Electric Corp., Douglas D. Danforth, the Mayor said. The private investors are comprised of 12 to 15 individuals and corporations, Caliguiri said.

title: WITNESS CRIES AS SHE PRESENTS LIGHT OF AGED
description: As 77-year-old Lillian Robbins sat in her wheelchair and talked of being old in New York City, she broke down and started to weep.

title: Gunman Shot by Police Dies
description: A gunman who held a convenience store clerk hostage for four hours before being shot by the police Tuesday died today, the authorities said.

title: Tunick to Conduct
description: Jonathan Tunick, the composer and noted theatrical orchestrator, will conduct the Palm Garden Salon Orchestra in two free concerts Sunday.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $890,000 for the quarter and $6,013,000 for the six months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $273,000 for the quarter and $43,000 for the six months.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: John Carpenter will direct and Kurt Russell will probably star in ''Big Trouble in Little China,'' an $18 million 20th Century-Fox movie about a truck driver who has his truck stolen in San Francisco's Chinatown.

title: 'What More Could Israel Offer Than the Desire to Make Peace?'
description: To the Editor:

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about broadcasters' reactions to the Federal Communications Commission's attack on the Fairness Doctrine omitted a phrase - ''of news content'' -in quoting Corydon B. Dunham, executive vice president and general counsel of NBC. He said: ''Government regulation of news content is wrong, whatever it is called. We welcome the F.C.C.'s principled stand that its Fairness Doctrine should be repealed.''

title: INTERNATIONAL TRANSTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISN'T IT TIME TO SELL THE POSTAL SERVICE?
description: The United States Postal Service is at it again. Created out of the old Post Office Department in 1971 as a Federal corporation, it was given a clear mandate: Operate like a business and end the need for taxpayer subsidies. Well, it hasn't quite worked out that way. Postmaster General Paul Carlin just announced that the Service is losing $1 million a day - despite a 10 percent hike this February in the price of a first-class stamp.

title: Advertising;   The Rights Of Dead Celebrities
description: TO advertisers, certain personalities, such as John Wayne, Elvis Presley and W. C. Fields, are as bankable now as when they were alive. In some ways they are even more attractive.

title: PETROLEUM DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: RECORDINGS WILL CARRY ADVISORY ABOUT LYRICS
description: The Recording Industry Association of America has announced that record companies will put advisories on album and cassette covers identifying recordings that are believed to contain sexually explicit lyrics.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS is essentially a small town surrounded by grand houses, vestiges of the Victorian hotels that once lined the Broadway promenade, two race tracks, a polo field and a spa that retains a trickle of the mineral water that brought the town its initial fame. Because of this, people tend to run into each other repeatedly, more so during August, when similar interests in thoroughbred horses and racing and a bewildering number of parties throw them together constantly.

title: BAHAMAS CLINIC USED SERUM WITH AIDS VIRUS, U.S. SAYS
description: The Federal Centers for Disease Control say that patients who received blood-derived drugs dispensed by a cancer clinic in the Bahamas were exposed to a virus associated with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: CLOROX COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $2,650,000, or about 10 cents a share, from the sale of Cream of Rice cereal brand.

title: Georgia Federal
description: Fuqua Industries said that the board of Georgia Federal Bank has voted in principle to accept a revised $220 million buyout offer from Fuqua. Fuqua has offered $27.75 a share for the 7.9 million shares outstanding for Georgia Federal, the biggest savings bank in the state with assets of $2.4 billion. Fuqua, an Atlanta diversified consumer products and services company, which in 1984 posted sales of $855 million and net income of $37.6 million said no changes were planned at Georgia Federal.

title: Lightfoot in Westbury
description: Gordon Lightfoot, the Canadian folk singer and songwriter, will appear at the Westbury Music Fair on Sunday, for one performance only, at 7 P.M. Tickets are $13 and are available at the Westbury Music Fair box office and at Ticketron locations. Information: (516) 333-0533. To get to the fair, at 960 Brush Hollow Road in Westbury, L.I., take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 40 or the Northern State Parkway to Exit 342 and follow the signs.

title: ATV SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. CONSIDERS NEW SOLUTIONS TO FARM CRISIS
description: Reagan Administration officials say they are searching for a new approach to the increasing problems of farmers and their bankers while putting aside the White House's earlier plans for fundamental changes in Government agriculture programs.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Detroit dispatch by The Associated Press in Business Day on Wednesday about Toyota Motor Company sales carried figures that the company says were overstated because of a computer programming error. Toyota now says it sold 68,753 cars in July, 32.3 percent more than in July 1984.

title: REUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
China Tells of Floods That Have Killed 283
description: Floods caused by torrential rains have killed 283 people and left 14,000 homeless in southern China, raising the death toll in a series of storms nationwide to more than 500, the official People's Daily said today.

title: MEDIPLEX GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN SPECIFIES WHAT REGULATIONS WILL BE ISSUED IN THE YEAR
description: President Reagan today sent Congress the Federal Government's first comprehensive annual listing of planned health, safety and economic regulations.

title: Jamaica Pays Fee For Jet's Return
description: An Air Jamaica jet impounded by Customs agents at Kennedy International Airport Wednesday in a move to force the line to tighten security against drug smuggling was returned to service yesterday, the airline said.

title: The U.N. Today; Aug. 9, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: PATRIOTS' PHELAN TO MISS SEASON
description: Gerard Phelan, one of Doug Flutie's key receivers at Boston College, will miss the 1985 season after five hours of knee surgery, the New England Patriots announced yesterday.

title: Deak Halts Krugerrand Sales
description: Deak-Perera, the nation's largest currency dealer, has suspended sales of South African Krugerrand gold coins in the United States, a regional manager said today.

title: Explosion Rips Ship Burning in the Pacific
description: An explosion ripped through the main cargo bay of a burning freighter loaded with Japanese cars today, forcing the commander of a Coast Guard cutter nearby to reconsider his plans for the ship, including possibly restarting the ship's engines and escorting her to an Alaskan port.

title: FOR CAMACHO, TRUTH IS HARD TO FIND
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho wears it on his T-shirts: ''The Moment of Truth.'' But he does not see the irony.

title: LAURENTIAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Economic Scene;

Wage Pattern Among Blacks
description: This is the second of two columns by Mr. Loury, professor of political economy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. Leonard Silk is on vacation.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Joe Dumars, a McNeese State guard who was the Detroit Pistons' top draft choice, has agreed to terms on a multiyear contract, according to the club, which gave no financial details. . . . John Gabriel, the Philadelphia 76ers' video coordinator, has been named an assistant to the team's new coach, Matt Guokas. . . . William Donald Schaefer, the Mayor of Baltimore, said he favored construction of a dual-purpose stadium to serve as the home of Orioles and to attract a new National Football League franchise to replace the Colts. . . . Alan B. Ross, who resigned last January as vice president of corporate communications for Subaru, was named executive director of the United States Ski Team. . . .The Rangers signed the defenseman Jim Andonoff, their fifth-round draft choice in 1983. The 20-year-old Andonoff played the last two seasons with the Belleville Bulls of the Ontario Hockey League.

title: No Faults Are Found In Challenger Engine
description: A microscopic inspection today indicated that the engine that shut down prematurely after the space shuttle Challenger's launching July 29 is in good condition.

title: New DeLorean Effort
description: John Z. DeLorean, whose first try at building a revolutionary automobile ended in a sea of red ink and cocaine trafficking charges, said today he was back in business and would produce the world's fastest car at a plant to be built here. He declined to name his financial backers.

title: K.G.B. Detains U.S. Reporter
description: Gary Thatcher, a reporter for The Christian Science Monitor who was returning to the Soviet Union from an assignment in Finland, was detained for three hours and had his notebooks seized by K.G.B. agents, the State Department and the newspaper's editor said today.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net gains on the sale of real estate investments of $1,085,000, or 23 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,170,000, or 29 cents a share, for the six months. c-Including a net gain on the sale of real estate of $807,000, or 29 cents a share.

title: Philadelphia Police Bomb Had Powerful Explosive
description: The two-pound bomb the police dropped May 13 on the headquarters of the radical group Move contained C-4, a powerful military explosive that police commanders had earlier denied was part of the device, according to a top city official.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CLEMENCY SOUGHT FOR 76-YEAR-OLD WHO KILLED HIS INCURABLY ILL WIFE
description: Gov. Bob Graham and the State Cabinet were asked today to grant clemency to a 76-year-old man serving a life sentence for killing his wife, who was suffering from Alzheimer's disease.

title: NIXON CURBS ACTIVITIES AFTER SKIN CANCER SURGERY
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon curtailed his public schedule after a complication arose from surgery he underwent last week to remove a large cancerous tumor from behind his left ear, his administrative assistant said yesterday.

title: Missouri Bank Retreats
description: Mark Twain Bancshares Inc., a St. Louis-based bank holding company, has dropped plans to operate a bank in Overland Park, Kan., in defiance of Federal interstate banking laws. It will merge the Kansas bank into the Mark Twain Kansas City Bank.

title: MATTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $5,400,000 for the quarter and $13,400,000 for the 6 months.c-Including tax credits of $8,500,000 for the quarter and $11,400,000 for the 6 months and a securities exchange gain of $2,157,000 for the 6 months. Year-ago results are pro forma.

title: Let Them Eat Bread
description: It is a typical Friday morning at Mayflower Liquors on M Street in downtown Washington. The floor, the cash register, even a few bottles of cabernet and zinfandel are covered with a fine dusting of flour, and the telephone is starting to ring. Be calm, Washington, the bread has arrived.

title: Working Profile: Beryl W. Sprinkel;   Alive and Thriving In Economic Advice
description: If Beryl Sprinkel had unlimited power, he would decree one major change in the management of national economies: He would reorder the sequence of pain and pleasure.

title: BECKER IS ELIMINATED
description: The Wimbledon champion, Boris Becker, was eliminated from the $150,000 Kitzbuehel Head Cup Tournament today in a 6-3, 6-1 first-round loss to Diego Perez of Uruguay.

title: IN BOGART RETROSPECTIVE, 40 FILMS IN SIX WEEKS
description: ''The chances are you'll get off with life,'' Humphrey Bogart tells Mary Astor before the police take her away. ''That means if you're a good girl, you'll be out in 20 years. I'll be waiting for you. If they hang you, I'll always remember you.''

title: BIOGEN NV reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANEL, URGING SALARY RISES, TERMS U.S. LEADERS 'CRITICALLY UNDERPAID'
description: A Federal advisory commission said today that members of Congress, Federal judges and other top officials were ''critically underpaid'' and recommended a new procedure for setting their salaries.

title: NICARAGUAN REBELS SAID TO OPEN MAJOR DRIVE WITH NEW WEAPONS
description: Substantial shipments of weapons in recent months have permitted Nicaraguan guerrillas to open a new anti-Government drive inside Nicaragua, according to rebel officials, Western diplomats and Hondurans familiar with the rebels' operations.

title: KOCH AND BLACK AND HISPANIC COUNCIL MEMBERS TRADE SUPPORT
description: Mayor Koch, trying to increase his support among minority groups, has traded endorsements with a number of black and Hispanic City Council members. And, in some cases, the Mayor has withheld public endorsements of friendly minority-group candidates, if Mr. Koch's approval might handicap them, according to his campaign aides.

title: POOH KAYE TO DANCE AT THE MODERN MUSEUM
description: There are people who decided to become dancers after seeing Anna Pavlova - or Rudolf Nureyev, or Martha Graham - perform. For Pooh Kaye, the moment of recognition occurred when she saw a dancer named Barbara Dilley crawl, in a performance by the avant-garde Grand Union company in 1972.

title: MUSIC: SKROWACZEWSKI
description: STANISLAW SKROWACZEWSKI, the conductor who made his Mostly Mozart debut in the Monday-Wednesday pair of concerts at Avery Fisher Hall, is no stranger here, having appeared with various musical organizations since his New York Philharmonic debut in 1960. His Metropolitan Opera debut took place in 1969 with a Mozart opera, ''The Magic Flute.''

title: Canadian Exports Drop
description: A slowdown in the United States economy was responsible for a 3 percent drop in Canadian exports in June, the Government said today. Canada sold $9.7 billion worth of goods in June while its imports totaled $8.5 billion.

title: A Smithsonian Anniversary
description: Twenty years ago, the secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, S. Dillon Ripley, established the Resident Associate Program, and 8,000 Washingtonians signed up. It was an outreach effort, to acquaint local residents with the broad range of museum activities and facilities through lectures, tours and trips all over the area.

title: SCREEN: 'DIM DUM' BY WANG
description: ''Dim Sum: A Little Bit of Heart,'' Wayne Wang's first film since his original, wise and funny ''Chan Is Missing'' (1982), looks as if it were a movie in search of itself. It's so gentle that it seems to apologize for taking up our time, though it certainly means to be a serious contemplation of the erosion of traditional values among Chinese-Americans living in San Francisco.

title: ART: GUGGENHEIM'S RECENT ADDITIONS
description: WHEN a museum mounts an exhibition of recent acquisitions, it always lays itself bare. Acquisitions tell us something about a museum's collection, about where a museum wants to go and about its curatorial eye and taste. They also encourage us to ask questions about acquisitions policy. Why and how do particular works of art enter a museum collection?

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., said it would post a gain of $17.5 million, or 71 cents a share, in the third quarter on its sale of 5 million shares of James River Corp. common stock at $32.10 a share.

title: Murray A. Geisler; Improved Logistics for Military Plans
description: Dr. Murray A. Geisler, a leading authority on military logistics and operations research, died of leukemia Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 68 years old.

title: HOUSTON MAYOR ENTERS RACE WITH LONG-SECRET WEAPON: HER HUMAN SIDE
description: Meet the new Mayor of Houston: She is Kathryn J. Whitmire, not to be confused with Kathryn J. Whitmire, the old Mayor. Mrs. Whitmire is trying to prove to voters that there is more of a human being behind the staid urban manager as she faces a powerful challenge for re-election from Louie Welch, 66 years old, a former five-term Mayor of Houston.

title: Clinton Garden Party
description: A party in celebration of the Clinton Community Garden will be held tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the garden, West 48th Street between Ninth and Tenth Avenues.

title: 34 Nkomo Followers Are Reported Seized
description: Thirty-four supporters of Zimbabwe's opposition political party have been arrested in the last two weeks and are being held for questioning, according to the police.

title: VENTREX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MOORE MEDICAL PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Per share figures reflect a 3-for-1 stock split paid in May 1985.

title: Suspect in Killing Attempts Suicide
description: A 65-year-old Queens man charged with murder in the suffocation of his cancer-stricken wife last month was in critical condition last night, apparently after a suicide attempt, the police said.

title: DREXEL STUDYING ROLE IN MGM DEAL
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that, subject to further investigation, it expected to tell Ted Turner within a few days that it feels ''highly confident'' it can raise the nearly $1 billion in cash he needs to buy the MGM/UA Entertainment Company.

title: CARIBBEAN CARNIVAL OF MUSIC AND DANCE
description: THE Caribbean Carnival parade that is scheduled to begin Sunday afternoon at 1:30, at the corner of West 58th Street and 10th Avenue, will be a mixture of Caribbean, Latin American and West African traditions. It will wind its way up Amsterdam Avenue to Damrosch Park at Lincoln Center, and each of the parade's distinct cultural elements will find expression in performances of music and dance, from 2:30 to 5 P.M.

title: Mansfield Heard From
description: Mike Mansfield, who celebrated his 82d birthday last March, has told the White House he would like to return from the assignment as Ambassador to Japan that he has held since 1977. He has served similar notice on several occasions in recent years, but this time Administration sources say the former Senate majority leader really means it.

title: Texas Bank Cuts Payout
description: The First City Bankcorporation of Texas said it slashed its quarterly dividend to 15 cents, from 32 1/2 cents, because of the deterioration of principal lending markets.

title: U.S. Women Fall
description: The United States women's national volleyball team today suffered its fourth straight defeat in Japan, losing to the Japanese national team, 15-7, 15-5, 15-5. The fifth match in the six-game good-will series will be played Saturday at Okazaki.

title: A Comic Book Fair
description: For those who wish to embellish a comic book collection, or perhaps start a new one, a comic book and collectibles fair will be held Sunday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. at the Roosevelt Hotel, Madison Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Driesell Stays Put
description: The money was tempting, the fringe benefits were even better, and the offer had nostalgic appeal. But Lefty Driesell, the Maryland basketball coach, decided that a chance for a national championship in his adopted state was more attractive than a $150,000 annual salary, a $250,000 beach house and a return to his Virginia birthplace.

title: Olympian Feat
description: How serious are the French about defeating rival bids from Barcelona, Amsterdam, Belgrade, Brisbane and New Delhi, and thereby winning the right to hold the 1992 Olympic Games in Paris? Pretty darned serious. So much so that Alain Danet, the president of the Paris organizers' executive board, has set for himself the task of visiting every single one of the International Olympic Committee's 92 members before the I.O.C. votes on the site next year.

title: CAVCO INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: DOUGHTIE'S FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ACS ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Suit by Sex Shops On Times Sq. Fails
description: A Federal appeals court panel yesterday upheld the $2 billion Times Square redevelopment plan against a challenge from four owners of sex-oriented shops that would be displaced from 42d Street by the project.

title: FILMS OF TRUFFAUT AND HIS FAVORITES
description: Who can resist a man so in love with the movies that as a boy he played hooky 200 times to see his first films, braving nervous cramps and headaches and parental wrath; whose every work breathed wit and humanity; who changed forever the way films look and how we look at them? This was Francois Truffaut, who died last October at the age of 52.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose $649.1 million, to $210.08 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Inc. has signed a $300 million contract with Nynex Material Enterprises, the company said. Under the agreement, Northern Telecom is to supply New England Telephone and New York Telephone, two Nynex companies, with digital switching systems, computerized operator stations and software.

title: David Golden, 77, Is Dead; Film Executive and Manager
description: David Golden, the motion picture executive producer of ''Love Story'' and production manager of ''Kramer Versus Kramer'' and ''Fame,'' died Wednesday after a car accident in Oregon. He was 77 years old and lived in Beaverton, Ore., and Manhattan.

title: Grayson Hall, Actress, Of Stage, TV and Film
description: Grayson Hall, a stage, television and film actress who was nominated for an Academy Award in 1964, died of cancer Wednesday at New York Hospital. She was 58 years old and lived in Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: UNITED STATES VACATION REORTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Zeffirelli's 'Romeo' At the Metropolitan
description: Franco Zeffirelli's film ''Romeo and Juliet'' will be shown tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82d Street, as part of a series devoted to films set during the Renaissance.

title: Parks, Piers, Pollution and Westway
description: Westway is down, not out, and still worth fighting for on the merits. Federal Judge Thomas Griesa's decision blocking a landfill permit for the $2 billion highway and waterfront development project is a serious blow. If it is upheld on appeal, the project is dead. The appeals process itself might take months, pushing the court's decision past Sept. 30, the deadline for localities to exchange Federal highway funds for mass-transit money.

title: CELINA FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $21,920. c-Net loss.

title: Nets Deny Hiring Coach
description: A Nets official, denying reports that the club has made its choice for a new head coach, said yesterday that it did not expect to announce the selection until Monday at the earliest.

title: BEHIND THE NEW BASEBALL PACT, COMPROMISES
description: Neither representatives of the major league baseball teams nor the players claimed victory yesterday as a result of the two-day baseball strike, and there was disagreement over the role played by Commissioner Peter Ueberroth in reaching a settlement.

title: BALANCE COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss from discontinued operations of $710,189.

title: NORTHWESTERN NATIONAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FLAKEY JAKE'S INC reports earnings for 12 wks to June 19
Union Head Active In Talks for T.W.A.
description: Vicki L. Frankovich has been active in the flight attendants' union for most of her 16 years at Trans World Airlines, and in that time she has helped negotiate four contracts in bargaining sessions with management.

title: Day Camp for the Homeless
description: Children pounded purple modeling clay, and sometimes pounded each other. Blocks, jigsaw puzzles, books, crayons and toys littered the floor in a typical nursery school mess.

title: Bidders for T.W.A. Said to Be Talking
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor who has all but gained control of Trans World Airlines, held negotiations yesterday with representatives of his rival bidder, Frank A. Lorenzo, sources close to the situation said.

title: Hard Thinking on a Soft Landing for the Dollar
description: To the Editor:

title: SEEKING THE PROPER MIX OF DRINKING AND MUSIC
description: When this city was gripped by recession three years ago and unemployed steelworkers were going hungry, Bruce Springsteen gave tens of thousands of dollars to local food banks.

title: Park to Purchase 2 Radio Stations
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. said that it had agreed to sell WPAT-AM and WPAT-FM, which broadcast to the New York City area from Paterson, N.J., to Park Communications Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Armed Marshals Begin To Escort U.S. Flights
description: Armed air marshals have begun flying on a limited number of United States commercial airline flights as part of the Government's increased effort to prevent hijackings, an airline industry source said today.

title: ACID RAIN THREATENS WATER IN WEST, CONSERVATIONISTS SAY
description: Officials of two environmental groups asserted today that thousands of lakes and streams in the western United States, including waters in some of the best-known national parks, were highly susceptible to damage from acid rain.

title: STUDY FINDS GENETIC DAMAGE IN PLANTS AFTER ATOMIC BLAST
description: Scientists have found evidence of genetic damage in plants exposed to radiation from the atomic bombing of Nagasaki four decades ago.

title: LCS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'Motown Revue' a Reprise Of 60's Variety Shows
description: An eerie sense of time-warp permeates ''The Motown Revue Starring Smokey Robinson,'' NBC's amiable attempt to revive old-time television variety shows. Musically, the hour-long program gambles on the notion that Motown's 1960's song catalogue is a communal touchstone for millions of pop nostalgists who can't get enough of those oldies but goodies.

title: CURBS BOLSTERED
description: Sixteen more people were reported slain here in violence overnight, bringing to 20 the number killed since renewed riots, looting and clashes with the police erupted in black townships around this southeastern city three days ago.

title: BRONX MAN SHOT TWICE IN DISPUTE OVER SEAT ON CROWDED IRT TRAIN
description: A passenger on a crowded East Side subway train yesterday morning suddenly rose to his feet, pulled out a small handgun and fired two bullets into a man with whom he had been arguing over a seat, the police said. Five other passengers were hurt in the stampede that followed.

title: EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
ALLEGHENY & WESTERN RY reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CARDINALS' TUDOR WINS ONE-HITTER
description: John Tudor pitched a one-hitter and Andy Van Slyke and Terry Pendleton hit consecutive home runs to cap a five-run first inning, powering the St. Louis Cardinals to an 8-0 victory tonight over the Chicago Cubs.

title: United Energy's Stock Up Sharply
description: The price of United Energy Resources Inc.'s stock rose sharply yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange as speculation continued that the company would soon disclose a takeover bid from the Midcon Corporation.

title: AMERICAN PRECISION INDUSRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in June 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 9, 1985
description: International

title: AMERICAN BANKERS INSURNCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $831,000 for the quarter and $951,000 for the six months. c-Including capital gains of $698,000 for the quarter and $1,034,000 for the six months.

title: NATIONAL GUARDIAN ALARM SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $192,000 for the quarter and $344,000 for the 6 months.

title: Renaissance Festival
description: Jousting, drama and other medieval merriment continue this weekend at the New York Renaissance Festival in Sterling Forest at Tuxedo, N.Y. Appearing tomorrow to oversee many of the day's events will be Regis Philbin, co-host of ABC-TV's ''Morning Show.''

title: ROLE IN NICARAGUA DESCRIBED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration acknowledged today that officials on the National Security Council were involved in the operations of the insurgents who are seeking to topple the Nicaraguan Government.

title: Peru Chief Continues State of Emergency
description: Peru's new Government extended a state of emergency in six states today in reaction to rebel attacks, including a car-bombing Wednesday outside police headquarters that seriously wounded five people.

title: Coca-Cola Attire Draws an Outcry
description: The Coca-Cola Company seems to be getting the kind of attention it would rather not have these days.

title: Group Says the Kremlin Let 174 Jews Leave Last Month
description: The Intergovernmental Committee for Migration said today that the Soviet Union allowed 174 Jews to emigrate in July, the highest monthly total since December 1982.

title: IT'S ALL AMERICA'S FAULT
description: Greece is becoming sharply polarized again. The villages have two coffee shops - one where supporters of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Socialist Government gather and one for the opposition, so they can denounce each other in friendly surroundings free of inhibition.

title: Weighty Problem
description: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants knows about defensive talent himself, and so he can understand the disappointment of Buddy Ryan, the Chicago Bears' defensive coordinator, who became so upset with William (The Refrigerator) Perry the other day that he called him ''a wasted draft choice and a waste of money.''

title: Bridge: Third-Seeded Team Beaten In Opening of Spingold Play
description: First-round play in the Spingold Knockout Teams here Wednesday produced one of the biggest upsets in recent bridge history. A group of stars that included three members of the 1985 United States world championship team went down to four unknowns.

title: Toys for Tomorrow's Green Berets
description: To the Editor:

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A RUMOR OF REVOLT: The ''Great Negro Plot'' in Colonial New York. By Thomas J. Davis. 320 pages. Free Press. $19.95.

title: Plant Blast Kills Worker
description: An explosion that rattled windows three miles away ripped apart a small metal building at the plant of a military contractor today, killing one worker and injuring seven, the authorities said.

title: Girl, 7, Shot in Head From a Passing Auto
description: A 7-year-old South Bronx girl was shot in the head and critically wounded last night when someone in a passing car fired three shots at an apartmnt building and hit the girl who was standing on a fire escape, the police said.

title: MEYERS PARKING SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Zero-Coupon Securities Introduced in London
description: Quadrex Securities Ltd. yesterday introduced zero-coupon securities to the British Government bond market, with an offering of $:309.3 million face amount of zero-coupon issues, known informally as ''stags.''

title: Moscow Trips Cited in Trial
description: Soon after an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation began an affair with a Russian woman, she and a Soviet consular official traveled separately to Moscow at the same time, evidence in the agent's trial showed today.

title: Ex-Town Worker Tells Of Payments in Nassau
description: A former employee of the Town of Hempstead's Sanitation Department testified today that he lost a job promotion in 1973 because he stopped contributing to the Republican Party.

title: Rittereiser Gets 2d Post
description: Robert P. Rittereiser, who became president of the E. F. Hutton Group Inc. two months ago, has been named to the additional post of chief operating officer, the company said yesterday.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Recalled Joe Johnson, pitcher, from Richmond of the International League.

title: Royal Dutch Net Falls
description: The Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reported today that second-quarter earnings dropped 26 percent, to $814 million, from $1.1 billion in the same period last year. Revenues fell 5 percent, to $22.9 billion, from $24.1 billion in the 1984 quarter.

title: FEAR VISITS HOMETOWN OF UGANDA'S FALLEN LEADER
description: An unnatural stillness, overlaid with sorrow, has enveloped this town in the northern region of Uganda.

title: PROCTER & GAMBLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SUPRADUR COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HANDEL UPDATE BY MOZART
description: If Mozart were here to witness our preoccupation with period instruments and ancient performing practices, he would probably wrinkle his brow in puzzlement and go on about his business.

title: UNION SPECIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. AND SOUTH AFRICA AIDES MEET IN VIENNA OVER 'SERIOUS SITUATION'
description: Senior American and South African officials met today at the United States Embassy in Vienna at Pretoria's request to discuss the situation in South Africa, the White House and the State Department said.

title: 3 FACE CHARGES IN PLOT TO EVADE GASOLINE TAXES
description: Three gasoline distributors were indicted today on charges of evading an estimated $1.5 million in gasoline taxes.

title: FAUROT, GUILBEAU ARE CRUCIAL FOR JETS
description: There are plenty of questions unanswered in the new defensive formation for the Jets, who hope that Ron Faurot and Rusty Guilbeau will provide solutions to two of the problems.

title: AUCTIONS
description: THOUSANDS of examples of Kenneth Lynch's metalwork - including a bronze lamp made for Louis Comfort Tiffany, steel doors from the Chrysler Building and iron baptistery gates from St. Patrick's Cathedral -will be auctioned later this month at his 15-acre property on Route 7 in Wilton, Conn. The sale, organized by Guernsey's, one of New York's smaller, more enterprising auction houses, is expected to total about $1.5 million.

title: Article 179091 -- No Title
description: MTV Networks Inc. said yesterday that Forstmann Little & Company, an investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, and a group of MTV's management had offered $31 a share, or a total of $471 million, for the cable service company.

title: CONNECTICUT G.O.P. UPHELD ON PLAN TO OPEN PRIMARIES
description: A Federal appeals court ruled yesterday that Connecticut cannot bar the Republican Party from allowing unaffiliated voters to take part in its primary elections.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about the economic impact of the baseball strike misidentified a professor at the Wharton School of Finance and Commerce. He is Dr. Edward B. Shils.

title: SABINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Latest quarter and six months includes a net gain of $251,000 on the sale of non-oil and gas assets.

title: THE I.B.M. SLIPPAGE IN JAPAN
description: Amid concerns in the United States that the Japanese computer industry is overtaking the American industry, one of the toughest competitors in America, the International Business Machines Corporation, has been encountering rough going here.

title: COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $117,000. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $178.

title: ARAB LEAGUE'S SUMMIT MEETING IS EXTENDED
description: Arab leaders extended their summit meeting to Friday, seeking ways to support a Jordanian-Palestinian move toward peace talks with Israel without further alienating hard-line nations that boycotted the meeting.

title: MEESE DISCUSSES PRESSER CASE
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, saying he is uncertain how much Senate investigators want to know about the Justice Department's decision to drop an investigation of the Teamsters Union president, Jackie Presser, said today that his agency would ''cooperate fully'' in the Senate investigation.

title: Multimedia Sweetens Plan
description: Multimedia Inc. said yesterday that it would sweeten slightly the recapitalization plan it was offering to shareholders. The move comes three weeks after Multimedia paid a large premium for the 10 percent stake in the company held by the Washington investor Jack Kent Cooke.

title: Haitian Art Displayed At Central Park Gallery
description: Art from Haiti is featured in the ''World of Enchantment,'' an exhibition at Central Park's Arsenal Gallery. The exhibition includes more than 30 paintings, iron sculptures, art objects and painted screens, some of which are for sale.

title: ART: NEW PAINTINGS ON DISPLAY AT THE MET
description: OTHER parts of other museums may lay down and die in the middle of August, but the European paintings department at the Metropolitan Museum of Art bestirs itself in ways that never cease to amuse and surprise. Just to begin with, visitors who patrol the Andre Meyer galleries this weekend will find (on loan from a private collection) a masterpiece too long lost to view - the small version of Seurat's ''Poseuses.'' Just a few feet away are no fewer than 19 paintings by Cezanne. Some of these are loans which, though familiar from previous summers, will never be stale.

title: APPLAUSE FOR LAUREN
description: It was a small presentation of about 50 pieces, and it took about 15 minutes from the first white T-shirt that opened the show to the flowered pants with blue or purple satin bathrobe coats that ended it. It turned out to be a smash. Ralph Lauren had captured the current feeling for serene, uncomplicated clothes that everyone would like to wear right now. By the end of the day of resort openings, people were stopping each other on Seventh Avenue to tell each other how good the Lauren collection was.

title: Laurel and Hardy, Plus Klezmer Music
description: Live performances of klezmer music will accompany screenings of six silent Laurel and Hardy shorts Sunday at the Carnegie Hall Cinema, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street. The films - ''Duck Soup,'' ''You're Darn Tootin,' '' ''Double Whoopee,'' ''Liberty,'' ''Habeus Corpus'' and ''Big Business'' - were made in the late 1920's.

title: CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $131,400 for the reversal of a tax credit.

title: Outdoor Art Exhibit
description: The Central Park South Outdoor Art Exhibit continues this weekend along 59th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday.

title: EMPLOYERS CASUALTY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $976,769 for the quarter and $1,314,948 for the six months.

title: INTERNATIONAL REMOTE IMAGNG SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company reported no sale for the year-ago second quarter.

title: QUEST FOR PRIVACY DRIVES REALTY BOOM IN LITCHFIELD
description: George M. DeVoe banked his single-engine plane and gestured down to an ultramarine sparkle half lost in an expanse of forest green.

title: SALE REFLECTS MARKET CHANGES
description: Where in New York does Alydar always beat Affirmed? Only at the annual Saratoga yearling sales, where the first two nights of auction results this week reflect the changing commercial breeding market.

title: FIRST CAROLINA INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PANEL SEEKS TO CLOSE PARK WHERE 2 WERE SLAIN
description: The Oakland Borough Council decided tonight to try to find a way to close down the private park where 2 people were killed and 19 others wounded or injured in a gun battle Sunday.

title: SPRINT SAYS LOSSES COULD GROW IN '86
description: Sprint Communications Inc., the big long-distance telephone company that has been buffeted by market changes since the breakup of A.T.&T. said yesterday that its losses could widen in 1986.

title: Dining Out Guide: Eating Out of Doors
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: LARRY FORGIONE, the Pied Piper of American-produced food and wine, earned well-deserved kudos as the innovative chef of the River Cafe several years ago, and more recently at his own restaurant, An American Place, on Lexington Avenue. His latest venture is an eclectic little grillery in the new Morgans Hotel on Madison Avenue called Morgans Restaurant.

title: NAT WARMAN
description: Nat Warman, the president of the Dumont Camera Corporation, a major Manhattan supplier of photographic and electronic equipment, died of cancer Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Drug Co., Pawtucket, R.I., said James Salmanson had been appointed president and chief executive, succeeding Donald Salmanson, who has retired.

title: Officer Shoots Man in an Eviction
description: A man being evicted from a Times Square hotel attacked two police officers with a makeshift spear yesterday and was shot in the left shoulder by one of the officers, the police said.

title: Friend of Quiet
description: To the Editor:

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SLATTERY GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $76,000 for the quarter. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $102,000 for the quarter.

title: Don't Hand Conrail To Norfolk Southern
description: To the Editor:

title: White House Transformers To Get a Nontoxic Coolant
description: Electrical transformers in the White House complex will be drained and filled with nontoxic coolant after the discovery that two pieces of the equipment were leaking polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCB's, in an underground vault, it was announced today.

title: Sosnoff Holds 9.5% of Caesars
description: Martin Sosnoff, the New York investor, said yesterday that he owns 2.8 million shares of Caesars World Inc., or 9.5 percent of the total outstanding, and has requested that the company give him a seat on its board.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT SMALL BUSINESS INESTMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income figures represent net investment income.

title: A CHAT WITH VONNEGUT (AND KILGORE TROUT)
description: ''The Creative Edge,'' Public Broadcasting's weekly series on contemporary artists, looks at Kurt Vonnegut in its latest program. Mr. Vonnegut, the author of, among other works, ''Slaughterhouse Five,'' ''Cat's Cradle'' and ''Deadeye Dick,'' talks about himself. From time to time, Kilgore Trout, an alter-ego from his novels, appears in a dramatization, and at the end of the program they meet. On television, it's an amusing conceit.

title: HAPPY BIRTHDAY , XEROX 914
description: When this baby came into the world 25 years ago, it weighed 648 pounds and measured 48 inches to the top of the control panel. The father, the inventor Chester Carlson, and the mother, the Haloid Xerox Corporation, named it the Xerox 914 Copier.

title: 3 Miami Air Controllers Dismissed Over Drugs
description: The Federal Aviation Administration said today that it had dismissed three Miami air traffic controllers for purportedly peddling cocaine and marijuana at work and had ordered six others to enter rehabilitation programs.

title: REICHMANNS PLAN SALE OF SOME OF GULF ASSETS
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. is planning to announce as early as Friday that it will sell its refining and marketing assets in western Canada to Petro-Canada, the Government-owned company, for more than $500 million (American money), according to oil industry sources. Spokesmen for both companies refused to comment.

title: FILM: YIDDISH CINEMA
description: THE Yiddish movie was a phenomenon of modern times, sired by a triumph of the young century's technology, the talking picture, in 1927, and strangled, in large part, by the century's technological ability to murder en masse most of those who spoke the language in Europe. The linguistic assimilation of immigrant offspring in America completed the cycle.

title: SCHOOL'S DRUG-TEST PLAN MEETS CRITICISM IN JERSEY
description: A decision by the school board here to require all high school students to be tested once a year for alcohol and drug use ran into immediate opposition today from the American Civil Liberties Union and some education groups.

title: Diner's Journal
description: ''I HAVEN'T waited in line so long to meet somebody since I met the Pope,'' declared Jerry Rothmer, extending his hand to Paul Prudhomme, who was sitting at a small table signing copies of his cookbook.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $11,656,000, or 16 cents a share, for the quarter and $22,138,000 for the six months. c-After extraordinary losses of $19,908,000 for the quarter and $3,738,000 for the six months.

title: A Worthwhile Trivial Pursuit
description: Anyone who likes baseball trivia would simply love Brad Curtis, because he is an exceptionally devoted champion of his chosen pastime: baseball trivia. And he puts it to work for him, too. Curtis, a 49-year-old pension consultant in San Francisco, grew up in Fairfield, Conn., where his father was a semipro pitcher. Pop frequently took young Brad on outings to Ebbets Field, the Polo Grounds and Yankee Stadium, and baseball talk abounded in the Curtis home. The years slipped by, and the boy became a man, but he never lost his childhood passion for the summer game. And several months ago he got an idea: Why not share his glee with a large number of disadvantaged kids by taking them one afternoon to watch the Giants at Candlestick Park? And, more than that, why not make accomplishment of this goal as much fun for himself as he possibly could?

title: Churches Compile List of Drug Sellers
description: A group of Brooklyn churches has given the police a list of 72 storefront drug-selling operations, and the Police Commissioner said yesterday that the department would seek to get enough evidence to close down at least 60 of them by the end of the year.

title: POPE IN TOGO AT START OF AFRICAN TOUR
description: Pope John Paul II, arriving here today to a festival of singing and dancing, declared that the Roman Catholic Church was open to traditional African customs and sought to preach a faith that was ''authentically Christian and authentically African.''

title: JOHNSON ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net gain of $178,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of real property.

title: RAPHAEL PHILIPSON, A TEACHER WHO NURTURED WRITERS, DIES
description: Raphael Philipson, who praised, chastised and encouraged generations of writers during nearly three decades as faculty adviser to the student newspaper at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx, died Monday at Cottage Hospital in Santa Barbara, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Bulgari Official Listed as Fugitive
description: Nicola Bulgari, an official of the Bulgari jewelry store in Manhattan, was listed as a fugitive yesterday when he failed to appear in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to face charges in a sales-tax evasion case.

title: JAPANESE RECALL ATTACK THAT WASN'T
description: The once-independent city of Kokura, now carved into two wards of this industrial center, is the lucky stepchild of Japan's nuclear suffering.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about indictments against the Bulgari jewelry store and the Christie Brothers Fur Corporation misattributed a quotation in some editions. It was Michael F. Armstrong, a lawyer for Bulgari, who said, ''Criminal prosecutions will not increase tax revenue but simply will cause customers to go to the trouble of having items delivered.'' It was not Finance Commissioner Paul Crotty.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Second Chances in Space
description: The shuttle Challenger is back from space after a successful mission. The reasons for its triumph underscore the obstacles that threaten a far more ambitious space machine - the ''Star Wars'' defense shield.

title: Note and Bond Prices Erratic
description: Treasury note and bond prices moved erratically yesterday, but closed at higher levels as the Treasury sold $6.5 billion of new 30-year bonds to complete a record sized three-part financing at interest rates that were lower than many analysts expected a week ago.

title: TOYS FOR TOMORROW'S GREEN BERETS
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK-FOOTED FERRET ALMOST EXTINCT AS PLAGUE STRIKES DOWN ITS PREY
description: The black-footed ferret, which made a significant comeback a few years ago, is once again on the brink of extinction, wildlife researchers reported this week.

title: TERROR GANG ACTIVE IN 1970'S
description: The Red Army Faction, which authorities suspect of involvement in the bombing at Rhein-Main Air Base, is the successor organization of a band that gained notoriety in the 1970's under the name of the Baader-Meinhof Gang.

title: BEL FUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $94,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $114,000, or 2 cents a share, for the six months.

title: 5 Ex-Officers in Philadelphia Indicted on Payoff Charges
description: Five former city police officers, including a chief inspector, were indicted today on charges of taking payoffs in return for protecting illegal vice operations, bringing to 34 the total number of officers charged in a continuing Federal investigation of corruption.

title: 'Dreamgirls' Closes Sunday
description: ''Dreamgirls,'' the Broadway musical directed and co-choreographed by Michael Bennett, will play its 1,522d and last performance Sunday afternoon at the Imperial Theater, ending a run that lasted more than three and a half years. The musical, which won six Tony Awards in 1982, had a book and lyrics by Tom Eyen and music by Henry Krieger; Michael Peters was the co-choreographer. Featured in the cast are Deborah Burrell, Teresa Burrell, Lawrence Clayton, Vondie Curtis-Hall, Clinton Derricks-Carroll, Loretta Devine, Roz Ryan, Eric Riley and Weyman Thompson.

title: OFFER MADE TO AMEND GAS PACTS
description: Prices that pipeline companies have been forced to pay for natural gas could be significantly reduced as a result of negotiations under way between the Columbia Gas Transmission Corporation and its gas producers.

title: Gordon Fisher Is Dead; Southam Papers' Head
description: Gordon Fisher, president and chief executive officer of Southam Inc., which publishes 15 daily newspapers in Canada, died Thursday of liver cancer in Toronto, a family spokesman said. He was 56.

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ROYAL DUTCH/SHELL GROUP OF COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: For Royal Dutch Petroleum net income equals $1.90 and $4.73 a share for the latest quarter and 6 months and $2.49 and $5.73 a share for the year-ago quarter and 6 months For Shell Transport & Trading net income equals $1.11 and $2.76 a share for the latest quarter and 6 months and $1.52 and $3.50 a share for the year-ago quarter and 6 months. Both Royal Dutch Petroleum and Shell Transport & Trading are listed on the New York Stock Excahnge.

title: WILLIAM L. CHAPMAN 2d
description: William L. Chapman 2d, a managing director of Liberty Capital Management, a New York investment advisory concern, died of heart failure last Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 56 years old.

title: CONCERT: KIRCHNER AT TANGLEWOOD
description: The 1985 Tanglewood Festival of Contemporary Music came to a close tonight with a fine, thoughtful, well-balanced orchestral program in the Theater-Concert Hall. It was conducted by Leon Kirchner and included music by Roger Sessions, David Del Tredici and Mr. Kirchner himself.

title: Gun Arrest at White House
description: A woman carrying a loaded pistol was arrested today as she waited in line to tour the White House with her family, the Secret Service said. The .25-caliber pistol was detected when the woman, Deborah Darnell, 28 years old, of Paducah, Ky., went through a metal detector.

title: Flags
description: A sanitation truck, sweepers twirling merrily, lumbered up Broadway yesterday morning.

title: I.B.M. HAS SLOW START WITH ITS JX
description: With great fanfare, I.B.M. Japan introduced its JX personal computer almost a year ago. More powerful than I.B.M.'s ill-fated home computer in the United States, the PCjr, and smaller than a PC, the JX boasted sparkling color graphics and the capability to use either Japanese or English software. Its introduction marked I.B.M.'s advancement into Japan's small business and home marketplace, potentially a huge base of computer users in a gadget-happy country.

title: SCREEN: 'DANCE WITH A STRANGER'
description: LIKE Francois Truffaut's ''Peau Douce'' (1964), the very good new English film titled ''Dance With a Stranger'' takes an utterly commonplace crime of passion and finds something very particular in it. Unlike Truffaut's hard-edged romantic drama, a fictional tale about the last, fatal liaison of a philandering literary celebrity, the new film, based on a true story, contains no characters who would have had any claim to fame except for the events that ended their story.

title: Dow Moves Up 4.82; Other Indexes Advance
description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday as investors were encouraged by the warm reception given the Treasury's three-stage refunding.

title: OPTROTECH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW YORK IN AUGUST A FEAST OF FESTIVALS
description: IN these lazy days of August, New York traditionally takes a moment to catch its breath and celebrate its rich cultural diversity with citywide festivals. For a month, the city ceases feeling like the Big Apple -the all-consuming hub of world communications and commerce - and becomes a sprawling collection of community events that swirl together a rainbow of musical colors and accents. This weekend, the array of indoor and outdoor programs in the city constitutes a veritable summer Super Bowl of activity in both the folk and classical arts.

title: FOOTE CONE & BELDING COMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect merger withGoldin- Harris Communications Inc. accounted for on a pooling of interests basis.

title: FILM: 'SUMMER RENTAL,' DIRECTED BY CARL REINER
description: ''SUMMER RENTAL'' is a wan but good-natured hot-weather comedy, with a big debt to ''National Lampoon's Vacation'' plus a few nice touches of its own. John Candy is on familiar territory as the clownish patriarch of an all-American suburban family, but Mr. Candy is fun to watch under any circumstances. ''Summer Rental,'' which was directed by Carl Reiner and opens today at Loews State and other theaters, starts out by showing him under extreme duress, living the kind of workaday life that is terribly stressful. It then sends him on the kind of vacation that's even more so.

GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday 'BEAST' ON STAGE ''In the Belly of the Beast,'' the book by Jack Henry Abbott, who spent 25 of his first 37 years in prison, has been adapted as a play and updated to include references to Mr. Abbott's 1982 trial for fatally stabbing Richard Adan, an actor and waiter, outside an East Village restaurant. Mr. Abbott, sentenced to 15 years to life for manslaughter, is now serving time for another offense at the Federal Penitentiary in Marion, Ill. The play, adapted by Adrian Hall and the director, Robert Woodruff, will be presented at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, by the Mark Taper Forum of Los Angeles in association with Seymour Morgenstern. Performances this weekend are 8 tonight and 9 P.M. tomorrow. Tickets are $20. Information and reservations: 242-0800. STUFF OF DREAMS Such stuff as dreams are made on -dramatic vignettes with stark black-and-white images and primal, animalistic sounds - will be depicted in an experimental dance and theater performance by Pam Quinn, a choreographer and dancer, and Michael O'Connor, an actor and writer, as part of the Dance Theater Workshop's series ''The Out-of-Towners (and Others).'' The piece, ''Other People's Dreams,'' and two other dance and theater works, will be performed at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street, at 8 P.M. today and tomorrow. Tickets are $7 and reservations are recommended. Information: 924-0077. Saturday MARSALIS AT WESTBURY Wynton Marsalis, the trumpeter who won Grammy awards in 1984 and 1985 in both jazz and classical categories, will be playing jazz, and only jazz, at the Westbury Music Fair at 8 P.M Saturday.

title: TEWELL SHOOTS 64 TO LEAD IN PGA
description: The first round of the 67th PGA Championship today was reminiscent of the first round of the 114th British Open last month, because one of the tour's steady but average golfers, Doug Tewell, set a Cherry Hills Country Club course record of seven-under-par 64.

title: A CONDOMINIUM UPTOWN FOR ART-ORIENTED BUYERS
description: New York City is justly famous for the way its neighborhoods can change character in just one or two blocks, and nowhere are such transitions more apparent than in the east 60's of Manhattan.

title: CAR BOMB KILLS 2 ON A U.S. AIR BASE IN WEST GERMANY
description: A car bomb exploded today outside the headquarters building at this United States military base, killing two Americans and wounding about 20 people, both Americans and West Germans.

title: A VAST SEA OF CHINESE THREATENS TIBET
description: It is now more than 30 years since China forcefully occupied Tibet. In this period, our religion and culture has been destroyed. The people of Tibet have suffered tremendous physical and economic deprivation, and at least 1.2 million have died as a direct result of the occupation. But never, even in the worst of times, did the Tibetans lose their distinct national identity. That is the threat we face today: The complete assimilation and absorption of our people by a vast sea of Chinese settlers streaming across our borders.

title: Market Place;   The Rebound By Insurers
description: WALL STREET professionals seem to have finally come to a consensus about the property and casualty insurance business: A major rebound in underwriting profits is under way. But that is where the agreement ends.

title: Williams and the Judds
description: The country music star Don Williams is appearing with the Judds, the mother-daughter country vocal duo, at the Westbury Music Fair tonight at 8 o'clock. Tickets are $15.75 and are available at the box office, at Ticketron locations, or by calling (516) 333-0533. To get to the fair, at 960 Brush Hollow Road in Westbury, L.I., take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 40 or the Northern State Parkway to Exit 342 and follow the signs.

title: Hutton Fined by Maine
description: E. F. Hutton & Company has been fined $7,500 by the state for failing to check, as required by state law, whether Maine investors could absorb possible losses in a movie distribution deal, Attorney General James E. Tierney said today. The state negotiated a settlement requiring Silver Screen, a Delaware limited partnership, to offer refunds to all Maine investors who bought the securities. Hutton has an interest in Silver Screen, which buys movie rights from Walt Disney Productions and resells them, said Dennis J. Harnish, an assistant attorney general.

title: Party Boat Trips Successful
description: 1Margate, N.J.:Bluefish have become somewhat scarce, but medium-sized Atlantic bonito are plentiful a few miles offshore. Fluke fishing in bay waters remains excellent and a few weakfish are being caught in the same area. Barnegat, N.J.: Day and night party-boat bluefish excursions continue. Seaside Park, N.J.: Weakfishing in Barnegat Inlet remains excellent and fluke fishing in the inlet is good. Point Pleasant, N.J.: Party-boat anglers are enjoying good catches of fluke in half-day ocean trips, and the half-night bluefish excursions are equally successful. #2Sea Bright, N.J.:Anglers are having a ball with 2- to 4-pound members of weakfish in the Navesink River. Large weakfish are also plentiful in the bay.

description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that the United States ''has to have'' more than 50 MX intercontinental missiles if it is to pose a credible deterrent to the Soviet Union. He indicated he would again ask for a full force of 100 missiles next year.
