description: The United States Football League filed a $90 million antitrust suit in Federal court today, charging the National Football League conspired to monopolize professional football and undermine the Oakland Invaders.

title: GIANTS' FLOWERS TRANSFORMS
description: In his bachelor days, said Larry Flowers, ''I was a wild guy who would go out and party instead of studying the playbook.'' A year ago, he married ''a very lovely lady, a smart lady,'' and he said his life was better.

title: CABARET: BRADLEY SINGS POP
description: BRUCE VERNON BRADLEY, an Air Force lieutenant colonel who turned to the theater after his retirement in 1977, won favorable attention in his off-Broadway debut a few years ago singing British music hall material in a revue called ''Give My Regards to Leicester Square.'' In his cabaret act on Tuesday at Jan Wallman's, 28 Cornelius Street, his program went well beyond the British music hall tradition to American pop songs, musical theater and even a song in Yiddish.

title: U.S. Judge Strikes Down Texas Picketing Laws
description: Several Texas laws restricting picketing that led to a five-year dispute between vegetable growers and union organizers have been struck down by a Federal district judge, who ruled they violated constitutional rights to free speech.

How to Fight AIDS
description: A million Americans have been exposed to AIDS virus, and the number falling victim to the deadly disease climbs remorselessly: 1,000 new cases in 1982, 2,500 in 1983, 5,000 in 1984 and 10,000 expected this year. An effective treatment remains elusive, as does a vaccine to protect those at risk. Where will it stop? Why is the conquest of AIDS still so distant?

title: JAPAN FILLS THE GAP
description: Japan-bashing seems to be back in vogue. But instead of beating up on Japan and our other foreign competitors, we owe them a vote of thanks. Here's why.

title: THE BEST OF TIMES
description: ''Recalled to Life.'' That's the ''Blazing strange message''

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION OF 'NORMA'
description: BELLINI'S ''Norma'' is the epitome of a bel canto opera, a work that calls for a soprano in the title role who commands nothing less than a prodigious vocal technique and the artistry to turn that technique into a powerful expressive tool. In our time Maria Callas and Joan Sutherland have been the memorable Normas, each in her own way matchless as the Druid priestess betrayed by a caddish Roman lover. It is, of course, unfair and unrealistic to expect Olivia Stapp, who essayed the role in the New York City Opera's new production of ''Norma'' last night, to measure up to those already legendary voices. Still, something closer to the ideal than offered by this performance ought not to be out of the question.

title: A CAT AND DOG TALE
description: A few weeks ago Elizabeth Hanford Dole, the Transportation Secretary, heard a cat meowing near the Watergate apartment she shares with her husband, the Senate majority leader, Bob Dole. Mrs. Dole persuaded the Watergate manager to open the nearby apartment and there she found a cat stranded on the balcony. Since the owners were apparently out of the city, Mrs. Dole took the cat to her apartment.

title: U.S. WILL NOT SUE IN BAN OF SPANISH
description: The Federal Justice Department will not file suit against Mayor Thomas Dunn, who was accused of violating Hispanic city workers' civil rights in 1983 by ordering them to speak only English on the job.

title: NO PARTY AT VON BULOW HOME
description: The state Republican Party today decided not to hold a fund-raising party at the mansion where Claus and Martha von Bulow lived before she fell into a coma. John A. Holmes, the party chairman, said so many people wanted to attend the Aug. 20 event it would have been difficult to maintain security. Mr. von Bulow, 58 years old, was acquitted June 10 of two charges of trying to murder his wife by injecting her with insulin. Mrs. von Bulow, 53, is in a coma in a New York City hospital.

description: Louise Brooks, the silent movie actress from small-town Kansas whose helmet of bobbed brunet hair became her trademark and a symbol of the disdainful flapper of the 1920's, died of a heart attack Thursday at her home in Rochester. She was 78 years old and for nearly 30 years had lived in retirement in a small one-bedroom apartment, sick, poor, proud and alone.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46 1. The flame is beginning to glimmer. Explain. 2. A tolling bell at 8:15 A.M. broke the silence, as hibakusha and others remembered Little Boy. What are hibakusha, what was Little Boy and what was the occasion? 3. The City Landmarks Preservation Commission is considering an unusual move to allow owners of three newly designated landmarks to temporarily change the buildings' interiors whenever necessary. What kind of buildings are they? 4. A man dismissed by political commentators as an ''American import'' and a ''racist lunatic'' when he was elected to the Israeli Parliament a year ago is now the most talked-about political figure in Israel, and his popularity is soaring. Who is he? 5. Sunday was a banner day for baseball as Tom Seaver and Rod Carew reached career milestones. What were they? 6. The pilot of a Delta Air Lines jet that crashed at the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport may have been hobbled in his efforts to avert the disaster by an order from the control tower. What was the order and what were the circumstances? 7. A former Government official has signed a book contract for ''in excess of $2 million,'' one of the highest amounts any publisher has ever paid for a single book. Who is he? 8. In its first major study of the profits of military contractors in nearly a decade, the Pentagon concluded that profitability had been (reasonable/unreasonable) and that (few/many) changes were needed in how the military pays its manufacturers. 9.

title: Books of The Times;   A DELIGHTFUL TRIFLE
description: THE ILLUSTRATED ZULEIKA DOBSON. Or an Oxford Love Story. By Max Beerbohm. With 80 illustrations by the author. Introduction by N. John Hall. 350 pages. Yale University Press. $19.95. ''Excuse all this to-do,'' said the late Max Beerbohm, explaining why he was so upset with typographical mistakes in the first printing of his novel ''Zuleika Dobson.'' ''If one is writing a history of civilisation or propounding some great new gospel printers' errors do not matter - they even brighten a thing up. But a trifle must be perfect.''

SUSPECT IN WIFE SLAYING DIES
description: A 79-year-old man who the police say shot his ailing wife to death in a hospital room before shooting himself died today, a spokesman for the Worcester Memorial Hospital said. The suspect, Abel Montigny, died of a .38-caliber bullet wound in his head, the spokesman said. Mr. Montigny's wife, Leona, 76, died Thursday afternoon after being shot in the head at the hospital, where she had been recovering from abdominal surgery earlier this week.

title: ALBA-WALDENSIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: UNPLANNED JURY DUTY ENSNARES PASSERS-BY
description: A judge who ran out of prospective jurors for the obscenity trial of a bookstore owner sent sheriff's deputies into the streets to seize unsuspecting passers-by for jury duty.

title: THE SOCIAL SECURITY BUDGET SHUFFLE
description: As part of the political deal that restored the solvency of the Social Security trust fund two years ago, Congress decreed that both the payroll-tax income and benefit payouts would be removed from the Federal budget in 1992. Not good enough, says President Reagan. He wants Congress to ''stop toying with the emotions'' of pensioners and make the break in the 1987 budget.

title: SIGNAL AND ALLIED ADVISER FEES SET
description: The First Boston Corporation and Lazard Freres & Company will share a $20 million fee for advising, respectively, the Allied Corporation and the Signal Companies in the nearly $5 billion merger of the two concerns, according to documents released yesterday. Copies of the 324-page proxy describing the merger are being sent to nearly 330,000 shareholders in one of the largest mass mailings in business history.

title: ATLANTIC FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (FT. LAUDERDALE) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $683,000 from a preferred stock dividend issued by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.

title: INQUIRY PLANNED OVER BOMBING IN PHILADELPHIA
description: District Attorney Edward G. Rendell said today that he would conduct a criminal investigation of the May 13 bombing by the police of a house occupied by members of the radical group Move.

title: WALLACE'S DOCTORS SAY HIS SURGERY IS SUCCESSFUL
description: Doctors said today that the July 24 surgery on Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was a success, meaning that pain from a 1972 shooting that left him paralyzed should subside.

title: SUNSTAR FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss of $424,000 for the quarter and $412,000 for the nine months and a gain of $406,000 for the quarter and nine months on the disposal of discontinued operations. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $428,000 for the quarter and $614,000 for the nine months.

title: FRANK B. HALL
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, the big insurance brokerage, said it has arranged to borrow up to $50 million from Reliance Group Holdings Inc. on a short-term basis. The company said it will replace all of the short-term borrowings with permanent financing as part of a major recapitalization, which is expected within two months. Reliance, which is controlled by the New York investor Saul P. Steinberg, is the largest shareholder in Hall, with a 19 percent stake.

title: EXPEDITORS INTERNATIONAL OF WASHINGTON reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RAPE TRAUMA: SEEKING COURT ACCEPTANCE
description: For more than a year after the rape occurred, the woman was haunted by it. She wept about it by day and dreamed of it at night. She lost sleep and gained weight. She was tense, fearful, unable to concentrate on her work. She stayed away from friends, avoided sex and severed an important romantic relationship. In short, she was transformed from a healthy, well-adjusted individual into one who was emotionally adrift and floundering.

title: GF CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ASIAN-AMERICANS COMPETE TO BUILD QUEENS COMPLEX
description: There is a Bacigalup's Restaurant on the rumpled Main Street shopping strip in Flushing, Queens, and the Free Synagogue is active a block away on Roosevelt Avenue.

title: PALOOKA AGAINST PALOOKA
description: During the brief baseball strike the other day my sympathies gravitated en masse to the players. They were being called an overpaid bunch of palookas by the very people who should have been pulling for them: namely, all the country's miserably underpaid palookas who are likely to get even more underpaid in the coming years as American business uses more and more sweated Asian labor to undercut the pay of American palookas without baseball skills.

title: EX-GENERAL TELLS OF NICARAGUA ROLE
description: A retired United States Army general who is active in assisting and advising Nicaraguan rebels said today that he was in contact with a member of the National Security Council in the White House to keep him informed of his work, including fund raising for the rebels.

title: JAPAN-SAUDI DEAL
description: A Japanese consortium led by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries has won a $330 million contract to build a power plant in eastern Saudi Arabia, the official Saudi press agency said. The contract, awarded by the Saudi Consolidated Electric Company-Eastern Region, is for a 1,200-megawatt steam turbine plant to be built at Qurayyah on the Gulf.

title: BELDEN & BLAKE ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. MOVES TO BAN 6 PRESERVATIVES FROM FRESH VEGETABLES AND FRUITS
description: The Federal Government moved today to ban the use in fresh vegetables and fruits of six sulfite preservatives that the Food and Drug Administration said had been linked to at least 13 deaths since 1983.

title: TALES OF THE SPA
description: The bidding on a yearling brother to Mom's Command stalled briefly at $650,000 Tuesday night in the sales pavilion here. The bid-takers at the podium were craning their necks to see if the last underbidder would go a little higher, but a young woman was leaning over and talking to him.

title: EVENING NEWS EASES STANCE ON SALE
description: The Evening News Association, one of the nation's largest communications companies, has permitted its investment bankers to circulate financial data among ''8 to 10'' prospective investors, a source with direct knowledge of the situation said yesterday. The move is regarded by analysts as a significant step toward the sale of the company.

title: FILM: 'SCIENCE PROJECT,' FROM JONATHAN BETUEL
description: ''My Science Project'' is a cheerful teen-age adventure film that in its snappier moments resembles a far less clever and less expensive ''Back to the Future.'' Despite a plot that has few interesting twists and a shoestring budget, the film glimmers with moments of drollery. Its running joke is the casting of Dennis Hopper as an ex-hippie high school science teacher who likes to tell his students about the time ''way back in the 60's when all you needed to finish school was a Frisbee.''

title: KEY TRONIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $980,000 from the sale of property.

title: SPYING JURY TOLD OF FINANCES
description: Richard W. Miller was in desperate financial circumstances when he began his sexual affair with a Russian emigre, a prosecution witness testified today.

title: LIFE INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $593,000 for the quarter and $1,739,000 for the 6 months from the sales of securities and real estate. c-Including gains of $1,193,000 for the quarter and $2,125,000 for the 6 months from the sales of securities and rela estate.

title: PAN AM STOCK TRADES HEAVILY
description: Pan American landed atop the New York Stock Exchange most-active list for the third straight session yesterday, amid continuing takeover speculation.

title: DIVERS SEARCH BAY FOR CRASHED PLANE
description: New Jersey marine police divers began searching the Delaware Bay about a mile off the coast for a small airplane that crashed Thursday night, the Coast Guard said.

title: HOLLIS PULLS OUT OF SINCLAIR OFFER
description: The board of Hollis Brothers said today that it was pulling out of a proposed $16 million deal to take over the troubled Sinclair Research, a computer company founded by the British inventor, Sir Clive Sinclair. Hollis, a company controlled by Robert Maxwell's Pergamon Press, said it was following the advice of its bankers, who said they could not recommend the rescue plan for Sinclair.

title: Uganda Bans Rallies But Vows to Free 1,400
description: Uganda's new military Government banned political gatherings today but pledged to free 1,400 prisoners jailed by the previous Government.

title: FIREFIGHTERS AND POLICE HOLD GAMES
description: Instead of catching criminals or fighting fires, more than 4,700 police officers and firefighters from 22 nations are in San Jose this week running, swimming, shooting, boxing, vaulting, bowling and otherwise exerting themselves in dozens of sports.

title: CROSS COUNTRY A STEP AT A TIME
description: Rob Sweetgall, a 37-year-old chemical engineer, is nearing completion of a one-year hike through the 50 states meant to demonstrate the physiological effects of long-distance walking. Last night he rested near Bennington, Vt., en route to the other New England states and finally to New York City for the finish Sept. 5 at Pier 16 at the South Street Seaport.

title: NATPAC INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
OF AIDS AND THE LACK OF CONFIDENTIALITY
description: Bernard L. (Bud) Broyhill, a 28-year-old Navy enlisted man, says he was betrayed by Navy doctors a few months ago after he developed symptoms of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: PLY-GEM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Getting Even For a Mayoral Gibe
description: Politicians never forget.

title: FOREST FIRES BURN HOMES IN CALIFORNIA MOUNTAINS
description: Three forest fires charred thousands of acres in the Sierra Nevada today, destroying homes and forcing the evacuation of scores of residents near Lake Tahoe.

title: BROWN, ROBERT C. & CO.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STRIKE AT TRIBUNE RAISES ANGER AT TEAMSTERS
description: While members of the country's oldest national union, the International Typographical Union, are voting on whether to merge with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, union printers here are striking against the Chicago Tribune, and teamsters are crossing the picket line.

title: BOND PRICES CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Bond prices continued their advance yesterday on forecasts of slower economic growth.

title: AIRSHIP AWARDED A NAVY CONTRACT
description: Airship Industries said today it had been awarded a $200,000 study contract by the United States Navy that could mark the return of the airship to the American air fleet.

title: KOCH CONTINUES TO LEAD IN FUND-RAISING EFFORTS
description: Continuing to far outspend his opponents, Mayor Koch spent $1,184,098 in the last three weeks in his campaign for renomination for a third term.

title: DECOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-After a nonrecurring net charge of $2,794,000 primarily for writedowns of radio station equipment and inventory and provisions for losses of stations to be closed.

title: JUDGE SAYS JERSEY CAN SHIP TAINTED SOIL TO NEVADA
description: Efforts to clean up the first of about 200 radium-contaminated homes in Essex County have advanced, with clearance to ship radioactive soil out of the area, state officials said today.

title: TO GET TO THE OTHER SIDE
description: Getting across the Hudson from New Jersey in rush hour is already a formidable challenge. It will get worse. Transportation planners foresee 50,000 more Manhattan-bound commuters by 1990. A welcome new Port Authority report suggests ways to absorb them. The region's economic health can be protected from the rush-hour crush, but only if the suggestions are promptly put into practice.

title: CYRIL AND METHODIUS: NEITHER GREEKS NOR BULGARIANS - BUT SLAVS
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;

VIDEO COLOR MODIFIED IN PRODUCTION OF TAPES
description: A color modifier for use in the production of television tapes was patented this week for the RCA Corporation, Princeton, N.J. The inventor is Robert N. Hurst, an engineer in the broadcast systems division in Camden, N.J.

title: BLOCK ESTIMATES WHEAT LIMIT
description: Secretary of Agriculture John Block said today that farmers preparing to plant 1986 winter wheat could plan on a farm program that would ask them to reduce acreage by 20 to 30 percent.

title: HOWE TRIES TWINS
description: The pitcher Steve Howe, released at his request by the Los Angeles Dodgers earlier this season, will work out with the Minnesota Twins for several days, then probably sign a contract with the team, Manager Ray Miller said. ''There's no doubt that I want him,'' Miller told The Minneapolis Star and Tribune.

title: WARNER TO BUY OUT AMEX UNIT
description: Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would exercise its option to buy the 50 percent of Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. owned by its partner in the venture, the American Express Company. It will pay $450 million and assume Warner Amex's $500 million in debt.

title: LABOR CENTER FILLING A DATA VACUUM
description: In early 1982, Dan Swinney, vice president of his union local, had a serious problem.

title: NAVRATILOVA IS SURPRISED
description: Claudia Kohde-Kilsch of West Germany upset Martina Navratilova, 3-6, 6-4, 6-3, today to advance to the semifinals of the $280,000 Canadian Open Tennis Championships.

title: FIVE ARE INJURED
description: A four-car BMT subway train derailed yesterday morning shortly after pulling out of the DeKalb Avenue station in downtown Brooklyn.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Workers took measurements from the plaster casting of the original flame of the Statue of Liberty to make molds for a new copper-skin torch. 2. The bell sounded in Hiroshima, 40 years to the minute since the first atomic bomb, called Little Boy, was dropped on the city. Hibakusha, the Japanese term for survivors, literally means bomb-affected people. 3. Broadway theaters. 4. Rabbi Meir Kahane. 5. Seaver, the erstwhile Met who now plays for the White Sox, became the 17th major league pitcher to win 300 games. Carew, the California Angels' first baseman, became the 16th player to have 3,000 career hits. 6. The order, for the jet to slow to avoid overtaking another plane, came as the jet encountered a sudden wind shift, which can be fought by speeding up. 7. David A. Stockman, the former director of the Federal Office of Management and Budget. 8. Reasonable. Few. 9. The BBC canceled a broadcast that featured a politician purported to be the chief of staff of the Irish Republican Army. 10. The first Xerox 914 Copier. 11. Judge Thomas P. Griesa barred construction of the Westway project, criticizing a report by the Army Corps of Engineers that said its environmental impact would be minor. 12. Gooden won his 11th game in a row, and his 17th of the season, by beating the Cubs. The previous Met team record was set by Seaver in 1969 when he won 10 consecutive games. 13.

title: COCA COLA SETS TEXTILE SWITCH
description: The Coca-Cola Company promised today to try to fulfill the ''all-American'' promise of ads for clothes that carry its name, after some textile makers learned the garments were mostly stitched abroad.

title: AMERICAN OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PRICES OF CRUDE RISE; HEATING OIL IS STABLE
description: Crude oil prices rose slightly yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with prices for September deliveries climbing 6 cents and prices for October deliveries 14 cents. Heating oil prices remained stable; prices for September deliveries increased less than half a cent.

title: A BETTER HOME FOR AIDS PATIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: BOY MAYOR MAY LOSE IF HE WINS CAMPAIGN
description: The 12-year-old Mayor of this farming community in southeastern Texas will be forced to leave office if voters on Saturday help him keep a campaign promise to officially put Crabb on the map.

title: FLORIDA PLANS MEASURES ON HIGHWAY ROBBERS
description: Gov. Bob Graham today pledged a sweeping effort to stop armed bandits who have ambushed and robbed nearly 100 motorists since Jan. 1 on a five-mile stretch of Interstate 95 between Miami and Fort Lauderdale.

title: BELL RESOURCES IS SUED
description: The Justice Department today filed a civil suit charging Bell Resources Ltd. and Weeks Petroleum Ltd. with violating Federal premerger notification requirements in the acquisition of about $61 million of Asarco Inc. common stock. The suit was filed in the Federal District Court in New York at the request of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: ARTIFICIAL HEART RECIPIENT IS TO LEAVE HOSPITAL
description: William J. Schroeder, the longest-living recipient of an artificial heart, is to be discharged Sunday from Humana Hospital Audubon and move to a specially equipped apartment nearby, a Humana spokesman said today.

title: FREMONT GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net realized gains of $140,000 for the quarter and $20,000 for the six months and gains from discontinued operations of $28,000 for the quarter and $125,763,000 for the six months. c-Including net realized gains of $224,000 for the quarter and $457,000 for the six months and gains from discontinued operations of $2,219,000 for the quarter and $4,013,000 for the six months. d-Net loss.

title: THEATER: 'WOMEN WITHOUT MEN,' BY GALLARDO
description: Edward Gallardo's ''Women Without Men'' is a home-front play with a difference. The characters, six women whose husbands are, in several cases, dead or missing in action in World War II, are of varying Hispanic backgrounds. The play deals not only with the loneliness of women on their own, but also with questions of familial loyalty, ethnic identification and discrimination. In the central case, the play is also concerned with the jealousy that exists between a mother and daughter, neither of whom has found a place of her own in a male-dominated society.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 10,1985
description: International Violence spread in black townships around Durban, pitting South African black rioters against white policemen and Indian vigilantes armed with shotguns and pistols. At least 52 people were reported to have been killed in four days of riots, The fatalities represented the most sustained bloodletting in 11 months of unrest in South Africa that has now claimed about 600 lives. [Page 1, Column 6.] South Africa's political climate will have a direct impact on relations between Pretoria and Washington, the Reagan Administration told South African officials in a ''serious''discussion, Administration officials said. The presentation of the United States position stopped short of an ultimatum on the part of the American officials who met with the South Africans in Vienna this week. [1:5.] The Arab League did not endorse the Jordanian-Palestinian accord outlining a joint effort for peace with Israel. It only ''noted'' the accord at a special meeting in Casablanca, Morocco, that was attended by moderate Arab countries. In a communique expressing the consensus of the 16 Arab delegations, issued at the end of the three-day meeting, the Arab League members ''noted with appreciation'' a ''detailed explanation'' of the accord of Feb. 11 presented in a closed session of the meeting by King Hussein of Jordan and Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the accord's major signers. [1:1.] National Federal deficits will be higher than projected through 1988 even if Congress achieves all the spending cuts in the budget plan it approved last week, according to Reagan Administration and Congressional budget officials.

title: MEESE TO COOPERATE IN PRESSER INVESTIGATION
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d, saying he was uncertain how much Senate investigators wanted to know about the Justice Department's decision to drop an investigation of the teamsters' union president, Jackie Presser, said Thursday that his department would ''cooperate fully'' in the Senate investigation.

title: SOME ASK WIDER SOUTH AFRICA PRESSURE
description: Some activists in the United States say they may begin to put pressure on a wider variety of American corporations doing business in South Africa.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Dow Chemical Co., Midland, Mich., said it completed the previously announced acquisition of Filmtec Corp. for about $75 million.

title: AIR EXPRESS INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $593,000 for the quarter and $1,005,000 for the six months.

title: REAPPLYING THE TEST OF MORE'S CONSCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

description: b-Including extraordinary items of $80,000 for the quarter and $1,975,000 for the six months.c-Including extraordinary items of $80,000 for the quarter and $5,475,000 for the six months. d-Net income.

title: WILSON WILL WAIT
description: Dave Wilson, the New Orleans quarterback who asked to be traded when the Saints signed Bobby Hebert earlier this week, said he had talked things over with Coach Bum Phillips and decided it would be better to wait until his sore arm had completely healed from off-season shoulder surgery before pressing for a trade.

title: GIRL SHOT IN BRONX LISTED AS CRITICAL
description: A 7-year-old girl who was shot in the head during a shootout between rival gangs in her South Bronx neighborhood was in ''extremely critical condition'' yesterday, a hospital spokesman said.

title: GARETT HAGEDORN DIES: STATE SENATOR IN JERSEY
description: State Senator Garrett W. Hagedorn, an 18-year member of the New Jersey Legislature, died of a heart attack today in Belfast, Me., where he and his family were vacationing. He was 74 years old and lived in Midland Park.

title: SUNSHINE-JR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Bookstore Holdup Veiled in Mystery
description: As the name suggests, they specialize in mysteries at the Mysterious Bookshop. But the most puzzling crime story that they now have in stock cannot be found on a shelf.

title:
PATENTS;

COMPOUNDS EFFECTIVE IN TREATMENT OF GOUT
description: A preparation for the treatment of gout has been patented for the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: THE HUMBLING OF AN ERSTWHILE SPELLING BEE CHAMP
description: Correct spelling isn't the virtue it used to be, but some of us still espouse accurate orthography if only because we feel more comfortable in a world of consistencies and standards. Considering the present enthusiasm for free-spirited anarchy in spelling, we can't pretend that champions of correctness represent a concensus. Nevertheless, we continue to proofread menus, public signs and publications and to make captious sounds when we encounter a particularly sacreligious violation of orthodoxy.

title:
PATENTS;

PLASTER CAST'S USE SIMPLIFIED
description: VLADIMIR GOLYAKHOVSKY, who was a prominent and successful orthopedic surgeon in the Soviet Union who came to the United States in 1978, has invented a method of applying plaster casts in treating bone fractures and dislocations.

title: INDIANS FATE IN SOUTH AFRICA: THEY ARE TRAPPED IN MIDDLE
description: Anwar Rumharak, a 19-year-old invoice clerk who is of Indian descent, stood on a ridge today and watched as young Zulus on the next ridge chanted war cries, threatening carnage.

title: U.S. Proposes to Send M.I.A. Team to Hanoi
description: The United States proposed to Vietnam today that an American delegation go to Hanoi to discuss Vietnam's recent offer to resolve the missing-in-action issue, a State Department spokesman said.

title: STOCKS FALL SHARPLY AS A RALLY FIZZLES
description: The stock market, showing little reaction to a firmer bond market, turned sharply lower yesterday as an early attempt at a rally failed.

title: COMPUDYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a gain of $2,000 for the quarter and a loss of $48,000 for the nine months from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $207,000 from discontinued operations.

title: ANOTHER TOP TEAM BEATEN IN SPINGOLD KNOCKOUT PLAY
description: Another top-ranked team was on the sidelines when third-round play in the Spingold Knockout Teams began here this afternoon at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals.

title: THEATER: ONE-ACT PLAYS, 'SCREAM' AND 'SOLDADO'
description: El Teatro Campesino, the Mexican-American company from California, is celebrating its 20th anniversary by presenting two one-act plays that inaugurated the company - ''The Dark Root of a Scream'' and ''Soldado Razo'' by Luis Valdez - at the Public Theater as part of this year's Festival Latino in New York. The company was established in 1965 to entertain and instruct California vineyard workers who were on strike, and it remains dedicated to theater that speaks to political and social issues. Mr. Valdez is no stranger to New York; his ''Zoot Suit'' was on Broadway in 1979. But these short plays, early protests against the Vietnam war, have not been seen here before.

WAINOCO OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income includes an extraordinary credit of $447,000 for the year- ago second quarter and $447,000 for the year ago six months.

title: POPE VISITS PALACE IN TOGO, THEN A WOMAN'S MUD HUT
description: Pope John Paul II, apparently disturbed by his visit to this nation's opulent presidential palace, broke his schedule today to stop at a mud hut and speak with an impoverished woman about her life.

title: BIG SPLASH
description: O.K., maybe you can't win them all.

title: U.S. IS REPORTED TO WARN PRETORIA
description: The Reagan Administration, in a ''serious'' discussion, has advised South African officials that the political climate within their country will have a direct impact on relations with Washington, Administration officials said today.

title: STIFF PENALTY GIVEN TO S.M.U. FOOTBALL
description: The Southern Methodist University football coach, Bobby Collins, said today that the school would appeal a National Collegiate Athletic Association penalty that will reportedly bar football scholarships for one year and keep the Mustangs from bowls and television appearances for two years.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SIGNS AND SCENES Saturday is a busy Fifth Avenue day from 34th Street north to Central Park - what with shoppers, strollers and sightseers drinking in the spectacle of this New York show street. At 42d Street and Fifth Avenue, the main and majestic steps of the New York Public Library are fenced off during refurbishing, but it is worthwhile to duck around the corner and enter on the 42d Street side. The main reading room on the third floor is still heady with the rare scent of old books. And down the hall are two fine exhibitions for those who don't want to sit but prefer to look and move on.

title: A THOROUGHLY UNFAIR QUIZ ABOUT NEW YORK
description: This being a city of immigrants, a native of New York is defined as anyone who has lived here for more than six weeks, developed the correct attitude toward all things trans-Hudson, especially New Jersey, and knows how to pronounce Houston Street. But not even native New Yorkers can hope to know all of the city's peculiar ins and outs. Consider a few thoroughly unfair questions:

WILL OF IRON
description: Like many other competitors, Pat Griskus is training for the Hawaii Ironman Triathlon. His day starts at 6:30 A.M. with a 30-mile bike, followed by 45 minutes of weight training. Then he swims one or two miles, runs five miles, and bikes another 25 miles. The difference between Griskus and other competitors is that he is an amputee.

title: SUSPECT IS HELD IN BRONX ATTACKS
description: A man was arrested last night in connection with a series of eight attacks, four of them sexual, on women in a northern section of the Bronx, the police said.

description: Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said today that the president of Yale University, A. Bartlett Giamatti, would make the ''strongest possible'' Republican candidate next year against Sen. Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.

description: The 29 American peace activists who said they were held captive for a day by anti-Sandinista rebels arrived today in this town on Lake Nicaragua, a spokesmen for them said.

title: MAX KROOK, 72, DIES, EX-PROFESSOR
description: Max Krook, a retired professor of applied mathematics and astrophysics at Harvard University, died Sunday at his home in Arlington, Mass. He was 72 years old.

description: Don't Rely On Strangers,'' warns a poster in the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown. Along with that good advice, Greyhound Bus Lines also offers, free, ''Tips for Teenagers Traveling Alone,'' a guide to food, shelter and counseling services in New York.

description: The brochure brims with bustle and hope.

title: PRICE INDEXES TO BE LATE
description: The Labor Department postponed today its scheduled monthly release of the Producer Price Indexes for July because of a series of ''processing errors'' that were not discovered until Thursday night. It said statisticians would work through the weekend and that the figures would be released at 2 P.M. Monday.

description: In the summer of 1981, it was the Rubik's Cube. The next year it was wobbling antennae attached to plastic headbands.

title: STAGE: 'NAVAJA,' FROM PUERTO RICO
description: The play presented by Puerto Rico's Teatro del Sesenta at the Public Theater's opening Thursday of the Festival Latino of New York is, even for those with limited understanding of Spanish, staged and performed most engagingly. It is a pity that an imperfect comprehension puts a barrier between a non-Spanish-speaking audience and a full appreciation of the show.

title: BELLAMY DEFENDS BROOKLYN SQUATTERS
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday supported the decision of some Brooklynites to break the law by breaking into abandoned city-owned buildings and taking them over as squatters.

title: GUARANTEES OF SAFETY FOR THE INSURANCE INDUSTRY
description: A recent report from Washington disclosing that 10 percent of the nation's savings institutions are effectively bankrupt has further diminished public confidence in the nation's banking system. This revelation comes on the heels of the failure of state-sanctioned bank guarantee funds in both Ohio and Maryland to protect savings and loan depositors earlier in the year.

title: PROVINCETOWN-BOSTON AIRLINE reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 2 Terror Groups Assert They Bombed U.S. Base
description: Two terrorist organizations, West German and French, took joint responsibility today for the car bombing of a United States air base Thursday, describing the base as a ''clearing house for wars in the third world from Western Europe.''

title: Fashion in Harlem
description: A block party and fashion show are planned today by the Harlem Institute of Fashion on West 126th Street, between Lenox Avenue and Seventh Avenue.

title: PLAYING THE ROLE OF CHAMPION
description: Somewhere, in some old John Garfield movie, there must have been a character like Jose Luis Ramirez as violins played in the background.

title: SWARM OF KILLER BEES HAS BEEN DESTROYED IN A CALIFORNIA HIVE
description: A swarm of aggressive Africanized honey bees invaded a commercial beehive in California's Central Valley and was destroyed, state officials said today.

title: ARTHUR WALKER FOUND GUILTY IN SPYING CASE
description: A Federal District judge today found Arthur James Walker guilty of spying for the Soviet Union and of conspiring with his brother in what American officials have called the most damaging spy case in decades.

title: LESSONS IN LABOR UNREST
description: For years, Bredhoff & Kaiser has been one of the nation's leading labor union law firms, representing such clients as the A.F.L.-C.I.O., the United Steelworkers and the National Education Association. Now it is learning at close range what labor unrest is all about. The firm's own employees, members of the Office and Professional Employees International Union, have announced plans to set up picket lines Monday in front of the offices at 1000 Connecticut Avenue, protesting such things as proposed salary cutbacks and elimination of Christmas bonuses.

title: TREVINO LEADS IN PGA BY SHOT
description: A confident Lee Trevino shot into the lead during the second round of the 67th PGA Championship today. Trevino, who captured the PGA Championship in 1974 and 1984, predicted that he would win this one at the Cherry Hills Country Club.

title: Japan Posts Trade Surplus
description: TOKYO, Aug. 9 (AP) -

title: PEARLE BOARD BACKS BID BY GRAND MET
description: Pearle Health Services Inc., which operates a chain of eye-care centers. said yesterday that its board had endorsed a $386 million takeover bid from Grand Met U.S.A., a subsidiary of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food, hotel and gambling company.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The signal we're sending to spies is that when you get caught, you'll pay the full penalty.

title: ARAB CHIEFS FAIL TO BACK JORDAN-P.L.O. PACT
description: A special meeting of the Arab League that was attended by moderate Arab countries today ''noted'' the Jordanian-Palestinian accord outlining a joint effort for peace with Israel, but it did not endorse the accord.

title: HATHAWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $87,000 for the quarter and $366,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,452,000.

title: HIGH-TECH CATALOGUE FOR VIDEO
description: IT is a catalogue with a high-tech twist: instead of reading it you watch it, with the help of your video-cassette recorder.

title: FEES FOR USING TELLER MACHINE
description: WITH the expansion of automated teller machines and switching networks linking the machines at different financial institutions around the country, some banks and savings and loan associations are instituting special service charges for customers who use teller machines.

title: CARROLS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
GOVERNOR VETOES BILL ON LOTTERIES
description: A bill that would have allowed charitable and other authorized organizations to sell prize tickets similar to those issued by the state's instant lottery game has been vetoed by Governor Cuomo.

title: ISLANDERS HIRE DIRECTOR
description: Darcy Regier, a former National Hockey League defenseman who coached the Indianapolis Checkers in the International Hockey League last season, has been named director of hockey administration for the Islanders. The 28-year-old Regier, who played for the Islanders and the old Cleveland Barons in a 26-game N.H.L. career, retired after the 1983-84 season.

title: ALLIED SECURITY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WITNESS NAMED
description: Kevin Koch, who spent more than six seasons entertaining Pittsburgh fans as the club's mascot, the Pirate Parrot, has been identified by a Pittsburgh newspaper as the witness who wore a hidden transmitter to help the Federal Bureau of Investigation secure evidence against one of seven defendants indicted by a grand jury investigating drug abuse among major league players. The Pittsburgh Press, quoting an unnamed law enforcement source, said that the 32-year-old Koch, who resigned his mascot position in June, had helped arrange a purchase of cocaine last November from Dale M. Schiffman, a freelance photographer who was later indicted on 111 criminal counts by the grand jury.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, AUSUST 10,1985
description: Companies

title: SEWAGE LINE LEAK CLOSES 4 BEACHES
description: Up to 500,000 gallons of raw sewage poured into Long Island Sound on Thursday, and officials today closed four public beaches at the beginning of what promised to be a hot, sunny weekend.

title: COUPLE SHOT DEAD ON W. 44TH ST.
description: A West Side couple were shot to death yesterday as the man followed a nightly routine of meeting his wife to see her safely home from work.

title: JUDGES' REVERSAL DROPS LEMOND
description: Olaf Jentzsch of East Germany won the Colorado National Monument stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic today, after the race judges had installed Greg LeMond as the winner and then reversed themselves.

title: WILD WEST IN BROOKLYN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE V.I.P.'S ARE COMING, BUT THE SWISS ARE BLASE
description: The Perle du Lac, a one-star restaurant owned by the city of Geneva, commands a picture-postcard view of the southern end of Lake Geneva.

title: Juan Gabriel to Sing
description: The Mexican singing star Juan Gabriel will make his New York City debut at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum tonight at 7:30. Tickets are $20, $22 and $25, and are on sale at the Garden box office and through Ticket World (307-7171).

title: WHITE HOUSE AID TO NICARAGUAN REBELS REPORTEDLY WORRIED C.I.A.
description: The National Security Council's direct involvement with the Nicaraguan rebels in the last year caused ''some disquiet'' among Central Intelligence Agency officials who feared the activities might be illegal, a senior Administration official said today.

title:
PATENTS;

APPARATUS DEVISED TO FORM EMULSIONS
description: An apparatus to form emulsions useful for numerous industrial purposes has been invented for the Biotechnology Development Corporation, Newton, Mass.

title: WOHL SAID TO TAKE NETS POST
description: To the end, the Nets remain secretive about the identity of their next head coach. But according to a team source, the Los Angeles Laker assistant coach Dave Wohl accepted the position after meeting with team officials Thursday in New Jersey.

title: ASTROCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $62,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $243,000, or 11 cents a share, for the six months.

title: JOBS NOT BASED ON PATRONAGE, SUPERVISOR SAYS
description: Thomas M. Gulotta testified in Federal District Court today that since taking office as Presiding Supervisor of the Town of Hempstead in 1981 he had insisted that town employees be hired and promoted on the basis of merit, not political patronage.

title: A Request From the Chef
description: Helene Greece was settling into her first day on the job as publicity manager for Radio City Music Hall.

title: GALILEO ELECTRO-OPTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CRAM'S BID FAILS
description: Steve Cram failed in his attempt to set his fourth world record within a 25-day span, running the 1,000 meters in 2 minutes 12.85 seconds.

title: NEW BOMBER DESCRIBED AS A FLYING-WING CRAFT
description: The supersecret Stealth bomber being developed by the Air Force is the shape of a flying wing, essentially an aircraft with no fuselage or tail, Senator Barry Goldwater said today in the first public confirmation by a Government official of the bomber's design.

title: LEO L. MELLAM, 79, ADVOCATE OF SHIPPING WITH CONATINERS
description: Leo L. Mellam, a trucking executive who was a leader in developing containers as a method of shipping, died Monday after a long illness at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: TSC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: INSOLVENCY FEARS GROW FOR JAPANESE SHIPPER
description: Japan's Sanko Steamship Company, one of the world's leading tanker companies, may be headed for insolvency.

title: Canadian Singers
description: Kate and Anna McGarrigle, the Canadian singing and songwriting duo, will appear at the Bottom Line (15 West Fourth Street) tonight and tomorrow, Shows tonight are at 8:30 and 11:30 and tomorrow at 8 and 11 P.M. Tickets are $10. Information: 228-6300.

title: CARDINALS WIN ON CONSECUTIVE HOMERS
description: Andy Van Slyke and Terry Pendleton hit consecutive home runs for the second straight game tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals rallied with a four-run fourth inning to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 5-4.

title: PETTIBONE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics Empire State Games, at Buffalo. Third day of the four-day competition in the state festival. Baseball Mets vs. Chicago Cubs, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden goes for his 12th victory in a row. (Television -Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:20 P.M.) Yankees vs. Red Sox, at Boston, 2:05 P.M. (Radio - WABC, 770 2 P.M.) Royals vs. Toronto Blue Jays, at Kansas City. (Radio - WCBS 880, 8:20 P.M.) Boxing Jose Luis Ramirez, champion, vs. Hector (Macho) Camacho, 12 rounds, for the World Boxing Council lightweight championship at Riviera Hotel and Casino, Las Vegas, Nev. This is the second defense for Ramirez, who won the title from Edwin Rosario in November in San Juan. (Television - HBO, 10 P.M.) Football Jets vs. Philadelphia Eagles, at Giants Stadium, 8:30 P.M. Jets and Eagles play their first National Football League exhibition game of the season. (Television - Channel 5, 11:30 P.M., tape. Radio -WABC 770, 8:30 P.M., live.) Giants vs. Broncos, at Denver. Preseason exhibition. The Giants opened with a victory over the Houston Oilers in last week's Hall of Fame game. (Television - Channel 11, 9 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 9 P.M.) Golf PGA Championships, at Cherry Hills Country Club, Denver, third round. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.) L.P.G.A. Henredon Classic, at High Point, N.C., third round. Running Asbury Park (N.J.) 10K Classic, 9 A.M. This year the race that begins and ends at Convention Hall has been designated The Athletic Congress National Championship.

title: TRIDEX CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Year-ago revenue and net income included $317,000 of rental income from property sold in fiscal 1985.

title: NORTHVIEW CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: OUR LESS-THAN-OVERPAID MERCHANT SEAMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: SHOE IMPORT CURB DEBATED
description: President Reagan discussed with his Cabinet advisers today the issue of protecting the domestic shoe industry from surging imports, but made no decision.

title: NBC USES 'FOCUS GROUP' ON 2 NEWS PROGRAMS
description: NBC's two newest forays into the television magazine format are the first news programs at the network to be subjected to a ''focus group,'' one of the standard tools of market research in Hollywood and on Madison Avenue.

title: POLL TRACKS AMERICA'S FOOD TASTES
description: A new survey of American eating habits finds that people all over the country are purchasing elaborate ready-made dishes, having food delivered and grazing instead of eating three square meals a day. It also shows that trends that began on the East and West Coasts are moving inexorably inland even as they are losing favor where they began.

title: A.T.&T. JOB CUTS
description: The American Telephone and Telephone Company officials here said today that another 1,000 plant workers will lose their jobs over the next two weeks.

title: TIME-SHARING THE TUDOR
description: A Long Island developer who converted a string of motels into resort cooperatives and condominiums has made a deal to buy the Tudor Hotel on East 42d Street in Manhattan, where he plans to sell rooms through a time-share plan. If approved by state officials, it will be the first attempt at time-sharing for a hotel here.

title: MOROCCAN TO URGE U.S. TO BACK JORDAN-P.L.O. EFFORTS
description: King Hassan II of Morocco said today that he would try to convince the Reagan Administration that dealing with a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation offered the ''best means of achieving a just and comprehensive solution to the Arab-Israeli conflict.''

title: U.S. PREPARING NEW PRODUCTION OF NERVE GASES
description: At the new Army chemical factory that local residents nonchalantly call ''the nerve gas plant,'' the waiting conveyor belts are wrapped in protective plastic.

title: NIHILATOR FAILS TO WIN
description: Marauder, who upset the overwhelming favorite, Nihilator, in the first heat, was awarded a walkover victory in the $242,400 Adios Pace today after Nihilator, who bounced back to win the second heat, was scratched from their scheduled race-off.

title: THIS MORALITY LESSON RUNS WILD
description: What are the ways in which television can look at our times, and what does it find when it looks? It depends. What does it want to find? Moral lessons, or information carefully sorted out so that it can be of use? On the whole, programs that deal in information work better. Moral lessons suffer from their own sense of conviction. They don't have to be justified so much as propounded. Consider, for example, two television programs, one past, one yet to come, both dealing with roughly the same topic - the dropping of the atomic bomb and all that has happened since. A recent CBS program, ''Hiroshima Plus 40 Years . . . And Still Counting,'' gave us information, some of it new. We were able to use it. A WOR-TV program, ''Years of Danger, Years of Hope: The Postwar World,'' does not give us information so much as it gives us a point of view. It makes morality simple.

title: COUNTY SHOWS MODEST GROWTH SINCE CENSUS
description: THE sparsely settled northern town of Lewisboro has shown Westchester's greatest percentage increase in population since 1980, according to a recent study of the county's 43 municipalities.

title: AFRICAN RIFT: BIRTH CONTROL Vs. TRADITION
description: In Africa, having many children has customarily been considered a gift of divine favor and having none, a great curse.

title: Returning a Surplus To the Taxpayers
description: I read your article on proposed Suffolk County tax refunds with great disappointment [''Suffolk Ponders Windfall From Lilco,'' July 7] . As prime sponsor of the budget cap bill, approved by the voters at the November 1983 general election by referendum, I wish to correct certain misstatements quoted in that article.

title: THE YEARS SINCE THE YEARBOOK
description: IN my dusty yearbook, dated 1965, I found the photo of Phil and me sitting on the hood of the dark-green '55 Chevy. I'm now on the far side of 35 and nervously holding something the mailman just delivered - an invitation to my high school reunion.

title: CERTIFYING TEACHERS
description: Last spring, 1,357 seniors at New Jersey's teacher-training colleges took the National Teacher Examination, which measures the knowledge of prospective elementary school teachers. It was announced last week that 13 percent of them failed the general knowledge test and 4 percent failed the subject-matter exams.

title: TERESA LAYDEN IS WED TO ROBERT M. BAUMAN
description: Teresa Anne Layden, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Layden of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert Mark Bauman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry C. Bauman of Maryville, Mo. The Rev. Robert E. Weiss performed the ceremony at St. Cecilia's Roman Catholic Church.

title: PLAY FOR SPINGOLD BRIDGE TITLE NARROWS DOWN TO 16 TEAMS
description: Sixteen top-ranked contract bridge teams battled here today in the Spingold Knockout Championship, which will end Tuesday. All other events will end Sunday at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer National Championships, the biggest tournament ever played anywhere.

title: MISS ROGERS TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howland P. Rogers of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Tuxedo Park, N.Y., have annnounced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Pell Rogers, to David Stephen Charles Williamson, a son of Mrs. David A. F. Williamson of San Francisco and Napa Valley, Calif., and the late Mr. Williamson. An October wedding is planned.

title: FROM ARF TO ZAP!
description: Jack Rosenthal's article ''From Arf to Zap!'' (On Language, June 30), which focuses primarily on differences among languages, is even more fascinating in its revelation of the difference between printed language and sound itself. When I was a child, in the days of silent movies, before television, we actually spoke those written words to indicate sounds connected with our play.

title: A MARKET OF WOODEN BOATS
description: The season for boat shows has emerged this year as a time for owners and would-be owners to sample the market. For some, the familiar clinking of wire rigging against mast and spreaders in a boat basin jam-packed with new-model sailboats is an irrepressible sound. But not for everyone.

title: HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS SEEN IN DRUMS AT RADICALS' HOUSE
description: Preliminary test results show several of the 32 drums found in a Chester County house abandoned by the radical group Move contain small amounts of hazardous solvents, officials have reported.

title: SAINTS CAPITALIZE ON PATRIOT FUMBLES
description: Morten Andersen kicked four field goals of 40 yards or more, and the New Orleans Saints took advantage of five New England turnovers for a 32-20 National Football League exhibition victory over the Patriots today.

title: POOL, AND PRIDE, RETURN TO THE SOUTH BRONX
description: To the people who grew up in the neighborhood, who saw it flourish and then nearly die, the Crotona Park Pool sometimes seems like an enormous mirage, its Caribbean-blue waters shimmering amid the empty lots and tightly packed brick apartment buildings of the South Bronx.

title: Topics;   Injuries Avoided Living Sculpture
description: Few children can resist a sack race, few men a tug of war and few women the chance to race an egg on a spoon to a finish line. But why 12 people entered the contest, held last week on the football field at Franklin & Marshall College in Lancaster, Pa.

title: MEETING A DEMAND
description: A building boom in the late 1970's and early 1980's gave Hauppauge, in western Suffolk County, some 12 million square feet of industrial space in the form of high-technology research-and-development facilities. The commercial expansion not only provided an estimated 35,000 jobs but also created a demand for housing in that part of the county.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: OIL AND WATER: The Struggle for Georges Bank. By William H. MacLeish. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) Courtroom dramas and tales of men who go down to the sea make natural beach-blanket books.

title: THE FASTEST PITCHER IN AMERICA
description: TY STOFFLET CASUALLY WARMS UP along the first-base sidelines, his underhand deliveries swooping across the orange terry-cloth towel that serves as a makeshift home plate. The effortless left-handed tosses seem more appropriate for the evening paperboy than for America's fastest softball pitcher.

title: August 11, 1985
Quotation of the Day
description: ''If you have Japanese investment you get a good deal, but if you are 100 percent American you get a bad deal.'' - Lee A. Iacocca, the Chrysler chairman, on negotiations with the United Auto Workers. [23:4.]

title: A PRIVATE ATTORNEY AND A PUBLIC MAN
description: ''I FIND it very difficult not to be occupied - doing something all the time,'' said Peter T. Affatato of Massapequa Park.

title: RESPECT FOR FOOD
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ADVISERS BRANCH OUT
description: POLITICAL consulting used to be almost as seasonal as Christmas trees, though never as beloved. Between Labor Day and Election Day, pollsters, television commercial producers and general political advisers spent 100-hour weeks trying to get their candidate-clients into office. Then they virtually faded from public sight until the next spate of electioneering.

title: POWER DINING
description: As a relative newcomer to the system of ''power lunching,'' I was amused by Russell Baker's article ''The Patriotic Lunch'' (Sunday Observer, June 30). A summer internship has afforded me a chance for several expense-account lunches.

title: Dance
description: Dance Theater Workshop's annual ''Out-of-Towners'' series this week introduces Wendy Morris from Minneapolis, who will present the New York premiere of a multimedia work, ''Shadow to Frame,'' at 8 P.M. Thursday through Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 W. 19th St. Miss Morris has danced in Minneapolis with visiting experimental choreographers such as David Gordon, Dana Reitz and Bill T. Jones, but the advance word on this piece is that it should be regarded in the ''performance art'' genre. The theme is said to be ''personal and cultural attitudes toward death and immortality'' and involves video work by James Byrne, slides by Dorit Cypis and music by Wendy Ultan and William Larkin.

title: HANDLING SCANDAL
description: To the Editor:

title: A Familiar Face for Bolivia
description: Gen. Hugo Banzer came in first, albeit narrowly, in last month's inconclusive national election, but last week Bolivia's Congress picked a 77-year-old economist, Victor Paz Estenssoro, to be President. Mr. Paz Estenssoro, who ran a close second, two percentage points behind General Banzer, on July 14, immediately called for ''pragmatic, realistic and concrete measures'' to avert national bankruptcy.

title: PUMPING UP MACINTOSH'S MEMORY
description: ONE of the amusing facets of writing a review column is that with a little skill and luck one can quite often achieve that happy state wherein almost all readers agree - that the columnist is wrong. Whenever I write about the Macintosh, I try to balance the machine's faults against its strengths, watching carefully for my own prejudices.

title: VIETNAM VETERANS GIVE EX-COMRADES A HAND UP
description: Since he returned from the Vietnam War in 1968, Benjamin Smith has not worked at the same job for more than 16 months. He has, at different points, been a Consolidated Edison lineman, a stock clerk, a fast-food server, a census taker, a forklift operator and a factory worker.

title: SUSHI JOINS THE EAST END MENU
description: THIS season, sushi has come to the Hamptons. Omasa in Montauk, one of three restaurants serving sushi in the resort area, offers a complete Japanese menu as well. It is the Long Island branch of a restaurant in Hartsdale, in Westchester County.

title: DESPITE 20 YEARS OF FEDERAL AID, POVERTY STILL REIGNS IN APPALACHIA
description: A new concrete highway near here, Appalachian Corridor G, curves smoothly through wide, newly blasted granite canyons and soars over resculpted green mountains.

title: MEDIATORS EASE COURTS' LOAD
description: WITHIN the last five years, out-of-court resolution of disputes in municipalities has become an increasingly popular alternative to having cases settled in formal judicial settings.

title: GREEN LEADS IN PGA
description: Hubert Green, an almost forgotten player on the PGA Tour, has changed his way of dressing and changed his way of swinging. This was all done recently to change his way of finishing in tournaments.

title: A WORTHY SONDHEIM STAGING
description: HAVING regaled audiences with such mainstream musicals as ''Barnum,''

title: 30 Arrested After Fight At New Caledonia Club
description: A fight among Melanesians outside a nightclub today led to the sacking of a dozen stores, a clash with the police and about 30 arrests, the police said.

title: HARRY ROTHMAN, DISCOUNT CLOTHING RETAILER, DIES
description: Harry Rothman, a Manhattan discount clothing retailer for six decades, died Friday of pulmonary disease at his home in Manhattan. He was 82 years old.

title: THE PROMISE OF ORSON WELLES
description: Orson Welles has, in many ways, reminded me of Dr. Samuel Johnson, most specially for being an extremely interesting conversationalist.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN IN ANGLO-SAXON ENGLAND: And the Impact of 1066. By Christine Fell with chapters by Cecily Clark and Elizabeth Williams. (Indiana University, $24.50.)

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: QUEEN OF HEARTS. By Dan McCall. (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $15.95.) Those old standbys Love and Death figure in almost any novel of worth, but here Dan McCall has made their collision his exclusive subject.

title: NANCY HEINZEN A BRIDE
description: Nancy Alice Heinzen and Gregory John Strizich, a son of Mrs. Joseph Strizich of Peoria, Ill., and the late Mr. Strizich, were married yesterday. The Rev. S. Wyndham Anderson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Bruce R. Heinzen, in Plandome, L.I. The bride's father is chief of general surgery at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.

title: F.A.L.N. SUSPECTS ARE CONVICTED IN CHICAGO
description: The F.A.L.N., an organization whose stated goal is independence for Puerto Rico, has in recent years claimed credit for nearly 120 bombing attacks in several American cities. Last week, four suspected members who called themselves freedom fighters were convicted in Chicago of plotting more explosions.

title: A TERRIBLE BEAUTY IS BORN. HOW?
description: I will maintain that the artist needs only this: a special world to which he alone has the key. - Andre Gide

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC MADE FUN FOR CHILDREN
description: UNDER a bright blue-and-white tent behind the Italianate mansion that was once a summer cottage for the oil heir Edwin S. Harkness, two mimes frolicked as deer and birds while eight musicians played a Mozart serenade.

title: DO YOU DO WINDOWS?
description: Don H. Clausen, an official of the Federal Aviation Administration, was reminiscing the other day about the rigors of political campaigning.

title: THE PUREST AMBITION OF ALL
description: THE AMATEURS By David Halberstam. 221 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $14.95.

title: POLITICS EMBROIL A FAMOUS FESTIVAL
description: The Edinburgh International Festival, which starts today and runs until Aug. 31, is the biggest arts bonanza in the world. Now in its 39th year, it continues to draw a glittering array of artists and large crowds of visitors to its stony, bright, castle-dominated city. For example, this year's program includes a Japanese ''Macbeth,'' a South African ''Miss Julie'' and the Moscow State Circus.

title:
ART;

CALDER MENAGERIE IN YONKERS
description: ALEXANDER CALDER (1898-1976), who has a high and secure place in our history through his invention of the mobile and its counterpart, the stabile, which stands on the ground, had a passion for animals. This passion infused all of his work and is perhaps the reason why Calder is synonymous with delightful.

title: TOPICS
description: THIS year we are privileged to have a thrush in the garden again. I take it as a symbol of good times. Last year we had no thrush; we had our two families of cardinals, chickadees, robins, all kinds of sparrows, mockingbirds, cuckoos, goldfinches, pine siskins, warblers. But I was convinced that after the severe winter, our thrushes had sought deeper woods, sermonizing to myself about the declining ecology.

title: JANET KEYES TO MARRY JOHN O'CONNELL
description: Mr. and Mrs. Fenton Keyes of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Janet Bayard Keyes, to John Ryan O'Connell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. O'Connell of Center Valley, Pa., and East Hampton, L.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: V.A. IS FAULTED OVER LENGTH OF HOSPITAL STAYS
description: About one-third of the patients studied in Veterans Administration hospitals in 1984 did not belong there but were admitted because of mismanagement and poor testing by doctors, according to a report by a Congressional investigative unit.

title: ESTATE PLANNING: THE SOONER THE BETTER
description: ESTATE planning is perhaps the most emotionally charged aspect of family finances. Sitting down to draw up or revise a will is clear acknowledgement of mortality. ''Many older people are reluctant to have a will,'' says William J. Arnone of Buck Consultants, a New York employee benefits consulting firm. ''They feel it's the kiss of death.''

title: VICTIM IN SING SING WARD FACES DOUBLE ISOLATION
description: Parole took on new meaning, the man said, when he learned he was suffering from acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: The Rebels Are Back in the Money In Nicaragua
description: President Reagan signed legislation last week providing $27 million for the Nicaraguan rebels, opening up a pipeline Congress had cut off last year. But even before the new law could take effect, the insurgents seemed to be gaining headway.

title: WEST BANK ARABS HAVE RARELY FELT SO CORNERED
description: The Israel-Palestinian conflict appears to be entering a new phase, one which for many Israelis seems more frightening and difficult to cope with than much that has gone before. A new mood of despair among West Bank Arabs seems to be growing. Their hopes have been dashed by the destruction of the Palestine Liberation Organization as a military force in Lebanon, the failure of the P.L.O. to develop an effective political initiative and by Israel's refusal to negotiate with credible Palestinian leaders over the future of the West Bank.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: 2-DAY FOLK FESTIVAL Bonnie Raitt and Doc Watson are the headliners for a two-day bluegrass, country and folk festival at Silver Cloud Park, Rondout Country Club, Route 209 in Accord, a small town near Kingston in Ulster County. Appearing with Miss Raitt from noon to 11 P.M. Saturday are Taj Mahal, Vassar Clements, Happy & Artie Traum, Jay Ungar, Jimmy Arnold, Don Haynie and Sheryl Samuel.

title: CAMP WHRE STRAINS ARE ALL MUSICAL
description: WESTCHESTER'S Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, Joseph M. Caverly, likes to recall the time, three years ago, when he was sharing a bench and a conversation with a distinguished older gentleman on the grounds of Mountain Lakes Camp, the 1,000-acre county park in North Salem.

title: Religion No Threat To Public Schools
description: Re: ''Equal Access: Pitfalls for Our Schools'' [Opinion Page] : To one who attended a public high school in New York City in a more liberal, relaxed time, the current frenzy of anxiety over permitting religious groups to meet on school grounds during nonschool hours seems altogether unnecessary. When I was in high school, religious groups had the same privileges as others: language clubs, stamp clubs, band practice, etc.

title: MUST ONE MOURN FOR THE CAREER LEFT BEHIND?
description: SOMEWHERE in my past, certainly no later than college in the early 1960's, I absorbed the concept that what a middle-class ''professional'' man did for a living was, in fact, his Career or Work.

title: RONDA
description: To the Editor: Readers of your excellent article on Ronda (Travel, July 14) should be aware that because of its superlative scenic location, the Hotel Reina Victoria is the focus of many daily and overnight bus tours from the Costa del Sol. A portion of the Victoria's rooms face not the embankment view but the entrance courtyard filled with noise and bus fumes.

title: SEAGRAM PUTS ITS FAITH IN CHEMICALS
description: THE Seagram Building is one of the jewels of Park Avenue - a sleek Mies Van de Rohe skyscraper of bronze and glass. At its epicenter is Edgar M. Bronfman, chief executive of Seagram Company Ltd. and son of its founder. But Seagram, the world's largest distiller, is finding liquor demand plummeting in the face of health concerns. And Mr. Bronfman, corporate scion of one of the world's wealthiest families, must now scramble to keep the business growing for the next generation and beyond.

title: GASOLINE TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSANNE BROOKS AND DAVID L. HINTON ARE MARRIED
description: Susanne Brooks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremiah P. Brooks of Saginaw, Mich., and David Longstreet Hinton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dirck Longstreet Hinton of Reno, were married yesterday in a Protestant ceremony at the Deer Park Villa in Fairfax, Calif., by the Rev. Ned H. Holmgren.

title: DR. T. P. SWEET AND DR. TROEGER EXCHANGE VOWS
description: The marriage of Dr. Melody Beth Troeger, who received a Ph.D. degree in pharmacology in May from the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine, to Dr. Timothy Patrick Sweet, a dental resident at the State University of New York Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, took place yesterday at St. Aloysius Roman Catholic Church in New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. J. Peter Cullen performed the ceremony.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Sussex County, Augusta, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (201) 729-7272. Today - Three Village, Old Field, L.I. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (516) 725-1953. Today - Epilepsy Foundation, Oldwick, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (201) 832-7402.

title: REPORTERS SAY PASTORA REBELS HELD 29 IN NICARAGUA
description: Armed men who detained a group of Americans for a day this week were probably commanded by the anti-Sandinista guerrilla Eden Pastora Gomez, journalists who accompanied the group said today.

title: America's Doomed Mideast Policy
description: American policy in the Middle East is headed, willfully and witlessly, toward a fiasco. But there are grounds for optimism: the policy may collapse before it gets too far down that road.

title: THE QUEST FOR SKIN RENEWAL
description: THE SKIN CONSTANTLY RENEWS ITSELF. Older surface cells are shed and newer ones rise to replace them. With age, the cycle slows down. Increasingly, though, people are prodding nature to hasten the process. With the help of exfoliating agents - washcloths, loofahs, sponges, brushes, grainy creams and lotions - they hope to realize a vision of baby-new skin.

title: WORRIES PERSIST ON PLUTONIUM
description: PLUTONIUM contamination 25 years ago at an Air Force base here has come back to haunt town residents and military and township officials in recent days, underscoring the need for safety in an area where a sprawling military reservation and rolling farmlands warily coexist.

title: EFFORT TO SAVE 3 BUILDINGS FAILS
description: NORWICH will soon lose three historic properties because a two-year search by the Norwich Community Development Corporation failed to find a developer to rehabilitate them.

title: NEW CONCERN ON FOREIGN-BORN
description: ''ALL you have to do,'' John Allen, Westchester County's Acting Commissioner of Social Services, said recently, ''is walk down a street in Yonkers, Mount Vernon or Peekskill to see the difference.''

title: 10,000 LOBSTERS ARE LET GO
description: State and Federal officials have seized nearly 10,000 egg-bearing lobsters at the Atlantic Lobster Company in Lynn, Mass., and released them in Boston Harbor. The officials said state law prohibits possession of lobsters bearing eggs, and the illegal transfer of lobsters falls under Federal law. They said the lobsters seized in Monday's raid had come from Canada.

title: MARIE SCHWIND IS WED
description: Marie Elizabeth Schwind and Matthew Allen Daud plan to be married next month, according to the announcement of their engagement made by her mother, Elizabeth Ann Schwind of Lodi, N.J. Mr. Daud is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred A. Daud of Upper Montclair, N.J. Miss Schwind, also a daughter of the late Carl Schwind, is a senior accountant with American Express Travel Related Services in New York, and Mr. Doud is a captain with Holiday Airlines at the Newark International Airport.

title: APARTMENT JAILING
description: AFTER Dr. Milton Avol, a neurosurgeon who lives in Beverly Hills, Calif., was found guilty in June of failing to correct health, safety and fire code violations in four apartment buildings that he owned, the judge gave him a choice: 60 days in jail or 30 in jail and 30 living in one of his rundown apartments.

title: MISS AUGELLO IS WED TO MICHAEL S. CARTER
description: Laurence Augello, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Michel Augello of Bayonne, France, was married yesterday to Michael Scott Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Carter of Ridgewood, N.J. The Roman Catholic ceremony was performed at L'Eglise St.-Etienne in Bayonne.

title: CD'S ACHIEVE SPLENDID UNIFORMITY OF SOUND
description: One of the proudest claims made on behalf of the new compact disks - CD's for short - is their unprecedented frequency response. It is virtually ''flat'' (i.e., uniformly even) over the entire audible range from 20 to 20,000 hertz (cycles per second). To appreciate the meaning of this, it is necessary to clarify the relation between frequency response as an engineering specification and the experience of musical sound.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 11, 1985 Fiction

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: JIAN. By Eric Van Lustbader. (Villard, $17.95.) In the latest novel by the author of ''The Miko'' and ''The Ninja'' we move first from Tokyo to Washington, then to Hong Kong, Peking, Moscow and the Crimea - and back again several times.

title: CHARLES A. HIGGINS
description: The Very Rev. Charles Ashley Higgins, retired dean of Trinity Episcopal Cathedral in Little Rock, Ark., died Aug. 2 in Helena, Ark. He was 72 years old.

title: Recent Sales
PHILADELPHIA SUBWAY SLAYING
description: A subway rider stabbed a fellow passenger to death and wounded another early today in an argument over a pack of cigarettes, the authorities said.

title: GROSS WINS AGAIN
description: Michael Gross, the West German swimmer who won two gold medals and set two world records at the 1984 Olympics, has been busy this year making up for another record that got away - the 200-meter butterfly.

title: A DELAWARE DOG'S BEST FRIEND
description: FOR more than two years, Frank E. Collins, a letter carrier, and a mongrel, Daisy, contradicted all those stories about letter carriers and dogs being natural enemies.

title: CURRENCY THREAT
description: FEARFUL that coming electronic color copying machines would be so good they might be used to reproduce paper currency, the United States Treasury began in 1978 to consider altering the bills.

title: UNDERSTANDING ROSE'S RECORD
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A MAN WHO CHAMPIONED BLACKS IN BALLET
description: Dance, Havelock Ellis suggested, is the most austere of the artistic disciplines. ''He is right, of course,'' Karel Shook wrote in ''Elements of Classical Ballet Technique,'' ''but he doesn't go on to say that the austerity he speaks about, which is at the core of what we do as dancers and teachers, is tempered with joy, graciousness, elegance and a commitment to the vagaries of humanity which become illuminated and beautiful when translated into art.''

title: 'AUTHENTIC' MUSIC
description: To the Editor:

title: UGANDA RELEASES 1,200 FROM PRISON
description: Uganda's new military rulers freed more than 1,200 political prisoners today and announced that the country's main rebel movement had agreed to peace talks next week.

title: 'NO-FRILLS' SEAFOOD IN SOUTH NORWALK
description: MAYBE it is psychological, but seafood seems to taste fresher the nearer one gets to the shore. And in the new Sono Seaport Seafood Restaurant in South Norwalk, one cannot get much closer to water, in this case the Norwalk River.

title: AN OPERA HOMECOMING
description: FOR Alfredo Silipigni, general director of the New Jersey State Opera, next Sunday will be something of a homecoming.

title: SAFEGUARDING FILM AGAINST X-RAYS
description: BILL TAYLOR of Massapequa Park, L.I., was on his dream vacation, a safari to Africa. With a new 35-millimeter telephoto lens for his camera, he proceeded to shoot his trip from beginning to end. After it was over, he placed the film in his luggage and headed home.

title: AMERICAN SANCTIONS: ONLY A FIRST STEP
description: THE recent declaration of a state of emergency in South Africa should have removed any lingering doubts that the Reagan Administration's policy of constructive engagement is a monument to moral myopia and wishful thinking. We must reject the naive notion that we can gently persuade the South African Government to abandon apartheid, and instead advance racial justice by joining other countries in applying economic pressure against South Africa.

title: AN ODDITY THEN, A LEGEND NOW
description: ABOUT 200 years ago, as legend has it, a hermit named Sarah Bishop lived in a cave near North Salem.

title: A VACANCY
description: The Center for National Policy, a nonprofit research group founded in 1981 by a group of leading Democrats, is looking for a new president. Ted Van Dyk, a former aide to Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey who has headed the center since its establishment, is resigning as of Oct. 11 to re-establish the private consulting concern he operated in Washington in the 1970's.

title: LENDL, MCENROE WILL MEET IN FINAL
description: Ivan Lendl overcame a disputed call on match point to defeat Jimmy Connors, 6-0, 4-6, 6-4, today in the semifinals of the $315,000 Volvo International tennis tournament.

title: Ex-Solidarity Aide Released After 2 Days of Questioning
