description: A longtime official of the banned labor union Solidarity said he was detained by the police Thursday in the northern port of Szczecin and questioned for 48 hours before being released today.

title: INNOCENTS ABROAD
description: To the Editor: I have noticed with considerable interest the plethora of letters relating to ''innocents abroad'' who have been victimized by street thieves and relieved of their money, passports and other possessions.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BUILDING SAND CASTLES The days of building castles in the sky are over for the summer when sand is more available and thus more practical. So all dreamers - and other creative souls - get you to Nassau Beach Park in Lido today where from 10:30 A.M. to 1 P.M. there's a sand castle competition, with prizes on deck in three categories: family, 10 years to 14 years, and over 14 years. Registration starts at 9:30 A.M. and while there's no charge to compete, there is a fee of $3 to park at the beach on Lido Boulevard. Incidentally, in Montauk, at Hither Hills State Park, there are weekly sand castle contests at 9:15 A.M. Fridays through Aug. 30. A $3.50 parking fee is in effect and permits the use of all of the facilities at this oceanfront park.

title: NARROW HOUSE RECIEVES WIDE ATTENTION
description: IT is small. It is skinny. It is charming. Its uniqueness has lured hundreds to see the curiosity of a 3-story house that is 10 feet wide and built on a parcel of land 12 1/2 feet wide. What is affectionately called the skinny house is located at 175 Grand Street here.

title: Ohio Abortion Clinic Damaged In Blast
description: An abortion clinic was bombed here today, and another was the site of a demonstration that led to the arrest of four people, the police said.

title:
ABOUT MEN;

FULL POCKETS
description: SWIM ONLY WHERE I CAN skinny-dip. I take to water of moonlit northern lakes, the deep pools of tropical streams. Here, amid water striders and fallen blossoms, I rest spread-eagle on my belly, my nose just above the surface, taking in a frog's-eye view of the world. I have no use for bathing suits, because most of them have no pockets.

title: WHAT IT DOES TO ONE DOCTOR
description: ONE FRIDAY AT NOON, AFTER FOUR gray days of rain, the leaden clouds over northwestern Oregon drew apart and the sun filled the operating room of Dr. Peter Bours's clinic in Forest Grove. The winter light came through clerestory windows set in the peak of the cathedral ceiling, filtering through the glossy leaves of the palms and ferns in the loft, falling gently on Dr. Bours, his nurse and the pregnant woman lying on the operating table.

title: KRICKSTEIN AND GOMEZ AT RYE HILTON
description: HIS rise in the tennis world has been phenomenal, reminiscent of John McEnroe's eight years ago. Westchester youngsters follow his exploits avidly and try to duplicate his style on the court. At age 15 he made his big breakthrough, reaching the round of 16 at the United States Open, the youngest male ever to have gone that far in the nation's premiere tournament. He turned professional shortly afterward, and now at 18, ranks 12th in the world and plays on the United States Davis Cup team.

title: WRITING THE BOOK ON PARTNERSHIPS
description: In bridge, as in life, a successful partnership does not depend merely on business like efficiency: Self-control and psychology are also important if the partnership is to survive and prosper.

title: WEDDING PLANNED BY MISS TRAYNOR
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Michael Traynor of Berkeley, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Ann Traynor to Nicholas Priest Holder, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Richmond Holder of Chestnut Hill, Mass. The wedding is planned for October.

title: Topics;   Injuries Avoided Softer Sells
description: Most auto companies argue that air bags don't work, and cost too much besides. But while they've been arguing, others have been installing these automatic crash restraints with fine results.

title: COUNTRY CLUB TO BE MIXED-USE CENTER
description: WHEN the New Jersey Turnpike opened in 1951, traffic thundered uninterrupted through the rich, flat farmland of South Brunswick past the genteel country club known as Forsgate.

title: NUCLEAR DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: 50'S FLASHBACK
description: BY NOW, THE YOUNG HAVE PRACTI-cally finished with the 1950's, advancing to the next decade for their dress-up flair. Nevertheless, the 50's are still firmly fixed as a fertile area for grown-up clothing inspiration. The evidence of this is apparent in many designer collections - though not all - for this fall, both in the United States and France.

title: BIDS TO BUY CONRAIL HIT SNAG IN CONGRESS
description: Norfolk Southern's $1.2 billion bid to take Conrail off the Federal Government's hands - and a counteroffer proposed by investment bankers Morgan Stanley and Company - appears to have been stalled dead in their tracks.

title: IN MOOSUP, V-J IS PATRIOTIC FOCUS
description: VIRTUALLY ignored for many years, V-J Day is being recalled once again throughout the nation as the 40th anniversary of Japan's surrender to the Allied forces nears. The surrender, on Aug. 15, 1945, brought an end to World War II.

title: BERNOULLI BOX
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE JOINS BATTLE AGAINST MARIJUANA
description: THREE state-police airplanes flew across rural areas of Connecticut last week as part of a nationwide effort to eradicate marijuana crops.

title: FOR THE PRESIDENT, THE TOUGH PART COULD BE JUST BEGINNING
description: A certain air of ruddy self-confidence has long been one of President Reagan's patented assets. Last week he dispensed some Reagan-brand optimism as he prepared to head for California for vacation. He dismissed the cancerous pimple removed from his nose as a minor problem, appending a seasonal warning to fellow sunbathers. His skin cancer, he advised, was a cost of overexposure to the sun and his vain urge for ''a coat of tan, dating back to my lifeguard days.''

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING COOL NATURE'S WAY
description: WHEN it comes to keeping cool in the summer, nature's own air-conditioning is hard to beat.

title: GOING PUBLIC WITH PRIVATE VIRTUES
description: INDEPENDENT WOMEN Work and Community for Single Women. 1850-1920. By Martha Vicinus. Illustrated. 396 pp. Illinois: University of Chicago Press. $27.50.

title: DOING WELL - AND NOT SO WELL - BY MOZART AND WAGNER
description: Each new performance of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' evokes that oldest of esthetic cliches - the treacherous difficulty of being simple. Mozart's wonderfully ambiguous exercise in spirit and flesh, humor and seriousness, is hard, indeed, for any set of re-creators to grasp despite the directness of the music; and we in America - where popular wit often centers on whimsy, ridicule and quick gags -are particularly guilty of ''Magic Flutes'' padded with Disneylike animals, Spirits who travel by balloon or airplane and faintly parodied Taminos and Paminas.

title: HUDSON RIVER VALLEY'S FIRST COMMERCIAL TV STATION TO STRESS LOCAL NEWS
description: The Hudson River Valley, one of New York State's most rapidly growing regions, is about to get its own commercial television station.

title: DR. MOSES SWICK, DEVELOPER OF A TECHINQUE FOR DIAGNOSIS
description: Dr. Moses Swick, a retired New York City physician and professor of urology who pioneered techniques for taking X-rays of the kidney, bladder and urinary tract, died Wednesday at Doctors Hospital of a gall-bladder infection. He was 85 years old.

title: MEMORIAL TO HONOR HOLOCAUST VICTIMS
description: WHEN Martin Berger traveled to Vienna two years ago, he took a side trip to West Germany to see Dachau. ''I have a particular sensitivity to the place,'' said Mr. Berger, a real estate developer in the county, ''because my father's entire family was exterminated there.''

title: L.I. FISHERMAN JOIN THE JAPANESE
description: THREE miles off the beach at Gurney's Inn in Montauk, a Japanese ship rides calmly at anchor. The ship, the Suzuka Maru, is a floating fish-processing plant that has been keeping busy since the beginning of the summer buying hundreds of tons of squid from Montauk trawler fishermen.

title: HE HAS POMP, BUT LITTLE CIRCUMSTANCE
description: At noon this Thursday, if all goes as scheduled, Emperor Hirohito of Japan will appear on a flower-bedecked stage near his palace in Tokyo and commemorate one of the few times in his long life when he did something that really mattered.

title: SEPT 21 WEDDING FOR MISS BARNES
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Daniel S. Barnes of Radnor, Pa., that their daughter Caroline Porter Barnes and Christopher King Henningsen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor W. Henningsen Jr. of Pelham Manor, N.Y., are to be married Sept. 21.

title: NEW I.R.A. PROVISION
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PROMISE OF ORSON WELLES
description: We all have our favorite Orson Welles experience (''Orson Welles: The Unfulfilled Promise,'' by Barbara Leaming, July 14).

title: TOPICS
description: SIGNS of summer are everywhere. The bells from the Good Humor truck ring in the late afternoon, camp trunks are tagged in the hall, and stickball games pre-empt even fried chicken dinners.

title: BRAZIL POLITICS: MANY PARTIES, MORE TO COME
description: If democracy means the right to form political parties, freedom is rampant in Brazil: since the armed forces stepped down in March this year, 25 new parties have been legalized, and more are waiting in the wings.

title: Bomb Threat Interrupts Jetliner Flight to Miami
description: A caller who said a bomb had been placed on an Eastern Airlines jet forced an emergency landing here, officials said today.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: DEFENDANT: A Psychiatrist on Trial for Medical Malpractice. An Episode in America's Hidden Health Care Crisis. By Sara C. Charles and Eugene Kennedy.

title: BLACK LAWMAKERS IN POLL SEE TENSIONS WITH JEWS
description: A survey of black members of Congress by a major Jewish organization has found that the legislators feel blacks deeply resented the Jewish reaction to the Rev. Jesse Jackson in the Presidential campaign last year.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: 'COCKROACHES' UPSTATE The world premiere of ''Hunting Cockroaches'' by the Polish playwright Janusz Glowacki will conclude the summer season of the River Arts Repertory company at the Byrdcliffe Theater in Woodstock, N.Y., Aug. 20 through Sept. 1.

title: JERSEY CITY TO DUMP WATER
description: Jersey City will dump 25 million gallons of water from the Boonton Reservoir into the Rockaway River Monday in an attempt to dilute a putrid odor from the stream near Parsippany, state officials said. A spokesman for the Department of Environmental Protection, Jim Staples, said the odor was created when chemicals got into a water treatment plant and destroyed the bacteria that kill solid-waste particles.

title: COERCION KEY IN G.O.P. TRIAL
description: ONE by one, past and present employees of Nassau County have taken the witness stand in Federal District Court in Uniondale over the last two weeks to tell how they gave 1 percent of their salaries to the Republican Party. Many testified that they gave voluntarily, but with the belief that the donations would help them get raises and promotions in the Republican-dominated county.

title: WHAT I DID IN THE WAR
description: ''WHAT did you do in the war, Mom?''

title: MANAGING THE DEATH MACHINE
description: THE DESTRUCTION OF THE EUROPEAN JEWS Revised and Definitive Edition. By Raul Hilberg. Three volumes. Maps. 1,274 pp. New York: Holmes & Meier. $159.50.

title: LIVING PROOF OF TIME'S PASSAGE
description: SHE was camera-shy then. At nine pounds, nine ounces she cried, rolled away from the sudden bright light of the Polaroid One-Step and furiously kicked her legs and arms. When I tried to console my red-eyed, wet-cheeked baby in my arms, I noticed that she had wet through her home-coming dress onto her crib sheet. It was the first time I changed her diaper. The next pages of my photo album contain happier pictures of Julie. Her first stroll, at three weeks old, shows her slightly smiling face peering out of a red-hooded sweatshirt jacket and the rest of her covered with hand-crocheted blankets. In another shot, she sticks out her tongue playfully - a feat her grandparents marveled at. ''Who taught her how to do that?'' they said, giggling over the telephone 1,500 miles away.

title: THE OUTSPOKEN TRAPPIST
description: THE HIDDEN GROUND OF LOVE The Letters of Thomas Merton on Religious Experience and Social Concerns. Edited by William H. Shannon. 669 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $27.95.

title: CONTROL IMPORTS THROUGH BILATERAL PACTS
description: THE United States in the 1980's faces a stark choice: Reformulate trade policy to restrict imports or sit by while industries that the country needs to maintain its standard of living are wiped out by imports from low-wage nations.

title: SUBURBS AID YOUNG ALCOHOL ABUSERS
description: Two suburban programs for teen-agers with drinking problems have recently expanded their efforts.

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING COOL NATURE'S WAY
description: WHEN it comes to keeping cool in the summer, nature's own air-conditioning is hard to beat.

title: MARIANNE FRANCK WEDS DANIE CHUSID
description: At the Plainfield (Mass.) Congregational Church yesterday Marianne Seelye Franck, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter G. Franck of Sfax, Tunisia, was married to Daniel Chusid, a son of the late Moses Chusid of New York.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: MARINE STUDY CENTER Mystic Marinelife Aquarium is attempting to raise $4.3 million to construct a whale and dolphin study center that would specialize in the rescue and rehabilitation of marine mammals. The center would also do research in marine mammal medicine.

title: 50 YARDS OF CHEWING GUM
description: THE WILLYS DREAM KIT By Jan Novak. 311 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: EAGLES SCORE 28 STRAIGHT POINTS
description: Before the rookies came in, filled with desire and jitters and poor play, the Jets enjoyed some productive moments tonight as they opened their exhibition season by bowing to the Philaelphia Eagles, 37-17.

title: GOODEN: DEATH AND TAXES
description: THE FIRST thing Dave Johnson said when the strike was over was, ''Is it Doc's turn?'' He said it with the glee of a man who would have some voice in whether it was Doc's turn.

title: PACKER TACKLE SIGNS
description: Ken Ruettgers, an offensive tackle from Southern Cal who was the Green Bay Packers' first-round draft choice, agreed to a series of one-year contracts and said he would report to training camp over the weekend. ''I'm absolutely thrilled to be joining the Packers,'' he said.

title: U.S. NUCLEAR ARMS WERE KEPT IN JAPAN IN 50'S, ARTICLE SAYS
description: An article to appear in next week's issue of The Nation magazine says the United States stored nuclear weapons in Japan from 1955 to 1957.

title: STRANGER IN THE CLOSET, DOUBT IN THE JUDGMENT
description: IT was a Sunday afternoon, and my aunt who lives in the city (on East 10th Street), was visiting us on Long Island.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

COIN SHOW PREVIEW
description: The 94th anniversary convention of the American Numismatic Association opens Aug. 20 at the Baltimore Convention Center. It is the year's biggest coin show and ANA officials anticipate an attendance of more than 15,000.

title: EAGLES OWNER: IRON HAND, TIGHT FIST
description: WHEN the Philadelphia Eagles began training camp in late July, 7 of the club's 11 draft choices had not signed and 11 veterans had not reported because of contract disputes.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: STUBBORN CHILD. By Mark Devlin. (Atheneum, $14.95.) Mark Devlin, who tells his sometimes touching, but often maddening, story in ''Stubborn Child,'' spent his youth ''warehoused'' in a home for delinquents.

title: RUSSIAN LEGACY FADES IN NORTH CHINA
description: In the heart of the old Russian quarter, everybody knows the old lady, though few recognize her name. A visitor has only to stop a Chinese along Tongjiang Street to have him point along the way to the pilared building at No. 5 that was once a synagogue, now the office of the Xunhua district prosecutor and tax bureau.

title: STATE STIFFENS DRUNK-DRIVING PENALTY
description: Governor Cuomo has signed a law authorizing the police to impound the cars of motorists caught driving drunk after their license has been suspended or revoked for drunken driving.

title: KINGMAN GETS HIS 400th HOMER
description: Dave Kingman became the 21st player in baseball history to hit 400 home runs when he hit a two-run homer in the first inning that helped Oakland beat Seattle, 11-5, tonight.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''What the factory orders and leading indicators are showing is the very smallest of the beginnings of a bumping on the floor. What I and many others have been saying is that the third quarter is still going to be very sluggish.''

title: JOHN LEWIS'S PIANO AND BACH'S CLAVIER
description: When Wynton Marsalis made a splash as a jazz musician playing classical music, record companies sensed a winning formula. It's still nearly impossible to get an original jazz composition recorded, but all of a sudden jazz musicians have been offered the run of the Baroque and Classical repertory, ready or not.

title: 'AUTHENTIC' MUSIC
description: To the Editor:

title: Hormel Braces for Strike At a Plant in Minnesota
description: A contract covering more than 1,500 meatpackers at a Hormel plant expired today, and the company braced for a strike by a union local early next week, a Hormel spokesman said.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Bears Begin To Prowl For more than a year, investors had bet that declining interest rates, low inflation and dozens of undervalued stocks would have the market soaring in the second half. But, said Robert S. Salomon Jr., managing director of equities research at Salomon Brothers, most bets were off as of last week. On Friday, the Dow Jones industrial average closed at 1,320.79, down 32.76 points from the week before.

title: WARNING LABELS FOR ROCK-AND-ROLL
description: In response to pressure from a parents' group, the record industry announced last week that companies would start putting warnings on albums and cassettes that contain sexually explicit lyrics. But the industry's critics were not satisfied.

title: STATE BANDS WITH 6 OTHERS IN THE BATTLE ON ACID RAIN
description: CONNECTICUT and its Northeastern neighbors are mounting a regional assault on the Federal Government to try to force tighter controls over acid rain.

title: OPERA: BELLINI'S 'NORMA' GIVEN NEW PRODUCTION
description: BELLINI'S ''Norma'' is the epitome of a bel canto opera, a work that calls for a soprano in the title role who commands nothing less than a prodigious vocal technique and the artistry to turn that technique into a powerful expressive tool. In our time Maria Callas and Joan Sutherland have been the memorable Normas, each in her own way matchless as the Druid priestess betrayed by a caddish Roman lover. It is, of course, unfair and unrealistic to expect Olivia Stapp, who essayed the role in the New York City Opera's new production of ''Norma'' Friday night, to measure up to those already legendary voices. Still, something closer to the ideal than offered by this performance ought not to be out of the question.

title: PARITY A KEY ISSUE
description: For the fifth time in seven years, negotiators for the Chrysler Corporation and the United Automobile Workers will face each other Monday as bargaining for a new labor contract begins.

title: OF REVOLUTION AND OTHER EXCESSES
description: ONE EARTH, FOUR OR FIVE WORLDS: Reflections on Contemporary History. By Octavio Paz. Translated by Helen R. Lane. 213 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $14.95.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: 13 HITS HELP YANKS TO FIFTH IN ROW, 7-3
description: Ideally, said Manager Billy Martin today, his Yankee team will not look ahead. The trick, he said, was to get the Toronto Blue Jays to look behind.

title: TANGLEWOOD STAGES BACH'S 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION'
description: Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' has recitatives and arias, a central character and singers in lesser roles, and a chorus that comments on and sometimes becomes involved in the action. Yet, as everybody knows, this musical setting of the events related to the crucifixion of Christ isn't an opera.

title: TAX-CREDIT LOSS: 'NO SMALL IRONY'
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: MOZART AT OCEAN GROVE Oscar Shumsky, the violinist, and his son, Eric, a violist, will perform Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante with the Cathedral Symphony Orchestra Thursday evening at the Mozart Festival in Ocean Grove's Great Auditorium.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATION DRAWS ATTENTION TO FEDERAL JUDGE IN MISSISSIPPI
description: HATTIESBURG, Miss. Aug. 7 - For the past 12 months scores of witnesses have paraded through the second floor of the United States Courthouse here, where a special Federal grand jury has been investigating allegations of public corruption in southern Mississippi.

title: KATHERINE S. DAY BECOMES A BRIDE
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Good Shepherd in New York yesterday Katherine Stinson Day, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis DeVournsey Day Jr. of Philadelphia, was married to James Andrew Sutton 3d, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Sutton Jr. of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Vincent Ioppolo performed the ceremony.

title: INSURANCE RATES SOAR FOR DENTISTS
description: DESPITE recent legislative action to reduce state malpractice insurance rates, Long Island dentists say that sharp increases in the cost of premiums this summer will cause fundamental changes in the types of care and service available.

title: STUDENTS PROTEST SCHOOL'S EVICTION
description: Students and supporters of the New York School of Ballet picketed on Broadway yesterday to protest the school's eviction from the Upper West Side building where it was founded 16 years ago.

title:
DINING OUT;

HARMONY AND FLAIR INOSSINING
description: ONLY six months old, Cafe Keenan already exhibits the potential of growing into a superior restaurant. The harmonious, esthetic environment crossed with the kitchen's flair and its commitment to fine ingredients should, in time, flower into a vigorous hybrid. Meanwhile, there is much pleasure to be had noting its development.

title: DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITY ADVANCES IN BROOKLYN
description: IN physics, critical mass refers to the smallest amount of material necessary to sustain a chain reaction. In downtown Brooklyn, where visions of a commercial real-estate revival have smoldered without result for years, that point may finally be at hand.

title: EX-OFFICER SAYS BROTHER TAUGHT HIM HOW TO SPY
description: After Arthur James Walker learned that his brother was a spy for the Soviet Union he became ''curious'' about the tricks of the espionage trade, according to statements he has made to the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: CLARA SCHUMANN: The Artist and the Woman. By Nancy B. Reich. (Cornell University, $25.) Clara Schumann was one of the remarkable women of the 19th century, and she deserves this scholarly, well-documented biography.

title: A RULING BUT NOT AN END TO GLOBE LIBEL CASE
description: Both the plaintiff and the defendant claimed victory last week in the Boston Globe libel case, but neither side had given up the fight. In an unusual decision, a jury found that the Boston Globe had published ''false and defamatory'' material about a former gubernatorial candidate but that the article as a whole was neither false nor defamatory.

title: No Headline
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul D. Carmichael Jr. of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Kristen Danae Carmichael to Christian Ernst Fritz Olsson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gunnar Olsson of Mijas, Spain.

title: LISA CHRISTOFFERS, LAWYER, IS MARRIED TO MAKOTO YANO
description: Lisa Ann Christoffers, a June graduate of the Yale Law School, and Makoto Yano, an assistant professor of economics at Cornell University, were married yesterday at the Community Presbyterian Church in Mountainside, N.J. The Rev. Elmer A. Talcott performed the ceremony.

title: GOODEN WINS 12TH IN A ROW
description: Dwight Gooden kept blazing along yesterday, pitching the Mets to an 8-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs before 48,310 fans in Shea Stadium, winning for the 12th straight time and running his record to 18 and 3 in his second summer in the big leagues.

title: OFF-SEASON IS HIGH SEASON FOR THEATER IN LONDON
description: You won't hear any impresario, performer or critic talking of a London ''season'' these days, because the word has become an archaism. Once the theatrical year was actually eight months or so, beginning in September and ambling to a halt in May, like its counterpart in New York; but no longer, no more. Thanks to the growing reliance of the London theater on the tourist trade, off-season is now high season, and sticky July and blowzy August are as busy times as any.

title: ONE MAN'S LOVE FOR ART IS SHARED IN EXHIBITION
description: From the 1950's to the 1970's, knowledgeable people in the arts would make the short trip from New York City to the suburb of New Rochelle to see a remarkable private collection of drawings in the home of a business executive, Curtis O. Baer.

title: 15-YEAR HELPING HAND FOR WRITERS
description: NO matter how many times people are told to forego a career as a writer, or how ominous the statistics about limited opportunities and economic realities, nothing is going to deter the ''obsessed'' writer.

title: MORE MOVIES, A POLITICAL COMIC STRIP AND GORE VIDAL
description: Cable's newest specialty, it seems, is to de-specialize.

title: F.A.A. CONTRACT SPURS HIGH-TECH EFFORT
description: AFTER two years of planning, a $12 billion decade-long project designed by the Federal Aviation Administration to replace the nation's entire flight-guidance computer systems is under way.

title: SHARON SCHREIBER A BRIDE
description: The marriage of Sharon Jane Schreiber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Al Schreiber of Brooklyn, to Jacob Bouganim took place yesterday at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.

title: CAMACHO WINS BY DECISION
description: The smart guys, the one who took the 2-1 odds, maybe now they'll believe Hector (Macho) Camacho, who obviously knew what he was bragging about.

title: GREAT HARRY'S HYPOCRISY
description: HENRY VIII By Jasper Ridley. Illustrated. 473 pp. New York: Viking. $24.95. ALTHOUGH Henry VIII is best known for his radical solutions to his marital troubles, in Jasper Ridley's new biography Great Harry's tyranny pales in comparison with his genius for politically terrorizing an entire nation. With wry, cynical wit, Mr. Ridley, whose other biographies include ''Lord Palmerston,'' demolishes the characterizations of former biographers who portrayed a promising young humanist gradually corrupted by such powerful and evil bureaucrats as Cardinal Wolsey and Henry's secretary, Thomas Cromwell, later Earl of Essex. In Mr. Ridley's persuasive view, Henry was no fallen angel. He was always cruel, his eyes no less piggy in the golden opening years of his reign (when at 17 he befriended famous European intellectuals like Erasmus and Sir Thomas More) than when they look at us out of Holbein's famous portrait, where we see King Henry, legs apart, arms akimbo, the perfect picture of arbitrary and absolute patriarchal power, the huge tun of a man we know from the bloated shape of his armor in the Tower of London, the man who ended up as a plague to his people.

title: Open Primaries In Connecticut
description: A Federal appeals court decided last week that political parties, not states, should decide whether to allow voters who are not members to participate in a primary election. The case before a three-judge panel in Manhattan involved an effort by the Republican Party in Connecticut to open its primary last year to independent voters, a move blocked by Democrats in the State Legislature.

title: WHERE TOMORROW'S DANCERS PREPARE FOR STARDOM
description: Mary Day can no longer climb steps two at a time. When she first opened the Washington (D.C.) School of Ballet back in 1944, her body had the spry, athletic jaunt of a dancer, and she would lope up the stairs as she went from studio to studio, checking on students, teaching classes and stealing a pirouette or two in front of an empty mirror.

title: Voters Spurn Young Mayor On Plans for Incorporation
description: Voters in this farming community overwhelmingly rejected a plan today to incorporate, a move the town's 12-year-old Mayor had sought in hopes of preventing annexation by neighboring cities.

title: AN OLYMPIC FLAVOR IN BUFFALO FOR THE EMPIRE STATE GAMES
description: The opening ceremonies of the eighth Empire State Games presented bands, an orchestra, skydivers, fireworks, the climax of a torch relay, the wisdom of ageless Al Oerter, and more than enough inspiration for everyone. A Rocket Man did not zoom into the stadium, nor did an alien appear from outer space, but then, the top ticket price was $3, not $200.

title: SHARON HOOPER AND JAMES COTT MARRY
description: Sharon Allison Hooper, the daughter of Mrs. Harry A. Hooper of Richmond and the late Mr. Hooper, was married in Charlottesville, Va., yesterday to James Lloyd Cott, a son of Mrs. Lester Wunderman of New York and Sagaponack, L.I., and the late Ted Cott of New York. The Rev. Douglas Loyd, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the chapel at the University of Virginia, of which the bride is an alumna.

title: Zimbabwe Police Seize Passports From Nkomos
description: The police have seized the passport of the opposition leader Joshua Nkomo and detained two top officials of his party, his wife said today.

title: CONSIDERING THE CASE OF THE DISAPPEARING TENOR
description: There is a shelf beside my office desk on which recently published books accumulate until I get around to deciding whether they are worth saving. Looking over this purgatorial collection the other day I was struck by the preponderance of books about female opera singers. In addition to three large volumes devoted to prima donnas down through the ages and one roman a clef about the career of a diva, the pile contained biographies, autobiographies, memoirs or appreciations of Maria Callas, Janet Baker, Kiri Te Kanawa, Lotte Lehmann, Dorothy Kirsten, Galina Vishnevskaya, Marilyn Horne, Elisabeth Schwarzkopf and Rosa Ponselle. The male of the species lost out badly by comparison, with books by or about Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo, Tito Gobbi and Enrico Caruso.

title: RETURN TO SHADY LANE STIRS MEMORIES OF PAST
description: ON one of those rare days in June -sparkling clear and blue-skied, pleasantly warm - I went home again. And it took more than the 25 years that had passed to find my way back from Rome to Shady Lane Farm. It took my readiness to look back at times that can be no more.

title: CONNECTICUT SEEKS A STARRING ROLE
description: AFTER frequent appearances in television commercials and music videos and a few bit parts in feature films, Connecticut, according to Elisabeth Ingoldsby, is on the verge of making it big in the movies.

title: OFFENSE STRONG IN 30-20 TRIUMPH
description: The Giants, a team that has lived for years on its defense, put on an offensive show tonight. They ran for 221 yards, passed for 192 more and soundly beat the Broncos, 30-20.

title: MAKING SURE ATHLETES GET AN EDUCATION
description: IT has been one year since Northeastern University created the Center for the Study of Sport in Society as the first university-based program to address the issue of the exploitation of student-athletes and their educational rights on a nationwide scale.

title: THE DISH IS ONLY PART OF IT
description: Those big dish antennas are certainly the most conspicuous part of the private earth stations that allow viewers to receive programs directly from satellites rather than from local television stations and cable systems. However, the dish is only part of the complete earth station, and the associated electronic equipment greatly affects the final result. While an earlier column in this space discussed the dish itself, our present concern will be with its electronic ancillaries and its proper installation.

title: LOOKING UP TROUBLE
description: THE FIRST time I went to England, George told me to look up a baron. Let us call him Lord Flutter. ''When you get down around the Cotswolds, nip over to the castle and look up Lord Flutter,'' George urged.

title: NEW YORK'S THRIVING HISPANIC BANKS
description: CARLOS CORREA, director of New York operations for Banco de Ponce, likes to describe his institution as ''a David going up against the Goliaths'' of American banking. But among New York's Hispanic population - at least two million people, and growing larger every day - Banco de Ponce is itself something of a giant.

title: 6 DEAD IN NEW FLARE-UP IN BEIRUT
description: At least six people were reported killed as new fighting, the most intense in several weeks, flared overnight between Christian and Moslem militia forces in Beirut and its suburbs.

title: A SUDDEN SILENCE IN THE HOUSE
description: THE house is extremely quiet these days.

title: VITALITY WITHOUT POPULARITY FOR COUNTRY-MUSIC'S WOMEN
description: On the country-music sales chart of the Billboard magazine most recent to this writing, the top 13 positions are occupied by men. Given the prominence of weepy sentimentality in country music's history, this suggests that the macho-outlaw movement may have gone too far. Perhaps the paucity of women at the top of the charts just now is a mere coincidence. If it isn't, it suggests a musical genre in deep trouble.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

RABBINICAL GOALS
description: There are committees to consider issues relating to aging, youth, family life, education, social action, congregational leadership and even liturgy. ''The work of the liturgy committee is to screen new prayer books for theological, ideological and stylistic considerations,'' Rabbi Jack Stern explained. ''For example, we try to be very scrupulous in our avoidance of sexist language. We don't say brotherhood of man but rather refer to a shared humanity.''

title: FOR THE WHITNEY, ADDING LESS MAY RESULT IN MORE
description: Maybe the only real solution to the problem of adding to the Whitney Museum of American Art on Madison Avenue is not to put a modern building, as some have suggested, or a post-modern one, such as Michael Graves has designed, beside Marcel Breuer's present structure. Perhaps the real answer would be to put up a limestone Beaux-Arts building, preferably one that looked as if it had been there for a long time and once spanned the entire blockfront. With any luck, in a few years people would begin to talk about what a shame it was that the Breuer building had intruded upon a lovely stretch of Madison Avenue and caused the demolition of the northern half of one of the city's finest classical compositions.

title: MISS O'GORMAN PLANS TO BE MARRIED SEPT. 21
description: Martha Alan O'Gorman, an editorial assistant with the Cold Spring Harbor (L.I.) Laboratory, and Stephen Colton McMaster, senior product manager at Del Laboratories in Plainview, L.I., plan to be married Sept. 21.

title: JONATHAN BUSHEY MARRIES MISS JAY
description: Melissa Catherine Jay, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Peter Jay of Port Washington Estates, L.I., and North River, N.Y., was married yesterday to Jonathon Raymond Bushey, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Raymond Joseph Bushey Jr. of Brookville, L.I. The Rev. Charles H. Morris, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Jay home in Port Washington Estates.

title: THE HIGH COST OF LOW PRICES
description: * Over the last three years, the Huffy Corporation cut the average price of its bicycles to $63 from $74 -yet the Dayton, Ohio, manufacturer continues to lose sales to even cheaper imports from Taiwan.

title: MANAGING CLUB CRISIS AT HARVARD
description: Mason Hammond, 82 years old, lover of porcelain, retired professor of Latin and the history of ancient Rome, crossed the sunny brick terrace in front of the Harvard Faculty Club the other day, took off his wide-brim straw hat and, passing through the doorway, seemed immediately at home in the club's cool, handsome and slightly dowdy environs. It was after noon. Mr. Hammond was ready for lunch.

title: Hiding the War in the White House
description: When war comes, warned Senator Hiram Johnson in 1919, truth is the first casualty. The maxim applies to Nicaragua. America's covert war there has filled a whole hospital - and yet more evasion and deception came to light just last week.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTY
description: SOLDIERS' PAY, by William Faulkner. (Washington Square/Pocket Books, $4.95.) Published in 1926, ''Soldiers' Pay'' was Faulkner's first novel. In it, a mutilated and amnesiac soldier comes home from war. On his way he meets a war widow and a veteran, who accompany him to his small Southern town. An unsigned review in The Book Review said ''This book rings true. It is the opinion of this reviewer that it belongs among such excellent conceptions of war and man as are to be found in 'What Price Glory' and C. E. Montague's 'Disenchantment.' '' Washington Square/ Pocket Books has also republished Faulkner's second novel, the 1927 MOSQUITOES ($4.95). In ''Mosquitoes,'' Faulkner placed his myriad characters on a New Orleans matron's yacht, where they buzzed and stung each other for several days. Reviewers continued to hail Faulkner's writing but chided him for trying to be too clever.

title: TED TURNER'S LATEST DEAL
description: In the film industry's early years, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer claimed ''more stars than there are in the heavens.'' United Artists, founded by some of the most hallowed names in the Hollywood pantheon, was another power in the business.

title: ERIN MCGILLICUDY BECOMES THE BRIDE OF JONTAHAN B. MILLS, A LAWYER, IN RYE
description: Constance Erin McGillicuddy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Francis McGillicuddy of Rye, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Butler Mills, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Willis Nathaniel Mills Jr. of Wilton, Conn. Msgr. Donald Pryor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: ECONOMIC WARFARE WOULD BACKFIRE
description: ANTI-APARTHEID economic sanctions, passed overwhelmingly in the House and apparently headed for Senate approval, would have no impact on South Africa's racial policies. Although replete with bipartisan indignation, the proposed sanctions would prove as effective a weapon as a 21-gun salute -lots of flash and noise and an acrid whiff of gunpowder, but no fear of anyone being hurt.

title: 'MERRY WIVES' HITS A DULL NOTE AT DREW
description: When the music in one's memory bank intrudes upon the words of Shakespeare, something must be askew.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Prices Off on Togs For Swim, Leisure The Endless Summer opened first in Paramus, N.J., then on Central Avenue north of the Greenburgh Nature Center in the Scarsdale Park Mall in 1983 and the newest store is in The Mall at Short Hills, also in New Jersey. The Scarsdale and Paramus branches are selling women's swim and leisure wear in sizes 4 to 46 with cup sizes A to DD, with a current sale dropping prices by 25 to 40 percent until cleared. Nonsale items include previews of 1986 styles.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 11, 1985 Fiction

title: REPAIRING THE HOUSE OF GUCCI
description: THE name Gucci is normally associated with wealth, high fashion, fine leather goods and a certain patrician style. But lately, it has been tied to gossip column stories about a father and a son at each other's throats and ashtrays and tape recorders hurled across a board room.

title: HITTING BECOMES BUSH LEAGUE
description: DAVE HOSTETLER, the first baseman for the Iowa Cubs, noticed something odd as he perused the American Association statistics recently. Only seven players in the eight-team league were hitting better than .300; only two of those had as many 200 plate appearances. ''That's amazing to me,'' said Hostetler, who at 29 is in his fifth year in the Triple-A league. ''Usually there are about 15 guys over .300, and there are a lot of guys hitting over 30 home runs and driving in a lot of runs. It's just not here this year.''

title: U.S. IS SAID TO TELL SOUTH AFRICA THAT POLICIES COULD HARDEN
description: The Reagan Administration has told South African officials that an ''emotional climate'' exists in the United States that could harden American policies toward that country, a senior Administration official said today.

title: WIESENBERGER: BIBLE OF THE INDUSTRY
description: THE Wiesenberger yearbook, formally called Wiesenberger Investment Companies Service, is the oldest, largest and most all-embracing of the mutual fund guides. Many libraries subscribe, and the book's fans include many well-known professionals in the securities business.

title: NEW YORK CITES FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 26 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: NEW YORK SCHOOLS FACING A SHORTAGE OF 4,200 TEACHERS
description: With less than a month to go before classes resume in New York City's public schools, the Board of Education faces what it calls a ''critical shortage'' of teachers.

title: AUGSBURG
description: To the Editor: The article ''Augsburg at 2,000'' (Travel, June 30) was of more than passing interest to me; I am a native of that city with ambivalent feelings about it, as would be logical for a refugee from Nazi Germany.

title: U.S. RULING CLOUDS TV-ACCESS DEBATE
description: A RECENT Federal Court ruling has brought confusion and uncertainty to the state's effort to increase public access to cable television.

title: ARE MOVIES READY FOR REAL ORIENTALS?
description: It was at the movies that my father first saw America. In Shanghai cinemas he watched ''North by Northwest'' and ''It's a Wonderful Life,'' whetting his appetite to cross an ocean. Years later, as his Chinese-American son, I sat in southern California theaters, and saw an America that did not include me - an exciting land, a romantic land, but not my land.

title: THREE ACTORS EXCEL IN A DOUBLE BILL
description: AN evening of one-act plays, ''Lone Star'' and ''Private Wars'' by James McLure, being presented by the Arena Players Repertory Company, is not about the two plays as much as about the three actors who appear in them.

title: THE ART AND ANGST OF JIMMY ERNST
description: WELL-PREPARED survey exhibitions stimulate new insights. This is particularly true of the current Jimmy Ernst installation at Guild Hall in East Hampton, where the conflict running through four decades of painting will likely come as a surprise to those who knew the late East Hampton artist as one of the gentlest, kindest and warmest of human beings.

title: WHEN THE COAST ISN'T CLEAR TO THE COAST
description: Standing guard at the Greenwich checkpoint, Rick Allegrini has seen it all: borrowed passes, attempted bribes, and, most recently, two people trying to sneak past by hiding in the trunk of a car. The more people try to get to the beach, the more the people who own the land along the shore try to keep them out.

title: VIOLENCE SPREADS IN THE WEST BANK
description: In what appeared to be the latest in a series of individual attacks involving Jews and Arabs, an Israeli settler was stabbed today as he walked past the Arab marketplace in Hebron, in the occupied West Bank.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 11, 1985
description: International

title: IT'S HARDER TO FIND A MIDDLE GROUND IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: DURBAN, South Africa

title: ON AMERICAN THEATER AND 'AUTHENTIC' MUSIC
description: To the Editor: Ido agree with Frank Rich [''Highs and Lows of the London Stage,'' July 14] that one cannot help being struck by the extraordinary vitality and variety of London theater - here, indeed, is God's plenty - as compared to the sclerotic world of Broadway. But I think it's time that all of us involved in the theater take a closer look at the real source of our woes, which is not strictly, as Mr. Rich and others keep pointing out, the finances of Broadway or the commercialized packaging of everything or the challenge of television, or - what may be called the ''Masterpiece Theater'' syndrome -the feeling that actors with British accents are superior to actors who talk American.

title: GUIDES WITH A 10-YEAR PERSPECTIVE
description: IN addition to the Wiesenberger yearbook, two of the other handbooks cover all mutual funds, both load and no-load. Each one - Donoghue's Mutual Fund Almanac and the Mutual Fund Sourcebook - takes a different approach to the market.

title: SCREEN: 'INSIGNIFICANCE,' MYTHIC TALE OF THE 50's
description: MOST films these days carry a perfunctory, small-print disclaimer stating that the characters and events we are about to see are fictitious and any resemblance to persons living or dead is entirely coincidental.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: An official of the Army Corps of Engineers told a United States Senate panel last month that the controversial Tocks Island dam on the Delaware River - proposed in the 1960's, but never built -would have seen New Jersey through the current water shortage.

title: MARCOS DOES HIS BEST TO KEEP FOES OFF BALANCE
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos faces a growing Communist insurgency and constant demands for reform from Washington and international lenders. The credibility of his Government has been under attack since last year, when a citizens board found that a military conspiracy involving the chief of staff of the armed forces, a close friend of the President, was responsible for the August 1983 murder of opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. And this week, the opposition is to file a motion to impeach the President in the National Assembly. Yet a week ago, Mr. Marcos reversed himself, saying he was ''seriously considering'' holding Presidential elections this year to ''renew the President's mandate with the people.''

title: KEY AIDE FOR JOBS AND DEVELOPMENT
description: Earlier this year, Governor Cuomo chose his Banking Commissioner, Vincent Tese, to take over two key state jobs: the newly created position of Director of Economic Development and chairmanship of the State Urban Development Corporation. As economic-development director, Mr. Tese will coordinate more than 20 agencies that had sometimes been criticized for operating with a lack of coordination. As head of U.D.C., traditionally a builder of large public projects ranging from low-income housing to New York City's convention center, he is shaping an agency whose mission is shifting in emphasis from physical development to job creation.

title: Poor Turnout In Casablanca
description: It was billed as the last best chance for the Arab League, but when the organization met in Casablanca last week, some nations made their absence felt. While representatives of 16 of the 21 members of the league assembled, all but 10 heads of state sent regrets.

title: MOM'S COMMAND TAKES THE ALABAMA
description: In what is becoming a familiar and predictable sight this year, Mom's Command today opened a huge lead over the best 3-year-old fillies around and stretched her advantage to an easy victory in a classic race despite posting a mediocre time. It is the style that carried her through a sweep of the New York filly triple crown earlier this year, and today it got her a four-length victory over Fran's Valentine in the Alabama Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: STONEWARE WITH A SPECIAL TOUCH
description: A man, hollow-eyed and haggard, is shown in a tangle of writhing snakes on the surface of a mud-colored late-1880's stoneware bottle. This is a jug with a message - and one of many surprises in a small, select show of mostly 19th-century American ceramics, on view through Sept. 8 in the American Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The vessel is a passionate expression of protest against the evils of drink.

title: HOW TO SURVIVE THE WINTER -- WITH BASIL
description: IT took Americans a long time to discover basil but now, at the end of every summer, we wonder how we are going to get through the winter without it. This herb has become almost indispensable as a flavoring for tomatoes (whether ripe fresh or canned Italian plum), eggplant, peppers and certain fish, chicken and pasta dishes. Unfortunately, when dried, basil is almost worthless. Unlike some other herbs -rosemary, thyme or tarragon, for example - its taste does not intensify in this state, it seems to vanish.

title: TENDERFOOT AMONG THE SHERPAS
description: At dawn the sun creeps over a high ridge and you can feel the morning chill in your bones. A voice calls from outside the tent, offering hot tea. Shaking off a night's sleep, you groggily splash yourself with warm water from a tin bowl. After a breakfast of oatmeal, dry biscuits and coffee, you are off for another day of trekking up and down the steep foothills of the Himalayas.

title: TOPICS
description: IT was balloon day at Moriches Elementary School - a celebration of the school's 10th birthday. Children's voices buzzed through the school in anticipation of the afternoon's events.

title: AN OUTBREAK OF PARTISANSHIP
description: THE nation's governors in recent years have for the most part been so close ideologically that it has often been difficult to distinguish Democrats from Republicans. Collectively, on matters that affect their interests, they have from time to time been at odds with both the Reagan White House and Democratic Congressional leaders. Thus, a bitter partisan dispute that broke like a mountain thunderstorm at the 77th annual meeting of the National Governors' Association last week left many of them shaken about the future of their nonpartisan approach.

title:
ANTIQUES;

A TRADITION IS UPHELD IN KENT
description: THE Kent Antiques Show, now in its 37th year, is the oldest summer show in Connecticut. It has achieved that status because, year after year, exhibitors have offered good antiques, the authenticity of which they guaranteed.

title: ALEXANDRA D. GARBERS TO WED DAVID PRUNER
description: Announcement has been made by Virginia Garbers of Boston and Frederick Garbers of New York of the engagement of their daughter Alexandra Devlin Garbers to David Randall Pruner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Pruner of Greenwich, Conn. The wedding is planned for Oct. 12.

title: THE SECRET BEHIND STAR WARS
description: IN THE MILITARY, THEY ARE known as ''skunk works'' - an elite band of scientists and engineers laboring in secrecy on important projects. At the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, a Federal site for the design of nuclear weapons and other advanced technologies, about 45 miles east of San Francisco, they are known variously as ''O Group'' or ''Lowell's group'' (after Lowell Wood, the founder). They are ''eccentric and extraordinarily bright,'' says a high Livermore official. To a critic within Livermore who opposes the construction of new weapons, they are ''bright young hotshots who are socially maladjusted. All their time and energy is spent on science.''

title: POPE URGES AFRICAN LEADER TO UPHOLD RIGHTS
description: Pope John Paul II today offered three African Presidents what a Vatican official called ''an implicit pact,'' promising Roman Catholic support in return for a respect for freedom, social justice and human life.

title: F.C.C. DENOUNCES FAIRNESS DOCTRINE
description: The Fairness Doctrine, which requires broadcasters to cover important community issues and present balanced reporting and differing views on controversial matters, was upheld by the Supreme Court in a 1969 landmark case. But that didn't stop critics from raising questions.

title: T. A. SCULLY WED TO ANN HOFFMAN
description: The marriage of Ann Elise Hoffman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Hurlock Hoffman of Pittsburgh, and Thomas Andrew Scully, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Scully of Philadelphia, took place yesterday at the Fox Chapel Presbyterian Church in Pittsburgh. The Rev. John H. Scott performed the ceremony.

title: HANNAH FELTON BECOMES A BRIDE
description: Hannah Montgomery Felton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar Conway Felton of Princeton, N.J., was married at Trinity Episcopal Church there yesteray to John Louis Lyons, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Tolman Lyons of Andover, Mass. The Rev. Jean R. Smith, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Richard K. Gross, the Roman Catholic chaplain of Phillips Academy in Andover, of which the bridegroom is an alumnus and where his father is a history teacher, co-officiated.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MARIA THERESA By Petra Mathers. Illustrations by the author. 32 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95. (Ages 5 to 9) Here is the story of a chicken who flees the coop. You know the type. No ordinary laying hen, this one sometimes stops ''in mid-peck as if listening to faraway voices.'' Favored by a guardian who fills her head with opera, she often wanders from the flock to watch the traffic teeming below her rooftop perch. She is, of course, a New York City chicken. And one day, when Signora Rinaldo forgets to close the gate, Maria Theresa jumps.

title: CITY S.R.O. MORATORIUM LEAVES 113 PROJECTS IN LIMBO
description: IS it an S.R.O., or is it not? For the residents and owners of 113 buildings in New York City, it is a question that won't go away.

title: MUSICAL PORTRAYS STREET LIFE
description: ''THERE are three kinds of people who haven't made it,'' said the composer Charles Frink of New London. ''Those who tried and failed, those who were too discouraged or beaten down to try, and those who decided not to. These people tend to gather in places like Bank Street.''

title: Q AND A
description: Exemptions for Elderly Question: I have been told that any New York City resident age 65 or over in a rent-regulated apartment is automatically exempt from rent increases. Is this true? . . . R. F. McC., Manhattan Answer: No. Only rent-regulated tenants age 62 or over who are not receiving public assistance, who have a disposable household income of no more than $10,000 and whose rent is one-third or more of their monthly income can apply for exemption from rent increases through a city program known as SCRIE - Senior Citizen Rent Increase Exemption. The landlord receives a certificate for a tax abatement equal to the amount of the exemption. For more information, write SCRIE, 17 John Street, 4th floor, New York, N. Y. 10038 or call 566-5541. Preferential Rent Question: I just heard of something called preferential rent. What is this? . . . J. W., Manhattan Answer: Preferential rents, which are usually for family members or friends of the owner, are rents lower than the Redinger legal maximum. A tenant with a preferential rent has all the rights and obligations of those under the rent regulations, according to Nathaniel Geller, assistant deputy counsel in the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal. When the lease expires or the tenant vacates, the maximum lawful rent can be restored. Previous Commitment Question: I have a three-year lease, written by a previous owner, with an option to renew for three more years because of improvements I made. Can the new owner refuse to honor my option? . . . L. B., Manhattan Answer: If you have an option in writing signed by the previous owner, this is a contractual right that the new owner cannot abrogate even though state law no longer obliges landlords to offer leases of longer than two years, according to Mr. Geller and other lawyers.

title: DAVID LIFLAND WEDS MISS RADMER
description: Catherine Ann Radmer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roland H. Radmer of Cottage Grove, Wis., was married yesterday to David Thomas Lifland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William T. Lifland of Princeton, N.J. The ceremony was performed by Mayor Barbara Sigmund of Princeton Borough at the home of the bridegroom's grandparents, Mr. and Mrs. Abbot Low Moffat, in Princeton.

title: DIVIDED YOUNG DEMOCRATS PICK WOMAN AS CHIEF
description: The election this year of the first woman as national president was supposed to be a proud moment for the Young Democrats of America.

title: POLIO'S PAINFUL LEGACY
description: In the dispute over how to handle postpolio syndrome, I want to vote strongly on the side of exercise. I've experienced the muscle-weakening described in Joy Horowitz's article and put it down to the aging process.

title: CAREN A. SENTER GREENWICH BRIDE
description: Caren Amy Senter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Senter of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to Francis J. Mootz 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Mootz Jr. of Chesterfield, Mo. Rabbi David Fass performed the ceremony at the Belle Haven Club.

title: MAKING THE LANGUAGE THEIRS
description: AFRICAN SHORT STORIES Edited by Chinua Achebe and C. L. Innes. 159 pp. Portsmouth, N.H.: Heinemann. Paper, $5. THE PENGUIN BOOK OF MODERN AFRICAN POETRY Third edition. Edited and with an introduction by Gerald Moore and Ulli Beier. 315 pp. New York: Penguin Books. Paper, $6.95.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT WINS LICENSE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has approved a full-power operating license for the Unit 1 reactor at the Philadelphia Electric Company's Limerick nuclear plant.

title: D-DAY IN THE WAR ON MARIJUANA
description: Americans worried about the decline of Yankee ingenuity may take cold comfort at that being demonstrated by native growers of marijuana. These are high times on the pot farm. During the 1980's, growers in the United States have become the fourth-largest suppliers of marijuana on our own streets, after Colombia, Mexico and Jamaica.

title: IN GUATEMALA, THE ARMY'S RETREAT MAY BE GOOD POLITICS
description: The Guatemalan Army is running out of money, options and time. After 30 years of nearly unbroken rule, the commanders who govern the country have proved incapable of managing the worst depression since the 1930's. At the same time, they find themselves fighting a continuing guerrilla war with aging equipment, while public support withers and foreign friends dwindle in a period when military regimes are less and less accepted in polite international company.

title: Music
description: Although Bonnie Raitt never attained the massive popularity enjoyed by Carole King and Linda Ronstadt during the 1970's, it was not for lack of talent. The singer, guitarist and sometime songwriter, who will be at the Ritz (11th Street, between Third and Fourth avenues) on Wednesday, came out of the Cambridge, Mass., folk scene in the late 1960's, but her stylistic range has always gone way beyond folk to include blues, rock, country and pop.

title: A NEW LOOK THAT'S MORE THAN THE SUM OF ITS PARTS
description: WHICH came first, the tights, the wrap skirts or the big blouses? It's hard to say, but a number of stylish New Yorkers have matched these garments and come up with one of the summer's most appealing and up-to-date combinations.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

PINE LAKE (SHANGRI-LA)
description: LINDA and Steve Rozenfeld are pedigreed Pine Lakers. Their parents spent summers at Pine Lake. They did, too -and attended its day camp. They met at Pine Lake, got married (admittedly not on the premises), and moved into their own Pine Lake bungalow. All their children have indulged in Pine Lake summers.

title: NOW IT'S THE I.R.S. VERSUS STUDENT-LOAN DEFAULTERS
description: The Department of Education has tried everything from friendly letters to collection agencies to get a million people to pay the more than $4 billion they owe in Federal student loans. Nothing has worked. Last week the department played what a spokesman called ''the ultimate trump card.'' William J. Bennett, the Secretary of Education, announced that defaulters will have 60 days to work out a repayment schedule and begin to pay back their loans; after that, their names will be turned over to the Internal Revenue Service, with instructions to start withholding any income tax refunds due up to the amount owed.

title: MISS BIRD TO WED GARY W. MASSEY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bird Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Stuart, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Hasler Bird, to Gary W. Massey, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayne H. Massey of Forestville, Md. The wedding is planned for late next month.

title: PLANNING FOUGHT BY CATSKILL FARMERS
description: In 1845, tenant farmers in Delaware County killed a sheriff and tarred and feathered dozens of other people in protests against the wealthy landowners who controlled much of the area.

title: EFFORT IS STARTED TO BRING BACK BUS RIDERSHIP
description: WESTCHESTER officials, concerned about recent losses in ridership on the county's extensive bus system, are taking steps to increase ridership and thus decrease the subsidies the service receives. Better marketing - promoting the advantages of ridership and telling prospective riders where and when to catch a bus -plus $100,000 for a marketing study this fall are among plans to turn about the losses.

title: THE VESCO WATCH
description: The elusive Robert L. Vesco is in Havana, according to no less an authority than Fidel Castro. The Cuban leader also acknowledged last week that the fugitive American financier is receiving medical treatment. Mr. Castro said he did not know the financier, who, it is often said, has been providing economic counseling to Havana, and angrily denied a Justice Department report that he was under house arrest.

title: The Pitfalls En Route To a Dream (SER>First of two articles
description: THE purchase of a vacation home is normally the fulfillment of a dream rather than a practical search for shelter. No wonder buyers show an impatient tendency to overlook or downplay any problem likely to interfere with the enjoyment of its special delights.

title:
ART;

AT YALE, 2 EXHIBITIONS OF POPULAR ART
description: ''IF spontaneity, dream indicated composition, abolition of the everyday, and the conquest of revelatory emotion constitute Surrealism, then Haiti has been Surrealist all along.''

title: RESCUING HAWKS
description: THEY were smuggled into this country from Finland as eggs in May 1984 and were seized a month later by the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service as fledgling Northern goshawks. Last month 25 of the hawks, confiscated in California and Illinois, were flown to England by British Airways for eventual release to the wild.

title: ULSTER CATHOLICS FIGHT BRITISH TROOPS AFTER PROTESTANT PARADE
description: About 200 Roman Catholic youths, angered by a Protestant parade through their neighborhood, hurled gasoline bombs at British troops today, who fired a hail of rubber bullets to repel them.

title: A PATIO IS NOT A FRONT PORCH
description: I MISS a front porch. For 20 years I have lived in a ranch house with its smooth, uncluttered facade, just three steps and a stoop to allow ingress and egress from our domicile.

title: PLAYERS SCORE MAJOR VICTORY IN DEFEAT OF SALARY CAP
description: TIM LOLLAR earned $50,000 one year, $300,000 the next. Tony Pena went from $72,500 to $365,000. Fernando Valenzuela increased his income from $350,000 one year to $1 million the next.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:When we retire next year my husband and I plan to tour the United States in a mobile home. Can you suggest books that would list campgrounds and places of special interest? How does one get the Golden Passport allowing admission to all the national parks? - P. G., Morristown, N.J. Answer:Woodall's Campground Directory (Woodall Publishing Company, $12.95) gives details of thousands of state, national park and private campgrounds in the United States, Canada and Mexico. The private parks are rated by Woodall representatives who, the company says, visit them every year. Under each state the directory describes tourist attractions, gives road rules and includes maps. Some restaurants are listed along with information on a restaurant hot line that provides the names of places that cater to drivers of recreational vehicles.

title: MEMORIES FROM 1945 LIVE AS ART
description: The atomic bomb that hit Hiroshima smashed the city and burned inhabitants, and in smaller ways, the fireball seared millions of tiny, hideous details into the survivors' minds.

title: KEY CLERIC SEIZED AS HE LEADS MARCH NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: One of South Africa's most outspoken critics of apartheid, the Rev. Allan Boesak, was arrested today along with 18 other people, many of them clergymen, after defying a police order against attending a funeral in a black township near Cape Town.

title: LOVE A PARADE? YOU'RE IN THE RIGHT PLACE
description: There is a single, sharp crack when the 144 marines shoulder their rifles. Then, at the same, precise instant, the men in navy, gold-buttoned jackets stride forward, their white trousers bending at the knee, their bayonets glinting, their step steady and measured.

title: INDIA SAYS IT HAS AN ADVANCED ATOM REACTOR
description: Amid new warnings to Pakistan about developing a nuclear bomb, India announced this week that it had successfully commissioned a large new atomic reactor described as capable of producing fuel for a nuclear weapon.

title: HARVARD TO DROP AN ADMISSION TEST
description: Applicants to the highly competitive master of business administration program at the Harvard Business School will no longer be required to take an admission test.

title: GOVERNOR OF ALASKA WEIGHING IMPACT OF IMPEACHMENT INQUIRY
description: Gov. Bill Sheffield was relaxing today at a remote lake, where an aide said the Governor was assessing the damage that recent impeachment hearings might have inflicted on his chances for re-election.

title: CONSMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings

title: A CHANCE TO COVET THY NEIGHBOR'S HOUSE
description: FOR a cheap vacation, you cannot beat house-sitting.

title: BIZARRE TRIPLE PLAY BAFFLES PARTICIPANTS
description: Despite the two-day players strike, major league baseball was not deprived of its weekly contribution to ''bloopers, bleeps and blunders.'' If fans were wondering how anyone could top the Yankees' foul-up on Aug. 2, when Rickey Henderson singled to center field and Bobby Meacham and Dale Berra were thrown out at home plate, the St. Louis Cardinals and Chicago Cubs obliged last Thursday, collaborating on a triple play that isn't likely to be duplicated soon.

title: VICTIMS OF ABUSE SEEK HELP IN EXPERIMENTAL COURT
description: Almost 4,000 women have sought help in the last year and a half at an experimental criminal court here for cases of domestic violence.

title: UNFLATTERING CRITIQUES
description: To the Editor:

title: VOYAGE TO COMFORT
description: IT WAS THE FIRST SPACE THE COUPLE HAD LOOKED AT AFTER they decided to move downtown. Although they had lived for many years in an apartment on the Upper East Side, a new baby, an enviable collection of large modern paintings by such artists as Alex Katz, Fernando Botero and Rufino Tamayo, and the need to entertain large crowds prompted them to consider living in what had once been a warehouse of an Oriental rug dealer. Situated on lower Fifth Avenue, the nearly 4,000-square-foot space boasted some 40 windows and a forthright view of the Empire State Building.

title: HONEYMOON LEADS TO A RACING CAREER
description: For Ed Pimm, the driver of one of only two American-built cars in the Domino's 500 at Mount Pocono, Pa., next Sunday, the path to his seat behind the wheel of Skoal Bandit Eagle started seven years ago on his honeymoon.

title:
DINING OUT;

SEASIDE FARE, MINUS THE SAND
description: NOT far from the southernmost tip of New Jersey is a seven-mile-long beach bordered by Avalon to the north and Stone Harbor to the south.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

COMMUTER AIDS
description: METROPOOL, the Stamford, Conn., based nonprofit commuter transportation company, is playing matchmaker to commuters in Westchester and Fairfield Counties. And it is employing a tried-and-true technique for that purpose: the personal newspaper advertisement.

title: THE EMPEROR'S NEW CLOTHES: REVISING CHILDREN'S CLASSICS
description: FILM MAKERS, led primarily by Walt Disney, have always taken great liberties in their productions of juvenile classics. Perhaps publishers feel that Hollywood has inured readers to tampering with fairy tales and fables, because in recent years new and sometimes startling versions of the classics have been appearing in bookstores. Now that libraries are no longer the main purchasers of children's books, publishers are becoming increasingly conservative about the titles they release. Knowing only what has sold, not what will sell, in the last five years they have been churning out a steady supply of illustrated gift editions of standard works in the public domain. Parents just cannot read every new story that comes out each year, so they generally buy the titles they enjoyed. But when they buy ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' they expect it to be ''The Sleeping Beauty.'' Unfortunately, in many of the lavish and well-publicized new gift books, children are getting far less than the glossy packaging promises.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: OLD MOTHER WEST WIND. Golden Anniversary Edition. By Thornton W. Burgess. Illustrated by Harrison Cady. Little, Brown.

title: KATHERINE MANNNG WEDS CAREY DUNNE
description: Katherine Wise Manning, a producer for Channel 13's ''Currents,'' a weekly public affairs program, and Carey Richard Dunne, an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, were married yesterday. Judge Paul D. Shapero of the Stamford (Conn.)

title: LONGSTANDING DIVISIONS KEEP UGANDA EDGY
description: The steely stare of soldiers greets motorists and pedestrians in this crumbling East African city in the aftermath of the military coup that overthrew the Government of President Milton Obote two weeks ago. Tension is apparent on the faces of all residents, African and Western, but it is the Ugandans who appear most fearful after the latest eruption of the divisive volatility that has plagued them and their ancestors for more than 600 years.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The table of contents in The Times Magazine today omits the page number for the solutions to last week's puzzles. They are on page 51 of the magazine.

title: M. S. ROY, MEMBER OF BOBSLED TEAM, IS WED TO CAROLINE HARRIS DARLINGTON
description: At St. Eustace Episcopal Church in Lake Placid, N.Y., yesterday Caroline Harris Darlington, a daughter of Mrs. Fred E. Brown of Harding Township, N.J., and Lake Placid and Peter Darlington of New York and Lake Placid, was married to Matthew Spencer Roy, a son of Margaret Roy of Saranac Lake, N.Y., and the late George Robert Roy. The Rev. William D. Hayes performed the ceremony.

title: FOR BRITAIN'S COAL MINERS, BITTERNESS LINGERS
description: It is not his debts, which are many, or his clothes, which are few, that most trouble Jeffrey Johnson, a West Yorkshire miner, in the aftermath of his union's yearlong strike, which collapsed in March.

title: 'CLAWS' -- JUST WHEN YOU THOUGHT CRABBING WAS SAFE AGAIN
description: IT WAS a cloudy summer day with a stiff north wind. Not a good day for the beach.

title: OPPORTUNITY CALLS
description: STEWART BROWN didn't grow up wanting to be a police officer. After completing high school in 1978, he went to the University of Southern California as a pre-med student.

title: VOICES RING OUT AT A FRESH AIR CAMP
description: Not even the chirping of birds could be heard throughout the densely wooded acres of the Anita Bliss Coler girls camp in upstate New York. But at half past noon, a chorus of hallelujahs and clapping echoed through the trees as more than 200 girls sang grace before lunch.

title: ROGERS AND LONGO WIN STAGES IN COORS CLASSIC
description: Thurlow Rogers of the United States and Jeanne Longo of France took victories today in the Aspen Circuit Race of the Coors Bicycle Classic.

title: CARDS TIE FOR FIRST: MCGEE HAS 7 HITS
description: Willie McGee, the National League's leading batter, completed a seven-hit outing by rapping four hits, including a three-run homer, to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 13-4 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies in the second game for a sweep of a day-night doubleheader.

title: FOR FILIPINO REBELS, A 'NEW DEAL' VIA THE GUN
description: The boyish-looking guerrilla, smoking a cigarette and cleaning his .45-caliber pistol, had just finished what was for him a day's work. That afternoon, he said, he had killed a colonel in the Philippine Constabulary.

title: 2 Killed and 27 Hurt In Chilean Protests
description: Two people were killed, 27 were hurt and at least 275 were arrested in clashes between the police and anti-Government demonstrators Friday night, the police said today.

title: VIRGINIA GREENE WEDS
description: At the Old First Presbyterian Church in Huntington, L.I., yesterday Virginia A. Greene, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Greene of Huntington, was married to N. Scott Johnson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman E. Johnson of Madison, Wis.

title: MORBIER: CHEESE WITH A DASH OF ASH
description: ITS known, most commonly, as that funny French cheese with the black streak running through the center. It's called Morbier, and the most authentic version can be found about seven miles north-east of the tiny Jura mountain village on the Freanche-Comte that gives its name to this supple cow's milk cheese.

title: WASTE CONVERSION
description: Cutting costs is one thing, but using waste to cut them is another, and that is precisely what the New Rochelle Hospital Medical Center is doing. Last month, the hospital set into operation a plan put together by James Vigilis, its director of engineering and assistant administrator.

title: POLLUTION, FROM TOP TO BOTTOM
description: Seven northeastern states asked a Federal appeals court last week to force the Environmental Protection Agency to adopt tougher rules to curb dispersal of pollutants that contribute to acid rain. Their suit, the latest of several court challenges, is aimed at coal-burning plants in the Middle West that use tall smokestacks to disperse emissions.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Cars Live Vestron Video 59 minutes. $29.95 Slick and sullen, the Boston-based Cars have perfected an ultracommercial new-wave style of surprising substance.

title: POLICE RECRUITS LEARN THE LAW OF SURVIVAL
description: ''You don't become a police officer in the Police Academy. You become a trained recruit capable of learning the real job in the real world.''

title: 3 YOUTHS ARE CHARGED IN S.I. BEATING DEATH
description: Three young people were charged with second-degree murder yesterday in the death Friday night of a New Jersey man found beaten to death in a park in West New Brighton, S.I., the police said.

title: STRIKE: MIXING FAN'S EMOTION, BUSINESSMAN'S LOGIC
description: NOW that the baseball strike is over, some questions I hear the fans discussing are: Why did it happen? Who is responsible for the settlement? Who won and who lost? Is there a solution?

title: LILIPUTIAN SOLDIERS ON PARADE
description: Britain's leading stately homes are brimming, as one would expect, with paintings of the great masters and rare furnishings. But two of them - Wilton House and Blenheim - have a surprise in store for visitors: extraordinary collections of miniature lead soldiers. Each collection is significant in that it includes figures from two separate periods of toy-soldier artisanship. Wilton House contains an impressive collection of late 18th- and early 19th-century two-dimensional soldiers known as ''flats,'' all set in dioramas and tableaux representing such historic battles as the Charge of the Light Brigade. At Blenheim, a vast assemblage of early 19th-century three-dimensional figures called ''Lucottes'' represent the colorful armies of Napoleon.

title: POLIO'S PAINFUL LEGACY
description: I want people to know that there is a place to turn for information and help with problems related to polio. For 66 years, the Easter Seal Society has been providing services to people of any age with any disability.

title: LISA SCHNEIDER IS WED TO WILLIAM BERNHARD
description: Lisa Schneider, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Schneider of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Bernhard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bernhard of Sands Point and Montauk, L.I., and Culebra, P.R. Town Justice George Sirignano performed the ceremony at the Schneider home.

title: FULL HOUSE
description: ON JULY 31, Pat Harmon retired at age 69 as sports editor of The Cincinnati Post, a position he held for 34 1/2 years. He held onto the position for two reasons: first, he loved writing about sports, and second, there were 13 mouths to feed at home, and sometimes more.

title: WINANS IS SENTENCED
description: R. Foster Winans, a former reporter convicted of passing advance information to stockbrokers from a stock market column he wrote for The Wall Street Journal, was sentenced last week to 18 months in prison, a $5,000 fine and five years' probation, including 400 hours of community service. Mr. Winans had requested community service in lieu of jail time.

title: GOURMET FOOD TO GO: A GUIDE FOR THE HUNGRY
description: SULTRY summer days are still the best excuse to leave the cooking to someone else, and now, thanks to the growing number of gourmet takeout shops around the state, a delightful meal -from chilled soup to nut-studded brownies - can be arranged at a moment's notice.

title: ORNAMENTAL GRASSES CAN ENHANCE THE GARDEN
description: Fescues, bluegrasses, perennial ryes and bents are the grasses that make lawns green. These grasses have an established place in the home landscape for the traditional velvety greensward. But they are not the only grasses to plant in gardens.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE CENTRE OF THE UNIVERSE IS 18 BAEDEKERSTRASSE. By Jonathan Gathorne-Hardy. (Hamish Hamilton/David & Charles, $15.95.) The title story of Jonathan Gathorne-Hardy's heterogeneous collection of six is about a man who knows too much.

title: E.A. ROSENTHAL OF MONTEFIORE
description: Edmund A. Rosenthal, the former chairman of the board of the Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx, died yesterday of a heart attack in Sturbridge, Mass., while returning to New York from a vacation. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PAYING BY DISEASE, NOT BY THE DAY
description: THE promise of medical science never seemed brighter - researchers are continually finding effective new drugs, devices and therapies. But the cost of it all is rising faster than the rate of inflation, and faster than the Federal deficit. With bipartisan agreement, Washington has imposed stringent cost controls on its biggest health program, Medicare, which provides insurance for doctor and hospital costs for 30 million elderly and disabled people. Medicare now pays hospitals a set amount for each case, depending on the diagnosis, regardless of how long the patient is hospitalized. This system, being put into effect over a three-year period that began in October 1983, has given hospitals new incentives to economize. But some members of Congress and many physicians say it has adversely affected the quality of care, prompting some hospitals to discharge patients prematurely.
