A recent study found that the system of fixed payment rates for each of 468 diagnostic categories discriminates against certain hospitals because it ''does not adequately reflect the complexity and severity of illness'' and the variations among patients with the same diagnosis. A spokesman for the Health Care Financing Administration, the agency that runs Medicare, agreed some adjustment was needed. Private employers and insurance companies are also cracking down on costs. In the new competitive climate, doctors, hospitals and nursing homes are seeking new, more efficient ways to deliver care. To analyze these trends, The Week in Review called on two experts: Professor Karen Davis, an economist who is chairman of the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Johns Hopkins University School of Hygiene and Public Health, and Dr. Raymond Scalettar, a trustee of the American Medical Association who specializes in internal medicine in Washington, D.C. Excerpts of their discussion with Robert Pear, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, follow. Question.

title: SCHOOLDAYS, WORKDAYS
description: Out of the mire of a 13-year-old desegregation suit in this Washington suburb has sprung an innovative approach to educating the modern child -transforming ''latchkey'' children, who return from school to homes left empty by working parents, into ''workplace'' children.

title: ALMANACS FOR THE HOT NO-LOAD FUNDS
description: THE assets of no-load mutual funds have been steadily increasing, both in absolute dollars and as a percentage of overall mutual fund assets. It is not surprising, therefore, that three of the six mutual fund almanacs - The Handbook for No-Load Fund Investors, The Individual Investor's Guide to No-Load Mutual Funds and the Dow Jones-Irwin Mutual Funds Yearbook - are solely devoted to the no-loads.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WINTERS COMING, WINTERS GONE. By Allen Glick. (Pinnacle, $15.95.) This novel begins with a view through a rifle scope at night of Vietnamese landscape, and ends back in the United States a decade later as a child is born.

title: SARAH ROSSBACH, DOUGLAS FLEMING ENGAGED TO WED
description: Sarah Rossbach, a writer, and Douglas Morrison Fleming, a vice president of J. P. Morgan Investment Management Inc., plan to be married Oct. 5.

title: SENSORS AT NEWARK WARN OF WINDHEAR
description: Federal Aviation officials and administrators of Newark International Airport are well aware that the crash that took over 130 lives at Dallas-Fort Worth Airport on Aug. 2 and the phenomenon said to have caused it could be repeated here, but state-of-the-art equipment designed to spot the problem and safeguard against it is in use at the airport and quite effective say officials.

title: The City's Policy On Gun Applications
description: The letter of Gerald Preiser, chairman of the Coalition of New York State Sportsmen [July 14] was accurate in the main. Indeed, last year approximately 70 percent (actually 69.2 percent) of full carry pistol license applications were disapproved in New York City.

title: RISE IN TICK-BORNE AILMENTS OVER WIDE AREA IS REPORTED
description: Growing numbers of wild animals in populated areas of the Northeast, the upper Middle West and the Pacific Coast are increasing the number of dangerous tick-borne diseases, a Harvard scientist has warned.

title: HELATH & MEDICINE
description: THEY talked about ''shrinking,'' ''down sizing,'' ''down scaling'' and ''streamlining,'' but state health planners who met in New Brunswick last month all meant the same thing: Reducing the number of hospitals in New Jersey.

title: MISS UPHAM WED TO WILLIAM B. VINER
description: Rebecca Thompson Upham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thompson E. Upham of Woodstock, Conn., was married in the Congregational Church there yesterday to William Babcock Viner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur W. Viner of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. James Harrison performed the ceremony.

title: GRAND VEFOUR: GRAND DINING
description: Like an heirloom jewel in an ever-changing setting, the 18th-century Palais Royal glows softly in the heart of Paris, a reminder of a glorious past. Stepping through its arches is a leap into another time, with echoes of the last century coming from the central garden and the shops and restaurants surrounding it.

title: DUKAKIS ACTING TO CLOSE A RIFT
description: GOV. MICHAEL S. DUKAKIS of Massachusetts is trying to mend fences with liberal constituents after criticism for recommending that homosexual couples not be permitted to adopt children.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: SPUNK. By Zora Neale Hurston. (Turtle Island Foundation, 2845 Buena Vista Way, Berkeley, Calif., 94708, $8.95.) This splendid, energetic collection combines widely anthologized stories with others that are virtually unknown and brings Zora Neale Hurston's considerable talents into clearer focus.

title: FINGER LAKES
description: Late summer and early fall are perhaps the best times to visit the Finger Lakes of central New York State. By August the waters have warmed sufficiently to allow for comfortable swimming and September brings the peak of the harvest in the region's vineyards, fields and orchards. In October the reds and yellows of the deciduous trees are especially vivid among the muted grays, greens and purples of the rounded hills blanketed with evergreens.

title: DISCOVERIES FROM THE GREAT CABIN
description: THE ART OF CAPTAIN COOK'S VOYAGES By Rudiger Joppien and Bernard Smith. Volume One: The Voyage of the Endeavour, 1768-1771. Illustrated. 247 pp. Volume Two: The Voyage of the Resolution and Adventure, 1772-1775. Illustrated. 274 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $50 each. TUCKED away in every corner of the earth are wayside shrines to Capt. James Cook, the Pacific explorer and discoverer - cairns to say he was here, plaques to remember the rememberings of him there. His relics are in glass cases, on shelves, in safes on five continents. A day would not pass without bacteria, humidity and dust adding to the worries of the caretakers of his things. A year would not pass without some document or artifact or painting from his voyages of discovery joining the fetish commodities sought by governments, galleries and libraries. There is a world army of security guards and guides possessive of his relics, roting his history.

title: Westway Loses A Big One In Federal Court
description: Westway, the road designed to run along lower Manhattan's Hudson River shore, was supposed to be partially sunk under landfill. Last week it may have been completely sunk by a Federal District Court judge who stopped the Army Corps of Engineers from issuing a permit for its construction.

title: IDA PRUITT, 96, WHO FOSTERED FRIENDSHIP WITH THE CHINESE
description: Ida Pruitt, a writer and medical social worker who trained China's first modern caseworkers and spent her life promoting Chinese-American understanding, died July 24 at Presbyterian-University of Pennsylvania Medical Center in Philadelphia. She was 96 years old.

title: CHANGE LINKED TO THE MOST COMMON GENETIC DISORDER IS IDENTIFIED
description: Members of an international research team, led by Dr. Maria New of New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, has identified a genetic mutation that they believe results in the most common disorder caused by hidden defective genes that has yet been discovered.

title: HANDLING SCANDAL
description: To the Editor:

title: DUAL ROLE A TEST FOR SHORE ATTORNEY
description: FOR Kevin W. Kelly, it has been one major prosecution after another. The 38-year-old Brick Township lawyer, in private practice in the town where he lives, is also a part-time assistant Ocean County prosecutor.

title: SWEET REVENGE
description: It was a flagrant violation of the most basic tenet of amateurism, and when Scottish athletic officials learned that Andy Williamson had participated in a professional foot race, openly accepting a prize for a second-place finish, they wasted no time in doing their duty. Williamson participated in the offending race, a 60-yard dash at a meet in Montrose, last Sunday.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: Another summer will have passed by the time state senate reconsiders a proposal that was supposed to have helped protect New Jerseyans from clam poachers and polluted clams.

title: GETTING EVEN WITH CHOPIN
description: LUCREZIA FLORIANI By George Sand. Translated by Julius Eker. 230 pp. Illinois: Academy Chicago Publishers. $16.95.

title: MINOR REPAIRS CAN MAKE CASEMENT WINDOWS WORK WELL
description: CASEMENT windows that swing open and close like a door and have hinges along one side will usually work for many years without trouble. But in time most will need some periodic maintenance to keep them operating smoothly. As they age, some no longer close as snugly as they should, allowing cold drafts and even water to enter when a storm strikes.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The Montreal Expos have recalled Floyd Youmans, a pitcher acquired from the Mets in the Gary Carter deal, from the Indianapolis Indians of the American Association, and said he would start Monday against the Cubs in Chicago. To make room for Youmans, the Expos placed the pitcher David Palmer on the 21-day disabled list . . . Tony LaRussa, the White Sox manager, decided not to appeal the two-game suspension he drew for bumping an umpire during an argument in the Yankees' game last Sunday. . . . The White Sox announced they will put the outfielder Oscar Gamble on unconditional waivers Monday. . . Orlando Pizzolato, the Italian runner who was a virtual unknown until he won the 1984 New York City Marathon, has entered the 1985 race in October.

title: THE PROMISE OF ORSON WELLES
description: Why is it that the American news media always dwell on images of Orson Welles as ''the failed wunderkind,'' ''the broken promise,'' etc.? While they paint a sympathetic portrait of an aging artist who has ''heard the Chimes at Midnight,'' they lose perspective of the man's unparalleled achievements.

title: Soviets to Let In Inspectors
description: The Soviet Union has long condemned Western proposals for inspection of nuclear weapons sites, arguing that the surveillance would just be a pretext for ground-level spying missions in the motherland. More recently, Soviet diplomats have occasionally made tenative suggestions of their own for on-site inspection, but in the tangle of ''strings'' tied to most arms-control offers, nothing has come of the notion.

title: A GLIMPSE OF EDEN ON SAFARI IN ZAIRE
description: ''Don't run when he charges,'' warned our tracker-guides as we hacked our way through the jungle. We were in Zaire, in central Africa, stalking mountain gorillas. According to zoologists, there are fewer than 400 of them left in the world, and there are none in captivity. The only place they are found today is the 275-square-mile range of the Virunga Mountains, which straddle the borders of Zaire, Rwanda and Uganda.

title: CANDIDATES VYING WITH BASEBALL
description: IT'S the summer doldrums and talk around the State House is of the race for Governor and baseball, not necessarily in that order.

title: BRIEF HOMECOMING
description: William J. Schroeder finally went home last week.

title: Liberia Says It Foiled Plot to Kill Americans
description: The Liberian Government says it has foiled a plot to kill Government officials and Americans living in the West African country.

title: SPICING UP VERSATILE RICE
description: ONE OF THE MOST INTRIGUING ASPECTS OF FOOD IS THE APPEAL OF EDIBLES -including noodles, potatoes, basic white bread doughs and rice - that are basically neutral in flavor. Each requires adornments, the flavors of which seem to become much more assertive once they are added. This is true of potatoes when they are blended with almost any flavor known to man, including onions (as in potatoes O'Brien) or caviar; of white bread doughs when mixed with anything from raisins and nuts to herbs or spices and cheese, and of rice, the most universally versatile of them all. You blend it with meats and spices for a fine Sichuan dish, or with an incredible variety of seafood for a Spanish paella. You blend it with tomatoes, Mexican-style, and with chopped giblets and condiments to make the ''dirty rice'' of the Louisiana kitchen.

title: EQUESTRIAN HOLIDAY, A TALE OF THREE CITIES
description: On Horseback Along Spain's Ancient Trails More than 500 years ago, ranchers in Spain, seeking easier movement of their herds, formed a union called La Mesta to establish a network of trails.

title: Cable TV
description: Four famed actresses, all ''Late Show'' fixtures, can be appreciated anew this cable week for a cluster of meaty roles in rarely revived films from Hollywood's golden era. Yes, those were the days - and faces: Barbara Stanwyck, Bette Davis, Loretta Young and that grande dame Ethel Barrymore.

title: 2 RECORDS MORE IMPRESSIVE
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GOOD ACTING IN POOR MOVIES
description: Kevin Costner has lately been the record-holder when it comes to rotten luck on the part of an aspiring young actor. Mr. Costner played the dead man in ''The Big Chill,'' which was bad enough before the role itself was eliminated. Then Mr. Costner played a rakish, dashing high school graduate in ''Fandango,'' a film hardly anybody saw. Now he is the principal scene-stealer in ''Silverado,'' which is not exactly going through the roof. There are worse things than giving good performances in films that get little attention - giving terrible performances in very popular films, for example - but tell that to Mr. Costner. The best that he or other actors in similar circumstances can hope for is that an enterprising casting director will decide to play fairy godmother. Fortunately, that has happened for Mr. Kostner, who can now be seen starring in John Badham's ''American Flyers.''

title: MIAMI TO VOTE ON STRENGTHENING MAYOR'S ROLE
description: Miamians will vote in a special election Tuesday on whether to change the City Charter and the ground rules for the regular municipal election Nov. 5.

title: J. J. OLVANY WED TO KENDRA KERR
description: Kendra Kerr and John J. Olvany, 1982 graduates of Williams College, were married yesterday at the Glencoe (Ill.) Union Church. The Rev. Russell J. Becker, pastor of the interdenominational church, and the Rev. Thomas J. Swade, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Viva Zapata! Starring Marlon Brando, Anthony Quinn, Jean Peters; directed by Elia Kazan, 1952 Key Video 112 minutes. $59.95 An opportunity to see Marlon Brando at the peak of his powers delivering a passionate, mesmerizing performance as the Mexican rebel leader Emiliano Zapata is but one of the attractions of this film.

title: NEW ISSUES IS THE FIRST DESIGNED ELECTRONICALLY
description: The United States Postal Service has combined something old with something new in the recently-released Frederic Bartholdi commemorative. The stamp, which honors the French sculptor of the Statue of Liberty, was released last month in a ceremony held at the Federal National Memorial in New York.

title: NO LONGER ALONE
description: A GOOD-SIZED garden of corn, beans and collard greens stands behind the light-green, one-story house. A ramp beside the barbecue leads to the back door because Idella Robinson had to use a wheelchair.

title: STOP TRASHING CURRENT CROP OF NEW YORK POLICE CANDIDATES
description: To the Editor:

title: LOWER MORTGAGE RATES BRING OUT SHOPPERS IN DROVES
description: WITH interest rates down to their lowest level in at least five years, brokers and builders report that metropolitan-area residents are out in force shopping for housing.

title: A RETIRED STATE JUSTICE
description: L. Barron Hill, a former State Supreme Court justice in New York, died of heart failure Thursday in a nursing home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89 years old and had lived in Palm Beach for 10 years.

title:
INVESTING;

THE COMING SHAKEOUT IN GENERIC DRUGS
description: EARLY this month, the Food and Drug Administration approved the manufacture of generic versions of Inderal, one of this country's top-selling drugs, made by American Home Products. Some analysts expect that as many as two dozen companies, including the chemical giant, American Cyanamid, will produce identical versions of this blood-pressure drug.

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING COOL NATURE'S WAY
description: WHEN it comes to keeping cool in the summer, nature's own air-conditioning is hard to beat.

title: ALEX BELIEVES IN COMMUNICATING
description: TRACER By Frederick Barthelme. 126 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $13.95.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN CROTON-ON-HUDSON
description: BACK in the 1920's, when it was the home of writers, actors, artists and left-wing intellectuals, Croton-on-Hudson was known as ''Greenwich Village on the Hudson.''

title: MEDICAL OFFICIALS WORRY ABOUT AIDS IN PRISONS
description: Inmates with acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, are being watched with growing concern by prison medical directors around the country who are uncertain how to care for them.

title: NO-FAULT INSURANCE IS AN OUTRAGE THAT CRIES OUT FOR REAL REORM
description: THE findings of a study made by the United States Department of Transportation - a study that I had requested - should come as no surprise to most New Jersey motorists: We pay the highest automobile-insurance premiums in the country.

title: IN THE SUMMER OF '38, A GARDEN REVEALS CERTAIN MYSTERIES
description: ONE day, all day, in the summer of 1938, I hauled rocks in my brother's small red wagon. For a time I felt like a fool pulling that wagon down the street with its load of dumb misshapen things, but I had made a promise to Mrs. Green, an old woman on my street in Flatbush, and being very young, innocent and trusting, I intended to keep that promise.

title: FLORIO VOWS FIGHT ON SUPERFUND BILL
description: A BITTER intra-party battle over the nation's fund to clean up hazardous-waste sites has moved out of a House committee, with Representative James J. Florio promising to fight to the end for the Superfund on the House floor.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on July 28 with a review of ''Chekhov'' misidentified the man on the right. He was George Ashley, not Stuart Sherman.

title: VIEWERS FINALLY GET TO CALL THE SIGNALS
description: It is being touted as the electronic version of a trip to the video cassette rental store and as the next big leap in home entertainment. Whether pay-per-view television will live up to the claims of its proponents is a matter of dispute in the cable television industry.

title: THE COSMOS AND THE FARMYARD
description: THE BOOK OF SORROWS By Walter Wangerin Jr. 339 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $15.95.

title: THE BIG NUMBERS
description: WHEN David Schwartz was 6 years old, he wanted to find out how many pages there were in the Brooklyn, N.Y., telephone directory. One by one, he turned the pages and watched the two-digit numbers give way to three- and four-digit numbers.

title: MORE FARMS USE ALBANY TAX BREAKS
description: The number of farms in New York State that receive a partial exemption on their property taxes has increased by more than 50 percent, according to the State Board of Equalization and Assessment.

title: THE RIGHTS OF ANIMALS AND REQUIREMENTS OF SCIENCE
description: Animal welfare groups have gone on the offensive to reduce the suffering of laboratory animals. And despite warnings from scientists that valuable research may be hampered, the tactics seem to be paying off. Just last month, Federal agencies suspended funding for research at two prestigious medical centers.

title: MILITARY SHAKE-UP IS SEEN IN MOSCOW
description: Early last month, military commanders from around the Soviet Union gathered in Minsk for what was called a ''training assembly.'' There are signs that far-reaching business was transacted.

title: A CLUSTER OF CASES MAKES ESPIONAGE HARD TO IGNORE
description: Senator Patrick J. Leahy of Vermont is perhaps best known in Washington as senior Democrat on the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. But until recently, he said, most of his constituents were clearly more concerned about his efforts on behalf of Vermont's farmers, not on the intricacies of intelligence policies that seemed to involve seamy doings in faraway places.

title: Radicals Cheer The Verdict
description: The prosecutors had accused seven men and women on trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan of plotting robberies and jailbreaks, but the defendants said they were being persecuted because they are black revolutionaires. When the jury came in with a verdict last week after a trial of more than two months, the seven were found guilty only of possessing weapons and of using false identifications to buy guns and visit jails.

title: MARY HICKEY IS WED
description: Mary Gail Hickey, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Pope Hickey of Larchmont, N.Y., and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and John Andrew Barry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Michael Barry, also of Larchmont, were married yesterday. The Rev. Carsten Martensen performed the ceremony at St. Augustine's Roman Catholic Church in Larchmont. Mrs. Barry is a senior auditor with the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation. Her husband is a financial consultant with Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

title: MORAL SERIOUSNESS
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Account for Baseball
description: The baseball strike is over, a welcome development. But questions linger. Chief among these is how much money the owners of the 26 major league teams are really losing.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

AN ARMENIAN ART IN JERUSALEM
description: Among the favorite souvenir-shop items in Israel are ceramic plates and tiles decorated with fanciful plants and indolent beasts, all arranged in a lulling, rhythmical symmetry. Most of them are copies of copies that have their origin in a modest shop in the Old City of Jerusalem, and few, if any, can compare with the originals. Those may be found only at Jerusalem Pottery.

title: STALKING THE WILD WINDMILL
description: In the foreword to A FIELD GUIDE TO AMERICAN WINDMILLS (University of Oklahoma, $85), Donald E. Green, a historian at Central State Universtiy, Edmmond, Okla., says his first impulse was to suggest calling T. Lindsay Bakers' manuscript ''Everything You Always Wanted To Know About Windmills, And More.'' It's easy to see why. Mr. Baker, the publisher of the quarterly Windmillers' Gazette, exhaustively examines the history and technology of the American windmill, which played an instrumental role in the nation's westward expansion by allowing water to be pumped from underground in remote areas.

title: KATHRYN BAYER WED TO GREGORY DAVID SIPP
description: Kathryn Marie Bayer, the daughter of Mrs. Rudolph L. Bayer of Roslyn, L.I., and the late Mr. Bayer, and Gregory David Sipp, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John L. F. Sipp of Emerson Hill, S.I., were married yesterday. The Rev. Nils Blatz, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony in the garden at the home of the bride's aunt, Mrs. Merrill E. Liston, in Bedford, N.Y.

title: A HYBRID SPACE
description: Until recently, when the typical industrial tenant needed an office, the requirement was met by simply putting up walls and a door somewhere in the building.

title: MARIO CARIELLO, EX-QUEENS CHIEF
description: Mario Joseph Cariello, a former State Assemblyman and judge who was Borough President of Queens for much of the 1960's, died Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Long Island City, Queens.

title: DAZZLING COLOR IN MUSIC FROM RUSSIA
description: He was a great bear of a genius, Mily Alekseyevich Balakirev, an energetic, opinionated, belligerent creature whose life was one of history's saddest paradoxes. Largely self-taught, he was a self-made man condemned to self-destruction, a spirit ahead of his time who outlived the principles he upheld. Although we think of him as a mid-19th-century Romantic, Balakirev (1837-1910) died only a month before the premiere of Stravinsky's ''Firebird,'' on which subject he himself had contemplated an opera years before. He founded Russia's ''Mighty Five'' and was its leading force, yet of the works produced by these extraordinary musical amateurs, only those of Cesar Cui have fallen into greater oblivion.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Ambiguity of Mothers In ''What Did I Do Wrong?'' (Arbor House), Lynn Caine describes the historical fluctuations, the changing credits and debits, of motherhood.

title: ANOTHER 6-YEAR DRIVE
description: In the 197 years since the Constitution was adopted, nearly that number of proposed amendments have been introduced in Congress to limit a President to one six-year term. Now still another effort is under way, co-sponsored by two somewhat unlikely allies, Senators Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, and Dennis DeConcini, Democrat of Arizona.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: Q'S LEGACY. By Helene Hanff. (Little, Brown, $14.95.) For any fan of ''84, Charing Cross Road,'' Helene Hanff's new memoir is a guaranteed pleasure, for it tells the story behind the story of how her famous book was born.

title: Broadcast TV
description: ''Brideshead Revisited,'' elegant, lavish and grand, will be shown in its entirety, straight through, 11 episodes at one sitting. The project is called ''Brideshead 'Til Dawn,'' and it will start Friday evening at 9 on Channel 13 and roll on until 9:30 the following morning.

title: CHRISTINA D. GILL WEDS DR. ANDREW TERSHAKOVEC
description: Christina Dzvenyslava Gill, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Gill of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday to Dr. Andrew Michael Tershakovec, a son of Prof. and Mrs. George Tershakovec of Miami. The Very Rev. Taras Lonchyna and Msgr.

title: SOCIOLOGIST ON THE HUSTINGS
description: MAX WEBER AND GERMAN POLITICS 1890-1920 By Wolfgang J. Mommsen. Translated by Michael S. Steinberg. 498 pp. Illinois: The University of Chicago Press. $50.

title: RAISE FOR RIGGINS
description: John Riggins hasn't signed his name yet, but Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Washington Redskins, may have found a way to keep his star running back on the team for one more season - a rich one-year contract that, according to team sources reached by The Associated Press, would pay Riggins $850,000. Riggins, the sources say, will sign tomorrow.

title: BACK BEHIND BARS
description: Responding to a complaint from a tenant of a Greensburg, Pa., apartment building one night last week that a BMW sedan was parked in his assigned space, two police officers conducted a routine check and discovered that the car had been stolen. They checked further and learned that it was driven by a new resident of the building.

title: ARTS FESTIVAL ENLIVENS PASTORAL CATSKILLS VILLAGE
description: PALENVILLE, N.Y. -

title: How Not to Bring Down the House
description: The City Landmarks Preservation Commission last week designated three Broadway theaters built during the 1920's as landmarks to help shield them from demolition or alteration. The commission is considering extending protection to more than 30 other playhouses in midtown, in some cases as early as this week, as part of an effort to preserve the theater industry in the face of redevelopment of the neighborhood.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: The new president of the state's League of Women Voters first developed a political consciousness as a child in Czechoslovakia, where her father published a liberal newspaper which caused the family to flee during the Communists takeover in 1948.

title: SEEING THE CONTINENT BY RAIL
description: Have you ever thought of overtaking a plane? Take the train. Not any old iron horse, but the real thing, the T.G.V. (Train a Grande Vitesse), which runs from Paris to Lyons at an average speed of 168 miles an hour.

title: ACROSS THE BORDER, A VARIED SELECTION
description: ACROSS Westchester's border with Connecticut is a different musical horizon.

title: EX-TURKISH CHIEF SAYS DEMOCRACY IS ON RISE
description: Bulent Ecevit, the former Prime Minister who has been banned from politics since the military coup of 1980, says the spirit of democracy is gaining in Turkey despite what he called an undemocratic government.

title: ON LONG ISLAND, NEW BON VOYAGE
description: LITTLE JENNY, the oldest American merchant vessel scheduled to sail in the 1986 centennial celebration for the Statue of Liberty in New York harbor, will be launched in Centerport harbor. L.I., at 11 A.M. Saturday.

title: COASTAL STATES TRY TO SAVE THE VANISHING 'STRIPER'
description: Striped-bass populations in Northeast coastal waters are alarmingly low after a decade of decline, but the North Atlantic states have begun a concerted effort to cut harvests and save the fish, and in one estuary - the lower Hudson - they are doing quite well, marine biologists say.

title: ELIZABETH BOATWRIGHT TO MARRY OCT. 5
description: Elizabeth Brownley Boatwright and Robert James Crowley Jr. plan to be married Oct. 5. Col. Charles Capps Boatwright, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Boatwright of Alexandria, Va., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mrs. Robert James Crowley of Milton, Mass., and the late Mr. Crowley.

title: Blast at Research Center Injures Two in Maryland
description: An accidental explosion at the Naval Ship Research and Development Center injured at least two people today, including a man who suffered burns over 90 percent of his body, officials said.

title: UNWED WORDS
description: HOW DO YOU BREAK a linguistic taboo?

title: NO MORE HIROSHIMAS
description: 'In order that Hiroshima's inferno never be repeated anywhere, we strongly urge the United States and the Soviet Union, who hold the fate of humankind in their hands, to halt all nuclear testing immediately and to take decisive steps at the summit talks in Geneva toward the total abolition of nuclear weapons in the interests of all humankind.'

title: AT CAMP, EDUCATION IS MUTUAL
description: IT was a sunny day halfway through the season at Camp Wapetuck, a day camp run by the Scarsdale Recreation Department. Small groups of children 5 to 8 years old were scattered about the campgrounds at the Quaker Ridge Elementary School, playing ball with their counselors, fluttering a multicolored parachute, practicing their tennis strokes.

title: BAG LIMIT ON DUCKS SOUGHT
description: NORTH AMERICAN duck populations have declined alarmingly, says the United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and because of that the agency is proposing a 25 percent reduction in hunter harvest of the birds this fall and winter.

title: PUFF OR CHARITY?
description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect in Four Killings Is Arrested in Montana
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation captured Gerald Ross Pizzuto at his sister's home here Friday, ending a manhunt for the suspect in the beating deaths of two Idaho gold miners and the slaying of two Seattle residents.

title: AT LAST, STRAWBERRY ARRIVES
description: ON this team, the Kid does the catching and bats cleanup.

title: MISS JONS IS THE BRIDE OF PETER KENT SHEPARD
description: The marriage of Lorna L. D. Jons and Peter Kent Shepard, personnel management specialists with the Defense Communications Agency in Falls Church, Va., and the Naval Supply Systems Command in Arlington, Va., respectively, were married yesterday. Rabbi Jay Heyman performed the ceremony at the Kay Spiritual Center of the American University in Washington, of which the bridegroom is a graduate.

title: DINA GREENFIELD BETROTHED TO DR. RICHARD B. SCHECTER
description: Maita Greenfield Blume of Great Neck, L.I., and George Greenfield of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Dina Ellen Greenfield to Dr. Richard B. Schecter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Schechter of Coconut Creek, Fla. The wedding is planned for November.

title: VACATIONING IN VILLA LUXURY
description: You may not be able to live quite like the Queen of England, but you can vacation very much like her sister.

title: TOWN TEST FOR NONZONING
description: NORTH CANAAN, once a sleepy community in the northwestern corner of the state, is taking on a new look.

title: A GOLD SANCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: INDIA IS SAID TO URGE SRI LANKA TO GIVE IN ON TAMIL AUTONOMY
description: The Sri Lanka Government and leaders of Tamil guerrilla groups are to resume their talks Monday amid indications that India has been pressing Sri Lanka officials to make more concessions to the insurgents.

title: AN ARTIST CO-OP LOOKS BACK
description: IN celebration of its fifth anniversary, the Northport Galleries, one of the Island's four cooperatively run exhibition spaces, is offering a show titled ''Members Past and Present.'' Works by 13 of the original group of 17 artists who founded the gallery in early 1980 are on view, along with pieces by others who have been members over the years and the current roster, now numbering 26 artists.

title: IT IS PEAK SEASON FOR DAY-LILY FANS
description: GERALD HARDY is one of 10 day-lily hybridizers in Connecticut. As he tends to the 500 varieties in his two-acre garden in Salisbury, Mr. Hardy is learning that the potential for new breeds, and new color combinations, is almost unlimited.

title: FLORIO ASSAILS MILITARY'S DUMPING
description: THE newly discovered dumping of ''massive'' amounts of hazardous wastes at the Naval Air Engineering Center here will renew Congressional concern over how the military deals with its cleanup problems, Representative James J. Florio said last week.

title: APARTHEID'S LONG, GNARLED ROOTS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: POLIO'S PAINFUL LEGACY
description: With all the recent news coverage of the postpolio syndrome, I have become more concerned about the overdiagnosis of this syndrome rather than with the failure to recognize it (''Polio's Painful Legacy,'' by Joy Horowitz, July 7). Many survivors of polio are presently at the age when other skeletal and neurological problems occur.

title: The Iceberg Cometh
description: In our last gloom-and-doom installment, Captain Reagan was at the bridge, smiling amiably into the fog, as the ship of state headed straight for the iceberg of a second-term, trillion-dollar deficit.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

MUSIC TO THE EARS
description: It seemed, at times, like ''The Perils of Pauline'' or another of those old breath-halting movie serials involving daring last-minute rescues. For months, the fate of the county's summer concert by the New York Philharmonic, a yearly event since 1980, had hung in the balance. Although free to the public, the concert costs more than $50,000 to stage.

title: PROJECT AIMS TO PRESERVE FOLKWAYS OF THE HMONG
description: Chao Song's broad smile fades when he considers the fate of his ancient culture in a high-tech world.

title: WHY TWO FRONTS ARE BETTER THAN ONE
description: The strategy of a second front, brought to prominence by Alexander Alekhine, has been questioned as superfluous by some critics. They argue that if the superior side cannot force the issue in one sector, why should he succeed in a second that is, on the face of it, no different from the first?

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: ANA P. By I. I. Magdalen. (Overlook, $16.95.) I. I. Magdalen is the pseudonym of a former member of the British intelligence services.

title: HIGH IN THE TREES, HOUSES TO DREAM IN
description: IT is August, and the tree house season is in full swing. Youngsters are scaling oaks, maples and elms and wriggling through trapdoors, settling into wooden hideouts for an hour, an afternoon or an entire night. Some tree houses are simple platforms; others are elaborate structures. But with imagination, any tree house can become a secret meeting place, a space rocket or a pirate ship.

title: AT AIRPORT, LONG NIGHT'S JOURNEY INTO DAY
description: FOR Richard DeMichael of New Rochelle, it was a typical evening.

title: MGM/UA IS ADDED TO TURNER'S EMPIRE
description: Ted Turner succeeded in acquiring MGM/UA in a complicated $1.5 billion deal in which he will resell United Artists to Kirk Kerkorian for $500,000. Mr. Turner adds a film studio to his media empire and, through MGM's huge film library, assures that his superstation WTBS will have continued access to movies. Mr. Kerkorian gets tighter control over the United Artists unit, which he could use as a base for other acquisitions.

title: SIGNING ON THE DOTTED LINE IS THE LEAST OF IT
description: In the dusty recesses of the New York City Board of Elections headquarters on Varrick Street, behind the rows of desks where clerks stamp voter registration forms, court was in session last week, with the careers of scores of candidates in next month's primary elections hanging in the balance.

title: MORATORIUM OFFERS CHANCE TO END ARMS RACE
description: ''Downhill to the Summit' (editorial,July 31) describes the Soviet moratorum on nuclear testing as a 'cynical propaganda blast.'' It is you who plays the cynic. The proposal offers a real opportunity to reverse the arms race, and it is in the security interests of the U.S. to grasp that opportunity. You fail to mention that the Soviet moratorium invites reciprocation by the U.S. and pledges an extension of the moratorium beyond Dec. 31 if our Government replies in kind. Saying, as you did, that ''a brief pause...is useless' is way off the mark. Surely a mutual moratorium might be an excellent first tsep to a comprehensive test ban.

title: MUST PAINTING AND MUSIC GO THEIR SEPARATE WAYS?
description: What to do about music is a perennial problem for painting. ''To every angel his harp'' was once the formula, and to every shepherd his hand-cut pipe. Cherubim opened their mouths wide in compulsory song. As for the lute and the lyre, it was twang, twang, twang all day and all night when they turned up in art.

title:
ANIQUES;

WHAT CAN SMALL MUSEUMS OFFER?
description: Like most public institutions grappling with lack of adequate funding, staff and space, regional museums have become increasingly innovative in order to survive.

title: FROM ZURICH TO ROME THE EASY WAY
description: The first-class railroad ticket from Zurich to Rome was exactly 150 Swiss francs, which at the day's exchange rate worked out to $58.14.

title: CASTING CAN MAKE OR BREAK A SHOW
description: Even if he didn't have to get soaking wet on stage every night, I would still feel sorry for Don Correia, the unlucky performer cast as the hero of Broadway's extravagant adaptation of Hollywood's classic musical ''Singin' in the Rain.'' While ''42d Street'' tells us that tap dancers can go out on a Broadway stage as nobodies and come back as stars, Mr. Correia entered ''Singin' in the Rain'' a somebody and emerged from it a fall guy.

title: IT'S DAVID AND GOLIATH ON THE TURNPIKE
description: AT the Connecticut Turnpike rest stops in Darien, Fairfield and Milford, many travelers have walked by the burgundy awnings with the words ''Nathan Hale's'' on them, and then proceeded on to McDonald's. The name meant nothing more to them than that of a hero of the American Revolution.

title: A MUSIC FESTIVAL THAT CELEBRATES FINNISH CULTURE
description: Art and nature live in glorious harmony in the lake district of eastern Finland.

title: AGONY ON THE L.I.E.
description: IT's called the ''Super Slab'' by CB buffs. Others have dubbed it the world's longest parking lot.

title: IDEALIST ON THE LAM
description: BEFORE MY LIFE BEGAN By Jay Neugeboren. 391 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.95.

title: MOLLY SWORD MARRIED TO PETER J. MCDONOUGH JR.
description: Mary Pitcher Sword, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Sword of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday to Peter John McDonough Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. McDonough of Plainfield, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Wallace M. Alston Jr., a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Raymond Lukenda, a Roman Catholic priest, co-officiated at the Nassau Presbyterian Church.

title: YOUTH KILLED AND 4 OTHERS INJURED IN HIT-RUN NEAR COLUMBIA
description: A Queens teen-ager was killed and four others were injured early yesterday when they were struck by a hit-and-run car at 115th Street and Broadway near Columbia University, the police said.

title: THE PROMISE OF ORSON WELLES
description: What is announced as a cautionary tale about misspent genius is, in fact, a chilling account of Hollywood's most ghastly crime of neglect. Surely, ''frustrated,'' ''thwarted,'' even ''silenced'' characterize more accurately than ''unfulfilled'' the talents of the greatest American film maker after D. W. Griffith, also cruelly exiled in limbo by blinkered moguls. SAM TANENHAUS Brooklyn

title: DELAWARE SPLIT ON RAIN AND PLAN TO MAKE SOME
description: With each step in the ankle-deep mud, John Tarburton's boots squelched, scattering flocks of seagulls feeding on worms brought to the surface of the steaming earth by this morning's deluge.

title: TRIALS BEGIN FOR LITTLE AMERICA'S CUP
description: LONG Island Sound sailors call the breeze a smoky southwesterly. It drifted mildly across to Connecticut from Long Island through a light haze.

title:
GARDENING;

KEEPING COOL NATURE'S WAY
description: WHEN it comes to keeping cool in the summer, nature's own air-conditioning is hard to beat.

title: SENIOR TENNIS KEEPS THEM YOUNG
description: THEY have lost more than a few steps in covering the court, and are wary about going to the net for fear of being lobbed into exhaustion. Many wear knee and elbow braces like badges of honor. But they represent a breed that is flourishing more than ever on the Island.

title: Topics;   Injuries Avoided Mannerly Mail
description: In popular belief, the U.S. Postal Service is as impersonal as a zip code and as efficient as those stamp machines that are always out of order. What to expect, therefore, when a letter arrives encased in a transparent envelope from the Office of the District Manager, Postmaster, New York, N.Y. 10199-9998?

title: Wallace Leaves Hospital
description: Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama was released from a hospital today, 17 days after undergoing spinal surgery to relieve pain associated with a gunman's attack on him 13 years ago. Mr. Wallace, who is 65 years old, has been paralyzed from the waist down since he was shot in the spine in Maryland in 1972 while he campaigned for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He was met at Craig Hospital today by his wife, Lisa.

title: Give Squatters a Chance
description: It sounds so simple and sensible. New York has a housing shortage. The city owns almost 6,000 abandoned residential buildings. Some New Yorkers clamor for the right to rehabilitate them and return them to the tax rolls in exchange for ownership. Why not let them do so? Yet to city officials, it isn't that simple. Those arguing for the chance to earn a home with their personal labor - sweat equity - are also squatters, who have broken into the vacant buildings they would renovate.

title: SARAH C. TANNER WEDS HORACE PRESCOTT SMITH
description: Sarah Carpenter Tanner, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Ogden Tanner of New Canaan, Conn., and Horace Prescott Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bayard W. Smith of Windsor, Vt., and Tenants Harbor, Me., were married yesterday. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan.

title: ARGUELLO RETURNS TO PAY DEBT
description: Alexis Arguello, who will cease looking for Billy Martin in a beer commercial and instead again seek a record fourth world title, denied today that money was the root of all boxing comebacks.

title: U.S. Agrees to Detain Jailed Cuban Refugees
description: The Justice Department has decided to continue taking custody of Cuban inmates released after serving time for crimes committed since they arrived in the United States in 1980.

title: REUNIONS: THE LIFE YOU SEE MAY BE YOUR OWN
description: ''CLOSE your eyes . . . take a deep breath . . . imagine yourself walking into school. See the people around you. Hear the voices and the sounds as young people swell the hallways and head into another day.''

title: NEWARK: DISCOVERING AFRO-AMERICANS
description: THE increasing number of exhibitions of Afro-American art has shaped one's awareness that an important part of our cultural past and present has been sadly neglected.

title: CONSTANCE COLLINS WEDS
description: Constance S. Collins of Riverside, Conn., widow of Judge James F. Collins of the Connecticut Superior Court, was married at home yesterday to George H. Cain, a partner in the law firm of Day, Berry & Howard in Stamford, Conn. Judge David M. Shea of the Connecticut Supreme Court performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, was formerly vice president, secretary and general counsel of the Flintkote Company.

title: TRADING RED INK FOR BLACK
description: David A. Stockman shouldn't have to worry about balancing his budget. It was reported last week that the former director of the Office of Management and Budget had signed a contract with Harper & Row in excess of $2 million, the largest amount the 168-year-old house has ever paid for a book.

title: COME FLY WITH ME
description: The National Air and Space Museum has published the eighth in its series of large-format paperback books, each devoted to one of the most famous aircraft in the museum. For the first time, the subject is a World War II Japanese plane: the night fighter that its own navy called Gekko or ''Moonlight'' and that American forces called Irving.

title: NEW LIFE FOR A RARE REQUIEM
description: The manager of the classical department at Tower Records was excited. He was unpacking a shipment of compact disks. ''The first Faure Requiem on CD!'' he said. ''And it comes from Omaha.'' Indeed it did, sort of, and we wondered why and how, and along the way found out some other interesting things about this recording.

title: WHO WAS TO BLAME FOR THE BOMBING?
description: THE ROOT The Marines in Beirut, August 1982 - February 1984. By Eric Hammel. Illustrated. 448 pp. New York: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: PLANS FOR AGED CROTON SYSTEM
description: WESTCHESTER County is New York City's leaky faucet. During the 1985 drought, while lawns go unwatered and showers are shortened, each day an estimated 50,000 gallons of water leaks out the granite blocks on the Croton Dam spillway and into the Croton River, down the Hudson River and finally into the Atlantic.

title: U.S. SAID TO OFFER SOVIET A PLAN FOR SUMMIT MEETING AGENDA
description: The United States has proposed that President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, discuss arms control, regional issues, human rights and relations between the two countries when the two leaders hold their summit meeting in Geneva in November, a senior Reagan Administration official said today.

title: 2 LINKED TO GREENPEACE BLAST SAID TO BE OFFICERS
description: The two people charged in New Zealand with blowing up a Greenpeace ship last month were part of a Defense Ministry security team and held the ranks of captain and major in the French armed forces, the state-owned French radio said today.

title: SPRING HILL WAS FAMOUS BEFORE SATURN
description: To the Editor:

title: POLO PLAYERS MOUNT UP AS GAME REVIVES
description: POLO, once the quintessential game of the rich, is having a revival, with Connecticut one of its centers. But unlike in the 1920's and 1930's, when polo and wealth always rode together, most of the new players come from other than the leisured class. And an increasing number are women.

title: ANNE BURR STANTON WEDS
description: Anne Burr Stanton, a daughter of Jane Stanton of Brooklyn Heights and the late Robert F. Stanton of Atlantic Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Richard Lawrence Malone, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence E. Malone of Washington. The Rev. F. Goldthwaite Sherrill performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church in Brooklyn Heights. Mrs. Malone received a master's degree in social work in June from New York University. Her husband, a musician and composer, graduated magna cum laude from Oberlin College.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Puccini's 'Boheme' A Royal Opera production featuring Neil Shicoff, Ileana Cotrubas, Marilyn Zschau, Thomas Allen; conducted by Lamberto Gardelli, 1982 Thorn EMI/HBO Video 115 minutes. $39.95 Should video-taped operas attempt to duplicate a live performance on the small screen? Or should they be considered works of art unique in themselves?

title: ELDERLY FIND HOPE IN HOME-SHARING
description: MISS A is hard of hearing and has difficulty walking because of a hip injury. A year ago, when she was 78 years old, she had to give up the apartment she had long occupied when the owner appropriated it for a family member.

title: REAGAN TAX PLAN AND IMPLICATIONS IN THE NORTHEAST: FEAR AND REASSURANCE
description: Although much of the debate over President Reagan's plan to overhaul the income tax system has focused on problems it might cause for the Northeast, experts who have studied the plan say that its effects on the region would actually be mixed.

title: THE VATICAN IS PUTTING VIDEO TO WORK
description: The Vatican, which over the decades has developed sophisticated press and radio operations, is now trying to come to terms with the video age. It is doing so by means of the Vatican Television Center, which was founded in 1983 with the mission of documenting all Pope John Paul's activities.

title: ON DOUBLING INTO DOUBLE PLAY
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A POTPOURRI OF MUTUAL FUND YEARBOOKS
description: THE mutual fund industry has grown significantly in recent years, thus building an expanded market for yearbooks that provide statistical information about mutual funds. And just as the funds themselves are set up with a variety of objectives, so are the books that describe and analyze the companies in this field.

title: 2 MEN CHARGED WITH ROBBING 8 IN CRIME SERIES
description: Two men, in less than an hour, robbed eight people, sexually assaulted a woman, and stole two automobiles, $420 in cash and more than $1,000 in jewelry early yesterday in Jamaica, Queens, the police said.

title: WIN, $5.60, TAKES BARUCH
description: Win, whose owners are smarting from his failure to have been invited to run in the Arlington Million in two weeks, showed that he has not lost his good form of last year by scoring a narrow victory over Cozzene in the $99,000 Bernard Baruch Handicap today at Saratoga.

title: China Textile Objections
description: China told nine visiting American Congressmen about its objection to a proposed bill that would cut its textile exports to the United States, an American Embassy spokesman said Friday. China has warned that the bill would seriously jeopardize Sino-American trade relations. The delegation is led by Representative Sam Gibbons, Democrat of Florida.

title: Howe Is Signed To Twins Pact
description: Steve Howe, the relief pitcher released by the Los Angeles Dodgers earlier this season at his own request, signed a contract with the Minnesota Twins today. The terms and the length of the contract were not disclosed.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Search for PCB's Begun In All Federal Buildings
description: Government inspectors are checking electrical transformers in Federal buildings nationwide for leaks of PCB's that could emit dioxin, a poisonous substance, in a fire, officials say.

title: BOGGS OF RED SOX SETTING THE STANDARD FOR HITTING
description: As this summer rolled along and the times at bat piled up and Wade Boggs's batting average inflated, it occurred to Joe Morgan that there was something the Red Sox third baseman wasn't showing him.

title: NEWPORT: BREAKERS BALL LIGHTS UP A NIGHT
description: The Breakers Ball here last night could easily have been interpreted as an English lawn party, but there were a few very American exceptions. One was a postmidnight buffet of country sausages and hash-brown potatoes, another was a brass-band welcome of a Roosevelt with ''Happy Days Are Here Again,'' and last but not least were fireworks that lit up the night mists over Narragansett Bay, Jane Dick, tall and resplendent in a Jacqueline de Ribes ball gown, slipped into the receiving line in the white marble Great Hall of The Breakers, the shorefront palazzo Cornelius Vanderbilt built 90 years ago. She joined Noreen Drexel, Countess Anthony Szapary and Helen Winslow and muttered to the Countess: ''Syvie, everybody's trying to get hold of another Brit before the season ends.''

title: 2 CLING TO CHINA, EVEN AFTER 21 YEARS OF NO CHOICE
description: Against the scale of suffering that was commonplace here in the first 30 years of Communist rule, the two women were minor casualties, incidental figures in a huge tableau of repression.

title: 2 SAN CLEMENTE PROJECTS SET OUT TO HONOR NIXON
description: Next to Interstate 5 here, a sign invites travelers to a roadside restaurant and sales office for a time-sharing real estate project with the promise of a chance to view artifacts from the past of Richard M. Nixon.

title: BRIEFING;A Broiling Issue
description: Behind the scenes in your Government, a struggle is taking place over whether installing McDonald's and Burger King restaurants on military bases represents preservation of the great American culinary tradition or betrayal of the free enterprise system. With 23 of these fast-food outlets already in place at camps and airfields as far away as Tokyo, Congress has ordered a cease-fire in the conflict while the Pentagon prepares a report.

title: PAST AND PRESENT HOLDINGS
description: The Smithonsian Institution has sold its stock in the following companies, asserting that they have not agreed to the Sullivan Principles:

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE;Economist at Chemical Loses His Department
description: Following similar steps taken by a number of money center banks in recent years, the Chemical Bank has disbanded its economics department and is seeking to place its staff of 40 -a figure that includes 20 economists - in other areas of the bank.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: LATIN FLOURISHES The soothing of souls attributed to music will be demonstrated at 7 P.M. today up in Central Park at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Delacorte Theater, near the 81st Street-Central Park West entrance. This is a free event of the Festival Latino in New York, now under way under the auspices of Joseph Papp, who heads the Shakespeare Festival.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: I never grieve for the other team.'' Dave Johnson, Mets manager, speaking about Cubs' injuries, after New York completed a three-game sweep of Chicago. [C1:6.]

title: SAFETY SYSTEMS WERE ADDED BEFORE PLANT WAS REOPENED
description: The leak of aldicarb oxime yesterday at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant in Institute, W.Va., came three months after the company reopened the section of the plant involved.

title: REPORT SAYS SMOKING CAUSES HEAVY HEALTH DAMAGE IN BLACK PEOPLE
description: Cigarette smoking inflicts disproportionately high health damages on black Americans, according to a new study, whose authors assert that research on the effects of smoking on blacks' health is inadequate and call for an increase in antismoking programs directed toward blacks.

title: Antismoking Litigant Dead
description: John M. Bullitt, a professor of English at Harvard University, died Friday of lung cancer in Boston. He was 64 years old. Professor Bullitt announced at a news conference June 19 that he was filing a $70 million Federal lawsuit against the Tobacco Institute and three tobacco companies, charging that they negligently failed to warn him of the dangers of smoking. Professor Bullitt was an authority on 18th-century English literature.

title: MCENROE TOPPLES LENDL IN TWO SETS
description: John McEnroe, applying constant pressure with his serve-and-volley game, wore down Ivan Lendl, 7-6, 6-2, today to win the $315,000 Volvo International tournament.

title: THE DROUGHT HOT LINE IS FINDING NO SHORTAGE OF CURIOSITY
description: Unlike the upstate basins on which New York depends for its water, the reservoirs of civic curiosity and ingenuity are filled to capacity this summer, judging from an informal survey of telephone calls received by the city's Environmental Protection Department.

title: 76ers Stake Hopes On New Forwards
description: The Philadelphia 76ers have tried hard over the last two years to find the eventual replacements for Julius Erving and Bobby Jones.

title: BRITISH ELECTRONICS LOSING MOMENTUM
description: Britain's electronics and telecommunications industry, so frequently a showpiece in the visions of a bright future advanced by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her Conservative ministers, has lost its momentum.

title: INVESTMENT BANKER FOR UNIONS
description: When Brian M. Freeman, an investment banker, is negotiating a deal, he bluffs, he demands and, very calculatingly, he sometimes insults his adversary to gain the upper hand.

title: Schools Held Hostage in New Jersey
description: In June, New Jersey's Legislature passed a bill increasing the minimum salary for public-school teachers to $18,500 from the current minimum of $14,800. Now Governor Kean threatens to veto it unless the Legislature also goes along with his plan to pay bonuses to outstanding teachers, a plan militantly opposed by the state teachers' union. In doing so, he gambles irresponsibly with the future of New Jersey's schools.

title: Belgian Output Up 1.5%
description: Industrial production in Belgium rose 1.5 percent in May from April and was up 3.5 percent from a year earlier, the National Institute of Statistics said Friday. The rise came mainly from an increase in investment activity outside the building sector.

title: A Prize in Journalism For 2 Swiss Fugitives
description: Two men who broke out of a Swiss jail last week announced their escape to a radio station and won the prize for the best news item provided by listeners.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Sports World Specials column last Monday about the history of the mile and the 1,500-meter run misstated the results of Olympic 1,500-meter competitions. Athletes from English-speaking nations have won 14 such races, and those from other countries have won 6.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Cable's 'Must-Carry' Rules Benefited No One
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Approves Grant On Domestic Violence
description: The Justice Department has approved a grant of almost $300,000 to the National Coalition Against Domestic Violence after delaying the award because of complaints by conservatives that some of the money would help activists in behalf of lesbians.

title: NETWORKS PONDERING BUDGET CUTS
description: News executives at ABC and CBS are deciding how to make the significant cuts in their 1986 budgets that top management has requested, according to network officials, producers and correspondents. NBC News is also drawing up its budget for next year but so far no major cuts are anticipated, a top official there said.

title: TOXIC CLOUD LEAKS AT CARBIDE PLANT IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: A small cloud of toxic chemicals escaped from a Union Carbide plant near here this morning, and at least 135 residents were treated for eye, throat and lung irritation.

title: Ken Brett's Summer Job
description: THE clubhouse is not without its decor.

title: SPAIN'S NEW TEAM BACKS AUSTERITY
description: Spain's new economics team appears intent on maintaining the Government's austerity program and introducing free market measures even though there is growing discontent within the ruling Socialist Party.

title: ADVERTISING;Foote, Cone Reports Record Net in Quarter
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., Chicago, reported net income for the second quarter rose 33.3 percent, to $6 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $4.5 million, or $1.26 a share, in the period last year. The $6 million profit was a record for any quarter. Revenues were up 5.5 percent, to $75.4 million, compared with $71.5 million in the 1984 quarter.

title: Police Smuggle Arms in Test Of Airport's Security System
description: Police officers acting on Mayor Dianne Feinstein's orders smuggled a gun and a grenade aboard airplanes to test security at San Francisco International Airport, officials said.

title: LACKLUSTER EARNINGS IN 2D QUARTER
description: Weak economic growth led to lackluster corporate earnings in the second quarter, with the bright spots overwhelmed by depressed profits in a wide range of industries.

title: FIVE STUDENTS ARRESTED
description: An off-duty New York City Housing Authority police officer was badly beaten by a group of men outside his home here yesterday, the Nassau County police said.

title: MANVILLE PLAN SEEKS SLASH IN COSTS
description: The Manville Corporation, which recently offered to pay $2.5 billion to settle asbestos health claims against the company, is in the midst of a program to sell or close some operations and slash costs.

title: NEW JOBS, OLD BATTLE, ODD NAME
description: Now that General Motors has chosen a little town in Tennessee as the manufacturing site for its new Saturn cars, bidders who vied with each other to swap land and tax incentives for the project's economic benefits are competing for a somewhat smaller project, the plant the Toyota Motor Corporation of Japan plans to build in the United States.

title: Iran Press Agency Reports Big Demonstration in Medina
description: Thousands of Iranian pilgrims demonstrated in the holy city of Medina in Saudi Arabia last Friday calling for the downfall of the superpowers, Iran's national press agency said today.

title: BRIEFING;Of Name(s)
description: Johns Hopkins University of Baltimore and Washington has become sufficiently tired of people calling it ''John'' to issue an eight-page leaflet explaining the derivation of its name. Having got your attention with seven pictures of Johns, including Adams, Dillinger, Lennon and Wayne, it explains that the man who gave $7 million to found the university and hospital in 1873 was named after his great grandmother, Margaret Johns. His odd first name was a last name. ''We're proud of our distinctive name,'' the leaflet concludes. ''Please use it correctly and often.'' In their heart of hearts, the two institutions want to be called ''The Johns Hopkins etc.,'' but they're taking the problem one step at a time.

title: STRONG ODOR ALERTED RESIDENTS TO CHEMICAL PLANT PROBLEMS
description: Vicky Terry said she was sleeping today when the toxic white chemical cloud drifted over homes near the Union Carbide Corporation plant here.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Faster Economic Data
description: Allan H. Young, newly appointed director of the Commerce Department's Bureau of Economic Analysis, is pressing to speed the flow of economic data to the business community and the general public.

title: YANKEES TAKE 6TH IN A ROW
description: More and more, the Yankees find themselves thinking back these days. They still have seven games to whittle off the Toronto Blue Jays' lead in the American League East. But they can remember bigger deficits.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Workers at Hormel Plant In Minnesota Study Offer
description: Workers at the Geo. A. Hormel & Company plant met today to discuss what the company said was its final contract offer, but the president of the local union said it was not significantly different from the original proposal.

title: Strike at Truck Plant Ends
description: Striking United Automobile Workers at an AM General military truck plant overwhelmingly approved a proposed contract Friday, ending a two-week walkout. Officials of Local 5 said hat more than 85 percent of the local's 650 members who voted favored ratification of the new contract, which will remain in effect until June 30, 1988.

title: RELATIONSHIPS;FRIENDS FOR TEEN-AGE PATIENTS
description: ONE morning not long ago, 17-year-old Elissa Darvin walked into the hospital room where a 16-year-old, who had been in a three-week coma, was lying. On a chair by the window a huge stuffed monkey reigned over her half of the room. ''I just got him today,'' the patient said with a grin. The two had never met.

title: MARATHON ENDS GAMES
description: Karl Blaeuer used a late kick in the last two miles of the men's marathon today to capture the gold medal on the final day of the Empire State Games.

title: ELLIOT TAKES FIRST IN MICHIGAN 400
description: Bill Elliott moved closer to a million dollar season today. After an early unscheduled pit stop dropped him to last place, Elliott worked his way back to capture the 400-mile Nascar race at Michigan International Speedway.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;PENSION PLANS' SURPLUS ASSETS
description: CONGRESS is looking at what has been a big corporate windfall in recent years - and could tie some strings around it.

title: Roll Wins Stage Of Coors Cycling
description: Bob Roll of Pleasant Hill, Calif., shot to the lead with half a lap to go today to win the Vail criterium stage of the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: 125 AMERICANS LEAD MARCH IN BELFAST
description: A group of 125 Americans marched today at the head of an Irish nationalist parade by thousands of people through West Belfast.

title: NATIONAL LEAGUE;PHILLIES' RAWLEY STOPS CARDINALS, 4-1
description: Shane Rawley pitched a six-hitter today as the Phillies defeated the Cardinals, 4-1, and dropped St. Louis one game behind the first-place Mets in the National League East.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;Setting Priorities
description: He may be the young brother of Bernard and Albert King, stars in the National Basketball Association, but Gerald King has a mind of his own when it comes to basketball, to his academic future and to his life in general.

title: Canadian Jobless Off
description: Canada's unemployment rate decreased to 10.4 percent last month, from 10.5 percent in June, the Government's statistics agency reported Friday. The latest rate was the lowest since May 1982, when 10.2 percent of the work force was unemployed. Statistics Canada said full-time employment increased by 62,000, to 9,564,000, in July, while the number of part-time jobs declined by 24,000, to 1,751,000.

title: The 'Brutal Cops' Americans Love
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-CANADIAN RIFT ON WOOD EXPORTS
description: A serious confrontation over Canada's growing lumber exports to the United States appears to be looming, with a flurry of legislation before Congress to limit shipments through duties or quotas.

title: AT HOME ABROAD;Angry at Success
description: When Japan surrendered, 40 years ago, Gen. Douglas MacArthur undertook not just to occupy but to remake the country. If he had been asked then what his most extravagant hope was, I think he might have said: to channel the drive of this aggressive people away from militarism and into economic ambition.

title: ROCK: DON HENLEY SINGS AT PIER 84
description: DON Henley, the Eagles' principal lead singer, drummer, and with Glenn Frey, one of its main songwriters, is the only member of the defunct Los Angeles rock group to make consistently impressive solo records. And at Pier 84 (12th Avenue and 45th Street) where he appeared with an excellent nine-member band on Friday evening, Mr. Henley showed himself to be an compellingly feisty solo concert performer as well.

title: George J. Nelson Dies; Founded Mutual Fnd
description: George J. Nelson, a stockbroker and financial consultant who established the Nelson Fund, which came to be known as the mutual ''fund for millionaires,'' died Aug. 2 while vacationing in Valbella, Switzerland. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: New York City's Board of Education Is Worth Rethinking
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 12, 1985
description: International

title: BRAZIL MAY DELAY CREDIT AGREEMENT WITH I.M.F.
description: Rather than accept an austerity program that could slow the country's economic recovery, Brazil's new Government now appears to favor postponing, until 1986, the conclusion of a credit agreement with the International Monetary Fund.

title: Donna Haupt, Writer, Weds Amir Rosenthal
description: Donna E. Haupt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Haupt of New York, was married yesterday to Amir Rosenthal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Rosenthal of Ramat Hasharon, Israel. Jean Kotkin, the executive director of the American Ethical Union and a leader at the New York chapter of the Ethical Culture Society, performed the ceremony at a Manhattan loft.

title: BEIRUT BARRAGE KILLS 10 AND WOUNDS 47
description: Rival Christian and Moslem militia gunners unleashed their fiercest barrage on Beirut in two months today, killing at least 10 people and wounding more than 47, security officials said.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER RIOTS, WATTS STILL SMOLDERS
description: An entire generation has grown to adulthood in Watts since rioting there shocked the world two decades ago. Despite efforts to improve conditions, residents still live with high unemployment, gang violence, crowded schools and difficult relations with the police.

title: REAGAN TO SEEK 'FUTURE AGENDA' AT SUMMIT TALK
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan planned ''to set an agenda for the future'' in his November summit meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: A SALVO FROM THE OTHER SIDE
description: One of the Reagan Administration's notable innovations in Pentagon lobbying and public relations has been the annual edition of ''Soviet Military Power,'' a glossy paperback that purports to detail the full nature of the threat of the Russians' armed might.

title: SOVIET DRIVE ON DRINKING GETS QUICK RESULTS
description: Two months after it took effect, a tough new liquor law, backed up by a police crackdown, has brought a transformation in the social rituals of the Soviet Union.

title: BARBED TAPE: JAGGED ARMOR ON THE NEW YORK LANDSCAPE
description: On a residential street in Murray Hill in Manhattan, the razor-edged coils of steel strike a jarring note. Ringing the top of a temporary scaffold on a 16-story luxury cooperative at the corner of Park Avenue and 39th Street, their message to would-be burglars is unmistakable.

title: HEART RECIPIENT MAKES 2D TRY AT LIVING OUTSIDE OF HOSPITAL
description: William J. Schroeder was released from the hospital today for the second time since his artificial heart was implanted last November, and was driven to a specially equipped apartment where he will live.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 12, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;Praise for Trade Official
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, in office less than two months, is getting high marks at the White House and in Congress for the way he defused recent trade conflicts with the European Economic Community over steel, citrus and pasta. ''He's doing a nice job,'' a White House official commented.

title: MARKET PLACE;Summer Hopes Have Faded
description: WHAT started out to be a summer to remember on Wall Street is turning into one that many investors would like to forget, as the stock market slips and slides from one disappointment to the next. The bottom line, the professionals now say, is that stock prices may have to sink further before they can again soar.

title: THE CITY;Fireman Catches Stabbing Suspect
description: A Bronx firefighter using a six-foot firemen's hook last night apprehended a man who was stabbing another man with a knife, the Fire Department said.

title: Janet Ann Silverman Marries Kevin Gerard Tobin
description: The marriage of Janet Ann Silverman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Silverman of Providence, R.I., to Kevin Gerard Tobin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard Tobin of Brooklyn, took place yesterday in Bristol, R.I. Family Court Judge Haigenush Bedrusian performed the ceremony at the Haffenreffer Estate of Brown University.

title: A RULING ON SCHOOL REPORTS
description: A Federal District Court has affirmed the right of Dr. Robert Fay, a pediatrician in the Albany area, to receive duplicate copies of all school information mailed to the home of his former wife.

title: SMITHSONIAN INSTITUTION;PRESSURE ON FOR MORAL SIGNAL ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: Three times a year, a select group of American leaders in business, public service and culture gather in Washington as the Smithsonian Institution's board of regents and make decisions of cultural and educational importance concerning the museums under their control.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS;More Trouble
description: The players' strike may have been brief, but Commissioner Peter Ueberroth appears to have another labor problem.

title: AROUND THE NATION;Parachute Accidents Kill Two Skydivers in Illinois
description: Two skydivers were killed today in separate parachuting accidents at the Nelson's World Freefall Convention, the authorities said.

title: CAMACHO WINS LAST LAUGH
description: The clown had the last laugh, after all. Two days before winning his second world title, he was throwing soda cans around at a news conference. Once, he grabbed a waiter's tray of drinks and walked with it straight into a swimming pool. Often, he would say he was the ''kid of the 80's'' and he dressed accordingly with more sequins than a Las Vegas chorus line and sometimes with less cloth.

title: THE CITY;Girl in Bronx Park Stabbed to Death
description: A 16-year-old girl was fatally stabbed in Crotona Park in the Bronx Saturday night by a man who she said had raped her, the police said.

title: NEW NERVE GAS PLAN LEAVES TESTS AND STORAGE UNDECIDED
description: The expected decision to end a 16-year moratorium and resume military production of chemical weapons is being celebrated by the Pentagon as the end of a long campaign.

title: WASHINGTON WATCH;No One for Safety Post
description: Labor Secretary Bill Brock is having trouble finding someone to head the Occupational Safety and Health Administration. Several prospects have turned down the job. These include Dr. Bernard Goldstein, a former senior research official for the Environmental Protection Agency and Marcus M. Key, a Texas physician and educator and former head of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health.

title: A ROUNDUP OF QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS AT 274 COMPANIES
description: Revenues Net Income April-June Change April-June Change 1985 From '84 1985 From '84 ($ 000) (%) ($ 000) (%)

title: MAYORS AWARD $145,000 TO HELP FIGHT AIDS
description: The United States Conference of Mayors awarded $145,000 today to help pay for educational projects in eight cities, including a ''safe-sex musical,'' to combat acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY;Strike Strategies, No Longer Needed
description: Although most had been ready for the worst, people in the crowd at Shea Stadium yesterday said they were happier to be at a Mets-Cubs game than in Phase 1 of whatever Alternate Emergency Baseball Strike Contingency Plans they had devised.

title: Bomb Wounds 2 in Spain
description: A bomb exploded early today in a car near this Basque city, slightly wounding two police bomb experts, the police said. The bomb experts had been sent to deactivate the device after an anonymous telephone call was received. No group said it was responsible, but the police said they believed the bombing was the work of the Basque separatist organization E.T.A.

title: U.S. LOSES AGAIN
description: The United States women's national volleyball team ended without a victory in its six-game exhibition series in Japan, losing by 15-3, 15-11, 15-7 to the Japanese national team in the final match today.

title: Nigeria Captures Under-16 Soccer
description: Nigeria won the first under-16 World Soccer Tournament today with a 2-0 upset of West Germany. The Nigerians were on the defensive much of the game, but the West Germans were unable to penetrate and suffered from sloppy passing. In a match for third place, Brazil defeated Guinea, 4-1.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Thailand Reports Firing Across Mekong River
description: Thai military authorities said today that Vietnamese and Laotian forces had been firing across the Mekong River at Thai positions for three days. The Thais were reported to have returned the fire.

title: Pop Singer Safe In Race Mishap
description: Simon le Bon, the lead singer of the Duran Duran pop group, spent 20 minutes trapped underwater with five of his crewmen after his yacht capsized today during the final race of the Admiral's Cup series.

title: Sculpture in Dallas
description: Contemporary sculpture by Jonathan Borofksy, Beverly Pepper, Anthony di Caro, Mark di Suvero, Tony Smith and Jenny Holzer and others will be on exhibition at the NorthPark Center in Dallas, through Dec. 31. The exhibition, which marks the 20th anniversary of the shopping mall, opened on Aug. 1 and contains 34 large-scale works by 24 leading contemporary artists. The architecture of the NorthPark mall, built in 1965, set a precedent that was widely copied in shopping malls around the country. It has also served as a cultural center in Dallas, and for the last 15 years has been the home of the Dallas Repertory Theater.

title: BREAKS 2 RECORDS
description: Nancy Lopez shot a 6-under-par 66 today, romped to a 10-stroke victory in a $210,000 tournament and set two Ladies Professional Golf Association records in the process.

title: GROWING PLY-GEM IS TURNING HEADS
description: In 1943, when the Grumman Corporation was churning out aircraft on Long Island for the war, it also was keeping a bonfire going 24 hours a day burning the birch plywood crates in which it received aluminum shipments.

title: ADVERTISING;Budget Is Doubled By Domino's Pizza
description: Domino's Pizza said it had doubled its advertising budget, to $26 million, to introduce its new ''One Call Does It All'' advertising theme.

title: THE CITY;Jail Guards Seek Dismissal of Chief
description: About 100 city correction officers held a rally yesterday to ask Mayor Koch to dismiss the City Commissioner of Correction, Jacqueline McMickens, because of what they called her ''inhumane'' treatment of jail guards.

title: AROUND THE WORLD;Iran and Iraq Report Clashes and Shelling
description: Iran said today that its troops killed or wounded 135 Iraqi soldiers in 24 hours of fighting. Iraq said ''a number'' of Iranians were killed or wounded in the new clashes.

title: IN THE HAMPTONS, ALDA FILMS 'SWEET LIBERTY'
description: No dog is mean enough to bite Alan Alda. Even bearing the full weight of a movie on his shoulders - directing, writing and starring in the new ''Sweet Liberty'' - he is good humored, cheerful, smiling his crinkly smile. Throughout the Hamptons, the word has spread that Mr. Alda might really be just what he appears to be: nice.

title: THE CITY;Koch Vows to Try To Add Housing
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that he would make housing a top priority if he were elected to a third term. But he condemned what he called the ''lawlessness'' of squatters who recently took over several city-owned buildings.

title: Richard Ahlert Is Dead at 63; Song Writer and Composer
description: Richard Ahlert, the song writer and composer, died Friday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y., following a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: Gunman, 85, Slain by Police
