title: Movie Making
description: They look like everyday New York youngsters. But they're going to be in pictures.

title: Advertising;   Mullen Is the Choice Of Javelin Software
description: Mullen Advertising and Public Relations of Beverly Farms, Mass., will serve as the first agency of record for the Javelin Software Corporation.

title: MALNUTRITION IN ELDERLY: WIDESPREAD HEALTH THREAT
description: MALNUTRITION may account for a substantially greater portion of illness among elderly Americans than has long been assumed, according to several medical experts on aging.

title: Gibson Says He'll Campaign For 5th Newark Mayoral Term
description: Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson said today that he would seek a fifth term next year and ruled out running for Congress.

title: I.B.M. TO DROP DISK SUPPLIER
description: Computer Memories Inc., the Chatsworth, Calif., company whose production troubles with hard disk drives was blamed for the slow start of the International Business Machines Corporation's PC-AT, said yesterday that it would lose its I.B.M. contract at the end of the year.

title: 4 Hurt in Classroom Blast
description: Four elementary school children were injured tdoay, two of them critically, after an explosion in a summer school science classroom where they were making sparklers. An instructor said two students were jamming wire elements with a pestle when the blast erupted at 10:30 A.M. at the Murch School in Northwest Washington. Three boys and one girl were taken to Children's Hospital, and Theresa Fulton, a hospital spokesman, said the children's injuries included shock and second- and third-degree burns.

title: 42D ST. WATER MAIN SPLITS, DELAYING TRAFFIC FOR BLOCKS
description: A crack several feet long was found in a water main at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue early yesterday morning, forcing the main to be shut down and disrupting traffic on 42d Street for blocks.

title: 134th Death in Texas Crash
description: A 76-year-old Florida man has become the 134th fatality in the crash of a Delta Air Lines jetliner at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport Aug. 2, a spokesman for Parkland Memorial Hospital said. Sidney Segal, of West Palm Beach, who had been treated for burns over 35 percent of his body and a fractured pelvis and clavicle, died at 10:45 P.M. Sunday, the spokesman said. His wife, Florence Segal, 76, was also killed in the crash.

title: 2 Chutists Die in Accidents At Convention for Skydivers
description: Two skydivers were killed Sunday in separate parachuting accidents at the Nelson's World Freefall Convention, the authorities said.

title: CHOICE OF ARMS FOR $25 MILLION
description: The international weapons market is awash with military equipment, easily acquired by almost anyone with cash. From accounts of the weaponry already possessed by the Nicaraguan rebels, it is possible to estimate what they might seek with further aid.

title: MILGRAY ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Firebomb Found in Frankfurt On an Empty U.S. Army Train
description: An incendiary device was discovered early today aboard an empty United States Army troop train and was removed before it could go off, the West German police reported.

title: Advertising;   Halstone Fragrances Moves to Korey, Kay
description: Halston Fragrances Inc., a division of Halston Fragrances Worldwide, has switched to Korey, Kay & Partners from Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: AIDES PLAN STRATEGY FOR PRESSING REAGAN AGENDA
description: The White House has begun a high-level planning effort to determine how President Reagan can best promote a variety of top foreign policy and domestic programs, senior officials said today.

title: Fleet Financial Bank Purchase
description: Fleet Financial Group, the Providence, R.I., banking and financial services company, said it had reached agreement to acquire the Merrill Bankshares Company of Bangor, Me., in a stock transaction valued at $132 million.

title: Article 186913 -- No Title
description: A Federal district judge today ordered the Government to pay $1.25 million to the families of three lobstermen who were lost at sea in a storm that the National Weather Service had not predicted.

title: Dunston In; Bowa Out
description: The Chicago Cubs put Larry Bowa, their 39-year-old shortstop, on waivers yesterday after snapping a seven-game losing streak with an 8-7 victory over the Montreal Expos in Chicago.

WITNESS SAYS HE SAW OFFICERS STRIKE STEWART
description: A student testified yesterday that he had seen transit police officers kick and hit Michael Stewart on Sept. 15, 1983. But on cross-examination, he acknowledged that a month and a half later he had filled out a questionnaire saying he was ''not positive'' such a beating had taken place.

description: The New Jersey Nets have scheduled a news conference for today at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, apparently to name Dave Wohl as new head coach.

description: OF the many thrills associated with long-distance computer communications, few surpass the first glance at the telephone bill. Home computer users who while away the hours perusing electronic bulletin boards across the country can run up truly impressive phone bills.

description: To the Editor:

title: Dental Identification
description: The American Dental Association reports it is working on a proposal to implement a nationwide identification system, primarily intended to aid the search for missing children, that would use a tiny plastic disk bonded to a back tooth. A 10-digit indentification number and a toll-free telephone number would be written on the microdisk, which then would be glued to a tooth with a clear composite resin.

title: Whistle-Blower; Horn-Blower
description: Consider the treatment of two civil servants who work in the Defense Department, Ernest Fitzgerald and Mary Ann Gilleece. Mr. Fitzgerald is a senior management analyst in the Air Force who has rightly won public notice as a ''whistle-blower.'' His job is to see that Air Force contractors do their job properly. He cares about it so deeply that he fought for 13 years to get his job back after being fired in 1969 for telling Congress about a $2 billion cost overrun on the C-5A transport.

title: McDonnell Planes
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said that agreement had been reached to sell commercial aircraft worth about $300 million to Toa Domestic Airlines of Japan. An official of the St. Louis-based corporation said the planes, whose number was not specified, were twin-engine, 150-passenger MD-81 and MD-87 aircraft. He said Toa had been a regular buyer of McDonnell Douglas planes.

title: ODETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: RESOURCE EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WURLITZER CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ROBLIN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 15
THERMAL PROFILES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHAMPION PARTS REBUILDERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Dropped Passes Are Jets' Concern
description: When a team is coming off a 7-9 season, when its offensive line is composed of strangers, when its quarterback has started only five regular-season games, then the receivers had better not contribute to the confusion by dropping passes.

title: Boeing Contract
description: The Boeing Company is being awarded a $102.8 million fixed-price Air Force contract to deliver and install re-engineering kits for KC-135 aircraft, the Pentagon said. The contract is expected to be completed in September 1986.

title: 3 Charged in Iran Parts Sales
description: The owner of an electronics company and two employees were charged today with conspiring to export military parts to Iran, Federal prosecutors said. The owner, Steven Sanett, 33 years old, was also charged with attempting to export military components. He is accused of purchasing a shipment of military tubing, then selling it to a Swiss company, which would then direct it to Iran.

title: 40,000 ARE TO BE SENT HOME FROM ETHIOPIAN RELIEF CAMPS
description: The senior United Nations official in Ethiopia has announced plans to send more than 40,000 people from relief camps at Makale, in the northern Tigre region, back to their homes and farms.

title: $31 Million Prison Opens in Jersey
description: Governor Kean officially opened the $31 million Riverfront State Prison today, saying it would ease prison overcrowding while aiding Camden's economy.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Juli Veee, who spent four years with San Diego before last season, has signed a three-year contract that returned him to the Sockers of the Major Indoor Soccer League. . . . Andrew Toney, a Philadelphia 76er guard, was placed in a walking cast yesterday for treatment of a sprained right ankle. Toney will remain in the cast for two to three weeks and will then be re-examined. . . . John Walker of New Zealand will defend his title in the fifth annual Fifth Avenue Mile set for Sept. 28, the New York Road Runners club announced yesterday. . . . Marvelous Marvin Hagler, the middleweight boxing champion, and the World Boxing Association were sued in United States Federal Court in Newark by James Kinchen, a middleweight contender.

title: REXON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: METS HANG ON TO WIN 8TH STRAIGHT
description: Sid Fernandez did not achieve everything he wanted to last night. The Mets' 22-year-old left-hander matched a career high by striking out 13, and he had a dramatic one-hit shutout for eight innings. But he was not around for the finish of the Mets' eighth straight victory last night at Shea Stadium.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: CAGLE'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After a loss of $23,000 for the quarter and income of $95,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations and tax credits of $76,000 for the quarter and $147,000 for the 6 months. Results for the year-ago quarter have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Sakowitz Store Sold to Dunlap
description: Sakowitz Inc. said it agreed to sell its store in Amarillo, Tex., to the Dunlap Company, a Forth Worth-based retail chain.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Released Larry Bowa, shortstop, and recalled Shawon Dunston, shortstop, and Steve Engel, pitcher, from Iowa farm team.

title: MECHANICAL TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
LANCER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LONDON EXHIBIT SHOWS MANY TALENTS OF FORTUNY
description: The name of Mariano Fortuny is irrevocably connected with the finely pleated silk tunic dresses he first created in 1907. They are now collectors' items, but some are still worn by their proud owners. An exhibition at Liberty, the London department store, shows that there was a great deal more to Fortuny than his pleated Delphos dresses, as he named them after the ancient Greek style that inspired them.

title: SEAPORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: South African Black Is Wounded in Joke
description: A 19-year-old white South African was fined $200 today after she told a court she shot a black maid in a joke.

title: Court Protection Sought By Sanko Steamship
description: The Sanko Steamship Company, one of the world's largest operators of oil tankers, has applied for court protection from creditors under the corporate rehabilitation law, officials of the Kobe district court said today.

title: OPERA: FAYE ROBINSON AS ELVIRA IN 'PURTANI'
description: IF it took a revival of Bellini's ''Puritani'' to lure Faye Robinson back to the New York City Opera after an absence of six years, then the revival at the State Theater on Sunday night was worth it on that count alone. Miss Robinson qualifies as one of America's finer contributions to the international operatic stage; her soprano voice is a beautiful instrument that she deploys with considerable skill, she moves freely on the stage and she has star quality.

title: ENSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $1,413,000 for the quarter and the 6 months from the settlement of litigation.

title: A TOXIC CHEMICAL SPILLS IN CAMDEN
description: About 3,000 gallons of a highly toxic, flammable liquid spilled yesterday when a forklift struck a storage tank pipe at a chemical plant in Camden, N.J. Fumes affected at least 35 workers and firefighters, who were treated at a local hospital, and about 200 people were evacuated from a two-block area around the plant.

title: VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: QUESTIONS ABOUT CARE OF PRESIDENT PERSIST
description: THE President's recent medical problems have raised clouds of confusion and contradictions, and perhaps some questions about the general adequacy of his care.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Japan Cabinet Resignation
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone today accepted the resignation of Cabinet Minister Toshio Komoto, who offered to quit when the shipping firm he founded became the largest business failure in Japanese history.

title: Eleanor E. Seiling, 78, Dies; Headed Animal-Rights Unit
description: Eleanor E. Seiling, the founder and president of United Action for Animals Inc., a national animal-rights organization, died Aug. 7 at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. She was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SERVING IT SMOKED
description: AT this time of year, when bluefish are running in Long Island Sound, I bring back my catch and prepare a batch of home-smoked fish. They are delicious summer appetizers served with thin slices of dark bread and creamy horseradish sauce.

title: Semper Fidelis
description: He pulled every string he could think of, but not even a famous Senator or a concerned Congressman could keep Eddie Meyers in an Atlanta Falcon uniform beyond training camp. Meyers, a 1982 graduate of the Naval Academy, who set several school rushing records, was signed by the Falcons as a free agent in 1982 and has faithfully attended every Falcon training camp since.

title: GORBACHEV DENIES SOVIET COMPLETED NUCLEAR TESTS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that a week-old Soviet halt of nuclear testing was verifiable by existing means, and he renewed his call on the United States to join the moratorium.

title: FOUNDER OF ANTICRIME GROUP
description: Carl M. Loeb Jr., a prominent businessman and a founder of the National Crime Prevention Council, died yesterday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital after suffering a stroke. He was 81 years old.

title: Teacher Shot on W. 91st St.
description: A teacher on her way to classes at the Trinity School on West 91st Street was wounded yesterday morning by two bullets fired by a man who then fled in a car, the police said. One bullet pierced the left hand of the woman, Shelley Fishman, 38 years old, of Fort Lee, N.J., and a second grazed her head. She was reported in good condition at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: 101 Detainees Freed From Prison by Israel
description: Israel freed 101 prisoners, most of them Lebanese Shiites, from Atlit prison near Haifa today.

title: FARED ROBOT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including a nonrecurring gain of about $1,000,000 from the disposition of assets.

title: ACTORS MAY CALL A STRIKE
description: Leaders of Actors Equity, in a letter that reached key union members yesterday, said they were considering calling a strike against the association that repepresents 77 major regional theaters, including several in New York.

title: Chip Orders Hold Steady
description: Semiconductor orders in July remained at the same low level as in June, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association.

title: ZAYRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: Sales figures do not include leased department sales. Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split paid in May.

title: 'America, the Beautiful' Gets a Job in Sales
description: To the Editor:

title: KIRBY EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss after a loss of $29,146,609 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: RUTLEDGE RELIVING AN ANXIOUS STRUGGLE
description: Sometimes it seems that nothing happens here. In one corner of the campus, a group of 10-year-old girls rode horseback. Nearby, some youngsters took a canoe out onto the pond. The Giants worked out in another corner, but the dull thuds of practice could not be heard up the hill.

title: Strike Threat at Sun-Times
description: Editorial employees at The Chicago Sun-Times voted 129 to 1 Monday to authorize the setting of a strike date if a contract dispute cannot be resolved. About 275 members of the Chicago Newspaper Guild have been working without a contract since May 31, said Charles Nicodemus, chairman of the guild unit at the newspaper. He said that issues included management demands for concessions involving severance pay and night differential payments, and a proposal to remove some jobs from guild coverage.

title: Copter Crashes in Turkey
description: A Canadian helicopter pilot was killed today while taking seismic surveys for oil when his aircraft hit a power cable and crashed in eastern Turkey, the state radio said. It identified the pilot as Mario Jorge Calisto.

title: UNILEVER GROUP OF COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Unilever NV. c-Unilever Plc.

title: Avellini at Ease in Jet System
description: Despite the strong possibility the Jets will have only Ken O'Brien and Pat Ryan as quarterbacks when the season opens, Bob Avellini, the third-stringer, feels so comfortable right now that he goes home for lunch between practice sessions.

title: Rare Rhino Born on Coast
description: A rare Indian rhinoceros has been born in the Los Angeles Zoo, officials said Monday.

title: PREFERRED HEALTH CARE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PHOTON SOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
It's Sanders, As in Heisman
description: Slippery Rock (Pa.) State likes to bill itself as ''the Snoopy of college football,'' but when its sports information people herald their star running back as a 1985 Heisman Trophy candidate, they are barking up the wrong tree.

title: NAVY ENDS BAN ON CONTRACTING WITH DYNAMICS
description: The Navy announced today that it had lifted a ban on signing new contracts with the General Dynamics Corporation, bringing five months of penalties against the company to a close.

title: SCREEN: 'KEY EXCHANGE,' A COMEDY
description: AS it has littered the language with jargon relating to commitments, relationships and something called ''personal space,'' the Yuppie phenomenon has transformed great sections of Manhattan from neighborhoods with a healthily heterogeneous social and racial mix into new jungles of mostly white, middle-class gentrification.

description: b-Includes a charge of $14.2 million for restructuring of Smith-Corona typewriters and the closing of a coated paper products plant.

MIAMIANS OVERWHELMINGLY REJECT PLAN TO GIVE MORE POWER TO MAYOR
description: Miami voters today overwhelmingly turned down proposals to give the Mayor more power and to choose future mayors in partisan elections.

title: The Yacht Club Is Getting Shipshape
description: Another lighting fixture came to attention the other day when it emerged from its stately home in the New York Yacht Club and stopped pedestrian traffic.

title: Media Guide Goof
description: The first copies of the 1985 media guide to be distributed by the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers rolled off the presses earlier this week, and it was then that Jerry Walker, the team's public relations director, felt his heart rolling up into his throat.

title: MEDICARE-GLASER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SOUTH AFRICA DAMPENS TALK OF RACIAL CHANGE
description: South African Government officials and pro-Government commentators seemed to have started a campaign today to dampen speculation that President P. W. Botha is about to announce radical racial change that will erode privileged white ways of life.

title: PT COMPONENTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
U.N PENSION FUND DIVESTS ITSELF OF HOLDINGS TIED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: The $4 billion United Nations pension fund has rid itself of all holdings in companies that do business in South Africa, it was announced today.

title: NEW SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 14, 1985
description: International A tail fin was found 80 miles from the mountainside where a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet crashed Monday with 524 people aboard. The tail fin's separation from the fuselage was regarded by aviation experts as important in trying to determine why the jet crashed. Four passengers survived. The loss of life was the highest in a single plane crash in aviation history. [Page A1, Column 6.] The home of Winnie Mandela and an adjacent clinic she runs in a black township in South Africa were badly burned in a fire. Mrs. Mandela, wife of the jailed nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, charged that the fire was set by the ''security branch directed by the Government in Pretoria'' in an effort to undermine the outlawed African National Congress, which her husband led. The police raided her home a week ago, after firing rubber bullets and using whips to break up a demonstration outside. [A1:3.] An impeachment move was defeated by allies of President Ferdinand E. Marcos of the Philippines. A parliamentary panel rejected an opposition motion charging him with graft and corruption, violating the Constitution and other crimes. [A9:1.] National The computer-based safety system at the Union Carbide plant in Institute, W. Va., was not programmed to predict the path of the toxic gas that leaked Sunday, causing 135 injuries. Union Carbide acknowledged this after the system's manufacturer charged that a series of omissions by the Union Carbide staff was responsible for its apparent failure.

title: Blue Jays Beat Rangers by 5-3
description: Lloyd Moseby and Rance Mulliniks hit consecutive homers as the Toronto Blue Jays, scoring all their runs in the first inning, defeated the Rangers by 5-3 tonight.

title: LEHIGH VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $433,000 for the quarter and $697,000 for the 6 months, a gain of $419,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of discontinued operations, a gain of $200,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of mineral rights and a gain of $421,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of a 50 percent interest in Dori Shoe Co. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $70,000 for the quarter and $193,000 for the 6 months and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $14,000 for the quarter and $27,000 for the 6 months.

title: SMALLER LEAK PUTS WEST VIRGINIA TOWN ON EDGE
description: A chemical spill from the Union Carbide Corporation's South Charleston works, on an island in the Kanawha River, caused a brief emergency here tonight that added to tensions already heightened by a more serious leak Sunday at the company's plant in nearby Institute.

title: PLANS FOR A MILITARY DRAFT ATTRACT NEW ATTENTION
description: The signs are no bigger than a sail on a distant horizon, but with the economy improving and jobs easier to get in civilian life, service in the armed forces has begun to look less attractive. Add to that a shrinking pool of men of military age over the next 10 years, and talk of resuming the draft begins to rumble.

title: Bishop Edward Swanstrom; Directed Catholic Aid Group
description: Bishop Edward E. Swanstrom, former executive director of Catholic Relief Services, died Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness. He was 82 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

description: b-Net income including a gain of $1,809,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of a unit and income of $91,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY CELEBRATES A HAPPY 50TH
description: FIFTY years ago today, President Roosevelt signed into law what has proved to be the most successful piece of domestic legislation in our nation's history. The 1935 Social Security Act launched a new era of Federal activism on a broad front and radically transformed the relationship between the American people and their Government.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. The Mets, on a streak that has put them into first place in the National League East, send Ron Darling to the mound in search of his 11th victory.

title: APPEALS PANEL UPHOLDS DISMISSAL OF LAWSUIT ON NICARAGUAN POLICY
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the dismissal of a lawsuit accusing the United States Government of illegally supporting the Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: Offering From M.T.A. Has Top Yield of 9.90%
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority's $150 million issue of commuter facilities revenue bonds was tentatively offered yesterday through underwriters led by Dillon, Read & Company with a maximum yield of 9.90 percent for 9 3/4 percent bonds due in 2015 at a price of 98 1/2.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JEAN RHYS: THE COMPLETE NOVELS. Introduction by Diana Athill and photographs by Bressai. 574 pages.

title: Evening News
description: Two television producers have agreed temporarily to stop soliciting Evening News Association stock from Michigan residents in a hostile $453 million takeover bid for the newspaper and broadcasting company, lawyers said. The agreement by Norman Lear and A. Jerrold Perenchio will remain in effect until a Federal appeals court decides whether Michigan law applies to the takeover fight, said Theodore Souris, a lawyer representing the producers. Arguments are scheduled for next Tuesday in Cincinnati.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: PANEL POSTPONES LANDMARK PLAN FOR THE THEATERS
description: The City Landmarks Preservation Commission yesterday temporarily put off designating more Broadway theaters as landmarks. Commissioners said they first wanted to agree on what restrictions would apply to theaters that received the status.

title: DANCE: FOLKLORIC TROUPE FROM PUERTO RICO
description: THE Gibaro de Puerto Rico was interrupted by rain about halfway through its performance on Saturday night at the Damrosch Park Bandshell, where the Puerto Rican folkloric dance company performed as part of the Lincoln Center Out-of-Doors Festival. But Gibaro returns tonight, and the charming and exuberant San Juan-based troupe is well worth a visit.

title: Before It's Too Late in South Africa
description: IF the South African Government proceeds on its present course, internal disorder will continue and violence may become so great as to lead ultimately to a confrontation with forces supported by the Soviet Union. Even in the face of such a prospect, the United States should state unequivocally that it will not find it morally or politically acceptable to support the whites against the blacks.

description: France has the Tour de France bicycle race. The United States has the World Series, the Super Bowl, the Kentucky Derby, the Indianapolis 500, the Final Four, the Stanley Cup playoffs, much more and, somewhere way down the line, the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: When a Personal Note Is Made to Go Public
description: To the Editor:

title: THE POP LIFE
description: FOUR of the hit singles on this week's black pop charts, credited to four different artists, were written, arranged and produced by three brothers from Brooklyn and three of their cousins, known collectively as Full Force. And in the last six months, Full Force has produced three albums as well.

title: Latin Money Supply Up
description: Money supplies have been soaring in Latin America much faster than anywhere else, the International Monetary Fund says in the current issue of the official I.M.F. Survey.

title: The Luxury Market
description: It had seemed to both experts and amateurs for some time now that Washington was acquiring more luxury hotels than the city and its expense-account visitors could afford. The first break in the market came yesterday, when Regent International Hotels sold its interest in the newest and one of the most elaborate of these, the $64 million Regent, to the local developer and majority owner.

title: It's Time to Give All Welfare Recipients a Chance at Workfare
description: To the Editor:

title: WOHL IS NAMED NETS' COACH
description: Dave Wohl, who played for five National Basketball Association teams and served as an assistant coach with three, was officially named the Nets' coach today.

title: Utility Bonds In California
description: M-S-R Public Power Agency, a consortium of municipally owned utilities in Modesto, Santa Clara, and Redding, Calif., is offering $242 million of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 9.323 percent for bonds due 2021, through underwriters led by E. F. Hutton & Company. The bonds are rated single A by both Moody's and S.& P. The financing includes other bonds yielding from 6 percent in 1987 to 7 1/4 percent in 1990, 8.60 percent in 1996 and 9.178 percent in 2005. Proceeds will be used to retire bond anticipation notes issued by M-S-R to purchase an interest in a coal-fired power plant.

'61 DEATH OF FIGURE IN INQUIRY ON ESTES IS RULES A HOMOCIDE
description: In a case linked to Lyndon B. Johnson and Billie Sol Estes, a convicted swindler, a state judge today ordered that the official cause of death of an Agriculture Department employee 24 years ago be changed from suicide to homicide.

title: SINGAPORE LEADERS FIND DEMOCRACY FLAWED
description: As Singapore celebrated the 20th anniversary of its independence over the weekend, a new generation of national leaders seemed to be moving closer to endorsing a one-party state for this former British colony.

title: Bomb Kills Officer in Chile
description: A Chilean navy officer died today and a navy sergeant was wounded while trying to defuse a bomb in the town of Penablanca, 70 miles northwest of Santiago, a navy communique said. A suspected left-wing rebel was killed by his own bomb outside the police museum in Santiago yesterday and a police officer was shot in a subsequent fight with the dead man's companions. The attacks followed demonstrations last week to protest suspected police involvement in the murders in March of three Communists.

South African Torture Of Detainees Reported
description: Amnesty International expressed ''grave fears'' tonight for the safety of prisoners detained in South Africa under emergency regulations introduced July 21.

title: The Young Drinking Driver
description: Three teen-age boys stagger from a party toward a car. The picture on the television screen freezes and the following message appears: ''You drink, you drive, you die.''

title: CARBIDE COMPUTER COULD NOT TRACK GAS THAT ESCAPED
description: The computer in the safety system installed earlier this year at the Union Carbide plant in Institute, W.Va., was not programmed to predict the path of the particular toxic gas that leaked Sunday, causing 135 injuries.

description: b-Including capital gains of $9,767,000 for the quarter and $14,905,000 for the 6 months. c-Including capital gains of $2,447,000 for the quarter and $4,637,000 for the 6 months.

title: Output Off in Britain
description: Britain's seasonally adjusted output in all industries fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in June from May, but was up 4.3 percent from a year earlier, the Government said today. This compares with a month-to-month rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in May, when the annual pace of increase was 6.4 percent. The June drop in industrial production was due to a seasonally adjusted 8.4 percent decline in oil production, which was depressed by a shutdown of oil fields for summer maintenance.

title: DISPUTED INCINERATOR PLAN FOR BROOKLYN NAVY YARD NEAR VOTE
description: Final approval for the construction of a huge incinerator at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard, the first stage of the largest new public works project undertaken by the city in years, will be considered tomorrow by the Board of Estimate.

title: Andujar Wins 19th By Beating Pirates
description: Terry Pendleton singled home the tie-breaking run in the sixth inning tonight and Darrell Porter followed with a two-run double as Joaquin Andujar became the first 19-game winner in the major leagues as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Pittsburgh Pirates 6-5.

title: INMED CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
description: b-Including a gain of $586,557, or 60 cents a share, from the sale of land.

title: FARMHOUSE CHEESE NOW 'MADE IN U.S.A.'
description: FIVE years ago, if you wanted to taste a farmhouse cheese you pretty much had to make it yourself or buy a European import. Suddenly, all that has changed. American farmhouse cheeses, meaning cheeses made on the farm where the dairy herd is raised, are increasingly available in specialty cheese shops and at farmers' markets, and often by mail order from the farmers themselves. While they are not exactly taking over from the presliced, prepackaged, plastic-wrapped products that continue to be the favorites of many Americans, they are delighting the palates of cheese purists.

title: GATES LEARJET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: AGENCY SEEKS TO IMPROVE TRUCK INSPECTIONS
description: The Federal Highway Administration is reorganizing its truck safety inspection program in an attempt to satisfy industry and Congressional critics who say it is ineffective and should be removed from the agency's jurisdiction.

title: Sprint Sets Layoffs In Marketing Push
description: GTE Sprint, the big long-distance telephone company, said yesterday that it would lay off 600 employees, or just under 9 percent of its 7,000-person work force. The layoffs will affect all divisions and include top managers, although the number of executives to lose their jobs was not specified.

title: County Official Defends Handling of Abuse Cases
description: A county prosecutor here defended her handling of child sex abuse cases before a panel considering whether she should be removed from office.

title: Louisiana Power
description: A Federal District Court judge has dismissed a $1.5 billion suit filed by a subsidiary of Middle South Utilities Inc. against members of the Louisiana Public Service Commission.

description: b-Net income including an extraordinary credit of $41,000.

title: End of an Era
description: Feel like a shiftless summer spendthrift when you read reports on the Federal budget? Relax, you may already be complying with the Deficit Reduction Act of 1984 every time you open a bottle of liquor. A relatively obscure provision of that law eliminated the longstanding requirement for a special Federal paper seal atop each bottle, allowing manufacturers to use a cap or seal of their own design and saving the taxpayers about $1.7 million a year. The new rules went into effect July 1, and the new bottles should be replacing old stock in neighborhood stores just about now.

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The net income in the latest 6 months was exceeded by preferred dividend requirements.

title: Channel Record
description: Peter Johnson, a 26-year-old geologist from Midland, Tex., set a record for swimming the English Channel from France to England yesterday when he covered the 21 miles in 8 hours 20 minutes despite a midchannel breakdown by his escort boat and a pause to shout a marriage proposal to his girlfriend. According to the Channel Swimming Association, Johnson's time cut 14 minutes off the previous record, set last year by an English swimmer, Lyndon Dunsbee.

title: PREPARATIONS THAT PRESERVE PORK CHOPS' SUCCULENT FLAVOR
description: BY rights and by tradition, the words ''pork chops'' should immediately evoke a bevy of flattering modifiers, such as ''tender,'' ''succulent'' and ''soul-satisfying.'' But at an informal dinner-table symposium, the assembled company - a household cook, several family members and one regular Wednesday-evening freeloader -found that the only word they could conjure up was the single adjective ''dry.''

title: EXCEL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HIGH PLAINS OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Justice Department;   Merits of Pushing for Spying Trials
description: On the Monday morning that Arthur J. Walker went to trial on charges of espionage, his defense lawyers made an offer they thought would be irresistible.

title: SANDWICH CHEF INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
REAGAN TO USE SENATE PLAN AS A VETO GUIDE
description: Senior White House officials said today that President Reagan would use the discarded Senate budget resolution as a bench mark in considering whether to veto appropriation bills passed by Congress this fall.

title: ZULU LEADER SETS PRIMARY DEMANDS
description: The leader of South Africa's six million Zulus said today that the program of change that President P. W. Botha of South Africa is expected to unveil Thursday will be of no interest to him or other black leaders unless it includes an explicit promise of power-sharing for blacks.

title: PHOTO CONTROL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in March 1985.

title: Gasoline Price Drop Is Seen
description: Consumers can expect to pay at least a nickel and maybe as much as a dime a gallon less for gasoline by Christmas as a surge of imports forces United States refiners to reduce profit margins and cut wholesale prices, according to a Government report published this week.

title: Alcoa Debentures Due Date Is 2015
description: Aluminum Company of America is offering $150 million of 12 percent sinking fund debentures due 2015 at a price of 99.6, to yield 12.05 percent, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: NEW NEW YORKERS TURN BACK TO BOOKS
description: AFTER moving to New York City last month, Gina Veltman thought her new life would be a series of weekends eating out and dancing. That was before the reality of city prices took hold. Now she has a different pastime - reading.

title: Berkshire to Shut Textile Division
description: Berkshire Hathaway Inc., the Omaha-based insurance and textile company controlled by the investor Warren E. Buffett, said it would close its textile operations in New Bedford, Mass., by the end of the year, thereby withdrawing from that business.

title: TSR INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Tainted Cheese Epidemic Declared Ended on Coast
description: The food-poisoning epidemic caused by tainted Mexican-style cheese and blamed for about 95 deaths and hundreds of illnesses throughout the country was declared over Monday by Los Angeles County health officials.

title: GOLDEN AND RIVALS DEBATE DONATIONS
description: Three Democratic candidates for Brooklyn Borough President yesterday challenged the incumbent, Howard Golden, over his acceptance of large campaign donations from real-estate developers and the timing of announcements of several real-estate developments in the borough.

title: BOSTON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BERKEY PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax benefits of $657,000 for the quarter and $1,243,000 for the 6 months, income of $515,000 for the quarter and a loss of $264,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. c-Including tax benefits of $462,000 for the quarter and $1,077,000 for the 6 months and income from discontinued operations of $887,000 for the quarter and $548,000 for the 6 months.

title: LINCOLN INCOME LIFE INSURANCE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TACO VILLA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Part of Life Insurance Unfairly Tax-Exempt
description: To the Editor:

title: CRASH MYSTERY: WHAT DAMAGED TAIL?
description: Speculation on the cause of the Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 disaster Monday centered yesterday on the discovery of a large part of the vertical tail some 80 miles from the crash site.

title: 'Religious Bigotry' On Sun Myung Moon
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Closes Mixed; Dow Up 1.01
description: Stock prices ended mixed yesterday, with late afternoon activity spiked by a downturn when several brokerage houses carried out sell programs.

title: Foreman Says G.O.P. Never Pressed for Gift
description: A foreman for the Town of Hempstead's Highway Department testified in Federal District Court today that he had never been pressured into contributing to the Republican Party since he began working for the town in 1951.

title: Federal Judge in Florida Loses Bid to Halt Inquiry
description: A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia refused today to halt an investigation into the activities of Federal District Judge Alcee Hastings of the Southern District of Florida.

title: PART OF JET'S TAIL IS FOUND 80 MILES FROM CRASH SCENE
description: Rescue workers continued today searching through the wreckage of a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet on a mountainside in central Japan, and a navy ship reported Tuesday finding part of the plane's tail in the sea 80 miles from the crash site. A second piece of wreckage was found nearby later.

title: RESTAURANT GUIDES: PERSONALIZED VIEWS OF NEW YORK SCENE
description: WHEN Aubrey and Harriet Moss get the urge to eat out, as they do about three times a week, they often consult their current and back issues of The Restaurant Reporter, a newsletter devoted to reviews of New York City restaurants. ''Their taste is somewhat similar to ours,'' said Mr. Moss, a businessman who lives in Oradell, N.J., and usually travels into the city in search of a fine meal. ''What they like, we like, and the style of writing is fun.''

title: MARCOS ALLIES BAR IMPEACHMENT BILL
description: An attempt to impeach President Ferdinand E. Marcos was defeated tonight when a parliamentary committee rejected an opposition motion charging him with graft and corruption, violating the Constitution and other ''high crimes.''

title: Comings and Goings
description: Donald Shields, president of Southern Methodist University, has reportedly sent letters to about a dozen boosters linked to football recruiting infractions, banning them from school athletic facilities and ordering them not to talk to student-athletes or prospective recruits. . . . Oscar Gamble, the Chicago White Sox pinch-hitter, has been given his unconditional release. . . . The University of Georgia will retire football jersey No. 34, which was worn by Herschel Walker, in ceremonies before the game against Alabama on Sept. 2 in Sanford Stadium. . . . Hours after the New York Road Runners Club announced Monday that John Walker, the defending champion, would run in the Fifth Avenue Mile, Walker angrily denied the announcement, saying he was not committed to the Sept. 28 race and was angry at Fred Lebow, the race director, for not offering enough appearance money to ''all of us regulars'' who have made the race ''what it is.'' . . . The Rangers signed Bryan Walker, a 20-year-old defenseman who last season scored 71 points in 65 games with Moose Jaw, Saskatchewan, of the Western Hockey League, and also signed Bill O'Dwyer, a free-agent center. . . . Tim McCalister, the Oklahoma guard who threw a cup of water at an official during last year's national collegiate basketball touirnament, has been disqualified from the next N.C.A.A. tournament game the Sooners play.

title: LACLEDE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 Sentenced In Kickbacks
description: The first two of ten current and former southern California aerospace industry employees accused of accepting kickbacks in awarding Government contracts were sentenced today.

title: JERSEY SCHOOL'S DRUG TEST BLOCKED
description: A state judge temporarily barred a regional high school today from requiring all its students to take urine tests for drug or alcohol use.

title: CHEMICAL PIPE SIZE CALLED KEY SAFETY FACTOR
description: Senior Union Carbide officials said in interviews today that the leak of toxic gas on Sunday might indicate a need for changes in piping and valve systems at chemical plants throughout the country.

title: RESEARCH TEAM CITES TREATMENT OF LIVER CANCER
description: A Johns Hopkins University cancer scientist said today that his research team had developed the ''first effective treatment'' for advanced stages of liver cancer, a disease that is almost always fatal. However, the scientist, Dr. Stanley E. Order, stressed that the treatment had helped only seven patients get rid of all traces of the disease, while some of the others were at a plateau where their tumors seemed neither to grow nor to shrink.

title: Intelogic Head Brings 25 Years of Experience
description: John Hale has nearly 25 years of experience in the computer business, and it seems likely that he will need it in his new job as president and chief executive officer of Intelogic Trace Inc.

title: MAJOR REALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
PLUTONIUM TRACE CALLED NORMAL IN CITY'S WATER
description: Normal traces of plutonium were found in the last of the tests made after an elevated level of the radioactive substance showed up in one sampling of New York City's water, Federal energy officials said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: COOL JAZZ ON CONCRETE One remedy for hot August is cool jazz. The open-air acoustics on asphalt cannot be faulted, except for a little additional percussion now and then from cars passing over potholes or buses sounding off. But the price is right: The concerts are free.

title: China's Jersey Plan
description: A closed paper mill in Paterson, N.J., could return to operation soon as China's first overseas industrial venture.

title: Control Data
description: The Control Data Corporation said that its recent downward revision of earnings put its first-half financial results in violation of restrictions on revolving credit arrangements with its banks but that the banks agreed to temporarily relax the restrictions.

title: INDIA'S 'TEJI' (BULL) MARKET
description: A typical day on the floor of the Bombay stock exchange: About 2,000 frantic, sweating brokers are packed into an immense, sweltering room. They are pushing and shoving each other and everyone seems to be screaming.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: TO watch the midsummer sun go down, a crowd of elegantly dressed men and women have gathered for a rooftop party in uptown New York. The city's million lights provide a fairy tale-like backdrop. The stars and the new moon make the sky feel close to the roof. Cheeses and sushi have been arranged with great care.

title: Turner Expects Loss in Quarter
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. will report a loss for the second quarter and the first half because of charges related to its unsuccessful bid for CBS Inc., the company's chief financial officer, William Bevins Jr., said. The charges are expected to be about $20 million.

title: Killing of G.I. Linked To West German Blast
description: The West German police said today that they were investigating a possible link between a car bomb attack at the United States Rhein-Main air base Thursday in which two Americans were killed and the killing of a United States soldier the night before.

title: USE OF PHONES HELD CAR SAFETY FACTOR
description: Something unexpected happened while Michael J. Connolly was talking on the telephone not long ago. He lost control of his car.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TRANSOHIO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $350,000 for the quarter and $2,644,000 for the 6 months.

title: MORMONS GO BACK TO A SACRED VALLEY IN MISSOURI
description: From his house on a steep hill a mile south of this crossroads village, Graham Doxey stood looking out over a lush green valley toward a strand of woods lining the Grand River.

title: Man Slain in 42d St. Theater
description: A man was beaten to death in the Apollo Theater by another patron during a dispute yesterday afternoon, and last night a Manhattan man was being held as a suspect in the slaying, the police said. The victim was not identified, but the police said the suspect was Robert Smalls, 45 years old. The killing occurred at 3 P.M. in the theater, a movie house on 42d Street west of Broadway.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page on Saturday about rape trauma syndrome misnamed the author of the book ''The Ultimate Violation.'' She is Judith Rowland, not Patricia Rowland.

title: Prosecutors Drop Move To Oust 3 Coast Justices
description: The California District Attorneys Association is dropping its campaign to oust Chief Justice Rose Bird of the California Supreme Court and two colleagues because the group fears it might lose its tax-exempt status.

title: SYRACUSE SUPPLY CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have been restated reflect a 50 percent stock split paid in March.

title: Manville's Plan Is Said to Gain
description: Attorneys for the Manville Corporation and its creditors reported progress yesterday in trying to fashion a settlement based on a company plan of reorganization that includes an offer to pay $2.5 billion to asbestos victims. Federal Bankruptcy Judge Burton Lifland adjourned the proceedings until Sept. 4 to give the attorneys more time to negotiate.

title: 2 U.S. Marshals Wounded
description: Two United States marshals were shot and critically wounded today as they were transferring two convicted bank robbers between prisons, the authorities said. One of the prisoners, wounded in the leg, was recaptured a few miles away and the other was arrested about 400 miles away in Illinois after stealing a series of vehicles, officers said. The marshals, Wayne Ruud and Henry Carlson, both of Duluth, Minn., were in grave or critical condition at St. Luke's Hospital in Duluth.

title: AMERICAN EXPLORATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PLAN FOR PRIVATE FRENCH TV STIRS WIDE CRITICISM
description: A French Government decision to allow private television stations for the first time in this country has run into opposition from both the left and right.

title: Kodak Plans to Market To Black Consumers
description: The Eastman Kodak Company has named a minority-owned agency to provide specific marketing and advertising to black consumers. The Rochester company appointed Uniworld Group Inc., a 16-year-old, New York City agency that also handles minority advertising for General Motors, American Telephone and Telegraph, General Foods and Burger King.

title: DISCOVERIES
NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: NBC OFFERS 'HEARTBEAT,' A RARE BOOK MUSICAL
description: NO original drama with music on television can be all bad. The book musical is an under-represented form, found mostly in bite-sized episodes on MTV. That's why it's good to have ''HeartBeat'' around. The one-hour NBC production, on Channel 4 at 10 P.M., is mostly bland and almost entirely derivative, but it does show that someone is trying.

title: D'Amato's Weak Comment on Pay Kickbacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Rebels Said to Seize Southern Uganda Town
description: Uganda's most powerful rebel group has seized control of Masaka, the country's third-largest town, and appears to be preparing to march on the capital, travelers returning from the Masaka area said today.

title: QUAKER OATS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $6,300,000, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and the year for the sale and restructuring of business.

FIX-CASE MISTRIAL CALLED AND VACATED
description: A state criminal judge ordered a mistrial today in the point-shaving case of John Williams, the former Tulane University basketball star, but four hours later the judge vacated that order.

title: HOMAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $3.6 million for the quarter and 9 months and tax credits of $2.2 million for the quarter and $1.5 million for the 9 months. c-Net loss. d-Including extraordinary credits of $15,000 for the quarter and $1.8 million for the 9 months, a charge of $346,000 for the quarter from the reversal of a tax credit and a tax credit of $269,000 for the 9 months.

title: NEW YORK TO REQUIRE THAT HOSPITALS SEEK DONATIONS OF ORGANS
description: Hospitals in New York State will be required as of Jan. 1 to ask families for organ donations whenever a patient dies.

title: Sukova Defeats Villagran, 6-4, 6-1
description: Fourth-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia struggled to a 6-4, 6-1 second-round victory over Adriana Villagran of Argentina in the $150,000 United Jersey Bank Classic today.

title: BELLWETHER EXPLORATION COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F. MURRAY ABRAHAM JOINS AN OLD FOE
description: F. Murray Abraham is together with Mozart again, but this time speaking for him, not against him.

title: ISRAEL CALLS FOR PROSECUTION OF 12 IN ARABS' DEATHS
description: Attorney General Yitzhak Zamir called today for the prosecution of a general, five members of the General Security Services, three soldiers and three police officers in connection with the beating of two captured Arab bus hijackers who died a short while later.

title: Pro Football;   A Fit Riggins Says He Won't Be 'Bad'
description: John Riggins, one day after ending a three-week holdout from the Washington Redskins, declared himself fit yesterday and promised not to be a ''bad boy'' off the field this season.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 14, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Decolonization Committee - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $72,000 for the quarter and a tax benefit of $408,000 for the year. c-Including tax benefits of $189,000 for the quarter and $764,000 for the year. d-Net income.

title: MARANTZ CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - Announced that Lenn Sakata, second baseman, had agreed to play with Rochester of the International League.

title: Foote, Cone Chief Retiring
description: John E. O'Toole, the 56-year-old chairman of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications Inc., has announced plans to retire at the end of the year. He will be succeeded by Norman W. Brown, 54, who will also continue as president and chief executive.

title:
Economic Scene;

Agriculture's Bleak Outlook
description: THE performance of agriculture has continued to decline throughout the current strong business expansion. Farm export sales have slumped. Farm asset values have continued to fall. And farm income has stagnated at levels that are unacceptably low for many farmers. As a result, farm business failures have increased sharply from the very low levels of the past two decades. Problems on the farm have spilled over into rural communities, and financial pressures on agribusinesses and farm lenders have increased markedly.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Cites Bar Owner on Bias
description: The Justice Department filed suit today against the owner of a restaurant-lounge in Virginia Beach, Va., because he collected a $5 cover charge from black people while white people were admitted free. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Alexandria, Va., charged Robert Bradshaw, the owner of Brad's Second Generation, with discriminating against black patrons. The suit asked the court to compensate victims of the discrimination.

title: PUBS IN FERMENT: STODGES IS OUT, VIDEO IN
description: The local corner pub has always been something of a British institution, as much a part of national identity as afternoon tea or a stiff upper lip.

title: Jailed Turk Testifies In Plot Against Pope
description: Officials of the Rome court trying a case of purported conspiracy to kill Pope John Paul II have received testimony from a Turk imprisoned in West Germany, one of the officials said today.

title: Words From a War
description: Drawn from various sources, notably ''The American Treasury,'' Selected by Clifton Fadiman. Harper & Row, 1955. Praise the Lord and pass the ammunition. HOWELL MAURICE FORGY, on the cruiser New Orleans, Pearl Harbor, Dec. 7, 1941.

title: Fostering a Middle East Dialogue
description: Judith Kipper, a resident fellow at the American Enterprise Institute here, is a Middle East maven.

title: METS TAKE 9TH STRAIGHT
description: Their confidence building with almost every pitch, the Mets barreled along to their ninth consecutive victory last night. The starting pitching was good, the relief pitching was excellent, the hitting was timely, and the result was a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium.

title: $101 Million Issue By Oregon School
description: The Multnomah County School District No. 1 in Portland, Ore., is offering $101.3 million of general obligation refunding bonds with a maximum yield of 9.30 percent for bonds due in 2004, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

QUIXOTE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

Scrawls Overlooked
description: Water is an important weapon in the war against graffiti in city parks. But the drought emergency has made it too precious to use.

title: ASPEN RIBBONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HAGLER KEEPS TITLE, AVERTING A STRIKE
description: A sugar mill strike in Maracaibo, Venezuela, was avoided, according to Bob Arum, when the World Boxing Association desisted in withdrawing title recognition from Marvelous Marvin Hagler.

title: D'AMATO'S WEAK COMMENT ON PAY KICKBACKS
description: To the Editor:

FLANIGAN'S ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29

title: Officials May Expand Quarantine of Killer Bees
description: Government officials are debating whether to expand a quarantine area after concluding that up to four swarms of aggressive Africanized bees escaped from the first colony of such bees in the United States.

title: TOWLE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
A Busy Day
description: When the player strike ended last Wednesday, the American League responded by immediately scheduling five doubleheaders among the full docket of seven matchups that had been previously set for Thursday. The National League, with greater flexibility because of its unbalanced schedule, decided to make up all the lost games at future dates - and thereby aborted a chance to add a little note to baseball history.

title: 2 Far Eastern Tours
description: Members of Congress customarily take advantage of their August recess to make fact-finding trips abroad, and this year at least two of these missions are of more than passing political interest. On Thursday, Bob Dole of Kansas, the Senate majority leader, is taking off for the Far East with six Senate colleagues on a two-week, five-nation swing that will focus on trade policy.

title: RUNOFFS IN NEW YORK'S PRIMARIES BARRED BY U.S. JUDGE IN BIAS SUIT
description: A Federal judge yesterday struck down the state law providing for runoff elections in New York City primaries, declaring that it unconstitutionally discriminated against minority voters and candidates.

title: A Sensitive Marketing Campaign
description: MOST marketers and advertisers would say that a true professional can handle any product. Take Mary George, vice president for marketing for the VLI Corporation, a pharmaceutical and consumer products company that markets a contraceptive. Not only does she market a controversial and sensitive product, but she is also one of 10 children and a Catholic.

title: BLAZE RUINS HOME OF PRETORIA CRITIC
description: The home of Winnie Mandela, a leading foe of apartheid, and an adjacent clinic she runs in a black township outside this city were badly damaged in a fire early this morning.

title: PALACE MAY PROVE BIRTHPLACE OF ALEXANDER
description: The largest royal palace ever discovered in Greece is being excavated near here by the archeological authorities of western Macedonia.

title: DANCE: HAITIAN TROUPE
description: THE imprimatur of the New York Shakespeare Festival's ''Festival Latino in New York'' is an impressive one. But it was hard to believe New York's Haitian community could not do better than the dance presented by the Louines Louinis Haitian Dance Theater on Monday at the Public Theater.

title: LANGLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1985.

title: RETAIL SALES ROSE IN JULY A SLIM 0.4%
description: Retail sales posted only a modest rebound in July, the Government said today, and analysts contended the report was another blow to the Reagan Administration's hopes for a healthy economic upturn in the second half of 1985.

title: ISRAEL OBJECTS TO U.S. TALK WITH PALESTINIANS
description: Israel has told the United States that it would object to any meetings between a Palestinian-Jordanian delegation and a State Department official who arrived in Amman today for talks.

title: Fire Aboard Japanese Ship
description: Fire broke out today aboard a Japanese fishing vessel, about 600 miles south of Dutch Harbor in southwest Alaska, but all 17 crew members were safely evacuated onto another ship, a Coast Guard spokesman said. Meanwhile, an inspection team was examining another Japanese ship, the Coral Ace, for seaworthiness after it had burned at sea for about a week. The Coral Ace, carrying 2,500 cars to Los Angeles, arrived at Dutch Harbor, where firefighters put out its flames.

PANEL URGES IMPROVEMENT OF CITY ELECTION SYSTEM
description: The election apparatus in New York City is ''highly inefficient'' and ''archaic'' and millions of dollars is needed to improve it, a citizens group said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., a Sunnyvale, Calif., maker of computer circuits, said it planned to extend for an additional three months a program of reduced pay for executive, managerial and professional personnel.

title: Letter: On Foster Care;   The Special Need of Older Children
description: To the Editor:

title: STEEL STRIKE: LOWER WAGES A KEY ISSUE
description: The three-week-old strike by 8,200 steelworkers at the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation, the first major strike in the industry in more than a quarter of a century, illustrates the turbulence within both the industry and the union.

title: WINE TALK
description: Anyone who has driven south from Paris to Burgundy in winter quickly realizes that it's not like driving south from New York City to, say, Virginia. Here, at least until one comes to the Rhone Valley, it gets much colder.

title: HUTTON: WHERE THINGS STAND
description: The Justice Department is beginning to say we told you so.

title: Golden Pacific Named in Suit
description: Uninsured depositors of the failed Golden Pacific National Bank filed a class-action suit yesterday against the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency charging discrimination in the closing of the Chinatown bank and failure to justly compensate all depositors.

title: HARRIS GRAPHICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RULING ON RUNOFFS SAID TO HAVE WIDE IMPACT
description: Attorneys who were instrumental in overturning New York's runoff primary law predicted yesterday that a Federal judge's ruling would bolster their case against similar statutes in 10 Southern states.

title: STREAK BY YANKEES COMES TO AN END
description: When the game was over, Marty Bystrom dressed quickly and walked out the clubhouse door, disappearing quietly into the crowd that was leaving Comiskey Park.

title: Shape of Lights to Come
description: Years ago and high above city streets, cobra heads began replacing bishop's crooks. Now, what might best be described as shoe boxes are showing up as well.

title: T.W.A. TEXAS AIR TALKS SET
description: The board of directors of Trans World Airlines yesterday gave the Texas Air Corporation an opportunity to work out an agreement with T.W.A. that could dilute Carl C. Icahn's holdings or could lead to the sale of valuable assets that would make the airline much less attractive to Mr. Icahn.

description: The past few days have not been pleasant for Irwin Rubin, the 57-year-old chairman and chief executive of Computer Memories Inc.

description: EVERY year more than one million American infants undergo an operation that the medical profession declared unnecessary more than a decade ago. That operation is circumcision, the removal of the prepuce, or foreskin, that covers the glans of the penis.
