title: COMPUTER FACTORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WARNER AMEX INTEREST ALIVE
description: The major bidding group that lost the battle for Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. is looking at increasing its offer for the cable company. Time Inc. and Tele-Communications Inc. ''are mulling'' a $950 million bid for Warner Amex, according to sources close to the companies. But the sources emphasized that a higher offer was not imminent and that the companies were considering all their options.

title: CUOMO VOTES TAKEOVER-CURB BILL
description: Governor Cuomo vetoed today a bill that would have made it harder to take over New York corporations.

title: Baldwin Plan Reviewed
description: A proposal that would increase the projected payment to policyholders of the Baldwin-United Corporation is being reviewed by Arkansas and Indiana insurance commissioners, insurance industry sources said today.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $482,000 from the early retirement of debt.

title: TOUGH CANADIAN STANCE IN CHRYSLER BEGINNING
description: Canadian auto workers told Chrysler Canada Ltd. today that they would insist on raises to make their compensation equal to that of employees at General Motors and Ford.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Country-Fresh Fare Christel's, a takeout shop at 311 East 92d Street, has an appealingly spare, scrubbed country look that fits happily with the style of the food served there - country-fresh, simple and beautifully prepared.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AEL Industries, Montgomeryville, Pa., which makes military electronic systems, has appointed Mark Ronald and George King senior vice presidents.

title: Chairman Sees Growth For Fleet Financial
description: J. Terrance Murray has been acting more like a shopper on a spending spree than a New England banker.

title: BILL MOYERS RETURNS TO CBS EVENING NEWS
description: After an absence of seven months, Bill Moyers has returned to ''The CBS Evening News With Dan Rather'' as its resident commentator. But at the same time, Mr. Moyers said in an interview, he has given up on prime time at CBS as an regular outlet for reporting on serious issues.

title: Yankees' Sheehy Dies
description: Pete Sheehy, the clubhouse attendant who spanned seven decades with the Yankees, died tonight at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

title: STRIKE OF 4 BUS LINES DISRUPTS TRAVEL FOR THOUSANDS IN QUEENS AND BRONX
description: Nearly 150,000 riders in Queens and a corner of the Bronx scrambled for substitute transportation yesterday after drivers and mechanics went on strike against four private bus lines serving those areas.

title: FOLKLORE MIRRORS LIFE'S KEY THEMES
description: Most people find contemporary superstitions and popular beliefs quaint, and sometimes amusing. In Illinois, for example, driving around the house in low gear is said to cure a family member's illness. In North Carolina, if the first bird seen on New Year's morning is flying high there will be good health during the year. But to professional folklorists, these beliefs are no less than a window into the psyche and a revelation of national character.

title: WHEELS GO ROUND
description: Because Gerry Cooney cannot bring himself to train or fight any more, he has been twitted by a portion of the public and the press that had hailed him as a great white hope only a few years earlier. Then, he was living out the ''Rocky'' fantasy for others; now, he is a faintheart who doesn't want to pay the price, for others.

title: People
description: James V. McConnell Jr. has been named executive vice president and managing director of the New York office of Campbell-Ewald. He will also serve on the agency's board and executive committee.

title: PUBLIC PROJECTS: ARE THEY VIABLE IN THE CITY ANYMORE?
description: In his 158th press release of 1979, Mayor Koch announced that the city had chosen the Brooklyn Navy Yard and an undetermined location in the Bronx as the sites for the city's first two ''resource recovery plants.'' ''It is hoped,'' the release said, ''that the Navy Yard facility could be in operation by 1984, and that a facility in the Bronx could be also in operation by this date.'' But it did not work out that way. Now, a year after the plants were to have been open, the Board of Estimate is about to authorize the start of work on the project at the Navy Yard.

title: NEW YORK RALLY ASSAILS SOUTH AFRICA
description: Thousands of people carrying banners and flags and chanting slogans of freedom rallied yesterday at 42d Street and Second Avenue against South Africa and its policy of racial separation, then marched toward the South African consulate.

title: ARGENTINA'S LOST CHILDREN: SOME HAPPY ENDINGS
description: In March 1977 the police came and kidnapped the 16-month-old daughter of an Argentine couple while they were out. A month later, they took away their 4-month-old son.

title: WHERE IT ALL BEGAN: HISTORIC BILL SIGNED
description: On Aug. 14, 1935, Franklin D. Roosevelt signed the Social Security bill in the Cabinet Room of the White House. Following are excerpts from a dispatch from Washington published in the Aug. 15 editions of The New York Times:

title: MICROFRAME INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COGNITRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss including tax credits of $141,000 for the quarter and $173,000 for the 6 months.

title: Suit Settled By Datapoint
description: The Datapoint Corporation, the financially troubled computer company, said that it had agreed to pay a shareholder group $22.5 million, settling a class-action suit that charged the company with misstating revenues for seven quarters between 1980 and 1982.

title: FORWARD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: BRIDGE: RUBIN AND MAHAFFEY MEET IN FINAL OF SPINGOLD TEAMS
description: The final of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship began here this afternoon with teams led by Ron Rubin of Livingston, N.J., and Tom Mahaffey of St. Petersburg, Fla., in opposition.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 14, 1985
description: Companies

title: Penn Central's Next Move
description: THE Penn Central Corporation has been reshaping its operations ever since it emerged from bankruptcy proceedings in 1978, but analysts say the former railroad operator, now involved mostly in high technology and energy, may be on the final leg of its journey.

title: WASHINGTON REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Figures reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid July 12.

title: Coca-Cola Clothes
description: The Coca-Cola Company, which last week promised to try to fulfill the ''all-American'' promise in advertisements for its Coca-Cola clothes, said that it had decided with Murjani International Ltd., the manufacturer of the clothes, to accelerate production in the United States. Coca-Cola said the arrangement with Murjani was intended not to disrupt the apparel maker's existing relationships with its Far Eastern manufacturers.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $2,486,000. c-After an extraordinary credit of $2,679,000.

title: FEDERAL OFFICIALS QUESTION CREDIBILITY OF CARBIDE
description: Led by Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Senate minority leader, top Federal health and environmental officials flew here from Washington today and, after a tour of the Union Carbide Corporation plant, asserted that the company and the chemical industry generally had lost ''credibility.''

title: A Medical Building on West Side
description: IN 1981, the New York State Attorney General's office approved the first offering plan for a commercial condominium in New York City. Since then, most of those developed have been small conversions designed for lawyers, artists, architects or other professionals or business executives. Often, these conversions have been done in residential buildings that already included professional space.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY MARKING GOLDEN ANNIVERSARY
description: As they celebrate the 50th anniversary of Social Security this week, politicians, historians and economists say their biggest task is to halt the erosion of confidence in America's largest, most important and most successful social program.

title: ANDOVER CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We can never insure 100 percent of the population against 100 percent of the hazards and vicissitudes of life, but we have tried to frame a law which will give some measure of protection to the average citizen and to his family against the loss of a job and against poverty-ridden old age.'' -Franklin D. Roosevelt, signing the Social Security bill on Aug. 14, 1935. [B6:2.]

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $251,328 for the quarter and $3,050,046 for the year. c-Including net income from discontinued operations of $489,721 for the quarter and $627,977 for the year.

title: GAF Stake in Carbide
description: The GAF Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired slightly more than 5 percent of the outstanding shares of the Union Carbide Corporation, the chemical manufacturer whose stock has fallen over the past few months as the result of plant accidents in both Bhopal, India, and the United States.

title: Springsteen Gives $30,000 to Food Banks
description: In keeping with a tradition he started in other cities, the rock singer Bruce Springsteen contributed $10,000 to the Greater Chicago Food Depository, another $10,000 to its Milwaukee counterpart and $10,000 to the Steelworkers Union in Gary, Ind.

title: ROANOKE ELECTRIC STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Taking Off the Armor
description: Before the camera's invention it was harder for famous people to be seen naked by their fans than it is today. Consider King John. ''Bad King John,'' we call him today, because he was portrayed in the movie by Claude Rains and was mean to Errol Flynn playing Robin Hood.

title: Remarkable Skaters
description: A very special group will be in the audience at the matinee performance today by the John Curry Skaters in the Kennedy Center Opera House: a dozen children from the Tyler School for the Visually Impaired, fresh from the ice themselves. Under arrangements made by the National Committee, Arts with the Handicapped, the young people will come to the theater in midmorning, be fitted with skates and given instruction by the Curry troupe on the rink on stage. Then they will have a box lunch in the theater's green room before going to the matinee.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ON a recent trip to Italy, I dined exceedingly well in a small restaurant outside Siena at midday. The main dish consisted of thin-sliced white veal that had been cooked on one side in a hot skillet.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Cubs Lose Sanderson
description: Rick Sutcliffe, Dennis Eckersley, Steve Trout and Dick Ruthven were already out with injuries, and now Scott Sanderson, the Chicago Cubs' fifth starting pitcher, is gone. Sanderson suffered a sprained right knee while pitching to Tim Raines of the Montreal Expos in the second inning of the Cubs' 4-1 loss yesterday in Chicago. Dr. Jacob Suker told Jim Frey, the Cubs' manager, that X-rays had revealed a tear in a ligament and that Sanderson's knee would be immobilized for two days and re-examined Friday. But Frey said it appeared Sanderson would be lost for at least four weeks.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Aug. 2, of Dr. Julia B. Robinson, a mathematician, misstated her age. She was 65.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: A BALLET EXPERIMENT ENDS ITS FIRST SEASON
description: A choreographer is at work with two young dancers in a small studio in Carlisle, Pa. The three work to taped piano music, oblivious to the summer heat and to a row of onlookers. The dancers are among the 25 advanced students and new professionals selected to participate in the Carlisle Project, an innovative exploration of training for the classical ballet. The choreographer is Bonnie Scheibman, one of 10 choreographers from around the country chosen to take part in this workshop - the final event of the yearly project, which ended Sunday and will resume in September.

title: 52 Killed in Collapse Of Building in India
description: A crowded building in a slum collapsed early today as residents slept, killing at least 52 people and injuring 56, the police reported.

title: PRICES OF DEBT SECURITIES FALL
description: Prices of debt securities fell modestly yesterday as securities dealers sought to attract buyers for recently auctioned, but still unsold Treasury issues.

title: FOR SURVIVORS AND KIN, JOY AMID SORROW
description: After surviving a jumbo jet crash into a mountain and a night stranded in the wreckage among more than 500 dead, Keiko Kawakami, 12 years old, just wanted to know where her parents were.

title: Puget Sound Pact
description: The Puget Sound Bancorp said it agreed definitively to merge with the Savings Bank of Puget Sound in a transaction valued at about $125 million. Under the agreement, each share of Savings Bank of Puget Sound would be exchanged for $22.50 worth of Puget Sound Bancorp common stock. After the merger, Savings Bank of Puget Sound would operate as a subsidiary of Bancorp.

title: POPE APOLOGIZES TO AFRICANS FOR SLAVERY
description: Pope John Paul II today apologized to black Africa for the involvement of white Christians in the slave trade.

title: This Teacher Shortage Was Predictable
description: Why is New York City suddenly hustling to hire 4,200 teachers before the opening of schools on Sept. 9? Reasons are complex, but on one point the Koch administration and the teachers' union bear heavy responsibility: They have dallied for a year in contract negotiations.

title: THORATEC LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Article 188892 -- No Title
description: The General Motors Corporation said that it would spend $1.2 billion to modernize stamping plants in Ohio and Indiana.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Northern Indiana Mortgage Bonds
description: The Northern Indiana Public Service Company is offering today $170 million of 12 percent first mortgage bonds due in 2015 at a price of 99 3/4, to yield 12.03 percent to maturity.

title: Market Place;   Atlantic City: A Full House?
description: AT first glance, the gambling industry in Atlantic City appears to be doing well, with gross revenues at record levels last month and the prospects for improvement bright. But to Wall Street, it is down on its luck, the victim of overexpansion that could cause a shakeout of less sturdy competitors.

title: BUSINESSES' JUNE SALES SLID 2.1%
description: Sales by businesses plunged 2.1 percent in June, the second biggest decline on record, as unsold inventories continued to pile up and give further evidence of a weak economy.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRUCE, ROBERT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income There are no year-ago share earnings because the company went public in November 1984.

title: HERS
description: MY EARLIEST memory pertaining to ethics, and my first ethical mentor, date to kindergarten and to a ritual we had at the school water fountain called ''frontsies and backsies.''

title: Jury Picked for 2d Trial Of San Diego Mayor
description: A jury of eight women and four men was sworn in today for the second perjury and conspiracy trial of Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego, who faces removal from office if convicted of any of the charges.

title: LEUCADIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $1,343,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $1,570,000 for the quarter and $3,639,000 for the 6 months and losses from discontinued operations of $646,000 for the quarter and $970,000 for the 6 months.

title: COMMUNITY GARDEN EXPERTS: TENDING THE GREEN CITY LOTS
description: EVERY summer, it happens all over New York. Where there was rubble and shattered glass in an empty lot, suddenly there are apple trees, herbs and a bed of flowers. Where there was a mound of trash, rows of lettuce, tomatoes and peppers spring up. New community gardens appear, but they do not appear spontaneously. Would-be neighborhood gardeners must organize a community group, find a plot, lease it, clear it, improve the soil, plant it and maintain it.

title: REAGAN AIDES MAP REPEAL OF RULES ON BIAS IN HIRING
description: The White House staff has drafted an executive order repealing requirements that Federal contractors set numerical goals to remedy possible job discrimination.

title: STUDENT'S SPATIAL SKILLS DECLINE
description: A HOUSEWIFE unpacks a new set of dishes and fits them into the narrow cabinets of her galley kitchen. Across the hall, her neighbor, an architect, has spent the weekend building free standing closets in his apartment. He judges the height and width by eye and corrects the proportions as he goes along.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 15, 1985
description: International

title: More Heroes
description: Same spot. Similar crisis. Different heroes.

title: WRATHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes income from discontinued operations of $13,000 for the quarter and $154,000 for the 6 months; gains on disposal of discontinued segments of $4,143,000 and $3,633,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and extraordinary tax credits of $1,986,000 for the quarter and $2,546,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $566,000 for the quarter and $904,000 for the 6 months.

title: Technology;   'Hearing' Tools About to Break
description: HOW do you know if your robot is in trouble? A human operator can see immediately when a drill bit or milling tool breaks and can shut the machine down to replace it. But in an automated factory, designed to operate around the clock with minimal human tending, unexpected breakage can cause a serious problem.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A PROPERLY constructed fence should last for many years without needing repairs, but a poorly built one may soon have posts leaning and rails sagging, creating an eyesore in addition to a possible hazard.

title: College Player Kills Himself
description: Brian Hiemer, a senior tight end on the University of Nebraska football team, died today from a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the head, authorities said.

title: FUR VAULT INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
CRS SIRRINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WITH BASES LOADED, TABLER IS THE BEST
description: When the bases are loaded, the man you want pitching is probably Dwight Gooden, the strikeout master of the big leagues, who is shooting for his 13th straight victory this afternoon in Shea Stadium. And when the bases are loaded, the man you want hitting is indisputably Pat Tabler of the Cleveland Indians.

title: Of Clemency
description: Since taking office, President Reagan has commuted the sentences of 13 people who had been in prison for violations of Federal laws. One was a boyhood friend of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India, Adil Shahryar, who was serving 35 years for setting off a firebomb, fraud and other violations in Florida. Mr. Reagan signed the clemency papers June 11, the day Mr. Gandhi arrived in Washington for a visit with the President.

title: SOVEREIGN DON WINS AGAIN
description: Nobody likes Sovereign Don, but the colt keeps on winning. Despite being dismissed by bettors and handicappers and belittled by his handlers, the 2-year-old today won his third consecutive graded stakes, hanging on to win by a neck from Roy in the $90,000 Sanford Stakes at Saratoga Race Track.

title: DYNAMICS' BRIEF STAY IN PENTAGON'S DOGHOUSE
description: Of all the disputed military contract charges the General Dynamics Corporation has grappled with, perhaps the most politically embarrassing case involved a dog named Fursten.

title: CRAIN'S FOLDS ITS COMPETITOR
description: New York City Business, the one-and-a-half-year-old publication that has chronicled the ups and downs of doing business in New York, has discovered first-hand how competitive a market the city can be.

title: Texan Wins Reprieve Minutes Before Death
description: Jay Kelly Pinkerton, a 23-year-old man ordered to die for raping and killing a woman, won a temporary stay of execution early today minutes before he was to be put to death by injection.

title: MOROCCO TRIES TO FOIL REBELS WITH 1,550-MILE WALL OF SAND
description: Within about 10 days, Morocco will finish building a huge wall of sand and electronic sensors that is revolutionizing antiguerrilla tactics, according to senior Moroccan military officers.

title: NO SUBJECT TOO TRIVIAL FOR A 'HOW-TO' BOOK
description: TREKKING through the wasteland of the publishers' fall catalogues - well, some of the pages of some of the catalogues - I have found myself thinking more than once of Dwight Macdonald and of James Thomson the Younger. Dwight Macdonald, because of a delightful essay he wrote some 30 years ago called ''How-Toism'' (it can be found in his collection ''Against the American Grain''), in which he cast a critical eye over the phenomenon of books that tell you how to win friends and how to boil an egg, books on posture (''Sitting Pretty'') and books on deportment (''Your Carriage, Madam!''), books that show you how to master all the various arts of the Good Life and of gracious living.

title: DOMINION TEXTILE LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: WILLIAMS ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $2,679,000 for the quarter and $6,311,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $7,048,000.

title: Floods Kill 4 in Ethiopia
description: Floods killed four people and left 7,000 homeless in Ethiopia this week, an official of the Government's relief agency said today.

title: Denmark Plans to Sell Its Debt Paper Directly
description: Denmark and Merrill Lynch Money Markets Inc. are expected to announce today a financing program making Denmark the first foreign country to sell debt directly in the domestic commercial paper market.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: WALLACE STEVENS. A Mythology of Self. By Milton J. Bates. 319 pages. University of California Press. $24.95.

title: KOCH ANNOUNCES NEW REGULATIONS ON USE OF WATER
description: Mayor Koch yesterday stepped up the campaign to conserve New York City's dwindling water supply, announcing new enforcement measures and ordering the installation of water-restricting shower fixtures in more than two million apartments, hotel rooms, hospital rooms and offices.

title: CARDIFF EQUITIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $759,000 for the quarter and $989,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $292,000 for the quarter and $440,000 for the 6 months.

title: When the Trash Can't Be Buried
description: Today the New York City Board of Estimate takes up the City Planning Commission's unanimous recommendation to approve a high-temperature incinerator, to be built in the former Brooklyn Navy Yard. There is not enough room in New York City to continue burying 20,000 tons of solid waste a day, nor time to dally further with mythical alternatives.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: PARK AVENUE OPERA These well-known songs - ''Wanting You,'' ''Softly, as in a Morning Sunrise,'' ''Stout-Hearted Men'' and ''Lover, Come Back to Me'' - have at least two things in common: They were written by Sigmund Romberg (1887-1951) and were in the score of his light opera ''New Moon.'' Set in the Caribbean during the French Revolution, ''New Moon'' is based on the life of an 18th-century French aristocrat and the story includes romance, adventure and a struggle for freedom.

title: TRADING SLOW
description: Stock prices managed a small gain yesterday in continued light trading.

title: A STUDY OF NEW YORK CATHOLICISM
description: THE Catholic Archdiocese of New York may be the most interesting institution in New York; certainly it is one of the more enduring. Mayors, whole neighborhoods and professional sports teams come and go; the chancery on Madison Avenue stays on forever. WCBS-TV examines the Archdiocese in ''Beyond the Altar: The Catholic Church in New York,'' a one-hour report on Channel 2 at 10 o'clock tonight. It is respectful but not obsequious, and even if it tells you things you already know, it does so in an intelligent way.

title: Maryland Cargo Loss
description: The Maryland Port Administration will give shippers $4.1 million in subsidies and price cuts and has started an advertising campaign to recapture cargo business lost to Hampton Roads, Va., and other ports. The package could reduce the agency's operating profits by almost 25 percent, but the port administrator, W. Gregory Halpin, said that continuing diversion of cargo from Baltimore into Hampton Roads ''represents a loss of over $20 million to the economy of the state of Maryland.''

title: More Drug Tests
description: Arizona State has become the latest school to require drug tests for student athletes.

title: Bauer and Longo Win Coors Legs
description: Steve Bauer, a 1984 Olympic silver medalist, pulled away with five laps to go today and won the 47-mile Estes Park Circuit Race, part of the Coors International Bicycle Classic.

title: Advertising;   Coke Held Not to Be Real Thing
description: THE Sugar Association, an industry group primarily responsible for scientific research, information and education, struck out at the Coca-Cola Company yesterday with advertising that links the company's reduced use of sugar from 1979 to 1984 to the declining market share of regular Coca-Cola. (It is this decline, hastened by the introduction of Diet Coke in 1982, that analysts say led to the replacement of the product with new Coke in April.) In advertising created by North Castle Partners Inc. of Greenwich, Conn., the association is spending one-tenth of its $2.5 million budget over two days. Full-page advertisements in 13 major newspapers show a chart illustrating the loss of market share of regular Coke.

title: STORMS OF CHANGE
description: Private traders sell food and clothes and household goods in hundreds of street markets around the city. Billboards on the main avenues advertised G.E., Xerox, Sony. A leading publishing house has issued Chinese translations of Plato, Sir Thomas More, Ricardo, Schopenhauer and Freud - ''An Introduction to Psychoanalysis.''

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: GROCERY-BAG ART
description: Grocery-Bag Art Competition, International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street; 212-536-6787.

title: Met Streak Ends at 9 As 9th-Inning Rally Fails
description: Their hitting, in general, was meager. Their clutch hitting, particularly by Keith Hernandez, was nonexistent. For the Mets, this all translated into a 2-1 loss to the Philadelphia Phillies last night at Shea Stadium, putting an end to their nine-game victory streak.

title: CHICAGO PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $778,000 for the quarter and $13,967,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $3,500,000 for the quarter and $7,900,000 for the 6 months.

title: Mexican Mission Blast Kills 2 Guatemalans
description: A hand grenade exploded inside the grounds of the Mexican Embassy today, killing two Guatemalan employees who were working in the yard, officials said.

title: GUY MCRAE MINARD, HEADED KIMBERLY-CLARK COMPANY, 78
description: Guy McRae Minard, a former chairman of the Kimberly-Clark Corporation, one of the largest paper products companies in the nation, died of cancer Tuesday at the North York General Hospital in Toronto. He was 78 years old and lived in Toronto.

title: Suit Filed Against Montgomery Ward
description: The owners of 10 Montgomery Ward & Company catalogue stores have filed a $8.25 million suit over the company's decision to drop its catalogue business.

title: STAGE: A MUSICAL SENDUP, 'TALES OF TINSELTOWN'
description: OLD Hollywood musicals get a send up in ''Tales of Tinseltown,'' an ambitious new musical by Paul Katz and Michael Colby playing at the Musical Theater Works as part of the Summer Directors Festival '85, but they don't get sent very high. A girl leaves her farm to seek stardom and hitches a ride to Hollywood with a youth who wants to be a screenwriter. He comes to despair and she to degradation before they leave Hollywood seeking love and reality in New York. This play might be subtitled ''Saved by Sin,'' but it is not that sophisticated; although there is some delicious satire, sentiment blunts its bite.

title: Midway Jets Sale
description: Midway Airlines said today that it had completed the $35 million sale of three former Air Florida jets, concluding its long-awaited acquisition of the debt-ridden airline.

title: LANDMARK LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: WILSON BROTHERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Jays Win on Stieb's 4-Hitter
description: Dave Stieb pitched a four-hitter, and Jesse Barfield scored twice and drove in two runs as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Texas Rangers tonight, 4-1.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Who Cares What Agca Says?
description: What began in May as ''the trial of the century'' is recessing in August as a farce by Pirandello -with eight more months to go. Having persuaded an Italian magistrate that Bulgarians hired him to murder the Pope, Mehmet Ali Agca has made a buffoon of himself. To the dismay of those who believed him, he has claimed divinity, promised to perform miracles and offered conflicting accounts of his assassination attempt. ''If he wanted to destroy his own credibility,'' fumed the Italian prosecutor, ''he has succeeded magnificently.''

title: DOCTOR CHASES SUSPECTED ROBBER AND SHOOTS HIM
description: A 66-year-old podiatrist shot and wounded a man who had assaulted and robbed him in his East Side office Tuesday night, the police said yesterday.

title: DURHAM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $4,385,000 for the quarter and $5,958,000 for the 6 months. c-After a capital loss of $93,000 for the quarter and a capital gain of $878,000 for the 6 months.

title: Speaking Out
description: Andrea Jaeger woke up yesterday and couldn't believe what she did Tuesday night at courtside during the United Jersey Bank Classic in Mahwah, N.J., the last major women's tune-up before the United States Open. ''I guess I do some crazy things,'' she says.

title: WHAT'S OFF SCHOOL BOOKSHELVES
description: If Holden Caulfield, Anne Frank, Romeo and Juliet, and Huckleberry Finn were all bound together for an instant in the pages of the same book, what would they say to one another?

title: Hair, Cut
description: On a bus recently, trying to determine the gender of a young person sitting opposite, we suddenly realized that it had been a long time since we'd seen any hair. At least not the hair that was celebrated in the musical and movie of that name.

title: TEXSCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Manville Closing
description: The Manville Corporation said today that it would close its plant in the central New Jersey town that took its name from the company.

title: CHILI'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Accountability for All
description: To the Editor:

title: UNITED STATES MEDICAL ENTERPRISE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BLACK MUSICIANS MEET IN MICHIGAN
description: William Warfield's life was shaped by the music lessons he took as a child in a public school in Rochester. Knowing that he wanted to be a singer, he signed up for the school's foreign language classes, too.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., a subsidiary of the American Express Co., has named G. Richard Thoman president of its international division.

title: New York, Then and Now
description: All I know is just what I read in the papers, or what I see for myself as I travel hither and yon. I'm back in New York, that city of skyscrapers where they endeavor to make the height of their buildings keep pace with their prices.

title: UCCEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,145,000 for the quarter and $1,945,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $375,000 for the quarter and $535,000 for the 6 months.

title: Dial-a-Phenomenon
description: The Smithsonian Institution is also getting ready for an expected surge of calls on its Dial-a-Phenomenon line as Halley's Comet comes into view. Mary Combs, a Smithsonian spokesman, said the number, (202) 357-2000, had been getting 4,000 to 5,000 calls a month, with recent calls spurred not by the comet but by the Pleiades summer meteor shower, which is showing off quite a bit this week.

title: Chinese Deal Held Up
description: The United States is holding up a French company's sale to China of an advanced communications system that it fears could be used for military purposes, industry sources said today. The dispute centers on the sale of a sophisticated switching system for use in Peking and Shanghai.

title: CORRECTION OFFICERS ROLE AS GUIDES IGNITES DISPUTE
description: A simmering dispute between the City Correction Commissioner and the president of the correction officers union has flared over the Commissioner's use of the officers as guides and guards at a national convention of correction officials here.

title: MR STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $230,000 for the quarter and $421,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $453,000 for the quarter and $375,000 for the 9 months and an extraordinary gain of $1,000 for the quarter.

title: Jokes No Problem for Giant
description: Conrad Goode, currently the starting center for the Giants, has an answer for his fellow offensive linemen when they kid him about the possibility of the team's acquiring Bart Oates, the center for the United States Football League's Baltimore Stars.

title: AREA IN QUEENS IS CLEARED OUT IN TOXIC THREAT
description: A fire yesterday at a Queens plant containing various cyanide compounds forced the evacuation of homes in surrounding blocks and injured 11 firefighters, officials said.

title: A Bridge's Story
description: Most plaques that have been tacked up to the Brooklyn Bridge over the decades are of the self-commemorative type, put up by those who - understandably - would like to be linked with that venerable crossing.

description: The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange.

title: KANSAS CITY SERENADES JAZZ HERITAGE
description: Jazz in Kansas City may not be what Kansas City jazz used to be, but, with a series of celebrations scheduled in the next few weeks, it is alive and thriving.

title: AUTO HAULERS AND INDUSTRY REACH TENTATIVE AGREEMENT
description: A tentative agreement was reached today on a new contract that would end a 19-day strike by 21,000 automobile haulers who drive trucks that take new cars to dealers from factories or ports.

title: Dr. Albert Christy Santy, 80; Treated Performing Artists
description: Dr. Albert Christy Santy, an internist who played a key role in forming the Health Care Institute for Performing Artists, died Saturday at his home on the East Side. He was 80 years old.

title: Sailor Is Guilty of Conspiring To Sell Secret Data From Ship
description: A Navy man was convicted today by a Federal District Court jury of theft and conspiracy for stealing top secret cryptographic cards from the U.S.S. Peoria.

NAIL-STUDDED CAR BOMB KILLS 12
description: A car packed with nail-studded TNT exploded in a fireball today outside an apartment complex in East Beirut, the Christian area of the city. At least 12 people were killed and 120 wounded.

description: b-Net income

title: Moore to Fight
description: Davey Moore, the Bronx boxer who has fought only three times since he lost his World Boxing Association junior-lightweight title on an eighth-round knockout by Roberto Duran on June 16, 1983, will challenge Carlos Santos of Puerto Rico for Santos's International Boxing Federation junior-lightweight crown on Aug. 31 in San Juan, P.R. . . . The World Boxing Association bantamweight champion, Richie Sandoval, has signed to fight Mexico's Jose Gallegos in a 10-round nontitle fight Aug. 24 in Phoenix.

title: India in Accord With Assam Activists
description: Leaders of a six-year campaign in the northeastern state of Assam in which thousands have died have reached an accord with the Indian Government on most issues, negotiators said tonight.

title: TELEPHONE & DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $347,000 for the quarter and $603,000 for the 6 months.

title: VIOLENCE AND APARTHEID
description: The images this weekend linger. Black South Africans tear down the former home of Mohandas K. Gandhi outside Durban systematically, seeing a shrine of peace as no more than a source of free building material. A day later, a black crowd incinerates a fellow black depicted as a sellout.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Traded Matt Kofler, quarterback, to the Indianapolis Colts for an undisclosed future draft choice.

title: JUPITER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Royal Exhibition
description: It is more than three months off, but the forthcoming exhibition of art from private British houses is already starting to jam the telephone lines at the National Gallery of Art.

title: Injured Fan Loses
description: Back in 1978, when she was 11 years old, Karen Friedman was standing behind the first-base dugout in the Astrodome during a game between the Astros and the Pittsburgh Pirates when she was hit by a line drive that broke a facial bone and left her with permanently impaired vision. Last month, a jury hearing a damage suit stemming from the incident found that the owners of the Astros had been negligent in not warning Miss Friedman of the danger of foul balls and awarded her $180,000.

title: The Unheroic Truth About John Peter Zenger
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Aide Joins Raytheon
description: Lawrence J. Korb, the Pentagon's overseer of the all-volunteer force, is resigning to become vice president for corporate operations at the Raytheon Corporation, the nation's ninth-largest defense contractor, the Pentagon said today.

title: AMERICAN BAKERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $754,000 for the quarter and $1,456,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $832,000 for the quarter and $1,507,000 for the 6 months. Results for the latest periods include operations from Cotton's and Coast-to-Coast which were acquired in the first quarter of 1985. Results for the year-ago periods include operations of Langendorf which was sold in the fourth quarter of 1984.

title: FIXING SECRET DRAWERS
description: SECRET drawers and hidden recesses in furniture probably date from the mid-17th century, when the skills of the cabinetmaker over his predecessors were most marked. But it was during the following century, when cabinet work became more elaborate, that makers used their imagination and skills to a greater extent.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mario Andretti, who suffered a broken collarbone and a hairline hip fracture in a crash July 28, has been given medical clearance to drive in this weekend's Pocono 500. . . . The two-time National Collegiate Athletic Association 200-meter track champion, Kirk Baptiste, has decided to bypass his final season of eligibility at the University of Houston. Baptiste, who earned a silver medal in the 200 at the 1984 Olympics, will compete for Athletics West Track Club.

title: COOL PLASTIC GRIP FOR A TEAKETTLE
description: IT'S KNOWN around his office as the ''Tea Bird,'' because of the little red bird on the spout of Michael Graves's new teakettle for Alessi, the Italian housewares manufacturer. ''The bird makes sense,'' Mr. Graves, a Princeton-based architect, said, ''because the kettle tweets when the water boils.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL VOTES TO BAR BIAS AGAINST PEOPLE WITH AIDS
description: The City Council today unanimously approved an ordinance protecting victims of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, from discrimination in jobs, housing and health care.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day on Monday with an article about second-quarter sales and profits misstated Johnson & Johnson's earnings increase. It was 30 percent, over the 1984 quarter.

title: BOGERT OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GORBACHEV OFFER IS DISPUTED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration, responding to a halt in nuclear testing by the Soviet Union, insisted today that the moratorium was being imposed at a time of Soviet nuclear advantage.

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MILITARY NEARS ACCORD ON AIDS BLOOD TESTS
description: The Pentagon reached a tentative agreement today with civilian blood agencies that will require them to notify military physicians if tests indicate that blood donated by military personnel contains an antibody associated with AIDS.

title: BEAR, STEARNS PLANNING TO GO PUBLIC
description: Bear, Stearns & Company, a Wall Street maverick that is one of the few remaining large brokerage partnerships, has decided to make its first public offering of stock and debt securities, Alan C. Greenberg, its chief executive, said yesterday.

title: ALTOS COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,594,000 for the quarter and $2,897,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,031,000 for the quarter and $5,009,000 for the 6 months.

title: Carbide Leak Puts Chief Of Safer in Limelight
description: As head of a small company that sells services to an industry of giants, C. Gary Gelinas says he has always tried to keep a low profile. But events beyond his control put his company, Safer Emergency Systems Inc., in the news this week anyway.

title: A Hero
description: Sudden circumstances of life and death can make sudden heroes. Take Willie Tyler, for example. He does not know how to swim, but he rescued a young woman from the Harlem River.

title: Jartran Write-off
description: Frank B. Hall & Company, the big insurance brokerage, said that a write-off for its investment in Jartran is expected to be between $50 million and $75 million. Hall had previously announced that it had planned to dispose of Jartran, a truck rental company in which it has a $98 million investment. It said that it was considering various methods of disposition but that there could be no assurance it will be able to dispose of Jartran as a going concern.

title: DRESSER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOR '45 INVASION FORCE ON GUAM, A JOYOUS REPRIEVE
description: The writer of this dispatch was a correspondent in Guam for The New York Times at the time of the Japanese surrender in 1945.

title: CHEMICAL INDUSTRY BRACES FOR TOUGHER REGULATION
description: The leak of a toxic chemical from a Union Carbide plant in Institute, W.Va., coming after a number of less serious but widely publicized accidents across the country, has sent an alarm through the chemical industry.

title: E & B MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. SEEKING TO DETERMINE IF SPY HAD GREATER ROLE THAN THOUGHT
description: Although Arthur J. Walker has been found guilty of spying for the Soviet Union, Federal officials say they are continuing to investigate whether his espionage activities were more widespread than he has acknowledged.

title: WALKER TELECOMMUNICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Cable Agency Planning Major Radio Campaign
description: The Council for Cable Information, the industry organization that promotes cable television, will announce a $750,000 network radio campaign today. The spots will feature Lisa Birnbach, author of ''The Official Preppy Handbook.''

title: A BIRTHDAY PARTY AT HYDE PARK FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr., whose father signed the Social Security bill into law 50 years ago, and Robert F. Wagner Jr., whose grandfather sponsored it, joined hundreds of people who benefited from it at a nostalgic ceremony here today.

title: USLIFE INCOME FUND INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: The net income represents net investment income. USLIFE had a net realized gain from security transactions of $627,776, or 12 cents a share, for 1985, compared to $126,506, or 3 cents a share, for 1984.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $68,183,000 and an extraordinary charge of $9,947,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,613,000.

title: Refco's President Outlines Overhaul
description: Refco Inc., one of the world's largest futures brokerage organizations, said yesterday that it was restructuring its six client-service groups into a new company, Refco Group Ltd., with $1 billion in assets and more than $100 million in capital.

title: Dr. Walter Langsam, Former College Head
description: Dr. Walter C. Langsam, a historian who was former president of the University of Cincinnati and Wagner College on Staten Island, died today after a long illness. He was 79 years old.

title: Insurers Face Big Losses in Rash of Jet Crashes
description: The crash of a Japan Air Lines Boeing 747 jumbo jet on Monday - following two other airline disasters in the last two months - will result in severe 1985 underwriting losses for the international aviation insurance industry, according to American aviation insurance experts who estimate that such losses may have already exceeded $150 million.

title: RISE OF JACK LANG, A SUPERSTAR OF FRENCH CULTURE
description: Jack Lang, the French Minister of Culture, who caused a stir some time ago by talking about American cultural ''imperialism,'' was in Brittany the other day to advance a new cause, French-Breton bilingualism, and his reception was of the sort accorded movie stars and matinee idols.

title: Flyers Sign Five
description: The Philadelphia Flyers have signed five veterans, including the center Ron Sutter, who emerged last season as one of the National Hockey League's best defensive forwards. The Flyers also signed Sutter's twin brother, Rich, the defensemen Ed Hospodar and Brad Marsh and the forward Ray Allison, as well as two rookies, Dave McClay and John Stevens.

title: Why 30% (but Not 40%) Mayors?
description: Judicial overkill: Federal Judge Charles Brieant has held that New York City's runoff primary election violates both the Constitution and the law. He finds that the State Legislature created the runoff in 1972 for the unconstitutional purpose of defeating racial and ethnic minorities, and he rules that those minorities suffer politically in violation of the Voting Rights Act.

title: SALE PLAN FOR CONTROL DATA UNIT
description: The Control Data Corporation said yesterday that it was seeking to sell a majority share of its supercomputer manufacturing unit in what analysts called an apparent effort to stem a deepening financial crisis at the company.

title: Park of Peace
description: A tiny sliver of a park across the street from the United Nations is becoming the most commemorative quarter-acre in New York City.

title: State Names Director Of Cash Management
description: Maryanne Gridley, former senior legislative budget analyst for the New York State Senate Finance Committee, has been named director of cash and debt management, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan announced.

title: HURCO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
description: b-Net loss.

title: New AC&R Account
description: AC&R Advertising, a member of Ted Bates Worldwide, has been assigned all the advertising, direct marketing and public relations for the Advertising Checking Bureau. The account was previously handled by Cramer-Krasselt in Chicago, and the billings are estimated at $1 million. The bureau supplies ad checking copies from every United States newspaper and several magazines.

title: Shriver, Sukova Advance
description: Pam Shriver, Helena Sukova and Steffi Graf advanced to the quarterfinals of the $150,000 United Jersey Bank Tennis Classic at Ramapo College with straight-set victories today.

title: C.D. Rates Move Up
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit continued to move higher for the week ended yesterday. But rates on money market mutual funds and bank money market accounts again showed almost no movement.

title: TELECOM PLUS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Marietta Contract
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation's aerospace unit is being awarded a $260 million contract for work on the MX missile program, the Air Force said.

title: Pollution Bonds For Kansas Utility
description: Burlington, Kan., is offering $79.5 million of adjustable-rate pollution control revenue bonds on behalf of the Kansas Gas and Electric Company, through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: SOTHEBY'S SETTLEMENT IS APPROVED BY JUDGE
description: A judge in Manhattan yesterday approved a settlement between the State Attorney General and Sotheby's involving a disputed 1984 auction of rare Hebrew books and manuscripts. Under the agreement, the most valuable works will be recalled from the buyers and redistributed to institutions where they will be made available to the public.

title: Poor Ol' Justice
description: ''Well, Steve,'' Attorney General Ed Meese told an interlocutor on ''Good Morning America'' the other day, ''I'm afraid this is one case where poor ol' Bill Safire didn't know what he was talking about.''

title: NEW YORKERS SUFFER AS THE MERCURY HITS 94
description: After a mild beginning, summer descended on New York with a steamy vengeance yesterday, wilting man and beast alike on the hottest day of the year.

title: GAF Filing On Carbide
description: The GAF Corporation, in confirming yesterday that it had bought a 5.6 percent stake in the Union Carbide Corporation, described the purchases of shares as an ''investment position.'' GAF added that it was considering a number of options, ''including the possibility of a business combination'' between the companies, which are competitors in the chemical industry, In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, GAF said that it had not yet determined whether to pursue such an arrangement.

title: Judge Speeds Bhopal Case
description: A Federal judge yesterday speeded the schedule for legal arguments on whether claims against the Union Carbide Corporation over the gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, should be heard in the United States or in India.

title: UNITED COMPANIES FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect the 2-for- 1 common stock split paid April 1, 1985.

title: Pakistan Tells of Plan To End Martial Law
description: Prime Minister Mohammed Khan Junejo said today that martial law in Pakistan would be lifted after eight years and democracy completely restored within five months.

title: Meese Praises Mexico For Anti-Drug Efforts
description: The United States Attorney General, Edwin Meese 3d, praised Mexico's cooperation today in efforts to stem international drug trafficking and insure the safety of American tourists here. But he said there was ''still a long way to go.''

title: MORE FRAGMENTS OF JAPANESE AIRLINER FOUND AT SEA
description: Japanese authorities investigating the crash of a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet on Monday found new fragments of the vertical tail and of an air-conditioning duct floating Wednesday in waters far from where the plane went down.

title: HEADING FOR THE HILLS: TODAY'S BERKSHIRE SETTLERS
description: TO LIVE in the Berkshires year round is a common summer daydream of many city dwellers. For four couples, such daydreams developed into winter planning and, eventually, spring construction at four sites: a brick and marble carriage house, a horse barn dominating a pastoral view, a Shaker forge dating to the 1840's, and a spot underneath a grass-covered knoll known mostly to deer and woodchucks.

title: Coupling Break Brings Spill Of Water at Three Mile Island
description: Three thousand gallons of low-level radioactive water spilled today inside the reactor containment building at Three Mile Island's damaged Unit 2, a spokesman said.

title: MARTIN'S DECISION STIRS STEINBRENNER
description: Despite a vow that there would be workouts until the team is in first place, Manager Billy Martin has decided to give the second-place Yankees the day off Thursday.

title: BIG PRIZES ON THE LINE
description: From Aug. 24 to Sept. 2, thousands of fishermen will be taking part in the Empire State-Lake Ontario King Salmon Derby, an affair that this year offers more than $116,000 in cash and merchandise prizes.

title: PETE SHEEHY, YANKEE
description: Whenever somebody would poke his head into the Yankee clubhouse and make sounds about redecorating, Pete Sheehy would not let him touch the rugged oak table in the center of the room.

title: MANHATTAN BOROUGH PRESIDENT RACE: STYLES CLASH
description: There are few sharp differences on issues among the three candidates for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Borough President, and so in many ways they find themselves arguing about the different styles of leadership they offer.

title: ALFRED HAYES, 74, A NOVELIST, POET AND SCREENPLAY WRITER
description: Alfred Hayes, an American poet, novelist and screenwriter who made a major contribution to Italian neo-realistic films after World War II and whose best-known novel, ''The Girl on the Via Flaminia,'' also became a play and movie, died of meningitis yesterday at Sherman Oaks (Calif.) Community Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived with his family in Encino, Calif., writing only poetry.

title: U.S. AIDE AND JORDAN IN TALKS
description: A United States official discussed a Middle East peace plan today with King Hussein and top Jordanian officials, the Jordanian press agency said. The agency said the Jordanians had insisted on peace talks that would include the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Three in Rhode Island Indicted Over Mortgages
description: The former head of a state housing agency was charged today with 20 felony counts, including 15 for embezzlement, in an indictment that also named a past Rhode Island House Speaker and a bank officer.

title: AMBULANCES, UNDER A NEW POLICY, PICK UP ONLY EMERGENCY PATIENTS
description: Ambulance crews, acting under a new city policy and with the guidance of doctors, yesterday began refusing to pick up people not judged to be emergency cases.

title: IN A TREND TO PAINTED FURNITURE NEW COLORS, PATTERNS EMERGE
description: FOR most of the 20th century, mass-produced furniture was a matter of industrial production done in the fewest steps possible. Seldom did the brush of an artist touch the surfaces. Beautiful form may have been a design objective, but the form was left unadorned.

title: G.O.P. SEEKS SUN BELT GAIN IN '86 VOTING
description: The 1986 elections are shaping up as a major test of the Republican Party's long-term strategy for gaining political dominance in key Sun Belt states.

description: In the cerebral aerie of Cambridge, where Graham T. Allison spends most of his work week as dean of Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, one hears little good said about Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: WOOLWORTH, F W CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ASPEN FESTIVAL HEAD REGAINS AUTHORITY AFTER 6-YEAR BATTLE
description: The Aspen Music Festival and School, now in their 36th year, convey a unique aura of mellowness and familial contentment in the cause of music. But just beneath the surface lie impassioned battles of principle and personality. On Tuesday a six-year battle between the president and dean, Gordon Hardy, and the board of directors came to a climax with the reassertion of Mr. Hardy's authority and the resignation of the bulk of the board leadership.

title: OFFICER TOLD GRAND JURY STEWART WAS COMBATIVE
description: One of the six transit police officers on trial in the death of Michael Stewart told a grand jury last year that the 25-year-old prisoner was ''bucking, kicking and scratching'' with such fervor that she assumed he was an ''emotionally disturbed person.''

description: b-Net loss.

title: Freddie Mac Issue
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, sold $150 million of 15-year mortgage participation certificatese at an average price of 99 21/32, to yield 10.78 percent. The certificatse are offered at various prices through securities firms. The certificates, which are a kind of mortgage pass-through security, are backed by a pool of 15-year fixed-rate home mortgages.

description: Sticks and stones may break his bones, but when it comes to verbal assaults on his softer tissue, words merely egg Terry Forster on.

title: HANOI HANDS OVER REMAINS OF DEAD
description: The Government today turned over what may be the remains of 26 Americans missing in the Vietnam War. It also indicated acceptance of a proposed visit by senior United States officials later this month to resolve the entire issue of the missing in action.

description: Treasury note and bond prices rose modestly yesterday, reversing most of the declines of the previous two days, as traders were encouraged by fresh statistics showing a weak economy.

description: More than 1,100 people, most with impressive academic credentials, have qualified for an innovative New Jersey program that allows them to become public school teachers without first taking undergraduate courses in education.

description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. said today that it would reduce its stake in its South African subsidiary to about 40.4 percent, from 50.4 percent. The subsidiary, Barclays National Bank Ltd., is the largest bank in South Africa and protesters in Britain against South Africa's racial policies have demanded that Barclays sell its holding.

description: ''A water rat is a cheat. A water rat turns a deaf ear to a tenant who asks that a dripping faucet be repaired.

title: Patrick Hines, Actor On Broadway, Was 55
description: Patrick Hines, an actor who appeared in dozens of plays, ranging from Shakespeare to musicals, died of a heart attack Monday in his Manhattan apartment. He was 55 years old.

AUTOMOBILE RACER PUTS SAFETY FIRST
description: Back in the early 1970's, when Tom Sneva was a part-time racer and a full-time high school mathematics teacher and bus driver at Sprague High School, outside Spokane, Wash., he helped his brothers solve a problem.

title: YANKS GET 4 IN 9TH TO BEAT WHITE SOX
description: The game seemed won and lost so many times tonight that even Billy Martin, the Yankee manager, marveled at the twists and turns.

title: ISAAC'S STORMY F.D.I.C. REIGN
description: In his five and a half years as chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, William M. Isaac has been put through the wringer.

description: b-Including realized investment gains of $4,227,000 for the quarter and $5,646,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss including a realized investment gain of $632,000. d-Including a realized investment gain of $116,000.

title: POINTS TO CONSIDER IN CHOOSING A PET
description: MAKE of it what you will: companion, member of the family, child substitute, guardian or status symbol. But a pet is also a responsibility - and sometimes a burden.

title: Clinton Hill History Honored
description: Brooklyn's Clinton Hill neighborhood, a stretch of tree-lined streets and well-kept homes, has been placed on the State and National Registers of Historic Places, state officials said Tuesday. Clinton Hill has one of New York's largest concentrations of row houses from the post-Civil War period.

title: SAUL, B F REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of property of $677,000 for the quarter and $5,544,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes a gain of $136,000 on the sale of property.

description: b-After net losses of $606,000 for the quarter and $527,000 for the 6 months from equity in unconsolidated subsidiaries. c-Net income d-Including net income of $1,003,000 for the quarter and $1,677,000 for the 6 months from equity in unconsolidated subsidiaries.

title: BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $48,065,000 for the quarter and $70,354,000 for the 6 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $21,670,000 for the quarter and $43,116,000 for the 6 months.

title: CARVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Meatpackers at Hormel Plant Vote for Strike on Saturday
description: Union meatpackers at Geo. A. Hormel & Company overwhelmingly rejected the company's final offer today and said they would stage the plant's first strike in 52 years at 12:01 A.M. Saturday.

title: Bridge: The Mahaffey Team Scores Upset in the Spingold Final
description: A last-ditch surge in the early hours yesterday morning gave an upset victory in the Spingold Knockout Team Championship to a team headed by Tom Mahaffey of St. Petersburg, Fla.

title: THE MANY INCARNATIONS OF SHEPARD'S 'CURSE'
description: Kathy Bates had everything arranged. She gave up a precious lease on a Manhattan apartment. She put her furniture into storage. She bought a plane ticket to California so that she and her boyfriend, who lives out West, could ''give up this bicoastal stuff.''

title: The U.S. Response
description: The Soviet Embassy took out a large advertisement in The New York Times earlier this week to criticize the United States for, in the Russian view, hindering the Geneva arms talks, so a State Department spokesman, Charles Redman, was asked at the daily press briefing if there was any American response.

title: Head of Asia Division Named by Doyle Dane
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach Group has announced that its Asia division, which it said has been ''suffering from benign neglect,'' will be headed by Alan R. Pilkington, the executive vice president and director of business development at D'Arcy MacManus Masius Worldwide.

title: Trade Group Posts Study
description: The ballooning trade deficit has halved economic growth over the last year and could trigger another recession with ''destabilizing'' consequences for the global economy in the assessment of the nation's 13,000 manufacturers.

title: BUILT HOTEL AND RESTAURANT CHAIN
description: J. Willard Marriott, who transformed a tiny root beer stand in Washington into the Marriott Corporation, a $3 billion lodging and food service empire, died Tuesday night, apparently of a heart attack, at Huggins Hospital in Wolfeboro, N.H., near his summer residence. He was 84 years old and lived in Washington.

title: EDISON BROTHERS STORES INC reports earnings for 10 wks to June 29
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $2,600,000 for the quarter and $5,300,000 for the 6 months. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $1,400,000 for the quarter and $1,000,000 for the 6 months and a nonrecurring net gain of $1,900,000 for the 6 months from the sale of real estate.

title: New Subway Cars Withdrawn To Remove a Derailment Risk
description: The Transit Authority said yesterday that it had withdrawn 40 Canadian-made subway cars from service on the IRT No. 1 line because of failure to remove a coupling device that caused a risk of derailment on curves.

title: Yeutter Urges Japan to Act
description: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, told Japan's Foreign Minister, Shintaro Abe, today that it was not too late to halt growing protectionist sentiment in the United States, a Foreign Ministry official said.

title: TRW Unit Gets Contract
description: A unit of TRW Inc. has been selected to design a communications network for the Defense Department that would handle intelligence and command and control message traffic.

title: MONARCH CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $127,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: PILOT TO TOWER: 'IMMEDIATE, AH TROUBLE'
description: Following are excerpts from conversations Monday between Japan Air Lines Flight 123 and air controllers at two locations in and around Tokyo, as made public by the Transport Ministry, and excerpts from a communication between the plane and J.A.L. officials over an internal company radio frequency, as made public by the airline. The pilot and the air controllers spoke in both English and Japanese, which was translated by The New York Times.

title: SERVICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January.

title: AUG. 1-10 CAR SALES FELL 10.1%
description: New-car sales fell 10.1 percent in the August 1-10 period, the major American automobile manufacturers said here today. At the same time, light truck sales increased by 11.2 percent, compared with the same period in 1984.

title: QUEENS BUS STRIKE IS CALLED OFF AS UNION GAINS A TENTATIVE PACT
description: Striking drivers and mechanics reached a tentative settlement with four Queens bus lines last night, ending a strike that began Tuesday and affected 150,000 daily riders on express and local buses in Queens and the Bronx.

title: JOHN PAUL URGES SELF-RELIANCE
description: Pope John Paul II today visited the people of this impoverished country in the heart of Africa and told them not to expect miracles.

title: GLASSMAKERS USE NEW TECHNIQUES
description: GLASS is a challenging craft medium, requiring years of training, meticulous planning - and usually a costly studio. Since new technology allows lower temperatures and smaller furnaces, glass artists no longer need to go into a factory to produce.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Detroit yesterday on car telephones incorrectly described the Nassau County Police Department's enforcement policy. The department says it will stop a motorist using a car phone only if the vehicle is being operated improperly.

title: STORAGE EQUITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Warning on Textiles
description: A visiting American Congressman said today that the United States wanted to expand trade with India but might have to cut textile imports because of a slump in the industry in the United States. Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, said the United States might be forced to cut textile imports from India by 15 percent next year. He is the head of a nine-member delegation visiting India to discuss trade ties.

title: BEKER INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a net gain of $1,300,000 from an insurance claim settlement.

title: TOM BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: HARPER'S WINS RIGHTS TO REPRINT 'THE LOVER'
description: Harper & Row, taking another step toward establishing itself as a major publisher of paperback books, won the reprint rights Tuesday to Marguerite Duras's best-selling novel, ''The Lover,'' for $155,000.

title: WEST VIRGINIA TO TRACK HEALTH OF 135 IN FUMES
description: The West Virginia Health Department will conduct a long-term study of the health of all 135 people sent to hospitals Sunday by a leak of toxic gas at the Union Carbide Corporation's plant at Institute, W.Va.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 15, 1985
description: The Economy

title: DAMON CREATIONS INX reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
Fenway Failings
description: For a right-handed power hitter who has slugged 24 homers this season, Steve Balboni of the Kansas City Royals is a regular pussycat at Fenway Park, where friends and relatives from Brockton, Mass., his hometown, often come to see him play. The 6-foot-3-inch, 225-pound first baseman has not been able to take advantage of the usually friendly left field wall (which is truly a Green Monster to him) in three part-time seasons with the Yankees and nearly two complete years with Kansas City.

title: THREE MORE ARE KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICAN VIOLENCE
description: Three people were killed in separate incidents today as the worst wave of racial violence in this nation in recent history continued in scattered townships. The new strife came on the eve of what is expected to be a major policy statement on apartheid by President P. W. Botha.

title: INQUIRY IS SOUGHT ON AID TO REBELS
description: Common Cause, the Washington-based lobbying group, called today for Congressional investigations of the National Security Council's involvement with the Nicaraguan rebels over the last year.

description: b-After a nonrecurring pretax charge of $3,700,000. c-Net income.

title: A DEVELOPER IN PALM BEACH WHOSE OBSESSION IS LUXURY
description: MICHAEL BURROWS displays his obsessions like the eclectic works of modern art that cover his office walls and the interiors of the multimillion-dollar homes he builds in Palm Beach.

title: PETER RATHVON Jr.
description: Peter Rathvon Jr., the secretary and general counsel of Associated Universities Inc., the nonprofit organization that operates Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island, died of a massive cerebral hemorrhage last Friday while visiting Kiev in the Soviet Union.

title: METAL DOORSTOPS IN ANIMAL SHAPES
description: DOORSTOPS can be both functional and decorative. The Hog Wild! catalogue carries two doorstops in the shape of a pig. One, of heavy black wrought iron, measures 9 1/2 by 6 1/2 inches and sells for $25; the other, of concrete, costs $30.

title: STAGE: DOUG SKINNER IN COMIC MODE
description: IN the course of his new show, ''An Attractive Production,''

description: Oil companies offered the Federal Government $391.1 million today in high bids for mineral leases on 210 tracts off the Texas coast.

description: b-Net income

title: BRIEFS
description: * BASF A.G., Ludwigshafen, Germany, said it would produce about 2,000 cubic meters of chimney gas-collecting catalyzers in a new plant starting in 1987 under license from Japan's Mitsubishi Petrochemical Co.

title: CURBING WEEDS IN GARDEN
description: MOST gardens are won or lost during midsummer, when weeds thrive and wills wane. Given enough time, any weed-control task can be performed manually. But if time is a problem, consider a modified chemical approach.

title: 240 Union Carbide Workers Face Layoff at Georgia Plant
description: Officials at Union Carbide's Woodbine plant say 240 workers may be laid off until an investigation is completed into the cause of Sunday's gas leak at the company's plant at Institute, W. Va.

title: MICROSEMI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Help Latins Trade Away Debt
description: The Latin debt crisis will not be solved, or even significantly ameliorated, without help from United States trade policy. President Reagan will have an opportunity to administer such help this month, as he decides whether to approve the International Trade Commission's recommendation to restrict shoe imports from Brazil. The Administration should stick to its free-trade guns -or risk disastrous implications for Latin America's financial stability.

title: CENTURI INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $301,000 for the quarter and $749,000 for the 6 months.c-After a loss of $30,887 for the quarter and a net of $889,463 for the 6 months from discontinued operations, tax credits of $163,800 for the quarter and $526,000 for the 6 months and a loss of $1,399,039 for the 6 months on retirement of convertible debts.

title: MILTON CRANE
description: Milton Crane, a professor of English and a literary critic, died of pneumonia Monday at a nursing home in Washington, where he had resided for the last 10 years.

title: HURRICANE IN GULF STIRS EVACUATIONS
description: Hurricane Danny, with winds of up to 75 miles an hour, churned across the Gulf of Mexico toward the Louisiana coast tonight and the National Hurricane Center in Miami issued hurricane warnings from Freeport, Tex., to the Mississippi River in Louisiana. The storm forced 20,000 workers off oil rigs in the Gulf of Mexico and sent thousands of coastal residents fleeing inland to safety, the authorities said.

title: INVACARE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Net income.

title: AMERICAN MEDICAL BUILDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NASSAU CORRECTION COMMISSIONER SAYS POLITICS WASN'T A JOB FACTOR
description: Nassau County's Correction Commissioner testified today that he had never hired or dismissed anyone on the basis of whether they had contributed to the Republican Party.
