description: b-Including net gains of $12,000 for the quarter and $3,000 for the 6 months from operations to be disposed of. c-Including pretax gains on the sale of real estate of $538,000 for the quarter and $2,403,000 for the 6 months, net income of $2,000 for the quarter and net loss of $11,000 for the 6 months from operations to be disposed of.

title: MINNESOTA INQUIRY HEARS PROSECUTOR
description: Days before she abruptly dropped charges that 21 residents had sexually abused children in the small Minnesota town of Jordan last fall, the prosecutor still believed she could proceed on the basis of largely uncorroborated allegations made by young children, according to her testimony at a hearing today.

title: Westinghouse Loses Its Case
description: A Federal judge today ordered the Westinghouse Electric Corporation to obey a Pentagon subpoena and surrender internal documents sought by auditors in a search for waste and fraud among military contractors.

title: WESCO FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After gains on the sale of securities of $2,964,000 for the quarter and $3,057,000 for the 6 months. c-After a gain on the sale of securities of $6,942,000 for the quarter and the 6 months.

title: Approval Sought For Solar Panels
description: The Southern Company, an electric utility holding company, is seeking Federal permission to form an investment subsidiary that plans to form a joint venture to make and sell solar panels that produce electricity. Southern's president, Edward L. Addison, said yesterday that the joint $7.2 million effort would mark the first involvement by an American utility in the manufacturing of photovoltaic panels, which convert sunlight directly into electricity.

title: Israeli Military to Try General in Arab Deaths
description: An army general will be tried before a military disciplinary court on two counts of unjustified use of violence for participation in the beating deaths of two Arabs who hijacked a Israeli civilian bus, a military spokesman said today. The procedure is a milder one than a court-martial.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch July 31 about a hearing before a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on press coverage of the Trans World Airlines hijacking in June misstated testimony by Ben H. Bagdikian, dean of the School of Journalism of the University of California at Berkeley. Mr. Bagdikian said that he did not know if the Pentagon had told the press about a preparatory military move in the T.W.A. hijacking, but that in some previous incidents officials had leaked information to the press for strategic reasons and the press was later unfairly criticized. He urged the subcommittee to determine if this was the case in the T.W.A. hijacking before assuming irresponsibility on the part of the press.

title: Pro Football;   Dorsett Accepts Contract
description: Tony Dorsett ended his holdout today when he agreed to a new five-year contract with the Dallas Cowboys, the team president Tex Schramm announced.

title: TERMINAL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CONTENTION OVER CBS'S 'WEST 57TH'
description: Don Hewitt, executive producer of ''60 Minutes,'' the network's highly rated, 17-year-old weekly magazine, recently placed two signs in the elevator at CBS News headquarters on West 57th Street to mark the premiere Tuesday of the network's other weekly magazine, ''West 57th.''

title: CHARGES ON DONATIONS MADE IN MAYORAL RACE
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday accused Mayor Koch of immorality, charging that he had tailored his policies to please wealthy real-estate contributors. The Mayor, in turn, held an angry, nearly hourlong news conference at which he defended his policies and accused Miss Bellamy of engaging in ''vile techniques.''

title: CAMP LETS ADULTS PLAY ASTRONAUT
description: Eight women and 23 men spent a recent weekend lost in space together here at a 50-acre space playground for adults. They were united as weekend astronauts in a session at the United States Space Camp.

title: DOCUTEL-OLIVETTI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Commodore Sees Loss for 4th Period
description: Commodore International Ltd. said yesterday that it expects a loss of about $80 million for its fourth quarter ended June 30, largely because of inventory write-downs.

title: COURT IN POPE CASE QUESTIONS A TURK IN GERMANY
description: Members of an Italian court trying eight men accused of conspiring to murder Pope John Paul II questioned a right-wing Turk today about information he says he received that the purported plot was arranged by the Bulgarian secret service.

title: Clergymen Assert Abduction In Nicaragua Wasn't Staged
description: A group of religious leaders denied today at a news conference here that American activists had staged an abduction by supposed Nicaraguan insurgents.

title: CARTOONIST COMBS THE CAPITAL TO DO IT JUSTICE
description: Who is the real Congressman Bob Forehead? Washingtonians have long speculated about the prototype for this fictional lawmaker, star of the comic strip ''Washingtoon,'' who hits the big time this week in a live-action television series.

title: $200 Million Issue For Houston Light
description: The Brazos River Authority, Texas, is offering $200 million of pollution control revenue bonds on behalf of the Houston Light and Power Company, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: WARM CARBONATED DRINKS NO HIT ON SPACE MISSION
description: Neither Coca-Cola nor Pepsi-Cola came out a winner with the Challenger astronauts who tested carbonated beverages in orbit for the first time, the crew said today.

title: DEFENSE ASKS DISMISSAL OF TULANE CASE
description: A defense attorney for John Williams, the former Tulane University basketball star who is on trial in a case involving point shaving, filed a motion in State Criminal Court tonight asking the judge to dismiss the case on grounds of prosecutorial misconduct.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Philadelphia Phillies, at Shea Stadium, 1:35 P.M. In the finale of a seven-game home stand, Dwight Gooden tries to gain his 19th victory and match St. Louis's Joaquin Andujar. (Television - SportsChannel, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN, 1050; 1:30 P.M.). Dodgers vs. Atlanta Braves, at Los Angeles. (Television - WTBS, 5:05 P.M.). Golf Ladies P.G.A. MasterCard International Pro-Am, at Knollwood Country Club, Elmsford, N.Y., and Westchester Hills Golf Club, White Plains, N.Y., 9:30 A.M. The official opening round has been moved to tomorrow. Today's play will be in a scramble format at both Knollwood, situated off exit 4 of the Cross Westchester Expressway, and Westchester Hills, situated off exit 8. $200,000 Nestle World Championship of Women's Golf, at Buford, Ga., opening round. Nancy Lopez is back to defend her title at the new home of this invitation event in the style of the men's World Series of Golf. A dozen women will compete. Buick Open, at Grand Blanc, Mich., opening round. Michelob Long Island Golf Classic, at Bethpage State Park, 9 A.M. Second and final day of amateur stroke play tournament. Tennis Women's United Jersey Bank Classic, at Ramapo College, Mahwah, N.J., 10 A.M. and 7 P.M. Player's Challenge Canadian Open, at Montreal (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. to 11 P.M.). Westchester World Invitational, at Rye Town Hilton, Rye Brook, N.Y., 1 and 6:30 P.M. Second-day opponents in the round-robin tournament are Robert Green vs. Mel Purcell and Wojtek Fibak vs.

title: Dutt to Receive $775,000 Bonus
description: The Beatrice Companies have agreed to pay James L. Dutt, who resigned under pressure Aug. 3 as the company's chairman, $775,000 in addition to compensation due under existing employment contracts, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: People
description: * William J. McDonough Jr. has been promoted to senior vice president, group management director at Foote, Cone & Belding/New York.

title: T.W.A. Talks See No Results
description: Advisers for Trans World Airlines and the Texas Air Corporation met yesterday but did not reach an agreement on proposals made by Texas Air that could make it difficult for Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, to take control of T.W.A.

title: ARGENTINE TRIAL HEARS LAST WITNESS
description: The first part of the public trial of nine former military rulers ended today, after a dramatic 16-week airing of the most painful period in Argentine history.

title: A DELIVERYMAN IS KILLED TRYING TO KEEP TRUCK
description: A bakery deliveryman who clung to the side of his speeding truck for seven blocks in a desperate attempt to stop a man who was stealing it was killed early yesterday when the vehicle crashed in Times Square.

title: CAMBELL RED LAKE MINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Between Guilt and Innocence
description: Whence comes Scotland's unique criminal verdict of Not Proven? During a recent trip to Scotland, an interest in law and lineage sent me off on a search for answers.

VOLUME UP SLIGHTLY
description: The stock market closed narrowly mixed yesterday as investors continued to assay the course of interest rates and the economy. Trading accelerated slightly.

title: APPROVAL IS GIVEN FOR INCINERATOR AT BROOKLYN SITE
description: The Board of Estimate, rejecting the last-minute appeals of neighborhood residents, gave final city approval yesterday for construction of a garbage-burning incinerator at the old Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: SCREEN: 'VOLUNTEERS'
description: Take a healthy helping of ''Raiders of the Lost Ark,'' a dollop of ''The Bridge on the River Kwai,'' a dash of any Tarzan movie, a soupcon of ''Casablanca,'' a whiff of ''The Wizard of Oz'' and a stunt or two from a favorite Saturday serial, stir frenetically, and if you're lucky enough to have snappy dialogue by Ken Levine and David Isaacs, you may end up with as funny a movie as ''Volunteers.''

title: New Shelling in Beirut Kills 10 and Hurts 45
description: Lebanese gunmen battered Beirut with a barrage of rocket, mortar and tank fire today, killing 10 people, hitting the presidential palace in Baabda, a Christian suburb, and forcing thousands of people into bomb shelters.

It is the first time Mr. Shaw, who led one of the most popular bands of the Swing Era, has been in a New York jazz club since his quintet left the Embers on 52d Street in 1954.

description: A man once accused by the Justice Department of concealing his wartime membership in the Waffen SS was critically injured early yesterday when a pipe bomb exploded at his home in Paterson, N.J.

description: The Seuffert Band will celebrate its 87th anniversary with a free concert Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Music Grove of Forest Park, off Woodhaven Boulevard and Forest Park Drive, Queens. The program is to include the pianist Gary Steigerwald in Gershwin's ''Rhapsody in Blue,'' plus other music by Eric Coates, Wagner, Dvorak, Herbert L. Clarke, Bucalossi and Sousa.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN PRESIDENT'S SPEECH FAULTED BY MEMBERS OF CONGRESS
description: The pointed refusal by President P. W. Botha of South Africa to propose any specific political changes while making his speech in Durban today was seen by several members of Congress as a disappointment that would only harden the movement to impose economic sanctions on South Africa.

title: Ethics According to General Dynamics
description: When the Navy announced this week that it had lifted a ban on contracting with the General Dynamics Corporation, it said the company had ''developed a comprehensive ethics program that will apply to all employees.'' Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. ordered such a program May 21 when he disciplined the multibillion-dollar arms merchant for ''a pervasive corporate attitude that we find inappropriate to the public trust.''

title: Pharoah at Sweet Basil
description: Pharoah Sanders, a powerful, compelling saxaphonist who ranges effortlessly from ballads to blues to African high-life rhythms, is at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, tonight through Sunday. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M. and Sunday at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M. There is a $10 cover and $6 minimum. Information: 242-1785.

title: MISTRIAL DECLARED FOR EX-TULANE STAR
description: Defense lawyers who earlier refused to ask for a mistrial for John Williams, the former Tulane basketball star, changed their minds today, asked for a mistrial and got it.

title: 'BAR ESPERANZA'
description: ''BAR ESPERANZA,'' the 1983 Brazilian film that opens today at the Public Theater, means to be a sophisticated comedy about a lively group of Rio de Janeiro artists and bohemians who hang out at Dona Esperanza's remarkably tolerant drinking establishment.

IT'S TIME TO CROSS SOME BRIDGES: A GUIDE TO 4 PROMINENT PROMENADES
description: UNTIL a few weeks ago, New Yorkers with a passion for walking across bridges had reason to feel unwelcome. They saw new crossings built without pedestrian paths and old walkways lost to vandalism, neglect or the automobile.

title: GANDHI ANNOUNCES ACCORD IN DISPUTE OVER IMMIGRATION
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, declaring that India had overcome another threat to national unity, today announced the settlement of a bitter dispute that has led to thousands of deaths in the northeastern state of Assam.

title: FILM: 'YEAR OF DRAGON,' CIMINO IN CHINATOWN
description: MICHAEL CIMINO has a distinctive way of making things look and sound, but he could never be accused of having a style. If style is a director's way of shaping and intensifying his audience's perceptions, then what Mr. Cimino has amounts to its very antithesis. In ''Year of the Dragon,'' a busy and elaborate film that manages to be inordinately messy, his tactics are a constant distraction, dissipating the viewer's interest at every turn. That, even more than excess, was the fundamental problem with ''Heaven's Gate,'' and it is still every bit as egregious. It is no pleasure to report that Mr. Cimino's reputation as the man who best exemplifies what can go wrong with big-ego, big-budget film making remains unchallenged.

description: The Virgin Atlantic Challenger, a powerboat trying to beat the trans-Atlantic speed record of the liner United States, filled with water and sank just below the surface in stormy weather today only hours from the British lighthouse that marked the end of her 2,850-mile course.

title: TWO ABANDONED BLACKS ARE RENEWED IN HARLEM
description: There is a bittersweet tone in Wilfred George Gooden's remarks as he walks along Amsterdam Avenue to the corner of 144th Street in Harlem. In the rich cadences of his Jamaican accent, still strong after 40 years in New York City, he speaks with pride about this block and how it has been transformed over the last decade from a row of abandoned and burned-out shells to a vibrant residential strip with stores at street level.

title: NO TOXIC RESIDUE FOUND ON PRODUCE
description: Laboratory tests have so far found no evidence of toxicity in the garden fruits and vegetables of residents whose property was in the path of a toxic gas leak Sunday, the director of the West Virginia Health Department said tonight.

The Phoenix-based corporation is a frequent issuer of such obligations, which it assembles from a group of home builders who are its owners.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike McGee, the Los Angeles guard who averaged 10.2 points a game last season, has signed a multiyear contract, the Lakers announced. . . . Barry Bonnell, a utility player for the Seattle Mariners, was placed on the 15-day disabled list after suffering a torn muscle in his left calf during a game against the California Angels Wednesday night. . . . Benny Anders, a forward on the University of Houston basketball team, was sentenced to three years' probation after pleading no contest to a charge of possessing a firearm on school property in connection with an incident last May in which he pointed a gun at a student he said had thrown a starting block at him during an altercation in the school gym. . . . Arizona State will continue its search for a big-name basketball coach later on. But for the 1985-86 season, Steve Patterson, 37, will continue his duties as the school's interim coach, the school announced.

title:
ECONOMIC SCENE;

Policy Agenda For Farming
description: AGRICULTURE'S performance has continued to decline throughout the current business expansion. And unless changes are made in public policy, the outlook could be even more bleak.

description: The Minnesota Vikings obtained the National Football League rights to the wide receiver Anthony Carter from the Miami Dolphins yesterday for the linebacker Robin Sendlein and a 1986 second-round draft choice.

description: A Federal jury in South Carolina found yesterday that two former asbestos makers, the National Gypsum Company of Dallas and the United States Gypsum Company of Chicago, were not liable for the $284,000 cost of removing the product from five school buildings in Spartanburg, S.C., two years ago.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: ORDERING from a Chinese menu is like spending an hour in an enormous museum - to get the most from it you must instinctively whiz by the ordinary and zero in on the highlights. There is no formula for this skill; it just develops through experience. The strategy worked exceedingly well during visits to the Nice Restaurant, a new Chinatown establishment that, notwithstanding a couple of humdrum exhibits, has some real gems in its collection.

title: Goldcrest's Ex-chief Back at Film Concern
description: John D. Eberts, founder of Britain's Goldcrest Films and Television Ltd., has returned as chief executive after a two-year absence. His appointment, effective immediately, comes after management restructuring moves and cash flow problems at Goldcrest.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Washington dispatch July 24 about Vice President Bush's reflections on his role as Acting President during President Reagan's surgery included an incorrect report from the White House about the number of interviews he had given since the event. The Times's interview was Mr. Bush's third; he had also spoken with Michael Globetti of The Boston Herald and James Wieghart of the Scripps-Howard News Service.

description: The Jets' front office continues to go its own way. Other clubs rid themselves of coaches with losing seasons and keep the ones who win. With the Jets, a winning coach was allowed to resign after 1982, and a losing coach has now been given a boost of confidence.

Takeover Attempt

''I'm going to try to get the team,'' she said. Irsay's lawyers said they expected the court to rule that Irsay is the sole owner of the team and that it is not marital property subject to Mrs. Irsay's claim.

He and several of his teammates circulated among 450 Mets lovers, who had paid $100 to eat ribs, drink beer and mingle with players at Shea Stadium on Wednesday night before the game with the Phillies.

title: Accountants Queried

Meanwhile, an aide to the oversight and investigations subcommittee said the inquiry, which began in February and was to end this year, will now stretch ''well into next year.''

title: BROADWAY
description: THE trial of Dan White, who killed Mayor George R. Moscone of San Francisco and Supervisor Harvey Milk - the city's first avowed homosexual to hold high public office - is coming to Broadway. That is to say, Emily Mann's play about that riveting and polarizing 1979 trial, ''Execution of Justice,'' is scheduled to start rehearsals Jan. 7 and begin previews early in February at a theater still to be named.

title: Nicaraguan Rebel Fails In Bid to Head Group
description: The Miskito rebel leader Steadman Fagoth was forced to flee into Honduras from a rebel-held area in Nicaragua after he was unable to force the directors of the Misura Indian rebel organization to rename him as head of the group, a rebel spokesman said today.

title: H & H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Maleeva Loses in Default
description: Heat exhaustion forced third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria to withdraw midway through her third-round match, giving Iva Budorova of Czechoslovakia a 1-6, 6-3, 3-0 victory today in the $150,000 United Jersey Bank tournament at Ramapo College.

title: AMERICAN SURGERY CENTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: LATE hours continue to bubble along the Thames Street strip in Newport, R.I., particularly in the Black Pearl, the Ark and the Southern Cross, all vestiges of the America's Cup races two years ago. The Black Pearl was the hangout for American and Italian crews, the Ark was British territory and the Southern Cross was Australian turf. Drop in now and you'll find an emphasis on new American cuisine and an atmosphere less intense than before.

title: STAGE: 'BELLY OF BEAST'
description: THE prison letters of Jack Henry Abbott, published under the title, ''In the Belly of the Beast,'' gave a terrifying picture of a life lived almost entirely behind bars and in solitary confinement in maximum-security prisons. Abbott was a ''state-raised convict,'' who, from the age of 12 until he was released at 37, had spent only nine months out of institutions. Though Abbott's nightmare was not unique, it was demonic in its relentlessness - no light of charity was allowed to pierce the blackness of his incarceration. The book revealed a fervid self-taught mind, a literary sensibility and a deep paranoia.

title: SPEX GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'SUBURBAN BEAT,' AN NBC DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
description: ''SUBURBAN BEAT'' has possibilities. Think of the members of the A-Team as housewives. This is improbable (although no more improbable than the A-Team itself) but when a television program displays wit, then what's there to argue? ''Suburban Beat,'' an NBC ''development project,'' on Channel 4 at 10 o'clock tomorrow night, displays wit. On television, this is a valuable commodity.

title: Slain Zaire Nun Beatified
description: Pope John Paul II today beatified a Roman Catholic nun who chose to be killed rather than surrender her virginity. The nun, Marie Clementine Anwarite, demonstrated the ''primordial value accorded to virginity'' and an ''audacity worthy of martyrs,'' the Pope said. He said he forgave the man, a Col. Piere Colombe, who killed the nun during an incident in Zaire's civil war in 1964.

title: DIANA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $84,000. c-Net income including net from discontinued operations of $1,279,000.

title: ITT Payment Set
description: The Justice Department said that ITT Corporation had agreed to pay the Government $1.1 million for purported overcharges on Government contracts for communications and computer services. The department said the payment settles civil charges that ITT and its ITT Dialcom Inc. unit overcharged the Government by $680,000 from 1980 through 1983.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $5.3 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve announced a $5.3 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply yesterday, roughly twice as large as expected, The news stunned the credit markets. Although interest rates rose only modestly after the Fed's announcement, economists and traders expressed bewilderment over the combination this week of statistics showing a lackluster economy, but robust money supply growth for the week ended Aug. 5.

title: PATRICK PETROLEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses including income from discontinued operations of $1,405,615 for the quarter and $1,164,042 for the 6 months.

title: FOR HIGH VISIBILITY IN THE SUNSHINE
description: For many people summer began with a new pair of sunglasses.

title: Drexel Letter Sent On Turner Funds
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. yesterday issued a letter to Turner Broadcasting System saying it was ''highly confident'' that it could arrange the financing required for Turner's previously announced acquisition of the MGM/UA Entertainment Company. Turner will need about $1 billion to buy the company.

title: Paradyne Furlough
description: The Paradyne Corporation, a data communications equipment company, said that it would lay off all employees except field service engineers for six days without pay. The move is part of the company's continuing effort to reduce and control expenses during the current economic slowdown, it said. The furlough days are scheduled to be taken before the end of the year and will coincide with weekends and scheduled holidays.

title: SUSPECT IN SPY CASE FACED 'BREAKDOWN,' PSYCHIATRIC DATA SAY
description: Two years before Richard W. Miller was arrested on espionage charges, he was in danger of a ''real breakdown,'' his former supervisor in the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today.

title: INSTALLMENT DEBT RISES MODESTLY
description: Americans took on $6.79 billion more in installment debt than they paid off in June, the smallest gain since last November, the Government said today.

title: NASSAU WORKER DENIES SEEKING D'AMATO'S AID
description: A Hempstead sanitation worker who got a $300-a-year pay increase in 1971 after Alfonse M. D'Amato, then the town's Presiding Supervisor, made a $75 contribution on his behalf to the Republican Party, testified today that he had never directly asked Mr. D'Amato for help.

description: To the Editor:

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. The Yankees took three straight from the Red Sox last weekend in Fenway. (Television - Channel 11, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. The Mets begin a three-day trip before returning home for eight games against California teams. (Television -SportsChannel 7:35 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Padres vs. Atlanta Braves, at San Diego. (Television - WTBS, 10:05 P.M.) Golf $200,000 L.P.G.A. MasterCard International, at Knollwood Country Club, Elmsford and Westchester Hills Golf Club White Plains, off exits 4 and 8, respectively, of the Cross Westchester Expressway. Opening round, 8 A.M. Buick Open, at Grand Blanc, Mich., second round (Television - ESPN, 4 P.M., live.) Nestle World Championships of Women's Golf, at Buford, Ga. second round in invitation event for 12 leading women. Harness Racing The Meadowlands, 8 P.M. Sherman Almahurst, winner of all seven starts as a 2-year-old, is the 2-1 early favorite in the $1,344,000 Woodrow Wilson Pace. The Silverman entry of Michael Jonathan and Corner Stone is the 5-2 second choice. (Television - MSG Network, midnight.) Yonkers, 8 P.M. The $111,020 Bronx Filly Pace is the feature. The favorites are Semalu D'Amour, at 9-5, and Amneris at 3-1. Monticello, 7:30 P.M. Tennis Women's United Jersey Bank Classic, at Ramapo College, Mahwah, N.J., noon and 7 P.M. Quarterfinal round. In the third day of round-robin play, Bill Scanlon will play Wojtek Fibak; Gene Mayer will go against Miloslav Mecir and Barbara Potter will meet Melissa Gurney.

title: HURRICANE DROPS TORRENTIAL RAINS ON LOUISIANA
description: A hurricane with winds of 85 miles an hour sloshed across the swampy Louisiana coast today, unleashing tornadoes and torrential rain that forced the evacuation of up to 30,000 people.

title: 28 First Bank Units for Sale
description: First Bank System Inc., the Minneapolis-based bank holding company, said today that it planned to sell 28 of its regional banks in Minnesota, Montana and North and South Dakota. First Bank, the nation's 14th-largest banking concern, owns 78 banks and trust companies.

description: Shiva Naipaul, the Trinidad-born author and journalist, died of a heart attack Tuesday night in London, where he lived. He was 40 years old.

title: U.S. RESPONSE TO SPEECH IS GUARDED

description: W. H. Smith & Son Holdings P.L.C. said that it had agreed to acquire the Elson's group of companies in the United States for about $65 million.

title: SCREEN: 'RETURN OF THE LIVING DEAD'
description: ''THE RETURN OF THE LIVING DEAD'' is a movie that gleefully wants to go all the way in its depiction of voracious gore. Packed with sequences of famished zombies sinking their teeth into their victims' brains, it splatters the screen with images of rotting skeletons and twitching body parts.

title: Watchful Eye
description: With his program suffering from sanctions imposed in the wake of recruiting violations by alumni representatives, Vince Dooley, the Georgia football coach, has moved to keep boosters on a tight leash. Dooley, who is also the athletic director, said that about 120 boosters scheduled to attend a preseason seminar this weekend would be asked to sign an agreement that they will abide by National Collegiate Athletic Association rules. ''We have a responsibility to make sure they know what's right,'' said Dooley, who blamed unscrupulous boosters for the loss of seven of Georgia's 30 football scholarships for each of the next two seasons. . . . Korey Rasmussen, an expected starter in Brigham Young's defensive backfield, will miss the season because of a detached retina, Coach LaVell Edwards said.

title: OF BALLPARK FIGURES AND BALLPARK FIGURES
description: First, the forecasts. The Office of Management and Budget predicted it would win, 14 to 10. The Congressional Budget Office likewise predicted victory, 9 to 7.

title: Shapiro Takes Coors Race Stage
description: Doug Shapiro of Deer Park, L.I., won today's Golden-to-Boulder stage of the Coors International Bicycle Race, which was shortened by traffic problems in Boulder.

title: The White Prisoners of Apartheid
description: The architects of apartheid, South Africa's system of segregation and racial repression, are also its prisoners. Anyone who doubts that need only heed yesterday's long-awaited speech by President Botha of South Africa. Pressed at home and abroad for genuine change, the best he could offer was pitiful ''reforms'' unlikely to give even President Reagan plausible grounds for vetoing the mild sanctions Congress is likely to vote next month.

title: FATHER TAKES CHANCE ON SON IN WILSON
description: Twenty-year-old Richard Silverman has a good summer job: He races horses trained by his father.

She was 86 years old.

Whither This Lion in Late Summer?
description: Most of political Washington shuts down in August, but the California White House is full of fighting talk and confrontational threats of Presidential vetoes against Congress. This has left folks in Washington puzzled.

description: John A. Walker Jr. left a paper bag at a secluded Maryland site and waited for it to be retrieved by a ''contact,'' his lawyers said at a court hearing today.

GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday AFRICA IN BROOKLYN Gumboot, a South African dance that incorporates Zulu warrior movements with the motions of diamond miners, will be performed tonight by a troupe of dancers as part of the final weekend in Celebrate Brooklyn's dance series. The program, presented by Nana Dinizulu's African Dancers, Drummers and Singers, will also include a solo on a gome, a square drum played with the feet and hands. Morocco and the Casbah Dance Experience will also perform. Tomorrow, the festival will present Spanish dances by the American Spanish Dance Theater and the Spanish Dance Arts Company, and on Sunday Caribbean dances by Eyes and Rhythms. All performances are free and begin at 8 P.M. at the Prospect Park Bandshell, at Prospect Park West and Ninth Street in Brooklyn. Information: (718) 768-0699.

title: Tanzania's Ruling Party Picks a New Candidate
description: Tanzania's ruling party elected Vice President Ali Hassan Mwinyi today to succeed President Julius K. Nyerere, a leader of post-colonial Africa who is voluntarily stepping down after 24 years in power.

Cirella played in 66 games last season and had six goals and 18 assists.

title: Don't Duck on Federal Pay
description: The Federal commission appointed to recommend salary levels for the executive, legislative and judicial branches won't say what it thinks those levels should be. Though it finds high-ranking public servants ''critically underpaid,'' the commission focuses on a fundamental problem: the system for fixing salaries is unworkable and unconstitutional.

title: PAR PHARMACEUTICAL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Diner's Journal
description: THE gelati wave that has been washing over New York in the past year is still rolling along unimpeded as stylish new emporiums open all over town with neon lights, pastel walls and dozens of exotic flavors. The best gelati I have tasted, however, is not in one of these sporty new places but rather at an Italian delicatessen that was serving soft Italian ice cream long before it invaded the Upper West Side.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Corporate Earnings table in Business Day yesterday erroneously listed quarterly financial results for the Weldotron Corporation. The company's quarterly financial results have not been announced yet; the sales and earnings listed as Weldotron's were for the Wedtech Corporation.

title: The Republican Campaign
description: Preliminary, unofficial returns from ''Operation Open Door,'' the Republican campaign to persuade 100,000 Democrats in four states to defect, indicate that it is falling far short of its announced goals.

title: NEW RULES ON RADIOACTIVE WASTE
description: The Reagan Administration issued rules today governing the burial of high-level radioactive wastes. The rules are designed to keep the substances isolated from the public for at least 10,000 years.

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
America's Links to the Third World
description: Last year, when Dr Pepper cans showed up in Hattiesburg, Miss., with ''mysterious Middle Eastern'' writing on the lids, it was front-page news. Customers returned the cans unused. Before the nearby canning plant revealed that the cans were left over from a foreign export contract completed several years ago, rumors spread of a foreign plot.

title: Rizzuto Recovering
description: Phil Rizzuto, the former Yankee shortstop, was released from St. Luke's Hospital yesterday after undergoing a procedure designed to head off a heart attack.

title: Variety in AIDS Virus Hindrance to Vaccine
description: The virus suspected of causing acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, has so many variations in its genetic structure that developing a preventive vaccine may prove very difficult, if it can be done at all, researchers said today.

title: OPERA: MOZART'S 'MITRIDATE' IN CONCERT VERSION
description: THE Mostly Mozart Festival posed itself a difficult problem last night when it gave a concert version of one of Mozart's least known large-scale operas, ''Mitridate, Re di Ponto,'' a work he composed at age 14. ''Mitridate'' is a three-act opera seria in the most formal 18th-century style, with the usual royal despot who magnanimously relents and the tangled romantic plot typical of this genre. There is no way such a stylized work can be turned into a tongue-in-cheek parody without its essence being sacrificed. That, unfortunately, is what often happened in this otherwise welcome performance, which on the whole was beautifully sung but which had to bear the burden of a rib-poking narration that continually undermined the young composer's purposes.

title: HOMECOMING FOR SPRINGSTEEN
description: It was 3:30, a half-hour to go on the afternoon shift at the Nestle coffee factory in Freehold, N.J. - Bruce Springsteen's hometown - when one of the men on the line, a Yugoslav named Nikola Nikolic, started singing. The other workers picked it up, shouting Mr. Springsteen's anthem over the sound of the machinery: ''Born in the U.S.A. I was born in the U.S.A.'' It was the same song that one of those workers' wives, a 30-year-old schoolteacher named Pamela Kay, was begging to hear in the delivery room when she gave birth to her first child this summer. It was the same song that 18-year-old Brian Kaplan was listening to on his Walkman as he raced down West End Avenue in Manhattan on his 10-speed bicycle, headed for his job as a salesman at Tower Records.

title: MUSIC: SOLOISTS PERFORM MOZART
description: LINCOLN Center did not stint on soloists for the Mostly Mozart concerts presented at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday and Wednesday evenings. In a program given over entirely to Mozart - it was the same both times - Emanuel Ax played the Piano Concerto No. 17 in G, and Nadia Salerno-Sonnenberg the Violin Concerto No. 5 in A. Jorge Mester replaced the previously announced Peter Maag as conductor and took over a program that also included Four Entr'actes from the Incidental Music to ''Thamos, King of Egypt'' and the concluding Symphony No. 38 in D (''Prague'').

title: McCaw President Grew With Cable Company
description: Craig O. McCaw began his commmunications career in high school, selling subscriptions for his family's fledgling cable television company during summer vacation. Now, his closely held McCaw Communications Companies is a $100 million-a-year business, and still growing.

title: Concerts in the Bronx
description: The Bronx Arts Ensemble will present two free concerts of the same program of music by Handel and Bach Sunday afternoon in the Bronx. At 2 P.M. the group is to appear at the Van Cortlandt Mansion in Van Cortlandt Park, Broadway at 242d Street, and at 4 P.M. it is to perform in Keating Hall of the Bronx Rose Hill campus of Fordham University, at Southern Boulevard. Information: 549-1899.

title: A TEXAS AIR PROPOSAL ON T.W.A. FACES SNAG
description: A group of 24 United States and foreign airlines said yesterday that they would like to bid for the computer reservation system of Trans World Airlines if it is put up for sale. The move could complicate the Texas Air Corporation's efforts to prevent Carl C. Icahn from gaining control of T.W.A.

title: THE MOVERS ARE READY
description: It's a sad story currently buried in the fine print on the last line of a San Francisco Giants box score. On Tuesday, for instance, the box score revealed that the Giants had beaten the Houston Astros as Mike Krukow struck out 12 and hit a home run in his own behalf. But any enthusiasm that Krukow and his teammates shared must have been tempered by the feeling that no one cared. The box score from Candlestick Park read: A - 2,916.

title: U.S. AIDE MEETS WITH TOP ISRAELIS ON STALLED BID FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: Assistant Secretary of State Richard W. Murphy briefed Israeli leaders today on his discussions with King Hussein of Jordan. And Israeli officials said he indicated that efforts to get Middle East peace talks going remained deadlocked.

title: Are Books Like Bread?
description: The publishing industry, asserting that man does not live by bread alone, wants New York to exempt books, like food, from the sales tax. The proposal has bipartisan support in the State Legislature; the legislators would do well to think twice.

title: G.M. OFFERS 7.7% LOANS ON '85 LINE
description: The General Motors Corporation, which has been losing market share since late last year, said today that it would offer 7.7 percent financing on most of its 1985 cars and trucks.

But the rare event occurred yesterday when the Federal Reserve Board put out its monthly report on industrial production for July.

description: The Congressional Budget Office today credited Congress with making ''dramatic progress'' on cutting the budget for the fiscal year 1986 and projected a $175 billion deficit, in sharp contrast to Reagan Administration estimates of at least a $200 billion deficit.

Economic planners, in an annual Government white paper on the economy, said the country will be led into this era of information-related and service-oriented industries by the private sector.

title: Crescendo Of Tragedy
description: By coincidence, two meetings are now taking place that will mark a watershed for South Africa. One, in Durban, is the National Party conclave where President P.W. Botha announced new moves on race relations. The other, in Lusaka, Zambia, is the council of the African National Congress, which is planning its war strategy against apartheid.

title: A Swimmer With a Message
description: Next Tuesday - or maybe a day or so later if the weather does not initially cooperate - George Hauser will edge into the waters off Cap Gris Nez, France, and start splashing toward Dover, his second attempt in a year to swim the English Channel.

title: A Rare Chance for U.S. and Uganda
description: In the wake of the violent coup in Kampala last month, the conventional wisdom is that political instability and uncontrolled violence are to be expected for the indefinite future in Uganda, as in most of black Africa. Such thinking is overly simplistic and unfair. In the case of Uganda, it contributes to a self-fulfilling prophecy of failure and prevents the West from helping this neglected East African state regain its former promise.

Gallery of Science and Art on Madison Avenue at 56th Street offers a double-headed survey of American painting and drawing as it has existed since John Singleton Copley was active in Colonial times. The exhibitions in question are ''American Masters: The Thyssen-Bornemisza Collection'' and ''American Drawings and Watercolors From the Amherst College Collection.'' One of them gives great pleasure.

title: Army Eases Stand On Bell Contracts
description: Bell Helicopter, a unit of Textron Inc., has agreed to make improvements in its internal accounting system and as a result, the Army is modifying its freeze on monthly contract payments, Army officials said. Bell will now be eligible to receive full monthly progress payments on any contracts awarded after Aug. 8.

title: Soviet Activist Gets 3-Year Sentence
description: A Jewish activist who is a member of an unofficial peace group was sentenced today to three years at hard labor on a charge of ''malicious hooliganism,'' his wife said.

title: JOHN PAUL IN AFRICA: DARING TO PLAY THE CRITIC ABROAD
description: Pope John Paul II has made human rights a major theme of his papacy. During his African trip, he has brought that message to Governments that have jailed people for saying the same thing. In speech after speech, John Paul has taken leaders to task for corruption, exploitation of the poor and repression of political dissent. He has also criticized apartheid in South Africa and the indifference of the wealthy nations toward the poor on this continent.

description: Following are excerpts from President P. W. Botha's speech in Durban, South Africa, yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network:

title: CHINESE FIGURE PAINTING IS ON EXHIBIT AT THE MET
description: THE approach to the human figure in Western and in Chinese art is fundamentally different. In the West, the human figure has aroused immense curiosity and admiration. During the Renaissance, the elements, proportions and functioning of the human body seemed to hold the secrets to the universe. In Chinese art, on the other hand, there is almost no interest either in the structure and mechanics of the body, or in the idea of physical perfection, and human beings tend to remain mere dots in a purposeful, awesome but impersonal nature.

title: YOUTH TOASTS SUMMER AT SOUTH ST. SEAPORT
description: In the young and promising Wall Street career of Gary Jacobs it was Black Thursday. Two weeks into an E. F. Hutton training program, in the heat of stock-market trading, the fledgling floor clerk made a $3,000 error. Now he was drowning his sorrows with one of the specialties at the South Street Seaport, a blend of seven kinds of liquor with dashes of lemon juice and Coca-Cola.

Robin Weir, a hair-stylist for Nancy Reagan, is taking off tomorrow for the Orient, where he will spend 17 days in China demonstrating his expertise for Chinese students. title: Books of The Times;   His Generation
description: HORSE'S NECK. By Pete Townshend. 134 pages. Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. Pete Townshend, of course, is best known as the songwriter and lead guitarist for The Who - the primary author of the rock opera ''Tommy,'' and the author, too, of those much quoted lines, ''hope I die before I get old'' (which appeared on The Who album ''My Generation,'' some two decades ago). Over the years, Mr. Townshend has had something of a literary career as well: Besides owning a book shop called the Magic Bus, he ran a small press by the name of Eel Pie, and he currently serves as an associate editor at the British publishing house of Faber and Faber. In this, his first published volume of prose, he writes, each chapter ''deals with one aspect of my struggle to discover what beauty really is.''

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Larry Bird, the Boston Celtic star who was troubled by a sore elbow at the end of last season, apparently will not be undergoing surgery. Team officials told The Boston Herald that doctors had found no clear-cut problem that could be corrected by surgery and that Bird had been working out and shooting for several weeks with no problems. . . . William H. Sullivan Jr. confirmed that his family had engaged an investment bank ''to explore alternatives,'' but had made ''no commitment'' to sell the New England Patriots. . . . Stan Wasiak, the 65-year-old manager of the Vero Beach Dodgers of the Class A Florida State League, became the most successful minor league manager in history when his team beat West Palm Beach, 11-2, giving Wasiak his 2,497th career victory. . . . Alvin Gentry, an assistant basketball coach at the University of Colorado, was named an assistant to Coach Larry Brown at Kansas, replacing Bob Hill, who has joined the Knicks' staff.

title: 2-Day Music Festival Begins in Accord, N.Y.

title: Canada Inflation Slows
description: Canada's annual inflation rate slowed to 3.8 percent in July, from 4.1 percent in June, the Government's Statistics Canada said today. Inflation, as measured by the year-to-year change in consumer prices, now has been in the modest 4 percent range for 14 months. In July, a three-tenths of 1 percent rise in prices over June figures was due to increases in food prices, postal costs and hotel and motel rates, the agency said.

title: EMPIRE DEVOURING WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE BREEZE STRIKES OUT
description: The back of his light blue shirt had become dark blue by the second inning, save for a thin line down the middle of his back where the perspiration had somehow not spread. At the top of Shea Stadium, the rippling flags were nothing but a cruel reminder that a breeze was blowing somewhere else. The breeze Thursday was certainly not anywhere near home plate, where John McSherry was making a living.

title: CORRECTION
description: A dispatch from Washington yesterday about appointments to the new Presidential Commission on Americans Outdoors omitted the names of two panel members. They are Sheldon Coleman, chairman of the Coleman Company of Wichita, Kan., and Wilbur F. LaPage, director of the New Hampshire Parks and Recreation Department.

title: SCIENTISTS FIND AIDS VIRUS IN THE TEARDROPS OF A VICTIM
description: The virus believed to cause acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, has been found in the teardrops of a woman suffering from the disease, scientists said today, but they were uncertain whether someone could contract the disorder by repeated contact with tears.

title: CONVICT IN RAPE CASE LOSES AN EVIDENCE PLEA
description: Gary Dotson's attorney today lost a bid to have a retesting of the physical evidence from the trial in 1979 in which Mr. Dotson was convicted of raping Cathleen Crowell Webb.

description: It seems almost certain that he will set a major league record before the season is out, but as Keith Hernandez of the Mets closes in on the mark, the cry from baseball's statistical skeptics is a resounding ''So what?''

title: WASHINGTON URGED A NEW TO ALTER ROLE
description: Even before President P. W. Botha's much-anticipated speech, violence in South Africa and the hardening sentiments in the United States against the Pretoria Government were beginning to overwhelm President Reagan's policy of ''constructive engagement'' with the South Africans.

title: ON THE AIR
description: Viewers of a Washington television station got two very different views of a black South African leader the other night. First, on the ABC News program ''Nightline,'' Gatsha Buthelezi, the Zulu leader, told of his opposition to the white-led Government in Pretoria.

title: Representative Won't Be Charged
description: Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn, while he was still an Assemblyman, used state employees and funds in his 1980 race for Congress, but there is no basis for criminal prosecution, District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman of Brooklyn said yesterday.

title: Down but Not Out
description: Aboard the Intrepid, a new kind of battle is being fought against a new kind of foe: red ink.

title: 2d Resignation In Taiwan Case
description: Taiwan's Deputy Finance Minister said today that he intended to follow the example of the Foreign Minister and resign in the aftermath of the biggest bank scandal in the country's history.

title: DAY FOR VINDICATION
description: As surely as the sun will rise in the East and the local hotel operators will raise their rates for Travers weekend, a son of Danzig will win the 116th Travers Stakes today at Saratoga Race Track.

title: MISTRIAL ORDER OPPOSED
description: John Williams can never be tried again on charges of sports bribery involving three Tulane University basketball games if the mistrial order signed by a judge stands, prosecutors said today. They filed a motion asking Criminal District Court Judge Alvin V. Oser to soften the language of his mistrial order so the state could try Williams again.

title: TO THE VICTOR...
description: After delighting the running world by setting the purse of next year's Boston Marathon at $250,000, race officials turned yesterday to more prosaic matters: how to divide the prizes and how to come up with the money. The purse was set by the Boston Athletic Association, the marathon's sponsor, Thursday night, a month after it had voted to bow to competitive pressures and break with an 89-year tradition by offering money prizes for next year's race.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 2:30 P.M. This game was originally scheduled for tonight. (Television - Channel 4, 2:15 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 2:20 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 7 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7 P.M.) Boxing North American Championships, at Beaumont, Tex., featuring top amateurs from the United States and Puerto Rico, Canada, Mexico, the Dominican Republic, Grenada and Aruba. Among the United States fighters are Daryl Lattimore of Washington and Kevin Bryant of the Bronx, both of whom were winners at the recent National Sports Festival. title: AFTER DECADE OF FREEDOM, WHEELS OF JUSTICE TURN
description: In 1974, Baron Sumter was convicted of marijuana possession and sentenced to two years in prison. But the judge never told him when to surrender. For years Mr. Sumter has been living with his wife and two children in the central California town of Prunedale.

description: Grade One, a 49-to-1 shot who cost his owners $6,000 as a yearling, beat Michael Jonathon by a head to win the Woodrow Wilson Pace tonight and brought his owner the $672,000 first prize in the richest event in harness racing.

description: An attempt by the Philadelphia Eagles to trade Wilbert Montgomery hit a snag Thursday when the running back failed a physical examination with the Seattle Seahawks.

description: Pope John Paul II arrived here today for a visit that is expected to highlight the controversy over his strong opposition to contraception and sterilization.

description: Members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement, took over six radio stations here tonight and announced a truce.

title: BOTHA SPEECH: 2 SIGNALS
description: When President P. W. Botha addressed white followers in Durban Thursday night to speak of what he calls racial reform, he told them South Africa was crossing the Rubicon. The message was not lost on the black majority, either.

title: JEAGER IN OPEN
description: She has played only sporadically since suffering a shoulder injury a year ago, but Andrea Jaeger, the former teen-age tennis sensation, is still considered a hot property. Yesterday she was awarded a wild-card berth for the United States Open along with 14 other players. Joining Miss Jaeger in the women's draw of the event, which begins Aug. 27, will be Rosie Casals, a three-time American doubles champion, and such younger players as Linda Gates, the national collegiate champion, and Anna Ivan and Beverly Bowes of the Junior Federation Cup team. On the men's side, wild-card berths went to such experienced players as Tim Gullickson and such newcomers as Mikael Pernfors, the collegiate singles champion, and Jim Grabb and Luke Jensen of the Junior Davis Cup team.

title: FUGITIVE IS RECAPTURED IN COAST HOSPITAL BED
description: A man who fled from a Spokane jail where he was being held on a fugitive warrant was recaptured here today after his wife telephoned for an ambulance for her injured husband, who fell from a roof in his getaway, officials said.

title: A FIGHT TO ACQUIRE REVLON IS EXPECTED
description: Pantry Pride Inc. may be waging a losing battle in its multibillion-dollar campaign to take over Revlon Inc., even though Revlon is showing considerable interest in a Pantry Pride takeover, Wall Street investment bankers said yesterday.

title: HOUSE LOOKS INTO U.S. AIDE AND ANTI-SANDINISTAS
description: The chairman of a House subcommittee with jurisdiction over Latin American affairs wrote a letter to the White House today asking for all records about the involvement of a National Security Council official with the Nicaraguan rebels in the last year.

title: Schools Get Advice on Ruling
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett told school administrators Thursday that they must continue serving poor parochial school students while complying with a Supreme Court decision aimed at preserving the separatation of church and state.

GREETING CARDS FOR NO OCCASION
description: ''I KNOW I owe you a letter,'' reads the caption on the front of the greeting card, ''but now you owe me a card.''

title: Article 197165 -- No Title
description: The Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corporation has agreed to acquire Armco Inc.'s aerospace and strategic materials group for $415 million, the companies said yesterday.

title: A Long Shot
description: The city is in the throes of political campaigning for the Sept. 10 Democratic primary. But this is also the season for minor parties to file nominating petitions for the general election ballot in November.

title: CURB ON CAMPUS COMPUTERS: PENTAGN VS. ACADEMIA
description: The Defense Department's plan to prevent the use of supercomputers at American universities by students and scholars from the Soviet bloc marks a sharp new turn in the Reagan Administration's crackdown on the leakage of high technology, university officials say.

description: b-Net income including an extraordinary gain of $243,000.

title: BOTHA SPEECH SAID TO DISAPPOINT U.S.
description: Senior Reagan Administration officials said today that they were disappointed by the lack of major concessions to South Africa's black majority in a speech by President P. W. Botha. But they said there were several considerations that contributed to a restrained response by the United States.

title: DISTRIBUTED LOGIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31

title: Getty Synthetic
description: Air Products and Chemicals Inc. has signed an agreement to buy Getty Synthetic Fuels Inc., the world's largest producer of methane gas from landfills, the company said today.

title: E.P.A. HALTS WORK N TOXIC CLEANUPS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today it had temporarily halted or slowed cleanup work at 57 toxic waste sites to conserve money in case Congress does not renew the law establishing the cleanup fund. The law expires Sept. 30.

title: ONE KILLED AND 20 HURT IN ALABAMA TORNADOES
description: Tornadoes spawned by the remnants of the hurricane that struck Louisiana battered north Alabama today, killing a woman, injuring 20 people and heavily damaging dozens of buildings in several communities, the authorities said.

title: THEATER: RIAL'S 'BOLIVAR' AT THE FESTIVAL LATINO
description: ''They will not remember my ideas,'' Simon Bolivar cries out at the moment of his elevation into a godlike hero, ''and there will not be a shadow of the truth left about me, but only a statue.'' The sorrow that washes over one at that moment in ''Bolivar,'' presented by the Fundacion Rajatabla of Caracas, Venezuela, at the Festival Latino in the Public Theater, is a tribute to the dramatic vison of its author, Jose Antonio Rial, and its director, Carlos Gimenez. Their command of the audience's emotions in this revolutionary play is complete.

title: BIRTH CONTROL CONTROL
description: Imagine an American couple who ask their doctor for advice on controlling the size of their family. Then imagine the doctor giving them only one answer: periodic abstinence. That's unimaginable; even a physician who favored the rhythm method of contraception would at least describe the alternatives.

title: A.T.&T. SEEKING A RATE RISE
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would seek to increase, to 60 cents from 50 cents, the price of interstate and intercity directory assistance calls.

title: WILLIAM BAKER WEDS KATE HILL HADLEY
description: Kate Hill Hadley, the division operations geologist for the Eastern Explorations Division of Exxon in New Orleans, was married yesterday to William Charles Baker, the manager of product management for Dresser Industries, oil drilling specialists in Beaumont, Tex. The Rev. William Eddy performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass.

A Night With the Homeless
description: NOT long ago, after 38 years, I did something I had never thought of doing. With a friend -he's older and more experienced at this -I helped supervise a shelter for homeless women in Manhattan. The crux of this job is simply to be there from 7 in the evening until the women leave in the morning, around 6.

title: JETS' SPECIAL TEAMS DRAWING ATTENTION

title: SIMMS AWAITS STARTING CALL
description: Kickoff time Saturday night for the preseason game between the Giants and the Green Bay Packers at Giants Stadium is 8 P.M. At 7:59 P.M., said Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants, he will decide if Phil Simms will play.

title: LITTLE IMPACT SEEN IF OIL FROM IRAN IS CUT BY IRAQ
description: Amid conflicting reports about the damage Thursday's Iraqi air attack caused to Iran's main oil-export terminal on Kharg island, oil analysts said yesterday that a cutoff of oil from Iran would in itself have little impact on the world's oil market because of the current oversupply.

title: HANOI TO END EFFORT TO SEAT ITS CAMBODIAN ALLY AT U.N.
description: Vietnam's Foreign Minister said today that Hanoi would not fight to seat the Phnom Penh Government at the United Nations General Assembly this year. For more than five years, Hanoi has been trying to gain United Nations recognition for Phnom Penh.

title: RESORTS GETS 8.8% STAKE IN PAN AM
description: Resorts International Inc. disclosed yesterday that it owns an 8.8 percent stake in the Pan Am Corporation, the parent company of Pan American World Airways.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN RAND TAKES DRAMATIC FALL
description: South Africa's currency, the rand, fell dramatically against the United States dollar today, at one point reaching a record low. Market specialists said the decline was a result of President P. W. Botha's failure to announce major concessions to the black majority in a speech he made Thursday.

title: MANY MOURN A TRUE YANKEE
description: Yankee players, managers and executives, past and present, attended funeral services here this morning for the man whose life touched all of theirs, the clubhouse manager Pete Sheehy.

description: Like many other farmers here in the grain belt, E. W. Dixon was smiling today as he examined long, fat ears of corn in fields that now seem sure to give him one of the best crops he has ever produced.

Fantom of Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Leonard Thomas Sperry, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Sperry of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and Vienna. The Rev. Richard Leonard performed the Unitarian ceremony at the University Club in New York.

description: An outbreak of virulent citrus canker was confirmed today at a central Florida nursery, and agriculture inspectors began preparing for their biggest battle yet against the tree-killing disease.

description: At a festive City Hall reception yesterday, the winners of a sealed-bid auction of 149 brownstones in Harlem were announced.

description: For 15 years in the 1960's and 1970's, Winston Hill was one of the finest offensive linemen in professional football. From 1963 through 1976, he was a 285-pound offensive tackle who was Joe Namath's main blocking bodyguard with the Jets.

title: INDICTMENT CHARGES COMPANY ILLEGALLY EXPORTED JET PARTS

title: CABLE REPAIRS SHUT GOVERNMENT OFFICES
description: Major Federal and city office buildings in lower Manhattan were closed yesterday as utility workers toiled underground to fix electric cables that failed Thursday as demand for electricity was reaching a record level for the New York region.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Executive Changes column of Business Day on Wednesday about the Georgia Federal Bank misstated one of Dale E. Johnson's new titles. It is chief financial officer, not chief executive officer.

title: U.N. CHIEF MAKES PLEA FOR LEBANON CAPTIVES
description: Javier Perez de Cuellar, the United Nations Secretary General, appealed yesterday for the immediate release of seven Americans and six other foreigners kidnapped or missing in Lebanon.

title: D'AMATO SAYS HE KNEW OF G.O.P. GIFTS
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato testified today that, as an official in Nassau County during the 1970's, he had been aware of the practice of Nassau County government workers contributing 1 percent of their salary to the Republican Party, but that he had not regarded it as coercive.

title: GAF, AND CHIEF, TURN AROUND
description: Two years ago, during a lengthy and blistering battle for control of the GAF Corporation, a dissident shareholder, Samuel J. Heyman, vowed to accomplish two things: win control of the floundering company and sell many of its operations, particularly its core chemical business.

title: CITY OPERA EXPANDS PERFORMANCE SCHEDULE
description: The New York City Opera will play a one-week engagement at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center next June, officials of the company announced this week. It will also extend its residency at Wolf Trap from one week to two. These new commitments, along with the previously announced spring season of musical comedy in New York, will add six weeks to the City Opera's performing schedule, for a total of 27 weeks for 1986.

title: A REAL RINGER
description: Walt Williams Jr. has been a regular on the Professional Bowlers Association tour for three years, but the 25-year-old bachelor from Chino, Calif., would much rather be pitching horseshoes.

title: REAL ESTATE
description: The Veterans Administration is having good fortune these days in one of its lesser-known sidelines, the sale of houses. As part of its services to veterans, the agency guarantees home loans for them.

title: MEDICAL DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LOWLY PIRATES COOL OFF METS
description: Ed Lynch joined his pitching mate Dwight Gooden at the end of a streak tonight. Lynch, who had not lost a game in six straight starts since June 28, lasted just five innings, allowing eight hits and four earned runs as the Mets took a 7-1 pummeling from the Pirates in front of 9,289 at Three Rivers Stadium.

title: Karen Loucks Marries Donald Richard Klein
description: The marriage of Karen Bade Loucks, a daughter of Mrs. William D. Loucks Jr. of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Mr. Loucks, to Donald Richard Klein, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Klein of York, Pa., took place yesterday at the American Yacht Club in Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Lichti, a Dutch Reform minister, performed the ceremony.

title: MAYNARD OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Bridge:;   Age Is Served in the Victory Of Mahaffey in the Spingold
description: The result of the Spingold Knockout Team Championship in Las Vegas, Nev., earlier this week was a remarkable triumph of age over youth, setting several records.

title: EALING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROFIT SYSTEMS N C reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TECHNICAL COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEW YORK AREA POWER SUPPLY CALLED AMPLE
description: Despite spot power problems Thursday in lower Manhattan and northern New Jersey, the utilities serving both areas have access to far more electricity than they are likely to need this summer and have little fear of systemwide blackouts, according to officials.

title: US ORDERS EXTRADITION OF EX-MEXICO CITY CHIEF
description: A Federal magistrate ruled here today that Arturo Durazo Moreno, a former Mexico City police chief, should be extradited to Mexico.

title: IN FEAST OF FAMINE, THERE IS BREAD IN RUSSIA
description: The collective farm chairman lost his job and his Communist Party membership and now faces trial on criminal charges. Three of his subordinates also lost their jobs. Their crime: feeding bread to pigs.

title: HOME BUILDING OFF BY 2.4% IN JULY
description: Construction of new housing, an important gauge of future economic activity, fell a surprising 2.4 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported yesterday.

title: ATE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: LONGVIEW FIBRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a credit of $2,198,000 from the reversal of previously deferred income tax.

title: PROPOSALS ON ARMS WORTH EXPLORING
description: To the Editor:

title: Save the Teaching Profession, the Beirut of Occupations
description: IN a short time, teachers and supervisors, refreshed from their long recess, will be returning to their desks. Pupils, despite moans to the contrary, are eagerly awaiting the sound of school bells. Stationery stores are displaying stacks of notebooks and pencils, while clothiers are featuring back-to-school specials. Our custodial staff is mopping and buffing my four-story brick building, and the grand old dame is anxious to open her arms for a 57th year.

title: Bomb Victim on Critical List
description: A man who was once accused of concealing his wartime membership in the Waffen SS was still in critical condition tonight from injuries he suffered when a pipe bomb exploded at his home here. The man, Tscherim Soobzokov, 61 years old, remained in St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center. A spokesman for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Michael McDonnell, said the bureau's task force on terrorism was investigating the incident, which occurred Thursday.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $217,000 for the quarter and $169,000 for the 6 months.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIDE TO MRS. REAGAN RESIGNS
description: Jennefer Hirshberg has resigned as press secretary to Nancy Reagan after serving six months and will be replaced by Elaine Crispin, who is Mrs. Reagan's personal assistant, the White House said today. Mrs. Reagan's press office said Miss Hirshberg would take a new position with the Office of Management and Budget to assist in the transition between the departing director, David A. Stockman, and his successor, James C. Miller 3d. The changes will be effective Sept. 3.

title: ROOKIE GOLFER LEDS WITH 67
description: Kim Shipman, a rookie on the tour of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, today shot a 67, her best score as a pro, to lead the first round of the MasterCard International Pro-Am.

title: UNSHACKLE THE TELEPHONE COMPUTERS
description: The electronic switching systems that route telephone calls are computers, not very different from those that book hotel reservations or navigate the space shuttle. Yet the companies that own most of them - A.T.& T. and the local Bell operating companies - can't use them as computers without specific Government permission. In fact, none of these companies can sell products or services directly in unregulated markets. They can do so only through subsidiaries strictly separate from their regulated businesses.

title: NATURE'S SUNSHINE PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STRIKING CAR HAULERS SET TO RESUME WORK SUNDAY
description: More than 20,000 striking automobile haulers will return to work Sunday, even though their votes on a proposed new contract will not be counted until mid-September, a spokesman for the teamsters' union said today.

title: SUBPAR SPORTSMANSHIP
description: From the time he was 12 years old and was disqualified from a tournament for turning in a false scorecard, David Robertson, a 28-year-old one-time British youth champion, has been a troubling figure in European golfing circles. When he was 14 he was disqualified from a tournament for improperly marking his ball on a green.

title: CONFERTECH INTL reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NEW GREENPEACE SHIP TO CONFRONT FRANCE ON NUCLEAR TESTS
description: The chairman of the Greenpeace environmental group said today that a new ship, much larger than the one sunk in New Zealand last month, would leave Amsterdam Sunday for the South Pacific to protest French nuclear tests in the region.

title: IRENE KOENIGSBERGER, RESEARCHER IN RUBBER
description: Dr. Irene Diner Koenigsberger, who as a New York University doctoral candidate in 1920 discovered a method for determining the life of rubber tires, died Monday at her home in Washington. She was 87 years old.

title: PERCEPTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $43,608. c-Net loss.

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary gains of $615,000 for the quarter and $164,000 for the year. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $615,600.

title: CHARGIT INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. Cautions Thrift Units
description: Federal regulators have told the nation's savings and loan institutions to examine their interest rates and trim them if they are far above those being paid by competitors.

title: AMTECH RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
ITEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1 million for the quarter and 6 months and extraordinary gains of $6.4 million for the quarter and $4.3 million for the 6 months. c-Net losses.

title: SLANEY TOPS TIME
description: Mary Decker Slaney trimmed almost a second off her American record yesterday in the 800-meter event at an international track and field meet in Bern, Switzerland.

title: FORMER CHIEF OF FRITO-LAY INC.
description: Harold R. Lilley, former head of Frito-Lay Inc. and a former member of the board of Pepsico Inc., died of a heart attack Tuesday. He was 72 years old.

title: UGANDA RULERS NAME A BRITON CHIEF JUSTICE
description: Uganda's military rulers named a British subject as the country's Chief Justice today and appointed four more ministers, completing a civilian Cabinet.

title: Broad Market Decline; Dow Off 5.04, to 1,312.72
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday as investors weighed the $5.3 billion bulge in the nation's basic money supply announced after the close of trading on Thursday. Analysts said that the rapid money growth reduced the chances that the Federal Reserve would stimulate the economy by encouraging lower interest rates.

title: NATIONAL INTERGROUP BARS LEUCADIA BID
description: Directors of National Intergroup Inc. said today that they have rejected a merger proposal from the Leucadia National Corporation because the bid is highly conditional and because a sale at this time would not be appropriate.

title: BISHOP TUTU SEES A 'CATASTROPHE' FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: In a stinging reply to President P. W. Botha, Bishop Desmond M. Tutu said today that the prospects for peaceful change in South Africa were ''virtually nil'' and that the nation was ''on the brink of a catastrophe.''

title: ARMY ACTS TO HELP FAMILIES COPE WITH PRESSURES OF MODERN MILITARY LIFE
description: A clown came to a day care center on this Army post to pass out balloons on a warm day not long ago. The children, balloon strings tied around their wrists, squealed and dashed about a grassy yard. A bit later, to the sound of tiny hands clapping, a delivery boy brought pizzas for lunch.

title: POLYDEX PHARMACEUTICALS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $768,043 on the sale of the company's Scotia Marine subsidiary. c-Net losses.

title: SORTING OUT SOLUTIONS TO CITY'S TRASH
description: An agreement by city officials this week to build an incinerator in Brooklyn is only the first of what promises to be a decade of difficult technological and political decisions about what to do with the 21 billion pounds of garbage New York produces each year.

title: HOME FEDL SAVINGS & LOAN OF THE ROCKES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ENERGYNORTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: NEW YORK'S LUKEWARM 'WELCOME BACK' FOR SEASONED TEACHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 YOUTHS KILLED BY TRAIN IN JERSEY
description: Two teen-agers who the police said were drinking beer with friends near railroad tracks here were killed by a train Thursday night, authorities said today.

title: Article 197298 -- No Title
description: Bail was set at $50,000 today for Robert Herman Meier 2d, a 19-year-old Michigan man who was arrested here Thursday on charges of defrauding the parents of a newspaper carrier missing for nearly three years. United States Magistrate Edmund Maxwell scheduled a hearing for Aug. 26 to allow the Government time to show probable cause to try Mr. Meier on a charge of fraud by wire. He is accused of taking $11,000 from the parents of Johnny Gosch, the missing boy, after telling them he could return their son if they paid him to free the boy from a drug dealer in Mexico City.

title: United Delays Change on Fares
description: United Airlines said today that for ''competitive reasons,'' it was postponing by one week a sweeping change in its fare structure that was due to take effect tomorrow.

title: VOTING REFORM, LONG OVERDUE
description: For years, the sorry state of the New York City Board of Elections was a dirty little secret shared only by political insiders. The secret erupted into a public scandal last fall when board incompetence nearly disenfranchised thousands of new voters. Politicians were finally forced to take notice. The result may be real reform in time for the next Presidential election, in 1988, but only if City Hall can install management capable of modernizing the board's operations. As crucial will be the Legislature's political restructuring of the board to guarantee its long-term ability to function.

title: FIREFIGHTING IS ON JOB FOR PRIVATE ENTERPRISE
description: To the Editor:

title: Cash Balance Pension Plans
description: A NEW type of retirement plan has been developed that combines some of the best features of traditional pension plans with some of the advantages of corporate savings plans.

title: Laker Settlement
description: Sir Freddie Laker, a pioneer of cut-rate air travel, has lost his attempt in the high court to block an out-of-court settlement of Laker Airways' antitrust suit. High Court Judge Sir Nicholas Browne-Wilkinson, who had heard the case in private, today approved the $48 million deal, which 10 leading airlines had offered to the creditors of the bankrupt airline. Sir Freddie, who says the airlines conspired to drive him out of business in 1982, wanted the court to withhold approval from the settlement negotiated in the United States, saying it was ''pitifully inadequate.''

title: COLOMBIANS IN MIAMI SEEK TO IMPROVE IMAGE
description: Enrique Cabrera, a Colombian businessman here, says he gets two reactions to the ''Colombian Import and Products'' sign on his truck. Teen-agers wave happily at him on the street. Police officers do not.

title: RADIO STATION IN KANSAS FACES POSSIBLE FINE
description: The Federal Communications Commission has given an administrative law judge the power to fine a Kansas radio station for business practices that may have violated Federal standards, but not for its antiblack and anti-Jewish broadcasts.

title:
PATENTS;

Eat Toxic Materials
description: A PROFESSOR at the University of Illinois, Ananda M. Chakrabarty, one of whose inventions led the Supreme Court to rule that forms of life can be patented, received another patent in that field this week. He and Scott T. Kellogg of San Diego, a microbiologist, were awarded patent 4,535,061 for microbes that can eat toxic materials in the environment.

title: HOSPITALS CHIEF, FACING AN INQUIRY RESIGNS HIS POST
description: The president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation resigned yesterday after telling city officials he was under criminal investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney.

title: DR. GROSS IN LIMBO
description: To the Editor:

title: ARIS PHILLIPS
description: Aris Phillips, a researcher in structural and mechanical engineering and the Robert Higgin Professor of Mechanical Engineering at Yale University, died Aug. 9 at his home in North Haven, Conn.

title: 19 DIE IN WIDESPREAD BEIRUT SHELLING
description: Christian and Moslem forces exchanged artillery and mortar fire today in barrages that spread from southern Beirut to engulf most of the city.

title: CARBIDE ORDERS STRICTER POLICY ON ALERTS
description: Managers of Union Carbide Corporation plants must sound alarms in nearby communities at the first hint of a release of toxic material and ''apologize later'' if the evacuation proves unnecessary, the company's top executive said today.

title: CITIZENS UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NOVELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Including tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $200,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a tax credit of $225,000.

title:
PATENTS;

Microwave Scalpel Aids Instant Blood-Clotting
description: A surgical scalpel that uses microwave energy to produce instant blood-clotting was patented this week by Leonard S. Taylor, an electrical engineer at the University of Maryland.

title: CONCERT: 'MITRATE' PERFORMED AT MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL
description: The Mostly Mozart Festival posed itself a difficult problem last night when it gave a concert version of one of Mozart's least known large-scale operas, ''Mitridate, Re di Ponto,'' a work he composed at age 14.
