''Mitridate'' is a three-act opera seria in the most formal 18th-century style, with the usual royal despot who magnanimously relents and the tangled romantic plot typical of this genre. There is no way such a stylized work can be turned into a tongue-in-cheek parody without its essence being sacrificed. That, unfortunately, is what often happened in this otherwise welcome performance, which on the whole was beautifully sung but which had to bear the burden of a rib-poking narration that continually undermined the young composer's purposes.

title: ESKIMOS VIEW RADAR STATIONS AS BLOTS, NOT BLIPS
description: When the United States and Canada announced plans last spring to overhaul the North American air-defense system, the news evoked little enthusiasm from the people who live in the region.

title: Energy Official Quits In Overcharge Dispute
description: A Government administrator in charge of recovering billions of dollars in oil overcharges has resigned after Energy Secretary John S. Herrington rejected a proposal to double the amount of claims against drillers and refiners.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: SUSSEX AIR SHOW Champion aerobatic pilots, wing walkers, World War II fighters and bombers, flying comedy acts, hot-air balloons and an Army parachute demonstration - all will be part of the annual air show at Sussex Airport Thursday through Sunday.

title: A PARTY FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: BORN of necessity, its early years were marked by weakness, and many thought its life would be brief. But it grew to be one of this country's most-important, successful and respected innovations. In 50 years, it has given $1,800 billion to 115 million people across the United States.

title: CON ED CONTINUES REPAIRS ON CABLES
description: Utility and city officials yesterday were still learning the extent of the damage from a series of underground electrical fires in lower Manhattan Thursday as repair crews worked around the clock to replace burned cables and restore power to buildings that had been blacked out.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: BAG ART IN MANHATTAN An unlikely art, that of brown paper bags, will be celebrated Wednesday at a logical place, the New York headquarters of the International Paper Company at 77 West 45th Street.

title: THE CATALOGUE LOOPHOLE MUST BE CLOSED
description: MANY people prefer to buy clothing and other expensive items from mail-order catalogues to avoid paying sales taxes. What they don't realize, however, is that in doing so they are breaking the law. Actually, they do owe the tax, but in most cases catalogue owners are not required to collect it, state tax authorities cannot force compliance and so it goes unpaid.

title: TENURE: A VARIETY OF ALTERNATIVES
description: ONE of the most hotly debated issues among faculties and administrators on campuses today is what to do about the dwindling opportunities for tenure, the virtually ironclad guarantee of lifetime teaching employment.

title: FABLED FOOTPRINTS IN THE STREETS OF BATH
description: You can hardly walk a yard in Bath without duplicating the footsteps of some literary ghost. Start at the stately Royal Crescent, continue through the Circus and south to Queen Square, then cut east to the High Street: you are tracing the precise route Dickens's Sam Weller took to the greengrocer's shop in whose upper rooms he found a party of carousing footmen and watched the host dance the ''frog hornpipe'' on a table. Or go north from the Pump Room across Cheap Street to Milsom Street: with you is Jane Austen's coquettish Isabella Thorpe, followed by two mildly lustful young men, whose notice she ''was so far from seeking to attract that she looked back at them only three times.''

title: WRITERS' REJECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE TROUBLED FACULTY;

PART-TIME INSTRUCTORS PROLIFERATE
description: THE extraordinary pressures and complex issues facing the academic world today have resulted in greater visibility for faculty members who teach part time. According to experts, their numbers have been growing since the 1970's, fueled by three main factors: financial cutbacks for higher education; low turnover among older, tenured faculty, and an increase in the number of graduate-degree holders, particularly among members of the baby-boom generation who want to teach at a time when the college population is dwindling. As part-time faculty members become more prominent on the nation's campuses, their status is causing friction among several factions:

title: CHILDBIRTH CLASSES FOR THE FAMILY
description: WHEN Joanne Hyman of New Milford returned home after delivering her second son in June, Robbie, her 5-year-old, climbed onto her lap and whispered in her ear.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HERITAGE FESTIVAL While members can't legitimately offer a guarantee with every admission ticket, the Huntington Historical Society likes to say that ''the sun always shines on the third Sunday in August.'' You can find out at Huntington's Heckscher Park at the society's Heritage Festival. Today's, from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., is the 22d annual shindig, and, as usual, comes complete with historical displays (including some fancy footwork by the Huntington Militia), an array of international foods representative of the area's various ethnic strains, music and dance performances, and a 125-booth antiques show. Admission is $2, or 75 cents for children ages 5 through 12, with those under 5 free. Parking is available at the Gerard Street Post Office. Buses will take festival-goers to the park on Route 25A at no charge.

title: AN AMERICAN IN PARIS: HIS BASKETBALL IN NEW YORK
description: NOT long ago, the four-time Olympic champion discus thrower, Al Oerter, used the term ''cabin fever'' to describe the agitated state he found himself in while recovering from an injury. By Oerter's account, his body was so wired for hard and regular use that, once deprived of his workouts, his mental equilibrium was out of whack.

title: BORDER CROSSINGS
description: To the Editor: I also had an unsettling experience upon arrival in Rumania. Out of about 285 fellow passengers, I was singled out at the Bucharest airport and taken to an office for interrogation by a uniformed official.

title: A Reservation
description: The Nuclear Weapons Freeze Campaign is planning an international conference in Geneva in early September, and its leaders are worried that the cost of Swiss hotel rooms may be a little daunting to some would-be delegates. Therefore they have reserved space for up to 100 visitors in the city's underground nuclear defense bunkers; the charge of 7 Swiss francs (about $3.10) the first night and 5 ($2.20) a night thereafter includes a bed, sheets and showers. Not to mention a provocative environment.

title:
GARDENING;

WHY THE MIMOSA ISN'T RECOMMENDED
description: IN response to a recent article that noted the Japanese scholar tree, Sophora japonica, and the golden rain tree, Kolreuteria paniculata, as being desirable summer-flowering trees, a reader asked why the mimosa, Albrizia julibrissin, had been ignored.

title: MISS MCCORMICK WEDS J. G. MURRAY 2D
description: In the Galvin Chapel on the campus of Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill., yesterday Maureen Anne McCormick, a daughter of Mrs. Robert D. McCormick of Chicago and the late Mr. McCormick, was married to Joseph Gerard Murray 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Murray of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. D. Bradley Murray, uncle of the bridegroom, performed the Roman Catholic ceremony.

title: JOAN MCDONNELL TO MARRY IN FALL
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert R. McDonnell of Hamden, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter Joan Morris McDonnell to Francis Joseph O'Connor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas D. O'Connor of Loudonville, N.Y., and Watch Hill, R.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: CHILD DROWNINGS ON THE RISE ON ISLAND
description: AT 7 P.M. on July 13, a 2-year-old Elmont boy was reported missing by his mother. Nassau County police officers began searching for the boy and shortly afterward found him in five feet of dirty water in an unused backyard pool. At 9:38 P.M. he was pronounced dead.

title: THE TWEEDY 'BIRDERS' SEEK A NEW IMAGE
description: IT is an old joke: ''Where does a 500-pound canary sit?'' ''Anywhere it wants to.'' Perhaps if there were quarter-ton tweety birds lurking in the fields and forests, bird-watching - or ''birding'' as it is now called - would be a more accepted American pursuit. Television beer commercials might then depict swarthy, perspiring ornithologists returning from a rough day on the range, clothes pecked to ribbons, swapping lies over a couple of tall cool ones.

title: FRANCE SPEAKS UP FOR REGIONAL LANGUAGES
description: The daily newspaper Liberation, which is known for its sauciness and irreverence, the other day printed headlines in seven apparently exotic languages across its front page. They were all versions of the phrase, ''My tailor is rich'' - the standard first sentence of every English primer. There was ''nimmer schnidder isch risch,'' which is Alsatian, and ''pinvidik eo va c'hemener'' which is Breton. The phrase was repeated in Corsican, Armenian, Basque, Occitan (otherwise known as patois) and Flemish. This was the newspaper's way of reporting on a new initiative by the Socialist Government to promote cultural and linguistic diversity in France.

title: GIANTS VICTORIOUS: JETS ARE DEFEATED
description: The Giants won their third straight preseason game tonight, an inelegant 10-2 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

title: SPECTACULAR DEBUTS CREATE WORRY ABOUT THE FUTURE
description: Miranda Richardson, a new English actress who's been acting professionally for only six years, makes such a spectacular film debut in ''Dance With a Stranger'' that you almost worry how she'll ever be able to equal - much less top - it.

title: LINKS BETWEEN BOMBS IN BOSTON AREA SOUGHT
description: Federal, state and local authorities were investigating a possible link between the planting of explosive devices in Boston and Cambridge, one of which blew up in the face of a police bomb expert.

title: Verbatim;   On One-Party Rule
description: 'The democratic system of government does not have a stabilizer to steady the ship against the waves of popular demands that want to be satisfied immediately. That is why many governments elsewhere roll from left to right and right to left every now and then.

title: 'SKY IS LIMIT' FOR WORLD RECORD HOLDER
description: KARYN TARTER, the greatest female weight lifter in history, stood 10 feet away from the bar and made the rest of the world disappear. She exhaled furiously through tightly pursed lips and trained her gaze on the weight.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: BIRD BEHAVIOR. By Robert Burton. (Knopf, $18.95.) With the help of amateurs, including the hordes of just plain bird watchers, knowledge about the most visible of man's faunal cohabitants on earth has been growing rapidly.

title: THE BEST DEFENSE: THINK OFFENSIVELY
description: It shouldn't happen, yet there are players who let themselves get caught in defensive thinking when they are called upon to defend.

title: 2 FROM STATE ASSIST CHINESE UNIVERSITY
description: AN economics professor from Connecticut is helping to establish the first university in China since 1949 to follow the American model of higher education.

title: ARTHUR LEE WED TO VIRGINIA RICH
description: At the First United Methodist Church in Saranac Lake, N.Y., yesterday Virginia Martha Rich and Arthur Farren Lee, 1984 graduates of Bates College, were married by the Rev. Richard Chatterton.

title: Fast-Food Restaurants Add Job Applications to the Menu
description: Some McDonald's franchises in this area are having so much trouble filling jobs that they have begun asking customers whether they are interested in standing behind the counter instead of lining up in front of it.

title: ISRAEL'S PERES: VOTERS TURN TO HIM, IF NOT TO HIS PARTY
description: After almost a year as the head of Israel's national unity Government, Prime Minister Shimon Peres has established himself as the dominant figure in Israeli politics today, according to Israeli political experts.

title: PROS AND CONS OF A WELL KNOWN PERENNIAL
description: In high summer, open wetlands throughout the Northeast glow with purple loosestrife. A determined emigrant from Europe, this wildflower has spread rapidly in areas to its liking, especially in wet meadows and ditches along highways.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 18, 1985 Fiction

title: LAURA KLINE PLANS TO WED MICHAEL P. LAZARUS IN FALL
description: Laura Fennelly Kline and Michael Paul Lazarus plan to be married Sept. 28, her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Patton Kline of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., have announced.

title: BEHIND THE TAKE-CHARGE MOOD AT REAGAN'S RANCH
description: UNPLANNED events sometimes have a way of intruding on Presidential vacations. Ronald Reagan and the supporting cast he travels with were at his ranch near here in 1981 when American fighters downed two Soviet-built Libyan warplanes, and again in 1983, when Korean Airlines Flight OO7 was shot down by Russian pilots.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: PHILIP'S GIRL . By Lucy Ferriss. (Schocken, $14.95.) The deft conclusion of this first novel is not hinted at by its clumsy beginning.

title: MISS MINTON TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. David M. Minton 3d of Cos Cob, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Shaw Minton, to Salvatore Toscano, a son of Air Marshal Gennaro Toscano of the Italian Air Force, retired, and Mrs. Toscano of Rome. An October wedding is planned.

title: A ONE-WOMAN ACT NO MORE
description: LILLIAN M. KATZ, sitting in a conference room decorated in mauve, casually flipped through a 150-page Lillian Vernon mail-order catalogue and pointed to products. She rarely passed a page without singling out at least one item she had at home. ''I use that,'' she said about a pitcher with icer. Ostrich feather dusters, tea kettles and a crystal vase with glass marbles elicited similar responses.

title: THE REID REPORT
description: Speaking not as an engineer but as a ''layman,'' County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke said last week that the county would probably need a new resource-recovery plant to supplement the one that has been operating for less than a year in Peekskill.

title: SOME GET THROUGH THE PIPELINE
description: SUSAN DANNENBAUM, an associate professor of medieval English literature at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., became tenured last spring. For Dr. Dannenbaum, that seal of security means being spared the fate that five other who were rejected for tenure in her department now face: looking for another job.

title: G.O.P. TRIAL: MANEUVERS OFF STAGE
description: WHILE the Nassau County Republican Committee and former and present government employees have been battling in court for three weeks over charges that the workers were forced to give 1 percent of their salaries to the party, both sides worked behind the scenes on an out-of-court settlement.

title: COUNTRY JAUNTS: HILLS, CAVES, STATELY HOMES
description: Bath is built in a bowl between hills, where the river Avon bends. To the south the land rises steeply in the direction of the Mendips; to the north lies the high plain of Gloucestershire. The surrounding countryside is never less than pleasant, and sometimes spectacular. Journeying outward from Bath, in as many small forays as you have time for, you can find much to divert the mind, intrigue the imagination, or please the eye.

title: MOZAMBIQUE'S PIVOT TOOWARD THE WEST BRINGING FEW RESULTS
description: When Mozambique celebrated its 10th anniversary of independence from Portugal in June, it was not surprising that the guests included several Russians, who arm this Marxist country, and others from lands professing socialism.

title: SOCCER FANS DISRUPT TRIBUTE
description: Liverpool soccer fans, blamed in large part for a riot that took 39 lives at a game in Brussels last May, disrupted a memorial service today for the victims at the start of the new English soccer season.

title: IRASCIBLE HEROES AND INNOCENT BLOCKHEADS
description: THE COLLECTED STORIES OF WILLIAM HUMPHREY #371 pp. New York: Delacorte Press/Seymour Lawrence. $19.95. WHEN William Humphrey's first novel, ''Home From the Hill,'' a father-son drama set in rural Texas, was published in 1958, it appealed both to readers and critics. With its Faulknerian canvas, dazzling hunting scenes, respect for the natural order of things and preoccupation with family connections, it took an unpretentious but firm place in the Southern literary tradition. Though Mr. Humphrey's affinity to William Faulkner and Mark Twain has often been mentioned, he is in fact an odd man out of current American literature, encompassing its extreme poles of rustic energy and refined sensibility. An eloquent and exciting narrator when he describes shooting a wild boar or skinning a squirrel, he seems emotionally more himself when unearthing vexatious Henry Jamesian truths about human relations.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KIPLING, KERN AND MONTEVERDI
description: Swing Time Starring Fred Astaire, Ginger Rogers, Victor Moore, Helen Broderick; music by Jerome Kern; directed by George Stevens, 1936 RKO Homevideo 103 minutes. $34.95 Fred Astaire takes dancing lessons in this one.

title: ENGLISH LANGUAGE RULE SPLITS CALIFORNIA CITY
description: A battle is being waged in this citrus-growing community between Hispanic and non-Hispanic residents over a new ordinance that declares English the city's official language.

title: HARD TIMES BEFALL A GRAND OLD LADY
description: THE grand old lady of Thomaston has fallen on hard times. Years of genteel poverty and benign neglect have gnawed at her grandeur and covered her with the dust of anachronism. Like all great ladies, she was molded by her era, but her era was the 19th century.

title: Noraid Members March in Belfast
description: Pro-British loyalists called them ''terror tourists,'' and the Irish Foreign Minister urged them to leave. But 125 American members of the Irish Northern Aid Committee continued their visit to Northern Ireland last week, marching at the head of a nationalist parade in West Belfast to the sound of fifes and drums and cheers of support.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: If awards were given for delays in planning and building infrastructure, one would have to go to those involved with the new Route 88 bridge, which has been under construction in the Ocean County community of Point Pleasant since Oct. 17, 1980.

title: BUDD SETS RECORD
description: Zola Budd set a British record in the 3,000-meter run today at the European Cup track and field championships.

title: DEBATE GROWS ON TAX PLAN'S EFFECT ON SCHOOLS
description: President Reagan's proposal to eliminate the deduction for state and local taxes in calculating personal income taxes would lead to major changes in the financing of public schools, according to economists and educators.

title: SPAIN'S THIEVES MAKE U.S. TOURISTS A TARGET
description: Sue Norman, a choir singer from Denver, had just looked around momentarily for a taxi, she said, when she looked back and noticed her wallet was no longer in her purse.

title: TAKING TOYS SERIOUSLY
description: FOR ALL THE RUB-bish on the toy market today, it is still awash with safe, beautiful, interesting, durable playthings.

title: BROADCAST TV
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov's poular staging of ''Don Quixote'' returns to the small screen tomorrow evening, Monday, at 9:05 on Channel 13, with an encore on Friday afternoon at 1. The ballet offers a lighthearted look at Cervantes's dark idealist, Mr. Baryshnikov has let no opportunity pass for engaging bits of silly humor in this story of a poor but handsome barber, Basilio, and his courtship of the spirited Kitri.

title: KEEPING OUT THE GOOSE
description: THE newest weapon in the war against Canada geese and their messy droppings is the ''Goosebuster,'' invented by Freda Margiloff of Wind Mill Farm in Armonk.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL BILLS VETOED
description: GOVERNOR KEAN last week conditionally vetoed a package of environmental bills passed by the Democratic-controlled Legislature and recommended changes that would convert it into his proposal to create a New Jersey Environmental Trust to finance waste-water treatment, resource-recovery plant construction and the safe closure of landfills.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LANGUAGE EXCHANGE It began in 1978 as an English-language institute for Japanese-born wives who found themselves isolated in Westchester while their husbands worked in Manhattan. It has now mushroomed into five low-cost, cross-cultural programs open to the general public. The sessions are held at the Wainwright House at 260 Stuyvesant Avenue in Rye or at other nearby locations, for eight weeks to six months, beginning in September.

title: CONNECTICUT CITY TO HOLD A VOTE ON ABORTION
description: Residents of this industrial city in central Connecticut will be asked in a referendum in November whether they support legalized abortion, and groups on both sides of the issue are already starting campaigns in an attempt to sway voters.

title: TOP HONORS TO THE PASTA DISHES
description: STAMFORD may have been a late bloomer as far as restaurants go, but it is making up for its slow start, with new places blossoming every time we turn around.

title: DISARMAMENT GROUPS SEEK RALLYING POINT AFTER FALTERING ON ATOM FREEZE
description: Leaders of the disarmament movement say it is casting about for a new focus now that the drive for a bilateral freeze on nuclear weapons appears to have faltered in the wake of President Reagan's sweeping re-election.

title: BRITISH SCHOOL ISSUE: SPARE THE ROD AND...?
description: Until recently, students at the Brynteg Comprehensive School who were insolent or persistently truant were struck on the palms of their hands with a bamboo cane: once for a first offense but never more than three times for something serious.

title: AGING POCONOS RESORT TEAMS UP WITH A DEVELOPER
description: THE Delaware Indians, who once roamed the Pocono Mountains, long ago yielded dominion over the 2,400 square miles of wooded slopes and winding streams to the tourism industry. Today, virtually every road in the area passes inns, weekend cottage communities and fancy resorts.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;

EINBECK'S HISTORIC BOCK
description: In 1521, as Martin Luther was defending his 95 Theses at the Reichstag in Worms, the Duke of Braunschweig handed the reformer a tankard of heady bock beer as refreshment. This bracing brew came from Einbeck, the beer capital of medieval Germany and birthplace of the bock variety.

title: CHOLERA REPORTED IN KUWAIT
description: Ten new cases of cholera have been diagnosed in Kuwait, bringing to 20 the number reported this summer, the Kuwaiti press agency said today. It quoted a health official as saying the latest patients were in quarantine and precautions had been taken regarding people with whom they had been in contact. Officials have said the earlier cases originated abroad.

title: No Headline
description: Hilda Bary's July 7 article, ''Some Housewives May Deserve to Be Bored,'' exaggerates the bored-housewife syndrome and does not focus on the real problem - the availability of public transportation from New Jersey to New York City.

title: 'OCEAN QUEST': AFLOAT IN SUSPENDED DISBELIEF
description: ''OceanQuest'' is suspect. It even comes out and says so at the beginning. ''All underwater sequences are actual dives which occurred in the place and manner described,'' a sonorous voice says, reading the words on the screen. ''All scenes of marine life are photographed exactly as they occurred.'' Then comes the proviso, the part that makes you wonder: ''For purposes of dramatic clarity, some scenes were re-created and the order of events rearranged.'' What does this mean? It is impossible to tell exactly, although it does suggest that in ''OceanQuest'' things may not always be what they seem. In other words, ''OceanQuest'' is something like a docudrama; we don't know if what we see actually happened. For once, however, that doesn't matter. Indeed, if anyone is faking in ''OceanQuest,'' we'd really rather not know.

title: NEW YORK CITY LISTS FOOD OUTLETS' VIOLATIONS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 14 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: HOW PARENTS CAN HELP THE GIFTED
description: OF all the myths surrounding gifted children, probably the most common is that they can ''make it on their own.'' As a result of their advanced intellectual abilities, for example, they are expected to understand and be good at just about any subject they tackle. And they are often expected to cope better than other children with the variety of social pressures and situations that all children experience growing up.

title: DEDUCTIBILITY OF A BUYOUT
description: Question: A friend has given a tenant $8,000 to vacate an apartment. She says this is a deductible business expense. I disagree. Who is right? . . . D. C., Manhattan Answer: Courts have determined that the treatment of this fee can depend on your friend's plans for the apartment and the property and the nature of the transaction.

title: Recent Sales
JESSICA GALLIGAN AND JAMES GOLDSMITH ARE MARRIED
description: Jessica Elizabeth Galligan and James Douglas Goldsmith, who graduated in June from the Harvard Law School and are to join the New York law firm of Willkie, Farr & Gallagher as associates next month, were married yesterday at Shelter Island, L.I. Justice of the Peace Edward Hannabury performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's mother, Dr. Carol Wolfe Galligan of New York and Shelter Island.

title:
HOME VIDEO;

NEW CASSETTES: KIPLING, KERN AND MONTEVERDI
description: Monteverdi's 'Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria' A Glyndebourne Festival Opera production, featuring Dame Janet Baker, Benjamin Luxon and Richard Lewis, with Raymond Leppard conducting the London Philharmonic Orchestra and Glyndebourne Chorus, 1973 Video Arts International 152 minutes. $79.95 Monteverdi's operas combine a chaste Classicism with the heart-in-mouth theatricality of Verdi; he is rightly considered the father of opera.

title: TUNING IN LONG-DISTANCE CLASSES
description: WHEN school opens this month in Leedey, Okla., its 46 high-school students will be able to take German I and such enrichment classes as ''Learning Writing Through the Study of Literary Genre'' and ''The Soviet Bloc: A Mosaic.''

title: LYME DISEASE: NEW CASES COULD HIT 1,800 THIS YEAR
description: STATE health officials are forecasting a major increase in newly diagnosed cases of Lyme disease in Connecticut this year, probably to record levels.

title: APPALACHIAN WARRIOR
description: GROWING UP HARD IN HARLAN COUNTY By G. C. Jones. 177 pp. Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky. $19.

title: KENT Y. WHITAKER WEDS MISS LEWIS
description: Catherine Linehan Lewis, the daughter of Judge and Mrs. William Burke Lewis of Riverside, Conn., and Kent Yantis Whitaker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Whitaker of Kettering, Ohio, were married yesterday. The Rev. Vincent J. O'Connor performed the ceremony at St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: THE F.A.S.B. COMES UNDER FIRE
description: THE topic could not have been narrower - nor, some said, more boring. Yet when the Financial Accounting Standards Board, the rule-making body that sets binding accounting standards for virtually every publicly owned corporation in the United States, asked for comment on a proposal to change pension accounting rules, the response was awesome.

title: PUT TEETH IN THE LAWS ON TOXIC LEAKS
description: THIS past week, toxic chemicals were released from Union Carbide's plant in Institute, W. Va. The fact that a leak could occur at this plant, at this time, less than one year after the much greater disaster at Bhopal, points to some important lessons.

title: STUDY SHOWS TREND TO LONGER USE
description: WHEN historians look at behavioral patterns in this century, they are going to want documentation of the way that Americans viewed their cars, how they drove them and how much it cost to keep the country on wheels.

title: PESTICIDES WORRY BEEKEEPERS
description: THE honey bee, nature's ingenious go-between, is caught in a three-pronged dilemma.

title: THE PLAGUE OF MASTERPIECES ABATED SOME TIME AGO
description: Archeologists do not need to unearth complete cities or nations to know what a lost culture was all about. Sometimes talented diggers can see a universe, so to speak, in a grain of sand. Looking at a few shards, bones and fragmented tools, they extrapolate and reconstruct with great freedom, their creative imaginations probably fired by the scarcity of hard evidence. Too much tangible data, in fact, might only stifle the creative urge to build whole civilizations out of hints and hypotheses.

title: A DOWN-HOME ANALYST LOOKS ABROAD
description: SOME of the nation's most successful stock pickers have settled far from Wall Street's industry-specialist pigeonholes, in search of regional firms that will allow them the freedom to search out ''special situations.'' One of these investment expatriates is Richard M. Lilly, a 38-year-old securities analyst with Raymond, James & Associates Inc., a St. Petersburg, Fla., brokerage house.

title: NEW DELHI
description: To the Editor: Your article ''A Cook's Notebook on Dining in Delhi'' (Travel, June 9) brought back fond memories of my three excursions to India. I, too, enjoyed the atmosphere and ate the fine food at the Moti Mahal Restaurant in New Delhi.

title: ALL TOGETHER NOW
description: THE POWER ECONOMY Building an Economy That Works. By John Oliver Wilson. 302 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $19.95.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: LUCKY. By Jackie Collins. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) Meet the sizzling cast of Jackie Collins's new novel. There's our heroine, Lucky Santangelo, she of the black gypsy eyes, wide sensual mouth and supple tanned body with the longest legs in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: DR. JOYCE S. JEN TO WED OCT. 20
description: Dr. and Mrs. Norman C. Jen of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Joyce Susan Jen, to Dr. Kenneth Alan Freedberg, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Irwin M. Freedberg of New York City and Holderness, N.H. The wedding is planned for Oct. 20.

title: WOMAN FOUND SLAIN IN PARK
description: An elderly woman was found beaten to death in Morningside Park near the West 121st Street entrance early yesterday morning, the police said. Officer Norris Hollomon, a police spokesman, said the woman had apparently been beaten with a blunt object. He said that the police were unable to confirm the woman's identity, but that residents of the neighborhood had said she was homeless and lived in the park.

title: How About a Windfall-Profits Tax on Commercial Banks?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN THE WATER PIPES MAKE THOSE WEIRD NOISES
description: WATER pipes that bang, hammer or squeal are not only a nuisance, they may also be an indication of plumbing problems.

title: ACTORS TRY A NEW ROLE - PLAYING MANAGE
description: Imaginative directors have worked at Britn's National Theater, but perhaps few with the sweeping visual sense of Philip Prowse. In his debut at the National, Mr. Prowse took John Webster's revenge tale, ''The Duchess of Malfi,'' and turned it into a black-mass processional of haunting imagery, filling the stage with a panoply of environments, ranging from palatial chambers to spectral crypts. Behind every pillar there seemed to be a conspiracy in progress or the solitary figure of Death (Mr. Prowse's addition to Webster). Performance took second place to the director's striking conceptualization.

title: MCCORMACK CAPTURES STAGE OF COORS CLASSIC
description: Alan McCormack of Ireland dominated today's road race in the Coors International Bicycle Classic for his first stage victory.

title: THE GROWING WAR AGAINST IMPORTED BUGS AND BEASTS
description: In 1869 a naturalist named Leopold Trouvelot brought some caterpillar eggs from France to Massachusetts, hoping to give America a new type of silkworm. A few caterpillars escaped and Mr. Trouvelt brought forth onto this continent the gypsy moth, which has tormented foresters and gardeners ever since. It is only one of hundreds of pests that have arrived under seemingly innocent circumstances - Japanese beetles, Mediterranean fruit flies, peculiar creatures such as walking catfish and foot-long snails, and common nuisances like starlings.

title: PENSION FUND OF TEAMSTERS IS REPORTED BETTER MANAGED
description: Officials of the teamsters' principal pension fund are making needed changes, Congressional investigators said Friday.

title: Air Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. PLANS TO END NATIONWIDE CODE FOR CONSTRUCTION
description: The Federal Government is preparing to abolish building standards that have served for half a century as the basic guide for the nation's housing industry.

title: OUTFITTING MACINTOSH FOR THE OFFICE
description: HARD disks are rapidly reaching the category of necessary equipment for personal computers in business use. My own educated guess is that by the end of this year, half of the personal computers sold will be so equipped, either when they are purchased, or relatively soon thereafter by means of add-on components.

title: A DRAMA OF FAMILY LOYALTY, ACCEPTANCE - AND AIDS
description: While preparing to direct ''An Early Frost,'' a TV-film that is the first of any movies to focus on AIDS (acquired immune deficiency syndrome), John Erman went to meet a man who was dying of the disease in a New York hospital. He brought along Aidan Quinn, who is starring in the NBC-TV movie (which is scheduled to be broadcast this fall) as a young homosexual lawyer suffering from AIDS.

title: Camacho Is Eager
description: The new World Boxing Council lightweight champion doesn't plan to waste any time before staging his first defense.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: MERGER. By Peter F. Hartz. (Morrow, $17.95.) Aggression and treachery, hairbreadth escapes and last-minute reversals, ''white knights'' and ''shark repellents'' - all these and more can be found in the true-life adventure of the Bendix-Martin Marietta merger war.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN HOME VIDEOTAPES
description: HOME video stores grossed about $1.25 billion last year from renting and selling tapes - most of them movies. But with video cassette recorders in almost 30 percent of the nation's 80 million households, producers, corporations and advertisers are exploring more diverse ways to use the medium.

title: WILL A SHORTAGE OF HOUSING CRIMP ECONOMIC GAINS?
description: DURING rush hour, most highways in the metropolitan area are jammed with cars and buses headed in both directions, vivid if frustrating proof of the local economy's recovery from the malaise of the 1970's and the continued dispersion of jobs from New York City.

title: DENMARK
description: To the Editor: The articles ''What's Doing in Copenhagen'' and ''Seaside Village in Denmark'' (Travel, June 16) sparked conversation for us, having recently returned from eight days in Denmark.

title: A Promising New Treatment for Liver Cancer
description: A Johns Hopkins University scientist announced last week the development of the ''first effective treatment'' for advanced stages of liver cancer, a disease that is almost always fatal. Dr. Stanley E. Order reported that the treatment, which uses antibodies to seek out the disease and a radioactive substance that destroys it at close range, had shrunk tumors in nearly half the patients, a signficant advance over the 15 percent rate achieved with traditional drug treatments. All the patients had tumors that were too large to be surgically removed.

title: Art Trade Sealed For Philadelphia
description: AFTER eight years of discussion the Philadelphia Museum of Art has acquired 43,000 European prints from the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in exchange for six American works, valued at $1 million, and $1 million in cash.

title: YANKEE FARM YIELDS A BONUS CROP
description: IT used to be, and perhaps still is, an image of the Yankees and their owner: pinstripes and dollar signs, free agents, hefty contracts, incentive clauses, instant success. George Steinbrenner and the free-agent system seemed made for each other.

title: CREDIBILITY A CASUALTY IN WEST VIRGINIA
description: THE chemical industry suddenly seemed a lot more risky last week. The toxic gas leak at a Union Carbide plant in Institute, W.Va., sending 135 people to the hospital, was by no means the most serious American chemical accident. But among the public and regulators, it clearly produced the most alarm in recent memory.

title: UNBOWED, WINNIE MANDELA ENDURES
description: To Winnie Mandela, commitment is a balm that heals the souls of black people in a land where race can determine destiny.

title: CHIEF'S CRWN WINS
description: Chief's Crown, the forgotten 2-year-old champion of last year and the beaten favorite in all of the Triple Crown races this spring, redeemed himself and began a bid to reclaim the leadership of the nation's 3-year-olds with a decisive 2 1/4-length victory in the $293,000 Travers Stakes today at Saratoga.

title: A GROWING MARKET FOR HOW-TO TAPES
description: WOULD you buy a video about putting up paneling, hunting elephants or cooking Buffalo chicken wings? Videotape producers think that you would. They say that demand for how-to home videos, which generally sell for $20 to $50, is now large enough to support specialized offerings.

title: MALLARDS ARE HIS MEDIUM
description: IT'S not that Bob Cummings has a particular interest in ducks as ducks. The photographer, whose multi-image collages of ducks go on display today at the Elaine Benson Gallery in Bridgehampton as part of the annual ''Creatures Large and Small'' show, doesn't know a mallard from a common teal and couldn't care less about which is which.

title: IMAGES OF A SHIP'S PROUD PAST
description: The Normandie's 50th anniversary was to have been celebrated this year by a museum exhibition in New York of its glorious Art Deco fittings and furnishings. These designs won acclaim for the superliner at its 1935 launching when it was heralded as the world's most magnificent ship.

title: August 18, 1985
KENTUCKY'S LIVING FICTION
description: You may know someone who seems to have stepped out of the pages of a book; here in Greenup, in the Appalachian foothills of Kentucky, you can meet people who stepped into the pages of the late Jesse Hilton Stuart's fiction and see the spot where the event took place.

title: A B C'S OF SHOPPIN AND STAYING IN BATH
description: One of the joys of shopping in Bath is that all the shops are within walking distance of one another, although I must admit that it took me two days to complete the course. Another pleasure is that in addition to specialty shops, large London-based shops such as Marks and Spencer, Laura Ashley, Habitat, Monsoon, and Next have newly opened in this glorious town. Thus, instead of having to battle the traffic and crowds of London, you can do your shopping at a leisurely pace.

title: BROOKLYN WINS SERIES
description: Frank Rodriguez struck out 11 and hit a go-ahead home run today to lead Brooklyn to a 4-2 victory over Fern Creek, Ky., in the championship game of the Bambino World Series for boys 12 and younger.

title: BACK TO THE SOIL
description: THE FIRST TIME I SAMPLED Paul Tardieu's robust, natural wine, I was seated in his rose-filled garden in La Penne-sur-Ouveze, in Provence, on a sun-kissed Saturday in the middle of August. We were on our way to a casual picnic, with a basket full of crusty country bread spread with homemade rillettes, a few juicy little Cavaillon melons and a bottle of Vinsobres red. We'd heard from a friend that there was this French businessman turned organic farmer who was making a little red wine worth checking out. I was a bit skeptical: I'd sampled some of France's vin biodynamic and had not been duly impressed.

title: COLLEGE CALENDAR IS CHANGING
description: IT'S cold in upstate New York during winter months - so cold that beginning this school year, Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs will be emptying its classrooms and turning down its thermostats during January, a month that in the past was used for special four- to six-week internships. Its ''January Term'' will instead be held at the end of the school year in May, not only to help cut heating bills but also to better complement a new curriculum on the arts, foreign language and non-Western culture. Skidmore will thus join the 162 colleges and universities that, after countless hours of debate, have changed their calendars in the last two years.

title: RADIOACTIVE STEAM RELEASED
description: A power loss at the Dresden nuclear power plant here caused a small amount of radioactive steam from a nuclear power plant to be released into the atmosphere for more than two hours Friday.

title: LOVE-HATE FEELINGS IN 'CHEMICAL VALLEY'
description: In the contemporary folklore of ''the chemical valley'' of the Kanawha River, maroon cars turn irridescent blue and blue cars turn metalic maroon. In the vapors of strong chemical nights aluminum storm doors weld shut, and in the morning mists after overnight sulfuric acid spills the nylon pantyhose of women walking to work suddenly unravel cleanly at the knee, flopping down from the environmentally exposed hemline over dissolving plastic pumps.

title: Navy Spy Case Probe Continues
description: With one brother already convicted of espionage and the other preparing for trial, Federal investigators last week began to consider who recruited whom in the Walker family to spy for the Soviet Union. The Federal Bureau of Investigation acknowledged that it was continuing its examination of the espionage activities of Arthur J. Walker even though he has already been found guilty of passing two classified documents to his brother, John A. Walker Jr. Some Federal agents said they believed Arthur Walker may have launched his brother's spying career 20 years ago, rather than the other way around. Arthur Walker, a retired Navy lieutenant commander, taught antisubmarine warfare at the Atlantic Fleet Tactical School from 1968 to 1973. The F.B.I. is considering whether he served as a Soviet agent during those years, according to Government officials.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: POPE'S RHINO
description: Samia flew 210 miles just to see Pope John Paul II today.

title: WHY DICKENS PLAYS SO WELL ON STAGE
description: Who was the greatest, the most frequently performed and the most successful dramatist never to have written very much, well or successfully for the stage?

title: LINKS, PAST AND PRESENT
description: DAVID Harris remembers the days when they came in droves to his miniature golf course of Route 6. Mr. Harris, now 80 years old, owned not only the golf course but also the bungalow colony that was once next door. Night and day, he recalls, people would wait in line for the chance to tap little balls down little greens into little holes.

title: FUN AND GAMES FOR MASTERS
description: It was quite a picnic here Friday night: all the hot dogs you could eat, a hot-air balloon and even some much appreciated belly-dancers.

title: DRESSING TO A T - AND AND X, Y OR Z
description: WHAT is this summer's fashion message? Well, it may be a little garbled, but some people are apparently trying to spell it out. They are the ones wearing those sportswear separates with eye-catching patterns of letters or numerals.

title: FROM THE BENCH TO THE DEFENSE TABLE
description: Judges are on trial. From state judges in Chicago to county judges in Maryland, more jurists than ever are coming before the bar to face charges of breach of ethics or criminal activity.

title: EVACUATION PLANS POSE A HURDLE FOR SEABROOK
description: Opposition by town and state officials to the emergency evacuation plans being drafted for the Seabrook nuclear plant may threaten issuing of its operating license, according to opponents of the plant and one of its major owners.

title: ARTHRITIS: BUILDING AN INDUSTRY ON PAIN
description: ARTHRITIS entered Ann DeGrout's life when she was 28. She was walking down the stairs of her home one day when her knees inexplicably gave out. She felt a stinging pain. The symptoms worsened and it became clear that she had rheumatoid arthritis. Thirty years later, the disease is still with her.

title: Bracing for a Big Harvest
description: A late-spring dry spell prompted- d herron Federal forecasters a few weeks ago to speculate that for many crops the 1985 harvest would not be a barnburner. Last week, though, fresh from their latest spot-checks, the experts revised many of their estimates sharply upward, saying that the corn, soybean, sorghum, wheat and cotton crops would all be much larger than expected.

title: TESTS THAT STAND THE TEST OF TIME
description: THE Test has come into its own in recent years. It was selected by the editors of Science 84 as one of the ''20 Discoveries That Shaped Our Lives'' in this century. It has made it from no space in small-town papers and minimum space in city papers to front-page news. But what kinds of tests?

title: Hello, Baldness
description: With so many Washington residents in the public eye, it is probably not surprising that the capital seems to exhibit more than a casual interest in countering baldness. Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, was a pioneer in the hair transplant movement, and the Washington Hospital Center is about to begin its second study on drugs that are intended to treat baldness.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SUNDAY, AUGUST 18, 1985 International

title: INCREASINGLY, CHILDREN BEAR THE BURDEN OF POVERTY
description: IN Connecticut and across the country, the face of poverty is becoming the face of a child.

title: AN ATMOSPHERE OF SOPHISTICATION
description: THE atmosphere at Cafe Royale in Syosset is enormously appealing. Contemporary, casual elegance, the hallmark of the latest in restaurant design, creates a mutlilevel dining room suffused in rosy pink with effective, well-modulated lighting and gleaming brass railings to define the areas.

title: ANNE LOUISE WILT WED TO JEFFREY S. POORMAN
description: Anne Louise Wilt, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Wilt of Athens, Pa., and Jeffrey Spencer Poorman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel S. Poorman of Wilmington, Del., and London, were married yesterday. The Rev. Robert Scott performed the ceremony at the Lower Brandywine Presbyterian Church in Wilmington.

title: GOVERNOR'S SCHOOLS CATCHING ON
description: IN his 17 years, Sanjeev Khagram never shied from trying new things.

title: ALL-PURPOSE SUITS
description: THE 10-MONTH SUIT, WHICH WEIGHS BE-tween 8 and 11 ounces per linear yard of fabric, is the mainstay of a man's wardrobe. It is to the suit what the blazer is to sport coats.

title:
ART;

SUMMER SHOW OF TRENTON ARTISTS
description: FOUR painters make up the summer exhibition of the Trenton Artists Workshop Association at Ellarslie, the former elegant summer home that is now the Trenton City Museum, in Cadwalader Park.

title: JOAN CAROL GELLIS IS WED
description: Joan Carol Gellis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Gellis of Brooklyn, and John Joseph Dombrowski, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Dombrowski of Middle Village, Queens, were married yesterday at the Marcpiere restaurant in Melville, L.I. The Rev. John Heinlein, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Nathaniel Schwartz performed the interfaith ceremony.

title: BUILDING ON FAITH
description: SYNAGOGUES OF EUROPE Architecture, History, Meaning. By Carol Herselle Krinsky. Illustrated. 457 pp. New York: The Architectural History Foundation. Cambridge, Mass.: The MIT Press. $50. CAROL HERSELLE KRINSKY, a professor of fine arts at New York University, has written the most important account in any language of the synagogues of Europe. A few of these buildings were rebuilt again and again through several centuries, only to be closed by the Soviet authorities or destroyed by the Nazis. A handful, like the great synagogue in Budapest, have survived with ravaged congregations. Some, like the 14th-century synagogue in Worms, West Germany, have been restored as memorials for congregations that no longer exist. The hundreds of stories Mrs. Krinsky tells most often end in sorrow, but without exception they are a record of the will of Jews, century after century, to insist on their right to be themselves before God and all the world.

title: THESE RE THE HEIRS OF HOFMANNSTHAL
description: AUSTRIAN POETRY TODAY Edited and translated by Milne Holton and Herbert Kuhner. 274 pp. New York: Schocken Books. $25.50.

title: S. A. BILLINGS WED TO MISS SALTZMAN
description: The marriage of Penelope Washburn Saltzman, a daughter of Charles Eskridge Saltzman of New York and Cynthia Myrick Saltzman of New York and East Hampton, L.I., to Stuart Abbott Billings took place yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton. The Rev. Francis Creamer performed the ceremony. Mr. Billings is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Watson Billings of Salt Lake City.

title: THE WINNERS WHO NEVER WERE
description: THE golf courses and tennis courts of planned retirement communities attract older people the way merry-go-rounds at the Shore attact pre-teens. There is something about the courses and courts that brings out a hankering for sports glory, a hankering pent up through long working years.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Eric County Farm, Hamburg, N.Y. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (716) 592-7231.

title: TORONTO COOUNCIL BACKS BOMED STDIUM PLAN
description: The City Council voted by 12-9 today, after a 13-hour debate, to support a $2 billion, waterfront development project that includes a domed sports stadium.

title: MUBARAK IN TALKS WITH U.S. OFFICIAL
description: The Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern and South Asian Affairs, Richard W. Murphy, held what he termed ''useful'' and ''productive'' discussions today with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt on American efforts to spur Arab-Israeli peace talks.

title: HOW TO TREAT 'MOTHER' WITH A LITTLE RESPECT
description: EVERYWHERE you look these days, women are having babies. Just as we post war children were part of the first boom, so too, are we now creating a boom of our own.

title: THE INDUSTRIAL BELT SEARCHES FOR WAYS TO RETOOL ITS IMAGE
description: The old manufacturing industries that powered the economy of the Middle West - industrial machinery, construction and farm equipment, and steel - never seemed to recover from the recession of 1981-82. As a result, the states of the region are pushing hard to attract new businesses and create new jobs. Minnesota and Wisconsin have slashed their income tax rates, Iowa is giving hefty subsidies to on-the-job training, and Illinois is launching a $1.3 billion program to rebuild its aging highways and sewers.

title: FREE TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE YOUNG HEMINGWAY: THREE UNPUBLISHED STORIES;

CROSSROADS: AN ANTHOLOGY
description: Pauline Snow Pauline Snow was the only beautiful girl we ever had out at the Bay. She was like an Easter Lily coming up straight and lithe and beautiful out of a dung heap. When her father and mother died she came to live with the Blodgetts. Then Art Simons started coming around to the Blodgetts' in the evenings.

title: EXPANDED ROLE SEEN
description: RECENT disclosures of dumping at military installations in New Jersey are likely to create new oversight responsibilities for the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, Christopher Daggett, the agency's regional administrator, said last week.

title:
OUTDOORS;

PURSUING BASS IN THE 'BIG LEAGUES'
description: Perhaps it's the power and fighting spirit of the largemouth bass or the sheer exhilaration of anticipating his next encounter with one that keeps Don Cagiano on the professional fishing tournament circuit.

title: Umpire's-Eye View
description: Ever wonder what a fastball streaking across the plate looks like to the umpire crouched behind it? Now, thanks to television's never-ending quest for the ultimate angle, those who tune into ABC's telecast of the Little League World Series Aug. 24 will be able to find out. Frank Rizzo, the home-plate umpire, will be wearing a tiny camera attached to his face mask, and viewers will be treated to an umpire's-eye view of the game.

title: A LOOK AT TREASURES OF MATISEE AND CHAGALL
description: FROM the outside, there is little to indicate the treasures that lie within the Union Church of Pocantico Hills, the nondenominational church attended by several generations of Rockefeller family members.

title: AN ANCIENT DISEASE ADVANCES
description: In Ethiopia, the authorized term is ''acute diarrhea.'' In the Sudan, the favored euphemism is ''severe gastroenteritis.'' Western physicians and medical workers say, however, that there is no longer any doubt that the disease that has spread across the Horn of Africa in the last nine months is cholera.

title: M.C.I. 'Abuses'
description: To the Editor:

title: ROCK STAR AND ACTOR ARE MARRIED IN MALIBU
description: The rock star Madonna and the actor Sean Penn were married Friday on a quiet bluff overlooking the Pacific Ocean.

title: SEEING THE JERUSALEM OF DAVID
description: The search for the City of David, where ancient Israel was shaped as a cohesive nation, has occupied archeologists for more than a century.

title: BLESSINGS OF THE FLESH
description: INNOCENT ECSTASY How Christianity Gave America an Ethic of Sexual Pleasure. By Peter Gardella. Illustrated. 202 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $17.95.

title: MAKING GOLF A GOOD CAUSE
description: ''WE'RE always looking for new ideas and new ways of generating money for the children's hospital,'' said Marcie Rosenberg of Great Neck.

title: LESSONS OF A LITTLE WAR
description: GRENADA An Eyewitness Account of the U.S. Invasion and the Caribbean History That Provoked It. By Hugh O'Shaughnessy. Illustrated. 261 pp. New York: Dodd, Mead & Company. $14.95. ''IT has been a splendid little war,'' the American Ambassador to Britain, John Hay, wrote Col.

title: TOKYO ORDERS EXPANDED &$& Inspections
description: The Japanese Transport Ministry expanded its inspection program for the country's fleet of Boeing 747 jetliners today, ordering airlines to look for defects in the rear pressure bulkheads of relatively old planes.

title: YAZ FAN, YANKEE HITTER
description: HE was the odd man out in the dormitory at the University of Miami on that October afternoon in 1978. Most of the students were sitting in front of the large television screen rooting for the Yankees, but Mike Pagliarulo was pulling for the ''Sawks'' in his colorful Boston accent.

title: LAYERS OF HELL IN THE CITY
description: WAITING FOR THE END OF THE WORLD By Madison Smartt Bell. 322 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: MT. KISCO DISPUTES NEW PIPE
description: THE village of Mount Kisco is refusing to replace a deteriorated water pipe, insisting instead that six homeowners in Bedford pay an estimated $100,000 to replace it.

title: MANCHILD COMING OF AGE
description: MY YOUNGEST SON, MARK, has his suits and jackets fitted with extra care, because, 5 feet tall, he weighs more than 170 pounds and is built like a padded fire hydrant. He is dieting to fight that image, though, and has 27 Special Olympics awards on his wall to prove it, right beside life-size posters of Michael Jackson, Kenny Baker and Barbara Mandrell. Mark is a powerful swimmer, and five of the awards are for first place in the category.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about tree houses misstated the availability of a book by David Stiles. ''The Tree House Book,'' published by Avon Books at $7.95, remains in print.

title: JETS FACE PROBLEM ON RUNNING BACKS
description: Coach Joe Walton tonight continued the task of figuring which five running backs would make the Jets' roster.

title: Cable TV
description: One old Hollywood movie on cable that goes down as gently as whipped cream is ''No Man of Her Own'' (1932), with Clark Gable and Carole Lombard. It's showing on Tuesday at 10:05 A.M. on WTBS.

title: BLACK AIRMEN RECALL WAR ROLE
description: IT TOOK a war - World War II - for Roy LaGrone of Somerset to feel he was being treated like any other man.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 2 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 2 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 2 P.M.) Mets vs. Pirates, at Pittsburgh. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Basketball Stroh's Rucker Pro Summer League Playoffs, semifinal game, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, West 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, 5 P.M. Lite/NBA Pro-Am All-Star Summer Classic, at Nat Holman Gymnasium, City College, 138th Street and Convent Avenue, 1 P.M. Women's game featuring Nancy Lieberman, Pam and Paula McGee, followed by men's all-star game with Gus and Ray Williams, James Bailey, Ken Bannister, Roy Hinson and Rodney McCray. Bicycling Coors International Classic, California to Colorado, final day of race, Harlem Bicycle Classic, at Marcus Garvey Park, 120th Street to 124th Street, Madison and Fifth Avenues, 1:30 P.M. Nelson Vails, the Olympic silver medalist, is expected to compete. Boxing Juan Meza, champion vs. Guadalupe (Lupe) Pintor, 12 rounds, for the World Boxing Council superbantamweight title at Mexico City. This is the second defense for Meza since he dethroned Jaime Garza last November. His record is 43-6 with 35 knockouts. Pintor, former W.B.C. bantamweight champion, is 53-7-2 with 41 knockouts. (Television - Channel 2, 4:30 P.M.) Football Raiders vs. Washington Redskins, at Los Angeles. (Television -Channel 4, 1 P.M.). Golf Buick Open, at Grand Blanc, Mich., final round (Television -ESPN, 4 P.M.) Ladies PGA Master Card Invitational, at Knollwood Country Club, Elmsford, N.Y. Final round of 54-hole tournament.

title: Going Like 90 on 90th
description: It was his birthday, so Emanuel Bradley did what he has been doing on his birthday for years. He went out for a few holes of golf, 90 of them to be exact.

title: NUMBER OF FARMS IN NATION CONTINUES A 50-YEAR DECLINE
description: The number of American farms, continuing a 50-year decline, fell by 43,770 over the past year and by 147,880 since 1980, the Agriculture Department says.

title: TWO DISSENTING VIEWS
description: Hilda Bary missed the point.

title: TEMPORARIES ALSO GROW
description: AT the end of each academic year more than a third of the professors at Illinois State University, a vast 128-year-old public university in Normal, in the center of the state, lose their jobs. They are not dismissed; the contracts for their one-year temporary positions simply run out. And for them, the end of summer marks the beginning of a scramble to reserve new teaching positions.

title: DRUG TESTING FOR TEACHERS STIRRING CONCERN
description: MEDICAL technology that can measure minute amounts of chemicals in the body has raised disturbing questions on Long Island about whether teachers should be subjected to tests for illicit drug use as a condition for employment or job advancement.

title: TEACHING JUDAISM TO INTERFAITH COUPLES
description: The students stared at the the unfamiliar Hebrew letters on the blackboard as Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel, their instructor, led them through the lesson.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Fernando Martin, a 23-year-old Spanish basketball star, said he had decided to play for the Nets this season. Martin, who was drafted by the Nets, has been with the Real Madrid club since 1981. . . . Tom Byers, the winner of the Fifth Avenue Mile in 1982, has entered the 1985 race Sept. 28 along with Ray Flynn, the Irish record holder.

title: I HOME-SHARING, COMPATIBILITY IS VITAL
description: FACED with rising costs of renting an apartment or owning a home, elderly people, especially those with fixed incomes, are turning to an alternative - home-sharing, or matched living.

title: WHEN CONGRESS GOES HOME;   Connecticut: Beans, Boats
description: At first, this summer's recess was to be a vacation for Connecticut's second district Congressman, Sam Gejdenson, a time for him to look after his wife, Karen, who was recuperating from surgery, and his two children, Mia, 5, and Ari, 3.

title: An Accommodation
description: The Speer of the House of Representatives, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., regularly turns down invitations to appear on early morning television talk shows. ''Why get up at dawn to spend five minutes on the air?'' asked Christopher J. Matthews, chief spokesman for the Massachusetts Democrat.

title: SLOW CITY WAGE TALKS CALLED BANE OF BUDGETS
description: The failure of labor negotiators to produce timely wage settlements has hampered New York City's efforts to produce realistic budgets, according to the Citizens Budget Commission.

title: EDWARD PILE WED TO MISS JOHNSON
description: Jacqueline Strong Johnson and Edward Birchall Pile were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Newport, R.I., by the Rev. D. Lorne Coyle.

title: FILLING THE GAPS IN MEDICARE COVERAGE
description: MEDICARE, the Federal health insurance program for people over age 65, has gone a long way toward absorbing some of the health care costs of the elderly. But a major portion of those costs - close to 60 percent - are still borne by the patients themselves, either out-of-pocket or through extra insurance purchased privately.

title: A South African Who Will Refuse to Fight
description: The South African Government recently amended its Defense Act so that in the future white male citizens up to the age of 55 can be called for military service.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ON April 16, 1982, 20-year-old Alan Mondel of Elizabeth was fatally shot by robbers while waiting for food at a Burger King on Long Island. But his written words were not allowed to die. Helen Mondel, his mother, won't let them - no matter what it costs her in time and money.

title: RUBEN BLADES TURNS HIS TALENTS TO MOVIES
description: ''I've always believed that music can do more than offer an escape - it can help bring people together to change their lives,'' the Panamanian-born salsa star Ruben Blades declared recently.

title: TEAM GETS A DREAM TRIP
description: AS the smallest school in the Shore Line Conference in the eastern part of the state, Westbrook High's teams draw from only about 100 young men. That is about half the talent pool at the next smallest school in the conference, Old Lyme, and about a tenth of the number of young men at Guilford High.

title: CARNIVAL BEFORE A LIFELONG LENT
description: THIS REAL NIGHT By Rebecca West. 266 pp. New York: Viking. $16.95.

title: THE P.L.O. IN EXILE
description: ON A CRISP DAY LAST FEBRUARY, A SMALL group of men, once bitter enemies, sat around King Hussein's dining room table in the Nadwa Palace, in the Jordanian capital of Amman.

title: 2 NEW JERSEYANS SHOWING ABROAD
description: INVARIABLY, artists who have shown in Europe report that, with its centuries of tapestry tradition, it has a climate of acceptance toward textile art not paralleled in the United States. This summer, two New Jersey artists are having the opportunity to participate in exhibitions there.

title: Modest Comfort Bare Majority
description: For some years now shorts have been acceptable for American men, even stylish at times, in hot weather. Legend traces this good sense to the tropical reaches of the British empire, where shorts were military uniform and eventually adopted by civilians.

title: MARK SWANK ENGAGED TO CYNTHIA WHITMAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Cutler Whitman 3d of Katonah, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Graham Whitman, to Mark Frederick Swank, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Bruce Swank of Rye, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Oct. 5. Miss Whitman, a saleswoman for Kneedler Fauchere, a home furnishings concern in Denver, graduated from the Rippowam Cisqua School, Dana Hall and the University of Vermont.

title: U.S. COLLEGES SPREAD IN EUROPE
description: WHEN New England College purchased an 18th-century manor house in Sussex, England, in 1970, it was one of only a handful of American institutions of higher education to establish a campus overseas. But now the college, whose home campus is in Henniker, N.H., faces competition from several other colleges with campuses in England. As its director, Dr. Eric Nummala, said, ''American institutions have gone from just study abroad to study abroad with their own facilities.''

title: STATE'S FIRST STEEL-FRAME HOUSES ON WAY
description: AT Regents Square, a community of new patio houses just off Old Georges Road in South Brunswick, developers are taking an approach to house construction that is a new departure for New Jersey. The 120 two- and-three bedroom houses that the Berkeley Realty Group of Millburn is building there will all have steel frames.

title: THERESE ROSENBLATT EGAGED TO MARRY
description: Therese Sarah Rosenblatt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Rosenblatt of Washington, and Marshall Sonenshine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Sonenshine of Pompano Beach, Fla., plan to be married Sept. 29.

title: CELLULAR PHONES MAKE OFFICES OF CARS
description: IT is becoming a familiar sight along Connecticut highways - a business executive with the steering wheel in one hand and a cellular mobile telephone in the other, dealing, as an ad has put it, while he is wheeling.

title: Hanoi Turns Over Remains of 26
description: Vietnam took a step last week toward improving relations with the United States. It turned over the remains of 26 people who may have been among the 2,464 American servicemen missing when the Vietnam war ended in 1974.

title: 'CARPENTER'S GOTHIC'
description: To the Editor:

title: COCO BELLIS IS MARRIED TO DOUGLAS M. IRELAND
description: Courtney Demarest Bellis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Latimer Bellis of Bedminster, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Douglas Merritt Ireland, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Elwood Fremont Ireland Jr. of Southport, Conn. Canon John Morrow performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Gladstone, N.J.

title: CONNER SEEKS TO REGAIN CUP
description: Dennis Conner, the West Coast yachtsman whose 12-Meter Liberty lost the America's Cup to the Australians in 1983, thinks of his experience in sailing the way an airplane pilot measures his: in terms of hours on the job.

title: Headliners;   A Wife's Death
description: A Criminal Court judge in Queens last week dismissed murder and manslaughter charges against Kuert Semel, who said he had suffocated his terminally ill wife after she took an overdose of sleeping pills and begged him to kill her. The decision was not an endorsement of euthanasia.

title: A SMOKING BAN IS BAD BUSINESS
description: NASSAU COUNTY has on the table the most stringent no-smoking regulation in this country - mandated no-smoking sections in food-service establishments. Restaurants will suffer greatly from these unfair restrictions. We object strongly to the unfair burden it would place on restaurateurs trying to do business and serve customers in this area.

title: DOLPHINS' NEW PLAY: WAITNING FOR MARINO
description: IN the reception area outside Don Shula's office, a poster of Dan Marino is taped to the wall, across from the secretary's desk and just above the copying machine. And, oh, what a handsome guy he is. Curly hair. Bright blue eyes. Big smile.

title: STEADY INCREASE IS SEEN IN U.S. FARM YEILDS
description: Five years ago, in the wake of a worldwide production slump that embraced much of the 1970's, many farm economists concluded that a half-century of steady increases in agricultural productivity had been broken and that new scientific breakthroughs were needed to feed a rapidly rising population.

title: MISS BLACKMAR BECOMES BRIDE
description: Elizabeth Jean Blackmar, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Blackmar of Armonk, N.Y., and Montauk, L.I., was married yesterday to George Bell Adams 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Adams Jr. of New York and Old Field, L.I. The Rev. Henry E. Greene performed the ceremony at the North Greenwich Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Required Reading;   Arms and the Loser
description: Excerpts from a report to his constituents from Representative Thomas J. Downey, Democrat of Suffolk, Aug. 5:

title: THE ART OF PHOTOGRAPHING THE FACE
description: THE human face is as mysterious as it is revealing. This is what makes it spellbinding for photographers.

title: LABELING FOR FOOD TO BE BROADENED
description: The Food and Drug Administration, in a reversal of longstanding policy, is planning to allow food manufacturers to include statements about the health benefits of various foods and food products on their labels.

title: COMPANY MERGERS UP
description: CONNECTICUT companies bought more than twice as many out-of state publicly held corporations in 1984 as they did in 1983, according to a national survey of acquisitions and mergers.

title: A MIND LOST BY HANDFULS
description: ANOTHER NAME FOR MADNESS By Marion Roach. 241 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: AN IMPRESSIVE CAREER
description: About 40 years ago a young man appeared in various New York clubs, eager to sharpen an obvious talent for the game. Under the tutelage of the late Bob Appleyard, he became a brilliant cardplayer and was on the way to a unique bridge career.

title: Air Force Abandons Berkshire Antennas
description: The Army Corps of Engineers has been instructed to abandon efforts to buy land in the Berkshire Hills for a $22.7 million communications antenna complex because the project has been canceled.

title: SHOES THAT SELL - MADE IN AMERICA
description: IN fashion-conscious Milan, teen-age gangs have found a new target, an Italian newspaper reported recently. Instead of robbing people for money, the hoodlums strip them of their shoes - Timberland shoes, to be precise, made in the U.S.A.

title: Judge Rules Out New York Runoffs
description: Ever since a state law providing for runoffs in New York City primary elections was enacted in 1972, many black and Hispanic leaders have contended that it discriminated against minority candidates and voters. A Federal judge last week agreed.

title: Brooklyn Garbage Plant Approved
description: New York City has not fired up a new garbage incineration plant since 1961, largely because of protests from those who would live or work anywhere near such a facility. But now the old Brooklyn Navy Yard has gotten the city's final approval to be home for a state-of-the-art garbage-disposal plant whose 500-foot smokestack would be one of the tallest structures in the borough.

title: HARD TIMES IN THE MAIL-ORDER POETRY BUSINESS
description: NOT a season known for lots of laughs, tax time nonetheless offers the poet its share of amusements. This realization came to me not a moment too soon recently, when - having lost all plausible hope for a further delay or extension - I finally resolved to light a bonfire of the receipts and forms and canceled checks that buried my desk. Because I made over $200 in 1984 through the writing of poems, I was required to file a Schedule C - ''Profit or (Loss) From Business of Profession (Sole Proprietorship).'' This is the same form you would fill out if you operated a shoe repair or a greengrocer's, ran a shop that sold handbags or pasta or cameras or martial regaia. I've been filling out a Schedule C for some years now but this was the first time I saw the potential humor in a poet's applying its language to his own queer occupation. The form refers to accounting methods and bad debts, to inventory (''Let's see, I've got three poems I haven't yet sent out to magazines, or four if you count the one that's missing a middle quartrain'') and depreciation (''in retrospect, I suppose my 'Ode to Lunch' probably isn't imperishable'').

title: NIGHT COLLEGE: THE TWILIGHT ZONE
description: INSTITUTIONS really know how to keep secrets. Locked in anonymous files, piled into an overflowing desk drawer, or swept away by the janitorial staff, evidence can be well concealed. And so I should never have learned about the underside to institutional life, the Night Shift, had I not agreed to teach an evening course at the college where I had taught full-time for over a decade.

title:
NUMISMATICS;

AUCTION '85 TOP $9 MILLION
description: Atwo-day sale conducted at Auction '85 indicates that the rare coin market is alive and well. The sale was held in Chicago late last month and conducted by four leading coin auction companies. Two thousand lots were gaveled down for more than $8.3 million and the 10-percent buyer's fee brought the total to nearly $9.2 million.

title: DR. CARACCIO IS BRIDE OF ALAN D. CENTOFANTI
description: Dr. Babette B. Caraccio, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sal L. Caraccio of Rye, N.Y., was married at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection there yesterday to Alan Daniel Centofanti, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph D. Centofanti of North Providence, R.I. Msgr. Daniel V. Flynn, assisted by the Rev. Joseph Santurri, performed the ceremony.

title: Q and A
description: Question:I am a 35-year-old professor with a one-semester leave to come next spring. How can I find out about women's wilderness groups and extended hiking trips in this country and abroad? - R. B., Cambridge, Mass. Answer:Among sources of information is the international group called Outward Bound, which, because it is a nonprofit, educational organization, refers to its programs as courses. Its backpacking, mountaineering, sailing and other outdoor activities include courses for women only, some for the 35 and over age group. Tuition generally costs from $50 to $90 a day, including meals and accommodations but not travel to the course. There are about 25 Outward Bound schools in Europe, Australia, Asia and other parts of the world, and some of them, according to a spokesman at the national headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., offer expeditions specifically for women. The national office expects to complete the catalogue for its 1986 programs in the United States by the end of this month. (There are five Outward Bound centers in the U.S. and two in Canada.) It also has some details about courses in other countries and can supply the addresses of Outward Bound centers abroad. More information is available from Outward Bound, 384 Field Point Road, Greenwich, Conn. 06830 (203-661-0797 or, out of state, 800-243-8520).

title: GUESTS ADD DRAMA TO FRESH AIR CAMPGROUND
description: Kevin Chisholm sat down cautiously on a rock and looked out toward the lake. ''That was fun,'' he announced with a smile. ''I like that game.''

title: THE MAGICAL SUMMER OF TRACK'S RECORD BREAKERS
description: THE LOOK on Steve Cram's face was one of chagrin as he jogged a victory lap before a hometown crowd in Gateshead, England. For the first time in the 1985 season, he had failed an attempt at a world record. In cold and very windy conditions he'd fallen just short of Sebastian Coe's record for 1,000 meters. Cram's look was because he knew that the magic that had already brought him three of track and field's toughest records in a space of 20 days was still there. There were more records to come.

title: UNION AT TV STATION URGING BOYCOTT BY VIEWERS
description: Until recently, when Joyce Lopes watched television, she often turned to Channel 6, WLNE-TV, the only local television station based here.

title: EDINBURGH FESTIVAL GETS PRINCETON PLAY
description: A YOUNG white actress stands in a darkened theater, one of 12 performers in a circle.

title: BETH ISRAEL CLINICS UNABLE TO RENEW THEIR LEASES
description: A Beth Israel Medical Center clinic for alcoholics has closed and a Beth Israel clinic for heroin addicts is looking for new quarters because their leases for space in an East Village building have not been renewed, officials of the hospital say.

title: Challenging Japan In Product Quality
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

PHOTOS THAT CAPTURE TWO WAYS OF LIFE
description: IN the history of documentary photography, there have been surprisingly few professionals who have turned their cameras on their own kind. It is far more common for the photographer to be an outsider who records the details of slum life, mining towns or the rodeo, often with great sensitivity and compassion but nevertheless at a certain emotional distance from his or her subjects.

title: FUNDAMENTALISM STIRRING IN MALAYSIA
description: With national elections expected early next year, political leaders deplore what they see as the growing influence of Islamic fundamentalism on public life. The Government has served notice that it will not tolerate the trend. ''Religious extremism could threaten the very fabric of life and destroy the very success that we have achieved thus far,'' Musa Hitam, a Moslem who is Deputy Prime Minister and Home Affairs Minister, recently told foreign journalists.

title: CORPORATE TEACHING HELP DROPS
description: WHEN a professor of business law at Hampton University, a small black college in Hampton, Va., took ill last spring, Hamner Williams stepped in to teach his class for six weeks. But the 56-year-old Mr. Williams, now entering his second year of teaching at Hampton, is not a member of the faculty.

title: BABIES' SEATS ARE AIR SAFETY ISSUE
description: The Federal Aviation Administration requires that every airline passenger wear a seat belt during takeoffs and landings - everyone, that is, except children under the age of 2.

title: Marcos's Enemies Lose a Round
description: In a move that may cause him embarrassment but not likely unemployment, foes of Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos introduced a resolution last week calling for his impeachment. The charges, signed by 56 of the 57 opposition members of the National Assembly, allege that President Marcos's wife, Imelda, used his ''ill-gotten wealth'' to acquire mansions and estates on Long Island and in London and Rome, along with two office buildings in Manhattan valued at more than $150 million, a six-story East Side townhouse and other properties.

title: A GUIDE FOR STUDENTS WHO WORK
description: FOR the last three years, Anthony Bruno, a pharmacist who had earned his undergraduate degree almost three decades ago, has been taking classes at Queens College that will enable him to become a certified high school science teacher in New York State. It hasn't been easy, as his experience in last spring's semester demonstrated. ''I assisted a certified teacher from 8 A.M. to noon to fulfill my student-teaching requirement, then worked a regular day, which meant that I didn't get home for dinner until after 8 P.M.,'' Mr. Bruno said.

title: REAGAN RIGHTS POLICIES ASSAILED BY DEMOCRATS
description: Representative Mary Rose Oakar said today that the Reagan Administration had a ''callous disregard and contempt for civil rights'' both in this country and in South Africa.

title: MUSIC: BONNIE RAITT SINGS AT THE RITZ
description: BONNIE RAITT, who appeared before an adoring crowd Wednesday night at the Ritz, poses a fascinating example - for observers, that is; probably painful for her - of a popular artist torn between commerciality and what she loves to do best.

title: SIDNEY A. VON LUTHER, FORMER STATE SENATOR
