description: Sidney Albert von Luther, a two-term Democratic State Senator from Harlem in the early 1970's, died of cardio-pulmonary arrest Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and had been in ill health for several years.

title: SUIT DRAWS ATTENTION TO COACHING FOR EXAMS
description: A court order on Friday barring a company that prepares students for college-entrance tests from using facsimiles of ''secure,'' copyrighted questions owned by the Educational Testing Service has focused fresh attention on the issue of coaching.

title: CHESS MADNESS
description: I was overwhelmed by the complexity imposed by such precocious talent upon the relationship of the chess prodigy and his father.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEAR RAFE. By Rolando Hinojosa. (Arte Publico Press, University of Houston, University Park, Houston, Tex. 77004, Paper, $7.50.) Just as surely as Yoknapatawpha County, Macondo and Lake Wobegon belong to other literary settlers, Klail City, Tex., down in the Rio Grande Valley, is Rolando Hinojosa country.

title: BARGEMUSIC: REFLECTION OF A DREAM
description: It sits moored in the East River, its presence unassuming. In the shadow of the Brooklyn Bridge which towers overhead, it seems small, even humble. Were it not for a carved wooden sign stating simply ''Bargemusic, Ltd.,'' passers-by might not even notice the deceptively plain white barge on the shores of Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn.

title: HOUSING FOR DOWNTOWN GLEN COVE
description: Efforts to resuscitate the Northstage Theater in Glen Cove, L.I., failed last year when the 450-seat playhouse, which had most recently done duty as a dinner theater, was closed. But the 1.4-acre site on School Street where the theater stands is far from finished.

title: CHEESE IN RETAIL STORES IS TAINTED, CONCERN SAYS
description: General Foods Corporation, which has issued a nationwide recall of its Liederkranz cheese, says some of the contaminated cheese may have reached consumers.

title: Mystery Deaths At Baltimore Zoo
description: SOMETHING is killing the rare Angolan giraffes at the Baltimore Zoo, and until the mystery is solved, no more will be imported.

title: GUERRILLAS IN COLOMBIA SAID TO ABDUCT AMERICAN
description: An American oil executive who had been in Colombia just three months was reportedly kidnapped Friday night by leftist guerrillas, who abducted him blocks from his home in a wealthy Bogota suburb. No terms for his release were immediately issued.

title: YANKEES TRIUMPH: GAIN ON BLUE JAYS
description: The scoring was over with early, but there was tension just the same because the visitors kept knocking, but again and again they were stopped. The scoreboard, showing the Blue Jays falling down, then up, then down, became the focus. When Toronto fell down for good, the game in New York came to a stop.

title: LAURELEI LEE IS WED TO SEAN C. LINDSAY
description: At the Temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in Washington yesterday, Laurelei Lee, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Franklin Lee of Short Hills, N.J., was married to Sean Christopher Lindsay, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Rao Humphreys Lindsay of Lanham, Md. Franklin D. Richards, president of the temple, performed the ceremony.

title: The Only Weapons Against AIDS
description: AIDS is going to be with the world a long while. How should the institutions of society deal with those who fall victim to the cruel disease?

title: PILOT KILLED IN CRASH OF AD PLANE
description: A single-engine plane towing an advertising banner plunged into the sea about 200 yards off Manhattan Beach in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, killing the pilot and narrowly missing a Coast Guard boat, Coast Guard officials said.

title: LETTING IN 'LATCHKEY CHILDREN'
description: A TASK FORCE in a Long Island town discovers that nearly half its elementary-school pupils live in homes where there is no parent to look after them on their return from school.

title: Moped Rebellion
description: WHEN town officials of Block Island, R.I., began talking in May 1984 about tyranny and rebellion, it was not high taxes that had them angry. It was mopeds.

title: ANISA MEHDI HAS WEDDING
description: Anisa Marie Mehdi and Peter Warren Zimmermann were married yesterday at the Houghton Memorial Chapel at Wellesley College, from which the bride graduated in 1978. The Rev. Dr. Raymond Gibson, a Congregational minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Topics;   Modest Comfort The Safest Seats
description: The airline seats in greatest demand these days are in the back of the plane. The reason, of course, is that 29 survivors of the recent Delta Airlines crash and all four survivors of the Japan Air Lines disaster on Monday were seated in the tail section.

title: CAUSES OF HUNGER
description: We are writing in response to J. McKenna's letter, which contends that ignorance of basic nutrition and unwise shopping help keep people hungry (Letters, July 21, in response to ''Hunger in America,'' June 16).

title: OTTAWA
description: It used to be said that the most exciting thing about Ottawa was the train to Montreal. The Canadian capital still moves at a less dramatic pace than most American cities, but it has made a virtue of its tidiness.

title:
THE YOUNG HEMINGWAY: THREE UNPUBLISHED STORIES;

THE ASH HEEL'S TENDON
description: IN A FORMER UNENlightened time there was a saying ''In vino veritas,'' which meant roughly that under the influence of the cup that queers a man sloughed off his dross of reserve and conventionality and showed the true metal of his self. The true self might be happy, might be poetic, might be morbid, or might be extremely pugnacious. In the rude nomenclature of our forefathers these revealed conditions were denominated in order - laughing, sloppy crying and fighting jags.

title: S.M.U. GEVEN PROBATION
description: Southern Methodist University, the preseason favorite to win the Southwest Conference football championship, will spend the next three years on National Collegiate Athletic Association probation because of recruiting violations committed from 1981 to 1984.

title: POLITICIANS RUSHING TO RIDE BROOKLYN'S WAVE OF CHANGE
description: A billboard on the right-center field fence at Ebbets Field used to challenge the Brooklyn Dodgers, ''Hit Sign, Win Suit.'' The sign belonged to a Pitkin Avenue haberdasher, Abe Stark, who also happened to be the borough president during the Dodgers' last days in Brooklyn.

title: TOURNEY DRAWS TENNIS ACES
description: BRUNO ORESAR sounded disappointed. ''I'd like to meet him again,'' he said, referring to Boris Becker, the 17-year-old West German who astonished the tennis world by winning the Wimbledon title last month.

title: 21 SAID TO DIE IN CHINA MINE
description: Twenty-one miners have been killed in an explosion in a coal pit in southern China, a Hong Kong newspaper reported today.

title: CALIFORNIA GROWS HER OWN CUISINE
description: Florida has oranges and stone crabs, New York, lox and bagels. Louisiana has Cajun-style blackfish and Creole gumbo. Maine has lobster. Only California, with its customary modesty, claims to have invented, along with France and Italy, an entire cuisine.

title: OCTOBER WEDDING FOR D. R. MERRICK AND MISS SMOLER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Avrum David Smoler of New York City and Pound Ridge, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Jane Smoler, to Daniel Richardson Merrick, the son of Mrs. Charles Nelson Gregg Jr. of McLean, Va., and Dr. John Vaughan Merrick 4th of Puyallup, Wash. An October wedding is planned.

title:
WEEK IN BUSINESS;

ECONOMY STUMBLES EARLY IN THE 2D HALF
description: The economy faltered again, increasing worries that second-half growth will not be nearly enough to cancel out the near-stagnant first half. Despite Reagan Administration insistence that full-year growth will be 4 percent, some analysts are already revising downward their predictions. The latest indicators seem to bear them out: Retail sales, which helped carry the earlier recovery, were up a scant four-tenths of 1 percent in July. Business sales in June plunged 2.1 percent, and inventories rose four-tenths of 1 percent, pushing the inventory-to-sales ratio up to 1.38.

title:
DINING OUT;

SPICY TOUCH OF JAMAICA IN YONKERS
description: TRAVELERS and other adverturers yearning for ackee and codfish, beef patties, curried goat, pickled cod, callaloo, escovitch; subtle flavors from such spices as ginger, cinnamon, allspice and countless peppers in a seemingly endless range of flavors and degrees of heat; the patter of patois; and perhaps a glass of Appleton Special Gold on the rocks can sashay into The Jamaican, enjoy some island hospitality and have a mini-vacation without leaving home. The place is as comfortable for entire families as it is for couples, all of whom come for the food, the atmosphere, the music.

title: STRIKE AT 2 PAPERS POSSIBLE
description: Newsroom and advertising employees at The Philadelphia Inquirer and The Daily News have authorized union leaders to call a strike if a contract agreement is not reached with Philadelphia Newspapers Inc. by Sept. 1. The vote by the union, Local 10 of The Newspaper Guild, was Thursday night.

title: HOW PROFESSORS SEE THEIR FUTURE
description: COLLEGE faculty members are deeply troubled and anxious about their current status and prospects for the future. That is one of the conclusions to be drawn from a study of undergraduate education in America begun 18 months ago by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching. In preparing its report, the foundation surveyed more than 5,000 faculty members on campuses from coast to coast. Thousands of hours were spent talking to college presidents, faculty members and students.

title: 'SELLING OF L.I.': FURTHER RESPONSE
description: The concern expressed by Linda Martin about the devastation of Long Island's environment was commendable. I am curious as to just how far she has considered what this article has begun to address, however.

title: FEE-FI-FO-FUM TARTARS
description: Ernest Gill's article might have mentioned that John F. Kennedy's famous remark ''Ich bin ein Berliner'' is actually a grammatical gaff.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: HAILE SELASSIE'S WAR: The Italian-Ethiopian Campaign, 1935-1941. By Anthony Mockler. (Random House, $24.95.) For much of the Italian-Ethiopian war of 1935-41, Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia was either a struggling ruler - fighting the Italian invaders as well as rivals and defectors among his countrymen - or an almost helpless exile in England.

title: Why It's Only the South African Embassy
description: To the Editor:

title: MINORITY FACULTY: BLEAK FUTURE
description: INFUSED with the spirit of the time, Henry Gates Jr. entered graduate school in 1973, confident that within a decade or two, 10 percent of the nation's tenured professors would be black. However, as graduate-school enrollment among blacks and other minorities has declined over the last few years, Dr. Gates, a professor of English and African studies at Cornell University and the first black to receive a Mellon Fellowship, has seen his optimism ebb. ''When I started graduate school,'' he said recently, ''there was a general atmosphere in the academy encouraging minorities to become scholars. But that has all disappeared. It's depressing and distressing.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about tax exemptions on real estate in New York State misstated the worth of exemptions granted in 1983 to religious organizations for residential property. They amounted to $32.7 million.

title:
THE YOUNG HEMINGWAY: THREE UNPUBLISHED STORIES;

AN INTRODUCTION
GENIAL SIBERIAN PARTY LEADER A MAN IN GORBACHEV'S MOLD
description: The Siberian villagers had complaints about salty drinking water and about a shortage of bricks, not to mention poor-quality cosmetics and the dying reindeer herds.

title: ZIMBABWE SAID TO HOLD MEMBERS OF OPPOSITION
description: The opposition leader Joshua Nkomo said today that six senior members of his party, all city officials in Bulawayo, were detained Friday but that at least two were later released.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: COUSINS TO THE KUDZU. By William Doxey. (Louisiana State University, $16.95.) In 1933 Dr. Eugene Spaulding comes to Oughton, a small Southern town in which ''prototypical'' seems to be written on everyone's forehead; 200-odd pages later, he dies.

title: J-51 RULE CHANGE BRINGS CONFUSION
description: AN afterthought by the State Legislature late in this year's session has changed the rent-regulation rules for thousands of apartments in New York City that were created in older residential and nonresidential buildings under the J-51 tax-incentive program. But city officials say the new law has raised almost as many questions as it attempted to answer.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in last week's Westchester Weekly section about the Holocaust memorial in White Plains misidentified the landscape architects. The company's name is Armand Benedek & Associates.

title: DON'T FORGET FISH FOR THE GRILL
description: THESE days a good steak is as likely to come from a fish as a steer. In summer, with barbecuing so popular, many people are finding that a thick slice of meaty fish, seared on a hot grill, is as satisfying and appealing as a traditional porterhouse.

title: SUSTAINING THE GIFT IN SUMMER
description: ABOUT 15 children between the ages of 5 and 7 stand transfixed in front of a popcorn popper as its sizzles and thuds punctuate the mind-expanding electronic music of Philip Glass that spills out into the corridor. It is the close of a long day of art, drama, computers, gymnastics and storytelling in a summer program for the gifted at Columbia University's Teachers College. A visitor gets the feeling that the youngsters are calculating the velocity and patterns of the flying puffs of corn.

title:
ANTIQUES;

ANNANDALE: A REAL COUNTRY SHOW
description: ALTHOUGH visitors to the ''Antiques in August'' show and sale will not be admitted until 8 A.M. next Sunday, trucks, vans and station wagons laden with antiques will begin making their way off Route 22 and Interstate 78 toward this small town before daybreak.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

CONSERVATIVE CHIEF
description: The new executive director of the Federated Conservationists of Westchester County, Zelle Andrews, has no interest in preserving at least one thing - the tradition set by her two immediate predecessors of leaving the post to attend law school.

title: CHESS MADNESS
description: I am 10 years old, and I recognized, in the father who wrote the article on the chess prodigy, my own father.

title: CHANGING THE PLAN
description: When condominium projects were a new form of residential development, many early buyers found that they were relatively powerless if a builder changed his plans and built later sections of a development in a quite different character. Experience taught them that protection from such changes had to be built into the sales agreement, and many contracts now require buyers' approval of plan changes.

title: WITH A BURST OF COLOR AND A SPARKLE
description: CHILDREN, AS EVERY parent knows well, are keenly attuned to trends, clothing and otherwise. They know what they want to wear, and what they don't. A child's wardrobe is usually a mix - if not a match - of many things, and the newest fall offerings for this closet collection include Jacquard and whimsically patterned sweaters, brilliantly colored coats and jackets, jumpers, overalls and fancy pants for dress-up.

title: STATE U. PROFESSOR WHO LABELED ZIONISM RACIST IS DENIED TENURE
description: A professor at the State University at Stony Brook, L.I. who was involved in a controversy two years ago because a course he taught equated Zionism with racism has been denied tenure and will have to leave the university next year.

title:
ANTIQUES;

SHOW TO AID NEW LONDON MUSEUM
description: A CARAVAN of 175 dealers will gather Saturday to set up displays for the 22d annual New London Antiques Festival. The outdoor show, a benefit for the Lyman Allen Museum, is held each year on a hilltop on the Connecticut College campus. The exhibits, all for sale, will include country and formal furniture, from cradles to cupboards, and decorative accessories from early blown-glass tumblers to 19th-century folk art.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

THE LAMENTS OF AN UNHANDY MAN
KEEP MAIL ORDER OUT OF TAX COLLECTION
description: NOT MANY people have a clear idea of what a use tax is, and yet this tax may shortly enter the lives of most Americans.

title: JODY LIVECCHI IS MARRIED TO JOSEPH D. JOHNSON JR.
description: The Congregational Church of Manhasset, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Jody LiVecchi, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. LiVecchi of Plainfield, L.I., to Joseph Damon Johnson Jr., the son of Mr. Johnson of Tarrytown, N.Y., and the late Merle Smith Johnson. The Rev. Thomas Lamont performed the ceremony.

title: WAS MOSCOW OUR REAL TARGET?
description: ATOMIC DIPLOMACY: HIROSHIMA AND POTSDAM The Use of the Atomic Bomb and the American Confrontation With Soviet Power. Expanded and Updated Edition. By Gar Alperovitz. 427 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Penguin Books. Paper, $7.95. WAS the detonation of the atomic bombs over Hiroshima and Nagasaki the culmination of World War II or the beginning and principal cause of the cold war? Japan was the literal target and victim, but were the bombs used primarily to send a threatening message from the United States to the Soviet Union? In 1965, 20 years after Hiroshima and in the midst of the escalating controversy over the American war in Vietnam, the first edition of this book appeared with some startling answers to these questions.

title: HOPE IS OFFERED TO THE HARD-OF-HEARING
description: MY cat, Thumbelina, has the loudest meow you ever heard. I was greeted with that meow just now as I returned home from talking with the staff of a nursing home about hearing impairment. Maybe what I have learned from my own disability will spare hard-of-hearing patients in that nursing home the frustration of not understanding and not being understood.

title: TORNADOES INJURE 35 IN SOUTH CAROLINA TOWN
description: Tornadoes slashed through three mobile home parks today, tossing children, cars and trailers into the air and injuring at least 35 people, officials said.

title: RICHARD GOTTLIEB, LESLIE BROOKSHER MARRY IN CAPITAL
description: Leslie Carter Brooksher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. K. Dane Brooksher of Washington, and Richard Eric Gottlieb, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ferdinand Gottlieb of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, where Rabbi Jay B. Heyman and the Rev. John Hatcher, an Episcopal priest, co-officiated.

title: AMANDA NORTH WEDS SCOTT WINKLER
description: The marriage of Amanda Allan North, the daughter of Cecil Jackson North Jr. of Katonah, N.Y., and Helen Tasche North of Lyme, N.H., to Scott Timothy Winkler, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond William Winkler of Coral Gables, Fla., took place yesterday. The Rev. Richard Thayer, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony at the Stanford (Calif.)

title: Continuing Case Of the Wobbles
description: American assembly lines almost always slow a bit during the summer, but this year's industrial dog days are turning out to be even more sluggish than expected.

title: GUCCI TITLES
description: To the Editor:

title: TENANTS ARE POLLED
description: APARTMENT owners in the county recently asked their tenants for opinions on a new landlord-sponsored rent proposal, and only 30 percent of the tenants responding liked it - but the landlords say that was a good response.

title: SPIRIT OVERCOMES 60's REVIEW FLAWS
description: THE nonstop energy and good cheer of ''Ticket to Ride,'' subtitled a ''Sixties' Rock 'n'

title: TWO JAILED TURKS FINISH TESTIMONY
description: An Italian court left today after taking evidence in the Netherlands and West Germany that seems to lend credence to the view that the shooting of the Pope in 1981 was the work of a Turkish terrorist group with links to the Turkish underworld and to Bulgaria.

title: Asbestos Problem In Hudson County
description: I sympathize with the fears and frustrations of Laurel Team [Opinion, Aug. 4] about the possible existence of asbestos in her Hudson County apartment. At the risk of supplying even more depressing news, I must tell her that getting relief from Hudson County is highly unlikely.

title: HEALTH HAZARDS FOR BLACKS
description: A disproportionately high number of black Americans have coronary heart disease and lung cancer compared to other population groups in the country, even though they smoke at about the same rates, according to a new study that appeared last week in The New York State Journal of Medicine. The authors, Richard Cooper and Brian E. Simmons, attributed this difference to occupational hazards and various consequences of poverty. The chart indicates that the death rate from lung cancer for black men is 40 percent higher than for white men.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

UNITING SCIENCE AND BUSINESS
description: CARICATURES can sometimes give us a clue to the nature of our problems.

title: Soft Karate Chop
description: New college football rules allow offensive linemen to use their hands more than in the past and Florida State coaches want to make sure their linemen use them well. They have engaged a karate expert to teach them the martial art.

title: Of Honeybees and Yellow Rain
description: Two years ago, a group of scientists put forward the theory that what is called yellow rain is actually the feces of honeybees and not, as the United States Government contends, the effects of a chemical weapon used by the Soviet Union in Southeast Asia. Last week, the group, which was organized by Matthew Meselson, a Harvard biologist and chemical warfare expert, offered new data that cast doubt on the accuracy of accounts of people who claim to have been witnesses or victims of the alleged chemical attacks.

title: BINGE-EATING DISEASE FOUND TO AFFECT FEW WOMEN
description: A new study of bulimia, a disorder in which binges of eating are often followed by vomiting, indicates the problem is serious among a small percentage of American women but is not so prevalent as had been believed.

title: MUSIC: BRAZIL'S MARTINHO DA VILA AND SAMBA
description: S.O.B.'s, the Varick Street club and restaurant, has done much to champion Brazilian culture in New York, but its presentation of Martinho da Vila for four nights last week - the run ended on Friday - counts among its most notable contributions. Mr. da Vila is one of Brazil's most important samba composers and singers, and the performance that he and his nine-piece band offered at the early show on Thursday truly validated an old cliche: this really >was Carnival in August.

title: A 2-YEAR HANDS-ON AG SCHOOL
description: THIS summer, Bill Clymer is taming colts at a ranch in Polson, Mont. Donna Starr is processing milk into yogurt at a small farm in Westfield, Vt. And Laurie Chrysostom is teaching underprivileged high school students in Danby, Vt., how to hoe the soil, how to use a map and compass and how to trim a sheep's hooves. All three graduated in June from Sterling College, nestled in this state's Green Mountains. Their work is an extension of skills learned at Sterling, a two-year private college that provides courses in agriculture, forestry and wildlife management with hands-on fieldwork.

title: CHESS MADNESS
description: The article about Josh Waitzkin, chess prodigy, brought to mind the recent biographical sketch about Carl Icahn, published at the time of his bid to take over Phillips Petroleum.

title: RULING WEIGHED IN HOMELESS CASE
description: FROM June to December last year, Mary Richards and her two teen-age children lived in seven different locations in six different motels around the county. But while her addresses may have borne the names Peekskill Motel or Sheraton Inn, Mrs. Richards has always considered Port Chester her home.

title: LAKEHURST CALLED 'MONSTER' DUMP
description: Governor Kean conditionally vetoed a package of bills last week and recommended they be converted into a proposal to create an environmental trust fund. Page 4.

title: WHY THEY'RE LINING UP AT LUBY'S
description: SAN ANTONIO

title: MODEST REFORMS AND GRANDIOSE VISIONS
description: THE FEDERAL COURTS Crisis and Reform. By Richard A. Posner. 365 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25. CONSTITUTIONAL CHOICES By Laurence H. Tribe. 458 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $29.95.

title:
GARDENING;

WHY THE MIMOSA ISN'T RECOMMENDED
description: IN response to a recent article that noted the Japanese scholar tree, Sophora japonica, and the golden rain tree, Kolreuteria paniculata, as being desirable summer-flowering trees, a reader asked why the mimosa, Albrizia julibrissin, had been ignored.

title: AMATEURS RECOVER THE PAST
description: PIECES of New Jersey's past are being unearthed, salvaged and painstakingly preserved by a dedicated group of history lovers - from professors and truck drivers to nuns and businessmen - who donate their time and energy.

title: COLLEGE STUDY, COMMUNITY STYLE
description: An increasing number of larger universities around the nation are attempting to impart a more intimate atmosphere to learning, to counter the facelessness and impersonality that often accompanies academic life at such institutions.

title: ART
description: One of the more surprising experiences that the Metropolitan Museum has to offer at this moment is the sight of a whole squadron of devoted staff members dusting the pianos in the little gallery thatstands just to the left of the top of the main staircse.

title: 2 'DARING' SHOWS ACROSS THE BORDER
description: THE Penguin Repertory can be more daring than judicious in unearthing the obscure works of popular playwrights, who, as everyone knows have some work or other stuck at the bottom of the trunk.

title: DOUBTS ABOUT POLICE RAID TAKE HOLD IN PHILADELPHIA
description: Despite the death of 11 people and the loss of 61 houses, the public here stood solidly behind Mayor W. Wilson Goode in the aftermath of the siege last May of a house occupied by the radical group Move. But in recent weeks, a series of disclosures has rocked the Goode administration, raising questions about what happened during the assault on the house and the subsequent fire that destroyed a neighborhood.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KIPLING, KERN AND MONTEVERDI
description: Tina Turner Live: Nice 'n' Rough Thorn/EMI Video 55 minutes. $19.95 ''People all over the world ask me when I'm going to slow down, and you know what my answer is? I'm just getting started,'' declares Tina Turner in the middle of ''Proud Mary,'' one of the high points of this concert video.

title: CANADA LETS SOME REGAIN INDIAN STATUS
description: Earlier this summer the Canadian Parliament reversed a 114-year-old law that took Indian status away from women who married whites.

title: LED BACHE & CO. FOR 4 YEARS
description: George Weiss, a former chairman of Bache & Company, the investment brokerage house now known as Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., died of heart failure Thursday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 90 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: VICTORIA'S WARS
description: To the Editor:

title: MEASURING SPACE
description: To the Editor:

title: PROSPECTS
description: G.N.P: Going Nowhere Those who expect the Government to announce a major improvement in its preliminary second-quarter estimate of 1.7 percent growth in the gross national product will be disappointed, according to John D. Paulus, chief economist at Morgan Stanley & Company. He says this Tuesday's revision of the G.N.P. estimate is unlikely to vary from the preliminary figure issued in July.

title: LINCOLN CENTER: HELP FOR THE DISABLED
description: RUTH ELIZABETH KNAPP zooms around Lincoln Center in her electric wheelchair examining the height of a railing here, the weight of a door there, the distance from a bus stop to a curb cut, the visibility of signs indicating facilities for disabled people. As she goes, she asks questions everywhere: ''Where do seeing-eye dogs sit?'' ''Where are there removable seats for wheelchairs?'' ''What accommodations have been made backstage so performers with disabilities do not encounter difficulties?''

title: SABATINI ELIMINATED BY GRAF
description: Gabriela Sabatini captured the hearts of spectators at the sun-drenched United Jersey Bank Classic here today, but steady Steffi Graf, the 16-year-old West German, calmly stole their semifinal match, 4-6, 6-0, 6-3.

title: ENGLISH PICNIC, SOUTH SEA IDYLL
description: A Loaf of Bread, A Jug of Wine As the scenario goes, it is morning in London. A vintage Rolls-Royce - chauffeur-driven and bearing a butler - brakes to a halt outside a hotel. Two visitors enter, and the automobile proceeds on its way to Hever Castle in Kent, about an hour and a half distant.

title: FIRED CHIEFS
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Real Baseball Is Still Being Played
description: To the Editor:

title: DESPITE OFFICIAL IRE, ETHIOPIANS WARM TO U.S.
description: Nearly 10 months after the United States undertook a major famine relief effort in Ethiopia, relations between the two Governments remain strained and antagonistic, with few signs of approaching improvement, according to Western diplomats and Ethiopian officials.

title: 2 Thoreau Notebooks Believed Found
description: Two notebooks stored in a museum for years and containing flute scores, botanical samples and jottings may have belonged to the 19th-century naturalist and writer Henry David Thoreau and be worth thousands of dollars, experts say.

title: END IN SIGHT
description: Families in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn will begin moving next month into one of the last new housing projects to be built in the city in which all units will be subsidized under the Federal Section 8 housing-assistance program. Funds for the program, in which rents are based on tenant family income, dried up a few years ago.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: U.S. TESTS NUCLEAR WARHEAD
description: The United States conducted an underground test of a nuclear warhead today at its Nevada testing range, the first since it refused to join the Soviet Union in a moratorium on such tests. The Department of Energy announced that the warhead, with the explosive power of 20,000 tons of TNT, was exploded at 12:25 P.M. Eastern time. The department said the test conformed with international nuclear testing rules.

title: BRITAIN GETS INFLUX OF AMERICANS
description: DANIEL TUDEN felt a little frivolous when he decided last summer to spend a year studying economic history at the London School of Economics. The 25-year-old Cornell University graduate already owed more than $8,000 in college loans and he knew that he would have to add to his debt in order to attend. Besides, he wasn't sure how interested he would be in economic history.

title: 'NOBLE' SYMBOLS
description: In his article ''A Need for Medals'' (About Men, July 14), Owen Edwards suggests the need for symbols to acknowledge noble, everyday achievements.

title: A LIFETIME OF LAW AND QUIET DILIGENCE FOR JUDGE WEINFELD
description: It is very quiet in Foley Square at 4:30 in the morning, when 84-year-old Judge Edward Weinfeld usually arrives. The square is deserted except for the homeless people sleeping in the park across from the United States Court House.

title: STATE AID SOUGHT ON SHORE POLLUTION
description: PLEAS for help in ridding Long Island Sound of bacteria washing into it from streams and overloaded sewer systems in Westchester went out last week to state authorities from village and county officials.

title: IN BUFFALO, JOHN BARTLETT REICHENBACH WEDS MARGARET LYNN JACOBS, BROKER
description: Margaret Lynn Jacobs, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jeremy M. Jacobs of Buffalo, was married there yesterday to John Bartlett Reichenbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George S. Reichenbach of Carlisle, Mass. The Very Rev. James M. Demske, president of Canisius College, performed the ceremony at Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church.

title: PITCHING MAY HAMPER YANKEES AND ORIOLES IN STRETCH DRIVE
description: THE Yankees have at least one fan in the American League East rooting for them to catch the Toronto Blue Jays, who have been in first place since May 13. ''Don't you think the Yankees are going to close tight?'' Earl Weaver, the Baltimore Orioles' old and new manager, asked. ''We're thinking the Yankees are going to close tight'' - and then he added - ''and we're not that far behind the Yankees.''

title: INDIANS TO GATHER IN 2-DAY POW-WOW
description: THE sound of beating drums will echo along the banks of the Connecticut River next weekend as Indian tribes from throughout North America gather here for what is expected to be the largest native American event in the state's history.

title: ISRAEL'S CRITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLLY RANDOLPH WEDS EDWARD SPERRY
description: Holly Jean Randolph, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Charles Randolph of Manitowoc, Wis., was married yesterday to Edward Leavenworth Sperry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leavenworth Porter Sperry Jr. of Middlebury, Conn. The Rev. Glen Siferd of St. Paul's Methodist Church in Manitowoc performed the ceremony at the Randolph home.

title: THE BOLD SOPRANO
description: THE CAREER OF MAGDA V. By Joseph Machlis. 313 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. $13.95.

title: RELIEVING WORRIES OF OWNERSHIP
description: WORRYING about a country or beach house is like fretting about a child away from home. News of hurricanes, flooding or other natural disasters immediately conjures up images of calamities that must have surely taken place at the property.

title: A Resignation
description: Nanette Falkenberg is resigning as executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League, effective at the end of the year.

title: WHEN CONGRESS GOES HOME;   Early to Rise In Syracuse
description: On a cool, clear morning this week, Representative George C. Wortley, a Republican from Syracuse, began his workday early, sharing coffee and a Danish with the local heads of Federal agencies.

title: MISS KINNEY, W. S. SPEERS ARE MARRIED
description: Donna Elizabeth Kinney, the daughter of Lieut. Col. and Mrs. Donald E. Kinney of Bedford, Mass., and Ripton, Vt., was married yesterday to William Savage Speers, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., and Center Sandwich, N.H. The bridegroom's father, minister of the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan, performed the ceremony at Green Pastures, the Speers family home in Center Sandwich.

title: Braintree, Mass., In Water Battle
description: THE BATTLE of Braintree, it seems, started over weeds, specifically those in Sunset Lake. The Park Department of Braintree, an eastern Massachusetts town of 36,000 people, plans to pump 120 million gallons of water from the lake in October so that bulldozers can dredge an area choked with growth.

title: HARVARD CLUB TO REOPEN UNDER NEW MANAGEMENT
description: Management of the Harvard Faculty Club, which has catered to members of the university's faculty for more than 50 years, is to be taken over by an outside concern Sept. 9, the university says.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

PRINTS TO CHERISH IN PARIS
description: Museum shops have become a volume operation. Once relegated to an unobtrusive corner and carrying only a few items, many are now vast emporiums, but rarely can one find an original work of art and then only at a very high price.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE BABE RUTH OF BASS A LAZY summer afternoon on Long Island - if you've got a rod and reel, a small boat, maybe some liquid refreshment, there's nothing quite like the peaceful solitude of going fishing. If you're lucky, maybe you'll even catch a fish or two. If you're Dave Romeo of East Meadow, however, you'll catch a couple of thousand.

title: NO STARS, BUT LOTS OF VERVE AT THE REGIONAL FESTIVALS
description: Every year, from early spring to early summer, there are dance festivals across America sponsored by the National Association for Regional Ballet and by the American College Dance Festival Association. They can be both fun and exciting. Yet many New York dance fans may not even be aware of their existence.

title: MOVIE INDUSTRY SURGING ON L.I.
description: MOVIE studios and individual film makers are rediscovering Long Island as an attractive area to shoot everything from 30-second commercials to music videos to feature films.

title: OLD KYOTO, NEW KYOTO
description: Any American who has lived in Paris for more than three months will tell you that it's not the city it used to be in the glory days when he or she arrived. Just as converts are the most fanatic guardians of the faith, those who adopt foreign cities tend to be fiercely reactionary, preserving in imagination an ideal metropolis that may be derived more from literature and fantasy than first-hand observation. I adopted Kyoto for two years in the late 1970's, and during much of this time I imagined myself living in the 16th century or, rather, in a Kurosawa film.

title: BRONX RIVER PARKWAY: BEAUTIFUL IN 1925, BEAUTIFUL IN 1985
description: Curving gently around small ponds and under stone bridges, the Bronx River Parkway delights the eye with surprises. An egret, briefly glimpsed, white and elegant against dark water.

title: MASSACHUSETTS NURSE LOSES MIDWIFERY CASE
description: The practice of midwifery was upheld Thursday by the State Supreme Court, which said lay people may assist at home births in Massachusetts but nurses cannot do so without losing their licenses.

title: THE ROAD FROM MEDICINE HAT
description: OFTEN he would be the first one at the ball park, whether it was in Shreveport, La., or Great Falls, Mont., or Medicine Hat, Alberta, or any one of, literally, a hundred other towns he played in, and he would walk onto the field in the late afternoon and look round at the wooden stands, as he recalls, ''and imagine I was some place like New York Yankee Stadium and making the plays and hearing the crowd.''

title: NEW CASSETTES: KIPLING, KERN AND MONTEVERDI
description: Mowgli and His Brothers Produced by Chuck Jones Family Home Entertainment 25 minutes, $19.95 ''Mowgli and His Brothers'' is another tale from Rudyard Kipling's ''Jungle Book'' as interpreted by Chuck Jones. The story of the little boy raised as a wolf cub under the rules of the jungle lends itself nicely to highly stylized animation - in the opening sequence the wolf and the tiger emerge from abstract patterns, and then run across the screen like moving jewels.

title: NEW CASSETTES: KIPLING, KERN AND MONTEVERDI
description: L'Age d'Or Starring Lya Lys and Gaston Modot; directed by Luis Bunuel, 1930 Corinth Video 62 minutes, $59.95 The evening after Luis Bunuel's ''L'Age d'Or'' (''The Golden Age'') opened in Paris in 1930, it was attacked by fascists who threw bombs, slashed seats and hurled ink at the screen in the Montmartre theater where it was playing.

title: ASBESTOS WORK GOING ON AT 124 SCHOOLS IN JERSEY
description: Projects to remove or seal asbestos have been undertaken in 124 New Jersey public schools this summer, according to state officials. And, with a few exceptions, the officials said, all the work is expected to be completed before school opens next month.

title: TOOLS AND THE MAN: A MACHO MYSTIQUE?
description: ON any Saturday, it is not atypical to see one of my neighbors building a fence, another fixing his roof and yet another fixing his car. This is the real stuff of masculinity. A man with a hammer. A man who can clean his own carburetor. A man who knows how to use a miter box.

title: CANCER RESEARCHER WHO KEEPS TRYING
description: ''NOT everything I touch turns to gold,'' Dr. David Milton Goldenberg said in a recent interview, ''but I know that if I lose one, I'll win another. I just have to persevere.''

title: INHERITING A RENT-REGULATED APARTMENT
description: IN this city of scarce and expensive housing, rent-regulated apartments are like family heirlooms. A tenant may keep an apartment indefinitely as a primary residence and, in certain circumstances, pass it on to resident family members.

title: BRAZIL UNEARTHS PAST CORRUPTION
description: Long before it left office five months ago, Brazil's military regime had been found guilty of corruption by the jury of public opinion. Now the supporting evidence is beginning to surface.

title: A New Law on Transplants
description: Beginning in January, in an effort to alleviate the chronic shortage of organs for transplants, New York State will require hospitals to ask the families of all deceased patients for organ donations. The hope is that making such requests a matter of law will free doctors of the image of seeming to be unfeeling about a death and so improve their relations with the families.

title: BUILDING BOOM IN LONG BEACH
description: LONG BEACH ISLAND is in the midst of a condominium boom that has many residents happy about the new economic opportunities. But others say they fear a permanent change in their quiet seaside way of life.

title: BONN IS TROUBLED BY A SHIFT IN TERRORISTS' TACTICS
description: Despite West German successes in tracking down suspected terrorists at home and abroad, Government officials here say that details of the recent car bombing at the United States Rhein-Main Air Base, and a string of minor terrorist attacks since then, reflect a new strain of terrorist violence.

title: BLOOD DONORS SEEN IN NO RISK OF AIDS
description: ALTHOUGH donations to the state's blood banks have been slow in recent weeks, vacation schedules rather than increased public fears about aquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, is believed to be causing potential donors to stay away from bloodmobiles.

title: CARTER MAY GET RELEASE
description: The Oakland Invaders are about to release their wide receiver, Anthony Carter, from his contract as part of a plan to fold the United States Football League franchise, according to a published report.

title: RAILROAD LINKS GAINS TO HARMON SHOP
description: WORKMEN on the 8 A.M. to 4 P.M. shift at the Harmon Shop here have stenciled a slogan in white letters on a blue work cabinet: ''Make It Happen.'' But in their present surroundings the tense seems wrong. Something already has happened.

title: ON LEAVING CONNECTICUT FOR THE MIDDLE WEST
description: IMISS Connecticut. Recently I moved from my beloved Constitution State to Kansas City, Mo. All for a job. When Kansas Citians discover I'm from Connecticut, they have one of two reactions. Either it is ''Why didn't you take a job in New York?'' or ''You moved all the way to Kansas City just for a job?'' In case I didn't have enough doubts of my own.

title: MASSEY, AT 139, LEADS BY 2 STROKES
description: Debbie Massey, playing better as the result of a month's work on her game away from the weekly pressure of the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour, shot a three-under-par 69 today to take the lead in the second round of the MasterCard International Pro-Am tournament.

title: MISS CROSSLAND, A LAWYER, MARRIED TO FRANCIS QUINN
description: St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Newport, R.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Colleen Marie Crossland, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Archie Crossland of Sacramento, Calif., to Francis James Quinn, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Quinn of Newport. The Rev. Paul J. O'Rourke performed the ceremony.

title: PHILADELPHIA TUNES UP FOR ITS ANNUAL FOLKFEST
description: THE 24th Annual Philadelphia Folk Festival, one of the country's longest-running summer music events, is expected to bring 15,000 to 20,000 visitors next weekend to the rolling Pennsylvania countryside northwest of the city. This year's roster of performers includes 66 acts, among them such familiar names as Tom Paxton, Dave Van Ronk, John Hartford, David Bromberg and Taj Mahal. Some of the up-and-coming artists include Suzanne Vega, Frank Christian, Nanci Griffith and Bill Morrissey.

title: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN - ROCK'S POPULAR POPULIST
description: A quarter of a million people will hear Bruce Springsteen perform in the six-night stand that he starts tonight at Giants Stadium in New Jersey. If past tours are a guide, Mr. Springsteen will hear them, too, because Mr. Springsteen's fans sing along with every song in his three-hour-plus concerts - not just choruses, but every word. They care, passionately, about what his lyrics say.

title: Reagan Aides Draft a Repeal Of Hiring Rules
description: The evidence mounted last week that the Reagan Administration may be ready to further translate its sentiments on affirmative action into policy. The White House staff has drafted an executive order rescinding rules that require Federal contractors to set numerical goals to remedy possible job discrimination, it was reported.

title: RHYMING MUSICAL SPOOFS HOLLYWOOD
description: WHEN Michael Colby was growing up in Hewlett Bay Park, he wasn't really growing up at all, but carving his own whimsical path on the road to escapism.

title: A CHALLENGE FOR ENGINEERS: SCALING MUSIC FOR THE HOME
description: Long after the musicians are gone and the master tape is sealed ''in the can,'' the recording producer faces yet another musically vital choice. He must decide the dynamic range of the disk to be produced from the original tape.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LOVE, ELEANOR: Eleanor Roosevelt and Her Friends, by Joseph P. Lash. (McGraw-Hill, $8.95.) ''Love, Eleanor,'' published in 1982, was created out of the thousands of letters Eleanor Roosevelt wrote to close friends from the turn of the century to 1943. Like the woman who wrote them, they are private, public, political and international. Geoffrey C. Ward wrote in these pages that Mr. Lash's book helps ''provide the proper context in which to understand those letters'' and offers ''new insights into Mrs. Roosevelt's sometimes puzzling personality.'' A companion hard-cover volume, ''A World of Love,'' collects Mrs. Roosevelt's letters from the 40's to her death in 1962. THE THIN RED LINE, by James Jones. (Laurel/Dell, $5.95.) James Jones's World War II novel is about the men of Charlie Company, fighting on Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands. In 1962 Maxwell Geismar wrote here that it ''moves so intensely and inexorably that it almost seems like the war it is describing. . . . The special magic of Jones as a writer is that, discarding all the cliches and slogans of patriotism, of heroism and of war itself, remaining so absolutely honest about his theme, he yet manages to make these typical American fighting men both universally human, and exceptional.'' ARENA, by Hallie Flanagan. (Limelight, $12.95.) Hallie Flanagan directed the Federal Theater Project, a Government-sponsored Depression undertaking to give unemployed theater people jobs. (Among the many whose careers it helped was the young Orson Welles.) John Gassner commented in The Book Review in 1940 that ''seldom can a book on the theater be considered a chapter in national history.

title: SPARTAN'S ODYSSEY
description: THAT SUMMER WE took the boys out west by train. Easterners still said ''out west'' in those days when they meant Arizona, Utah, Colorado. I suppose nobody says it now, except old-timers too set in their ways to change. Nowadays, when every place is the same place, old-timers who remember when America was many different places are probably the only people who find remote territory remarkable enough to be spoken of with the awe implicit in ''out west.''

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 18, 1985 Fiction

title: CASINO LISTS TOP CITY CENSUS
description: THE casino industry has become so dominant here that it employs more people than the total population of the city and pays 62.4 percent of the resort's property taxes.

title: ALL-DAY KINDERGARTEN FIGHT RAGES
description: KINDERGARTEN is a world of discovery for a 5-year-old, whose time spent molding clay, painting pictures, playing house and reading stories offers one revelation after another about himself, his friends and his world.

title: WORDS OF THE RIGHT
description: A GENERATION AGO, people on the political right did not mind being called right-wingers. We kind of resented lunatic fringe, the great coinage of Theodore Roosevelt, and little old ladies in tennis shoes was known to be a knock, but right wing had a sassy connotation - even the ''moderate'' among us counted ourselves as part of a hardy band of conservatives, murmuring ''I'd rather be right'' as we consigned ourselves, legs bowed but heads unbowed, to the clubbiness of permanent-minority status. We could not understand why our counterparts on the liberal side winced when we called them left-wingers.

title: IRANIAN PRESIDENT TAKES LARGE LEAD IN BALLOTING
description: Iran's President, Hojatolislam Ali Khamenei, took a huge lead in election returns today, and it seemed certain that he would retain his office for another four-year term.

title: METS WIN, 4-3, AND TIE FOR FIRST
description: In Friday night's loss and through most of tonight's game, it seemed as if the pennant-contending Mets had turned the cellar-dwelling Pirates into world beaters.

title: RESERVE HONORS FOR DESERVING
description: To The Sports Editor:

title:
ART;

MUSEUM OF CARTOON ART CELEBRATES MARVEL
description: THAT large and ever-growing enterprise known as Marvel Comics is featured at the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook through Oct. 13. As testimony to the wide appeal of Marvel Comics, the museum had more than 1,000 people to celebrate ''Marvel Day'' on July 14. Spider-man put in an appearance ''in person.''

title: WRITER'S REJECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Becoming Speakable Using Jean-Paul Sartre as his example, Walker Percy shows how a writer reverses his alienation by sharing it with his readers. This is from ''Conversations With Walker Percy'' (University Press of Mississippi), edited by Lewis A. Lawson and Victor A. Kramer.

title: A KILLER'S MEMOIRS RESONATE ON STATE
description: In other cities, perhaps, an audience can watch the play ''In the Belly of the Beast'' and treat Jack Henry Abbott as a character. In New York, he is someone all too real. It was here that Mr. Abbott in 1981 was deposited from prison into two irreconcilable strata of society, a Bowery halfway house and the chic circuit of discos, talk shows and cocktail parties. And it was here, after but six weeks of freedom, that the convicted murderer killed again, stabbing a waiter in an argument over using a restaurant's bathroom. The next morning, with Jack Henry Abbott in flight, rave reviews appeared for his volume of prison letters.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

'TELL ME, GRANDFATHER'
description: ''TELL us about the past, tell us everything you can remember,'' we ask our parents and our grandparents.

title: FACES OF THE PEOPLE;   The Next New York
description: When New York voters go to the polls for the Sept. 10 primary election, they'll be choosing among more than candidates. Their votes will reflect what concerns they think will be important for the rest of the decade. What do New Yorkers want the city to be, do and become?

title: IT'S BLEAK AND BARREN, BUT NOT TO THE ESKIMOS
description: An Eskimo homeland may seem a curious goal to those who conceive of the Arctic as a frozen wasteland. But that is the aim of the Inuit, as Canada's 25,000 Eskimos call themselves.

title: NEW ISSUE RECOGNIZES VETERANS
description: While the media focuses on the 40th anniversary of the conclusion of World War II, the United States Postal Service has been recognizing veterans of other wars.

title: DANIELSON LEADS BROWNS PAST EAGLES
description: The veteran quarterback, Gary Danielson, relieved the rookie, Bernie Kosar, and threw three second-half touchdown passes tonight to give the Cleveland Browns a 28-14 exhibition victory over the Philadelphia Eagles.

title: CASTING A HEAVY SHADOW ON A PIVOTAL SITE
description: There is no building site in Manhattan like the one now occupied by the Coliseum. It stands at the southwest corner of Central Park, poised between midtown and the Upper West Side. It spans not one but two full city blocks from north to south, and fills the west side of Columbus Circle. Anything built there is bound to be more conspicuous than even the most prominent building on an avenue such as Park or Madison, for it can be seen from everywhere -from Central Park, from midtown, from uptown and from New Jersey. And a new building on Columbus Circle will do much more than change the skyline. More important, it will make a transition from midtown to the fast-developing Upper West Side, and as such it will set a tone - and a scale - for what happens further uptown.

title: Lauda to Retire Again
description: He did it once before and it didn't stick, but this time Niki Lauda says he really means it. The 36-year-old Formula One driving champion who has dropped out of eight races and not won any this year, said he would retire at the end of the season.

title: AMTRAK RESTORING SHINE TO STATIONS IN NORTHEAST
description: Throughout the Northeast, once-fading train stations are undergoing a renaissance as a $191 million Federal rebuilding program comes to fruition.

title: U.S. SETS RECORD IN SWIM
description: The United States team, anchored by the world-record holder, Matt Biondi, set a world record in the men's 400-meter freestyle relay today at the Pan Pacific swimming championships.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEE NO POSSIBLILITY OF U.S. ACCORD WITH SANDINISTAS
description: Reagan Administration officials involved in Central American policy say United States differences with Nicaragua cannot be resolved as long as the Sandinistas remain in power, and some indicate they favor the overthrow of the Sandinista leadership.

title: AID FOR GRAD STUDENTS SHRINKING
description: MORE students are finding it difficult to finance their doctoral studies, and as a result universities are coming up with everything from more research fellowships to graduated tuition plans to help them. Public universities as well as private institutions are seeking more financial aid for Ph.D. students, from alumni, business, government and other sources.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: HEALER By Peter Dickinson. 184 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $14.95. (Ages 12 and up) THE laying on of hands is the world's oldest form of medicine and has been described in almost every known culture. Ancient Egyptians as well as modern scientists have tried to define the source of this healing power. The early Christians attributed it to God, the peasants of the Middle Ages to royalty and 20th-century physicians to ''the powers of suggestion.'' The British writer Peter Dickinson explains it as ''harmonic energy'' and in his riveting new novel, ''Healer,'' has bestowed the ability to employ it on the unlikely person of a 10-year-old girl.

title: NO ONE THEY KNEW SAW A PSYCHIATRIST
description: BREAKING POINTS By Jack and Jo Ann Hinckley with Elizabeth Sherrill. 375 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.: Chosen Books/Zondervan Publishing House. $16.95.

title: Headliners;   Mistrial Called
description: Prosecutors trying the case of John Williams, the former Tulane University basketball player accused of shaving points in two games last winter, were charged with a foul last week, and a mistrial was declared. In the second day of the trial of the 23-year-old, 6-foot-10-inch star center, Mr. Williams's attorney discovered that prosecutors had not made available to him a taped statement made by a former teammate of Mr. Williams during the state's investigation of the case.

title: LOOKING FOR ANSWERS IN AN AVIATION CATASTROPHE
description: IN no other other country do domestic airlines pack their planes the way they do in Japan. Strict airport rules limit operating hours, so Japanese carriers try to squeeze in as many passengers as possible in the time allowed them. Twelve years ago they began to acquire a special American-made jumbo jet, the Boeing 747SR (for short range), reinforced to withstand jolts from frequent takeoffs and landings and able to carry more than 500 passengers.

title: JUNIOR AT HARVARD RALLIES U.S. STUDENTS FOR OVERSEAS DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS
description: Kamal Ahmad of Bangladesh was too busy taking final examinations last spring to accept the Peace Medal of the United Nations Development Program. So the Bangladeshi Ambassador to the United Nations accepted the prize in his behalf.

title: HUNDREDS OF EGYPTIANS GO HOME FROM LIBYA
description: The first of 100,000 Egyptian workers who have been expelled from Libya began arriving home today, further straining already poor relations between the Arab neighbors.

title: TOLLS END SET
description: THE day after Christmas, Connecticut residents will receive a holiday gift from the state when toll collection on the Connecticut Turnpike will be ended.

title: UMBRIA
description: To the Editor: After spending one sleepless night in noisy Perugia during a trip to Italy, we were desperate for a more tranquil place to serve as a base for our tour of Umbria. Fortunately I had brought along the article on Piero della Francesco (Travel, Dec. 16, 1984) with its practical information on Umbria, which mentioned the Tre Vasselle in Torgiano.

title: IN THE LOGIC OF EVENTS, HORROR
description: CRAZY WOMEN By Jack Matthews. 158 pp. Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins University Press. $12.95.

title: ROYALS RALLY IN 8th TO BEAT JAYS
description: Lonnie Smith's bloop single drove in two runs to highlight Kansas City's three-run eighth inning today as the Royals got a combined five-hitter from Danny Jackson and Dan Quisenberry to beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-2.

title: V.A. Hospital
description: ''Dismal surroundings'' and ''ineffective medical leadership'' were among the criticisms made last year of the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Veterans Administration Hospital in Montrose, N.Y., by a V.A. inspection team.

title: WHERE ENGINEERS THINK BIG
description: NASA's space shuttle. The Soviet natural-gas pipeline. The Panama Canal. All these projects are big, very big. In trying to manage, finance and build them, even talented executives often fail, according to those who have done it and those who have observed.

title: HOW EASILY HEART TURNS TO STONE
description: THE BUS OF DREAMS By Mary Morris. 236 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $15.95. THE stories in Mary Morris's new collection, ''The Bus of Dreams,'' have a light touch, and all give the appearance of looseness. Whether depicting life near Cape Canaveral in the early days of the space program, a day in the bedroom suburbs of Chicago, an American tourist in the slums of Lima, Peru, or a Caribbean vacation going sour, the stories have a deliberately sketchy quality, especially as Miss Morris evokes her characters' psychology. In fact, what these short fictions call to mind more than anything are newspaper clippings or news flashes, bits of familiar this and that whizzing by. Most of the 15 stories are topical to the core.

title: NEW JAZZ, LIKE THE OLD, HAS ITS ROOTS IN THE SOUTH
description: The importance of New Orleans and other Southern cities as the original incubators of jazz has long been recognized. During the Swing Era, the deep South bred bands like those led by Jimmy Lunceford and Erskine Hawkins, and the Arkansas-born saxophonist Louis Jordan was largely responsible for transforming bluesy small-band swing into the rhythm-and-blues of the 40's and 50's.

title: POLICE ARREST 152 IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African police reported today that they had arrested 152 people in the last 24 hours, one of the highest number of detentions in a single day since a state of emergency was declared in July. The police also said two more blacks had been shot dead in township violence.

title: ELISABETH DEANS A BRIDE
description: Elisabeth Suzanne DeBoeck Deans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Barr Deans Jr., was married yesterday at her parents' home in Mill Neck, L.I., to Joseph Douglas Grant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Grant of Pawtucket, R.I. The Rev. Robert Hollett, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: FEE-FI-FO-FUM TARTARS
description: With all due respect to Ernest Gill's lexicographical combings, it seems unnecessarily far-fetched to trace the American hamburger to a wild and wooly Tartar origin (''Hamburgers and Amerikaners,'' On Language, July 7).

title: In the Pentagon's Good Graces
description: In May, as he announced a moratorium on new contracts with two divisions of the General Dynamics Corporation, Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. said the Pentagon's differences with the company stemmed from nothing less than ''a pervasive corporate attitude that we find inappropriate to the public trust.'' Last week, the Navy lifted its ban, asserting that General Dynamics had mended its ways and that in some instances fuzzy Government regulations might have caused the company to stray.

title: Louganis Wins Again For Undefeated Season
description: Greg Louganis completed an undefeated season today with an easy victory in the 10-meter platform finals at the United States Outdoor Diving Championships.

title: WHO WILL LIVE ON UNITY ROAD?
description: UNITY ROAD is a street in a town on Long Island just outside New York City. It is only 500 feet long and runs from Marley Place to a dead end where the chain link fence encloses the town's public school property.

title: Headliners;   Designated President
description: Although Tanzania's presidential election is not until October, the results were announced last week.

title: COLLIERS MILLS: HAVEN FOR HIKERS AND HUNTERS
description: BY HIGH NOON in the middle of summer, it gets so hot here within the scrub-pine forest of Colliers Mills State Wildlife Management Area that it seems that even the deerflies must be perspiring.

title:
THE YOUNG HEMINGWAY: THREE UNPUBLISHED STORIES;

THE MERCENARIES
description: IF YOU ARE HONESTLY CURIOUS ABOUT PEARL FISHING conditions in the Marquesas, the possibility of employment on the projected Trans Gobi Desert Railway, or the potentialities of any of the hot tamale republics, go to the Cafe Cambrinus on Wabash Avenue, Chicago. There at the rear of the dining room where the neo-bohemians struggle nightly with their spaghetti and ravioli is a small smoke-filled room that is a clearinghouse for the camp followers of fortune. When you enter the room, and you will have no more chance than the zoological entrant in the famous camel-needle's eye gymkana of entering the room unless you are approved by Cambrinus, there will be a sudden silence. Then a varying number of eyes will look you over with that detached intensity that comes of a periodic contemplation of death. This inspection is not mere boorishness.

title: Goodbye, Public Policy
description: Roger W. Robinson Jr., a key player in formulation of White House international economic policy over the last three years, has told President Reagan that he will soon be leaving to rejoin private business as a Washington-based consultant. The 34-year-old adviser has kept a low public profile as senior director for international economic affairs at the National Security Council, having been brought to the White House in 1982 by William P. Clark, then the national security adviser.

title: A TOWERING GEOMETRY
description: TOWERS CONJURE UP ROMANTIC images of medieval castles and lighthouses and fortresses. They are also a neat architectural device for elevating a building enough to take advantage of the surrounding landscape. Both reasons compelled the Connecticut architect Herbert S. Newman to design a 40-foot tower, which is crowned in latticework, atop his Connecticut home. Only from this vantage point was he able to get clear views of Long Island Sound, from Mattituck Inlet to Lloyd Neck.

title: INDIA SCHEDULES PUNJAB ELECTIONS FOR Sept. 22
description: Less than a month after he signed an accord with Sikh leaders to end three years of confrontation, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi has decided to hold new elections in Punjab state next month to fill the 117-seat state legislature and 10 parliamentary seats, it was announced tonight.

title: OPERA COMPANY OFF TO SCOTLAND
description: CONNECTICUT Grand Opera has three performances of ''The Consul'' by Gian Carlo Menotti coming up this weekend, but if you want to see the show, you will have to get to Scotland.

title: PLANS FOR BETTER MUD FLAPS ON TRUCKS ARE OPPOSED
description: The Transportation Department is encountering stiff opposition to a proposal aimed at reducing the splash and spray of water from tractor-trailer tires running on wet roads.

title: JAZZ
description: Count Basie, who died in 1984, would have been 81 years old on Wednesday (Aug. 21). To mark the occasion, one of the many famous jazz musicians who came up through Mr. Basie's band, the saxophonist Illionois Jaquet, will give a free concert with his own orchestra at Lincoln Center on Wednesday evening at 8:15 in the Damrosch Park Band Shell.

title: REAGAN, IN RADIO TALK, CRITICIZES FARM PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan said today that the answer to farmers' financial problems could not be found ''in sticking with discredited programs and increasing Government controls.''

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: NOEL IN AUGUST From 11 to 5 today, the Brittania Bookshop in New Preston, which specializes in English and Irish literature from 1800 through World War II, will be the site of a Noel Coward festival.

title: IN MUCH OF AFRICA, SPIRITS ARE STILL THOUGHT TO PULL THE STRINGS
description: It was a toss-up over whose God had done the work, but it seemed clear that Someone was on the job.

title: MATCHBOOK ADS SUCCEED FOR LAWYER
description: Edward Horn's advertisements for his law firm have all the familiar trappings.

title: BIG DEVELOPMENT PLAN ANNOUNCED IN TORONTO
description: The Toronto City Council approved a $1.5 billion development plan today for an area now covered by railway tracks.

title: IN THE METRO
description: To the Editor: All those letters to the editor on muggings in the Paris Metro (Travel, July 28) came too late to forewarn me. On the last night of a 10-day stay in Paris last April, my bag, slung over my shoulder on a thin strap, was yanked off easily by a man who ran with it up the steps to the platform.

title: A PRIVATE-SECTOR BOOST
description: The decade-old effort to revive downtown Jamaica, Queens, has been made so far mostly through public projects like the opening of the Jamaica Arts Center, the expansion of York Community College and the start of construction on a 1-million-square-foot regional headquarters for the Social Security Administration.

title: FRESH TUNA CATCHES DINERS' FANCY
description: WHILE sport and commercial fishermen continue to harvest several species of tuna off Long Island in an unusually long and abundant season, a growing number of area residents have been discovering fresh tuna for home consumption.

title: DANCE: KOREAN TROUPE MAKES NEW YORK DEBUT
description: MODERN dance and the traditional were blended with an usual smoothness on Thursday when The Korean Contemporary Dance Company appeared in its New York debut at the New York University Theater, Most impressively, neither the new nor the old lost any inherent vitality, though thier combination had an integrity of its own.

title: CLAIRE L. GAMBACCINI TO WED IN NOVEMBER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Louis John Gambaccini of Ridgewood, N.J., and Belgrade, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Claire Louise Gambaccini to Capt. Stephen John Ressler, U.S.A., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Kenneth Ressler of Walnutport, Pa. The wedding is planned for November.

title: BOTHA'S MESSAGE: SOUTH AFRICA WON'T BUDGE
description: Disappointing its friends and enraging its enemies, South Africa said last week that it was not about to change its system. In a speech that the Reagan Administration had hoped would be conciliatory, President P.W. Botha rejected demands for even a declaration of intent to abandon apartheid.

title: PROUD AND PREJUDICED
description: THE HOUSE OF MITFORD By Jonathan Guinness with Catherine Guinness. Illustrated. 604 pp. New York: Viking. $22.95.

title: Gandhi Deals With Another Trouble Spot
description: India celebrated more than Independence Day last week. Less than a month after he forged an agreement with the dissident Sikhs of the Punjab, Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi had apparently quieted another longstanding conflict.

title: TEACHING PROFESSORS TO TEACH
description: THE camera rolls. A teacher in the economics department at Carnegie-Mellon University strolls into class, puts down his briefcase and begins: ''I think babies ought to be put on the free market. How many of you agree with me?'' The class is still. ''Nobody agrees? What's the matter with you people? Why don't you agree?'' Hands shoot up; the camera zooms in. The debate ensues until, just as the class gains the fury of a lynch mob, the teacher stops to make a statement about general economics.

title: INCOME LIMITS FOR MITCHELL-LAMA TENANTS INCREASED
description: GOVERNOR CUOMO has signed legislation raising the income limit for individuals and families who live in the city's subsidized Mitchell-Lama housing. The new law, which takes effect Nov. 2, will mean that people with incomes of more than $40,000 a year will be eligible to move in. But there's a catch - the waiting list, in some cases, is five years long.

title: FATAL ACCIDENT AND GAS LEAK AT LINCOLN TUNNEL TIE UP WIDE AREA
description: A fatal accident just west of the Lincoln Tunnel and a gas leak on a nearby street minutes later combined yesterday to shut down the tunnel's westbound lanes for almost four hours and back up traffic for miles in New Jersey and the West Side of Manhattan.

title: WHEN CONGRESS GOES HOME;   All Day at the Jersey Dumps
description: Representative Dean A. Gallo stood in the hot sun, alongside town council members, surveying a closed landfill that is laced with toxic contaminants.

title: MISS MCMAHON TO MARRY IN FALL
description: The engagement of Melissa Ann McMahon to Jonathan Paul Cramer has been announced by Mr. and Mr. James Franklin McMahon of New Canaan, Conn., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Irving I. Cramer of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Our revenge will be as powerful as their crimes.'' - Statement by the Lebanese Forces militia broadcast by the Christian Voice of Lebanon radio. [17:1.]

title: 2 Men Charged With Murder After Attack on Cambodian
description: The police have charged two men with murder in the beating death of Bun Vong, a 34-year-old Cambodian who died Wednesday of the effects of a beating he suffered Aug. 4. The Metroplitan Police brought the charges against John M. Febbi, 24, and Scott S. Arsenault, 23, both of Somerville, minutes after Mr. Vong died.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: EINSTEIN IN AMERICA: The Scientist's Conscience in the Age of Hitler and Hiroshima. By Jamie Sayen. (Crown, $17.95.) Jamie Sayen's biography of Albert Einstein adds little to what we know of the scientist's personal life, apart from numerous photographs of him and such endearing details as his refusal to wear socks.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WOMEN IN HELLENISTIC EGYPT: From Alexander to Cleopatra. By Sarah B. Pomeroy. (Schocken, $16.95.) Sarah B. Pomeroy, a professor of classics at Hunter College and the Graduate School of the City University of New York, has a longstanding interest in the women of antiquity.

title: Life, Death and Human Dignity
description: I may be terminally ill. I therefore face, in an intimate and personal way, the issue of my right to die. I am happy for those who are not ill, but they are terminal too and they should think about this question as it relates to themselves and those they love as friends or family or simply fellow human beings.

title: KATHRYN HEINTZ WED TO RICHARD K. BARCLAY
description: Kathryn Kristin Heintz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Clemens Heintz of Clinton, N.Y., was married yesterday to Richard Kenneth Barclay, a son of William David Barclay of Toronto and the late Mrs. Barclay.

title: THIRD PARTIES FEEL LURE OF GRASS ROOTS
description: THIRD parties - which traditionally run campaigns during national election years - have jumped into local municipal races throughout Connecticut this month.

title:
GARDENING;

WHY THE MIMOSA ISN'T RECOMMENDED
description: IN response to a recent article that noted the Japanese scholar tree, Sophora japonica, and the golden rain tree, Kolreuteria paniculata, as being desirable summer-flowering trees, a reader asked why the mimosa, Albrizia julibrissin, had been ignored.

title: JOANNE MANGAN MARRIES
description: At St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church in Nyack, N.Y., yesterday Joanne Katherine Mangan and Robert Harold Frey were married by the Rev. George E. Reinheimer. The bride, an administrative assistant with the Orange and Rockland Utilities Company in Pearl River, N.Y., is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter J. Mangan of Valley Cottage, N.Y. Mr. Frey is a sales representative for Becton Dickinson & Company's Edmont division, a maker of industrial safety equipment in Coshocton, Ohio. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Frey of West Nyack, N.Y.

title: COUNTY TAKES OVER ON MOTOR VEHICLES
description: ATLANTIC County is now in the motor vehicle agency business, manning the bureau whose agent, overwhelmed by a logjam created by lack of qualified help, unexpectedly quit.

title: MARK B. ARNOTT WED TO TESSA BEH, FASHION EDITOR
description: Teresa Amanda Beh, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth F. Beh of Plandome, L.I., and Mark Blyth Arnott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Arnott of New York, were married yesterday. The Rev. Ralph F. Ferro performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title:
GARDENING;

WHY THE MIMOSA ISN'T RECOMMENDED
description: IN response to a recent article that noted the Japanese scholar tree, Sophora japonica, and the golden rain tree, Kolreuteria paniculata, as being desirable summer-flowering trees, a reader asked why the mimosa, Albrizia julibrissin, had been ignored.

title: Giving God His Day in the Supreme Court
description: To the Editor:

title: SPEND A BUCK WINS BY A NOSE
description: Spend a Buck held off Carr de Naskra in the stretch and captured the $270,300 Monmouth Handicap by a nose today in track-record time at Monmouth Park.

title: MISS SOBEL IS ENGAGED TO KENNETH LESTRANGE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sanford W. Sobel of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Stacey Sobel, to Kenneth John LeStrange, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. LeStrange of New Hyde Park, L.I. The wedding is planned for October.

title: The Case of the Surprise Storm
description: On Nov. 21, 1980, four Massachusetts men set out from Cape Cod in fair weather for a week of lobstering on Georges Bank, a rich fishing area 100 miles off the Massachusetts coast. A day later they were taken by surprise by a storm that the National Weather Service had not predicted.

title: EXPERTS QUESTION DATA ABOUT MISSING CHILDREN
description: When a study prepared in 1983 by the Department of Health and Human Services suggested that 1.5 million children were reported missing each year, that number began rolling across television screens and editorial pages across the country.

title: NATURAL COMPLEMENTS
description: WE HAVE OFTEN WRITTEN ABOUT THINGS that go naturally together, marriages of foods and wines or spirits, spices, herbs and the like that subtly complement each other. We would count among these - in the luxury category -foie gras with the elixir among sweet wines, a genuine, rich, well-chilled Sauternes such as Chateau d'Yquem; or caviar with a glass of iced vodka. In a lesser category, we would mention walnuts with Madeira wine, or oysters, spinach and an anise-flavored liqueur such as Pernod or Ricard (as in oysters Rockefeller). Rum goes with black bean soup, and in Oriental dishes, blends of ginger, garlic and wine with a Sherry-like flavor are legion.

title: ONE OF THE PARAGONS AMONG WOMEN ARTISTS
description: Some there were whose hearts leaped up when it was made known earlier this month that Mrs. Wilhelmina Holliday was going forward with her projected National Museum of Women's Art in the former Masonic Temple in downtown Washington. Women artists have suffered, and suffer still, from the indifference of curators, dealers and critics. Not least have they suffered from the indifference, if not the downright hostility, of male artists, many of whom are obsessed with ''turf'' in their attitude to women artists.

title: 5-YEAR CONTRACEPTIVE IMPLANT IS BEING TESTED
description: A new contraceptive for women that is implanted under the skin ''provides an effective and reversible long-term method of fertility regulation,'' according to a report from the World Health Organization to be made public later this month.

title: MEATPACKERS STRIKE AT HORMEL PLANT INMINNESOTA
description: About 1,500 meatpackers struck the home plant of Geo. A. Hormel & Co. today, refusing to accept the same pay that other Hormel workers get despite threats by the company to leave the town where it is the principal employer.

title: KUDOS TO KAUFMAN
description: To the Editor:

title: THE AFTERMARKET IN QUALITY TV SHOWS
description: HOME video promised owners of video cassette recorders a respite from mundane television programming. People could just plunk a tape of a movie into the VCR and pre-empt any show on the air.

title: AN OLD-TIME BAND FOR SUMMER NIGHTS
description: TURN the clock back to the 1880's, gather a 20-piece band in a gazebo on a perfect summer evening and sit back and listen.

title: MUSIC: THE 'ST. MATTHEW PASSION' AT TANGLEWOOD
description: LENOX, Mass., Aug. 17 - The dramatic qualities of Bach's passion settings have prompted many companies to put them on the stage. At the Tanglewood Festival, opera has often been given in a semi-staged format, and the production style developed here by David Kneuss adapted itself naturally and effectively to the Boston Symphony's St. Matthew Passion last night. The drama was not veristically represented, but the soloists were robed -Christus in white, the others in vaguely clerical garb - and moved about freely as they sang. The Evangelist, who delivers the basic scriptural narration, stood at the front; Jesus, the other characters in the drama and the aria soloists were on a raised platform behind the orchestra, with the chorus arrayed behind and above them. Over their heads was suspended an enormous ornamental cross, flush to the underside of the bank of acoustical panels on the ceiling of Tanglewood's shed. The movements, directed by Mr. Kneuss, were simple and unobtrusive.

title: CONSUMER RATES
BOOKSHELF
description: Additional titles of interest: MORGAN AND THE ARTIST. Written and illustrated by Donald Carrick. Clarion/Ticknor & Fields. $12.95. (Ages 5 to 9) Morgan, an impish sort of fellow who appears on the canvas one day, serves as an inspiration and guide for a rather unsuccessful landscape artist named Frederic Toll.

title: A PAINTER'S WORLD IN BIGELOW HOLLOW
description: SUMMER afternoons and weekends, crowds of people are drawn to Bigelow Hollow State Park in Union, to boat or to picnic.

title: THATCHER'S HELICOPTER REPORTED IN NEAR-MISS
