description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain was nearly killed last month when an airliner had to take emergency action to avoid colliding with her helicopter, two British newspapers reported today.

title: LESTER COLE DIES: IN 'HOLLYWOOD 10'
description: Lester Cole, a screenwriter who was one of the 10 Hollywood figures sent to prison in 1950 for refusing to testify before a House committee investigating Communist influence in the motion-picture industry, died of a heart attack Thursday at the University of California-San Francisco Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: WHEN CONGRESS HOME
description: When Congress began its monthlong recess Aug. 2, some lawmakers headed for the beaches or the mountains, some for exotic foreign spots.

title: TEACHERS WON'T ADVISE OTHERS TO FOLLOW SUIT
description: Two-thirds of the schoolteachers in a national survey say they will remain as teachers, but nearly three-fourths of them balk at recommending the career to others, according to results of the poll made public yesterday.

title: Up, Violins
description: One of the relatively few things that Washington and New York have in common is hotels that are called Ritz Carlton (they acquired the name simultaneously) and that contain restaurants called the Jockey Club (the Washington one is older). This is because they are all owned by John B. Coleman, a man with a sense of order.

title: AMY J. STURSBERG PLANS A WEDDING
description: Mr. and Mrs. Carl W. Stursberg Jr. of Roslyn Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Jessica Stursberg, to Philip Gellert Barber, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Barber of New York and Wilmington, Vt. The wedding is planned for Sept. 28.

title: ONE DAY VIRGINIA REFUSED TO GIVE GRANDPA THE USUAL BIG KISS
description: LAST Saturday morning, as my husband prepared to leave for his golf game, I shouted to him from the kitchen, ''Better get home early, Elliott. The Redhead's coming.''

title: AN EAST-WEST 'CATALYST' CAMPUS
description: POLITICAL differences tend to disappear in scholarly international exchanges at the East-West Center, an unorthodox Federal facility here for cross-cultural study and research that is celebrating its 25th anniversary this year.

title: AUDREY YORK IS WED
description: Audrey Joyce York, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard E. York of Winston-Salem, N.C., was married yesterday to Kenneth Mark Weil, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Weil of Madison, N.J. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg and the Rev. Dr. Bruce Barrabee, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Mr. Weil, who is studying for an M.B.A. at Harvard University, and his wife are graduates of Duke University.

title: SUSAN Y. TRUITT IS WED TO PETER E. LUNDBERG
description: At St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan, Conn., Susan Young Truitt and Peter Erik Lundberg were married yesterday by the Rev. Elwood Stark.

title: GERSHWIN STARS IN A DISPLAY OF AMERICAN MUSICAL VARIETY
description: America is famous for the diversity of its peoples, considered one of its great strengths. Its 20th-century music has the same diversity and perhaps a similar strength. At least it offers something for everyone, from the mystical daring of John Cage to the brilliant tunes of George Gershwin, from the reputedly (wrongly so) dry academicism of Walter Piston to the complex eclecticism of today's younger composers. These unoriginal comments serve merely to open the notice of a mulligan of American-music recordings.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE ELECTRIC HARVEST. By Tom Davies. (New English Library/David & Charles, $15.95.) The time is the near future, just prior to the turn of the 21st century.

title: BEHIND THE JOKES 'VOLUNTEERS' PONDERS ALTRUISM
description: After the film director Nicholas Meyer made ''The Day After,'' a 1983 television movie about nuclear holocaust in America, somebody called him an altruist.

title: MISS MOSHOS, ACCOUNTANT, IS MARRIED TO JAMES BULEY
description: Elizabeth Moshos, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. George J. Moshos of Moorestown, N. J., and James Dale Buley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dale Buley of Seaford, L.I. were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. George in Philadelphia. The Rev. Demetrios S. Katerlis performed the ceremony.

title: CARDINALS LOSE, 5-4, TO EXPOS
description: Jim Wohlford belted a two-out triple in the ninth inning to score Vance Law and give the Montreal Expos a 5-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: A CARLIN COMEDY, A DELDERFIELD DRAMA AND VINTAGE GLEASON
description: There are no mattresses on the sidewalk, but it may seem as if George Carlin has been evicted.

title: CHESS MADNESS
description: I twitched with renewed anxiety as I read Fred Waitzkin's article ''Fathering a Chess Prodigy'' (July 21). My experience with my daughter, Andrea, bears uncanny parallels to his. She won innumerable chess championships between age 4 and 12, including the United States Pre-Teen Title.

title: SRI LANKA REBELS, CHARGING NEW KILLINGS, WALK OUT OF TALKS
description: Leaders of Sri Lanka's minority Tamils accused the army today of new massacres of Tamil civilians and stormed out of peace talks with the Government.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''What G.M. is having is a classic Macy's-style inventory clearance sale.''

title: CHURCH GROUP WINS CITY'S HELP IN BROOKLYN HOUSING DRIVE
description: A coalition of churches seeking to revive the battered neighborhoods of eastern Brooklyn has received a commitment from New York City to help expand single-family housing in the East New York section.

title: Hospitals Chief Quits Amid Probe
description: In its short but stormy history, five of six previous presidents of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation have either been dismissed or forced to resign. Last week, John J. McLaughlin became the sixth.

title: U.S. HOLDS UP AID FOR SUBWAY WORK
description: The Federal Government has suspended payment of $44 million for a subway project in Queens, citing ''concerns with the construction management practices'' of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: HE WAS UNBEATABLE
description: THE QUEST FOR THE PRESIDENCY 1984 By Peter Goldman and Tony Fuller with Thomas M. DeFrank, Eleanor Clift, Lucille Beachy, Joyce Barnathan and Vern E. Smith. Illustrated. 468 pp. New York: A Newsweek Book/ Bantam Books. $17.95.

title: A CHANGING WORLD FOR PROFESSORS
description: STEFAN CHRISTIAN, who is entering his senior year at Swarthmore College, wants to be a college professor, and next month he will start sending out applications for doctoral programs in the classics. It is a career that he says he would not have opted for as recently as five years ago, when the outlook for academic employment was much less promising. ''My professor has told me that there will be jobs opening up by the time I get my doctorate in 1992 or 1993,'' said Mr. Christian, 20 years old, who is from Alexandria, Va. ''More people will be retiring then and enrollments will begin expanding.''

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: THE New Jersey Commission on Science and Technology will award a total of $200,000 in ''bridge'' grants of up to $40,000 each to small companies that have received seed money under the Federal Small Business Development Act of 1982.

title:
DINING OUT;

2 DINING PLACES WITH RIVER VIEWS
description: IT has always been surprising and not a little disappointing that so few restaurants take advantage of the view across the Hudson River. But now, with the booming redevelopment of the river's west bank, that is beginning to change. The two establishments reviewed this week both opened within the last few months and both offer marvelous wraparound water views.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TO BE A REVOLUTIONARY. By J. Guadalupe Carney. (Harper & Row, $15.95.) As an American infantryman in World War II, J. Guadalupe Carney decided to shoot in the air rather than risk killing German soldiers.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE STREET. By Israel Rabon. (Schocken, $14.95.) Few novels are as unrelentingly grim, desolate or grotesquely landscaped as ''The Street,'' first published in 1928.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

LONG VAN OF THE LAW
description: During these last days of summer, what could be better then a 35-foot-long recreational vehicle with all the extras: a V-8 engine, heavy-duty generators, air-conditioning, three-speed automatic transmission, power steering, a 70-gallon gas tank and special body painting.

title: The Curse Of Mercutio
description: ''It's still pretty smoky down there,'' says a U.S. official, examining satellite pictures of Iran's Kharg Island oil depot, hit last week by Iraqi missiles.

title: OPERA, CONCERTS AND RESTLESS CONDUCTORS
description: Opera is the most expensive art, and 20th-century opera is not reliable at the box office; those two facts conspire to keep many modern works from attaining enough performances to become familiar. But Aaron Copland's publishers (Boosey & Hawkes) and the conductor Murry Sidlin are conspiring on their own to make Mr. Copland's only full-length opera a tad less expensive.

title: ADVERTISERS TEST AN UNCHARTED MEDIUM
description: LAST year when the Red Lobster restaurant chain was approached by Backer & Spielvogel, its advertising agency, to sponsor a home video of the health and diet book ''Eat to Win,'' executives decided to gamble.

title: ROGER PLATT IS MARRIED TO CHRISTIE R. MERCER
description: Christie Raymond Mercer and Roger Platt were married yesterday in the Chapel of Grace at Grace Episcopal Cathedral in San Francisco by the Rev. Gordon Griffith. The bride is the daughter of Mrs. Donald Winters Mercer of Santa Fe, N.M., and the late Mr. Mercer.

title: Mayor Tightens Water Rules To Curb Use
description: Mayor Koch said last week that the city would start getting tougher on New Yorkers who fail to follow restrictions on water use. Maximum fines for people who water their lawns in defiance of limitations imposed during the drought were raised from $100 to $500, and fines for washing cars from $100 to $200.

title: CONCERN HEIGHTENS ON LEAKING RADON
description: POLITICIANS and environmental officials here and in New Jersey and Pennsylvania are beginning separate campaigns to deal with radon, a naturally occurring radioactive gas that is leaking into some homes in northern New Jersey.

title: Wedded Bliss Is Back in Fashion
description: I figured the big question about our 20th wedding anniversary might be whether the local newspaper would send a reporter out to interview us, the way reporters always used to interview those old codgers who managed to hit 100. (''Mr. Scroggins offers no formula for longevity, although he acknowledged that he has polished off a quart of Jim Beam whisky every day of his adult life.'') I figured that might be the big question even though the local newspaper is The Village Voice. Or maybe I figured that might be the big question because the local newspaper is The Village Voice. In Greenwich Village, after all, we are known rather widely for being married. We enjoy a mild collateral renown for having chil-dren. Several years ago, in fact, I expressed concern that we might be put on the Gray Line tour of Greenwich Village as a nuclear family.

title: MIDSUMMER NIGHTS: THE STUFF OF DREAMS
description: A DIFFERENT sort of darkness descends on summer nights - later, softer, romantic and somehow more innocent.

title: BORDER CROSSINGS
description: To the Editor: I, too, have crossed numerous borders in Europe, both East and West. However, I disagree with the author of the ''cautionary tale'' that his trying experience entering Rumania is indicative of the difference between East and West.

title: E.P.A. Opposes Wetland Mall But Plans a Hearing on Issue
description: The Environmental Protection Agency's regional office has formally announced that it opposes construction of a shopping mall on Attleboro's Sweeden Swamp, but said it had not made a final decision to block the project.

title: THE LYKES ROLE
description: To the Editor:

title: WRITER'S REJECTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN WEST ORANGE
description: THOMAS A. EDISON lived and worked in West Orange from 1887 until his death at Glenmont, his West Orange estate, in 1931. The tranquility he sought when he moved from Menlo Park remains, but West Orange is no longer the center of manufacturing he helped to create.

title: TriBeCa Offices
description: IN June 1984, Shearson Lehman/ American Express won approval to construct an office building on city-owned land in TriBeCa. In return, the financial-services company agreed to lend support to a new elementary school to be built in the Manhattan community.

title: LOVE, MARRIAGE AND A PEPPERONI TO GO
description: SPRING 1958: Relaxing before finals. Went out last night with this guy from the department. Sat behind me last semester in my 8:30. Wild man! Drive-in movie and pizza afterward.

title: 'Selling of L.I.': Further Response
description: In responding to Linda B. Martin's timely and most excellent article [''The Selling of Long Island: Price of Progress Is Too High,'' Opinion Page, June 23] , Lawrence Kaplan and Herbert Mandel [Letters to the Long Island Editor, July 21] offer several distorted views.

title: MISS MCLAUGHLIN WEDS IN CHICAGO
description: At St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Chicago yesterday Kathleen Ann McLaughlin, an assistant buyer with R. H. Macy & Company in New York, and John deCarteret Blondel Jr., an associate with Goldman Sachs & Company in New York, were married by the Rev. Russell Gavin.

title: A LANDMARK IN BLACK MUSIC LIFTS ITS VOICE AGAIN
description: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 -

title: BORDER CROSSINGS
description: To the Editor: Edward Cowan's ''Along an East European Border'' (Travel, July 28) recalled my unpleasant experience. I've crossed most West European borders with great ease.

title: ARMY-REBEL PEACE TALKS ARE REPORTED IN UGANDA
description: A newspaper said today that the Ugandan Army had held secret peace talks with a field commander of the country's strongest rebel group.

title: CRIME
description: Like its predecessors, THE FAR AWAY MAN by William Marshall (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, $14.95) is set in Yellowthread Street in Hong Kong. Yellowthread Street is where the police station is located. Once again Chief Inspector Harry Feiffer is in charge of a bizarre case. There is this spooky killer who apparently strikes haphazardly. But after a while a pattern emerges. The series of murders appears to have something to do with vaccination certificates.

title: CANCER RESEARCHER HONORED
description: THE state's war on cancer -which kills 47 New Jerseyans on an average day -took a leap forward earlier this month when Governor Kean announced a $9.7 million award to Dr. David M. Goldenberg for his diagnostic work.

title: MURALS ABOVE THE MAILBAGS
description: The post office mural, with its scenes of history, industry, agriculture and progress, is a distinctively American art form. In DEMOCRATIC VISTAS: Post Offices and Public Art in the New Deal (Temple University, $37.95), Marlene Park, an art historian, and Gerald E. Markowitz, a historian, both at John Jay College in New York, show how this genre emerged from a ''curious interplay of federal bureaucrats, creative artists, and small town citizens.''

title: . . . Word of Warning
description: Even announcements made pro forma become memorable if they are embellished.

title: Officer Taken Hostage At New Mexico Prison
description: About 40 convicts at the New Mexico State Penitentiary took a corrections officer, Robert Greeny, hostage shortly before midnight tonight, according to a spokesman for the Corrections Department.

title: Big Bicentennial Plans
description: Some things about Washington institutions never change. The Commission on the Bicentennial of the Constitution is less than two months old, but it is already looking for more money to spend on the celebration and more staff to plan it.

title: CONGRESS AND E.P.A. WORK ON PROGRAMS TO IDENTIFY HAZARDS
description: Spurred by last December's chemical disaster in Bhopal, India, Congress and more recently the Environmental Protection Agency have been working on programs to help states and communities identify potential chemical hazards and develop emergency procedures for coping with leaks.

title: PLAN FOR CONDOMINIUMS SPLITS QUITE CHAUTAUQUA
description: On the front porches and in the high-ceilinged parlors of the Victorian houses that have become a hallmark of the historic Chautauqua Institution, a controversy is brewing over the construction of condominiums.

title: STUDENT STUNTMAN BECOMES 7TH TO CONQUER NIAGARA FALLS
description: A 22-year-old Rhode Island man and student stuntman today became the seventh person to plummet successfully over Niagara Falls.

title: Argentines Back Fight on Inflation
description: More than two months after President Raul Alfonsin introduced a bold and unexpected program to halt inflation, the majority of Argentines - worse off economically than they were the month before the plan was announced - remain behind the Government's effort.

title: BRIDGE: THE MANY CAVENDISH CLUBS KEEP A FAMOUS NAME ALIVE
description: When the great whist authority of the 19th century, Henry Jones, used the pseudonym ''Cavendish'' for his numerous writings he was not impertinently borrowing the family name of the Dukes of Devonshire. He was simply using the name of his London club, which had connections with the English aristocrats.

title: CAROL WILKINS GINIGER
description: Carol Wilkins Giniger, controller of the American Ethical Union and vice president of the K. S. Giniger Company, New York book publishers, died of cancer Aug. 11 at the home of her mother, Leona R. Wilkins, in Dennisport, Mass. Mrs. Giniger was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Recovering Legal Fees
description: The idea that lawyers who win civil rights, consumer and environmental lawsuits should be able to collect legal fees from the Federal Government has disturbed conservative members of Congress for some time now, and Senators Orrin G. Hatch of Utah and John P. East of North Carolina have long sponsored legislation that would limit the rate of recovered fees to $75 an hour, a relatively low figure by current standards. The Reagan Administration has supported such limits.

title: PENALTIES SINK RAIDERS, 14-9
description: The Los Angeles Raiders had two apparent touchdowns called back today against the Washington Redskins, and lost, 14-9, in a nationally televised preseason game.

title: FREDERICK BOLMAN, AN EDUCATOR AND AUTHOR, DIES
description: Dr. Frederick deWolfe Bolman Jr., a former college president who served as associate and then executive director of the Exxon Education Foundation from 1964 to 1977, died of cancer last Wednesday at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Stamford.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption in some copies Saturday with the Sports People column did not apply to the picture it accompanied. The picture showed the tennis player Andrea Jaeger, not the runner Mary Decker Slaney.

title: Bubka Triumphs; 2 Titles to Soviet
description: Sergei Bubka, despite falling short in an attempt to break the world record in the pole vault, won his event today and the Soviet Union took both the men's and women's European Cup track titles, breaking East Germany's longtime hold on the championships.

title: DENATIONALIZATION IN FRANCE
description: Pressures are building in France to sell back to private investors the great swath of industry and banking that President Francois Mitterrand and his ruling Socialists nationalized after they took power four years ago. The move comes just as many of these companies are finally turning a profit.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 19, 1985: *2*MONDAY Century Tel Entrprise RTE Corp First Interstate Bncrp San Diego Gas & Elec *2*TUESDAY American Cyanamid The Gap Inc Amer District Tel Longs Drug Stores Armstrong Rubber Ohio Edison Co Bandag Inc Robertshaw Controls Coleman Co Triton Energy Duquesne Light Wolverine World Wide Firestone Tire&Rbber *2*WEDNESDAY Belding-Heminway Marine Midland Banks Collins Foods Intl Morse Shoe GEICO Corp United Jersey Banks Intl Minerals & Chem Utah Pwr & Lt Magic Chef *2*THURSDAY Beneficial Corp Morton-Thiokol Inc Ex-Cell O Corp Steego Corp Interlake Inc Sun Chemical Corp *2*FRIDAY Bairnco Corp Scotty's Inc Dexter Corp South Jersey Indus Edwards (AG) Inc Varian Associates Harris Corp (Del) Whittaker Corp Piedmont Natural Gas

title:
AGAIN, THE SCOURGE OF CHEMICAL WEAPONS;

In Europe, A Move to Bar Them
description: CONGRESS has renounced the United States moratorium on production of chemical weapons, and next month it is expected to approve funds for that purpose. This could have grave and lasting effects on Western Europeans' attitude toward the Atlantic alliance.

title: Murphy, Benoit Win Road Races
description: Dave Murphy of England led an international field in the 13th Falmouth Road Race today, trimming 15 seconds from his previous winning time but falling 10 seconds short of setting a course record.

title: Brazil Coffee Chief Resigns
description: Karlos Rischbieter, the head of the Government coffee board, the Brazilian Coffee Institute, resigned Friday, the Government said.

title: ESTIMATES REDUCED ON 2D-HALF GROWTH
description: After saying for months that the nation's economy would rebound vigorously in the second half of 1985, many business economists now are downgrading their estimates of that rebound, or pushing it further back.

title: Dr. Richard S. Schloss Marries Meredith Jaffe
description: At the Midway Jewish Center in Syosset, L.I., yesterday Meredith Bryce Jaffe and Dr. Richard Steven Schloss were married by Rabbi Ezra Finkelstein. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Roy Jaffe of Plainview, L.I. Dr. Schloss is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Schloss of Brooklyn.

title: A 2-HOUR 'LIFESTYLES'
description: WE know where we are in ''Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous - The Superstars.'' We're in the land of superlatives, and price tags show us the way. Things aren't super; they're super-duper, and they cost big bucks besides. The two-hour program, on Channel 11 at 8 o'clock tonight, has a certain tacky charm.

title: CREDIBLE DETERRENT NEEDED
description: THE Reagan Administration has requested $163 million to produce chemical weapons. At the same time, the Administration is negotiating with the Soviet Union and others in Geneva to produce a treaty that will ban chemical weapons from the face of the earth. A contradiction? No. A credible deterrent is needed until an agreement can be achieved. We believe that restoring our deterrent will in fact facilitate an agreement.

title: JUST FOR GIRLS, NEW DRESSES INSPIRED BY THE PAST
description: Imagine that you want to design a line of children's clothes and you have access to the entire Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. That is what happened to Seibel & Stern, the girls' wear manufacturer licensed by the museum to produce clothing adapted from its collection.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: Marcy Ellen Ressler Weds John B. Harris
description: Marcy Ellen Ressler, a third-year law student at New York University, and John Barney Harris, an N.Y.U. Law School graduate who will become an associate next month with the New York firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, were married yesterday. The ceremony at Beth El Synagogue in Waterbury, Conn., was performed by Rabbi Charles Freundlich, assisted by Rabbi Leigh D. Lerner.

title: Media Suit By Ex-Officer
description: A former Evening News Association executive sued the media company Friday, asserting that it acted improperly in dismissing him on charges of giving confidential documents to outsiders in a $453 million takeover bid.

title: BOSTON PLANNING RENOVATION OF DECAYING LIBRARY BUILDING
description: Mayor Raymond L. Flynn and trustees of the Boston Public Library have announced a $13.4 million plan to renovate the library's central building, which has deteriorated to the point where its priceless book collection is threatened and its murals are withering.

title: South African Blacks Murdered by Blacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Storms Cause a Death And Injure 4 in Kansas
description: Violent storms tore through a mobile home park over the weekend, killing one man and injuring four others in central Kansas, officials said today.

title: OUTDOORS: PROTECTING GROUSE
description: ALTHOUGH the ruffed grouse, perhaps this country's most cherished upland game bird, has been around since the Ice Age and is found all across central North America from the Atlantic to the Pacific, its champions do not relax.

title: U.S. Swimmers Set Medley Mark
description: Matt Biondi led the American men's team to a world record today in winning the 400-meter medley relay at the Pan Pacific Swimming Championship, the second world record set by United States team members at the meet.

title: GAS PRICES TOOK A NEW PATH UP FOR SUMMER DRIVERS
description: During the energy crises of the 1970's, the American public learned that when crude oil prices rise, gasoline prices at the pump do too. For most of this year, however, the public has found that even when oil prices fall, gasoline prices may rise.

title: ETHIOPIA'S CAPITALIST AIRLINE
description: Imagine a corporation wholly owned by committed Communists but run on the basis of unabashedly capitalist principles. Or conceptualize a state-owned company in Africa that is lean, efficient and praised by its customers for its excellent service. Sound improbable? Then picture a generally profitable company, with relatively well-paid workers, all of whom are citizens of the poorest nation in the world.

title: Dr. Michelle Friedman Is Wed to Benjamin Belfer
description: At the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue yesterday Dr. Michelle E. Friedman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Friedman of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and Benjamin Belfer, the son of Henriette Belfer Jacobs of Forest Hills, Queens, and the late Maurice Belfer, were married by Rabbi Saul Berman.

title: Catching Up
description: * Marvin Skagerberg, the 47-year-old New Yorker who last month defeated a rival ultramarathoner in a coast-to-coast race from Los Angeles, feels none the worse for the exhausting effort but says he still does not have a complete sense of what he achieved. ''When I look at a map of the country,'' he explains, ''I don't have the feeling that I covered all that territory.

title: COHALAN ASSERTS LILCO'S PAYMENT MEANS A TAX CUT
description: Suffolk County Executive Peter F. Cohalan said yesterday that because of the Long Island Lighting Company's payment of $131 million in back taxes for its Shoreham nuclear plant, his next budget proposal would include a cut in property taxes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 19, 1985
description: International

title: MANVILLE'S DIFFICULT FUTURE
description: Josh T. Hulce, president of the Manville Corporation, likens the impact of the past three years on his company to being hardened by fire.

title: MEETING IS UNLIKELY FOR RACING'S BIG 2
description: Spend a Buck and Chief's Crown passed important tests in winning major races Saturday, but it is unclear when and if the nation's two top 3-year-olds will meet to decide the division championship.

title: U.S. HOSTAGE TOOK PHOTOS IN BEIRUT
description: One of the 39 Americans held hostage in Beirut after their plane was hijacked in June hid a camera from his Moslem captors and secretly took three dozen color pictures of his companions, the building in which they were confined and the surrounding landscape. He later gave the pictures to American authorities.

title: Celia Paul, Consultant, Wed to Stephen Rosen
description: Celia Ann Paul, the daughter of Sol J. Paul of Princeton, N.J., and Aileen Phillips of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to Stephen Rosen, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rosen of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Greenberg officiated at the bride's home in East Hampton, L.I.

title: Filipino Centrists Form An Opposition Alliance
description: Centrists of the opposition founded a new Filipino alliance today. They said it was a democratic alternative to President Ferdinand E. Marcos's Government and to the Communist Party campaign of armed revolution.

title: Cards Fall to Expos in 10th
description: Terry Francona's two-run single off the third baseman Terry Pendleton's glove in the 10th inning gave the Montreal Expos a 6-5 victory today over the St. Louis Cardinals and Joaquin Andujar.

title: SWISS LANGUAGE GAP WIDENS AS GERMANIC DIALECT THRIVES
description: The first sign greeting travelers at the Zurich airport says, in four languages, ''Welcome,'' ''Bienvenue,'' ''Willkommen,'' and ''Gruezi,'' a Swiss-German greeting that is roughly translated as ''God bless.''

title: Measuring Up
description: The hoary debate as to which homer was the most monstrous in major league history is being rekindled because of Paul Susman, a clinical psychologist and sports fan from Skokie, Ill., who is writing a book called ''Explosion: The Legendary Home Runs of Mickey Mantle.'' Susman long ago heard about a rocket that Mantle launched off Paul Foytack, a Detroit right-hander, at Tiger Stadium on Sept. 10, 1960, and he now has a bit of evidence, even mathematical evidence, that it was the longest ball ever hit by any batter anywhere.

title: Confusion Over Henderson
description: Rickey Henderson, missing a second consecutive game, did not play for the Yankees yesterday, and details about the center fielder's absence from the lineup were murky. After missing Saturday's game, Henderson said that he was told that he would miss yesterday's game as well.

title: DEMOCRATIC GROUP STUMPS CALIFORNIA FOR RECRUITS
description: A panel of Democratic leaders pledged to reshaping their party barnstormed in California last week, seeking recruits, money and credibility.

title: Banks Triumphs
description: Willie Banks of the United States won the men's triple jump today at the Nikkan Nighter Track and Field Meet with a leap of 56 feet 11 1/2 inches, 2 feet short of the world record he set June 16. Banks was the only American athlete taking part in the meet at the National Stadium.

title: Water-Saving Plates
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: 13 LAWYERS ARGUE 'THE NASSAU 1% CASE'
description: At times there are more lawyers than spectators in Courtroom A in Federal District Court here, where a six-member jury is hearing testimony in what has become known as ''the Nassau County 1 percent case.''

title: Kahane Steps Down As Head of the J.D.L.
description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, who founded the Jewish Defense League before becoming a member of the Israeli Parliament, has resigned as the group's leader, his successor said today.

title: Topics;   Restoring Rights Foolish Choice
description: According to a Federal court in Albany, Dr. Robert Fay, a divorced father of two, has the same right to receive information mailed from his children's school as his former wife. The wonder is not that Judge Robert Miner so held, but that Dr. Fay had to sue the school district for such elementary fairness.

title: . . . Utter Confusion
description: Repairs to the Manhattan Bridge have not made life at all easy for Brooklyn commuters.

title: Eleanor Biddle Lloyd Is Dead; Patron of Contemporary Art
description: Eleanor Biddle Lloyd, a trustee of several Philadelphia art institutions, died Thursday at her summer home on Cape Cod, Mass., after a short illness. She was 79 years old and lived in Haverford, Pa.

title: Minebea Borrowings
description: The Minebea Company said Friday that it would borrow $200 million from two syndicates to finance takeover bids for unspecified companies, said a spokesman for the Sumitomo Trust and Banking Company.

title: Advertising;   Club Med Tries New Campaign
description: IF Club Mediterranee, the 35-year-old French resort company, wanted to change its image as the provider of vacations for the young and the restless, it has not quite done it with its new $10 million media campaign.

title: Washington Watch;   Freer Trade In High Tech
description: DESPITE the big buildup of protectionist pressures in Washington, the United States and Japan are rapidly abolishing tariffs in high technology products.

title: 65,000 SPRINGSTEEN FANS WELCOME SINGER HOME
description: After 13 months on the road - after playing to sellout crowds in Australia, Europe, Japan and cities all across America - Bruce Springsteen came home tonight.

title: D'AMATO STYLE: PLAIN TALK AND HARD DRIVE
description: The Senator from New York put on his baby-talk voice. ''Penny, girl,'' Alfonse M. D'Amato cooed into the phone in his Washington office, ''do me a little favor, will ya?''

title: ISRAEL CLEARS A GENERAL IN 2 ARAB DEATHS
description: An Israeli general was cleared by an army hearing today of using excessive violence against two Palestinian bus hijackers who were beaten and kicked to death by Israeli Army and security personel.

title: SNAGS CITED IN QUOTA PLAN FOR STEEL
description: The Reagan Administration has failed to reduce steel imports, industry executives said last week, despite a pledge made 11 months ago to do so. But many said that they expected improved figures for the second half of this year.

title: Treasury Will Auction 2-Year Notes
description: Treasury financings this week consist of a two-year note auction on Wednesday besides today's regular auction of new bills due in three and six months.

title: Uplifting Endeavor
description: There is no marathon event in downhill skiing, and for a good reason: There aren't any mountains 26 miles high. Now, however, a group of eight skiers has surmounted this oversight of nature by developing an ingenious endurance test that could be called the multistage skiing marathon for the truly foolhardy. Instead of a single run down a 26-mile mountain, they decided to take a slope with a quarter-mile vertical drop and ski it 100 times each in a single day.

title: Voices on the Subway: A Parting Wish . . .
description: Riding to lower Manhattan on the Lexington Avenue IRT line, Michael R. Jacobson often notices a conductor on the sleek new R-62 cars who lets passengers off with a cheery exhortation.

title: Chemical Leak on Train Forces 2 Evacuations
description: A leaking railroad tank car that had forced the evacuation of 1,000 people overnight in Pendleton, Ind., prompted a second evacuation today after it leaked more of a toxic chemical, officials said.

title: In Islam, a Fundamentalist Confrontation
description: To the Editor:

title: Geers Gross Appoints An Old Nemesis
description: Geers Gross Advertising has named as its president Henry J. Wasiak, a man who as president of another company dismissed the agency seven years ago. He replaces Marvin Honig, who became executive vice president and chief creative officer at Leber Katz Partners last week.

title: RUN ON MARYLAND THRIFT UNIT
description: Depositors of Community Savings and Loan Inc. of Bethesda, Md., waited in line to make withdrawals over the weekend after the disclosure that a real estate investment subsidiary affiliated with the thrift unit had missed some debt payments.

title: ROCK: SRPINGSTEEN BEGINS 6-CONCERT SERIES
description: Let us not pussyfoot about this: Bruce Springsteen's opening-night New York-area concert at Giants Stadium here tonight - nearly four hours of it, counting a 40-minute intermission - was a flat-out, unqualified triumph. It was even markedly better than the remarkable show that Mr. Springsteen and his E Street Band offered here just over a year ago, in the Brendan Byrne Arena right across the parking lot.

title: Sandra C. Isham Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Sandra Calhoun Isham, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Heyward Isham of Washington and Sagaponack, L.I., was married yesterday to Alexander Vreeland, a son of Frederick Vreeland of Rome and the late Elizabeth Vreeland Tompkins of Washington. The Rev. John Miraglia of the Peace Community Church in Washington performed the ceremony at the Isham home in Sagaponack.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Wright Looks Ahead
description: Shortly before Congress recessed for August, Representative Jim Wright of Texas recounted the commitments he had received from Democratic colleagues to support his rising from majority leader to Speaker in 1987, after Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. of Massachusetts retires. They totaled, according to associates, 204 of the 253 current Democrats.

title: Futures/Options;   Hedging Debt With Stocks
description: ALTHOUGH Treasury bond and other long-term financial futures and options were designed to help portfolio managers hedge fixed-income holdings against adverse interest rate moves, experience has shown that these forms of insurance often provide inadequate coverage.

title: SCATTERED UNREST IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Isolated incidents of unrest continued in black townships around South Africa today, and a black woman was killed when she was run over by a truck driven by a man trying to flee looting and stone-throwing youths outside Port Elizabeth.

title: A Sound New Policy on Insurance
description: Mutual life insurance companies - insurers cooperatively owned by their policyholders - are asking the New York Legislature for the right to convert to stockholder ownership. It's a sensible proposition. This big New York-based industry needs the flexibility of stock ownership to thrive in the deregulated financial services industry.

title: Bonn Reported to Face 'Serious' Spy Scandal
description: A West German Cabinet minister's aide who disappeared early this month was a spy planted in the mid-1950's by the East German secret service, the D.P.A. news agency reported today.

title: CARBIDE LEAK HIGHLIGHTS DEFECTS IN SYSTEMS HANDLING TOXIC MATTER
description: The leak of toxic gas from a Union Carbide plant in West Virginia last week has focused new attention on safety design problems at thousands of chemical plant processing units where hazardous materials are handled, industry consultants say.

title: Gorilla That 'Talks' Cheered by New Pets
description: Koko, the ''talking'' gorilla that went into deep depression after her pet kitten was killed by a car, is cheering up as she learns to love two new feline companions, Lips and Smoky, her trainers say.

title: TOP U.S. AIDE SEES ABYSS OF VIOLENCE FOR SOUTH AFRICA
description: Robert C. McFarlane, the President's national security adviser, said today that both blacks and whites in South Africa are ''looking into an abyss of massive violence,'' and he urged black leaders to challenge the Pretoria Government to produce specific changes to match what he termed vague promises.

title: Bankrupt Nations Should Sell Assets
description: To the Editor:

title: Pintor Outpoints Meza for Title
description: Guadalupe Pintor, a hard-hitting veteran, won the World Boxing Council super-bantamweight crown today with a unanimous decision over Juan Meza.

title: FRANCE TO BLOCK PACIFIC PROTESTS
description: President Francois Mitterrand ordered France's armed forces tonight to prevent ''by force if necessary'' any attempt to enter French territorial waters where nuclear tests are scheduled to be held.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Both sides can get you. You never know which side is against you.''

title: EVEN A NIGHT ON THE TOWN SHOWS APARTHEID'S EFFECT
description: The man who sells Picassos and Chagalls in a glittery part of this city said: Well, no, things are not going too badly in South Africa these days.

title: The State of New York City Transit: 'It Makes Me Want to Cry'
description: To the Editor:

title: WHEN CITIZENS, AND SUMMER, CLAIM THE CAPITAL
description: ''When will Congress be back?'' a Washington cabbie, Naser Ashlam, asked plaintively. ''Business is bad.''

title: PAKISTANIS AWAIT RETURN OF ZIA'S FOE
description: After a year and a half of self-imposed exile, a popular leader of the opposition to President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq is scheduled to return to Pakistan this week for a family funeral and an emotional but uncertain welcome.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MANON' MAKES SEASON DEBUT
description: THE opera house is the worst place in the world to be when things are going wrong or only partly right. But now and then everything falls into place, as it did last night with the New York City Opera's ''Manon,'' and then there is nowhere in the world a melomaniac would rather be. This first ''Manon'' of the season rapidly developed into a love affair between the audience and the two principals: Faith Esham as the amoral, pleasure-loving Manon and Jerry Hadley as her puppet-on-a-string lover.

title: CITY OPERA: 'MIKADO'
description: SIR ARTHUR SULLIVAN'S overture to ''The Mikado'' -one great tune after another - is enough to put anyone in a good mood, and the sight of the Thierry Bosquet sets and costumes used at the State Theater can only heighten it when the curtain goes up, so any cast the New York City Opera puts into the piece has the public on its side before the Gentlemen of Japan utter a note.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: EXHIBITION ON JAMAICA It may seem incongruous - an art show in the lobby of a building that houses the offices of the F.B.I., the C.I.A. and the Immigration and Naturalization Service. But there's one on view at the Jacob K. Javits Federal Building, 26 Federal Plaza, called ''The Fifth Annual Art Exhibition -In Celebration of Jamaica's 23d Independence Anniversary.''

title: RINALDI TAKES JERSEY CLASSIC
description: Kathy Rinaldi, already an old pro in women's tennis at age 18, today defeated Steffi Graf to capture the championship of the United Jersey Bank Classic and her first American victory. The score was 6-4, 3-6, 6-4 in the 2-hour-7-minute match played before 4,083 spectators.

title: SPENCER-DEVLIN TRIUMPHS
description: Muffin Spencer-Devlin, attributing her success to a book on yoga that she was reading the night before, shot 10 birdies today on her way to a 64 and her first victory on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour.

title: New Post of President Filled at Chase Leasing
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced that Theodore L. Daleiden had been named to the new position of president at its leasing subsidiary, the Chase Manhattan Leasing Corporation.

title: Jan Amy Rostov Marries R. M. Kutler in California
description: Jan Amy Rostov, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Rostov of Greenwich, Conn., and West Dummerston, Vt., was married yesterday to Robert Martin Kutler, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Benton Kutler of Omaha.

title: . . . Helpful Advice
description: ''We are going to be held here by holding lights.''

title: TUTU SAYS HE WON'T JOIN OTHER ANGLICANS IN MEETING BOTHA
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu said tonight that he would not join an Anglican delegation that is to meet on Monday with President P. W. Botha to discuss ways to defuse black protests.

title: PLETHORA OF PUNTERS PERPLEXES GIANTS
description: Now things start to get difficult for the Giants.

title: Eileen M. Price Is Married To Steven Adam Farbman
description: Eileen Marcia Price, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Price of New York, was married yesterday to Steven Adam Farbman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Farbman of Sarasota, Fla. Rabbi Harlan Wechsler performed the ceremony at the Park Avenue Synagogue.

title: Leave Affirmative Action Alone
description: The Reagan Administration wants to repeal affirmative action requirements for Federal contractors in place for 20 years. The effort is just the latest in a series of retrogressive acts that ignore history and undermine social progress.

title: OIL INTERESTS BACK BUSH WITH MONEY
description: Donations from oil and gas interests accounted for a substantial portion of the more than $800,000 raised by Vice President Bush's political action committee in its first two months, according to the committee's first report, made public earlier this month by the Federal Election Commission.

title: SPANISH TRADE MEANS FRENCH TOWN'S RISE OR FALL
description: Salvador Dali once declared that the clock in the Perpignan railroad station was the navel of the universe. It is a question of perspective and Dali's guess about the true center of things is probably as good as anyone's. What can be said with some degree of accuracy is that this is very much the center of a part of France on the verge of profound change.

title: Superfund Cleanups Need a Congressional Push
description: To the Editor:

title: MAKER OF WEBER GRILL FIGHTS TO STAY ON TOP
description: With its potbellied profile, the Weber grill, manufactured by the Weber-Stephen Products Company, is something of a grande dame among charcoal grills. Each summer, the grill's stout silhouette is a standard feature at millions of outdoor barbecues.

title: Topics;   Restoring Rights Death, Black and White
description: The grossest racial segregation has been eradicated in most of America. Yet some vestiges of the old system remain. From a friend in rural east Texas comes word that one such remnant is disappearing, and not everyone is pleased.

title: FED SEEN FACING A DILEMMA
description: With the economy off to a weak start in the second half, but money supply growth still booming, Federal Reserve officials who meet tomorrow to set a course for monetary policy face a dilemma for which there is no simple solution that will satisfy everybody.

title: F.A.A. Sets Drug Use Tests
description: The Federal Aviation Administration Friday ordered annual urinalysis tests to check the agency's 14,000 air traffic controllers for use of drugs or alcohol abuse. ''There have been occasional incidents that suggest that the agency is not totally immune from the drug and alcohol abuse problems,'' said Donald D. Engen, the agency's Administrator. The tests will also be administered to agency pilots, safety inspectors, police officers and firefighters, he said, and penalties for using drugs will range from reassignment to dismissal.

title: MEMORIES OF COACHES
description: SHECKY GREENE stopped in Manhattan briefly before traveling to Browns Resort in the Borscht Belt for a show on Saturday night. While here, we visited. We had never met, but we had a few things in common. For one, he and I - he is older by 14 years - are the only two graduates of Sullivan High School in Chicago that I know of to make it to Carnegie Hall at the same time. The date was last March 28. He performed on stage and I sat in the audience and watched.

title: TEMPORARY: TYPIST OR FISCAL WHIZ
description: The President is guaranteed a job in this city for only four years. A Senator gets six. A House member has only two. In Washington, it seems, only the temporary workers are here to stay.

title: Edward Rust, 66, Dies; State Farm's President
description: Edward B. Rust, the president and chief executive officer of the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, died here today. He was 66 years old.

title: IN THE CARIBBEAN, A POPULAR NEW LEADER
description: In the annual carnival parade here this year - the biggest, most rambunctious celebration on this Caribbean island just off Venezuela - a tall, imposing woman in a pink and green lame costume got a little more attention than the other dancers.

title: ONE AMATEUR STAYS, ONE MOVES ON
description: IT was hot at the golf course as Jay Sigel faced his approach shot. Perspiration rolled down his jawbone. To the left of the 16th green, off the small stream he hoped to avoid, a faint mist rose. The golf course can be a dreamy place and this day it was. It was really hot. Everything around the golfers, the swinging oak branches and a few old country clubbers, seemed to hang limply like some old plants that had been left out to soak in the moisture.

title: NEW FIGHTING IN SRI LANKA AFTER TALKS FALTER
description: New fighting broke out today after the apparent collapse of peace talks between Government officials and minority Tamil rebels fighting for a separate state on the south Asian island nation.

title: YANKS TOP RED SOX, 4-2
description: Thrown off ever so slightly by the backdrop of a murky gray sky and the glow of the Yankee Stadium lights, Billy Sample dived headlong and made one of the most memorable catches of the Yankee season yesterday.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Co., Greenwich, Conn., has appointed Walter A. Scott senior vice president and deputy sector executive of its financial services sector. He was also named senior executive vice president of Associated Madison Companies Inc., the holding company for all of American Can's financial services subsidiaries.

title: 'HOMETOWN' ZEROS IN ON YUPPIES
description: Wide-eyed and smiling, they sat side by side in a sparsely furnished office just off the set of the new series they are writing and producing for CBS. For the hundredth time, Dinah and Julie Kirgo listened to The Question.

title: Miss Berinstein Becomes a Bride
description: Dori Ann Berinstein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan William Berinstein of Los Angeles, and Craig Mitchell Wasserman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bert W. Wasserman of Dix Hills, L.I., were married yesterday at Le Bel Age Hotel in Los Angeles by Rabbi Alfred Wolf.

title: LEMOND AND LONGO WINNERS
description: Greg LeMond, who had worn the race leader's jersey since the fifth day, won the 16-stage Coors International Bicycle Classic today along with his Red Zinger team.

title: Money Cited At S.M.U.
description: The recruiting of the tackle Sean Stopperich has been cited as the worst violation at Southern Methodist in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's decision to slap the school with the harshest penalty in N.C.A.A. history, The Dallas Times Herald reported today.

title: CALIFORNIA HEARING SET ON UNITARY TAX CHANGE
description: The latest effort to revise California's so-called worldwide unitary method of taxation, which determines the percentage of multinational concerns' profits that are subject to the state's 9.6 percent corporation tax, is scheduled for a key hearing Monday before a State Assembly committee in Sacramento.

title: ALCOTT IS WINNER IN PLAYOFF
description: Amy Alcott knocked in a two-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff today to beat Patty Sheehan and capture the Ladies Professional Golf Association Nestle World Championship of Women's Golf.

title: ARCHDIOCESE IS CONSIDERING A SHELTER FOR AIDS PATIENTS
description: The Archdiocese of New York is ''very seriously considering'' opening a center to shelter and care for victims of AIDS, according to John Cardinal O'Connor.

title: Bits of Thyroid in Beef Make 98 Ill in Midwest
description: Ground beef containing bits of thyroid glands from cattle that sickened at least 98 people has been removed from stores, a health official said today.

title: Sykes Datatronics
description: Sykes Datatronics Inc. said Friday that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code after two banks demanded repayment of $7.5 million in loans the company was unable to pay. The company, which makes computerized equipment for the telecommunications industry, was hurt by the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, its biggest customer. Sykes said it had $27 million in assets and $12.3 million in liabilities as of June 30.

title: Dwight Smith 3d, Lawyer, Is Wed to Mindy L. Kotler
description: The marriage of Mindy Linda Kotler, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. David Kotler of Kingston and Middletown, N.Y., to Dwight C. Smith 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Smith Jr. of Albany, took place yesterday at the bride's home in Middletown. Rabbi Alvin Roth and the Rev. Stephen C. Williams, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the interfaith ceremony.

title: WHAT RESORTS SEES IN PAN AM
description: Resorts International Inc., which disclosed on Friday that it had accumulated an 8.8 percent stake in the parent company of Pan American World Airways, may be attracted to the ailing carrier because it believes it will recover soon from its problems, analysts said yesterday.

title: LOST JOB LED TO A NEW CAREER
description: He works on antisubmarine systems for Analysis Technology Inc., a Navy contractor. His clearance has been upgraded from his days in the military. He has been part of the Presidential study on cost control, known as the Grace Commission, the Brookings Institution and IBM. As a sideline, he is president of his agency's $300,000 credit union.

title: COURT TO DETERMINE IF MISS LIBERTY IS A JERSEYAN
description: Is the Statue of Liberty a New Yorker?

title: Ford Korean Import Is Seen
description: The Ford Motor Company will begin importing a South Korean-made minicar about June 1987, an industry journal reported.

title: FATHER'S ARREST DEEPENS A SMALL-TOWN MYSTERY
description: When 13-year-old Sarah Ann Rairdon disappeared in May, the people of Underwood rallied together to search for her and comfort her family. When her body was found seven weeks later, they mourned together.

title: NEW YORK LOTTO PRIZE TO TOP $28 MILLION
description: Nobody won the $23 million grand prize in Saturday night's Lotto 48 game, so the jackpot will be at least $28.5 million for Wednesday's drawing, New York lottery officials said today.

title: Bell's Homer Helps Jays Win
description: Jesse Barfield hit a bases-loaded triple and George Bell drove in four runs with a two-run homer and a pair of sacrifice flies today, powering the Toronto Blue Jays to a 10-6 victory over the Kansas City Royals.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS LENDL
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe beat Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia for the second time in a week today, capturing the Player's International Tournament and its $51,000 top prize with a 7-5, 6-3 victory.

title: Washington Watch;   Thinking the Unthinkable
description: Most economists are not looking for another recession any time soon. They expect the Federal Reserve to continue letting interest rates fall to spur new growth.

title: TRUMP SAYS LIPPER SOUGHT A GIFT
description: Donald Trump, the real-estate developer, said yesterday that Kenneth Lipper, a candidate for City Council President who has criticized an opponent for accepting a campaign contribution from him, asked Mr. Trump to contribute to his own campaign.

title: Big Band
description: Without time to rehearse before the concert, a small crowd of strangers met outside an amphitheater in East River Park and picked up their instruments: vacuum-cleaner pipes, watering cans and soda bottles, drums, an electric organ, woodwinds and electric guitars.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: LAKE WOBEGON DAYS. By Garrison Keillor. 337 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: HUGGABLE NEGOTIATORS
description: SINCE the baseball strike was settled in two days and the season resumed on Aug. 8, there has been an overindulgence of baseball in this household, a gorging of the senses. At most hours of the day and night, the television has been buzzing to celebrate what we nearly lost: Gooden here, Guidry there, here a Cub, there a Brave, everywhere a high five.

title: CONCERT: SCHUBERT
description: SURPRISINGLY, the highlight of Saturday's Mostly Mozart program was not Yo-yo Ma, who sold out Avery Fisher Hall, but a performance of Schubert's ''Tragic'' symphony (D. 417) that found the festival orchestra playing with more character and commitment than has sometimes been the case. Gerard Schwarz's conducting caught both the nervous urge of the short melodic shapes in the first movement and the gentle, affecting plaint of the falling phrases in the second. There were times when one might have wished for a more liquid flow, more bouyant motion, but the orchestral sound was alert and well-balanced, and the piece held together most persuasively.

title: Soviet Grain Shortfall Seen
description: Although the Soviet Union's grain farmers have benefited from good weather this year, Western agricultural experts said Friday that the crop, estimated at about 190 million metric tons, was below target for the seventh consecutive year.

title: 4 Join Agent Orange Board
description: Four Vietnam veterans have been named to serve as members of an advisory board to help administer a $180 million Agent Orange settlement fund, a Federal judge said yesterday. The judge, Jack B. Weinstein of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, named Donna-Marie Boulay, a lawyer in Minneapolis; Albert Dandridge 3d, a corporate lawyer in Philadelphia; Vincent Martin Jr., a financial planner in Paramus, N.J., and John McElrath, a project manager for a data-processing company in Fairfax, Va. Charles Hagel was appointed July 11 to be chairman of the five-member board.

title: ROBERT MOTHERWELL GETS MACDOWELL MEDAL
description: In a ceremony marked by speeches that provoked laughter and tears, the artist Robert Motherwell today received the MacDowell Colony Medal for his lifetime contribution to the arts.

title: ACCEPTING TEEN-AGE REBELLION
description: THERE comes a time in parents' lives when their adolescent regards them as the most ill-informed people on earth. They are embarrassments: waving to their offspring on the playing field; insisting on telephone calls to mark a safe arrival; incapable of understanding why shirt collars must be worn up while sweatshirts must be artfully drooping off the shoulder.

title: Hutton Inquiry In Connecticut
description: The Connecticut Deputy Banking Commissioner, Howard B. Brown, has set for Oct. 7 a new hearing to determine whether to suspend E. F. Hutton & Company's licenses to do business in that state.

title: TEXAS EXECUTIONS SIGNAL RISING PACE
description: So many convicted murderers were scheduled to die last week in Texas that the state prison director has asked the courts to avoid scheduling more than one execution a day.

title: Moving to the Market
description: Imagine a bicycle manufacturer who finds he has to pay sharply different prices to get the steel he needs - from $225 to $700 a ton for the same steel products. Now you have an idea of some of the strains China's economy is undergoing as it moves toward a market system.

title: SUBWAY, ELECTIONS, ICE CREAM
description: No element of the renaissance in Pittsburgh has captured the fancy and imagination of its residents as much as the new 1.1-mile downtown subway, the shortest in the country. About a million passengers have climbed aboard since the subway opened on July 3.

title: Chile Gets I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund said Friday that it is providing Chile with an $850 million loan to be drawn over the next three years.

title: Go North, Young Man
description: ''Where the Boys Are,'' a hit movie in 1961, was based on a Michigan State professor's book about the flocking of students from Big Ten-like schools to Fort Lauderdale beaches, the better to enjoy the rites of spring. But, as everyone knows, the Big Ten's major athletic interest is football, not bathing, and a lot of schoolboys from Fort Lauderdale and other Florida cities who want to be a part of it are engaging in a migration of their own.

title: PIRATES FRUSTRATE METS, 5-0
description: The Mets left Pittsburgh today grateful to escape without being swept by the team with the worst record in baseball, and happy that St. Louis picked the same weekend to stumble.

title: Indian Loan Shift Urged
description: A. W. Clausen, president of the World Bank, assured India on Friday that it would get more money over the next five years, but said the Government must increase its commercial loans to supplement the bank's aid.

title: LEBANESE TROOPS FIGHT DRUSE AS CHRISTIANS VOW REVENGE FOR BLAST
description: Christian troops and Druse militiamen battled east of Beirut today, killing six civilians. Meanwhile, Christian leaders vowed revenge for a car bombing on Saturday that killed 55 people.

title: ''fter the Hostage Crisis, TV Focuses on Itself
description: AS the post-mortem on television's coverage of the Trans World Airlines hostage crisis comes to an end, and as journalists and others assess the damage done to the principle of a free press by Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's censorship of a BBC documentary on Northern Ireland, it is worthwhile to summarize what we are learning.

title: DANCE: 'SHADOW TO FRAME,' BY WENDY MORRIS
description: WENDY MORRIS'S ''Shadow to Frame,'' presented on Saturday at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, offered a shifting series of juxtapositions of several kinds of reality or life. Part of Dance Theater Workshop's ''Out-of-Towners (& Others)'' series, the performance piece by the Minneapolis-based choreographer posed a ''real'' image - a live performer - with images of reality of another sort, as the videotaped or photographed performer moved across screens scattered around the stage space.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, AUGUST 19, 1985
description: The Economy

title: Du Pont to Shut Plant
description: One of two ethylene production units at E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's Chocolate Bayou plant in Alvin, Tex., will be closed Oct. 1, the company said Friday. The shutdown will result in an 11-cent-a-share charge to Du Pont's third-quarter earnings, or an after-tax charge of $25 million, it said.

title: 2 Afghan Rebel Chiefs Said to Die in Combat
description: A main Afghan guerrilla group said today that two guerrilla commanders were killed in recent fighting and that an official of the country's Communist Government was assassinated.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What is the largest margin of victory by a major league team in a shutout game?

title: BASEBALL AND COCAINE: A DEEPENING PROBLEM
description: The use of cocaine by major league baseball players has been so widespread in recent years that scores of players have been implicated in criminal investigations as users, purchasers and, sometimes, as sellers of the drug. However, the players generally have not been prosecuted, and in some cases law enforcement officials have taken unusual steps to protect the players' identities.

title: Superfund Cleanups Need a Congressional Push
description: To the Editor:

title: JET'S INJURY LIST IS CONTINUING TO GROW
description: Darrol Ray and Billy Shields each squeezed into front seats on different buses Saturday night in Cincinnati, seats that are normally reserved for coaches on the Jets' trip to the airport after a game. The players were given those seats as consolation for being injured, and they were somber reminders of the Jets' troubled preseason.

title: U.S. AIDE FAILS TO MEET JORDAN-PALESTINIAN TEAM
description: A senior United States official left Jordan today without meeting with a Jordanian-Palestinian delegation.

title: Market Place;   Brand Names: Growing Lure
description: IN the hunt to identify the next corporate takeover target, many Wall Street professionals are looking in the most unlikely of places - the department store and supermarket shelf.

title: Law and Courage Stir in Chile
description: Chile's military rulers adopted yet another form of repression in March: death squads. In Santiago, three Communists were kidnapped and murdered by armed men in civilian clothes. Five trade unionists captured in the same raid were beaten and tortured by electric shock. Offices of a leftist human rights group were also raided and staff members were beaten and raped. For all its tyranny, President Augusto Pinochet's dictatorship was not previously known to cloak its crimes in civilian dress.

title: Topics;   Restoring Rights Doctoring Jefferson
description: As every schoolchild knows, the Declaration of Independence holds these truths self-evident - that all men are endowed with certain inalienable rights. But in Jefferson's Virginia, of all places, the word ''inalienable'' was deleted from a textbook used for seventh-graders.

title: AGENCIES' OFFICES TO REOPEN WITH PARTIAL ELECTRIC POWER
description: Thousands of government workers returning to work today will find no air-conditioning and only partial lighting in their buildings as engineers seek to restore full power to buildings blacked out last week in lower Manhattan.

title: BOOKS OF SMALL PRESSES KEY SOURCE OF REPRINTS
description: Major publishing houses, which have started trade paperback programs in recent years, are increasingly turning to small presses in their search for books to reprint. As a result, the little presses - including some mom and pop operations that may publish no more than one title a year - are beginning to have an impact on the American book business far out of proportion to their size.

title: DODGER STARTERS: SHADES OF 1960'S
description: THE NAME of the game in Los Angeles these days is ''Back to the Future.''

title: New Delhi Paves Way For Elections in Assam
description: The central Government dissolved the legislature in Assam today to pave the way for new state elections.

title: MEARS TRIUMPHS IN RETURN AT POCONO
description: Rick Mears, still recovering from injuries suffered in a racing crash last September in Canada, took the lead five laps from the end and went on to his first victory in more than a year today at the Domino's Pizza Pocono 500 Indy-car race.

title: Halaby Renewing Dulles Airport Tie
description: Najeeb E. Halaby is 69 years old, but the man who stepped down in the early 1970's as chairman and chief executive officer of Pan American World Airways still has dreams.

title: ''ightly Problem In a Neighborhood
description: Quietly genteel by day, East 31st Street, on the edge of Murray Hill, is transformed after dark into a nightlong traffic jam - horns honking, people shouting, police-car lights flashing.

title: CANDIDATES CLASH ON HISPANIC WORKERS' JOB GAINS
description: Beneath the orange, blue and red banners of the Ecuador Day Parade in Queens, Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy clashed over how well Hispanic New Yorkers are doing in the job market.

title: 2 DRIVERS IN ACCIDENT
description: A helicopter carrying Michael Andretti and Kevin Cogan, the race-car drivers, hit a high-voltage line and crashed this morning as it was taking off for a trip to Pocono International Speedway.

title: Air Reservation System Eludes Group's Director
description: Bruce Cunningham has been trying to buy a computer reservation system for a group of 24 United States and foreign airlines for the last three months - but so far without success.

title: HISPANIC ALIEN SURGE FUELS ASYLUM DEBATE
description: ''For years, for the Mexican, the movement to the United States has been almost a matter of manifest destiny,'' Arnoldo Torres says. ''Increasingly, it is becoming so for the Central American as well. It's a matter of survival. They will do whatever they have to do.''

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, 1 P.M. Finale of the four-game series and another chance for the Yankees to close in on the first-place Blue Jays.

title: Immigration Patrols Curbed In How They Hunt for Aliens
description: Immigration officers searching for illegal aliens may not stop people just because they look like Hispanic people and have a ''dirty, unkempt appearance,'' a Federal appellate court has ruled.

title: Washington Watch;   Trade Moves
description: M. Alan Woods, an alumnus of Sears World Trade and the Defense Department in the Ford and Nixon years, has become a deputy United States trade representative under the chief trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter. Clyde Prestowitz, now the top Japan trade expert at the Commerce Department, is expected to move over to the trade office as assistant trade representative for Japan.

title: No Talks Are Scheduled In Strike at Hormel Plant
description: A handful of pickets stood at entrances to the Hormel meatpacking plant here today, and no contract talks were scheduled in the dispute, in which workers have refused to accept the wages paid at other Hormel plants.

title: POPE APPEALS FOR FAMINE AID AND ORTHODOXY
description: Pope John Paul II concluded his visit to black Africa today with ''a solemn appeal'' on behalf of the victims of famine, renewed criticism of apartheid in South Africa and a firm call on theologians not to stray from Roman Catholic orthodoxy.

title: Sell Conrail to Conrail
description: The Federal Government wants to sell Conrail, the freight railroad patched together in 1976 from the wreckage of seven bankrupt private roads. Who should be allowed to buy it?

title: Letter: On Housing;   Squatters Are Not the Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: SHEIK'S EYESORE IS RAZED
description: A mansion that once created a furor when an Arab sheik painted it pea green and decorated it with garish nude statues and plastic flowers was razed today as neighbors toasted the demolition with champagne.

title: BUILDINGS TRIM SERVICES DESPITE REGAINING POWER
description: Full power was restored yesterday to buildings affected by electrical failures in lower Manhattan last week, but building managers curtailed some elevator service and air-conditioning as they continued to assess the damage.

title: Article 201431 -- No Title
description: The police here say they believe a bandit broke into a Brink's Inc. armored car substation Saturday and loaded more than 200,000 coins, $54,000 in quarters, into a white van, which was seen leaving the substation.

title: Moisture Held Cave-In Cause
description: Moisture accumulating in a layer of limestone probably contributed to the collapse of rock that killed three boys camping in a cave Friday night, the authorities said today. Cass County Sgt. Joe Baldassano said a geologist who examined the cave Sunday told him that the ceiling fell from the weight of moisture. The cave, at the base of sandstone bluffs along the Platte River south of Omaha, was made years ago during quarrying operations.

title: Chase to Buy Chesapeake Savings
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, trying to gain an early foothold in the Maryland financial marketplace, announced an agreement today to purchase an Annapolis savings and loan association.

title: UNIVERSAL HOLDING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $18,929 for the quarter and $20,069 for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: A TESTING FOR INSURERS OF MORTGAGE SECURITIES
description: In just a few years, mortgage-backed securities have grown from an arcane specialty into a booming, $350 billion Wall Street industry. But that market now faces a time of testing in the potential default by the Equity Programs Investment Corporation on the mortgage-backed securities it issued.

title: Republican for Mayor Opens Headquarters
description: Diane McGrath, the Republican candidate for Mayor, opened her campaign headquarters yesterday with an attack on the policies of Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy toward homosexuals.

title: HYTEK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BOSTON DIGITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
VIDEO MONITORS: WIDE ARRAY OF CHOICES
description: LESS than a decade ago most computers did not have video monitors. Instead, humans communicated with the machine by feeding bundles of keypunched computer cards into a chattering box. Some computers also had banks of toggle switches and blinking lights, and by deciphering the patterns of lights the user could get a fairly good idea of the mischief the mechanical brain was doing.

title: CITY OPERA TO PRESENT PREMIERE OF 'X'
description: The New York City Opera has announced that it will present the world premiere of Anthony Davis's opera, ''X,'' in September 1986 at the New York State Theater.

title: EX-TEAMSTER CHIEF GETS PRISON HOSPITAL TERM
description: A Federal district judge today ordered Roy L. Williams, the ailing former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, to serve a 10-year sentence in a prison hospital.

title: JAPAN SENDS 2D SPACECRAFT TO JOIN COMET
description: JAPAN yesterday launched its second spacecraft to observe Halley's comet next March, officials of Japan's Institute of Space and Astronomical Research announced.

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After capital losses of $163,000 for the quarter and $5,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income. d-After a capital loss of $5,000.

title: SHARON STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $663,000 for the quarter and $280,000 for the 6 months from the termination of a pension plan, a tax credit of $3,920,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a pretax gain of $57,063,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of equity securities. c-Including a pretax gain of $2,191,000 on the sale of equity securities. d-Net loss including a pretax gain of $8,412,000 on the sale of equity securities.

title: VALLEY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: MOSTLY OVER This summer's series of Mostly Mozart orchestral and chamber concerts at Lincoln Center is in its final week. Tonight's performance offers two pieces performed for the first time in the festival.

title: WAR'S END STIRS MEMORIES IN CHINA
description: An elderly Chinese official who bicycles past the Japanese Embassy every day on his way to work found himself flinching last week as he glimpsed the white banner with the red orb at its center fluttering from the embassy flagstaff.

title: FAIRCHILD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,129,000 for the quarter and $19,402,000 for the 6 months. c-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $2,795,000 for the quarter and $5,442,000 for the 6 months.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CALIFORNIA (AL) - Placed Geoff Zahn, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list. Recalled Urbano Lugo, pitcher, from Edmonton of the Pacific Coast League. Sent Darryl Sconiers, first baseman, to Edmonton for rehabilitation.

title: Interest Rates Close Mixed
description: Interest rates were mixed yesterday with short-term yields showing little change while note and bond yields fell slightly.

title: A Westway Plea
description: There is a new urgency for the proponents and opponents of Westway to put aside their differences and work together to preserve federal funding for improved transportation in New York City.

title: COVINGTON TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the quarter and $116,000 for the 6 months.

title: FALCON OIL & GAS CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
TO-FITNESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Cost of Crash Cleanup Is Set
description: Officials at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport estimate the cost of cleaning up and making repairs after the Delta Air Lines crash Aug. 2 at $1.7 million. The airport board said it expected Delta's insurance to cover all the airport's expenses stemming from the crash, in which more than 130 people were killed. The biggest item is $1.45 million for repairs to two four-million-gallon water tanks struck by the plane, a Lockheed L-1011.

title: TERRANO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KIDDIE PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FILM RIGHTS DISPUTED
description: A dispute has broken out over the rights to about 1,600 films in the MGM/UA Entertainment Company library.

title: MARYLAND THRIFT UNIT MORATORIUM
description: Responding to ''long lines and heavy withdrawals'' of deposits from one of Maryland's largest savings and loan associations, Gov. Harry R. Hughes yesterday orderered a 20-day moratorium on further withdrawals from the thrift institution.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $2,298,000. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,159,000.

title: LAWMAKER DRAWS FLAX ABOUT 'SOLO'
description: When members of the House travel at Government expense in the Congressional recess, it usually takes at least four or five of them to qualify for a Pentagon plane.

title: Another Chemical Leak In West Virginia
description: The authorities investigated the third chemical leak in a week in the Kanawha Valley today after a tanker truck spewed a nauseating irritant that sickened residents and forced the evacuation of 30 homes here, 10 miles west of Charleston.

title: Whirlpool Promotes 2 In Leadership Change
description: The Whirlpool Corporation, a major maker of home appliances, said yesterday that it had named two vice chairmen, the first step in a leadership transition that will culminate December 1987, when Jack D. Sparks, chairman, president and chief executive, is scheduled to retire.

title: Willow Defense Backfires
description: Many plants produce chemical defenses that put off or poison such enemies as insects and birds. Willow trees in the Sierra Nevada mountains of California, for example, produce salicin, a chemical that repels browsing deer, opossums and many insects.

title: POPE, IN MOROCCO, ASKS TOLERATION
description: Pope John Paul II paid a visit to this overwhelmingly Moslem country today and asked a crowd of 80,000 Moslems to join with Christians in accepting differences ''with humility and respect and mutual tolerance.''

title: U.S. TOLD TO USE COURT PRECEDENT IN DENYING AID
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday ordered the Reagan Administration to follow court precedents in determining who in New York State is eligible for Social Security disability benefits.

title: Schanberg Op-Ed Column In Times to Be Discontinued
description: After four years of writing his twice-weekly ''New York'' column on the Op-Ed page of The New York Times, Sydney H. Schanberg has been asked to accept another assignment, which is now under discussion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1985
description: Companies

title: S.M.U. Won't Challenge
description: Southern Methodist officials announced today that the university had decided against challenging the National Collegiate Athletic Association with a lawsuit, choosing instead to absorb severe sanctions against the football program and try to clean up the school's image.

title: MUSIC: LEONARD SLATKIN CONDUCTS PHILHARMONIC
description: IT looked like rain through early afternoon, but the evening weather yesterday was temperate, breezy, fresh and thoroughly enjoyable. Likewise the concert that Leonard Slatkin led on the Great Lawn of Central Park, with the New York Philharmonic in fine, relaxed form and an audience of some 150,000 in appreciative attendance.

title: BANKAMERICA REALTY INVESORS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including gains on the sale of investments of $1,131,000 for the quarter and $11,154,000 for the year. c-Including a gain of $896,000 on the sale of investments.

title: FATHER IN COURT ON MURDER COUNT
description: John Rairdon, who the police say led a search for his missing 13-year-old daughter and then confessed to killing her when she fought off his sexual advances, today was granted a public defender to defend him against charges of first- and second-degree murder and intrafamilial sexual abuse.

title: Con Ed's First Sale Since '74
