description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York announced plans late last week for its first public sale of securities since 1974, and its first tax-exempt bond financing.

title: SYNTECH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: Chess: Vaganian of the Soviet Wins 3d Interzonal, in Switzerland
description: The third and last Interzonal Tournament, held in Biel, Switzerland, was won by Rafael Vaganian, a 33-year-old grandmaster from the Soviet Union. His winning score was 12 1/2-4 1/2.

title: UNITED BANK CALIFORNIA SSB reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 22 Paper-Mill Workers Injured After Gas Leak
description: A chlorine gas leak at the Champion Paper mill here today injured 22 employees, four of them seriously, the authorities said.

title: DBA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Property Should Be Divided Equally in Divorce
description: To the Editor:

title: PANTRY BID IS OPPOSED BY REVLON
description: A takeover battle between Revlon Inc. and Pantry Pride Inc. burst into the open yesterday as Revlon announced a series of defensive steps and Pantry Pride made a formal tender offer.

title: MOTOROLA'S FAST-GROWTH PATH
description: For many middle-aged Americans, the name Motorola evokes memories of their first television set or car radio. These days, however, Motorola is making its mark in the high-tech world of semiconductors, computers and mobile phones.

title: TANDY BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $249,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $1,544,000 for the year related to estimated tax benefits and nonrecurring pretax gains of $322,000 for the quarter and $2,192,000 for the year relating to adjustment of the reserve for loss on disposal of the former Western World division. c-After a nonrecurring pretax loss of $7,269,000 for the quarter and year relating to the reserves for loss on disposal of the Western World division. d-Net loss.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The California Angels placed the pitcher Geoff Zahn on the 15-day disabled list because of tendinitis of the left shoulder.

title: Remembering Vietnam
description: The Luxembourg pottery maker Villeroy & Boch has produced a commemorative plate to honor Americans killed or missing in the Vietnam War, and the plate will have its official unveiling at a reception at the Luxembourg Embassy Sept. 4.

title: Mervin Riseman Dies; Headed Jewish Groups
description: Mervin H. Riseman, former chairman of the Greater New York Conference on Soviet Jewry, died last Wednesday at Mt. Sinai Hospital after a long illness.

title: Taxes and the Nobel Prize
description: Among the institutions interested in whether President Reagan's tax-simplification proposal is approved is the Nobel Foundation of Stockholm.

title: Hewlett's Net Is Down 12.7%
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., Aug. 19 (AP) -

title: KEILLOR REMEMBERS THE 'TOWN THAT TIME FORGOT'
description: Sitting on a sofa in his suite at the Algonquin Hotel, Garrison Keillor leans forward and looks at a microcassette recorder on the table. ''This is a little tiny one,'' he says, and then he picks it up and begins talking to it, into the microphone. ''How are you doing, Buddy?''

title: SHIFFMAN PLEADS GUILTY
description: Dale Shiffman, one of seven men indicted by the grand jury investigating drug sales in Pittsburgh, pleaded guilty today to 20 drug trafficking charges. Another 91 counts against Shiffman were dropped in a plea bargain agreement.

title: RADIANT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GROUP FINDS 49 V.A. DOCTORS WITH LICENSE DISCREPANCIES
description: The licenses of at least 49 doctors who were working for the Veterans Administration from 1983 to 1984 had been suspended, revoked or restricted, the American Medical Association said today.

title: Merger Discussions Disclosed by Cannon Mills
description: David H. Murdock, the financier who bought the Cannon Mills Company in 1982 for $413 million, has approached several other textile manufacturers to discuss a merger, according to a letter Mr. Murdock sent to company employees.

title: Stocks End Mixed in Light Trading
description: Stock prices finished narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday as investors waited to see several important economic reports scheduled to be released this week.

title: Wickes Issues
description: The Wickes Companies said it would issue as much as $400 million in new convertible preferred stock and as much as $50 million in new debentures to help finance its $1 billion purchase of the consumer and industrial products group of Gulf and Western Inc. The retailer, based in Santa Monica, Calif., said the new issues would be sold privately by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The company said earlier that it would raise the additional $450 million through a combination of bank financing and selling preferred and common stock. Wickes emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings in January.

title: Ford, Chrysler Loan Rates Cut
description: The nations second-and third-largest auto manufacturers, following the General Motors Corporation, yesterday lowered their rates on loans for most of their remaining 1985 model cars and trucks.

title: SUMMIT OILFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,318 for the quarter and $211,724 for the 6 months. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $575,000.

title: SUIT TO RENOVATE SHELTER FOR HOMELESS IS LOST
description: A Federal district judge today dismissed a lawsuit that would have forced the Government to renovate a crumbling shelter for the homeless, but ordered officials to find new homes for the facility's residents.

Charles Forman, executive director of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers, who said, ''These are frightfully expensive changes. On the other hand, they are frightfully cheap when you consider the cost of an accident.''

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEAN TACKLES NATIONAL ISSUES
description: GOVERNOR Kean of New Jersey became chairman in late July of the Education Commission of the States, a coalition of governors and state education officials. As a first project he named a study group to suggest what governors and legislatures could do to improve college education, pointing out that 80 percent of the nation's undergraduates attend state colleges and universities. Two weeks later the commission and the National Governors Association agreed to pay for a study of what states should be doing to improve public schools. The Governor, a former schoolteacher and college professor, will be co-chairman of that study. He also serves on a privately funded task force examining ways to build the professional status of teaching. In a recent interview Mr. Kean, a Republican, talked about what he sees as the most important national education issues and what he is trying to do about them in New Jersey.

title: Dixon's Day
description: It has been more than two centuries since the surveying of Maryland's northern border for the purpose of establishing what became known as the Mason-Dixon line, and yesterday, down in Baltimore, there was finally a commemoration:

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHEN Bonwit Teller opens its new petite department next week, one of the stars will be the equally new Anne Klein II line of petite sportswear. That should be good news for any woman less than 5 feet 5 inches tall who has always yearned to wear those broad-shouldered Anne Klein jackets or thought those big tweed coats would overwhelm her. Many of the same sophisticated styles as in the Anne Klein II line have been reproportioned for the petite figure. Proportion is the key word. The clothes are not just shorter, but scaled down, with waistlines curved in a bit and pockets raised. Yet the effect is far from that little-girl look of many petite styles of yore.

title: LEISURE CONCEPTS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Devils' Top Pick
description: The Devils have called a news conference for today, at which they are expected to announce the signing of the defenseman, Craig Wolanin, their top 1984 draft choice, and Pete McNab, a 33-year-old free agent center. Wolanin, 18, who played for the Kitchener Rangers of the Ontario Hockey League, was the third player chosen over all in the 1984 draft. McNab, whose father is the Devils' general manager, has accumulated 336 goals and 414 assists in his 11 National Hockey League seasons with Buffalo, Boston and Vancouver.

The back-to-school shopping season is upon us, and families throughout the land are setting off to outfit the children with clothes, notebooks, paper, pens and all the other equipment needed for youth's foray on education, including, the software publishers are hoping, appropriately edifying computer programs.

title: 3-YEAR LATIN DEBT CRISIS: GAINS, BUT PERILS PERSIST
description: In the three years since the third-world debt crisis erupted, arousing fears for the global financial system, great progress has been made. Largely because of painful austerity measures south of the border, there no longer seems to be any immediate danger of debt problems toppling big banks like dominoes.

description: Rabbi Meir Kahane, the founder of the militant Jewish Defense League, said yesterday that he had resigned the leadership of the organization, in part because he could not devote enough time to it.

description: Apple Computer Inc. plans to sell a factory that makes keyboards and ''mice'' for its Macintosh computer to the Alps Group, a Japanese company that now supplies Apple with disk drives and other components.

Article 202698 -- No Title
description: Some already knew the first trip they would take, or the style of house they would buy, when their $33.5 million ship - and their six numbers - came in.

title: About Education;   PARENTAL PRESSURE AT ISSUE
description: ARE parents a constructive force or a meddlesome threat to the schools? Commenting on a recent survey that found parents asking for a greater voice in running the schools, Judi L. Wallace wrote that a distinction should be made ''between parents who want only the best education for their own children and those parents who want to mold the schools to conform to their own religious beliefs.'' She added that the latter group was becoming increasingly vocal and active.

title: Two Teen-Agers Admit Writing Holdup Notes
description: Charges of attempted bank robbery against a 16-year-old boy were dropped today after two other teen-agers said he was the victim of fraudulent holdup notes they had left in the bank as a prank.

description: As he finished his term on charges of aiding two Salvadorans, a worker in the movement to give sanctuary to Central Americans said he planned to continue protesting United States policies in that region.

description: A Federal judge yesterday re-instated Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. as a candidate for mayor in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary.

description: In the rolling farm country of northeastern Dutchess County, they talk uneasily of the night ''Amadeus'' was sold out.

description: Scientists from the Los Alamos National Laboratory have developed a supersensitive X-ray camera for a future flight of the space shuttle.

title: GASTINEAU SUFFERS BROKEN THUMB IN DRILL
description: Mark Gastineau, perhaps the one player that the already-injured and defense-poor Jets cannot afford to lose, broke his right thumb in practice today but apparently escaped a long-term injury.

title: GRIFFEY CATCH SAVES YANK STREAKS
description: Should the Yankees still be riding high in September and should people start to talk of a destined team, they could point to a battered blue panel on the left-field wall of Yankee Stadium marking the most breathtaking moment of the seaosn.

title: LIBRARIAN AND SPORTS EXPERT
description: Robert William Henderson, who manned the counters when the New York Public Library opened on Fifth Avenue in May 1911 and retired in 1953 as chief of its vast main reading room, died Sunday at Hartford Hospital. He was 96 years old and lived in Hartford, having moved there from White Plains, his hometown for a half-century.

title: BANKER $15 MILLION RICHER
description: A bank president won $15 million in last week's Illionis lottery, making him the second-largest lottery winner in state history, officials said today.

title: BEST CATCH OF CAREER STUNS ALL
description: In that startling moment when he realized that, yes, he had really caught the ball, Ken Griffey said he became flushed, then chilled, definitely dazed. ''I could feel my toes and the webbing of my mitt,'' he said, ''but nothing in between.''

title: Lucas Joins Lakers
description: The Los Angeles Lakers strengthened an already strong front line yesterday with the acquisition of Maurice Lucas from the Phoenix Suns. The defending National Basketball Association champions gave up their 1988 and 1989 second-round draft choices for the 32-year-old power forward.

title: NO EVIDENCE FOUND THAT EXECUTIVE LIED IN 3 MILE ISLAND CASE
description: A Nuclear Regulatory Commission licensing board said today that it had seen no evidence to support allegations that the president of General Public Utilities Corporation had lied about the seriousness of the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant.

title: Coast Doctor Ordered to Jail
description: A physician has been sentenced to prison for violating the probation imposed after he pleaded no contest to involuntary manslaughter in the 1978 death of a patient during breast-enlargement surgery. The doctor, Ralph J. W. Small, 37 years old, was given a two-year prison term Friday after testimony disclosed that he had opened two offices without supervision, violating the terms of his probation.

description: Israel's coalition Government was facing a new crisis today, this time because of a dispute between Labor and Likud ministers over who may live in a rotting three-room apartment on a narrow alleyway in the marketplace here.

Dawdling Over Sentence Reform
description: Sentencing reform, one of the most important provisions of the 1984 Federal Crime Control Act, is also one of the most complex. That's why Congress provided 18 months for a commission to develop it. Now the White House is threatening the reform by letting nearly a year slip by with little action.

title: COCAINE DISRUPTS BASEBALL FROM FIELD TO FRONT OFFICE
description: Cocaine use among baseball players has been so pervasive in recent years that the drug's debilitating effects have tarnished individual performances, shortened careers and influenced the outcome of games and pennant races, club officials and players say.

title: GALANOS PARES DOWN LUXURY
description: There's no doubt about it. Simplicity is the way to go in fashion these days. Even James Galanos, who has been known for piling jewels upon jewels, has given his imprimatur to the pared-down look this fall. Wearing a striped seersucker jacket and white pants, the California-based designer showed his 150-piece collection informally yesterday in a suite at the Plaza Hotel.

description: More than 3,000 Air Canada flight attendants went on strike today at the peak of summer travel, but the airline vowed to keep flying.

title: Sears Tower Climb Is Foiled
description: A 24-year-old Australian and two assistants were arrested today outside the Sears Tower in what was apparently an effort to climb the world's tallest building for a parachute jump, the police said. Nicholas Feteris of Elwood, Australia, was arrested and charged with criminal trespass, a misdemeanor, when he returned to the 110-story building after being told to leave the premises. Kenneth Rick, 34, of Lake Orion, Mich., and Jeanette Augustin, 24, of Dearborn, Mich., also were arrested and charged with disorderly conduct.

title: NEW STUDIES EXAMINE SEXUAL GUILT
description: FOR some months social observers have been intently watching as a range of indicators continues to suggest that the country has entered a phase characterized by more conservative attitudes toward sexuality than those of the two previous decades.

title: Defiant Snake Handler Dies
description: A man who was free on bond after being charged in North Carolina with illegally handling snakes died today of a rattlesnake bite on the thumb, the authorities said. Charles Prince, 45 years old, was bitten here Saturday at the Apostolic Church of God and refused treatment, said Sheriff Gail Colyer of Greene County. Mr. Prince had vowed to defy laws against the religious practice of snake handling.

description: The Federal Election Commission today ordered Senator John Glenn's Presidential campaign to repay the Government nearly $75,000 for overspending in the Iowa caucuses and the New Hampshire primary last year.

Cooper Is Upset
description: Seth Antiles of West Orange, N.J., upset fourth-seeded Adam Cooper of Copiague, L.I., 6-3, 6-2, today in the opening round of the Shearson-Lehman Brothers Eastern clay court tennis championships. Second-seeded Dave Fishbach of Port Washington, L.I. beat Ken Feuer of Massapequa, L.I., 6-2, 6-2, and Bret Herman of Searingtown, L.I., beat Nick Haripopolos of Northport, L.I., 3-6, 6-2, 7-6.

description: Ultramar Canada Inc. said yesterday that it had ended negotiations with Gulf Canada Ltd. to buy Gulf Canada's refining and marketing assets in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces.

description: The Baldwin-United Corporation said today that it had settled $457 million in estimated claims for Federal income taxes owed by Baldwin-United and its subsidiaries before it filed for bankruptcy reorganization in 1983.

title: Genstar to Buy 27% of Canada Trustco
description: The Genstar Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy a 27 percent stake in the Canada Trustco Mortgage Company from the Manufacturers Life Insurance Company, and that it would seek to buy the remaining Canada Trustco shares for $45 (Canadian) a share, or a total of about $689.1 million in United States currency.

title: Hospital Corp. Shifts Officers
description: The Hospital Corporation of America said today that Thomas F. Frist Jr., 47 years old, the company's president and chief executive, would assume the title of chairman, effective Sept. 1.

description: Dorchester Master Limitted Partnership was organized in August 1984 and therefore there are no comparable year-ago results available.

title: K.W. GREENAWALT, LAWYER, DEFENDED RELIGIOUS LIBERTIES
description: Kenneth W. Greenawalt, a trial lawyer who often argued for the defense in cases involving religious liberties and the separation of church and state, died Sunday at his home in Hartsdale, N.Y. He was 81 years old. In January, he retired as a senior partner of the firm of Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives in Manhattan.

title: Tennis Computer Brings Quandary
description: The computer administered by the Association of Tennis Professionals for the purpose of ranking Grand Prix players has spit out another aberration. And this time it has done so with a vengeance, causing a magnificent dilemma for the United States Tennis Association only one week before the Open.

title: URBAN BLIGHT RETREATS BEFORE 'GREEN CONTAGION'
description: When William Penn designed Philadelphia, he said the city should take care to leave an acre of trees for every five acres it developed. That way his city would remain what he called a ''fine Greene Countrie Towne.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: JERUSALEM: Rebirth of a City. By Martin Gilbert. 238 pages. Illustrated. Viking. $25. NO city in the world can have captured more imaginations and stirred more hearts over the centuries than Jerusalem. No city, in the 19th century, was more liable to provoke comments on the dismal contrast between past and present, between the image and the reality. A stream of visitors recorded their impressions of the prevailing torpor, the poverty, the filth, the squalid squabbles between different races and religious communities.

title: CUCOS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Washington Post Buying Cable Units
description: The Washington Post Company said that it had agreed, as expected, to buy 53 cable television systems from Capital Cities Communications Inc. for $350 million.

description: A judge today denied a new trial for Gary Dotson, who was convicted of a 1977 rape that his accuser now says never occurred.

title: A T.W.A. VOTING PROPOSAL
description: Minority shareholders of Trans World Airlines would decide which offer for the airline to accept under a proposal to be presented to the T.W.A board today, a Wall Street source said last night.

title: METS WIN ON DOUBLES IN 8TH
description: Ron Darling grew a little older, pitched both in pain and out of trouble, and broke a three-game losing streak. Danny Heep came off the bench with a pinch-hit double. And Wally Backman supplied the winning hit, an eighth-inning double, leading the Mets to a 1-0 victory tonight over the Montreal Expos.

title: PENTAGON PROCUREMENT AIDE RESIGNS OVER ETHICS CHARGES
description: The Pentagon said today that a senior weapons procurement official had resigned in the face of charges that she violated Pentagon ethical standards by soliciting dozens of military contractors as customers for a planned consulting business.

title: Advertising;   New York Air Moves Account to Levine
description: New York Air has ended its two-year relationship with the Bloom Agency Inc. and moved its account to Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver Inc. in New York. But, almost making up for that loss, the agency's Dallas office has won additional business from an existing client, Campbell Taggart Inc., the baked goods subsidiary of Anheuser-Busch Companies.

title: A Dollar a Dream
description: The rise of New York's lottery jackpot to $33.5 million means stores are dispensing a record number of tickets for tomorrow's drawing - and almost as fast, moralists are dispensing advice. ''It's like throwing your money away,'' some say.

title: Officer Shoots Self Chasing 'Gunman'
description: A police officer accidentally shot himself in the foot today while looking for a muscular gunman who turned out to be an actor delivering a ''Rambo-gram.''

title: New Coke vs. Classic: The Verdict Is Still Out
description: Coca-Cola Classic, the revived original version of the world's best-selling soft drink, is now available in more than 80 percent of the nation's retail outlets. But retailers and fountain operators say it is still too soon to tell how well the latest incarnation of the old product will sell, and what effect it will have on sales of ''new'' Coke. And while consumer tastes will have a large say in the ultimate success or failure of a two-Coke strategy, the Coca-Cola Company seems determined not to let Classic usurp new Coke's role as its flagship brand.

TELESCOPE BUILDERS SEE HALLEY'S COMET FROM VERMONT HIILTOP
description: They came from all over North America, with telescopes as large as heavy artillery and as small as doll furniture. On a chilly Vermont hilltop under a sparkling black sky, they talked of telescopes and galaxies until nearly dawn, and then they they pointed their mirrors and lenses toward the east and beheld Halley's Comet.

title: GIANTS RELEASE MULLADY
description: In their largest roster cut of the preseason, the Giants dropped 16 players today. Coach Bill Parcells said it was not painful, except for the players who were cut, ''because I don't think any of them had the talent to make the team.''

title: IN RURAL QUEBEC, SPEAKING ENGLISH IS NOW PASSE
description: The language traditionally spoken in Quebec's Eastern Townships along the American border is in danger of dying out. The language is English. Lydia May, a longtime resident of Baldwin Mills, a town just a few miles north of Vermont, recalled that 25 years ago more than two dozen schoolchildren trooped aboard the local bus to go off to the English-language school. Today, she said, there are four children, and they must be bused to an English-speaking school nearly 30 miles away.

title: Liberty I. Suit Sent To a Jersey Court
description: A Federal judge refused today to hear a suit challenging New York State's sovereignty over Liberty Island, the home of the Statue of Liberty, and over nearby Ellis Island, and sent the case to a New Jersey Superior Court.

title: LAXALT WON'T RUN FOR SENATE IN '86
description: Senator Paul Laxalt, a key supporter of President Reagan in the Senate and one of the President's closest personal friends, announced today that he would not seek re-election next year.

title: Iran Rebels Deny Bombing
description: A spokesman for a group that supports the People's Mujahedeen, an Iranian rebel organization, said today that it was not responsible for a car bombing in Teheran on Sunday as charged by the Iranian Government press agency. The spokesman, Ali Safavi, said in Washington that the rebels condemned the bombing, in which 30 people were reported wounded.

title: WARNER COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Pillsbury Keeping Godfather's Pizza
description: The Pillsbury Company said that it would retain the Godfather's Pizza chain as part of its fast-food operations. There had been speculation that Godfather's, a troubled unit of Diversifoods Inc., would be sold after Pillsbury completed its $390 million acquisition of Diversifoods, an Illinois-based restaurant company, earlier this month.

title: BOTHA SEES SOUTH AFRICAN CHURCHMEN AND FALWELL
description: A delegation of nine South African churchmen met with President P. W. Botha today to seek major changes in the Government's racial policies. They came away from the encounter saying they had won no promises or concessions.

title: INDIA SAYS IT INDUCED TAMILS TO RESUME SRI LANKA TALKS
description: India said today that it had succeeded in inducing Tamil leaders to renew peace talks with the Sri Lanka Government.

title: MMI MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 2
Olympic Trio Rematch
description: Mary Decker Slaney of the United States, Maricica Puica of Rumania and Zola Budd of Britain will appear on the same track again tomorrow for the first time since their controversial race at the Summer Olympics at Los Angeles last year. Although the trio will be competing in the mile run in the Weltklaase meet in Zurich, the 12th stop on the 16-meet Grand Prix meet, they will officially be timed for 1,500 meters as they chase the world mark of 3 minutes 52.47 seconds, set in 1980 by Tatyana Kazankina of the Soviet Union. When the trio last met on Aug. 10, 1984, Mrs. Slaney collided with Miss Budd and Miss Puica went on to win the gold medal in the 3,000 meter run.

title: IMATRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company had no sales for the year-ago second quarter and 6 months when it was in the development stage.

title: Automobile Row Bids Farewell to Broadway
description: No one can count how many journeys began on Automobile Row, how many noses pressed against showroom windows in the West 50's, how many miles were recorded by odometers that had read ''0'' on Broadway. Now, it is over.

title: $50,000 Worth of Pondering
description: They charge $50,000. They don't do windows. But they do tell you how.

title: THE DANCE: PILOBOLUS PERFORMS AT JACOB'S PILLOW
description: It was an ordinary performance by Pilobolus on Saturday afternoon at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here. Cheers, a teasing cry of ''Encore!'' and a few fairly testy arguments welled up in the audience as the program ended with the group's new ''Carmina Burana, Side 2.''

title: BEVIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PAWNEE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-The company was formed in June 1984 and did not report comparable year-ago results.

title: U.S.-BRITISH TREATY ON EXTRADITION AT ISSUE IN 2 I.R.A.-RELATED CASES
description: Proposed changes in an extradition treaty between the United States and Britain that would allow the transfer of people accused of political crimes have become an issue in the cases of two men fighting extradition to Britain.

title: American Brands Names Unit Chief
description: American Brands Inc. said yesterday that the American Tobacco Company, a division, would become a separate subsidiary Jan. 1, and it named the division's president, Thomas C. Hays, to be chief executive of the new subsidiary.

title: AFTER A BRIEF WARMING, U.S.-CUBAN TIES COOL ANEW
description: American and Cuban officials agree on one thing these days: that relations between the United States and Cuba have reached one of the lowest points in years. .

title: K MART CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Can Canada Inc., Toronto, has appointed C. Flemming Heilmann president and chief executive officer, succeeding Barrington Pocock.

title: TELECOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $103,000 for the quarter, a loss from discontinued operations of $155,000 for the 6 months, gains from the early extinguishment of debt of $2,498,000 for the quarter and $2,541,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $36,000 for the quarter and $63,000 for the 6 months, a tax credit of $576,000 for the quarter and 6 months and a gain from the early extinguishment of debt of $237,000 for the 6 months.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Joseph M. Breen has been named a senior vice president at Richardson, Myers & Donofrio of Baltimore.

title: U.S. INSURANCE HELD DOUBTFUL
description: The Community Savings and Loan Association of Bethesda, Md., probably will not be able to qualify for Federal deposit insurance, primarily because its losses from real estate investments will be significantly larger than expected, according to Federal and thrift industry officials.

title: Bridge: Split Regional Play Provides Increase in Winning Smiles
description: The final Sunday of a tournament normally generates, if one excludes side games, two, three or perhaps four groups of happy winners. On Sunday there were seven, certainly a record for the East Coast.

title: Reagan Selects 2 as Envoys
description: President Reagan intends to nominate Clyde D. Taylor as Ambassador to Paraguay and Natale Bellocchi as Ambassador to Botswana, the White House announced today. Both are deputy assistant secretaries of state. Mr. Taylor is in the Bureau of International Narcotics Matters and Mr. Bellocchi is in the Bureau of Intelligence and Research.

title: U.S. CRITICIZES TUTU OVER REFUSAL TO JOIN IN A MEETING WITH BOTHA
description: The Reagan Administration criticized Bishop Desmond M. Tutu today for boycotting a meeting between nine South African churchmen and President P. W. Botha.

title: 24 Are Reported Dead In Philippine Battles
description: At least 24 people were killed and 35 wounded in separate battles involving Communist guerrillas in the southern Philippines in the last two days, military spokesmen said today.

title: Liberals' Hypocrisy on South Africa
description: One is led to believe that the demonstrators calling for American companies to divest themselves of their South African holdings care deeply about the victims of discrimination and violence in that country. But the evidence suggests they are preoccupied more with ideology than with people.

title: WINDSOR LIFE INSURANCE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: RARE BIRDS HATCH IN WHISKY BARREL IN NEW ORLEANS ZOO
description: The Audubon Zoo says chirps coming from a sealed whisky barrel where a female South Asian rhino hornbill is nesting indicate the first successful hatching in captivity of the rare bird.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about major publishing houses buying reprint rights misstated the amount Ballantine Books paid Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, N.C., for ''Raney,'' a first novel by Clyde Edgerton. It was $15,000.

title: ARTRA GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $175,000 on the sale of security. c-Including a tax credit of $230,000. There were no share earnings for the latest quarter due to the reduction of retained earnings applicable to redeeming common stock. Corrected from Saturday's editions.

title: HARKEN OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TRAGIC PAGE FROM JETS PLAYER FILE
description: Mike Hickey never met Brian Hiemer, but Hickey wishes now that he had.

description: b-Including tax credits of $66,000 for the quarter and $117,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $60,000 for the quarter and $93,000 for the 6 months.

title: WINN ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
3 Men Involved in Shootout Spray Bullets on 181st St.
description: Three men, one firing a submachine gun, let loose a spray of bullets in a shootout on a residential street in Washington Heights last night.

title: ZEHNTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Including tax credits of $126,000 for the quarter and $495,000 for the year. c-Net income.

title: MAI HOLDINGS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: MAI Holdings and its subsidiary, MAI Basic Four, commenced operations on Jan. 30, 1985.

title: REALTY REFUND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Careers;   A Job Lift From Data Processing
description: DATA processing knowledge can be useful in advancing a career. At least Rita Eusanio, 26 years old, who works for Price Waterhouse, the big accounting and management consulting firm, has found that to be true.

title: NATIONAL ROYALTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DETROIT MEDIA BID IS RAISED
description: Norman Lear and A. Jerrold Perenchio, the Hollywood producers, yesterday raised their offer for the Evening News Association by 25 percent.

title: Litton Contract
description: Litton Industries said that its precision gear division had received a $109 million contract from the Boeing Vertol unit of the Boeing Company to supply new transmission components for 240 Army Chinook helicopters, built by Boeing, which are being modernized.

title: STUDIES UNRAVEL ROLE OF GENETIC MARKERS IN DISEASE RISK
description: SCIENTISTS are making important progress in unraveling the nature and significance of a special group of hereditary factors associated with susceptibility to some of the most serious and baffling of human diseases.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: TUESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1985
description: International

title: July Personal Income Up 0.4%
description: The personal income of Americans rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in July as a big jump in Social Security benefits bolstered a meager increase in wages and salaries, the Government reported today.

title: Advertising;   Importance Of Color Packaging
description: IT is known as the yellow jug antifreeze case. The Union Carbide Corporation, which markets Prestone II antifreeze in a yellow container, sued the BASF Wyandotte Corporation and Fred Meyer Inc. in a Portland, Ore., court to prevent them from selling their antifreeze in yellow one-gallon containers. The color yellow, Union Carbide said, belonged to its product. If all antifreeze products could use yellow it would confuse consumers.

title: AMERICAN RECREATION CENERS reports earnings for Year to May 29
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid on July 31, 1985.

title: ACCOUNT IS READ OF OFFICER'S BID TO CURB STEWART
description: A transit police sergeant charged with perjury in the death of Michael Stewart told a grand jury last year that he had helped restrain the prisoner by placing a foot on his lower body and putting a nightstick between his cuffed hands.

title: Unitary Tax Bill Gains
description: A bill that would revise California's use of the worldwide unitary method of taxing multinational corporations passed the state's Assembly Revenue and Taxation Committee today, keeping alive its chances for passage in the current legislative session. The vote was 9 to 4. The measure would allow companies to exclude foreign property, payroll and sales from the tax formula in determining the percentage of their profits that are subject to the state's tax.

title: VANZETTI SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TECHNOLOGY RESEARCH reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STATUS GAME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: GOV. THOMPSON OF ILLINOIS TO SEEK A FOURTH TERM
description: On Sunday, Gov. James R. Thompson asked state officials to reserve his license plate number, GOV 1, for four more years. And this morning the 49-year-old Republican made the official announcement that surprised no one in this politically crucial Middle Western state:

title: Food, Food, Food
description: Last January, Elizabeth Wallace went to a gala party in a Washington museum and noticed that huge amounts of food had been left uneaten. Add that to the similar quantities left at embassy balls, political get-togethers and corporate receptions, she thought, and a lot of food is being wasted at a time when the capital's homeless population is growing and many people are going hungry.

title: CUOMO SEEKING LOCAL BUDGET CURBS
description: The Cuomo administration, citing a threat of Federal budget cuts, today for the first time included local governments and school districts in its annual request for spending reductions.

title: WINSTON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $42,000 for the quarter and $446,000 for the 6 months and tax credits of $259,000 for the quarter and $692,000 for the 6 months.

title: BOBBY REYNOLDS
description: Bobby Reynolds, a former halfback who was one of the leading career rushers for the University of Nebraska, died today at Bryan Memorial Hospital here.

title: ARIZONA SAFETY AIDE IS REPORTED CHOSEN FOR U.S. TRUCK POST
description: An Arizona public safety official has been chosen by the Federal Highway Administration to oversee its truck safety inspection bureau, Department of Transportation and trucking industry sources said today.

title: PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to July 21
description: b-Including tax credits of $82,000 for the quarter and $53,000 for the 6 months. c-Net losses.

title: INTELLIGENT COMMUN. NETORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RADIATION TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
RIDGEWAY EXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 3o
Thailand Textile Plea
description: Thailand lobbied vigorously today against pending legislation to limit textile imports into the United States, telling a Congressional delegation such legislation would affect its security posture as a pro-Western ''front line state.'' Prime Minister Prem Tinsulanonda said that Representative Sam M. Gibbons, Democrat of Florida, the delegation head, had said he would try to find a compromise that would have the least impact on Thailand.

title: 'HYDRO PRESSURE FALLING'
description: Following are excerpts from the cockpit voice recorder of Japan Air Lines Flight 123, as released tonight by the Japanese Transport Ministry and translated by The New York Times. The elapsed time of the tape is indicated in minutes and seconds. 1:05 - CAPT. MASAMI TAKAHAMA: Right turn. What's this?

title: New Filings By Schwab
description: Charles R. Schwab, a director of the BankAmerica Corporation and chairman of its discount brokerage subsidiary, has amended his filings to the Securities and Exchange Commission to show he has sold more BankAmerica stock recently than previously reported. The sales have attracted attention because ofthe huge loss BankAmerica reported for the second quarter.

title: Market Place;   Gains Forecast For Blue Chips
description: AT a time when many money managers are switching investment strategies, Arthur Gray Jr. is holding to a steady course. He continues to favor big, diversified blue-chip companies, which he believes will reap the rewards of an economic expansion over the next 18 months.

title: LITTLEFIELD, ADAMS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $97,000 for the quarter and $267,000 for the 6 months.

title: PLAINS RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Dept. of Easy Answers
description: Almost every night all summer long, upwards of 7,000 people pack the Wolf Trap Farm Park for the Performing Arts in the Virginia countryside 15 miles west of the capital, and not a few of them have asked: What's a wolf trap?

title: Live Coverage of Indy
description: For the first time in its 20 years of televising the Indianapolis 500, ABC will provide live coverage of America's premier auto racing event.

title: COUNTY PROSECUTOR DEFENDS DROPPING SEX ABUSE CASES
description: A county prosecutor today defended her decision to dismiss charges of sexually abusing children against 21 adults in the little Minnesota town of Jordan.

title: A TV AD DRIVE SPAWNS CULT HERO FOR THE KLUTZY
description: Perhaps it's his white socks. Or his paunch. Or his plastic pocket protector. Perhaps it's the feeling that here at last is one junior executive who does not jog or wear a Walkman or eat macadamia gelato or own a pair of Reebok shoes.

title: Peace Group to Confront France at Test Site
description: A spokesman for Greenpeace said today that the environmental group would go ahead with its campaign against French nuclear tests in the Pacific despite orders by President Francois Mitterrand authorizing the use of force against its ''peace flotilla.''

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PROPERTY CAPITAL TRUST (BOSTON)(A) reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Indonesia Indicts Critic Of Suharto Government
description: A prominent Government critic and former secretary general of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations was indicted by an Indonesian court today for subversion and involvement in a terrorist conspiracy.

title: SOVIET MUST SHIFT ON MAJOR ISSUES, M'FARLANE INSISTS
description: Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, said today that ''even incremental improvements'' in the relations between the United States and the Soviet Union would be hard to achieve without changes in Moscow's approach to major issues.

title: Acquisition By Coast Bank
description: Great American First Savings Bank, a San Diego-based savings bank, today signed a letter of intent to buy Home Federal Savings and Loan of Arizona for $36.50 a share, or a total of $102.3 million.

title: YORK RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $40,000 for the quarter and $148,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $33,000 for the quarter and $83,000 for the 9 months.

title: Bolar Agrees to Drug Halt
description: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company said yesterday that it had agreed to stop marketing about 20 generic prescription drugs that it had reformulated without the approval of the Food and Drug Administration.

title: PASTA & CHEESE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Eaton Contract
description: The Eaton Corporation is being awarded a $1.8 billion contract for defensive avionics for B-1B bombers, the Air Force said. The multiyear procurement provides for 92 packages of instruments to help the bombers avoid detection by enemy radar and aircraft. Work on the contract is expected to be completed in June 1988.

title: CITY OPERA: MASSENET'S 'MANON'
description: THE opera house is the worst place in the world to be when things are going wrong or only partly right. But now and then everything falls into place, as it did Sunday night with the New York City Opera's ''Manon,'' and then there is nowhere in the world a melomaniac would rather be. This first ''Manon'' of the season rapidly developed into a love affair between the audience and the two principals: Faith Esham as the amoral, pleasure-loving Manon and Jerry Hadley as her puppet-on-a-string lover.

title: WELDOTRON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Talking Business/with Giglio of Bear, Stearns;   Local Projects: Fund Squeeze
description: Infrastructure is a fancy word for some very basic things that are often taken for granted. Projects for clean water, good roads, mass transit, waste disposal and other public structures take years to build, and longer to pay for. But without them, the quality of life suffers and local economies wither.

title: EARLY CALIFORNIA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $39,000.

title: Trial Opens in Arkansas Over Death in 1960
description: Hoping to bridge a 25-year gap between a black man's death in jail and the murder trial of two white former law officers, a prosecutor today showed jurors a scale model of the jail building as it appeared in 1960.

title: ABC FILM ON ALCOHOLICS' CHILDREN
description: It was an eerie instance of life imitating art: A distraught woman accosted patrons at a bowling alley in the Simi Valley north of Los Angeles, asking if anyone had seen her teen-age son, who had run away from home after a fight with his alcoholic father. At the same bowling alley that afternoon, a television movie was being filmed that bore remarkable similarities to the woman's true-life story.

title: Mortgage Rate Study
description: Borrowers are choosing adjustable-rate mortgage loans with interest rates linked to a more volatile index than a year ago, meaning attractive rates being offered now could swing up rapidly if short-term rates head up, according to a study released today. The United States League of Savings Institutions said that adjustable-rate mortgages, indexed to the relatively slow-moving ''cost of funds,'' accounted for almost half of the adjustable loans in 1984. but just over one-fifth of the adjustables made in May 1985.

title: XTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BELLAMY URGES A 31% RAISE IN STARTING PAY FOR TEACHERS
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy yesterday called for an immediate 31 percent increase in the salary of newly hired public school teachers, in addition to any increase negotiated in collective bargaining.

title: SOME FAMILIAR NAMES ON CUTDOWN LIST
description: By 4 P.M. today, National Football League teams must reduce their rosters to 60 players, the first mandatory limit that will lead to the in-season maximum of 45 players per team.

title: AMERICAN NATIONAL PETROEUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NETWORK KEEPS ALASKA LEGISLATORS IN TOUCH
description: One day in April, a reporter from northern Alaska asked Senator Frank H. Murkowski about plans to close a Federal weather station in the Arctic Ocean that issued early storm warnings to the coastal communities.

title: Spendthrift for Sale
description: The principal owners of Spendthrift Farm, the blue-chip thoroughbred nursery in Lexington, Ky., that houses 38 stallions, including Seattle Slew and Affirmed, said they would sell their controlling interest in the farm if they can find a single buyer for their 63.67 percent of the company's stock. The announcement was made through the offices of Spendthrift Farm Inc., which became a public corporation last year when Leslie Combs 2d and his son, Brownell, extended a public stock offering for 36.3 percent of the farm. The Combses said they would sell their shares only if they could find a buyer who would purchase their entire interest and who would agree to buy any other shares that became available.

title: TITAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: bNet income.

title: TEECO PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
181 Autos Ranked for Safety
description: Small two-door cars and Japanese models dominate the list of automobiles with the worst records of injury and vehicle damage in crashes, an insurance industry group said today.

title: Reading Tea Leaves on the Civil Rights Uproar
description: Once again a civil rights proposal drafted by senior officials of the Reagan Administration has set off a political furor. But this time much of the debate is within the Administration itself.

title: A Presidential Plug
description: A foreword by Ronald Reagan will appear in a forthcoming book, ''Norman Rockwell's Patriotic Times,'' that will be sold through regular commercial channels. The White House press office said no other such advance endorsement had been given by the President while in office.

title: Becker Advances
description: Boris Becker of West Germany, the 17-year-old Wimbledon champion, defeated Shahar Perkiss of Israel, 6-2, 6-3, today in the opening round of the $375,000 Association of Tennis Professionals Championship.

title: NEW SWIMSUITS: DARING VARIETY
description: Next year's swimsuits are appearing on New York fashion runways now as a key part of the resort showings. The same kind of familiar stretch fabrics that fit like a second skin continue to prevail - the news is that a bit more skin is occasionally covered. Sometimes a swimsuit leg may descend an inch or two down the thigh; a bra top may cover a bit of the midriff. A ruffle around the neck or leg and some shirring serve as softening agents, but not enough to obscure the basic truth: Today's fashion swimsuits do little to disguise a figure's faults.

title: MALIBU GRAND PRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CITY RETAIL SALES ROSE 0.1% IN JULY
description: New York City retail sales in July rose only one-tenth of 1 percent over the same 1984 month, remaining in the plateau that has been evident for more than a year, according to a spot-check.

title: NVF CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a gain on the sale of securities of $65,639,000 for the quarter and 6 months, a credit of $663,000 for the quarter and 6 months in connection with the termination of a pension plan and a tax credit of $4,720,000 for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $330,000 for the quarter and $703,000 for 6 months.

title: Wrapping Washington in a Ribbon of Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Syntex to Acquire 18% of Genetics
description: The Syntex Corporation said that it had agreed to buy 18 percent of the Genetics Systems Corporation of Seattle for $8.50 a share, or a total of $40 million. The companies will begin a joint program to develop diagnostic products for infectious diseases, including acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, and sexually transmitted diseases.

title: ABUSE OF THE AGED MUST END
description: I recently became aware of a serious problem in this country while working on a film that takes place in a nursing home where the patients are systematically abused. Some of the abuses in the script shocked me, and I assumed they had been exaggerated for dramatic purposes. I was devastated when I found out that the reverse is true: the abuses had been toned down to make them acceptable on television.

title: CSM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POLAR BEARS ON 'NOVA'
description: THE best part of ''In the Land of the Polar Bears'' isn't about polar bears; it's about snow geese. When you've seen one polar bear, you've pretty much seen the tribe. Snow geese are more interesting because, for one thing, they have families. You can see them in the ''Nova'' production, a rerun, on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: Coldwell Banker Head Announces Retirement
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that C. Wesley Poulson would retire as chairman and chief executive of its Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group at the end of the month.

title: Advertising;   TV Campaign Against Crime
description: The Department of Justice will begin its first national television campaign on Sept. 2. The public service commercials were designed to encourage citizens to assist law enforcement officials by coming forward to ''Report. Identify. Testify.''

title: CABLE PROPOSAL AT NBC
description: Key representatives of NBC's affiliated stations have given qualified support to a proposal by NBC for a 24-hour news service for cable subscribers that would compete with Ted Turner's Cable News Network, network and station officials said yesterday.

title: Farm Problem
description: Another barometer of the Cubs' woes is the dearth of talent in the farm system, which, the front office acknowledges, will not be capable of a significant contribution for at least two or three years.

title: CAR BOMBS KILL 29 IN MOSLEM BEIRUT
description: Car bombs exploded outside a cafe and a mosque in the Moslem sector today, killing 29 people and wounding 82. The bombings were believed to be in revenge for similar attacks in the Christian sector that took 70 lives last week.

title: Swapping Stations Imperils Public TV
description: Public television stations are being tempted by seductive talk of station-swapping. Some public stations -those close to the broadcasting equivalent of the poverty level - are being lured by offers to trade in their valuable very high frequency channels for hard cash and a weaker ultrahigh frequency channel held by a commercial station.

title: AVANT-GARDE COMPUTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: BAYLOR'S ART OF BEING HIT
description: The thud so often heard when Don Baylor is at the plate is not ball against bat, but ball against shoulder, ball against elbow, ball against forearm, ball against rib, ball against back, ball against leg and ball against batting helmet.

title: FLASHLIGHTS OF VIRGINIA POLICE SCREEN FOR DRUNKEN DRIVERS
description: It all seemed routine. In a well publicized program of checking motorists' sobriety at checkpoints, the police here beamed their flashlights into cars.

title: JACOBSON STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net loss.

title: FIRECOM INC reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $93,690.

title: Nine Horses Die
description: Nine horses were killed when fire destroyed a barn at The Red Mile harness track, authorities said.

title: DUNKIN' DONUTS CORP reports earnings for 13 wks to July 27
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split which was distributed on April 19, 1985.

title: HERITAGE ENTERTAINMENT YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Maneuvers
description: In the old days, political maneuvering for Presidential nominations began surfacing late in the year before the election. Any public display of interest or activity earlier than that was regarded as premature or even in bad taste, to the extent that any such standard was observed in politics.

title: 'THE FLAXFIELD'
description: ''THE FLAXFIELD,'' Jan Gruyaert's Belgian-Dutch film opening today at the Film Forum 1, is a studied, handsome, dour film about life on a Flemish farm at the turn of the century and, particularly, about the terrible consequences of an aging farmer's jealousy of his only son.

title: U.S. Studies Case
description: John Williams, the former Tulane basketball star who has been accused of participating in a point-shaving scheme, may face Federal charges if a Louisiana judge refuses to clear the way for further prosecution of state charges against him, according to the United States Attorney in New Orleans. ''We are monitoring the case,'' said the official, John Volz, who added that if the state case against Williams collapsed, ''we will look into the possibility of pressing Federal charges.''

title: Philadelphia Bombing Reportedly Planned in '84
description: The police had planned as early as a year ago to use explosives in evicting Move members from their fortified house in west Philadelphia, The Philadelphia Daily News reported today.

title: RAVEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW SPATE OF CARBIDE LAWSUITS
description: Lawyers who have sued the Union Carbide Corporation over the gas leak disaster in Bhopal, India, filed new multimillion-dollar damage suits yesterday against the company, this time on behalf of victims of the Aug. 11 gas leak at Carbide's similar facility in Institute, W. Va.

title: Freddie Mac to Package Multifamily Mortgages
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, announced a new program yesterday to buy mortgages on multifamily properties and repackage the loans into a mortgage pass-through security to be sold to investors.

title: Federal Failures in the AIDS Epidemic
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSOCIATED DRY GOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective August 9. Sales figures for the latest quarter do not include the sale of Powers Dry Goods Co. effective at the end of June.

title: International Flavors' Top Officers to Resign
description: International Flavors and Fragrances Inc., in a surprise move, announced yesterday that both its chairman, Henry G. Walter Jr., and its president, S. James Spitz Jr., would resign.

title: TVI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in the Company Briefs column in Business Day yesterday about Manufactured Homes Inc. misstated the company's location. It is based in Winston-Salem, N.C., and has no affiliation with the company of the same name based in Marshall, Mich.

title: On-the-Job Living
description: Moving into the job as executive director of the Henry Street Settlement on the Lower East Side means more than moving into an office. It means moving into the settlement.

title: Two Men and Boy Held In Deaths in Nebraska
description: Two men and a boy are being held on charges of first-degree murder after two bodies and a cache of weapons, ammunition and explosives were found on a farm here, the authorities said.

title: Rail Union Vetoes Arbitration
description: The United Transportation Union has rejected arbitration as a means of reaching a new contract with the rail industry, the National Mediation Board said today. The move could ultimately result in a strike against most of the nation's major railroads.

title: CORPORATE PROFITS DOWN
description: After-tax corporate profits declined by four-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, the fifth consecutive quarterly decline, the Commerce Department said today.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,364,000 for the quarter and $1,444,000 for the 6 months and a charge of $6 million for the quarter and 6 months from the writedown of certain assets. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,438,000 for the quarter and $2,729,000 for the 6 months.

title: Boesky Sells Stake
description: Ivan F. Boesky, the New York investor, said that he has sold part of his stake in Scott & Fetzer Company for about $14 million, reducing his holding to 4 percent, from 7.3 percent. Kelso & Company's proposed $62-a-share leveraged buyout of Scott & Fetzer, a Westlake, Ohio, household product concern, fell through recently after the Labor Department threatened action against the buyout.

title: INDIA'S SIKHS LOSE A SOURCE OF STABILITY
description: The assassination of Harchand Singh Longowal removes a moderating force of stability at a time when it appeared that, thanks in large part to his efforts, a long-festering conflict in the Punjab was finally nearing a solution.

title: ETHNIC CALENDAR, PUMP FROM ITALY
Experiment in Dunning
description: The return address was intriguing - a post office box in Southampton, Pa. Pennsylvania? Inside the letter, to a Manhattan worker, was a surprise - a New York City parking ticket.

title: U.S. News Switches To Dancer Fitzgerald
description: U.S. News & World Report, the news weekly owned by Mortimer B. Zuckerman, has switched agencies to Dancer Fitzgerald Sample from Foote, Cone & Belding.

title: COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONSCO ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $80,041. c-Net loss.

title: GOODEN FANS 16, WINS 13TH IN ROW
description: After two somewhat prosaic starts that raised a few eyebrows, Dwight Gooden came blazing back in full command last night in Shea Stadium. In an overpowering performance spiced with 16 strikeouts, the most in the big leagues this year, he pitched the Mets to a 3-0 victory over the San Francisco Giants, and ran his winning streak to 13 games and his season's record to 19 and 3.

title: NARRAGANSETT CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including capital gains of $1,313,000 for the quarter and $1,447,000 for the 6 months. c-After capital losses of $485,000 for the quarter and $71,000 for the 6 months.

title: Top Yield Is 9 1/4% On Illinois Bonds
description: The State of Illinois is offering $150 million of general obligation bonds with a maximum yield of 9 1/4 percent for bonds due in 2015, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: FINE-BAG MAKERS IN NEW VENTURE: FINE GOAT CHEESE
description: THE work shirt is an unfaded blue, and the jeans look suspiciously stiff. But the real tipoff that Miles Cahn is no ordinary farmer is his fine leather belt. Until last month, Mr. Cahn, who is 64, and his wife Lillian, 61, were Upper West Siders and co-owners of Coach Leatherware, the New York manufacturer whose Coach bag is a fashion standard. This month they are goat farmers.

title: NORDSTROM INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Sales figures have been restated to exclude service charges and other income which are now credited against costs and expenses.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
I.B.M. AND N.Y.U. JOIN TO PRODUCE COMPUTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had begun work with New York University on a new experimental supercomputer to try to resolve the debate in the data-processing community over whether several processors inside a computer are better than one.

title: Security Set to Buy Arizona Bancwest
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest bank holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Arizona Bancwest Corporation for about $480 million.

title: TONS OF RIBS, 2 MILLION MESSY FINGERS
description: THERE were two million messy fingers in Cleveland last weekend. They got that way by grabbing the million ribs that were eaten by the 200,000 people who came to the National Rib Cook-Off.

title: Space Factory Planned
description: A Houston company, using no Government money for its multimillion-dollar venture, won approval today to build and operate the first commercial factory in space. The facility will operate automatically, with only periodic maintenance visits by astronauts. Space Industries said the factory is expected to be ready in 1989.

title:
Economic Scene;

An Emerging China's Impact
description: ONE-FOURTH of the population on our globe has begun its economic takeoff: China has finally started a steady effort to modernize. Long-term results of this endeavor could have a huge impact on the world economy and on the strategic power balance.

title: DOW UP 11.20
description: The stock market staged its best rally in more than a month yesterday, propelled by a combination of optimistic interest rate forecasts and technical factors.

title: Judge Adjourns Murder Trial Of Leaders of Grenada Coup
description: Chief Justice Sir Archibald Nedd today adjourned the trial of 19 leftists accused of the murder of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop to hear a defense motion seeking free access to the defendants.

title: POLICE-TEST CRITIC GETS A REPRIMAND
description: A city official said yesterday that she had been ''singled out for retribution'' and warned by Personnel Director Juan U. Ortiz that she might be dismissed because she publicly criticized the last written test for police officers as too easy.

title: Volcker Gives View On Curbs
description: The Federal Reserve Board would seek to tighten its controls on monetary growth should the economy and the money supply grow faster than current expectations, its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, said in a letter written on Aug. 6 that was released today.

title: 2 FOR MATTINGLY
description: The Yankees lacked pitching tonight, but there was no shortage of power. They ripped five home runs - two by Don Mattingly, who pushed his runs batted in total to 100 - and endured several harrowing moments before finally subduing the California Angels, 8-5, at Anaheim Stadium.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Recalled Dave Owen, infielder, from Iowa farm club. METS (NL) - Signed Larry Bowa, shortstop. FOOTBALL BUFFALO (AFC) - Acquired Pete Metzelaars, tight end, from Seattle.

title: METROPOLITAN LIFE TO BUY CENTURY 21 REAL ESTATE
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation, the nation's largest real estate sales organization, from the Transworld Corporation.

title: ST. LOUIS BID TO REMOVE SERRA WORK
description: The City of St. Louis is considering calling a referendum on whether to remove a major sculpture in the downtown area by Richard Serra, whose ''Tilted Arc'' in Lower Manhattan is facing possible relocation by the Federal agency that commissioned it.

title: Politics;   Of Hens' Teeth and Control of the Senate
description: A single Republican Senator decided this week not to seek re-election and suddenly both parties are reassessing their prospects in the 1986 Senate elections.

title: US MUTUAL FINANCIAL CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bankruptcy Filing by Parent of Thrift Unit
description: The Bell National Corporation, which owned the Bell Savings and Loan Association of San Mateo, Calif., said last night that it had filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: PLANTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $681,000 for the quarter and $2,949,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $905,000, a tax credit of $369,000 and a loss of $555,000 on the spinoff of a unit.

title: BOREK SHOOTS 68 TO LEAD MET OPEN
description: The flawlessly prepared golf course of the Mountain Ridge Country Club, a Donald Ross masterpiece, looked inviting today but it was not so hospitable when it came to scoring in the first round of the Met Open.

title: RESIDENTS AND NONPROFIT GROUP TO RESTORE A CHICAGO NEIGHBORHOOD
description: When Francisco Perez walked through his neighborhood on the Southwest Side, he saw streets littered and pocked with potholes. Gangs were recruiting. Some of his neighbors, unsure of their future and hampered by high repair costs, were letting their homes run down.

title: DEERE & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including net gains of $22,900,000 for the quarter and $40,000,000 for the 9 months from the reduction of LIFO inventory and net charges of $8,300,000 for the quarter and $22,300,000 for the 9 months from employment reductions. c-Including net gains of $5,700,000 for the quarter and $19,300,000 for the 9 months from the reduction of LIFO inventory, a gain of $28,500,000 for the quarter and the 9 months from a onetime tax law change and a gain of $8,100,000 for the 9 months from a patent infringement settlement.

title: SIGNED JULY ACCORD WITH GANDHI
description: A leading Sikh political figure was shot and killed today by Sikh assailants in the Indian state of Punjab.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amfesco Industries, Plainview, L.I., which makes athletic and casual footwear, has elected Jack Entel president, succeeding David Greenblatt, who was elected to the new office of chairman and chief executive officer.

title: A Drastic Proposal On Civil Rights
description: Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., President Reagan's controversial chairman of the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights, recently suggested that the commission might have outlived its usefulness. Citing the half-billion-dollar-a-year, 14,000-employee civil rights bureaucracy, he talked about abolishing the commission in 1989. From our perspective, sooner would be better than later.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 21, 1985
description: The Economy

title: FISH WHOLESALERS PLY RETAIL TRADE
description: LOBSTERS for $2.99 a pound, fresh whole bluefish for 79 cents a pound and pearly white halibut steaks for $4.99 a pound. Those were a few of the prices last week at some of the retail fish markets run by major seafood wholesalers. There are now several in the New York area, in New Jersey, Brooklyn and Manhattan. They offer wide selection, low prices and generally good quality.

title: PHOENIX MEDICAL TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MEMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: STATE AND U.S. ENTER BRIEFS CRITICIZING WESTERN JUDGE
description: Federal and state sponsors of Westway said in court papers yesterday that the judge who last month again blocked construction of the project had conducted an ''inquisition'' and engaged in ''judicial overreaching of the highest order.''

title: CLAIRE'S STORES reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a stock split in fiscal 1985.

title: Prince Tennis Spots Set for Next Week
description: Prince Manufacturing Inc. will begin a $3 million print, radio and television campaign with a two-week blitz during the U.S. Open tennis tournament beginning next Tuesday.

title: JUDGE ORDERS 5 OFF CITY BALLOTS, INCLUDING FARRELL
description: A state judge ruled yesterday that Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. may not appear on the Sept. 10 ballot as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for mayor.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $3,083,000 in the latest quarter and $3,211,000 in the latest six months. c-Includes income from discontinued operations of $762,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,514,00 for the year ago quarter and discontinued operations of $1,602,000 for the year ago first half and extraordinary credits of $2,514,00.

title: Margaret Hewes Dead at 87; Producer of Broadway Plays
description: Margaret Hewes, one of the first women to produce serious drama on Broadway, died last Thursday in King Edward Memorial Hospital in Bermuda after an operation to repair a broken hip. She was 87 years old and had lived in Bermuda for many years.

title: Dole Warns Taipei on Curb
description: The Senate majority leader, Bob Dole, urged Taiwan today to take drastic measures to cut its large trade surplus with the United States.

title: Deaths in Home Fires Drop 14%, Study Says
description: The number of people who died in home fires dropped 14 percent in 1984, largely because of far fewer deaths in arsons, according to a report issued today.

title: NODAWAY VALLEY CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Substance Repelled By Form
description: Recently I learned about Form 5500-C.

title: ARDEN INTERNATIONAL KITCHNS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $79,000 for the quarter and $157,000 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $57,000 for the quarter and $62,000 for the 6 months.

title: BBDO Unit In South Africa Sold
description: FALLOUT from the political turmoil in South Africa is beginning to be felt along Madison Avenue.

title: Greenland Seeks U.S. Money For Eskimos Moved for Base
description: Greenland is seeking as much as $5 million from the United States to compensate villagers who were moved to make way for an airbase extension, a Danish Government official said today.

title: CAST COULD INHIBIT GASTINEAU
description: It is called Bennett's Fracture, but it has nothing to do with Barry Bennett of the Jets.

title: Father-Son Team
description: Peter McNab, the 33-year-old free-agent center whose signing with the Devils was announced yesterday by General Manager Max McNab, becomes the fourth man in National Hockey League history to play for his father. Those earlier: Lynn and Muzz Patrick, who in the 1930's and 40's were employed by General Manager Lester Patrick of the Rangers, and Brent Imlach, who was briefly with Toronto in the mid-60's, when the Maple Leafs' coach and general manager was Punch Imlach.

title: NEWSPAPER BATTLE IN DETROIT COULD END IN A DRAW
description: The newspaper war between The Detroit News and The Detroit Free Press, combatants for over a hundred years in a bruising struggle for dominance here, may be entering a new and final phase.

title: Colavita in Line For G.O.P. Post
description: The Erie County Republican chairman, Victor Farley, has dropped out of the race for state party chairman, leaving the Westchester County chairman, Anthony Colavita, the apparent victor, a state party leader said today.

title: Other Dinner Trains
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Computer Unit Fills Key Post
description: The Computervision Corporation, a financially troubled maker of computerized design and manufacturing systems, yesterday named one of its directors, Robert L. Gable, to the new post of vice chairman and chief operating officer.

title: LIONEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Including tax credits of $487,000 for the quarter and $689,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $1,820,000 for the quarter and $2,315,000 for the 6 months. The company is listed on the Philadelphia, Midwest and Pacific stock exchanges. The company is operating under Chapter 11 of the U. S. Bankruptcy Code.

title: Texaco Will Sell Copper Unit Stake
description: Texaco Inc. said that it had agreed to sell its 50 percent stake in the Escondida copper deposit in Chile to Utah International Inc., a subsidiary of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia. Terms of the transaction, which increases Utah International's stake in the unit to 100 percent, were not disclosed.

title: Only Human
description: Boris Becker responds to the enormous adulation he has received since triumphing at Wimbledon: ''I'm just a human being.

title: Nicholas Eden, Earl of Avon And Former Aide to Thatcher
description: Nicholas Eden, the Earl of Avon and a former under secretary in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Cabinet, died Saturday after a long illness, it was reported today. He was 54 years old.

title: FEDERAL REALTY INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Man Said to Be Ex-Nazi Gives Up in Costa Rica
description: A man accused of being a Nazi war criminal whose United States citizenship was revoked in 1982 has surrendered to Costa Rican authorities, the Government reported.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EACH morning, Al Greenberg leaves his apartment at Fifth Avenue and 12th Street to walk Eleanor, the family's basset hound. And each morning, at the end of the stroll, Mr. Greenberg stops at the corner newspaper vending machine. He inserts the proper amount in coins, opens the door, removes a paper, closes the door, puts the paper under his arm and takes Eleanor back to the apartment.

title: German Failures Up
description: A total 6,783 businesses filed for bankruptcy protection in West German courts in the first half of 1985, up 12.6 percent from the 1984 period, the Federal Statistics Office said today.

title: Federal Failures in the AIDS Epidemic
description: To the Editor:

title: GIRL WINS RIGHT TO JOIN FOOTBALL TEAM
description: An administrative law judge in New Jersey ruled yesterday that a 15-year-old girl - a 5-foot-5 would-be wide receiver - can play on her high school football team this fall.

description: b-Operating loss. c-Net loss.

APPEALS COURT ORDERS CBS TO PAY HELMS'S FEES IN SUIT
description: A Federal appeals court today ordered CBS to pay attorney fees to Richard Helms, a former Director of Central Intelligence, for what the court said were the ''groundless litigation tactics'' used by the network in the libel suit of Gen. William C. Westmoreland.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
On Television
description: Members of the House of Representatives should be aware that a quarter of all the 85 million American homes with television sets can now watch the gavel-to-gavel broadcasts of its floor sessions on C-Span, the cable public affairs network. Not all these people are actually tuned in, of course, but the network's latest marketing survey indicates a large potential audience out there.

title: KEAN BACKS HALT IN INVESTING TIED TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Governor Kean said today that he would sign legislation to withdraw $2 billion in state investments from companies doing business in South Africa, as a protest against the Pretoria Government's policies of racial separation.

title: The Young Conservatives
description: In the subjective political history-book of young conservatives, there have been three generations since the New Deal. The first included such pioneers as Senator Barry Goldwater and William F. Buckley, and the second brought forth the New Right, the political organizers behind Ronald Reagan and leaders like Howard Phillips of the Conservative Caucus and Edwin J. Feulner Jr. of the Heritage Foundation.

title: A Crisis of Courtesy Epitomized by New York City Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-E.P.A. Head Leads Inquiry
description: The Union Carbide Corporation today named William D. Ruckelshaus, a former Administrator of the Federal Environmental Protection Agency, to head an investigation into the Aug. 11 leak of toxic gases at the company's plant in Institute, W.Va., in which 135 people were injured.

description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: CULLINET SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Australian Union Protesters
description: The police arrested more than 100 people today during union demonstrations against tough anti-strike laws passed by the conservative Queensland state government. The police moved in after more than 2,000 people gathered outside the state parliament buildings at the start of a new parliamentary session. Queensland unions have been in dispute with the state government since laws were enacted in February imposing constraints on union activities.
