description: Asset figures represent net assets.

title: LOTTO FEVER TURNS INTO $41 MILLION EPIDEMIC
description: All over New York yesterday, there were dreams for sale - 19,000 a minute.

title: Frank Kelley, Who Got Emmy For Apollo Coverage by NBC
description: Frank R. Kelley, who was national and foreign editor of The New York Herald Tribune, and later a reporter, writer and producer for NBC News, died Monday of a heart attack at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: NEW YORK LEADING OTHER CITIES IN U.S. IN POPULATION GAIN
description: Between 1982 and 1984, New York City gained more people than any other city in the country, reversing a decline in the 1970's in which its recorded population fell by nearly 800,000, according to a study by the Federal Bureau of the Census.

title: RESTAURANT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for 12 wks to July 13
EDUCATIONAL COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Mexicali and Seoul Gain
description: Armando Verdugo went 4 for 4 and knocked in four runs as Mexicali, Mexico, advanced to the semifinals of the Little League World Series with a 6-3 victory today over Staten Island. In the opening game of the 39th annual tournament, Seoul, South Korea, routed Maracaibo, Venezuela, 13-2, getting two home runs and five runs batted in from Zin-Young You.

title: Petro-Canada Write-Down Set
description: Petro-Canada, is taking a $486 million after-tax write-down on assets associated with frontier exploration. Petro-Canada said it has incurred about 40 percent of total industry spending on exploration in the Labrador, Baffin and Arctic Island regions since it began operations in 1976.

title: Laxalt's Road Ahead
description: It is a long way from Nevada to Washington, and it is a varied career from public prosecutor to private law practice to lieutenant governor to governor to operator of a hotel and casino to service in the United States Senate.

title: Revlon Reportedly Protests Bank's Role in Bid
description: The Chemical Bank is running into strong objections from Revlon Inc. over a loan the bank provided to help Pantry Pride finance a $1.8 billion hostile takeover bid for Revlon, sources close to the huge cosmetics company said yesterday.

title: Topics;   Reverberations Whine Not
description: Some New Yorkers still feel a sense of loss on learning the news. The city, as part of its ongoing refurbishing of the Brooklyn Bridge, is slathering $3.1 million worth of epoxy on the bridge's road surface to eliminate that whine.

title: HUGHES SUPPLY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
T's That Never Make the Evening News
description: To the Editor:

title: CARSON PIRIE SCOTT & CO reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in June 1985.

title: U.S. Priest Held for 3 Days By the Honduran Authorities
description: A Roman Catholic priest from the United States was detained Sunday for investigation of possible ''crimes against the security of the state'' and then released late Tuesday.

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $305,000 for the quarter and $363,000 for the 6 months and nonrecurring gains of $401,000 for the quarter and $601,000 for the 6 months from the sale of leases. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: PIPE BOMBS FOUND OUTSIDE 2 BUILDINGS IN THE WALL ST. AREA
description: Two pipe bombs with timing devices were discovered before dawn yesterday outside two office buildings in the Wall Street area and were safely removed by police bomb experts.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: RETURN TRIPS. By Alice Adams. 195 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPAIN'S AUSTERITY PLAN HITS HARD AT YOUTHS
description: At the Government mint last month, 30 apprentices were in the 11th day of a classroom lock-in. The Government had said there was no money for them.

title: EXOTIC VEGETARIAN DISCOVERY: THE CUISINE OF AN INDIAN STATE
description: IT seems to be one of those unexplained quirks of history and society. Though a large percentage of Indians living in New York and elsewhere in the United States migrated from the state of Gujarat, and though many of us are interested in preparing vegetable dishes as part of a healthy diet, the incredibly tasty vegetarian cuisine of India's Gujarat region is unfamiliar to most Americans.

title: FOX-STANLEY PHOTO PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
SOAP OPERAS CAST A SPELL OVER INDIA
description: The possibility that Badke, an attractive young social worker, might not marry handsome Dr. Ashwani Kumar alarmed and dismayed the viewers of India's most popular television soap opera last year.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: WHEN an American rock ''underground'' first emerged as a viable alternative to ''Top 40'' radio back in the mid-1960's, the musicians, fans, disk jockeys and other participants in the new scene found themselves face to face with a basic and rather perplexing issue. The costs of equipping themselves, producing rock records and staging rock concerts were well beyond the means of the average band or would-be rock entrepreneur. ''The magic's in the music, and the music's in me,'' audiences exulted. But who was going to pay the bills?

title: CHRONAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $180,000 for the quarter and $238,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: Wilander Gains
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden, the defending champion, defeated Vince Van Patten, 6-0, 6-1, today in the first round of the Association of Tennis Professionals Championship.

title: REPAYMENT PLAN FILED BY BALDWIN
description: The Baldwin-United Corporation and a subsidiary, the D.H. Baldwin Company, filed a joint reorganization plan today in United States Bankruptcy Court under which Baldwin-United estimates that it will ultimately pay unsecured creditors as much as $140 million in cash.

title: Ulster Car Bomb Wounds 2
description: Two passers-by were wounded today when a car bomb exploded near a police station in Newcastle, 40 miles south of Belfast.

title: Tunisia Said to Expel 253 Libyans for Spying
description: Tunisia has expelled 253 Libyans, including diplomats, for spying, the official press agency reported today.

title: ICAHN WINS A ROUND IN T.W.A. BID
description: The directors of Trans World Airlines in an unexpected move voted unanimously yesterday to reject any proposals that would give the Texas Air Corporation the ability to thwart Carl C. Icahn in his bid for the carrier.

title: Manville Sued By Holder
description: In the first protest on the Manville Corporation's recently released proposed plan of reorganization, a shareholder has filed suit in Delaware Chancery Court to force the company to hold an annual meeting.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. WILL PROCEED WITH AN ARMS TEST ON SPACE TARGET
description: The White House announced today that, despite Soviet objections, the United States would proceed with the first American test of an anti-satellite weapon against an object in space.

title: Coveting Miss Liberty
description: New York and New Jersey have differed on matters like pollution of the Hudson, the movement of jobs from Manhattan and the building of Westway. These are serious issues, susceptible to amicable resolution. But now some New Jerseyans have gone beyond the bounds. They're suing to take the Statue of Liberty away from New York.

title: SARA LEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels, at Anaheim, Calif. The Angels' Reggie Jackson will try to add to his career home-run total; he hit his 523d Monday night. (Television - SportsChannel, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:30 P.M.) Little League World Series, at Williamsport, Pa., through Saturday. Boxing Billy Costello vs. Lonnie Smith, 12 rounds, for Costello's World Boxing Council superlightweight title, at Madison Square Garden. First preliminary, 8 P.M. The semifinal is a 10-round junior-middlweight bout between Wilfredo Benitez and Kevin Moley, and there will also be a 12-round superlightweight bout between Saul Julio, from Colombia, and Reyes Cruz, from the Dominican Republic. This is the fourth defense for the undefeated Costello, 30-0 with 17 knockouts, and his first outside his hometown, Kingston, N.Y. Smith, from Denver, is 20-0-1. Benitez, a three-time former champion from Puerto Rico, is 46-4-1, and Moley, from Selden, L.I., is 21-0 with 18 knockouts. Golf Walker Cup Matches, at Pine Valley, N.J. This is the first of two days in the biennial amateur competition between the United States and a team of Irish and British golfers. #70th Met Open Championships, at Mountain Ridge Country Club, West Caldwell, N.J. Second of three days. Tennis Hamlet Challenge Cup, at Jericho, L.I., through Sunday. Shearson Lehman Brothers Eastern Clay Court Championships, at Old Field Tennis Club, 400 Greenlawn Road, Greenlawn, L.I., 2 P.M., through Sunday.

title: Pentagon Forms Panel To Review Missile Plan
description: The Pentagon said today that it had formed a nine-member panel, headed by John M. Deutch of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to review the Midgetman nuclear missile program.

title: Hockey Defection
description: A Czechoslovak ice hockey star, Peter Klima, has apparently defected to the West while training with his national team in West Germany, a West German hockey official said yesterday. Klima, 22 years old , was a member of the Czechoslovak squad that won the world championship in Prague earlier this year.

title: ANGELICA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Offer for Spendthrift
description: A day after the principal owners of Spendthrift Farm announced that their 63.7 percent interest in the thoroughbred operation was for sale, they received a $27 million offer from two Kentucky horsemen. The prospective buyers are Richard D. Broadbent 3d, president of Bloodstock Research, Inc., a family-owned thoroughbred sales company, and Robert R. Hagopian, president of the Kentucky Horse Center Inc., a thoroughbred syndicator. Hagopian said he and Broadbent had delivered the offer yesterday morning to Leslie Combs 2d and his son Brownell Combs 2d, the principal owners of the famous breeding farm in Lexington, and had given them a deadline of 5 P.M. Friday to accept or reject it.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on the Style page Aug. 3 about prepaid legal services misquoted Gerald Mann, administrator and chief counsel of the legal plan of District Council 37 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. The council's prepaid legal services plan charges no fees for any of its legal services.

title: RESEARCH-COTTRELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss of $1,500,000 from discontinued operations in the year- ago quarter and $33,000,000 in the latest nine months. c-Net income.

title: Esso A.G. Closings
description: The West German subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation said that it would close refineries in Hamburg and Cologne, putting 800 employees out of work.

title: Lord, Geller Gets Account at Chemical
description: Chemical Bank, the sixth-largest bank in the country, has appointed Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein to develop its corporate advertising.

title: PENNEY, J C CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
BankAmerica Shock Lingers
description: IT has been a few weeks since the BankAmerica Corporation handed investors a series of shocks.

title: TALKING BASEBALL, SNORTING COCAINE
description: They called it ''the Cooperstown room.''

title: Transactions
description: MONDAY FOOTBALL ATLANTA (NFC) - Released Micah Moon, linebacker; Ashley Lee, safety; Dan Dufour, guard; Willie Curran, wide receiver; Chucky Davis, running back, and Leon Thomasson, cornerback. Placed back, and Rydell Malancon, linebacker.

title: 41 Police Aides Removed In Peru Cocaine Inquiry
description: The new Government has dismissed 41 of the nation's most senior police officials in a widening investigation of links between law enforcement authorities and the cocaine trade.

title: FOR MIDWEST GOVERNORS, UPBEAT MOOD AFTER LONG DECLINE
description: The Governors of seven Middle Western states have spent the last three days on this tiny island between Lake Huron and Lake Michigan, giving an upbeat answer to the question of whether the Middle West is pulling out of its decline.

title: WINE TALK
description: It was Tim Johnston on the telephone.

title: Ugandan Rebels Reject Peace Overtures
description: The main Ugandan rebel group rejected peace overtures from the new military Government today and threatened to fight on unless talks start soon.

title: $271 Million Issue By New Mexico
description: New Mexico is offering $271 million of refunding bonds backed by severance taxes.

title: U.S. WOULD FREE PRESSER'S UNCLE TO AVOID RETRIAL
description: The Justice Department has told a Federal judge it would agree to release from jail the uncle of Jackie L. Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, rather than risk exposure of sensitive information, a department official said today.

title: Poland Arrests Colonel Over Underground Case
description: A Polish Army colonel has been arrested in connection with the detention in April of Slawomir Bielecki, head of one of Poland's main underground publishing houses, the Government said today.

title: Topics;   Reverberations Ha-gen-da-tsu
description: In 1960, a Polish immigrant named Reuben Mattus needed a luxurious-sounding name for his rich new American ice cream - something evocative, exotic. He settled on Haagen-Dazs, meaning it to sound cold, clear and Danish.

title: TRW in Bid For Intelogic
description: TRW Inc., seeking to expand its hold on the third-party computer service business, said yesterday that it had bid $177 million to acquire Intelogic Trace Inc., a recently created company that formerly was the domestic customer service division of the Datapoint Corporation.

title: GRAPHIC TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ANTI-SATELLITE ARMS ISSUE
description: Scientists say that the American anti-satellite weapon, if fully developed, will be vastly more advanced than the Soviet one. They say it will be a marvel of high-technology miniaturization.

title: EAGLE ESCAPES HOLDOUT FINE: HE'S CUT
description: After weeks of holding out for a new contract, Dean Miraldi, a starting tackle for the Philadelphia Eagles last season, finally gave up. He reported to camp Monday, 24 days late, met with Coach Marion Campbell and agreed to pay fines of $1,000 a day -only to learn that he wouldn't have to pay them. He was cut.

title: HYDROMER INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-Including interest income of $46,613. c-Including interest income of $137,136.

title: TO TEST OR NOT TO TEST?
description: The image is a frightening one. A pitcher, zonked out from something he inhaled between innings, decides he can blow the batter away with an inside pitch. The batter, zonked out from something he inhaled between innings, decides he is immortal and leans into the pitch.

title: CITY IS ADDING WATER PATROL TEAMS TO DETECT HARD-TO-FIND PIPE LEAKS
description: As New York City's reservoir levels continue to decline toward the 50 percent mark, officials are struggling with underground water leaks that cost an estimated 50 million or more gallons a day.

title: A Colonial Shopping Village
description: EARLY in 1984 W. Averell Harriman, international statesman and former Governor of New York, donated 137 acres in Woodbury, N.Y., to the municipality to do with as it wished.

title: Scholarship Campaign
description: The Reader's Digest asked advertising agencies yesterday to help it promote a $500,000 scholarship program aimed at discouraging high school students from drinking and driving.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about London as a place for trying out shows for Broadway misidentified the authors of the musical ''Chess.'' They are Tim Rice, Benny Andersson and Bjorn Ulvaeus.

title: RETRIAL OF SAN DIEGO MAYOR IS OPENED
description: A county prosecutor asserted today that Mayor Roger Hedgecock won his office in 1983 because of a ''secret agreement'' to bankroll his election campaign with hundreds of thousands of dollars in illegal contributions from J. David Dominelli, a jailed financier, and his former companion, Nancy Hoover.

title: Time for a Truce in the Japan Trade War
description: In the recent 40th anniversary celebration of the end of World War II, two facts were obscured that need to be made clear. First, we're still at war with Japan. Second, we're losing.

title: Yankees Build
description: If a winning major league team is the product of a winning farm system, then the Yankees' future could not look much brighter than it does right now. Four of New York's five minor league clubs are solidly entrenched in first place, with the end of regular-season play less than two weeks off.

title: PUBCO CORPORATION, DEBTOR-IN-POSSESSION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including extraordinary income of $270,000 for the quarter and $785,000 for the 6 months. c-Including extraordinary income of $176,000 for the quarter and $386,000 for the 6 months.

title: Lingering Obligation
description: Most city workers were on the job last Jan. 21 when City Council President Carol Bellamy closed her office to honor the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., giving about 50 staff members a paid holiday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, said its Bell Atlantic Enterprises unit had signed an agreement with Compaq Telecommunications Corp. to offer a telecomputer product.

title: CORRECIONS
description: An article Aug. 4 about attempts to revive the oyster industry of Wellfleet, Mass., inaccurately reported the amount of shellfish that the town shipped at the turn of the century. The correct figure is 300 barrels a day.

title: TUTU SCORNS U.S. CRITICISM OF HIS ACTION
description: Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Anglican leader, said tonight that he could not ''take seriously'' criticism by the Reagan Administration over his refusal to attend a meeting Monday between church leaders and President P. W. Botha.

title: MANHATTAN BOROUGH PRESIDENT CANDIDATES DEBATE
description: City Clerk David N. Dinkins yesterday questioned the commitment to minority representation on the Board of Estimate of his two opponents for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan borough president, Assemblyman Jerrold Nadler and Seymour Friedman, a former judge.

title: Publicizing Farmers' Plight
description: Personalized license plates have long been a symbol of prestige or, some would say, vanity. Now Representative E. Thomas Coleman, Republican of Missouri, hopes to use them to ''drive home'' an important message to his colleagues.

title: BIG GAINS FOR VIDEO CASSETTES
description: In the bare-knuckled brawl among new entertainment technologies, the video cassette has crushed the videodisk, rolled over the video game, outmaneuvered pay-cable movie channels and outdistanced home computers. Now the video-cassette industry -one that did not exist eight years ago - is attracting almost as much money as movie box offices.

title: MARYLAND THRIFT UNIT CLOSING FOR TWO DAYS
description: The troubled Community Savings and Loan Association of Bethesda, Md., closed its nine offices yesterday for what it said would be two days of a cooling-off period after a three-day run by depositors.

title: AT A HOLY CITY IN FRANCE, NO ROOM FOR A TAVERN?
description: The souvenir shops in this sainted city of pilgrims, shops that have names like Our Lady of Perpetual Aid, offer an array of flickering, plastic objects for sale that may fall short of high art. But the shops reflect the dominant tone of Lourdes, where some 45,000 of the faithful come every day to visit the holiest Roman Catholic site in France.

title: Federal Spending That Works
description: In the era of the hammer that costs $435 and the $6 million gun that won't shoot straight, it is easy to complain about how recklessly the Federal Government spends people's money. According to a new study, however, Washington has learned how to do at least one thing right: help children.

title: KIMBARK OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Lakers Get Help From Salary Cap
description: In a manner of speaking, the Lakers beat the Celtics again this week - with help not from Kareem or Magic but from the National Basketball Association's salary-cap rules.

title: ECONOMY'S GROWTH 2% IN QUARTER
description: The economy expanded at a 2 percent rate in the second quarter, somewhat faster than was estimated last month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MARKETING SYSTEMS OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company did not commence active operations until November 1984 and had no revenues for the year-ago periods.

title: KENNEDY ASSASSIN SEEKS REHEARING ON PAROLE
description: The lawyer for Sirhan B. Sirhan today sought a new parole board hearing for the assassin of Robert F. Kennedy, citing an atmosphere of frivolity by board members when they considered the question in June.

title: AMERICAN COMMUNICATIONS & TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $1,343,000 for the quarter from the sale of a subsidiary and $1,792,000 for the 9 months from the sale of three subsidiaries. c-Net loss. d-Including interest income of $162,000.

title: 'PEARL,' MINI-SERIES ON ATTACK
description: ''Pearl'' is the television equivalent of a good read, a good long read. It doesn't strain us; we keep turning pages, and so what if we know early on how it will all turn out? When our attention wanders, ''Pearl'' reclaims it with with a love scene, a sinking battleship or another flight of Zeros. The six-hour mini-series, first shown in 1978, will begin with a two-hour episode on Channel 11 at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CONCERT FOR THE COUNT Tonight at 8:15 in the Damrosch Park Band Shell in Lincoln Center, a 16-piece band led by Illinois Jacquet will pay tribute to Count Basie on his 79th birthday. Admission to the concert for the legendary band leader is free.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''I don't know how to play, but everyone's tired of being poor.''

title: Baxter Travenol Names Chairman
description: In an apparent gesture of conciliation, Baxter Travenol Laboratories, which is acquiring the American Hospital Supply Corporation, announced yesterday that Karl D. Bays, American's chairman and chief executive officer, would become chairman of Baxter's board and the board's executive committee.

title: HELP FOR AIDS PATIENTS PLANNED BY ARCHDIOCESE
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York said yesterday that it was organizing a ''comprehensive plan for the study and care of AIDS patients'' and that as part of the plan it would open a shelter for patients in a vacant convent in Manhattan.

title: SALEM NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
JUDGE LIMITS PLAINTIFF CLASS IN NASSAU G.O.P. SUIT
description: The claims by Nassau County employees who charge they were forced to contribute to the Republican Party to get raises and promotions were limited to a three-and-a-half-year period today by a Federal judge.

title: BOSTON FIVE CENTS SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $411,000.

title: COURT CASES REVEAL NEW INEQUALITIES IN WOMEN'S PAY
description: Congress outlawed the most blatant forms of employment discrimination against women more than 20 years ago, but Federal judges and other Government officials report that employers have found new, more subtle ways to justify paying women less than men. Courts have accepted some of the justifications and rejected others, depending on the facts of each case.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
TO BOTHA'S RIGHT, RATTLING OF SWORDS
description: The tones are sonorous and seem reasoned and the message is this: The revolution is coming, and the blacks will try to take all, and the whites will fight back for the land that is theirs. And they will win.

title: STARRETT, L S CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
New York Agency Bonds
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is offering $295 million of bonds to finance prison construction with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9.22 percent for bonds due in 2016, underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company said yesterday.

title: Engineers' Corps Rejects a Mall
description: The Army Corp of Engineers said today that it had denied a developer's application to build a shopping mall in North Haven that had been contested for nine years by the city of New Haven.

title: Fighting in Western Sahara
description: Polisario guerrillas fighting Morocco for the independence of Western Sahara said today that they had killed 270 Moroccan soldiers near the border between Algeria and the disputed territory. A communique carried by the official Algerian press agency said the fighting occurred Monday in the Mahbes area.

title: ANAREN MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SMITHFIELD FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: STORMS SAID TO KNOCK OUT ALARMS FOR WIND SHIFT AT DETROIT AIRPORT
description: The alarms for abrupt wind shifts at Metro Airport in Detroit have been knocked out five times in four months by thunderstorms, aviation experts have reported.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''LOOK Ma, no cavities'' is becoming a lasting truth for millions of American youngsters. Thanks to a variety of decay-preventing advances in recent decades, today more than half the nation's 9-year-olds are cavity free and the University of Minnesota can operate a No-Cavity Clinic that delivers what it promises: ''Give us a child without cavities who follows our program and we can keep him cavity free indefinitely,'' says Dr. Michael Till, who defied skeptics in starting the clinic three years ago.

title: CARDS' NIGHTMARE: 17-2 LOSS TO ASTROS
description: Mark Bailey hit his second grand slam of the season, and Dickie Thon drove in four runs with a triple and home run to highlight a 19-hit attack that lifted the Houston Astros to a 17-2 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

title: STEWART JURORS HEAR TESTIMONY ON CHOKE HOLDS
description: Transit police officers are not taught choke holds and are ''discouraged'' from using that method of restraint because it ''could kill a person,'' according to grand jury testimony read to the jury in the Michael Stewart case yesterday.

title: A Talmadge Comeback?
description: Former Senator Herman E. Talmadge, who was narrowly defeated for re-election in 1980 after having been ''denounced'' by the Senate for financial misconduct, appears to be thinking about trying to recapture his old seat next year. From Georgia comes word that William Hamilton & Associates is conducting a statewide poll on voter reaction to the possibility that the 72-year-old Democrat might challenge Senator Mack Mattingly, the Republican who forced his retirement. Mr. Talmadge became Governor of Georgia in 1948 and moved to the Senate in 1955. In addition to the 1979 condemnation by his colleagues, factors contributing to his defeat included a widely publicized divorce, a bitter Democratic primary campaign and problems of alcoholism, now said to have been resolved.

title: KINCAID FURNITURE CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
Bride Stayed Home
description: When Barbaro Garbey, the Detroit infielder, flew out of Detroit on Monday just hours after his marriage to Kim Grutza, it had all the makings of a high-spirited honeymoon flight, or almost all anyway. In addition to Garbey, the celebration flight carried 15 Tiger teammates who had attended the ceremony in suburban Bloomfield Hills as well as the rest of the Detroit team.

title: PRESENT CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 21, 1985
description: International

title: ONCE-GREAT TURKISH CITY WORRIES ABOUT FISH
description: Fish and football are the pride and worry of what was once the fabled city of Trebizond, seat of the last Byzantine empire to fall to the Turkish conquest.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: ESPECIALLY in midsummer, I like to browse through markets imagining which foods would blend best with one another. Recently, I was in the mood to serve guests a seafood salad as a light lunch out of doors.

title: PUTTING RECIPES TO PAPER: A MINEFIELD OF VERBAL VEXATIONS
description: THE writing of recipes may seem a minor exercise of linguistic ability, but as anyone who has tried it will attest, it is a minefield of verbal vexations. Not only must food writers have a scientist's orderliness of thought, a lawyer's knack for giving directions that cannot be misconstrued and a teacher's grasp of the darkness of uninstructed minds, they also need the patience of a saint and the prudence of a sage. The very words in which recipes are written constantly threaten to get out of hand.

title: PROSECUTOR FOR NEW ORLEANS FACES TOUGH LEGAL CHALLENGE
description: In his younger days, before he became United States Attorney in New Orleans, John Volz had a difference of opinion with his flamboyant boss, District Attorney Jim Garrison, who was convinced that there was a conspiracy in the assassination of President Kennedy.

title: INJURIES CHANGE GIANTS' PLANS
description: In what has been a mild summer for injuries, luck may be running out on the Giants. First, their place-kicker, Ali Haji-Sheikh, went down over the weekend, and then late Monday afternoon Kenny Hill suffered a sprained left hamstring that will keep the backup safety out for about two weeks.

title: PERRY DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DRUG PROBLEM SEEN AS EASING
description: Three people involved in fighting drug abuse in baseball said today that the problem, although still serious, was on the decline.

title: HME FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN (MERIDIAN) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HEBRON SQUATTERS EVICTED BY ARMY
description: The Israeli Army today evicted a group of members of Parliament from an apartment in Hebron that they had occupied since Thursday. The legislators said they were there to establish the right of Jews to settle wherever they wanted in the West Bank.

title: VOTE BY COMPUTER: SOME SEE PROBLEMS
description: When the great political bosses of the past set out to steal an election, they would order their ward heelers to vote the cemetery. Often, historians say, the bosses were successful.

title: BRIDGE: VICTORS IN KNOCKOUT TEAMS SURVIVE FIRST-ROUND 'LOSS'
description: The bye round, in which some players twiddle their thumbs while others are fighting at the card table, is always an unsatisfactory method of organizing a knockout team event. It has been generally abandoned, but the alternative, involving three-way matches, cannot be used for a small number of teams.

title: Deere's Net Down 85%
description: Deere & Company reported today that its net income in the third quarter, ended July 31, plunged nearly 85 percent, to $4.5 million, or 6 cents a share, from $29.4 million, or 43 cents a share, a year ago. Sales of $1.02 billion for the quarter were off slightly from $1.04 billion in the period a year ago.

title: HOME DEPOT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
9 Die in Ethiopia Floods
description: Floods in Ethiopia's grain-growing Rift Valley region have killed nine peasants and left 8,000 homeless in the last few days, a Government spokesman said today. The spokesman, Berhane Deressa, deputy head of the Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, said it was too early to assess the full damage to the region.

title: ISRAELI ENVOY KILLED BY GUNMEN IN CAIRO SUBURB
description: An Israeli diplomat was killed and two embassy employees wounded in a Cairo suburb today when three men sprayed their car with submachine-gun fire.

title: HODGSON HOUSES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is listed on the Boston Stock Exchange.

title: AFGHAN FIGHTING IS REPORTED
description: Soviet troops have mounted what appears to be a major offensive against Afghan rebels in southeast Afghanistan, and heavy fighting has already taken place, Western diplomats and guerrilla sources said today.

title: FALWELL DENOUNCES TUTU AS A 'PHONY'
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell called Bishop Desmond M. Tutu a phony today and began a campaign to block imposition of economic sanctions against South Africa. The step came amid growing evidence that American conservatives were deeply divided on the issue.

title: William McMurren, 57, Dies; Head of Morrison Knudsen
description: William H. McMurren, an engineer who was chairman of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation, died Monday in Boise, Idaho. He was 57 years old and lived in Boise, the headquarters of the construction concern.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a net writedown of $88,075,000 for the quarter and the 6 months related to excess facilities mainly in the energy related construction oil and gas services business.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
South Africa Does More Than Detain Dissidents
description: To the Editor:

title: A BRITISH INVASION OF CAPITAL MARKETS
description: The British are coming to Wall Street. Aiming to emulate American brokerages and commercial banks that are firmly entrenched in the London financial market, merchant banks from Britain are scrambling to expand into the New York capital market.

title: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an unusual gain in the first quarter of $6,600,000, or 14 cents a share, on the sale of the boston store division.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: MODERATE SIKH IN SHADOW OF MILITANTS
description: Harchand Singh Longowal, who was assassinated in Punjab yesterday, was a moderate leader of the Sikh political party, Akali Dal, who signed an accord with the Government last month.

title: VERIT INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $475,000. c-Net income including net from discontinued operations of $74,000. Year-ago results have been restated for discontinued operations.

title: RAYMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: ALLIED STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: b-Including a gain of $1.11 a share for the quarter and the 6 months on the sale of a leashold interest in a shopping center and a onetime charge of 29 cents a share for the quarter and the 6 months for the consolidation of operating divisions and store closings. Results include provisions for LIFO of $1,500,000 for the latest 6 months and $1,800,000 and $3,300,000 for the year-ago quarter and 6 months respectively.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Shift at Bloomingdale's Michel Guerard is leaving Bloomingdale's. The French chef's food shop, which has been at the 59th Street store for three years, will be replaced by Gerard's Haute Cuisine.

title: JAPAN JET WAS CARRYING RADIOACTIVE MATERIAL
description: The Japan Air Lines airliner that crashed on Aug. 12 was carrying 61 packages of radioactive materials manufactured in the United States for medical research and diagnosis in Japan, according to the New England Nuclear Corporation, a subsidiary of Du Pont based here.

title: A.T.&T. Tax Ruling Case
description: The United States Tax Court has been asked to decide whether some of the shares A.T.&T.'s stockholders received when the Bell System was broken up were actually a third of a billion dollars in taxable dividends.

title: DECORATING FOR CAKES
description: DECORATING cakes is a specialized task that takes professional pastry cooks years of practice to master. The professionals use pastry bags with nozzles that give them the flexibility to make elaborate designs. Home cooks are not usually concerned with the fine points of forming complicated patterns, however.

title: Bumper Cocaine Crop Seen as Coming to U.S.
description: Tons of good quality, cheap cocaine is on its way to the United States, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Manhattan, said today after a 16-day trip to South America that he called an ''eye-opener.''

title: WEBCOR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Yr to March 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's edition.

title: ASPIN THREATENS TO SNARL BILL ON ARMS OVER MX DISPUTE
description: Representative Les Aspin, the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has threatened to hold up legislation authorizing next year's military programs unless the Reagan Administration commits itself to a permanent limit on the MX intercontinental missile.

title: ELRON ELECTRONIC INDUSRIES LTD (ISRAEL)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: News Distributor Bought by Nehoc
description: The Metropolitan News Company, primary distributor of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and other newspapers to newsdealers in New York City, was acquired yesterday by the Nehoc Company, a holding company formed by Robert B. Cohen, principal owner of the Hudson County News Company. Terms were not disclosed.

title: DEL-VAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
G. Heileman's Brewery Plans
description: The G. Heileman Brewing Company said yesterday that it planned to build a new brewery in Milwaukee in a bid to lure import beer drinkers.

title: Gen. R. W. Hasbrouck, Officer in World War II
description: Maj. Gen. Robert W. Hasbrouck, commander of the United States Seventh Armored Division in Europe in World War II, died Monday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: Police Seize Suspect in Rash Of Holdups at Supermarkets
description: A man suspected of holding up two Upper East Side supermarkets with a shotgun yesterday morning and fleeing in a stolen Porsche with license plates that read ''THE IT'' was arrested later while driving the car in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: GOLDEN WEST HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to May 25
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $426,000 for the quarter and $1,534,000 for the year and provisions for losses on the disposition of discontinued operations of $702,000 for the quarter and $1,015,000 for the year. c-Including tax credits of $212,000 for the quarter and $651,000 for the year and losses from discontinued operations of $93,000 for the quarter and $101,000 for the year.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 1
Books: Those Who Brought Great Music to Life
description: THE GLORIOUS ONES: Classical Music's Legendary Performers. By Harold C. Schonberg. 510 pages. Times Books. $24.95. FOR over 30 years Harold C. Schonberg, the author of ''The Glorious Ones,'' was either music critic or senior music critic for The New York Times, and during all those years artists and impresarios alike, while anxious and even a little fearful of what he might say, knew they were dealing with a man of intelligence and enormous passion, a skilled reporter who said exactly what he pleased with a firm, unfoolish style and always with a deep commitment to music.

title: TOTAL ASSETS PETROLEUM (NORTH AMERICAN) LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Interest Rates Turn Down
description: Interest rates for short- and long-term debt securities fell slightly yesterday, reflecting continued hopes that a weak economy will soon lead to further rate declines.

title: FOR A 'FLAGLADY,' ROAD WORK HAS ITS WOES
description: Sometimes they run you down and sometimes they ask you out. So it goes in the life of a flagperson on a summer road-construction project, according to Yvonne, the self-described flaglady of First Avenue.

DAYTON-HUDSON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: b-After a charge of 6 cents a share from repositioning of operations. Results for the latest periods reflect charges for LIFO provisions equal to 3 cents a share for the quarter and 9 cents a share for the 6 months. Year- ago results reflect charges for LIFO provisions equal to 2 cents a share for the quarter and 8 cents a share for the 6 months.

title: Baltimore Votes to Withdraw Funds Used in South Africa
description: The Baltimore City Council has approved a measure asking the trustees of the city's pension funds to end all investments in companies that do business with South Africa.

title: Fruits of a Cartel
description: Sunkist, the citrus cooperative, calls the idea ''democratic self-determination.'' Consumers Union, conservative thinkers and a surprising number of fruit growers give it a different, more accurate label: a Government-enforced cartel.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Larry Keating, athletic director at Adelphi University for six years, was named to the same spot at Seton Hall. The 41-year-old Keating replaces Richard Regan, who was named to the executive board of the school's athletic fund. . . . Nick Vanos, a 7-foot-2-inch center who starred for Santa Clara last season, signed a contract with the Phoenix Suns that will reportedly bring him $1 million over five years. Vanos, who averaged 16.8 points and was 11th among collegians with an average of 10.8 rebounds last season, was a second-round draft pick and the 32d player taken over all. . . . Two high-ranking tennis professionals, Aaron Krickstein and Eliot Teltscher, have withdrawn from the United States Open because of injuries.

title: ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION AND AIDS LINK TESTED
description: Research has begun in Boston and San Francisco to determine whether artificial insemination could cause acquired immune deficiency syndrome in a woman if the sperm donor was carrying the virus.

title: SCHOOLS IN DETROIT CITED ON ASBESTOS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed fining the Detroit Public Schools $434,500, the largest penalty the agency has sought against any school district for violations of regulations on asbestos in schools.

title: Free Music and Dance Aboard the S.I. Ferry
description: For the price of a ride on the Staten Island ferry, performances of music and dance can be enjoyed next month. Beginning Sept. 6 and continuing every weekend through the month, free music and dance will be offered aboard the ferry on trips to and from Staten Island.

title: Mets Get Bowa To Help Infield
description: The Mets filled one of the most threatening holes in their defense with one of the most experienced gloves in baseball yesterday when they signed Larry Bowa as a reserve shortstop for the remainder of the season.

title: Modern Heroes
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: France Adopts Election Law For New Caledonia in Pacific
description: The National Assembly today passed a law regulating elections in New Caledonia and giving native Melanesians a majority in the territorial assembly although they are a minority of the population.

title: Famine Relief Funds Are Being Spent Prudently
description: To the Editor:

title: WHITE HOUSE MESSAGE ON ANTI-SATELLITE ARMS
description: Following is the text of a White House statement on anti-satellite weapons, as issued here today:

description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: DEB SHOPS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a special loss on investments of $298,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and the 6 months. Share earnings reflect a 50 percent stock dividend paid July 1, 1985.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: THERE are hotels with which I identify to a degree that may well be aberrational.

title: Letter: On Energy Conservation;   An Oil-Import Fee Is Bad Public Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: REVLON'S NEW ALLURING LOOK
description: After several years of lackluster earnings, Revlon Inc., a company famous for making women look more glamorous, is beginning to look more alluring itself. So much so that it is having to fight off a hostile suitor that has recognized something other investors had not: The cosmetics and health care giant is worth far more than the stock market was reflecting. As recently as a month ago, Revlon's shares were trading at $42.50, giving them a total market value of $1.6 billion.

title: Jury Shown Videotape In Trial of F.B.I. Agent
description: Jurors in the trial of Richard W. Miller, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, began their third week by watching a videotape of Mr. Miller carrying a legal-size envelope to the auto of Svetlana Ogorodnikov last September in what prosecutors today asserted was a spying tryst.

title: REPORT TERMS FLAWS MINOR IN 63D ST. TUNNEL
description: A consulting company hired by the Transit Authority to inspect the 63d Street subway tunnel has concluded in a preliminary report that the structure has no major flaws.

title: Developer Expects a Permit For Ferry Service to Jersey
description: The Koch administration is expected to issue a permit soon for a Weehawken-to-Manhattan passenger ferry, according to a New Jersey developer.

title: RICHTON INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TENNIS LADY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: PAUL HARRIS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
A DIFFERENT KIND OF CHINA SYNDROME
description: If Congress lets it go through, the Chinese will soon be able to act on President Reagan's agreement allowing them to buy American nuclear reactors for electric power. Some may ask whether we should be making nuclear reactors available to China. But the more interesting question is why on earth the Chinese would want to buy them from a country that has made such a singular botch of its own nuclear power program.

title: Test Sought for Diabetes Risk
description: Screening tests that pinpoint telltale antibodies in the blood could help identify an estimated one million Americans who risk getting diabetes, perhaps in time to prevent the disease, researchers say.

title: So Let Them All Eat Hoboken Bread
description: On Aug. 9 an article on the Washington Talk page told the story of thick, chewy bread with a crunchy crust that was shipped here each week from A & B Bakery in Hoboken, N.J., and avidly consumed by Washingtonians.

title: BROWN-FORMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect the repurchase of about 15 percent of the company's common stock over an 11 month period that began in June 1984.

title: New El Salvador Inquiry In Killing of Archbishop
description: A Salvadoran court has ordered the reopening of an investigation into the killing of Archbishop Oscar Arnulfo Romero of San Salvador, who was killed by a sniper five years ago, a spokesman for the Attorney General's office said today.

title: A Yen to Write
description: Perhaps mindful that the public's taste for political tracts has certain limits, politicians seem to be turning to the more popular literary form of the novel.

title: CARDIOSEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
INFORMATION INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $15,998 for the latest first quarter and $18,129 for the year- ago first quarter.

title: TOON OF JETS GOES FROM FIRST TO LAST
description: The Houston Oilers signed one of their first-round draft choices yesterday, Richard Johnson, a cornerback from Wisconsin, and were on the verge of signing the other, Ray Childress, a defensive end from Texas A&M.

title: NEW WAYS TO STOP A CORPORATE RAIDER
description: Corporate takeover defenses are becoming shrewder and more sophisticated by the day. First there was the ''poison pill,'' a tactic that corporate boards of directors adopted to make it prohibitively expensive for a would-be raider to acquire control. Lately , several corporations have cooked up another way to fend off hostile bidders - they offer existing shareholders a sweet deal but exclude the predators from the party.

title: HOSPITAL CHIEF QUIT IN INQUIRY ON INVESTMENT
description: The investigation that led to the resignation of John J. McLaughlin as president of the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation last week was prompted by a criminal complaint filed by one of his investment partners, associates of Mr. McLaughlin said yesterday.

title: Games Bailed Out
description: The first Masters Games, a sort of Olympics for the not-so-young that has drawn 8,000 older athletes from 60 nations to Toronto for competition in 22 sports, has been saved from financial disaster by a $222 million grant from the Canadian and Ontario Governments. ''We had to do it to make sure the athletes who had trained and prepared could continue to compete,'' said Otto Jellinek, the Federal Minister of Fitness and Amateur Sport, who explained that the games, scheduled to end Sunday, could not have been completed without the grant.

title: Check Inquiry Clears I.R.S.
description: An investigation by an Internal Revenue Service inspector has found no evidence to support charges that the agency systematically false-dated refund checks to avoid interest payments.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Livingston Miller has joined the Marschalk Company as senior vice president, associate creative director.

title: NEW HOSPITAL WARDS FOR CHILDREN OFFER LIVELY DESIGN, MORE FREEDOM
description: A TODDLER pokes her hands into a sandbox, oblivious to the noisy enthusiasm of two small boys engrossed in an air hockey game. Another child crawls around an indoor slide, while a young mother sings Spanish lullabies to her sleeping baby.

title: Irrefutable Logic
description: Archie Cooley, who has built a wildly explosive offense as the football coach at Mississippi Valley State, tells why his former job as a Tennessee State defensive coach is responsible: ''I used to go home and draw X's and O's, and see what I'd do to stop it. Then I came up with something I couldn't stop.''

title: FILIPINOS PROTEST TO MARK THE AQUINO SLAYING
description: The second anniversary of the slaying of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was marked today in anti-Government demonstrations across the Philippines.

title: EAC INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest periods include the operations of Frantz Manufacturing Co. consolidated as a subsidiary as of May 1.

title: MATERIALS RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
Coercion Denied In G.O.P. Trial
description: The Nassau County Commissioner of Drug and Alcohol Addiction testified in Federal District Court today that he had never required the 250 workers in his department to contribute to the Republican Party.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * AM General Corp., Detroit, has been awarded a $44.7 million contract for 2,381 utility trucks for cargo and troops, the Army said.

title: 42 SLAIN IN BEIRUT IN HEAVY SHELLING
description: At least 42 more people were reported killed over the last 24 hours today as Christian and Moslem gunners bombarded Beirut's residential districts and the airport with artillery, rocket and tank fire.

title: BUSINESS GROUPS RESIST CHANGES IN TAX PLAN
description: Business backers of President Reagan's tax revision plan are warning that their support will collapse if Congressional tax writers bargain away the reductions in corporate and individual tax rates contained in the plan.

title: What's Constructive in South Africa?
description: As South Africa crackles with violence, American debate over the impending tragedy seems somehow lost in last year's headlines. The Rev. Jerry Falwell of the Moral Majority rushes to speak on behalf of an amoral minority, proffering indecencies to comfort the oppressors in the name of anti-Communism. People deeply offended by apartheid remain locked in stale argument about feeble economic sanctions.

title: Great Western Suit
description: The Great Western Financial Corporation, parent of the nation's third-largest savings and loan organization, has filed suit against the Citadel Holding Corporation over an apparently aborted $109 million takeover of Citadel. The suit also names Alfred Roven, who headed a group of dissident shareholders opposed to the merger and eventually got Citadel to name him and two associates to Citadel's board.

title: SOVIET SAYS TESTING BY THE U.S. IN SPACE RENEWS ARMS RACE
description: The Soviet press said today that the American decision to go ahead with the test of an anti-satellite weapon marked the start of an arms race in space.

title: PHIBRO TO PULL OUT OF SOUTH AFRICA
description: Phibro-Salomon, the financial conglomerate that trades everything from bonds to gold, said yesterday that it would end its operations in South Africa and close its Johannesburg office.

title: Hazardous-Waste Proposal
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed on Tuesday to ease or possibly eliminate insurance requirements for operators of hazardous-waste dumps. The proposal would apply only in the 11 states that have chosen direct Federal regulation of hazardous-waste disposal. The states are Alabama, California, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, New York, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Wisconsin and Wyoming.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: POURING a concrete walk, path or moderate-size terrace can safely be tackled by any reasonably handy homeowner willing to work hard. It is not especially difficult, and only a few inexpensive tools are required. Considerable savings can result.

title: Dalton Returns
description: Georgetown's Ralph Dalton, the backup to Patrick Ewing for three seasons, will return to the team for the 1985-86 season although he was graduated in May. Dalton has a year of eligibility left because he missed his freshman season due to a leg injury.

title: VALSPAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Rsults from the latest quarter and nine months include results of the company's mobile coatings business acquired in August of 1984.

title: Nortek, Transway
description: The Transway International Corporation said it had received an unsolicited offer to be acquired by Nortek Inc. for $40 a share, or about $265 million.

title: FOR A MALL, BOTH PRAISE AND GRIPES
description: It had been dubbed the ''$100 million shopping center'' and the opening of the Galleria mall here five years ago this month was marked with the kind of pomp usually reserved for heads of state.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHINESE MARTIAL ARTS Wushu is a national cultural sport in China. It is seldom seen here, but in ''Wushu: Chinese Martial Arts,'' a troupe of 21 title winners and Wushu stars will perform tonight at Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue. Wushu combines gymnastics, acrobatics and ancient Chinese fighting styles.

title: A Priest Pleads No Contest To Eight Sex-Related Counts
description: The Rev. P. Henry Leech, a Roman Catholic priest accused of having sex with children, pleaded no contest to eight counts, and prosecutors said Tuesday that they want him to go to jail.

title: Texas Water Bond Yields Set
description: An $80 million issue of Texas water development bonds was offered yesterday with yields ranging from 6.20 percent for bonds due in 1988 to 7.1 percent in 1990, 8.15 percent in 2995, 8.80 percent in 2000 and 9.05 percent in 2005 through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: KEY ENERGY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Stocks Rise Again; Dow Adds 5.83
description: Stock prices, aided by strength from secondary issues, ended moderately higher yesterday after Tuesday's strong advance.

title: 24,000 A.T.&T. JOBS TO BE ELIMINATED FROM SYSTEMS UNIT
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 24,000 jobs in a sweeping cutback at its big information systems division.

title: TIME RUNS OUT FOR DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA PROPOSAL
description: The death knell sounds Thursday for a proposed constitutional amendment that would have given residents of the District of Columbia the same voting rights in Congress as other citizens of the United States.

title: LOWE'S COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FIRSTSOUTH SA reports earnings for Yr to June 30
FURNITURE ARTFULLY CRAFTED BY HAND
description: AN exhibition in East Hampton, L.I., of the work of two furniture craftsmen is off the beaten path, both literally and figuratively. The Pritam & Eames gallery may be only a few blocks away from the food and clothing boutiques that line Main Street, but this display of desks, tables and chairs of Jere Osgood and Thomas Hucker is light-years away from trendy, mass-produced furniture.

title: Clashes in South-West Africa
description: South African-led troops have killed 14 guerrillas in clashes in South-West Africa during the last 13 days, a communique issued here said today. The security forces suffered no losses, it said, adding that the new casualties brought to 482 the number of guerrillas from the South-West Africa People's Organization who have been killed since the start of the year. The organization has been fighting to end South African rule of the disputed territory and establish an independent country known as Namibia.

title: Bridge: New Martin Hoffman Book Offers Advice for Defenders
description: The relative importance of bidding, play and defense is a matter that can be argued at length.

title: Market Place;   Tax-Exempt Trusts Flourish
description: WHATEVER uncertainties may exist in the securities markets, many people continue to buy tax-exempt unit investment trusts at a record clip. ''Tax-exempt trust volume totaled $9 billion for the first seven months of 1985,'' according to John Nuveen & Company. ''This compared with $8.8 billion in the same period last year.''

title: Military Plane Returns Without Congressman
description: A military plane dispatched to Brazil last week with one Congressman aboard has returned to the United States, leaving the lawmaker and his daughter in Honduras for a private vacation.

title: GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1,200,000. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $748,000.

title: SHORT INTEREST ON BIG BOARD OFF 2.8 MILLION SHARES
description: The following Big Board companies show large changes:

title: REAL-ESTATE SURGE IMPERILS SMALL DANCE STUDIOS
description: The New York School of Ballet will close its doors after the 6:30 P.M. class tomorrow. The school, one of the leading ballet training institutions in the city, has until Aug. 31 to vacate premises into which it moved in 1969 at the invitation of George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein.

title: CORPORATION FOR ENTERTAINMENT & LEARNING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: A Matter of Air Bags
description: In the past five months, 12 cars owned by the Government have been in moderate-speed crashes and the drivers have walked away with no injuries or, at worst, minor scrapes and bruises.

title: A Setback
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Century 21's President Pleased by Takeover
description: The company he leads has been sold, but Richard J. Loughlin, president and chief executive of the Century 21 Real Estate Corporation, said yesterday that he was not concerned or offended that he was not informed of the price it fetched.

title: A Treaty That Would Belie U.S. Neutrality on Northern Ireland
description: To the Editor:

title: Lure of the Classroom
description: As president of the New York Public Library, Dr. Vartan Gregorian trades in ideas. Beginning Sept. 30, he will teach a course in the history of ideas at the New School.

title: Taiwan Official Named
description: The Government said today that Robert Chien, 57 years old, had been nominated as Finance Minister named to replace Lu Jen-kang, who resigned following charges of unethical business practices at the Cathay Industrial Group, one of the nation's biggest industries.

title: MASTERS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including the recovery of a doubtful account receivable of $600,000.

title: Vital Options Missing in a Land of Options
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-ASSOCIATES OF SAN DIEGO MAYOR OPEN TESTIMONY FOR PROSECUTION
description: A former aide to Mayor Roger Hedgecock of San Diego and his former stockbroker were the first witnesses today in the retrial of Mr. Hedgecock on charges of campaign-fund felonies.

title: CONSUMER COMPLAINTS
description: Comedians like to joke about unscrupulous used-car salesmen, but a new study shows that they generate fewer consumer complaints than home-furnishings stores, dry cleaners or department stores, among others.

title: CHIEF PROSECUTOR OUSTED IN ALASKA
description: The chief state prosecutor, who was instrumental in bringing impeachment proceedings against Gov. Bill Sheffield, was dismissed today from the post he has held for 10 years.

title: MACNEAL-SCHWENDLER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After charges of $157,000 for the quarter and $263,000 for the 6 months from equity in losses of discontinued operations and a loss of $2,073,000 for the quarter and 6 months from the discontinuance of discontinued operations. c-Net income.

title: Pilots Back Frontier Plan
description: Members of the Air Line Pilots Association have joined flight attendants and transport workers in ratifying Frontier Airlines' proposed $400 million employee stock ownership plan entailing undisclosed wage and benefit concessions.

title: YANKEE BATTERS THRIVE IN WILD VICTORY
description: The evening was a long, seemingly endless struggle for the Yankees, who scored seven runs in the first two innings but then had to wait until the 10th inning to beat the California Angels, 13-10, tonight. The victory, their seventh straight and 14th in the last 15 games, moved them to within three games of Toronto in the American League East.

title: Ethics on Line
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: EMULEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
PITTOCK FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses.

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Parental Boycotts
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Another View
description: Chili Davis of San Francisco, who defied Gooden's mastery with three hits Tuesday night, explains why he has little patience for the endless talk of immortality: ''He ain't God, man.''

title: The Ballot Message - and Mess
description: New York's primary election campaign could well be decided by court fights over election rules. After the Board of Elections threw Herman D. Farrell off the ballot for mayor, a judge reinstated him. Then another threw him off again, along with four of the six candidates for City Council president. More court decisions are certain. With the candidates constantly in flux, the sure losers are the voters.

title: WITNESS SAYS OFFICER USED A CHOKE HOLD ON STEWART'S NECK
description: A prosecution witness told a jury yesterday that a transit police officer had applied a choke hold to Michael Stewart's neck with a nightstick.

title: 26 INDICTED ON CHARGE OF RUNNING ORGANIZED-CRIME GROUP IN JERSEY
description: Twenty-six people were accused today of running the New Jersey branch of an organized-crime group, officials said.

title: School Principal Slain in Jersey
description: A Philadelphia high school principal was shot and killed today in what appeared to be a marital dispute, authorities said.

title: T.V.A. CITING SAFETY, TO SHUT DOWN NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority, citing concern over key emergency safety equipment, announced today that it would shut down the Sequoyah Nuclear Plant indefinitely.

title: ECONOMICS LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
2 ROOKIES TO START AS JETS CORNERBACKS
description: Bud Carson came close to sighing today as he contemplated the rookies lined up at the Jets' two cornerback spots. In his highly regarded career as a defensive coordinator, rookies have rarely started for him.

title: Agency in Georgia
description: The Cobb County Marietta Water Authority, in Georgia, is offering $63.1 million of water revenue refunding bonds with a maximum yield tentatively set at 9.33 percent for bonds due in 2005 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The financing includes bonds yielding from 5 percent in 1986 to 7 percent in 1990, 8 1/4 percent in 1995, 9 percent in 2000 and 9.10 percent in 2001. The bonds are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

title: ETHICS ON LINE
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: FIREFIGHTERS STIR DEBATE ON SAFETY OF PLASTICS
description: Firefighters and the plastics industry traded charges today in a debate over the safety of plastics in fires.

title: Rosalind Newman Troupe
description: New dances by Rosalind Newman, set to music by Vivaldi, Buddy Holly and others, will be presented by the choreographer's dance troupe Sept. 25 to 29 at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street. The performances mark the opening of the theater's dance season and the 10th anniversary of the dance company.

title: JAMES RIVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
BACKING PRETORIA DIVESTITURE BILL SAID TO HELP KEAN IN CAMPAIGN
description: Political supporters and opponents of Governor Kean said today that his decision to sign a South Africa divestiture bill would probably eliminate what might have been a troubling issue in his re-election campaign this year.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
New Approach Rejected In Effort to Save Farm
description: The Iowa Supreme Court today rejected an effort by a farm couple to head off foreclosure by placing a lien against their property based on the value of the work they put into the land.

title: MILITARY REPORTEDLY OPPOSED USE OF U.S. MARINES IN BEIRUT
description: The Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff told a House committee investigating the 1983 truck-bombing of the Marine garrison at the Beirut airport that the military chiefs had unanimously advised President Reagan against deploying marines in Lebanon in the first place, according to a committee member.

title: NEW ZEALAND LINKS GREENPEACE ATTACK TO A FRENCH OFFICER
description: The New Zealand police said today that a woman charged with bombing the Rainbow Warrior, flagship of the environmentalist group Greenpeace, was a captain in the French Army.

title: Religious Group Begins $103 Million Financing
description: The Sisters of Providence, a religious congregation that operates 13 hospitals in 4 states, has started a major financing program this week with a $103 million issue of hospital revenue bonds for a hosptial in Anchorage.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS SOUTH AFRICANS IN VIENNA OFFERED POWER-SHARING
description: South African officials told high-ranking Reagan aides at a meeting in Vienna that the Government was prepared to make political changes that were more significant than steps ultimately announced by Pretoria, a senior Administration official says.

title: Richard Yardumian, Composer, Dies at 68
description: Richard Yardumian, a modern classical composer, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his home in Bryn Athyn, Pa. He was 68 years old.

title: Tunisia Expels 30 More Libyans
description: Tunisia today expelled 30 more Libyan diplomats, raising the number of Libyans ordered out of the country in the last two days to 283.

title: Baseball;   EXPOS NOT OUT OF IT, HERZOG CAUTIONS
description: Report from the enemy camp: Whitey Herzog picked up the telephone in Houston the other day, and said it was a three-way race in the National League's East, not just a two-way race between the Mets and his St. Louis Cardinals.

title: REXNORD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary credit of $1,621,000 for the year-ago nine months.

title: AFTER YEARS OF TURMOIL, JUDGE IS YIELDING JOB OF INTEGRATING BOSTON SCHOOLS
description: The Boston school desegregation case, which brought mob violence and an image of bigotry to the city that calls itself the cradle of American freedom, is ending.

title: Abortion Center Is Suing 13 Under Antiracketeering Law
description: An abortion clinic whose equipment was damaged in protests filed suit Tuesday against 13 antiabortion activists under a United States racketeering law, charging they conspired to close the clinic.

title: McEnroe, Lloyd at No. 1
description: John McEnroe and Chris Evert Lloyd yesterday were named the top-seeded players for the men's and women's division of the United States Open tennis championships, and no one has ever received that distinction more often.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Francisco Giants, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Sid Fernandez, who has won his last two starts and possesses a better strikeouts-to-innings pitched ratio than Dwight Gooden this season, will pitch for the Mets in the final game of the three-game series. (Television -SportsChannel 7:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. California Angels, at Anaheim, 10:35 P.M. Ron Guidry will try for his 17th victory. (Television - SportsChannel 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:30 P.M.) Chicago Cubs vs. Braves, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS 7:35 P.M.) Little League World Series, at Williamsport, Pa., through Saturday. Golf Walker Cup Matches, at Pine Valley N.J. Scott Verplank, the Western Open Champion and the first amateur to win a professional tour event since 1956, will compete for the United States against a team of Irish and British golfers. Second of two days. #70th Met Open Championships, at Mountain Ridge Country Club, West Caldwell, N.J. Final round of three-day tournament. NEC World Series of Golf, at Firestone Country Club in Akron, Ohio. Dennis Watson, who won the 1984 Series with a nine-under-par 271, will defend his title. L.P.G.A. National Pro-Am, at Lone Tree Country Club and Meridian Golf Club in Denver. Amy Alcott, the winner of last week's L.P.G.A. Nestle World Championship, and Muffin Spencer-Devlin, who won the MasterCard International Pro-Am last week, are scheduled to compete. Betsy King will defend her title. Other Events HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. TENNIS: Executone Hamlet Challenge Cup at Jericho, L.I., through Sunday.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $386,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Place Roger Clemens, pitcher, on 15-day disabled list.

title: ONLY THING TO FEAR
description: Does Ronald Reagan have a political philosophy?

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DEMOCRATIC BALLOT FIGHTS HAVE COURTS IN DISPUTE
description: Until a few days ago, the only combatants in the upcoming citywide elections were the candidates themselves. Now, the antagonists have come to include judges as well.

title: Advertising;   Leo Burnett Is Chosen For Tropicana Account
description: The Beatrice Companies chose the Leo Burnett Company as its advertising agency for Tropicana citrus products.

title: Commonwealth Edison Offering
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company, the Chicago-based utility, is offering $400 million of notes and bonds today through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: Drug Use: Tigers' View
description: Jim Campbell, the Detroit Tigers' president, said the team has released at least one player because of extensive drug use and that some former or current Tiger players have used cocaine. But he said he believes that drug problems on his club have been fewer than on most major league teams.

title: EPIC SEEN HALTING ALL PAYMENTS
description: The financially troubled EPIC Holdings Ltd. - parent of the Community Savings and Loan Association of Bethesda, Md., which temporarily halted operations this week after a run by depositors - has notified most of its investors that it will cease making payments on all of its $1.4 billion in mortgages and mortgage-backed securities, Federal officials said today. If such action leads to a default, it would be one of the largest on record.

title: LANCE SUES U.S. ON BANK REPORT
description: Bert Lance has sued the Federal Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, accusing the agency of illegally making public a bank examiner's report critical of Mr. Lance.

title: Johnson Matthey
description: The British Petroleum Company said it sold its stake in Johnson Matthey P.L.C., amounting to 4.75 million shares, or about 3.6 percent of the total outstanding. The company bought the stake last October after the Bank of England stepped in to rescue its troubled banking subsidiary. B.P. held extensive talks with Johnson Matthey on a possible collaboration or merger. But B.P. was unable to obtain sufficient commercial information to go ahead with joint plans.

title: COLLINS FOODS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: THE VIEWS OF A PIONEER
description: The subject of drugs in baseball recently elicited a letter that discussed a related aspect of the problem. The letter was signed by a man named Johnson from New York.

title: Daily Express Bid Wins Clearance
description: A takeover bid for the Daily Express newspaper empire built by Lord Beaverbrook has received Government clearance.

title: 9 IN BOSTON CITED IN HOUSING GRAFT
description: Three city aides and six private developers and contractors have been charged with racketeering and conspiracy in what Federal officials said today was a plot to circumvent the city's housing code in the North End and the exclusive Back Bay area.

title: Make Simplification This Year's Goal
description: To the Editor:

title: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a capital gain of $70,680. c-Including a capital gain of $37,024. Year-ago results have been adjusted for the merger of North American National and Pan Western Corp. in August 1984.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: ATTORNEY PREDICTS PRESSER'S UNCLE WILL BE RELEASED TO AVOID RETRIAL
description: A lawyer for the uncle of Jackie L. Presser, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, predicted today that his client would be freed from prison next week because prosecutors have refused to disclose sensitive details about Mr. Presser.

title: RAPE CASE JUDGE CALLS RECANTATION 'IMPLAUSIBLE'
description: The judge who heard Cathleen Crowell Webb's original assertion that Gary Dotson raped her says her recantation of the charges was ''implausible.''

title: BATTLING DRUGS: APPROACHES VARY
description: No one knows the extent of cocaine use in baseball and there is no basic agreement among the commissioner, the owners and the players on the proper way to approach a solution to the problem.

title: Serious Subway Crime Is Reported Down 15%
description: Serious crimes on the city's subway system in the first half of this year declined by more than 15 percent from the same period last year, the Transit Police Department said yesterday.

title: 2 DEATHS TRACED TO BOTULISM
description: An elderly Queens couple died of botulism last week after eating a salted white fish called kapchonka, the city's Health Department said yesterday.

title: 700 Commodore Layoffs
description: Commodore International Ltd., the home computer manufacturer, announced yesterday the layoffs of 700 employees worldwide, or 15 percent of its work force, calling the action ''an ongoing streamlining of its business operations.''

title: Ex-Labor Secretary Held To Have Erred on Press
description: Former Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan improperly closed hearings on the cause of a Utah mining accident that killed 27 people, a Federal judge has ruled.

title: AUTO GROUP FIGHTS ANTI-THEFT PLAN
description: A proposed Transportation Department regulation designed to reduce automobile theft is being fought by a group of foreign-car importers who say their business could be crippled by the terms of the ruling. The importers, who make up much of the so-called gray market in luxury cars, are supported by the Justice Department.

title: Technology;   Computers That Reason
description: PERSONAL computer users will be able to benefit soon from the artificial intelligence products being created on more sophisticated and powerful computers now.

title: No Chance
description: The longest line in New York yesterday that did not end at a Lotto machine was probably the one on the sixth floor of the Gimbels store at Herald Square, where for two hours Gary Carter signed autographs and answered questions about his injured knee while a long line of fans snaked this way and that.

title: MAVERICK RESTAURANT reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AMERICANS HELP IN FRENCH RESTORATION
description: THIS summer, a group of southern Californians traveled to Ivry-le-Temple, a village of 581 inhabitants in the Oise region north of Paris, to present the Mayor with a check for the equivalent of $1,200. The money will be used to begin rebuilding the village's half-ruined church of Notre-Dame.

title: 4th Sentenced In Kickbacks
description: A Hughes Aircraft supervisor said to have headed a defense kickback scheme was sentenced Tuesday to two years in prison and a $10,000 fine, becoming the fourth Hughes employee sentenced in the plot.

title: Differences
description: They were no longer young. They were no longer able-bodied. But the men whose final haven was Sailors' Snug Harbor still had one thing in common with other seafarers: a life governed by shipboard rules.

title: CARDS WIN ON PORTER'S HOMER
description: The pinch-hitter Darrell Porter hit a three-run homer in the ninth inning to break a 4-4 tie and send the St. Louis Cardinals to a 7-4 victory over the Houston Astros tonight.

title: Mild Quake in Wyoming
description: An earthquake rattled northwest Wyoming and eastern Idaho today, dislodging some rocks in the Snake River Canyon but causing no injuries or damage, officials said. A police spokesman here said the quake felt ''like somebody shaking you to wake you up.''

title: WESTSIDE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
PRETORIA WARNS MRS. MANDELA ON VISITS TO HUSBAND
description: The South African authorities threatened tonight to curb the access of the black activist Winnie Mandela to her imprisoned husband, Nelson, a leader of the African National Congress, who is serving a life sentence in Pollsmoor prison outside Cape Town.

title: ANALOG DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: b-Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in April 1985.

title: CONCERT: RAMPAL AND FLUTE
