description: JEAN-PIERRE RAMPAL, ''the man with the golden flute,'' was one of the first classical artists to become a ''crossover'' star, but he has maintained the integrity of his first calling more consistently than some. He may churn out albums of worthless music (or of music whose worth has little to do with his talents and affinities), and he may not have kept his technique up to virtuoso pitch, but when he appears as a serious flutist he delivers the genuine article. The Mostly Mozart chamber music concert over which he presided Tuesday was an evening of pleasantry and galanterie, not exactly memorable, perhaps, but cherishable.

title: SMITH KNOCKS OUT COSTELLO FOR CROWN
description: Lonnie Smith is from Denver and is used to wide-open spaces. He saw plenty of them last night at the Garden as he captured the World Boxing Council's superlightweight championship by knocking out Billy Costello at 2 minutes 31 seconds of the eighth round.

title: ETHICS ON LINE
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BankAmerica Realty Investors, San Francisco, has named as a trustee C. Preston Butcher, regional partner, president and chief executive of Lincoln Property Co. N.C. Inc.

title: Rodgers in Marathon
description: Bill Rodgers, the four-time winner of the New York City Marathon who has been boycotting the event in recent years, has patched up his differences with the race director, Fred Lebow, and has entered the Oct. 27 race. The 37-year-old Rodgers, who won the New York race four straight years beginning in 1976, had a falling out with Lebow, reportedly over money. ''He felt he deserved more respect moneywise,'' said Lebow, who has been able to show Rodgers and other top marathoners more respect since New York City allowed him to offer big cash prizes.

title: EQUALITY AND PROGRESS
description: ''We have too much egalitarianism. It's hard to eliminate.'' Startling words to hear in a China that we have seen for so long as the apostle of an egalitarian society. And the words came not from an outsider but from a leading expounder of ideology in the People's Republic.

title: Playing Dirty
description: The balls and the tennis shoes will not look quite so squeaky clean at the United States Open this year, at least not for quite so long as in the past.

title: ICAHN SET TO GO OVER THE TOP
description: Carl C. Icahn said yesterday that he intended to raise his stake in Trans World Airlines to more than 50 percent, giving him control of the nation's fourth-largest carrier and the biggest international airline serving the North Atlantic.

title: Contractor's Guilty Pleas
description: A Defense Department contractor and one of its vice presidents have pleaded guilty to overcharging the Government more than $1.5 million for components to the Army's radar-guided Gatling machine gun.

title: SOVIET SAID TO USE CHEMICAL TO TRACE AMERICANS' MOVES
description: The United States accused the Soviet Union today of using a mysterious powdery substance as an aid in tracking the movements of Americans and possibly other foreigners in Moscow.

title: Yields Fall on Treasury Issues
description: Yields for short- and long-term Treasury issues declined modestly yesterday, spurred by a drop in the overnight rate for bank loans in the Federal funds market and continued hopes that a weak economy will cause the Federal Reserve to ease monetary policy.

title: CORDIS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CARDILLO TRAVEL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Revenue for the year-ago 6 months has been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: CARTER HAWLEY HALE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,735,000 for the quarter and $510,000 for the 6 months and a gain of $63,050,000 for the quarter and the 6 months on the sale of Waldenbooks.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE URGES GREATER USE OF ARBITRATION
description: The Chief Justice of the United States urged lawyers today to use arbitration and mediation efforts as a way of reducing the backlog of cases in the Federal and state court systems.

title: SLANEY'S MILE TIME SETS WORLD RECORD
description: Mary Decker Slaney of the United States, unbeaten outdoors this season, held off Maricica Puica of Rumania today and broke the women's world record for the mile.

title: Advertising
description: Lincoln-Mercury, a division of the Ford Motor Company, will be spending the majority of its $80 million annual television and print budget to introduce its 1986 models on Sept. 22.

title: FENCE OF WOOD AND SLATE
description: IT may just well be the only fence on Long Island that has a name.

title: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * All Brand Importers Inc. has assigned its Clausthaler Non-Alcoholic Beer to the Bloom Agency/New York.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: Results for the latest periods include the operations of G.C. Murphy Co. acquired in June.

title: Pierce G. Fredericks, Writer And an Editor for The Times
description: Pierce G. Fredericks, a writer and editor, died of a heart attack Tuesday while on vacation in Wellesley, Mass. He was 65 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: DICKEY-JOHN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including gains of $138,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter from the sale of equipment and $375,000, or 23 cents a share, from the sale of equipment and the settlement of a patent infringement suit.

title: ANTIQUE-HUNTING MADE EASIER BY UPSTATE GROUPS OF DEALERS
description: FOR many people, browsing in antique shops is one of the pleasantest ways to spend a summer day. And going north from New York City along the Hudson River, there are several towns that make it a particular pleasure.

title: Arizona Hospital Authorized To Implant an Artificial Heart
description: The University of Arizona Medical Center says it has received approval from the Federal Food and Drug Administration to use the Jarvik-7 artificial heart.

title: Inquiry Clears Texas Bank
description: Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. said today that the Comptroller of the Currency had advised its flagship bank, Texas Commerce Bank-Houston, that it had been cleared of charges in connection with loans made to two directors.

title: CHANGES URGED ON BALLOT RULES FOR NEW YORKERS
description: Political and civic leaders called for fundamental changes in New York State's electoral system yesterday, a day after a state judge ordered one candidate for mayor and four for City Council president offthe Democratic primary ballot because of mistakes in labeling and numbering petitions.

title: Levi Strauss
description: Levi Strauss & Company said that the HHF Corporation and a group of 10 banks headed by Wells Fargo Bank N.A. had entered into a $1.45 billion credit agreement for the financing of a leveraged buyout of the San Francisco-based apparel manufacturer. The agreement is part of a previously announced offer by Robert D. Haas, president and chief executive, and other members of the company's founding family to take the company private.

title: Park Service Imposes New Beach Boys Ban
description: The Beach Boys have been banned again from the annual July 4 celebration at the Washington Monument, this time because the National Park Service wants a more ''family-oriented'' program, a spokesman said.

title: U.S. Seeks to Limit Signs At Park in the Capital
description: The Government has proposed to regulate the size and number of protest signs in Lafayette Park across the street from the White House, and the idea is not going over well with the people who demonstrate there.

title: FAR-FLUNG RESCUE TEAMS AGAIN REHEARSE DRILLS FOR CRASH OF SPACE SHUTTLE
description: In a somber ritual repeated before every mission, rescue teams from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration are busy this week preparing for something they hope will never happen: the crash of an American space shuttle.

title: Advertising;   Motor Club Group Picks St. Louis Agency
description: Kerlick, Switzer & Johnson Advertising of St. Louis has been awarded the advertising for a AAA Motor Club co-op made up of 13 automobile clubs from 12 states, representing about 4 million members.

title: CHRONOLOGY OF ROBIN'S TROUBLES
description: Following is a chronology of events leading to yesterday's announcement by the A. H. Robins Company that it has filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code:

title: Lee Suspended
description: The state Ethical Standards Commission yesterday suspended and fined New Jersey Boxing Commissioner Robert W. Lee for accepting contributions from fight promoters and casino executives.

title: Banks Reach Brazil Accord
description: A committee of commercial banks has agreed to extend a moratorium on payments of principal on Brazil's foreign debt for another 140 days, the banks said yesterday.

title: INDIANS DEFEAT BLUE JAYS, 5-2
description: Julio Franco and Joe Carter drove in two runs each tonight and Neal Heaton pitched a six hitter as the Indians scored a 5-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: AMERICANS GIVEN MOSCOW BRIEFING
description: American residents here were informed of assertions about the use of a potentially harmful chemical by the K.G.B. in an extraordinary series of briefings today.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A DRUNKEN FATALITY AND FORGIVENESS
description: For more than two years, Frank and Elizabeth Morris dedicated their lives to punishing the drunken driver who had killed their only child.

title: HAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FIRESTONE TIRE & RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $4,000,000 for the quarter and $5,000,000 for the 9 months. c-Including net from discontinued operations of $17,000,000 for the quarter and $26,000,000 for the 9 months and extraordinary credits of $2,000,000 for the quarter and $8,000,000 for the 9 months.

title: COURT IN MASSACHUSETTS UPHOLDS CHRISTIAN SCIENCE MONITOR'S DISMISSAL OF A LESBIAN
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court today upheld the constitutional right of The Christian Science Monitor to dismiss a lesbian employee who refused to participate in a church-ordered ''healing.''

title: LITTLE IS KNOWN ABOUT THE CHEMICAL
description: A chemical alleged by the State Department to have been used by the K.G.B. in tracking the activities of Americans is so little known that it does not appear in any of the standard chemical reference books.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 22, 1985
description: Companies

title: TECHNICAL EQUITIES CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
AMERICAN BUSINESSPHONES reports earnings for Yr to June 30
Eckerd in Talks On Possible Merger
description: After fending off an apparent takeover bid by the Dart Group Corporation earlier this year, the Jack Eckerd Corporation said yesterday that it was considering a possible ''sale, merger or business combination.'' It said that it and Goldman Sachs & Company, its investment banker, were holding preliminary discussions with a small number of companies.

title: SCHOOLS AROUND STATE WILL BE BIG WINNERS
description: The feverish ticket sales that pushed yesterday's Lotto jackpot to a record $41 million, to be paid over 20 years, is expected to provide nearly as much to local school districts throughout New York State - immediately.

title: Itel, Great Lakes
description: The Itel Corporation has again raised its stake in Great Lakes International Inc., the company said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Yr to May 31
SUDBURY HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Yr to May 25
description: b-Includes extraordinary credits of $2,324,000 for the latest year and $685,000 for the year ago. c-Includes extraordinary credits of $754,000 for the latest quarter and $416,000 for the year ago quarter.

title: A Limit to U.S. Rights In Central America?
description: To the Editor:

title: Fifth Avenue Phil Makes Himself at Home
description: Usually, it is not voluntary. But at the Children's Zoo in Central Park, a wild woodchuck has moved in on his own.

title: SIDNEY LUMET IN 3-YEAR LORIMAR PACT
description: In a throwback to the days of the studio system when actors and directors were under long-term contract to individual studios, a major director, Sidney Lumet, has signed an exclusive three-year contract with Lorimar. The intention is for the director to make a minimum of three motion pictures. He will be paid a yearly salary whether or not the movies get produced.

title: FINDING A CURE FOR AIDS
description: Public awareness of the AIDS epidemic is now greater than ever before. The numbers explain why.

title: TENNESSEE SEEKS TO BLOCK NUCLEAR WASTE PLAN
description: Tennessee filed suit today seeking to block the United States Energy Department from asking Congress for approval to store spent nuclear fuel in the state temporarily.

title: Article 207089 -- No Title
description: Braniff Inc., which emerged from bankruptcy proceedings last year, reported yesterday that it had second-quarter net income of $13.6 million, or $1.10 a share.

title: Harris H. Thomas, a Teacher At Phillips Exeter 40 Years
description: Harris Henderson Thomas, who taught at the Phillips Exeter Academy in Exeter, N.H., for 40 years, died Tuesday after a series of strokes at the Francis E. Parker Memorial Home in New Brunswick, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Advertising;   Celebrities In Tune for Newspaper
description: CHARLES SCHWAB, the discount broker, sings? Yes, in a new national television campaign beginning today for USA Today, the three-year-old national daily newspaper.

title: Security Pacific Forms A Friendly Partnership
description: When the Security Pacific Corporation announced this week that it would make its first move into full-service interstate banking by buying the Arizona Bancwest Corporation for $480 million, the deal was not a quick association of two companies with little knowledge of one other.

title: A SUICIDE SPURS TOWN TO DEBATE NATURE OF A GAME
description: A suicide by a local youth who often played a fantasy game called Dungeons and Dragons has triggered a debate in this rural northeastern Connecticut town about whether the game should be allowed in the public schools during free periods.

title: Kin of Jet-Crash Victims Visit Site on Japan Peak
description: Grieving relatives tossed flowers and farewell notes from a helicopter today as they flew over the mountain in central Japan where a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet crashed nine days ago.

title: EMERGENCY ROOM USE DROPS IF PATIENT PAYS, STUDY FINDS
description: If people covered by insurance are required to pay a portion of the cost of their medical care, they are far less likely to use hospital emergency rooms for treatment of colds, scrapes and other minor ills, according to a new study.

title: EVENTS: NAVAJO TEXTILES
description: Navajo Textiles: A Century of Change, Newark Museum, 49 Washington Street, 201-733-6600.

title: USAir Attendants Ratify Pact With 2-Tier Wage Structure
description: Flight attendants at USAir have ratified a new contract, accepting a two-tier wage scale with lower rates for newly hired workers, their union announced.

title: All Aboard For Cooperstown
description: Youth will have a significant fling at Shea Stadium this Sunday when Dwight Gooden takes his next turn.

title: Loss Data, Gained
description: Are you more likely to be injured in a Chrysler Le Baron or a Buick Electra? Which car is likely to be more expensive to fix? The Transportation Department used to collect and publish the data needed to answer such safety questions. But the Reagan Administration ended the practice, saying that if consumers really wanted the information, the private sector would sell it to them.

title: GROWING LAVENDAR IN ITS MANY VARIETIES
description: LAVENDER is in bloom now, but fragrance is an elusive quality with this clan: not all of its members have a deep scent. Twenty species have been identified, and sorting them out is tricky as the names have changed over the centuries. Some lavenders are hardy in this climate; others are not. Even clones of particular cultivars are not as fragrant as others.

title: CORRECTION
description: In the Executive Changes column on Tuesday, the new title of Anthony J. Butterworth at Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. was incorrect. He was named president of the international division of the consumer products group, not president of the whole group.

title: PUTTING THE BOUNTY OF SUMMER GARDENS TO WORK
description: THEIR complaints are typical of those who work the land: not enough rain, too many weeds, poor soil. Conversations tend toward comparisons of last year's failures with this season's bounty. And they enjoy little of their home-grown crops themselves.

title: Hotel Approved For Chautauqua
description: The Chautauqua Institution has approved construction of a $5.5 million hotel in the heart of this historic resort, averting a possible legal challenge by its developers.

title: INDIA HONORS ASSASSINATED SIKH LEADER
description: Government offices, private markets, businesses and educational institutions were closed today throughout the Punjab, and elsewhere in India, to honor a slain Sikh leader.

title: Firestone Net Declines 73%
description: The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company said today that it earned $13 million, or 31 cents a share, in its fiscal third quarter, a 73 percent drop from $48 million, or $1.06 a share, a year earlier. Sales fell to $994 million from $1.03 billion.

title: Benefit Variety Show
description: An evening of music, poetry and comedy featuring F. Murray Abraham, Joseph Chaikin, Ronnie Gilbert, Sheila Jordan, Peter Schickele, Danitra Vance and others is planned for Sept. 18 at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. Mr. Abraham is host for the 8 P.M. event, to raise funds for the Volunteer Stroke Rehabilitation Program. Tickets are $25, $50 and $100. Information: 864-5400.

title: Douglass Shoots 69 To Lead Met Open
description: A light, steady rain and the undulating greens of the Mountain Ridge Country Club combined today to make scores high for the second consecutive round of the Met Open. Only six players broke the par of 71.

title: BELLAMY AND KOCH AT ODDS WITH FARRELL DURING DEBATE
description: Mayor Koch and City Council President Carol Bellamy, often poles apart on their views of the state of the city, agreed yesterday that its economy was strong enough to withstand Federal budget cuts next year. But a third mayoral candidate, Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr., offered a far more pessimistic forecast.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must come up with an alternative to avoid this madness.'' -Mayor Koch, on election ballot rules. [B2:5.]

title: FIRE ERUPTS IN ARIZONA EXPLOSIVES DUMP NEAR TESTING SILO
description: Fire broke out today in a cache of millions of pounds of explosives next to a missile test silo, forcing the evacuation of about 40 workers and the diversion of military flights over the area, the authorities said.

title: BRANIFF INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax benefits of $6,000,000 for the quarter and $6,700,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss.

title: IRRIGATION POLICY ASSAILED ON COAST
description: Two organizations today charged the Federal Bureau of Reclamation with spending more than $1 billion in illegal ''hidden subsidies'' to provide irrigation water to large corporate farmers in California's Central Valley.

title: Ford Attacker Denied Parole
description: Sara Jane Moore, the former bookkeeper and California housewife who tried to kill President Ford in 1975, was denied parole today by the United States Parole Commission. Miss Moore, who is 55 years old, is serving a life sentence at a Federal women's prison in Pleasonton, Calif. A spokesman for the commission said it continued her request for parole until the year 2000.

title: JOHNSTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
'HOMETOWN,' NEW SERIES ON CBS
description: ''Hometown'' was inevitable. There had to be a television series about yuppies, and the only question was, how would yuppies be regarded? As figures of fun - quiche, white wine and all that? As survivors of the 1960's - blighted hopes, arid dreams, upscale living that makes everyone feel empty? ''Hometown,'' indebted to ''The Big Chill,'' leans toward the survivor interpretation. The CBS series has its premiere on Channel 2 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HITLER: Memoirs of a Confidant. Edited by Henry Ashby Turner Jr. Translated by Ruth Hein. 333 pages. Illustrated. Yale University Press. $29.95. OTTO WAGENER was mesmerized by Adolf Hitler's eyes. In his memoir he writes: ''From the first, his eyes caught and held me. They were clear and large, trained on me calmly and with self-assurance. His gaze came, not from the pupil, but from a much deeper source - I felt as if it came from the infinite. It was impossible to read anything in these eyes. But they spoke, they wanted to speak. They did not ask, they talked.'' And what banal talk! What mythic drivel!

title: Labor Department;   A Democrat? A Liberal? In This Administration?
description: On Stephen Schlossberg's newly decorated wall in the Labor Department are a series of framed quotations from, among others, Woody Guthrie, the songwriter; Joe Hill, the union activist, and George Meany, the former head of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. And this one, from Nicola Sacco: ''It is true, indeed, that they can execute the body but they cannot execute the idea, which is bound to live.''

title: METAL BOOKMARKS
description: TWO new brass bookmarks are available from the shop at the National Trust for Historic Preservation in Washington. Patterned after Frank Lloyd Wright's design for the cutout clerestory windows at the Pope-Leighey House in Mount Vernon, Va., the bookmarks are two and a quarter inches long and sell in a set of two (one is nickel-plated and the other is gold-washed) for $10.

title: Nets Get Mickey Johnson
description: Mickey Johnson, a former Net who was traded to Golden State for Micheal Ray Richardson in 1983 after a falling out with the Nets' coach, Larry Brown, was reacquired by New Jersey yesterday. The Nets' new coach, Dave Wohl, said he expected the 33-year-old forward to become ''a key reserve'' and provide ''solid leadership'' to the team.

title: ZIA CRITICS THRONG PAKISTAN FUNERAL
description: Tens of thousands of mourners thronged the funeral rites today of the son of Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, in one of the biggest displays of opposition to the Government since Mr. Bhutto was overthrown in 1977.

title: SCANA CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
SCHICK INCORPORATED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
MEXICAN REJECTS OUSTING SANDINISTAS
description: Mexico's Foreign Minister today criticized sentiments in favor of overthrowing the Nicaraguan Government, saying such an action would have ''very unfortunate consequences'' for Latin America.

title: ROSE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Kroger Unit's Purchase
description: The Kroger Company said today that its Dillon division had purchased a convenience-store chain and an affiliated dairy in Pennsylvania. Kroger, a food retailer and drugstore operator, declined to disclose the price for the purchase of Turkey Hill Dairy Inc. of Conestoga, Pa., and Farmland Industries of Lancaster, Pa., which operates as Turkey Hill Minit Markets.

title: METS LET ONE SLIP AWAY TO GIANTS
description: There they were in the top of the ninth inning last night at Shea Stadium, and the Mets had it all going again: one out, nobody on base, Roger McDowell firing the sinkerball and the Mets savoring a 2-1 lead they had just taken over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Wennington in Accord
description: Bill Wennington, the 7-foot St. John's center, came to terms with the Dallas Mavericks yesterday on a four-year contract that will reportedly bring him $250,000 a year. One of the Mavericks' three first-round draft choices this year, Wennington, the 16th selection over all, is also one of two St. John's players taken in the first round.

title: MICROSOFT AND I.B.M. JOIN FORCES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has agreed with the Microsoft Corporation, a key software supplier, to develop fundamental software for personal computers, the companies said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, a United Nations dispatch Aug. 17 on South Africa incorrectly quoted a statement by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Mr. Perez de Cuellar, discussing an Aug. 15 speech by President P. W. Botha, said the address ''did not give any indication of imminent changes for the elimination of the apartheid system, the lifting of the state of emergency and the unconditional release of Mr. Nelson Mandela and all other political prisoners and detainees in South Africa.''

title: Peabody Sues Posner Over Plan
description: The Peabody International Corporation said it has sued Victor Posner, the financier, and a group of companies he controls, charging security law violations in connection with Peabody's plan to merge with the Pullman Company.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: EIGHT CRIME GROUPS ARE ACTIVE IN JERSEY, ACCORDING TO F.B.I.
description: Experts with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, in beginning a drive against organized crime in the New York metropolitan area two years ago, said eight crime factions were active in New Jersey.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 22, 1985
description: International

title: Advertising;   Addendum
description: * Sport Magazine said that, effective with its January 1986 issue, it will increase its advertising rates by 7 percent.

title: Ex-NASA Engineer Heads Orbit Project
description: Maxime A. Faget spent 35 years sending rockets into space for the Government as an engineer at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Now he is heading a project that plans to send private industry's first workshop into orbit.

title: OPERA: 2 AMERIACN WORKS BASED ON CHEKHOV
description: Originally, the Lake George Opera Festival planned to make its final production of the 1985 season a double bill of new operas based on Chekhov by the young American composer Richard Wargo. By June it became clear that Mr. Wargo wasn't going to finish ''The Music Shop'' in time, although his ''Seduction of a Lady'' was ready. What to do? The answer was to find another one-act American comic opera by a young composer who, like Mr. Wargo, came from Pennsylvania and was educated at the Eastman School of Music. And one that could be cast with the same three singers who sang in the Wargo.

title: WALTER READE ORGANIZATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
In Congress, the Mail Must Be Answered
description: Although many in Congress wish they could spend all their time on the weighty affairs of state, a more mundane task of no less importance is the daily mail.

title: Thrift Unit Posts Loss
description: Westside Bancorporation Inc., parent company of the Westside Federal Savings and Loan Association, said today that it lost $45.7 million in the fiscal year ended June 30. In the final quarter, Westside had losses of $32.7 million.

title: Courting a Defector
description: Peter Klima, the Czechoslovak hockey star who apparently defected to the West on Tuesday while on a training visit to West Germany, had not surfaced yesterday, but there were reports that the 22-year-old forward might be on his way to Detroit with a satchel full of Red Wing money.The club, which holds the National Hockey League rights to Klima, provided no details, but according to hockey officials in Resenheim, West Germany, where the Czechoslovak team has been training since Aug. 13, a Red Wing scout arrived in the town recently with a bag containing $100,000, presumably to persuade Klima that his future lay in the N.H.L.

title: Why 'Tire' Is a Central Part of Retirement
description: To the Editor:

title: THERE'S MONEY IN LOTTO FOR THE GADGETS AS WELL
description: As record numbers of lottery players waited and dreamed in lines that wound and coiled across New York yesterday, a barrage of gimmicks and gadgets promised them a surer route to Lotto's $41 million.

title: Continental Air
description: The Continental Airlines unit of the Texas Air Corporation said it plans to begin service from Los Angeles to San Jose, Calif., and Seattle. On Aug. 29, the company will begin offering three scheduled flights daily between Los Angeles and Seattle at a cost of $69 one way. On Aug. 30, the company will begin operating six flights between Los Angeles and San Jose for $29 one-way.

title: ROBINS, IN BANKRUPTCY FILING, CITES DALKON SHIELD CLAIMS
description: The A. H. Robins Company, besieged by health claims from its Dalkon Shield birth control device, filed yesterday for bankruptcy protection from its creditors. It became the second major American company to do so because of expanding damages from defective or dangerous products.

title: Deductibility of Taxes Is Crucial
description: To the Editor:

title: C.D. and Money Fund Yields Rise
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds showed increases for the week ended yesterday. Yields on money market accounts, however, held firm for the fourth consecutive week.

title: Article 207290 -- No Title
description: ''I hope the New York State lottery goes to $60 million and there's only one winner,'' said Michael Wittkowski. ''That'll take all the pressure off me.''

title: METRO TEL CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
WALKER CUP BATTLE PROVES COMPETITIVE
description: The United States Walker Cup team found itself in a surprisingly difficult struggle against the team from Britain and Ireland today after the squads of amateur golfers finished the first of the two days of the biennial competition tied at 6 points apiece.

title: HERS
description: SOME time ago, in his column in The New York Times Magazine, William Safire noted concern over the fact that our mother tongue has raised a word for the hatred of women (misogyny) but neglected a comparable one for the hatred of men. Mr. Safire reported that two readers had written to suggest the words misandry and misandronist, terms that each apparently considered a fresh coinage.

title: Hanson Trust Bids for SCM
description: Hanson Trust P.L.C., a British conglomerate, announced yesterday that it had made a $720 million tender offer for the SCM Corporation, the American chemicals, office and paper products company.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,503,000. Share earnings and shares outstanding reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable Sept. 4, 1985.

title: Centennial Gets Chief
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced the appointment of Anthony C. La Scala, president of the retail banking division of the Great Western Financial Corporation, to head the management team of Centennial Savings and Loan Association.

title: TEL ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
If You Win . . .
description: There are several steps to take if one wins the Lotto game, according to the state lottery director, John D. Quinn.

title: Laker Agrees To Settlement
description: Sir Freddie Laker, who pioneered discount trans-Atlantic flights, today abandoned his battle to prove that the world's airlines plotted to bankrupt him and accepted a settlement he earlier called ''pitifully inadequate.''

title: Alf Landon Is Slightly Hurt
description: Alf M. Landon, the former Kansas Governor who was the 1936 Republican nominee for President, fell while getting out of bed Tuesday, but X-rays revealed no broken bones, said his wife, Theo Landon. Mr. Landon, 97 years old, complained of pain after the fall and was taken by ambulance to a hospital for the X-rays. He returned home afterward, his wife said.

title: You Can Look It Up
description: The Library of Congress collects everything. Everything.

title: JUST IN CASE YOU MISSED IT: 14,17,22,23,30,47
description: The balls spun. The tubes spit them out. And the magic numbers that spelled $41 million were: 14, 17, 22, 23, 30, 47.

title: CBS AND A.P. DISCUSS OVERSEAS NEWS VENTURE
description: CBS is talking with The Associated Press about setting up a joint venture to gather video news overseas, officials of both organizations said yesterday.

title: LILLY PLEADS GUILTY TO ORAFLEX CHARGES
description: Eli Lilly & Company pleaded guilty today to criminal charges that it failed to inform the Federal Government about four deaths and six illnesses related to its arthritis drug Oraflex. It was fined $25,000 for these and other charges.

title: BENSON SEES BEAUTY IN GAME
description: His blond hair and short-cropped beard could not hide the fact that faces have muscles. It is a wide face, unmistakably a football player's or a wrestler's or one belonging to somebody who eats well. But that's not to say it is a mean face, except that it has a tremendous capacity to look mean. Looking mean is a vital asset for a lineman.

title: Union Pacific To Drop Deal
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said that it planned to rescind its agreement to buy for $108 million the Missouri-Kansas-Texas Railroad Company, a subsidiary of Katy Industries. Union Pacific cited the railroad's inability to retire certain debt certificates issued when it reorganized in 1958.

title: SCI SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
THE WAY HOME IS HARD FOR INDIANS OF NICARAGUA
description: Rodolfo Herman and about 100 other Miskito Indians were to have begun a long-awaited return to their homeland along the Coco River on a certain day recently.

title: BBC IS CAUGHT UP IN NEW FUROR
description: For the second time in a month, the British Broadcasting Corporation has become ensnarled in a controversy that calls into question its cherished image of political independence.

title: THE EVOLUTION OF ROCK, A LONG AND WINDING ROAD
description: DECISIVE moments in rock-and-roll - Elvis Presley's spectacular appearance on the Ed Sullivan show, for example, or the Beatles' attempts to enliven pop-song traditions with influences from classical and experimental music - are epiphanies that still reverberate with meaning. But historians of popular culture rarely treat them as isolated events significant in themselves. The tendency is to put these moments in a context of a broader, more general understanding of the music's history. According to this point of view, Mr. Presley's triumph belongs entirely to the 1950's, though he gave one of the most inspired performances of his life much later, on his 1968 television special. This view makes up in coherence what it lacks in attention to detail -tracing popular music from decade to decade is much neater than following the messy, multidirectional flow of musical influences and inspirations as they occur in real life.

title: MANCINI TRADES IN GLOVES FOR ACTING
description: Thumbing his nose at a $3 million purse and turning his face toward Hollywood, Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini bid bye-bye to boxing yesterday and said hello to an acting career.

title: A CONTROVERSY IN TRIBECA: IS IT ART OR AN EYESORE?
description: ''I think it's an exercise in bad taste,'' Kathryn Freed said.

title:
ECONOMIC SCENE;

The Strains With Japan
description: DESPITE some progress by Congress in reducing Federal expenditures in the 1986 fiscal year, the budget deficit remains high and could easily balloon back to the $200 billion range in the event of a cyclical economic slowdown. Thus, the now familiar pattern of high interest rates, overvalued dollar and bloated United States trade deficit is also certain to continue in the years ahead. Frustration over this situation will also continue to strain the economic relationship between the United States and Japan.

title: DURABLES ORDERS FELL 2.8% IN JULY
description: Orders for durable goods plunged 2.8 percent in July as both the military and civilian segments of the economy suffered declines, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Pacific Bell Debentures
description: Pacific Bell, a subsidiary of the Pacific Telesis Group, is offering $400 million of 11 3/8 percent debentures due in 2024 at a price of 98.842 to yield 11.51 percent through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Seeking Ads That Cost Less
description: IN 1982, R. Gordon McGovern, president of Campbell Soup Company, challenged the company's in-house agency, S. C. Advertising Inc., to come up with some innovative ways to promote its many food brands.

title: CONGRESS WILL GET PLAN TO EVEN OUT FEES FOR MEDICARE
description: The Department of Health and Human Services is drafting a report to Congress recommending a major change in the way the Government pays physicians under Medicare, the health insurance program for the elderly.

title: Of Races, Straits, Fjords, Rias, Estuaries and Great Jones Street
description: To the Editor:

title: San Francisco Slaying Tied to 'Night Stalker'
description: A killer dubbed ''the night stalker'' by the Los Angeles police for seven slayings there since March was linked today to the killing of a man in San Francisco.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,441,000 from an accounting change.

title: SCREEN: 'WARNING SIGN'
description: IT had to happen. Like the inevitable next step in recombinant-DNA research, ''Warning Sign'' merges the new socially conscious, technological-disaster genre - a la ''China Syndrome'' and ''Silkwood'' - with the good old mad-scientist monster movie. The film, which opens today at the Criterion and other theaters, is nearly as well crafted as it is confused, a lickety-split, implausible thriller that never lets its earnestness impede the action.

title: U.S. STRATEGY OF TOUGHNESS: A COUNTER TO THE RUSSIANS
description: In the maneuvering in advance of President Reagan's meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev in November, the United States is taking a tough line on arms and other issues in response to what it sees as a Soviet public relations campaign.

title: New Chief at Fairchild
description: Emanuel Fthenakis, who was named president of Fairchild Industries in May, has been named to the additional post of chief executive, effective Oct. 1. He succeeds Edward G. Uhl, 67 years old, who remains chairman of the aerospace and communications company. Mr. Fthenakis, 57, joined Fairchild in 1971 and was named an executive vice president last year. Before coming to Fairchild, which is based in Chantilly, Va., he worked for Bell Telephone Laboratories and the General Electric Company.

title: FIRST FEDERAL SAVINGS BANK MONANA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $33,480 from a Federal Home Loan Mortgage dividend.

title: Spy Suspect Granted Transfer to U.S. Prison
description: Federal District Judge Harvey Alexander 2d in Baltimore agreed today to permit Michael L. Walker, a Navy yeoman charged with spying for the Soviet Union, to move to a Federal prison from a county jail in Maryland.

title: Citrus Campaign
description: The Florida Department of Citrus plans a $12 million national campaign to reinforce the image of Florida's juice processors and strengthen the position of licensed brand owners of Florida orange juice. The sunshine state processes 90 percent of its oranges. The 12 month-campaign, created by Dudley-Anderson-Yutzy in New York, includes network television advertising, national magazine ads and a $3 million consumer coupon program.

title: SOWETO BLACK LEADER SAYS POLICE RAPED GIRL
description: A black leader from the township of Soweto asserted today that two black policemen raped a girl as she returned home from school this week. He said it was one of many incidents of lawless behavior by policemen in the area.

title: It Was a Long Night on the Ice
description: With a laughing woman in his arms, Adam Leib of the John Curry Skaters swooshed across the ice of the Kennedy Center's Opera House.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Sports People column yesterday on the Masters Games in Canada incorrectly reported the amount of a Government grant to the games.

title: A TRANSIT OFFICER'S TESTIMONY IS READ TO STEWART TRIAL JURY
description: A transit police officer told a grand jury that another officer restrained Michael Stewart by arching him over the back seat of a van that was transporting the prisoner to district headquarters.

title: DANCES BY PARSONS ON VIEW
description: Dance Theater Workshop has presented ''The Out-of-Towners,'' a festival of dance created by choreographers and performers working outside New York, for eight summers now. This year, the series is called ''The Out-of-Towners (and Others).'' The ''Other'' is New York's own David Parsons, a leading dancer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company and a young choreographer who has attracted much attention. New and recent works by Mr. Parsons will be on view tonight through Wednesday at 8 o'clock at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street. Joining Mr. Parsons will be Kate Johnson and Christopher Gillis, also of the Taylor company, and seven other modern dancers.

title: Search May Be Over
description: Tom Young, the Rutgers basketball coach, may be headed south. According to a series of published reports in Virginia, he has been picked by an Old Dominion search committee to replace Paul Webb as the school's head coach.

title: Bridge: Cinderella Team in Spingold Turned Out to Be Landau's
description: At every major national knockout team event, some group of little-known players has a good run and enhances their reputations by defeating some established stars.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Steve Martin and Rick Moranis will star in a film version of the hit Off Broadway musical ''Little Shop of Horrors.'' Frank Oz, the puppeteer who directed ''The Muppets Take Manhattan,'' will direct for Geffen Films.

title: Sri Lanka Aide to Meet Gandhi in New Delhi
description: A top Sri Lanka official will meet Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in New Delhi Friday in a renewed effort to reconvene peace talks between Colombo and Tamil rebels, an Indian official said today.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES PLANS TO DEVELOP WEAPONS IN SPACE
description: President Reagan, in a speech that reinforced the Administration's toughening posture toward the Soviet Union, today strongly defended plans to develop a defensive weapons system in outer space.

title: Diner's Journal
description: YOU are hit with a blast of a familiar aroma upon entering the sprawling dining room, a blend of sea air and hot spices. All over the room, animated diners wearing plastic bibs are hammering away at mounds of steaming red crabs, sending shards in all directions.

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $88,026 for the quarter and $168,620 for the 6 months.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary item of $132,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and the year. c-Including extraordinary items of $193,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $581,000, or 29 cents a share, for the year.

title: WEINBERGER FACES DECISION ON FATE OF $4.5 BILLION ANTIAIRCRAFT GUN
description: Senior officials in the Pentagon told Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today that the Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun had continued to have trouble tracking and destroying targets in recent tests, according to a source familiar with the weapon.

title: WESTERN ENERGY DEVELOPENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Maynard Walker Dies at 89; Art Dealer Almost 40 Years
description: Maynard Walker, an art dealer in New York City for nearly 40 years who was among the first to show the works of leading American regionalist painters, died of pneumonia Tuesday at St. Joseph's Hospital in Carbondale, Pa. He was 89 years old and lived in Lake Ariel, Pa.

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax provision of $3,200,000 for the anticipated loss on the company's investment in Seabrook Unit II.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AFRICAN MUSIC
description: Celebrate Brooklyn will present African music this weekend at the Prospect Park Band Shell, near Ninth Street and Prospect Park West in Brooklyn.

title: Alan Holden, Who Assisted On Sonar Project, Dies at 81
description: Alan Holden, a physicist who helped develop sonar equipment used to detect submarines during World War II, died Tuesday of a heart attack at Memorial Hospital in Morristown, N.J. He was 81 years old and lived in New Vernon, N.J.

title: Film on Animal Abuse
description: ''The Animals Film,'' a documentary about abuse of animals in the food and scientific industries, will be shown the next four weekends at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Cubans at Detention Center Riot in Bid to Return Home
description: Cuban inmates rioted at a Federal immigration detention center early today, setting fires, breaking windows and furniture, and shouting that they wanted to be returned home, the authorities said.

title: Lost Expense Checks Mar Jazz Ceremony
description: Misplaced expense checks delayed performances Wednesday night by Woody Herman and other jazz greats honored at the International Jazz Hall of Fame's induction ceremony.

title: AUCTIONS
description: This is the season when the engraved invitations with the distinguished list of patrons begin arriving inthe mail, asking you to go to a benefit auction. Every organization from Carnegie Hall to the Inernational Sephardic Education Foundtaion to the Gay Men's Health Crisis for AIDS is planning to hold such a fund-raising event in the coming months.

title: CBS NOVICE STEPS IN FOR RATHER
description: On Wednesday night, ''The CBS Evening News with Dan Rather'' became ''The CBS Evening News with Forrest Sawyer'' and millions of viewers doubtless found themselves asking, ''Forrest who?''

title: I.B.M. Sierra
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said, as expected, it will start volume shipments Friday of its top-of-the-line 3090 computer, known as the Sierra. I.B.M. originally said volume shipments would not begin until November, but the company said last month that it was able to accelerate the delivery schedule, a move some securities analysts said could improve the company's third quarter earnings.

title: VACU-DRY CO reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Ads Curtailed By Japan Air
description: Japan Air Lines has stopped advertising in Japan and abroad for ''a period of mourning'' for the 520 passengers of a J.A.L. flight who died in a Boeing 747 crash on Aug.12.

title: DISTANT POLLUTION TIED TO ACID RAIN
description: For the first time, changes in the acidity of rainfall have been directly linked to changes in pollution emissions hundreds of miles away, according to a new scientific report.

title: Hutton Denies Takeover Bid
description: Takeover rumors engulfed E.F. Hutton & Company yesterday, pushing the stock of the big Wall Street brokerage house up $1.375 a share, to $35.625, with 925,000 shares changing hands.

title: WORLD WAR II REPRISE OFFERED BY CHANNEL 13
description: WORLD WAR II was hugely destructive, the most cataclysmic war in history. ''From Blitzkrieg to the Bomb,'' a compendium of battlefield newsreel footage, shows engines of the cataclysm. Many images are redundant; battlefields look alike. But as World War II recedes in our memories, the documentary is a useful reminder of what the war was like. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Revlon Is Sued
description: Pantry Pride Inc., pursuing its $1.8 billion takeover bid for Revlon Inc., said that its controlling stockholder, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., had sued Revlon in Delaware Chancery Court to invalidate a ''poison pill'' adopted by Revlon to make a takeover more expensive. Named as defendants were Michel C. Bergerac, chairman of Revlon, and other directors. The court set a hearing for Sept. 10 on its motion for a preliminary injunction, Pantry Pride said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All the 21 people are the shareowner of this ticket and will get the prize.

title: A.M.C. Cuts Rate To 7.5 Percent
description: The American Motors Corporation lowered its discount car financing offer from 8.5 percent, to 7.5 percent, to compete with recent incentives offered by the Big Three auto makers.

title: Time Expires On MTV Bid
description: Forstmann Little & Company's bid for MTV Networks Inc. passed a 5 P.M. deadline yesterday, but by late evening there was still no word as to whether or not a deal had been reached.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
DIGIGRAPHIC SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After nonrecurring losses of $4,814,998 for the quarter and the 6 months for the establishment of a bad debt and inventory reserve.

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Capital Cities Offering Notes
description: Capital Cities Communications Inc. is offering $200 million of 10 1/2 percent notes due 1997 at a price of 99 1/2 to yield 10.574 percent through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: N.F.L. PLAYERS WANT ROSTERS EXPANDED
description: Gene Upshaw, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said yesterday that he has intensified his effort to persuade league owners to expand roster sizes to 49 players. When the season opens Sept. 8, each team will carry 45 players.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: Every October Robert Thorne revisits his father's grave in rural Pennsylvania, a few miles from the spot where the 1956 Thorne senior, a career diplomat, died of gunshot wounds. Although the official verdict was a hunting accident, Thorne, a boy of 14 at the time, has never doubted that it was suicide. But why? More than 20 years later, the question still oppresses him.

title: FORD TO CUT WOKERS BY 10,000
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to reduce its white-collar work force by 20 percent, or about 10,000 workers, over the next five years, company officials announced today.

title: SCREEN: 'DETECTIVE,' BY JEAN-LUC GODARD
description: IN his cerebrally comic new film, ''Detective,'' Jean-Luc Godard poses the question, ''Who killed the Prince?'' That we never do learn who killed him, or even who the Prince was, is very much the point of Mr. Godard's ebullient new shaggy-dog story, in which more than a dozen mysterious and/or myopic characters slink around the corridors and through the bedrooms of a fine old Paris hotel, working at cross-purposes to attain money, love and happiness, all of which elude them.

title: MINNESOTA'S BATTLE WITH MISQUITOES
description: Mention mosquitoes, and Jean Malaske, a clerical worker in the Mayor's office, responds: ''Our state bird, you mean?''

title: F.C.C. Filing By Murdoch
description: Lawyers for Rupert Murdoch have warned that his New York Post and Chicago Sun-Times newspapers ''might very well cease operations'' unless the Federal Communications Commission grants a two-year waiver of a rule barring single ownership of both a television station and a daily newspaper in a city.

title: Interest Rates Fall Slightly
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday, with the movement coming after the Federal Reserve announced a $900 million increase in the nation's basic money supply.

title: Canada Trustco
description: The Canada Trustco Mortgage Company said it had reluctantly advised shareholders to accept the Genstar Corporation's takeover offer of $45.20 a share, or more than $1.2 billion (Canadian).

title: Softball May Phase Out Yellowstone's Bears
description: To the Editor:

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $289,000 for the quarter and $1,539,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $14,930,000.

title: Tranquil Memorial For a Coney Islander
description: A small slice of Coney Island has been named after one of its beloved citizens.

title: A Huge Cloud of Sahara Dust Approaching Coast of Florida
description: A huge but harmless Sahara dust cloud 1,000 miles wide is heading west across the Atlantic Ocean and experts warn that it may strike Florida by this weekend.

title: Booklet on Drug Use And AIDS Assailed
description: Los Angeles County and the Federal Government helped finance a pamphlet called ''Shooting Up and Your Health,'' which gives advice on how to safely inject drugs, according to three county supervisors, who called for an inquiry.

title: Ryder-Aviall Deal
description: Ryder System Inc. said that it had agreed to acquire Aviall Inc., a Dallas-based aviation repair company, for $25 a share, or a total of about $125 million.

title: SUNRISE MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
FLORIDIAN BACKS CLEMENCY MOVE IN MERCY DEATH
description: Gov. Bob Graham recommended today that a 76-year-old man serving a life sentence for killing his incurably ill wife be released from prison pending the outcome of his appeals in state court.

title: Purex to Clean Up Mitchel Field Area
description: A Federal judge has approved an agreement for the Purex Corporation to pay as much as $15 million to clean up contaminaated soil and water in the Mitchel Field area over 10 years.

title: BOYD ABSENT AS RED SOX WIN
description: Wade Boggs and Jim Rice delivered run-scoring singles during a four-run third inning and the rookie Mike Trujillo (3-2) pitched eight strong innings tonight, helping the Boston Red Sox break a six-game losing streak with an 8-4 victory over the Texas Rangers.

title: End of an Era
description: Bill Barber, the last active player remaining from the Philadelphia Flyers' two Stanley Cup champion teams, announced his retirement yesterday, more than a year after a knee injury halted the left wing's 12-year National Hockey League career. Barber, 33, a first-team All-Star in the 1975-76 season, underwent surgery to reconstruct his right knee in April 1984 and did not play last season.

title: JOSEPH DELLICARRI
description: Joseph DelliCarri, the director and conductor of the Bronx Symphony Orchestra and an associate professor of music at Lehman College, died of cancer Tuesday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Little Ferry, N.J.

title: JUSTICE ISSUES ARE DEBATED IN RACE FOR DISTRICT ATTORNEY
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan and his opponent in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary, C. Vernon Mason, disagreed sharply yesterday on a wide range of criminal-justice issues and on the quality of Mr. Morgenthau's performance over the last 10 years.

title: GERBER SYSTEMS TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: The Hay Group Names President to Top Posts
description: The Hay Group, an international management-consulting concern based in Philadelphia, has named its president, Charles E. Fiero, to the posts of chairman and chief executive, effective Oct. 1.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: FRIDAY, AUGUST 23, 1985
description: International

title: BOSSES TAKE IT IN STRIDE
description: How do New York's high-powered businessmen stay on their toes? Some of them do it by giving the chauffeur the day off and walking to and from work.

title: Of Races, Straits, Fjords, Rias, Estuaries and Great Jones Street
description: To the Editor:

title: THE NEW ATTRACTIONS OF CABLE
description: If Warner Communications Inc. and the American Express Company had attempted to sell Warner Amex Cable Communications as recently as three years ago, they would have been hard pressed to find a buyer.

title: OPEC May Meet Oct. 3
description: Oil ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries have tentatively scheduled a special conference for Oct. 3 to discuss production, an OPEC source confirmed today.

title: Of Races, Straits, Fjords, Rias, Estuaries and Great Jones Street
description: To the Editor:

title: DUPLEX PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-After a charge of $129,000 from the sale of the company's wholesale office supply business. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July.

title: ICAHN SAID TO SEEK TEXAS AIR PULLOUT
description: Advisers representing Carl C. Icahn and the Texas Air Corporation are involved in talks to get Texas Air to withdraw its offer for Trans World Airlines, and thus speed Mr. Icahn's ability to buy out the remaining shareholders and name his own directors, sources involved in the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Spy Dust on the Summit Road
description: There's a new, unwelcome entry in the glossary of diplomacy: nitrophenylpentadienal. It's the chemical the State Department says the Soviet Union uses to track diplomats in Moscow. That's a crude breach of the respect that civilized countries accord to diplomats, especially if the chemical is harmful. But the mysterious spy dust, like the White House's announcement of a new anti-satellite missile test, is a stage prop in a larger drama: President Reagan's meeting with the Soviet leader, Mikhail Gorbachev, in November.

title: Park Service Imposes New Beach Boys Ban
description: The Beach Boys have been banned again from the annual July 4 celebration at the Washington Monument, this time because the National Park Service wants ''a more family-oriented, traditional-type'' program, a spokesman said Wednesday.

title: 'Cheapside' Premiere
description: William Shakespeare, Christopher Marlowe and Robert Greene are among the characters in the play ''Cheapside,'' which will have its American premiere this weekend at the White Barn Theater, Newton Avenue, Westport, Conn.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CHARTER 77 SPEAKS OUT AGAIN
description: SEVENTEEN years ago this week, on Aug. 21, 1968, the armies of five Warsaw Pact countries entered Czechoslovakia to put a stop to the democratic renewal there. Since then, Aug. 21 has been a traumatic anniversary for us.

title: Carried Away Over Pigeons
description: Back in April, an article on this page identified Greg Bradsher in passing as the man at the National Archives who once discovered the entire history of the Army Pigeon Corps deep in the dusty files of Government. Reaction took a while, but last week an official of the American Pigeon Racing Association phoned from San Diego, said she had been searching for these priceless documents for years and announced she would fly to the capital next month to examine the whole nine cubic feet.

title: Lifters Lifted
description: Three Canadian weight lifters who had been scheduled to participate in next week's world championships in Sweden have been suspended from the national team for using anabolic steroids to improve their performances.

title: AN HEIR IS ACCUSED OF KILLING MOTHER
description: A man who stood to inherit millions of dollars from a tobacco fortune was arrested today and accused of murdering his mother and her adopted son by blowing up their car.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE Russian Tea Room is one of those places that are far more than the sum of their parts. If I were to cavil about every flaw in the food and service without consideration for its distinctive charm and dynamic atmosphere, the result would be a skewed portrait and a major disservice to this celebrated New York institution.

title: G.O.P. Claims Crossover Gain
description: With 54,000 changes in voter registration, the Republican Party claimed a qualified victory today in its ''open door'' drive, a 100-day, four-state blitz to get 100,000 registered Democrats to cross over to the Republican side.

title: ECI TELECOM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The U.N. Today: Aug. 23, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Palestinian Rights - 10:30 A.M.

title: Doctor's Orders
description: Joe Price, the Cincinnati Reds pitcher who has been plagued most of the season by a sore elbow, said he had been told he will need an operation, probably before the end of the season, to remove calcium deposits from the elbow. ''It'll probably be sooner than later,'' said Price after consulting a specialist, Dr. James Andrews, in Columbus, Ga.

title: Managing Partner?
description: Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Pittsburgh Pirates, said he was part of a group of investors who were trying to buy the financially-strapped team, which has been put up for sale by the Galbreath family. Tanner, who declined to identify the other investors, said his group had had some discussions with the Pirates' treasurer, Doug McCormick, and planned further talks. ''I think some progress has been made,'' he told The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette, ''but there's a long way to go.

title: Nassau Witnesses Say 1% Was a Gift
description: The Director of Employee Relations for Nassau County testified in Federal District Court today that he had never received a grievance from a county worker complaining that employees had to contribute to the Republican Party.

title: CONCERTS IN HUDSON VALLEY
description: Carrie Smith will be singing the blues tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Galli-Curci Theater in Margaretville, N.Y., in the sixth annual Hall of Fame jazz festival, one of several concerts in the Hudson Valley this weekend.

title: Who's on First
description: Historically, Democrats have generally favored fairly vigorous expansion of the nation's money supply to promote maximum economic growth. Most Republicans have tended to favor the Federal Reserve's erring on the side of monetary restraint because of their fears of inflation.

title: Tunisia on Military Alert For Attack by Libya
description: Tunisia put its armed forces on alert today in response to what diplomatic sources said was a Libyan threat to use military force in a widening dispute between the two North African countries.

title: IMMIGRANT FACTORY WORKERS SHARE DREAM, LUCK AND A LOTTO JACKPOT
description: In the end, the vision that tantalized millions of New Yorkers materialized for a group of men who had come to America in search of the American dream.

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: METALBANC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Searle Head To Quit Post
description: G.D. Searle & Company said yesterday that its chairman and chief executive, Donald H. Rumsfeld, will leave those posts after Aug. 31, in anticipation of Searle's $2.7 billion merger with the Monsanto Company. The company said Mr. Rumsfeld, a former Secretary of Defense, whose departure had been expected, will ''continue to assist in the transition'' for a period after he steps down.

title: HIGHER BID IS EXPECTED
description: The SCM Corporation's stock price jumped $1.125 a share yesterday, to $64.125, a day after the Hanson Trust P.L.C. said it would offer $60 a share for the chemical and typewriter company.

title: Block Warns of Farm Trouble
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today it may be necessary for some farmers to lose their businesses so the entire troubled farm industry can be freed from ''heavy-handed'' Government policy.

title: INFORMATION SOLUTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: N.B.A. Changing Its Draft Lottery
description: The seven-team National Basketball Association lottery, which decided the order in which the nonplayoff teams made their selections in the 1985 college draft and enabled the Knicks to select Patrick Ewing, will have a new format for the upcoming season.

title: LEACH GETS A LATE CALL AND TOSSES 3-HIT SHOUTOUT
description: It was 20 minutes or so to game time last night in Shea Stadium, and Terry Leach remembered it this way: ''I was sort of lying on the table in the clubhouse finishing up the crossword puzzle, and Davey Johnson came up and said: 'I hate to do this to you, but you're pitching.' ''

title: Worthen Bank Problems
description: The Worthen Bank and Trust Company violated Federal laws in lending money to companies owned by major shareholders, the Comptroller of the Currency said. The comments are in a prospectus published by the bank's parent company, the Worthen Banking Corporation.4 The prospectus says the Comptroller found Worthen Bank violated Federal laws by extending credit on preferential terms to entities jointly owned by Stephens Inc. and the Lippo Holding Company, both major shareholders of Worthen.

title: Stock Prices Show a Broad Decline
description: Stock prices closed broadly lower yesterday as two key economic reports indicated continued sluggishness in the economy.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Bomb Threat at La Guardia Shuts Terminal 50 Minutes
description: A bomb scare shut down the massive central terminal at La Guardia Airport for 50 minutes last night, inconveniencing thousands of travelers and affecting 31 incoming and outgoing flights.

title: People
description: Stephen D. Bowers has resigned as president of LeAnce/Herbert/Bower Public Relations and Advertising, Newport Beach, Calif.

title: SOVIET DENIES USING CHEMICAL TO TRACK AMERICANS
description: The Soviet Union denied today that it had used a potentially dangerous chemical in tracking the movements of Americans in Moscow and accused Washington of using the allegations to ''poison the atmosphere between our two countries.''

title: Dining for Practice
description: How do you open a banquet hall that can serve 2,500 people in a single sitting? Very carefully.

title: GEORGE E. CLARK
description: George E. Clark, retired president of the Adams Express Company, a general management and investment concern in Baltimore, died last Friday at the Cape Cod Nursing Home in Buzzards Bay, Mass.

title: Salvador Rebels Report Anti-Transport Raids
description: Leftist rebels said today that they had inflicted 109 casualties on Government soldiers during a three-day campaign to paralyze national transportaion.

title: Save the City's Water
description: NEW York's water crisis continues and the response of city officials is to arbitrarily restrict usage, exhort us to conserve, and pray for rain. When the drought eventually ends, water authorities ought not congratulate themselves on their handling of another crisis. What they should do is realize that universal water metering is the best long-term solution to New York's water problem and announce their intention to begin metering by the end of the decade.

title: Grassley and the Democrats
description: Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa was one Republican who got an assist from Ronald Reagan's presence at the top of the ticket in 1980 and unseated a popular Democrat, Senator John Culver. Since then, Iowa went Democratic in the 1984 Senate election and Mr. Grassley has become a major Democratic target when he seeks re-election next year.

title: RECOGNITION EQUIPMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MACROCHEM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LIBERIAN CITIBANK AIDE ON TRIAL
description: A international banking executive for Citibank, who is a leader of an opposition party in Liberia, went on trial yesterday on sedition charges in Monrovia, the Liberia capital, according to United Nations and State Department officials.

title: AFRICANS HOPE A COAT OF GREEN HERALDS A HARVEST
description: A threadbare coat of green now covers much of the landscape of the western Sudan.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Including a gain of $82,000 for the quarter and 6 monthe from the disposal of disocntinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $17,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $59,000. d-Including a gain of $352,000 from disocntinued operatins.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Spy Jurors Hear a Code Name
description: Jurors in the espionage trial of a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation learned today of the bureau's code name for the case, Whipworm.

title: Asian Bank Sets Bonds for U.S.
description: The Asian Development Bank announced plans yesterday to sell the first issue of yen-denominated bonds in the American capital market.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 23, 1985
description: Companies

title: THE U.S. BUSINESS ROLE IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Editor:

title: Man Indicted in Child's Death
description: A man who led a community search for his missing 13-year-old daughter was indicted today on charges of first-degree murder and sexual abuse in her slaying. The man, John Rairdon, 38 years old, also was indicted on charges of second-degree murder and second-degree sexual abuse of Sarah Ann Rairdon, whose body was found six weeks after she disappeared.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Arion Laboratories, Hyannis, Mass., a division of the Ariono Corp., has appointed Robert Livingston chief executive officer.

title: ALLY & GARGANO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses including the net effect of $405,000, or 18 cents a share, related to a bad debt writeoff. Revenue figure represent gross billings.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: The Big Two
description: Few football leagues anywhere have been so dominated by so few teams over the decades as the Big Eight, which explains why the results of the conference-sponsored summer football poll have, for the most part, been so thoroughly predictable since sportswriters and broadcasters were first asked 40 years ago to pick the next season's champion. Indeed, it has frequently seemed that the poll's voters are assigning the title rather than prognosticating it.

title: CITY TO SELL AUDUBON SET
description: New York City will sell a rare set of engravings by John J. Audubon at a Sotheby's auction in October, to raise funds for the city's Department of Records and Information Services, Mayor Koch announced yesterday. The city hopes to raise more than $1.2 million from the sale.

title: U.S. ASSERTS ITS PROTEST IS NOT AIMED AT TALKS
description: The United States said today that its protest over the Soviet Union's purported use of a possibly hazardous chemical to track the movements of Americans in Moscow was not intended to ''sabotage'' the summit meeting scheduled in November between President Reagan and Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: The Reagan Judges
description: THE growing apprehension about President Reagan's possible appointments to the Federal judiciary is puzzling indeed. The common criticism is that the appointments process is being corrupted by politics and ideology. For the first time, the argument goes, the Federal judiciary is in danger of being dragged into the muck and mud of American politics. In fact, history is hardly on the side of the President's critics.

title: Rooney, Pace Offer
description: The Rooney, Pace Group Inc. said that it had decided to extend for a second time its offer to swap its outstanding $25.7 million of floating-rate notes for a package of stock, convertible preferred stock and convertible notes. The offer has now been extended to Aug. 27. Rooney Pace said that as of yesterday, 75 percent of the notes had been swapped.

title: TOROMONT INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: Financial results for fiscal 1984 and 1985 have been adjusted to reflect changes in purchasing power of the Israel Shekel against the U.S. dollar. The dollar figures are at the rate of exchange at March 31, 1985, which is 858.5 Israel Shekels to the dollar.

title: Building the Next New York
description: On Dec. 15, 1973, New York City gave urban America a vivid illustration of two words. One was surprise, which is what the driver of a 10-ton asphalt truck must have felt when it suddenly fell through the elevated West Side Highway to the street below. He suffered minor injuries. For the highway, the accident was fatal, and introduced the other word, infrastructure. The busy thoroughfare, deeply decayed, had to be torn down.

title: MAN ACCUSED OF STARVING HIS MOTHER IS RELEASED
description: The police said they were forced Wednesday to drop murder charges against an Air Force sergeant accused of starving his mother to death because his actions violated no state law.

title: FARADAY LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $10 for the quarter and $83,550 for the year.

title: New Firearms Law Tougher on Criminals
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times;   Game Within a Game
description: In their rented house on Long Island, Rick Aguilera and Sid Fernandez might talk about shopping or commuting or maybe even their principal occupation, which is pitching a baseball. But just as likely, they are discussing their true passion in life, which is hitting a baseball.

title: DENNING MOBILE ROBOTICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company is still in the development stage and reported no revenue figures.

title: IN JAPAN, DREAMS YIELD TO REALITY
description: When Randy Bass comes to bat the people sing his name. They wave the big No. 44 flag - his number - and on each downbeat of his song they call out together, ''Bassu.'' When he came to play baseball in Japan three years ago, Bass would look out at the bleachers where the crowds were packed and where the chanting was most passionate, and be reminded of Saturday afternoons at home, when he would watch Oklahoma play football against Oklahoma State and everything in a game mattered so much.

title: Weaver's Wrath
description: Manager Earl Weaver of the Baltimore Orioles comes down hard on Tippy Martinez, who suffered a bout of wildness in Wednesday night's victory at Seattle: ''We brought in Tippy with the six-run lead so we could give him work, but he either complains about getting too much work or too little work. He can stand in the bullpen and throw strikes from the warm-up mound, but when he comes out to the field, he wasn't doing it. We may have used him badly since he's been in Baltimore, but he's certainly gotten paid well to be misused.''

title: Westside Bancorp Decision Soon
description: Federal regulators hope to decide within a week whether a conservator or a receiver should be named for the Westside Bancorporation, which has been left with a $29.5 million negative net worth after heavy losses, a spokesman for the Federal Home Loan Bank of Seattle said.

title: THRIFT UNIT RESCUE PLAN ADVANCES
description: A two-step rescue of Maryland's troubled Community Savings and Loan Associaton and its nationwide real estate syndication subsidiary was close to being proposed yesterday, investment banking sources said. They added that the first step of the bailout, if approved, could be achieved in two weeks - in time to prevent a default by the real estate subsidiary and a broader crisis in the mortgage-securities market.

title: Mexican Loan Accord
description: Treasury Secretary Jesus Silva Herzog plans to lead a delegation to New York next week to complete the rescheduling of $48.7 billion in principal payments on Mexico's foreign debt, the Treasury Department said today.

title: 3 CANDIDATES FOR MAYOR SPLIT ON HOUSING ILLS
description: There is a premise on which all three major candidates seeking the Democratic mayoral nomination can agree: New York City is in the midst of a housing crisis.

title: FIRE IN REMOTE ADIRONDACKS AREA BURNS OUT OF CONTROL FOR FIFTH DAY
description: A serious fire has burned out of control over 120 acres of forest wilderness on a mountainous ridge above Lake George for the past five days.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a credit of $7,440,000 for the settlement of litigation. Results for the latest periods include the operations of Generra Corp. acquired in the fourth quarter of last year.

title: STAGE: 'DROOD,' A MUSICAL IN THE PARK
description: WHILE it may be possible to imagine a more exciting show than ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' the jolly new musical at Central Park's Delacorte Theater, it's hard to picture a more democratic one. The audience not only gets to see this New York Shakespeare Festival extravaganza for free, but it also gets to help write the script's ending. ''Edwin Drood'' is a very loose adaptation of the half-finished novel Dickens left at his death in 1870. When Dickens's plot runs out in mid-Act II of the musical version, the audience ''solves, resolves and concludes the mystery'' by voting by voice and hand to a series of multiple-choice propositions.

title: PRE-PAID LEGAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Other Side Of Rose's Quest
description: Who is the most likely candidate to be the party of the second part, the man who delivers the pitch that Pete Rose then lines through the middle or skips through the hole or dribbles down the line for his 4,192d hit, the one that puts him ahead of Ty Cobb? Let's see if we can figure it out: Entering last night's play at Pittsburgh, Rose was 14 hits short of his goal. In the starting lineup only against right-handers, he had played in 90 of Cincinnati's 117 games this season and had hit safely 81 times, an average of 0.9 hits a game. At that pace, he would require 16 games, including the start against Rick Rhoden last night, to set the record.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday The faces seem stunned by a vision just out of view, haunted by a war barely out of mind. And yet the black and white portraits of people visiting the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington never show the memorial itself. They only record, in stark expressions, the reactions since 1983 of Americans confronting their recent past. The 13 photographs by Judith Ross are part of a new exhibition of the work of four young American photographers at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, that will be on display until Dec. 3. The exhibition of 40 photographs includes still lifes, technical experiments, and an autobiographical portfolio by Antonio Mendoza, a Cuban-born photographer. The other photographers represented are Zeke Berman and Michael Spano. Admission to the museum is $4.50 for adults, $3 for students, and $2 for the elderly. Weekend hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. today through Sunday. Information: 708-9400. This will be the last weekend to see an exhibition of eight large pieces designed to show the potential for ceramics in architecture at the American Craft Museum II at the International Paper Plaza, 77 West 45th Street. The museum is closing this Sunday after three years of exhibitions. A new Craft Museum is scheduled to open next year at 40 West 53d Street.
