The pieces on display are meant to demonstrate how ceramics can be used with rooms, doors and walls, and include a patterned tile floor, a satirical wall mural of a contemporary urban landscape, and a painted entranceway swirling with miniature nudes.

title: DISAPPEARANCES FROM BONN FUEL SPY-RING FEARS
description: A major spy scandal has begun unfolding in West Germany.

title: 54 DIE AS BRITISH CHARTER JET CATCHES FIRE IN MANCHESTER
description: Fifty-four people were killed today when a British charter jet burst into flames as it roared down a runway at Manchester Airport in northern England, then broke in two.

title: SIGNING OF 3 SYNTHETIC FUEL PACTS LIKELY
description: The Synthetic Fuels Corporation, struggling to stay alive as Congress weighs its extinction, said today that it expected to sign final contracts to commit $744 million on three projects in Colorado, Utah and Texas within the next three weeks.

title: Ford Attacker Denied Parole
description: Sara Jane Moore, who shot at President Ford in 1975, was denied parole Wednesday by the United States Parole Commission.

title: TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
ROSS STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
KEYCON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a pretax gain of $11.5 million from the sale of pretax assets of the company's residential door lock business.

title: AS TEXAS REPUBLICAN PARTY GROWS, SO DO RIFTS
description: For years the Republican Party of Texas had trouble getting anyone to run for office, but now it may have more candidates than it wants. Rifts are opening in the party as it is taking hold on once Democratic soil.

title: JACK GOODSTEIN, 84, OF BUILDING CONCERN IN NEW YORK, IS DEAD
description: Jack Goodstein, founder of the Goodstein Construction Corporation, which has erected more than 25 buildings in Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx, died Monday at Bellevue Hospital Center after he fell at one of his company's construction sites. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ad Pages Off, Spending Up Through July
description: The magazines that belong to the Publishers Information Bureau were collectively down 10.3 percent in advertising pages in July from the same month last year, to 9,467 pages. Monthly revenue was off by 8.6 percent, down to $308.9 million.

title: LIFE IN MOSCOW: EASE AND MISTRUST
description: For many foreigners living in Moscow, the allegation that a possibly dangerous powder is used to track their movements came as only another element in one of the world's more unusual environments.

title: Bush and the Conservatives
description: Alot of conservatives have never forgiven George Bush for running against Ronald Reagan in the 1980 Republican primaries, and some of the same people are not happy with the prospect that the Vice President may be the front-runner for the nomination to succeed Mr. Reagan in 1988. Take the memorandum from John T. Dolan, head of the National Conservative Political Action Committee, bemoaning the fact that Mr. Bush accepted an award as Republican of the Year earlier this summer from the Ripon Society, which he identifies as ''representative of the liberal Democratic wing of the Republican Party.''

title: PARTNERS OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sale of U.S. Stake in Conrail Faces More Hurdles
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee that must approve any sale of the Government's 85 percent interest in Conrail said that both the major offers for the carrier would have to be ''modified considerably'' to win committee approval.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Money Fund Assets Up
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds increased $1.91 billion, to $211.31 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, marking the largest weekly increase in two months, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Working Profile: Dr. Paula Stern;   Sisyphus Is in M*A*S*H, Fighting a Trade War
description: Her senior staff calls her ''the general.'' She calls her agency ''the M*A*S*H unit for America's economic casualties'' and ticks off numbers to show that at the front it's plenty hot.

title: BE-BOP ON EVERY CORNER AT VILLAGE JAZZ FESTIVAL
description: NEW YORK jazz fans are spoiled. Any time we choose, we can wander downtown and hear great musicians play three sets a night, at clubs where performers and audiences are sometimes just inches apart. The annual Village Jazz Festival simply makes it official; in a typical week, the clubs of Greenwich Village and environs - more jazz clubs per square foot than any other neighborhood in the world - offer enough first-rate jazz to compete with annual extravaganzas like Montreux and Kool. That is, for those who can afford the cover charges and minimums.

title: Kean Calls Session On Teachers' Pay
description: Governor Kean yesterday ordered the Legislature to return for a one-day special session Wednesday to force action on higher pay for teachers.

title: MEDIATION TALKS BROKEN OFF AT UNITED PRESS INTERNATIONAL
description: Talks to resolve contract problems between United Press International and the union representing its news workers broke off today, the Federal mediator said.

title: Addendum
description: Rose & Brosse Advertising announced that it was no longer a merger partner with Edwin Bird Wilson. The agency said it was now on its own, with offices at 171 Madison Avenue.

title: CARDS TRIUMPH ON BASES-LOADED WALK
description: The Houston Astros held a 1-0 lead going into the ninth inning tonight but St. Louis won the game, 2-1, helped by some timely substituting by Manager Whitey Herzog.

title: FAIR TO FEATURE FARM EVENTS
description: The Dutchess County Fair in Rhinebeck, N.Y., is offering hundreds of exhibits and contests this weekend featuring the agricultural aspects of life in the Hudson Valley.

title: Air-Traffic Inexperience
description: To the Editor:

title: Yugoslavia Reports AIDS
description: The press agency Tanyug said today that 10 cases of AIDS had been diagnosed in Yugoslavia. The 10, five men and five women, were identified after medical screening of 260 people from high-risk groups in Zagreb.

title: NORTH AND SOUTH KOREA AGREE ON FAMILY VISITS
description: North Korea and South Korea agreed today to allow 100 members of families separated by the Korean War to cross the border next month to locate relatives on the other side.

title: The U.S. Business Role in South Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Frantz Plan Loses
description: The Frantz Manufacturing Company said its board had rejected a $42.50-a-share leveraged buyout proposal from the S-F Group. It said the vote, 5 to 1 in favor, failed because of a unanimous vote requirement. Frantz said the negative vote came from Peter Fritzsche, a representative of EAC Industries, which is offering to acquire Frantz for stock.

title: Woman Shot to Death In Her Car at Red Light
description: A woman who stopped her car at a red light in Richmond Hill, Queens, was fatally shot at about midnight Wednesday by a man who tried to rob her, the police said. A suspect was arrested yesterday afternoon,and the police said he would be charged with murder.

title: What Senator D'Amato Knew
description: In the teeth of compelling court evidence, Senator Alfonse D'Amato of New York continues to insist he didn't know something that in the 1970's every Nassau County politician had to know: public employees who wanted to be hired or promoted in the county had to kick back 1 percent of their pay to the Republican Party, which controlled the county.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include 14 days of operations of the 449 Shop & Go Stores acquired in July.

title: GERBER SCIENTIFIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHERRY WEBB & TOURAINE SPEIALTY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Commissioner of Education Rules Girl May Play Football
description: New Jersey's Education Commissioner today upheld an administrative law judge's order that a 15-year-old girl be allowed on the football team at North Hunterdon High School this fall.

title: A NEW BREED OF CRIME FIGURE
description: When the customers of the Hole-in-the-Wall luncheonette at 115 Delancy Street got hungry, they sent out for food.

title: OLDEST LONG BEACH HOTEL TO UNDERGO CONVERSION
description: The history of this resort city by the sea - its rise, its decline, and its rebirth in the 1980's - has been intimately tied up with its hotels. The Paradise, the Nassau, the Royale, Waldman's Miami - they stood like surfside icons through the early part of the century, attracting the monied classes from New York, and capturing the spirit of an age of parasols, white tuxedos and jazz.

title: Consumer Prices Rose 0.2% in July
description: Consumer prices rose a moderate two-tenths of 1 percent in July for the third consecutive month, the Government said today. The increase means the Consumer Price Index has risen at an annual rate of just 3.5 percent for the first seven months of 1985, compared with 4 percent for all of 1984, the Labor Department said.

title: ZAHRINGER CAPTURES MET OPEN
description: George Zahringer 3d, a 32-year-old stockbroker, won the Metropolitan Golf Association's Open Championship today to become the first amateur to win that title and the Met Amateur in the same season.

title: The Slowdown At Restaurants
description: RESTAURANT sales, a discretionary spending item that analysts sometimes focus on to divine shifts in the economy, have been sagging lately. The downturn, which has occurred during the normally strong summer months, has had an impact on restaurant stocks and caused some analysts to revise their investment strategy toward the group.

title: COURT RESTORES 4 TO THE BALLOT FOR THE COUNCIL
description: An appellate court yesterday re-instated four City Council candidates in Brooklyn and Staten Island who had been ordered off the ballot because the cover sheets on their nominating petitions misstated the number of enclosed signatures.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Signed Tracy Jackson, guard.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about proposals to change New York State's election law incorrectly reported the candidates for New York City Comptroller in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary. The incumbent, Harrison J. Goldin, is opposed by Rafael Mendez and Dennis Speed.

title: NUMERAX INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: b-Includes a tax credit of $140,000 for the year-ago quarter and $946,000 for the year.

title: Investigators Cite Pilot Error In Fatal Puerto Rican Crash
description: Federal investigators have concluded that the crash of a Puerto Rican commuter airplane in which nine people were killed last year was caused by pilot error and other factors, including water in the fuel tank.

title: Australia Says Defoliants Did Not Harm Soldiers
description: An official study made public today has ruled out defoliants such as Agent Orange as factors in ill health among Australian veterans of the Vietnam War and their children.

title: JETS ACQUIRE 2 'BIG PERSONS'
description: The Jets, reacting to a seemingly endless string of problems on the offensive line, have acquired two veteran linemen and said they might possibly see action in the game Saturday against the Giants.

title: BANKS WATCH CORPORATE CASH
description: Until E. F. Hutton & Company pleaded guilty in May to overdrafting many of its bank checking accounts, a sort of laissez-faire attitude existed in the cash management relationships of many banks and corporations.

title: 'BIKO' FILM SHOWN AT U.N.
description: ''The Biko Inquest,'' a film based on the inquest into the 1977 death in detention of Steven Biko, the leader of the black consciousness movement in South Africa, was shown here today under the auspices of the General Assembly's Special Committee Against Apartheid and the Secretariat's Center Against Apartheid.

title: TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
City's Reservoirs Drop Below 50% Capacity
description: New York City's reservoirs dipped below 50 percent capacity yesterday for the first time in the current drought.

title: DIM PROSPECTS AT ARLINGTON
description: It almost seems appropriate that the Arlington Million at Arlington Park outside Chicago Sunday is being run at a track that was largely destroyed by a fire earlier this month. The race was thoroughbred racing's first $1 million event when it began five years ago, but now its appeal, prestige and credibility are dimming and its future is uncertain.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Fact of Life
description: Roger Stroman, a member of the Saudi team in the Little League World Series, a squad made up primarily of children of Americans working in the Middle East, reflects on a blown 5-1 lead and a resulting semifinal loss: ''It hurt to come so close. But the boys take it better than the parents do.''

title: Drug Reports Berated by Green
description: Dallas Green, president of the Chicago Cubs, called stories linking two of the team's pitchers, Steve Trout and Dennis Eckersley, with illegal drug use in 1982 ''unfair to my players'' and ''not a big deal.''

title: Evening News Says Sale Is a Possibility
description: The Evening News Association, which owns The Detroit News, said yesterday that it had notified its shareholders that it might be necessary to sell all or part of the company to provide the holders with the highest possible price for their shares.

title: VITALITY UNLIMITED reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SOME CALL BIG LOTTO REVENUE NO BOON TO SCHOOLS
description: Leaders of the education committees in the State Legislature said yesterday that extra lottery revenues did not necessarily mean more money for education because the state's budget for education was fixed.

title: YANKS' STREAK ENDS AT SEVEN
description: The Yankees' winning streak came to an end tonight when the pinch-hitter Bob Boone, who did not start because of a slightly pulled groin, singled to left field with two out in the bottom of the ninth to score Bobby Grich from second base for a 3-2 California Angels victory.

title: Mostek Layoffs
description: United Technologies Corporation's Mostex Corporation said it is laying off, effective Friday, about 500 additional employees because of the semiconductor slump. Layoffs will cover salaried and hourly employees in all areas at Mostek's headquarters and main manufacturing facility in Carrollton, cutting employment there from 3,000.

title: MEL LEWIS AND QUARTET
description: The drummer Mel Lewis will lead a quartet tonight and tomorrow at the Angry Squire, 216 Seventh Avenue, below 23d Street (242-9066). Live music begins at 10P.M. and continues until 2 A.M.; there is a $6 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: Natwest Seeks U.S. Brokerage
description: The National Westminster Bank P.L.C. of London said yesterday that it had applied to the Federal Reserve Board to set up a United States securities brokerage operation to function alongside its American banking unit.

title: Aerojet Contract
description: The Army said it would cut back research on an airborne optical sensor for the ''star wars'' anti-missile program to avoid a projected $100 million cost overrun by the Boeing Company, the prime contractor. The Strategic Defense Initiative office said the cutback would cause the termination of most of the work planned at the Aerojet Electro-Systems Comcontract from Boeing. The Hughes Aircraft Company, another subcontractor, will continue research on the optical sensor.

title: SHIFT IN ROLES AT THE RANCH
description: President Reagan's summer trip to California this year has spotlighted changes in how the vacation White House operates in the second term and how the roles of key players have shifted.

title: AS 21 MORE DIE, LEBANON MAKES PLEA TO SYRIA
description: As 21 more people were reported slain in continuing artillery duels here, the Lebanese Cabinet appealed to Syria today to help stop the killing.

title: PANSOPHIC SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SCREEN: 'CROSSOVER DREAMS'
description: ''Crossover Dreams'' was shown as part of the 1985 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 29. The film opens today at the Cinema Studio 1, Broadway and 66th Street.

title: GREENPEACE CASE: NEW FRENCH LINK
description: A woman suspected of having infiltrated the environmental group Greenpeace before a ship belonging to the group was bombed in New Zealand last month was identified in the French press today as an officer in the French external intelligence agency.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: HIDDEN ART TREASURES IN THE CITY
description: FOR someone who writes about art, years of visiting monuments, galleries and museums is likely to build a reservoir of ideas. Many of the ideas find issue in print. Most of those that don't revolve around art that is not contemporary. For one thing, contemporary art is the main subject for someone who writes regularly. For another, most conspicuous American art since Abstract Expressionism has been defined by its desire to question and distinguish itself from earlier art. Yet those other responses and ideas connected to older art never go away, never lose their urgency, never stop shedding light on the way the present is perceived.

title: FOLK CELEBRATION AT LINCOLN CENTER
description: When the composer Charles Ives was a youngster, he and his father used to enjoy hearing the sound of several different marching bands, all playing different tunes, converging on the town square. The organizers of the Folk Heritage Celebration at Lincoln Center on Sunday aren't planning to present the same sort of cacophony, but at noon, around the fountain in Lincoln Center Plaza, fiddlers, pipers and other performers will be strolling around, offering simultaneous solos, perhaps engaging in a few spontaneous jam sessions.

title: 20TH SHUTTLE SET TO GO TOMORROW
description: The countdown began this morning for the 20th space shuttle mission, planned as an eight-day flight to deploy three communication satellites and to try to activate a dormant satellite stranded in orbit last April.

title: BROADWAY
description: THE biggest pushovers for the ''sudden big chance in show business'' stories are theater people themselves, probably because there's always the back-of-the-mind niggle that says, ''It could happen to me.'' It almost never does, but almost isn't never, and here's one that did.

title: U.S. WINS WALKER CUP BY CLOSE MARGIN
description: Scott Verplank, the United States Amateur champion, edged Colin Montgomerie of Scotland, 1 up, at Pine Valley Golf Club today. Moments later Bob Lewis, a 40-year-old reinstated amateur from Ohio who once played professionally, finished off a 4 and 2 victory over Cecil Bloice of England.

title: Disappointing Temperance
description: The Soviet leader Mikhail S. Gorbachev's recent campaign against alcohol consumption is beginning to have a noticeable effect at his nation's diplomatic receptions here.

title: HAL Publications Names a Publisher
description: HAL Publications has named Charles S. Bullock publisher of Success! magazine, succeeding Henry W. Marks, who announced he was stepping down last week.

title: Attorneys for Plaintiffs Object to Robins Filing
description: A number of attorneys for women who are suing the A. H. Robins Company for injury from its intrauterine birth control device objected yesterday to the company's filing for bankruptcy protection.

title: CONTINENTAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
THE EVENING HOURS
description: IN assorted off-key notes rarely heard in Avery Fisher Hall, Gerard Schwarz's family and friends gathered in the Adagio Cafe after a Mostly Mozart concert to sing ''Happy Birthday'' to the conductor. ''We brought along the whole gang,'' his mother, Gerta, announced as she introduced her husband, her two daughters (''No. 1 Daughter, No. 2 Daughter''), her daughter-in-law, a son-in-law and grandchildren.

title: KEY IMAGE SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
Sallie Mae Is Offering Dual-Currency Bonds
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering 50 billion yen of dual-currency bonds in the European market and $100 million of notes in the Japanese bond market.

title: Advice for the Annoyed
description: When there are strange noises, silence, childish jokes or lewd questions at the other end of the line, do not discuss the call, even with friends.

title: State Senator and 3 Others Are Arrested as Squatters
description: State Senator Thomas J. Bartosiewicz and three members of a squatters group were arrested last night for breaking into an abandoned city-owned building in the East New York secton of Brooklyn, the police said. Senator Bartosiewicz was also charged with harassment after he ''struck and officer,'' according to Officer Robert Fitzpatrick, a police spokesman.

title: BRIEFS
description: American Airlines said that it would institute a $2.50 surcharge for passengers boarding at Boston's Logan International Airport, in response to a 5-cent-a-gallon fuel tax imposed by the city of Boston.

title: Of Races, Straits, Fjords, Rias, Estuaries and Great Jones Street
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: AFTER LOTTO DRAWING, DUBIOUS VICTORY CLAIMS
description: The telephones in the New York State Lottery offices were ringing all day yesterday with calls from England, Chicago, Des Moines and the Bronx, from people who falsely identified themselves as the winners of the $41 million Lotto jackpot.

title: EARLY AMERICANA
description: A free presentation of American music, dance and humor based on works from early to the mid-1800's will be offered by the Capricorn Theater Company today at 5 P.M. in the plaza at Lincoln Center. the event is part of Lincoln Center's Out of Doors series, which runs through next weekend. The group will present an excerpt from ''Music in the Western Country,'' written by Paul C. Echol, director of the theater company. Information: 877-1800

title: SCREEN: 'TEEN WOLD,' WITH MICHAEL J. FOX
description: ''TEEN WOLF,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, is a high-school comedy about a young man, a sweet-natured nonentity, who gains small-town celebrity and power when he discovers that he's a werewolf. For Scott Howard (Michael J. Fox), being a werewolf doesn't mean baying at the moon and chewing on the necks of former friends. It means that, when he wills it, he can turn into a werewolf who's a star basketball player and much in demand as a prom escort.

title: Mindless Babble in the Air
description: I like to ride in airplanes and always have. Like the Midwestern kids whose nighttime imaginations were fueled by the whistle of a distant locomotive, I, as a teen-ager, entered the arms of Morpheus on many occasions with my mind dreamily transfixed on the control panel of a DC-7.

title: MUSIC ON 'HOT SUNDAYS'
description: On a stage bedecked with red plastic bags hanging like balloons, a group of musicians played accordions, electric guitars, metal-plank drums, Asian temple blocks and maracas. The leader whistled and invited members of the audience to join in. Four hours later, the group of five had become a small orchestra.

title: Dining Out Guide: Chelsea
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: FOR LOTTO WINNERS, SPREAD IS FROM $13 MILLION TO $23
description: The holders of 113,670 tickets won prizes in Wednesday night's Lotto drawing, ranging from the $13,666,666 for each of three tickets that shared the jackpot to $23 for the tens of thousands of tickets that won fourth place, state lottery officials announced yesterday.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego Padres, at Shea Stadium, doubleheader, 5:35 P.M. Opener of a four-game series. (Television -Channel 9, 5:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 5:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Mariners, at Seattle, 10:35 P.M. Opener of a three-game series. (Television - Channel 11, 10:30 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 10:30 P.M.) St. Louis Cardinals vs. Braves, at Atlanta. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M.) Little League World Series, at Williamsport, Pa. Through Saturday. Boxing Gary Hinton vs. Joe Manley, 12 rounds, for Hinton's United States Boxing Association junior welterweight title, at Atlantis Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City. First preliminary, 8 P.M. This is the second defense for Hinton, from Philadelphia, who is 23-3-1 with 10 knockouts. Hinton fought Aaron Pryor in March for Pryor's International Boxing Federation title and lost on a split decision. Manley, from Atlantic City, is 22-3 with 13 knockouts. (Television - Madison Square Garden, 10 P.M.) Golf N.E.C. World Series of Golf, at Firestone Country Club in Akron, Ohio. Second round. (Television - USA, 4 P.M., live. 9 P.M.) L.P.G.A. National Pro-Am, at Lone Tree Country Club and Meridian Golf Club in Denver. Second round. Tennis Bobby Riggs and Vitas Gerulaitis vs. Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver, at Atlantic City Convention Hall, 9 P.M. Executone Hamlet Challenge Cup, at Jericho, L.I. Through Sunday. Shearson Lehman Brothers Eastern Clay Court Championships, at Old Field Tennis Club, 400 Greenlawn Road, Greenlawn, L.I. Through Sunday. Virginia Slims of Central New York, at Kutshers Country Club, Monticello, N.Y. Other Events EQUESTRIAN: $200,000 United States Cup, at Commonwealth Park in Culpeper, Va., 8 P.M. Forty riders are expected for this United States Grand Prix circuit event, which has the largest purse in the history of show jumping.

title: Mental Mistake Leads to Defeat
description: A last-inning mental lapse by the Morristown (Tenn.) shortstop allowed the winning run to score, giving Mexicali, Mexico, a 2-1 victory today and creating the first all-foreign Little League World Series final.

title: INDIA SAYS IT WILL GO AHEAD WITH VOTE IN PUNJAB SEPT. 25
description: The Indian Government announced tonight that it would proceed with elections in Punjab next month despite warnings that the balloting might prompt new assassinations and violence in the state.

title: U.S. CLERICS DEBATING ETHICS OF GIVING SANCTUARY TO ALIENS
description: Although providing sanctuary to those in danger is a tradition as old as the Bible, religious leaders are debating whether American churches and synagogues are justified in harboring aliens from Central America.

title: FAIR LANES inc reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $23,000 for the quarter and $684,000 for the year and extraordinary credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $8,986,000 for the year from the exchange of debt and tax credits.

title: PACE MEMBERSHIP WAREOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to July 21
description: b-Net income including tax credits of $82,000 for the quarter and $53,000 for the 6 months. Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

title: NAVY IS SHUFFLING ITS TOP LEADERSHIP
description: An extensive shuffling of the Navy's leadership began today with the reassignment of one admiral and the nomination of three vice admirals to become admirals and to receive new posts.

title: Together on Cloud Nine
description: The camaraderie was similar to that of the November evening in 1965 when the lights went out all over New York City. And of that morning in February 1982 when New Yorkers awoke to find that a snowstorm had turned the city into a vast crystal bowl.

title: CONSULTANT AND BARMAID ALSO BIG LOTTO WINNERS
description: He is a computer consultant. She is a barmaid. And Wednesday they each won $13.6 million.

title: ZYGO CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
GENESEE BREWING CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
STAR-GAZING AND -GRAZING
description: Beware, all notables traveling to Washington: Celebrity Service International has come to town and will be watching your every move in the capital city.

title: SUIT ON BOMBING DISMISSED
description: A judge dismissed a suit filed by William Kunstler, the activist lawyer, seeking a grand jury investigation and coroner's inquest into the police bombing and ensuing fire that killed 11 members of the radical group Move. Judge Alfred J. DiBona Jr. of Philadelphia Common Pleas Court dismissed the lawsuit Thursday, according to a spokesman for the District Attorney's office. Mr. Kunstler filed the suit June 25 on behalf of Louise James, who was the mother of one of the victims and who owned the house in which the group had its headquarters, and a local civil rights activist, Stanley Branche.

title: Grains of Salt for Indonesia's View of East Timor
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE CASE OF JAPAN
description: Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, addressing the Senate July 9 on a bill approved by his committee to require the President to counteract Japan's reputed failure to open its markets to American imports:

title: SYRIA SPONSORED CEASE FIRE BRINGS A RESPITE FOR BEIRUT
description: A Syrian-sponsored cease-fire went into effect today, bringing a pause - however temporary - in one of the worst rounds of factional fighting here in years.

title: STRIKE AT CORNELL MARS RECEPTION OF STUDENTS
description: Hundreds of service and maintenance employees went on strike at Cornell University today, complicating the arrival of students for the fall term.

title: U.S. WEIGHS PUBLIC ROLE IN REPORTING ESPIONAGE
description: Senior American intelligence officials, worried by the apparent ease with which spies penetrated American security, have been debating the establishment of an anonymous hot line and reward system to encourage public reports of suspicious activities, the Army's chief of counterintelligence said today.

title: LEISURE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After a loss of $40,000 for the quarter and a gain of $280,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months from extraordinary items. c-Including income of $10,000, or 1 cents a share, for the quarter and $110,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 9 months from extrordinary items. d-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: The clue in the crossword puzzle yesterday for 48 Down contained an incorrect reference to the author of ''Joe Egg.'' The play was written by Peter Nichols.

title: COPTERS SPOTTING WATERERS
description: Summonses for illegally watering lawns have been given to 15 homeowners as a direct result of helicopter surveillance ordered by Mayor Koch 10 days ago, the City Environmental Protection Department reported yesterday.

title: SPACEMATES
description: >While David A. Stockman, the former director of the Office of Management and Budget, is waiting to move on to the Wall Street firm of Salomon Brothers, he has taken up temporary working quarters with an old friend, Lawrence Kudlow.

title: SAUDI PRINCE DONATES $250,000 TO AILING BOY
description: A Saudi Arabian prince donated $250,000 to a family for a 14-year-old boy to undergo a triple transplant operation, family members said.

title: Skeptic Blasts Tape Measure
description: Paul Susman recently advanced the proposition (Sports World Specials, Aug. 19) that a home run hit by Mickey Mantle off Paul Foytack 25 years ago in Detroit was the longest wallop in major league history. Already, though, that idea has found at least one knowledgeable doubter.

title: EARLY PAYOFFS OF MORTGAGES
description: MANY banks and other major lenders are encouraging homeowners these days to repay their mortgages early. The lure lies largely in the fact that the total interest payment will be much less than when the loan is carried to maturity.

title: Carter Clears Waivers
description: Anthony Carter cleared waivers from the United States Football League and will don a Minnesota Viking uniform today.Carter, who caught 70 passes this year for the Oakland Invaders in his third U.S.F.L. season, agreed last week to a five-year, $2 million contract with the Vikings of the National Football League.

title: Cauthen Unhurt As Horse Falls
description: Steve Cauthen escaped injury today when his mount went down midway through a race at Goodwood.

title: ICAHN GETS CONTROL OF T.W.A.
description: Carl C. Icahn, the New York investor, won one of the largest prizes in corporate takeover history yesterday when he increased his stake in Trans World Airlines to 50.3 percent, assuring him of control of the nation's fourth-largest carrier.

title: RX FOR FEES: U.S. OUTLOOK
description: If the Federal Government adopts a fee schedule for physician services to Medicare patients, it could dramatically alter the economics of medicine and the behavior of physicians, health policy experts say.

title: GREENHOUSE JAZZ
description: The jazz singers Marion Cowings and Kim Shaw will give a free concert tomorrow at 3:15 P.M. at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue. Information: (718) 622-4433.

title: Medical Research Isn't Making Us Healthier;   Animals Have No Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: ROLFITE CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
YOUNG CHAMPION'S 'OVERNIGHT' SUCCESS
description: Awaiting the music for her floor routine, hands resting on hips, Sabrina Mar's fingertips almost touch across her narrow, black-clad waist. Surrounded by other elite-class female gymnasts, at 5 feet tall and 88 pounds, Miss Mar is the slenderest of the slender, a picture of elongate grace.

title:
PATENTS;

Pocket Terminal Used For Secured Banking
description: A pocket banking terminal and the method of its operation have been invented for the Atalla Corporation, a company in San Jose, Calif., specializing in electronic security. Patent 4,536,647 was granted this week to Martin M. Atalla, founder and chairman, and Ralph R. Bestock, a member of the engineering staff.

title: ALL THE WORLD'S A TENNIS COURT
description: And we each have our entrances and exits in the tournament of life. Mine began officially in the early Thirties when I was entered in summer camp in Vermont. It was a time when trains still carried people and the world had a slower game. It was still called - with some validity -lawn tennis, and tended to be played by gentlemen in long white pants and ladies in white pleated skirts.

title: MID-AUGUST AUTO SALES FELL
description: New-car sales for Aug. 11-20 were down 4.6 percent from the comparable period last year, the manufacturers reported here today. Sales of light trucks slipped 2.6 percent from last year.

title: CONTINENTAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SCM Board Sets Meeting on Offer
description: The SCM Corporation said its board will meet Sunday to consider a $60-a-share offer by Hanson Trust P.L.C. for all of SCM. The chemical and typewriter company has so far declined to comment directly on the offer from the British conglomerate.

title: A FUTURE FOR THE DISABLED
description: A thousand special New York State citizens graduate each year without ceremony and with little hope. They are the mentally disabled over 21 years old who are cut off abruptly from services and, for most, from the chance for a productive future.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CHICAGO (NL) - Activated Steve Trout, pitcher, and placed Dave Gumpert, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list.

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax provision of $3,200,000 for the anticipated loss on the company's investment in Seabrook Unit II.

title: Bell's Stockholders Back Guinness Bid
description: Arthur Guinness & Sons P.L.C. claimed victory today in its battle to acquire the Scotch whisky producer Arthur Bell & Sons P.L.C. for $518 million.

title: E-H INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $325,000 for the quarter and $1,477,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income including gains from discontinued operations of $303,000 for the quarter and $849,000 for the 9 months.

title: Adirondacks Fire Is Enclosed With Line Dug by Volunteers
description: Firefighters completed a two-foot-wide fire line around an Adirondack Mountain forest fire today and struggled to control more intense sections of the blaze, officials said.

title: A Cemetery Remembrance, With Volunteers' Help
description: One elderly woman visited the graves of her husband, her parents and her in-laws. Another visited her niece's grave. And a third put flowers next to the stone of a friend whom she had cared for 20 years ago.

title: SCITEX CORPORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: CARNEGIE HALL TO HOLD PHONE-A-THON
description: Carnegie Hall will hold a radio subscription drive on Sunday, Sept. 8, offering brief interviews with musical artists interspersed with excerpts from their recordings, from 3 to 7 P.M. on WNCN, 104.3 FM.

title: TECHNICAL COATINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Baseball Strike: Palooka Solidarity's Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Nortek Raises Transway Offer
description: Nortek Inc. has increased its takeover proposal for the Transway International Corporation to $298 million, from $265 million.

title: Computerland Attempt To Appeal Is Eased
description: The Computerland Corporation said today that a California court has cleared the way for it to appeal a decision that awarded partial ownership of the computer store chain and $141 million in damages to a group of outside investors.

title: LSI LIGHTING SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings have not been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split payable August 30.

title: Layoffs at G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said its Truck and Bus Group will lay off about 1,100 hourly workers next month because of softening demand for heavy- and medium-duty trucks and city buses.

title: STANLEY J. REIBEN, DEFENSE ATTORNEY AND ADVISER, DIES
description: Stanley J. Reiben, special counsel to Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink and chief defense attorney in the celebrated George Whitmore murder case, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: COURT KILLS F.C.C. RULE FAVORING WOMEN AS OWNERS OF FM STATIONS
description: A 1978 rule of the Federal Communications Commission granting women an advantage in competing for FM radio broadcasting licenses was struck down today by the Federal appeals court here.

title: MUSTANG DRILLING & EXPLORAION reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: 6 BLACKS KILLED IN SOUTH AFRICA DURING A PROTEST
description: The South African police shot and killed six black protesters, detained at least 18 prominent political activists and rounded up 500 black schoolchildren today.

title: METS LOSE 2 AND DROP OUT OF FIRST
description: On an evening when the offense withered, the Mets took the big plunge last night before 45,156 fans in Shea Stadium when they were swept in a doubleheader by the San Diego Padres and fell into second place, one game behind the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: William Tenebruso, Advertising Executive
description: William Tenebruso, senior vice president and director of corporate media services of Kenyon & Eckhardt, a Manhattan advertising agency, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the home of his fiancee in Cos Cob, Conn. Mr. Tenebruso, who was 44 years old, had recently moved to Greenwich, Conn., from Manhattan.

title: ANIT-SANDINISTAS VOW TO CUT ABUSES
description: Political leaders of the Nicaraguan rebels have decided to spend time in the field talking with rebel commanders and fighters in an effort to halt what they acknowledge are summary executions and other human rights abuses, according to one of the leaders.

title: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Yr to March 31
description: Results for fiscal 1984 and 1985 have been adjusted to reflect changes in purchasing power of the Israel Shekel against the U.S. dollar.The dollar figures are at the rate of exchange at March 31, 1985 which is 858,5 Israel Shekels to the dollar. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: No Headline
description: Supersecrecy and Supercomputers

title: TORTURE AND MURDER TIED TO SURVIVALIST GROUP STUN A NEBRASKA FARMING COMMUNITY
description: The Farm Belt's bucolic image is sometimes sundered, as it has been this week in this tiny southeast Nebraska community, where residents have only begun to absorb accusations of torture and murder on a local farm.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Athletics World University Games, in Kobe, Japan. The first day of this biennial competition, in which Matt Biondi, who has broken three world records in swimming in the last month, will be competing against the Olympic gold medalist, Michael Gross of West Germany, in the 200-meter freestyle. Baseball Mets vs. San Diego, at Shea Stadium. 7:35 P.M. (Television -Channel 9, 7:30 P.M. Radio -WHN 1050, 7:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Seattle, 10:05 P.M. (Television -SportsChannel, 10:00 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 10:00 P.M.) St. Louis Cardinals vs Atlanta Braves, at Atlanta, 7:40 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 7:35 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 7:25 P.M.) Detroit Tigers vs. California Angels, at Anaheim, Calif., 3:20 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 3:15 P.M.) Little League World Series, at Williamsport, Pa. The championship game will match Mexicali, Mexico, against Seoul, South Korea, in the first final not involving a United States team in the 39-year history of the tournament. (Television - Channel 7, 4 P.M.) Football Jets vs. Giants, at Giants Stadium, 8 P.M., exhibition game. The Jets, without a victory, take on the Giants, without a loss. (Television - Channel 11, midnight. Radio -WMCA 570, 8 P.M. WNEW 1130, 8 P.M.) San Diego Chargers vs. 49ers, at San Francisco, 3 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 3 P.M.) Miami Dolphins vs. Raiders, at Los Angeles, 9 P.M. (Television -Channel 4, 9 P.M.) Golf World Series of Golf, at Firestone Country Club, Akron, Ohio.

title: A JERSEY DIVESTITURE'S IMPACT
description: When average investors sell a stock, they simply phone a broker and tote up their profit or loss. But when a giant state pension fund, taking an ethical stand on a critical social issue, decides to unload some $2.6 billion worth of securities, there is much more at stake.

title: Q-MED INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
A STUDY OF FOOD BUYERS REVEALS SHIFTS IN TASTES
description: For more than a decade the Food Marketing Institute has been tracking the major trends and attitudes of supermarket shoppers. The surveys, called Trends, conducted by Louis Harris & Associates for the trade association of the wholesale and retail segments of the food industry, offer a comprehensive overview of the changes that have taken place in the last 11 years. Comparing the findings of the first study in 1974 with this year's shows how the public's concerns have shifted.

title: COAST SHERIFF SAYS 14 KILLINGS LINKED
description: A killer who has terrorized suburbs in both Southern and Northern California has now been linked to at least 14 slayings and possibly as many as 33 attacks, the Los Angeles County Sheriff said tonight.

title: UGANDA REBELS REPORT SURRENDER OF ARMY UNITS
description: Uganda's biggest rebel group said today that several army units had surrendered to its forces in towns north of Kampala.

title: DATA-DESIGN LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated for the acquisition of A.J. Electronics in March 1985.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SATURDAY, AUGUST 24, 1985
description: International

title: FLIGHT INTERNATIONAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: SCREEN: 'THE PROTECTOR,' FEATURING JACKIE CHAN
description: Jackie Chan, one of Asia's most popular stars, plays the title character in ''The Protector,'' although he protects no one and leaves about 100 corpses in the process. ''The Protector,'' which opened yesterday at the Gramercy and other theaters, attempts to move Mr. Chan into Clint Eastwood territory; he plays Billy Wong, an action-prone New York City policeman who takes plenty of lumps as he dispatches bad guys in New York and Hong Kong harbors.

title: U.S. TEAM ON MISSING PUTS OFF TRIP TO HANOI
description: A United States delegation scheduled to meet with Vietnamese officials to discuss the fate of missing American servicemen postponed its departure for Hanoi today after learning that Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach would not be present for the meetings next week.

title: IN SEARCH OF SATORI
description: RANSOM. By Jay McInerney. 280 pages. Vintage Books. $5.95. When Jay McInerney's first novel, ''Bright Lights, Big City,'' came out last year, it almost immediately became one of the season's publishing phenomenons. Set in the margins of Manhattan's literary community, the novel was acclaimed as a hip portrait of the artist as a young man, and as it became a best seller, stories about the 29-year-old author began appearing everywhere, from Interview magazine to Advertising Age. Mr. McInerney was photographed in trendy Joan Vass outfits, interviewed about his life and hailed, variously, as a gifted new writer, as a ''voice of his generation,'' and as the consummate yuppie success.

title: A $20.04 Billion July Deficit
description: The Federal Government said yesterday that it posted a $20.04 billion budget deficit in July, pushing the total red ink above last year's mark, with two months to go in the fiscal year.

title: FARRELL PUT BACK ON PARTY BALLOT
description: Brushing aside ''technicalities,'' a state appellate court yesterday ordered Assemblyman Herman D. Farrell Jr. reinstated to the Sept. 10 Democratic primary ballot for mayor. It also reinstated four candidates for City Council president.

title: PIEDMONT NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $770,541.

title: FANS RIDING HIGH ON HOPES OF A SUBWAY SERIES
description: The World Series belongs, of course, in New York.

title: CERTAIN DEALS OFFER A VARIETY OF THE ELEMENTS OF THE GAME
description: It is not only bridge students who like simple hands, with one clear-cut problem to solve; their instructors have the same preference. They look for a deal that shows in pristine purity a finesse, an end play, a squeeze or a counting problem.

title: SOUTH AFRICANS PROTEST ACTION AGAINST STUDENTS
description: Religious leaders, local officials and community activists in various black townships say police officers have been taking increasingly repressive measures against student protesters.

title: 15-SECOND COMMERCIALS ARE BLOSSOMING ON TV
description: The 15-second commercial, the sales pitch that is here and gone in a virtual blink, has moved one step closer to wide acceptance on the three television networks, according to broadcast industry and advertising officials.

title: MONEY, ACT I
description: Political action committees, those special interest groups sponsored by business and labor that help finance campaigns of favored political candidates, declined in number in the first six months of 1985, from 4,009 to 4,000, according to a report by the Federal Election Commission. While the decline was modest, it was the first since the commission began keeping records of these groups in 1974.

title: GREEK VASES ON DISPLAY
description: An exhibition of 65 ancient Greek terra-cotta vases will open Sept. 14 at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: AN OBSCURE ROAD TO THE OPEN
description: As construction workers were putting up vending booths and technicians were testing the new scoreboard inside Louis Armstrong Stadium at the United States Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Glen Layendecker sat in the locker room waiting to start his first match in his quest to qualify for the United States Open.

title: A DISASTROUS RAIL MERGER
description: To an old railroader, it comes as a shock that, with the ardent support of the Reagan Administration, two giant railroad companies - Consolidated Rail Corporation and Norfolk Southern Corporation - could merge. If this happens, it would be a bonanza for Norfolk Southern and a disaster for Conrail. For the public, it would be a serious and costly blunder.

title:
PATENTS;

Patent Office Asking Congress to Raise Fees
description: The Patent and Trademark Office announced this week that it has proposed raising its fees, effective Oct. 5.

title: AUTOMATIC DATA PROCESSING INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Why Greeks Are Angry
description: To the Editor:

title: KEWAUNEE SCIENTIFIC EQUIPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a net gain of $330,000 from the sale of assets and business.

title: Goodrich Plant To Be Closed
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that it will close its 40-year-old tire-manufacturing plant here in February, idling 1,900 workers. The plant makes tires for farm equipment, off-the-road vehicles and trucks.

title: POLICE CHIEF IS CHARGED IN DEATH OF HIS OFFICER
description: The suspended police chief of the community of Iola was charged today with first-degree murder in the shooting last month of his only full-time officer.

title: LEISURE DYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $164,000.

title: YANKS' NIEKRO WINS NO. 296
description: The Yankees, who had flexed their muscles in California, scored just three runs tonight off a rookie pitcher with less than three months of major league experience. But that was enough to give the Yankees a 3-1 victory over the Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome.

title: PATENTS Substitute For Bony Tissue
description: IMPLANTABLE porous devices that can be used as bone or hard tissue anywhere in the body were patented this week for Medical Biological Sciences Inc. of New York. The inventors named in the two patents are Dr. Arthur Ashman, a rehabilitative dentist, and Paul F. Bruins, a retired chemical engineering professor of the Polytechnic Institute of New York.

title: F.B.I. CHECKS AIDES' CONDUCT IN 3-YEAR INQUIRY OF PRESSER
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is conducting an internal inquiry into possible wrongdoing by its agents in the abortive investigation of Jackie L. Presser, law-enforcement officials said today.

title: Western Airlines Joins Fare War
description: Western Airlines, rebounding from five years of losses, has joined a West Coast fare war that could make a substantial dent in expected profits if it lasts long.

title: Battle of the Sexes a Dud
description: The much ballyhooed battle of the sexes was no contest tonight, as Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver routed Bobby Riggs and Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-2, 6-3, 6-4.

title: MERWIN H. SILVERTHORN
description: Lieut. Gen. Merwin Hancock Silverthorn, a former assistant commandant of the Marine Corps, died Aug. 14 at Bethesda Naval Medical Center.

title: QUAKE IN WESTERN CHINA IS REPORTED TO KILL 55
description: An earthquake in western China near the Soviet border killed 55 people, flattened wooden houses and severed communications, the Chinese seismological bureau said today.

title: STATE AIDES CALL SCHOOL DISTRICT DISCRIMINATORY
description: The State Education Department said today that the Sewanhaka Central High School District in Nassau County had discriminated against students on the basis of race, sex and handicap.

title: AN UNMANNED U.S. SPY PLANE CRASHES ON SALVADORAN PEAK
description: An unmanned United States spy plane crashed into a mountain in eastern El Salvador today while gathering information on rebel movements for the Salvadoran military, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: Summit Health
description: Summit Health Ltd. said it had signed a three-year, $33 million contract with the Ministry of Health of Saudi Arabia to manage five 100-bed hospitals. Summit plans to assume management of the Saudi hospitals in September and now has an office and program director in Riyadh.

title: MONEY, ACT II
description: The Folger Shakespeare Theater, rescued from a tragedy of its own when the trustees of its parent Folger Shakespeare Library reversed plans to close it down, has been constituted as a separate entity, thereby presumably assuring that it has not reached its last age, sans everything.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: RADIO RENT PARTY WKCR, Kings College Radio, Columbia University's FM radio station, has the distinction of setting the pace for presenting jazz on radio hereabouts. When appropriate - observing birthdays, marking deaths -the entire catalogue of a musician's recorded work is presented on the air, hour after hour, as long as it takes.

title: ANDUJAR GETS 20TH AS CARDINALS WIN, 6-2
description: Joaquin Andujar became the first 20-game winner in the major leagues this season as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Atlanta Braves tonight, 6-2.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are not trying to oppress people, but are doing this for their own benefit.''

title: Frontier Plan Advances
description: Frontier Holdings Inc. said today that the four labor unions of its subsidiary, Frontier Airlines, had completed the ratification of a new contract that it described as ''a major step'' in an employee buyout of the company. Shareholders will vote this fall on the $17-a-share plan. Frontier is raising $265 million in asset sales, partly through the sale of planes, to finance a large share of the buyout.

title: When a Felon Who Killed No One Is Treated Like a Murderer
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSOCIATED COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $88,026 for the quarter and $168,620 for the 6 months.

title: CLASSIC FILMS
description: Screenings continue this weekend in the Almi Classics Film Festival at the Festival Theater, Fifth Avenue at 57th Street. Today, an uncut version of Nicolas Roeg's ''Man Who Fell to Earth'' will be shown.

title: Letter: On the Federal Budget;   Hiding Behind Social Security Surplus
description: To the Editor:

title: MANVILLE CAN SUE U.S., JUDGE RULES
description: In a decision hailed yesterday by the Manville Corporation, a Federal judge ruled that the company could sue the Government to recover asbestos-related damages it paid to a naval shipyard worker.

title: BURGLARS STEAL A CRIME-FIGHTING ROBOT
description: Hero, a robot that is supposed to scare off burglars by saying: ''Warning, intruder! I have summoned the police!'' was caught sleeping on the job and stolen while its owners were on vacation, the police said today.

title: FLOATING POINT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Comings and Goings
description: Cliff Branch, 37-year-old wide receiver of the Los Angeles Raiders, was placed on injured reserve with a hamstring problem, diminishing his chances to make the team. . . . Ray Childress, a defensive end from Texas A&M who was the Houston Oilers' first-round draft choice, reached agreement on a contract that will reportedly pay him $1.85 million over four years. . . . Barry McGuigan, the World Boxing Association featherweight champion, has rejected lucrative offers to stage his first title defense in London; Birmingham, England; Glasgow, Scotland, or New York and will instead defend his title against Bernard Taylor of Knoxville, Tenn., in Belfast, Northern Ireland, Sept. 28. . . . Cedric Henderson, the 19-year-old Georgia basketball star who was declared academically ineligible for the 1985-86 season after winning reinstatement following suspension for his involvement in a recruiting violation, has given up on a collegiate career and has signed to play with a Milan team in the Italian Basketball League. . . . Richard Johnson, the former Wisconsin cornerback, signed a four-year, $1.7 million contract with the Houston Oilers.

title: DANCE: 'EYE OF THE GARDEN'
description: There have been many kinds of music, theater and dance presented in Creative Time's ''Art on the Beach'' summer series on the Battery Park Landfill. Each has, in varying measure, responded to that extraordinary setting of dunes, river and skyscrapers. One of the most sensitive responses has been ''The Eye of the Garden,'' a work by Lenora Champagne, Claudia Fitch and Glen Velez, performed on Wednesday.

title: SULLIVAN COUNTY CHAIRMAN IS INDICTED FOR VOTE FRAUD
description: The chairman of the Sullivan County Board of Supervisors was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of submitting forged write-in ballots that may have allowed him to win re-election in 1983.

title: GUSTAV JACOBY
description: Gustav Jacoby, a New York lawyer for 50 years, died Tuesday on vacation in Montreux, Switzerland. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the Metropolitan Open incorrectly attributed the quotation, ''My mind made promises my body couldn't keep.'' The golfer quoted was the runner-up, Bruce Douglass.

title: A GAMBLE FOR GANDHI
description: Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, stepping up his efforts to end the turbulence and bloodshed in the Punjab, has begun what associates say might be his most dangerous political gamble since he took office 10 months ago.

title: A Special Agony
description: For a while, at least, it's going to be hard for Richie Conway to take much satisfaction from the outstanding contribution he made in getting his Morristown, Tenn., team to the semifinals of the Little League World Series. Obscuring the memory of his 11 tournament victories on the mound and the .500 batting average that made him the team's dominant player will be the awful image of what happened in the sixth inning of the semifinal game against Mexicali, Mexico, Thursday when the 12-year-old boy, playing shortstop, tagged a runner at second to complete a double play.

title: STEEGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
SPARTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: T.V.A. SHUTS DOWN LAST NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority closed the last of its operating nuclear plants yesterday and stopped welding work on one that is under construction. The moves were part of an effort to address persistent management problems that have cast doubt on the safety of the authority's nuclear program, the nation's second largest.

title: CARBIDE ASSERTS STRING OF ERRORS CAUSED GAS LEAK
description: The large leak of toxic gas from a Union Carbide factory near here two weeks ago resulted from violations of plant procedures and other failures left uncorrected by plant workers for up to 10 days before the accident, company officials said today. They accepted full blame for the incident.

title: AUTODESK INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
5 SET TO RIDE SHUTTLE INTO SPACE TODAY
description: Five American astronauts are ready for the 20th flight of a space shuttle to deliver three communications satellites to orbit and make a bold attempt to revive another satellite already in orbit.

title: RATES ON U.S. ISSUES UP A BIT
description: Interest rates on Treasury debt issues rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday.

title: ALGOREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: STOCKS CLOSE MIXED AS DOW EDGES UP 0.22
description: Stock prices were narrowly mixed yesterday in slow pre-weekend trading as investors again failed to find any encouraging economic news.

title: STRATFORD FESTIVAL IN ONTARIO REACHES FOR SUCCESS
description: The unlikely beginnings of the summer drama festival here can be traced to a bitter, economically-sapping chicken pluckers' strike 33 years ago. City fathers at that time figured they could at least capitalize on the town having been named for Shakespeare's birthplace by a 19th-century booster.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BARRIER SCIENCE & TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Christo's New Wrapping in Paris
description: PARIS, Sept. 23  It was the best of times to be by the Seine. Over the weekend, sailboats were out in force, rainbowed with spinnakers. The excursion boats had never done such a trade. People were standing five and six deep on the Pont des Arts, the beloved footbridge downstream from the Pont Royal, and staring upstream. Motor cruisers went putt-putt, the all-but-naked sunbathers toasted themselves on centenarian stones, and even vagrants got onto their feet to see what was going on. They all got their money's worth, and not least the Mayor of Paris, Jacques Chirac, who came down on Sunday from the Hotel de Ville to thank Christo, the Bulgarian-born artist long resident in New York, for what he had done to enliven the city.

title: Murdoch Plans Bond Swap
description: Bondholders with $1.45 billion in debentures from the Metromedia Broadcasting Corporation will be given a chance to swap them for cash, preferred stock or a combination, according to Rupert Murdoch, chairman of News America Holdings.

title: FORTUNES CONTRAST FOR GIANTS AND JETS
description: When the Jets and the Giants first met in an exhibition game, Weeb Ewbank, the Jets' coach, announced that they were battling for the bragging rights to New York.

title: MAINTENANCE REVIEWED AT AMERICAN AIRLINES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration is in the final stages of a special investigation into maintenance practices at American Airlines, the nation's second largest passenger carrier, an F.A.A. offical said today.

title: BATHERS WARNED ABOUT POLLUTION AT JERSEY SHORE
description: Red flags have gone up along five miles of popular beaches off Wildwood Island in southern New Jersey, warning swimmers that raw sewage has been discharged into Atlantic Ocean waters.

title: FOR DISABLED, COMPUTERS ARE CREATING NEW LIVES
description: Once forced to rely on others to read, write or speak for them, about 20,000 people across the country are now using specially adapted personal computers to help make up for their disabilities.

title: SAVING ON UTILITY EXPENSES
description: THE New York State Public Service Commission has come up with a new board game called ''Play to Win: How to Save Money on Your Utility Bill.'' It is not nearly so much fun to play as Trivial Pursuit or Dungeons and Dragons or Monopoly, but it could help consumers save money on their utility bills.

title: Carol Kramer, Executive, Is Wed to Daniel Brachfeld
description: Carol Kramer, a vice president and management supervisor for McCaffrey & McCall Direct Marketing in New York, was married yesterday to Daniel Brachfeld, president of the DB Development Company, a suburban office-park developer in Fairfield, N.J. Rabbi Joel Goor performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of Dr. Norman Brachfeld, brother of the bridegroom.

title: EAC Reports Frantz Settlement
description: EAC Industries said it and the Frantz Manufacturing Company of Sterling, Ill., had settled lawsuits pending in both Delaware and the Federal District Court in Chicago regarding control of Frantz.

title: E. Richard Barnes, 79, Dies; Former California Legislator
description: E. Richard Barnes, a former California Assemblyman who denounced President Richard Nixon's historic trip to China as ''suicidal idiocy,'' has died at the age of 79.

title: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CONCERT: GRANT JOHANNESEN
description: It is hardly a secret that Mozart influenced Chopin greatly, and revealing evidence of this was provided in the pair of Mostly Mozart concerts at Avery Fisher Hall Monday and Wednesday. Chopin's Variations on ''La ci darem la mano,'' from Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' were performed by the pianist Grant Johannesen and the Festival Orchestra under the direction of Gerard Schwarz.

title:
PATENTS;

Cable Decoupling Eases Unloading of Air Cargo
description: Equipment and techniques for safely unloading cargoes from helicopters or other aircraft are described in a patent granted this week to Edwin Z. Gabriel, who heads an engineering consultant firm in Ocean Grove, N.J. Patent 4,536,024 describes hoist cables that can be decoupled quickly with minimum personnel.

title: CHEMLAWN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
Elizabeth Strode Wed To Robert Douglas Jr.
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ash Strode, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hildreth Hubbard Strode of Bronxville, N.Y., to Robert Lee Douglas Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas of Charlotte, N.C., took place yesterday in North Salem, N.Y. The Rev. Richard L. Leonard of the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York performed the ceremony at the Hammond Museum.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
HOPES ARE SCARCE IN HOPEFUL STAKES
description: They're giving away something called a ''handsome gold tone stainless steel keychain watch'' at Saratoga today, a horseshoe-shaped fob the size of a quarter that tells time. Fans may find it handy to bring it back on Sunday and use it to time the Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds. The giveaway watch is hardly a precision instrument, but this year an hourglass would suffice to clock what is surely the worst bunch of youngsters in a decade to contest the historic Hopeful.

title: BUFFALO'S MAYOR GRIFFIN IN CROWDED PRIMARY FIGHT
description: In Danny Zack's saloon the other night, Jimmy Griffin was having a few beers with some friends.

title: Taiwan Textile Accord
description: Taiwan said today that it had reached an agreement that would end a ban on the export of some textiles to the United States. The agreement, signed in Washington on Thursday, would allow Taiwan to export wool dresses, woven fabrics and cotton underwear to the United States, an official said. Exports of pillows and bedsheets were still banned, he said.

title: ENEX RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $221,000.

title: CREDO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ANOTHER THRIFT FREEZE IN MARYLAND
description: Maryland Governor Harry R. Hughes yesterday imposed a 60-day ban on most withdrawals from the First Maryland Savings and Loan, after officials of the thrift institution said its liquidity was in jeopardy.

title: RESERVOIRS STILL FALLING WITH NO END IN SIGHT
description: New York City's reservoir levels are expected to fall steadily over the next two months to as low as 30 percent of capacity, water officials said yesterday.

title: CIRCLE K CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest quarter include 14 days of operations of the 449 Shop & Go Stores acquired in July.

title: FORSTMANN MTV DEAL COLLAPSES
description: Warner Communications Inc. and Forstmann Little & Company said yesterday that they had ended two weeks of complex negotiations over Forstmann's offer for MTV Networks Inc.

title: No Headline
description: Companies Carl C. Icahn won control of T.W.A. The New York investor told the S.E.C. he has 50.3 percent of the company's shares, putting him in charge of the nation's fourth-largest airline. In addition, sources close to the situation said that Texas Air, Mr. Icahn's rival for T.W.A., had withdrawn its merger proposal, removing the largest potential block to his smooth assumption of control. Labor unions, which had feared a takeover by Texas Air, played an important role in the two-month-long struggle over the airline. [Page 31.] Union Carbide officials accepted full blame for a gas leak two weeks ago at an Institute, W.Va., plant. The company said there were violations of plant procedures by workers. [A1.] Unocal plans to refinance the $4.1 billion in debt that it took on in fighting off the takeover attempt by T. Boone Pickens. The company will buy back the notes it issued to shareholders, transferring the debt to banks and other investors at a lower interest rate. [31.] Forstmann Little and Warner Communications ended their MTV talks. Forstmann had twice extended the deadline on its $470 million offer for Warner's share of the music video service. Talks with other bidders are expected, with Viacom being mentioned most prominently. [31.] Manville can sue the Government to recover some asbestos damages the company paid, a Federal judge ruled. The ruling in the case of an injured naval shipyard worker may be an important step in Manville's efforts to get the Government to help pay the huge asbestos claims it faces.

title: MAYOR FEINSTEIN VETOES $8.8 MILLION IN rAISES
description: Mayor Dianne Feinstein has vetoed a labor contract that would have given $8.8 million in raises to women and members of minority groups employed by the city.

title: Pantry Pride's Plan for Revlon
description: Pantry Pride Inc. told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that if it succeeded in its $1.8 billion takeover of Revlon Inc., it would sell everything except the cosmetics business. It said it thought it could raise between $1.7 billion and $1.9 billion in the sales and might also sell Revlon's foreign operations.

title: Audit Finds Cranston '84 Bid Misspent Funds in Campaign
description: Senator Alan Cranston's campaign for the 1984 Democratic Presidential nomination improperly spent $12,454, nearly half of it in penalty charges for 736 bad checks, the Federal Election Commission says.

title: McNeilab Loses Tylenol Decision
description: A Federal judge ruled that a subsidiary of Johnson & Johnson cannot recover from its insurance company the $50 million it lost after the painkiller Tylenol was temporarily pulled from the market when seven people died of contaminated capsules in 1982. Distict Judge Frederick B. Lacey ruled that McNeilab Inc. was not insured against the loss by its carrier, the Affiliated FM Insurance Company.

title: 'PROTECTING THE PRESIDENT'
description: The Secret Service agent who helped capture John W. Hinckley Jr. after the 1981 attempt on President Reagan's life tells in his account of the incident that he had more trouble with helpful or angry witnesses to the shooting than with the gunman himself.

title: CONSOLIDATED FIBRES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary item of $132,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and the year. c-Including extraordinary items of $193,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and $581,000, or 29 cents a share, for the year.

title: CHERRY WEBB & TOURAINE SPEIALTY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Japan Crash Insurance
description: At least $27.5 million in accident insurance, the largest amount for a single accident in Japan, will be paid to victims of the crash of a Japan Air Lines plane 11 days ago, the Marine and Fire Insurance Association of Japan said today.

title: CONCHEMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Including a gain of $82,000 for the quarter and 6 monthe from the disposal of disocntinued operations. c-Net loss after a loss of $17,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $59,000. d-Including a gain of $352,000 from disocntinued operatins.

title: No Headline
description: Pearson C. Cummin 3d may seem an unlikely venture capitalist. In an industry preoccupied by computers, genetic engineering and other new technologies, his background is in marketing dog food, breakfast drinks and wine.

title: Virlana Tkacz Is Wed
description: Virlana Tkacz, a director and stage manager for La Mama Experimental Theater Club, and Watoku Ueno, a set designer for La Mama, were married yesterday at the Municipal Building in New York. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jaroslaw Tkacz of Maplewood, N.J. She graduated from Bennington College and received a Master of Fine Arts degree in theater directing from Columbia University. Mr. Ueno, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tokushige Ueno of Nakama, Fukuoka, Japan, graduated from the Sokei Academy of Fine Arts in Tokyo.

title: LLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,853,000 for the quarter and $2,798,000 for the year and an extraordinary credit of $1,932,000 for the year.

title: 13 Rescued From Gondola
description: Thirteen visitors to Daytona Beach were rescued by the Fire Department Thursday after a gondola ride at the Main Street Ocean Pier broke down, stranding the riders 100 feet above the sand. No one was injured. Officials said an electrical failure had caused the breakdown.

title: EX-C.I.A. CHIEF DOUBTS SOVIET POWDER REPORT
description: Adm. Stansfield Turner, the Director of Central Intelligence from 1977 to 1981, today questioned the Reagan Administration assertion that the Soviet Union began in 1976 to track American diplomats' movements with a potentially harmful powder.

title: Middle South
description: Middle South Utilities Inc. said a Federal appeals court had affirmed a lower court ruling prohibiting the Arkansas Public Service Commission from interfering in Grand Gulf Nuclear Station contracts that are exclusively in Federal jurisdiction. Middle South said the court had decided that the commission, seeking to cancel the agreements in order to deflect rate increases, would shift the burden to Mississippi and Louisiana, where Middle South has other units. Middle South said the agreement bars the commission from interfering with arrangements covering $2.1 billion in Grand Gulf financing.

title: FRIENDS' LETTERS PRAISE SPY SUSPECT
description: Supporters of Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy radioman charged with spying for the Soviet Union, have pledged nearly $250,000 in bail money, his lawyers said today.

title: AMERICAN SHARED HOSPITAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: COLORADO LISTS THOSE EXPOSED TO AIDS VIRUS
description: Over objections from the American Civil Liberties Union, the Colorado Board of Health has tentatively agreed to begin keeping a list of people who have been exposed to the virus that causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: ALLY & GARGANO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net losses including the net effect of $405,000, or 18 cents a share, related to a bad debt writeoff. Revenue figure represent gross billings.

title: ATTACKS ON SALVADOR CIVILIANS STRAIN TIES IN REBEL ALLIANCE
description: Relations between the political and military wings of the Salvadoran rebel coalition have grown more tense in recent months, but the continued alliance between the leftist parties and armed guerrilla groups is not threatened, according to senior rebel political officials.

title: Par for a Mother
description: Nancy Lopez recalls feeling the pangs that only a mother can know when, in a departure from habit, she left her young daughter in New York with daddy, Ray Knight of the Mets, instead of taking her along to a recent golf tournament: ''It was really strange not having her around. I had a lot of extra time on my hands and didn't know what to do with it. I found myself pushing things out of her reach even though she wasn't there.''

title: How to Contain A Million OTB Slips
description: Every day, the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation churns out a million betting slips. Every year, it also hands out about 30,000 trash-can liners and 100 trash cans to merchants' associations and community groups.

title: U.S. HAD ORDERED ENGINES MODIFIED
description: The Federal Aviation Administration ordered modifications last year in the type of engine that is said to have caused a fatal fire aboard a British Airways Boeing 737.

title: Hitting Frontier
description: This has been a year of quiet bats in the minors, and so it was especially surprising to find, in the Aug. 12 issue of The Sporting News, that one Walt McConnell of the Great Falls Dodgers was leading the Pioneer League with an average of .679. As it turned out, that figure was a mistake by 247 points, in McConnell's favor. The following week, the newspaper put matters right, but this time it listed another Great Falls player, Mike White, at .619, far better than the actual .350 that had already earned him a promotion from that rookie team to Los Angeles's Class A club at Bakersfield.

title: SORRY, WAMPUM FULL UP
description: It's been a successful summer on historic old Wampum Island, where success is measured by the number of automobiles transported from the mainland by the island ferry. Figures are not available, but everybody knows it's been a record season because Wampumburg, the island capital, has been paralyzed by gridlock from 11 A.M. to 10 P.M. most days since the middle of June.

title: The Disability Victory's Painful Price
description: The Reagan Administration's functionaries gave it a bland, abstract name: ''nonacquiescence.'' To the rest of the world the policy toward disabled people looked like lawless cruelty, and this week a Federal judge finally forbade it. That's an important victory, but it permits only restrained cheering. While the ruling demonstrates the residual power of the courts to remedy injustice, the case also illustrates the damage possible by an executive branch bent on flouting the law.

title: Medical Research Isn't Making Us Healthier;   Wrong Target of Ire
description: To the Editor:

title: Identity Crisis
description: Coach Dan Reeves of the Broncos assesses Ken Woodard, who is being asked to fill in for one very prominent but injured Denver linebacker: ''Is he a Tom Jackson? No. But neither was Tom Jackson when he came into the league.''

title: SPORTS COMPLEX GENERATES $1 BILLION AND RESPECT IN FORMER SWAMPLAND
description: By the time Bruce Springsteen completes his rock shows at Giants Stadium Aug. 31, the Meadowlands Sports Complex here will have counted as many people through its turnstiles during the last two weeks of the month as live in Cleveland.

title: FED PANEL BACKED REIN IN JULY
description: The Federal Reserve Board's senior policy committee decided in July that it would clamp down on the growth in the nation's money supply if it kept growing at the extremely rapid pace of May and June, according to the minutes of the meeting released today.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aeronca Inc., Charlotte, N.C., maker of aircraft and aerospace structures, said a management group is considering making a leveraged buyout proposal to the company's board at a price of $5.875 a share.

title: Del Mar Track Cancels Racing
description: Officials at the Del Mar race track canceled the Saturday race card after the United States Border Patrol raided the track early today, arresting about 100 illegal aliens working as stablehands.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. A winning New York State lottery ticket was purchased by a pool of 21 workers in Mount Vernon, N.Y., most of them recent immigrants, who signed a contract stipulating that they would share the jackpot, if any of their tickets won. 2. The use of cocaine by at least eight players on the team. 3.
