New York estimates that it gets $32 in Federal aid for every person counted by the Census Bureau, and recent studies show a population increase of 78,646 from 1982 to 1984, more people than any other city in the country. 4. Japan. 5. The United States accused the Soviet Union of using the powder as an aid in tracking the movements of Americans and possibly other foreigners in Moscow. 6. Senator Paul Laxalt, a key supporter of President Reagan in the Senate and one of the President's closest friends, announced that he would not seek re-election. 7. American theatrical producers are increasingly looking to London as a city in which to try out shows that may eventually come to Broadway. 8. He won the Travers Stakes at Saratoga, a leading test for 3-year-olds. 9. Criticism by the Reagan Administration over his refusal to attend a meeting between church leaders and President P. W. Botha of South Africa. 10. It was written by President Reagan, the first such endorsement he has given while in office. 11. In the New York City mayoral race, a Federal District Court judge ordered that the name of Herman D. Farrell Jr. be restored to the ballot, a decision subsequently overturned by a State Supreme Court justice. 12.

title: Boyd Is Back
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd, the Red Sox pitcher who stormed out of the Boston clubhouse Wednesday night vowing never to return, was back in uniform for last night's game against the Minnesota Twins in Boston after missing the game Thursday against the Texas Rangers. Boyd, who was docked two days' pay, rejoined the team after meeting with club officials, who said he had apologized for the walkout, which he attributed to frustration after giving up 10 hits in a 5-3 loss to the Rangers Wednesday night. He had left the clubhouse after a heated postgame exchange with the team captain, Jim Rice.

title: THE BOOM IN RADAR DETECTORS
description: Their makers call them aids to safer driving. Their advocates say they are a defense against entrapment. But to many law enforcement officials, they are simply tools to break the law.

title: When New York Means Getting Away From It All
description: Visitors may love New York for many reasons. But Joao Perry loves it for privacy.

title: BASIC EARTH SCIENCE SYSTEMS reports earnings for 1985
HAZLETON LABORATORIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $78,000 for the quarter and $171,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $297,000 for the quarter and $964,000 for the year. d-Net loss.

title: Aouita Sets Mark In 1,500-Meter Run
description: Said Aouita of Morocco, fighting pain from an injury, added the 1,500-meter world record tonight to his 5,000-meter mark. He then announced he would attempt to set three more world records before the end of the season.

title: U.S. FILES A RIGHTS SUIT ON VOTING IN CAROLINA
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had filed a civil suit charging that the Darlington County system of at-large council elections violates the Voting Rights Act and discriminates against black residents.

title: Medical Research Isn't Making Us Healthier
description: To the Editor:

title:
PATENTS;

Plane System Controls Flight Path and Speed
description: A flight control system for aircraft, patented for the Boeing Company in Seattle, is being used to replace the traditional functions of the pitch autopilot computer and thrust control computer.

title: MUSIC: BEAUX ARTS TRIO PLAYS FOR MOSTLY MOZART
description: The Beaux Arts Trio is such an established, beloved musical institution that even at somewhat less than its best, and in the really too large expanse of Avery Fisher Hall, the group attracted an overflow crowd and provided considerable pleasure Thursday night, in the last of this summer's Mostly Mozart chamber-music programs.

title: BRITISH AIRWAYS DENIES KNOWING OF A POSSIBLE 737 ENGINE PROBLEM
description: British Airways said today that it had not been told of the results of an American investigation into the reliability of aircraft engines of the type implicated in an airliner fire in northern England.

title: A HUDSON CRUISE
description: A cruise up the Hudson River on the Hudson Dayliner with the poet and musician Gil Scott-Heron and his band Amere Facade is planned tonight.

title: The 'Perfect' City Tree Takes a Subway Ride
description: A bushy four-foot-tall Brassaia actinophylla, better known as a Queensland umbrella tree, stood proudly in the Times Square subway waiting for the No. 1 local. Its owner, Julie Webster, hovered protectively.

title: VERPLANK RECEIVES EXEMPTION BY PGA
description: In an unprecedented move, Scott Verplank, who became the first amateur to win a regular PGA Tour event in 29 years when he captured the Western Open on Aug. 4, has been given an exemption as an amateur for all pro tour events through 1987.

title: Trade Deficit Up in Britain
description: Britain suffered its biggest trade deficit in a decade last year, with shortfalls in every commodity but oil, the Government said today.

title: Figures Not Festive
description: When the National Sports Festival ended its 10-day run in Baton Rouge, La., earlier this month, officials estimated that the event, billed as a tuneup for the 1988 Olympic Games, had lost $180,000.

title: ANALYST OUTLINES GIFTS TO G.O.P.
description: A statistical analyst testified today that in 1977 only 3 percent of the employees working for Nassau County contributed to the county Republican Party.

title: QADDAFI PLANS TO ATTEND CEREMONIES AT THE U.N.
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, plans to visit New York this fall to take part in ceremonies marking the 40th anniversary of the United Nations, a spokesman said today.

title: Taxing the Reader
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST GERMAN AIDE IN ESPOINAGE POST IS SAID TO DEFECT
description: A top-ranking official in West Germany's counterintelligence agency was reported today to have defected to East Germany.

title: Young Takes Job
description: As expected, Tom Young, the Rutgers basketball coach whose team competed in eight postseason tournaments in his 12 seasons, accepted an offer to become head coach at Old Dominion, replacing Paul Webb, who resigned to become an assistant athletic director of the Virginia school.

title: UNOCAL MAY REFINANCE ITS $4.1 BILLION DEBT
description: The Unocal Corporation, which took on $4.1 billion in debt in May to fight off a takeover attempt by T. Boone Pickens, said yesterday that it plans a refinancing to retire that debt.

title: ON GUATEMALAN CAMPUS, THE FIRST TEST IS SURVIVAL
description: The rector of the University of San Carlos here is out to set an unusual record. He would like to be the first head of the school to finish a term in office since 1978.

title: Westinghouse Deal
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that it had acquired the Gladwin Corporation of Taylor, Mich. Gladwin services continuous casters for the steel industry.

title: BEDFORD COMPUTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TAX CREDITS
description: To the Editor:

title: HERE'S LOOKING AT US
description: Do you have a vision of how the earth looks from above? Can you capture it in a drawing, a painting, a piece of sculpture, a model, anything except a photograph?

title: EAST HILLS OFFICIALS BATTLE OVER PAPER
description: THE Mayor of East Hills is accusing village officials of trying to censor the village newspaper, while some local officials and civic associations maintain that the Mayor has been abusing his power.

title: Kansas Police Are Seeking 3 In Abduction of State Trooper
description: Two men and a woman abducted a highway trooper at gunpoint today and left him, an elderly couple and their son bound but unharmed in a farm house, officials said.

title: OKLAHOMA IS NO. 1
description: THE 117th college football season opens this week like many of the recent campaigns - in an atmosphere of suspicion and scandal. Three of the stronger teams are serving punishments for violations in recruiting some of the athletes who helped them earn national rankings.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: AFRO-AMERICAN FOLKTALES: Stories From Black Traditions in the New World. Edited by Roger D. Abrahams. (Pantheon, Cloth, $22.95. Paper, $11.95.) In this sequel to his 1983 volume, ''African Folktales,'' Roger D. Abrahams has culled stories from American and Caribbean collections. Taken together, these tales reveal a world view marked by a gritty sense of realism. The good do not often triumph; the bad are inevitably more interesting character types. From creation myths to coded tales in which plantation masters are outwitted, the stories range across the heritage of an African past planted and tilled in the minds of slaves and their descendants. Mr. Abrahams's introduction traces the history of the tale collectors themselves, paying special tribute to Joel Chandler Harris, whose Uncle Remus and Brer Rabbit tales, he concedes, had racist undertones. Nevertheless, Harris rendered the exploits of animals with human qualities in a literary style quite close to the oral traditions out of which they came. Mr. Abrahams is not romantic about how the tales changed in their passage through the years and from Africa to the New World. Praise songs, epics and long genealogical recitations did not transplant. Perhaps this accounts for the more entertaining qualities of the previous collection; the immediacy of the mother culture gave the African folk tales more vivid moments. These Afro-American stories evince a survivor's sensibility, not without humor. The ones from urban America crackle with raw emotion. I was particularly struck by ''The Signifying Monkey,'' a trickster tale cast as a long tone poem.

title: SOMETIMES A REVIVAL IS MORE REWARDING THAN A PREMIERE
description: These days, many ballet companies have lots of interesting dancers but few interesting ballets.

title: MEN AND WOMEN OF LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MAN IS SEIZED IN BURGLARIES BY USE OF A POOL SKIMMER
description: A 28-year-old Long Island man was charged yesterday with a series of burglaries in which he was said to have used a long-handled swimming pool skimmer to reach through the windows of houses.

title: OFF THE BOARD, ONTO THE SCREEN FOR CLUE
description: Over the years movies have been adapted from novels, plays, comic strips, popular songs, even sex manuals. But ''Clue'' may be the first movie based on a board game.

title: Art
description: ''Japanese Ghosts and Demons: Art of the Supernatural,'' at the Asia Society Galleries, 725 Park Avenue, through next Sunday, is as irresistible as the title of the exhibition would lead us to believe. Through 100 prints, scrolls, screens, netsuke and sculptures, from the 17th through the 19th century, the show has assembled some of the more ferocious and engaging ghouls and goblins in Japanese art.

title: BETHLEHEM PINS HOPES ON MUSIC
description: While sneaking through the thick black oak and hemlock forests for a suprise attack on this settlement in 1755, the marauding Indians were panicked by what was for them an unearthly sound: the Moravian Trombone Choir.

title: Helen A. Ix Is Married
description: St. Mary Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Helen Adele Ix, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edward Ix of Greenwich, to Daniel Manning FitzPatrick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Anthony FitzPatrick of Plattsburgh, N.Y. The Rev. Mark Connolly, assisted by the Rev. Martin Hitchcock, performed the ceremony.

title: Carbide Issues Report on Leak
description: State and Federal inquiries are still under way, but the Union Carbide Corporation last week said it had concluded that a combination of human errors and equipment failures had probably caused the leak of toxic gases at its chemical plant in Institute, W. Va., on Aug. 11.

title:
ART;

UMBRIA'S BEAUTY INSPIRES ARTISTS
description: UMBRIA, the area of central Italy between Florence and Rome, along with neighboring Tuscany, has for centuries attracted untold numbers of artists. Although a sojourn in these picturesque provinces is no longer considered mandatory among American painters, the region still holds a special fascination, particularly for those inspired by gentle landscapes and luminous atmosphere.

title: Californian Has Organs From Separate Donors
description: Doctors at the University of California at San Francisco say a 51-year-old man has become the first person in the world to live with organs transplanted from two separate donors.

title: DEATH OF A BIG LOBSTER
description: A 30-inch-long 25-pound lobster that was at least 30 years old died two days before it was to be flown to Japan in exchange for a collection of colorful carp, New England Aquarium officials reported Monday. The aquarium had searched unsuccessfully for months to find a sufficiently large, live, native lobster to send to the Sunshine Aquarium near Tokyo. Six other large lobsters also died before the aquarium could fulfill its part of the exchange.

title: ANOTHER EXPO HURT
description: The Montreal Expos, whose late-season bid for the National League's Eastern Division championship had already been blunted by injuries to the pitchers Dan Schatzeder, David Palmer and Charlie Lea, received another blow Friday night. Joe Hesketh, a promising left-handed rookie, joined the other three pitchers on the disabled list after he fractured his left leg in a game against the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: MISS FRENCH WED TO GEORGE EVARTS
description: The marriage of Pamela Bliss French, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. V. French of Hopkinton, N.H., and Andover, Mass., to George Hammond Evarts, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jasper M. Evarts of Landgrove, Vt., took place yesterday. The Rev. Robert Daggett performed the ceremony at the Congregational Church in Hopkinton.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

FOR SOME, A TIME YOU CAN'T GO HOME
description: IT was moving day on July 2, a hot day in 1942. We were moving from the city to a solid, custom-built home in Yonkers with many rooms that piqued the curiosity of children. At 4, I was the oldest; then came Ellen, 3, and Andy, 6 months. While the moving men laid the Oriental carpet on the parquet floor in the living room, we ate hard-boiled egg sandwiches, sitting on the porch on gray boxes with blue letters that said ''Cashman Laundry.'' The porch was flagstone then, with black wrought-iron railings.

title: TEXAS TOWN ASKS, 'WHO KEPT THE RECORDS?'
description: Officials are searching for receipts and other indications of the financial status of this city where, for the last two years, it appears that no one remembered to keep records on such things as water bills, insurance and employees.

title: Q AND A
description: NONPRIMARY RESIDENT Question: Can a nonpurchaser in a noneviction conversion be evicted if he is not a primary resident and plans for the conversion were accepted for filing before July 20, 1982? . . . M. J., Manhattan Answer: In New York City, the answer is yes, according to Jane Rosenberg, assistant attorney general. Under Section 352eeee of the General Business Law, enacted July 20, 1982, grounds for eviction of nonpurchasing tenants in noneviction plans accepted for filing after that date were limited to nonpayment of rent, illegal use of occupancy, refusal of reasonable access to the owner or similar breaches of the lease. Total Mortgage Tax Question: I obtained an adjustable-rate mortgage for my house with an optional negative-amortization feature that could increase my mortgage as much as $187,000. Will I owe mortgage tax on the original amount or the potential amount? . . . J. A., Manhattan Answer: Article XI, Section 253 of the New York State Tax Law requires that the tax be computed on Redinger the principal obligation not only at the date of execution but at any time thereafter. Robert J. Mensing, a tax technician for the State Department of Taxation and Finance, says you would have to pay the tax on the full amount. Spouse's Name on Lease Question: I sent my landlord your article about a landlord being required to add a wife's name to a lease renewal [''Wait for the Wedding,'' June 23, 1985] and asked again to have my wife's name added to the lease.

title: THE MIND OF MENGELE
description: Dr. Lifton appears to believe it will be good medicine for us to witness psychiatry's reverse demonology: the transformation of a monster back into a man. Yet it seems to me that the relinquishing of the myth of the demon for the fiction of the double is not transformation but transposition from poetry to prose, with much resonance and folk wisdom lost in the process.

title: LEAVE PROUST ALONE
description: To the Editor:

title: A Lot of Cash, No Matter How You Cut It
description: Payday came early last week for a tavern employee in Troy, a computer consultant from Brooklyn and a group of 21 assembly-line workers at a plant in Mount Vernon, N.Y. They were the holders of the three winning tickets for a jackpot of $41 million in the New York State lottery game, Lotto, and they all promised to share the wealth.

title: VARIED DINNER MENU IN MADISON
description: THERE'S nothing about Cafe Lafayette in Madison to suggest that the white clapboard 1839 building was once a church or that its one-time pastor's ghost is said to haunt the attic, atoning perhaps for the murder in 1879 of a young parishioner.

title: TAKING ON 'TACKINESS' ON THE CAPE
description: Provincetown, once a remote, picturesque fishing village that attracted writers and artists fleeing the material world, is fighting to rid its main street of gaudy displays and street markets that obscure its historical charm.

title: THE MIND OF MENGELE
description: In the article ''What Made This Man? - Mengele''(July 21), Robert Jay Lifton proposes that a unique collocation of ideology and ambition transformed an ordinary person into a ruthless mass murderer by a process of ''doubling.'' However, the reader's attempt to understand this phenomenon is not well-served by an absence of essential information relating to early childhood experiences.

title: DALTON'S Y.M.C.A. IS SUED OVER DUES
description: THE Young Men's Christian Association of Dalton, Mass., a Berkshire County hill town, has a delinquency problem, according to its parent organization.

title: I.U.D. Maker Seeks Protection
description: The growing financial penalties for producing a defective or dangerous product last week drove a second major American corporation, the A. H. Robins Company, to file for what has been called pre-emptive bankruptcy.

title: VICTIMS GAIN A VOICE IN JERSEY'S PAROLE DECISIONS
description: Last fall, Gerald D. Clark Sr. expected to win a parole.

title: WINES WITHOUT CAPS
description: LESS AND LESS VERI-tas appears in the punctuation of vino. Today, we will dissociate ourselves from the roundheels of descriptivism and lay down ''Winespell, Safire's Rigid Rules for the Clarity of Capitalization in Wines.''

title: PROBLEMS OF CONTROL BY BOARDS
description: ARISE in the number of people who operate businesses and professions in residential cooperatives and condominiums is creating problems for boards of directors.

title: Chinese Bomber Lands in South Korea
description: A Chinese Air Force bomber crash- landed in a South Korean rice field Saturday night, killing one crew member and a South Korean farmer, officials said today.

title:
WESTCHESTER JOURNAL;

HISTORY FOR SALE
description: LAST month's classified newspaper advertisement was brief and to the point: ''For sale by the Town of Cortlandt: historic Upper Manor House (near Peekskill). Heavy renovation work required.''

title: INDUSTRIOUS BEAVERS PLAGUING HARWINTON
description: FIFTY or so beavers, doing what comes naturally, have made a mess in Harwinton this summer, and nobody has been able to do much about it.

title: UNIT ACTS ON FRAUD IN HOMELESS CASES
description: MONEY received by the homeless for temporary housing in the county is being misused, according to Acting Commissioner John J. Allen of the Department of Social Services. He said that the department was attempting to halt abuses and that while additional actions would be implemented by the end of the month, the problem might not be entirely corrected until next March.

title:
DINING OUT;

ONE HOTEL, 2 RESTAURANTS
description: HOTEL restaurants are not always the most exciting dining spots, but they usually develop a certain reliability fairly soon after they open.

title: PRESIDENT HOPING TO END 'SUSPICIONS' AT SUMMIT PARLEY
description: President Reagan, commenting on his planned meeting with Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, said today that he hoped to eliminate ''hostilities'' and ''suspicions'' between the two countries.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CHIC CAIRO
description: Well-traveled writers report on the special flair that constitutes style in cities East and West.

title: YONKERS DEVELOPMENT UNIT IS ONCE AGAIN IN JEOPARDY
description: ON the night of May 24, 1984, the Yonkers Community Development Agency was at the brink of extinction. It was saved by a freshman City Councilman, Frank J. McGovern Jr., whose decisive vote broke a deadlock over whether to approve an application that would have allowed the city to participate in the 10th year of the Federal Community Development Block Grant program, which for nine years had provided financing for economic development in deteriorating neighborhoods of the city.

title: ELIZABETH ANN BURNS, A BNK OFFICER, IS MARRIED TO CHRISTOPHER PAUL KIRBY
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Ann Burns, a corporate loan officer for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, to Christopher Paul Kirby, an account executive with Bear Stearns & Company in Boston, took place yesterday at St. Anthony's Roman Catholic Church in Falmouth, Mass. The Rev. Richard Andrade performed the ceremony.

title: ONLY THE WORLD BANK HAS THE MEANS
description: FROM almost every indication, the international debt crisis will soon resurface as the major international economic problem. The economies of many debtor nations are deteriorating, as the world economic growth that spurred Latin American exports in 1984 fades into memory. At the same time, political resistance to debt plans imposed by outsiders, such as the International Monetary Fund, is rising in debtor nations. And, perhaps most troubling of all, none of the major players in international finance have made contingency plans for a renewed crisis.

title: THE TRAP IN YOUR I.R.A. LEWIS J. SPERBER; Lewis J. Sperber is the president of Sperber Adams, a Westport investment concern.
description: HERE is a financial dilemma which looms in the future for a great many people in Connecticut and throughout the country:

title: LOW FARM PRICE FOR BEEF FAILING TO REACH SHOPS
description: The price farmers get for beef cattle has fallen sharply this year, but little of the saving has been passed on to shoppers, according to Government statistics.

title: MAKING 'SUN-DRIED' TOMATOES
description: DUCK if you see your neighbor coming up the drive with a large bag in his hands. He is probably trying to get rid of his tomatoes.

title: FINALLY, THE DEBUT OF WALL STREET WEST
description: BEFORE mammoth rejuvenation projects like Manhattan's Battery Park City ignited building booms and changed cityscapes in the nation's downtown areas, it seemed that a deadly cancer was spreading unchecked through the body of urban America.

title: MARTHA KENERSON FIRE ISLAND BRIDE OF WILLIAM BIERCE
description: Martha Lynne Kenerson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ryder Kenerson of St. Petersburg, Fla., was married yesterday to William B. Bierce, a son of Mrs. Augustine Hicks Lawrence Jr. of Delray Beach, Fla., Wilmington, Del., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, L.I., and the late Thurber Hoffman Bierce. Bishop John S. Spong of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark performed the ceremony at the Point O'Woods Church.

title:
NATURE WATCH;

BEACH FLEA, SAND HOPPER
description: Orchestia platensis Size: To one-half inch.

title: Two Brush Fires in Wyoming
description: Officials of the United States Forest Service said today that crews were close to containing two major forest and brush fires that had burned about 7,300 acres in northern Wyoming. The larger fire was in the Black Hills National Forest, where 6,500 acres of Federal, state and privately owned ranch land southwest of Sundance were scorched. The smaller blaze, involving 1,146 acres in a forested area near Bondurant, was 80 percent contained, officials said.

title: ERASING THE DEMOCRATS' WIMPISH IMAGE
description: Most Democrats admit they have a serious and growing image problem: The party of the stalwarts, President John F. Kennedy, Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey and Senator Henry A. Jackson - all of them committed to a strong, reliable military - is now widely seen as wimpish on defense. The concern is hardly academic. Many Democrats think it helps explain why the party's once-vast popular base is shrinking.

title: THE DANGERS OF IRREGULAR VOLTAGE
description: IT was during the muggy heat spell of last week, at a moment when my thoughts were far from my computer, that the machine simply lost its mind.

title:
INVESTING;

THE HAZARDS IN POLLUTION CONTROL STOCK
description: WHAT is bad for Union Carbide is turning out to be good - at least in cold financial terms - for many pollution control and waste cleanup companies: Since the beginning of the year, an index of six of these smaller companies, which trade over-the-counter, has advanced almost 68 percent, according to Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: AN AMERICAN VIEW
description: Having moved back to the United States recently after 10 years abroad, I was invited to lunch at the home of a new acquaintance in Greenwich, Conn. I dressed as I had been accustomed to dressing for ''ladies' luncheons'' abroad, from Poland to Spain: I wore a silk blouse with a skirt and jacket, small pearl earrings and high-heeled leather shoes.

title: Neither Yevtushenko Nor Shostakovich Should Be Blamed
description: To the Editor:

title: CLARK OUT 2 WEEKS
description: Terry Pendleton and Ozzie Smith each drove in two runs and Vince Coleman had three hits, a run batted in and two stolen bases as the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Atlanta Braves, 7-0, tonight in a game called because of rain in the sixth inning.

title: LUCILE IRWIN HAS WEDDING
description: Lucile Stapleton Irwin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Irwin of Norwalk, Conn., and Ian Howard Christoph, the son of Mr. and Mrs. James B. Christoph of Bloomington, Ind., were married yesterday. The Rev. Stanley Rousseau performed the ceremony and concelebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Alfred Bietighofer at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Norwalk.

title: FREE TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE SUMMERFIELD STORIES. By J. M. Ferguson Jr. (Texas Christian University, Cloth, $14.95. Paper, $8.95.) ''Walk long enough and far enough and we were sure to come to something in the end.'' This opening line from one of the stories in this first collection expresses the sense of infinity and loss that pervades the book. Set in New Mexico, the stories, although separate, are connected by the unfulfilled lives of several characters - in particular Summerfield, whose decline is echoed in the thoughts and actions of the others. In some ways, the various characters could be one, viewed at different times and from different perspectives. They are all engaged in the same bewildered search for what they want to become, and they are all bewitched by the vast, electrifying landscape that surrounds them, holding out the promise of a life that could be nobler, freer and more beautiful than it is. ''In summer piles of clouds, fierce and sunburned, are almost always adrift there, yet never seeming to consume the vastness of the blue they drift in, making you feel that you have forever.'' The people are dwarfed by this landscape, and they wander restlessly, searching to capture its nobility and absorb it into their own lives yet always failing to ''come to something in the end.'' This small collection contains a kind of beauty I have rarely come across in fiction. It exists not so much in the language, which is occasionally clumsy, as the atmosphere the stories create.

title: Margaret Ward Is Married
description: Margaret Kathryne Ward, the daughter of Nannie van Stade Ward of Aiken, S.C., and John G. Ward of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to Arturo Renaldo Yance, a son of Grimalda Yance and Lucio Patino, both of Lima, Peru. The Rev. Herbert H. Beardsley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Advent in Westbury, L.I.

title: POP: MALOPOETS OFFER THE SOUND OF AFRICA AT SOUNDS OF BRAZIL
description: THE MALOPOETS, a South African band from Soweto, played bouyant music Wednesday and Thursday at Sounds of Brazil. Their music calls for a little translation.

title: August 25, 1985
CORRECTION
description: An article in the Arts and Leisure section today on musicals incorrectly attributes the authorship of ''Annie Get Your Gun.'' The music and lyrics were written by Irving Berlin. The show was produced by Richard Rodgers and Oscar Hammerstein II.

title: BUSY LUTHIER WORKS TO SAVE 'DYING ART'
description: WHEN Bruce Springsteen stepped onto the stage at Giants Stadium for his recent record-breaking series of six concerts, the guitar he held was, like the Boss himself, a New Jersey product.

title:
GARDENING;

SOME CHORES FOR LATE SUMMER
description: AS summer winds down, it is again time to think seriously about several gardening tasks. All are best done early to take advantage of the ideal fall growing conditions.

title: So You Want To Run for Office
description: Candidates in New York City's Democratic primary found something last week on which all could agree: the state's electoral system, with its requirements for thousands of signatures on nominating petitions and its rigid application of rules, needs significant reform, and soon. The conclusion was reached after a disqualified mayoral candidate was reinstated, then thrown off the ballot again and then reinstated again, all within five days. Four of the six candidates for City Council president were also ruled off the ballot and then ordered restored. The candidates had committed technical violations, including mislabeling the cover sheets of nominating petitions and misnumbering the pages. One candidate for Council president, former Deputy Mayor Kenneth Lipper, was removed because his petitions contained 21 more names than he had claimed on the cover sheet.

title: OPERA STARS JOIN IN AIDS BENEFIT
description: A COUPLE of annual Long Island benefits, customarily held for different causes, have converged into a common one: to combat acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, a growing problem on Long Island.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Tuscan Year By Elizabeth Romer. Illustrated. 182 pages. Atheneum. $12.95.

title: VOTER SIGN-UP FEUD ENDS IN WATERBURY
description: THE intercession of a Federal judge and a prominent state politician helped Waterbury officials and community groups last week end a yearlong feud over voter registration.

title: D. D. VIRTUE WED TO MISS MINICUS
description: The marriage of Pamela Jean Minicus, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Minicus, to D. Douglas Virtue, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Virtue, took place yesterday. Both families are of Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. Robert J. McDermott performed the ceremony at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn.

title: AN EAST END CO-OP PLAN THAT FALTERED
description: IT seemed like a good idea to build a cooperative apartment complex on a former dairy farm in the Town of East Hampton. Urban professionals were expected to find the unspoiled, bucolic surroundings attractive. And with an on-site staff providing services like stocking refrigerators and shuttle buses for beach trips, co-op owners could relax on weekends and summer vacations without a care in the world.

title: PITCHMAN'S PITCHMAN
description: THERE is one of those commercials that local car dealers pay to these stations to run after midnight. It shows 20 acres of cars surrounding a hyperthyroid man who looks as if his name is Phil.

title: INVERLOCHY
description: To the Editor: Israel Shenker's amusing tale of his visit to Inverlochy Castle (Travel, July 21) takes me back to my own ''storming of the ramparts'' there.

title: PARIS PANACHE
description: Some say it is transmitted through the genes - as easy to acquire as brown hair or freckles. Others believe it is learned through an elaborate monkey-see, monkey-do process. It has been called a sixth sense, a tradition and a talent.

title: 1,100-HORSE SHOW MAY MARK TREND
description: WHEN the Hampton Classic begins tomorrow in Bridgehampton, it will mark not only its ninth year as an A-rated horse show - an event of international significance in equestrian circles - but it may mark a turning point in making the East End a desirable area for the breeding, raising and training of champion horses.

title: PETER BROOK TRANSFORMS AN INDIAN EPIC FOR THE STAGE
description: Imagine staging a nine-hour production based on an ancient Hindu poem combining strains of the War of the Roses and Gotterdammerung into the cosmic grandeur of an Indian epic. Stir in a clash of two great dynasties in the hands of the gods, opposing armies locked in battle and the moral struggle of ideal heroes representing divine forces arrayed against demonic ones. All this, set against a background of primordial forests and sumptuous palaces, is encompassed in the monumental saga, ''The Mahabharata'' - a theatrical challenge that would intimidate most directors.

title: On the Durability Of the Shoreham Plant
description: Howard Weinstein, in his recent article [''Why Shoreham Shouldn't Open,'' Opinion Page] , suggests a rather absurd reason for not opening the Shoreham nuclear power plant: The plant will not last forever.

title: WRITER TOLD 'FT. APACHE' ISN'T JUST HIS
description: IN 1976, Thomas Walker wrote a book called ''Fort Apache.''

title: A.T.& T. AND FORD PLAN HUGE JOB CUTS
description: A.T.&T.'s huge cutbacks in its Information Systems unit are being forced by the increased competition that resulted from divestiture, analysts say. A.T.&T. is planning to eliminate 24,000 jobs, about 7,000 in management, although no one yet knows how many workers will actually be laid off. The company eliminated 15,000 jobs in the unit after the breakup, but demand for business communications products has fallen, and analysts said the unit was losing as much as $1 billion a year.

title: Robert English Weds Elizabeth A. Tucker
description: Elizabeth Adele Tucker, a reporter for The Washington Post, and Robert David English, a policy analyst for the Department of Defense, were married yesterday at Prospect Garden at Princeton University. The Rev. Peter Jenkins, a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: HOW A GORWN MAN WAS SMITTEN BY PUPPY LOVE
description: THEY are gone now, and my house and heart seem empty. The puppies had taken over a corner of each.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Till the Clouds Roll By Starring Robert Walker, Van Heflin, Kathryn Grayson, Lena Horne, Tony Martin, Dinah Shore, June Allyson and Judy Garland; directed by Richard Whorf, 1946 Prism 120 minutes. $19.95 As drama, this is a thin, strained fairy tale about Jerome Kern, the great melodic pioneer of the American theater, played weakly by Robert Walker.

title: A UNIVERSITY SHRINKS TO FIT THE TIMES
description: As the number of high school graduates declines, colleges across the country are scurrying to find ways to keep their classes filled with able students. Some schools have turned to direct-mail campaigns while others are relying on more traditional tactics, such as offering scholarships to top students.

title: KANSAS SLAYINGS
description: THREE years ago this month, Iola, Kan., was terrorized by the slayings of three of its 7,500 residents. Two victims were teen-agers, one a 59-year-old woman. A fourth resident, Gerald Short, 15, was pistol-whipped. Sales of handguns and dead-bolt locks soared as the farming community scrambled to protect itself.

title: Ugandan Rebels Agree to Peace Talks
description: Uganda's military Government and the main rebel group, the National Resistance Army, said today that they would begin peace talks Monday in Nairobi.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE NEWBORN MOTHER: Stages of Her Growth. By Andrea Boroff Eagan. (Little, Brown, $15.95.) Despite more than occasional speculation and the relatively small sampling of women (58) on which her conclusions are based, Andrea Boroff Eagan has written what is in many ways a ground-breaking work on the process of growth and change that occurs in women in the months after they give birth.

title: NEW ANTI-SANDINISTA UNIT FORMING ON SOUTH BORDER
description: A major effort is under way to organize and arm a new Nicaraguan anti-Government rebel unit on the Costa Rican border that will be directly allied with the powerful Nicaraguan Democratic Force operating out of Honduras, according to members of the new unit and senior rebel officials.

title: SEALY HATHAWAY WED TO S. C. RODGER
description: Barbara Sealy Hathaway, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Phillips Hathaway of Owings Mills, Md., and Steven Charles Rodger of Greenwich, Conn., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Rodger of Greenwich and Stowe, Vt., were married yesterday at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Garrison, Md. The Rev. George E. Sinkinson Jr., assisted by the Rev. Ronald S. Fisher, performed the ceremony.

title: Susan Haff Is Married To Barry Armstrong
description: The marriage of Susan Ely Haff, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. C. Barse Haff Jr. of Old Lyme, Conn., to Barry Graham Armstrong, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald G. Armstrong of White Plains, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Lyme. The Rev. David W. Good performed the ceremony.

title: CINEMA WITHOUT VERITIES
description: AMERICAN DREAMING The Films of John Cassavetes and the American Experience. By Raymond Carney. Illustrated. 335 pp. Berkeley: University of California Press. $27.50.

title: ISRAELI SCHOOLS WORK OUT A PEACE PLAN
description: When a class of Jewish 11th graders in Jerusalem was asked, ''What are the things that come to your mind when you think of 'Arab,' '' the most common answers were ''dirty,'' ''construction worker'' and ''terrorist.''

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: HANDS OF A STRANGER. By Robert Daley. (Simon & Schuster, $16.95.) Joe Hearn, an ambitious inspector in the N.Y.P.D., finds himself falling in love with Judith Adler, the assistant district attorney for sex crimes.

title: LOST IN THE WOODS
description: IT WAS ONLY LATER THAT I began to reflect on the fact that ''kloochman'' means ''wife'' in Chinook jargon.

title: Recent Sales
description: Bridgewater $121,900 12 Saratoga Lane *2* 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 24-year-old split-level; *2* brick front, gas heat, 2-car garage; taxes $2,233. Jamesburg $98,000 16 Half Acre Road *2* 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 30-year-old Cape Cod; professionally *2* landscaped, large closets, 1-car garage; taxes $2,121. Ogdensburg $95,000 11 Madison Drive *2* 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 25-year-old split-level; *2* deck, pool, fountain in living room; taxes $2,100. Pittstown $205,000 Route 579 *2* 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new Victorian; fiberglass walls, *2* fireplace in master bedroom, 2 acres; taxes to be assessed. Upper Saddle River $595,000 17 Hillside Avenue *2* 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old Tudor; 5-zone heat; *2* 4 acres with pond and 1836 grist mill; taxes $8,561. Whitehouse $114,000 51 Old Highway *2* 28 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1830 farmhouse; front and side porches, *2* barn with studio, random-width flooring; taxes $1,930. OTHER AREAS East Northport, L.I. $165,000 10 Alba Place *2* 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 18-year-old colonial; den with *2* fireplace, eat-in kitchen, partial basement; taxes $4,000. Mount Kisco, N.Y. $322,500 188 Byram Lake Road *2* 6-bedroom, 5-bath, 55-year-old masonry/ stucco colonial; eat-in *2* kitchen, terrace, in-ground pool, 3-acre garden; taxes $7,133. Wilton, Conn. $320,000 69 Charter Oak Drive *2* 4-bedroom-, 2 1/2-bath, 10-year-old *2* contemporary; atrium, 2 acres; taxes $3,528.

title: THE FOLDED FAN DID MORE THAN COOL
description: ''I'd always traveled a lot and bought things along the way,'' said Charles France, the Oklahoma City collector. ''Sometime in my 20's, I decided to keep things, instead of giving them away as gifts.''

title: John Brown 3d Is Married To Robyn Ann Peterson
description: At Holy Trinity Lutheran church in Manhattan yesterday Robyn Ann Peterson and John Muir Brown 3d, graduates of Colgate University, were married by the Rev. Richard Zimmerman.

title: SMITH, RIDING CALYPSO WINS $200,000 U.S. CUP
description: The world's richest show-jumping competition, the United States Grand Prix League's $200,000 U.S. Cup, was won Friday night at Commonwealth Park by Melanie Smith of Litchfield, Conn.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: THE RICHEST WOMEN IN THE WORLD. By Kit Konolige. (Macmillan, $19.95.) Kit Konolige, a writer who lives in Philadelphia, has written ''The Richest Women in the World'' with all the pace and grace of the Yellow Pages, hopscotching from one case history to the next with such transitions as ''There are always the Rockefellers.

title: TODAY'S STYLISH MOOD
description: In New York, the new clothes are single-mindedly sleek, streamlined and sophisticated. The ones in Paris are particularly parisienne in their attention to clever cuts and details that emphasize the figure.

title: PAUL CRESTON, 78, A COMPOSER OF SYMPHONIES
description: The American composer Paul Creston died yesterday in San Diego after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: A SALUTE TO THE PERFORMING ARTS
description: The performing arts are becoming a lively philatelic subject. In former years the topic had been given only occasional recognition but in 1985, it burst onto center stage. Just as life is never again the same for an artist whose years of obscurity suddenly change with a starring role, should the new stamp theme catch on, the hobby could experience a major transformation.

title: G.O.P TRIAL AND HEMPSTEAD'S IMAGE
description: THE image of the Town of Hempstead has not fared well in the trial of the Nassau County Republican Party on charges that it coerced payments from workers in return for raises and promotions.

title: NEW 35-MILLIMETER FOR PROFESSIONALS
description: THE first 35-millimeter automatic-focusing camera built for professional use has been introduced, opening up new possibilities for greater picture quality in such instant-reaction circumstances as photographing flying birds, touchdown runs and dashing politicians.

title: FIDELITY AND FLINGS
description: Lance Compa's article ''The Faithful Desperado'' (About Men, Aug. 4) provides a sad commentary on the state of married life today. Mr. Compa states that he is not so sure he wants to be faithful and that he ''hankers'' for an uncomplicated fling.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CHANTERS WANTED One need not be Catholic to join the Catholic Choral Heritage Society of Connecticut, a group of men and women seeking new members for the fall season. For a year and a half, they have been rehearsing and performing Gregorian Chant at St. Justin's Church, 200 Blue Hills Avenue, Hartford, under the direction of Christopher Schaefer.

title: AFTER 'HEAVEN'S GATE,' 'DRAGON' DOESN'T LOOK BAD
description: In 'Year of the Dragon,'' Michael Cimino's first film since he nearly bankrupted United Artists with ''Heaven's Gate'' in 1980, Mickey Rourke plays - with a good deal of skill and intensity - Stanley White, a police captain, ''the most decorated cop in the history of the New York Police Department.''

title: FIDELITY AND FLINGS
description: Reading between the lines, I'd bet that Lance Compa is a trustworthy guy. Why isn't he proud of it? LAURIE CHERBONNIER New York City

title: WHAT'S NEW ION EXECUTIVE RECRUITING
description: EXECUTIVE search - the business of finding qualified people for high-level jobs - is an industry on the move. Ten years ago there were no more than 1,000 so-called headhunters around; today that number has doubled.

title: Bomb Threats on Arab Jets
description: A Saudi Arabian and an Egyptian airliner made unscheduled landings at Riem Airport here after receiving separate bomb threats, the police said today. No bomb was found in either case, they said.

title: RENTAL-HOUSING MARKET SHOWS NEW LIFE
description: OVER the last decade, construction of new rental apartments has declined farther and remained depressed longer than most other sectors of the state's housing industry. Several factors are responsible, including high interest rates, a consumer preference for ownership that led to the conversion of many buildings to condominiums and co-ops - and, according to developers, rent-control ordinances.

title: HATLESS OFFICERS IN NASSAU COUNTY
description: IT'S hats off, literally, for the Nassau County Police Department.

title: BASIE SCORES UPSET OVER TOP FILLIES
description: Basie, the lightweight and longest shot in a field of five, posted a 1 1/2-length upset victory over Heatherten and Life's Magic today at Saratoga Race Track in a strangely run Delaware Handicap in which carefully plotted strategies backfired at every turn.

title: RHODE ISLAND A CROSSROADS FOR COCAINE
description: About two years ago, the police here saw the first signs that something unusual was happening.

title: CAMPAIGNS TAKE SHAPE IN ABORTION REFERENDUM IN BRISTOL
description: LAURA MINOR, a leader of the abortion rights movement in Bristol, would rather there was not going to be a referendum on abortion in November's local election, but she thinks some good might yet come of it. ''It's time for people to start discussing this issue,'' she said.

title: AWARDS TO AID SCHOLARLY RESEARCH
description: THOUGH William Cronon, a Yale University historian and environmentalist, has just been awarded $164,000, he said he ''will not use this money to raise my standard of living.''

title:
ANTIQUES;

UKRANIAN FOLK ART IN MONMOUTH
description: FOLLOWING an open reception this evening from 5 to 7 o'clock, to which members of the Ukrainian community in the New York metropolitan area, patrons and the public are invited, 380 objects on loan from the Ukrainian Museum in New York City will go on view here at the Monmouth Museum through Oct. 13.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CHIC RIO DE JANEIRO
description: Well-traveled writers report on the special flair that constitutes style in cities East and West.

title: OFFICIALS STRUGGLE TO OFFER REMEDIAL CLASSES TO PAROCHIAL STUDENTS
description: School officials across the country report confusion and uncertainty as they rush to comply with a Supreme Court decision that Federal funds may no longer be used for remedial instruction on the premises of parochial schools.

title: KATIE PARIS AND MICHAEL H. HERBERT ARE MARRIED
description: The marriage of Katharine Paris, a systems engineer for the Pronto Banking Service of Chemical Bank in Jericho, L.I., to Michael Hodges Herbert, a systems analyst for E. F. Hutton & Company in New York, took place yesterday. Walter Lawton, a leader of the Ethical Culture Society of White Plains, performed the ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Roy A. Herbert, parents of the bridegroom, in Pound Ridge, N.Y. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Paris of Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: YANKS WIN, 4-3, WITH ONLY 2 HITS
description: Suddenly, the Yankees' bats have turned uncharacteristically quiet. Tonight, they mustered just two hits but still came away with a 4-3 victory over the Seattle Mariners, primarily because they were able to make the most of seven walks.

title: TOCKS ISLAND PLAN CALLED AN OLD ONE
description: We have been year-round residents a few miles from Tocks and are currently being ousted from our home by the Government, a financial hardship for us. I suggest General Kavanaugh visit this area.

title: STAMP OF APPROVAL
description: The personal check for $500, made out to ''Postmaster, Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.,'' was promptly delivered to Frank P. Vitalone's desk in an envelope bearing a canceled 22-cent stamp.

title: LONDON'S COURTS
description: To the Editor: What a fine job your three ''court reporters'' did in discussing the particular charms of London's Old Bailey and the Inns of Court (Travel, July 7).

title: ALL TOO SOON, CALIFORNIA FIGHTS VICIOUS BEES TO SAVE AGRICULTURAL INDUSTRY
description: From somewhere, probably a containerized shipment of oil-drilling equipment, a problem has arrived on the doorstep of California's multibillion-dollar agriculture business - one that scientists thought they had years to prepare for.

title: Fire on Runway In Britain Takes 54 Lives
description: Engine failure resulted in a Boeing 737 bursting into flames while taking off at Britain's Manchester airport on Thursday for a flight to the Greek island of Crete: 54 holidaymakers and crew members died, and 83 survived.

title: 2 FARMERS DEFY ORDER TOP RECOGNIZE A UNION
description: Two vegetable farmers have won a two-week delay in a contempt hearing on their refusal to obey a judge's order to recognize and bargain with New Jersey's first farm workers union.

title: STYLE AND SEDUCTION
description: You're too cerebral,'' Giorgio Armani used to shout at me when I worked for him in his studio.

title: KATHARINE MCKEE BECOMES A BRIDE
description: St. Aidan's Chapel in South Dartmouth, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Katharine Winston McKee, the daughter of Sheila Steck McKee of Seattle and the late E. Bates McKee Jr., to David Jackson McGrady, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Jackson McGrady of Hillsville, Va. Episcopal Bishop J. Brooke Mosley performed the ceremony.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BLACKSMITH JAZZ The Parsons Blacksmith Shop, moved to a new home on the Springs Village Green, was built in 1886 and is the last remaining smithy in East Hampton. It is being restored by the local historical society, with funds raised through the Blacksmith Shop Jazz Masters Series. The benefits continue with a sunset concert-picnic today starring Mel Lewis and his 17-piece orchestra. Mr. Lewis, tagged ''the ultimate big-band drummer,'' and his ensemble, regulars at the Village Vanguard, perform at 6:30 P.M. on the Green on Fireplace Road in the Springs section of town. The donation is $15, or $5 for teen-agers and $2 for children under 12. It's a bring-your-own-seating and picnic supper affair, although food will be sold. For reservations call 324-9308.

title: CAMBODIA TAKING LARGER WAR ROLE
description: Pressed by the Vietnamese to take a more active role in defending their country against attacks from three guerrilla armies, Cambodians are building ''strategic fences,'' planting mines and training ''suicide commandos'' for service on the Thai border, according to officials here.

title: AIR SAFETY CHECKS HELD AT AMERICAN
description: Officials of American Airlines and the Federal Aviation Administration are conducting two separate reviews of the giant passenger carrier's aircraft maintenance and safety procedures.

title: WERE THE PARTY FAITHFUL COERCED?
description: The Nassau County Republican Party is in the business of winning elections, something it does as well as any political organization in New York State, if not the country. Whether it will continue to do so depends in part on how the public responds to the last four weeks in a Federal courtroom here.

title: THIS TIME, THE GULF HAD ITS GUARD UP
description: ''Be Prepared'' is more than just a motto to folks on the Gulf Coast. It can mean the difference between life and death when it comes to hurricanes.

title: A CALL TO HOUSES IN DOVER
description: IT was once the most exclusive men's club in Delaware's capital. Membership was by invitation only. Sons followed fathers, and grandfathers, into the organization.

title: CASTRO'S MODEST PROPOSAL
description: The Latin America debt crisis, remote to many in the United States, isn't entirely comprehensible to many Latin Americans, either. That hasn't stopped President Fidel Castro from making it an obsession. ''It's like a fever with him,'' said a senior official.

title: MORE TURN TO SHARING TO COVER RISING RENTS
description: IF a Manhattan apartment can be home to one, it can be home to two.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, a dispatch from Cambridge, Mass., last Sunday on student efforts in development work abroad misstated a source of income for the Overseas Development Network. The organization has received $75,000 from the Hewlett and Packard Foundations.

title: Cynthia Titus Weds Joshua Powers Jr.
description: Cynthia Fairchild Titus, a daughter of Mrs. Samuel Sloan 3d of Little Silver, N.J., and Jupiter, Fla., and J. deWitt Titus of Savannah, Ga., was married yesterday to Joshua Bryant Powers Jr., a son of Mr. Powers of New York and the late Mrs. Powers. The Rev. Bruce Robbins performed the Methodist ceremony at the East Barnard (Vt.)

title: WHERE TO STAY, WHERE TO EAT
description: Whatever one may say about Austrian wine these days, Austrian food - particularly in the restaurants of Vienna -has never been so good. Viennese cooking no longer wallows in sauerkraut, knodeln, pig fat and pork, redeemed only by the Baroque flamboyance of its cakes. Of course, there is nothing to stop one from eating a knodel (dumpling) bedded on steaming sauerkraut peppered with caraway seeds and topped with a cluster of Wursteln (sausages), doused in mustard and downed with a pitcher of beer. But as daily fare this can prove disadvantageous to the figure, as one notices in the case of layered Viennese ladies relishing layered ice creams and pastries topped with lavish helpings of Schlag (whipped cream).

title: ART: AN ANDY WARHOL SHOW, FOR CHILDREN'S EYES
description: Andy Warhol, who put soup cans and scouring pads on museum walls, has now done the same for toy robots, mechanical dogs, roll-over mice, spaceships and clowns - and he has done it especially for children.

title: NEW MUSIC AT ASPEN: A MIXED BLESSING
description: Paul Fromm has long been this country's most visibly active patron of contemporary art-music. But he is a patron of a very particular kind. He is not a mere cornucopia, innocently convinced of the value (and prestige) of the new but willing to delegate to his betters -meaning other composers, music directors and administrators - all responsibility for picking which composers should be commissioned. But he is not a pure subjectivist, either, like Betty Freeman in Beverly Hills, who simply decides on the basis of her own taste that she likes a composer and then commissions him or her, more or less out of the blue.

title: IN PANANMA, U.S. BRIGADE PRACTICES CANAL DEFENSE
description: In the dense jungle only a few hundred yards from the Panama Canal, American paratroopers in full battle gear pulled themselves through green slime hand-over-hand on a rope, with only their helmets and rifles sticking out of the water.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: FOR Barbara Lightner of Old Bridge, every day is Christmas, even in the month of August. Even when it's 90 degrees in the shade.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Sunrise at Campobello Starring Ralph Bellamy and Greer Garson; directed by Vincent J. Donehue, 1960 Warner Home Video 144 minutes. $59.95 This faithful reproduction on film of Dore Schary's Broadway play ''Sunrise at Campobello'' dramatizes the turning point in the life of Franklin D. Roosevelt, the moment when he was able to triumph over crippling polio and return to active politics.

title: A RECORD $2.8 MILLION GIVEN BY TIMES FUND
description: The New York Times Company Foundation awarded grants totaling $2.8 million last year, a record amount for the foundation and a 73 percent increase over the previous year.

title: U.S. WETLANDS ARE DIAPPEARING
description: LESS than half of the 215 million acres of wetlands that existed at one time in the 48 contiguous states exists today, according to a report issued earlier this year by the United States Fish and Wildlife Service.

title: CAN TRANQUIL TIMES YIELD GREAT WORKS?
description: ''Novelists are like vultures,'' the Peruvian author Mario Vargas Llosa once said. ''We feed off decaying societies.'' His simile explains a great deal about the dilemma of American creative artists in the 1980's. Two generations of writers, film makers, musicians and visual artists have come of age since World War II ended. Born into comfort, most of them, these creators now live in a decade that is the apotheosis of affluence, the time when, as the novelist Jay McInerney put it, ''there's no cultural consensus beyond the idea that a Porsche or a Rolex are considered legitimate goals in themselves.''

title: MUSIC: ARRAU CLOSES THE MOSTLY MOZART FESTIVAL
description: THE final program of the 1985 Mostly Mozart Festival at Avery Fisher Hall, heard Friday night and repeated last night, offered two certified masterpieces preceded by an unfamiliar Mozart symphony that was very nice but not on the same exalted level as the other two. Gerard Schwarz and his orchestra treated them all accordingly.

title: THE MESSAGE OF BRAMAN
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Point of Clarification On Rent Guidelines
description: A tip of the hat to Betsy Brown for her excellent article [''Rent Board Weighs Means Test,'' July 21] on the current status of rent regulation in Westchester.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: ANNIE AND THE WILD ANIMALS Written and illustrated by Jan Brett. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 5) THE familiar theme of a cat's puzzling disappearance in ''Annie and the Wild Animals'' might easily be dismissed with a yawn as just another variation were it not for the author and illustrator Jan Brett's exquisite, tapestrylike watercolor paintings and the way she adds a new graphic dimension to a simple story.

title: HOSPITAL A PARTNER IN CENTER
description: A 136,000-square-foot complex of sports facilities, doctors' offices, clinics and shops is planned for downtown Meriden, in what organizers are calling the largest joint venture between a hospital and a private developer in the Northeast.

title: THE JEWEL IN NEWARK'S CROWN
description: NOW that summer is drawing to a close and vacationers are trickling back from their holidays in exotic places, they can have a try at this Trivial Pursuit-type question:

title: A Zia Opponent In Her Father's Footsteps
description: Benazir Bhutto returned to Pakistan last week from self-imposed exile and publicly accepted the political mantle of her late father in opposing the martial-law rule of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: The Dancing Princesses A Shelley Duvall ''Faerie Tale Theater'' production, featuring Roy Dotrice, Lesley Ann Warren, Peter Weller; directed by Peter Medax, 1984 CBS/Fox Video 60 minutes. $39.98 Aside from the diminution in their number, 6 instead of 12, ''The Dancing Princesses'' is among the most successful dramatizations from the ''Faerie Tale Theater'' TV series.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Gale Sayers, the Hall of Fame running back of the Chicago Bears, was named athletic director at Tennessee State. . . . Geoff Smith of Britain, the winner of the 1984 and 1985 Boston Marathons, has entered this year's New York City Marathon which will be run on Oct. 27. . . . Chris Evert Lloyd, Pam Shriver, Kathy Rinaldi, Anne White and Betsy Nagelsen have been named to the 1985 United States Wightman Cup team for matches against Britain in Williamsburg, Va., on Oct. 31, Nov. 1-2.

title: FLICKERS IN AN ELECTRONIC LANDSCAPE
description: INNER TUBE By Hob Broun. 210 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $14.95.

title: OLD CHESTNUT BLOOMS AGAIN
description: THEATER THREE in Port Jefferson has revived ''The Boyfriend,'' in a production that is notable only for its outstanding cast. If possible, this footnote in musical-comedy history is even frothier than it was in the 1950's.

title: Eliza Storey Wed to Michael Anderson
description: At the Harvard Memorial Church in Cambridge, Mass., yesterday Eliza Allison Tebo Storey, a daughter of Mrs. Charles Burlingham Jr. of Cambridge, Mass., and Old Black Point, Conn., and James Moorfield Storey of Boston and Great Cranberry Island, Me., was married to Michael James Anderson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon M. Anderson of Fullerton, Calif. The Rev. Peter J. Gomes, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: ARMORED CAR OFFICE ROBBGED OF $400,000 BY COMPANY WORKER
description: An employee of an armored car company held up its office in Bayside, Queens, yesterday evening and ran off with bags containing between $400,000 and $500,000 in cash, the police said.

title: DOCUMENTIN OUR RECORDED PAST
description: Under the auspices of A.R.S.C., and with help from the N.E.H., the A.A.A. has finally got the R.D.I. ready for distribution; soon, they hope, it will be integrated into R.L.I.N., if R.L.G.'s governing board gives approval.

title: Social Security as a Battle of the Generations
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadcast TV
description: (The following excerpts are from Mel Gussow's review of the original ''American Playhouse'' television presentation of ''The Gin Game.'' The production will be rebroadcast Monday evening at 9 on Channel 13.) Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy are consummate actors, a fact that is self-evident when one watches them gracefully thread their art in and around and under the words of D. L. Coburn's Pulitzer Prize-winning play ''The Gin Game.''

title: NUCLEAR HAVE-NOTS GROW RESTIVE
description: Forty years after the United States atomic bomb exploded over Nagasaki, nuclear devices are still being tested at the rate of one a week. Last year, the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China conducted 53 underground nuclear tests, according to the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, which is financed by Sweden's Parliament. The five countries have exploded 1,500 nuclear devices in all, the institute says.

title: A SONG ABOUT HITS
description: JANIE THOMPSON had no idea that her song would become so big. She never would have predicted that it would inspire a video that football fans would desperately want to buy. She has spent 30 years on the campus of Brigham Young University. She has been there more than long enough to know that Provo, Utah, is hardly a place where football followers would behave in a manner usually reserved for spots such as Pittsburgh, or Miami, or Iowa City, or Norman, Okla.

title: BUYER'S MARKET FORESEEN FOR CITY CONDOS AND CO-OPS
description: REAL-ESTATE experts are predicting a buyer's market for cooperative and condominium apartments in New York City over the next year, shaped by burgeoning new construction, worry over proposed changes in Federal tax law and jitters among owners that prices may already have risen so high that it is time to sell.

title: BIG GAIN FOR HORNUNG
description: Paul Hornung, no stranger to victories in his years as a back and place-kicker for Notre Dame and the Green Bay Packers, has won a hefty amount of money in court. Hornung was awarded $1.15 million in his lawsuit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association Friday in Louisville, Ky.

title: Democrat Urges Protection From Overseas Competition
description: The Reagan Administration has failed to take the lead to protect manufacturers from unfair foreign competition, Senator Jim Sasser said today in the Democrats' weekly radio address.

title: Jessica A. Zander Is Bride Of Robert Page in Syosset
description: The marriage of Jessica Amy Zander, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Zander of Roslyn Heights, L.I., to Robert Wilson Page, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Page of Lloyd Harbor, L.I., took place yesterday. Chief Judge Sol Wachtler of the Court of Appeals officiated at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Trotman, brother-in-law and sister of the bridegroom, in Syosset, L.I.

title:
DINING OUT;

LURE OF THE SEA, BIG BAND SOUNDS
description: ALTHOUGH The Restaurant at Glen Island Casino still commands spirit-lifting views of Long Island Sound and retains the sweeping glamour of a luxury liner, in almost all other respects it has made us, on recent visits, think about mutiny or jumping ship. It is saddening to report that this place has lost the class it once had and now seems to be running a steerage operation almost all the way.

title: Dr. Claudia L. Thomas Wed to Maxwell Carty
description: Dr. Claudia Lynn Thomas and Maxwell Delaine Carty were married yesterday at the Lemuel Haynes Congregational Church in South Ozone Park, Queens. The Rev. Marvin Mayfield performed the ceremony.

title: TENNESSEE TO ACT ON PRISONS
description: Gov. Lamar Alexander said Friday he would call a special session of the Legislature Nov. 5 to deal with the state's overcrowded prisons. Plans for the session were included in the state's latest proposal for easing the situation, which was submitted to Federal District Judge Thomas A. Higgins. Judge Higgins, ruling in a lawsuit filed by some prisoners, has ordered the state to reduce its prison population from 7,630 to 7,019 by Dec. 31.

title: BROKEN HILL OUTGROWS AUSTRALIA
description: THEY call the Broken Hill Proprietary Company the Big Australian - with good reason. This steel, mining, and oil monolith accounts for 3 percent of Australia's gross domestic product, 5 percent of exports and 10 percent of the value of all shares listed on the nation's stock exchanges. On an Australian scale, that's rather like being U.S. Steel, Asarco and Exxon rolled into one.

title: RUTH TITLE TO SARASOTA
description: Tim Collins scattered eight hits today as Sarasota, Fla., rolled to a 13-1 victory over San Gabriel Valley, Calif., in the championship game of the Babe Ruth World Series, 16-to-18-year-old division. The winners had 12 hits, including three by Mark Dawn, who hit a home run.

title: SUGAR'S SURE DANGER: PRICE
description: It's summertime and the slurping is heavy: Americans are consuming more sweeteners in everything from wine coolers to granola bars. Experts disagree on whether sugar and sugar substitutes pose a serious health risk. But there is no doubt that protecting a few thousand domestic sugar producers in the United States and Europe costs the consumer, and is bringing ruin to our friends in the third world. Common sense and common decency argue for serious reforms.

title: POLL FINDS DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES IN CITY GENERALLY AGREE ON ISSUES
description: There is overwhelming agreement on issues among candidates in the Sept. 10 Democratic primary election in New York City, according to a poll.

title: MARIE MURPHY IS BRIDE OF T. P. RYAN IN DARIEN
description: The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in Darien, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marie Belen Murphy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Murphy of Darien, and Timothy Paul Ryan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ryan of Williamsville, N.Y. The Rev. Robert G. Cregan performed the ceremony.

title: BOOKSHELF
description: A LEARICAL LEXICON: From the Works of Edward Lear. Compiled by Myra Cohn Livingston. Illustrated by Joseph Low. Margaret K. McElderry/Atheneum.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: IN his business dealings, Martin E. Lowell has often been told to go fly a kite, and nothing could make the 26-year-old North Brunswick resident happier.

title: THE MIND OF MENGELE
description: Robert Lifton quotes Hannah Arendt as contending that ''an ordinary person is capable of extreme evil,'' and he further quotes a former inmate physician at Auschwitz as saying, ''In ordinary times, Mengele could have been a slightly sadistic German professor.'' Both statements are no doubt true.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: DEATH IN BERLIN. By M. M. Kaye. (St. Martin's, $14.95.) Best known as the author of ''The Far Pavilions'' and other historical romances, M. M. Kaye in the 1950's produced a handful of murder mysteries - now being returned to print - that featured exotic locales and came out of her globe-trotting days as a British Army major's wife.

title: Megan Mooney Bride Of Michael C. Gordon
description: Megan Elizabeth Mooney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David William Mooney of Purchase, N.Y., and Stratton Mountain, Vt., was married in Purchase yesterday to Michael Colin Gordon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Emlen Gordon of Morristown, N.J., and Vero Beach, Fla. The Rev. John J. Cunniffe, vice chancellor-personnel, Military Vicariate-U.S.A., performed the Roman Catholic ceremony in the chapel at Manhattanville College.

title: MASADA
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed the story of the archeological dig at Gamla by Matthew Nesvisky (Travel, July 28). It was most interesting to read about this area, which figures so prominently in the annals of Jewish history during the Roman occupation, yet has been mostly neglected by subsequent historians.

title: KEAN ACTS TO DEFUSE A TOXIC-WASTE ISSUE
description: THE Kean administration moved quickly last week to try to head off political damage from a serious hazardous-waste problem caused by the state itself in South Jersey.

title: RED BANK REVIVAL
description: A hodgepodge of old factory buildings in downtown Red Bank, N.J., where military uniforms were turned out from the Civil War until the end of World War II does not seem a likely candidate for conversion into a vibrant new commercial center. But when Elaine and Theodore Sourlis look at this property they envision a mixed-use commercial center of offices, shops, art galleries and restaurants where space will be so attractive it can be sold as condominiums rather than rented.

title: WANTED: REPERTORY HOUSE FOR MUSICALS
description: It may be only a dream, but wouldn't it be a good thing to have a theater in New York playing American musicals in repertory the way the opera houses put on operas? We know from revivals that some of the oldies can draw large audiences. But all the revivals of the last 15 years account for only a handful of the available plays, and one has to think that among the hundreds of musicals lying on library shelves there are enough to keep a musical repertory house in business for a long time.

title: IN THE MIDDLE EAST, CONTINUED VIOLENCE IS A REGIONAL REALITY
description: The level of violence rose sharply in Lebanon last week and an Israeli diplomat was gunned down in Cairo. The violence in the two countries differed in scale and purpose, but in both it reflected a disturbing regional reality. Throughout the Middle East, no movement forward usually means movement backward.

title:
WINE;

SAMPLING THE FIZZY COOLERS
description: BECAUSE of the popularity of the original (California Cooler), the labels of at least a dozen new wine coolers have cropped up at area retail outlets. These products - currently outselling wine from France by more than a 2-to-1 margin - all contain grape alcohol and fruit juice (or fruit flavoring) and come in a range of fizzy flavors wide enough to please most palates. Prices are 85 cents to $1 for a 12- to 13-ounce bottle with alcohol content of 5 to 7 percent (slightly more than beer).

title: Anne Reilly Is a Bride
description: Anne Marie Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Reilly of Greenlawn, L.I., was married there yesterday to Joseph Philip Hadley, a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Philip Hadley of Gloucester, Mass. The Rev. Michael J. Torpey performed the ceremony at St. Francis of Assisi Roman Catholic Church. The bride is an assistant vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in New York. Mr. Hadley is a second-year student at the Columbia University School of Law.

title: FROM YUGOSLAVIA TO MONTVALE
description: AT a ceremony marking the delivery of 500 automobiles shipped from Yugoslavia earlier this month, Malcolm Bricklin, chairman of Yugo America in Montvale, raved about his company's latest import with the rapid-fire delivery of a super-salesman taping a 30-second television commercial.

title: THE PASSION OF OUR CALLING
description: ALL writers relish stories from the lives of the masters. We hold them in our minds as a kind of trade lore. We hope the biography of the great writer yields secrets of his achievement.

title: FEAR SPREADS AS CALIFORNIA SERIAL SLAYINGS GROW
description: Gun sales are soaring in this suburban city of tree-lined streets and Spanish-style stucco homes. And doors and windows are bolted shut.

title: RAIN NEEDED FOR FOREST FIRE
description: The two-foot-wide fire line cleared to contain a smoky Adirondack forest fire was holding today, but state officials said rain was needed to help put out the blaze.

title: DOWN UNDER FOR GOLF, TO THE OCEAN FOR JAZZ
description: A Pacific Golfing Holiday Titirangi, Muriwai, Waitangi, Wairakei, Arikikapakapa, Kelvin Heights, Russley.

title: CHINA CRITICIZES JAPAN ON VISIT TO WAR SHRINE
description: China has issued unusually sharp criticism of Japan, saying through its official press agency that Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone's official visit last week to a shrine for Japanese war dead ''pandered'' to those who wanted to expunge Japan's war guilt.

title: THE DOMINION OF WRATH
description: THE MANTLE OF THE PROPHET Religion and Politics in Iran. By Roy Mottahedeh. 416 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.95.

title: GREATER SAFETY FOR PALISADES IS SOUGHT
description: ON the evening of Aug. 14, James Reidy, 35 years old, of Toms River, climbed out on a ledge of the Palisades about 10 miles north of the George Washington Bridge. He ignored the pleas of relatives, a priest, psychiatrists and police officers and, the following morning - whether by design or accident - plunged almost 200 feet to his death.

title: MISS SULLIVAN BECOMES BRIDE OF JAMES D. KATZ
description: Colleen Sullivan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius J. Sullivan of Concord, Mass., was married yesterday to James Douglas Katz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice B. Katz of New York. Edward Sulesky, the clerk of the District Court of Central Middlesex County in Concord, Mass., performed the ceremony at the Concord Academy.

title: A GOODBYE FOR MR. CHIP
description: ''SORRY, I have to go now,'' I said to my friend. ''I see the cat with something hanging out of her mouth.'' I hung up the phone and dashed outside.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. San Diego, at Shea Stadium. 1:35 P.M. Dwight Gooden will attempt to become the youngest pitcher ever to win 20 games in one season in the finale of this four-game series. (Television - Channel 9, 1:30 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 1:30 P.M.) Yankees vs. Seattle Mariners, at Seattle. 4:35 P.M. Final game of a three-game series. (Television -Channel 11, 4:30 P.M. Radio -WABC 770, 4:30 P.M.) Basketball Stroh's Rucker Pro Summer League Playoffs, championship game, at Holcombe Rucker Memorial Playground, West 155th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard, 5 P.M. Michelob Half-Court Championships, at St. Vartan Park, 35th Street and Second Avenue, 10 A.M. New York champions vs. New Jersey champions in the culmination of a three-on-three tournament that included 230 teams. Golf World Series of Golf, at Firestone Country Club, Akron, Ohio. Final round. (Television - Channel 2, 3 P.M.) L.P.G.A. National Pro-Am, at Lone Tree Country Club and Meridian Golf Club, Denver, final round. (Television - ESPN, 5 P.M.) Tennis Association of Tennis Professionals Championship, at Mason, Ohio. Finals of this $375,000 event. (Television - USA, 2 P.M.) Shearson Lehman Brothers Eastern Clay Court Championships, at Old Field Tennis Club, 400 Greenlawn Road, Greenlawn, L.I., finals, 2 P.M. Virginia Slims of Central New York, at Kutshers Country Club, Monticello, N.Y. Executone Hamlet Challenge Cup, at Jericho, L.I. Final day of play. (Television - ESPN, 1 P.M.) Volleyball USA Cup Men's Volleyball Championship, at Madison Square Garden, 6:30 P.M. The first day of this round-robin, four-city tournament will match the 1984 Olympic gold medal United States team, led by Karch Kiraly, and the Soviet national team, which won the gold in 1980.

title: GADAMER AND THE GESTAPO
description: To the Editor:

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;

FESTIVALS SPOTLIGHT L.I. ARTS
description: WHILE Long Islanders will have plenty to do over the Labor Day weekend, two festivals will be among the main attractions.

title: Tocks Island Plan Called an Old One
description: I was amused at the remarks of Gen. Paul Kavanaugh regarding the Tocks Island Dam proposal [New Jersey Journal, Aug. 11] . He referred to the proposal's being made in the 1960's.

title: QUESTIONS RAISED IN '82 SEARCH OF PRESSER'S OFFICE
description: The Justice Department official who dropped an investigation of Jackie L. Presser agreed to a search in 1982 of the office complex where the teamsters' union president worked but not to a search of Mr. Presser's own office in the building, according to a source knowledgeable about the investigation.

title: CALENDARS
description: Horse Shows Today - Cooper Gate Farm, Baskin Ridge, N.J. Hunters; jumpers; equitation. 8:30 A.M. Information: (201) 766-5646.

title: FOR WHITES IN SOUTH AFRICA, TALK OF A TIME OF RECKONING
description: The signs are there: a line of ants, long dormant, penetrating, suddenly and mysteriously, from garden to sunlit kitchen; the smudge of pink cherry blossom on branches that had seemed barren; the swimming pools turning quickly green in the incipient heat.

title: WHO WILL RULE NEXT IN SOUTH AFRICA?
description: Whatever the anti-apartheid movement has in store for South Africa, it isn't democracy.

title: CARBIDE PRAISED FOR A FORTHRIGHT DISCLOSURE OF SAFETY FLAWS
description: Environmentalists and chemical industry officials praised the Union Carbide Corporation yesterday for being forthright in accepting full blame for failures that led to a toxic leak at its plant in Institute, W.Va., two weeks ago, but Senator Frank R. Lautenberg asserted that the disclosure will hasten an increase in Federal regulation unless the industry quickly solves its safety problems.

title: ZULU LEADER CRITICIZES FIGHTING AMONG BLACKS
description: The leader of the Zulus of South Africa said today that violence by blacks against blacks was a major obstacle to ending apartheid. He strongly criticized the outlawed African National Congress for such acts.

title: WOODSTOCK IS HOST TO POLISH EMIGRE'S WRY PLAY
description: ''An emigre,'' the playwright Janusz Glowacki said, ''is someone who has lost everything but his accent.''

title: AN ANSWER TO GARDENERS' QUESTIONS
description: The blonde woman was obviously upset as she rushed into Caroline T. Kiang's office in Riverhead, L.I.

title: CHEVEY CHASE VILLAGE: NO DEBIS, PLEASE
description: On a recent Sunday morning stroll on Irving Street in suburban Chevy Chase Village, Md., Burt Schorr, the deputy chairman of the Village Board of Managers, slipped in the mud.

title: BREAK THE HABITS OF MASS PRODUCTION
description: A FEW years back, America woke up to the fact that something was seriously wrong with its manufacturing. The response from industry has been determined and energetic. The familiar battle cry of ''productivity'' has been raised across the industrial heartland, spurring companies to establish productivity committees (or even czars), technology labs and control systems.
