Similarly, the President's Commission on Industrial Competitiveness made productivity its principal focus.

title: HOME STAND
description: Bruce Springsteen is no ordinary superstar. The most important people in America court and quote him and, as his recent world tour demonstrated, he is an international hero as well.

title: AMSALE ABERRA IS WED TO CLARENCE BROWN 3D
description: Amsale Aberra, a daughter of Aberra Moltot and Tsadale Asamenew of Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, was married yesterday to Clarence O'Neill Brown 3d, the son of Betty Brown Peterson of Warwick, Bermuda, and the late Mr. Brown Jr. of Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Jacob Wellbourne performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Montclair, N.J., assisted by Archbishop Yesak of the Ethiopian Orthodox Church in the Western Hemisphere, which is based in New York.

title: BARNEY THE OBSCURE
description: PEEPING TOM By Howard Jacobson. 266 pp. New York: Ticknor & Fields. $15.95.

title: HOTELS ARE SETTING FOR FAMILY REUNIONS
description: SUMMER is the traditional time of year for backyard family barbecues and reunions. But one would have a hard time finding a backyard big enough to hold all 275 members of the Antron-Bacote-King family. Yet 175 members from eight states converged in the county over Memorial Day weekend - not in a backyard but in the Westchester Marriott Hotel.

title: USE OF OBSCENITY COSTLY TO GRABACZ
description: Lori Garbacz lost her temper and her lead in the L.P.G.A. National Pro-Am today when she took a double bogey on the 16th hole and muttered an obscenity into a microphone during a live telecast by ESPN, the cable network. She was later fined $3,500, the largest fine ever handed out on the women's professional golf tour.

title: WRIGHT'S LEGACY IN WISCONSIN
description: On the southern approach to Spring Green, Wis., from State Route 23, the road bends in a long rainbow curve around two of Frank Lloyd Wright's most remarkable buildings, the Hillside School then Taliesin, which can be glimpsed through foliage across a long, flat, tilled field.

title: CHAIRMANOFTHEBOARD, $5.40, TAKES CANE
description: Chairmanoftheboard beat Falcon Seelster by a nose at Yonkers Raceway tonight to capture the $600,000 Cane Pace, the second leg of the triple crown series for 3-year-old pacers.

title: FINDING JOBS FOR CANDIDATES' SPOUSES
description: MORE and more search firms are adding human resource consulting to their roster of services. In some cases they offer it gratis as part of a search; more often, it is offered for an additional fee.

title: INEXPENSIVE CHIC: NEW YORK
description: Attractive well-made and versatile clothes, at affordable prices, are readily available for women willing to seek them out. They include those of wool jersey and body-hugging knits for both day and night.

title: SEEING VIENNA IN ITS PRIME
description: Visitors to Vienna in the next six weeks will certainly want to see ''Dream and Reality,'' the magnificent and haunting exhibition at the Kunstlerhaus on the Karlsplatz. It celebrates the most radical urban culture of modern Europe between 1895 and the First World War, together with the imperial expansion that preceded it and the social planning that came after.

title: THREAT OF STORM FORCES A DELAY IN SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: Storm clouds charged with lightning forced a one-day postponement of the launching of the space shuttle Discovery today. The five astronauts were set to try again Sunday morning to get their mission under way.

title: DIALING TEDDY KOLLEK
description: Perhaps the greatest compliment possible for Thomas L. Friedman's article ''Teddy Kollek's Jerusalem'' (Aug. 4) is the fact that even I enjoyed it.

title: END THE DRAG OF SPECIAL TAX BREAKS
description: A HALLMARK of the Reagan Administration's economic policies is to boost economic growth and productivity by dramatically increasing investment. So far, the hoped-for investment boom has yet to materialize. But even if it should come about, it will not bring the desired results. According to virtually every empirical study of the factors that are crucial to economic growth, the real priority should be to boost the quality of investment, not just the quantity.

title: NEW YORK STYLE (AT A REASONABLE PRICE)
description: One of the great strengths of the American ready-to-wear industry is that it seasonally produces up-to-the-minute clothing in a variety of price ranges. The latest fashion, whatever it may be, can be obtained for as low as $50 or as high as $5,000.

title: WHAT'S BETWEEN THE LINES AT THE MOSCOW BOOK FAIR
description: WHEN the first Moscow Book Fair was announced in 1977, American publishers were generally receptive. In addition to hoping to sell books in the Soviet Union, many saw it as an opportunity to contribute to detente. Most agreed to participate only on the condition that Jewish publishers and Israel also be allowed, a condition the Russians finally accepted. Once in Moscow some of the Americans attended a well-publicized dinner with prominent Soviet dissident writers. But by the time of the next Moscow fair, in 1979, several of those writers were in prison or had been exiled, and American publishers and writers had issued protests.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CHIC NAIROBI
description: Well-traveled writers report on the special flair that constitutes style in cities East and West.

title: SONGS OF THE PAST: AN ACCOMPANIMENT TO HISTORY
description: Turn historians loose and there's no telling where they'll discover the past. Here, for example, Virginia Yans McLaughlin has been mining for meaning in the lament of a song.

title: LAND O' THE LEAL
description: To the Editor: I savored the articles on Scotland. Two years ago my 18-year-old daughter and I saw much of Scotland through the windows of British trains.

title: MOZART'S BRILLIANCE IS NOT DIMMED BY ANALYSIS
description: Many people, including some musicians, resent the idea that musical genius can be studied, let alone explained, and it would be interesting to know why. Mozart, we learned from ''Amadeus,'' was a buffoon whom God inexplicably chose to take down his musical dictation, an eccentric fellow with a gift for accurate stenography. Beyond that, all must remain mystery. No peeking behind the veil, please. But why? Are we afraid we might discover the Wizard of Oz there?

title: David Peterson, Paige Matthews Exchange Vows
description: Paige Matthews, a daughter of Corinne Witt Wiley of Belvedere, Calif., was married there yesterday to David Peterson, a son of Sally Peterson and Peter G. Peterson, both of New York. The Revs.

title: SITTING IN UNEASY JUDGMENT
description: HE sat there quiet, subdued, neither insolent nor depressed; eyes blank in the impassive dark face. He stared at nothing, neither his accuser, nor his attorney, neither judge nor jury. Even when his attorney spoke to him, there was not the slightest animation or shift of emotion. He was a totally immobile mask. As he stared, his hands lay loosely clasped, partly covered by the limp, tacky shirtsleeves.

title: GOING ON IN THE NORTHEAST
description: QUAHOGS IN WICKFORD For those who love clams, especially the hard-shell quahog, the historic harbor village of Wickford, R.I., is the place to be today. The third annual International Quahog Festival is being held there from 10 A.M. to 8 P.M., and just about nothing is being left out.

title: PLAY IT AGAIN, ON HOLD
description: When telephone callers to the Arena Stage are put on hold these days, they are treated to a rendition of Johann Sebastian Bach's Brandenburg Concerto No. 3.

title: Thrashing the World to Punish Pretoria
description: To the Editor:

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: SOMETIMES in writing, as in real estate, location is everything. So it would seem for Jamie Sayen, author of ''Einstein in America'' (Crown Publishers, New York, $17.95) because, as he said in a recent interview, ''It was my good fortune to live next door to 112 Mercer Street, Einstein's home during his years in Princeton.''

title: BEARS MAKE FORAYS IN STATE
description: EARLIER this year, Conservation Officer William McNamara received a report of a bear wandering near Route 44 in Winsted. When he arrived at the scene, he found a black bear of between 150 and 200 pounds. He also found a large group of people who had stopped on the highway to view the creature and several police officers who were trying to keep onlookers away.

title: CONSUMER RATES
SUICIDE IS LINDED TO 2 SLAYINGS
description: A Queens man fatally shot himself in a Woodside tavern Friday, and a note that he left led detectives to his apartment, where they found the bodies of his wife and a friend of hers, the police reported.

title: SYNFUELS CORP. IS RUNNING ON EMPTY
description: It was to be America's most ambitious peacetime industrial mobilization, an undertaking which President Carter predicted would be ''greater than the sum total of the interstate highway system, the Marshall Plan and the space program all combined.''

title: VARIED CONCERTS AT SUMMER'S END
description: AS we get ready to turn the corner into September, it is time to consider, if not the last rose, at least the last concerts of this bountiful summer season. This Thursday at 8 P.M., for instance, you can enjoy an orchestral evening under the stars at Seaside Park in Bridgeport.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: WANTING. By Angela Huth. (Macmillan, $14.95.) The English novelist Angela Huth's fifth novel is a semi-satirical tale of interlocking and frustrated desires.

title: An Earned Right
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPACT 8-MIULLIMETER EQUIPMENT IS CHALLENGING THE HEAVYWEIGHTS
description: A year ago, it seemed a dubious innovation with uncertain prospects. Today, many people still consider it a dubious innovation, but the prospects for 8-millimeter video are looking up. Before long, the market will be so inundated with equipment of this type that the new format will be impossible to ignore and more likely will take off in a big way.

title: FLORIDA OFFICIALS ARE LOBBIED OVER CLEMENCY IN MERCY CASE
description: Roswell Gilbert's fight to leave prison while appealing a life sentence for what he argued was the mercy killing of his disease-stricken wife has stirred people across the nation to lobby the Florida Cabinet on the question of clemency.

title:
ART;

ENIGMATIC INTERIORS AT NOYES
description: TO GET out of the heat, one might try ''An Inside Place'' at the Noyes Museum here.

title: PENANG ISLAND
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned from a stimulating visit to Southeast Asia, we would like to comment on the article ''On Penang Island, A Legend Lives'' (Travel, June 30).

title: THE MIND OF MENGELE
description: I am the mother of 5-month-old twin boys. It is one thing to know generalities about Mengele; it is quite another to read specifics about his ''experiments'' while your own babies sleep.

title: COACH IN JAPAN WITH ALL-STARS
description: BEGINNING today, Westchester Community College's basketball coach will be helping the United States all-college basketball team in the World University Games in Kobe, Japan.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Service Slowdown The Government's index of leading economic indicators for July will not gladden many hearts when it is released on Friday. The index, which forecasts economic trends, will show a gain of only three-tenths of 1 percent for July compared with June's rise of 1 percent, says Raymond T. Dalio, president of Bridgewater Associates in Wilton, Conn.

title: ALMOST LEASED UP
description: When Olympia & York announced five years ago that it would put six million square feet of office space in four buildings in the World Financial Center, the eight-million-square-foot commercial complex it is developing in Battery Park City, skeptics questioned whether the developers would be able to fill the buildings at a time when several other large downtown projects would be coming on the market.

title: THE ENVIRONMENT
description: ASIDE from major nationwide citizens' suits such as those involving workers at the former Johns Manville asbestos plant in Somerset County or veterans exposed to Agent Orange - the toxic herbicide used in Veitnam -there have been relatively few major environmental lawsuits on behalf of citizens of New Jersey.

title: Dust Tracks In Moscow
description: It was just the sort of thing Karla might have used to keep tabs on Smiley, a powder that enables the authorities to tell where someone has been, whom he has been there with and, perhaps, whether anything was passed between them. But last week the United States angrily insisted it was fact, not fiction, accusing the Soviet Union of resorting to a little-known chemical, nitrophenylpentadienal, to track the comings and goings of diplomatic personnel at the United States Embassy in Moscow and, possibly, journalists, business executives and others.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 25, 1985 Fiction 1 FIRST AMONG EQUALS, by Jeffrey Archer. (Pocket, $4.50.) Three young men vie to be chosen Prime Minister of Britain.

title: GETTING INTO SHAPE
description: For those seeking reading matter to deflect small children from television, the Library of Congress has a new suggestion that's actually about 120 years old.

title: STUDY SHOWS U.S. RELIANCE ON SOUTH AFRICA METALS
description: The strategic importance of South Africa to the United States has long been stressed by the Reagan Administration, but a recent Commerce Department report paints a new portrait of strong American dependence on that country for strategic metals that are critical in industries ranging from aerospace and petroleum to jewelry and glass making.

title: SEX EDUCATION: 3 CHOICES
description: ELEVENTH-and 12th-grade students at Lindenhurst Senior High School this fall will become the first students on Long Island to be able to choose the type of sex education they want.

title: FAY S. ROOSEVELT IS MARRIED
description: Fay Satterfield Roosevelt, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Julian Kean Roosevelt of Oyster Bay, L.I., was married there yesterday to Julian Potter Fisher 2d, the son of Mrs. Peter Rowe Fisher of Oyster Bay and the late Mr. Fisher. The Rev. Robert T. Hollett and the Rev. Peter Pierson officiated at the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church.

title: ELLIOTT STILL TRYING FOR MILLION BONUS
description: It has been 13 years since anyone has dominated stock-car racing as Bill Elliott has this season. The 29-year-old driver from Dawsonville, Ga., has won 9 of 18 races run so far this year. He needs only 4 victories in the 12 remaining races to match Richard Petty's record of 13, set in 1972.

title: NEW CHALLENGE FOR DENNARD
description: Ron Brown, Jerry Butler and John Jefferson, wide receivers by trade, have never played on the same team. Yet their moves over the last year or so have had a profound effect on another wide receiver, who now finds himself playing for his third team in three seasons.

title: FREE TRADE
description: To the Editor:

title: OBESITY SUIT
description: CATHERINE McDERMOTT spent 10 years in court trying to gain a job as a systems analyst with the Xerox Corporation, a position she was denied after the doctor who conducted her pre-employment physical determined that, at 5 feet 6 and 249 pounds, she was obese.

title: BETWEEN A ROCK AND A HARD PLACE: GETTING PAINT OFF STONE
description: CHEMICAL paint removers, widely available in paint and hardware stores, are one of the fastest and easiest methods for removing paint from all kinds of surfaces. This is especially true where scraping or sanding is impractical - for example, on bricks, cement blocks or other heavily textured surfaces.

title: KELESI, A QUALIFIER, BEATS NO. 1 SUKOVA
description: Fifteen-year-old Helen Kelesi of Canada scored a dramatic 7-6 7-6 upset of top-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia today in the semifinals of the Virginia Slims Central New York women's tennis tourney.

title: A CENTER FOR GUIDE DOGS
description: ANTICIPATION is an essential part of breeding and training dogs - anticipation of young puppies, anticipation of new owners and anticipation of enriched human and canine lives as new ''families'' are created.

title: IDYLLS OF MINNESOTA
description: LAKE WOBEGON DAYS By Garrison Keillor. Illustrated. 337 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: New Style, Old Crimes
description: They lived in $500,000 homes, drove fancy sports cars and kept in constant touch with one another with beepers. Despite their contemporary style, law enforcement officials said, the 26 men indicted last week in New Jersey were engaged in traditional racketeering activities, including loan-sharking.

title: MIDEAST PEACE BID SEEN AT CROSSROAD
description: Officials here and in Egypt say they believe that efforts to revive Arab-Israeli peace talks are at a critical juncture, headed for either a significant breakthrough or a deadlock.

title: NETS GOT THE RIGHT GURY ON THE 2d TRY
description: IF you ask me, Dave Wohl is the perfect choice as head coach of the Nets. A much better choice, in fact, than the team's original selection, Villanova's Rollie Massimino. I'll tell you why. First of all, Rollie is the quintessential college coach, the kind who likes to think of his players as his sons. In a way, Massimino is like a chubby Ward Cleaver, the character from the 50's television show ''Leave It to Beaver.'' And Massimino's Villanova players, like Ward Cleaver's sons, Wally and the Beaver, have come to treat their ''dad'' with utmost respect and admiration.

title: HIGH HOME PRICES SPUR REMODELERS
description: With soaring real-estate prices making it cheaper to renovate houses than buy new ones, homeowners in the metropolitan area are adding on to their houses or finishing attics and basements more than ever before, according to zoning officials and contractors.

title: LYSSA SCHWARTZ MARRIES
description: At Temple Judea in Manhasset, L.I., yesterday Lyssa Hope Schwartz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Schwartz of East Hills, L.I., was married to Daniel Steven Goldberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford H. Goldberg of West Orange and Long Beach Island, N.J. Rabbi Abner Bergman, assisted by Cantor Richard Berman, performed the ceremony. Mrs. Goldberg graduated in June from the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law of Yeshiva University. Her husband is an associate at Goldman Sachs & Company in New York.

title: Government's Wider Role in Brown v. Board
description: To the Editor:

title: JULIE FULLER AND EARL F. MCINTIRE MARRY
description: The marriage of Julie Fuller, the daughter of Mrs. McIntosh Fuller of Riverside, Conn., and Robert Ferrey Fuller of Greenwich, Conn., and Earl F. McIntire, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter McIntire of Ann Arbor, Mich., took place yesterday in Ann Arbor. The Rev. Dr. William C. Hillegonds performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.

title: WALTON SEES GAINS DESPITE JETS' LOSS
description: In the emotional cauldron of a Jets-Giants game, there can be such a thing as a good loss. That was how Coach Joe Walton of the Jets saw the result tonight even though his young, struggling team had suffered its third consecutive preseason defeat.

title: Jennifer C. Cook Weds Will Ruhl
description: Jennifer Curtis Cook, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Francis Cook Jr. of Dedham and Hyannis Port, Mass., was married yesterday to William Taggart Ruhl, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. E. Ruhl of Asheville, N.C. The Rev. George E. Andrews, headmaster of St. George's School in Newport, R.I., performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's-by-the-Sea Episcopal Chapel in Hyannis Port.

title: HOUSE MOVES, QUALITY REMAINS
description: ABOUT six weeks ago, Veranda in Glen Cove moved from its pale blue, velvet-lined jewel box of a restaurant to new premises across the street. The new location, a former diner, is now unrecognizable in a conversion expanded and sheathed in fresh white siding, with a porchlike entry that actually makes the name Veranda more relevant.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE GLEANERS IT HAS been going on throughout the world since biblical days, and according to Ron Leuthardt, executive secretary of the Long Island Farm Bureau, it still occurs during every harvest on Long Island.

title: EAST GERMANY CELEBRATES BACH
description: The season marking Johann Sebastian Bach's 300th birthday is drawing to a close, but record releases marking that milestone pour forth unabated. One interestingly assembled series is the ''Bach Leipzig Edition,'' on East Germany's Capriccio label.

title: Martha Gilkeson Marries in Ohio
description: Martha Baldwin Gilkeson, a daughter of Dr. Robert Chapman Gilkeson of Los Angeles and Nancy Stevens Gilkeson of Cleveland, was married yesterday to Peter Driggs Todd, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Todd of Rye, N.Y. The Rev. Mary Von Weise performed the ceremony at St. Christopher's Episcopal Church in Gates Mills, Ohio.

title: METS, DARLING TOP PADRES, 5-1
description: For one day the joyous, rollicking season of the Mets had been interrupted. Then last night, everything picked up where it had left off and without a dramatic touch missing.

title: BACK FENCES OF THE MIND
description: GOSSIP By Patricia Meyer Spacks. 287 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: LONDON FLAIR
description: A summer afternoon in London. A fabulous creature emerges into the sunlight, blinking furiously after the intimate gloom of some designer shop. Its hair - ''it'' being of no easily determined sex - is blue-black; its face, powdered to a deathly white; its eyes, ringed in sooty shadow. It flaunts a fitted jacket of creamy slubbed silk, the front firmly buttoned up to a high standing collar, the shape flaring from the waist to fall in gentle curves at the knee. Beneath this trails a sarong of fragile muslin swept in drapes over tight white leggings. On its feet are embroidered slippers; around its neck, a torrent of gilt and pearl, and on its head, a confection of tortured straw. It pauses to cross the road and stands, mute, between a young man and an elderly couple.

title: SEWAGE WARNING REDUCES CROWDS AT 2 WILDWOOD BEACHES IN JERSEY
description: Weekend crowds at beaches in North Wildwood and Wildwood Crest were smaller than usual today, following the posting of signs banning swimming due to potential health hazards from raw sewage discharged into Atlantic Ocean waters.

title: 2 Blasts in Downtown Milan
description: Two bombs exploded in downtown Milan within minutes of each other Friday night, injuring three passers-by, the authorities said. No one took responsibility for the blasts.

title: Frances Perkins's Role
description: To the Editor:

title: PIQUET GAINS POLE SPOT
description: Steady rain during today's final qualifying session left Nelson Piquet of Brazil in a Brabham-B.M.W. holding the pole position for Sunday's Dutch Grand Prix.

title: GIANTS DEFEAT JETS IN OVERTIME, 34-31
description: Last Saturday, before a crowd of 1,400, Eric Schubert kicked the extra point that gave the Lakeland Regional High School alumni of Wanaque, N.J., a 7-6 victory over the Butler High School alumni. Tonight, before 60,918 spectators at Giants Stadium, he kicked a 30-yard field goal at 5 minutes 26 seconds of overtime. That gave the Giants a 34-31 victory over the Jets in their annual preseason game at Giants Stadium.

title: THE NEXT NEW YORK'S FINEST
description: The thousands of new police officers appearing on New York City streets are not an entirely reassuring sight. Mayor Koch has rightly given high priority to rebuilding a department decimated by the 1975 fiscal crisis. Yet the experience of the last year makes painfully clear that hiring isn't enough. The 13,500 officers hired in the last five years create urgent questions of deployment and control, questions for voters to contemplate as they decide how to vote in the Sept. 10 primary.

title: A GOOD COMPLAINT IS A JOY FOREVER
description: THERE are two kinds of complainers. There are those who bray in a nasal tone, like discontented donkeys. This type of complainer is, of course, thoroughly objectionable.

title: UNION SQUARE
description: A festive ceremony was held in May marking the $3.6 million restoration of Union Square Park in Manhattan. The park, just north of 14th Street at Broadway, had become a haven for drug dealers.

title: MARGARET MEAD FESTIVAL OF ETHNOLOGICAL FILMS
description: A journey into the lives of the people of South America, Europe and the United States will be offered at the ninth Margaret Mead Film Festival, beginning Sept. 9 at 6:30 P.M. at the American Museum of Natural History, Central Park West at 79th Street. More than 40 ethnological films will be shown during the four-day festival, with many of the directors present at the screenings.

title: Jazz
description: Charlie Parker, the great alto saxophonist and one-man modernizer of the jazz tradition, is as imposing and influential a figure as he was at the time of his death 20 years ago. ''Bird Lives!,'' the saxophonist's followers used to scrawl on walls around Manhattan; now there's a ubiquitous poster with the same headline, advertising ''A Salute to the Genius of Charlie Parker'' taking place at 8 on Saturday night, Aug. 31, at Town Hall.

title: THE VIRTUE OF PATIENCE
description: There is no one frame of mind best suited to chess. In many encounters, it is important to be adventurous and optimistic, the sort of player who confidently charges into complications whose outcome cannot be envisaged clearly. In others, it is more useful to be the scoffing defender, the sort of player who defies any opponent to overturn what he believes is sound and durable.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WORKS BY PATIENTS Dozens of works by patients of the Harlem Valley Psychiatric Center of Wingdale, N.Y., will be exhibited until Sept. 13 in the third-floor gallery of an outpatient clinic at 20 Church Street in White Plains, one of several clinics operated by the state throughout the county. The gallery is sponsored by the Central Westchester Community Advisory Board of the Psychiatric Center, and is open weekdays from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M., and from 4 to 7 P.M. Thursdays.

title: SCHANBERG'S GARDEN
description: To the Editor:

title: CARDINAL INSISTS NUNS RETRACT ASBORTION VIEW
description: Twenty-four nuns who contend that Roman Catholics can have differing views on abortion are coming under increasing pressure from the Vatican to retract a public statement they made on the issue and pledge adherence to traditional church teachings.

title: Bonn''s Chief Counterspy Goes East
description: Hundreds of thousands of East Germans emigrated to West Germany during the 19 years that Hans Joachim Tiedge, an immigrant himself, worked in the West German counterintelligence agency that keeps tabs on East German spies. The volume of traffic made his work harder in some ways and easier in others, as became clear last week: It was learned that Mr. Tiedge and three other well-placed immigrants had vanished, evidently back to the German Democratic Republic.

title: MODERN RACE BOATS CALLED LESS SAFE
description: The capsizing two weeks ago of Drum England, the 77-foot sailboat owned by British pop star, Simon Le Bon, is one of several recent disasters in offshore competition that raises serious questions about the safety of modern racing yachts. Are they, in fact, as safe as boats built 20 years ago?

title: CYNTHIA C. ZIEGLER WED TO PUBLISHER
description: Cynthia Curtis Ziegler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ziegler 3d of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Renfrew McDowell Brighton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Renfrew Brighton of Weston, Conn. The Rev. Ballard Dorsee, an Episcopal priest, officiated at the ceremony at an estate on Great Island.

title: Miss Baily Wed To Scott Wieler
description: The Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Cincinnati was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Mary McCord Baily, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Lippincott Baily of Cincinnati, and Scott Alan Wieler, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Wieler of Marlborough, Mass. The Rev. James Hanisian performed the ceremony.

title: TV'S PORTRAYAL OF CHILDREN CRITICIZED
description: Children on television bear little resemblance to children in the real world, according to a study by the National Commission of Working Women.

title: SPYING SUSPECT'S STATEMENTS TO F.B.I. AT ISSUE
description: The prosecution and defense have had little disagreement over the evidence presented in the first 12 days of the espionage trial here of Richard W. Miller, a former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: MIRROR IMAGES
description: We first notice them peering from the margins of illuminated manuscripts, then lurking at the edges of frescoes. Though we hear of (lost) examples as far back as the Greeks, painters were slow to take themselves as models because of their low social status.

title: ARCHIDIOCESE EXPANDING ITS CRIMINAL-JUSTICE ROLE
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York is expanding programs for criminal suspects, convicts and ex-offenders in a move to take a more active role in the criminal-justice system.

title: CRISTINA MUNOZ IS MARRIED TO DAVID E. EDELMAN
description: Cristina Munoz and David Edward Edelman were married yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marshall Munoz, parents of the bride, in Los Altos Hills, Calif. The bridegroom is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Norman H. Edelman of Princeton, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Philip McCrillis, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Cable TV
description: The Atlanta-based WTBS, cable's Goliath, continues to beam worthy vintage films our way. Take a contrasting pair due this week: ''The Talk of the Town'' and ''The Macomber Affair.''

title: U.S. FEELS THE HEAT ON SOUTH AFRICA
description: FUNERALS for blacks killed in South Africa's township violence have increasingly become political events in addition to being occasions for personal grief. Lately, the speakers have added a new theme. They denounce the United States almost as fervently as the white-minority Government in Pretoria.

title: YOUTHFUL STYLE
description: Popular looks for the fashionable young run the gamut from classic preppy to out-and-out camp - and include almost everything in between. Upwardly mobile post-baby-boomers have money to spend and a taste for dressing up and role-playing.

title: REISSUES EXPLORE JAZZ OF THE 50'S
description: If the labeling of successive periods of jazz - the Classic Era of the 1920's, the Big Band Era of the 1930's and 40's, the Be-bop Era of the 1940's and 50's - is to be brought up to date, this must be the Reissue Era. It is doubtful if such a wide range of jazz recordings of all periods and styles has ever been available as today, not only through the repackaging of old recordings by the companies that now own them but through mail order organizations such as the Smithsonian Institution, Time-Life, the Book-of-the-Month Club and the Franklin Mint Record Society.

title: SO NEAR THE UNITED STATES
description: SO FAR FROM GOD A Journey to Central America. By Patrick Marnham. 253 pp. New York: Elisabeth Sifton Books/Viking. $17.95.

title: PICKING THE PROPER VOLUME LEVEL
description: Most people play their compact disks - commonly called CD's - a lot louder than they do conventional LP records. In case anyone wonders how this information was obtained, be assured that we didn't eavesdrop through keyholes. Rather, we relied on reports by audio dealers that their customers nearly always like to listen at higher volume levels when a sound system is demonstrated with a CD than with a nondigital program source.

title: W. EUGENE SMITH THROUGH A LENS, DARKLY
description: HIS VOCATION, WILLIAM Eugene Smith once said, was to do nothing less than record, by word and photograph, the human condition. No one could really succeed at such a job; yet Smith almost did. By the time he died in 1978 in Tucson, Ariz. - at the age of 59 -he had created at least 50 of the most powerful photographic images of life at its darkest and tenderest moments.

title: TERMINAL SENTENCE?
description: A Federal judge last week reduced the 55-year prison sentence of Roy L. Williams, the former president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, but that provided little solace to Mr. Williams and his family. Judge Prentice Marshall ordered Mr. Williams, who is 70 and is terminally ill with severe emphysema and heart problems, to serve a 10-year sentence at a prison hospital in Springfield, Mo.

title: HALLORAN COMPLETES PASSAGE OF FLUTIE
description: The undersized quarterback whose exploits made him a big man on campus has already completed his first season as a professional. Doug Flutie is back at Boston College, but he is just a student now, completing his degree instead of touchdown passes. On Chestnut Hill, where the popular opinion is that the football program began with Flutie's arrival in 1981, the task will be to prove the program did not end with his departure.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: WHATEVER HAPPENED TO LADY CHATTERLEY'S LOVER? By Martin Levin. (Andrews, McMeel & Parker, Paper, $6.95.) Epilogues were common appendages to novels for generations, perhaps because these novels were written when it was believed that good eventually holds sway and evil does not.

title: NEW & NOTEWORTHY
description: LYING IN BED, by Mark Harris. (McGraw-Hill, $6.95.) Mark Harris's 11th novel is a series of letters between an impotent novelist-professor and a multitude of people. In 1984 Jerome Charyn remarked here that if the book ''is scratchy and verbose, it is also extravagantly funny and sad. . . . a squawky story about the telling of stories, a long, playful epistle to readers and writers.'' COLETTE, by Joanna Richardson. (Laurel/Dell, $4.95.) Colette, who died in 1954, lived 81 years. She was France's most famous female author, and even had a brief career as a dancer, mime and actress. Reviewers said in 1984 that while Joanna Richardson tells all about the writer's scandals, she does so without making a scandal of the biography. Because so many Parisian authors had something to say about Colette, the book has been described as a ripe and witty anthology of modern French criticism. Miss Richardson has a great subject, one reviewer said, and does not waste a single nuance. DOUBLE YOKE, by Buchi Emecheta. (George Braziller, $5.95.) Buchi Emecheta is a Nigerian-born writer who has lived in England since 1962 and who will be teaching at Harvard University this fall. This, her seventh novel, is about two students - one female, one male - at a Nigerian university. Their mutual love is tested by their conflicts with Nigerian society's traditional views of male and female roles. In 1983 reviewers complimented the author on her perception and the originality of her writing.

title: Schanberg's Garden
description: To the Editor:

title: NO NAME, NO FAME IN DUEL WITH ROSE
description: IN a summer 12 years ago, I was batting practice pitcher for the Cincinnati Reds. Nobody could realize it then that Pete Rose was just about halfway toward Ty Cobb's record of 4,191 hits. He was the hometown star on a team that was coming off a National League championship.

title: BECKER CREATES AIR OF UNPREDICTABILITY
description: UNTIL Wimbledon, any talk about the changing face of men's tennis sounded like idle speculation or wishful thinking. Until Boris Becker became the first unseeded player to win the world's most prestigious championship, there wasn't any reason to suspect that John McEnroe, Ivan Lendl, Jimmy Connors and Mats Wilander would lose their hold on the Grand Slam events. Even in retirement, Bjorn Borg was customarily a bigger topic of conversation at Wimbledon than all but the top-seeded players.

title: COORDINATOR SOUGHT FOR WOMEN'S AID
description: THE State Labor Department has created a new post to help ''displaced homemakers'' enter the job market, the first such statewide effort.

title: FOLLOWING MENOTTI TO SCOTLAND
description: Friday night, Connecticut opened in Scotland.

title: DRIVING TO WORK: ONE TOUGH JOB
description: I SHOULD have been suspicious when that recording went off the other morning before I even got out of bed. ''Good morning, Mrs. Barrett,'' the voice said. ''Your mission, should you decide to accept it, is to get from your home in Huntington Station to your job in Roslyn Heights this morning.''

title: INSURANCE
description: To the Editor; Frances Cerra made some misleading statements concerning commercial insurance (''The Hard Search for Property Insurance,'' Personal Finance, July 28). She referred to the period of ''cash-flow'' underwriting as ''a three-year period that ended last fall.''

title: A SPRING OF PROMISE BEFORE FRUSTRATIONS
description: IN the spring my vegetable garden was a picture of neatness and a wellspring of promise.

title: Ann M. McGill Exchanges Vows With Dennis Chien
description: Ann Marie McGill, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick McGill of Phoenixville, Pa., was married yesterday to Dennis P. Chien, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James T. T. Chien of Brooklyn. The Rev. Richard Williams performed the ceremony at the St. Basil the Great Roman Catholic Church in Kimberton, Pa.

title: FINAL CONCERTS BRING THE SUMMER SEASON TO A CLOSE
description: AS we get ready to turn the corner into September, let us consider the last concerts of the summer season. This afternoon, for instance, two enticing programs beckon from the Bronx, while in Katonah, the Caramoor festival is winding up with a Bach bonanza: the resident St. Lukes Chamber Ensemble playing all six of the Brandenburg Concertos. The starting time is 5:30 P.M. and the Carmoor reservations number is 232-5035.

title: SLIPPERS PAD INTO DAYLIGHT
description: AFTER padding around the town house all these years, at-home velvet evening slippers for men have kicked up their heels and are stepping outside. Stylishly, too, as befits footwear that retails in the vicinity of $100 a pair.

title: APPEAL TO BE HEARD ON MISS NEW JERSEY
description: A NEW JERSEY woman's contention that a rival who defeated her for the Miss New Jersey title in Cherry Hill last month was not qualified will be heard by a two-judge Appellate Division panel in Trenton on Tuesday.

title: GARY GIBLEN MARRIES ANA MARIA ITURRIAGA
description: Ana Maria Iturriaga, a daughter of Maj. Gen. Gaston Iturriaga of the Peruvian Air Force, retired, and Mrs. Iturriaga of Lima, Peru, and Guayaquil, Ecuador, was married yesterday to Gary Mark Giblen, a son of Shirley Giblen of Phoenix and the late Irwin Giblen. Judge Robert J. Corcoran of the Arizona Court of Appeals officiated at the Arizona Biltmore in Phoenix.

title: MT: LAUREL: PROBLEMS PERSIST
description: ALTHOUGH the Township of Mount Laurel finally has a housing plan and New Jersey has a Fair Housing Act, not everyone involved in the 14-year-old dispute over how the suburbs should develop and whether the poor will be able to live in them believes those issues are about to be resolved.

title: BEST SELLERS
description: Aug. 25, 1985 Fiction

title: TOKYO SAVOIR-FAIRE
description: The current crop of Japanese designers began showing their styles in Paris about five years ago, to empty rooms scattered around the city. Today, their presentations take place in the same tents as the French ready-to-wear shows in the Tuileries Gardens, and they are jammed. The Japanese openings are regarded as the start of the ready-to-wear showing season.

title: COOL BIRDS FLY SOUTH IN JULY
description: When do Americans go to the tropics? In the winter, usually. Why do they go? To get warm, mostly. The idea is to lie in the sun drinking papaya juice and perspiring gently, while back home one's neighbors trudge around in heavy overcoats, dodging the slush flung up from the wheels of taxis.

title: PRETORIA ARRESTS 27 TOP OPPONENTS AS CLASHES GO ON
description: The South African authorities said today that 27 leading opposition figures had been seized in the last 24 hours in the newest crackdown on dissent.

title: MILAN ELAN
description: Ever since the Middle Ages, when it was moneylender to the world, Milan has been synonymous with wealth. Today the city has 424 different banks, with 770 branches. And, on the fashionable Milanese woman, money walks.

title: HAIR ANALYSIS LABS CRITICIZED
description: People who consult hair analysis laboratories to determine the state of their health may be frightened into believing they are seriously ill, says a doctor who found a lab that told a healthy teen-ager she might have hardening of the arteries.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: SUNDAY, AUGUST 25, 1985
description: International

title: 2 CONCERTS TO AID ANTI-HUNGER EFFORT
description: THERE will be no international video hookups. No stadiums full of star-crazed rock fans. And in one case, the money raised will not go to starving Africans, but to Connecticut's hungry instead.

title: JACKSON CRITICIZES DEMOCRATS ON PARTY RULES
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today called on the Democratic Party to break down barriers against minority groups rather than continuing ''its present course of resisting and being dragged along kicking and screaming into the future.''

title: HOW MEDIA CAN HELP COLLEGES
description: IT is, by now, a recurring, all-too-familiar scenario. An athletic scandal breaks on a college campus. It could involve falsified grade records; courses not attended but satisfactorily credited to a transcript; unauthorized payments to team members, in one form or another; phantom jobs not performed but paid for; disreputable behavior by athletes involving drugs, social conduct, or theft; ''point-shaving'' related to gambling interests; flexible or manipulated ''standards'' in mindless courses or curricula that enable academically unqualified athletes to enter, continue in, or graduate from some college or university.

title: Miss Townsend Is Wed Upstate
description: Shelley Brainard Townsend and Thomas Derby Graham were married yesterday by Canon George F. French at Christ Episcopal Church in Cooperstown, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Louis Busch Hager of New York and Cooperstown and Lyman Bass Townsend of Pittsford, N.Y. Mr. Graham is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell D. Graham of Montclair, N.J.

title: PRISON MINISTRY TAKES A NEW APPROACH
description: DURING his 15 years as a corrections officer with Westchester County, Benjamin Jones said he has noticed a lot of changes in the inmate population. He has seen greater numbers of younger people being incarcerated and has watched them return to the penetentiary again and again.

title: ISRAEL CENTER HONORS SPIES WHOSE NAMES WERE AS SECRET AS THEIR MISSIONS
description: Some of them were killed by double agents; others were hanged in the central squares of Damascus or Baghdad, and still others died years ago in circumstances so shrouded in mystery that even today no one will speak about them.

title: CLASSES FOR GIFTED PROVOKE DEBATE
description: WHERE - if anywhere -should a line be drawn separating exceptionally intelligent children from the ordinary?

title: WEB-FOOTED BABIES AND PEOPLE IN EXTREMIS
description: THROUGH THE SAFETY NET By Charles Baxter. 216 pp. New York: Viking. $14.95. RUMOR And Other Stories. By James Robison. 169 pp. New York: Summit Books. $14.95.

title: PCB DISPUTE VEXES BASS FISHERMEN
description: ONE of summer's most familiar seafood dishes - baked or broiled striped bass - has been conspicuously missing from the menus of many New York restaurants this season because of the warning issued last spring by state health officials concerning the unacceptable levels of PCB's in some of the fish.

title: SHELTERING THEATERS FROM GROWTH
description: THE theater zoning district, a 50-block stretch in midtown Manhattan that has been sheltered by blanket zoning guidelines since the late 1960's, faces more restrictions as the City Planning Commission next month begins public hearings on proposed new limitations.

title: CORRECTION
description: The headline of an article last Sunday about three American shoe companies - Timberland, Reebok and Rockport - mistakenly suggested that all three companies' shoes are manufactured in the United States. All of Reebok's shoes and 88 percent of Rockport's are made abroad.

title: CAN IACOCCA KEEP CHRYSLER MOVING?
description: LEE A. IACOCCA has become a best-selling author and his Chrysler Corporation is making more money on each car and truck it sells than even the mighty General Motors Corporation. A company that six years ago was teetering on the edge of bankruptcy and begging for Federal help has emerged as a small, effective and feisty combatant in the increasingly competitive automobile business.

title: A Peacemaker's Violent Death
description: Sikh assassins last week tried to destroy Rajiv Gandhi's campaign to negotiate a solution to one of the murderous religious and ethnic feuds that threaten the Indian nation. Four gunmen killed Harchand Singh Longowal, president of the Sikh mainstream party, Akali Dal, less than a month after he signed an accord with Prime Minister Gandhi aimed at ending three years of separatist violence in the state of Punjab.

title: NEW WOMEN, NEW PROBLEMS
description: DISORDERLY CONDUCT Visions of Gender in Victorian America. By Carroll Smith-Rosenberg. Illustrated. 357 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The University of Life Thomas Gibson Bowles, grandfather of Nancy, Jessica, Unity and Diana Mitford, was, even by British standards, something of a character. In ''The House of Mitford'' (Viking), by Jonathan Guinness with Catherine Guinness, Bowles defends the working classes. They are not uneducated, he says, but Thoroughly well educated; their whole powers, mental and physical, are cultivated and developed by them in the very highest degree for the work they have to do in life. . . . When members of Parliament know as much of history and statesmanship as ploughmen do of ploughing; when ministers can conduct a negotiation as safely as a hansom cab-driver guides his cab, or a bargeman his lighter; when parsons have brought their light to shine before men as bright and as true under all circumstances as a few common sailors keep the Varne or the Owers in all weathers . . . and when ladies have learnt to wear their dresses as well as their sempstresses stitch them - then I shall listen with more patience to them when they talk of others being uneducated. A Domed and Glowing Space In ''The Creative Explosion'' (Cornell), John E. Pfeiffer describes the discovery of fire, several hundred thousand years ago.

title: PADRES' OFFENSE IS WEAKENED BY THE DEPARTURE OF WIGGINS
description: THE SAN DIEGO PADRES look like a team that won't repeat as National League champions, and they could blame cocaine for that look. ''We miss Wiggins,'' Ballard Smith, the Padres' president, said. Smith was not regretting the trade that sent Alan Wiggins to Baltimore, but he was candidly focusing on what is most likely the primary reason the Padres have fallen significantly behind the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: WROTE PLAYS AND SCREEN COMEDIES
description: Morrie Ryskind, who wrote or collaborated on comedies and satires ranging from the Pulitzer Prize-winning musical ''Of Thee I Sing'' to the Marx Brothers film ''Animal Crackers,'' died yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 89 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Outdoors column and an accompanying picture caption in last Sunday's sports section mispelled the name of a contender in a professional bass fishing tournament in Arkansas. He is Don Caggiano.

title: TENANTS TEST LAW TO RESOLVE REPAIR DISPUTES
description: ANNIE SMITH was recalling the times she brought an umbrella into the bathroom because so much water was pouring through the ceiling.

title:
GARDENING;

SOME CHORES FOR LATE SUMMER
description: AS summer winds down, it is again time to think seriously about several gardening tasks. All are best done early to take advantage of the ideal fall growing conditions.

title: HOYAS LOSE GRAHAM
description: Michael Graham, a 6-foot-9-inch forward who helped Georgetown to the national collegiate championship in 1984, will not return to Georgetown this fall. Graham, after averaging 4.7 points and 4 rebounds a game as a freshman, did not play last season because of academic problems. According to The Hoyas, the school newspaper, Rev. Thomas Healy, the president of Georgetown, said: ''He's had an open offer to come back on scholarship, but it was understood that he would not play basketball until he built a transcript which was respectable.''

title: WORKING AND DREAMING OF SUMMER NIGHTS ON SPEEDWAY
description: For years now, Gary Kiefert has had a private little dream.

title: SUITING UP
description: After playing on the golf team and getting cut from the boys' lacrosse squad, Elizabeth Balsley decided that the best test in sports was on the gridiron. An administrative law judge ruled last week that the 15-year-old high school junior should be allowed to pursue her dream of playing wide receiver for the North Hunterdon (N.J.) High School football team.

title: ERIC MICHAEL HUEBSCHER WEDS STEPHANIE D. LAZAR
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York yesterday Stephanie Diane Lazar, a daughter of Clare Lazar of New York and Amagansett, L.I., and the late Dr. Norman D. Lazar, was married to Eric Michael Huebscher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Huebscher of New Hyde Park, L.I. Rabbi Mordechai Winiarz performed the ceremony.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES WITH SOME COUNTY PRIVATE INVESTIGATORS
description: BOB MAGNUSSON is 6 feet 2 inches tall, blond and lean.

title: JOHN PAGLI JR. IS WED TO MISS MCANDREWS
description: Anne-marie McAndrews, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James J. McAndrews of Madison, Conn., and John Michael Pagli Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Pagli of Scarsdale, N.Y., were married yesterday. The Rev. Cyriac Maliekel performed the ceremony at St. Margaret Roman Catholic Church in Madison.

title: URSUS HORRIBILIS: DANGEROUS AND ENDANGERED
description: THE GRIZZLY BEAR By Thomas McNamee. With drawings by Gordon Allen. 308 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: DEFEATS ON THE HOME FRONT
description: THE YEARS OF MACARTHUR Volume Three: Triumph and Disaster 1945-1964. By D. Clayton James. Illustrated. 848 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $29.95. IN last volume of D. Clayton James's biography of Gen. Douglas MacArthur (1880-1964), the greatest military figure of his day turns to peace and revives the energies of the Japanese to develop a modern state. He then returns to war, in Korea, and, after a period of defeat, fashions the Inchon landings, one of the outstanding military feats of the century. He is honored to the point of idolatry, but then his reputation is eroded, and his judgments about the Korean War are proved wrong by a powerful offensive by Communist Chinese armies. Contemptuous of President Truman, impudent toward the Joint Chiefs of Staff, MacArthur is removed from command.

title: LONDON'S COURTS
description: To the Editor: Thanks to Donald Goddard's article, we relived some delightful hours of our own walks through the Inns of Court.

title: FRESH AIR CAMPERS RETURN TO WAITING ARMS
description: It was a time for smiles and tears, greetings and farewells when the remaining Fresh Air Fund youngsters returned home to New York City last week. The children, who spent two weeks at one of the organization's summer camps, streamed into the bus station at 175th Street and Broadway, where families and friends waited.

title: STIEB LOSES, NO HIT BID IN 9TH, BUT BLUE JAYS WIN
description: Dave Stieb gave up two home runs in the ninth inning tonight after coming within three outs of pitching the first no-hitter in the nine-year history of the Toronto Blue Jays, who went on to beat the Chicago White Sox, 6-3.

title: BOOKSTORES ARE DIFFERENT
description: To the Editor:

title: CAROLINE LANE WED TO TIMOTHY CALLIGAN
description: At the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., yesterday Caroline Diana Lane, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Marcus Lane of Greenwich, was married to Timothy Michael Calligan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dennis Calligan of Madison, N.J. The Rev. Walter Wagoner, a Congregational minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: TEACHERS IN SPAIN EAGER FOR THEIR NEW YORK TEST
description: Ignacio Galarraga walked out of an office in the Ministry of Education and Science here the other day, lighted a cigarette and said he felt ''agitado,'' which loosely means churning inside. He had just learned he was on his way to New York City to be a teacher.

title: FOR A COURTESANS CORPS
description: The nation has become blotto over Lotto. State governments have found a way to soak the poor, and the poor are lapping it up: Ten billion dollars a year is now being extracted legally from the pockets of the suckers, as the media lustily publicize the ''winners'' and beaten-down moralists mumble about the states' ill-gotten gains going toward good causes like education.

title: CASHING IN ON THE PENTAGON CONNECTION
description: Two victims of a Defense Department reorganization had their going-away parties last week in separate offices along the executive corridor of the Pentagon.

title: NEW LOCAL BANKS SAY SMALL IS BETTER
description: BY October, Raymond Cordani will make the step from bank regulator to bank officer, when the Summit National Bank opens in Torrington with him as its president.

title: BILINGUAL PUPILS SAID TO HAVE EDGE
description: Children who grow up speaking two languages display superior cognitive abilities and are more sophisticated than other children in their understanding of language, according to research reported at the meeting of the American Psychological Association here.

title: 'I FELT I HELD THE PASSWORD' - TRAVELS TO SHELLEY'S ROCKY SHORE
description: IT was the late autumn of 1972 when I came down to the Gulf of Spezia. By then I had been filling notebooks about Percy Bysshe Shelley for nearly three years, and was possessed by him, and the voices of his family and friends.

title: 1982-84 CARS RANKED BY ISURERS USING DAMAGE AND INJURY CLAIMS
description: Here is a list of automobile rankings by the Highway Loss Data Institute covering 1982-1984 cars, based on insurance industry examination of damage and injury claims.

title: SECURITY SHAKE-UP EXPECTED IN BONN AFTER DEFECTION
description: A significant shake-up of West Germany's intelligence operations appears imminent after the announced defection to East Germany of a senior counterintelligence officer, well-placed Government officials said today.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Furniture to Rent For Home, Office International Furniture Rentals of New York has headquarters and a showroom in Hawthorne, as well as a computerized warehouse there to service additional I.F.R. showrooms in Manhattan, in Jericho, L.I., and Stamford, Conn. There are 17 locations throughout the Northeast, including stores in New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Massachussetts.

title: A BOOST FOR CLINTON
description: The redevelopment of Clinton, the gritty residential and commercial neighborhood west of Times Square, will get a major boost with the completion of a 43-story rental apartment building now under construction at 42d Street and 11th Avenue.

title: 60 YEARS OF PASSION AND COMPASSION
description: WORDS THAT MUST SOMEHOW BE SAID Selected Essays of Kay Boyle 1927-1984. Edited and with an introduction by Elizabeth S. Bell. 262 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. $16.50.

title: No Peace, No Talks
description: India's attempt to sponsor peace talks between Sri Lanka Government officials and Tamil separatists failed last week in the face of renewed communal killing.

title: NOW, ONLY CRACKS AT HANCOCK TOWER
description: SOMETHING does not love the windows of Boston's sleek Hancock Tower. They started breaking in 1972, four years before the building opened, taking flight on the gusty breezes off the harbor.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: Guyana Leader Says He Plans To Seek Better U.S. Relations
description: Guyana's Government plans to improve its cool relations with the United States, Desmond Hoyte, the new President, said in an interview this week.

title: CHEKHOV'S STORIES THROUGH THE EYES OF SEVEN PLAYWRIGHTS
description: The first day of rehearsal began like any other. At 10:30 A.M., the 14 members of the Acting Company and their production crew gathered at 890 Broadway - commonly known as ''Michael Bennett's place'' - and, after the official group portrait, it was time for the actors to be seated around a large table with the author in attendance and launch into the first reading of the play.

title: MALTBIE, WATSON TIE FOR SERIES LEAD
description: Roger Maltbie continued to display a mature and tenacious game today on one of the PGA Tour's longest courses as he tied for the lead for the third straight day in the 24th annual NEC World Series of Golf.

title: CORNELL AGREEMENT REACHED
description: Negotiators for Cornell University and the United Auto Workers reached agreement tonight on a new contract. If approved by union members Sunday, the settlement would end a strike by service workers that began Friday as students began to arrive on campus.

title: PRO-SHOREHAM GROUP RAISING THE ANTE
description: A RECENTLY formed lobbying group created to help pave the way for the opening of the Shoreham nuclear power plant is causing concern among opponents of the plant.

title: Julia Means Talcott, an Artist, Is Wed To James Benjamin Meigs in Vermont
description: Julia Means Talcott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Hooker Talcott Jr. of Brookline, Mass., and Waterford, Vt., and James Benjamin Meigs, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert Randall Meigs of Portland, Ore., were married yesterday. The Rev. Francis H. Geer, the bride's cousin, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the Waterford Congregational Church.

title: Goode Urges End to Inquiry
description: Mayor W. Wilson Goode says he wants the Federal authorities to end a four-year investigation of police corruption in Philadelphia because ''we can't have two cooks in the same kitchen.'' The Mayor said Friday, ''I feel we have the capacity in the Police Department to root out corrupt behavior of police officers.'' Twenty-five officers, including the department's former No. 2 man, have been convicted or have pleaded guilty to charges stemming from the investigation.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:I plan to spend Dec. 20 to 30 in London. I know that almost all museums will be closed Dec. 24 to 26, but what about shops, restaurants and, most importantly, theaters? What, if anything, can I expect to find open during those three days? -N. P., Washington Answer:It's difficult to generalize this far in advance about London's traditional close-down during Christmas week, because the decision to close often depends on individual proprietors and managers. Most museums will close for the three days. Most stores will be open on Tuesday, Dec. 24 (although many will call it a day in midafternoon) and close on Dec. 25 and 26. (Dec. 26, or Boxing Day, as it is called, is, like Christmas Day, a public holiday.) A few shops are likely to take the whole week off. On the other hand, some will start post-Christmas sales on Dec. 27 or 28.

title: THEATER: 'PARIS BOUND A PHILIP BARRY COMEDY
description: In the first act of ''Paris Bound'' (in revival at the Berkshire Theater Festival), Philip Barry sets up his premise, neatly according to formula. A wealthy young couple - Yuppies of the 1920's - have just been married and are about to embark on a golden future together.

title: CALL IT PAKISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;

NEW ISREAL MEDAL DESIGNED BY HOLOGRAPHY
description: Government-sponsored medallic art tends to be stereotyped and straightforward with little or no originality. A new medal from Israel is clearly an exception to this rule. It carries a design by Yaacov Agam, an innovative Israeli-born artist and features holography which appears to be the first use of this process on a government-issued coin or medal.

title: PERSONAL STYLE
description: Designers, manufacturers and retailers have all come to realize that, although a businesswoman may wear tailored clothes and dark colors for her workday life, she wants to maintain her individuality underneath it all - probably in the form of a few frills. Increasingly, women are choosing lingerie of silk and satin. And that lingerie is often lavished with lace or tucks or embroidery.

title: F.B.I. SAYS 12,000 FAULTY REPORTS ON SUSPECTS ARE ISSUED EACH DAY
description: At least 12,000 invalid or inaccurate reports on suspects wanted for arrest are transmitted each day to Federal, state and local law-enforcement, agencies, according to projections by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: RIGGS STILL SMILING
description: Bobby Riggs, who pocketed at least $100,000 from his latest ''hustle'' Friday night when he and Vitas Gerulaitis lost an exhibition doubles challenge match to Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver at Atlantic City Convention Center, showed no chagrin after the 6-2, 6-3, 6-4 setback. ''Hey, I don't feel I'm embarrassed or disgraced by any means,'' said Riggs, 67 years old.

title: ON THE FRINGE
description: While southern Putnam County is nowhere close to matching neighboring Westchester County or Connecticut's Fairfield County in the size and scope of its office development, it has been growing in the last few years in its appeal to developers and office renters.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;

HORSES, RIDERS
description: HORSES. They paw at the ground, kick up dust, whinny and shake their manes. They trot jauntily around a ring, walk sedately, sometimes just stand still while people groom and fuss over them; their heads poke out of stalls with expressions one could anthropomorphize as soulful.

title: LAND O' THE LEAL
description: To the Editor: My wife and I were delighted by the articles devoted to the ''Land o' the Leal,'' Scotland (Travel, July 21), the land of our birth and growing-up days.

title: RETEST DEMANDED
description: Michel Viau, one of three Quebec weight lifters suspended last week after traces of anabolic steroids were found in their urine, claims he has not taken the drug since 1983 and is demanding to be retested. ''I have no proof I didn't take it,'' said Viau.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: FLEMINGTON HORSE EXPO Tiny Shetland ponies and the giant but gentle Clydesdales, elegant dressage and breakneck barrel racing -all will be part of the Horse Expo Thursday through Labor Day at the Flemington Agricultural Fair.

title: WOMAN OF THE YEAR
description: Melinda Bass has been described as the woman who ''defines the woman's movement in Westchester,'' and tomorrow she is to be named the county's Woman of the Year.

title: CAMBODIA FEARS RICE SHORTFALL FROM DROUGHT
description: A Cambodian official said today that if a drought now scorching the paddy fields of several provinces did not end within the next month, the country could face a million-ton rice shortage.

title: MONUMENTAL TASK FOR ARLINGTON RACE
description: Less than one month after its grandstand was destroyed by fire, Arlington Park will turn its scarred face proudly to the public in the nationally telecast running of the Budweiser-Arlington Million here Sunday.

title: FIRST VOLLEYS OF '88
description: THE CENTRAL, inescapable fact of life of the Olympic movement is that the games happen only once in four years. For television networks, that's just enough time to write the contracts and move the cameras; for spectators, that's just enough time to make travel plans and take out long-term loans for the tickets. For athletes, however, the four years of an Olympiad can last more than a lifetime.

title: Boy With AIDS to Get Schooling by Telephone
description: A 13-year-old boy barred from school because he has acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, will start classes Monday through a telephone hookup to his home, a school spokesman says.

title: University Head Resigns Over Spending Practices
description: Amid allegations that he misspent thousands of dollars of school funds, Robert L. Green, president of the University of the District of Columbia, resigned Friday.

title: SURGERY FOR CLEMENS
description: Dr. Arthur Pappas, the team physician for the Boston Red Sox, has recommended that Roger Clemens, a right-handed starter, undergo surgery to repair a ''small flap tear'' in the cartilage disk surrounding his right shoulder.

title: Miss VanHoven Becomes a Bride
description: Pamela Ryder VanHoven, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. VanHoven of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Michael Weld Clark, a son of William G. Clark of Greenwich, Conn., and Mrs. Augustus B. Field 3d of Tuxedo Park, N.Y. The Rev. John Olofson, a Methodist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich.

title: SOCIAL REVOLUTION SWEEPS THROUGH SOVIET UNION
description: The Soviet Union is in the grip of a demographic and social revolution that is breaking up families, lowering the birthrate and contributing to alcoholism, juvenile delinquency and crime, a leading Soviet demographer says.

title: SUM OF VIOLENCE
description: RECORDER OF THE BLACK EXPERIENCE A Biography of Monroe Nathan Work. By Linda O. McMurry. Illustrated. 154 pp. Baton Rouge: Louisiana State University Press. $20.

title: THE CAPITAL FROM A TO Z
description: ALBERTINA Selections from the world's largest graphic collection have recently been shown in New York, but a visit to the collection's home in the 180-year-old former palace of an archduke at 1 Augustiner Strasse (telephone 524232), near the State Opera, is always worthwhile. The sullen gray building contains 45,000 drawings, watercolors and etchings, including works by Durer, Rembrandt, Raphael, Michelangelo and Titian, and a million prints from five centuries, which are displayed in rotation. Open Monday, Tuesday and Thursday from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M., Wednesday from 10 to 6, Friday from 10 to 2, Saturday and Sunday from 10 to 1. Admission 50 cents, children and students free. BREAKFAST It is included in the rates of almost all hotels except the five-star Bristol, Hilton Wien and Imperial and a few plainer houses. Hotel breakfasts usually consist of a container of coffee or tea that will fill two big cups, cream, two or three semihard rolls that in the local dialect are known as Semmel, and little packages of butter, jam, maybe honey and soft cheese. Toast, orange juice and eggs are optional extras. The Viennese Breakfast offered by coffeehouses at $2.50 to $4 features good coffee or tea, the omnipresent Semmel, a croissant, butter, jam and a soft-boiled egg. Some older Viennese cling to their traditional Gabelfruhstuck (fork breakfast) at around 11 A.M., when they will order a couple of frankfurters, a small goulash or kidney and eggs with a beer at a tavern for $4.00 or so.

title: COPING WITH THE COST OF A NURSING HOME
description: AS technology helps more Americans live into their 80's, the problem of their rising health- care costs assumes increasing urgency. ''Lawyers have done a good job arranging people's financial affairs after death,'' but they have to start thinking about lifetime planning, says Peter J. Strauss, a partner with Strauss & Wolf, a law firm that specializes in problems of the elderly.

title: PORCELAIN AND PHILANTHROPY
description: AT THE age of 75, his wife of 43 years dead since December, Natan Celnik of Long Beach has been spending his summer saying farewell to his business.

title: HER LAST WEAPON IS HUMOR
description: WOMAN WANTED By Joanna McClelland Glass. 280 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $13.95.

title: India Said to Deport 3 Tamil Leaders
description: Three guerrilla leaders from Sri Lanka were deported today from the Indian city of Madras to Britain and the United States, sources in Madras said.

title: Sons of Zimbabwe Ex-Leader Say They Now Back Mugabe
description: Two sons of a former Prime Minister announced Friday that they were leaving their father's political party to support the Government.

title: Sick Pet Needs Help, Not Good Intentions
description: ''A Lesson in Love - Learned Too Late'' [Opinion Page, July 14] was touching; however, I find it most frustrating, as I'm sure others in my profession will be dismayed by her account of the death of her bird Pebbles.

title: ACTRESS SHINES IN MUSICAL
description: A BRASSY belter in the Ethel Merman mold, she sings ''I Can Sing,'' substituting for the famed Merman vibrato an unwavering steadiness and stretching the last word into a long, long line - so long that one feels inclined to clock it.

title: FERRYBOATS ARE INSPIRING A NEW WAVE OF ENTHUSIASM
description: In the 1950's and 60's, almost a dozen ferry lines that connected Manhattan to Brooklyn and New Jersey went out of business. Transportation planners and commuters talked of the boats as part of an earlier, less hurried age, a quaint but obsolete reminder of New York as an island metropolis. Now, in a decade of bullet trains and space shuttles, the ferryboat may be making a comeback.

title: Malinda Murphy Weds in Scotland
description: The marriage of Malinda Fitler Murphy, youngest daughter of Mrs. Nelson A. Rockefeller and Dr. James S. Murphy, both of New York, to Francis Menotti took place yesterday in Gifford, Scotland. The Rev. John Wilson performed the Church of Scotland ceremony at Yester Church.

title: ON THE DURABILITY OF THE SHOREHAM PLANT
description: With reference to ''Why Shoreham Shouldn't Open,'' I am very unimpressed by presentations based on hearsay and unscientific opinions.

title: A FEAR OF METAPHORS
description: Donald Hall is quite right that metaphor is more than a device of speech, it is an alternate mode of thought.

title: BOSCO'S NEW MISSION AT B.Y.U.
description: HIS performance in the fourth quarter of the Holiday Bowl game last Dec. 21 was, for all intents, Robbie Bosco's formal entry into the 1985 Heisman Trophy race. In what could be thought of as his first primary on that clear but brisk night in San Diego, Bosco showed the Heisman voters he was more than just another pretty arm in the pass-oriented Brigham Young University football program. It was an impressive campaign speech.

title: 'CARNIVAL' LACKS COHESION
description: THE weeds appear to be as high as an elephant's eye and the lighting reflects a bright golden haze on the meadow before dawn. At first sight, the show might as well be ''Oklahoma!''

title: PIANO-BAR VIRTUOSO
description: THE first time I saw Dillson Petrey playing a piano, he was almost literally hopping back and forth on the bench as he bounced out a lively version of the Gershwin standard ''But Not for Me.'' It was a late fall evening in 1981, at Virgil's, now Jonathan's, opposite the Port Washington movie house on Main Street.

title: ANNI ALBERS AND THE THREAD OF ART
description: ''YOU can go anywhere from anywhere.'' That conviction of Anni Albers's describes a career that began when she discovered that ''limp threads'' could be constructed into art.

title: EXXON ENDOWMENT
description: Governor Cuomo cruised the Hudson Highlands recently on the 36-foot-long tour boat, the William O. Benson. The Governor and Commissioner Henry G. Williams of the Department of Environmental Conservation came to the waterfront village of Cold Spring Aug. 14 to turn over $1.5 million to the Hudson River Foundation.

title: APPLES AND SOUTH AFRICA
description: I am an addict - an apple addict. I must have countless apples throughout the day, and they must crunch. That is why I am particularly fond of Granny Smith apples, a perennially hard, green, crunchy variety that America began to import a few years back to supplement the domestic crop. The only problem, for me at least, is that Granny Smiths come from South Africa.

title: VISITOR FROM SIBERIA ATTRACTS EAGER BIRDERS TO JAMAICA BAY
description: The ritual begins just before high tide along the mud flats of Jamaica Bay, where scores of bird watchers have gathered for the last three weekends, waiting for a glimpse of a Siberian sandpiper half a world from home.

title: EDMERALD VILLAGES
description: SEEING GREEN The Politics of Ecology Explained. By Jonathon Porritt. 252 pp. New York: Basil Blackwell. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $6.95. AMERICANS generally react with confusion to the question ''Have you ever heard of the Green movement?'' It's largely a European phenomenon, if not un-American. So Americans, if they read ''Seeing Green,'' will be introduced to a new ideology, which Jonathon Porritt, the director of Friends of the Earth in England, hopes to transplant to the Colonies.

title: 41 Die in North India Floods
description: At least 41 people were killed in landslides and floods that hit India's northern states of Himachal Pradesh and Uttar Pradesh in the last two weeks, the Press Trust of India said today. Several low-lying villages in Uttar Pradesh were under water after the Ganges and Ghagra Rivers burst their banks, the news agency said.

title: POLISH ECHOES AND IRONIES
description: IN FEBRUARY OF 1935, MY FATHER, ADAM Kaufman, jumped bail, and carrying skis he did not know how to use, he slid and stumbled from his native Poland into temporary sanctuary in Czechoslovakia.

title: IN QUOTES
description: 'I'm not going to be bribed into shafting my shareholders.' Michel C. Bergerac Revlon's chairman, rejecting a Pantry Pride offer to let him keep his job if Revlon was taken over.

title: BASEBALL AND COCAINE
description: 'You probably spend as much time researching (whether a player uses drugs) as you do finding out about whether a guy can bunt or hit and run.' rrDick Howser rrmanager of the Kansas City Royals, explaining how the widespread use of cocaine among ballplayers affects trades. rr'There's no doubt I was addicted. I didn't care about the game. The majority of the time we were in a hurry to get the game over with and do it all over again.' rrLonnie Smith rrRoyals outfielder who entered a drug treatment center in 1983.

title: SCHOLAR POSITION FOR ELDERLY PROGRAMS
description: SOMETIMES, David P. Shuldiner has a tough time attracting an audience.

title: A DAILY EVENT: OPENING THE WALLET
description: CAN any one of us delve back into our pasts, as far back as last week, say, and conjure up a day when our wallets were not opened up and ravaged? I tried, heaven knows, and could not come up with a fleeting memory of a day without dishing out.

title: LINKING LANDSCAPE TO MODERNIST PAINTING
description: AN old legend in art history circles tells of the skillful, esteemed professor who once claimed the ability to base his entire discussion of the Renaissance on a single illustration.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN SAYVILLE
description: WHEN Craig Eckert decided to change jobs this year and relocate from a suburb of Tampa, Fla., the location of his new company in central Long Island allowed him to settle just about anywhere in Nassau or Suffolk Counties. ''We spent two weeks looking at homes in towns all over the Island,'' he said. ''We chose Sayville.

title: WATER PLAN STIRS COMMUNITY DISPUTE
description: IN January, high levels of benzene and other volatile chemicals were found in the wells of a few homes here.

title: NEVER TOO OLD TO WIN
description: He knows about the grueling daily practices, forcing himself to go the distance even when he may not feel like it.

title: COSMOPOLITAN CHIC BANGKOK
description: Well-traveled writers report on the special flair that constitutes style in cities East and West.

title: A.T. & T. Says It Will Cut 24,000 Jobs
description: Not too many years ago, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company was perhaps as red-ink proof as a company can be; to sign on with A.T. & T. was, for many employees, to be set for life. But last week the company had bad news for a startling number of its workers: one way or another, 24,000 positions are to be eliminated by the end of 1986.

title: FILMING IRANIANS AND RUSSIANS - WHAT'S ALLOWED
description: Objectivity may be the first casualty of the totalitarian state. The free flow of information and ideas is precisely what a controlling regime cannot permit, for that, by definition, marks a loss of control. And such insular societies typically maintain an equal watchfulness on the images and the information that they allow to trickle out to the observing world. Such are the conditions underlying a pair of documentaries coming to cable this week, bringing glimpses of Iran and of the Soviet Union - but the similar limitations imposed upon these projects have been addressed in radically different ways.

title: MONEY STILL FLOWS AS WESTWAY BATTLE CONTINUES IN COURT
description: As the decade-long legal battle over Westway drags on, the money to finance limited preliminary work continues to roll in - $227.5 million since the first legal challenge to the multibillion-dollar highway and development project was filed in 1974.

title: NEW TRENDS FOR FALL
description: FOR THE LAST SEVERAL YEARS, A GREAT number of the new designs produced by architects and decorators have heralded a Victorian revival tailored to the 1980's. One manifestation has been a crop of shingle-style houses - with their gabled rooflines, widow's walks and rambling porches -that recall cottages built around the turn of the century in summer colonies along the East Coast. Another is the cozy, yet cluttered rooms that have been created in every place from Los Angeles ranch houses to Manhattan studios. Their elaborate and often heavily curtained treatments, multipatterned and trimmed upholsteries and endless arrays of bibelots have summoned up long-dormant images of romantic opulence.

title: KEEPING DRY, JAPANESE STYLE
description: In June in Japan, when the soft rains fall, city streets blossom with plaids, stripes, polka dots and splashes of color. Even men do not restrict themselves to unrelieved black but spread their wings of green, maroon, brown, blue and gray in solid tones and subdued patterns.

title: CATERING TO A FEW SELECT INDUSTRIES
description: THE proliferation of executive recruiting firms has brought with it a fervent quest on the part of each one for less-populated niches in which to grow.

title: Sympathy Extended To Karen Ann's Family
description: I would like to add my condolences to the family of Karen Ann Quinlan. Her adoptive family suffered 10 painful, agonizing years.

title: Medicare By the Book
description: In drafting a report recommending standard Medicare payments to doctors, the Federal Government is proposing to fundamentally alter the economics of medicine.

title: NEW YORK CITES FOOD OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health last week released a list of 25 food establishments cited for violating the health code.

title: ELIZABETH BRUNS IS WED
description: Elizabeth Bruns, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry G. Bruns of New London, N.H., was married there yesterday to Thomas Edward Sargent Johnson, the son of Marjorie Decker Johnson of Clifton, S.I., and the late Edward E. Johnson. The Rev. Robert Thurston performed the ceremony at the First Baptist Church. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is the advertising coordinator of Bon Appetit magazine in New York, where Mr. Johnson is a marketing representative with Allnet Communications.

title: NAVAL COMMANDER NAMED
description: Commodore Richard Butts has been named commander of the Philadelphia Naval Base to replace Rear Adm. James Austin, who is retiring after 31 years in the Navy.
