Commodore Butts is assuming responsibilities over 16,680 Navy and civilian personnel assigned to more than 35 area shore commands and is taking command of naval detachments in Boston and New York.

title: PHOTEINE ANAGNOSTOPOULOS WEDS JAMES B. STYNES
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown, N.Y., yesterday Photeine Marie Anagnostopoulos, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Michael E. Anagnostopoulos of Bellevue, Ill., was married to James Brendan Stynes, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Brendan J. Stynes of Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. Ronald Gray performed the ceremony.

title: RITA SALBERG
description: Rita Salberg, a member of the national executive committee and New York regional board of the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith, died Wednesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 58 years old. Mrs. Salberg, a native of New York City, was a graduate of Brooklyn College and a teacher in the New York City public school system for 14 years.

title: FOODS HELP SPICE VERMONT IMAGE
description: Only a couple of years ago a can of maple syrup or a block of cheddar cheese pretty much marked the limits for culinary shopping in Vermont. A few harvests later and the shelves are thick with foods like tarragon mustard and raspberry applesauce, all developed and produced in home kitchens around the state.

title:
GARDENING;

SOME CHORES FOR LATE SUMMER
description: AS summer winds down, it is again time to think seriously about several gardening tasks. All are best done early to take advantage of the ideal fall growing conditions.

title: FRIGHT GRIPS BRAZIL AS AIDS CASES SUDDENLY RISE
description: A rapid rise in the number of cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome in Brazil has produced what health authorities here are calling ''a collective neurosis'' over the danger of a major epidemic of the disease.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: JERUSALEM: Rebirth of a City. By Martin Gilbert. (Elisabeth Sifton/Viking, $25.) It is hard to imagine a holier and less tranquil city than 19th-century Jerusalem, as depicted by the historian Martin Gilbert.

title: OGUNQUIT
description: Ogunquit and its coastal neighbors, the Yorks, Wells and the Kennebunks, have been drawing crowds of summer visitors for more than a century. The seacoast region of southern Maine, a roughly 25-mile stretch of irregular coastline, boasts a sampling of everything the state has to offer. There are rugged, rocky cliffs and white sand beaches, salt marshes and pine woods, art galleries and craft shops, lobsters and lighthouses.

title: FOREIGN STUDENTS FACE TRAVAILS
description: AN estimated 500 foreign students have been spending the summer studying at Long Island colleges, and although many say they would much rather be home, they are afraid that if they leave they will not be allowed back in the United States.

title: NOW, MORE PRODUCTS THAT CAN TALK - AND LISTEN
description: IT began about five years ago, when a universe of chattering appliances descended on American consumers. Clocks that admonished ''You're late for work.'' Refrigerators that reminded ''Dust my coils.'' Microwave ovens that hollered when dinner was ready. Bathroom scales that blurted out the bad news.

title: METS BUILDING A FOUNDATION TO LAST FOR YEARS TO COME
description: WHEN your farm system produces Darryl Strawberry and Dwight Gooden in successive seasons, and both are voted rookie of the year, and when it graduates Roger McDowell, Lenny Dykstra and Rick Aguilera the following year, what can you do for an encore?

title: Ontario Arrests 4 Protesters
description: The police arrested four Greenpeace protesters today when they climbed down from a bridge connecting Ontario and Michigan after an overnight protest against purported chemical dumping, officials said. The four were charged with trespassing and released.

title: Greek Opposition Chief Quits Party Presidency
description: The head of the major opposition party, Constantine Mitsotakis, resigned today after party squabbling over the date of a party congress.

title: GOVERMENT WORKERS NUMBER 16.4 MILLION
description: Civilian government employment totaled 16,436,000 in October, a rise of 2.5 percent from a year earlier, the Census Bureau says, while the overall payroll rose 9.7 percent to $26.9 billion at the same time.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: I, KOCH: A Decidedly Unauthorized Biography of the Mayor of New York City, Edward I. Koch. By Arthur Browne, Dan Collins and Michael Goodwin.

title: ONE-TRACK MINDS
description: New Jersey has more people and cars per square mile than any other state, and state transportation officials believe that its population density and transportation problems make it just the right place at just the right time for development of an extensive monorail system.

title: THE WORLD Visiting Rights For Koreans
description: The Korean peninsula wasn't all that was divided 40 years ago. Many families were, too. But for the estimated 10 million Koreans separated from relatives, there seems new hope of reunion.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Sunday about an effort of a church coalition to revive some Brooklyn neighborhoods misidentified the group hired to train its members. The group is the Industrial Areas Foundation.

title: CONDOMINIUMS STIR LAWRENCE
description: THE Village of Lawrence's few remaining mansions, built in the belle epoque and tucked in among country clubs in a secluded section, may be turned into expensive condominiums if the Village Board passes a proposal to allow the conversion.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: AMERICAN ARMS SUPERMARKET. By Michael T. Klare. (University of Texas, Cloth, $24.50. Paper, $10.95.) America takes pride in being the world's breadbasket.

title: WHY SATURDAY MORNING IS ONE BIG 'CARTOON GHETTO'
description: From 8 A.M. to 1 P.M., the tension never lets up on Saturday-morning television. Snorks, lovable underwater creatures, get out of their depth and are saved by intelligent porpoises. Smurfs, lovable blue gnomes only three apples high, get into trouble - again and again, in their 90-minute time slot - and bail each other out. Superfriends - Superman, Wonder Woman, Batman and Robin -clash with supervillains. Even Mr. T, his muscles and Mohawk softened into a lovable cartoon figure, repeatedly comes to the rescue of his teen-aged team.

title: S.M.U. ATTEMPTS TO OFFSET PENALTIES
description: On Friday, Aug. 16 at 6 P.M., the National Collegiate Athletic Association ended its 29-month investigation into charges of recruiting violations by the Southern Methodist University football program by announcing its verdict - guilty of 36 rules violations. That was not as much of a surprise as the penalties, which were unprecedented. The Mustangs, expected to be one of the nation's most powerful teams this season, were placed on three years' probation. They were stripped of 45 scholarships for the next two years, all 30 in 1986 and 15 in 1987. They are not eligible for the Southwest Conference title this season and next season, and they cannot appear in a bowl after this season and after next season. Finally, they will not be allowed on television in 1986.

title: DISPUTE POSTPONES COUNTY'S BUS GARAGE
description: THE county's plan to build a $10.5 million bus garage in Yorktown has been postponed, according to officials, while the county seeks to resolve issues raised by a growing opposition.

title: ELECTION LAW BATTLES A TRADITION IN NEW YORK
description: New York State's election law, which last week produced the spectacle of citywide candidates being thrown off the Sept. 10 primary ballot in wholesale lots, has for years been the bane of political challengers.

title: ATLANTIC CITY RAIL PLAN REVIVED AGAIN
description: THE on-again, off-again rail line between here and Philadelphia is on again, and Paul H. Baker, supervising planner for the state Department of Transportation, said work could start within six months.

title: DRUG-ABUSE HEARING HELD
description: TOM, a 19-year-old witness, told Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and United States Representative Benjamin A. Gilman last week that he had started using drugs when he was ''about 12.''

title: IN THE DAWN, A DAY AND A LIFE REBORN
description: A DULL, motionless night. Haven't seen a car either way for 20 minutes. Long stretches between exits. Sensing my vulnerability, I fail to suppress the rising trepidation. . . . Mentally rehearsing strategies to employ - in case. Blocking out the ''what ifs.''

title: WAITING IN THE WINGS
description: THERE ARE certain food flavors, herbs and spices that always seem to hold center stage -year after year, decade after decade. Bay leaf, thyme, parsley, chives and tarragon are obvious examples. But there are others that seem to stand blushingly shy in the wings, rarely hearing the applause of the dining-room audience.

title: FOR TROUBLED VIETNAM VETERANS, NEW HELP
description: Five years after the Vietnam War ended, Tom Eiss, a former marine, drove off a cliff.

title: CONFOUNDING THE SAGES
description: The two teams in the final of the Spingold Knockout in Las Vegas earlier this month represented a remarkable contrast.

title: 'Doing Lunch': More Than It's Said to Be
description: There are those of us who occasionally enjoy a lunch meal at Renee's in Scarsdale (''About Westchester,'' July 14) who do not see it as an opportunity to display the latest acquisition to our wardrobes, or to be seen eating the proper food or discussing who went to what social function.

title: ENSHRINING THE FURHRER
description: HITLER - MEMOIRS OF A CONFIDANT Edited by Henry Ashby Turner Jr. Translated by Ruth Hein. Illustrated. 333 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $29.95.

title: DRAWING A BEAD ON A TARGET IN SPACE
description: When President Reagan announced the go-ahead last week for a crucial test of the Air Force's anti-satellite weapon, he gambled on two fronts. First, the test could further complicate the arms control face-off with the Soviet Union. Second, the device might not work.

title: NAMES AND GENEALOGY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE CHANGING WORLD OF NEW YORK INTELLECTUALS
description: WHEN I WAS 17, I read a story by Delmore Schwartz that introduced a new word into my vocabulary. ''New Year's Eve'' concerned a group of young writers and editors in New York City who decide to have a party on a grim winter's night in the 1930's. In the opening scene, the host and one of his cronies are engaged in a bitter dispute about who should be invited to the party. ''Since both of them were intellectuals,'' Schwartz noted, ''both resorted to theories about the nature of a party and about each other's characters.'' Intellectuals? ''New Year's Eve,'' I later discovered, was a portrait of Schwartz's gang on the staff of the Partisan Review, a magazine I read avidly in college - and not just the current issues, but the heavy, maroon-bound volumes from the 30's and 40's announcing the latest article by Lionel Trilling or Edmund Wilson, a new poem by Wallace Stevens or Allen Tate, a story by Saul Bellow or Bernard Malamud. To see the work of my literary heroes in its original form, the way it had appeared before most of them were famous, was a strange experience; it made them somehow less sanctified, more real. I was discovering these writers the way their original audience had, leafing through a periodical meant to be picked up from the newsstand and read in a Greenwich Village cafeteria.

title: A FEAR OF METAPHORS
description: A round of applause for Donald Hall's deft diagnosis of ''tropophobia'' - the fear of figures of speech (''A Fear of Metaphors,'' On Language, July 14). Like other maladies of the spirit, this one subsists on a distorted view of reality, in this case - linguistic reality.

title: CHILD WELFARE
description: Quality Time Don Johnson, one of the stars of the television program ''Miami Vice,'' was asked, in a recent television interview, how he makes room in a suddenly busy schedule for his family. He began somewhat apologetically, but ended by saying, ''The time I spend with my family is quality time.''

title:
GARDENING;

SOME CHORES FOR LATE SUMMER
description: AS summer winds down, it is again time to think seriously about several gardening tasks. All are best done early to take advantage of the ideal fall growing conditions.

title: SALT IN HUDSON IMPERILS POUGHKEEPSIE WATER
description: The flow of the Hudson River has been so reduced by the drought in New York State that salt water borne on ocean tides has moved upstream to within six miles of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., threatening the city's water supply.

title: 'SHOWCASE' REPLY
description: To the Editor:

title: CAREFUL, BORIS IS WATCHING - MAYBE >cc12.1>
description: They call him Igor, Ivan or Boris. They refer to him with a finger pointed at his presumed microphone in the ceiling, they raise silent toasts to him and fantasize of getting together for a drink.

title: RUNNING TO RUIN
description: EIGHT miles into my first marathon, I knew the doctor had been right. I'd never make it. The sciatica I suffered from, dormant until that point, had made its presence known. Each step was punctuated by a knifelike pain radiating down the back of my right leg.

title: WHY MANY SEARCH FIRMS STAY SMALL
description: RECRUITING is an industry in which bigger is not necessarily better. It faces a real Catch 22: The more corporate clients, the fewer companies that are fair game for a raid.

title: Wyoming Cities Allowed To Get New Gas Supplies
description: Residents of two Wyoming cities have overwhelmingly approved letting their city governments go shopping for natural gas supplies to circumvent the prices of local gas pipeline companies.

title: PUERTO RICO SEES HARM IN TAX PLAN
description: Despite what appear to be unfavorable odds, Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon is stepping up efforts to save a tax privilege that has created thousands of jobs on the island from elimination under President Reagan's tax revision proposal.

title: A SCULPTURE PARK FOR DI SUVERO'S LADDERS TO THE SKY
description: Mark di Suvero is one of the most seductive and ambitious sculptors alive. His welded and bolted steel constructions recline, strut, sniff the ground, shake their heads and write and draw themselves in space. We can swing on them, bang them, spin them, climb them and play them, like a street musician plays tubs and pans. As soaring and menacing as they can seem, di Suvero's sculptures are always, in the end, welcoming and friendly. Anyone visiting his retrospective at the Storm King Art Center in Mountainville, N.Y., is likely to have a good time.

title:
ANTIQUES;

AMERICAN FURNITURE AT ATHENEUM EXHIBITION
description: AMERICA'S oldest settled inland region lies along the banks of the Connecticut River, winding back from Haddam to Northfield, Mass. It was here, in the towns and villages on both sides of the river, social historians say, that the first true American style of furniture was developed.

title: MAGAZINE SHOWS: A TIME FOR DECISION
description: Television seems to be at a watershed, and even if this is not so apparent as the ascent of Milton Berle, say, or the birth of instant replay, it is likely to have a more far-reaching effect. The issue is television journalism; specifically, what is it? On one side of the issue are traditionalists, and on the other side are the new people, who may be identified not so much by their age as by their devotion to video. Loosely speaking, the traditionalists embrace a discipline, while the new people look to a technique. How well can they blend images, words and music? Traditionalists say that's not enough, and that in journalism the story must come first. This may seem like an academic argument; it is not. It centers on what television thinks about news. Does it think it's important? The argument broke out when CBS News presented ''West 57th,'' its new magazine show, two weeks ago. If it had been presented by CBS Entertainment, there would have been no argument. ''West 57th,'' however, was a triumph for the new people. Video won; journalism lost, and traditionalists wrung their hands. Fred Friendly, a former president of CBS News, said in a newspaper interview that ''West 57th'' was a ''piece of glitz,'' while William Leonard, another former president, said that it wasn't journalism ''by any stretch of the imagination.'' CBS News, in turn, defended its new program. It was ''solid journalism,'' ''good journalism,'' ''the product of a brand new generation of TV journalists.''

title: EGOS AS BIG AS THE MET
description: THE GLORIOUS ONES Classical Music's Legendary Performers. By Harold C. Schonberg. Illustrated. 509 pp. New York: Times Books. $24.95.

title: RISING RENTS THREATENING 'LITTLE INDIA'
description: The area of spice bazaars, sari shops and curry restaurants on the East Side of Manhattan known as Little India is beginning to feel the gusts of changing times.

title: MAKING THE BEST OF IT WHEN THE FATES CONSPIRE
description: Sometimes even frequent travelers take trips on which almost everything seems to go wrong. Such was my experience recently on a journey that took me from New York to Detroit on a Friday evening and then, the next day, to Philadelphia. Some of the situations were unavoidable - acts of God, they are commonly called - but some illustrated the value of forethought and of knowing what alternatives may be at hand.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All outbreaks of violence turn the clocks of liberation back.'' - Chief Gatsha Buthelezi, leader of the Zulus of South Africa. [18:1.]

title: FAITHS AT ODDS OVER RAZING AIRPORT'S CHAPELS
description: A master plan for Kennedy International Airport that envisions demolishing the airport's Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish chapels has been condemned by the New York Board of Rabbis as a ''sacrilege reminiscent of benighted alien governments.''

title: RETARDED EXPANDING SCOPE
description: A TWO-YEAR-OLD campaign to help retarded people in Greenwich is beginning to have an effect.

title: 2 Israelis Are Victims Of West Bank Attacks
description: Unidentified gunmen killed one Israeli and seriously wounded another today in separate attacks in Arab towns in the occupied West Bank, Israeli military sources said.

title: UPDATED: THE CLEAN ALL-AMERICAN LOOK
description: Sportswear with simple, straightforward lines has long been a cornerstone of American fashion. It still is, very much so, but these days sportswear separates are being reapportioned in ways that make them quite up-to-date.

title: SUMMER VACATION: HERE'S A QUICK QUIZ
description: THIS summer Sally and Phil Skinner and their two children, Amy and Scott, are sharing a house for a week on Lake Winnipesaukee with their good friends Bunny and Ed McBean; the twins - Jimmy and Josh; Baby Anne and Aunt Eleanor. Using the available facts for each situation, solve the following problems.

title: REAGAN RIDES HORSE FOR FIRST TIME SINCE SURGERY
description: President Reagan went horseback riding today on his California ranch, resuming one of his favorite outdoor activities six weeks after he underwent cancer surgery.

title: REPUBLICANS START TO WORRY ABOUT SIGNS OF SLIPPAGE
description: The Republican Party came rolling out of the 1984 national elections with such momentum that its goal of becoming the dominant political party no longer seemed implausible. But last week, even as President Reagan was proclaiming that ''realignment is real,'' Republican exuberance was tempered by signs that the 1986 elections could deal a major setback.

title: THE FACE OF TODAYT
description: Many women who follow trends in fashion are less aware that in makeup, too, times change.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Atlas of Ancient Egypt By John Baines and Jaromir Malek. 240 pages. Facts on File. $35. Atlas of the Roman World By Tim Cornell and John Matthews. 240 pages. Facts on File. $35.

title: NOT A FREE LAUNCH
description: The Reagan Administration has been particularly keen on getting people to pay user fees for Federal services that have customarily been free. The National Park Service charges fees of $1 to $30, for example, for such things as using a boat launching ramp, and there has been a proposal that the Coast Guard charge a $20 fee for rescuing boaters.

title: The Oraflex Deal
description: Product liability was the issue for another drug concern, and for the Justice Department last week. In an arrangement with the Department, Eli Lilly and Company pleaded guilty of criminal charges and was fined $25,000 for failing to inform the Food and Drug Administration about four deaths and six illnesses related to Oraflex, an arthritis drug it was marketing.

title: A RED GROOMS TRAVELING CARNIVAL
description: The one thing that can be said with certainty about the work of Red Grooms -painter, draftsman, sculptor, environmentalist and movie-maker - is that everybody enjoys it. Walking through his current retrospective at the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts in Philadelphia, the visitor is witness to a collective love-in of a kind that is very rare in an art gallery.

title: CORRECTION
description: An item in the Ideas and Trends section last Sunday about the incidence of lung cancer in American men gave an incorrect impression about smoking among blacks. Black men took up cigarette smoking in large numbers in the years during and after World War II.

title: CATCHING UP
description: * At training camp last spring, the world champion Detroit Tigers were so high on Chris Pittaro as a second baseman that they made room for him by moving Lou Whitaker to third. After a few days, Whitaker objected, so the 23-year-old Pittaro began the season as the regular third baseman. But 6 errors in 14 starts, combined with a batting average of only .242, sent him first to the bench and then to Nashville, Detroit's Class AAA affiliate, where he has not exactly prospered. With the season winding down, Pittaro is batting under .200 and is only occasionally in the starting lineup, splitting time between second and third. ''We may have brought him along too quickly,'' acknowledges Frank Franchi, Detroit's director of player development. ''But we won't be influenced by his stats at Nashville. We know he can play. He'll have every chance of making the Tigers again next spring.''

title: PANELISTS CITE BIOLOGICAL ROOTS OF HOMOSEXUALITY
description: Many parents of homosexual children believe homosexuality is rooted in biological rather than psychological causes, according to participants in a special discussion today at the annual convention of the American Psychological Association.

title: BUSH AND THE RIPON SPEECH
description: Does an appearance before the Ripon Society, that refuge of moderate Republicans, disqualify a politician as a conservative? When Vice President Bush spoke at a Ripon fund-raising event and accepted the society's Republican of the Year award late in July, several conservative groups responded with anti-Bush statements.

title: Washington Watch;   Credit Unions
description: Credit unions won an influential ally to their cause of retaining tax-exempt status in any new new tax revision.

title: PAUL CRESTON, 78, COMPOSER AND ROMANTIC STYLIST, DEAD
description: The American composer Paul Creston died Saturday in San Diego after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: New Shekel Approved
description: The Israeli Government voted today to introduce a new shekel worth 1,000 times more than the present currency, which has been legal tender for the past five years. The long-expected revision followed the erosion of the currency from 6 shekels per dollar when the shekel replaced the Israeli pound in 1980, to 1,487.40 per dollar today.

title: MAIN STREET, SIBERIA: ALL BUT THE SNOW IS IMPORTED
description: When the eggs come in, there is almost nothing but eggs on the shelves of the tiny general store in this remote Siberian settlement. The unpaved streets are filled with villagers gingerly carrying home stacks of eggs on their cardboard trays.

title: Some Stores in West Pull Gatorade From Shelves
description: A batch of Gatorade was taken from some stores in six Western states after a man became ill from suspected urine contamination, but no nationwide recall of the beverage was planned, its makers said today. They said it was an ''isolated incident.''

title: President Resigns At Casino Concern
description: The Elsinore Corporation said that Robert R. Maxey, president and chief executive officer, had resigned and would leave the company at the end of October.

title: Melissa Auerbach Is a Bride
description: Melissa J. Auerbach, an associate in the Chicago law firm of Cornfield & Feldman, was married in New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday to Edward B. Schultz, director of contract administration for the Illinois Union of Social Service Employees, Local 2000, of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees in Chicago. Rabbi Amiel Wohl performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William Auerbach. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Schultz of Tuscola, Ill.

title: DANCE: MUSSMANN'S 'HARBORS WAIT'
description: THE Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art is a pretty place to spend a day, with its layered nooks and crannies, sculpture for punctuation and a green haze of trees in summer. It is not so easy a place in which to present dance, however, as the museum does each year in its Summergarden series. But Linda Mussman and her Time and Space Limited company actually harnessed the museum itself and made inventive use of its garden space on Friday evening in ''Harbors Wait,'' a piece created for Summergarden.

title: SCREEN: FESTIVAL OFFERS 3 FILMS ON JAZZ PIANISTS
description: THE Village Jazz Festival film program at the Bleecker Street Cinema offers three documentaries about pianists today, two of them New York premieres.

title: Lesson of the Schumer Case
description: Did Charles Schumer use his state legislative staff improperly for campaign work when he ran successfully for Congress in 1980? The United States Attorney in Brooklyn once said yes and recommended prosecution but was overruled by the Justice Department in Washington. Now Brooklyn District Attorney Elizabeth Holtzman, after her own investigation, finds that Mr. Schumer violated no state law but asks the Federal Election Commission to determine whether he should have reported the staff campaign work as campaign contributions.

title: Karen Howard Married
description: The marriage of Karen Peterson Howard, an actress, to Victor Montagne Earl 3d, general counsel for the accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Co., took place Saturday at the bride's home in Amagansett, L.I. The Rev. Frederick Rapp performed the Episcopal ceremony. Mrs. Earle is the daughter of A. Hawley Peterson of Naples, Fla., and the late Medora Peterson. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. Earle Jr. of Bridgehampton, L.I., and the late Marian Webster. Previous marriages for both bride and bridegroom ended in divorce.

title: ON CLOSING STORES AND SELLING SIN
description: For the last 113 years, the little storefront catalogue outlets of Montgomery Ward have been mainstays of rural life in Texas. In places like Carrizo Springs, Mexia and Giddings, they have brought the comforts of modern life, the washers, lawn mowers and, more recently, the video recorders, to remote pockets of civilization, and at a good price.

title: LITTLE BROTHER
description: When William Perry, the huge lineman known as The Refrigerator, completed his collegiate eligibility last season and moved on to the Chicago Bears as a first-round pick, the sense of loss at Clemson was mitigated somewhat by the knowledge that there was still a big Perry on the team. He is Michael Perry, who as a freshman last season played next to his older brother at defensive tackle.

title: Board Closes Thrift Unit
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said Friday that it had closed the Alliance Savings and Loan Association of Kenner, La., and had ordered the transfer of its estimated $144 million in insured deposits to another bank.

title: QUESTION BOX
description: QUESTION: With all the fuss over Pete Rose's quest to pass Ty Cobb on the regular-season hit list, how does Rose compare with Cobb in World Series batting?

title: PRAISE FOR GOODEN FROM PITCHING ELITE
description: The date was Sept. 11, 1947. The Brooklyn Dodgers, battling for the National League pennant, were playing the Cardinals in St. Louis, and Ralph Branca, 21 years old, was looking to become one of the youngest pitchers ever to win 20 games.

title: A Simple, Balanced Plan for Tax Reform
description: PRESIDENT Reagan's tax reform plan is under attack on all fronts. Some critics complain that it penalizes the average middle-class family while allowing the super-wealthy to benefit. Meanwhile, every deduction he hopes to eliminate has an army of defenders equipped with reams of data. And the plan is suffering even more from the charge that it would drain tax revenues at a time when we face mammoth deficits.

title: Less Liberty in Liberia
description: Unhappy Liberia has its own version of one man, one vote. There, only one man's vote matters. The man is Samuel K. Doe, the former sergeant who at age 28 ensconced himself as president in 1980 after his soldiers bayoneted a civilian predecessor. Mr. Doe is now a five-star general whose most conspicuous victory is over the calendar. He has added two years to his age so that, officially, he will be 35, as required by the Constitution, when the people of his West Africa country choose him as president in November's election.

title: SUDAN GUERRILLAS STEP UP ATTACKS
description: Immediately after the overthrow of President Gaafar al-Nimeiry in early April, the Sudan's new leaders declared that settling the long civil war in the south was their ''top priority.''

title: Washington Watch;   New Man at the White House
description: Stephen I. Danzansky, partner in the Washington office of Willkie Farr & Gallagher, the late Wendell Willkie's law firm, is moving to the White House to become the senior official in the National Security Council overlooking international trade issues, according to an Administration official.

title: Report on Reagan-F.B.I. Ties
description: A California newspaper says F.B.I. documents show that Ronald Reagan gave information to Federal agents investigating Communism in Hollywood when he was an actor, but the White House said today that the records contained nothing new.

title: 7.7% RATE IS LURING CAR BUYERS
description: Ten days after the General Motors Corporation began offering special 7.7 percent financing on most of its 1985 models still in stock, G.M. dealers around the country are reporting dramatic increases in customer visits to showrooms and are anticipating similar increases in sales.

title: A FED CAMP IN THE ROCKIES
description: The most striking thing is the double-barreled incongruity of it all.

title: IRAQ REPORTEDLY STRIKES IRAN OIL DEPOT AGAIN
description: Iraqi warplanes raided the Iranian oil terminal at Kharg island in the Persian Gulf today for the second time in 10 days, marine salvage executives said.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Mean, Clean Streets; Lumbering Home
description: A Times editor just returned from vacation reports: ''It was a real shock to find out how bad the city's expressways are compared with, say, unpaved gravel lumber roads in northern Maine. The one from Greenville to Millinocket, for instance, is unmacadamized for about 25 miles.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: COUNCIL PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES CHALLENGED ANEW
description: At least three Democratic candidates for City Council president who were restored to the Sept. 10 primary ballot by an appellate court late last week are now being challenged in the state's highest court.

title: Esquire Video Venture
description: Esquire Magazine and Serendipity Productions, a video production company, have formed a joint venture to produce a line of how-to videos called ''Esquire Success.''

title: Marine Dies in Copter Crash
description: The Marine Corps' newest and largest helicopter crashed with five people aboard today, killing one marine and injuring the four others, the authorities said.

title: COLLEGE PLAYERS TO COMPETE AGAINST INTERNATIONAL STARS
description: A recent plum for collegiate bridge players received little publicity and a small number of players found themselves facing very favorable odds.

title: Sara Solis-Cohen Wed in Pennsylvania
description: The marriage of Sara Solis-Cohen to Peter Andrew Rabinowitz, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Rabinowitz of New York, took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Solis-Cohen Jr., parents of the bride, in Rydal, Pa. Rabbis David S. Wice and Gunter Hirschberg officiated.

title: 2 Attacks Attributed To Killer in California
description: A man dubbed the night stalker who is believed to have killed 14 people shot a man and sexually attacked a woman today, the 35th and 36th assaults attributed to the killer, the police said.

title: Phillip C. Gildan Weds Laurie Beth Leinwand
description: Laurie Beth Leinwand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. David Leinwand of White Plains, was married yesterday to Phillip Clarke Gildan, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert L. Gildan of North Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Arnold S. Turetsky performed the ceremony at the Park Lane Hotel in Manhattan.

title: ANTIABOTION DISPUTE
description: In a split in antiabortion ranks, the Ad Hoc Committee in Defense of Life has accused the United States Catholic Conference of ''a broad retreat'' from its position that the Supreme Court should reverse its 1973 decision permitting abortion. The conference, which consists of all active Roman Catholic Bishops in the country, denies such a move.

title: NEW YORK CITY TRIBUNE SUSPENDS PUBLICATION
description: The New York City Tribune, a daily newspaper founded by followers of the Rev. Sun Myung Moon more than three years ago, will suspend publication after today, the newspaper's management announced last night.

title: Rainier Bank Selects Young & Rubicam
description: Young & Rubicam, San Francisco, has been appointed as the advertising agency for the Rainier Bancorporation, a Seattle-based bank holding company with assets of $7.6 billion.

title: CARBIDE'S DEEPENING QUAGMIRE
description: By blaming its own employees and equipment for the toxic gas leak at its Institute, W.Va., plant, the Union Carbide Corporation has fallen deeper into a corporate quagmire of litigation, overburdened management and public cynicism about its concern for safety.

title: Meese Defending His Record
description: Attorney General Edwin Meese 3d marked his first six months in office today with a spirited defense of his record, saying that critics of the Administration's civil rights policies ''are way out of step'' with most Americans.

title: Federal Funds Help Spread Procreation Dogma
description: To the Editor:

title: SOME BUSES GET A SEAL OF APPROVAL...
description: Although it is no rival for the Good Housekeeping Seal of Approval, the Transit Authority's ''Quality Control Bus'' decal is showing up on more and more vehicles around town.

title: Col. Leslie Shope Dies at 91; Led Radio Free Europe Fund
description: Col. Leslie R. Shope, a former president of the Radio Free Europe Fund, died last Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I. He was 91 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Saudi Oil Production Off
description: Saudi Arabian crude oil production fell again in the first three weeks of August to between 2.2 million and 2.4 million barrels a day despite the kingdom's clear wish to increase output, oil and diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf said today.

title: RISE IN AFRICA DEBT WORRYING BANKS
description: Sub-Saharan African countries, faced with mounting foreign debts and rapidly rising debt service, are finding it increasingly difficult to repay their loans, raising concerns within the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund as well as among commercial bankers.

title: A Blow to Poor Tenants
description: To the Editor:

title: MARINO'S MEETING CALLED CONSTRUCTIVE
description: Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphins' quarterback who is holding out for a new contract, had what his attorney described as a ''very constructive meeting'' yesterday with Joe Robbie, the team's managing general partner.

title: What Space Battle Stations Cannot Do for Us
description: To the Editor:

title: CORNELL WORKERS RATIFY NEW PACT
description: Service and maintenance workers at Cornell University ratified a new contract today, ending a two-day strike in time for the beginning of classes this week.

title: EX-DETAINEES IN SOUTH AFRICA SAY POLICE METHODS HAVE BEEN HARSH
description: Five weeks after South Africa proclaimed a state of emergency, those most affected by it and some of those detained under its provisions say they see patterns that suggest a many-pronged attack by the authorities.

title: Heavy Supply of Issues Expected
description: After last week's strong performance in the credit markets, where bond prices rose and yields fell despite a flurry of new issues, securities dealers are preparing for another week of heavy supply in the corporate and tax-exempt sectors.

title: Clashes and Kidnappings Disrupt Beirut Anew
description: Moslem forces shelled Christian areas today in a new violation of a Syrian-brokered truce.

title: F.A.O. Schwarz Gets A New Top Executive
description: The Christiana Companies announced that Peter L. Harris, a discount retailing executive, had been named president and chief executive of F.A.O. Schwarz, the tony toy store chain that Christiana acquired in June for an undisclosed sum.

title: PHOTOGRAPHER'S NAME OFFICIAL FOR MOUNTAIN
description: Mount Ansel Adams was officially dedicated this weekend in honor of the late photographer whose work captured the splendor of the park for more than 50 years.

title: DONALD EDWARD HEWES
description: Donald Edward Hewes, the former head of the space agency's lunar landing research for the Apollo project of the 1960's, died Friday at Mary Immaculate Hospital here.

title: 5 Killed and 12 Injured In Maryland Bus Crash
description: A charter bus skidded out of control on a bridge over the Monocacy River, killing five people and injuring 12 others. The bus bounced violently between guard rails for 200 feet, hurling several passengers into the water.

title: Burton Y. Berry, 83, Is Dead; Career Diplomat for the U.S.
description: Burton Y. Berry, a career United States diplomat, died Thursday at his home in Zurich.

title: A Coda for Eddie Condon's
description: IN the early hours of Aug. 1, Eddie Condon's, the last of the legendary 52d Street jazz clubs, closed its doors. Condon's had never lacked for gifted musicians or devoted customers. It had fallen victim, instead, to an urban form of AIDS - Accretive Industrial Development Syndrome.

title: MACHINE TOOL ORDERS CONTINUE THEIR DECLINE
description: Orders for American-made machine tools declined to slightly more than $200 million in July, a drop of 14.6 percent from the previous month and 35.9 percent from July 1984, according to a report to be released today by the industry's trade association.

title: Barge Damaged in Collision Leaks Chemical in California
description: Nearly 150,000 gallons of caustic soda, considered extremely dangerous to marine life, leaked today from a barge that collided with a ship in Long Beach Harbor.

title: AT A GAMES CONVENTION, FUN AND FANTASY REIGN
description: Stuart Carlston, at 6 feet 8 inches tall, looked more like a giant than an elf as he joined a group of players for the game ''Advanced Dungeons & Dragons.'' But there he stood in a black elf's suit, sleeves flowing to his furry white boots and a black-and-purple-striped cape.

title: BAR PANEL TO CONSIDER DOHRN'S FITNESS
description: She was a leader of the Weather Underground and a fugitive for nearly 11 years from charges that she participated in violent protests.

title: Stacey W. Beebe Becomes a Bride
description: Stacey Watson Beebe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Marius Beebe of Bedford, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kenneth James Dreshfield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Charles Dreshfield of Duluth, Minn. Cantor Raymond Smolover performed the ceremony at the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club.

title: Sarah Gates Wed in New Hampshire
description: Sarah MacMillan Gates, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart W. Gates of Portland, Ore., was married yesterday to Clifford Llewellyn Fitzgerald 3d, a son of Virginia H. Fitzgerald of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. Fitzgerald Jr. of Stamford, Conn. The Rev. Phillip Zaeder, chaplain of the Phillips Academy, of which the bride is an alumna, performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Community Church in Whitefield, N.H.

title: MUSIC: CATSKILL FESTIVAL
description: The Catskill Conservatory's Summer Chamber Music Festival is a bit off the beaten path, but so is the fare it offers; searching it out is worthwhile. Salt Springville is a hamlet so tiny that there are innkeepers and restaurateurs hardly a dozen miles away who have never heard of it. The Catskill players perform here on Friday nights in a lovingly restored 18th-century Dutch barn; the programs are repeated Saturday evenings in East Meredith and again Sunday afternoons in Rensselaerville.

title: U.A.W., FUTUTRE UNCERTAIN, CELEBRATES 50TH YEAR
description: There were only about 200 people gathered at Detroit's Fort Shelby Hotel 50 years ago when the United Automobile Workers was founded.

title: UGANDA REMOVES PRIME MINISTER
description: The Ugandan Prime Minister has been dismissed by the military Government, the state radio said today. The move came on the eve of peace talks with rebel leaders.

title: Rev. Charles Rebholz Is Dead; Taught 30 Years at St. John's
description: The Rev. Charles B. Rebholz, a former headmaster of St. John's Preparatory School in Brooklyn and a professor for three decades at St. John's University in Queens, died Saturday at Germantown (Pa.) Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at St. Vincent's Seminary in Philadelphia.

title: THE DISHEARTENING HOUSING SLOWDOWN
description: To understand why economists are becoming more pessimistic about the economy, it helps to know that Charles H. Sanford is giving out free curtains.

title: OLD MAN'S GAME
description: Lining base hits may be a young man's job, as 26-year-old Willie McGee and 27-year-old Wade Boggs are demonstrating. But blasting the ball over the fence seems to be work for more experienced hands.

title: Save the Lunch, but Not the Subsidy
description: To the Editor:

title: DATA FOR CAMPAIGN STOLEN FROM OFFICE
description: The office of City Councilwoman Carolyn B. Maloney was broken into over the weekend and a computer disk drive containing her campaign schedule and ''confidential constituent information'' was taken, according to an aide.

title: L.I. DRIVER KILLED IN CREEK PLUNGE
description: A Long Island man was killed early today when his car hit a guardrail, jumped onto a drawbridge and fell 20 feet into an Oyster Bay creek, authorities said. A passenger managed to escape as the car filled with water.

title: AMID SOME REGRETS, ROSE IS SAVORING HIS SUCCESS
description: IN the black night, in a woodsy area about 16 miles north of town, the car came to a stop at an intersection and the headlights illuminated a green sign, which read Spooky Hollow Road. It was close to 11 P.M. last Friday. The car turned left and followed Spooky Hollow Road for a short distance, then turned left down another dark road, and then turned left again.

title: YANKEES OUTSLUG MARINERS
description: The afternoon was a struggle for the Yankees, but it probably should not have been. Not after Dan Pasqua, the rookie from Yonkers, drove in four runs, and certainly not after Don Mattingly crushed a two-run homer in the seventh inning.

title: TOWNSELL BRIGHT SPORT FOR JETS
description: When you're the Jets' coach and your preseason record is 0-3, and you face the Los Angeles Raiders on opening day in two weeks, well, what are you smiling about today, Joe Walton?

title: ACTIONS TAKEN TO SPEED REAGAN'S TAX PROPOSAL
description: While most of official Washington has left town for the summer, tax specialists on Capitol Hill and at the Treasury Department have been laying the groundwork to speed legislative action on President Reagan's tax overhaul proposal when Congress returns from its recess.

title: EXHIBITION OF ISLAMIC ART PROVOKES CONTROVERSY
description: A major exhibition of Islamic art, containing one of the finest displays of miniatures and Arabic calligraphy shown in public for more than a generation, is drawing big crowds this summer at the Musee Rath here.

title: MEXICO-ONCE MORE AT THE BRINK
description: MEXICO is once again in dire economic straits -worse, perhaps, than in 1982, when it reached the brink of bankruptcy.

title: INTEREST RATES FELL IN AUGUST
description: Interest rates have declined since early August as traders and investors have bet that a weak economy will keep inflation and credit demands low and eventually cause the Federal Reserve Board to take actions that will bring additional reductions in short-term interest rates.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 26, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Council for Namibia - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: U.S. WILL PAY OUT MILLIONS OVER '82 PAN AM CRASH
description: The Federal Government has agreed to pay millions of dollars to relatives of the 145 passengers killed in the crash of a Pan American World Airways jetliner outside New Orleans in 1982, officials of the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: SEA FLOOR DISCOVERIES POSE NEW EVOLUTIONARY QUESTIONS
description: Exotic deep-sea life forms, creatures once thought to thrive only in scalding, sulfur-rich water far below the last feeble penetration of sunlight, are now being found in a rapidly growing number of habitats on the ocean floor, biologists report.

title: Effects of News Media On Policies to Be Studied
description: Students will examine how the news media shape government policy at Harvard's new Center for Press, Politics and Public Policy, set to open in several months, school officials said.

title: Getting Phone Costs Out of Orbit
description: American regulators have decided to let a few private companies launch their own international communications satellites. Until now, that was permitted only to Intelsat, the 109-country consortium that controls the business; so the decision is good news. Competition could bring more efficient use of this dazzling technology. But the Federal Communications Commission's action is only a small first step. If most consumers are to reap the benefits, Washington will have to convince regulators in other countries to let open competition work.

title: ON AND OFF THE COURT, GARRISON HAS MATURED
description: ON the eve of the United States Open, Zina Garrison, the 21-year-old sixth-seeded player, would like to clarify some of the misconceptions about Zina Garrison.

title: Accounts
description: Carolee Jewelry Inc., which makes faux jewelry, to McCaffery & Ratner.

title: Roger Holt Wed To Renee Brown
description: Renee Brown, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Brown of Brooklyn Heights and Westhampton Beach, L.I., and Roger James Holt, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Ralph Holt of Los Angeles, were married yesterday. Rabbi Isaiah Zeldin performed the ceremony at the Hotel Bel-Air in Los Angeles.

title: AS AMTRAK FACES CUTS, BUSINESS IS BOOMING
description: Like many long-distance trains this summer, Amtrak's southbound Crescent has few empty seats when it stops each day in this steamy east Mississippi town.

title: 6 DEMOCRATIC MAYORAL FOES DIFFER SHARPLY IN TV DEBATE
description: In their only scheduled televised debate before the Sept. 10 primary election, the six candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination clashed last night - over schools, transit and housing, but most of all, over how Mayor Koch has put his imprint on the city.

title: RIGHTS ADVOCATE WILL NOT BE MOVED
description: Old-timers in Washington cannot recall anything like the current United States Civil Rights Commission. For years, the purely advisory agency issued, without dissent, reports finding everyone from the President to the smallest agencies negligent in enforcing the laws that protect the rights of minorities and women.

title: HANSON TRUST SETS SIGHTS ON A BIG DEAL
description: For eight weeks Lord Hanson, chairman of Hanson Trust P.L.C. and one of Britain's most-admired and most-feared corporate raiders, has countered speculation that the proceeds of a $725 million rights issue would either be used to purchase a British company or left earning a useful return on the money markets.

title: LINING UP FOR 'BLUES' FOR BREAKFAST
description: The customers begin gathering at 7:15 A.M. every Saturday. By 7:29 a line of 20 has formed. At 7:30 breakfast is served.

title: The Worm and the Apple;   Mean, Clean Streets; Gutter Politics
description: New York City's 130 Offtrack Betting parlors generate more than 21 million stubs annually. Many of them, torn in half by disappointed losers, end up as street litter, with the coffee cups and other trash left by patrons who cluster on the sidewalks studying the Racing Form.

title: UP TO THE LIMIT
description: Harvest has started in Sichuan Province in southwest China.

title: TUDOR CITY SQUATTERS
description: For the last several years, residents in the quiet midtown haven of Tudor City have noticed a choice, but unused, piece of real estate in their midst: a three-story, boarded-up brownstone on East 41st Street.

title: Pastime on Stalled Elevator
description: A woman left by herself in a skyscraper's pitch-black elevator for four hours in a power failure Saturday said she passed the time doing aerobic exercises. The woman, Faye Weisler, 30 years old, was the only person on the elevator at the time because most offices in the building were closed. She said she remained in contact with the ground floor watchman's desk by a telephone in the elevator until power was restored.

title: More Marijuana Taken From Sunken Trawler
description: Salvage workers today raised a sunken trawler off Cape Cod and found 103 bales of marijuana aboard, bringing to nearly 600 the number of bales found in the scuttled ship, officials said.

title: GOODEN'S 20TH A MILESTONE AS METS DOWN PADRES, 9-3
description: Pitching through a fine mist, Dwight Gooden was not in control. The ball was too slick and it slipped away, over the batters' heads, past the catcher's mitt, and once even into the outfield. There was Dwight Gooden, on his biggest day, standing in the rain, shaking his head. In the oldest baseball vernacular, the pitcher had no rhythm.

title: ROGERS D. RUSK
description: Rogers D. Rusk, professor emeritus of physics at Mount Holyoke College in South Hadley, Mass., died Aug. 15 at his home in McConnelsville, Ohio.

title: LITTLE RECENT RAIN IN CATSKILLS
description: New York City's reservoirs in the Catskills have so far received almost 3 inches less rain than normal for August, a spokesman for the city's Department of Environmental Protection said yesterday.

title: BIG PLAY IS FACTOR IN GIANTS' VICTORY
description: For the Giants, the bottom line in their 34-31 overtime victory over the Jets Saturday night was that they proved they could make the big play.

title: ROBERT L. ROSENTHAL
description: Robert L. Rosenthal, an executive of Chesebrough-Pond's Inc. in Greenwich, Conn., died of a heart attack Aug. 14 while vacationing in Cape Cod, Mass.

title: COMPUTER FLAW STALLS SHUTTLE FLIGHT
description: A mysterious computer failure on the space shuttle Discovery today forced a postponement of at least two days in launching the spacecraft on its mission to deploy three satellites and repair one already in orbit.

title: Carol First, an Editor, Weds David A. Sailors
description: The marriage of Carol First, the managing editor for W. H. Freeman & Company, a science publishing house in New York, to David Ade Sailors, an industrial and commercial photographer, took place yesterday at the Manhattan home of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Sharpe, brother-in-law and sister of the bride. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg with the Rev. Karl Gillmeister, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY LWORRIES ABOUT LUCHOW'S
description: Is the landmark Luchow's a landmark?

title: LAUDA CAPTURES DUTCH GRAND PRIX
description: Niki Lauda of Austria fought off his French McLaren-TAGPorsche teammate Alain Prost to take his 25th career victory by inches in the Dutch Grand Prix today, depriving Prost of precious points for the 1985 world title.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We're all just fortunate to be part of Dwight's little world.'' - Gary Carter, Mets' catcher, after Gooden became youngest pitcher ever to win 20 games in a season. [C1:3.]

title: FEDERAL FUNDS HELP SPRERAD PROCREATION DOGMA
description: To the Editor:

title: DEATH ROWS GREW 16%
description: The execution of criminals in the United States increased sharply in 1984, and a record 1,405 inmates were on death rows by the end of the year, the Justice Department said today.

title: 4 FAVORITE 'HONEYMOONERS' EPISODES
description: IT'S not that WPIX needs an excuse to show reruns of ''The Honeymooners.'' It shows them six nights a week as it is. At the same time, there's nothing wrong with showing four episodes in one night and making it an occasion. In fact, it's a lovely idea. ''The Honeymooners,'' 30 years old, is still fresh, and four episodes are better than one. They will be seen on Channel 11 starting at 8 P.M.

title: COURSE TO TRAIN PILOTS ON WIND DANGERS DUE
description: Federal officials who have been slow to adopt an advanced system for detecting sudden, violent changes in wind direction, the suspected cause of a Delta plane crash, have approved a much cheaper program to train pilots about these changes.

title: Officer Adds Title At Morrison-Knudsen
description: The Morrison-Knudsen Corporation, the construction and engineering concern, said it had elected its president, William J. Deasy, to the additional post of chief executive.

title: Poll of South African Blacks Finds Most Favor Sanctions
description: South Africa's urban blacks overwhelmingly support international trade sanctions against the Pretoria Government, but most doubt apartheid will be ended without civil war, according to a poll published by The Sunday Times of London today.

title: REAGAN WEIGHING TRADE SANCTIONS, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: President Reagan is considering punitive actions against ''unfair'' trade practices, but has decided not to curb the volume of foreign shoes coming into the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: MORE RUNS FEARED AT THRIFT UNITS
description: Banking and Government officials expressed concern today that the ban on withdrawals late last week at the First Maryland Savings and Loan Association could jolt depositor confidence and lead to widespread withdrawals at other Maryland thrift units that have yet to receive Federal deposit insurance.

title: Ally & Gargano Income
description: Ally & Gargano reported gross agency income of approximately $7 million for its 1985 fourth quarter, an increase of about 23 percent over the same period last year.

title: HISPANICS IN STATE IN WORST POVERTY
description: Hispanic residents of New York State are poorer, less educated and more prone to serious health and social problems than any other segment of the population, white or black, according to two new studies.

title: AS A POLICE OFFICER PATROLLING BROOKLYN'S STREETS, A POET FINDS HIS MUSE
description: Three years ago, he was moving drug addicts off the corners and watching his back on a grim beat in Brooklyn. He carried two guns and a blackjack and wore a bulletproof vest. When people asked him in the summer if he was hot, he said, ''Yeah, but it's cold in the morgue.''

title: CITY OPERA: PUCCINI'S 'TURANDOT' IN SEASON DEBUT
description: PUCCINI'S ''Turandot'' requires three things above all: big, thrilling voices, visual spectacle and orchestral sweep. The first two are very expensive. Just the thing, one would think, for the New York City Opera to stay away from - but, approached from that point of departure, the production revived Saturday at the State Theater comes surprisingly close to success.

title: FILM: FRENCH COMEDY, 'MY OTHER ''HUSBAND'' '
description: ''MY OTHER 'HUSBAND,' '' Georges Lautner's French comedy, which opens today at the 72d Street Playhouse, is a sort of feminist ''Captain's Paradise,'' about a bright, pretty, self-possessed young woman named Alice (Miou-Miou) who, quite efficiently and happily, divides her time between two fully equipped households, neither of which is aware of the other.

title: 15-Year Home Loans Gain
description: The 15-year mortgage, almost unheard of a year ago, accounted for one in seven loans made by some of the nation's largest mortgage bankers during the first week of August, a trade group said Friday.

title: U.S. GRAND JURY STUDYING F.B.I. MOB-INQUIRY LEAK
description: A Justice Department official said yesterday that a Federal grand jury was investigating how reputed organized-crime figures obtained a secret document containing key information about an inquiry into their activities.

title: SUFFRAGE ANNIVERSARY
description: Washington cultural institutions always seem to be trying to broaden their base. The Library of Congress offers folk music, the Smithsonian sponsors plays, the National Gallery of Art holds classical concerts, the Folger Shakespeare Library presents Renaissance music.

title: ROCK VIDEOS DRAWING FILM STARS AND DIRECTORS
description: Directing a rock video might seem a long way from playing the Broadway lead in Tom Stoppard's ''Real Thing'' or portraying Swann in a film adaptation of Proust's ''Remembrance of Things Past,'' but Jeremy Irons says he loved it and thinks music videos have ''enormous'' possibilities.

title: ECONOMIC UNCERTAINTY FOR BRAZIL
description: For much of the last five months, a fierce power struggle between the Finance Minister, Francisco Dornelles, and the Planning Minister, Joao Sayad, has prevented Brazil's new civilian Government from formulating a coherent economic policy.

title: Australian Brewery Bid
description: The Australian investor Alan Bond, who captured the America's Cup yacht trophy, appeared Friday to have gained another prize, the Castlemaine Tooheys brewing company.

title: WOLLMAN RINK' LONG SERIES OF MISSTEPS UNDER SCRUTINY
description: When winter comes, the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park will be overrun not with ice skaters, but with technicians and consultants who have begun once again to try to understand a five-year-old story of construction problems and delays.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. ENCOURAGED PRESSER INQUIRH IN 1983, EX-OFFICIAL SAYS
description: The Justice Department encouraged the Labor Department to continue its investigation of Jackie Presser in 1983, several years after the F.B.I. had begun using the teamsters' president as an informer, investigators in the case said today.

title: PAPAL POWER, $16 CAPTURES HOPEFUL
description: Papal Power, a 2-year-old who had run the fastest six furlongs of the Pimlico summer meeting, proved that that romp was no fluke by scoring a five-length upset victory over a sloppy track today in the Hopeful Stakes for 2-year-olds at Saratoga Race Track.

title: British 737 Is Landed After Engine Overheats
description: British Airways Boeing 737 with 80 people aboard made an emergency landing at Heathrow Airport today after a signal light indicated that one of its two engines had overheated, officials said.

title: Latin Debt Crisis
description: Latin America needs international aid and free access to markets in industrialized countries to overcome its debt crisis and bolster democracy, Colombian President Belisario Betancur said Saturday. Mr. Betancur said that the region needed to double its exports in the next five years to cope with interest payments on the $360 billion debt while still developing its economies. He said the regional debt crisis was made worse by a flight of capital, which he estimated at over $50 billion in the last three years.

title: Lucille L. Mendelsohn Married to Eric S. Fain
description: Lucille Louise Mendelsohn and Eric Steven Fain were married yesterday by Rabbi Burt A. Siegal at the Roslyn (L.I.) Country Club. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Mendelsohn of Great Neck, L.I. Mr. Fain is the son of Carol Fain Walters of New York and the late Bernard I. Fain of Barrington, R.I.

title: MARCOS SEEMS TO DROP '85 ELECTION IDEA
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, who said earlier this month that he was seriously considering calling a presidential election this year, has now apparently decided against it. The next scheduled presidential balloting is in 1987.

title: ...OTHERS JUST SIT
description: Speaking of which, whatever happened to the 850 Grumman Flxibles that were taken out of service in February 1984 and put up for sale a year later?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Aug. 26, 1985 : *2*MONDAY Detroit Edison Toro Company Excelsior Income Shs United Illuminating Orion Capital Corp Watkins-Johnson *2*TUESDAY Angelica Corp Macy (RH) & Co EDO Corp National Gypsum Gannett Co New England Elec Sys Hayes-Albion Corp Southwest Airlines IPALCO Enterprises Westvaco Corp *2*WEDNESDAY Barry Wright Corp Philip Morris Bowater Inc Reading & Bates Corp Ceco Industries Inc Square D Co Conwood Corp Stanley Works Deere & Co Trico Industries First Virginia Banks Tucson Elec Pwr Key Banks Wynn's Intl Pennsylvania Pwr&Lt *2*THURSDAY Ametek Inc Lee Enterprises Arvin Industries *2*FRIDAY Aetna Life&Casualty Sanders Associates

title: SLAYER OF PLANS HE FINDS TOO COSTLY
description: In the mid-1960's, a young California lawyer and boxing enthusiast helped organize a syndicate to invest in what he still considers to be ''the fastest, hardest-hitting middleweight I've ever seen.''

title: 8 KILLED IN MAINE PLANE CRASH
description: Samantha Smith, the girl who visited the Soviet Union after writing a letter to the former Soviet President Yuri Andropov, was on the passenger list of a plane that crashed near Auburn-Lewiston Municipal Airport, killing eight people, sources said.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: STRINDBERG. By Michael Meyer. 651 pages. Illustrated. Random House. $24.95. AUGUST STRINDBERG doubted whether tuberculosis really existed, but he believed in vampires. He was also convinced that he had mastered the art of making gold. Not long after X-rays were discovered, he confided to a friend that he himself had discovered them 10 years before; on the other hand he dismissed radium as a fraud. Once, while sitting in an open-air restaurant, he suddenly produced a syringe and injected an apple on a nearby tree with morphia, explaining to the proprietor that he was a botanist. On another occasion, during a visit to the zoo, he began expounding his theory that gorillas were descended from a union between a shipwrecked sailor and a female monkey; by way of proof he produced two photographs that he carried around, showing the alleged similarities between the palm of an old sailor's hand and a monkey's paw.

title: Washington Watch;   Answering Charges
description: Japanese semiconductor manufacturers will submit a 130-page brief today to the office of the United States trade representative formally replying to charges by their American competitors that the Japanese maintain severe restrictions on access to their market.

title: BUILDING MUSEUM GAP
description: The new National Building Museum was to have opened its first exhibit in Washington's classic Pension Building next month, but the show of architectural drawings for famous Government structures and monuments had to be postponed until Oct. 24. The building museum had not allowed enough time for its own rebuilding.

title: FISHING THE CONNECTICUT
description: A RECENT afternoon on the Connecticut River did not alter my long-held belief that in the Northeast in August freshwater anglers should remain at home cursing the heat and dreaming of October.

title: INTRODUCING THE S.&P. 250
description: WHEN the Chicago Mercantile Exchange announced last week that it planned to introduce futures on an index of over-the-counter stocks this fall, the second-largest futures market again showed that it had not lost its innovative touch.

title: U.S. DEFEATS SOVIET IN CUP VOLLEYBALL
description: It won the Olympic Gold Medal last year, and now the United States men's volleyball team is proving it is probably the best in the world.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: MONDAY, AUGUST 26, 1985
description: International

title: A CORRECTION
description: An answer last week involving the number of former Big Five coaches who are now head coaches in the National Basketball Association was inaccurate because it incorrectly identified the coach of the Sacramento Kings. Phil Johnson replaced Jack McKinney last Nov. 18, reducing the number to four.

title: MALTBIE WINS SERIES GOLF BY 4
description: Continuing to enjoy the best year of his 11 on the PGA Tour, Roger Maltbie made golf look almost routine today on the long, dull, but difficult Firestone Country Club South Course when he shot 4-under 66 to win the NEC World Series of Golf by 4 shots.

title: Danis Lloyd Married To Ronald Alan Sher
description: The marriage of Danis Cory Lloyd to Ronald Alan Sher took place yesterday at the Terrace Restaurant in New York. Rabbi Charles Davidson performed the ceremony.

title: CARDS TOP BRAVES, CAPTURE 5th ROW
description: The St. Louis Cardinals won their fifth straight today with a 5-2 victory over the Braves that sent Atlanta to its sixth consecutive defeat.

title: To Keep New York's Auction Houses Honest
description: To the Editor:

title: Suzanne M. Silver, Artist, Married to Michael Swartz
description: Suzanne Maura Silver and Michael Dov Swartz were married yesterday at the Henry Lindenbaum Center in New York by Rabbi Elihu Schagrin.

title: Gail B. Hochman Is Wed
description: Gail B. Hochman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert Hochman of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Michael H. Levi, the son of Inge Levi of Great Neck, L.I., and the late Eric Levi. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Rainbow Grill. The bride, who will retain her name, is a literary agent with Brandt & Brandt in New York. Dr. Levi is a postdoctoral fellow in clinical microbiology at Montefiore Hospital.

title: French Socialists Fail To Agree on Manifesto
description: Senior members of the governing Socialist Party failed today to agree on a manifesto to be presented to the party's October congress.

title: YOUNGER PLAYERS BATTLE DOUBTS
description: LIKE a majority of Americans, Mike Leach did not have the cold, hard cash to buy a new car. So he went to a bank and applied for a loan, listing ''tennis professional'' as his occupation. The bank officer gave him a puzzled look. ''Where do you teach?'' he asked Leach, who explained that he wasn't a teacher but a player.

title: August Less Than Vintage
description: IN recent years, August has often been a vintage month for the stock market. In 1982, the Dow Jones industrial average swept ahead 92.71 points in that month and did even better in 1984 with a gain of 109.10 points. In 1983, August saw the industrials tack on a comparatively stodgy 16.94 points.

title: BECKER TOPS WILANDER IN A.T.P. FINAL
description: Boris Becker, serving 10 aces to his opponent's two, defeated Mats Wilander today, 6-4, 6-2, in the final of the Association of Tennis Professionals Championship here.

title: VANITY FAIR'S SLICK FORMULA
description: Soon after Tina Brown took over as editor in chief of the troubled Vanity Fair in January 1984, she began hearing talk of her pending dismissal and the magazine's pending demise. It had already gone through two editors and had developed an image as a pretentious, intellectual monthly.

title: NEW CALEDONIANS MAY BOYCOTT VOTE
description: A spokesman for the main pro-independence group in New Caledonia says the group will probably call for a boycott of elections in the French Pacific territory. The group will meet early next month to decide whether to take part in the vote, the spokesman said.

title: TELEPROMPTER TAKES 'MILLION'
description: It was fitting that today's Budweiser-Arlington Million, staged before 35,651 people in the makeshift stands of a track destroyed by fire 25 days ago, was won by a jockey who earlier in the week could not even pass a physical.

title: AIDE TO PRESIDENT OF WEST GERMANY IS ARRESTED AS SPY
description: West Germany's espionage scandal widened today with the disclosure that a secretary in President Richard von Weizsacker's office had been arrested on charges of spying.

title: EMPLOYEE SOUGHT IN $163,000 THEFT
description: An employee of an armored-car company was sought by the police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation yesterday in connection with a $163,000 robbery Saturday night at an office of the concern in Bayside, Queens.

title: CRUZ BEATS COE: LEWIS LOSES AGAIN
description: Joaquim Cruz of Brazil beat Sebastian Coe of Britain with a time of 1 minute 42.55 seconds for 800 meters at the Mobil Grand Prix track and field meet today. The clocking was the fastest in the world this year.

title: JOINING HANDS IN THE FIGHT AGAINST PRONORGRAPHY
description: Last month during the National Organization for Women convention in New Orleans, Andrea Dworkin led an antipornography march of 100 people down Bourbon Street. Wearing her trademark blue denim overalls, bullhorn in hand, she led chants that included ''Hey, hey, ho, ho, pornography has got to go!''

title: RABBIT'S FEAT
description: When Steve Cram went on his spree of record-breaking this summer, it seemed that he ran in the shadow of no man, smashing the world marks in the 1,500 meters, the mile and the 2,000 before narrowly falling short in the 1,000. But in three of those races, he did indeed run in the shadow of one man, by design.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium, 7:35 P.M. Ed Lynch will face Fernando Valenzuela in the first of a two-game series.

title: Nepal Frees 1,649 of 1,750
description: Nepal today announced the release of 1,649 people detained for questioning about bomb blasts in June that killed seven people. It said 101 people were still in custody and announced the start of legal proceedings against extremists accused of involvement in the blasts.

title: ENTWINED WITH 'STAR WARS,' ANTI-SATELLITE DEBATE GROWS
description: The effort by the Air Force to perfect a weapon that can destroy satellites has taken on new scientific and political importance because of the program's identification with ''Star Wars,'' according to Government officials and outside experts.

title: SCM Says Bid Is Inadequate
description: The SCM Corporation said yesterday that its board of directors had unanimously voted to ask shareholders to reject a $60 a share, or a total of $755 million, offer by Hanson Trust P.L.C. of London. The company said the offer was inadequate and was not in the best interest of stockholders.

title: HELPING FAMILIES DEAL WITH CHRONIC PAIN
description: Phyllis Kingery remembers coming home night after night from her secretarial job to find her husband, Bill, a former construction worker, immobilized in a reclining chair, a heating pad on his back. Some nights she would ask how he was feeling, and he would reply that the pain was bad. Other nights he would be too drugged to give a report, and in a way, she says, it was a relief not to hear it.

title: A RAVAMPED HIGH SCHOOL FINDS NEW POPULARITY
description: By the time it closed two years ago, Charles Evans Hughes High School in the Chelsea section of Manhattan had become so undesirable that not a single child graduating from the junior high school across the street was willing to go on to Hughes.

title: Washington Watch;   LATIN AMERICA DEBT AUSTERITY
description: ALTHOUGH President Fidel Castro of Cuba has urged his Latin American neighbors to declare a moratorium on their debts, most of the countries, including Nicaragua, are trying to stay on good terms with their bankers.

title: Lebanon Rocket Hits Israel
description: A Katyusha rocket fired from Lebanon landed today in northern Israel but caused no casualties or damage, military sources said. The rocket attack was the second in 24 hours and the fourth since Israel withdrew most of its forces from Lebanon more than two months ago.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: OBSERVATION POST Rents are high, good restaurants and fine clothes are expensive, but the view from the most impressive architectural specimen on the Hudson River between midtown Manhattan and the George Washington Bridge costs only 25 cents. The architectural beauty is the Riverside Church, and the panoramic views of upper Manhattan, New Jersey and, on clear days, the Bronx and Queens, are from the church's 392-foot tower. The observation deck is reached by elevator and stairs, and the lack of a crowd often stimulates contemplation.

title: Sri Lanka Soldiers Kill 26 Rebels
description: Soldiers on a training mission have killed 26 Tamil rebels at a terrorist training base, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Security said today.

title: JOSEPH T. HORAN
description: Joseph Taaffe Horan, a foreign correspondent and an assistant to his publisher, William Randolph Hearst, died Thursday at his home here. He was 87 years old.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Amerifederal Savings Bank, Lawrenceville, N.J., has appointed R. Scott Twigg senior vice president.

title: BLOCK ON 'GOOD WILL' SOVIET TRIP
description: Agriculture Secretary John R. Block arrived in Moscow today and said he and a top-level team of American farm figures were seeking to expand agricultural trade with the Soviet Union during a weeklong ''good will'' trip.

title: BLACKS PROTESTING 2D VOTE-FRAUD TRIAL IN ALABAMA
description: Jury selection begins Monday in the trial of the first of five Greene County voting rights workers charged by a Federal grand jury with vote fraud.

title: Ways That Penguins Differ From People
description: To the Editor:

title: THE PERILS OF SHYNESS ON THE JOB
description: FOR years, Bob Hanson, a 32-year-old San Francisco computer programmer, was passed over for promotion even though he was the top performer in his department. Instead of asking why, Mr. Hanson continued to assume difficult projects in the hope that his efforts would be recognized some day.

title: PAUL THEROUX CHANGING PUBLISHERS AFTER 20 YEARS
description: In the latest switch of a best-selling author from one publishing house to another, Paul Theroux is moving to G. P. Putnam from Houghton Mifflin, the publisher of the two dozen novels and travel books he has written over the last 20 years.

title: India Seeking Oil Bids
description: India will ask foreign oil companies to submit new bids to explore oil in the country's offshore and onshore areas, Nawal Kishore Sharma, the petroleum minister, said today.

title: RECRUITING ADS SCREEN CANDIDATES
description: THE International Business Machines Corporation gets 1.3 million job applications each year. That is enough prospective employees to more than replace its total worldwide work force of nearly 400,000 every four months.

title: A CARNIVAL FOR STARS, LESSER LIGHTS AND FANS
description: THE United States Open is a tennis carnival with 13 different competitions taking place over a 13-day period on the 16-acre grounds of the United States Tennis Association's National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadow Park.

title: 4 MORE ARRESTED IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The police reported four incidents of unrest in South African black townships today. The incidents came against the backdrop of the authorities continued crackdown on dissent.

title: 22 RARE DEER ARE RETURNED TO NATIVE GROUND IN CHINA
description: More than 120 years after an intrepid French missionary peered into an imperial hunting park here and discovered a breed of deer unknown in the West, a joint enterprise by a British aristocrat and American benefactors has brought the animal back to China.

title: BAINES'S 3-RUN HOMER BEATS BLUE JAYS
description: Harold Baines blasted a three-run homer and Floyd Bannister won his first game in more than two months as the Chicago White Sox beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 5-3, today.

title: DWIGHT GOODEN CAN'T GET A GRIP
description: THE world learned something about Dwight Gooden yesterday: he doesn't take to pitching in a tropical rain forest. If the ownership were to move the Mets to El Yunque, P.R., for example, it might take Gooden until Labor Day before he won his 20th game of the season.

title: NEWPARK RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company did not disclose year- ago revenue figures.

title: PALMER BACK
description: The 1985 Skins Game will feature an increased purse, a new site, and the return of Arnold Palmer, the commissioner of the P.G.A., Deane Beman, said yesterday. The 55-year-old Palmer will join Jack Nicklaus in the four-men field - the other two selections will be announced later - for the two-day, 18-hole event, which will be sanctioned by the PGA Tour for the first time. The purse has been increased from $360,000 to $450,000 for the event, which will be held at the Nicklaus-designed Bear Creek Golf Club at Murrieta, Calif., north of San Diego, Nov. 30-Dec. 1.

title: INFRARED INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW KIND OF SUPERNOVA
description: Two astronomers using the 200-inch telescope at Palomar Observatory, Calif., have stumbled on a distant supernova explosion - one they believe to be of a type previously unknown to science.

title: CLEMENCY MOVE RULED OUT IN FLORIDA'S 'MERCY DEATH'
description: A 76-year-old man sentenced to life for killing his terminally ill wife lost his bid for freedom today when two more members of the Florida Cabinet rejected the Governor's recommendation to free him while he appeals his murder conviction.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $401,000 for the latest quarter and $540,000 in the latest six month period. c-Includes a net from discontinued operations of $64,000 in the year-ago period and $111,000 in the ye4ar-ago six months. d-Net income.

title: WORLCO DATA SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SMUCKER, J M, CO.  reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HORFORD FAVORS L.S.U.
description: Tito Horford, the 7-foot basketball star from the Dominican Republic, has told the N.C.A.A. he wants to attend Louisiana State University and not the University of Houston. Tom Ford, Houston's athletic director, said yesterday that he had received a telephone call from Tom Yeager of the N.C.A.A. informing him that Horford had placed a phone call to him from the L.S.U. campus at Baton Rouge, La.

title: METALLURGICAL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: METROPOLITAN LIFE THE VICTOR IN COMMERCIAL LEAGUE PLAY
description: The actuarial mind is well-suited to bridge, so it is not surprising that insurance teams have been prominent for several decades in the Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League.
