This is now less evident than it used to be, but Metropolitan Life won the premier division this year, just as it has done for more than half of the past 15 seasons.

title: KILLINGS CAUSE A RIFT IN CHILE MILITARY
description: As Gen. Augusto Pinochet approaches his 12th anniversary in power, his military Government has been shaken by accusations that it was involved in the brutal killing of three Chilean Communists.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: American Hospital Supply Corp., Evanston, Ill., said its American Critical Care division had agreed to distribute a line of injectable anti-cancer products manufactured by International Pharmaceutical Products Inc.

title: ARGENTINE AGREEMENT DUE TODAY
description: Argentine officials and bankers from around the world are expected to sign a long-delayed agreement today to reschedule Argentina's foreign debt.

title: AIDS VICTIM STARTS SCHOOL OVER TELEPHONE
description: Ryan White, who has been barred from school since December because he has acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, today attended the first day of classes by a special telephone line linking his home to his seventh-grade classroom.

title: Accounts
description: Advanced Information Management, a computer services company, to Gray Strayton International, Waltham, Mass.

title: ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 1
YANK BULLPEN NEEDS RELIEF
description: The Yankees arrived here late Sunday night with a sweep of the Seattle Mariners but also with a substantial problem. They keep winning, but they remain in desperate need of a complete game.

title: FLOW SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the retroactive effect of a 3-for-2 stock split effective March 22, 1985.

title: PARLEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: SCM RISES ON BUYOUT SPECULATION
description: The stock of the SCM Corporation rose sharply again yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange on speculation that the company's management, possibly with the help of Merrill Lynch & Company, may be moving ahead with plans for a leveraged buyout.

title: SHARING TELEPHONE SERVICES
description: Rockefeller Center, perhaps the nation's best-known office complex, is moving to offer its thousands of business tenants a new service. By this time next year, if things go as planned, companies will be able to buy their basic telephone service not from the New York Telephone Company, but from Rockefeller Center itself.

title: WOMAN'S BODY FOUND IN HER MANSION ON L.I.
description: The body of a 31-year-old woman was found today on the second floor of her estate here, the police said.

title: INTELLIGENCE SHAKE-UP IS EXPECTED
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl met today with his Interior Minister about what intelligence experts are calling one of the worst spy scandals in West German history.

title: MGM Grand Offer
description: MGM Grand Hotels Inc. said it had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to determine the fairness of a $126 million offer by the investor Kirk Kerkorian to acquire the 30 percent of the company's common shares that Mr. Kerkorian does not already own. The company said Drexel Burnham would review other possible offers for the hotel company, but sources close to MGM Grand said they were not aware that any other serious offers had been made.

title: ANOTHER CHEMICAL LEAKS AT CARBIDE
description: Poisonous hydrochloric acid leaked tonight from a Union Carbide plant about a mile and a half from where an estimated 60,000 people had gathered for an outdoor concert, but the spill was contained quickly, and no injuries were reported, the authorities said.

title: DEVELOPING CANADA OIL SANDS
description: Unlike the United States, where Congress cut off funding for synthetic fuels development on July 31, Canada is pressing cautiously ahead with a number of efforts to develop its substantial oil-sands resources, potentially one of the largest synthetic fuel endeavors anywhere.

title: LUNCH AT TENNIS CENTER HELPS CENTRAL PARK COURTS
description: While Mats Wilander practiced on the grandstand court, about 100 people gathered for lunch at the Racquets Clubs at the National Tennis Center at Flushing Meadows, where the United States Open begins today. The lunch was to aid the restoration of the tennis complex in Central Park, a project of the Central Park Conservancy's Women's Committee.

title: DISCUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public on August 1 and did not report year-ago figures.

title: Nortek Chief Proves Acquisition-Minded
description: Ralph R. Papitto has often said his goal is to build Nortek Inc. into a billion-dollar-a-year company by 1986. As chairman and chief executive of the maker of construction supplies, metal products and electrical supplies, he has pursued numerous acquisitions - apparently with that end in mind.

title: 2 Utilities In Payout Halt
description: Two Louisiana subsidiaries of Middle South Utilities Inc. announced today that they had decided not to pay a dividend on common stock.

title: Remembering L.B.J.
description: This evening, on the 77th anniversary of Lyndon B. Johnson's birth, some old friends and associates will make the trek across the Potomac River into Virginia to lay a wreath at a monument to the 36th President, who died in 1973.

title: Federal Aid to Black Colleges Up $14 Million, Agency Says
description: The Reagan Administration increased Federal aid to black colleges by $14 million last year, according to a report made public today by the Department of Education.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
9 METRO-NORTH TRAINS HALTED
description: Nine trains on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's Hudson line were stalled for 90 minutes yesterday evening after the railroad cut off power to the third rail to repair a switching problem in Tarrytown, a spokesman for the railroad said. Power was turned off between Ossining and Irvington from 6:30 P.M. to 8 P.M., affecting thousands of commuters on trains between Grand Central Terminal and Poughkeepsie. The problem involved the 5:33 P.M. train to Ossining, which was unable to switch tracks properly at Tarrytown.

title: Morgan Executive Is Moving to Drexel
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the investment banking firm that pioneered the use of high-yield ''junk'' bonds for corporate clients, is rapidly building a staff to expand a similar business internationally.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: TUESDAY, AUGUST 27, 1985
description: Companies

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Philippine Investment
description: Investments in the Philippines totaled $340 million last year with 64 percent of the amount invested by foreigners, the state-run Philippine News Agency said today.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
San Diego Selling Bonds for Utility
description: San Diego is offering $100 million of industrial development revenue bonds on behalf of the San Diego Gas and Electric Company, through undrwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: TEAMS SHUFFLING AND TRADING
description: A handful of trades highlighted a busy day for National Football League teams yesterday, as another cutdown approached and teams began reaching the 50-man roster limit by today's 4 P.M. deadline.

title: 2 BRAZILIAN FINANCE AIDES QUIT
description: Two of Brazil's senior finance officials resigned today in the first Government shake-up since civilian rule returned to the country last March.

title: REVLON PLANS BUYBACK WORTH $57.50 A SHARE
description: Directors of Revlon Inc., fighting a takeover bid by Pantry Pride Inc., yesterday approved an offer to repurchase up to 10 million shares of its common stock for new notes and preferred stock valued at $57.50 a share.

title: COWBOYS WIN ON SEPTIEN KICK
description: Rafael Septien's 24-yard field goal with three seconds remaining gave the Cowboys a 15-13 exhibition victory tonight over the Chicago Bears.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Texas Ban on Sodomy
description: A Federal appellate court today upheld a Texas law that makes private homosexual activity illegal.

title: CASES IN THREE STATES CHALLENGE PRIVACY OF TALKS WITH CLERGY
description: The concept that a discussion between a clergyman and a churchgoer is confidential, a long tradition protected by law in most states, has come under challenge in recent cases in California, Texas and Florida.

title: Former Senator Baker
description: Howard H. Baker Jr. has dropped out of the Senate, presumably to clear the way for another run at the Presidency, but that has not kept him from maintaining both a political and personal tie to the institution. Mr. Baker, a former Senate majority leader, has been named senior adviser to the Dirksen Congressional Center, which sponsors research on Congress and is named for the late Everett McKinley Dirksen, a predecessor of Mr. Baker's as Senate leader and, not incidentally, Mr. Baker's father-in-law.

title: FLOCKHART TO BLUES
description: The Montreal Canadiens traded the center Ron Flockhart to the St. Louis Blues after a disappointing season in which he scored only 27 points in 54 games.

title: SCREEN: 'STEVE LACY'
description: AS a subject for a jazz documentary, Steve Lacy makes things easy. He is both an important musician - the first soprano saxophonist in modern jazz - and an articulate one. In ''Steve Lacy: Lift the Bandstand,'' the film maker Peter Bull lets him tell his own story, illustrating it with remarkable archival footage and live performances from a 1983 Public Theater concert by Mr. Lacy's sextet. The 50-minute film will have its world premiere today at the Bleecker Street Theater, 144 Bleecker Street, as part of the Village Jazz Festival film series.

title: JAMESWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: Sales figures do not include sales by leased departments of $4,609,000 in the latest quarter, $4,763,000 in the year-ago quarter, $8,929,000 in the latest 6 months and $8,054,000 in the year-ago 6 months.

title: BUDD SETS 5,000 METER RECORD
description: Zola Budd sliced more than 10 seconds off the women's world record for 5,000 meters today after secretly entering the meet to avoid possible anti-apartheid protests.

title: ROSS, A J, LOGISTICS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: Year-ago results were not available because the company went public on July 12.

title:
EDUCATION;

COURSES ON ENTREPRENEURSHIP
description: IN Kansas, back in 1958, two young brothers attending Wichita State University opened the first fast-food Pizza Hut and met with enormous success: They eventually managed to sell enough pizzas, mushrooms and pepperoni to become a $1.8 billion-a-year franchise operation, with outlets situated throughout the United States as well as in Hong Kong, Kuwait, Britain and Spain.

title: REPORT SAYS ELI LILLY FAILED TO TELL OF 28 DEATHS
description: American officials of Eli Lilly & Company had reports that at least 28 deaths overseas were linked to the arthritis drug Oraflex, but did not disclose them while seeking Government approval to sell the drug, according to a Justice Department report.

title: FOOTWEAR RESPONSE PREPARED
description: The American shoe industry is withholding comment on President Reagan's expected rejection of import quotas or tariffs while its trade association and Washington lobbyists work out a response and strategy.

title: Coors Sets Announcement
description: The Adolph Coors Company said yesterday that it would make a major announcement tomorrow concerning the brewer's ''long-range plans and strategies.'' The company would not comment further.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A STILLNESS HEARD ROUND THE WORLD. The End of the Great War:

title: RUTH L. BELSKY
description: Ruth L. Belsky, a founding member of the Lincoln Square Synagogue in Manhattan and a Bronx County Democratic committeewoman for many years, died of a stroke at the Jewish Home and Hospital in Manhattan Friday. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Evening News Case Reversal
description: A Federal appeals court today overturned a lower court decision that allowed state regulators to delay an attempt by two television producers to buy the Evening News Association for $566 million.

title: SECTION 301 IS POLISHED AS U.S. TRADE WEAPON
description: The Administration's emerging new trade strategy, defusing protectionism at home by putting pressure on foreign governments to open their markets, turns on a provision of United States trade law that permits the Government itself to file an unfair-trade complaint.

title: ROCKLAND JURY SELECTION
description: Jury selection began today in the trial of a man accused of slaying a Norwegian fashion student earlier this year. The defendant, Bernard LeGeros, 23 years old, of Manhattan, is charged in the Feb. 23 shooting of Eigil Dag Vesti, 26, a student at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

title: DANCE: DAVID PARSONS
description: DAVID PARSONS' dances are bright, likable and accomplished. Being a leading dancer with the Paul Taylor Dance Company, as Mr. Parsons is, doesn't hurt. And Mr. Taylor's influence was evident in the gutsy movement style and the zany and mordant humor that characterized a program of new and recent works presented by Mr. Parsons on Sunday evening at the Bessie Schonberg Theater, 219 West 19th Street. But Mr. Parsons is clearly a promising choreographer - and also a disturbing one.

title: A Change In Outdoor Ad Buying
description: THE outdoor advertising industry has come a long way since the days when its marketing efforts were limited to ''Your message here'' signs posted in the middle of blank billboards.

title: Chip Producer
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation predicted pretax and net losses for the first quarter of its fiscal year 1986 and said it expects losses to continue ''until there is a significant and sustained improvement in its components segment.'' In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, National Semiconductor said it had net sales of $175.7 million for the period from June 1 to July 28, and a net loss for the period of $44.3 million. The company made the disclosures in connection with a planned public offering of $100 milion in depositary preferred stock.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
BONDS STEADY IN SLOW VOLUME
description: Bond prices were little changed in very light trading yesterday.

title: Ceramics Engineers In Demand
description: STEADY, although not booming, growth lies ahead for the ceramics industry, according to Rustum Roy, a Pennsylvania State University professor who specializes in ceramics. There is much faster growth, however, in the demand for ceramics engineers.

title: PSYCHIC LAB TO CLOSE
description: The McDonnell Laboratory for Psychical Research, established six years ago to provide facilities for scientists to try to detect and study such parapsychological phenomena as extrasensory perception, mind control over inanimate objects and prediction of the future, will close Aug. 31 for lack of continued financing.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid August 20.

title: TELESPHERE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
A Fair Trial Issue
description: An effort has been mounted in Congress and by human rights activists to assure a fair trial for Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf, a Citibank executive and Liberian opposition party leader who went on trial last week in Liberia on sedition charges.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
House Sales Gain 1.6%
description: Sales of existing homes rose 1.6 percent in July from the previous month as a continuing fall in mortgage rates increased sales to their highest level in almost five years, a real estate trade group said today.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Dismissed Eddie Haas, manager.

title: TACO VIVA INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 26
description: b-After a loss of $21,437 for the quarter and income of $15,981 for the year from discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $9,566 for the quarter and $95,512 for the year. d-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: G & K SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect s 3-for-2 stock split effected December 3, 1984 and a 10 percent dividend on Class A Common Stock paid July 5, 1985 to holders of record on June 14, 1985.

title: GIANTS' TRIMS DIFFICULT
description: For the second consecutive season, the Giants, instead of having to make do with adequate talent, face the task of finding ways to trim a roster filled with good players.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: SHUTTLE CREW SET YET AGAIN FOR LIFTOFF
description: The space shuttle Discovery and its crew of five astronauts are ready to try again Tuesday morning to begin their planned eight-day mission. But approaching storms threatened them with another postponement.

title: SEGREGATED SOUTH AFRICA: CHANGES HAVE BEEN FEW
description: Although some forms of racial segregation have been eased in South Africa, as President Reagan noted in an interview made public today, there is still widespread segregation in many areas, enforced by law.

title: ARAB TROUPE APPLAUDED BY ISRAELI THEATERGOERS
description: The site is a mental hospital. The patient is a Palestinian from the Galilee named Ali, who went to work in Tel Aviv and adopted the Hebrew name Eli. He is bilingual and suffers from an identity crisis. Ali-Eli sits confined in a straitjacket and watches the story of his life played before him.

title: A DRAMATIC MOMENT IN EFFORT TO SAVE THE BIGHORN SHEEP
description: AN old saying among wildlife experts, that a sick bighorn is dead bighorn, was proved wrong recently when D-Day, a 3-year-old bighorn sheep, was returned to the wild.

title: Hispanic Supplement
description: Beginning Sept. 8, The Dallas Morning News will distribute a 16-page, four-color national newspaper supplement for Hispanic readers. Called Vista, the magazine will be included in the Sunday editions of the paper. It will be written in English and will feature Hispanic personalities and activities.

title: SCIENTIFIC COMPUTERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Buyout Talk And Rorer
description: WHEN the Rorer Group adopted anti-takeover measures earlier this year, the Fort Washington, Pa., drug and medical product manufacturer probably thought the buyout rumors that had dogged it for years would ease. It was wrong.

title: COMPENSATION IN JAPAN AIR CRASH IS LIKELY TO EXCEED $100 MILLION
description: Besides being the worst single-plane catastrophe in aviation history, the crash of a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet two weeks ago is likely to become one of the most expensive disasters as well.

title: $535.1 Million of Bonds Are Offered by Dallas
description: The City of Dallas is offering $535.1 million of general obligation refunding bonds tentatively priced through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: AMPUTEE DENIED MEDICAID
description: A 70-year-old amputee was declared ineligible to receive Medicaid assistance for an electric bed and other equipment after news reports of her graduation with her daughter and granddaughter from a high school here. The amputee, Mildred Macturk, who lost most of her left leg almost three years ago, said that Medicaid had paid for the rental of the equipment since March 1982. However, six days after the graduation, Medicaid denied the funds to buy the equipment.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS SUPPORT FOR TUNISIA AS TENSIONS ON LIBYAN BORDER RISE
description: The United States today affirmed its support for Tunisia's security, amid a sharp rise in tension between that North African country and neighboring Libya.

title: DON'T TAMPER WITH A GOOD THING
description: Another August in Saratoga is over. The horses and horseplayers are on their way back to Belmont Park, the tourists who have gladly paid $20 for T-shirts and phony Indian artifacts are but a sugar-plum memory to the merchants, and the townfolk have reoccupied their homes, the August rentals having paid the mortgage for another year.

title: Oil Stockpile In Venezuela
description: Venezuela has amassed a stockpile of 90 million barrels of oil, reflecting a steep decline in exports, the Caracas newspaper El Nacional reported today in an article that quoted unidentified sources in the Government-owned petroleum industry.

title: HUGE PRODUCTION OF ANTIMATTER PLANNED
description: WORKING round the clock under an Illinois prairie, physicists are preparing to switch on the world's largest factory for the production of antimatter, the rare and baffling particles that exist as shadowy mirror-images of all the subatomic particles in the universe.

title: India Increases Security In Punjab After Killings
description: Security was further tightened in the Punjab today after Sikh gunmen shot and killed two Hindus in the first slayings since a moderate Sikh leader was killed last week by Sikh extremists.

title: CARLSBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $910,000 for the quarter and $2,049,000 for the year and a writedown on certain construction projects of $1,647,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,345,000 for the quarter and $1,985,000 for the year.

title: Dunes Subsidiary
description: Dunes Hotels and Casinos Inc. said that its subsidiary, M & R Investments Inc., had not made a $527,000 monthly interest payment on a $68.6 million loan from Valley Bank of Nevada.

title: EX-REP. CHARLES SANDMAN. NIXON SUPPORTER, DIES
description: Charles W. Sandman, a New Jersey Superior Court judge and former United States Representative who was one of President Richard M. Nixon's strongest supporters during Congressional impeachment hearings in 1974, died Monday at Burdette Tomlin Memorial Hospital in Cape May Court House, N.J., after suffering a stroke Aug. 18.

title: Torstar and Southam in Stock Deal
description: Two of Canada's biggest publishing companies, the Torstar Corporation and Southam Inc., announced a stock swap today and said they planned to combine forces on some fronts.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: McCann-Erickson Creates Ads for Pace
description: McCann-Erickson has created six 60-second radio commercials for Pace University in New York.

title: RADIATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
People Parody Planned
description: TSM Publishing plans a parody of People magazine for national distribution at Halloween.

title: BECKER IS RIDING MOMENTUM
description: The limousine was double-parked in front of the University Club in Manhattan, waiting to whisk Martina Navratilova to the next stop on her Monday morning business trip. On the day before the start of the United States Open, the thoroughly modern tennis player had appointments to keep before heading to the National Tennis Center, where she planned to brush up on her game in preparation for defending the singles championship she has won two years in a row.

title: CHAMPIONS
description: Never mind about the Yankees and the Mets, the Giants and the Jets. New York already has a champion in the under-16 team from the Blau-Weiss Gottschee soccer club of Ridgewood, Queens, which triumphed little more than a week ago at the national tournament in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: Dr. George Stroll Dies at 86; Physician on Shelter Island
description: Dr. George M. Stroll, a general practitioner for more than 50 years and the only physician on Shelter Island, N.Y., before his retirement three years ago, died Saturday night at Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport, L.I. He was 86 years old and a resident of Shelter Island.

title: ARTISTS' AGENT IS FOUND SLAIN ON W. 24TH ST.
description: A vice president of an artists management company was found stabbed to death yesterday morning in his ransacked apartment in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, the police said. Detectives said he had apparently been killed during a robbery attempt.

title: MEXICO SEEN NEEDING $2 BILLION OF NEW LOANS
description: Mexico, about to reschedule payment of much of its existing foreign debt, will probably need $2 billion to $3 billion in new loans next year to help close the gap in its finances, according to its chief debt negotiator.

title: JETS' SHIELDS TRIES TO TACKLE PROBLEM
description: It didn't make any sense to Billy Shields, who has been a professional offensive lineman since 1975. He was forgetting what he was supposed to do.

title: BORDER INCIDENTS STRAIN COSTA RICA-NICARGUA TIES
description: A series of border incidents in recent weeks has added to the already growing tensions between this country and its neighbor to the north, Nicaragua.

title: CHILDREN OF MIGRANT WORKERS INSPIRED BY SUMMER STUDIES
description: For the last 10 years, Alta Rodriguez, 17 years old, has spent her summers laboring in California's grape fields.

title: WITHHOLDING JUDGMENT
description: Bob Feller, now 66 years old, remains acutely sensitive of his own place in baseball's history books. He also finds a lot wrong with the way things are today, and he seems not at all inclined to offer thoroughly ungrudging praise, even to Dwight Gooden.

title: STANDARD LOGIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 2
description: b-Including tax credits of $19,200, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $112,700, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months.c-Net loss.

title: SUPERMARKETS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: Results include the operations of Purity Supreme Corp. which was acquired on August 8, 1984 and accounted for as a purchase.

title: A Tale of Three Great Communicators
description: To hear Mark Fowler, David Markey and Diana Dougan talk about American telecommunications policy is to hear nearly harmonious chants advocating deregulation of the industry at home and aggressive export of American telecommunications technology abroad as a key tool for economic trade.

title: Dow Slips by 0.67 in Slow Trading
description: The stock market continued its up-again, down-again pattern yesterday to close slightly lower in one its slowest days of the year.

title: AUDIOTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Minute Maid Orange Soda
description: The Coca-Cola Company yesterday introduced yet another soft drink. This time, however, the product will not fall under the Coca-Cola brand name, which has gotten more than its share of marketing attention this year.

title: AUTOMATED SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ALLY & GARGANO INC reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: b-Including the net effect of $405,000, or 18 cents a share, related to a bad debt writeoff. c-Net loss. Revenue figures represent gross billings. Corrected from Friday's editions.

title: Ford May Increase Production Abroad
description: The Ford Motor Company is prepared to move production of some large-car engines abroad, possibly to Mexico, should the Federal Government refuse to relax fuel-economy laws for the next three years, a top company official said today.

title: 9.57% Yield Set In Alaska Housing
description: The Alaska Housing Finance Corporation is offering $100 million of collateralized home mortgage bonds through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers.

title: TURN THE PAGE
description: Sports fans who are not heading to the stadiums or sprawling in front of the set these days have every opportunity to curl up with a good book, or at least a successful book. For the last two weeks, 6 of the 15 titles on the best-seller list compiled by The New York Times have been sports-related. They are: ''The Mick,'' Mickey Mantle's autobiography, No. 5 this week; ''Confessions of a Hooker,'' Bob Hope's reflections on golf, No. 6; ''Martina,'' the autobiography of Martina Navratilova, No. 7; ''The Amateurs,'' David Halberstam's account of the effort by four American men to win an Olympic sculling championship, No. 9; ''The Grasshopper Trap,'' Patrick F. McManus's amusing work about the outdoors, No. 12, and ''The Dangerous Summer,'' by Ernest Hemingway, an account of the Spanish bullfighting season of 1959, No. 13.

title: GLEMP WARNS GOVERNMENT AGAINST CONFRONTATION
description: In one of his strongest defenses of Roman Catholic values here, Josef Cardinal Glemp, the Polish primate, said today that believers would not support the Government unless it stopped propagating atheistic values.

title: FOR A CITY OPERA TENOR, A GOOD YEAR
description: ''Where I was raised,'' says Jerry Hadley, the trim and boyish Chevalier Des Grieux of the New York City Opera's current ''Manon'' revival, ''we had breakfast steaks, meaty sandwiches for lunch and a big hunk of meat for dinner. When you get past 30, you find that you can't partake with such impunity as you used to.''

title: TUTU'S SON ARRESTED IN SOWETO COURT
description: The son of Bishop Desmond M. Tutu, winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, was detained today under this nation's sweeping emergency powers after he purportedly made insulting remarks to authorities.

title: Sun Finance Unit
description: The McDonnell Douglas Finance Corporation has bought the finance subsidiary of the Sun Electric Corporation for $40 million and has agreed to provide financial services for Sun for five years, Sun said today.

title: Where Harmony Reigns
description: ''Every third person you meet on the street in Washington is a chorale conductor,'' said Paul Hill, who conducts the Paul Hill Chorale, a 165-voice amateur ensemble, in Washington.

title: POTTER IMPRESSIVE IN DEFEATING KELESI
description: Barbara Potter, competing in her first tournament in six weeks, unleashed her strong serve and capitalized on the nervous play of upstart Helen Kelesi to rally for a 4-6, 6-3, 6-2 victory and the singles title of the first Virginia Slims of Central New York Women's Tennis Tournament.

title: EMOTIONAL SUPPORT HAS ITS DESTRUCTIVE SIDE
description: Psychologists are drawing a picture of the emotional support offered by friends and family that affirms its value but points up the resentment and harm that well-meaning gestures can foster.

title: SORTING OUT CONFUSION IN PRINTERS
description: HOW does one choose the right printer when there are literally scores of new models being introduced each year?

title: SUMMER SCHOOL: FRISBEES AND FUNDAMENTALS
description: The catalogues were very crisp. The summer courses they described beckoned like Persian miniatures, each a tiny world of potential knowledge, color and adventure. Summer school - and in Boston, yet. The perfect polis of the higher learning. The longest lawn of Frisbee, and the fundamentals. A city whose bridges lead to institutes with domes and whose transit lines are named for colleges.

title: RUBELL WINS
description: Jason Rubell of New York defeated Valentine Stoyana, a former Rumanian Davis Cup player, 7-5, 6-0, to win the Shearson Lehman Brothers Eastern Clay Court Championship today at the Old Field Racquet Club.

title: CELTICS' CARR RETIRES
description: M. L. Carr, the 34-year-old Boston Celtic forward, announced his retirement last night after nine seasons in the National Basketball Association.

title: WHITTAKER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Eat on the Street? How Pedestrian
description: Jeffrey Marcus is a lawyer. He wears a gray suit, single vent. His glasses are pale tortoise shell. His shoes are black loafers. But in this city where people seem to strive for comformity, Mr. Marcus is something of an anomaly. He's got a rivulet of relish on his chin. ''That's the tradeoff when you lunch from the vendors - you eat fast and cheap but every so often you miss your mouth,'' Mr. Marcus said, plucking a cloth handkerchief from his pocket and dabbing away the evidence of his lunch-on-the-run.

title: INNOVATIVE SOFTWARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Trafalgar Has Minebea Option
description: Trafalgar Holdings Ltd., the investment company headed by Charles W. Knapp, said it had acquired an option from a London-based concern to buy a 23 percent stake in the Minebea Company, a Japanese manufacturer. In a rare situation in Japanese business, Minebea is embroiled in a corporate takeover attempt.

title: RESPONDING TO RUMORS OF DEPARTURE
description: Fifty police sergeants became lieutenants yesterday, but the question on many minds was whether someone new was about to become Police Commissioner.

title: ERNST, E C INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ON EVE OF NEW SEASON, NBC AIMS FOR TOP SPOT SER
description: Television's ground rules set the last week in September as the beginning of the 38th year of competition among the three networks, but the ratings war of autumn has already begun: Madison Avenue is second-guessing the networks' new lineups, viewers are being courted on the air and the replacements are already being readied.

title: OFF THE FIELD, BUTTLE REMAINS DEFIANT
description: Defiant. It remains Greg Buttle's attitude, even without a job in football. When a player -especially a veteran - gets cut from a football team he has questions about himself and his future and his ability. ''I didn't feel diminished at all,'' Buttle said yesterday. ''I said to myself, 'Well, there's another mistake.' ''

title: NIAGARA MOHAWK POWER CORP reports earnings for Yr to July 31
NEW ORLEANS SEEKS FRANCHISE
description: Governor Edwin Edwards of Louisiana and New Orleans Mayor Ernest Morial said today they were courting potential owners for a major league baseball franchise in New Orleans.

title: 3 IN MAYORAL RACE CALL MASS TRANSIT A KEY ISSUE, BUT DIFFER ON REMEDIES
description: The three major candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination agree that the most pressing transportation issue facing New York City is the improvement of mass transit.

title: U.S. WARNED CONGRESS OF G.I. ROLE IN NICARAGUA
description: The Reagan Administration, as part of its effort to persuade Congress to renew aid to anti-Sandinista rebels, argued that continued financing of the guerrilla force was necessary to avoid the risk of sending American troops to Nicaragua, according to testimony recently made public.

title: To Err in Humanities
description: Probably no publication has readers more finicky than does Humanities, the official publication of the National Endowment for the Humanities. An error is not likely to escape the attention of the professors, historians and linguists who make up much of the publication's readership, so it was not surprising that the current issue carries a rather arcane correction.

title: Uganda Rebels in Talks With Government
description: Uganda's military rulers met today with the country's main guerrilla organization in an effort to end a four-year-old insurgency.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: Yvon Joseph, the former Georgia Tech center chosen in the second round in the National Basketball Association draft by the Nets, signed a $200,000 contract to play in Spain, his lawyer, Richard Howell, said. . . . The veteran goalie Hubert Birkenmeier was signed to two one-year contracts Monday by the Chicago Sting of the Major Indoor Soccer League. . . . John Battle, a guard from Rutgers, signed a multiyear contract with the Atlanta Hawks. . . . Tom Byers, who won in 1982, and Ray Flynn, the Irish mile record holder, have entered the fifth annual Fifth Avenue Mile, to be run Sept. 28.

title: Ethiopian Rebels Win Clash
description: Eritrean rebels said today that they had killed or wounded more than 1,500 Ethiopian Government soldiers and shot down a MIG fighter plane in heavy fighting last week.

title: APOGEE ROBOTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
'OUR CHILDREN'S WAR'
description: ''OUR CHILDREN'S WAR'' is an example of a vanishing species - the half-hour, public-service documentary. Even public television seldom does programs like this anymore, and it's a pity because it is possible to do a half-hour documentary that looks good and also has something to say. ''Our Children's War,'' on Channel 5 at 8:30 P.M., is a proper example.

title: ADVANCED GENETIC SCIENCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $393,077 associated with the shutdown of a facility.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a reduction of $810,000 of tax provision for reversal of deferred taxes.

title: CARDS' STREAK AT 6 AS COX HALTS REDS
description: Danny Cox continued his season-long mastery of the Cincinnati Reds tonight, tossing a six-hitter as the St. Louis Cardinals won, 3-0, for their sixth victory in a row.

title: Fighting in Afghanistan Said to Increase
description: Western diplomats here said today that Islamic guerrillas and Soviet soldiers were engaged in heavy new fighting in eastern Afghanistan and that Soviet reinforcements were being poured into the area.

title: Leo Mattersdorf, 81, Author And Tax Consultant, Is Dead
description: Leo Mattersdorf, an accountant and tax consultant, died Friday at the John T. Mather Memorial Hospital in Port Jefferson, L.I. He was 81 years old and lived in Coram, L.I.

title: Mental Patient Killed As Hostage Is Freed
description: State troopers stormed through a door in a maximum-security mental hospital today and killed one of the two patients who had held a woman hostage for 17 hours.

title: 4 CANDIDATES TO LEAD COUNCIL SEEK TO REMAIN ON THE BALLOT
description: Four Democratic candidates for New York City Council president asked the state's highest court today to keep them on the ballot for the Sept. 10 Democratic primary.

title: U.S. TEAM TO LOOK AT CHEMICAL IN SOVIET
description: The State Department said today that it planned to send medical investigators to Moscow on Tuesday to determine the health risk posed by a chemical agent purportedly used to keep track of American residents in the Soviet Union.

title: Federated Stores
description: One of the nation's largest department store chains has agreed to tell consumers when their credit applications are rejected because of information obtained from a credit reporting agency, the Federal Trade Commission said today. The agreement covers Federated Department Stores Inc., based in Cincinnati, which operates more than 590 stores under a variety of names, including Bloomingdale's, Filene's, Foley's, I. Magnin, Burdines, Abraham & Straus, Bullock's and Sanger Harris.

title: NATHAN K. GROSS
description: Nathan K. Gross, the board chairman of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America, died of cancer Aug. 20 at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: COLUMBUS'S LOST TOWN: NEW EVIDENCE IS FOUND
description: ON the night before Christmas in 1492, the flagship of Christopher Columbus, the Santa Maria, ran aground on a reef off the North Coast of Hispaniola and was wrecked beyond repair. Accepting the hospitality of an Arawak chief, the men stripped timbers from the abandoned ship and erected a fortified settlement at an Indian town. Columbus named the place La Navidad.

title: METS STOPPED BY VALENZUELA
description: It might be said that even teams of destiny have to endure evenings like this one, long, humid, frustrating ones that take the punch out of a pennant drive.

title: OF POPCORN, LONELINESS AND VCR'S
description: After several years of enjoying the status of being a high-tech toy for the rich, a thinking man's answer to television and a home appliance whose importance is surpassed only by the refrigerator, the video-cassette recorder is finally vulnerable to complaints.

title: Documents in Agent's Home
description: Richard W. Miller had secret documents in his bedroom dresser the week before he became the only F.B.I. agent ever charged with espionage, prosecutors said today.

title: RESHAPING OF MESA IS PLANNED
description: T. Boone Pickens, the chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, saying that he was temporarily out of the takeover business, announced a major reorganization of the company yesterday. He said he would reshape the organization into a limited partnership to ''maximize values to shareholders.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: REEL WORLD STRING BAND The Reel World String Band has been described as ideal for dancing and just generally letting loose the spirit. There isn't room for dancing at the intimate, funky Folk City. But spirits are likely to be flying and feet to be stomping when this old-time Appalachian band performs there tonight at 8:30 and 10:30, if Reel World's appearance this summer at the Clearwater Revival is any guide.

title: SOVIET LIQUOR PRICES UP IN DRIVE ON ALCOHOLISM
description: The Soviet Union sharply raised prices today on liquor, beer and champagne, bringing the price of the cheapest brand of vodka to 6.20 rubles a half-liter, or $8 a pint.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: People
description: Raymond Dutch has joined Klemtner Advertising, a subsidiary of Saatchi & Saatchi Compton, as senior vice president and creative director.

title: ANGELES CORP reports earnings for Yr to June 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $2,129,000, or 71 cents a share.

title: WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HOW HEALTHY ARE THE OLDEST OLD?
description: MORE than 2.6 million Americans are now 85 years old or older. Often called the ''oldest old,'' they are the fastest growing segment of the population. By the year 2000 this group will increase to 5 million, and by 2040 to more than 13 million.

title: Dean Witter Strategist To Form New Concern
description: Robert H. Stovall, who for the last 16 years has been a leading investment strategist and stock picker for Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., will leave that firm this fall to help form a new investment advisory concern.

title: MURRAY SLAMS ANGELS
description: Eddie Murray ripped three home runs and drove in nine runs tonight, powering the Baltimore Orioles to a 17-3 rout of the California Angels.

title: TVI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Rider in Bed Race Injured
description: A 38-year-old woman riding a bed on wheels as part of a charity fund-raising event was seriously injured Sunday when the bed hit a light pole and she struck her head, the police said today. The victim, Carolyn Pike of Annapolis, was undergoing tests at the Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. The police said she appeared to be paralyzed immediately after the accident in the bed race.

title: U.S. GRUOP AIDING REBELS MAY HAVE BROKEN, TAX-EXEMPTION PLEDGE
description: A leading group raising money for Nicaraguan rebels obtained Federal tax-exempt status three years ago after pledging never to provide ''materiel or funds'' to insurgents, according to Internal Revenue Service documents.

title: BRAVES DISMISS HAAS
description: The orders came down this morning from Ted Turner, the Atlanta Braves' owner, who was distressed by the team's six-game losing streak and its fifth-place position in the National League West. Manager Eddie Haas was dismissed and replaced for the rest of the season with Bobby Wine, the third-base coach.

title: WHEN DREAMS ARE IMMUNE TO THE ODDS
description: FOR hours on end last week New Yorkers waited in those lottery lines, pulses quickened by hope, minds purged of logical perspective, hearts lusting for that big gold ring.

title: U.N. WILL LOSE SOME SMOKE-FILLED ROOMS
description: The smoke has not cleared entirely at United Nations headquarters, but it has been lifted somewhat.

title: Fremont General
description: The Fremont General Corporation said that it had stopped writing its general property and casualty insurance. The company said that in 1984 the line contributed 13 percent of its premium income and had 23 percent of the underwriting losses, while in the first half of 1985 it contributed about 15 percent of premiums and had 30 percent of underwriting losses. The company said that it would also limit its exposure on new and existing reinsurance business but would continue to write workers' compensation and malpractice policies.

title: E.E.C. Jobless Rate Up
description: The July unemployment rate in Common Market countries, excluding Greece, was an unadjusted 11 percent, up from a seasonally adjusted 10.8 percent in June and 10.6 percent in July 1984, officials said today. On July 31, 12.4 million people were unemployed, compared with 12.2 million in June and 12 million in July 1984, according to Eurostat, the Common Market's statistical service.

title: EDWIN DROOD'S TO OPEN ON BROADWAY DEC. 2
description: ''The Mystery of Edwin Drood,'' the new musical by Rupert Holmes playing through Sunday at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park, will move to Broadway in November with an opening scheduled for Dec. 2, according to Richard Kornberg, a a spokesman for Joseph Papp of the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, producer of the show.

title: TELEPHONE HELP FOR LEARNING-DISABLED
description: School days are nearly here again, which marks a time of tension for thousands of learning-disabled youngsters and their parents.

title: HYDE ATHLETIC INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK HOSPITAL AND 4 DOCTORS ARE SUED IN DEATH OF PATIENT, 18
description: A civil suit charges New York Hospital and four doctors with negligence in the death last year of an 18-year-old college student.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Mets vs. Los Angeles Dodgers, at Shea Stadium. 7:35 P.M. Final game of a two-game series. The Mets then travel to the West Coast and begin a four-game series in San Francisco on Thursday.

title: The Expansion Of Fraud Law
description: ONE of the bedrock notions of Anglo-American jurisprudence is that no one should be prosecuted for an act unless it has been clearly defined as a crime. In the E. F. Hutton bank fraud case, for example, one of the reasons Federal prosecutors gave for not bringing criminal charges against Hutton officials was a lack of legal precedent that overdrafting was illegal.

title: Tax-Free Issue A Con Ed First
description: A $256 million issue of 35-year tax-exempt bonds for the Consolidated Edison Company was tentatively offered yesterday at a price of 100 with a 9 percent coupon through Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: RIDERS GROUP CITES SMALL GAINS FOR SUBWAYS
description: A subway riders group released a survey yesterday that concluded subway service had shown some improvement in the year since David L. Gunn took over management of the Transit Authority but on average was no better.

title: CALIFORNIAN, 16, IS VICTORIOUS IN U.S. JUNIOR OPEN TOURNEY
description: Sixteen-year-old Adam Lief of Los Alamitos, Calif., scored a perfect 8-0 in winning the annual United States Junior Open Championship, which was held at the Student Union of the University of California at Berkeley.

title: PANEL DENIES SHOREHAM LICENSE
description: A Federal panel today said the Long Island Lighting Company's evacuation plan for its Shoreham nuclear plant was unworkable because of the failure of New York State and Suffolk County to participate, and it refused to order the issuance of an operating license for the plant.

title: SMID, FIBAK LOSE IN DOUBLES
description: Heinz Gunthardt of Switzerland and Balazs Taroczy of Hungary defeated Tomas Smid of Czechoslovakia and Wojtek Fibak of Poland, 6-4, 6-1, today in the doubles final of the $150,000 Executone Hamlet Challenge Cup tennis tournament. The match had been put off Sunday because of rain.

title: IBI SECURITY SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago figures have been restated to reflect a year-end adjustment of $195,000, or $48,750 per quarter.

title: ESTERLINE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $266,000 for the quarter and $933,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income. Year-ago results are restated.

title: Australian Beats Biondi and Gross
description: Jon Sieben of Australia won a battle among three of the world's top male swimmers today, winning the 100-meter butterfly at the 1985 World University Games by 0.06 seconds.

title: FOREST CITY ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
JUDGE, ORDERING TEAMSTER RETRIAL, QUESTIONS INQUIRY INVOLVING CHIEF
description: A Federal district judge today granted a new trial to a former teamster official and questioned the handling of the investigation, whose central figure is Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Buick Sales Goal
description: The Buick Motor division of the General Motors Corporation said that it plans to sell more than one million cars in the 1986 model year.

title: THIRD ACQUISITION IN MARYLAND IS SEEN FOR CHASE
description: Chase Manhattan Bank is close to reaching an agreement to buy a Maryland thrift institution that has been unable to qualify for Federal deposit insurance, banking sources said today.

title: U.S. WOMEN WIN IN CYCLING
description: Rebecca Twigg won the world title in the women's 3,000-meter individual pursuit tonight to give the United States its first gold medal in the track cycling championships in this north Italian town.

title: REAGAN MOVE DUE ON ON CITIES' OVERTIME PAY RULING
description: President Reagan will decide next week whether to endorse legislation to reverse a Supreme Court decision that required state and local governments to adhere to Federal wage and hour laws, a White House aide said today.

title: RUSTY PELICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
ACTION INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: Year-ago results include operations of Sabin Industries Inc. which was acquired in October 1983. Results for the latest quarter are after losses of 25 cents a share from the company's previously reported decision to discontinue its television promotion program.

title: DO PRIVATE FUNDS HARM PUBLIC SERVICE GOALS?
description: WHEN about 300 representatives of trusts and foundations created by Andrew Carnegie met here this month, much of the talk was about Carnegie's crucial role in placing philanthropy at the service of education and peace. The two causes became almost an obsession in the mind of the steel magnate, who to many is known mainly as a ruthless robber baron.

title: Georgia Agency's 10 1/2% Bond Issue
description: The Monroe County Development Authority in Georgia is offering $200 million of 10 1/2 percent pollution control revenue bonds due in 2020 and tentatively priced at par through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company.

title: Record Output Of Japan Cars
description: Japan's production of cars, trucks and buses climbed to a record high in July, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said today.

title: FIRST COINVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Sugar Program Feels Pressure
description: Sugar prices are so low that some large processors may forfeit millions of pounds to the Government instead of repaying Federal price support loans taken out on 1984 crop inventories, Agriculture Department officials said today.

title: Transway Stake To Goldman, Sachs
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company said today that it had bought a 5 percent stake in the Transway International Corporporation. Its filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission indicated that the New York investment firm was apparently hoping to benefit from increased bidding for the transportation company, which is based in White Plains.

title: ATLAS CONSOLIDATED MINING AND DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results for the latest periods were converted from Philippine pesos at the rate of 18.1823 pesos to the U.S. dollar for the quarter and 18.3013 pesos to the U.S. dollar for the 6 months. Results for the year-ago periods were converted from Philippinine pesos at the rate of 15.1353 pesos to the U.S. dollar for the quarter and 14.5687 pesos to the U.S. dollar for the 6 months.

title: NATIONAL COMPUTER SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FOR CUBA'S RADIO MARTI FANS, IT'S SOAP OPERA, NOT SOAPBOX
description: Mention the name Esmeralda to many people in Havana these days and you're likely to get a smile and a conspiratorial wink.

title: BLOCK, H R INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $3,036,000. c-Including a tax credit of $3,783,000.

title: Sri Lanka Soldiers Kill 10 Tamil Guerrillas C
description: Government security forces said today that they had killed 10 Tamil separatist guerrillas in a jungle battle in eastern Sri Lanka.

title: QUEBEC'S FAR NORTH: LAND OF THE BROKEN PROMISE?
description: When 10,000 caribou drowned trying to ford the swollen Caniapiscau River last September, the loss amounted to two years' supply of meat for the inhabitants of northern Quebec.

title: NOW, MIX VOLATILE CHEMICALS WITHOUT A BOOM
description: FOR all that's been gained by modern youth electronically - boom boxes, VCR's, video games, home computers - a lot has also been lost over the past couple of decades.

title: SLOAN TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SAY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 1
description: b-Including tax credits of $7,000 for the quarter and $80,000 for the year.

title: PHH GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FRANK PAXTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,304,000 on the sale of a division.

title: ELECTRO-NUCLEONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $161,000.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 27, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee for the 40th Anniversary of the U.N. - 3 P.M.

title: VIACOM AGREES TO CABLE DEAL
description: Viacom International Inc. agreed yesterday to buy all of Music Television Networks Inc. and the half interest that Viacom does not already own in Showtime/The Movie Channel Inc.

title: RYMER COMPANY reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: Beginning this year the company adopted a 13 week quarterly earnings format. In 1984 the first three quarters were 12 weeks each while the fourth was 16 weeks.

title: FAMILY STYLE WINS IN SPINAWAY STAKES
description: Family Style won the Spinaway Stakes for 2-year-old fillies today and gave her trainer, D. Wayne Lukas, a record eighth stakes victory here as Saratoga Race Track closed a 24-day meeting that was the most successful in its history.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Barco of California, Gardena, Calif., which makes career apparel, has named Lawrence J. Grill chief operating officer, succeeding Brian Kinahan.

title: KOCH MAKING DETERMINED BID FOR BLACK VOTES
description: For the first time in his political career, Mayor Koch is leading a pointed campaign for the votes of those New Yorkers with whom he has traditionally been weakest - the black electorate.

title: DEAN SIGNS CURBS ON PRETORIA TIES
description: Governor Kean today signed legislation requiring New Jersey to sell about $2 billion in pension-fund investments in companies with ties to South Africa.

title: APPEALS RULING ON 3 MILE ISLAND CLEARS A RESTART
description: A Federal appeals panel today denied petitions to block the restart of the undamaged Three Mile Island nuclear reactor and refused to order more Federal hearings on whether the unit could be operated safely.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Atlanta Braves vs. Pittsburgh Pirates, at Atlanta, 5:40 P.M. (Television -WTBS, 5:35 P.M.) Golf United States Amateur, at Montclair Golf Club, West Orange, N.J. Second day of medal qualifying.

title: CITY CRIME RATE DOWN 3 PERCEDNT FROM YEAR AGO
description: The total number of major crimes reported in New York City fell 3.6 percent during the first six months of this year, compared with the same period last year, the Police Department said yesterday.

title: Brazil Names Bank Chief
description: Dilson Funaro, who was sworn in as Brazil's Finance Minister today, named Fernao Bracher, vice president of the Bradesco Group, as the new central bank president.

title: A Shift at N.L.R.B.
description: Jim Stevens, the counsel for the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee, is expected to be named a member of the National Labor Relations Board, according to Congressional and Labor Department officials. Mr. Stevens would succeed Robert P. Hunter, the senior member of the board, who will leave the agency this month.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Released Dave Finzer, punter; Donald Jordan, running back; Tom Andrews, offensive tackle; Jack Cameron, wide receiver; Charles Bennett, defensive end; Mike Stoops, defensive back; Tom Andrews, offensive tackle; Joe Spivak, guard; Brent Duhon, wide receiver; Don Kindt, tight end, and Jeff Kacmarek, defensive tackle.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug. 10
description: Per-share figures reflects 2-for-1 stock split paid May 10.

title: STATEMENT BY WEINBERGER
description: Following is the text of the announcement by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger on his decision to stop buying the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun:

title: AFTER 11 YEARS AS PLAYER, CONDON EYES NEW CAREER
description: When the mud was flying and the bitterness was rampant before and during the 1982 players' strike, Tom Condon of the Kansas City Chiefs was always a voice of reason and restraint.

title: Argentine Debt Accord Signed
description: Argentina and its creditor banks, as expected, signed an agreement yesterday to reschedule part of Argentina's foreign debt and provide it with $4.2 billion of new loans. The signing, however, was delayed almost six hours by a last-minute hitch, which both sides attributed to ''technical reasons.''

title: People
description: Donald Blauweiss has joined Saatchi & Saatchi Compton as senior vice president, creative director.

title: SPY SCANDAL: JOLT FOR KOHL
description: West German politicians and Western diplomats believe that the espionage scandal that erupted over the last week is likely to erode the prestige of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's conservative coalition and sow distrust among the Atlantic allies.

title: Argentine Rebel Gets 10-Year Sentence
description: An Argentine court today sentenced a former rebel leader to 10 years in prison for taking part in political violence during the late 1970's.

title: FAVORITE FOODS TO MARK A CHANGE OF SEASONS
description: PERHAPS it has to do with the nature of the holiday: happy and carefree yet just a little wistful. In the mind at least, if not on the calendar, Labor Day weekend marks the end of summer, the last chance to celebrate the season in the sun before the cooler, and busier, days of fall move in.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: I HAVE always thought that the food of New Orleans is a fascinating coming-together of cultures, exhibiting at the same time the influences of Africa, Spain and my native country, France. I am particularly intrigued by the adaptations of traditional cuisines, cooking techniques and ingredients.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ON OUTER COURTS BIG DAY AS WELL
description: For most of the seeded players in the United States Open tennis tournament, the opening day of matches is very much like just another easy day at the office. They arrive at the National Tennis Center in Queens and park in a special lot reserved for them, sign a few autographs, and then sashay onto a court to dispose of a lowly ranked opponent. They succeed so often with such ease that later in the day, they might spend another couple of hours on a practice court working up a sweat.

title: The Downturn At Value Line
description: THE newly issued annual report of Value Line Inc., the nation's largest investment advisory service, contains fresh evidence that individuals are shying away from participation in the stock market.

title: Shiite Gunmen in Beirut Hijack Christians in Bus
description: Violence continued here today, as a group of Shiite Moslem gunmen hijacked a busload of Christians bound for Beirut's airport and rival militiamen shelled in and around the capital.

title: A FAMILIAR FACE SHUTS DOWN YANKS
description: Tommy John, whose career seemed at an end when he was released two months ago by the California Angels, came back tonight to beat the Yankees - another of his former teams - in grand style. John allowed just three hits over seven innings, and the Oakland A's closed out a 3-0 victory over the Yankees, who lost consecutive games for the first time in nearly four weeks.

title: NOT-GUILTY PLEAS IN TICKET CASE
description: Three Hawaii men charged with operating a large Super Bowl ticket counterfeiting ring earlier this year have pleaded not guilty to charges of conspiracy and forgery.

title: 20 Indicted After Blast At Fireworks Plant in '83
description: Twenty people were indicted today on Federal charges stemming from a 1983 explosion at a clandestine fireworks factory in Tennessee that killed 11 people.

title: TRIAL OF EX-F.B.I. AGENT HEARS TAPE ON TRIP PLANS
description: Less than four hours before he was arrested on espionage charges last fall, people accused of conspiring with a Federal agent discussed the suspect's willingness to meet Soviet intelligence officials in Europe, according to a tape recording played by the prosecution today at his trial.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1985
description: International

title: CUSTOM LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Including an extraordinary gain of $112,764 from the conversion of convertible subordinated debentures into preferred stock.

title: TALKS TO REVIEW ATOM PACT OPEN WITH A U.N. WARNING
description: A conference called to review a 1968 treaty aimed at halting the spread of nuclear weapons opened here today with a rebuke to the world's major nuclear powers by the Secretary General of the United Nations, Javier Perez de Cuellar.

title: Marketing Against the Competitor
description: THE average corporation develops its marketing strategies based on its perceptions of the consumer's wants and needs. But a growing number of marketers think that approach may be outdated. Instead of focusing on the customer, they contend, marketing strategy should concentrate on the strengths and weaknesses of a company's competitors.

title: Real Estate;   City Helps Company Relocate
description: WHEN Stroheim & Romann, a decorative fabric company now 120 years old, moved into 60,000 square feet of space at 10 West 20th Street in 1970, its executives thought they had found a safe haven from the commercial gentrification that had pushed them out of two previous sites on lower Madison and Park Avenues. The building was owned and operated by an overcoat manufacturing concern, and the neighborhood included many men's clothing and accessory companies.

title: JETS NOT COUNTING ON TOON FOR OPENER
description: It appears unlikely that the Jets will have their No. 1 draft pick, Al Toon, in the lineup on opening day, Sept. 8. In fact, there will not be many high draft selections in that lineup, which indicates why the Jets are struggling these days.

title: PANTRY PRIDE CHAIRMAN HUNTS BIGGEST PREY YET
description: Few corporate raiders engaged in their first hostile takeover battle would have thought themselves to be more qualified to land their prey than Ronald O. Perelman, Over the last eight years he has built a successful mini-conglomerate, MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings Inc., by borrowing heavily to buy a stable of companies, then putting his own brand of financial wizardry to work on each by selling off just the right assets and squeezing the remainder of the business to produce hefty cash flows.

title: NO BIG GAMBLE FOR THE BIG TEN
description: The Big Ten has unloaded its round-robin football schedule this season, a change that will allow each of its teams to play three nonleague games instead of the traditional two. Given some beatings the conference has taken from outsiders the last several years, that might initially seem a little daring.

title: U.S. POVERTY RATE DROPPED TO 14.4% IN '84, BUREAU SAYS
description: The national poverty rate declined last year by nine-tenths of a percentage point, to 14.4 percent, the largest one-year decrease in more than a decade, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: EFFECT ON FORD EARNINGS ECPECTED TO BE MINIMAL
description: The cancellation of the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun project will have little impact on the earnings of the Ford Motor Company, industry analysts said today.

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: EARLY TALLY SHOWS PRINTERS' UNION REJECTING MERGER WITH TEAMSTERS
description: The International Brotherhood of Teamsters appears to have lost a major organizing drive for workers in the publishing industry, labor officials said tonight as ballots on a proposed merger with the International Typographical Union were being counted.

title: U.N. Mediates a New Round Of Talks on Afghan Conflict
description: A United Nations mediator met separately with the Foreign Ministers of Pakistan and Afghanistan here today for a new round of talks aimed at ending the Afghan conflict.

title:
Economic Scene;

The Growth In Service Jobs
description: A HUGE restructuring of industry is under way in this country. Employment is declining in such goods-producing industries as steel, apparel, textiles and leather, but increasing in industries that provide services like health care, banking and merchandising. Both trends are likely to continue. Should that worry us? Not if we understand what is happening and learn to adjust to the trends.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
RUNNERS WARNED OF MENTAL DANGER
description: Jogging meets many deep-seated psychological needs that most runners are not conscious of until they are prevented from running, according to a new study described here today at the annual convention of the American Psychological Association.

title: U.S. OARSMEN UPSET SOVIET
description: The United States heavyweight eight overtook the favored Soviet Union crew to win its qualifying heat today in the opening round for men at the World Rowing Championships on Belgium's Hazewinkel course.

title: BURNUP & SIMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $186,000.

title: J.A.L. CRASH STUDY TO TAKE MORE TIME
description: A Government panel said today that it would need ''considerable time'' to determine what caused the crash of a Japan Air Lines jumbo jet two weeks ago.

title: DEMOCRATS WEIGH TAX PLAN SHIFTS
description: Democrats on the House Ways and Means Committee said today that they had been privately discussing ways to reshape President Reagan's tax overhaul plan into a package that would give a bigger tax cut to the middle class and less relief to the wealthy.

title: C.F.T.C. CITES COMEX AFTER A FIRM'S COLLAPSE
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission filed an administrative complaint yesterday against the Commodities Exchange in New York, the Comex Clearing Association and a variety of individuals in the wake of the collapse last March of the Volume Investors Corporation, a member firm that was put into receivership following a big upsurge in the price of gold.

title: Election Laws That Stifle Democracy in New York State
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. KICKBACK-TRIAL TESTIMONY ENDS
description: The 174th and final witness testified today in the 22-day-old trial in which some Nassau County government workers say they were forced to give 1 percent of their annual salary to the Republican Party to get promotions, pay increases and other benefits.

title: A VICTORY BY REVLON SEEN NEAR
description: Revlon Inc., using a defense similar to one that worked for CBS Inc. against an unwanted takeover by Ted Turner, may be on the verge of defeating a nearly $2 billion takeover by Pantry Pride Inc., Wall Street professionals said yesterday.

title: Israel to Free 100 From Atlit
description: The Israeli Army said today that it would release 100 Lebanese detainees from its Atlit Prison on Wednesday, leaving about 135 prisoners from Israel's three-year occupation of southern Lebanon. Israel last released 100 other prisoners on Aug. 13.

title: ELECTION LAWS THAT STIFLE DEMOCRACY IN NEW YORK STATE
description: To the Editor:

title: FAYETTE MANUFACTURING reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
CHEMICAL LEAK PROMPTS AN ALERT
description: Thousands of residents of at least four townships and one borough northwest of here were advised to take precautions early today after a chemical leaked at a resin factory, the police said.

title: JANIS MATULIS
description: Archbishop Janis Matulis, head of the Latvian Lutheran Church, has died at the age of 74, the Soviet Government press agency Tass said today. Archbishop Matulis, who was graduated from the Department of Theology at Latvian University in Riga in 1940, became the head of the Lutheran Church in Latvia in 1969.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 28, 1985

title: EVOLUTION OF 'DROOD' AS MUSICAL
description: One night in early 1983, resting backstage after a performance at an East Side nightclub, Rupert Holmes got a note. ''Enjoyed your show,'' it said. ''Are you interested in writing a musical? If so, call me.'' The signature belonged to Gail Merrifield, director of play development at the New York Shakespeare Festival.

title: All the President's Wits
description: How do you politely measure the state of a President's wits?

title: PEDRO GUERRERO: DODGERS' WARRIOR
description: It's not as if Pedro Guerrero cannot chew gum and walk at the same time, or talk to reporters and tie his shoelaces at the same time. He's a bright man with a patient smile, and he has mastered English as well as he has mastered National League pitching. But why would you want him to worry about bunts and grounders when he should be thinking about the real stuff in life, hitting?

title: 12-YEAR TERM TO CHICAGO JUDGE
description: The highest-ranking judge charged in a Federal investigation of corruption in the Cook County courts was sentenced today to 12 years in prison for taking bribes and fixing traffic cases.

title: One Potato, Two Potato . . .
description: It started as a classroom project for fifth-grade pupils in Brussels and ended as a museum in Washington for one of the most common and most taken-for-granted of foods: the potato.

title: STEWART QUIET IN VAN, OFFICER'S ACCOUNT SAYS
description: A transit police officer told a grand jury last year that Michael Stewart, combative and frenzied during most of his time in police custody, was quiet and motionless after being put into a police van en route to the Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was pronnounced comatose on arrival.

title: RATINGS
description: Sea creatures were lurking. Con artists were working. The Civil War was ending. And six candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination were debating.

title: 'NOT WORTH COST'
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today halted purchases of the Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun, saying the weapon's performance was ''not worth the additional cost.''

title: 5 JERSEY DEFENDANTS IN MOB INVESTIGATION ARE RELEASED ON BAIL
description: Five men charged with belonging to the New Jersey branch of the Luchese organized-crime group, including one of the branch's purported leaders, have been freed on bail over the objections of prosecutors.

title: BANK BUILDING & EQUIPMENT CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
The Yes-Ma'am Brigade
description: Of all the V.I.P. calls to the White House West Wing, none rate a higher priority than the intramural queries and directives from Nancy Reagan, who reigns over in the East Wing. Like other First Ladies, her eye can range from protecting the President's political image to guiding social details below the salt.

title: ALASKAN MAGAZINE IS A CULTURAL BIRDGE
description: NOT long ago, as the Highway Department was expanding an Alaskan road, a Tlingit Indian ceremonial object known as Peace Rock was blown up. An old Tlingit man, seeing that half the rock had been pulverized by explosives, asked: ''What does it mean?''

title: The Key to Developement Is Transit;   The Next New York's Underpinnings
description: In the bright sunshine of a balanced budget, candidates for mayor of New York are not talking about possible future deficits. They should be. In 1975 the city plunged overnight from prosperity into the near-bankruptcy of a $1.9 billion deficit. Now, rising tax receipts and Federal and state grants are balancing the budget even though city expenses have doubled. New Yorkers are asking for more services, but as the Sept. 10 primary nears, they should also ask how candidates will pay to keep them at present levels.

title: MARATHON PRIZES SET
description: Prize money for the Oct. 27 New York Marathon will total $273,800, the race director, Fred Lebow, said yesterday.

title: THE SCREEN: 'BULLSHOT,' A PARODY FROM ENGLAND
description: WHEN movie parodies work, their delirium is such that it really doesn't matter if one has any particular knowledge of - or affection for - the material being parodied. It may help but it's not necessary. Good parodies can stand alone, which explains the popularity among the young of the Monty Python films, especially ''Monty Python and the Holy Grail'' and ''Life of Brian,'' as well as ''Airplane!'' and the classic of them all, Mel Brooks's ''Young Frankenstein.''

title: LAM RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $446,000 for the quarter and $1,222,000 for the year. c-Including a tax credit of $198,000.

title: DEY TEST FOR B.Y.U IN KICKOFF CLASSIC
description: LaVell Edwards heard the gripes all spring. He listened to the arguments all summer. The Brigham Young University football coach knew that people were complaining that his team's weak schedule last season made the Cougars undeserving of their national championship, despite their unbeaten record in 13 games.

title: CIRCLE THE DATE
description: If the Mets and the Yankees can stay within striking distance of the division leaders for the next couple of weeks, then Thursday, Sept. 12, figures to be a very special day for New York baseball.

title: CHINESE ARTIST'S FAMILY RENOVATING HIS LEGACY
description: Official guidebooks make no mention of it, and anybody riding a bicycle down the narrow alleyway in Peking's Western district could easily pass by without knowing that No. 13 Kuache Hutong has a place in the history of Chinese art.

title: KOCH PROPOSES PRINTING CENTER AT ARMY TERMINAL
description: The Koch administration announced yesterday that, in an effort to keep the city's printing industry from leaving, it would spend $33 million to turn the old Brooklyn Army Terminal into a center for graphic-arts companies.

title: Man Sentenced in Killing Of Suspected Kidnapper
description: A father who fatally shot a man suspected of kidnapping and sexually assaulting his son was given a suspended prison term today and sentenced to five years of probation.

title: BIONDI CAPTURES 2d SWIM EVENT
description: Matt Biondi of the United States and Igor Polyanski of the Soviet Union, both world-record holders, won swimming gold medals today as their two countries struggled for the overall medal lead at the World University Games.

title: Freddie Mac Sets Rate On New Certificates
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, yesterday announced interest rates on $700.9 million of pass-through certificates, which are backed by mortgages of multifamily loans.

title: FRANCE ASKS HELP IN GREENPEACE INQUIRY
description: The Prime Minister of France called on New Zealand today to turn over ''all the facts'' it has on the sinking of a ship belonging to Greenpeace, the antinuclear and environmentalist group.

title: Edwards Trial Judge Refuses To Prohibit Sealed Evidence
description: A Federal judge refused today to bar prosecutors from using sealed evidence in the racketeering trial of Gov. Edwin W. Edwards of Louisiana and seven others.

title: DAVIS WATER & WASTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Net income for the latest first quarter includes an unascertained gain on the recent sale of a pipe making facility.

title: A Space for Gibran
description: The planned memorial to Franklin D. Roosevelt may have long since foundered in the capital, but the proposal for a memorial to Kahlil Gibran is reported moving along quite well, with planners focusing on architectural ideas and sites along the Mall.

title: Addendum
description: Technical Publishing Co., a subsidiary of Dun & Bradstreet Corp., said it will shift the editorial and sales operations of its International Group to London from New York, effective Sept. 1.

title: Strong Medicine For Trade Deficit
description: When it comes to trade, America has long been of one mind: free trade. I know I've been a free-trader all my life. But it's time for all of us to reassess this basic belief.

title: METS FALL 3 GAMES BACK
description: The Mets went quietly again, showing only one late spark of resistance last night, and suddenly the team that had ridden through the summer as if on a cloud was three games from first place.

title: ARIEL SHARON SIGNS PACT FOR AN AUTOBIOGRAPHY
description: Ariel Sharon, Israel's Defense Minister during the invasion of Lebanon and now Minister of Trade and Industry, has signed a contract to write his autobiography for Simon & Schuster. The amount of money Mr. Sharon will receive has not been disclosed.

title: WOMEN IN GOVERNMENT
description: Only 8 percent of the top posts in city government are held by women, said the Coalition of Leading Women's Organizations. No, answered Mayor Koch, the figure is 30 percent.

title: Lottery Aids No School
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOLITION REQUEST FOR OLD LUCHOW'S
description: AS a Save-the-Original-Luchow's rally takes place today at noon near Union Square, the drama will be playing itself out in city offices downtown.

title: Now Hear This: No More Seminars
description: Secretary of the Navy John F. Lehman Jr. has enjoyed an image around Washington as a cost-conscious weapons shopper, even while presiding over the most expensive Navy buying spree in peacetime history.

title: U.S. OFFERS SOVIET TALKS ON AIR LINK
description: The United States has told the Soviet Union that it is ready to open talks next month for resuming direct air travel between the two countries, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: 8-Currency Offer By World Bank
description: The World Bank offered an eight-currency borrowing, amounting to $321.4 million, from the Unico Group of European and Japanese cooperative banks.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: EVERYONE, drug dealers excepted, seems to love the recent renovation of Union Square Park. The park, which dates to 1833, has probably never looked so gloriously open, light and inviting and, nearby residents seem to agree, the results have been well worth the year and over $3 million that the Parks Department restoration took.
