title: GOOD GRAPE HARVEST BUT LOW PRICES
description: The chemistry is just right for the 1985 California wine harvest and crush, but grape growers will be disappointed with prices, industry insiders say. They noted that many New York State grape growers also face weak demand and low prices for wine grapes.

title: CHARGE GUNNRUNNING
description: An American couple whose boat developed engine trouble on a voyage from Florida to Panama have been under detention for nearly three weeks on the Atlantic coast of Nicaragua, according to relatives and the State Department.

title: Cessna Stock Rises $4.75
description: The Cessna Aircraft Company's stock rose sharply, closing at $25 a share, up $4.75, as new rumors spread that the company may be a takeover target.

title: MINOR LEAGUER HURLS NO-HITTER
description: Rich Stoll pitched a no-hitter today to lead the Indianapolis Indians to a 3-0 victory over the Buffalo Bisons in the first game of an American Association double-header.

title: The Death of a Gun
description: The Army's Sergeant York antiaircraft gun has finally been canceled. After eight years of development, and the waste of $1.8 billion, Secretary of Defense Caspar Weinberger yesterday shot down a weapon so expensive, so ill-conceived, so ludicrously incapable of hitting maneuvering aircraft that it had become a painful embarrassment. What lessons can be learned from the episode?

title: JERSEY A-PLANT REACTOR SHUT
description: Unit 2 of the Salem nuclear power plant in southwestern New Jersey was shut down early today, apparently because of a faulty valve, utility officials said. A spokesman for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, which owns and operates the plant, said that there was no radiation leak and no injuries.

title: Gas Suit Settled In New Mexico
description: The Federal District Court in Colorado ordered the reimbursement of about $75.6 million to 350,000 current and former residential customers of the Gas Company of New Mexico, a unit of the Public Service Company of New Mexico. The Brewer Class Distribution Project, which was set up by the court to distribute funds connected with the settlement, said more than $26 million of checks will be mailed in the next two weeks and additional mailings will be made later.

title: THE ARMY'S ABANDONED ANTIAIRCRAFT GUN: A CHRONOLOGY
description: Following is an outline history of the Army's canceled Divad antiaircraft weapon:

title: PRESSER UNCLE MAY DROP REQUEST FOR RETRIAL
description: An uncle of Jackie Presser, the president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, may withdraw his request for retrial on embezzlement charges, his lawyer said today.

title: TOXIC SHOCK SYNDROME
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: LORIMAR PLAN FOR WARNER
description: Lorimar Inc., the fast-growing entertainment and advertising company, said today that it intended to acquire up to 15 percent of Warner Communications Inc.

title: Maryland Concern
description: The Maryland National Corporation priced an offering of $75 million worth of subordinated floating-rate capital notes.

title: Key Rates
description: n.a. Not available* Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: NOT MUCH TO SAY
description: Claudell Washington, the Atlanta outfielder, tells why he was not surprised by the dismissal of Manager Eddie Haas, who had acquired a reputation for being extraordinarily uncommunicative: ''This wasn't a Triple-A team, but he ran it like a Triple-A team. I tried to talk to him once. That didn't take long.''

title: AN EDUCATIONAL CAMPAIGN FOR 'HEART-HEALTHY' MEALS
description: THE facts about fats, cholesterol and heart disease, and how to buy and prepare ''heart-healthy'' foods will be the focus of a first-of-a-kind supermarket-based education campaign next month by the American Heart Association and its affiliates in all 50 states.

title: WILDWOOD DELAYS BEACH REOPENING
description: The ban on ocean bathing here and in neighboring resorts because of sewage pollution will continue Wednesday for at least a sixth day.

title: A HISTORIAN OF JAZZ, AUTHOR AND TEACHER
description: Rudi Blesh, a jazz historian and author, died of a stroke Sunday at his farm, Hill Forge, in Gilmanton, N.H. He was 86 years old. Mr. Blesh was best known as the author of ''They All Played Ragtime'' (1950), the first full-length book on the subject, which he wrote with Harriet Janis, and of ''Keaton'' (1966), a biography of the silent film comedian Buster Keaton. He also wrote ''Shining Trumpets,'' a scholarly history of Afro-American music; ''Collage,'' also written with Miss Janis, and ''Modern Art U.S.A.''

title: Mine Kills 7 in Sri Lanka
description: A road mine killed seven people in Sri Lanka today. Defense Ministry sources said six navy personnel and a women died when their jeep set off a land mine two miles from the Trincomalee Naval Base in northeast Sri Lanka.

title: The Honorable Silence of John Peter Zenger
description: To the Editor:

title: Northwest Buys 3 Boeing 747-200's
description: NWA Inc.'s Northwest Airlines said it would buy three new long-range Boeing 747-200 aircraft.

title: WUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''I have decided to terminate the Sergeant York (Divad) Army air defense weapon system.

title: P.& G. Proposals On Takeover Bids
description: The Procter & Gamble Company will ask its shareholders to approve various anti-takeover amendments. The company said the steps were intended ''to encourage any person seeking to obtain control of the company to deal directly with the board,'' adding that it ''is not aware that any party has plans of any nature to acquire or seek control of the company.''

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Strawberries in August Dark red and glistening fresh strawberries from upstate New York, juicy and full of an extraordinary flavor, are available at several Greenmarkets - Tuesdays and possibly Thursdays at the World Trade Center (Church Street) and Fridays and Saturdays at Union Square. At $2.50 a pint, the price is rather high, but every berry is guaranteed by Gerald Posner, the grower-vendor, whose company is Strawberry Fields Ltd.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Atlantic Richfield Co., Los Angeles, said Edward Benson Jr. had retired as vice chairman and would become vice chairman emeritus.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in The Living Section last Wednesday on retail fish markets run by major wholesalers in the New York area gave an incorrect telephone number for the Shell Lobster Company. The correct number is 212-243-3400.

title: GIRL WHO VISITED SOVIET MOURNED IN MOSCOW
description: The death of Samantha Smith in an airplane crash Sunday was widely reported in the Soviet press today, and the schoolgirl who traveled to the Soviet Union at the invitation of the Soviet leader Yuri V. Andropov was depicted as a child who became a champion of peace after her visit.

title: R.E.M., THE ROCK BAND, THRIVES ON AMBIGUITY
description: BY all the conventional wisdom of the music business, the Georgia rock band R.E.M. should be a commercial washout. Its songs take odd forms, sidestepping the repetition that usually makes pop hits; Michael Stipe's voice is often buried amid the band's busy guitars, and his lyrics, even when deciphered, are thoroughly enigmatic.

title: Bonds Rise in Light Trading
description: Bond prices rose by as much as three-quarters of a point yesterday, but trading was so light that market participants did not attach much significance to the increase.

title: WESTVACO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
EDUCATION CHIEF PLANS TO TEACH
description: The State Education Commissioner said today that he would spend part of his time teaching in Connecticut public schools this year.

title: CHINESE CITY TAKES CAPITALIST ROAD A BIT TOO FAR
description: When reporters from Hong Kong were invited to buy Chinese babies in the free market here earlier this month, it was the latest in a series of shocks that have undermined the Shenzhen Special Economic Zone, principal showcase for Deng Xiaoping's ''open door'' economic policies.

title: Reprieve Is Suggested For Man Who Shot Wife
description: A 76-year-old man serving a life prison sentence for killing his ailing wife could leave prison with a 60-day reprieve from Gov. Bob Graham, attorneys said today.

title: U.S. PENALIZES CROCKER BANK OVER REPORTING
description: The Treasury Department announced today that it had imposed civil penalties of $2.25 million on the Crocker National Bank of San Francisco for failure to report cash transactions totaling $3.9 billion over four years.

title: KOHL VOWS ACTION IN BONN SPY CASE
description: The West German Government vowed swift action today to restore shaken confidence in its internal security system, while the opposition Social Democratic Party asked that the Interior Minister be dismissed.

title: MCENROE BARELY SURVIVES
description: When the final point was played almost four hours after the match began, John McEnroe raised his left arm to the crowd, more in relief than in celebration. What should have been nothing more than an afternoon workout became a struggle for survival that lasted until evening and very nearly resulted in what might have been considered the most shocking upset in the history of the United States Open.

title: V BANK SYSTEMS INC.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nigeria
description: Geography With an area of 356,700 square miles, Nigeria is about the size of California, Nevada and Arizona combined. Its name derives from that of the Niger River, the third-longest river in Africa, and its territory ranges from southern coastal swamps to tropical forests, from open woodlands, grass and savannas to semidesert in the far north. Nigeria, which is relatively flat, has rich oil and mineral deposits. Population Nigeria's population, estimated to range from 80 million to 95 million, includes some 250 tribal groups. About half the people are Moslems, primarily in the north. There are many Christians in the south. English is the official language but major African languages, such as Hausa, Yoruba and Ibo, are widely used. About 70 percent of the population is illiterate. Economy Nigeria is one of the largest suppliers of oil to the United States. It must import 70 percent of its food and raw materials. In addition to oil, which accounts for more than 90 percent of its foreign exchange, Nigeria also exports cocoa and rubber.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: John Ralston has left as president of the Portland Breakers of the United States Football League and has been replaced in the post by Jack Galmiche, the club's vice president. . . . Ted Turner, the Atlanta Braves' owner, said he would not name a permanent manager until after this season. Eddie Haas was dismissed Monday and Bobby Wine was appointed manager on an interim basis.

title: AUTOPSY SHOWS L.I. OIL HEIR'S WIFE WAS SLAIN
description: The estranged wife of an heir to an oil fortune, found dead in an upstairs room of her suburban Long Island mansion, was murdered, the police said today.

title: JEWS OF CRACOW AWAIT U.S. BAR MITZVAH BOY
description: Not since the Jews of Cracow, Poland, were sent to die at Auschwitz has a young boy become a man in the city's ancient Remu synagogue. For the handful of Jews who remain, now elderly and impoverished, the joys of a bar mitzvah have been part of the past, never to be relived.

title: Hitch Reported In Icahn Pact
description: The Texas Air Corporation has decided at the last minute not to go along with a plan under which it was to withdraw its merger agreement with Trans World Airlines, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: TURF INJURIES CITED
description: As many as 20 percent of high school football players' injuries -predominantly leg injuries - may be due to playing field turf conditions, according to a Pennsylvania State University study released yesterday. ''A lot of people may think 20 percent is minimal but multiply that by all high schools in the country, and that's a lot of players,'' said Donald Waddington, professor of soil science.

title: A LINE OF UTENSILS FOR NONSTICK PANS
description: NONSTICK fry pans were not very popular among professional chefs and some home cooks when they first appeared, in part because they had certain cooking limitations. Since the pans never reached sufficiently high temperatures, the old generation of Teflon and other coated pans never browned or seared meats correctly.

title: AN ANTI-APARTHEID CLERIC IS HELD ON EVE OF PLANNED PROTEST MARCH
description: A leading anti-apartheid activist was detained today, a day before he was to lead thousands of protesters in a march to demand the release of the jailed black nationalist Nelson Mandela.

title: CROWLEY, MILNER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Singapore Journalist Named as President
description: Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew today named Wee Kim Wee, head of the state-run broadcasting corporation, as Singapore's president.

title: GAF Raises Stake In Carbide to 7.1%
description: The GAF Corporation, in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, said yesterday that it had raised its stake in the Union Carbide Corporation to 7.1 percent. GAF said two weeks ago that it had acquired 5.6 percent in Union Carbide as an ''attractive investment opportunity'' and that it was considering a number of options, ''including the possibility of a business combination'' between the two chemical companies.

title: SHORT RETIREMENT
description: Saying he ''couldn't go out a loser,'' the former World Boxing Council superlightweight champion Billy Costello ended his six-day retirement.

title: AILING YOUNGBLOOD REITRES FROM RAMS
description: Jack Youngblood, a standout at defensive end for the Los Angeles Rams since 1971, announced yesterday that he was retiring because he doesn't believe he can live up to his past standards.

title: Johnson Controls In Sale of Assets
description: Johnson Controls Inc. said yesterday that it would sell parts of its Hoover Universal Inc. and Ferro Manufacturing Corporation subsidiaries to a unit of Citicorp for about $217 million. The operations being sold were acquired earlier this year by Johnson, which said that the units reported combined sales of $360 million in 1984.

title: Bus Driver in Maryland Crash Had Record of Traffic Tickets
description: Police officers investigating the crash of a chartered bus in which five people died said Monday that the driver had 22 motor vehicle convictions on his record, including 13 for speeding.

title: Sakowitz Closing Five of Its Stores
description: The financially troubled Sakowitz Inc. will close five stores, including two in Houston, as part of its plan to reorganize under the Federal Bankruptcy Code, officials said.

title: POSTAL INSTANT PRESS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Ethiopian Faults Aid Teams
description: The chief of Ethiopia's famine relief operations today criticized private agencies operating in his nation, saying that some of the funds and materials they have collected have not reached Ethiopia. ''Once they come into the country, some non-governmental organizations are reluctant to tell us how much they have brought into the country,'' Dawit W. Giorgis, director of the Ethiopian Relief and Rehabilitation Commission, said. ''There should be some sort of accountability,'' he added. Mr. Dawit declined to identify which agencies are involved.

title: GROUP WOULD AID NICARAGUANS HERE
description: Nicaraguan civic groups here have begun a campaign to win permission for tens of thousands of Nicaraguans in this country to live and work legally in the United States.

title: BANK OF NOVA SCOTIA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $19.7 million from the sale of the bank's interest in Vancouver Centre. The Bank of Nova Scotia is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: Winking at Apartheid
description: President Reagan thinks that apartheid is repugnant, in which belief he is joined by most civilized people. President Reagan also thinks that apartheid is disappearing, that segregation has ended in South Africa under a ''reformist'' regime reacting to a civil rights movement resembling that of the American 60's. In this belief he is joined by no one who cares about life and liberty and the South African abyss.

title: PACKING A LUNCH BOX FOR SCHOOL
description: MILLIONS of parents are once again facing the five-day-a-week question of what to pack in their youngsters' lunch boxes. Although Government-sponsored school lunches are available to nearly all children, many parents object to the often fatty and overcooked foods typically served and would rather choose what their children eat. Sometimes the children themselves object to school lunch, not just to the food but also to the lines they must stand in to get it.

title: Ads on Cable To Be Honored
description: The Cabletelevision Advertising Bureau yesterday announced an annual awards program to honor outstanding achievement in advertising on cable television. The award will be more than merely an honor: the grand prize brings $25,000 to the individual or group within an agency that creates a campaign that makes the best use of cable.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
A FIERY FOE OF APARTHEID: ALLAN BOESAK
description: When Allan Boesak, president of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches, became embroiled in a public episode involving his personal life earlier this year, he told his supporters that official efforts to besmirch him would not blunt his political mission.

title: Goldman Protects Its SCM Interest
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, adviser to the SCM Corporation, is protecting itself in case Hanson Trust P.L.C. of Britain sweetens its $60-a-share takeover bid, SCM documents showed yesterday. SCM, with Goldman, Sach's support, has termed Hanson's offer ''inadequate.''

title: AGENCY RENT-A-CAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid Aug. 14.

title: SNIPING REPORTED ON SOUTHERN STATE
description: The state police said today that they were investigating reports that bullets shattered windows on two cars traveling on the Southern State Parkway in the last week.

title: ALCOTT SIDELINED
description: Amy Alcott, the fourth-leading money winner on the Ladies' Professional Golf Association tour this season, will be sidelined indefinitely after falling on an escalator and injuring her leg.

title: Bar Challenges Southland Aide
description: The State Bar of Texas is seeking to suspend the license to practice law of a top Southland Corporation official convicted of proxy fraud.

title: FRIES ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: The company broke even in the year-ago fourth quarter.

title: POWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
FINDING THE CORRECT FINESSE MAY REQUIRE A CAREFUL LOOK
description: Finesses come in many shapes and sizes. The perceptive reader may be able to spot the finesse that was necessary in six diamonds doubled on the diagramed deal, but it is far from obvious.

title: 'LES AND BESS,' A PLAY ABOUT RADIO, ON PBS
description: ''BREAKFAST WITH LES AND BESS,'' by Lee Kalcheim, was slender when it appeared Off Broadway; it is slender on ''American Playhouse'' tonight. At the same time, it crackles with suppressed hysteria, and its jokes are a good deal more than one-liners. It can be seen on Channel 13 at 9:30 P.M.

title: Diligent, Dedicated and Responsible Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: ARREST OF CLERIC PROTESTED BY U.S.
description: The United States said today that it had formally protested to South Africa over the arrest of Dr. Allan Boesak, the anti-apartheid activist.

title: RENAULT PULLOUT
description: Renault, the financially troubled automobile maker, announced in Paris that the company would pull out of Formula One racing after this season. Renault reported losses of $1.55 billion last year.

title: COMP-U-CARD INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $408,000 for the quarter and $731,000 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $149,000 for the quarter and $178,000 for the 6 months.

title: 6 YEARS LATER, A TRIUMPH OVER TRAUMA
description: RENEE KATZ. In the summer of 1979, that name was blazoned across the front pages of every newspaper in New York, a testament to the single moment on a subway platform that could irrevocably change a person's life.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THREE ONE-ACTS Three one-act plays, presented by the Soupstone Project, are being staged evenings at 8 o'clock, through Saturday, at St. Clements Church, 423 West 46th Street.

title: What's Good About U.S. Nuclear Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Productivity Up at 1% Rate
description: Nonfarm business productivity rose at an annual rate of 1 percent in the second quarter of 1985, the Labor Department said today. Gains were especially strong in the manufacturing sector because of competitive pressure from imports.

title: AT CBS, GOAL IS TO HOLD CENTER OF TV AUDIENCE
description: A few weeks ago, when NBC tied its previous winning streak by coming in first in the ratings for 11 straight weeks, Brandon Tartikoff, president of NBC Entertainment, went into the archives to see which network held the all-time record.

title: 7 Crewmen Are Killed in Crash Of Tanker Plane in California
description: An Air Force KC-135 tanker aircraft crashed today in a training exercise at Beale Air Force Base, killing all seven men aboard, a military spokesman said.

title: MORGENTHAU GIVEN CHARGES OF PRIMARY PETITIONS FRAUD
description: A State Supreme Court justice has referred to the Manhattan District Attorney allegations that workers hired by a polling concern to collect nominating petitions for Seymour Friedman, a candidate for Manhattan borough president, forged and altered petitions.

title: Restoring Teachers' Dignity
description: Where are the teachers? New York is looking for 4,200 of them for unfilled positions for the coming school year, and New York is not alone. Miami is selling teaching jobs the way it sells condos - recruiting teachers from the Frost Belt, offering free trips complete with beach parties. Los Angeles is virtually hiring off the street. Georgia and other states are looking abroad to fill vacancies.

title: TURMOIL CONTINUES TO BESET NIGERIA
description: By the sheer number of its people and the size of its economy, Nigeria looms as the giant of Africa. Another upheaval in sub-Saharan Africa's largest military establishment augurs uncertainty and political unrest in an entire region.

title: CARDS CAPTURE 7th STRAIGHT
description: Willie McGee's two-run triple in the eighth inning helped give the Cardinals a 6-4 victory over the Reds tonight as St. Louis extended its winning streak to seven games.

title: SNAG SEEN OVER LOAN IN EQUITY RESCUE TALKS
description: Negotiators trying to rescue the Equity Programs Investment Corporation have begun to fight over who will get $100 million that the big real estate company borrowed from its parent, the Community Savings and Loan Association, investment banking sources said yesterday.

title: SOUTHEAST'S TIMBER INDUSTRY SLOWED AND LOGGERS IDLED BY RISE IN IMPORTS
description: The logging trucks still rumble through this poor, sparsely settled corner of eastern Mississippi, hauling bundles of trees cut from the area's thick stands of pine to the sawmills and woodyards that remain at the heart of the local economy.

title: BELL'S FEARED HUTTON INQUIRY
description: Executives, past and present, at E. F. Hutton & Company are awaiting Sept. 5 with more than a little trepidation. That is the day former Attorney General Griffin B. Bell plans to release the findings of his internal investigation into the brokerage firm's bank overdrafting scheme and who was responsible.

title: GETTING ALONG
description: Lebanese and Israelis coexist peacefully in the heart of the garment district.

title: The Honorable Silence of John Peter Zenger
description: To the Editor:

title: AMTRAK SER VICE BACK TO NORMAL ON JERSEY LINES
description: Full service was restored to Amtrak and commuter rail lines early today while rail officials sought to determine what caused a 12,000-volt power line on tracks linking New Jersey and Manhattan to snap Monday just before the afternoon rush hour.

title: ENTERTAINMENT PUBLICAIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Allnet's Merger Set For December
description: Allnet Communications Services Inc. and the Lexitel Corporation said that they would merge by December, forming a new company yet to be named. Each will receive half of the new company's stock, according to Steve Ingish, an Allnet spokesman.

title: EVENING NEWS BID ADVANCES
description: The takeover bid by Norman Lear and A. Jerrold Perenchio for the Evening News Association advanced yesterday when the Federal Communications Commission granted their company, L. P. Media, approval to proceed with its $576 million offer.

title: WINE TALK
description: ARE wine explosions, like other explosions, governed by the basic laws of physics?

title: CARLTON ALMOST READY
description: Steve Carlton, who has been sidelined since June 22 with a shoulder injury, pitched a simulated five-inning game yesterday, leaving the Philadelphia Phillies' manager, John Felske, impressed.

title: PETROLITE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
NEW CURATOR OF MET'S PHOTOS
description: Maria Morris Hambourg has been appointed associate curator of the Metropolitan Museum's Department of Prints and Photographs, museum officials announced this week. She will be responsible for researching, exhibiting and enlarging the museum's collection of more than 12,000 photographs, dating from the mid-19th century to the present.

title: RANDOLPH POSTS 65 TO LEAD AMATEURS
description: Sam Randolph, runner-up in last year's United States Amateur golf championship, shot 65 today to lead the first of two qualifying rounds of the 1985 championship. Randolph's score was five under par for the Montclair Golf Club.

title: 275 in Illegal Fur Trade In 6 States Are Charged
description: A fur company covertly run by Federal agents infiltrated the illegal fur market, and about 275 people in six states were charged with violating Federal statutes that protect rare fur-bearing animals, the United States Attorney's office announced today.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: SOUTH AFRICA BARS FINANCIAL TRADING AS UNREST GOES ON
description: The South African Government yesterday suspended trading on the country's stock and currency markets as the South African currency plunged to its lowest level ever. The suspension is in effect until Monday.

title: STAGE: CHRISTIE MYSTERY, 'MURDER AT THE VICARAGE
description: USUALLY in an Agatha Christie mystery, characters enter singly or in pairs, but in ''Murder at the Vicarage,'' almost every time the French doors are opened, the stage is filled with suspects. Who killed Colonel Protheroe - his spoiled daughter, his unfaithful wife, her artist lover or the nervous assistant vicar? The finger points, and then points in a different direction, in this intricate mystery. John Raymond's production at the Apple Corps Theater is adept enough to keep the audience watching and guessing.

title: PHONE-A-GRAM SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results include tax credits of $20,931 in the latest year and $41,069 in the prior year.

title: CAMBODIA ON BRINK OF REBIRTH, OR DECAY
description: Nearly seven years after Vietnamese soldiers replaced the brutal Pol Pot regime with a Government friendly to Vietnam, Cambodia is an exhausted and isolated nation, struggling to develop - and still haunted by the threat of Pol Pot's troops.

title: RECOMPENSE FOR SUMMER'S END
description: FULL of fleeting days of sun, a friend sighs at the ads for the county fair when the end of August looms. ''It's over,'' he says of summer. Thinking of the high leaves of a red maple that have just begun to suggest their coming change of color, I agree too readily - another sign that fall is in the air.

title: TEXAN HITS THE JACKPOT: $350,000 FOR FIRST NOVEL
description: A 37-year-old Texas woman recently completed her first novel, picked a literary agent's name out of a writer's magazine and sent off her manuscript to New York. The agent sent it to editors at five major publishing houses. All five expressed interest, and one bought it a few days ago - for $350,000.

title: ORBITING SHUTTLE SUCCESSFULLY LAUNCHES 2 SATELLITES
description: The space shuttle Discovery, threading the eye of a menacing rainstorm, rocketed into orbit today to begin a mission to be highlighted by a daring and ingenious attempt to repair a stranded satellite.

title: SECRETARY OF EDUCATION RETURNS TO THE CLASSROOM
description: Education Secretary William J. Bennett took over a seventh-grade social studies class today and led the students in a discussion of the Declaration of Independence.

title: SUN COAST PLASTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $106,700 for the quarter and year. c-Net losses.

title: DALFORT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net losses.

title: How Are South Africa's Jailed Children Faring?
description: To the Editor:

title: New England Life
description: The New England Mutual Life Insurance Company yesterday announced the completion of a 5-billion-yen five-year loan from the Japanese life insurance industry.

title: ELDORADO MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
EXPLANATION FITS
description: Tony Gwynn of the San Diego Padres elaborates on the reason why, trying to go from first to third on an infield grounder, he was tagged out by Philadelphia's Rick Schu, whose foot was blocking the bag: ''I didn't figure on Schu's shoe.''

title: William V. Banks Dies at 82; Founded Detroit TV Station
description: William Venoid Banks, 82 years old, the founder of the first black-owned and black-operated television station in the United States, died at his home Saturday.

title: A 'Dog Days' Market Climbs a Bit
description: Summer remained the dominant factor on Wall Street yesterday. Most investors continued to ignore the stock market while at vacation hideaways, and those still in town struggled to prop prices up a bit.

title: CITY BARRED FROM SHELTERING HOMELESS FAMILIES IN OFFICES
description: A state judge barred New York City yesterday from sheltering homeless families overnight in welfare offices, ruling that all such families were entitled to immediate beds in hotels or shelters.

title: WANT A GOOD TABLE? IT'S AVAILABLE NOW
description: THIS is the city's most comfortable week, when tables at in-demand restaurants can actually be found, and when theater box office ticket sellers smile when you step up to buy seats that may well be unavailable after next Monday. Department store sales have begun and there aren't as many other shoppers to compete with. In fact, there are simply fewer people around, a circumstance that, according to many, makes the city decidedly more civil.

title: BIG B INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Aug 2
GIRLS AND FOOTBALL: BOARD EASES STAND
description: The North Hunterdon Regional School District today voted to drop a proposal to ban girls from boys' sports teams after 15-year-old Elizabeth Balsley won a court ruling allowing her to play football.

title: GINATS DROP JENNINGS AS LANDETA WINS JOB
description: Dave Jennings, who joined the Giants as an obscure free agent 11 years ago and went on to become one of the finest punters in the team's history, was released today as the Giants trimmed their roster to the mandatory 50-player limit.

title: S & K FAMOUS BRANDS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
DUCKWALL-ALCO STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Soviet Signs Intelsat Pact
description: An agreement was signed today in Geneva between the Soviet Union and Intelsat, the multination satellite communications group, that provides for a mutual exchange of technical and operational information.

title: NETS LOSE NO. 1 PICK
description: Lewis Schaffel, the general manager of the Nets, said he found out from reading a newspaper that Yvon Joseph, the team's first draft choice, had an offer to play in Spain. Joseph's attorney, Richard Howell of Atlanta, said Monday that the 27-year-old center, a native of Haiti, had accepted an offer of $200,000 a year to play for Valladolid in Spain because the Nets never met with him until Aug. 18 and then had offered a one-year guaranteed contract worth $75,000.

title: IMMUNOMEDICS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: KING INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued casino operations of $2,705,616. c-Includes net from discontinued casino operations of $462,076 plus a gain of $288,000 from operations discontinued prior to 1984 and net of $272,000 from a reduction of foreign and U.S. income taxes.

title: Sears Appoints Head Of Coldwell Banker
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company has named Arthur J. Hill chairman and chief executive officer of its Coldwell Banker Real Estate Group.

title: HOPING FOR HORFORD
description: Louisiana State athletic officials were awaiting transcripts and a ruling by the N.C.A.A. yesterday in their quest to sign Tito Horford, a 7-1, 245-pound prep basketball star, to a national letter of intent.

title: SCHOOLS ASKING ADVICE ON PUPILS WITH AIDS
description: The New York City Health Commissioner has asked medical experts for advice on how the public-school system should deal with children who have AIDS.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

title: Decline in Mining Deaths
description: Death rates among miners in the first half of 1985 declined to the levels of two years ago, the Mine Safety and Health Administration reported today. Thirty-four coal miners died in work-related accidents from January through June, the Federal agency said, as against 57 fatalities in the same period last year.

title: TOYS 'R' US INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 4
Uganda's Talks With Guerrillas Stall
description: Peace talks between Uganda's month-old military Government and members of the nation's main guerrilla group broke off today with no apparent progress made, officials said.

title: COME ON OVER
description: AFTER WINNING $13.7 MILLION IN THE State Lottery the other day, Joe Moore of Brooklyn said he might now be able to afford to live in Manhattan. Actually, he can do it on a little less, but the question is how his relatives will behave if he takes the plunge.

title: President Named At Fotomat Chain
description: The Fotomat Corporation named John R. Chase yesterday to be president and chief operating officer of the financially struggling chain of retail photofinishing stores, effective immediately.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bell Atlantic Mobile Systems, a unit of Bell Atlantic Corp., Philadelphia, said it had entered a marketing partnership with Dollar Rent-a-Car to put Alex cellular mobile telephones in 100 Philadelphia-area Dollar cars by the end of the summer.

title: Carnation Unit Is Sold
description: The Carnation Company said it had sold its genetics division, which deals with bovine artificial insemination, to a new company controlled by Clark A. Nelson, a senior vice president of Carnation. Terms of the transaction were not announced.

title: PLEASURES, FROM PANDAS TO PIGSKIN
description: Sometimes it seems that all 535 members of Congress are out of town, having been taken as far as their committee assignments and junketing privileges can be stretched. The President is in California, and the Vice President in Maine. And six of the nine Justices of the Supreme Court are away, presumably charging up their batteries for the opening of their next session in October.

title: FRESH AND FOLKSY
description: GEORGE PHILLIPS kneeled in the back of his battered pickup truck and held out an ear of corn. ''You can tell if it's fresh by checking the end of the cob,'' the New Hartford, Conn., farmer said. He ran a callused thumb over the whitish end where, in a farm field earlier in the day, he had broken the cob off the stalk. ''After a day, this turns brown,'' he said. ''Go into the store and you'll see it's brown.''

title: Quarantine in Florida Against Fruit Fly Lifted
description: The Agriculture Department today lifted a three-month-old quarantine imposed to stop the spread of the Mediterranean fruit fly near Miami.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE ACCIDENTAL TOURIST. By Anne Tyler. 355 pages. Knopf. $16.95. LOOKING out the window of an airplane, Macon Leary, the hero of Anne Tyler's newest novel, ''The Accidental Tourist,'' has a kind of epiphany: ''It came to him very suddenly that every little roof concealed actual lives. Well, of course he'd known that, but all at once it took his breath away. He saw how real those lives were to the people who lived them - how intense and private and absorbing.'' It is from just such private lives that Miss Tyler herself has spun her own minutely detailed art, rendering them with such warmth and fidelity that her readers, too, are startled into a new appreciation of the ordinary and mundane. Like John Updike, she has taken as her fictional territory that sprawling American landscape of the middle class, and in 10 novels now, she has claimed as her special province the family in all its contrary dimensions.

title: 7 WAYS TO AVERT DROUGHT UNDER STUDY BY CITY
description: City officials yesterday began reviewing seven long-range proposals for easing future water shortages, including desalination of water from the Atlantic Ocean and piping water from the Great Lakes.

title: LIST OF TAINTED IMPORTED WINES GROWS
description: The list of Austrian wines imported into the United States that have been found to contain levels of poisonous diethylene glycol has grown to 35, according to Norris Alford, chief of product compliance at the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. For the first time the agency has also found traces of the chemical in a brand of imported German wine - 1984 Haus of Franz Liebfraumilch, Nahe, Qualitatswein A.P. Nr 1 907 021 129 84.

title: Fear of Flying
description: An Air India 747 explodes, killing 329. . . . A Delta plane goes down in Dallas with 133 fatalities. . . . 520 perish in a Japan Air Lines 747. . . . A British Airtours 737 burns, killing 54. . . . Samantha Smith dies in a commuter air crash. . . .

title: STEVENS, J P & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-After charges of $44.5 million for the quarter and $60,930,000 for the 9 months for the cost of restructuring certain operations and a nonrecurring pretax capital gain of $23,270,000 for the 9 months from the sale of a subsidiary. c-Net income. Results for the latest third quarter do not include operations of Foote & Davies which was sold at the end of the first quarter.

title: Dual Position Filled at Tiger
description: Robert P. Jensen has been elected president and chief executive of Tiger International Inc., the diversified transportation company. He succeeds Wayne M. Hoffman, who will remain chairman.

title: British Press Battle Erupts
description: A major press takeover battle erupted in Britain today when a publishing group initiated a $312 million bid for the Daily Express empire built by Lord Beaverbrook.

title: New York Air Fills Vacant Presidential Job
description: Douglas C. Birdsall, a top marketing executive at Continental Airlines, has been named president of New York Air, the five-year-old carrier that has faced difficulties in carving a niche in the competitive Northeast market. He is the fourth person to hold the post since 1982.

title: NBC AIDE TO JOIN COLUMBIA
description: Steve Sohmer, an executive vice president at the entertainment division of the NBC television network, will join Columbia Pictures on Sept. 9 as president and chief operating officer.

title: Hancock-Buckeye
description: The John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company and the Buckeye Financial Corporation announced that their merger had been called off by mutual consent. The companies cited long delays for regulatory approval. John Hancock, a diversified financial services company with $24.8 billion in assets, holds a $5 million investment in Buckeye.

title: IN CAPE TOWN, APERITIFS AMID THE ANGER
description: Images of a day in South Africa:

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS AND SANDINISTAS MEETING AGAIN
description: Talks between Roman Catholic bishops and the governing Sandinista Front resumed here this week, according to church and Government spokesmen.

title: Hanoi Offers Proposal On Missing U.S. Soldiers
description: Vietnam offered a two-year plan today to resolve the issue of nearly 1,400 Americans missing in action in the Vietnam War.

title: UNHAPPY TIME FOR KEVIN CURREN
description: His name will be preserved in the history books of Wimbledon under the heading, ''runner-up.'' But that hardly guarantees a tennis player immortality. Boris Becker won the singles championship at the all-England Club and reaped the spoils. Kevin Curren settled for ''nice match'' and a front-row seat where he has watched Becker take a worldwide victory lap.

title: Letter: On Public Service;   A Step Forward on Federal Pay
description: To the Editor:

title: Agencies Set Sights On Video
description: IMAGINE renting a movie at the local video store, popping it into the video cassette recorder and seeing - a commercial.

title: INJURY ADDED TO DEMOTION
description: It may sound odd, but athletes often look good when they are hurt.

title: IMMIGRANTS' SCHOOL NEVER SAYS NEVER
description: The message outside the Emily Griffith Opportunity School is clear. The blocklong building beckons with ''Opportunity'' in capital letters above the door.

title: KENCOPE ENERGY COS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss. c-Net income.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: Margret Broadley Dies at 81, Author of Books on Careers
description: Margret E. Broadley, author of career guidance books and a freelance writer, died Tuesday at her home here. She was 81 years old.

title: Cognitive Dissonance
description: How can doves, who urged detente with the Soviet Union despite slave labor in the gulag, oppose ''constructive engagement'' with South Africa, where repression is real but at a far lower order of magnitude?

title: PERKIN-ELMER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2 million.

title: GIANTS SIGN OATES, A CENTER
description: For the last six weeks, since the United States Football League's championship game in Giants Stadium, the Giants had been attempting to sign Bart Oates, who played in that game. Now the exasperating chase has ended and Oates has become a Giant.

title: UNITED STATES SHOE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
CAPE TOWN POLICE BATTLE THOUSANDS TRYING TO MARCH
description: The police in this coastal city, using shotguns, whips, rubber bullets and tear gas, today battled thousands of protesters drawn from all of South Africa's racial groups.

title: RUSSELL PEARCE HEUER
description: Russell Pearce Heuer, retired chairman of the General Refractories Company of Philadelphia, died last Friday.

title: ROCKERS TO RIDE ON
description: ROBERT BRAUN, left, comes from Hutchinson, Minn., and usually paints theater and opera scenery, builds models and designs furniture.

title: COPYRIGHT DISPUTE SWIRLS AROUND 2 SCULPTURES
description: At first, the two works appear identical: both are gazebo-like structures made from iron bars that radiate from a domed top. But a closer look reveals some dissimilarity, including some differences in the materials used and the decorative details.

title: After the Landing
description: For passengers using New York's airports, the plane trip is often a lot easier than the journey from the airport.

title: UNITED TOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes a loss from discontinued operations of $234,574 and a tax credit of $534,000.

title: Satellite Nods 4 1/2 Hours
description: The nation's main weather satellite began staring out into space Sunday, but it was fixed, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration reported today. An unexplained timing upset caused the Goes-6 satellite to turn its eye toward space for four and a half hours, the officials said. The transmission of 14 groups of 256 commands retimed the revolving satellite so that its instruments would come on when facing the earth, not when looking out.

title: Mostek Names Officer
description: James P. Fiebiger, assistant general manager of the semiconductor division at Motorola Inc., has been elected president and chief executive of the troubled Mostek Corporation. Mr. Fiebiger comes to the position after continued losses at the United Technologies Corporation subsidiary, layoffs of more than a third of its workforce and an announcement in June that it was re-evaluating its presence in the semiconductor business. He replces Harold L. Ergott Jr., who resigned in June and was reassigned to United Technologies' headquarters.

title: FIRST MUTUAL SAVINGS ASSOCIATION OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Norway's Saga Loses Benin Deal
description: The West African state of Benin has canceled a deal with Norway's Saga Petroleum Group and handed control of the country's oilfields to a Swiss-based concern, the Norwegian company said. Saga, which was responsible for production and expansion of the country's Seme oilfield, does not know why it was thrown out, a company spokesman said.

title: WYLE LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
RUTH GORDON, THE ACTRESS, DIES AT 88
description: Ruth Gordon, an actress and writer whose perpetual energies seemed to defy time, died yesterday at her summer home in Edgartown, Mass. She was 88 years old.

title: ATTRACTIONS SEEN FOR U.S. INVESTORS
description: Investors in the United States reacted calmly yesterday to the shutdown of the South African stock and currency markets. Shares of that country's companies, which continued to trade in the United States and elsewhere, declined only moderately.

title: Easco to Sell Unit
description: The Easco Corporation has agreed to sell its hand tool division for $105 million to $110 million, and said it would take a one-time pretax write-off of $30 million to $35 million. Easco said the buyer was a new company, Peter W. Smith & Company of Chicago, in conjunction with several current hand tool managers and outside investors. The new owners, who should acquire the company in October, have agreed to assume the division's debt.

title: SCM Deal Seen Under Study
description: Kohlberg, Kravis Roberts & Company, a New York investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts, is investigating the possibility of doing such a deal for the SCM Corporation, according to Wall Street sources. Earlier this week, sources disclosed that Merrill Lynch & Company, the brokerage firm, was also studying a leveraged buyout at the request of SCM's management.

title: Virginia and Taxes
description: Barely back from their summer vacation, members of the House Ways and Means Committee will head for the Virginia countryside Sept. 7-8 for a weekend of discussions of President Reagan's proposed tax changes and presentations by several economists offering their own advice.

title: SHONEY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 4
COLUMBIA TRUSTEES' PANEL URGES PRETORIA DIVESTITURE
description: A Columbia University trustees committee recommended yesterday that the university divest itself of its $39 million worth of common stock in American corporations with operations in South Africa, the university announced yesterday.

title: DOCTORS WHO PRIZE MEDICAL ANTIQUES
description: THE pharmacy jars have labels indicating their contents: arsenic, belladonna, hemlock, curare, strychnine. Other bottles, glowing a deep cobalt blue, contain embalming fluids. Operating sets, many nestled in handsome cases, contain ivory-handled instruments, attesting to their vintage - before the age of sterilization - and conjuring lurid visions of surgery in earlier eras. A walnut case is filled with cataract knives; a rosewood box has a set of instruments that include a gold-plated corkscrew device with serrated edges. ''To bore a hole in the skull,'' the doctor says cheerfully. ''One of man's oldest operations.'' A doctor's office furnished with such an array might inspire thoughts of time warp. However, in this case the doctor, a Manhattan ophthalmologist named Stanley Burns, practices medicine according to normal modern-day standards. But his surroundings evoke powerful echoes of the 19th century, for Dr. Burns is a history buff and an avid collector of medical antiques, which he has used not only to decorate his offices but also to create a minimuseum of medical history.

title: CARL KARCHER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 9
135th Death in Dallas Crash
description: A 49-year-old Florida teacher has become the 135th person to die as a result of the Delta Air Lines jet crash at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport Aug. 2, it was reported today. Kathleen Wright of Fort Lauderdale died Tuesday at Parkland Memorial Hospital.

title: LAOTIAN NEEDLEWORK COMES TO AMERICA
description: WHEN Chang Xiong fled Communist forces in her native land of Laos in 1975, along with other Hmong, the mountain people who provided help to American forces in the Vietnam War, she discovered that the needlework skill she had acquired as a young girl was not just a handy craft but a means of survival. Interned for more than a year in a refugee camp in Thailand, she and other Hmong women began making needlework for sale. Eventually, sponsored by the International Institute of Rhode Island, a refugee settlement agency, Mrs. Xiong, along with her husband and six children, settled in Providence, R.I., where hundreds of other Hmong have since immigrated.

title: ROSE'S BASES-LOADED WALK BEATS CARDS
description: Pete Rose drew a bases-loaded walk with two out in the bottom of the 12th inning tonight to give the Cincinnati Reds a rousing 7-6 comeback victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: EQUITEC FINANCIAL GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
ABC HUNTING FOR WAYS TO REVERSE ITS DECLINE
description: Pater Kaplan

title: Comings and Goings
description: ABC-TV announced it would interrrupt scheduled programming to provide special reports when Pete Rose ties and breaks Ty Cobb's career record of 4,191 hits. The network said it may televise Rose's tying and record-setting hits live if they should occur on Sundays, Sept. 22, 29 or Oct. 6. . . . Donna Margine, former assistant coach at Fairfield University, was named head women's basketball coach at Cortland State.

title: DOCTOR TESTIFIES SHE SAW 2 OFFICERS KICK STEWART
description: A Manhattan epidemiologist testified yesterday that two officers kicked Michael Stewart twice while he was in police custody at Union Square nearly two years ago.

title: Evening News
description: The Evening News Association board of directors met yesterday until late in the evening but failed to make an announcement concerning bids for the company, whose holdings include the Detroit News and television properties. A spokesman said that the board would resume meeting today, and that an announcement was likely to come today. An offer for the company made by a group headed by Norman Lear and A. Jerrold Perenchio expires on Friday.

title: JAZZ: BILLY BANG QUINTET
description: THE piano at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street) quaked visibly Tuesday under the assault of Yosuke Yamashita's solo concert. Mr. Yamashita performed in a Village Jazz Festival special free event; he is a leading Japanese jazz musician, and his concert was videotaped for a documentary and recorded for a live album.

title: East-West Postures Allow No New Hope
description: To the Editor:

title: Rates Set on Issue By Farm Agency
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation has announced the interest rates on $1.669 billion of six-month and nine-month bonds.

title: COMMERCIAL SHEARING INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
FRANK B. WALKER
description: Frank B. Walker, former editor in chief of The Montreal Star, died of a heart attack Tuesday.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day about Lorimar Inc. yesterday incorrectly characterized the company's plan to buy shares of Warner Communications. Lorimar said it contemplated buying up to 15 percent of Warner's outstanding common stock, not a takeover.

title: Saatchi Begins Link With Istanbul Firm
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Compton Worldwide announced that, effective Sept. 1, it will enter into an exclusive associate arrangement with a major advertising agency in Turkey, Guzel Sanatlar.

title: Don't Break Up the U.S. Postal Service
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC STANDS IN A VARIETY OF STYLES
description: SCHIRMER Music at 40 West 62d Street has a large selection of music stands. Three sizes of metal stands made by Hamilton are available. The No. 400 ($14.75) stands approximately four feet high and has two extension bars that raise and lower the stand. The No. 600, which sells for $18.75, rises to five feet in height and has three extensions; it folds into a small, compact package. The No. 2 ($20.95) also has three extensions, rubber tips on the legs and an adjustable music tray. Among the many other music stands sold here is a conductor's stand complete with a baton tray and a light, both of which must be purchased separately; the stand costs $175. Double stands can also be specially ordered.

title: PHILLIPS-VAN HEUSEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 4
description: b-Year-ago quarter sales include $6,932,000 from a retail operation sold at the end of the year. c-Year-ago half sales iclude $13,333,000 from operations sold at the end of the year.

title: U.S. Agency Urges Banning Chemical Used With Apples
description: Eating an apple a day treated with the chemical daminozide could cause cancer over a lifetime, the Environmental Protection Agency said today in recommending a ban of the pesticide.

title: Accounts
description: Coachmen Recreational Vehicles, a division of Coachmen Industries of Elkhart, Ind., to BBDM Cunningham & Walsh, Chicago.

title: Mesbla-Comercio
description: Mesbla-Comercio Internacional, the Brazilian trading company, has agreed to sell China 60,000 small trucks and construction technology, a company spokesman said. The $900 million deal is to be signed by a visiting Chinese delegation at the end of September, a Mesbla-Comercio spokesman said. The two-ton trucks are to be shipped in kit form to a diesel engine factory outside Shanghai.

title: DULUTH BEAR OUTLOOK: BUSY
description: For reasons that are less than clear, record numbers of black bears are invading this city of 100,000 people at the western end of Lake Superior.

title: STOP THE CENSORS
description: It's no secret that a lot of people in this country are spending a lot of their time keeping an eagle eye on what students read. But there's evidence that the number of self-professed censors is growing, and that the scope of their surveillance is expanding. It's a depressing trend, worth noting as a new school term begins.

title: 2-Year-Old Gets $8,500; Parents Held on Coast
description: A 2-year-old girl robbed a Brink's guard of $8,500 at International Airport Tuesday, the authorities said today.

title: GENERAL MAGNAPLATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
STATE DEPARTMENT DENOUNCES PRETORIA
description: The State Department denounced South Africa today for using force to block a protest march and for officially banning the largest organization of black high-school students.

title: JENNINGS BECOMES A JET A DAY AFTER GIANTS CUT HIM
description: One day after he was released by the Giants, Dave Jennings was claimed on waivers today by the Jets, who are trying to solve the punting woes that have troubled them throughout the preseason.

title: BIG DEMAND FOR NOTES
description: Interest rates were little changed in the credit markets yesterday, in spite of a highly successful auction of new 5-year Treasury notes. After lethargic sessions on Monday and Tuesday, trading activity picked up somewhat, market participants said.

title: DETECTIVE SLAIN DURING RAID ON 'DRUG FACTORY' IN JERSEY
description: A New Jersey state police narcotics detective was killed by a shotgun blast in a shootout and his assailant wounded last night as a large force of state and local law-enforcement officials raided a ''drug factory'' in Westville, N.J., the police said.

title: MANDELA RELATIVE CRITICIZES REAGAN
description: A daughter of Nelson Mandela, the jailed leader of the outlawed African National Congress, asserted today that the Reagan Administration's policy of constructive engagement with South Africa ''seeks to violate the fundamental commitment to justice of the American people,'' and has not been beneficial to South Africa's black population.

title: U.S. Rowers Dominate
description: The American team today advanced all but one of its boats to either the semifinal or final rounds of the World Rowing Championships.

title: SETTLEMENT IN INDIAN DISPUTE ISN'T WITHIN REACH, AIDE SAYS
description: William P. Clark, the former Secretary of the Interior, has concluded that he cannot settle a land dispute between the Hopi and Navajo people.

title: Big Production In Yankee Past
description: When it comes to producing runs, the Yankees have the best 1, 2 punch in major league baseball in Don Mattingly and Dave Winfield. After Tuesday's games their combined 192 runs batted in were 14 more than Eddie Murray and Cal Ripken have driven in for Baltimore and 19 more than than the total created by Tommy Herr and Jack Clark of St. Louis, the National League's most prolific pair of run producers.

title: POLICE STUDY DIVORCE PAPERS IN MURDER CASE ON L.I.
description: Detectives have been poring over a thick stack of divorce papers in hopes of finding clues to the slaying of a woman found shot to death this week in her mansion here.

title: Libel Judgment Upset In Kansas City Star Case
description: A judge Tuesday overturned a $275,000 libel judgment awarded to a former outdoor editor, saying the writer had failed to prove The Kansas City Star had published articles about his dismissal with reckless disregard for whether they were true.

title: U.S. Team Arrives in Soviet To Check on Tracking Dust
description: A team of United States experts arrived here today to inspect Americans' work areas, cars and homes for a chemical powder that the State Department says the Russians have been using to track the movements of Americans.

title: THE HIGHLY SKILLED TEAMWORK BEHIND THE MASTER CRAFTSMAN
description: IN the crafts field, the traditional perception is that of an artisan working alone to create an object - a statement of his personal esthetics made a reality by the skills of his own two hands.

title: Bridge: The Blanchard Team Uses A Rare Partnership System
description: In a major knockout team event, such as the Vanderbilt or the Spingold, most teams consist of two or three fixed partnerships. A few teams have five players, with one fixed partnership and one player alternating with two partners.

title: Vote by British Rail Guards
description: Britain's 11,000 railroad guards have voted narrowly against going on strike, their union said today. The guards voted last Friday on whether to take industrial action against plans by state-run British Rail to introduce trains without guards as an economy measure. The result showed that 4,815 guards had voted against striking while 4,360 voted for it.

title: SOVIET SCHOOLS: IS SKEPTICISM STARTING TO SPROUT?
description: ''The United States is washed by the Atlantic Ocean in the east and by the Pacific Ocean in the west,'' begins a chapter in a seventh-grade Soviet English-language textbook.

title: CABLE ADVERTISING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $330,916 for the quarter and 6 months from the writedown of goodwill and intangible assets.

title: 16,500 FETUSES TO GET BURIAL AFTER LONG FIGHT ON FUNERAL
description: After three years of argument, the County Board of Supervisors has decided to bury 16,500 aborted fetuses found in a container at the home of a man who ran a medical laboratory.

title: CCX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $108,000 for the quarter and year and tax credits of $290,000 for the quarter and $501,000 for the year. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $1,178,00 for the quarter, a loss of $605,000 from discontinued operations for the year and a tax credit of $333,000 for the quarter and year.

title: MINIMUM PAY FOR TEACHERS GAINS IN JERSEY
description: The Assembly today passed a bill making $18,500 the minimum salary for all public-school teachers in New Jersey.

title: ANSWERS ARE OFFERED BY 'MASTER GARDENERS'
description: Along the Front Range of Colorado, the queries concern beetles on the pinon pine, what to do about the scale on aspen and what happened to very expensive sod laid down over the backyard clay.

title: IS THE MUSIC CUSTOMER ALWAYS RIGHT?
description: A FEW weeks ago, I attended the American premiere production of ''The English Cat'' by Hans Werner Henze at the Santa Fe Opera, and loved almost everything about it. Among the delights was the stage direction by Charles Ludlam. Although Mr. Ludlam has been a fixture of Off Broadway for years, with his Ridiculous Theatrical Company, I had never encountered his work before - other than by reputation, which was for broad, campy humor. But this production of ''The English Cat,'' while it had its campy moments, was wonderfully fresh, sweet and sensitive - a ''thinking man's 'Cats,' as I called it in my review.

title: Japanese Production
description: Production at Japan's factories and mines grew 5.8 percent in July from a year earlier, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The pace of growth was up slightly from June's 5.6 percent, but in recent months the rate exceeded 7 percent.

title: NEWS SUMMARY: THURSDAY, AUGUST 29, 1985
description: International

title: Our World Is Full of Linguistic Chauvinists
description: To the Editor:

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Latest 12 months results reflect a writeoff of $33,553,000 of the Hunter No. 4 power plant.

title: Storm Moves Toward Florida
description: Tropical Storm Elena whirled to life today, lashing the Florida Keys with 55-mile-an-hour squalls as it gained strength off the northern coast of western Cuba, forecasters said. The storm was headed toward the warm, open waters of the Gulf of Mexico, where it could further strengthen into a hurricane Thursday, the weather service said.

title: The U.N. Today: Aug. 29, 1985
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY Committee on Information - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: THEIR CLASSROOMS: BOSTON'S OPEN LOTS
description: ''We're beautifying from within.'' said Charlotte Kahn. ''Our on-the-job training projects in depressed neighborhoods re-use some of the 16,000 vacant house lots.'' Mrs. Kahn is the director of Boston Urban Gardeners, a nonprofit group known as BUG that, through its Landscape Skills Training Program, is teaching low-income Boston residents the installation and maintenance of outdoor plantings.

title: BLACK UNION CALLS STRIKE IN GOLD AND COAL MINES
description: South Africa's most powerful black trade union, the National Union of Mineworkers, called a strike tonight for 62,000 of its 150,000 members in gold and coal mines and threatened a wider stoppage if the authorities tried to break it.

title: PLANT LEAK IS CALLED NONTOXIC
description: Federal officials said today that irritating fumes from a chemical plant that spread over a 20-mile area Tuesday did not pose a serious health hazard, and evacuated residents returned to their homes.

title: Britain to Offer Dublin Security Role in North
description: Britain plans to offer the Irish Government a consultative role over security in Northern Ireland, a British minister said today.

title: WALLACE RALLY RAISES HOPE FOR ONE LAST HURRAH
description: For the 3,000 people who paid $5 apiece to crowd into the state's sweltering agricultural coliseum last weekend, it was the first public glimpse of Gov. George C. Wallace since he returned home from surgery last month in Colorado.

title: GRACE STUDY ON FEDERAL SPENDING CALLED ASSAULT ON SOCIAL PROGRAMS
description: Public Citizen, a Ralph Nader lobbying group, charged today that a campaign led by J. Peter Grace to cut Government waste was ''a thinly disguised assault on social welfare programs'' and a misleading effort to portray itself as the impartial ally of ordinary taxpayers.

title: ARMEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
CHARTING KERKORIAN'S COURSE
description: The secret ways of Kirk Kerkorian occasionally exasperate and anger some shareholders, but few can argue that they have not made money by remaining loyal to businesses controlled by the low-profile, high-stakes West Coast investor.

title: Little League Inquiry
description: Dr. Creighton Hale, president of the Little League Baseball World Series, said an informal investigation had begun into charges that the team from Seoul, South Korea, which won this year's championship, violated tournament rules. The investigation is focusing on charges that the team came from a league with more teams than permitted by tournament rules and that it improperly practiced before June 24.

title: CONCERT: MEHTA IN BROOKLYN
description: THE weather was perfect for an evening out of doors on Tuesday, and the Brooklyn setting of the New York Philharmonic concert, Prospect Park, was choice. The tops of a few apartment buildings were visible over the trees, but otherwise the city seemed remote. A huge round moon encircled with haze added a final touch of picture-book charm to it all.

title: Sikh Faction to Boycott Elections in Punjab
description: The militant wing of the main Sikh political party, the Akali Dal, decided today to boycott Punjab state elections Sept. 25 and renew its struggle for Sikh autonomy.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Metropolitan Report Wednesday incorrectly reported the date of the opening of New York City public schools. Schools will open on Sept. 9.

title: CBS OFFERS TO SELL 3 PUBLISHING UNITS
description: CBS Inc. is trying to sell off three of its publishing units - Holt, Rinehart & Winston's general books, Praeger and Winston-Seaberry - a company spokesman said yesterday.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSOM ORGANIZATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $24.9 million for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of shares of Reuters Holdings PLC. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: EPIC UNIT IS SUED BY AN INSURER
description: One of the private mortgage insurers backing the obligations of the troubled Equity Programs Investment Corporation charged yesterday that Equity Programs' mortgage company had misrepresented the nature of its real estate deals, and the insurer sought to rescind its coverage on the securities sold by that company..

title: THE TRADE-OFFS OF A MANHATTAN ADDRESS
description: ''I ALWAYS had this vision of myself in New York City,'' said Susan Varisco, who moved to the Upper East Side shortly after graduating from Harvard last year. ''I grew up in Boston and felt sort of stifled there after a while. New York seemed like the natural next step - some place crazier, a little more impulsive.''

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
POVERTY DATA AND FAMILIES
description: With economic recovery and the creation of jobs being cited as major reasons for the sharp decline in poverty last year, many economists say it is not clear whether the decline will continue or prove temporary.

title: KOHL TO DISMISS TOP INTELLIGENCE AIDE IN SPY SCANDAL
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl has decided to dismiss a top West German intelligence official and to replace him with Bonn's representative at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Kean Signs Bills Mandating Public-Area Smoking Curbs
description: Governor Kean signed bills today requiring nonsmoking areas in movie theaters, libraries and other public places, effective in six months.

title: Election Correction, Short Term
description: Though New York's Court of Appeals yesterday failed to resolve all the confusion over primary election ballot challenges, it took a step toward restoring common sense to the electoral process. Its decision underscores the Legislature's responsibility to reform the State Election Law.

title: COORS SET TO BUILD PLANT IN VIRGINIA
description: The Adolph Coors Company, in a move that will prepare it for continued expansion in the Northeast, said yesterday that it would build a $70 million packaging plant in Virginia, and that it would eventually build a $500 million brewery there.

title: STATE OUTPACES NATION IN SHIFT TO SERVICE JOBS
description: New York State's economy is being transformed more quickly than that of any other state by a broad, nationwide shift from manufacturing jobs to service-industry employment, the Federal Government said yesterday.

title: Luxembourg and Film
description: Crown Prince Henri and Crown Princess Maria Teresa of Luxembourg are coming to Washington soon for a gala that will open the European Community Film Festival with a movie close to the royal hearts, ''Conge fir e Mord,'' which is Luxembourgish for ''Vacation for a Murder.''

title: Required Reading;   On Making Cars
description: Howard H. Kehrl, vice chairman of General Motors, in an address before a Worldesign conference in Washington Aug. 21 on integration of the world's automobile industries:

title: But Who Would Build Westway, on Time and Within Budget?
description: To the Editor:

title: FIRE SHUTS GRAND CENTRAL AND STRANDS THOUSANDS
description: A smoky fire swept through 16 abandoned railroad cars in the lower level of Grand Central Terminal yesterday, shutting the entire terminal through the morning rush hour and early afternoon and disrupting travel for tens of thousands of commuters.

title: ELECTRICAL MAKER SETS BUYBACK
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, which introduced a string of takeover defenses only four months ago, announced yesterday that it would buy up to 14 percent, or 25 million shares, of its stock. Analysts estimated the cost at $1 billion in cash.

title: FIBER ART: NEW TWIST IN WEAVES
description: AS the field of fiber art receives increased recognition, some of its craftsmen are widening their horizons. Many now choose to ''weave'' in clay, metal or plastic tape rather than conventional yarns. Two fiber artists who have crossed these boundaries will be shown at the Gayle Willson Gallery in Southampton, L.I., beginning Saturday.

title: GRANTREE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-After losses of $414,000 for the quarter and $779,000 for the 9 months from the company's Canadian operations and a nonrecurring provision of $889,000 for the quarter and 9 months for the liquidation of losses. c-Net income after losses of $215,000 for the quarter and $753,000 for the 9 months from the company's Canadian operations and a gain of $185,000 for the 9 months on the sale of real estate.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Magnetics Corp., Sherman Oaks, Calif., which manufactures credit and debit card products and optical character recognition equipment, has elected to its board Richard M. Rosenberg, vice chairman and a director of the Crocker National Bank and chairman of Mastercard International Inc.

title: HECHINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
KAMIKAZE RICK TRIUMPHS AT BELMONT
description: Kamikaze Rick, whose handlers have long maintained that she is the only 3-year-old filly capable of beating Mom's Command, scored a narrow victory under an outstanding ride by Angel Cordero Jr. yesterday to win the Gazelle Handicap on the opening card of Belmont Park's 48-day fall meeting. A crowd of 14,660 turned out in sparkling weather as the horses returned from a month at Saratoga to find a fair and fast race track.

title: Warner-Lambert Buyback Planned
description: The Warner-Lambert Company said it planned to repurchase up to three million common shares, or about 4 percent of the total outstanding. The company would not comment on the price of the repurchase, which analysts valued to be as much as $115 million.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: AS homeowners and apartment dwellers have become more security-conscious in recent years, sales of alarm systems and pick-resistant door locks have risen. However, many people do not realize that in addition to spending money on better locks and alarms, a number of other steps can be taken - some at little or no cost -to help make things more difficult for a would-be burglar.

title: NEW RULERS IN NIGERIA ANNOUNCE SHAKE-UP OF MILITARY COMMAND
description: Nigeria's new military rulers announced an overhaul of the leadership of the armed forces today.

title: Credit Unions' Stand
description: The nation's credit unions, fighting to keep their Federal tax-exempt status, said today that a survey shows their fees for checking accounts and other services are cheaper than those charged by banks and thrift institutions. Joe Perkowski, chairman of the Credit Union National Association, declared that forcing credit unions to pay taxes as they do would mean ending some services or charging more.

title: Data Retrieval Improvements
description: Text written on paper must be in a specific order. This article, for instance, has a particular order of paragraphs, and the reader will normally follow it from beginning to end in sequential fashion.

title: Browner Returns
description: Ross Browner returned to the Cincinnati Bengals yesterday after a six-game stint in the United States Football League and a postseason layoff the past two months.

title: PRICE OF CITY LIFE HARD ON THE YOUNG IN ARTS, THEATER
description: FREDERICK G. ERTL is getting pushed around. Four years ago, he and his wife moved to New York City from Seattle to work in the theater. The first year, they lived in a one-bedroom apartment on East 82d Street. The second year, they shared a two-bedroom apartment with a roommate on East 20th Street. Now they live in Park Slope in Brooklyn. High rents there are chasing them to Fort Greene.

title: WIDE-OPEN KICKOFF EXPECTED
description: The first college game of the season should be a high-scoring bit of pass-and-catch football when Brigham Young meets Boston College at 8 o'clock Thursday night in the third Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium.

title: WESTCHESTER ACTS TO END BANK TIES TO SOUTH AFRICA
description: Westchester County has moved to stop using banks that have business ties with South Africa.

title: Where Does It Stop?
description: The street is narrow, noisy, full of life. Buses push their way through bicycles loaded with everything from a huge wooden wardrobe to live ducks: 30 of them, tied to the bicycle by the feet. On each side there are small private shops, storefronts opened recently in the old houses that line the street.

title: An Arms Lesson From History
description: The Administration's decision last week to test its new anti-satellite weapon may result in a dangerous and irreversible arms race in space. If President Reagan is at all serious about arms control, he will postpone the proposed ASAT test - at least until after the Geneva summit meeting in November.

title: People
description: Josephine Cummings has been named executive vice president and executive creative director at Tracy-Locke, Dallas.

title: TESCO AMERICAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $27,000. Year-ago results have been restated. Results for the latest year reflect legal expenses of $210,000 related to the company's bankruptcy proceedings.

title: CHILEAN CATHOLICS TELL OF ATTACKS
description: Roman Catholic Church officials here say that in the last few months, there has been an ''alarming'' wave of kidnapping and torture cases, many involving young people from church-based social action groups.

title: SABATINI, RINALDI LOSE
description: Not long after the Women's Tennis Association announced recommendations aimed at relieving the physical and mental pressures for players under 16 on the pro tour, Gabriela Sabatini, the 15-year-old Argentine sensation, and Kathy Rinaldi, who turned pro four years ago at the age of 14, were victims of first-round upsets yesterday.

title: RADIO NETWORK BILLINGS UP
description: The Radio Network Association reported that network radio billings for July were up 16.1 percent over the same month last year, increasing to $28.1 million, form $24.2 million.

title: REID-PROVIDENT LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $436,000 from an insurance settlement.

title: Surge by Westinghouse Lifts Dow
description: With the blue chips buoyed by a strong performance by Westinghouse Electric, stock prices ended moderately higher yesterday after lethargic early trading.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alamco Inc., Clarksburg, W. Va., said it had completed the sale of interests in 116 oil and gas wells to Geovest Energy Inc. for $12 million. Alamco received net proceeds of about $6.1 million, which was used to repay debt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A society can never effectively come to terms with its problems by repressing dissent.

title: Fast Adjustment
description: Already, he sounded like management: ''I know this business, so I know what I would say to an agent representing a rookie, expounding on his client's greatness. 'Wait a minute,' I'd tell him.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Sales for the latest periods include sales of Miller-Wohl Co. of $72,897,985 for the quarter and $143,273,985 for the 6 months. Miller-Wohl was consolidated effective June 23, 1984.

title: CYBERMEDIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Gulf Canada Unit Plans Shutdown
description: Gulf Canada Ltd. said that a division, the Gulf Canada Products Company, planned to stop making petroleum and petrochemical products at its Montreal East refinery by November. The company said that it would continue to supply its petroleum product customers in Quebec and the Atlantic provinces.

title: CAESARS WORLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
No Relief
description: John Franco is not a slob, but when his baseball career is thriving he could pass for one. Above all, he is superstitious.

title: Reagan Says He Hopes To End 'Nuclear Threat'
