description: President Reagan, in a message to a nuclear nonproliferation conference, said today that he wanted to build a more cooperative relationship with the Soviet Union and ''rid the world of the nuclear threat.''

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A CERTAIN PEOPLE: American Jews and Their Lives Today. By Charles E. Silberman. 458 pages. Summit. $19.95.

title: SPARTECH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 3
Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 A.M. - Hana Mandlikova vs. Annabel Croft Second Match - John McEnroe vs.

title: STRAWBRIDGE & CLOTHIER reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CITY'S DROUGHT IMPERILS TROUT IN THE DELAWARE
description: The drought affecting New York City is endangering the trout in the upper Delaware River, one of the best trout-fishing areas in the Northeast.

title: WHO'S READING WHAT, AND WHY, THIS SUMMER
description: Be it gorging on Gothic novels, scanning searing headlines or perusing political treatises, reading is as much a part of the Washington schedule as Congressional hearings and cocktail parties. Washingtonians are obsessed with the printed word, often it seems because they are either writing them or being written about in them.

title: Republicans and Money
description: Some of Washington's most powerful Republicans are already helping Marc Holtzman, a 25-year-old Reagan-Bush supporter, in his plans to campaign next year for the Congressional seat in northeastern Pennsylvania now held by a Democrat, Paul E. Kanjorski.

title: TEXFI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 2
description: b-Net income. c-Includes a gain of $2,825,000 on exchange of debentures for the third quarter and $2,825,000 for the latest nine months and a tax credit of $40,000 for the third quarter and $218,000 for the nine months.

title: SENATE PANEL SUGGESTS OFFSHORE-BANK PENALTIES
description: A Senate subcommittee today urged as one measure to combat money laundering the possible imposition of sanctions against countries with offshore banks whose governments refuse to cooperate with United States law enforcement authorities.

title: 1,000 JAM CHURCH IN GIRL'S MEMORY
description: Samantha Smith, the schoolgirl who traveled to the Soviet Union for peace, was mourned today by 1,000 people, including a Soviet diplomat and her television co-star, Robert Wagner.

title:
GARDEN THEMES ECHO THE CHARACTER OF THEIR SURROUNDINGS;

SCULPTURE IN A VERDANT STONE QUARRY
description: RISING out of an abandoned bluestone quarry in the Catskills near Saugerties, N.Y., is an impressive and enigmatic spectacle: the environmental sculpture garden known as Opus 40. In the garden, hundreds of yards of stone drywall constructions combine with native trees and pools of water to make a supremely romantic landscape.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO HAVE DROPPED 3 OFFICIALS FROM LILLY CASE
description: Justice Department lawyers recommended that three officers of Eli Lilly & Company be prosecuted for failing to disclose deaths or ailments tied to the arthritis drug Oraflex, but senior department officials overruled the lawyers, according to Administration sources familiar with the case.

title: A SAIL MAKER WHO GOES TO SEA
description: CHARLES ULMER'S business is always at sea.

title: New Request By Icahn Seen
description: Carl C. Icahn is expected to ask the directors of Trans World Airlines to declare that the Texas Air bid for the airline is an ''impossibility'' due to his majority holding and that it is no longer bound by its merger agreement, sources close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Owen Le Grand Scott, Ex-Chief of News Magazine
description: Owen Le Grand Scott, executive editor of U.S. News & World Report for 31 years, died of a stroke today at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 87 years old.

title: U.S. CONCERNS FACE ADDED OBSTACLES
description: South Africa's suspension of currency and stock trading threatens to make conditions even tougher for American corporations with operations there, business consultants and academic experts said yesterday. But a number of companies took a wait-and-see attitude about the effect on their operations there.

title: SOUTH AFRICA PROTESTS PRODUCE HOPES FOR NEW GENERATION OF BLACK ACTIVISTS
description: In the cool of midnight Tuesday, under the bronzed, beckoning arm of a statue of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the Morehouse College campus, more than 1,000 black tudents stood and roared in unity with South African blacks the Zulu phrase they had just learned: ''Amandla ngawethu! Freedom is coming!''

title: MARSH CLARK, AT 56, REPORTER WAS CHIEF OF BUREAUS FOR TIME
description: Marsh Clark, a senior correspondent for Time magazine and former chief of its bureau in Johannesburg, died of cancer at his home there on Tuesday. He was 56 years old. Mr. Clark spent 22 years as one of Time's most widely traveled foreign correspondents, according to a magazine spokesman.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: FALL CRAFTS FESTIVAL
description: Autumn Crafts Festival, Lincoln Center/Fordham University Plaza, Columbus Avenue and 62d Street, 212-677-4627.

title: Thrift Unit Held Insolvent
description: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28 -The Federal Home Loan Bank Board and the state savings and loan commissioner declared the Presidio Savings and Loan Association of Porterville, Calif., insolvent yesterday. marking the ninth supervisory action taken by the Bank Board this year against California thrift institutions.

title: Stolen Auto Is Linked To Los Angeles Killer
description: An anonymous telephone tip today led the police to a station wagon believed to have been used in the most recent attack by a killer suspected in the deaths of 14 people.

title: Lois Pitts Named For Murjani Line
description: Murjani International said it had appointed Lois Pitts Gershon/GGK as the advertising agency for its clothing line by the designer Tommy Hilfiger.

title: NO CARS, NO FLIES, BUT LOTS OF FUDGE
description: For years drivers have cruised Michigan's freeways while their car radios played the hit songs of the Four Tops. But when the pop-soul group from Detroit arrived here for a concert last week they discovered there was not a whole lot of cruising going on. By law.

title: YANKS RETURN AFTER MILD SLIP
description: Willie Randolph, who has been through nine summers of pennant races in the Bronx, says it is far too early to begin worrying about minislumps and winning streaks. The portion of the season that he calls ''the real emotional part'' hasn't even begun.

title: FIRE FRUSTRATES TRAVELERS BUT INTRIGUES ONLOOKERS
description: All morning yesterday, commuters and office workers swarmed through the streets of midtown Manhattan, trying to adjust their workday routines to the five-alarm fire that swept through tunnels underneath Grand Central Terminal.

title: CURREN IS UPSET
description: Order was restored to the top ranks of the United States Open tennis tournament yesterday, thanks in part to John McEnroe.

title:
GARDEN THEMES ECHO THE CHARACTER OF THEIR SURROUNDINGS;

LANDSCAPED WILDFLOWER WILDERNESS
description: CREATED in the early 1930's by the landscape designer Will C. Curtis and the horticulturist Howard Stiles, the Garden in the Woods in Framingham, Mass., is 15 acres of naturalistic plantings within a 45-acre wilderness. Over 1,500 species and varieties of native wildflowers and plants are spread along trails that wind through a dramatic landscape of ridges, wetlands and New England trees.

title: WNBC SPECIAL REPORT OF HOUSING FOR ELDERLY
description: ''NEW HOMES FOR OLD'' -clever title, but also misleading - is about the elderly. Where can they live when they are no longer independent? It is an important question, and WNBC-TV, whose production this is, is intelligent, diligent and surprisingly cheerful in looking for an answer. The half-hour report will be seen on Channel 4 at 9:30 P.M.

title: Young Players Limited
description: After studying the recommendations of the International Tennis Federation and completing an 18-month study into the problems of increasing injuries and mental fatigue, the Women's Tennis Association yesterday announced new eligibility rules for its players which would limit the number of tournaments in which younger players may participate in a calendar year.

title: Cutting Words
description: Grant Ledyard, the Ranger defenseman who was shipped to the farm last year before returning at midseason, when asked to disclose the most fearsome words he had ever heard: ''Craig wants to see you.''

title: Major-League Pension Plan Looks Illegal
description: To the Editor:

title: A BITTER RIVALRY FOR COUNCIL PRESIDENCY
description: Two Democratic candidates for City Council President are questioning each other's character and integrity in one of the most vituperative radio and television advertising campaigns in recent years.

title: Reaction in South Africa
description: Reaction to the Government's suspension of trading on the country's currency and stock markets has been mixed. Some people contend that less extreme measures could have been taken to protect the rand, including ordering South Africa's gold-mining companies to repatriate all of the dollars they earn. Others said, however, that any efforts to help restore confidence and stability in the foreign exchange markets were welcome.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8:05 P.M. Phil Niekro goes for victory No. 297 as the Yankees open an 11-game homestand.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 9.50 9.50 13.00 DISCOUNT RATE * 7.50 7.50 9.00 FEDERAL FUNDS * 8.08 7.93 11.20 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 7.07 7.05 10.65 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS * 7.19 7.18 10.74 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 10.00 9.96 12.86 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 10.38 10.38 12.57 TELEPHONE BONDS 11.56 11.56 13.67 MUNICIPAL BONDS * 9.79 9.82 10.54

title: MIDCON OFFER
description: The Midcon Corporation said it had received a request for more information from the Federal Trade Commission in connection with its $1.1 billion tender offer for United Energy Resources. The request extends the waiting period for Midcon's $41-a-share tender for 18.1 million United Energy shares from Sept. 10 to 10 days after the date Midcon complies with the F.T.C. request.

title: AIGUEBELLE RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: CAESARS NEW JERSEY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: Results for the latest periods reflect pretax charges of $3.4 million for the quarter and $4.7 million for the year based on the likelihood that the company will invest in below-market yield bonds to satisfy certain investment obligations under the Casino Control Act.

title: CALIFORNIA HEARING IS SET ON USE OF THE DEATH PENALTY IN SPY CASE
description: A Federal district judge in San Francisco has ordered a hearing on whether Jerry A. Whitworth, a retired Navy radioman, could be executed if convicted of spying.

title: WESTERN GOVERNORS SEE DEFICIT PERIL
description: Governors of eight Western states ended a three-day meeting here today after being repeatedly told that record Federal budget deficits were creating serious long-term economic problems for the West.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BUT WHO WOULD BUILD WESTWAY, ON TIME AND WITHIN BUDGET?
description: To the Editor:

title: Wildwood Bathing Ban Ends
description: Officials announced here today that bacteria levels from sewage off this and nearby resort communities had improved enough to call off a six-day ban on ocean swimming. Marc Pfeiffer, the Wildwood Business Administrator, said samples taken Monday had shown that levels of the fecal coliform bacteria were within safe limits.

title: F.C.C. DOUBTS ITS TRADE ROLE
description: The Federal Communications Commission has determined that it probably cannot use its equipment certification authority to retaliate against Japan for blocking telecommunications imports from the United States.

title: 4th Gold Medal Won by Biondi
description: Matt Biondi of the United States won his fourth gold medal of the World University Games today, anchoring a United States relay team to victory in the 4x100-meter freestyle relay.

title: Tokyo to Add Stockbrokers
description: The Tokyo Stock Exchange announced plans today for its first membership expansion in nearly four decades. The move could seat foreign brokerage firms for the first time and ease trade friction with the United States.

title: INTERPHARM LABORATORIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Who Sank the Rainbow Warrior?
description: France's President, Francois Mitterrand, has a diplomatic, political and moral problem that won't go away. Almost from the moment that the environmental ship Rainbow Warrior was bombed and sunk in New Zealand, people in and out of France suspected official French involvement. Now the official report by Bernard Tricot, a respected opposition figure, has, if anything, made the suspicions worse. They will endure until the French Government explains the inconsistencies and closes the gaps.

title: G.E. Unit Switches To Palo Alto Agency
description: The Calma Company, a subsidiary of the General Electric Company, has switched agencies to Tycer-Fultz-Bellack of Palo Alto, Calif., from Chiat/Day, San Francisco. Billings are estimated at between $750,000 and $1 million.

title: Wheeling Labor Ruling
description: A Federal District Court judge in Pittsburgh today upheld last month's decision by a bankruptcy court allowing the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to void its labor contracts.

title: F.A.A. ORDERS A CHECK ON PRATT JET ENGINES
description: The Federal Aviation Administration today ordered inspections of Pratt & Whitney jet engines on a fourth of the airliners operating in the United States.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: POP-SOUL CABARET The singer and comedienne Jenifer Lewis is one of the most talented of a new breed of pop-soul entertainers who make interesting connections between Broadway and post-Motown pop-soul music. Tonight, and for the following two evenings, Miss Lewis will perform ''The Best of Jenifer Lewis,'' a composite of the most popular pieces from her critically praised solo cabaret shows at Don't Tell Mama, at 343 West 46th Street. Shows are at 11 P.M. Miss Lewis, who was once a member of Bette Midler's backup group, the Harlettes, has a brash, defiant stage manner and can take a song like ''I Heard It Through the Grapevine'' and twist it into a comic melodrama.

title: RARE CRAFT IS USED TO RESTORE A WINDOW
description: THERE are three intricately patterned amber glass windows in Olana, the exotic mansion built from 1870-76 by the noted landscape painter Frederic Edwin Church on a hill overlooking the Hudson River near Hudson, N.Y. And while many visitors touring the landmark house might assume that they are looking at painted or stained-glass windows, the reality is quite different: the three windows are rare examples of scherenschnitte, the northern European art of elaborately cut paper.

title: Mayor Turns Attention To Hispanic New Yorkers
description: Answering ''Definitely!'' when asked if his timing were related to the Democratic mayoral primary 12 days from now, Mayor Koch announced some things he wants to do for Hispanic New Yorkers.

title: Thrift Unit Assessment
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today announced its third special assessment on thrift institutions insured by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation. The assessment will generate about $250 million for the ailing deposit insurance fund.

title: Falwell Appearance Canceled Over South Africa Remarks
description: The Rev. Jerry Falwell was dropped from a prayer breakfast at the Neptune Festival next month because of his recent remarks about South Africa, the festival's organizers announced today.

title: ONEIDA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
description: b-Net income.

title: The 'Junkyard Dog' Earns a Blue Ribbon
description: In the eyes of some Pentagon-watchers, when the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun failed its test, John E. Krings passed his.

title: Photographs of Paris
description: The changing face of Paris from the late 1920's to the early 1930's will be shown in a display of 141 photographs by Therese Bonney at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including tax credits of $1,512,000 for the quarter and $3,100,000 for the 9 months, a net loss of $1 million for the quarter on the sale of investments and a net gain of $3,055,000 for the 9 months on the sale of investments. c-Net income. d-Including net income from discontinued operations of $172,000 for the quarter and $652,000 for the 9 months.

title: Drug-Testing Plan
description: Drug-testing would become mandatory at all National Collegiate Athletic Association championship events and postseason football games under legislation being prepared by a special committee, John Toner, the chairman of the committee, said yesterday. Toner, former president of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said the six-member committee met last week to refine the proposals that would be made at an N.C.A.A. Council meeting in October.

title: UNIVERSAL-RUNDLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: MUSIC: YAMASHITA'S JAZZ
description: The piano at Sweet Basil (88 Seventh Avenue South, at Bleecker Street) quaked visibly Tuesday under the assault of Yosuke Yamashita's solo concert. Mr. Yamashita performed in a Village Jazz Festival special free event; he is a leading Japanese jazz musician, and his concert was videotaped for a documentary and recorded for a live album.

title: MET-PRO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: SUCCESSOR NAMED TO DU PONT CHIEF
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company yesterday promoted Richard E. Heckert to the new post of deputy chairman and said he would succeed Edward G. Jefferson as chairman and chief executive when Mr. Jefferson retires next May.

title: CONNECTICUT FINDS THIRD OF FLXIBLES UNRELIABLE
description: Grumman Flxible buses, which were scrapped by New York City last year for safety reasons, have proved so unreliable in Connecticut that one-third of the state's fleet of Flxibles goes unused.

title: AUSTRON INC reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: Year-ago results include a gain equal to 2 cents a share from a change in U. S. tax law.

title: BENEATH GRAND CENTRAL, HOME IS A RAILWAY CAR
description: There are about 300 of them. Most are men. Many are elderly, disabled or mentally ill. They are given supper daily by relief workers.

title: How Analysts View Cessna
description: ANALYSTS were divided yesterday in assessing the Cessna Aircraft Company after its stock jumped 4 3/4 points on Tuesday, topping the record set in early 1984, apparently in response to takeover rumors.

title: 3 COUNCIL CANDIDATES OFF BALLOT AGAIN
description: Three of the six Democrats who want to be president of the New York City Council were ruled out of the race today by the state's highest court, pending further court action.

title: Concerns Said To Avoid Tax
description: Forty major corporations - including American Telephone and Telegraph, Boeing and General Dynamics -paid no Federal income tax last year, according to a study of 275 large, profitable companies conducted by Citizens for Tax Justice, a labor-sponsored research and advocacy organization.

title: G.M. Plant Move
description: The General Motors Corporation will consolidate its diesel engine manufacturing plant at its Redford Township, Mich., facility, the company said.

title: STOCKS OF BRITISH CONCERNS IN SOUTH AFRICA FALL AS A RESULT OF FREEZE
description: The City of London responded anxiously today to South Africa's freeze on currency and stock dealing as shares of leading British companies heavily involved there fell and banks quoted huge spreads between the price at which they would buy and sell the South African rand.

title: MEXICO RESUMES FULL RELATIONS WITH EL SALVADOR
description: Mexico announced today that it would send an ambassador to El Salvador, restoring full diplomatic relations for the first time in five years.

title: SHUTTLE PROBLEM WILL PROLONG REPAIRS TO SATELLITE
description: Flight controllers said tonight that the damaged electronics in part of the space shuttle Discovery's mechanical arm almost certainly will prolong the planned satellite repair operations, requiring spacewalks on two separate days.

title: ISRAEL RELEASES 113 DETAINEES: UP TO 150 REMAIN IN CUSTODY
description: Israel released 113 detainees today, most of whom were Shiite Moslems, and sent them back to Lebanon on Red Cross buses. They are part of the same group whose freedom was the key demand of the Shiites who hijacked a Trans World Airlines jetliner June 14 and took 39 Americans hostage.

title: Owners Ratify
description: Major league owners gave final approval yesterday to the five-year agreement with the players' association that ended the two-day strike earlier this month. At a news conference in St. Louis, Commissioner Peter Ueberroth said the owners voted unanimously to ratify the agreement that was reached Aug. 7.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: THURSDAY, AUGUST 29, 1985
description: International

title: Chokoretto-Chippu Cone
description: To the Editor:

title: RESTAURANT MANAGEMENT SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Aug. 4
description: Per share figures and average shares reflect a 4-for3-stock split paid Aug. 12.

title: C.D.'s, Money Funds Off
description: Rates on certificates of deposit and money market mutual funds fell again in the week ended yesterday. Money market accounts, on the other hand, continued to hold firm.

title: LOAN CURB TIED TO CREDIT RISKS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: The South African Government's suspension Tuesday of currency trading followed the refusal by dozens of major international banks to renew loans to that country's large borrowers, bankers said yesterday.

title: BUT WHO WOULD BUILD WESTWAY, ON TIME AND WITHIN BUDGET?
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSESSING FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT
description: Almost 20 years ago, in 1966, Congress passed the Freedom of Information Act, establishing the general principle that Federal agencies must open their document files for inspection upon request by any United States citizen.

title: PRINTER'S UNION REJECTS A TEAMSTER MERGER
description: The International Typographical Union, whose printers and mailroom workers are employed at about 500 newspapers in the United States and Canada, soundly defeated a proposal to merge with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, the typographical union announced today.

title: Girl, 5, AIDS Victim, In School Evaluation
description: Whether a 5-year-old girl who has AIDS will attend public kindergarten here next Thursday depends on the findings of a child study team, officials here said today.

title: Wilkes on Waiver List
description: Jamaal Wilkes, the forward who has averaged 17.9 points a game in 11 National Basketball Association seasons, was placed on waivers yesterday by the Los Angeles Lakers. Wilkes, a 6-foot-7-inch, 190-pounder, was a starter for most of his eight seasons with the Lakers.

title: RANDOLPH MEDALIST IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: Sam Randolph survived his second day of the Perils of Pauline to emerge as the medalist in the 85th United States Amateur golf championship.

title: EARLY START AIDS HUNTING PLAN
description: If you plan to visit a hunting preserve or engage the services of a guide in the fall or winter, you should already be arranging for such endeavors.

title: SHOE DECISION SEEN STIRRING FOES IN CONGRESS
description: President Reagan's rejection of the shoe industry's pleas for help against imports will intensify protectionism in Congress, including moves to legislate shoe import quotas and reduce Presidential discretion in trade cases, key legislators and their aides said today.

title: DICK WAKEFIELD
description: Dick Wakefield, who received a $55,000 signing bonus from the Detroit Tigers in 1941 but never fulfilled that promise as a major leaguer, died at his suburban Detroit home Monday night, apparently from natural causes. He was 64 years old.

title: UNION CARBIDE PLANNING TO CLOSE SOME PLANTS AND REDUCE ITS STAFF
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, reeling from the effects of last December's toxic gas leak at Bhopal, India, and other problems, yesterday announced a drastic consolidation.

title: HIS SPIRIT SOARS ON THE WINGS OF THE TERN
description: It is a gray day by the sea. The wind blows cool from the northeast and the vault above the sand is ashen. The season is ready to shift, and those who sit by the surf staring out to sea wear light jackets now and turn their faces mournfully into the wind.

title: TYLAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
ISRAELI ARMY RAIDS 3 LEBANESE TOWNS, DETAINING DOZENS
description: Israeli troops, backed by helicopters and armor, swept into three Shiite Moslem villages in Lebanon today, where they were said to have detained dozens of people suspected of being guerrillas.

title: Fakery Fought
description: What's in a name? Money, when the name is Cartier, Izod, Gucci, Rolex, Polo, Vuitton or any of dozens of prestigious labels attached to expensive products.

title: REAGAN REJECTS SHOE IMPORT CURB
description: President Reagan, calling protectionist measures ''ineffective and extremely expensive,'' today rejected pleas from the ailing domestic shoe industry for a curb on imports.

title: Fitch Suspends Ratings Of 4 Middle South Units
description: Fitch Investors Service Inc. announced yesterday that it had suspended the debt and stock ratings of all four operating companies of Middle South Utilities Inc.

title: HERS
description: BORDERING the glass panel of my front door, in six-inch block letters, are the words ''Sanctus, Sanctus, Sanctus.'' An occasional passer-by knocks to ask if this is a convent. A sanctuary of some kind? A sect? Something praiseworthy or peculiar?

title: 'FLAT' METS GET READY FOR FINAL PUSH
description: In a year that has been pronounced by streaks all over baseball, there was no great despair among the Mets that they had come upon a lull. But they seemed to be quietly calculating just when they would turn on the concern, full-steam.

title: Village Walking Tours
description: The streets of Greenwich Village, in the vicinity of Sheridan Square, will be explored on walking tours Sunday led by Michael Levin.

title: THOSE CONTAMINATED WINES
description: The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, a relatively inconspicuous Federal agency that normally attracts little public attention as it goes about its statutory duties, has been in the news lately because of tainted wine from abroad.

title: RED SOX END SLIDE IN 17-2 ONSLAUGHT
description: Tony Armas drove in five runs, and Rich Gedman had four as the Boston Red Sox ended a five-game losing streak with a 17-2 romp over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

title: Margret Broadley Dies at 81; Author of Books on Careers
description: Margret E. Broadley, author of career guidance books and a freelance writer, died Tuesday at her home here. She was 81 years old.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE GREAT BRITISH PICTURE SHOW.

title: Of Stress, Hope and Playing the Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 'MERRY WIDOW' STARS REFLECT ON COMEDY
description: James Billings and Jack Harrold will never forget the night it rained so hard that they couldn't hear themselves sing on stage. It happened 10 years ago at the Caramoor Festival during a performance of ''The Merry Widow.'' That was one of the first times they played the roles of Nisch, the embassy aide, and Baron Popoff, the Monrovian Ambassador to Paris, which they will be singing this weekend when Franz Lehar's lilting turn-of-the-century operetta returns to the New York City Opera.

title: Texaco Capital In 5-Year Issue
description: Texaco Capital Inc. is offering $200 million of 10 percent, 5-year Euronotes at a price of 101 1/4, through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Just Salute, O.K.?
description: Some issues seem to bob along endlessly in Washington, like ducks in a bathtub, and chief among these is what to call a one-star naval officer, besides Sir or Ma'am. For decades Rear Admiral had been the title, but then the Navy changed that to Commodore Admiral in 1980, and recently changed it again to simply Commodore.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After losses of $6,475,000 for the quarter and $7,446,000 for the year and a gain of $785,000 for the year from the cumulative effect of an accounting change. c-Net income. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $148,000 for the quarter and $816,000 for the year extraordinary tax credits of $840,000 for the quarter and $2,811,000 for the year.

title: WESTERN TIMOR'S PROBLEM: TOO MANY PROBLEMS
description: ''You came here from Bali?'' said a disbelieving resident of this place. ''What for?''

title: NORTHWESTERN STEEL & WIRE CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $3,686,000 for the quarter and an approximate charge of $10,074,000 for the quarter and year to recognize the cost associated with the establishment of a limited term early retirement incentive program for salaried employees. c-Including a gain of $3,053,000 from the refund of previously paid taxes, income of $900,000 from pension plan actuarial assumption changes and a charge of $3.6 million associated with employee early retirements.

title: Lemar Parrish Arrested
description: Lemar Parrish, the former National Football League defensive back who was voted to the Pro Bowl eight times, was in the Palm Beach County jail yesterday, facing charges of cocaine trafficking and conspiracy. County officials said Parrish, who played pro football for 13 years, was arrested at his Riviera Beach, Fla., home Tuesday night by undercover agents. The agents found seven ounces of cocaine worth about $15,000, two handguns and $56,000 in cash in the house, said Tom Thompson, a spokesman for Palm Beach County Sheriff's Department.

title: Absent Soviet Team
description: Angered at the composition of the Soviet team that was to have competed in today's Ivo van Damme track meet in Brussels, Wilfried Meert, a meet director of the International Amateur Athletics Federation, has banned the team from competing in the event. Meert was particularly upset at the absence of Tamara Bykova, the women's world high jump champion, saying, ''We planned the women's high jump especially for Bykova and then they failed to send her.'' Meert charged it was a breach of the rules to pledge athletes for such a meet and then cancel their participation at the last minute, called it ''a farce'' and told nearly all of the delegation to go home.

title: HOSTOS COLLEGE IS TO GET NEW CAMPUS IN BRONX
description: A new $118 million campus complex, one of the largest construction projects in the recent history of the South Bronx, will be built for Hostos Community College, the president of the college said yesterday.

title: FEDERAL JUDGE FACES CHARGES IN BRIBERY CASE
description: A Federal district judge in Mississippi was indicted today on charges of accepting oil-well royalties as a bribe and lying to a Federal grand jury about his influence in a drug case.

title: Northwestern Steel and Wire
description: The Northwestern Steel and Wire Company said its auditor, Arthur Andersen, will qualify its report for the company's financial statement for the year ended July 31.

title: ABRAMS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Carl Haverlin, Leader In Radio and Historian
description: Carl Haverlin, a pioneer in radio broadcasting, the longtime president of Broadcast Music Inc., who was also an authority on the Civil War, died of heart failure on Monday at West Park Hospital in Canoga Park, Calif. He was 86 years old and lived in Encino.

title: G.M. Layoffs Begin At Jersey Plant
description: The General Motors Corporation said that the layoffs of 4,800 workers at its Linden, N.J., auto assembly plant would begin Friday to allow the factory to be retooled for a new line of cars.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A comprehensive test ban will not reduce the number of nuclear weapons in the world by one.

title: AIRLINE FINED $1.3 MILLION AFTER COCAINE IS SEIZED
description: The United States Customs Service fined Eastern Airlines $1.3 million today, saying its baggage handlers in Colombia had smuggled nearly a ton of cocaine into the country aboard two of the carrier's jets.

title: INTERNATIONAL THOMSON ORGANIZATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $24.9 million for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of shares of Reuters Holdings PLC. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: MOVIE TO HAVE DISCLAIMER
description: As a result of pressure by Asian-Americans, MGM/UA has agreed to put a disclaimer on ''Year of the Dragon,'' a movie about drug traffic and gang warfare in New York's Chinatown.

title: SOUTHERN CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
BAYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
ART: JOE ZUCKER CYCLE
description: JOE ZUCKER takes subjects and images with broad popular appeal and makes paintings that are unexpected, imaginative and irreverent. His work owes a good deal to Pop Art and Abstract Expressionism and something to fabric art, Color Field painting and Minimalism. But his deepest roots lie in the American cultural tradition that begins with Mark Twain and uses everyday, down-home language to narrate adventures that are filled with humor, speculation and satire.

title: Jimmy Giuffre Quartet
description: The clarinetist, flutist and saxophonist Jimmy Giuffre will lead a quartet tonight at 8 at Greenwich Music House, 27 Barrow Street.

title: People
description: * Larry Olshan, president of Wells, Rich, Greene Entertainment division, has been named to the additional post of president and general manager of WRG/West, succeeding Richard Kelly, who left the agency.

title: Boeing Contract
description: The Boeing Company has been awarded a $405.8 million Air Force contract to build offensive weapons-control systems for 82 B-1B bombers.

title: ALO-SCHERER HEALTHCARE YEAR reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Virginia Bank Head Quits
description: Douglas H. Ludeman has resigned as president of United Virginia Bankshares Inc., in the wake of a finding by the company's audit committee that he violated company rules by buying stock in three other bank holding companies at the same time United Virginia was buying shares in two of the companies.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a report by a Columbia University trustees committee on the university's investments in companies with operations in South Africa gave the incorrect date of the committee's formation. It was formed in May 1984.

title: NEW DELAY FOR 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Efforts for an immediate reopening of the Three Mile Island nuclear plant were thwarted today when a Federal court said its earlier order blocking a restarting was still in effect.

title: Leo Burnett's Stake
description: Leo Burnett International said it had purchased a 60 percent interest in Marsden Hartmann, an advertising agency with headquarters in Zurich. As of September, the Swiss agency will be known as Marsden, Hartmann and Leo Burnett Nerbeagentur A.G., and will be headed by David Marsden as managing director and Erich Hartmann as creative director. Marsden, Hartmann expects 1985 billings of about $14 million. Earlier this year, Leo Burnett acquired another Swiss agency based in Lausanne, which became AD Leo Burnett S.A.

title: Keycorp Appoints Unit Chief
description: Keycorp, the fast-growing bank holding company based in Albany, yesterday announced the creation of a new subsidiary, Key Bancshares of New York Inc., and named Robert W. Bouchard as its president and chief executive.

title: J. Walter Jones Jr., 64,; Fund-Raiser for Agnew
description: J. Walter Jones Jr., a real estate executive and fund-raiser who served 80 days in jail for arranging an illegal contribution to the 1972 Nixon-Agnew campaign, died of cancer Monday. He was 64 years old.

title: MICHAEL CODD, EX-POLICE COMMISSIONER, DIES
description: Michael J. Codd, who as Police Commissioner during New York City's fiscal crisis led a department troubled by thousands of layoffs, died yesterday at his home in Elmhurst, Queens. He was 69 years old.

title: Bridge: First 'Grand Squash' Scored By a Nomenclature Expert
description: For the past half century, the high priest of bridge nomenclature has been George Coffin of Waltham, Mass. He has devised terms for many situations in play and defense, particularly in the end-game department, and has strived, with mixed fortunes, for uniformity in spelling.

title: Cards Acquire Cedeno
description: With the division races swinging into September and teams from New York challenging the leaders, the St. Louis Cardinals and Toronto Blue Jays made moves yesterday designed to add right-handed punch to their lineups. The Cardinals, who will not have Jack Clark available until Sept. 8 because of a rib cage injury, acquired Cesar Cedeno from Cincinnati for Mark Jackson, a minor league outfielder.

title: Apple Founder Cutting Stake
description: Steven Jobs, chairman of Apple Computer Inc. and one of its founders, intends to sell 500,000 Apple common shares, further lowering his stake in the personal computer company.

title: Peru Cancels Occidental Pact
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said today that the Government of Peru had canceled its production and exploration contract with the company, but would negotiate a new contract within 90 days after determining whether Occidental should invest more in new oil exploration in compliance with Peruvian law.

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG WINS, 28-14
description: Robbie Bosco opened the college football season and his campaign for the Heisman Trophy tonight in a fashion that should convince anyone that he is a worthy candidate.

title: PEARLE SYSTEMS LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
U.S. SAYS PRETORIA WORSENS TENSIONS
description: The Reagan Administration said today that ''a sharp deterioration'' in the situation in South Africa had caused an erosion of confidence in that country's financial stability, and that moves toward easing some apartheid restrictions had ''stalled.''

title: THE DANCE: CODANCECO
description: A PERFORMANCE by Codanceco at the Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival on Wednesday at the Damrosch Park Band Shell offered the perfect combination, as one audience member put it - an affordable overview of work by younger modern dance choreographers. Admission to festival events is, of course, free. And Codanceco, a fine small dance group founded three years ago by Nancy Duncan, has a remarkably sure artistic perspective and repertory for so new a company.

title: TELEVIDEO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income. In the latest quarter the company had a pretax loss of $21,666,000 after providing $19.5 million as a reserve against potential excess and obsolete inventory.

title: Marlin Appear Far Offshore
description: 1Margate, N.J.:Anglers in an Atlantic City-based billfish tournament last weekend discovered good numbers of blue marlin - one of over 800 pounds - last weekend, but the location's distance, 80-90 miles offshore, puts it out of reach of small boats. White marlin have been caught at the 28-Mile Wreck, and wahoo and dolphin are fairly abundant. Big bluefish are being taken 20 miles offshore, where Atlantic bonito are also numerous. The warm water has also attracted some unusual species for this latitude, including Spanish mackerel. Barnegat, N.J.: Day and night party boat bluefishing excellent. Seaside Park, N.J.: Bluefish are in the surf near Barnegat Inlet; weakfish are being caught in the bay and from the inlet's bulkhead, and a few small striped bass are being taken in the mornings. #2Sea Bright, N.J.:Large bluefish are numerous about 6 miles off Sandy Hook, and smaller ones are all along the beaches. Fluke are not numerous, but they are good-sized. A few medium-sized weakfish are being caught in the bay and smaller ones from the outer beaches. Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn:

title: WHAT CATCHES THE ARBITRAGER'S EYE
description: The arbitrage action in stock index futures that has played havoc with the stock market on several days this month stems from careful scrutiny of minuscule price fluctuations in the amount of the premium paid for a Standard & Poor's 500 futures contract.

title: 2 POWER BATTLES BEHIND SCENES IN BOROUGH RACE
description: The often-bitter fight for the Democratic nomination for Brooklyn borough president pits the incumbent, Howard Golden, against three challengers. But it also involves at least two significant contests for political power in the city.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: Friday WORLD'S FAIR RETROSPECTIVE Picturephones, spanking new Ford Mustangs and visions of a future filled with moon buggies and factories on wheels - in short, the sights and sounds of the 1964-65 World's Fair in Flushing Meadows - would hardly seem like history to many who were there. But 20 years later, an exhibition of photographs, films, music and paraphernalia from the fair demonstrates the many ways in which the nation has changed since the days just following the New Frontier. The retrospective, entitled ''The Mighty Fair,'' is presented by the Flushing Council on Culture and the Arts and is open from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today and tomorrow and from 1 to 5 P.M. Sunday at the Flushing Gallery, 136-73 41st Avenue (between Main and Union Streets), in Flushing, Queens. Admission is free. Information: (718) 463-7700.

title: EX-BONN AIDE GOES ON TRIAL IN PAYOFF SCANDAL
description: Otto Lambsdorff, who until last year was Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Economics Minister, went on trial here today with two other defendants in a political payoff scandal.

title: Baby Dies; Stepfather Held
description: A six-month-old girl died at Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn yesterday, and the police arrested her 19-year-old stepfather who, they said, fatally injured the child by throwing her to the floor.

title: Officer Is Questioned In Slaying of Woman
description: A woman driving an automobile was fatally shot with a revolver belonging to an off-duty police officer who was riding with her last night on the Van Wyck Expressway in Queens, the police reported.

title: FIGHTING SPREADS NEAR CAPE TOWN
description: South African policemen firing shotguns, rubber bullets and tear gas from armored trucks battled stone-throwing schoolchildren today as violence around this city, now in its second day, spread further in black townships and mixed-race suburbs.

title: BOLIVIA ADOPTS AN AUSTERITY PLAN
description: The new Government floated the peso today, effectively devaluing it by 95 percent, and raised gasoline prices by 1,000 percent.

title: Nihilator Fails
description: Nihilator failed today in his attempt to break the world pacing record for the mile, set by his sire, Niatross.

title: U.S. SAYS SCHOOLS SHOULDN'T BAR PUPILS WITH AIDS
description: Most children with AIDS should be allowed in the classroom, and school officials should do their best to protect the pupils' privacy, Federal health authorities said today. The statement came amid dispute over letting victims of the ailment, acquired immune deficiency syndome, go into public schools.

title: Weekend Convention For Film Buffs
description: Film buffs, particularly those fond of silent features, will gather this weekend at the Penta Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 33d Street, for a convention sponsored by the Society for Cinephiles. Vintage silent movies, such as John Barrymore's ''Beau Brummel,'' will be shown continuously throughout the day, and there will be an array of collectibles on display.

title: MIGUEL OTERO SILVA
description: Miguel Otero Silva, a Venezuelan author and journalist, died of a heart ailment here Wednesday.

title: SEVEN OAKS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nicaragua Said to Free American Couple
description: The State Department said today that Nicaragua appeared to have released an American couple arrested this month on suspicion of anti-Government activities.

title: Arguments Heard in Appeal Of Ruling Blocking Westway
description: A Federal appellate court panel in Manhattan heard arguments yesterday over a lower court's ruling this month that barred the construction of the Westway project.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $238,000 for the quarter and $512,000 for the year. c-Net loss.

title: SANDINISTAS ON NEW TACK IN DEALINGS WITH INDIANS
description: No one here is quite sure what autonomy for Nicaragua's Atlantic coast region would mean, but everyone is for it.

title: Another Game
description: After an offseason in which absolutely nobody expressed interest in bringing him into camp, Franco Harris reconciles himself to the end of his 13-year career as one of the greatest of all running backs: ''I love football. But you come to realize it's not the only game in life.''

title: 2 HELD IN BABY-SMUGGLING RING
description: A woman who runs a halfway house for unwed mothers has been charged, along with her daughter, with being part of a baby-smuggling ring that preyed on the unmarried women, selling their infants for at least $5,000, the authorities have announced.

title: SPY SCANDAL IN WEST GERMANY WIDENS
description: A spy scandal took fresh turns today with disclosures that a West German internal security officer had been questioned about a friendship with an East German agent and that an East German diplomat had defected to West Germany.

title: ESPRIT SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Hyundai Plant Set
description: The Canadian Government said an agreement was reached with Hyundai, the South Korean auto maker, to build a $147 million assembly plant in Canada that will employ 1,200 workers and produce 100,000 cars annually by 1990. The company's subcompact Pony has become Canada's top-selling imported car this year.

title: VERPLANK ADVANCES IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: Scott Verplank and Sam Randolph, the favorites, advanced today in the first two rounds of match play of the United States Amateur golf championship. But it wasn't easy.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $2,314,000.

title: WOODWARD A GOOD START FOR TITLE SERIES
description: The Woodward Stakes tomorrow is about as good a beginning to Belmont Park's fall championship series as anyone could have hoped for. A field of six was entered yesterday, and the main interest is in seeing how Chief's Crown will fare against two key older rivals, Track Barron and Vanlandingham. Those three look several lengths better than Skip Trial, Bounding Basque and Mo Exception.

title: AN ATYPICAL PLAYER GAINS THIRD ROUND
description: Bud Schultz, a sandy-haired, 6-foot-4-inch graduate of Bates College, is the antithesis of the kind of player emerging on the professional tennis circuit these days.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: JOE MANTEGNA seems to be making a career out of playing what he calls ''sleazeballs.'' He won the Tony Award in 1984 for best featured actor as the unscrupulous real-estate salesman Ricky Roma in ''Glengarry Glen Ross.'' And in ''Compromising Positions,'' the comic whodunit that opens today (review on page C5), he plays Dr. Bruce Fleckstein, a lecherous suburban periodontist who is murdered because of his liaisons with his female patients.

title: ARIZONA MAN GETS ARTIFICIAL HEART
description: Surgeons at the University Medical Center in Tucson yesterday implanted an artificial heart in a 25-year-old man to sustain his life until they can find and then transplant a human heart.

title: U.S. Clears Practice of Exclusives
description: AFTER nearly two years of review, the United States Justice Department has decided that the practice of granting advertising exclusivities does not violate antitrust laws, according to Justice Department officials.

title: HOW TO OPPOSE BOTH MOSCOW AND PRETORIA
description: To the Editor:

title: Aaron Marc Stein Dies at 79; Writer of 100 Mystery Novels
description: Aaron Marc Stein, a mystery writer who also wrote under the names George Bagby and Hampton Stone, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Book-of-Month Selects 'Ferraro: My Story'
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro's book, ''Ferraro: My Story,'' which the 1984 Democratic candidate for Vice President wrote with Linda Bird Francke, has been chosen as the main selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club for January.

title: REEVES COMMUNICATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.8 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve late yesterday announced a larger than expected $2.8 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply, but the news had a very limited impact in the credit markets, where interest rates were little changed on the day.

title: Heart Stopper
description: Since becoming a manager earlier this season, Bobby Valentine has acquired a reputation for talking up the talents, and boosting the spirits, of his hapless Rangers.

title: Too Much of a Trip
description: The headline of yesterday's Manchester Union Leader read: WELCOME, NE GOVERNORS! (EVEN YOU, MARIO) It alluded to the exchange earlier this month between the newspaper and Governor Cuomo. First, the Governor attacked a New Hampshire Congressman for supporting the Reagan Administration plan to disallow state and local income tax credits.

title: Covering Afghanistan
description: Congress has decided that one thing needed in Afghanistan is an effective ''media service'' for reaching outside news organizations with the story of the struggle against Soviet occupation forces. Accordingly the United States Information Agency is advertising in the Federal Record for ''concept papers'' on strategies for better gathering and marketing of Afghan combat news. Under a $500,000 grant by Congress, the agency is to try to encourage closer coverage of the fighting by outside reporters, to train and equip Afghan television cameramen and even to move toward creating ''an independent Afghan Media Resource Center in proximity to the war zone.''

title: Jam Session Outdoors
description: Musicians who will be in the vicinity of Grant's Tomb on Sunday may want to bring along their instruments and join an open concert, sponsored by the group Salon Bon Ton.

title: BUTTES GAS & OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After writeoffs of investments in a real estate affiliate of $5.4 million for the quarter and $7.7 million for the 6 months. c-Net income.

title: G.I. TRAINING: BUILD A ROAD IN HONDURAS
description: Deep in the lush Aguan valley, United States Army combat engineers have been carving a dirt road 16 miles long through the green brush and across the shallow streams of this remote region in north-central Honduras.

title: What Mozart Missed
description: Few publications are more single-minded than the special-interest newsletters that blanket the Washington scene each day to propagandize policy-makers on myriad issues. A few bother to include movie reviews to catch the wandering eye with a self-serving but sometimes delightful perspective.

title: MISSING ANYTHING? BLAME AN EDITOR
description: With the height of the tourist season, people from all over the world flood into Washington. Many come to visit the city's testaments to the history of America, the memorials, monuments and other famous buildings that make Washington such an attraction.

title: 2,500 Held in India To Curb Tamil Protest
description: The police here said today that they had arrested 2,500 people who were organizing a mass demonstration against the deportation of three campaigners for a separate Tamil homeland in Sri Lanka.

title: Virginia Asks U.S. to End Overseer Role on Bias
description: The state of Virginia asked today to be excused from further monitoring by the Federal Government of its efforts to desegregate its public colleges and universities.

title: Struggling Jaeger Is Beaten by Jordan
description: In the debating parlors of women's tennis she is known as Exhibit B in the continuing investigation into the effect of injuries and demon burnout on younger players. On a tennis court she answers to the name Andrea Jaeger, and as a teen-ager, she was often described as the last of the tomboys, a persistent baseliner known for her brash manner and affinity for computer games.

title: Long Wheelchair Trip Ends at Nation's Capitol
description: After four months in which he wore out 14 pairs of gloves to protect his blistered hands, Michael King ended his cross-continental wheelchair trip by rolling to the Capitol here Wednesday and proclaiming, ''You're only as handicapped as you let yourself be.''

title: SHAPIRO PROPOSES A PROPERTY TAX CUT
description: Peter Shapiro, the Democratic candidate for governor, said today that if elected he would propose a permanent 15 percent property-tax cut for all homeowners and tenants in New Jersey.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds decreased $2.03 billion, to $209.28 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Assets of the 70 institutional funds fell $1.85 billion, to $52.67 billion, while the 188 general purpose funds were up $161 million, to $61.8 billion, and the 88 broker-dealer funds were down $341.1 million, to $94.8 billion.

title: Austria's Wine Laws Tightened in Scandal
description: The Austrian Parliament today adopted a strict new law aimed at restoring faith in the country's wines after a wine-doctoring scandal that has damaged sales in much of the world.

title: NEWMAN AV COMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-Including a tax credit of $9,549. The company went public in December 1984.

title: D H HOLMES LTD.  reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $2,338,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of investments and other properties. c-Including a pretax gain of $491,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of investments and other properties.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: * Carlsberg Corp., a financial services company in Santa Monica, Calif., said it received a merger proposal of $11 a share from a ''financially qualified party.'' Carlsberg, which has about 4.6 million shares outstanding, did not identify the bidder.

title: TEXACO ASSETS SALE
description: Texaco Inc. said today that it had completed the sale of itsstock in the Getty Coal Company to Utility Fuels Inc. of Houston, continuing a program of selling unwanted assets it acquired in last year's $10.2 billion takeover of the Getty Oil Company. Getty Coal has a 55 percent interest in lignite reserves in the Malakoff-Cayiga lignite field near Athens, Tex. Terms of the sale were not disclosed.

title: Who's Who In Rutgers Book
description: Before they were so abruptly altered, Fred Gruninger's plans for Labor Day weekend called for him to watch a Rutgers football scrimmage and partake in a family golf outing. Instead, the Scarlet Knights' athletic director will be listening to a number of candidates vying to succeed Tom Young, who after 14 years resigned as basketball coach the other day in favor of the vacancy at Old Dominion.

title: IN A BROKEN COMMUNITY, FRAIL HOPE
description: Two years ago, Elizabeth Katitswe used to say things about the authorities that were halfway defiant. But that intimation of protest has gone from her voice and now she seems more inclined to shrug and say, without much hope, that, maybe, one day, things will be better.

title: SPY SUSPECT MOVED FROM MARYLAND JAIL TO A FEDERAL PRISON
description: Michael Walker, a Navy yeoman charged with spying for the Soviet Union, has been moved to a Federal prison where he is working as an orderly in the dispensary while awaiting trial, prison officials said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Abbott Diagnostics of North Chicago has assigned several of its business groups to Sutton Communications.

title: U.S. AFFIRMS IT WILL CONTINUE NUCLEAR TESTING
description: The head of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency said here today that the United States would continue its underground nuclear testing program regardless of objections from most of the other countries that signed the 1968 treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

title: SPECTRUM OF JAZZ PIANO MASTERS IN VILLAGE CLUBS
description: FOR people who love jazz piano, New York City is a kind of paradise. The qualifier is deliberate; piano jazz can be a wonderfully subtle art, and not every piano bar or jazz club is an ideal listening room, especially when some folks want to listen and others want to talk. If you're the sort of fan who likes to buy compact discs or high-quality Japanese pressings and enjoy yourself in a soundproof room, you may never find a club environment as ideal for listening to the nuances in the music. But if you stay in that soundproof room, you're going to miss something.

title: Top Matches For Today
description: STADIUM Morning 11 A.M. - Hu Na vs. Pam Shriver (4) Second Match - Hank Pfister vs.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: LE PERIGORD is a survivor among an endangered species in New York: a solid French restaurant in a civilized setting that is conducive to both tranquil socializing and discreet business entertaining. This cozy spot with an Old World ambiance on the eastern reaches of 52d Street is far from the business executives' midtown lunch circuit, so if you are trying to steal a client from the competition it is a relatively safe place to do it.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices rose yesterday for the third consecutive session, but the pre-Labor Day volume remained depressed and investors continued to dust off old takeover rumors as their only source of excitement.

title: VISITING TENNIS PLAYERS FIND TOUCH OF HOME LIFE
description: The United States Open is on, and all the tennis players are living like kings and queens in fancy hotel suites, enjoying room service and being chauffeured to Flushing Meadow in limousines. Right? Wrong. Just some of them are. Other players are not so well off as the McEnroes and the Navratilovas and are not so well known as the Lendls and the Evert Lloyds. They ''stay privately,'' which in tennis parlance means they are staying in private homes in the metropolitan area.

title: LITTLE PRINCE PRODUCTIONS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Giants Face Their Final Test
description: When the Giants finish their preseason schedule Friday night against the Steelers in Pittsburgh, the game will have different meanings for different players.

title: 10% Eurobonds From G.M. Unit
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation is issuing $250 million of 10 percent Eurobonds due Oct. 1, 1992, at a price of 99 3/4, through a group of underwriters led by Swiss Bank Corporation International.

title: Officer Is Seized in Robbery
description: A New York City police officer was charged yesterday with third-degree robbery.

title: U.S. and Hanoi Plan To Recover War Dead
description: The head of an American delegation said today that the United States and Vietnam were working on a unified plan to account for nearly 1,400 Americans still missing in the Vietnam War.

title: Homeless Shelter in Capital Is Staying Open Temporarily
description: The Federal Government said today it would not close a dilapidated 800-bed shelter for the homeless as scheduled Saturday because new space has not been found for the residents.

title: TENTATIVE ACTORS EQUITY PACT
description: Negotiators for Actors Equity and the nation's major regional theaters reached tentative agreement on a new contract yesterday, two days before a strike deadline. The agreement covers several New York theaters and thousands of New York-based actors and stage managers who work annually in regional theaters around the country.

title: AUCTIONS
description: IN the roiling cultural scene of the Lower East Side, an auction coming up next month promises to spotlight several of the neighborhood's prevailing issues and trends, ranging from gentrification to the price of contemporary art.

title: STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
THE BUDGET AMENDMENT-NOT SO CRAZY AFTER ALL
description: Despite the fact that many people think a balanced budget amendment is crazy, there is a way to make it a practical solution to the deficit crisis. It will not require financial magic, nor will it be a futile exercise.

title: Textron to Sell Stock, 3 Units
description: Textron Inc. said it planned to offer 4 million shares of common stock and sell three divisions to further trim the $1.4 billion debt incurred by its purchase of the Avco Corporation of Connecticut.

title: PRETORIA SENDING HEAD OF CENTRAL BANK TO U.S.
description: The head of the South African Reserve Bank, Gerhard de Kock, will fly to the United States from London Friday in an effort to shore up his country's foreign credit, South African officials said today.

title: Dave Jennings Hangs Tough
description: If Dave Jennings's punts had twisted a little more slowly in the wind, he might not have found himself twisting slowly in the wind on Tuesday night, a man without a job for the first time in 11 years.

title: Mailer's Mother, 87, Is Dead
description: Fanny Mailer, mother of the author Norman Mailer, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at her home in Brooklyn. She was 87 years old. Mrs. Mailer, who was born in Long Branch, N.J., operated a personnel-placement business, the Miss Baltimore Agency, until her retirement in the late 1960's. In addition to her son, she is survived by a daughter, Barbara Wasserman of Manhattan; 10 grandchildren, and 2 great-grandchildren.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WESTCHESTER FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company went public in March 1984 and no comparable year ago per share figures are available. Net income for the latest year included an extraordinary credit of $259,000 from a dividen paid by the Federal Home Loan Bank.

title: NUCLEAR PLANT RESTARTED
description: The Unit 1 reactor at the Diablo Canyon power plant was restarted Wednesday after repair of a water pump that forced officials to stop the plant Tuesday before it could mark 100 days of continuous operation.

title: Like Father, Like Son
description: His name is labor in New York.

title: How to Oppose Both Moscow and Pretoria
description: To the Editor:

title: FLOW GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Includes loss of $7,000,000 from discontinued operations.

title: DAVIS'S HOMER BEATS METS IN 10
description: Mark the name: Chili Davis, 25-year-old switch-hitting outfielder for the San Francisco Giants. He brutalizes Met pitching, and he absolutely owns Jesse Orosco. He even hits Dwight Gooden. And he struck again today.

title: FLARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: THE LABOR DAY ARRAY: FESTIVALS TO FIREWORKS
description: LABOR DAY weekend is, without a doubt, America's most bittersweet three-day holiday. With it, the warm, playful rhythms of summer end and the cooler, more serious days of autumn begin. But although the holiday lacks Memorial Day's anticipation of summertime fun and the joyful laziness of the Fourth of July, Labor Day weekend signals the last bash of summer.

title: CITY SCHOOLS TO USE $2.25 MILLION TO RETSORE AND ADD SPORTS TEAM
description: The Board of Education has begun a $2.25 million program to restore and expand sports programs eliminated or reduced a decade ago during the city's fiscal crisis.

title: Amoco in Deal On Bank Cards
description: The Amoco Oil Company and the Associates Corporation of North America said that they would offer free Visa and Mastercard accounts to more than one million members of Amoco Multicard. The new bank credit cards will be issued by Associates National Bank of Concord, Calif., an affiliate of Associates, Amoco officials said.

title: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES TO OMIT PAYOUT
description: Middle South Utilities, the nation's fifth-largest utility holding company, said yesterday that it would omit its quarterly dividend for the first time since it was organized 36 years ago.

title: FILM: 'POSITIONS' A COMEDY
description: WHEN Dr. Bruce Fleckstein, the youngish periodontist in an upscale Long Island commuting village, is found murdered in his high-tech office, several dozen suburban housewives, including his own, go into mourning. Fleckstein, you see, was not your ordinary, ''this isn't going to hurt'' dentist, the sort of fellow who keeps a stash of lollipops in his cupboard.

title: Now Batting . . .
description: Eighty years ago today, in Detroit: Ty Cobb makes his major league debut, bats fifth in the Tiger lineup and contributes to a 5-3 victory with a double against Jack Chesbro of the New York Highlanders.

title: U.S. TEAM TO TAKE 2 WEEKS FOR CHEMICAL TESTS IN SOVIET
description: A team of investigators from the United States said today that they planned to spend up to two weeks studying the purported Soviet use of a chemical dust to track the doings of resident Americans.

title: U.S. HALTS FAIRCHILD PAYMENTS
description: The Air Force today suspended payments of about $4 million a month to the Fairchild Republic Company of Farmingdale, L.I., in a dispute over the company's work on several Government contracts.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Rains of Error
description: The Reagan Administration has a strange ardor for chemistry, but little aptitude. It has introduced nitrophenylpentadienal (spy dust) and trichothecenes (yellow rain) into the language of diplomacy, while trying to erase acid rain from the lexicon. Unfortunately errors abound in the Administration's laboratory work.

title: SOUTH AFRICA'S ECONOMY FACES 2 URGENT THREATS
description: Just last month, South Africa's economy appeared to be reviving after three years of the country's worst downturn in half a century.

title: Time to Clear the Smoke Out of Dining Rooms
description: To the Editor:

title: SAGE-ALLEN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
THOUSANDS FLEE AS STORM NEARS U.S. GULF COAST
description: A hurricane swept toward the Gulf Coast tonight as more than 125,000 people from Florida to Louisiana fled coastal homes, jamming highways to escape the growing storm's 95 mile-an-hour winds and high tides.

title: EVENING NEWS TO GO TO GANNETT
description: The Gannett Company agreed yesterday to buy the Evening News Association for $1,583 a share, or a total of about $717 million, in a cash merger, the companies said. The decision ended weeks of speculation about the fate of one of the leading media companies, which has been controlled by the Scripps family for 112 years.

title: Reagan Praises Duarte On Arrests in Cafe Raid
description: President Reagan congratulated President Jose Napoleon Duarte today for the Salvadoran Government's ''speed and professionalism'' in the recent arrests of suspects in a terrorist attack in a cafe that left 13 people dead, including 4 United States marines.

title: FRUIT-CHEMICAL BAN WEIGHED
description: The Federal Environmental Protection Agency is considering a ban on a chemical that is widely used to regulate the growth of apples and, to a more limited extent, other fruits. The regulator, daminozide, is a suspected carcinogen.

title: MILITARY BACKS DOWN IN DISPUTE OVER CONGRESSMAN'S BRAZIL TRIP
description: The Defense Department and the Air Force retreated today in their dispute with a Congressman over his use of a military plane for a fact-finding trip to Brazil.

title: ASTRONAUTS PUT SATELLITE IN ORBIT
description: Astronauts today launched the third and last communications satellite from the space shuttle Discovery and moved ahead with plans to visit and repair another satellite stranded in orbit.

title: NEW-HOME SALES ROSE 1.4% IN JULY
description: Sales of new single-family houses rose 1.4 percent in July, to the highest level in almost two years, the Government said yesterday. It also revised upward its figures for April, May and June, showing a much stronger performance than previously reported.

title: OF STRESS, HOPE AND PLAYING THE LOTTERY
description: To the Editor:

title: NIEKRO WINS NO. 297
description: Phil Niekro, the 46-year-old marvel, reassumed a role last night that he had taken up a year ago: the Yankee stopper. He did it in a 4-0 victory over the California Angels at the Stadium that stopped a minislide of two straight losses by the Yankees and moved them four games back of first-place Toronto in the American League East.

title: Petro-Lewis S.E.C. Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged today that the Petro-Lewis Corporation defrauded its shareholders and investors in limited oil and gas partnerships by issuing false statements. The S.E.C. also said the company failed to file proper reports with the Government.

title: Union Carbide Rating Review
description: The Union Carbide Corporation's debt rating may be reduced, Moody's Investors Service announced yesterday.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Angeles Corp., Los Angeles, a diversified investment management company, has promoted Robert S. Sedor to first vice president.

title: Diner's Journal
description: HAMBURGER HARRY'S, the sleek grillery that brought the Bearnaise burger to TriBeCa last year, has opened a second branch, near Times Square, at 145 West 45th Street. It sports the same violet walls, neon highlights, blond wood tables and open charcoal-mesquite grill.

title: Tidal Wetland Tour
description: The Constitution Marsh, on the grounds of the Boscobel Restoration in Garrison, N.Y., is the subject of a nature walk and talk sponsored by the Audubon Society on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. The area, one of the largest tidal wetlands in the Hudson Valley, became an Audubon Sanctuary in 1970.

title: THOSE STRANGE MARKET TURNS
description: One day early this month in the midst of an otherwise lazy summer afternoon the stock market was grabbed by an undertow that pulled the Dow Jones industrial average down 21.73 points. And last week, stocks bounded up 11 points one day and down 11 on another for no apparent reason.

title: CHARMING SHOPPES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 3
THE EVENING HOURS
description: How, one wonders, do parties on Cape Cod compare with parties in the Hamptons? Both attract writers and artists and, in August, psychiatrists. Outdoor parties in both places also attract mosquitoes.

title: 'UNIONS TODAY,' ON PBS, EXAMINES LABOR TACTICS
description: MONDAY is Labor Day, a time to think about unions. Where have they been? Where are they going? ''Unions Today: New Tactics to Tackle Tough Times'' is not sanguine about the future of unions, although it does express cautious hopes. Union membership is declining, but new techniques are being used to arrest the decline. ''Unions Today'' will be seen Monday on Channel 13 at 6 P.M.

title: Florida Thrift Unit
description: The board of First Savings Bank of Florida has agreed for the company to be acquired by a holding company to be formed by the investment partnership Rosenkranz & Company of New York for $36 a share, or $96 million, the company said. The bank said it expects its directors and officers will continue in place. As of June 30, the bank had assets of $759 million.

title: COMMAND AIRWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net loss.

title: 19, Going on 20
description: Jerry Koosman has pitched in the major leagues for 19 years, and, despite the fact that he will turn 43 next Dec. 23, and despite an ailing knee that has caused Philadelphia to put him on the shelf for the rest of the season, he hopes to make it an even 20.

title: ADC TELECOMMUNICATIONS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
Buster Poindexter
description: Buster Poindexter, alias David Johansen, will sing selected rock and pop songs tonight and tomorrow at Tramps, 125 East 15th Street (777-5077). Sets begin at approximately 9:30 P.M. and midnight; there is a $9 cover and a two-drink minimum.

title: ARGENTINE STRIKE REPORTED TO FAIL
description: President Raul Alfonsin apparently won a political victory today as a nationwide strike, called by labor unions to protest his economic austerity program, failed to win wide support.

title: OFFICIALS REPORT NO EVIDENCE OF BROAD SPREAD OF AIDS
description: There are no signs that AIDS is spreading beyond the two main risk groups, homosexuals and intravenous drug users, New York City health officials said yesterday.

title: $195 Million in Bonds Offered by Honolulu
description: Honolulu is offering $195 million of general obligation bonds through underwriters led by Citibank with yields ranging from 6.90 percent for those due in 1989 to 8.40 percent in 1995, 9.10 percent in 2000 and 9.40 percent in 2006 through 2008.

title: CARRIAGE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
FOR YOUNG FARMER, JOY IN JUST BREAKING EVEN
description: The late summer days are getting shorter, but the work is still long and hard for farmers like Shorty Gladbach.

title: Son of Watts Grocer Found Guilty in Shooting
description: The son of a grocer in the Watts area who received national attention for resisting a wave of gang terrorism was convicted today of voluntary manslaughter in the shooting that touched off the attacks.

title: Per Monsen of Norway Dies; Was Journalist Since 1930's
description: Per Monsen, a Norwegian journalist who was former director of the International Press Institute and editor in chief of the Norwegian news agency N.T.B., has died, his family said today. He was 72 years old.

title: L.I. FESTIVAL CELEBRATES JHEWISH ROOTS
description: From a new composition by David Amram to biblical scenes painted on silk, the creations on display at the Jewish Arts Festival of Long Island will be freshly minted but traditionally inspired.

title: ONE OF THE TOUGHEST IMAGE PROBLEMS IN TOWN
description: It is a fact of ambassadorial life that much time is spent polishing the image of one's country. But for some on Embassy Row, that is a harder task than just attending state functions and being seen with the right people.

title: AQUANAUTICS CORP reports earnings for Year to June 30
description: After losses from discontinued operations of $565,742 for the latest year and $2,010,493 for the previous year.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-After a provision of $3 million to reduce real estate held for development and the sale of the company's Arizona Sunsites development to its exstimated net realizable value.

title: Revlon Debt To Double
description: Revlon Inc. said yesterday that its offer to give stockholders $575 million of notes and preferred stock for 10 million shares of common stock would double the company's debt to $956 million and create ''significant'' new interest costs.

title: Prince Spaghetti Sauce To Fallon McElligott
description: Prince Foods, Pennsauken, N.J., has switched its Prince Spaghetti Sauce account from Venet Advertising of Union, N.J., to Fallon McElligott Rice of Minneapolis.

title: GAZ METROPOLITAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SEARS IS CLEARED OF MAINE CHARGE
description: A judge in Maine Superior Court yesterday dismissed most of a consumer-protection case filed by the state against Sears, Roebuck & Company, rejecting arguments that the retailer engaged in misleading sales tactics and sold service contracts on items that were already covered by warranties.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: TIME TO CLEAR THE SMOKE OUT OF DINING ROOMS
description: To the Editor:

title: It's O.K. To Stay At Home
description: Strolling through New York one day I overheard a conversation behind my back. ''I've been round the world once already,'' the man was saying querulously to his wife, ''and I don't see why I've got to go again.''

title: Bernie Worrell Band
description: The keyboardist Bernie Worrell, formerly with Parliament-Funkadelic and the Talking Heads, will lead his own funk and rock band tonight and tomorrow at the Bottom Line, 15 West Fourth Street, at Mercer Street (228-7880). Shows begin at 8:30 and 11:30 P.M.; tickets are $8.

title: THE SCREEN: 'GODZILLA 1985'
description: ''GODZILLA 1985,'' which opens today at the RKO National Twin and other theaters, is supposed to be an update on the prehistoric creature introduced to American audiences in 1956, in the English-dubbed, Japanese-made exploitation film ''Godzilla, King of the Monsters.''

title: Charlie Parker Tribute
description: The saxophonists Lou Donaldson and James Moody each will lead a quartet, and the pianist Barry Harris will lead a trio, in a tribute to the be-bop pioneer Charlie Parker tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street (491-9031). Tickets are $25 to $100.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: FRIDAY, AUGUST 30, 1985
description: International

title: GEORGIA BONDED FIBERS reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $118,000 for the quarter and $119,000 for the year and a charge of $52,000 for the quarter and year from the cululative effect of a change in accounting.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International

title: SIGNAFORM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
QUINONES WARNS ABOUT FEARS
description: Schools Chancellor Nathan Quinones said yesterday that, in determining how the public-school system dealt with children who had AIDS, ''fear is not going to be the factor by which we will separate children.''

title: Thanks and Apologies
description: Alfredo (Tito) Horford said he was confused during his odyssey that ended this week with his enrolling in and attending classes at Louisiana State University.

title: The Recovery In Productivity
description: THE United States cannot regain its competitive position in the world without substantial productivity improvement. After a decade of sluggish growth and a long and steep recession, productivity has picked up considerably in the past two years. Does this mean we have returned to higher sustained growth rates?

title: HEIST, C H CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income. Results for the latest year reflect a pretax loss of $270,000 on the sale of an aircraft and an interest charge of $89,000 on additional taxes assessed by the I.R.S.

title: The Yupping of Ave. A
description: To the Editor:

title: Making War the Private Way
description: An organization called the U.S. Council for World Freedom was granted Federal tax-exempt status in 1982 after its treasurer pledged that it would never provide ''materiel or funds to any revolutionary, counterrevolutionary or liberation movement.''
