This council now boasts it has raised as much as $300,000 for the ''contra'' rebels fighting Nicaragua's leftist regime. What about the tax pledge? The council president says he didn't know about it. Besides, says the current treasurer, the fund-raising has President Reagan's backing and ''the blessings of the Government.''

title: Is That a Shoe Dropping?
description: The show-me state is also the shoe-me state and maybe even the shoo-me state, if political gossips are to be believed. Missouri, one of the biggest shoe-producing states, is to be visited Monday, Labor Day, by President Reagan, only days after he rejected the shoe industry's pleas for a curb on imports.

title: BRADY, W H CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
HUDSON APPLE GROWERS SAY THEY HAVE LOST 30% OF CROP
description: On the eve of the New York State apple harvest, Hudson Valley fruit experts are predicting that the crop will be reduced by one-third because of damage from frost and hail last spring.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Doug Flutie, who was the hot topic of conversation during the 1984 college football season when he was throwing passes for Boston College, will be discussing someone else's feats this season. Flutie, the 1984 Heisman Trophy winner and the quarterback for the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League, has joined ABC Sports as a studio analyst for its college football season. . . . Livingstone Bramble will defend his World Boxing Association lightweight championship against top-ranked Tyrone Crawley, Oct. 12 in Reno. . . . But Carlos Santos of Puerto Rico will not defend his International Boxing Federation junior middleweight title in San Juan tomorrow.

title: U.S. STUDY OF LAKES FINDS FEW ACIDIFIED EXCEPT FOR FLORIDA'S
description: The Environmental Protection Agency reported today that a survey in 1984-85 found few lakes in the Eastern, Southeastern and upper Middle Western states with high acid content.

title: 4 BUSINESS GROUPS IN SOUTH ASK FOR STABILITY
description: Four organizations representing the great majority of commerce and industry in this nation said today that confidence and credibility in the economy could be restored only if major steps were taken to end political instability. They said those steps include accommodating blacks in the political system.

title: CRIME: 3 CANDIDATES DIVIDED ON STRATEGY
description: All three major candidates for the Democratic mayoral nomination say they want to see more police officers walking beats in New York City.

title: FLEETWOOD ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 28
Dining Out Guide: Labor Day Weekend
description: Following is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current, and only weekend hours are given.

title: LAWYER IN G.O.P. TRIAL CALLS COERCION MAIN ISSUE
description: The attorney representing some government workers in Nassau County in their suit over contributions to the Republican Party told the jury in his summation today that the case concerned ''the right to freely associate with the party of one's choice.''

title: Aircraft Carrier Group To Move to West Coast
description: The home port of the nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Nimitz, with a battle support group of up to 15 warships, will be moved from Norfolk, Va., to Everett, Wash., by 1991, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. announced today.

title: WOODWIND 'FIREWORKS' TO CELEBRATE HANDEL
description: Authenticity in Baroque music does not always mean small performing forces. If you want to make a noise in the great outdoors, the authentic (unmiked) way to do it is to assemble the players of sonorous instruments in crowds that would make the most inflated Romantic orchestrator blush. To this end, the score of Handel's ''Royal Fireworks Music'' calls for no fewer than 24 oboes, along with 12 bassoons, 9 trumpets and 9 horns, supplemented by contrabassoons and percussion.

title: APPRAISALS OF PROPERTY QUESTIONED
description: The appraisals performed on many of the houses involved in EPIC Holdings Ltd.'s real estate activities were done by a company that had connections to EPIC, former EPIC employees and Wall Street sources said today.

title: A WEST INDIAN CARNIVAL COMES TO NEW YORK
description: FROM New Orleans to Rio de Janeiro, Carnival comes in February - one last community party before Ash Wednesday and Lent. New York City's carnival is delayed; after all, it's cold in February. Since the 1940's, the city's English-speaking West Indian community has had a big blowout on Labor Day weekend.

title: MEDIA BID ON COAST
description: The board of Freedom Newspapers Inc., a family-owned newspaper and broadcasting chain based in Santa Ana, Calif., today voted 9 to 4 to reject an offer by Harry H. Hoiles, who holds one-third of the company's stock, to acquire total ownership of the chain. The offer values the company at more than $900 million.

title: U.S. OFFICIAL SAYS ETHIOPIAN SUFFERING EASES
description: The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development said today that the majority of the famine victims in Ethiopia are now receiving at least some food, and he characterized the situation in that country as ''greatly improved'' since a Western relief effort was started 10 months ago.

title: HUDSON'S BAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $4,750,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the disposal of miscellaneous businesses. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Devils Trade Meagher
description: The Devils acquired Perry Anderson, a left wing, from the St. Louis Blues yesterday in exchange for the center Rick Meagher and the Devils' 12th choice in the National Hockey League draft next year.

title: 'One-Man Sideshow'
description: He bills himself as a ''one-man sideshow,'' and today through Monday John Bradshaw will eat fire, lie on a bed of nails and perform other feats at the Museum/Theater of Coney Island, Boardwalk and West 12th Street, in Brooklyn. Mr. Bradshaw is a former circus barker who has performed at folk festivals and museums around the country. He will appear continuously, with breaks, from 1 to 7 P.M. Admission is 99 cents. Information: (718) 372-5159.

title: AMF ANNOUNCES PLANS TO SELL 13 SUBSIDIARIES
description: AMF Inc. said yesterday that it was putting up for sale 13 of its businesses, which last year accounted for 53 percent of the company's total sales of $1.09 billion.

title: No Headline
description: The Governors of eight Northeastern states, citing widespread contamination problems, said today that the state and Federal governments would have to take more vigorous action to protect underground water.

title: Grey to Handle Special Coins
description: Grey Advertising has been named to handle advertising and promotion for the Treasury Department's Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island Commemorative Coins.

title: Fidelcor to Buy IVB Financial
description: Fidelcor Inc., the parent company of Fidelity Bank, said it would acquire the IVB Financial Corporation, parent of Industrial Valley Bank and Trust Company, for $168 million.

title: ART: ON DISPLAY AT THE STUDIO MUSEUM IN HARLEM
description: FIRST mooted 20 years ago by the Junior Council of the Museum of Modern Art, and initially intended as a work space for artists, the Studio Museum in Harlem, at 144 West 125th Street, is a model to all other institutions in its feeling for reason and proportion. It does not aim to be 12 stories high, let alone to take over 125th Street as far as the eye can see. It does not have splashy temporary exhibitions that turn out to be a lot of fuss about nothing much. It does what it is there to do, quietly and effectively, and it has a completely professional staff that knows how to show works of art to their best advantage. There isn't a prima donna in the bunch, either.

title: Elk Says I.B.M. Settled Patent Suit
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has paid a ''substantial sum'' to Elk Industries in an out-of-court settlement of a patent-infringement suit, Elk said.

title: Auction Houses List Season's Benefit Sales
description: The following are the major benefit auctions scheduled at Sotheby's and Christie's in the coming season. Information numbers are provided in most cases.

title: An Ashley By Any Other Name
description: Remember when they used to name baby girls Rose, Violet, Iris, Daisy, Lily? Now read the birth announcements welcoming girls named Jordan, Morgan, Cameron, Kelly, Whitney, Brett. Quite the makings of a Park Avenue law firm a few decades hence!

title: REAGAN PROPOSES A FREEZE ON PAY OF CIVIL SERVANTS
description: President Reagan recommended to Congress today that it grant no general pay increase for more than two million Federal civilian workers next year.

title: EPIC UNIT'S TRIP TO THE BRINK
description: The lingering financial crisis at Maryland-based Community Savings and Loan Association and its real estate subsidiary, the Equity Programs Investment Corporation, continues to raise the possibility of broader ramifications. Not only could many individuals and financial institutions suffer losses, but, as Federal and state regulators delve into the situation, more and more questions arise as to how such a large investment operation could have gone awry without more warning.

title: AVNET INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SQUATTERS SOUGHT IN TERMINAL ARSON
description: Grand Central Terminal returned to normal yesterday as investigators began searching for four to six squatters they believe may have set the blaze that forced the closing of the terminal Wednesday, officials said.

title: Police in Guatemala Detain Hundreds in Student Protest
description: Guatemalan riot police detained hundreds of students and fired tear gas to break up violent protests today at a 50 percent increase in transport fares, witnesses said.

title: BROADWAY
description: A COMPANY set up to produce musicals for the screen would usually rate nothing more than a huge yawn on Broadway, but it's amazing how quickly yawns disappear when a slice of the action is in the offing.

title: 'A Huge Oak Tree Crashed to the Ground'
description: To the Editor:

title: EX-WHITE HOUSE LAWYER TO HELP GREENHOUSE
description: A former White House counsel, Lloyd N. Cutler, will represent the antinuclear and environmental group Greenpeace in its legal battle with the French Government over the sinking of the ship Rainbow Warrior, Greenpeace announced today.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL CINCINNATI (NL) - Reactivated Bob Buchanan, pitcher. Placed Joe Price, pitcher, on disabled list.

title: SCREEN: 'EUREKA,' BY NICOLAS ROEG
description: ''Eureka,'' Nicolas Roeg's new movie, contains elaborate scenes of a gold hunt, a voodoo ceremony, a rainstorm, a bloody suicide, a bloody murder, a Colonial-style trial and sexual acrobatics. All are unbelievable, which may have been intended, since the screenplay by Paul Mayersberg aspires to be larger than life.

title: STAGE: JAY LENO
description: JAY LENO is a brainy lug with a heart of gold.

title: Executive Will Fill 2 Top Mostek Posts
description: The United Technologies Corporation, in picking a new president and chief executive for its troubled semiconductor subsidiary, the Mostek Corporation, has chosen an experienced hand in the industry.

title: MSA REALTY reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company began operation in April 1984 and did not report comparable year-ago 6 months results.

title: UPSTATE CAMPUS NOW CONDOMINIUMS
description: First the site of the Halcyon Village condominium community was a hotel that went bankrupt, then it was a finishing school and college that went bankrupt. One developer was foreclosed after trying to sell the property in parcels. At one point the main campus was auctioned and no one met the minimum bid. But the latest owner, James J. O'Dea, is not concerned about the less than halcyon past fortunes of the property.

title: SUMMIT HEALTH LTD reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Sales Slump Hurts Diebold
description: A DISAPPOINTING profit picture, according to security analysts, has sent the shares of Diebold Inc. this week to their lowest level in three years. The company is a leading manufacturer of automated transaction systems and security equipment for banks and other customers, including stores.

title: FEAR OF AIDS GROWS AMONG HETEROSEXUALS
description: SARA RIMER

title: GTE Satellite to Orbit
description: The GTE Corporation said today that its fourth communications satellite, Spacenet 3, would be launched Sept. 12 by the French Ariane 3 rocket from Kourou in French Guiana.

title: LTV Steel Cuts Salaries of 8,000
description: The LTV Steel Corporation, in another step to reduce losses from its steel operations, said yesterday that it would cut salaries 7 percent and make other cuts in compensation for 8,000 salaried employees. The reduction, effective Sept. 1, affects employees of the LTV Steel Flat Roll and Bar Company and the LTV Steel Tubular Products Company in Ohio, Pennsylvania and Illinois and at LTV Steel's headquarters in Cleveland.

title: ISRAEL HOLDS AN AMERICAN IN FERRYING OF GUERILLA
description: Israel said today that it was holding an American and an Australian who it said were captured last Saturday on a yacht with six Palestinian guerrillas.

title: Gutted Building, No Permit
description: Under the incongruously serene gaze of two cherubim, a drama began yesterday afternoon at the former Madison Square Church Mission House that would soon involve top officials in the Buildings Department.

title: Greek Conservatives Re-Elect Leader but Rival Quits Party
description: Constantine Mitsotakis was re-elected leader of the conservative New Democracy Party today, but his main rival resigned from the party and invited others to join in forming a new group.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 8 P.M. Second of a four-game series. (Television - SportsChannel, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 8 P.M.) Mets vs. Giants, at San Francisco, 11:05 P.M. (Television - Channel 9, 11 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 11 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Cubs, at Chicago, 2:20 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 2:05 P.M.) Boxing Doug DeWitt vs. Robbie Sims, middleweights, 10 rounds, at the Trump Casino Hotel in Atlantic City, 10 P.M. DeWitt is 25-1-3 with 16 knockouts. Sims, the half-brother of Marvelous Marvin Hagler, is 23-4-1 with 17 knockouts. Football Giants vs. Steelers, at Pittsburgh, 7:30 P.M. (Television - Channel 11, 7:30 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 7:30 P.M.) This is the Giants' final preseason game. The Steelers have Mark Malone at quarterback and Walter Abercrombie and Anthony Corley at running back, but they will be without some key players because of injuries. Frank Pollard, their leading rusher last season, has a broken hand; Bennie Cunningham, the tight end, and Gary Dunn, a nose tackle, have sprained knees. San Francisco 49ers vs. Seahawks, at Seattle, 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 4, 9 P.M.) Golf United States Amateur, at Montclair Golf Club, West Orange, N.J. Round of 16 will be played in the morning and the quarterfinals in the afternoon. B. C. Open, Endicott, N.Y. Second round. Tennis United States Open, at National Tennis Center, Flushing Meadow, 11 A.M. and 7:30 P.M. (Television - USA, 7:30 P.M. Highlights on Channel 2 - 11:30 P.M.) Other Events HARNESS RACING: Yonkers, 8 P.M. HORSE SHOW: Hampton Classic, Snake Hollow Road, Bridgehampton, L.I. THOROUGHBRED RACING: Belmont Park, 1 P.M. (Television - SportsChannel, 6:30 P.M. and 11 P.M.) Atlantic City, 8 P.M. Monmouth Park, 1:30 P.M. VOLLEYBALL: U.S.A. Cup, at Springfield Civic Center, Springfield, Mass., 6:30 P.M. The United States national team, 3-0 in the round-robin portion of the tournament, will take on the Soviet Union (2-1) in the final.

title: Eagles Win
description: Ron Jaworski passed for 150 yards in three quarters as he led the Philadelphia Eagles to a 20-16 exhibtion victory over the Detroit Lions tonight.

title: THE HOUSING PUZZLE;   The Homeless, of All Kinds
description: Since World War II six Mayors of New York have struggled to cure the housing shortage, yet today it's worse than ever. People sleep in hallways; municipal shelters overflow; good buildings decay and poor families huddle in sleazy hotel rooms.

title: Nigeria Ends Curfew And Reopens Seaports
description: Nigeria's new military authorities lifted a dusk-to-dawn curfew today that it had imposed on major cities after the coup Tuesday. It also reopened all seaports.

title: Gil to Debut Sept.3 With Ballet Theater
description: Jean-Charles Gil, formerly a principal dancer with the Ballet National de Marseilles, will make his American Ballet Theater debut during the company's season at the Metropolitan Opera House, from Sept. 3 to 15. Mr. Gil will dance Albrecht in ''Giselle'' on Sept. 10 and Sept. 15, partnering Marianna Tcherkassky.

title: POISON IN THE AIR
description: Can't anything be done to curb the noxious diesel fumes spewed into the air from buses and trucks and inhaled by millions of New Yorkers?

title: 22 Afghan Refugees Begin Hunger Strike
description: A group of 22 Afghan refugees has gone on a hunger strike to protest being detained pending action on their applications for political asylum.

title: SOLDIERS WIN A RULING IN AQUINO CASE
description: Eight Philippine military men accused in the assassination of the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. won an important legal victory today when the Supreme Court upheld the exclusion of key evidence against them.

title: PLAINTIFF'S CREDIBILITY QUESTIONED IN NASSAU CASE
description: The attorney representing the Nassau County Republican Party against charges that it forced government workers to contribute to the party told the jury in his summation today that the plaintiffs had failed to prove that the contributions were not voluntary.

title: Gone Newslettering
description: The Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of 175 like-minded organizations, has begun a newsletter to report on Government actions or, as it sees it, inaction, on enforcing civil rights laws.

title: HEART RECIPIENT GAINS GROUND, DOCTORS REPORT
description: Michael Drummond, the 25-year-old man whose life is being sustained by an artificial heart until it can be replaced with a human heart, was reported as much improved today but still very weak.

title: ON UPGRADING LIABILITY POLICY
description: HARVEY BERNSTEIN, a New York businessman, had long been satisfied with the standard personal liability provisions of his residential insurance policy. But about a year ago, he decided to take out additional coverage to give him further protection.

title: TRADE GAP 22% LESS FOR JULY
description: The nation's trade deficit narrowed to $10.5 billion in July, the smallest since January, the Government said today.

title: GLOBAL MARINE DEBT REVAMPING
description: Global Marine Inc., which is in default under the terms of its loan agreements and publicly traded debentures, said it was critical that an agreement on a debt restructuring with its secured lenders be reached within the next two weeks. The company said discussions on a restructuring were continuing, but ''several important issues remain to be resolved.''

title: The President, as Amended
description: As deaths mount in South Africa, Americans can be forgiven for wondering what their President thinks about it. He seemed to say last weekend that the news wasn't so bad, that a ''reformist'' regime in Pretoria was ending all racial segregation, indeed had already done so in hotels and restaurants. It was then left to his flustered colleagues to amend, clarify and ''put in context'' their boss's verbal safari through an imaginary South Africa.

title: PENTAGON TO TEST ALL NEW RECRUITS FOR POSSIBLE SIGNS OF AIDS VIRUS
description: The Defense Department announced today that it would screen all prospective military recruits for possible exposure to the AIDS virus. Those who show signs of exposure in two separate blood tests will be rejected for military service.

title: Publisher Feared Drowned
description: The Coast Guard has suspended its search for a fourth-generation Detroit publisher, missing and feared drowned after a boating accident on Grand Traverse Bay in northern Michigan.

title: WATSCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Including net from discontinued operations of $114,000 for the quarter and $223,000 for the 6 months.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the British Petroleum Company's second-quarter results misstated its profits and revenues in dollar terms. The company's $:344 million profit equals $481.6 million at the current exchange rate, while its revenues of $:9.97 billion are equivalent to $13.96 billion.

title: MARC RICH TALKS FAIL
description: Switzerland and the United States have failed in three days of talks to resolve a dispute concerning the commodities broker Marc Rich, Swiss officials said today. Mr. Rich was fined by a United States court when he withheld documents from the Internal Revenue Service that the Swiss had ruled confidential. Switzerland said the United States should have asked them for legal assistance under a 1977 bilateral accord rather than unilaterally fining Mr. Rich.

title: Glen Wilkinson Dies; Partner in Law Firm
description: Glen A. Wilkinson, chairman of the George Washington University board of trustees and a partner in the law firm of Wilkinson, Barker, Knauer & Quinn, died of cancer yesterday. He was 74 years old.

title: MANHATTAN MAN IS CONVICTED IN $7.9 MILLION DEPOT ROBBERY
description: A Manhattan man was convicted Thursday night of participating in the $7.9 million armed robbery of a Wells Fargo depot last April.

title: RESURGENCE IN CANADA GOLD
description: In the early 1980's the high price of gold caused Canada's Government and mining industry to make some decisions that seemed imprudent when bullion's price fell by nearly two-thirds. Now, with the world's most productive gold fields caught in the turmoil of South Africa, the Canadian moves are starting to seem shrewd.

title: PANEL TO DECIDE AIDS SCHOOL CASES
description: A special committee will decide on a case-by-case basis whether New York City school children with AIDS should attend regular classes, city and school officials said yesterday.

title: Evelyn Ankers Is Dead; 'Queen' of the B-Films
description: Evelyn Ankers, an actress known in Hollywood as the ''Queen of the B's,'' died of cancer Thursday at her home in Haiku on the island of Maui. She was 67 years old.

title: Gone Fishing
description: It may be Labor Day weekend, and the temperature yesterday may have reached 85 degrees, but Rudolph G. Penner, director of the Congressional Budget Office, saw snow in his forecast.

title: MEASURE EXTENDING TRADE-IN FOR WESTWAY TO BE PROPOSED
description: The chairman of the House Committee on Public Works and Transportation said yesterday that he would introduce legislation giving New York City 90 extra days to apply for a shift of Federal funds from the Westway project to other highway and mass-transit projects.

title: WIRING A SMALL CAR FOR EXTRA FUNCTIONS
description: Joseph O. Sinniger and Richard M. Peterson of the technical staff at the RCA Corporation's laboratories in Princeton, N.J., were granted patent 4,538,262 this week for a system that enables a small car to be wired for more electronic features.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS BACK ON COUNCIL BALLOT
description: Three candidates for the Democratic nomination for City Council president were ordered reinstated on the Sept. 10 primary ballot yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: SOVIET TO BUY U.S. WHEAT
description: The Soviet Union told John R. Block, the United States Agriculture Secretary, today that it would buy some one million metric tons of American wheat, thus defusing a potential dispute over the two countries' long-term grain accord.

title: PC QUOTE reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TIGER DIAGNOSIS
description: Another chapter in the Detroit chronicle dealing with the difference that a few short months can make:

title: ROONEY ACTS TO CUT ITS LOSSES
description: Problems are continuing to mount at Rooney, Pace Group Inc.

title: Gas Leak in India Kills 1 and Injures 150
description: A cloud of chlorine gas escaped from a chemical plant in an industrial suburb today and spread through residential areas, killing one person and injuring at least 150, officials reported.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL TEXAS (AL) - Acquired the pitchers: Matt Williams and Jeff Mays from Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Argentine Tango Ensemble
description: Tango Argentino, an ensemble of 30 Argentine musicians, dancers and singers, will begin performances on Oct. 8 at the Mark Hellinger Theater, 247 West 51st Street. The troupe appeared last June at City Center.

title: TREASURY RATES UP SHARPLY
description: Interest rates on Treasury securities rose sharply yesterday. A bout of speculative selling before the Labor Day weekend caused prices of long-term bonds to fall just over a point.

title: THE SCREEN: HORROR TALE, 'CREEPERS'
description: The gore starts spattering in earnest too late to save ''Creepers,'' a dim-witted horror movie that opened yesterday at the RKO Warner and other theaters. It creaks along for its first hour or so, failing to work up any chills as a killer terrorizes a Swiss girls' school that has cuckoo clocks in every salon.

title: SILVERCREST INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 31, 1985

title: PARISHIONERS BLOCK ARCHDIOCESE'S AIDS SHELTER
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has withdrawn a plan to shelter AIDS patients in a former convent on the Upper West Side because irate parents threatened to keep their children from attending a parochial school next door, archdiocesan officials said yesterday.

title: MISTAKEN IDENTITY
description: A mystery man adorns the cover of the Giants' 1985 media guide.

title: STORMS HAMPER HOLIDAY DEPARTURES
description: Amid rumbling thunderstorms, torrential rains and a few tornadoes, tens of thousands of New Yorkers abandoned homes and offices yesterday for the Labor Day weekend and streamed away in search of sea breezes, quiet country glades and lingering illusions of summer.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a charge of $7,535,000 for the quarter and a provision of $5,500,000 for the quarter and the year in connection with restaurant closings. c-Including a provision of $4,800,000 for the quarter and the year in connection with restaurant closings. d-Net income.

title: AMERICA WEST AIR
description: America West Airlines Inc. said it had agreed to acquire 12 Boeing 737-200 aircraft over an eight-month period from Ansett Airlines of Australia. America West said the total aircraft and related spare parts package were valued in excess of $160 million. Initial deliveries are scheduled for early 1986, America West said.

title: Conviction of Hansen Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court today upheld the conviction of former Representative George V. Hansen, Republican of Idaho, who was sentenced to 5 to 15 months in prison for filing false documents with Congress.

title: FLEET NATIONAL INVESTIGATION
description: The Fleet Financial Group's principal subsidiary, the Fleet National Bank, is the latest bank holding company to announce that it is under investigation by Federal authorities concerning the reporting of large cash transactions.

title: Going Gold
description: The United States may soon have its first gold coins since the $5 piece was discontinued in 1933. The Mint has struck no gold coins since 1933 other than occasional commemoratives like the Olympic coin of limited issue last year or the Statue of Liberty/Ellis Island coins to be issued later this year. But a measure to revive gold coins for wide circulation is moving quickly, if quietly, through Congress.

title: 36 ARE KILLED AND DOZENS INJURED IN TRAIN CRASH IN CENTRAL FRANCE
description: A passenger train derailed early today near this central French town and a freight train hit the wreckage, killing 36 people and injuring dozens, officials said.

title: GOLD MINE SALE
description: The Standard Metals Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Sunnyside Mine, one of the richest gold mines in the West, to Echo Bay Inc. of Edmonton, Alberta. Standard, which is based in New York, said it would receive $20 million and a 30 percent royalty share on future profits. The sale of the mine, seven miles north of Silverton, is subject to approval by the Federal Bankruptcy Court, where Standard Metals filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in March 1984.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: SATURDAY, AUGUST 31, 1985

title: AFTER LAG, TEACHERS START TO CATCH UP ON PAY
description: After a decade of losing ground economically, American public school teachers are beginning to catch up. Their average salary is now $23,546, and in each of the last two years that average has risen more than 7 percent, twice the rate of inflation.

title: IN CALM NEW ORLEANS, HOLIDAY MOOD PREVAILS
description: With Hurricane Elena apparently defying predictions and headed away from here, much of New Orleans declared a holiday today to rest up from the pre-hurricane rigors of the day before.

title: A STROLL ON THE BEACHES
description: Labor Day signals the psychological end of summer. And tomorrow, the public can bid the season farewell on the city's beaches with Parks Commissioner Henry J. Stern and the Park Rangers.

title: FOR SOME, SUMMERTIME'S BOUNTY BECOMES A BANE
description: The telephone calls usually begin in late July. The stealthy visits occur in August, when the situation is desperate. The exact date is flexible and depends on the local growing season. The calls and visits don't let up until the middle of September. The caller begs, pleads and, when desperate enough, offers bribes. The visitor just drops the package at the back door and leaves, without so much as a knock.

title: IN SOVIET, EAGER BEAVER'S LEGEND WORKS OVERTIME
description: Fifty years ago tonight, a Ukrainian miner named Aleksei G. Stakhanov hewed 102 tons of coal in a single shift, 14 times more than his norm, setting a Soviet record.

title: COMPUTER CONCERN CUTS WORK FORCE
description: Computer Memories Inc., which earlier this month lost an International Business Machines contract that accounted for much of its sales, said it had laid off more than 36 percent of its workers in the United States. Computer Memories' chairman, Irwin Rubin, said pink slips had been given to 160 of the 440 workers at the company's headquarters here.

title: INQUIRY ON GROSS BY A STATE PANEL PUT OFF A MONTH
description: A state administrative hearing to determine whether Dr. Elliot M. Gross, New York City's Chief Medical Examiner, was incompetent or negligent in his handling of autopsies has been postponed for a month under circumstances that are in dispute.

title: SAFE BET
description: Dwight Gooden may not have changed the way baseball is played -not yet, anyway - but he is certainly rewriting the rule books in Las Vegas.

title: ASTROS BEAT CARDS: WALLING DRIVES IN 3
description: Denny Walling drove in three runs tonight and the rookie Glenn Davis doubled and pounded his 10th homer as the Houston Astros defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 7-5.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 26
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $5,735,000.

title: GATT EFFORT BY U.S. GAINS
description: A majority of the 90-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade has endorsed an American effort to advance the pace of discussions among world trading nations of a new trade round this fall, according to GATT officials.

title: SOUTH AFRICA REBELS SAY THEY WILL MEET BUSINESS DELEGATION
description: The African National Congress, the guerrilla organization fighting the South African Government, asserted today that it planned to talk with a group of South African business leaders soon on the prospect of dismantling the apartheid system.

title: PHYLLIS GEORGE QUITS 'CBS MORNING NEWS'
description: After less than eight months on the air, Phyllis George has resigned as co-anchor of ''The CBS Morning News,'' the network announced yesterday.

title: Struck Steelmaker Loses On Jobless Benefits
description: A Federal district judge has denied a request by the Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation to bar striking steelworkers in Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia from collecting unemployment benefits.

title: Reagan Moves to Block National Railroad Strike
description: President Reagan today issued an executive order invoking a two-month cooling-off period under the National Railway Labor Act to head off a threatened national railroad strike.

title: PAYMENTS HALTED BY PHILADELPHIA
description: The city halted payments today for the reconstruction of 61 homes destroyed by fire in the siege of the radical group Move.

title: RUTGERS PANEL URGES ENDING INVESTMENTS IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: Top Rutgers University officials have recommended dropping the college's $7.5 million investment in companies doing business in South Africa, the school announced today.

title: GREENMAN BROTHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
Man Kills Woman and Himself On 85th St. Near Second Ave.
description: A man shot and killed a woman described as his girlfriend before shooting himself to death on East 85th Street at about 3 A.M. yesterday, the police said.

title: Clarity and the Court of Appeals
description: New York's Court of Appeals this week finally made clear that minor petition errors need not disqualify a candidate from the ballot in the Sept. 10 primary. Any previous high court statement to the contrary, said the judges, had been ''misconstrued.''

title: ADIRONDACK FIRE NEARLY OUT
description: A forest fire that had been burning out of control since Aug. 18 over 200 acres of Adirondack woodlands on a mountain just north of Lake George was ''99 percent out'' last night, according to a state forest ranger, James White. He said heavy rains on Aug. 26 and 27 and again last night had helped to extinguish the fire, which rangers, volunteers and inmates from nearby prisons fought to contain.

title: LIKE OLD TIMES AT TARTAN FARM
description: ''Most people think a horse trainer is a guy in a checked jacket who steals chickens at midnight,'' says John Nerud, whose own tastes run to solid-color blazers and steaks. But the Hall of Fame trainer is looking a little checkered around the corners of his mouth these days, where a few more crinkly smile lines than usual tell the story of the 2-year-olds in Barn 41.

title: Johnny Lindell Dead; Former Yankee Player
description: Johnny Lindell, a pitcher and outfielder with the Yankees from 1941 to 1950, died of lung cancer at Hoag Hospital in Newport Beach last Tuesday. Chuck Stevens of the Association of Professional Baseball Players of America made the announcement today, which would have been Mr. Lindell's 69th birthday.

title: LA-Z BOY CHAIR CO reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
CTG INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SHOULDER TROUBLE
description: Bruce Sutter, the Atlanta Braves' highly paid relief pitcher, will visit Dr. Stan London, the St. Louis Cardinals' team doctor, in hopes of finding the cause for a nagging shoulder injury.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: SOMOZA'S LAST DAYS ''The Tail of the Tiger,'' a play by Ralph Pezzullo about the last days of the Somoza regime in Nicaragua, is playing at Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue at Tenth Street. The author is the son of Lawrence A. Pezzullo, who was the United States Ambassador to Nicaragua before, during and after the Sandinista revolution. The play, based on real events, takes place in Somoza's bunker. Much of the dialogue in the play is based on Somoza's tapes of conversations in his bunker, as well as the senior Mr. Pezzullo's recollections.

title: PCA INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to August 4
description: b-Net income.

title: SALVADORANS TELL OF ROLES IN SLAYINGS
description: Three Salvadorans appeared at a Government news conference today and described what they said had been their role in the killings of 13 people here, including four United States marines.

title: BIG CATCH ON THE LINE
description: A close call at Auburn:

title: SRI LANKA REPORTED TO AGREE TO MORE SELF-RULE FOR TAMILS
description: The Sri Lanka Government, pressed by India to make concessions to Tamil insurgents, has agreed to a new formula to grant more self-rule to Tamil areas, Indian officials said today.

title: THIRD DAY OF UNREST IN CAPE INCREASES DEATH TOLL TO 28
description: Schoolchildren in this mixed-race area outside Cape Town hurled rocks at the police and set up barricades of blazing tires across the highways today in a third straight day of violence in the region.

title: NEW TOOL IS REPORTED IN BLOOD CANCER FIGHT
description: Doctors have reported that they can accurately pinpoint the origin and type of cancerous blood cells, improving diagnosis and treatment, by using microscopic probes that delve into the genes of renegade cells.

title: A.T.& T. DEAL CLEARED BY U.S.
description: The United States Commerce Department today cleared a plan by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Compania Telefonica de Espana to build a $200 million microchip plant in Spain, the Spanish company said.

title: BRAD RAGAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
'7 Feet 11 Inches, 499 Pounds'
description: Over the years, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has shown annoying obtuseness about the National Crime Information Center. In the face of widespread evidence that this computerized data network is beset with problems, the F.B.I. has insisted it was just providing a conduit for information and could not enforce standards for accuracy.

title: Let All Parents Get Involved in Our Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: City Seeks a Brutality Inquiry
description: The city's Civil Rights Commission today called for a Congressional investigation into more than 100 cases of alleged police brutality here in the last two years.

title: HOMECRAFTERS WAREHOUSE reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: Tidal Wetland Tour
description: The Constitution Marsh, on the grounds of the Boscobel Restoration in Garrison, N.Y., is the subject of a nature walk and talk sponsored by the Audubon Society on Sunday at 2:30 P.M. The area, one of the largest tidal wetlands in the Hudson Valley, became an Audubon Sanctuary in 1970.

title: FACTORY ORDERS FELL 1.3% IN JULY
description: Orders to United States factories declined a sharp 1.3 percent in July, the biggest drop in 10 months, the Government reported today.

title: RAIN DELAYS AMATEUR
description: Rain and darkness combined today to frustrate completion of the four quarter-final matches of the United States Amateur golf championship. Play had been suspended because of lightning at 3 P.M. and was resumed at 4:40.

title: Seoul to Let Chinese Pilot Go to Taiwan
description: South Korea said today that it would allow the pilot of a Chinese bomber that crashed in a rice field to go to Taiwan despite Chinese protests.

title: YANKEE BATS SILENT IN DEFEAT
description: The evidence indicates the Yankees are in their first prolonged hitting slump of the season. The symptoms are many, including an inability to convert runners in scoring position and a failure to take advantage of an opponent's mistakes. But the Yankees can't see it.

title: METHOD OF HELPING AFFIX A SIGNATURE
description: A hand printer designed to enable a handicapped person to apply a signature to a document was patented this week for Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.

title: 13 HELD IN $7 MILLION CONNECTICUT THEFT
description: Federal officials said yesterday that 13 people had been arrested in the 1983 robbery of $7 million from a Wells Fargo depot in West Hartford, Conn., and that the chief suspect had been given refuge by Cuba.

title: COMPOUNDS IN TREATING EPILEPSY
description: A SERIES of compounds for the treatment of epilepsy is covered by a patent granted this week to Charles M. Darling, associate dean and professor of medicinal chemistry at the Auburn University School of Pharmacy in Alabama.

title: Key Rates
description: * Municipal Bond Index, The Bond BuyerSalomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. Beth Balsley, who won the right to play on her New Jersey high school football team, is believed to be the first girl in the New York metropolitan area to do so. 2. Nigeria. Five. 3. They will be salvaged for parts for other weapons. 4. Salt water is advancing up the Hudson, threatening the city's water supply. Temperatures are rising in the upper Delaware, endangering the trout population. 5. Bob Feller, who won his 20th game when he was 20 yeas 10 months 5 days old, playing for the Cleveland Indians, had held the record since 1939. 6. It was the first European settlement in the New World, established by the crew of Columbus's flagship, the Santa Maria, which ran aground there. 7. It halted trading on the country's stock and currency markets until Monday. 8. The elderly. 9. To restore and expand sports programs eliminated or reduced a decade ago in the city's fiscal crisis. 10. A state law that requires contracts to be divided among various construction specialities so there is no general contractor. Each contract must be given to the lowest bidder even if the concern is not the most able. 11. Benazir Bhutto, daughter of the former Prime Minister, now dead. She had just returned from a self-imposed exile. 12. The Crocker National Bank of San Francisco failed to report cash transactions totaling $3.9 billion. Five other banks have been penalized for similar violations. 13.

title: PRICES PAID TO FARMERS DROP 3.2 %
description: Prices that farmers get for raw products dropped 3.2 percent in August, marking the sixth consecutive monthly decline and reducing the index to its lowest mark in almost seven years, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: G.M. SETS 3% AVERAGE PRICE RISE
description: The General Motors Corporation today announced price increases on its 1986 model cars that it said ranged from 2.4 percent to 3.8 percent and averaged 3 percent across its model lineup.

title: Israel Arrests 14 Arabs In the West Bank
description: Israel arrested another 14 West Bank Arabs today after seizing 18 Thursday night.

title: CARBIDE BEGINS SHIFTS: GAF STAKE UP TO 9.9%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, swept up in a fresh round of takeover rumors, moved rapidly today to reduce its work force, buy back stock and restructure its management.

title: MARRIOTT MARQUIS HOTEL: AN EDSEL IN TIME SQ.?
description: There is a new building at Times Square, and it is called the Marriott Marquis Hotel. It costs upwards of $400 million and it is chock-full of the latest technology. But it is to architecture as the Edsel was to automobiles - awkward, gangling and out of touch.

title: MICROWAVE FILTER reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
TAX CLAIM ON PROMOTER
description: Donald Walker, the promoter of the 1984 Dallas Grand Prix, owes more than $17 million in back taxes and penalties, the Internal Revenue Service said in court documents.

title: LANCE AND GEORGIA BANK ACCUSED BY COMPTROLLER IN CHECK SCHEME
description: The Comptroller of the Currency today accused Bert Lance and the Calhoun First National Bank in Georgia and some of its employees of repeated instances of check kiting and improper use of bank funds.

title: CHECKING ON PRICES IN MARKETS
description: A BILL that will enable inspectors to impose immediate fines on supermarkets that fail to mark prices on the items they sell has been passed by the New York State Legislature and takes effect at the beginning of next year.

title: FABRIC WHOLESALERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split as of June 1985. Year-ago figures are pro forma because the company changed to fiscal year ending June 30 in June 1984.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX FOR JULY SHOWS 0.4% ADVANCE
description: The Government index intended to predict the course of the economy rose four-tenths of 1 percent in July, the Commerce Department reported today. Analysts said this latest index of leading indicators, together with a substantial downward revision in the increase estimated for June, suggested continued listless economic growth over the next several months.

title: INSITUFORM EAST reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHICAGOANS PROTEST A FRESCO PROJECT
description: Is it a fresco or is it graffiti? That is the question city officials, artists and residents of two neighborhoods on the North Side are disputing.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
GIANTS END SUMMER 5-0 MOWATT INJURED
description: The Giants played their best game of the summer tonight, especially with big defensive plays, and routed the Steelers, 24-14.

title: NATIONAL MICRONETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 29
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $1,656,000 for the quarter and $7,522,000 for the year, a loss of $19,544,000 for the quarter and year on the disposal of discontinued operations and a tax credit of $469,000 for the year. c-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $1,468,000 for the quarter and $2,652,000 for the year and tax credits of $339,000 for the quarter and $898,000 for the year.

title: VILLAGE WALKING TOURS
description: The streets of Greenwich Village, in the vicinity of Sheridan Square, will be explored on walking tours Sunday led by Michael Levin.

title: WALTON IS HEALTHY
description: Bill Walton passed a physical examination yesterday and then met with Celtics officials to discuss the final phases of a trade that could bring him to Boston in a deal involving Cedric Maxwell. Dr. Tom Silva, the Celtics' team doctor, who examined Walton, said ''good'' when he was asked how the examination went. Walton's career has been marred by foot and hand injuries.

title: AUDITOR QUALIFIES REPORT ON PLAYBOY
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc., publisher of Playboy magazine, said yesterday that its auditor, Price Waterhouse & Company, would not give Playboy's annual report its full blessing because of uncertainties over Playboy's ability to collect on a $37.9 million note.

title: FINGERMATRIX INC reports earnings for Year to May 31
OFFER FOR EX-COACH
description: Arizona State, in an attempt to reach an out-of-court settlement, has made a offer to Bob Weinhauer, the basketball coach it dismissed last month.

title: ELECTROMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
SPACELINK LTD reports earnings for Year to May 31
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $218,000.

title: THE LONG FIGHT FOR T.W.A.: UNIONS DECIDED THE WINNER
description: As recently as mid-June, Frank Lorenzo, the maverick chieftain of the Texas Air Corporation, had all but locked up control of Trans World Airlines, the nation's fourth-largest air carrier. Yet barely two months later, the prize that would have enabled him to build an airline empire suddenly was wrested away by a takeover financier, Carl C. Icahn.

title: TUNIS REPORTS A RANSACKING
description: Libyan agents have ransacked the home of a Tunisian diplomat in Tripoli and stolen some valuable items, the official Tunisian press agency said today. It said members of ''organizations responsible to the Libyan regime'' broke into the home of the envoy, Mohammed Abbes, a diplomat working at the Tunisian mission in Tripoli who was away on vacation.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of incorrect information provided to the Police Department, a holiday schedule published yesterday gave the wrong starting time for the Labor Day parade at 26th Street and Fifth Avenue. It will begin at 9:30 A.M. Monday.

title: A SEAL TO PREVENT PIPE JOINT LEAKAGE
description: A flange arrangement that meets Environmental Protection Agency regulations on the handling of hazardous materials was patented this week.

title: A MOBILE OFFICE FOR CAREER GUIDANCE
description: A shiny new van was parked outside Junior High School 54, on West 107th Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues. Inside, Darren Carter was playing what looked like a video game.

title: FOREIGNERS WHO GET TRANSPLANTS IN U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: The Fate of New York City Hinges on Housing Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. CREATES AN OFFICE FOR ANTI-SANDINISTA AID
description: President Reagan announced today that he had set up a special office to distribute $27 million in ''humanitarian assistance'' to the rebels who are seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: LEVI STRAUSS
description: The founding families of Levi Strauss & Company have acquired 99.8 percent of the outstanding shares in the apparel manufacturing company, Levi's said today.

title: VICOM INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CHEMICAL FABRICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income.

title: FLORIDA BANK
description: The Citizens and Southern Georgia Corporation said it had completed its $470 million acquisition of the Landmark Banking Corporation of Florida. The company said it would seek to greatly expand corporate banking activities in Florida through commercial lending and marketing of cash management services. The combined bank has assets of about $12.3 billion.

title: MIZLOU PROGRAMMING reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company did not have revenue in the year-ago periods.

title: LINEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: 3 Navy Officers Are Censured In Bethesda Hospital Deaths
description: Three Navy officials have been censured in connection with the hiring and appointment of Comdr.

title: Foreigners Who Get Transplants in U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: THRIFT UNIT'S MERGER NEAR
description: The Pacific Realty Corporation said its Guaranty Federal Savings and Loan Association unit had agreed to acquire the Farm and Home Savings Association for $31 a share, or a total of about $214.3 million.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The United States Government has repeatedly stated the importance of Nelson Mandela's release as a key step in moving South Africans toward a national dialogue in its private and public statements.'' - Anita Stockman, speaking for the State Department. [1:1.]

title: How to Tailor Taxes For Optimal Effect
description: To the Editor:

title: VIOLENT INCIDENTS AGAINST ASIAN-AMERICANS SEEN AS PART OF RACIST PATTERN
description: Two Cambodian refugees were followed by a car one night as they drove home from a party in a working-class suburb of Boston. They stopped and got out, only to be severely beaten by a gang of white men. One of the Cambodians suffered a skull fracture and died 10 days later.

title: ETHICS STAY
description: It is an old Washington story.

title: A SOLIDARITY BOOK MARKS BIRTH IN '80
description: Today, five years after he signed the accord founding Solidarity, Lech Walesa finished his shift at the Gdansk shipyard and laid a wreath at a memorial to slain workers as 500 people cheered.

title: MARINO DUE TO REPORT
description: Dan Marino, the Miami Dolphin quarterback who has been holding out since late July, is expected to return to camp today but without the renegotiated contract he wanted from Joe Robbie, the Dolphins' managing general partner. No matter, says a source close to Marino.

title: CROWDED PSYCHIATRIC AREAS IN CITY'S HOSPITALS ASSAILED
description: The chairman of New York City's Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday that the psychiatric wards of city hospitals had become so overcrowded that some patients must sleep on the floors and in the chairs of emergency rooms.

title: MILITARY CONTRACTS
description: The ITT Corporation has been awarded a $373 million contract for work on the B-52 bomber, the Air Force said.

title: METS WIN ON 5-HITTER BY DARLING
description: The Mets ended a three-game losing streak tonight and moved within two games of the St. Louis Cardinals when they scored an unearned run in the ninth inning and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 2-1.

title: Books of The Times Bootlegging and Cars
description: DOGWOOD AFTERNOONS. By Kim Chapin. 249 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $13.95. For most American kids, outside New York City anyway, cars are part of adolescence - getting a license is as much a rite of passage as learning to shave, buying a pair of high-heeled shoes, or going to the high school prom. In Kim Chapin's first novel, ''Dogwood Afternoons,'' however, cars are not just a symbol of independence or a place to neck with your sweetheart; they define an entire way of life. Cutting back and forth between a small-town stock car race, and a young driver's memories of growing up and learning the trade, the book is, at once, a paean to the sport of automobile racing and an old-fashioned story of coming of age.

title: 'One-Man Sideshow'
description: He bills himself as a ''one-man sideshow,'' and through Monday John Bradshaw will eat fire, lie on a bed of nails and perform other feats at the Museum/Theater of Coney Island, Boardwalk and West 12th Street, in Brooklyn. Mr. Bradshaw is a former circus barker who has performed at folk festivals and museums around the country. He will appear continuously, with breaks, from 1 to 7 P.M. Admission is 99 cents. Information: (718) 372-5159.

title: CONNECTICUT DRINKING AGE GOING UP
description: Every Tuesday, Garbo's bar here sponsors a College Night, with a reduced cover charge and cheaper beer prices for its scholarly drinkers.

title: IN DEFENSE OF SILENCE
description: The designation of ''radio-free zones'' on sections of New York City's beaches and at the Sheep Meadow in Central Park is an encouraging sign that our public officials are waking up to the wonderful, but defenseless, world of silence. It is an awakening that I hope spreads across the country.

title: ETHIOPIA RETAKES TOWN FROM ERITREAN REBELS
description: A strategic town held by Eritrean rebels for two months has been recaptured by the Ethiopian Army, according to both the rebels and the Ethiopian Government.

title: Gone
description: It may be coincidental, but as Congress prepares to resume grappling with the Federal budget and its unrelenting deficit, Washington buses are displaying among their noncommercial advertisements a vintage quote attributed to Herbert Hoover: ''Blessed are the young for they shall inherit the national debt.''

title:
PLAYERS;

A DIFFERENT PATH TO THE U.S. OPEN
description: The story of Akeem Abdul Olajuwon's introduction to basketball is now an integral part of sports lore: A coach is traveling along a road in Nigeria when he eyes two teams playing soccer. One of them has a goalie who is at least 7 feet tall. Slamming on the brakes, the coach gets out and asks the kid if he has ever dunked a basketball. The rest, as they say, is history.

title: Botha Is Crossing an Ominous Rubicon
description: To the Editor:

title: WHY JAPAN IS AHEAD
description: Roger the roofer couldn't believe it was happening. ''Be serious, Mr. Bulmer,'' he said.

title: COAST ASSEMBLY CHALLENGES U.S. ON AIR BAGS
description: The California Assembly is challenging the Federal Department of Transportation's proposal to drop its requirement of automatic seat belts or air bags in automobiles if the states adopt laws requiring the use of seat belts.

title: SCOA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 27
U.S. WAR HERO DENIES ANY PART IN DRUG RACKET
description: A World War II veteran, who at the age of 17 became the nation's youngest Medal of Honor winner, said today that he was not ''a big wheel in a dope racket'' but was rather a victim of bad luck.

title: PUPIL BATTLING KLECKO FOR STARTING SPOT
description: The indomitable Joe Klecko replaces his pupil tonight - and that gives the game at Green Bay more meaning than merely the final exhibition game for the Jets.

title: U.S. HOLDS TO DEFICIT ESTIMATE
description: The White House Office of Management and Budget predicted today that the budget deficit for the fiscal year starting in October would be $178 billion, almost the same as it predicted last April.

title: ROONEY, PACE GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
description: b-Net income.

title: HALL & CO. STAKE
description: Martin Sosnoff and the Atalanta/ Sosnoff Capital Corporation told the Securities and Exchange Commission they had bought 885,700 shares, or 5.6 percent, of the stock of Frank B. Hall & Company between July 23 and Aug. 23. The stock was bought at prices ranging from $29.527 a share to $31.437 a share, for a total price of $27.2 million. The purchases were solely for investment purposes.

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $1,646,000 for the quarter and year from the settlement of litigation. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $879,000, an extraordinary gain of $1,729,000 from the early retirement of debt and a tax credit of $824,000.

title: REGIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
LEWIS AND SLANEY WIN IN BRUSSELS
description: Carl Lewis recovered his winning form, and Mary Decker Slaney extended her string of victories this season to 12 at the Ivo van Damme Memorial track and field meet tonight.

title: 10 KEY LAWMAKERS OPPOSE PRESIDENT ON VOTING RIGHTS
description: Several key members of Congress, including Bob Dole, the Senate majority leader, and the Republican National Committee filed briefs in the Supreme Court today opposing the Reagan Administration in a major voting rights case.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Circle K Corp., a holding company based in Phoenix, said it intends to acquire the 20 percent of Shop and Go Inc. that it does not already own for $16.50 a share in cash, instead of stock.

title: Jam Session Outdoors
description: Musicians who will be in the vicinity of Grant's Tomb on Sunday may want to bring along their instruments and join an open concert, sponsored by the group Salon Bon Ton.

title: TANDON TO LAY OFF 131 OF WORK FORCE
description: The Tandon Corporation said it was laying off 131 workers, most of them manufacturing employees, effective today.

title: Give the Dying Their Voice
description: ''Happily, my mind is still functioning,'' a seriously ill Jacob Javits wrote on the Op-Ed page recently, ''but if it should stop, I believe, I would be dead - and there would be no use in prolonging the agony. We owe it to ourselves and the ones we love to make provision for such moments. It is in the highest interest of humanitarianism that we prepare for these moments with living-will laws.''

title: Welfare Plan Advances In Coast Legislature
description: The California Assembly overwhelmingly passed and sent to the State Senate a measure requiring most able-bodied welfare recipients to seek jobs as a condition of receiving their government grants.

title: TOURISTS BULLISH ABOUT STOCK EXCHANGE
description: Wall Street was nearly deserted at 9:30 the other morning. But a crowd of 100 or so tourists had already lined up in the lobby of 20 Broad Street, home of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: ASTRONAUTS MANEUVERING SHUTTLE TOWARD STRANDED SPACE SATELLITE
description: Astronauts today steered the space shuttle Discovery toward a rendezvous with a stranded communications satellite and were ready to go outside their spaceship Saturday morning to haul the satellite aboard for repairs.

title: Police Identify Suspect In 16 Killings on Coast
description: The man wanted in a series of 16 killings that have spread terror throughout California was identified tonight as Richard Ramirez, a 25-year-old native of El Paso, law-enforcement officials announced at a news conference.

title: PROTECTIVE DEVICE FOR JOGGER'S EARS
description: A sound inhibitor for audio transducers, patented this week, is already being manufactured and sold under the trademark Earsaver.

title: OPENING SHOT IN THE CHRISTMAS TOY BATTLE
description: Louis Gostinger is already preparing for Christmas.

title: HOME FROM THE HAMPTONS
description: In my last job, I was able to take off Mondays in the summer to avoid the traffic from the Hamptons on Sunday night, but now I have to be in for the Big Meeting on Monday morning. I struggled with the thought of driving and rejected it. The train was inconvenient. I decided, finally, to give the plane a try.

title: MERRY-GO-ROUND ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
Johnny Carson and Wife Granted a Dissolution
description: Johnny Carson and his third wife, Joanna, were granted a dissolution of their 10-year marriage today under which the host of ''The Tonight Show'' will pay Mrs. Carson $35,000 a month for 64 months beginning Sept. 1, unless she remarries or dies.

title: U.S. ASKS INCLUSION OF MANDELA GROUP IN PRETORIA TALKS
description: The United States has urged South Africa to allow the outlawed African National Congress to take part in any discussions between the Government and black leaders on the country's future, State Department officials said today.

title: Gerhardt W. Hyatt, 69, Dies; Ex-Chief of Army Chaplains
description: The Rev. Gerhardt W. Hyatt, second vice president of the 2.7-million-member Lutheran Church Missouri Synod who was a former Army Chief of Chaplains, died Friday. He was 69 years old.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44. 1. ''I want to be able to play like the rest of the guys,'' said the player, No. 18. ''I'm not going to back down.'' Who is No. 18? 2. An apparently bloodless coup took place in an African country. What is the country, and how many successful coups have there been since the country won independence in 1960? 3. After spending $1.8 billion, the Pentagon has halted purchases of the Sergeant York antiaircraft gun saying the weapon's performance was ''not worth the additional cost.'' What will the military do with the 65 weapons that have been delivered? 4. Lower water levels resulting from the drought in New York are adversely affecting two rivers. What is happening? 5. Dwight Gooden, at the age of 20 years 9 months 9 days, became the youngest pitcher in the modern baseball era to win 20 games in a season. Who was the previous record holder? How old was he? How long did he hold the record? 6. Archeologists believe they are on the verge of finding the remains of La Navidad in what is now Haiti. What is noteworthy about La Navidad? 7. As the South African rand dropped to its lowest level ever, the country's government took dramatic action. What did it do? 8. New Census bureau figures show that the national poverty rate declined last year.

title: AMARCO RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Including a gain of $440,000 for the quarter and year from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Morocco's Sand Castle War
description: To the Editor:

title: WITNESS TELLS OF ADMISSION BY FORMER AGENT
description: A former Federal agent, Richard W. Miller, broke down after four days of questioning by Federal Bureau of Investigation and admitted he had showed his Soviet lover a classified document in his bedroom, an F.B.I. agent testimony today in Mr. Miller's trial on espionage charges in Federal District Court.

title: FARM HOUSE FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Nigeria Capital Appears Calm As Roadblocks Are Removed
description: Lagos was calm today and roadblocks were removed three days after a coup changed the Government.

title: East River Ferry Test To Begin on Thursday
description: Ferry service between lower Manhattan and downtown Brooklyn will begin next Thursday and continue for six weeks on a trial basis, officials said yesterday.

title: COMINGS AND GOINGS
description: The Cleveland Indians have notified Don McMahon, the pitching coach; Ed Napoleon, the first-base coach, and Dennis Somers, the bullpen coach, all of whom were hired by the two previous managers, that they will not be retained for next season.

title: Rebels Said to Kill 17 in Zimbabwe
description: The Government said today that 17 people were killed in a rebel attack on a village in Matabeleland Thursday night.

title: AFRIKANER EXECUTIVE SPEAKS OUT
description: One of South Africa's most powerful Afrikaner businessmen has said that the Government has only one ''final opportunity'' to introduce the reforms needed to bring about political and economic stability.

title: LABOR DAY CLOSINGS
description: United States stock and commodity markets will be closed Monday in observance of Labor Day. Government offices, banks and many businesses will also be closed. Most foreign exchanges, however, will be open.

title: CITY OPERA: BELLINI'S 'NORMA,' THREE NEW CAST MEMBERS
description: Newcomers into New York City Opera casts are divided between ''debuts'' and ''firsts,'' debuts being singers appearing with the company for the first time and firsts being those singing a particular role for the first time. Thursday evening's performance of Bellini's ''Norma'' offered one debut and two firsts, one of the firsts - Cynthia Rose as Clotilda, Norma's confidante - being in a role so tiny that nothing really can be said except that Miss Rose didn't disgrace herself.

title: SCM ANNOUNCES OFFER FOR LEVERAGED BUYOUT
description: To thwart a hostile takeover attempt by Hanson Trust P.L.C., the SCM Corporation yesterday announced a leveraged buyout offer worth at least $854 million to take the company private.

title: Not-So-Lethal Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: TOROTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
description: b-Net income.

title: AMERICANS GAIN
description: The United States team continued to surprise the competition today by qualifying five of its six crews in the men's and women's semifinal rounds of the world rowing championships.

title: PRETORIA'S CHIEF BANKER BRINGS LOAN PLEA TO U.S.
description: The governor of South Africa's central bank arrived in New York yesterday for urgent talks with officials of Citibank and other commercial banks to try to find a way out of South Africa's financial crisis, banking sources said yesterday.

title: NORSTAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to August 3
description: b-Net income.

title: CPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 20
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,558,000 for the quarter and $3,143,000 for the 6 months. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $97,000 for the quarter and $65,000 for the 6 months.

title: POP: SQUEEZE, BRITISH GROUP, AT PIER 84
description: Four years ago, the British pop group Squeeze seemed on the threshold of the kind of enormous popularity currently enjoyed by groups like Wham!, Culture Club, and Duran Duran. Led by the songwriting team of Glenn Tilbrook and Chris Difford, Squeeze forged a promising blend of Beatles-influenced pop and bouncy new wave rock.

title: PBS LEADS IN NEWS EMMYS
description: ABC and CBS took the top prizes for coverage of a breaking story at the National News and Documentary Emmy Awards Thursday, while PBS won the most awards.

title: STORM MENACES A BROADER AREA OF FLORIDA COAST
description: Long stretches of the Gulf Coast stood abandoned today as people in beachfront communities and resorts from Gulf Shores, Ala., to Tampa Bay in Florida fled the approach of Hurricane Elena.

title: REGULATING THE ART BUSINESS
description: In the rush to regulate the art auction business in New York City, government officials are likely to chase the auction houses out of town. The pious regulators say they are acting in the public interest, but they're ignoring many benefits that auction houses bring to the city's art consumers, dealers and government coffers. And unless the regulators proceed with caution, those benefits could easily be forfeited.

title: DOW DECLINES 1.12 IN MIXED MARKET
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday after three consecutive days of increases, as Wall Street sleepwalked its way into the Labor Day weekend, ignoring a spate of economic news, some good and some bad.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Baseball Yankees vs. California Angels, at Yankee Stadium, 1:20 P.M. (Television -Channel 4, 1:15 P.M. Radio - WABC 770, 1:15 P.M.) Mets vs. Giants, at San Francisco, 4:05 P.M. Dwight Gooden will seek his 21st victory, which would make him the leader in the major leagues. (Television - SportsChannel, 4 P.M. Radio - WHN 1050, 4 P.M.) Atlanta Braves vs. Cubs, at Chicago, 4:05 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 4:05 P.M.) Houston Astros vs. Cardinals, at St. Louis, 8:05 P.M. (Radio - WCBS, 880, 7:50 P.M.) Football Jets vs. Packers, at Green Bay, Wis., 8 P.M. This is the Jets' last chance to avert an exhibition season without a victory. (Television - Channel 5, 8 P.M. Radio - WABC, 770, 8 P.M.) Houston Oilers vs. Cowboys, at Dallas. 9 P.M. (Television - Channel 2, 9 P.M.) College Games: Purdue vs. Pitt at Pittsburgh. 7:30 P.M. (Television - ESPN, 7:30 P.M.); Oregon vs. Washington State, at Pullman, Wash. 8 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 8 P.M.); Florida State vs. Tulane, at New Orleans. 12:30 P.M. (Television - WTBS, 12:30 P.M.) Golf United States Amateur, at Montclair Golf Club, West Orange, N.J. Semifinal round. B.C. Open, at Endicott, N.Y. Tennis United States Open, at National Tennis Center, Flushing Meadows, Queens, 11 A.M. (Television - Channel 2, 12:30 P.M. USA, 7:30 P.M.) Thoroughbred Racing Belmont Park, 1 P.M. The $300,000-added Woodward Stakes for 3-year-olds and up at a mile and an eighth is the feature.

title: RCA COMPLETES SALE OF HERTZ UNIT
description: The RCA Corporation said that it had completed the sale of a subsidiary, the Hertz Corporation, to UAL Inc., corporate parent of United Airlines.

title: CONNORS REMAINS PEOPLE'S CHOICE
description: He walks onto the stadium court to calls of ''Jimbo, Jimbo,'' the sentimental favorite of the crowds at the National Tennis Center who enjoy watching Jimmy Connors reprise the role that made him famous. They have heard that Connors is nearing the end of his career and that he is no longer in a class with John McEnroe or the new kid in town, Boris Becker, but he is a survivor and to New Yorkers, there is no bigger compliment.
